column2: AFTER consulting a chart of vital statistics, this interested onlooker has a better understanding of what makes the Dodgers run. Of course, without consulting a chart, anybody who follows baseball would know that Larry the Red MacPhail has a hand in making the Dodgers run. Or two hands. And Lippy Leo Durocher, too. With hands, feet and a brisk tongue.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 14 -- The joint declaration by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill produced tonight a profound and extremely favorable impression in this country, where it is considered a statesmanlike document that might prove to have marked a turning point of the war.

George M. Cohan wrote a play called "Pigeons and People" back in 1933, but the Broadway playwright overlooked a few dramatic angles, according to reports reaching Manhattan last night from the Brooklyn courts.

VICHY, France, Aug. 14 -- There was no official reaction to the British-American declaration today, but in informed quarters the attitude was taken it revived a doctrine that past experience had proved to be insufficient to maintain peace.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14 -- John Kramer of Montebello, Calif., went out on the center court at the Casino today and played the finest tennis to come from his racquet all season in gaining the semi-finals of the Newport invitation tournament.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The election of B.C. Vaughan of Toronto, president of Canadian National Railways and of the Central Vermont Railway, as president of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad was announced here today following a meeting of the board of directors.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- New England's Napper Tandy, 6-year-old son of Koodoo, a sire who is not well known, easily defeated a lot of stylish horses today in the Hessian Handicap as 10,342 persons watched.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A stronger dressed trade and some reduction in receipts failed to bring buyers into the hog market actively today and only medium and light weights held steady, while heavy butchers and sows sold at steady to 10 cent lower prices. Steers were steady to 15 cents lower as demand lagged and around steady prices prevailed on lambs.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

The steadily increasing flow of gray cloth to buyers this week came to an abrupt stop yesterday as mills released only small quantities of cloth for sale. Since Monday converters and industrial users had been cheered by the apparently growing willingness of mills to sell, and print cloth sales alone had averaged 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 yards for the first three days of the week.

Cooler weather this week improved the demand for most classes of fresh meats. Prices appeared firmer yesterday and some salesmen asked higher prices for lamb, pork and cow beef. Steer hinds and ribs were steady. Bull beef was strong and veal about steady. Kosher steer chucks and plates were nominally steady to strong.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Although, there was jubilation here today in all anti-Axis embassies and legations when the results of the meeting at sea between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill were announced, there was a noticeable lack of official comment by the heads of various diplomatic missions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The text of the official statement on the Roosevelt-Churchill meeting follows:

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 14 -- New York State Police officials were among 100 persons including judges, prosecutors, lawyers and others who assembled at the Ridgefield (Conn.) State Police Barracks today to witness a demonstration of an automatic alcoholometer described by its Yale University inventors as "foolproof" in blood alcohol analyses of drivers under the influence of liquor.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 15 -- After twenty-four hours of fierce fighting along the entire 1,800-mile front, the Soviet High Command late last night reported the evacuation of Kirovograd, about 250 miles east of Uman, on the headwaters of the Ingul River, and Pervomaisk, some sixty-two miles southeast of Uman.

TOKYO, Aug. 14 -- The attempt to assassinate Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma, veteran Japanese statesman and the strong man in the second and third Konoye Cabinets, has proved a profound shock to the Japanese people, who have rallied around him and his cause.

A "cool spell" halfway through August, with an early morning fall in the temperature to 54 7/8 -- the breaking of the low record for the day, so the weather-man -- said was undoubtedly a relief from the 90-degree temperature of the fortnight past, but was rather generally classed as inappropriate for midsummer.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Serge Koussevitzky is making it a policy to give at least one major work with chorus and soloists at the Berkshire Symphonic Festival each year. Last year it was Bach's B minor Mass. This season fell on Beethoven's lofty and impassioned Missa Solemnis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Senator Truman charged the War Department today with "needless waste" of $100,000,000 in carrying out more than $1,000,000,000 in camp and cantonment construction.

HAVANA, Aug. 14 -- The German Consulate of Santiago de Cuba has been ordered closed and the Consul, Anton Heisinger, directed by the Cuban Ministry of State to leave the country, Minister Jose Manuel Cortina announced today.

Women who can "sculpt their weight in marble" are replacing men in the traditional male art of the hammer and chisel at Columbia University's third annual outdoor Summer sculpture exhibition. Out of thirty pieces of the Summer students' work placed on display yesterday on the grounds of East Hall, twenty-eight represent the work of women artists, many of whom weigh less than their creations.

Nine thousand soldiers of the crack "Fighting First" Division, their khaki uniforms contrasting sharply with the war gray of eight transports, landed at the Army Base at Fifty-eighth Street and First Avenue in Brooklyn and boarded twenty special troop trains yesterday in the greatest single movement of troops ever conducted at the Army's Port of Embarkation.

In line with the growing power of the national defense effort and the rapid expansion of business generally, commercial loans of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $35,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $2,372,000,000, the highest level for these banks in nearly a decade.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 15 -- Royal Air Force planes were reported striking in strength over the French coast before dawn today, after a large force of British Blenheim bombers yesterday afternoon attacked the docks at Boulogne.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The fact that Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Roosevelt have met is regarded in Great Britain as far more important than anything that was announced as the outcome of their meeting.

Having about exhausted their patience waiting for the arrival of some competition that apparently is never going to come, the Yankees yesterday decided to put a heavy foot on the throttle. They wheeled a few of their long-range guns into action, unfurled three homers along with a liberal sprinkling of triples and doubles, and without much ado sank the hapless Senators in both engagements of a double-header at the Stadium.

EAST OTIS, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Delegates to the Western Hemisphere Encampment of Girl Scouts and Girl Guides at Camp Bonnie Brae heard addresses today from three leaders in the Girl Guide and Girl Scout world movement. Mrs. Arethusa Leigh-White, director of the World Bureau of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts; Miss Mary Wilson, of the Office of Coordinator of Latin-American Affairs, and Miss Graciela Mandujano, director of the Chilean Institute of World Education.

Tomato Juice Prices Advanced Tentative prices on the 1941 pack of tomato juice were named here yesterday by the California Packing Corporation and revealed advances much more moderate than had been expected on the Del Monte line.

The charge that Mayor La Guardia, through intermediaries, had agreed with the five Democratic county leaders to accept the county reform bills recently passed by the City Council, but later had "double-crossed" them by having the Board of Estimate withhold its approval, was made at a meeting of the board yesterday by Councilman Louis Cohen, Bronx Democrat.

Bank clearings for the twentythree major cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,863,387,000, or 33.2 per cent more than the $4,403,168,000 for the similar week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Savings effected at the expense of national security are a poor economy. No patriotic American, in or out of Congress, would dispute that. Perhaps that is the reason why economy is not much emphasized as justification for the paring of a little more than $1,000,000,000 from a House supplemental national defense bill by the Senate, which passed the measure yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Federal regulation of the sizes and weight of motor vehicles was recommended today to Congress by the Interstate Commerce Commission, with Commissioner Walter M. W. Splawn dissenting.

Additional amounts of suitable rayon yarns which, will be required as substitutes for silk are estimated at about 22,000,000 pounds per year, according to a special analysis of the procurement of rayon, and cotton yarns in the present emergency which was sent yesterday to members of the National Association of Hosiery Manufecturers by Earl Constantlne, president.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 14 -- The Assembly's mounting concern, not only at the physical encroachment of American defense bases on the colony's territory, but at their cumulative effect upon local government -- and possibly ultimately involving the island's sovereignty -- was reflected in a motion discussed at a secret sitting lasting two and one-half hours and arising from the government's decision to appoint civilian governors in the future.

MONTREAL, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Arthur Blaikie Purvis, 51, head of the British Supply Council in North America, has been killed in the crash of a transatlantic plane at a British airport, the Ferry Command of the Royal Air Force announced tonight.

Because of its larger seating capacity, the Shubert has been selected as the most suitable house for "Pal Joey" when the musical comedy reopens with a matinee on Labor Day after a suspension of two weeks. Compared to the Barrymore, where the show closes tomorrow, the Shubert has about 300 more seats.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- The Roosevelt-Churchill peace program announced today was officially described here as a not-too-clever effort to drive a wedge into the Reich morale, and its eight points were held to remind the Germans unhappily of President Wilson's fourteen.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- A factory which will raise the Buffalo output of Curtiss pursuit planes to 500 a month was dedicated today in the presence of government officials and thousands of workmen.

FOR HOW LONG? Once upon a time a man went to his doctor about some new symptoms and was told the situation called for a fortnight in the hospital. If neglected the case might develop into a general and permanent breakdown.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation had consolidated net profit in the first six months of this year of $10,664,338, according to the report of G.W. Vaughan, president, announced yesterday. In the first half of 1940 the consolidated net profit amounted to $6,235,969.

The conflicting claims of the German and Russian communiques again posed a completely contradictory picture yesterday. Berlin reported great victories in the Ukraine, while Moscow said "there was nothing important to report."

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- The list of 361 candidates who passed the June dental licensing examination was announced today by the State Department of Education. A total of 750 took the examination, but many of them did so for the second time in order to gain experience, the department authorities stated.

Reflecting higher fabric prices and probable increased labor costs, volume dress price lines will be advanced 75 cents at wholesale, it was reported here yesterday. Highlighting the increases are rises in the important $4.75 price line to $5.50, and in the $2.87 1/2 range to $3.62 1/2.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Eugene Pitou gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at Adare, her home in First Neck Lane. Among the guests were Mrs. Wesley C. Bowers and Mrs. Winfield Scott Schley, who is visiting Dr. and Mrs. Bowers at the Bouwerie; Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray, Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk, Mrs. William Saint Lawrence, Mrs. R. Swift Maguire, Mrs. Fenton Taylor, Mrs.

Sugar, rubber and tin futures were added yesterday, to the growing list of important commodities, to feel the impact of Federal regulations. Trading in these commodities was suspended as a result of Federal price-control orders issued by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, in the drive to control inflationary forces and conserve vital defense materials.

Here are expressions of opinion of newspapers of the country on the meeting of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES, The Associated Press and The United Press:

The purchase by the New York City Housing Authority of two large properties on the West Side for inclusion in the site of Amsterdam Houses, proposed low-rent development, was announced yesterday. The properties are 213 and 215 West Sixty-second Street and 210 to 214 West Sixty-third Street and were bought from the City and Suburban Homes Company, John A. Cahill, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Secretary Morgenthau stated today that the Treasury was studying the question of higher social security taxes on a broader basis and the supplementing of them by a "dismissal" wage with a view to preventing inflation now and providing a cushion against post-war dislocation.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- A scheme for assuring Great Britain a regular, sufficient and mobile labor force on her docks was announced today by Labor Minister Ernest Bevin. He admitted it was "a somewhat novel development."

In achieving an international conference at sea President Roosevelt has carried through an interesting and dramatic plan that has been steadily in his mind since the rise of Hitler began to threaten the peace of the world. Though what the President always conceived as a peace conference materialized as a war conference, the setting and the scene follow his original idea.

The flow of mortgage money into new loans on real estate in Manhattan increased sharply last month over June, according to the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York, which shows, however, a reduction in the number of such advances.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Senate completed action today on a $6,838,436,000 supplemental national defense appropriation bill and sent it back to the House for consideration of amendments.

A field of 607 amateur golfers competed yesterday for 137 places in the national championship starting field, and when they were all through with their sectional qualifying tests there were few surprises to record.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark divided a double-header tonight before a crowd of 12,277. The Little Giants lost the first game, 3 -- 2, but came back strongly to take the second, 7 -- 4.

Announcing the declaration by the directors of the third dividend of $1.50 a share to be ordered this year, compared with three dividends of $1.25 each in the respective quarters of 1940, K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, reported yesterday net sales of $507,966,137 for the first six months of 1941, a gain of 20 per cent over the $422,643,281 in the 1940 period.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 14 -- Nearly a week after publication of the long communique recapitulating the successes obtained by German, arms, objective military observers here are inclined to believe that the "Blitzkrieg" is developing into a war of attrition. They give full credit to the German High Command for its achievement.

ALTOONA, Pa., Aug. 14 -- William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France, warned today that the United States faced war "sooner or later" and made it plain that he felt there would be less risk in immediate involvement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 -- Frank Capra's negotiations to join United Artists as a partner were terminated today with an announcement by Capra that he had withdrawn because of delays on the part of the studio. He said that he had asked David O. Selznick, with whom he was participating in the deal, not to include him in any further talks with United.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The umpires would have saved a lot of time and work if they had called the game between the Indians and the Browns today when rain fell in the sixth inning, with the score tied at 2 -- all.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn ordered last night the arrest of John B. Kepner, 61 years old, of 583 West 215th Street, Manhattan, who, the District Attorney charged, was the ringleader of a group of automobile thieves that had stolen 300 to 500 cars in the last three years and sold them as far away as Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Unusual precautions were taken by the United States Government to cloak in secrecy the fact that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill were to meet at sea. The rumor of their meeting circulated freely but official sources refused to confirm or deny it until today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, expressed his opinion to a House committee today that Representative Dies of Texas was "not a responsible member of Congress."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A price ceiling of 52 cents a pound on Grade A pig tin, effective on Saturday, was set today "to meet the inflationary situation in tin prices created by concern over shipments from the Far East."
SITKA, Alaska, Aug. 14 (UP) -- An explosion blasted tons of rocks today on workmen constructing a naval air station at the southern tip of Japonski Island. Five men were reported killed.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 14 -- While investigation of the anti-Chilean plot charges brought against five leaders of the Nazi movement in Southern Chile were moved to Puerto Rico, the Chamber of Deputies in a special session took up today the bill presented last night by Deputy Julio Barrenechea, a leading Socialist, to stop Nazi-Fascist penetration.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Troops took battle stations in Washington coastal ranges today, aiming to beat back a mythical invader and save the inland cities from the fate which befell the shoreline.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Tod have gone to the Meadow Brook Club in Derby, Vt.

An increase of 70 per cent in airplane deliveries over the corresponding period a year ago is disclosed by Donald W. Douglas, president of the Douglas Aircraft Company, in the report covering the six months ended on May 31, issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Widespread price advances continued in the wholesale commodity markets in the week ended on Aug. 9, with the Bureau of Labor Statistics's index of nearly 900 price series moving up 0.4 per cent to 89.6 per cent of the 1926 average.

The House has approved and sent to the President the bill previously passed by the Senate to "freeze" Government holdings of cotton and wheat for the duration of the war. Under the measure the Government is forbidden to avail itself of the rising price trend by reducing the stocks it acquired in making price-supporting loans in past years.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Ray Billows, golf's "Cinderella Boy," may or may not be a contender for the national championship when the amateurs gather at Omaha for the blue ribbon event week after next.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement for the week ended yesterday revealed today a further rise of u1,153,000 in note circulation to u668,177,000, a new record. Reserves were depleted by u1,156,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- One of the four United States tankers diverted from the West Coast trade to transport supplies to Russia sailed today from Los Angeles for Vladivostok with 95,000 barrels of aviation gasoline, Secretary of the Interior Harold Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, announced.

Republican organization leaders made strong efforts yesterday to avoid the two principal contests in the party primary, that of John R. Davies against Mayor La Guardia for the nomination for Mayor and that of Stanley M. Isaacs, the incumbent, against Edgar J. Nathan Jr., organization designee, for the nomination for Borough President of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 9 totaled 878,549 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 4,516 cars, or 0.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 151,476 cars or 20.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 217,526 cars, or 32.9 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Milo J. Warner, national commander of the American Legion, informed delegates to the New York State Legion convention, in session here this morning, of the announcement of the meeting between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, and then called upon the President to clarify the resulting situation.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Aug., 14 -- Representatives of the Office of Production Management discussed with officials of passenger car and truck manufacturers today the elimination of aluminum pistons from 1942 passenger cars, trucks and buses as part of a program, to conserve aluminum, chrome, nickel, zinc, copper and rubber.

MANILA, Friday, Aug. 15 -- General Douglas MacArthur inducted the six-year-old Philippine Army Air Corps into the Far Eastern United States armed forces at a brief ceremony today. He told the Filipino fliers:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- During the week ended Aug. 13 member bank reserve balances declined 53,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $80,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $16,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset by decreases of $49,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $3,000,000 in money in circulation and by increases of $21,000,000 in gold stock, $16,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $3,000,000 in Treasury currency.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- The joint declaration yesterday by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill "contains nothing new," and even if their eight points for a new world order could be enforced they are "now too late," authorized quarters said today.

The Roosevelt-Churchill statement yesterday on war and peace aims, which confirmed reports of a secret rendezvous of the two leaders at sea which had kept the world on edge, produced no unanimity of opinion in Wall Street and apparently was a negligible factor in the stock market.

PRINCETON, N.J, Aug. 14 -- Secretary Morgenthau's current proposals for broadening the income tax base are directly in line with public sentiment throughout the country. However, the nation's voters would favor an even stiffer tax on the lower income groups than any recommended in Washington, either by the Treasury or by Congress.

The Associates Investment Company, one of the five largest automobile finance companies, reported yesterday net income for the first half of this year at $1,158,843, or $11.82 a share on 98,000 shares of preferred stock outstanding, against $1,459,690, or $14.89 a share, for the first half of 1940.

Nassau County, L.I., sold yesterday a new issue of $825,000 of bonds for refunding and relief purposes to the Franklin Square National Bank of Franklin Square, L.I. The identity of associates of the bank in the bidding was not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Authority for the issuance of $20,000,000 Series E equipment-trust certificates was asked of the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company.

While advertising's main function is to sell goods, it is being put to some diverse uses as a result of the present emergency. In recent weeks steel mills, through newspaper ads, have urged residents of their communities to collect scrap iron; a rayon company advised the hosiery industry of the amount of yarn it has available, and an oil company corrected one of its magazine ads in newspaper advertising.

Mayor La Guardia asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to consider amending the 1941 capital budget to provide for Initial financing of a new municipal airport, second only to La Guardia Field in size and importance, on Jamaica Bay in the Idlewild section of Queens.

For comparison with the Roosevelt-Churchill eight-point program there is presented herewith the text of the famous "14 points" laid down by President Wilson in an address before a joint session of Congress, Jan. 8, 1918:

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Much to the surprise of the wheat trade the market opened little changed today, despite what were regarded as bullish developments after the close yesterday. However, mills quickly absorbed the offerings and when a large-sized buying order hit the pit through a New York house prices ran up around 2 1/2 cents a bushel, with all deliveries selling at new seasonal high prices.
BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- After almost a year of patient waiting, Fiddler Bill McGee today experienced the strange sensation of starting, finishing and winning a ball game.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The will of Russell Colgate, filed for probate today in the Essex County Surrogate's office here, left .$300,000 to charitable, religious and welfare organizations, with $150,000 of this sum bequeathed to his son and daughter to select their own benefactions.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Miss Gertrude Robinson Smith, president of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival Corporation, had as guests tonight in boxes 1 and 2, at the opening of the third series of concerts at Tanglewood, her mother, Mrs. Robinson Smith; Miss Miriam K. Oliver, Mrs. James R. Hunt, Malcolm Vaughan, John Cunningham and Counts Robert de Cairy and Roman Nichaelowski.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- A hitherto unclassified civilization among the aboriginal inhabitants of America 1,500 years ago may have been uncovered by excavations near Glenwood, N.M., it was stated today by the Field Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Expectations of new moves by the United States Government to enlarge and accelerate material aid to Great Britain, Russia and China and other countries that may later resist the aggressions of the Axis powers sprang high in Washington today following disclosure of the Roosevelt-Churchill meeting at sea.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- As the police today questioned Naohiko Ishiyama, reportedly a member of the notorious Black Dragon Society, who yesterday shot and seriously wounded Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma, there seemed no doubt that the motive of the crime was political and possibly connected with the Baron's strong stand for a cautious foreign policy to prevent a complete break between Japan and Britain and the United States.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Aug. 15 (UP) -- British, and American informants, after a study of dispatches reporting the conference between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, said today that full British-American co-operation in the Far East now was "an established fact" and that Japan might be restrained, for a time, from any immediate new "aggression" in this part of the world.

The Roosevelt-Churchill declaration was generally hailed by organizations and individuals here yesterday as a blueprint for a democratic "new order," as a "victory code" and as "the 'Mein Kampf' of democracy."
ROME, Aug. 14 -- The Anglo-Saxon declarations of war aims made by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill will not be minimized here since their historic importance is too great.
Maxie Shapiro, East Side lightweight who is campaigning for a bout with Champion Lew Jenkins, got his revenge over Leo Rodak of Chicago last night at Ebbets Field.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The White Sox swept through the Tigers today in both games of a double-header, 3 to 1 and 3 to 0, to run their spurt to eleven victories in their last fourteen contests.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Fresh from the Roosevelt-Churchill conferences at sea, where, among other things, the problem of United States aid was discussed in its major phases, Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Supply in the British Government, arrived here by plane today to arrange for all the tanks, airplanes and foodstuffs the United States can supply.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 -- Chicago handed Pittsburgh its fourth straight lacing today in a 6-to-2 game that saw f ur Pirate pitchers fail to silence the Cubs' busy bats.

Confirmation of the report that Mrs. Marion Hasler of New York, Miami and Cat Cay, British West Indies, had taken a 246-pound broadbill on nine-thread line off Louisburg, N.S., evoked considerable comment yesterday from those who heard the news.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club won low-gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today when she toured the Siwanoy Country Club course, scene of the recent New York State championship, in 40, 46 -- 86.

Unless prime contractors receiving large defense orders from the government accelerate the letting of some of the work to smaller shop units, the government should write a clause in future contracts making such division mandatory, Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti asserted yesterday at the luncheon session of the seventh State defense production clinic at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Arrangements for registering New York and New Jersey troops among the 30,000 men stationed here for absentee voting in the September primary elections were ordered today in bulletins issued both by the Forty-fourth Division and post headquarters.

When London is bombed and shrines like St. Paul's, the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey are damaged or destroyed, it touches us where it hurts. They are part of our tradition. Nor are we surprised at the tales that come to us of the fortitude and bravery of the British.

The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday through Lauson H. Stone, chairman of its conduct committee, that it would take "immediate action" against three chemistry professors in two city colleges who have been accused in testimony before the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigation the public schools of being stockholders in a chemical concern supplying chemical kits to students in city colleges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Department-store sales for the week ended Aug. 9 were 46 per cent higher than for the corresponding week a year ago, while sales for the week ended Aug. 2 were up 27 per cent over the corresponding period of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- That an ever-increasing number of companies are sharing in the general business increase, many of them without benefit of defense orders, and that more companies, facing problems created by increases in commodity prices and uncertain deliveries, are building up raw materials inventories and reshaping their buying policies, are indicated in the monthly business survey of the New England Purchasing Agents Association, released today.

The great winds of history blew the two gray ships together in the shadowy lanes of the North Atlantic. They met at some predetermined point of latitude and longitude, there in the narrowing moat between two hemispheres where enemy submarines stalked the convoys shuttling back and forth from the Arsenal to the Fortress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A joint declaration of eight bases for world peace to follow "final destruction of the Nazi tyranny" was made public through Washington and London today in the names of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill after a series of historic and dramatic conferences between the two leaders somewhere on the Atlantic.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 14 -- When Henry Lewis poked through the deciding goal a few minutes before the final bell on Cochran Field this afternoon, the Pelicans captured the Meadow League half of the Meadow Brook Club's twelve-goal championship and qualified to meet Pegasus in the title play-off Saturday afternoon.

Hope that additional vessels will be put on runs to India, South Africa and Latin America was raised among foreign traders yesterday following a telephone survey conducted this week by the local office of the Department of Commerce among exporters and importers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Senate attaches said they assumed the Army extension, bill would be flown to President Roosevelt at sea in order to get it on the books as quickly as possible. General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, originally fixed Aug. 1 as the deadline on which the measure could be enacted without inconvenience to the Army.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The War Department announced today that it plans to construct $2,000,000 terminal facilities for lease-lend supplies in the vicinity of Caven Point in Jersey City, N.J., which is part of New York Harbor. The department said the project was "subject to satisfactory negotiations for the real estate."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A prediction, that the rate of expansion under the nation's defense program will slow down was made today in a report by the division of research of the Works Progress Administration.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- In a special communique issued from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters somewhere on the Eastern Front the Germans declared this evening that the defense of the Western Ukraine by the Russian armed forces was facing complete collapse.

OTTAWA, Aug. 14 -- Prime Minister William MacKenzie King today expressed on behalf of the Dominion of Canada full association with the declaration that was issued at the close of the Atlantic conference between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- After escaping injury in a fall during the first race at Narragansett, Jockey Teddy Atkinson came back today to win the New Haven Purse, an allowance for 2-year-old fillies, with G.F. Strickland's Pompa Negri.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The war Department released the following orders today dated Aug. 13:

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 14 -- Wilhelm Leichum, one of Germany's best track athletes in the pre-war years, was killed in action on the Eastern Front, it was learned today. He was twice European champion in the broadjump and three times holder of the German record.

The strike of members of Local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, at three shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company was terminated last night by an agreement brought about by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The United Light and Power Company, top unit in a $500,000,000 Utility System operating in the Middle West and Southwest, announced today from its headquarters here in letters to stockholders that it will comply with orders by the Securities and Exchange Commission stripping the system to about one-half its present size.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Miss Helen Jacobs, Greenville, Del., national tennis champion from 1932 to 1935, was eliminated from the Essex County Club's invitation tourney today as she was swept from both singles and doubles competition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Considerable surprise was occasioned in Department of State and diplomatic circles here today when the White House sent to the Senate the nomination of Willys R. Peck to be United States Minister to Thailand.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 14 -- Riots of "Communist inspiration" were reported here today to have broken out in Paris during the last two days, in which at least six persons were killed and nineteen others seriously injured when the police fired on the demonstrators.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 14 -- It is reliably reported here that General Francisco Franco has ordered the deportation from Spain of Cardinal Segura y Saenz, formerly Spanish Primate and recently Archbishop of Seville, as a result of criticism of government policies at a conference held in the Seville Cathedral last week.

Battery Park was "saved" last night by the New York , Guard from the insidious activities of "subversive elements," which attempted to start a riot to cover up some projected dirty work to shipping facilities at Pier A.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The seven-day-old strike at the Caldwell propeller plant of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation was ended this morning in compliance with a request of the OPM and the National Defense Mediation Board that workers go back while their demands are being weighed.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Aug. 15 -- Russian troops in the Southern Ukraine sector have been forced to withdraw along a wide front, evacuating two key points of the Odessa defenses, according to a Moscow communique issued shortly after midnight tonight.

Independent steamship operators and other operators banded together in shipping "conferences" filed new freight rate recommendations with the United States Maritime Commission yesterday under the compulsion of the new Ship Warrant Bill recently signed by President Roosevelt.

Expeditions to market this weekend will be pleasant occasions for conscientious shoppers. News from the Consumer's Service Bureau of the Department of Markets is that meat prices either have declined or remain unchanged from last week.

BUFFALO, Aug. 14 -- After two and a half hours of turbulent debate, the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. convention tonight adopted a strong declaration amending the constitution to bar from office members of Communist, Fascist or Nazi organizations.

Frank Gruber, recent newcomer to the mystery-novel field, who has a contract with Farrar Rinehart for mysteries almost ad infinitum, has changed his pace slightly and done a Western novel. It is called "Outlaw" and will be published Sept. 11.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A constantly moving circle of destroyers, patrol boats and other small warships formed a precautionary defensive ring around the Roosevelt-Churchill conference ship and United States planes droned overhead, The Daily Mail said today in a dispatch from its correspondent "somewhere on the American Atlantic Coast."

The arrest of the owner of an inconspicuous midtown sewing machine repair shop late yesterday afternoon in the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey led to the revelation that an organized gang of criminals, most of them Negroes, had been hampering defense preparations through burglaries in shops making uniforms for the Army, Navy and marines.

Some of the women enrolled in Britain's defense forces perform their service by looking into mirrors in which they see, not the reflections of their uniformed selves, but the puff of exploding anti-aircraft shells. Such increasingly military roles assigned to women were described by Mary Craig McGeachy of the British Ministry of Economic Warfare, in a lecture last night at the Museum of Science and Industry.

Delegates to two Catholic conventions which will be in session at the Hotel Commodore today continuing through Wednesday arrived yesterday and last night. They will attend the eighty-sixth annual convention of the Central Verein of America, an organization of Catholic men of German descent, and the twenty-fifth annual assembly of the National Catholic Women's Union, whose members also are of German origin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 --Industrial output in the United States is just double that in the middle of 1938, when it had reached about the point which prevailed throughout the whole period of the first World War, the Department of Commerce stated today.

HERE'S fun! Ellsworth Vines qualified for the national amateur golf championship to toe played over the Omaha Field Club course, beginning a week from Monday. That's the same lanky Ellsworth who was the top tennis player of the world, first as an amateur and later as a professional.

VICHY, France, Aug. 15 -- Death will be the penalty for the slightest Communist activity in Paris, it was announced today by General Heinrich von Stuelpnagel, commander of the German armies of occupation in France. The warning was published this morning in all the Paris newspapers, following riots this week in which the police had to fire on a crowd attempting a demonstration.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The anti - Communist forces led by President R.J. Thomas and Walter P. Reuther of Detroit won a majority of the membership on the executive board of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., tonight.

The duty of the organized religious forces in the present world crisis will be the topic of many sermons tomorrow. Several clergymen will comment on the Roosevelt-Churchill peace platform, especially the plank that declares their belief "that all the nations of the world, for realistic as well as spiritual reasons, must come to the abandonment of the use of force."

In order to avoid a conflict of opening dates, the League of New York Theatres, the managerial organization, has notified its members that the following shows have registered their Broadway premieres:

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The hog trade turned more active today, but price trends were mixed, only light and medium weight swine being in good demand and their values advancing 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight. Both, cattle and sheep were steady. The steer trade reflected a healthy undertone with weighty steers more active than heretofore.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- This city was selected today by the Office of Production Management for a new experiment in solving industrial and labor dislocations by bringing representatives of government, labor and industry into conference on common problems.

Believing that a luxury market is now in the making, Parfums Ybry, which in 1930-31 spent more than 5200,000, plans to resume national advertising in October. The program was made possible by a sales increase of 50 per cent in the last year.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Despite the presence of a former national and British amateur golf champion, plus any number of other links luminaries, it remained for a one-time Yale oarsman, Jimmy Knott, to capture the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Maidstone Bowl tourney today.

National defense has forced the postponement for at least a year of the old-fashioned county fair that was to have been staged in Madison Square Garden from Sept. 10 to 20, officials of the American Institute of the City of New York, the sponsoring organization, announced yesterday.

Officials of newsreel companies yesterday expressed dissatisfaction with the manner in which the historic meeting at sea of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill had been photographed by official American and British photographers aboard the U.S.S. Augusta and the H.M.S. Prince of Wales.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 15 -- Every United States soldier eventually may carry a vial of his own blood serum tucked away in his knapsack for immediate transfusion in case he is wounded on the battlefield.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Elmer Layden, commissioner of professional football, today approved a schedule of sixteen exhibition games for National League teams. Five of the games involve the Kenosha (Wis.) Cardinals, a strong independent team coached by Johnny Blood, a former National League star.

Moving erratically throughout the session in quiet trading, price on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at net losses of 3 to 6 points. The opening was firm, but uncertainty over developments in Washington and abroad induced traders to assume a cautious attitude.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: This is an indictment against the home-run, the modern Chinese excuse for, a circuit clout. Let us look at the record and reason. The most common and frequent base hit is, the single. The ballplayer who bangs out 200 hits

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The value of the new-fangled helmets worn by baseball players was proved again the other day over in Brooklyn when Camilli and Reiser of the Dodgers were beaned by Errickson of Boston and escaped serious injury because the helmets

More than 200 French merchant marine officers and licensed seamen have deserted their vessels in American harbors since the fall of France in the Summer of 1940, and about 160 of them have offered their services to the Free French leaders in London, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- It was revealed today that the crash of a ferry plane last night, in which Arthur B. Purvis, chairman of the British Supply Council in North America was killed, had taken the lives of twenty-one others, eleven of them United States pilots engaged in the ferrying of American bombers to Britain.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- One of the largest dinners here tonight was given by Mr. and Mrs. Verner Z. Reed Jr. at Terra Mare.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- Henry Fonda and John Payne were named today for leading roles with Randolph Scott in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Ten Gentlemen From West Point," which will go before the cameras in October. Tyrone Power previously had been mentioned for the film, but was withdrawn because of conflicting assignments.

DURHAM, N.C., Aug. 15 (U.P) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox tonight expressed the hope that President Roosevelt, upon his return from, his historic meeting with Prime Minister Winston Churchill, would submit the eight-point declaration of peace terms for formal adoption by Congress as "America's principles."
To Sports Editor of Tfcs New York Times: May I express myself concerning something that has puzzled and annoyed me for a long time?

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Foreseeing a big opportunity to reinforce regular transportation agencies during the defense emergency, the National Food Distributors Association will devote the major part of its convention program here, beginning next Wednesday, to the role the store-door grocery wholesalers can play in the distributive field over the next twelve months.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Although the national sweepstakes here tomorrow and Sunday will be America's largest speed boat event of the season and may, with its nearly 300 entries, prove to be the largest regatta of all time anywhere, it probably will sound the death knell of the famous Gold Cup classic.

Pour four-story apartment houses known as 57-79 Avenue O, Brooklyn, comprising the entire west blockfront between West Eighth and West Ninth Streets, have been sold by the 57-79 Avenue O Corporation, represented by Wasserman, Behr Shagan, attorneys, to a syndicate comprised of Samuel J. Sussman, Sol Rothkopf and J. Bombart.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., scored his first victory on record over Frank Parker of Spring Lake, N.J., today and Donald McNeill, the national champion from Oklahoma, gained a largely uncontested victory over John Kramer of Montebello, Calif., in the semifinals of the invitation tennis tournament at the Casino.

The command of the Navy's air base at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn changed hands at 11 A.M. yesterday with traditional ceremony when Commander Edward O. McDonnell of the Naval Reserve relieved Commander Don F. Smith, who has been in charge of the base since June 8, 1939.

THE oldest by far of all our first families should gather their clans into a society. It might tie called the S.D.S.M. The initials, of course, would stand for Sons and Daughters of the Siberian Migration, and the members would be the American Indians whose ancestors,' according to many authorities, came to this country from Siberia by way of the Bering Straits town and country houses are scattered over America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Because more than 40 per cent of examined men are being classified as unfit for general military service, an "alarming" percentage, the Commission on Physical Rehabilitation recommended today a government-financed program of voluntary physical rehabilitation of rejected selectees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Estimating the prospects for the furniture industry, the Commerce Department reported today that many domestic furniture woods such as cherry, maple, oak, walnut and birch are available in good quantity, though a future shortage of mahogany may develop due to increased demand for its use in planes and shortage of transportation facilities.
The War Department will open a central purchasing department on Monday for Army post exchanges at 111 Eighth Avenue, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Alejandro Carrasquel, the towering Venezuelan who until a few weeks ago wasn't entrusted with a starting pitching assignment, won his sixth victory of the year against no defeats for the Senators today by turning back the Red Sox 6 to 3.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 15 -- Delegates from all States of Colombia were in the capital today for the convention of the National Liberal party that opens tomorrow for selection of a candidate to President of the Republic Caucuses and reported political deals through the week have left the situation confused, but the trend is definitely in favor of former President Alfonso Lopez.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Today the War Department announced that it had awarded contracts totaling $39,743,911. Firms in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

That dash of rain which cracked down on the city yesterday afternoon did a number of annoying things to the Yankees, individually and collectively. For one thing, it washed out the opening clash of a four-game series with the Athletics at the Stadium at the very moment the Bronx Bombers were all set to dash out on the field to give the Mackmen a going over.

Reserve Requirements What with all the current moves to forestall or check inflation, it is only natural that the subject of increasing reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System should come up again in banking circles.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The 369th Coast Artillery Regiment from Harlem, in training at Fort Ontario, will be commanded for ten weeks, starting Aug. 24, by Lieut. Col. Demaurice Moses, in civil life a New York attorney. He will be in charge while Colonel Chauncey M. Hooper and nine officers on his staff are attending Artillery School at Fort Monroe, Va.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Most hitters are urged to hit the ball with full strength when they step up to bat. As a consequence they all are shooting for the outfield walls and as often as not wind up by hitting long meaningless flies into the hands of waiting outfielders.

Enforcement of fair trade contracts will be helped immeasurably by a court decision this week under which a retailer who cuts prices on a protected item can be made to surrender the stocks he has on hand and enjoined from handling the procuct in the future, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by officials of retail trade groups in the drug, gasoline, tobacco and grocery lines.

The volume of new bond financing this week, amounting to $4,393,000, was the smallest for any week since that ended on June 14, 1940, when the total was $3,809,600. This week's new bond flotations comprised seven municipal loans, ranging in size from $100,000 to $2,716,000.

VICHY, France, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Outbreaks of arson, bombings and anti-Jewish violence spread through both Nazi-held and unoccupied France today as German military authorities warned bluntly that the entire population of the occupied zone would suffer if "Communist" outbreaks continued.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Whirlaway will run tomorrow in the oldest race renewed in the United States when he goes to the post for the seventy-second Travers, and there are only a few who think that he will be beaten for the $22,500 mile-and-a-quarter prize.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15 -- The combined forces of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Berkshire Music Center's orchestra, chorus, chamber music and opera divisions and the 250 army bandsmen from Camp Edwards on the Cape gave the gala benefit for the USO and the British War Relief at Tanglewood this afternoon and evening the appearance of a manyringed musical circus.

The meeting place of the President and the Prime Minister was like a guarded island in a perilous sea. The two great battleships that bore them to the rendezvous, the Augusta and the Prince of Wales, anchored close together while the passengers exchanged their history-making visits, were ringed around with walls of steel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Taxation of all wages and salaries, dividends and interest at their source was proposed to the Senate Finance Committee today by the United States Chamber of Commerce as one way of increasing Federal revenues by 54,500,000,000 annually.

Miss Dorothy Dyer Butler, daughter of Mrs. James Butler of this city and Bedford Hills, N.Y., and the late Mr. Butter, has completed plans for her marirage to Lewis Bradley Harder, son of Mrs. Crawford Burton of this city and East Hampton, L.I., and Lewis Francis Harder of Philmont, N.Y.

The State of Delaware awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,165,000 of public-improvement bonds to a syndicate comprising B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., Schmidt, Poole Co. of Philadelphia, Barclay, Moore Co. of Philadelphia, Dolphin Co., R.S. Dickson Co. inc., Suplee, Yeatman Co., Inc., of Philadelphia and Bioren Co. of Philadelphia.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Mitchel Gardens, one of the first defense housing projects for the Army's noncommissioned officer personnel, will be opened tomorrow at ceremonies attended by representatives of the Federal, State and local governments and civilian groups.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Following is the text of the gasoline curtailment order issued by Leon Henderson at the request of Secretary Ickes:

TOKYO, Aug. 15 -- The program for the post-war world proclaimed by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill is attacked in Japan as contrary to her aim to create a "Greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere" and to "liberate the Orient from the shackles of white capitalism."
CAIRO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

The Rivoli Theatre, which has been closed since May 9, will reopen on Labor Day, Sept. 1, with the local premiere of Universal's "Unfinished Business," the management announced yesterday. The film, which was directed by Gregory LaCava, stars Irene Dunne and Robert Montgomery.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 15 -- Lieut. Col. William B. Walters and Lieut. Col. William Clarke, two New Yorkers who ran away from home in their midteens, joined the Army and stayed with it until they are now regimental commanders, brought their outfits home today from secret manoeuvres.

Trading was fairly active on most classes in the wholesale meat markets yesterday. Prices of steer hinds and ribs, veal and pork cuts were unchanged. Lamb was strong to $1 higher. Cow and bull beef was steady to strong. Kosher chucks and plates and veal foresaddles were steady, while lamb foresaddles were strong to mostly $1 higher.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 -- Plans to bring the nation's twenty-six aluminum ware plants into defense production were discussed at a meeting here today, called by Sidney Hillman, associated director of the Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Consumption of cotton by United States mills in the year ended on July 31 was the largest on record, surpassing the previous mark by about 22 per cent, Census Bureau officials said today. Exports, on the other hand, were the smallest since Civil War days.

Patrolman Nicholas Tully of the East 104th Street station, who shot and critically wounded another patrolman and killed the patrolman's accomplice after the two men had attempted, it was charged, to extort money from a Harlem candy stora proprietor Thursday night, received a personal commendation yesterday from Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine for his act.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Two revelations of growing dangers to the United States were made tonight by Secretary Stimson in a radio address to men of the Army.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The arrival of eight new sixteen-ton tanks mounting cannon marked a forward march at Pine Camp this week into a new mode of combat manoeuvres.

Wholesale purchasing continued during the past week in record-breaking proportions, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The production trend was steady against a rising volume of orders, as a lack of raw materials caused activity to slacken in several industries.

Joseph W. Frazer, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., announced yesterday to stockholders a consolidated net income of $111,442 for the three months ended on June 30 after all charges and provision for Federal income taxes at existing rates.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- If Britain is invaded this Autumn and the whole country is occupied by the enemy and supplies from overseas are cut off, the people would still be fed adequately for weeks, it was said today when a plan for "shadow larders" was made public.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- What appears to be a renewed German offensive -- concentrated on the three major salients, but actually extending the entire length of the front between the Arctic Ocean and the Black Sea -- is now in progress. The German Army apparently has been slowed down in the northern and northwestern sectors, but is managing to gain considerable territory in the Southern Ukraine.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15 -- The text of the prepared address of Lord Halifax at the benefit performance of the Boston Symphony Orchestra tonight was as fallows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A proposal that Premier Joseph Stalin receive "high representatives" of the United States and Great Britain in Moscow to discuss "long-term" plans for defeat of the Axis was transmitted to the Soviet leader today by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill in a joint message.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox climbed to within a half game of third place in the American League tonight by defeating Cleveland, 5 to 2, before 34,879. It was their twelfth victory in fifteen games.

Brig. Gen. Archibald Campbell, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Campbell of 11 1/2 East Eighty-seventh Street, and Cold Spring, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Margaret Campbell, to Richard Fairfield Humphreys, son-of Mr. and Mrs. London Humphreys of 2 East Eighty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 2 was 4,859,080 shares, compared with 4,952,890 shares in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

TOKYO, Aug. 15 -- "Further to enhance the traditionally friendly relations between Japan and Thailand," the governments of the two countries elevated their diplomatic representatives to the rank of Ambassador, it was announced today.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Having released, as an antidote to the Roosevelt-Churchill declaration, two special communiques last evening prophesying the imminent collapse of the Russian forces in the Western Ukraine, the German High Command retired again today behind its customary veil of silence.

A Connecticut correspondent has called attention to the appearance of snapper blues off Branford during the past few days. It may be too early to anticipate a run of these scrappy little fellows that have brought so much fun to the Long Island Sound fishermen of varying ages in bygone years, but many in the vicinity of New Haven are hoping that this isn't just a flash in the pan.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- About one hundred members of the New York League of Locality Mayors, Inc., arrived here this evening for their annual three-day convention.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15 -- The increasing unity of the two great English-speaking peoples in the cause of ending chaos and insuring a better world for all was the keynote sounded by speakers at the gala benefit put on at Tanglewood today by the Berkshire festival forces for the USO and the British War Relief.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Little Pat won the $1,200 FreeFor-All Pace on the Illinois State Fair's closing Grand Circuit program today, but Atlantic Hanover, the brown gelding from Hanover Shoe Farms, stole the show in the third heat by pacing the fastest mile this year, 1:59 3/4.

Despite the presence on the calendar of two offerings amounting together to $9,050,000, new State and municipal issues scheduled for sale next week by sixty-eight municipalities make a total of only $13,444,311. This compares with sales of $11,950,487 in the current period and with a weekly average of $36,162,884 of new offerings for the year to date.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Aug. 15 -- The precedent-shattering cruise that opened a new era of British-American relations when President Roosevelt agreed with Prime Minister Churchill to peace aims predicated upon prior "destruction of the Nazi tyranny," will end tomorrow when the President debarks at Rockland, Me.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. John Crerar grave a dinner tonight at Driftwood, her home on the ocean, for her niece, Mrs. MacKeen Bacoa of Halifax, N.S., who is visiting her. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Valentine B. Macy Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Francis Oakey, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. Condon, Mr. and Mrs. Hudson Budd, John H. Morice and Oakley Radway.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, retired, wartime commander of the Twenty-seventh Division and now director of Civilian Defense in New York State, appealed this morning at the State convention of the American Legion for immediate entry of the United States into the war.

The Roosevelt-Churchill eight points, accompanied by yesterday's letter to Premier Joseph Stalin, and the military-naval discussions that undoubtedly prefaced the agreement may have a profound effect upon the course of the war.

The management of the International Utilities Corporation, of which Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey was elected chairman last week, won a victory over opposition groups yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber granted a temporary injunction restraining the holding of an extraordinary stockholders' meeting which had been called for Aug. 19 in Baltimore for the purpose of voting on the ouster of all but one of the present directors.

Inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 20 per cent during July over the same month last year, while sales during that month rosa to 22 per cent, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Sam Barry will carry on where the late Howard Jones left off as head man of the University of Southern California football regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- All American citizens and aliens desiring to enter or leave the United States after Sept. 1 will be required to obtain entry or exit permits, or their equivalent, under new regulations now under preparation by the State and Justice Departments.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, for the second week in a row, won low gross' honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association with 37, 44 -- 81 over the north course of the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

ALBANY, Aug. l5 -- The names of 690 law students, graduated in June and passing the State Bar examination, were announced today by the State Board of Examiners, consisting of John Kirkland Clark of New York City, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and John T. DeGraff of Albany. A total of 1,263 applicants was examined on June 24 and 25.

Realty activity along the West Side in Manhattan yesterday was featured by the purchase by the Laneva Holding: Corporation of the nine-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 102.2 feet- at 115-17 West Seventy-first Street from, the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

A client of Joseph S. Altschul, attorney, has purchased from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the two-story taxpayer at 102-02 to 102-04 Northern Boulevard, on the Goutheast corner of 102d Street, Corona, Queens. The building covers a plot 40 by 115 feet. The mortgage of $50,500 which the bank held on the property has been satisfied.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A tentative draft of its first regulations restricting installment buying under the President's recent order was issued to credit agencies today by the Federal Reserve Board. The aim is to combat inflation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Here is the prepared text of the radio address tonight by Secretary Stimson to the soldiers of the Army:

Convinced that the post-war program announced by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill as the result of their secret rendezvous at sea was only an overture to more momentous moves associated directly with the conduct of the war, traders reduced activities on the stock market yesterday to a minimum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Masonite Corporation, Chicago, engaged in the manufacture and sale of hardboard products, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 35,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent series cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, involving $3,675,000.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Supreme Court Justice Francis D. McGarey here held late today that preferred stockholders of the Queensborough Gas, and Electric Company and of the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company were entitled to an accounting of the profits of those firms and of the Long Island Lighting Company, by which the two companies are controlled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A 10 per cent cut in the deliveries of gasoline to filling stations, garages and other retailers in seventeen Eastern States was ordered today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, at the request of Secretary Ickes, Federal Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 16 -- The United States is expected to become the chief guardian of "the democracies' ramparts" in the Pacific, while providing a steady flow of war aid to Russia, under plans worked out by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill, it was stated here early today.

LISBON, Portgual, Aug. 15 -- It was learned from a high Vichy source tonight that General Maxime Weygand had a heated argument with Admiral Francois Darlan and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain before his recent departure from Vichy for North Africa.

EAST OTIS, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Girl Scout and Girl Guide delegates to the Western Hemisphere encampment at Camp Bonnie Brae today exchanged recipes and cooked some of the dishes to show how good they were.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 15 -- First actual practice on Camp Stewart's new small-arm range for anti-aircraft and anti-tank fire started today. Battery G of 207th Coast Artillery Regiment of New York City was the first command to open fire.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and, other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- The Walt Disney cartoon studios shut down tonight, laying off about 1,000 employes for at least two weeks because of a new outbreak of labor difficulties which had been settled temporarily July 29 when the nine-wreck strike of the Screen Cartoon Guild was ended.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 15 -- The declaration of war aims issued yesterday by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill was greeted with warm approval here.

St. Stephen, whose wise laws were a model to medieval Europe and whose religious fervor won him sainthood, was the first King of Hungrary. And he is still venerated by his countrymen, who celebrate his feast as their great national holiday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- In a brief debate which was slowed up by repeated efforts to obtain a quorum, the Senate passed today and sent to the House a substitute defense highway bill for that vetoed recently by President Roosevelt.

Dennis Standing-Bear, 12-yearold grandson of old Chief Standing Bear who was Sitting Bull's most belligerent political opponent, led three fellow Sioux Indians into New York last evening. The four youngr braves, all school-mates at a mission school in Pine Ridge, S. D., evidently had heard about what happened to Indians on Manhattan Island.

Monthly Government estimates of crop yields throw some light on the farm bloc's activities. The "ceiling" on prices for wheat and cotton has been fixed at 10 per cent above the imaginary "parity" with prices of what the farmer has to buy, or "at the July 29' j price, whichever is higher."

Dr. Robert Leigh, founder and first president of Bennington College for women, has just resigned. It was in 1928 that he began to seek support for his notion of a new college on a new plan. Its students were not to number more than 250. There should be one teacher for about every five students.

The reports of 137 Class I railroads in the United States to the Interstate Commerce Commission show an aggregate net operating income in June of $93,261,372, compared with $48,090,783 in June, 1940. The combined net operatin, income of these carriers in the half-year was $433,538,411, compared with $245,523,110 in the 1940 period.

NEW YORK Mrs. Ripley Hitchcock and her sister, Mrs. William Greig Walker, who have resided at 28 East Seventy-third Street for many years, have left for their new home at Cliffview Drive, Silvermine Falls, Norwalk, Conn.

Here is the saga of Peter, the jealous sea lion, whose refusal to play second fiddle to Annie, the penguin, caused a commotion yesterday morning in Fifth Avenue, between Forty-ninth, and Fiftieth Streets, when fourteen penguins replaced seven sea lions in the Prometheus Fountain at the Sunken Plaza of Rockefeller Center.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 14.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Congress sent to the White House today a $7,550,000,000 Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bill after restoring $750,000,000 of the $1,347,000,000 eliminated from the measure yesterday by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A fifteen-page questionnaire went out to 225 members of the steel industry today as part of an effort by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply to obtain data on which to base decisions on any adjustments that might become neccessary in the ceiling prices established for iron and steel products.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, who was denied designation for renomination by the New York County Republican organization because of his appointment of Simon W. Gerson, Communist writer, as a member of his staff, announced last night his withdrawal as a candidate for renomination and simultaneously announced his candidacy for election to the City Council.

An apartment of seven rooms and three baths in 1130 Park Avenue has been leased by Harold Bernstein, cotton merchant, from Marcus Brown Co., agents, in a rental arranged by Warren Marks Associates, brokers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Mr. and "Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who have been spending part of their wedding trip at his Adirondack mountain lodge, attended the races today and had as guests in their box Mr. and Mrs. Bertrand L. Taylor of New York.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 15 -- The Roosevelt-Churchill eight-point declaration, though widely and prominently displayed in the Swiss press today, brought little comment, leading editorialists preferring to "feel the international pulse."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Three hours of rain and a tough course played havoc today with the hopes of some 140 golfers to break par in the first eighteen holes of the $5,000 Times-Union open at the Oak Hills Club as only two shotmakers managed to better the magic mark of 70.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Rookie Bob Muncrief checked the Detroit Tigers on six hits tonight, while the St. Louis Browns made the same number of blows good enough for a 6-to-l triumph, largely because of Outfielder Joe Grace's third-inning homer with two on base.

Two unidentified submarines, traveling on the surface of the water, were sighted about 400 miles west of Horta, the Azores, last Thursday at dusk by passengers aboard the Atlantic Clipper, it was reported yesterday when, the Pan American Airways flying boat landed here.

In the great volume of comment on the dramatic meeting of Mr. Churchill and Mr. Roosevelt on the high seas the chief note of skepticism and of opposition (outside of the Axis nations) is sounded by certain members of Congress. The comment of Senator Walsh of Massachusetts is a case in point.

The first ship constructed in the United States for the British Government since the days of the World War is to go down the ways of the Todd-California Shipbuilding Corporation at Richmond, Calif., this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Assurances that Britain will not need American man power to win the war with the Axis powers if she can have the fullest possible material aid and moral support from this country were given by Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Supply of the British Government, to key defense officials here today.

HIGH POINT, N.C, Aug. 15 -- Fourteen-year-old Miss Nancy Merki, who was a cripple the first eight years of her life, set a new American record for 1,500 meters today as she sent her Portland, Ore., team booming' into the lead on the first day of the A.A.U.'s women's national swimming championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Arthur B. Purvis, chairman of the British Supply Council in North America, who was among the twenty-two persons killed in a plane crash in Great Britain yesterday, was eulogized by high officials here today.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 16 -- More than 300 big British bombers attacked Hanover, Brunswick and Magdeburg through Thursday night, setting huge fires and spreading destruction in the three German cities, the Air Ministry reported.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- The Russian army of the Ukraine is engaged in a grim and historic retreat, leveling fields and wrecking factories in its wake, for a finish fight against the German forces on the Dnieper River line, authoritative sources reported today.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Hypocrite, racing for Harry A. Parr 3d, won Narragansett Park's featured $3,500 claiming race today with a half-length victory over the favored Calexico, owned by Miss Carrie Hardin.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Under a fine ride by Jockey Jack Richard, the Arcturus Stable's consistent sprinter Smacked won the Epinard Purse, a six-furlong feature at Washington Park today.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Aug. 15 -- Wide fluctuations were in evidence as the Bourse opened. today. Amsterdam Trading was 13 higher at 464 but most of the gains were lost on heavy profit-taking and the close was irregular and lower.

Contractual relations with the Kemkit Scientific Corporation, 391 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, have beer broken by City, Brooklyn and Quens Colleges, it was learned yesterday. The action followed disclosures by the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee showing that two City College professors and the head of the Chemistry Department at Brooklyn College had had financial interests in the concern, which supplied students with chemistry kits required for laboratory work.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The qualifying round of the first annual Hummocks Country Club invitation, tournament was staged today in rain and a shifting wind. The Unusual weather conditions played havoc with the scores of the sixty-one contestants, and despite the perfectly groomed layout the best score of the day was a 77.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 -- Johnny Vander Meer's twelfth victory of the year and his fourth in succession sent Cincinnati into a third-place tie with the idle Pittsburgh Pirates today as the Reds, held to five hits, defeated Chicago, 3 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A joint United States Army-Civil Aeronautics program for the training in this country of more than 600 Latin-American pilots and technicians was announced today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- The State Banking Department announced today in its weekly bulletin that it had issued a certificate declaring the establishment of an insurance department in the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

The nation's capital during the Civil War is the subject of "Reveille in Washington," Book-of-theMonth Club selection for September that will be published by Harper's on Aug. 28. The author is Margaret Leech (Mrs. Ralph Pulitzer) who undertook the research on the book five years ago at the suggestion of the publishers.

TOKEPA, Kan., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Alf M. Landon said today that "it is evident from the way the Roosevelt-Churchill momentous meeting and statement were handled that there was a well-staged effort to mislead the American people as to the purpose of this meeting."

Trade Here Up 30-40% in Week Retail trade here continued to show striking percentage gains this week in comparison with a year ago. Department store volume was estimated as showing a rise of 30 to 40 per cent over the 1940 week.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 15 -- It was revealed here today that British bombers attacked the Corinth Canal in Greece last Wednesday and Friday nights, apparently causing sufficient damage to prevent the passage of Axis shipping for a considerable time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The following is the text of a joint message from President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill delivered today by the United States and British Ambassadors to Joseph Stalin, President, of the Soviet of People's Commissars of the U.S.S.R.:

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Outside interest in the wheat market fell off sharply today and professional operations also were restricted. Commission houses, however, were fair buyers on the dips, as were mills and when local shorts tried to cover they found offerings light.

VICHY, France, Aug. 15 -- What is to happen to Edouard Daladier and Leon Blum, former Premiers; Guy La Chambre, former Air Minister, and General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, former generalissimo of the then Allied forces, under the new dispensation announced by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, in his broadcast to the nation last Tuesday?
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I hope your readers will not fail to acknowledge our debt to Hitler for making possible the already historic Declaration of the Atlantic.

FORT DIX, Aug. 15 -- Undaunted by a sudden downpour, Brig. Gen. James I. Muir, Eighty-seventh Brigade commander, finished an "off the record" talk to the 4,000 men of his command assembled in an open field this morning". The new brigade commander spoke for fifteen minutes in the rain.
