HAVANA, Aug. 15 -- Five German consular officials and the former Italian Consul General, Amadeo Barletta, were ordered to leave Cuba by Sept. 5 "for reasons convenient to American policies and the Cuban nation," Jose Manuel Cortina, Minister of State, announced today.
Busy Summer Student We are at the end of the Summer session season College work, both in the studying and the teaching, is one American industry that has been moving against the trend of the times.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 (AP)-- The German High Command communique said today:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Miss Francesca, Lippincott Villa, youngest daughter of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa of New York and Newport, was married here this afternoon to Hugo Rutherfurd of New York, son of Winthrop Rutherfurd of Allamuchy, N.J., and Aiken, S.C., and the late Mrs. Alice Morton Rutherford, in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

MANILA, Aug. 16 -- This city, which is closer to war and aggression than any city under the United States flag, is adapting its easygoing civilian life almost unawares to surroundings resembling an armed camp. Parks are being turned into drill grounds and quiet, walled nooks into target ranges.
VICHY, France, Aug. 16 -- Jean Lacroix has hanged himself. He was buried today in his native village of La Ricamarie, not far from Lyon. He was 24 years old. He leaves a wife and a young child.
BERLIN, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Both the Roosevelt-Churchill eight points and plan to aid Russia drew scornful words today from Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels.
MOST of the outdoor Summer concert series in this country came to a close last week and statistics have already started to pour in. They all show that Americans turned out in record-breaking numbers.

ERNST LOTHAR, Viennese writer of light, readable fiction, has based his latest novel on a young girl's diary. Franzi Longer, so the author tells us, was a close friend of his for more than a year. She left her native Vienna voluntarily after the Anschluss to live in Paris, where she married a French journalist.
BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Women golfers will gather at Manchester in the Green Mountains this week for the women's annual invitation tournament for Vermont next Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

COLUMBUS, Ga. YOU hear a roar of motors and the hiss of rubber tires on concrete, and the "Rolling Fourth" is passing by. Mile on mile of trucks and trailers and cars, crammed with the "gasoline doughboys" of the Army, loaded heavily with equipment and ammunition, towing guns and the stuff of war.

A four-hour moonlight cruise up the Hudson on the river steamer Peter Stuyvesant has been arranged for Sept. 4 under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society. Shipboard games, dancing to the music of a well-known orchestra and other festivities have been devised for the occasion.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Sammy Snead of Hot Springs, Va., today coupled an even par 70 in the $5,000 Times-Union open golf tournament with yesterday's 67 for a thirty-six-hole total of 137 and remained on top at the halfway mark of the seventy-two-hole grind.

MRS. MARGARET CULKIN BANNING, some time last Winter, took off enough time from her popular fiction serials to make an airplane trip around South America. Now she has published a haphazard diary of that trip.

VICHY, France, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Paris police warning the population that sabotage on railway lines serving the occupied French capital was threatening the city's food supply, offered one million francs reward tonight for information leading to the arrests of the wreckers.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 16 -- A report of the operations service of the Fourth Corps Area today revealed the record of the War Department of the last year in supplying 400,000 men with equipment and accessories for service.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Lou De Filippo, Fordham center, arrived in camp today to bring the Eastern College All-Star football squad to twenty-nine and complete the roster except for the eight men who will play in the Chicago All-Star game Aug. 28.

Settlement of the six-month strike of the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., against The Jewish Day was announced last night in a joint statement by Robert Daru, attorney for the management of the Jewish-language newspaper, and Nat Einhorn, executive secretary of the Guild.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Fifty young women of experience and ability in the related fields of recreational and social work, family welfare and protective services and community organization will come here from all parts of the country next week.

At a historic conference held in a ship somewhere on the North Atlantic two men of the sea spoke some vigorous words for the truth last week. Mr. Roosevelt, once Assistant Secretary of the United States Navy, and Mr. Churchill, once First Lord of the British Admiralty, defined the terms of an honest peace.

England's request for greater quantities of bacon, pork products, beef and cheese under the lease-lend act will be a bullish factor in the food markets, but the government's mechanism for price control will prevent any appreciable advance in prices to American consumers, leaders of the industry asserted here yesterday.

Six out of ten new automobiles are sold on the installment plan; one out of every two refrigerators or washing machines is sold on a time-payment basis; almost seven out of ten women buy furniture on this basis, and one out of every ten men takes ten weeks to three months to pay for his clothing purchases.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- Germany claimed important gains tonight in a new offensive on the central front against Moscow, a drive from Finland toward Leningrad and an advance of about 180 miles in seven days of furious fighting toward the heart of the Ukraine.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- London quarters reported today that the forthcoming three-power conference of Russia, Britain and the United States would be directed not only at augmenting the flow of war supplies to the Soviet for her war against Germany but also to plans for making Japan "stop, look and listen."
CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Reds made it four-in-a-row over Chicago and won their fifth straight victory today, 4 to 1, behind Elmer Riddle's brilliant three-hit hurling.

The government order curtailing by 10 per cent deliveries on gasoline to retailers in seventeen Atlantic seaboard States received a mixed reception yesterday. At the same time it was indicated that the order would not be put into effect until after the weekend.

OURS is a day when vast historical novels are the rule. The public appetite for large - scale reinterpretation of the past has reached a pitch unknown since the great successes of Sir Walter Scott were a blazing literary phenomenon.

SUGGESTIONS to the effect that car owners might have to curtail their motoring, even their week-end trips, in order to conserve rubber, were strongly discounted in a statement issued by the American Automobile Association last week.

RIO DE JANEIRO. THE American car, much too broad for the single-track road of leveled reddish earth, dashed around curves at an absurd speed as it made its way through the jungle-covered hills near the coast in the State of Santa Catharina in Southern Brazil.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- On a three-hit shut-out by Johnny Rigney, the White Sox moved to within half a game of the third-place Red Sox and a game of the second-place Indians by beating the Tribe, 1 to 0, today.

WITH THE ARMY IN SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Nearly 800 airplanes, including some of the Army's fastest and newest bombers and pursuit planes, will participate in the Louisiana war games for 500,000 troops, it was learned officially today.

A YEAR ago Germany launched its Luftwaffe at England and the Battle of Britain was on. The British Royal Air Force, outnumbered as to planes and men, rose to the defense and, in a last-ditch stand as glorious as any to be found in history, finally beat off the invaders.
EVEN the most charitable critic, when dealing with recent building in New York (and selecting only what is distinguished by some merit), must tend to sound like a grouchy old Pecksniff.

ANGELA DU MATURIER'S third novel is dominated, as was her first, by sex, but Vivian Osborne of "The Little Less" is depicted as abnormal, whereas "The Perplexed Heart" merely gave to a woman the role of sexual libertine so long, in fiction, the man's prerogative.

EPHRATA, Pa. -- This community will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of its incorporation on Friday. But that anniversary is not an adequate measure of the age of the settlement. In fact, Ephrata was founded as a Utopian colony more than 200 years ago, an experiment that has commanded the interest and respect of historians for many years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- About 700,000 factory workers received pay increases during the period from May 15 to June 15, Secretary Perkins reported today. A total of 2,200,000 employes in manufacturing industries received increases during the three months ending June 15.

OGUNQUIT, Me., Aug. 16 -- The Cliff Country Club was the setting this afternoon for the largest benefit fete of the season here, a Fall parade featuring a military fashion review. The beneficiary was the York County Chapter of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- With Anglo-American policy respecting the Far East as fixed by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill still a secret, Japan is refusing to allow a group of more than 100 American citizens to leave that country, it was officially revealed here today.

It must have been a source of deep satisfaction to Henry Ford to see the realization, even though still in experimental form, of his long dream of an automobile whose whole superstructure should be made of plastics. With body and fenders mounted on a tubular steel frame, such a car was unveiled at the annual Dearborn Festival.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Newark made it two out of three in its series with Jersey City today by taking the final game of the set, 6 to 0.

LEE SHUBERT, taking a little time out from his multitudinous activities, examined the prospects for the new season the other day. All signs, he said, point to a boon in the theatre because of the national defense program.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- Thirty-eight students have won special scholarships, given to children of deceased soldiers, sailors or marines who enlisted from New York State, the State Education Department announced. The competition was conducted in June.

ALTHOUGH it was only a short while ago that radio was treating the American composer with as much respect as it might a fledgling crow, today all that is changed and broadcasters consider the American composer a cherished songbird whose voice should be heard throughout the land.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- Soviet sources here declared today that German offensives were being repulsed all the way from Lake Onega, on the Finnish front, to the sector west of Kiev. They acknowledged Nazi successes only in the southern Ukraine, where the situation, although confused, "is everywhere under control."

METEORS The Perseid shower has raised the curtain on the chief meteor season of the year. It is the "season" only because more meteors are visible. Actually it is estimated that at least 20,000,000 meteors enter the earth's atmosphere every day and a minimum of one a day reaches the earth's surface.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- A gala ball for Britain, one of the largest benefit entertainments of the season here, was given tonight at Seaview Terrace, the Summer home of Mrs. Herbert Shipman. The ballroom, library and other large rooms of the villa were given over to the event, which drew a large attendance of members of the Summer colony and their week-end house guests.

Within the last few years, women have come to depend upon artificial jewels, upon plastics and plated gold and silver, to give interest and sparkle to a somber gown. Such, ornaments, being comparatively inexpensive, heretofore have been readily replaced.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Miss Mildred Turrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Turrell of New York, was married this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church here, to David Haskell Lanman Jr., son of Mrs. Lanman of this place, and the late Mr. Lanman.

Asserting that rent control would do "irreparable harm" to the real estate industry, John Marbach, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, has urged real estate boards of the State in defense centers where housing shortages exist to set up local rent arbitration committees to hear complaints and to seek to adjust such complaints by negotiaion and arbitration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- An anti-aircraft shell which releases a whirling net of steel cables in the sky to entangle enemy aircraft at which it is fired is disclosed in a patent (No. 2,251,918) granted to Horace W. Dawson, soldier attached to Headquarters Battery, First Battalion, Tenth Field Artillery, stationed at Fort Lewis, Washington.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Miss Catherine Sommer Murphy, daughter of Mrs. M. William Murphy of this city, and the late Mr. Murphy, was married here in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral this morning to Dr. George Albert Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Graham of Brooklyn.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Campaign pledges to bring more war industries to Westchester County, to build thousands of new homes for the middle class, to modernize the county government and to develop the county further as an arcadian retreat for New York business men will ring in the ears of the county electorate for the next two and a half months, according to advance indications today from the November election candidates.

"CUT line twenty-two!"... These columns having been given over recently to the life and times of the average radio actor and the new professional caste of announcers, it seems appropriate to vary the series by presenting something "unheard" of in radio -- the director.

AT one of the business sessions of the annual convention of the American Philatelic Society at Baltimore on Tuesday through Saturday one of philately's most controversial problems will be considered, namely, whether stamps which are known to have been repaired or reperforated or regummed should be rubber-stamped on the reverse with notations so indicating.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Joseph C. Menendez, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said tonight he had suspended Earl Southard as Illinois commander of the organization and ordered him to face a V.F.W. court-martial on charges of violating his membership oath.

American manufacturers operating subsidiary plants in Argentina and Brazil last week sought a way out of the predicament into which they have been thrown by publication of the official American blacklist. Delicate problems of policy with severe penalties for mistakes confront American producers in attempting to reconcile business operations of their subsidiaries with blacklist demands and at the same time remain within the laws of the two countries in which they operate.

The Army of the United States passed a crisis last week in its own and its country's history by a margin of one vote. The close vote by the House on the eighteen months' service extension bill coincided with a growing recognition on the part of the press, the public and of the soldiers themselves that all was not right with the Army.

GRATITUDE: English View Here is an extract from a letter I have just received from England: "An employe of one of the government offices, in relating his experiences of the bombing of his home in which he lost everything, said: 'With, hundreds of others, some half-dressed and others with hardly any clothing, I went to the American Eagle Club, where we were given everything we required.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Alsab, little brown colt purchased at auction for $700 a year ago, drove to a length victory in the $45,420 Futurity at "Washington Park today to become the nation's leading 2-year-old, both in money winning and performance.

NEW YORK Mrs. John. C. Juhring, accompanied by Mrs. Hayse Collins, who has been residing in Florence, Italy, for many years, will leave the Ambassador today by motor for York Harbor, Me., where they will spend several weeks.

The ungainly, four-funneled warship Seattle, which since 1927 has served as a land-locked curiosity to millions of observers staring at her from river boats and suspension bridges as she lay at her birth in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, will be set free to "sail" away within the next ten days, it was announced here yesterday by Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the yard.

Homemakers who are redecorating this Fall will work out many an unusual wall treatment if the suggestions offered by the display rooms just opened in the stores are followed. In the light of the innovations, just painting the four walls the same color or covering them with one design of wallpaper seems a bit naive.

BUFFALO, Aug. 16 -- At its concluding session today the annual convention of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., adopted a resolution calling for aid to those peoples who continue to fight against Hitler and his allies," but it also opposed "the enhance of the United States into reign wars."

TORONTO -- When he was a small boy, the late Sir Henry Pellatt read of feudal castles with drawbridges and moats secret staircases. He grew up, became rich, then built a dream castle. Nearly thirty years ago Casa Loma was finished, splendid with turrets, narrow windows high up in towers, huge stone ornamental fence, a wide terrace instead of a moat.

THE fifth annual Mozart festival at Asheville, N.C., will be held Aug. 28-31, under the sponsorship of the Asheville Mozart Festival Guild, Inc. Participants will include the Festival Orchestra; the Festival Chorus of forty-five mixed voices; the Raleigh String Quartet and numerous vocal and instrumental soloist.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- All the fury of the gods of rain, pent-up during an evening of fantastic cloud effects in the Champlain Valley, was unloosed tonight ten minutes before Tom Cook's annual Indian pageant was to have its tenth renewal in the sky-roofed amphitheatre walled by the stockade he built with his own hands.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- Women's apparel stores reported a 50 per cent increase in the week's sales. The four-week gain now stands at 30 per cent for these stores, bringing the gain for the year to Aug. 9 to 13 per cent.

TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- Startled by the eight-point program proclaimed by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill and the secret military agreements believed to be behind the program, Japan was further alarmed today by the British-American offer of maximum aid to Russia, backed by the statement that "already many shiploads have left our shores and more will leave in the immediate future."

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined again during the week ended Aug. 3. The index dropped to 131.0 from 132.1 for the week, ended Aug. 2 and an all-time high of 133.3 for the week ended July 26. It stood at 107.3 for the week ended Aug. 10, 1940.

Although the migratory bird regulations for the year have yet, to be announced, some observers have already concluded that whatever changes are likely to occur will relate to Wilson's or jacksnipe and woodcock.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The following extracts I have taken from a very recent letter from a distinguished Canadian engineer. He describes graphically certain phases of American participation in the present war effort in Canada as received from the other side of the border.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The capture of the iron ore district of Krivoy Rog, west of the Dnieper River, claimed by the German High Command, is hailed by the Berlin press as a shattering blow to the war economy of the Soviet Union.

Unruffled by the knowledge that they had "gotten American" during the twenty-two months in the United States, three British youngsters took the Dixie Clipper for Lisbon yesterday at La Guardia Field on their way home to "share the hardships" of war with their mother and stepfather.

RICHMOND, Calif., Aug. 16 -- At a ship building site which seven months ago was only a bare mud flat the 10,000-ton freighter Ocean Vanguard slid into San Francisco Bay late today as the first of a fleet of cargo vessels to be launched in this country for the British Government.

Bobbing at their anchors today in the Riverside Y.C. harbor will be found cruisers from six units of the United States Power Squadrons which arrived late yesterday afternoon from an intersquad rendezvous. Represented will be the Westchester, Stamford, Norwalk, Housatonic, Mid-Hudson and Mohawk-Hudson Squadrons.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Olney B. Mairs gave a dinner tonight at Hearthstone for General and Mrs. Robert Lee Ballard, who are their week-end guests. Later the party attended "Main Street," put on in Guild Hall last right and tonight by the Rolling Studio Players.

September will be one of the great show months of the open-air season this year, with thirty-seven exhibitions listed in various parts of the country. Bench shows will be staged in twenty States, New York leading with eight. There will be two in Massachusetts and the same number in Pennsylvania, while New Jersey and Connecticut each has a single event scheduled.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Wars and rumors of wars, which ever have created new demands for the services of women, again are swinging wide the doors of some government offices in Washington.

FEW political books published in London during this war have been given a reception in the English press like that accorded the volume entitled "Two Years of German Oppression in Czecho-Slovakia," published last Spring by the Department of Information of the Czecho-Slovak Ministry in London.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 16 -- Syrian and Lebanese public opinion has hailed the dismissal of a number of former Vichy officials who had been retained under the Allied administration as the first indication of coming reforms in the former mandated territory.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The deepest mud that Saratoga can produce failed to ruffle the charging Whirlaway, who ran in the three-horse Travers Stakes today as if he were the only horse on the track. He won, of course, for his eleventh victory of the season, and one that pushed his earnings to $275,636.

The most pressing problem facing American industry today is the need to "mesh in" government orders with civilian goods production, without too serious a dislocation to the latter. One company which has succeeded in accomplishing this objective with little difficulty is the Lionel Corporation, maker of toy trains, which has taken on substantial government orders for battleship and cruiser binnacles, eight-inch compasses, naval gun sights, bearings and couplings.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco won her first major tennis tournament in four years of trying today -- and she did it the hard way in the role of giant killer.

In this tale Pedro and Margarita, children of a Spanish merchant of Panama, and his beautiful Spanish wife are left orphaned and homeless when Panama was sacked and destroyed in the seventeenth century by the buccaneer Morgan and his 1,200 followers.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. Isaac E. Emerson of Baltimore will open her home, Whitehall, for a benefit fashion show and tea on the afternoon of Aug. 26, which will be sponsored by the Dunes Club branch of the British War Relief Society, of which Mrs. Robinson Bull is general chairman.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 17 -- British fighters and bombers, again winging over Northern France on several offensive sweeps yesterday, shot down nineteen Nazi fighter planes, for a loss of four British fighters, the Air Ministry reported.

A SURPRISE stamp from Honduras is a 1-centavo brown bearing the date "15 Sept. 1942" under a portrait of A. Francisco Morazan, and an inscription "La Patria" (the Fatherland). Sept. 15, 1842, is the date when Morazan, one of Central America's Liberal party leaders, was executed by Costa Rican rebels, and thus the stamp commemorating the centenary of his death is released more than a year ahead of time.

A general mobilization of all the resources of the FHA in the defense areas adjacent to New York City to meet the rapidly growing demand for living quarters in those vicinities was announced yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the FHA.

The new cargo vessel Lightning, the first of five C-2 freighters being built by the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Chester, Pa., for the United States Lines, will be launched next Saturday afternoon. The company announced yesterday that Miss Roberta Quirk of Chevy Chase, Md., would sponsor the ship and christen her with the name of a famous sailing vessel of early American merchant marine days.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique today:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The bone of the argument of your correspondent, Ushichiro Tokumi, is that America has failed to "eradicate the remnant of imperialism" in the Far East and that it is unfair that Japan should be called upon to renounce "her claim for special rights in her own sphere."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- After a breathing spell of some weeks the resurgence of strikes in defense plants has again raised fundamental questions of governmental labor policy.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 16 -- Marshal Semyon Budenny's retiring Russian forces in the southern Ukrainian sector are still holding along a semi-circular line running about fifteen miles north of Nikolaev and Odessa, according to a Moscow broadcast tonight.

THE collection of original musical manuscripts formerly in the possession of the late Dr. Jerome Stonborough of Vienna has been acquired for the Gertrude Clarke Whittall Foundation Collection of Musical Autographs, which has just been established in the Library of Congress.

CARRYING on with the American League pennant race is like carrying out a corpse. It's a dead issue. The Yankees could go along on their hands and knees from now on and still get over the finish line ahead of any pursuers. What happened to those other ball clubs that were going to raise hob on the Harridge circuit this season?
August introduces one or two garden pests new for the season, brings back others in the form of second broods, and sees a very gradual diminution in the horde of adult Japanese beetles.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One reads and hears a great deal these days concerning another German peace offensive, supposedly due next month. It is predicted that Adolf Hitler will promise to retire, presumably, as you suggest on Aug. 9, in Topics of The Times, to "allow Winston Churchill to stick to his pledge never to make peace with the present German regime."

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Reference in the Anglo-American declaration of peace aims to raw materials did not surprise the British commodity trade. It is known here that the British Government considered internationalization of commodity supplies as the basis for improvement of trade relations even before the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A United States naval observer's story of the part played by an American-built flying boat in the action that sank the German battleship Bismarck on the morning of May 27 was made public today by the Navy Department.

RED Army bands entertain from Moscow short waves between English news bulletins from the Russian front. The other night Moscow was particularly loud and self-assured. One noted a marked change in the format of Soviet broadcasting.

ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The campus of Bard College, residential unit of Columbia University, has been improved during the Summer. The library has profited most from the program of modernization put into effect last year.

An arbitration award granting wage increases of 8.16 per cent to 3,300 employes of the Railway Express Agency in the metropolitan district averted yesterday any danger of a strike delaying railroad deliveries. NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -After a season of adversity such as few national champions have experienced, Donald McNeill won his first tennis trophy of the year today.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival swung into its final phases tonight with the last program but one. The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, devoted the greater part of tonight's concert at Tanglewood to two contemporary works -- one by an Englishman and the other by an American, once again underscoring the hands-across-the-sea motive that has characterized much of this year's festival.

ANOTHER "SULFA" -- The newest of the "sulfa" family of drugs was released last week for general use by the medical profession. Its chemical name is 2-sulfanilamido-pyrimidine -- or sulfadiazine for short. It was first described before the American Chemical Society in Cincinnati in April, 1940, by four scientists of the Lederle research staff and is now manufactured in bulk by Lederle'a parent corporation, the American Cyanamid Company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- A petition addressed to President Roosevelt urging "immediate action by our Navy to destroy all enemy vessels and aircraft which threaten our vital sea lanes" has been signed by 131 faculty members of the University of Chicago, who oppose the isolationist attitude of President Hutchins.

ROCKLAND, Me., Aug. 16 -- President Roosevelt said upon coming ashore here this afternoon from his historic meeting at sea with Winston Churchill that he and the British Prime Minister had reached a complete understanding on all aspects of the war situation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 16 -- Teachers at Western Reserve University are carrying on a program of community and regional education. BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 16 -- Negotiations are under way, it was learned today, for the purchase by Argentina of 88,000 gross tons of Italian shipping, which will go a long way toward eliminating the present acute shortage of ships available for inter-American trade.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 16 -- About 135 leaders from many sections of American life will serve as sponsors of the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the institute, said today.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Civil and military authorities are at loggerheads over who has police jurisdiction on Burlington County highways passing through the Fort Dix military reservation, it was disclosed today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Tommy Goodwin, the former New York State amateur ruler, stamped himself as the man to beat in the first annual Hummocks Country Club invitation golf tourament today. Although the long-hitting Briar Hills ace was not one of the four who deadlocked for the medal yesterday, he performed almost flawlessly, both this morning, when match play got under way, and this afternoon.

NUTLEY, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Billy Dear of Essex County, winner recently of the John Anderson Memorial tournament and the sectional qualifying round in the national amateur championship test, today joined with Bill Behrens of the home club to win a pair of matches in the second annual Yountakah Country Club invitation best-ball tournament.

THE other day the sea turned red off the New Jersey coast. Rhodophyceae (red algae), better known as seaweed, invaded the coast along a twenty-mile stretch, giving the surf a crimson hue. Natives quickly explained the phenomenon: the tropical growth had been carried northward by the Gulf Stream and forced inshore by strong easterly winds; earth tremors, said some, might have dislodged the weed from the ocean's bottom.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Establishment of a hemispheric surplus commodities plan, designed to help American nations sell their excess products without upsetting tariff schedules, is being considered by agricultural officials.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Retail trade moved higher under impetus of "scare" buying this week but it was outstripped by the rush of retailers to place commitments with the wholesale houses. A check of representative retailers indicated an average for the city of about 35 per cent ahead of last year, but this was helped along by several dollar-day suburban sales which took place a week earlier in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Representatives of seven Southern California aircraft manufacturers and leaders of three labor unions were asked today by Sidney Hillman, OPM Associate Director General, to meet here on Monday to discuss "matters open between management and labor."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 16 -- Argentine labor reaffirmed its repudiation of totalitarianism and its adhesion to democracy today in a huge meeting staged here by the Confederacion General del Trabajo, leading South American labor organization.

POINT O'WOODS, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Despite the threat of rain and a stiff northwester in the forenoon, a fleet of fifty-one craft participated in the annual August regatta of the Point O'Woods Yacht Club today.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 16 -- as a parting shot before being shipped to Aqueduct for a rest, A. J. (Whitey) Abel's Honey Cloud today won the $5,000 added King Philip Handicap at Narragansett Park.

Rumors having got about that Bernard Shaw, the celebrated vegetarian, had eaten a piece of meat, Symon Gould of the American Library Service wrote to headquarters to find out. Mr. Shaw's reply follows:

The following is a translation of a letter written to a friend in New York by a highly educated Frenchwoman who is still living in occupied France. The letter is dated early in May, but the writer states it had to be smuggled out of the Nazi-dominated territory, so the delay in its receipt here is understandable.

While there has been a general relaxation of employer specifications in recent weeks, the growing shortages in the labor market here are still being aggravated by the refusal of some employers to consider certain applicants. The dropping of barriers is expected to continue, however, as employers find it impossible to obtain workers who meet every requirement.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Plans were completed today for a "Gay Nineties" costume party to be held Sept. 6 at the swimming pool. This is the same day as the annual Tuxedo Dog Show and the park will be filled with visitors.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Members of society here for the racing gave many luncheons, dinners and teas today, celebrating the Travers week-end, the height of the racing season.

Negotiations to avert a threatened strike of 8,000 workers in the installation department of the Western Electric Company collapsed here yesterday, but officials of the independent union involved promised they would not order a walkout pending action by a "super-panel" of Federal conciliators in Washington.

THE gravest crisis ever faced by American democracy is driving many to an expression of their views. The battle of the books is upon us: never have pamphlets poured out in such cornucopian abundance, or in a better cause.

Russian Crucible For more than three centuries after the Turks captured Constantinople in 1453 the Black Sea remained virtually a private lake of the Sultans. Then the Russia of the Czars took the port of Odessa on the great lake's northern shore.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN Greta Garbo makes one of her infrequent pictures, Metro's usually energetic drum beaters muffle their soundings, and only strange, incongruous reports are permitted to escape from the stage where she works.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Earl Southard, newly elected Illinois commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, was suspended from office today and ordered to report for general court-martial on charges arising from his activities aa secretary of the Citizens Keep America Out of War Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The largest practical demonstration of camouflaged buildings in this country will test the theories and practices of the Corps of Army Engineers when a new center of twenty buildings is erected adjoining Fort Belvoir, Va., the War Department said today.

Holding that the destiny of the United States will be determined by the nation's course of action in the next eight months, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd in an interview yesterday called upon all Americans to subjugate their personal beliefs to the national safety and welfare and face the coming decisive period in world history as a united nation.

SEVEN hundred and fifty years ago Duke Berchtold V, of Zaeringen founded Berne, today the Swiss capital, as a military post on the frontier between French-speaking Burgundy and German-speaking Alamannia. In commemoration, Switzerland will release on Sept. 6 a 10-centimes red, black and orange stamp inscribed "750 Jahre Bern" (750th Anniversary of Berne) and bearing the dates 1191-1941.

Year in and year out, come rain or drought, the most colorful flower for midsummer garden borders is the Garden Phlox (P. paniculata). This star performer well deserves its high reputation. It has a cast-iron constitution, an extremely long flowering period, a wide range of both brilliant and lovely soft hues, is sweetly scented and makes the bravest midsummer showing for mass effect in the garden.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 16 -- Inatitutad as a special section of study in the broader curriculum of architectural instruction, City Planning is offered at Yale for the benefit primarily of students who desire to specialize in this field so closely allied to architecture.

As to Peace Aims Blueprints of a brave new world after the war have begun to appear. Some are in rough outline and some are complete in every detail ready to serve. They are naturally to be had in great variety, for every one of us has definite ideas on a truly perfect world.

With nothing to stir it into activity, the market for shares on the New York Stock Exchange drifted through two hours of trading yesterday and showed the lowest volume since May 31: only 119,600 shares. Except for May 31, the Saturday after Memorial Day, the day's turnover was the smallest for any day since Aug. 24, 1940.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- The German offensive continues in the face of stubborn resistance by the Red Army. The stiffest fighting is reported in the Ukraine, where the German Army has been able to make a considerable advance, despite the opposition of Marshal Semyon Budenny's forces.

Reports announced yesterday from the Federal Works Administration and the Federal Housing Administration show rapidly increasing activity in the construction of homes in defense areas. John M. Carmody, head of the Federal Works Organization, reported that more than 90,000 houses for workers in defense localities are completed, under construction or about to be constructed in 249 districts in forty-one States, the District of Columbia, Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Panama Canal Zone.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 -- A three-run rally, launched by Ernie White's wild throw on Frankie Gustine's squeeze bunt, gave the Pittsburgh Pirates three runs in the eighth inning and a 4-to-2 decision over the Cards today.

THERE was somewhat more bidding of "psychics" in the national tournament, concluded last week at Asbury Park, than there had been in national championship play for several years. Most of the psychic bids seemed to meet the same fate as the 1932 and 1933 psychics, which were made on utterly worthless hands and which the experts finally abandoned as generally unprofitable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Equipped with a fire force of 144 new 37-mm. guns and 160 powerful 75-mm. guns, three new Provisional GHQ Anti-Tank Groups will participate in the large-scale manoeuvres to be held in Louisiana next month between the Second and Third Armies.

The cotton, market yesterday continued on the erratic course which it set on Friday. After opening at overnight gains of 4 to 9 points, which established the high marks for the session, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 5 to 10 points below Thursday's final quotations, and then recovered to close at net gains of 1 to 4 points.

WASHINGTON -- Highway engineers are making a psychological study of a unique creature of the twentieth century, the automobile driver. The outstanding characteristic of the typical driver, according to preliminary findings of the investigators in the Public Road Administration, Federal Work Agency, is his insistence on freedom of movement for himself on the public highways.

INDUCTION: General Douglas MacArthur, United States commander in the Far East, last week inducted the 6-year-old Philippine Army Air Corps into the United States Far Eastern forces. The Air Corps was the first unit of the Philippine Army to be incorporated into the United States Army under a Presidential proclamation issued three weeks ago.

VICHY, France. No problem which France faces today seems so hard as that of the nearly 2,000,000 French prisoners held by the Germans in occupied France, Germany, Poland, Austria and Czecho-Slovakia. By the end of 1940 fewer than 1,000,000 of these men had been located, properly identified and registered, and already there were 100,000 pages of records in the International Red Cross.

Samuel Seabury and Charles C. Burlingham, leaders of the Fusion movement, hailed yesterday the withdrawal of Stanley M. Isaacs as a candidate for renomination for Borough President of Manhattan in the Republican primary as a signal contribution to the campaign to prevent return of control of the city government to Tammany Hall.

MENANDS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Flornell Glamorous champion whippet owned by the Mardormere Kennels of Mrs. George Anderson of Glen Head, L.I., and shown by Percy Roberts, continued the recent domination of Eastern dog shows by imported specimens, taking the chief honors at the seventh annual fixture of the Mohawk Valley Kennel Club, held at Mid-City Park today.

Germany's invasion of Russia was long in the planning. Months ago Hitler asked his diplomats in Moscow and Ankara how much time would be required for German armies to reach Leningrad and Kiev, with Moscow a little later. He received vague, cautious replies. He asked his military attaches in those two capitals. From them he received estimates more to his liking. "Three weeks -- at most."

THE editor of this diary of a flight sergeant in the Luftwaffe says in a preface that the pages are unbelievable, but adds that if they were not it would not be necessary to publish them. That does not appear to be a sound criticism, for what is written is seldom anything but what the public has been led to expect from Nazi fighters, particularly with regard to their philosophy.

Discussing the present day rental problems, I. Berger, writing in the current issue of Real Estate News, published by the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, holds that rents must continue to rise in order to cover the corresponding increase in the cost of building maintenance.

The Maritime Commission's newest phase of ship construction, a contemplated order of 566 more merchant vessels to cost $1,246,650,000, may be concentrated on standard vessels of high quality and high speeed, rather than the slower and simpler vessels of the emergency ugly-duckling type.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- A 23-year-old pitcher and an outfielder almost twice that age combined their potent efforts to stall the Brooklyn pennant drive today as Professor Casey Stengel's Braves took the opener of the three-game series, 4-1, from the Dodgers, who thus blew a chance to take the league lead and still trail the Cards by half a game.

AMERICAN operatic artists formerly got most of their training in small opera houses in Europe, but now that the war has made European training impossible, substitute centers are being created in this country. A fully equipped theatre has been built at the Berkshire Music Center, and this Summer the Deertrees Theatre at Harrison, Me., as we have already reported, has been converted into an opera school.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 15 (delayed) (AP) -- After a heated controversy involving British and Italian interpretations of treaties governing the Dardanelles, the Turks today permitted the Italian naval tanker Tarvisio to proceed to Rumania for oil -- but under the condition that hereafter there will be no exceptions to the rules.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- France is faced for the full year 1941 with expenditures for government and for the German Army of occupation totaling 280,193,864,000 francs, and estimated receipts of only 68,205,014,000 francs, the Commerce Department reports.

All of us have gone through the experience of taking a "bad" child and making him "good," Dr. Alice V. Keliher of New York University said recently, but we don't really change the child, we bring out something different in him.

Numerous lines were temporarily withdrawn from sale in the wholesale markets last week as the result of advancing prices and shortages, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Steamship owners and unions representing licensed maritime officers agreed at a conference with the Maritime Commission today on a uniform plan for the payment of war bonuses to licensed personnel sailing American-flag ships into danger zones.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Faced with requests from Russia for enormous quantities of war supplies, and urged by Lord Beaver-brook, British Supply Minister, to send Britain "more and more of everything," Washington officials said today the defense production program must be expanded from, beginning to end.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Many dinner parties were given in advance of the lecture tonight in the auditorium of the Southampton High School for the benefit of the social service work of the Southampton Hospital. The event was under the auspices of the lecture committee of the Schola Cantorum of New York.

Two thousand and two hundred civilian volunteers, who have been chosen as zone and sector air-raid wardens in the recently organized Air Raid Warden Service of the Police Department, will attend the opening session of a training course on their newly assumed duties to be held tomorrow night at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

In one of the most secluded spots in the financial district, at the corner of Gold Street and Maiden Lane, almost in the shadow of the massive structure of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is lodged one of the most important cogs in Wall Street's intricate system of financial machinery; namely, the Reserve Bank's Foreign Property Control Department.

More stringent regulation of installment selling, now being worked out by the Federal Reserve Board, should benefit rather than injure department stores, according to retail executives who carefully studied the question during the last week.

The main plot of this story is said to be based on actual fact, although the bizarre adventures recounted in it are admitted to be fictitious. Drew Gibson, accompanied by his wife, flies to Rio de Janeiro on a diplomatic mission having to do with the good neighbor policy.

FORTY-FIVE years ago this month -- the actual date was Aug. 15, a Saturday -- a young Kansas editor was hurrying to exchange the torrid heat of his native State for the coolness of Colorado's mountains. His printer just that moment was crying for copy against edition time, and in the interlude before train departure the editor sat down to write.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that Premier Joseph Stalin had received favorably the proposal advanced by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill for a meeting with British and United States representatives in Moscow.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- One of the most dramatic chapters of this war has been brought to a conclusion with the fall of Sortavala, Finnish officials said tonight. This important key city on the northeastern coast of Lake Ladoga was taken by the Finns early today.

The Census Bureau has completed a new statistical study of mortality trends covering continental United States. It is the first ever made which embraced a full decade and all the States, and it may be accepted as authoritative. As expected, it confirms previous research by the insurance companies in revealing that in this century the life expectancy of the individual has been raised gradually from 48.2 years in 1900 to beyond 60 years at present.

HOW recently we were young and how swiftly we have changed is something one cannot fail to be impressed with after reading Agnes Morley Cleaveland's book, "No Life for a Lady." This easy-flowing, informal volume, written with humor and quiet wisdom, can be called both the autobiography of a person and the chronicle of a period and a section of the country.

IN the Eighteen Forties this country was swept by a revival of interest in Utopian theories. Within the decade there were founded more than thirty communities dedicated to the art of living with one's fellow man and liking it.

LONDON (By Wireless). IT is common experience in London today to see a sudden expression of glassy-eyed pain come over the face of a pretty woman in restaurant, bar, bus or other place. It doesn't mean a sudden headache or any other kind of physical discomfort.

Harry L. Dickerson, an executive associated for the last twelve years in the management of natural gas properties of the United Gas Corporation, an Electric Bond and Share Company affiliate, died yesterday afternoon in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.

BUFFALO -- The Great Lakes, America's great emerald necklace of fresh waters, are host this Summer to the largest passenger cruises in their history. More and more vacationists, their accents ranging from Southern drawls to Northeastern twangs, are visiting these inland seas, fascinated by lakefront scenery and man-made marvels, and scooped up merrily in the whirl of gay life afloat.

By a vote of 15 to 10 the Ways and Means Committee retained in its draft of the 1941 revenue bill (H. R. 5417) the provision for mandatory joint returns of married couples. Prior to passing the bill on Aug. 4, however, the House of Representatives struck out the provision by a vote of 242 to 160.

The most important tournament relating to women's future standards of golf in the metropolitan district is probably the junior girls' championship, slated this year for the Essex Fells Country Club on Sept. 3. Nevertheless there has been a decided slump from last year in entries so far received by Mrs. Ernest Korber, president and tournament chairman of the women's metropolitan, and as matters stand only a small group has signified an intention of competing.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- The medalist jinx that has fastened itself on so many qualifyinground leaders pulled big Jim Knott, former Yale oarsman, under in today's second-round match in the annual Maidstone Bowl invitation golf tourney at the seaside Maidstone Club.

TRAVEL LINES: Peace aims and post-war problems are among subjects to be considered at the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, Aug. 24-29, at Williams College, Mass.; the institute, held every two years, draws a notable group of leaders in business, education and labor....

IN large part because of the ever-increasing demands made upon them by business men, government officials, Army and Navy officers and technical experts and advisers traveling on national defense missions, the commercial airlines of the United States seem headed this year for a new world's record in passengers and express carried.

IN the midst of the present plethora of books for children on the Latin-American countries, it is pleasant to be reminded of our neighbors to the North. "Gay Kilties of Cape Breton" is a lively little tale of the daily doings of boys and girls in a picturesque and little-known section, written with ease and spontaneity.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 16 -- That the Germans have suffered very severe losses in Finland is today confirmed by a dispatch from the Svenska Dagbladet's Norwegian correspondent, who says that the disorganization and restrictions now prevailing on the Norwegian railways are caused by the "many thousand" wounded German soldiers from Finland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Regardless of what any one might have thought as to the wisdom, politically or otherwise, of the meeting at sea of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, no one in Washington, not even the bitterest critic of the prevailing foreign policy, was the least bit surprised.

Roosevelt Meets Churchill On the holystoned deck of a great gray warship, drifting somewhere in the cold Atlantic off the North American coast, two men sat talking. One, wearing a broad-brimmed flapping fisherman's hat and waving an elongated cigarette holder, was the President of the United States.

The proposals recently submitted to the office of the Borough President for rezoning the lower East Side area show that great stress is laid upon the necessity of enlarging the residential zone sections in that neighborhood and restricting the business and industrial areas.

ROME, Aug. 16 -- Virginio Gayda put the final seal of rejection on the eight-point declaration in his editorial today. He added very little to the comment in yesterday morning's newspapers, but at least he gave definite proof that what many Americans may have thought was an expression of platitude and the perfectly normal aims of all peoples was really a challenge to the structure, the leaders and the hopes or the totalitarian countries.

MEXICO CITY -- Not since the invasion of Mexico by General Winfield Scott just one hundred years ago has such an army of "Norte-americanos" poured across the Rio Grande. Europe's loss has been Mexico's gain.

THE young author of "My Mother Is a Violent Woman" has now proceeded to do right by his other parent in "My Father Is a Quiet Man." Father emerges as a character lacking the color and verve of the "Violent Woman" but quite evidently a man who knows what he wants and, in his quiet way, how to get it.

VICHY, France, Aug. 16 -- Henceforth, according to two constitutional acts promulgated today, "no one may serve in the army without taking an oath of fealty to the Chief of State," which ruling applies also to judges and magistrates.
NEW YORK Lady Decies will leave the Plaza today to visit her sister, Mrs. Seton Henry, in Torresdale, Pa.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Finnish offensive continued today, Finnish newspapers reported, while the Germans pushed upon Leningrad from the south. The Finns were said to be mopping up along the coast of Lake Ladoga and in the upper part of the Karelian Isthmus.

Among the notables scheduled to address the annual convention of the American Bankers Association in Chicago on Sept. 29 to Oct. 2 are Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury; Senator Tom Connally of Texas, chairman of the United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, and Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, director and coordinator of War Department statistics.

In the financial markets, Thursday's publication of the mid-ocean 8-point agreement of President Roosevelt and Premier Churchill had no effect. Stock market averages, which had gone down slowly during the week's early days, declined on the day of the announcement, did not recover, and there was little business done.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A daylight sweep by British fighter planes, similar to those along the French coast, was carried out over Sicily yesterday by airmen of the Middle East Command after Royal Air Force bombers had subjected the Sicilian harbor at Catania to a severe pounding during Friday night, the British reported today.

VICHY, France, Aug. 17 -- An important event last week was the resumption by the Bank of France of the publication of its weekly balance sheet, suspended at the outbreak of hostilities. The one just published shows the situation of the institution on July 10 and July 17.

Although advertising is far more informative today than it was several years ago, specifications of product qualities, construction characteristics and objective facts about performance are not frequently given, according to the results of a study made by the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, Inc.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, heading toward the International League pennant, whipped the second-place Royals today, 6-2 and 7-2, before 10,278 fans to boost their lead to six games.

A statement supporting the Roosevelt-Churchill manifesto was combined with an announcement yesterday of the merger of the metropolitan forces of the New York Chapter of the Committee to Defend America, 8 West Fortieth Street, and the Fight for Freedom, Inc., 1270 Sixth Avenue.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Aug. 5 at 105.8, compared with 105.4 a fortnight before, 105.2 a month before, 96.0 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- While good rains fell in parts of the main Corn Belt during last week, other sections remain dry, and official and trade reports indicate that a downward revision in the indicated yield of grain will be necessary in some areas.

The American Clipper of Pan American Airways arrived from Lisbon yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field, bringing among its fifty-two passengers six members of the commission sent by Mayor La Guardia to England five weeks ago to study and report on wartime safeguards.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Corn failed last week to reflect the action of wheat in the futures market on the Board of Trade to any great extent, because of profit-taking by professional traders and persistent hedging pressure, and prices averaged lower.

Declaring that "there has been a great deal of futile discussion as to which is America's enemy No. 1, nazism or communism," Bishop Aloisius J. Muench of Fargo, N.D., asserted last night before a youth mass meeting of the Catholic Central Verein of America and the National Catholic Women's Union at the Hotel Commodore that American youth must "take a bold stand" against both.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Slamming Sammy Snead, fresh from annexing the Canadian open golf title a week ago, took the Times-Union open today when he shot 73, 67 -- 140, even par, to add to his previous 36-hole total of 137 for a 72-hole mark of 277 over the 6,811-yard East course of the Oak Hill Country Club.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Jersey City moved within two games of the fourth-place Red Wings today by taking two from Rochester, 3 -- 0 and 4 -- 3.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- Another concrete step toward combining the huge resources of the Soviet Union, Britain and the United States into an economic bloc designed to facilitate the destruction of Adolf Hitler's Germany was accomplished yesterday. It was announced today that Britain and Russia had signed a trade agreement that would enable each country to benefit from the wealth of the other.
Three hawks that had been on exhibition for nine months at the Staten Island Zoological Society's quarters at Barrett Park, West New Brighton, entered military service yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Senator Vandenberg proposed today a 5 per cent manufacturers' sales tax to raise about $1,250,000,000 in new revenues, and asserted there was "substantial support" for the proposal within the Senate Finance Committee.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The comparative smallness of the British credit for Russia in the new trade pact was said today to mean little because Britain already is importing large amounts of goods from Russia and the credit applies only to the balance of British, exports over imports.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt gave a luncheon today at Beaulieu and Miss Julia A. Berwind entertained at the Elms.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Speculate interest in the wheat market fell off sharply last week, but new seasonal high prices were established as the result of short-covering plus a little buying by mills. The demand for flour, however, was much lighter than in the preceding week, and sufficient hedging pressure appeared against the movement of the new Northwestern crop to bring about a fair reaction from the best prices.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 17 -- In one of the fastest and hardest-played 12-goal finals the event has seen, Cocie Rathborne's Pelicans came through to the championship in this division of the Meadow Brook Club polo today, Fred Roe's sixth-period goal turning back Pegasus, 7 to 6.

Robert F. Suewer, manager of the De La Rama Steamship Company, 17 Battery Place, announced yesterday that the steamship line had received the approval of the United States Maritime Commission for the charter of four Panamanian freighters to augment its present fleet in the United States-Philippines service.

BERLIN, Monday, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Army of the Ukraine was reported to be falling back rapidly to the banks of the Dnieper River today after having lost Nikolaev to German and Hungarian, forces in hard fighting.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 17 -- Moving contrary to the markets in New York, most of those in the Continental European countries displayed strength last week in both shares and bonds. The cause was the persistent investment hunger which arose from sales of commodities, to offset which there is only a limited supply of investments, making an equilibrium of demand and supply impossible.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your correspondent Roger Burlingame rightfully rebukes the critics of his right to speak and advocate action on the subject of peace or war because his age exempts him from military duty. However, he should be careful in choosing authorities, and is on argumentative ground in citing the founders of the Republic and the Constitution.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Last week's course of the stock markets here was satisfactory although unexciting. Uncertainty over the government's borrowing policy caused a final rush to buy the 2 1/2 per cent war bonds before the issue closed.

OTTAWA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Canada's domestic exports reached a monthly high record in July at $169,691,600, compared with $100,782,062 in July, 1940, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. The increase was 68.3 per cent.

VICHY, France, Aug. 17 -- On Sept. 15 Jews in the unoccupied zone of France must cease exercising the professions enumerated in a law enacted last June. A decree to this effect will be printed in the Journal Officiel.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 17 -- The Finns scored their biggest success up to now in capturing Sortavala early yesterday but they are believed to have paid a disproportionate price for the victory.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Many parties were given for Tanglewood music festival visitors today. One of the largest dinners was that given by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest B. Dane Jr. of Boston at the Curtis Hotel, Lenox, for Dr. and Mrs. Serge Koussevitzky.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Voelkischer Beobachter today published on the front page a photograph of "a new German battleship" at sea firing fifteen-inch guns, leading to a belief that a sister ship to the Bismarck had been completed and put in service.

Perhaps the most illuminating remark made by the President on his return from his epic cruise was the reference to the need for "an exchange of views on what is happening in the world under the Nazi regime as applied to other nations." Mr. Roosevelt came back in jovial mood from the conference with Winston Churchill.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Southern Presbyterian missionaries detained at Tsingkiang by the Japanese military were released yesterday, the Japanese Consulate General here informed the American Consulate General today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Browns dropped back into a tie with the Senators for last place in the American League today as they split a twin bill with Detroit. St. Louis dropped the first game, 8 to 1, but won the second, 6 to 1.

The forthcoming motion picture, "Life Begins for Andy Hardy," is the first of the eleven films produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in this family series that the National Legion of Decency has found to be objectionable as entertainment for children.
BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Aug. 18 -- Today's Russian communique acknowledged the loss of Nikolaev and Krivoy Rog, but the Red Army is reported to be resisting stubbornly elsewhere in the Ukraine.

As the defense program enters the period when shortages begin to pinch, the Government faces the difficult problem of seeing to it that the burden of sacrifice is fairly shared. The present effort to curtail gasoline consumption in the seventeen Eastern States is a case in point.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Acting jointly, Great Britain and the Soviet Union have again, warned Iran to do something about the "excessively large" number of German "tourists" and other Germans in Iran.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Official newsreels of the historic meeting between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill were shown to the press today and indicated that they met off the coast of Maine -- presumably last Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

MILLBURN, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The fireman of a derailed milk train was killed and its engineer injured when the train plunged wildly for half a mile along its roadbed and overturned in the Millburn station here at 6:56 o'clock tonight. The train, operated by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, was derailed by an obstruction purposely placed on its track, according to company officials.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Most of the top-ranking United States chess masters have found their way here to compete for the New York State championship. As a result, the State title contest has become the principal American chess event of the year.
Purchases of housing properties in Manhattan featured realty activity in the borough over the week-end.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Top honors in the first annual Hummocks Country Club invitation golf tournament went to Tommy Goodwin, Briar Hills ace, who formerly held the New York State amateur crown, when he triumphed over Bert Kohlmann of Inwood, 2 up, in the final today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Washington nicked Heber New-some for nine timely blows today to defeat the Red Sox, 6 to 2, behind the five-hit hurling of Sid Hudson.

VICHY, France, Aug. 17 -- Marshal Petain's broadcast last week on the forthcoming labor charter to govern capital-and-labor relationships in the proposed "New France," contained numerous passages considered to be of exceptional interest to financial and industrial circles.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- The new British-Russian representations to Iran were regarded here today as emphasizing not only danger to the British and Soviet position in the Middle East if Germans are allowed to remain in Iran but danger to Iran's neutrality and even her independence.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices reached a new high of 96.7, thus recovering from the previous week's downtrend of 96.2. With a few exceptions most price changes occur ad in agricultural products.

ROME, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Virginio Gayda, authoritative Fascist editor, predicted today that the Russian war will end in the near future and "this will be the Axis answer to the proposed Anglo-American conference with Russia."

Arthur Wirtz, who arrived from Chicago on Saturday, will confer with the Rockefeller interests today concerning the new ice show which he and Sonja Henie plan to offer in the Fall. The new spectacle, according to Mr. Wirtz, probably will be more elaborate than "It Happens on Ice," but will not bear the same title.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- With the volume of business still at a low level, there were no signs of a break in the lull in the stock market here last week. Interest was focused on a few issues only, especially Farbenindustrie in anticipation of the financial transaction of which the executive of the Reich's largest privately owned corporation made some hints in a shareholders' meeting.

Detailed plans for repelling any attempt at invasion of either coast of North America have been completed by the Permanent Joint Canadian-United States Defense Board and are ready to be put into action, Mayor La Guardia, chairman, of the board's American section, announced yesterday in a broadcast commemorating the first anniversary of the Ogdensburg agreement under which the board was established.

For the third successive week, cotton prices last week continued to lose ground. Following an early decline, the market recovered sharply on Wednesday, but turned downward again in subsequent dealings. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange reflected net declines for the week of 23 to 25 points, and were at a level 135 to 142 points under the peak attained toward the end of last month.

THAT most respected of disaffected Nazis, Dr. Hermann Rauschning, former President of the Danzig Senate and author of "The Revolution of Nihilism" and "The Voice of Destruction," has written another book, called "The Conservative Revolution."* This is in part an apologia, a defense of his motives in joining the Nazi party. To that extent it is a monument to a guilty conscience.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Construction of an emergency fleet of twenty-five Great Lakes iron ore vessels was recommended to the Maritime Commission today by John D. Biggers, director of production in the Office of Production Management.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The average American family eats the same quantities of the same foods which it ate a year ago despite a 12 per cent rise in the cost of meals since August, 1940, a national survey showed tonight.

Economic and political systems, theories or procedures will remain "inadequate to solve the conflicts and inequalities of society until they are conceived in the spirit of charity and good-will as prevalent in individual character," the Rev. Dr. Howard W. Hintz, Brooklyn director of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, said in a sermon yesterday morning".

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The letter of Albert A. Volk indicates that some recent remarks of mine are open to serious misinterpretation. Under the circumstances I desire to clarify my position.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Liquidation by holders of September and October lard contracts, combined with weakness in cotton, depressed prices to a new low on the current movement last week, with all deliveries selling below 10 cents a pound at one time.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The new "streamlined" annual report of the State Controller, Morris S. Tremaine, appeared today. The old form of report, which usually took from ten to twelve months for publication, Has been abandoned, and the new form will be ready within forty-five days each year for those interested.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- A fourth screen version of the venerable stage property "Shore Leave," by R.P. Weston and Bert Lee, will be filmed this Fall by RKO under the title "Hit the Deck," with Ray Bolger in a leading role.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Aug. 17 -- Gallant little Miss Nancy Merki of Portland, Ore., as game a child as ever stuck a toe in the water, put a record-breaking finish to the women's national A.A.U. swimming championships today but the team honors went to the unheralded Riviera Club of Indianapolis.

Elijah's introduction to his servant "Go up now and look toward the sea," was the theme of the sermon delivered yesterday in St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of King's College, Halifax, N.S., when he commented on the parley held at sea last week between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- One of the things President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill discussed, but did not announce, was "the distribution of the Old World between the plutocrats and the Bolsheviki," said the Deutsche Diplomatisch-Politische Korrespondenz.

A rediscovery of "the kinship that exists among all men" and "the spiritual purpose in our tools of production," to enable men to have a clearer understanding of their problems, was urged at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, in a sermon by the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams of Prospect Avenue Methodist Church, Brooklyn.

Progress on many of the city 200 uncompleted capital project has been seriously hampered by the Federal system, of defense priorities on needed materials and supplies, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick disclosed yesterday. Unless these ratings are revised soon in the city's favor, Mr. McGoldrick warned, the situation will become "increasingly acute," with danger of a standstill on all affected projects.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 17 -- Following further setbacks of $3 a bale from the recent high levels for eleven, years and for the season in the first two sessions of last week, cotton futures here appeared oversold and by the end of Friday's session, retraced about two-thirds of these recessions.

In carefree, rollicking mood, several thousand Negro Odd Fellows and their families set forth yesterday morning for their annual excursion up the Hudson River. A delay in boarding the boat, caused by suspicion of counterfeit tickets, quickly transformed the crowd into a shouting, screaming, shoving mob.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- Since the beginning of hostilities on the Eastern Front, the German Air Force has sought to raid Moscow nineteen times, but almost half the communiques reporting this have stated that "enemy aircraft were unable to penetrate our defenses."

Determined to make amends for one or two rather sloppy performances of recent date, the Yankees regaled 44,412 enthusiasts at the Stadium yesterday with a dazzling pair of ninth-inning finishes that wrenched both ends of a double-header from the Athletics.

VICHY, France, Aug. 17 -- Two hundred thousand sacks that contained the United States gift of flour to the people of unoccupied France have been transformed into sheets, aprons, bibs, dresses, shirts and underclothing for the children of French unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Roosevelt went immediately into conference with Secretary of State Cordell Hull aboard his special train when it arrived here this morning from Rockland, Me., terminal port of the "vacation cruise" on which precedents were shattered by the President's meeting with Prime Minister Winston Churchill at sea.

PRESCOTT, Ark., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Unauthorized departure of forty-three Negro soldiers from a Southern manoeuvre area after a series of incidents involving them with police and civilians has been disclosed by Army authorities.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 -- While the iron and steel industry continued further study of the pig iron and steel mandatory priority order last week, virtually all steel consumers were rapidly analyzing their business in order to be in a good position to obtain preference ratings as soon as possible.

VICHY, France, Aug. 17 -- The desire of the Vichy government for "comprehension of its position" on the part of the United States is made manifest this week-end by newspaper discussion in which France is represented as the natural link between Europe and America, historically and sentimentally.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Cardinals lost their precarious hold on the National League lead today by splitting a double-header with the Pirates before 34,292 fans.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- By the heartbreaking margin of one solid single by Phil Masi, Brooklyn's John Whitlow Wyatt today missed entering baseball's hall of fame as the Dodgers swept both ends of a double-header with the Braves, 5 -- 1 and 3 -- 0, and moved back into the National League lead, displacing the Cardinals by half a game.

Listing the two American novels, "The Grapes of Wrath" and "Native Son" as "two popular contributions to our philosophy of American history," the Rev. Dr. John B. Thompson, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Norman, Okla., said yesterday morning that they told millions of Americans of two great migrations of misery in this country which stand, like shadows with enormous grudges, behind the doors of ambitious day.

It would be short-sighted foolishness to discount too heavily the German claims of successes on the Eastern Front or to place too much confidence in the ability of the Russians to withstand the Nazi onslaught indefinitely. Still, there can be no harm in recalling that just one year ago Axis propagandists were boasting that Great Britain was as near collapse as they would have the world believe the Soviets are now.

The eight-point statement by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill will be a memorable contribution to peace because it will "enormously encourage" the British and those fighting by their side and will also ring like a "melancholy death knell in the hearts of millions of their enemies," Alfred Duff Cooper, former British Minister of Information, declared in a broadcast over WABC last night.

Activity continued at a steady pace in the wholesale markets last week. With the absence of a Summer lull, retailers were already reordering briskly on Fall and Winter merchandise purchased early in the season. Fur-trimmed costume suits remained active sellers.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Charlie Root's third attempt to win his 199th major league victory was successful today as he beat the Reds, 4 to 2, after the Cubs had lost the opening half of a double-header, 6 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Striving for the first time in many years to increase the nation's farm production, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today a conservation program for 1942 which in certain respects is a reversal of previous policy.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- The experience he gained years ago playing on British seaside courses as a member of former American Walker Cup teams and golfing expeditionary forces has stood Jess Sweetser in good stead in the Maidstone Bowl tournament, annual fixture at the Maidstone Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Entertainments were held throughout the day for out-of-town guests at estates in the colony. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Manning McKeon gave a luncheon at their home, Plas-ar-Lyn, for Mr. and Mrs. George W. Whitaker of New York, who are spending the week-end with Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran at Ranley House.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Barring an emergency, Congress will mark time until after Labor Day.

TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- Preparations for the American-British-Soviet military conference in Moscow have caused Japan's political interest to shift from, the dangers of a further southward advance to the menace in the north. The Japanese view is summed up by the newspaper Hochi as follows:

The first faint sniff of Autumn in the air sends Manhattan residents off adventuring into the remotest corners of their city. Some of them follow a midtown street that leads eastward across wide avenues toward the river. And on a noisy corner they will come suddenly upon a small, sunny shop in blue and terra-cotta.

The London Bookseller, reporting on the effects of paper rationing and other wartime conditions on publishing, announces that in the first six months of this year 3,585 new books and new editions were issued in England, compared to 6,464 in the same period in 1940.
BERLIN, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Today's German Communique follows:
