WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- United States foreign trade in June decreased in value and volume from the levels of the immediately preceding months, according to figures issued by the Commerce Department. The value of exports, including re-exports, decreased by 12 per cent to $338,000,000 from $385,000,000 in April and May, while total imports declined by 6 per cent to $280,000,000 from $297,000,000 in May.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Naval reservists are in the same status as regulars for the period of the emergency, but will be returned to private life as soon as possible When the emergency is over, Secretary Knox stated today in a, telegram to Governor Lehman of New York.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- Piecemeal conversions of State, industrial and mortgage bonds in conformity with the trend to lower interest rates prevailing in the market continued at an accelerated pace in July, according to a summary published by the Frankfurter Zeitung.

Thirty-five hundred delegates and guests attended the opening of the eighty-sixth annual convention of the Catholic Verein of America and the twenty-fifth annual meeting of its auxiliary, the National Catholic Women's Union, at a pontifical high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Uncle Sam has beckoned his finger at George Schrafft, who received his bachelor's degree at Harvard in June, and in another few weeks he will be a buck private in the Army, because his draft board has said so.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Uncle Sam has beckoned his finger at George Schrafft, who received his bachelor's degree at Harvard in June, and in another few weeks he will be a buck private in the Army, because his draft board has said so.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- After three days of virtual silence in official and semi-official quarters on developments in the Ukraine, the High Command announced today that Nikolaev, Black Sea naval base, encircled since Thursday, had been taken and that Russian forces being pursued east of the Bug River showed ever-increasing signs of dissolution.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The War Department announced yesterday the award of contracts totaling $2,109,544. Firms in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

We have surrendered our aluminum pots and pans, swept the counters of silk, turned to plastics, adopted plywood in place of metal and wood where we could, expressed our willingness to use silver instead of tin for soldering, and otherwise readjusted our mode of living because of the shortage of essentials.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- A forlorn, battle-scarred band of Giants beat a weary retreat from Shibe Park tonight after a day of indignities in which, they dropped a double-header to the Phillies before 6,587 fans.
ROME, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Italian High Command's communique follows:
CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 18 -- A Camp Stewart anti-aircraft regiment reinforced by a separate battalion today was rushed to the defense of a theoretical "Army Corps."

FIVE years ago James Agee, the intense young Harvard-bred poet ("Permit Me Voyage"), went down to Alabama to study the lives of typical tenant-farmers in the Cotton South. Walker Evans, the brilliant Farm Security Administration photographer, went along to take some pictures at the same time. Certain of the pictures have since been reproduced elsewhere, but several dozen of them appear as a sort of preliminary to some 150,000 words of Mr. Agee's text.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Playing before 72,000 empty seats, the Senators defeated the skidding Indians tonight, 4 to 2. Only 8,365 fans were at the Municipal Stadium to watch Steve Sundra limit the Redskins to seven hits and hand them their thirteenth setback in the last fourteen games.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 19 -- The sinking of three German patrol ships off the Netherland coast by Royal Air Force bombers yesterday and several daylight bomber and fighter raids over Northern France, where an industrial plant at Lille, was bombed, following Sunday night attacks by more than 100 British bombers on Bremen and Duisburg, were reported last night in various announcements by the Air Ministry.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The sixtieth annual national doubles tennis championship began at the Longwood Cricket Club today with one of the quietest and least eventful opening rounds in years.

IT appears that Mr. Sam Goldwyn, the amazing movie magnate who is alleged to have coined the stunning phrase "Include me out," now wants to include everybody in. He has a screen problem on his hands and is calling for help. It's Mr. Goldwyn who is going to produce the film based on the life of the late Lou Gehrig and he doesn't know what actor to cast as Buster Lou.

The Engineers Public Service Company yesterday submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission a series of economic studies designed to show that both utility rate payers and investors would be the ultimate losers if the "death sentence" section of the Public Utility Holding Company Act were carried out.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Finnish forces storming down the west shore of Lake Ladoga toward Leningrad and a projected union with Germans driving upon the city from the south have captured Kurkijoki, a lake town ninety-five miles north of the Soviet Baltic center, the High Command announced tonight.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- For the first time, perhaps, an attempt has been made to draw the line between chess masters and chess experts, due to the unusual array of talent at Colgate University for the annual New York State Chess Association congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Aug. 13, 1941, aggregated $9,242,000,000. Total debits during the thirteen weeks ended Aug. 13, 1941, amounted to $133,425,000,000, or 26 per cent above the total reported for the corresponding period a year ago.

In as much as the consumers' durable goods industries are scheduled for sharp production cuts, the proposed restrictions on installment sales will probably have no serious effect on either sales or advertising campaigns, according to agency men yesterday.

After much travail Gilbert Miller has concluded arrangements with the British Ministry of Information and our State Department to bring over Barbara Everest from London to act Queen Anne in his offering of "Anne of England," opening Oct. 7 at the St. James, according to word received here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Operations in wheat futures today were on a reduced scale, and prices held within a range of about 3/4 cent a bushel. Easiness in Minneapolis had some effect on sentiment and there was also a little hedging pressure, but professional speculators were inclined to go slow on either side, pending further developments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Lord Beaverbrook, British Minister of Supply, is scheduled to gain a further insight into the workings of United States defense machinery when he attends a meeting tomorrow of the Council of the Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- For about $175 a year in salaries, the Office of Production Management has the services of brains whose earnings normally total $2,000,000 to $3,000,000. Some of the younger officials of the agency have learned a lot by close observation of captains of industry.
NEW YORK Major Gen. and Mrs. William Crozier have arrived from Washington and are at the St. Regis.

The easy fatalism with which many Americans discuss the "inevitability" of inflation is something which astonishes and appalls most European economists and financial experts here who have experienced its dreadful consequences at first hand. Inflation, they recognize, is not a natural calamity, like a hurricane or an earthquake, that falls upon a nation from without.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 16:
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18 -- A benefit bridge and fashion show is being arranged for the East Hampton Settlement House on Sept. 3 at the Maidstone Club.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 18 (AP) -- W.W. Vaughan's New Jersey-bred Roncat, a 4-year-old son of Catalan, gained his first victory in nine starts today when he won Narragansett Park's $1,600 Warren Purse from eight rivals. Sprinting six furlongs in 1:11 2-5, Roncat scored by half a length over Charm Bracelet, who was only a nose in front of Star Boarder.

A conference of Federal and State agencies, called to discuss the Federal Government's plan to build up a backlog of needed public works projects for the "emergency after the emergency," was told yesterday by Jacob Baker, coordinator of Public Works Reserve, that an expenditure on public works of probably $10,000,000,000 annually for five years would be needed to cushion the economic shock of a cessation of war conditions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- The national defense program was called a "godsend" to many penitentiary wardens today as the congress of the American Prison Association received reports of a rapid dissolution of serious disciplinary problems.

North and south, the red lights are clearly set for Japan. Any doubts still cherished by the Japanese Government that it can take further aggressive steps with impunity must have been resolved in the long interview yesterday between the Foreign Minister and the American Ambassador.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- A new issue of $100,000,000 short-term notes by New York State will be available tomorrow to ninety-four banks and firms which accepted today the proffer of Controller Morris S. Tremaine of these notes at an interest rate of twenty-one hundredths of percent, payable at maturity on March 19, 1942.

Forty-three persons were injured, none critically, and 100 others were thrown into a panic yesterday when a two-car electric train crashed into the rear of a one-car train that had stopped suddenly a few feet east of Clinton Street, Stapleton, S.I.

Several thousand WPA employes will be put in jobs in defense industries in this city under the expanded WPA training and re-employment program, it was announced yesterday after a conference of WPA officials with Fred R. Rouch, national director of the training and re-employment division of WPA at the local headquarters, 70 Columbus Avenue.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The Man o' War filly Dorimar, who sprang several surprises in Florida last Winter, was just as much of a shock to form players today when she captured the Hurricana Handicap at $18.40 for $2.

The consolidated net profit for the first half of 1941 reported yesterday by the Boeing Airplane Company and its domestic subsidiary, Boeing Aircraft Company, amounted to $2,011,361 after provision for depreciation and estimated income and profits taxes.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The picturesque Czar Peter house at Zaandam, historical landmark well known to American and other foreign tourists, may be demolished because under the German occupation travelers in the Netherlands are scarce, and the house no longer pays its way.

Trading in the wholesale market yesterday was fair to good. Prices were stronger all through the list with the exception of veal and calf hindsaddles, which were only steady. Lamb sold strong to mostly $1 higher. Cow beef prices were strong to 50 cents higher. Steer hinds and ribs sold at steady to strong prices, as did bull beef.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Mississippi Power Company and the Gulf Power Company, subsidiaries of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission amendments to their application to issue and sell bonds to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to facilitate defense expansion.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 19 -- A sharp protest against obstacles put in the way of Americans who wish to leave Japan or Japanese-controlled territory in China was submitted to Foreign Minister Teijiro Toyoda yesterday by United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew, who called on the Minister and discussed the situation with him for more than two hours.

PRESCOTT, Ark., Aug. 18 -- The morale of United States fighting men is in direct proportion to that of the citizenship, and if it is low, it is not the fault of the Army, Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear said today in commenting on magazine articles alleging that the spirit of the soldiers is poor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The National Defense Mediation Board began panel hearings today in the United States Gypsum Company strike and in the dispute involving the Erwin Cotton Mills, Durham, N.C.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- Isolated units of the Red Army have attacked the flanks of the main German forces or have cut their way back to the Soviet lines after the initial encirclement, it was reported today as the German Army continued its powerful all-out offensive and bitter fighting raged along the whole length of the front.

BUFFALO, Aug. 18 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York declared today at the annual convention of the International Association of Police Chiefs that "if we are called into action for the protection of the civilian population, it is not going to be a picnic; it is going to be a real job."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray entertained with a luncheon today at Ilex House, her home in Water Mill. Her guests included Mrs. J. Frederic Byers and Mrs. Geoffrey Thistleton-Smith of London, who is spending the Summer with her aunt, Mrs. John E. Berwind, at Minden, the latter's place in Bridge-hampton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- In a detailed report to Congressional leaders on his meeting at sea with Prime Minister Churchill, President Roosevelt today described Russia as the key to the immediate situation in Europe and raised the hope that the Soviet would hold out indefinitely against the Nazi military machine.

Hats Across the Sea Like many men who go away on trips with the best of intentions, Mr. Harry L. Hopkins returned with another man's hat. The new hat, which is much better than the old one, bears the initials W.S.C.

Military drill as well as instruction in first aid, bomb and fire control, gas defense and the like will be required of air raid wardens, it was announced by Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine last night in addresses to 2,600 zone and sector wardens and police officers at the Hotel Astor.

Declaring that there was keen disappointment among soldiers over the lengthening of the term of Army service, Lieut. Col. George J. Zentgraf, chaplain of the 244th Coast Artillery, formerly the Ninth Regiment, New York National Guard, at Camp Pendleton, Va., expressed hope yesterday afternoon that by the time he returned to camp it "will not have caused a tremendous exodus over the hill,'' as it will mean "the guardhouse for them when they get back."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The gasoline situation on the Atlantic seaboard is a mess and promises to become very much messier before it will clear up; all this because Mr. Ickes is trying to take on the role of an economic god, omniscient and omnipotent.

The 240-year-old deed conveying Scarsdale (Westchester County) from the Mohegan Indians to Lord Caleb Heathcote has been found in the Scarsdale town records, according to Richard S. White, manager of the Scarsdale Chateau apartment house group in that town.

MILLBURN, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Detectives of Millburn and the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad worked here today on two theories of the cause of the milk train wreck that cost the life last night of Leonard Pratt of Morristown, the fireman.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The American-British-Chinese Stabilization Board, acting to improve the value of China's currency, has fixed the Chungking dollar exchange rate at 511-32 American cents. This rate is approximately 10 per cent above the current "black market" exchange.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- In a setting remote from the turmoil of the world, eighty men, women and children clad as Indians put on tonight their twice-postponed pageant based on a script about Hiawatha by Tom Cook, a 65-year-old dirt farmer.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Relations between the United States and Japan were reported near the breaking point today following a long conference between the United States Ambassador, Joseph C. Grew, and Foreign Minister Teijiro Toyoda, at which Mr. Grew is reported to have warned that American pressure on Japan would be intensified unless she made fundamental alterations in her foreign policy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Perry Schwartz, all-league end, was among the missing as Coach Jock Sutherland touched off the Brooklyn Football Dodgers' preseason training grind at Hun School today. A scarcity of experienced wingmen and the nearness of the Chicago Bear battle.
Officials of oil companies and operators of filling stations were still confused yesterday over the Federal order to reduce by 10 per cent the deliveries of gasoline to retailers.

For the third successive session the cotton futures market yesterday held to a listless course, as traders awaited word from Washington on the President's action on the bill to freeze loan cotton for the duration of the war. As a consequence quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated narrowly and final prices were unchanged to 2 points higher for the day.

Trading in rayon greige goods in the primary markets practically ceased here yesterday as the mills awaited action on price ceilings by the OPACS. Information in important trade quarters was that mandatory levels would be established "within the week" and would probably cover sales by second hands as well as those in the primary markets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, urged today that individual income tax exemptions and allowances for dependents be cut at least in half.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 18 -- The potential capacity of the Burma Road into China is far beyond the usually estimated 30,000 tons a month, according to Daniel Arnstein, veteran American truck and taxi operator, who has arrived in Chungking after completion of a survey of the road for the United States Government.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Soldiers in Colonel Edward J. Towers's 165th Field Artillery loaded office and field equipment into 180 vehicles this afternoon in preparation for the regiment's departure from here at one minute after midnight for a week's training on the Tobyhanna Military Reservation in Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt might hurl more than 1,000,000 war-hardened Axis troops against the Red Army's defenses on the west bank of the Dnieper River in a gigantic effort to reach the Crimean gate to the Caucasian oil fields, Soviet sources said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Aug. 19 -- A German threat to Leningrad increased during yesterday's fighting. Today's Russian communique reports that Red Army troops were forced to evacuate the town of Kingisepp, east of the Luga River and seventy miles southwest of Leningrad, from which it is separated only by rolling plains.

The Axis propagandists are busy trying to minimize the importance of the meeting at sea between President Roosevelt and Winston Churchill and their joint declaration of the aims of the two English-speaking democracies in war and peace. The chief grist for their mill is still the narrow margin -- a single vote -- by which the House of Representatives passed the resolution for an extension of military training.

Retail Sales Here Up 36% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 36 per cent for the week ended Aug. 16, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The nomination of Rexford Guy Tugwell to be Governor of Puerto Rico was approved today by the Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs and will be reported tomorrow to the Senate.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Clarence Davison's long-shot American Derby possibility, Delray, ran to a handy triumph at Washington Park today.

HAVANA, Aug. 18 -- A sudden outbreak of bombings here tonight injured at least twelve persons and provided a puzzle for the police. After the first blast there were rumors to the effect that the attacks might have been the result of feeling among a radical element against the Spanish Falange.

The National Youth Administration for New York City and Long Island, mustering an orchestra of 120 young players, a chorus of thirty singers, Morton Gould as a guest conductor of one of his own works, and Mayor La Guardia as an intermission speaker, last night presented its first concert at the Lewisohn Stadium.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Joe Louis asserted on the witness stand today that it cost about $15,000 a year to maintain her station in life as the wife of the world's heavyweight boxing champion.
Because of the lack of rain and subsequent low water conditions, the trout season in New York State will not be extended beyond its present closing date on the last of this month.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- Authoritative military quarters in Berlin asserted tonight that the Russian campaign had again entered phase on which, for tactical reasons, no specific information relative to the progress of the operations could be released.
The right wing of the American Labor party formally gave its endorsement yesterday to two Fusion candidates for Borough President, Edgar J. Nathan Jr., in Manhattan, and Matthew J. Troy in Brooklyn.

With an entry list made up of players from various parts of the country, competition in the Richmond County Country Club's annual girls' invitation grass court tennis tournament started at Dongan Hills, S.I., yesterday. Included in the draw were five Californians, two players from the South and half a dozen from the Midwest.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Aug. 4, editorial comment was made concerning the matter of building ships on the Mississippi in the vicinity of New Orleans. From the standpoint of labor and climatic conditions, such locations are desirable, but with respect to sources of material supplies New Orleans is too remotely situated to enable vessels to be constructed under advantageous economic conditions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Japan has given no satisfactory explanation of her refusal to allow more than 100 American citizens to return home, Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared today as diplomatic conversations both in Washington and Tokyo indicated that tension in Japanese-American relations had not abated.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Delegates who asserted that they represented 1,000,000 farm families assembled at an emergency meeting today to plan a protest against price-control bills and other legislation which, they contend, "threaten the income and security of the American farmer."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Grain crops in the Southern Ukraine and in the Crimea should have been largely harvested by the middle of August, an Agriculture Department report today said, and the saving of these crops for Russia would appear to be a race with time against the advance of the Nazi war machine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Roosevelt announced today that American civilian pilots would ferry United States war planes from this country to British forces in the Near East under an arrangement permitting United States operation of air fields in Africa.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 13:

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 18 -- To keep pace in the modern world, a pharmacist must also be a beauty specialist, the annual convention of the American Pharmaceutical Association was told today by Dr. Justin L. Powers, director of the association's laboratories in Washington.
The American Export liner Exeter arrived from Lisbon yesterday with 195 passengers, including refugees from Europe coming here to live and Americans returning home.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The boys and girls won a flock of titles today as the forty-fourth Grand American clay target carnival got under way, and when the smoke cleared away from the greatest opening day barrage the classic has ever witnessed "Mr. Trapshooting" himself was in the spotlight.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Using American-built planes, pilots of the British Mediterranean Fleet blasted today at Axis positions in Libya, dropping a steady stream of high explosive and incendiary bombs on supply bases, troop concentrations and ports in a series of coastal raids.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Among those giving luncheons today at the Trackside Restaurant were Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward, Walter P. Chrysler, William A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States; Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Smith and Mr. and Mrs. Dion Keith Kerr.

The continued elusiveness of Nick Circella, alias Nick Dean, who is wanted as a government witness, resulted yesterday in a further postponement of the trial of Willie Bioff and George H. Browne, officials of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A ceiling for copper scrap, designed to re-establish its normal or "fair" relationship to new copper, was established today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have had since July 25 hints at an oil curb of Japan, halting of silk car-goes which were later permitted to unload, freezing of Japanese assets, and on Aug. 1 Presidential orders which sounded as if at last our confessed policy of appeasement in the Far East were ended.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Three horses bettered their previous records on the second day of Grand Circuit harness racing at the Wisconsin State Fair today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 18 -- British and Indian officers back in the Near East after seven weeks in Vichy French hands, during which they were sent by train from Salonika, Greece, to Toulon, France, through occupied territory, declared today pro-British sentiment was strong in both France and Yugoslavia.

Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, defended yesterday the right of labor to strike in vital defense industries. She emphasized freedom of decision on the part of the worker, declaring that although "some people are thinking we ought to put a stop to this sort of business," strikes cannot be clamped down upon without the surrender of something "precious" to every American.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Paraphrasing the nursery rhyme, Big Jack Hoerner didn't stand in a corner in the Great Lakes amateur golf championship today -- he took it over.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded a new issue of $5,000,000 of notes yesterday. The successful syndicate consisted of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, the National Shawmut Bank of Boston, the Merchants National Bank of Boston and the Day Trust Company of Boston.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Information reaching here front reliable sources in the Netherlands paints a distressing picture of the state of servitude to which the Netherland press has been reduced by the German authorities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Roosevelt reportedly decided today to make a final, personal appeal to officials of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Corporation to accept recommendations of the National Defense Mediation Board so that work may go forward on $493,000,000 worth of ships for the Navy and Maritime Commission tied up since Aug. 7 by a C.I.O. strike at the company's Kearny, N.J., yard.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 18 -- A mass demonstration, today by 3,000 sympathizers with the striking men at the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company from New Jersey locals of twenty-eight other C.I.O. unions created a major traffic problem, on the Lincoln Highway for about two hours, but was otherwise uneventful.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- The Yankees' tour of inspection to determine for themselves what has happened to the rest of the American League got a rather inauspicious start today. In fact, it did not start at all, inasmuch as a drizzling rain forced the Tigers to call off the opening clash of a three-game series with the Bronx Bombers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Roosevelt today signed legislation authorizing retention in Federal service for eighteen months beyond their regular terms of service of selectees, National Guardsmen, reservists and enlisted men of the Regular Army.

Considerable uncertainty with respect to a definite price policy continued in the low-end dress market yesterday. This was highlighted by the decision of an important manufacturer of $2.87 1/2 dresses to produce and sell some 50,000 dresses at that quotation despite the move last week to advance this range to $3.62 1/2.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill was reported reliably today to have called a meeting of the War Cabinet for a first-hand account of his secret discussions with President Roosevelt.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Aug. 18 -- The Bourse opened firm today with Netherlands Indies shares and shippings very firm and active. Trading at the close also was firm but with the demand for domestic industrials less active despite the gains.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP) -- President Thomas J. Lyons of the New York State Federation of Labor criticized tonight what he termed "unpatriotic, asinine leadership of unions outside the pale of the American Federation of Labor" for having encouraged anti-strike legislation during the national crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Department of Justice was represented today at the opening of a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission on applications involving the merging of a number of Eastern seaboard trucking concerns into a new company to be known as Associated Transport, Inc.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Though it has been open and in use for several weeks, the Robinson house on Kay Street, given to the Army and Navy Y.M.C.A. as a hospitality house by Mrs. E. Sanderson Cushman of Sands Point, L.I., was officially opened with a housewarming this afternoon.
Out of all the stories of those who were rescued from the East River after they had plunged from a height of thirty feet from the upper deck of the burning Panuco, one episode stood out.

VICHY, France, Aug. 18 -- A number of French Senators and Deputies who were too outspoken in their criticism of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's administration have been placed under administrative arrest in a crackdown against Communist and other dissident elements, it was disclosed today.

Books Abroad, the international quarterly issued by the University of Oklahoma Press, conducted in its Winter issue a symposium on the "world's worst book." Prominent editors and authors assailed many of the mighties of literature. Books Abroad is willing to close the matter with one observation: that two great names remain "sacred and serene" even after the symposium -- Shakespeare and Cervantes.

Hollywood, serving as the motion picture production center of the world, would produce only high standard pictures if the movie-going public would support them, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, declared yesterday on his return to New York from the cinema capital.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Alex Watson, Hudson River professional, and his amateur partner, John P. Jordan of Hummocks, won the weekly Westchester County Golf Association proamateur best-ball tournament today by touring the famous West course of the Winged Foot Club In a 5 under par, 34, 33 -- 67.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Contracts totaling $40,557,540 were awarded by the War Department today. The following, not previously announced, went to firms in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey:

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Shooting' sub-par golf on the first nine, Mrs. Fred Meissner and Joe Sylvester of Pomonok won the women's-pro golf tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. with 77 -- 8 -- 69 over the North Shore Country Club course today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Command issued this communique today:

Pending a reclassification of our efforts to increase this nation's aid to Great Britain while starting a stream of war materials to Russia and pending more definite information on the complex tax situation and news to clarify the Soviet situation in the Ukraine, business in the stock market continued yesterday at the recent slower pace, although the list had a decidedly better tone.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Arthur Straub, professional at the Homestead Golf Club of Spring Lake, and John A. Brady, Newark City Commissioner, today collaborated for a best-ball 29, 36 -- 65, seven under par, on the east course of the Essex County Country Club, to win the pro-amateur tourney that marked Jim Barnes day.

Habit-forming to an alarming degree are the crisp little potato sticks, covered with a film of golden cheese, which appear in trim tins all ready to serve. Tucked in the oven till they're piping hot and deliciously brittle, these shoestring potatoes with fancy coats are especially nice beside a juicy steak or chop, with perhaps a scarlet disk or two of tomato to complement their jaunty yellow.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Phils reverted to their usual habits today, dropping two games to the Reds, 13 -- 5 and 5 -- 4. Cincinnati thus broke a tie with the Pirates to take third place by a game and a half.

All thoughts of Sunday's double debacle at Philadelphia were brushed aside yesterday as the Giants squared off twice against the Cubs at the Polo Grounds and in double-quick time twice polished off the Chicagoans, 6 -- 4 and 7 -- 1. With Hal Schumacher and Cliff Melton in control and the Giants resorting to sound baseball again, the slim turnout under Coogan's Bluff was treated to some fine fielding and timely hitting.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.
Fire that spread with phenomenal speed destroyed Pier 27 in Brooklyn yesterday and wrecked the New York Cuba Mail Line freighter Panuco, which was being unloaded alongside.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Edward Small has engaged George Brent, Joan Bennett and Mischa Auer for the leading roles in "Twin Beds," which Tim Whelan will direct, starting Sept. 8. Stephen Morehouse Avery has prepared the scenario from, a play by Margaret Mayo and Salisbury Field which Small purchased from Warners; it has been filmed twice before, in 1920 and again in 1929 with Jack Mulhall.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 18 -- Vice Admiral Jose Machado Castro Silva, Chief of Naval Operations, declared today that he had no confirmation that mines were floating in Northern Brazilian waters, but added that the report was receiving the close attention of naval authorities, and that all port captains in Pernambuco, Natal and Fortaleza had been instructed to investigate the matter thoroughly.

Operators were principals in a number of the city realty deals reported yesterday. Several properties were purchased in Manhattan and the Bronx and a property on the West Side near Central Park was resold by an operator after a brief ownership.
WITH THE ARMY IN SOUTH WEST WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A Brigadier General got right up in the front ranks with his troops today and was captured by an invading enemy in the Pacific Northwest war games.

A trend toward declining inventories, due however to the inability of buyers to obtain quick deliveries on all types of materials, was reported yesterday in the current survey of business of the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit. Of members reporting on July experiences, 20 per cent indicated that their inventories had declined from the preceding month, the highest ratio since the defense program was started.

VICHY, France, Aug. 18 -- The publication of weekly statements has been definitely resumed by the Bank of France, the one published today being as of July 24. The principal changes noted are a rise in circulation of 500,000,000 francs, an increase in non-interest-bearing advances to the Treasury of 1,000,000,000 francs and a fractional decline in the gold coverage to 25.41 per cent, compared with 25.49 per cent on July 17.

The first full day of trading under the new ceiling prices on burlap found the market as slow as it has been in recent weeks. Offerings of spot and afloat goods were at a standstill as both buyers and sellers took time to digest the import of the latest development.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Marshal Semyon Budenny has succeeded in moving nearly half of his Ukrainian armies of some 700,000 men to the east bank of the Dnieper River after suffering heavy casualties, estimated at 150,000, under the smashing German drive, it was reported today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Jersey City supplanted Rochester in fourth place by a one-point margin tonight by taking its second straight double-header from the Red Wings before a crowd of 8,771. The scores were 2-1 and 5-2.

Fear that the 20 per cent coffee quota increase ordered in Washington some time ago may be carried over into the 1941-42 quota year which starts Oct. 1, is a major concern to the coffee industry at present, according to a report on the Inter-American Coffee Agreement, completed by the Commodity Research Bureau, Inc.

Possible Solution Possibilities appeared over the week-end that means more politically amicable than the East-land-O'Daniel bill might be found to subdue the Congressional farm bloc's agitation over the issue of Canadian mills meeting United States defense orders with textiles manufactured from Brazilian cotton.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 14 -- The problems of modern war did not end for Ecuador when her truce with Peru took effect July 31. Today she faces the necessity of feeding, clothing and housing thousands of her people who became refugees over night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Roosevelt today approved twenty-six projects in twelve States under the public works program, to provide facilities or services necessary to the health, safety or welfare of persons engaged in defense activities.

In a remarkably frank statement addressed to his fellow-Republicans Mr. John R. Davies explains why he is running for Mayor. "If," he says, "it were merely a question of good government in this city I should not be in this fight. * * * Except to oust Red fellow-travelers I would make few changes in present key places."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The issuance today of the long-awaited Form TFR-300, under which Federal Reserve Banks are to make reports on foreign fund freezing, revealed that it is to be used for a much wider purpose -- a census of all foreign-owned property subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.

The United States Army opened a buying office here yesterday, indistinguishable from the scores maintained in the city by corporate and voluntary chain organizations where manufacturers are interviewed and their merchandise "listed" for orders.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Aug. 16 there appeared a letter from Raymond S. Anderson in support of State or Federal supervision of labor unions.

NEWARK, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Paul V. Fortmiller, secretary-treasurer of the Jackson Perkins Nursery Company of Newark, internationally known rose growers, died yesterday of a heart attack at Cape Vincent while on a vacation fishing trip. His age was 50.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The White Sox strengthened their hold on second place today by shutting out the Athletics twice, 4 to 0 and 1 to 0.
ROME, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., and Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., whose fairways feud has been one of the national amateur championship's highlights in the past two years, will put on another of their golf duels tomorrow in the quarter-finals of the Great Lakes amateur tournament.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Spencer Scott, winner of the 1940 Hambletonian, took the $3,500 Matron Stake for 4 to 6 year-old trotters on today's Grand Circuit harness racing program at the Wisconsin State Fair, capturing two of the three heats.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Aug. 20 -- The "battle of the Leningrad defenses" appears to be in progress, with Russian forces, continuing their withdrawal just east of Kingisepp, according to Moscow radio reports.

As the national defense effort swings into stride and expansion of the military and naval arms and of the productive facilities of the nation pass into advanced phases, New York City office buildings are reaping some benefit because crowded conditions in Washington are forcing many governmental offices to look for quarters elsewhere.

The silence of death which falls upon a country overrun by the German Armies and delivered thereafter into the clutches of the Gestapo is being broken after long months in the case of Yugoslavia. To Ankara, the sole independent news center left anywhere near the Balkans, come reports of continuous uprising against the new oppressors.

The entire fifth floor, comprising 20,000 square feet of space in the Penn Terminal Building, 370 Seventh Avenue, has been leased to the Darling Stores Corporation, ladies' wearing apparel chain, which also has renewed its lease on the ninth and tenth floors of the same structure, bringing its total space to 60,000 square feet.

The left wing of the American Labor party, which, prior to the Hitler invasion of Russia, had announced its intentions of nominating a "peace candidate" for Mayor threw its affirmative support to Mayor La Guardia last night, and took the even more definite step of endorsing virtually all of the nominees of its hated enemy, the right wing of the American Labor party.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The American public is more pleased with the progress of defense production, now than it was six months ago, but a substantial number of voters are still far from satisfied. Despite the publicity given to gains in production of aircraft and other material, the proportion of people who think America's production is not going ahead fast enough is larger than the proportion who think it is.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Roosevelt emphasized today that it was imperative for the American people to realize they had a major struggle on their hands if the fight of the democracies against nazism was to be won.

Although the average of wholesale prices in June was 13 per cent higher than a year before, and although shipments under the Lease-Lend Act were larger than in May, exports from the United States in June, as now reported by the Commerce Department, were in value less than in the two or three preceding months and slightly less than in the corresponding month of 1940.

A series of meetings between government officials and selling agents for anthracite coal producers is now going on with a view to deciding whether there is any need for ceiling prices. No official decision has been reached as yet. Last week, there were scattered advances of 10 to 25 cents a ton at wholesale but these have not been reflected in retail quotations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- More than 450 delegates representing 1,000,000 farm families protested today against the price pegging program and went on record as opposed to the putting of maximum prices on any commodities until agriculture is put on an equal footing with industry and labor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Council of the Office of Production Management today took action to head off unemployment resulting from the impact of priorities and undue concentration of defense orders.

Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, announced yesterday the sale of 21,097 shares of its holdings in Autocar Company capital stock to the Liberty Aircraft Products Corporation, for an undisclosed consideration.

With two million fewer children in the public schools today than there were a decade ago, the death-knell of the nation is feeing sounded by seemingly patriotic advocates of birth control, the Rev. Hubert Beller, spiritual director of St. Gerard's Maternity Guild of the New York local branch of the National Catholic Women's Union, declared yesterday in warning women against "Sangerism."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Miss Barbara Sherwin Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Robinson of this city, was married in St. Aedan's Church here today to Charles Stanley Alien, also of New Haven, son of Mrs. C. Stanley Alien and the late Mr. Alien.
BERLIN, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The following communique was issued today:

The bulk of the new test campaigns and increased advertising appropriations appears to be coming from the food industry, which is not apt to be seriously affected by priorities except where some packaging materials and containers are concerned.

A Federal board of inquiry, which started an investigation yesterday into the fire that destroyed Pier 27, Brooklyn, and the New York Cuba Mail Line freighter Panuco on Monday, failed to establish the exact cause but did hear evidence of a new theory.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since the cause of death of birds in Central Park is unknown, judging by the letter of your correspondent, Miss Barbara Kent, obviously the first step in combating such deaths is to secure as freshly dead birds as possible and submit them to a chemical laboratory for examination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Vessels carrying supplies from West Coast ports to Russia could save time by following the Great Circle route from Seattle to the Orient and thus avoid the westerly gales frequently met on the more southerly track normally followed, the Department of Commerce announced today.
The texts of the addresses by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts at the mass meeting of the Council for Democracy follow:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- An assertion that President Roosevelt "in violation of the Constitution" had entered into an "offensive and defensive alliance" with Winston Churchill to "destroy the common enemy" and create a new world order was made in the Senate today by Senator Hiram Johnson, California Republican.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A general sales tax and a broadening of the income tax base were urged upon the Senate Finance Committee today by Livingston W. Houston as representative of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Two self-propelled streamlined cars embodying several new engineering features for mountain service on the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad were successful in running tests on the lines of the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the Reading Company between Jersey City and West Trenton, N.J., yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Hog values drifted 10 cents a hundred pounds lower today under pressure of liberal receipts, while beef cattle brought steady to strong prices and Spring lambs and yearlings were 25 to 35 cents higher.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Joseph Rosentover, president of the American Football Association, announced last night the franchise of the Jersey City Giants had been bought by the Cleveland Rams of the National League.

TRENTON, Aug. 19 -- The late Irving Wayland Bonbright, retired New York investment broker, created a $1,200,000 trust fund for the benefit of his widow, children and grandchildren, according to his will, which was probated today in Prorogative Court here on order of Vice Ordinary Henry T. Kays.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- Labor and management endorsed today a plan evolved by the Office of Production Management to move swiftly into other fields the employes of industries dislocated by priorities in the defense program.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Dr. and Mrs. Fenton Taylor gave a dinner with dancing tonight at The Galley for their son, Eugene S. Taylor, and members of the latter's house party, Miss Virginia Elwood of Chicago and George Holmes of Pittsburgh.

Cooler weather during the week ended last Saturday contributed to declines in the general and infant death rates in New York City, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince gave a large luncheon party at Marble House today. Mrs. Robert E. Strawbridge was a luncheon hostess at the Fosdick Cottage and Miss Sylvia Hillhouse also had luncheon guests.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The War Department's statement on the release of Selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers from training service was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- As President Roosevelt and Lord Beaverbrook, British Minister of Supply, conferred on measures to speed the flow of arms to Britain, Russia and China, Senator Byrd of Virginia condemned today the American defense production program as "appallingly ineffective" and demanded wholesale reorganization of administration to save it from failure.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 19 -- Eight persons were killed, two were injured seriously and three slightly in the crash of a Panair do Brasil liner on a mountain peak fifteen miles south of here yesterday, rescue parties reported tonight.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final adjustments.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Two airplane accidents in Florida today took the lives of a lieutenant and four naval air station cadets.

The Transamerica Corporation, a holding company, and its domestic subsidiaries had an estimated net profit of $3,506,492 in the first six months of this year, it was announced yesterday by A.P. Giannini, chairman of the board, in the second semi-annual statement issued by the corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Representatives of ocean-going seamen and ship operators opened a conference today under joint auspices of the Maritime Commission and Department of Labor to determine uniform war bonuses for traveling into danger zones, and to define such zones of excessive risk.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey said tonight that "if years stretch into decades without considerable progress in extending the good life among all of our citizens, I fear the less fortunate Americans might grow weary of the progress of democracy and attempt to improve their lot by more violent means."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Roosevelt called on all citizens today to enlist in a campaign against accidents. He asked the National Safety Council to lead an intensified campaign against wastage of life and property.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Italian Superpower Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for an order permitting it to reacquire some of its outstanding securities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Spokesmen for the British Government express the view that the chances of further Japanese aggression in the Far East, which President Roosevelt described as even, would be materially reduced if Britain and the United States+ could take upon themselves openly to draw the line where their military forces would come into play.

Negotiations were under way last night in Washington for a settlement of the strike of Gimbel Brothers department store employes that began yesterday morning. A mass picket line thrown around the store at Thirty-third Street and Sixth Avenue to mark the beginning of the walkout resulted in the arrest of nine pickets, including several officers of the United Department Store Employes Union, C.I.O.

Pacific Gas and Electric Reports were current in Wall Street yesterday that the Pacific Gas and Electric Company has revived plans looking toward the refunding of perhaps all or at least a major part of its $91,000,000 4 per cent bonds due in 1964, callable at 110.

First pipeline A few years ago Hollywood turned out a picture called "High, Wide and Handsome." It related, in addition to the romantic misunderstandings and reconciliations of its protagonists, the epic of constructing an early oil pipeline.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York started last night the census of all foreign-owned property subject to the jurisdiction of the United States by sending form letters and circulars to all banks in this district and to several thousand corporations and individuals on its mailing list.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 19 -- Unstinted support of President Roosevelt's foreign policy, the national defense program and all-out aid to England, Russia and China in the war coupled with, determination to preserve labor's rights in this country, including the right to strike were called for in addresses made today at the opening session of the seventy-eighth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Labor.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 19 -- There is no doubt that the influence of the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Writers Association does not extend to weather control. The group that reached here last night with hopes of starting out bright and early this morning for a bay fishing expedition were convinced of it about 5 A.M., if they hadn't reached that conclusion in other years.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Mayor Frank Hague, who recently "relinquished" his leadership of the Democratic party in New Jersey to Governor Charles Edison following the Governor's successful sponsorship of a legislative program for the readjustment of delinquent railroad taxes, disclosed today that he would not challenge the Governor on the tax issue on the floor of the Democratic State Convention next month.

Again taking its cue from the many uncertainties in the international picture and influenced also by the desire of traders to await a fuller pronouncement on the steps agreed upon at the historic Roosevelt-Churchill rendezvous at sea, the stock market's pace slowed yesterday to a walk.

Three Negro laborers accused of having sold spurious tickets to last Sunday's excursion in which three Negro women were trampled to death in a riot at the 132d Street Hudson River pier, were arrested yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- A special communique from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters announced this morning that exemplary collaboration of German, Rumanian, Hungarian and Italian forces had brought "the entire area west of the Dnieper in our hands."

The Charles H. Goddard residence on Linford Road, Russell Gardens, Great Neck, L.I., has been purchased by Mrs. L.R. Kennedy, who last month sold her home on Schenck Avenue in the Wyngate section of Great Neck, according to Edgar Storms Jr., Inc., brokers.

For almost a year and a half Will Geer wore the tattered attire of Jeeter Lester and was obliged to eat turnips in "Tobacco Road." All this is now a memory to Mr. Geer. In his next appearance the actor will be required to dress in the conventional manner and positively eschew turnips in "Great Whitewash," in which he will occupy one of the featured roles.

This is a war that moves from one point of the compass to the other like a black, untethered wind. All the belligerent and non-belligerent Powers, have tried to limit it, and their efforts have been defeated by the very nature of the struggle.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 -- The Yankees were thanking their stars tonight that their margin over their nearest competitor in the American League race is still a matter of sixteen games. For the launching of their final swing around the Western loop today began with anything but a grand flourish.

Delay in the distribution of the estate of the late Mrs. Virginia H. C. Heckscher, widow of August Heckscher, philanthropist, was foreshadowed yesterday in Surrogate's Court when Julian W. Curtiss of Greenwich, Conn., brother of Mrs. Heckscher's first husband, Edwin B. Curtiss, offered for probate a will by which his brother would have inherited her entire estate.

VICHY, France, Aug. 19 -- In accepting the oath of members of the French Council of State at Royat today Marshal Henri Philippe Petain declared that the time had come for all Frenchmen to make their choice.

Although grateful for the respite from German bombing, England is well aware that hard times are ahead and has been using the comparative lull to prepare for the next big assault, passengers arriving here yesterday aboard the Dixie Clipper reported.

A new issue of $681,354 of bonds for various purposes was awarded yesterday by the city of Toledo, Ohio, to a banking group composed of Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc.; Braun, Bosworth Co.; Ryan, Sutherland Co. and E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.

ROME, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- British planes attacked Catania, Sicily, early yesterday but caused no damage or casualties, the Italian High Command said today. The communique said that twenty-five persons were killed and thirty-seven wounded during raids on Catania on Friday and Saturday.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Judge Edwin T. Dickerson of the Baltimore Supreme Court took under advisement today a motion to enjoin stockholders of the International Utilities Corporation from holding an extraordinary meeting "to effect a change in the management of the corporation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The United States is still awaiting a complete and satisfactory explanation of Japan's refusal to permit the departure of more than 100 Americans from Japan on the liner President Coolidge, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.

The story of how two young soldiers from Brooklyn discovered that going A.W.O.L. can be something like getting on a nonstop merry-go-round was disclosed yesterday in Federal court. The khaki-clad young men, each 24 years old, had enlisted separately in the National Guard and been assigned to Fort Ethan Allen, Vermont.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- The Congressional Committee Investigating Anti-Argentine Activities today announced discovery of a list of approximately 3,000 persons characterized as unfriendly to Germany, and it was believed the list had been compiled by the German Gestapo.
ROYAT, France, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of Marshall Henri Philippe Petain's address to the French Council of State today:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain."

BERLIN, Wednesday, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The vital Black Sea port of Odessa stood under siege today, latest dispatches from the front reporting the massed big guns of the German Southern Army assaulting encircled Russian troops there while the Luftwaffe ranged far over the sea approaches and the Dnieper River to prevent escapes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Changing over of hedges from September wheat into the distant deliveries was a feature of the trading today on the Board of Trade. Scattered liquidation of holders of the September put that month 4 cents a bushel under the December early, the widest discount of the season, but late in the session there was support from mill interests, presumably against sales of flour and the differences narrowed again.

Production of crude petroleum in the United States last week averaged 3,953,300 barrels daily, a new high record and an increase of 41,350 barrels over the 3,911,950 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The production was 13,300 barrels in excess of the 3,940,000 daily calculated for August by the Bureau of Mines.

Tami Mauriello and Gus Lesnevich yesterday signed a contract at the New York State Athletic Commission offices for their fifteen-round light-heavyweight championship fight at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday. They posted forfeits of $2,500 each and were pronounced physically fit by Dr. William H. Walker.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood, former metropolitan champion, shot a 79, five over women's par, to take the low gross prize at the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament over the Hudson River Country Club course today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation, voiced the belief here today that price control was an "essential element" In the defense program, but he declared it was "silly" to think "we can control prices without controlling wages."

The elements, not the Pirates gave the Dodgers trouble yesterday. Squeezing in the two scheduled games at Ebbets Field proved more of a problem than the actual winning of them, but the combination of rain and darkness notwithstanding, the double victory finally was accomplished.

Dr. Goeobels and Virginio Gayda, joint holders of the world's record for the running broad jump to conclusions, will doubtless leap to a new finding on the basis of yesterday's announcement by the War Department that, unless this country "becomes more seriously involved in the international situation," substantial numbers of selectees and National Guardsmen will be sent home before Christmas.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 19 -- Theodore Marburg entertained at luncheon at Bideawhile today before a round-table discussion on "A Federation of the English-Speaking Peoples."

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The longest-priced horse in the Point Judith purse, the Tall Trees Stable's Ball Player, scored by twenty-one lengths over A.S. Hewitt's Karnak today in the mile-and-seventy-yard test at Narragansett Park.

Buyer Registrations Off Out-of-town buyers in the New York market during the week ended yesterday numbered 856 as against 925 in the previous week and 843 in the like period of 1940, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The supply problem in the textile industry has been further complicated by brisk consumer buying in recent weeks, which is depleting stocks much more rapidly than either manufacturers or stores had expected. This is particularly true of sheets and towels, with the result that mills are now practically sold up for the balance of the year and no spot goods are available.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The International Rubber Regulation Committee fixed today the export quota for the final three months of 1941 at 120 per cent of basic tonnages.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Running in a driving shower, which had broken thirty minutes before the race and made the track sloppy, Fenelon today captured the fourteenth Whitney Stakes before 9,309 persons who wagered $434,333 on an eight-race program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Roosevelt asked today immediate resumption of work at the Kearny, N.J., yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Corporation, declaring that renewed construction on $493,000,000 worth of naval and merchant ships was much more important to national defense than the union "maintenance of membership" clause at issue between the company and the C.I.O.'s Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Red Sox lost a pitchers' duel, 3 to 2, and then won a slugfest, 10 to 7, in dividing a double-header with the Browns today in games decided by ninth-inning rallies.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The outcome of adjourned games completed in a special session and fourth round results have brought about several changes in the standing of players competing for the New York State chess championship on the Colgate University campus.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Play in the national doubles tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club was at a standstill today because of rain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Contracts totaling $10,693,052 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area that received awards were as follows:

The cotton market yesterday broke away from its recent listlessness and, under the stimulus of buying from New Orleans and the trade, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced, to close at net gains of 10 to 13 points. Somewhat unfavorable weather reports from the growing belt and further complaints of weevil activity were factors in the better tone in the market.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Willie Crump's Three Percent ran to a smashing victory in the Bonnie Scotland Purse at Washington Park today, as the favored Woolford Farm's Silvestra finished seventh in the eight-horse race.

While the gasoline industry remained in a state of befuddlement throughout the East on the rationing question yesterday, the New Jersey State Motor Vehicle Department took steps to deter fuel-consuming techniques of driving such as "jack rabbit" starting, sudden acceleration and excessive speeding.

TOKYO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Japanese Government announced today that three types of American movies -- gang thrillers, ultra-torrid romances and those depicting "wasteful extravagance" -- would be barred after Sept. 1.
BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- Whether neutral Sweden will maintain her traditional leadership of the Scandinavian countries is discussed in a German press report and an official statement here.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd assured a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden last night that President Roosevelt was not trying to push this nation into war, but declared that his duty was to preserve American democracy at all costs, and that slavery was infinitely worse than war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- With further increases in the machinery, aircraft, shipbuilding and lumber industries offsetting reductions in activity in automobile factories and steel mills, industrial activity in July and the first half of August was maintained at the high level reached in June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

IT happened on Sunday, but the stout Mr. Bill Brandt of the National League Service Bureau was still babbling about it yesterday. Mr. Brandt is a native of Philadelphia and, in all the recesses of his secret soul, a great rooter for the Phillies. And the Phillies won a double-header on Sunday!

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Senator Mead of New York declared recently in the Senate that public support for the defense program was impaired by "the rising tide of criticism of the British war effort," and many officials here are hopeful that the Roosevelt-Churchill conversations may lead to elimination of certain British practices which, they feel, have damaged Britain's cause in this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The War Department disclosed today that it will release selectees and National Guardsmen from active duty after fourteen to eighteen months of service, with eighteen months the probable average, unless the world situation becomes more serious.
BUFFALO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Frank J. Wilson, chief of the United States Secret Service, called today for "teamwork" among law enforcement officers to protect "the liberty of the individual citizen."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- American planes are being rushed across the South Atlantic to strengthen British Middle East forces in anticipation of a German "atonement" campaign in the Southern Black Sea area this Winter, military authorities said tonight.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Jimmy Bloodworth belted one of Southpaw Al Milnar's pitches over League Park's short right field wall in the twelfth inning today to give Washington an 8-to-6 triumph over the slump-ridden Indians, who have droped six in a row.
Regardless of the outcome of the great campaign in Russia, operations in the Middle Eastern theatre of war may be expected to assume a more active character this Fall.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Premier Joseph Stalin has informed the British and United States Ambassadors of his eagerness for an early Moscow conference, which the Soviet press said today would bring nearer "the complete and final annihilation of Hitlerism."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The French should never, when they try to define their duty, forget what fate would befall them in the event of a German victory. I hope I may be allowed to show them a picture of this "New Order" to which they have been asked to adhere.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The Royal Air Force was reported officially today to have destroyed twelve German, fighter planes and scored bomb hits on "many German ships in wide-ranging offensive operations yesterday over occupied territory and the Channel."

With orders for plastic dolls running two and a half times what they were a year ago at this time, peak doll production is being reached now instead of October, leading manufacturers here reported yesterday. Retailers have sought to protect themselves against delivery difficulties and possible shortages for the coming Christmas season.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The marriage of Miss Anne Mumford Pratt, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pratt of the Pratt estate, here, and New York, to Edmund Stairs Twining Jr. of Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Twining of New York and Southampton, L.I., took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown at Locust Valley.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- If Britain loses the war we can expect short, sudden air attacks on our cities and we must be prepared, Mayor La Guardia of New York, National Director of Civilian Defense, warned leaders of the country's fire-fighting forces in convention here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A medical aid program for Russia involving the raising in this country of $1,000,000 for the purchase of supplies and surgical instruments "most urgently needed in the Soviet Union to aid its fight against the Nazis," was announced today by Edward C. Carter of New York, secretary general of the Institute of Pacific Relations and chairman of the disbursements committee, United China Relief, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 19 -- Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the United States Supreme Court declared here tonight that although the American people "are unequivocally and unalterably opposed" to communism, the democracies should support Russia in its campaign with Germany because the philosophy of nazism is the world's "overshadowing menace."

A client of Frederick Zane, attorney, has purchased from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, the twelve-story loft building at 121-23 East Twenty-fourth Street on a plot 50 by 98.9, feet, in a transaction arranged by Adams Co., Inc., brokers.
FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 19 -- A survey of enlisted personnel in the Forty-fourth Division revealed today that 15 per cent were above the Army's new age limit of 28 years.

Final plans have been completed in a nation-wide program for the sale of defense savings stamps in the country's 1,800,000 retail stores, whose owners have been enlisted in a "mass merchandising effort for the duration," it was announced yesterday by Major Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of a special retailers advisory committee appointed by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

A former member of a Bronx draft board went on trial before Judge John Bright in Federal court yesterday with a building contractor and the latter's son, charged with conspiring to evade the draft laws. According to Myles J. Lane, Assistant United States Attorney, the object of the alleged conspiracy was to keep Francis M. O'Connell, the son, out of the military service.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 20 -- To "meet the challenge of the situation," the Japanese Cabinet decided yesterday to put the entire shipping industry, including ship crews and shipbuilding, under State control.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Assets and deposits of national banks in the United States and its possesions on June 30 reached record figures, according to a report made today by Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency.

Many residential sections of the city shared in the apartment rental activity reported yesterday by brokers handling this type of business. Among the areas represented were the Park Avenue section, Greenwich Village, the East and West Sides of the Midtown sections and Jaokson Heights, Queens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Paramount signed Ben Ames Williams today to write a photoplay for Stirling Hayden dealing with the sailor-fishermen of Cape Cod. Hayden, whom the studio launched last year in "Virginia," and who has just completed "Bahama Passage" with Madeleine Carroli, is a New Englander and grew up with sailing ships, having served as master of a wind jammer.

Demand for most classes of locally dressed meat yesterday was fair to good. The market on steer hinds and ribs was steady to strong. Fresh pork cuts were strong, with loins, skinned shoulders and regular picnics $1 higher. Lamb carcasses sold mostly $1 up, and cow beef prices were up 25-50c.

Paramount's "World Premiere," which will open at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. John Barrymore heads the cast of the comedy, which includes Frances Farmer, Virginia Dale, Ricardo Cortez, Eugene Pallette, Sig Rumann and Fritz Feld in its supporting cast....

Sterling North, as chairman of he committee for the third awarding of the Limited Edition Club's Gold Medal, is asking; fifty literary critics throughout the country to make nominations for the book published in 1939, 1940 and thus war in 1941 "that most nearly attains the stature of a classic."

The number of persons currently owning shares of stock in American companies has reached the highest figure on record, and further such records are expected by the end of the year. This is indicated by a survey of the capital stock distribution of enterprises whose shares constitute 40 per cent of the total number of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
NEW YORK Vinton Chapin has returned from Dublin, where he is secretary of the United States Legation, and has joined Mrs. Chapin at the Plaza. Later they will go to their Summer home in Dublin, N.H.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Figures issued by the Admiralty today show that in the five weeks that ended Aug. 15 a total of 616,000 tons of enemy shipping -- the best figure yet reported -- was destroyed. The figure includes fifty-one ships, totaling 200,000 tons, credited to the Russians.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Bronzed by the sun and sea breezes enjoyed during his historic trip for conferences with President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrived back in London today amid vociferous cheers from an admiring populace.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The co-medalists -- Mrs. Russell Mann of Omaha and Miss Eleanor Dudley of Chicago -- advanced into the second round of the women's Western amateur golf championship today with easy triumphs, while the favorite, Miss Marion Miley of Lousville, survived a hard struggle in her first-round match.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated, Aug. 18:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 20 -- The German Army continued to press forward yesterday, making especially strong thrusts in the directions of Kingisepp and Novgorod, in the north; Gomel, in the center, and Odessa, at the southern extremity of the enormous front.

The Maritime Commission's tanker construction program has been augmented by fifteen high-speed oil carriers aggregating 240,000 deadweight tons, according to figures issued yesterday by the commission in its periodical progress report, covering contracts and building up to the first of August.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

Family heirlooms, which in peaceful years enhanced the mansions of London's Mayfair, are coming to the United States in increasing volume to help build up the dollar credits needed for expenses not covered by the lease-lend act, customs brokers and local dealers in antiques said yesterday.

VICHY, France, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Sharp outbreaks of fighting on land and sea between British and French forces in a tightening of Great Britain's "hunger blockade" around French Somaliland were reported tonight, bringing relations between the two former allies to another state of acute tension.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 21 (Reuter) -- A dramatic appeal was made to citizens of the Leningrad region early today by Marshal Klementy Voroshiloff, commander of the Soviet armies in the north. The appeal said, in part:

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Bryan M. Grant Jr. and Russell Bobbitt of Atlanta wearily plodded their way off the clubhouse turf of the Longwood Cricket Club at 7 o'clock this evening, the victors in the longest match within memory in a national doubles tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Direct negotiations arranged by President Roosevelt between officials of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Corporation and the C.I.O.'s Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers broke down again today, and further Presidential intervention was requested to end the thirteen-day-old strike at the company's Kearny (N.J.) yard.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Aug. 21 -- An indication of how hard-pressed are Marshal Semyon Budenny's Soviet forces in the Dnieper River elbow region was contained in an unconfirmed report from Bucharest, Rumania, early this morning that Russian sappers had blown up the great Dnieper dam near Dniepropetrovsk, releasing millions of tons of muddy, swirling water to flood the lowlands below to the delta.

Foreign traders here yesterday were disturbed by reports from Washington that England is asking a further curb on our exports to Latin America on the grounds that many raw materials, as well as the productive capacity tied up on export orders, are needed to help Britain in her war effort.

The President quoted Abraham Lincoln at Tuesday's press conference. "The military situation is far from bright," the Civil War President said to Mrs. Livermore of Chicago in 1862. "The fact is the people * * have got the idea into their heads that we are going to get out of this fix somehow by strategy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A general tax affecting all business and commodities, such as a manufacturers' excise tax, and a gross income tax collectible at the source from all wages, dividends and other personal income payments, was suggested to the Senate Finance Committee today by Laurence A. Tanzer, chairman of the committee on taxation of the Merchants Association of New York.
NEW YORK Lady Essendon, who had been staying at Pine Woods Camp, Buzzards Bay, Mass., is at the Ritz Tower.

For nearly twenty minutes last night, hundreds of New Yorkers dabbed at their faces and brushed their clothes, or else huddled under marquees, while fine, gritty dust particles formed a thin layer on Manhattan streets from the Battery to Columbus Circle.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association, in a statement to members under the title "Government Takes a Hand More and More in Advertising Matters," criticized yesterday "antagonism" of the government toward advertising, and warned of a desire on the part of officials and agencies for government control.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, who came to Ottawa today on his way to England, paid a warm tribute to American labor when he received the Canadian, press at the office of the British High Commissioner, Malcolm MacDonald.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- George D. Widener injected one of his homebreds into the 2-year-old situation when Anytime captured the $6,725 Albany Handicap today before 11,095 persons who completely overlooked the son of Reign Count in the betting.
ROME, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Italian High Command today issued this communique:
