VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The International Typographical Union should do "everything in its power to prevent the Congress for Industrial Organization from organizing within our jurisdiction," Jack Gill of Indianapolis, Ind., vice president, told the eighy-fifth annual convention of the I.T.U. here today.

MANILA, Aug. 20 -- The outline for a three-power anti-Axis offensive to match the military preparations undertaken in Asia was told here today by Henry F. Grady, special representative of the Federal Loan Agency, when he arrived by Clipper plane on a fact-finding tour of the Far East.

A new issue of $55,000,000 of New York City revenue bills was sold yesterday by allotment by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to a group of twenty-five banks and trust companies. All the bills will be dated Aug. 22 and will bear interest at the annual rate of onefourth of 1 per cent.

Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, told an America First Committee rally at Carnegie Hall last night that if America really committed itself to the destruction of Nazi tyranny, as pledged by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, it meant war for us.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The United States acted today to produce more aluminum than the rest of the world combined, with an annual output of 1,500,000,000 pounds. Also, the government announced, the Aluminum Company of America will cut its prices on ingot and fabricated aluminum by two cents a pound.

MADRID, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- The German Propaganda Minister, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, in an interview published today by the newspaper Informaciones warned South American countries that they would "become United States colonies" unless they halt American intervention.

Crowded far beyond normal capacity with refugees willing to endure any conditions to escape Nazidominated Europe, the 6,200-ton Spanish liner Ciudad de Sevilla arrived here yesterday amid a storm of complaints from her passengers.

The six-story apartment house at 1484 St. Nicholas Avenue has been sold by Chelsea Investors, a client of Goodman Mabel, to a purchaser represented by Abraham Schackne, according to Nehring Bros., Inc., who arranged the transaction.

How scientists, educators, religious leaders, writers and artist can best help to strengthen democracy to meet the threat of totalitarianism will be discussed at the second annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion, which will be held Sept. 8-12 at Columbia University.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Joe Hiestand, the Hillsboro, Ohio, farmer to whom trapshooting titles have been elusive the last two years, hopped back to the peak today by capturing the Class AA clay-target championship at the forty-second Grand American in one of the strongest fields ever to compete.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- Both the German march to the Dnieper and Anglo-American-Soviet collaboration are having political repercussions in the entire Near East.

Based on the assumption of a 50 per cent cut in burlap supply, the cotton textile industry will be called upon in the next twelve months to turn out 250,000,000 yards of bag fabrics in addition to the current production, it developed yesterday at a meeting of an industry committee with government officials.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Newspaper warnings that Britain's newly disclosed arrangements for possible trade with Japan might be considered appeasement brought hurried insistence from authoritative quarters tonight that the government was not retreating in the least from its stand against aggression in the Far East.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- The South Jersey Transit Authority announced today that it would seek a loan of $2,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to carry out an elaborate plan to link Philadelphia with South Jersey communities through high speed electric lines.

Eight additional bodies were found yesterday in the East River near Pier 27, Brooklyn, bringing to thirteen the known dead in the fire that destroyed the pier last Monday and wrecked the New York Cuba Main Line freighter Panuco, which was discharging cargo there.

We have reached a point in the defense program where we face the paradox of unemployment and depression growing out of the fact that defense priorities are depriving nondefense industries of the raw materials essential for their existence. This is true in the case of such materials as aluminum, copper, iron, steel, zinc, brass, nickel, tin, rubber, silk and cork.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Newark Bears took a giant stride toward the International League championship tonight, whipping the second-place Montreal Royals in both ends of a double-header, 2 -- 1 and 5 -- 3, for a clean sweep of a four-game series, and increasing their lead to eight games with twenty-two remaining to be played.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- German planes bombed British shipping off the Faeroe Islands and many other scattered targets last night, the High Command reported today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 21 -- Americans who are now waiting to see what further action the United States Government will take to obtain transportation facilities for their return home, and who in addition have been worrying about funds for themselves and their families in the United States in view of the freezing of their assets under American regulations, received cheering news yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 20 -- Witayor La Guardia of New York leadng in warnings of a coming new depression in this country as an aftermath of the war, speakers before the convention of the State Federation of Labor here today called for timely and adequate prepiration to meet the crisis.

JERSEY CIT, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Rochester climbed back into fourth place in the International League tonight by taking both ends of a double-header by the same score, 1 -- 0, from Jersey City, which dropped to fifth place. Max Surkont, 19-year-old right-hander, hurled a no-hitter in the seven-inning twilight game, while Hank Gornicki batted and pitched the Red Wings to victory under the lights.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at the Summer City Hall in Queens the appointment of Police Lieutenant Samuel J. Battle as a member of the Parole Commission, to fill the vacancy caused by the recent death of Lou Gehrig, famous first baseman for the New York Yankees.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Contracts totaling $57,818,252 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 20 -- In the most ambitious field problem yet undertaken by the 207th Coast Artillery (anti-air-craft) Regiment, New York's old Seventh, 1,400 troops completed today an overnight command post exercise.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The man at the filling station on the edge of this town said that the racing was just as good as ever. Everything was going on in the Saratoga tradition. Nice horses, nice races, nice people.

Sherburne (N.Y.) School District Roosevelt Weigold, Inc., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $120,000 of bonds of Central School District No. 1. This district comprises the town of Sherburne, North Norwich, New Berlin, Smyrna, Plymouth and Columbus in Chenango County, N.Y., and the towns of Hamilton and Brookfield in Madison County.

BERLIN, Thursday, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- A drive of "total annihilation" against the great Russian Army in the Ukraine has smashed twentyfive Soviet divisions in the Gomel area north of Kiev and increased Russian losses to about 5,000,000 men in sixty days of struggle, according to a midnight Nazi announcement.

TRENTON, Aug. 20 -- Eight Senators, three Assemlymen and several former legislators now occupying high positions were named at a public hearing today as having represented private property owners in sales to the New Jersey Highway Department.

The failure of statesmen of this and other nations "to recognize the cardinal principles of morality and justice in disclosing their war and peace aims" was criticized yesterday in a resolution adopted at the closing session of the eighty-sixth annual convention of the Catholic Central Verein of America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, said at a press conference today that the United States would be willing to give financial assistance to Russia for purchases of war supplies here, should the Soviets ask it.

Pier 27 was in flames along its whole 800 foot length. The Panuco was already a furnace, hidden in its own smoke and that from the dock. The burning vessel had to be towed from its berth where it threatened the neighboring waterfront. Two tugs chugged up.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Ruth Torgerson of Lakeville set such, a burning pace in the Long Island women's one-day golf tourney at the North Hempstead Club today that nobody else in the small field of twenty-five even came within gunshot reach of her.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer and Elmer Riddle gave masterful pitching performances today to lead the Reds to twin victories over the Phils. Vander Meer hurled a threehitter to win the first, 2 -- 0, while Riddle, gaining his fourteenth triumph, scattered six blows for a 3-0 triumph.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- A "healthy mixture" between the collective farming and the individual tilling of a plot of land by members of a collective farm -- such seems to be the recipe worked out for the Reich agrarian policy in occupied Russian territory.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- The German Army is trying to consolidate new advances and straighten out its line, which now roughly follows the valleys of the Dnieper, Dvina and Lovat Rivers between the Black Sea and Lake Ilmen and cuts northwestward toward the Baltic from the vicinity of Novgorod, on the shores of Lake Ilmen, to the Kingisepp region.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The gasoline and oil shortage on the Eastern Seaboard has already reached a stage described as "perilous" today by Ralph K. Davies, acting petroleum coordinator.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 20 -- Official circles here reflect an air of hopefulness that negotiations with Washington on oil and other questions will soon result in clearing the slate between Mexico and the United States. It is hoped also that there will be a resumption of diplomatic relations with Britain.

Dorris Clarke, 88-10 Whitney Avenue, a 35-year-old career social worker employed as a probation officer of the magistrates courts and liaison officer of the Wayward Minors Court, was named yesterday among nine women to receive the first Florence E. Alien Scholarships to the New York University School of Law.

Shorter skirts for American women may become the vogue in order to conserve fabrics in the emergency facing the textile and women's apparel trades, according to plans sponsored yesterday by the National Women's Undergarment Manufacturers Association at a meeting at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

Trial committees of the Board of Higher Education have recommended "summary dismissal" of two more City College faculty members found guilty of "conduct unbecoming a teacher," it was announced yesterday. The teachers are Dr. Walter Scott Neff, instructor in psychology, and Seymour A. Copstein, tutor in English.
A group of twenty-one American teachers and missionaries arrived here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Paula, ending a 20,000-mile journey from Syria that took three months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Sales of super markets -- grocery stores with annual sales of $100,000 or more -- amounted to $2,046,237,000 in 1939, or 26.5 per cent of the sales of all grocery stores, although the super markets themselves numbered but 2.7 per cent of the total, according to a report on super markets and self-service food stores issued today by the Bureau of the Census.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Hogs were steady to 10 cents a hundred pounds higher today reflecting an upward trend in the dressed trade, while cattle closed mostly weak to 25 cents lower. Spring lambs and sheep were strong to 25 cents higher.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The Rev. Dr. John Gideon Traver, educator and, Lutheran pastor for over a half century, died in Bassett Hospital here today.

Union officials announced last night that negotiations looking toward a settlement of the strike of Gimbel Brothers department store employes would be resumed at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Pickets representing the United Department Store Employes of Greater New York, C.I.O., marched outside the store all day yesterday, but all departments remained open for business.

George Sampson has completed his "long day's task" of rewriting and "digesting" the fourteen-volume "Cambridge History of English Literature" and the result, a single, compact volume of 1,094 pages and About 500,000 words, will be published by Macmillan Sept. 23 as "The Concise Cambridge History of English Literature."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Despite two home runs by Ted Williams, the leading hitter in the major leagues, the Red Sox lost a double-header to the Browns today, 11-9, and 4-3, the second game going ten innings.

The Cubs found it so simple to score against the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday that they even tallied one run on a foul fly to the catcher. And since they also were thoughtful enough to massage four New York pitchers for sixteen assorted hits, they had little trouble in making off with a 9-4 victory.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Contracts of $164,451 for construction of a connection between the Cross-County and Bronx River Parkways at the Fleetwood viaduct and for laying a center island on the southern end of the Saw Mill River Parkway were awarded today by the Westchester County Board of Acquisition and Contracts.

In the busiest day in almost two weeks, one which saw a return of buyers, the stock market righted itself yesterday as it threw off its indecision of the previous session. There was a return to the firmer tone manifested as the week started, and the improvement was steady throughout the day until the late afternoon, when a lull set in.

Despite higher taxes and operating costs, E.H. Little, president of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company announced a substantial gain in earnings in the semi-annual report mailed to stockholders today. The net profit for the first half of this year amounted to $2,635,051, equal after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.21 a share on 1,999,970 shares o' no-par common stock including 37,163 shares held in the treasury.
An Orator Unafraid An Orator with a good speaking voice was addressing a crowd in the street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Production of passenger automobiles between now and December probably will be cut about 20 per cent below the 1940 levels, William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, said today.

In an effort to prevent losing to newspapers some of their accounts which are affected by priorities and material shortages and cannot plan far ahead, several magazines this week broke a long-standing rule and agreed to accept cancellations of ads not actually on the press, if conditions demand it.
BUFFALO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Police Chief Charles W. Dullea of San Francisco said today that the automobile was becoming "a problem of such magnitude that almost defies solution."

Groupings and starting times were announced yesterday by Joseph C. Dey, executive secretary of the United States Golf Association, for the national amateur championship which starts Monday at the Omaha Field Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The precision pitching of the White Sox carried the second-place Chicagoans to their third straight shutout, one shy of the league record, and their ninth consecutive victory today as Johnny Rigney blanked the Athletics, 9 to 0, on three scattered singles.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Young men who file applications, seeking appointment as flying cadets, must pass a rigid physical examination. The most strenuous part of this examination has to do with the eyes. Every candidate must possess vision of 20/20 bilateral. This, in effect, means that one must be able to read a standardsized letter meant to be read at 20 feet at 20 feet -- the same for each eye.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 19:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- After a call upon Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the State Department today, the French Ambassador, Gaston Henry-Haye, declared that he had given assurances that nothing in the recent actions of the French Government at Vichy indicated military collaboration with Germany or surrender of the French fleet.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- The surging Cardinals took both ends of a double-header from the Braves today but added Terry Moore to their long hospital list when the Redbird center fielder was felled by a Boston pitch in the opening game.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Douglas Ford of Green Valley, the Westchester junior champion, and Joseph Mendes, champion of the home club, tied for the medal in the annual metropolitan junior golf championship as fifty-seven starters attempted to qualify on the narrow fairways of the Bonnie Briar Country Club course today.

Looking sheepish and worried, two youthful National Guardsmen who had hitch-hiked away from their posts at Fort Ethan Allen, Vt., for a visit to their homes in Brooklyn, pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges of having transported a stolen automobile across interstate boundaries.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Fighter-escorted Blenheim bombers raided an enemy airdrome near Alkmaar, the Netherlands, and attacked a number of German patrol vessels near the Frisian Islands yesterday, while fighters scouted the Channel and Northern France, the Air Ministry reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 -- Theodore Dreiser's "Sister Carrie," for several years regarded as Hollywood's most controversial story property has been revived by RKO and will go before the cameras this Fall with Ruth Warrick in the title role.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Lowell Mellett, administrative aide to President Roosevelt, believes that the American press associations and American radio can continue to render a great service to this nation only if "we do nothing to destroy the confidence they have created."

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- The German Armies in the Ukraine concentrated the main force of their drive yesterday on the "few" bridgeheads still held by the Russians on the west bank of the Dnieper River, it was announced here today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 20 -- Reports from Europe that the German Ambassador to Argentina, Edmund von Thermann, was about to be recalled received credence here because his situation became very difficult after revelations by the Chamber of Deputies investigating committee of questionable activities by his embassy.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Marshal Voroskiioff, in his appeal for civilian defense of Leningrad, said:
BERLIN, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The German High Command communique today said:
LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

Earnings of the automobile industry were slightly higher in the first half of this year than in the same period of last year despite Federal taxes and contingency provisions nearly four times as large, according to a compilation of eleven producers showing combined net profits of $149,385,483, against $145,357,431 in the same period of 1940, a gain of less than 3 per cent.

Out of the garbage pail came the inspiration for the 2-week-old AntiWaste Center, Inc., which was described yesterday as an important organization "in the defense setup" by Major Edward G. Riekert, executive director of the Office of Civilian Defense, Second Corps Area.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congress has finally enacted legislation to hold draftees eighteen months longer in the armed forces of the United States. In view of the grave danger that threatens the country, it is well that this has been done. A democracy not only confers benefits upon its citizens, it imposes responsibilities also.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- A quarrel between the A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions closed down all transportation facilities of the municipally-owned Detroit street railways today, despite Mayor Edward J. Jeffries' three-point proposal for ending the dispute.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- On the premise that a soldier who understands the cause for which he fights is likely to be more reliable than the soldier who does not, British military officials have decided to establish an Army Bureau of Current Affairs to enable officers tell their men why they are fighting and to keep them abreast of world events.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Official optimism in Washington and London over Russia's chance in the struggle with Germany is based on three assurances given to President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill by Harry L. Hopkins during their Atlantic conference, it was reported reliably tonight.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 20 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies today outlined to the House of Representatives the grounds of his proposed mission to London. The House then went into secret session with the Senate.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The "war" between the Reds and Blues had a climax today in a battle between two battalions on this third day of the annual cadet field exercises held in the vicinity of Washingtonville.

Coat Output Up Substantially Reports indicate that production in the women's coat industry continues well ahead of that of a year ago. The latest figures of the Recovery Board put label sales in the metropolitan area for the first half of this month at 26 per cent above a year ago, and 15 per cent ahead of 1939.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Roosevelt will leave tomorrow for Hyde Park, where on Saturday he will greet the Duke of Kent, youngest brother of King George VI of England.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The State Funding Commission has authorized the School District of Bergenfield to issue $704,000 in 3 1/2 per cent refunding bonds to be exchanged for $643,000 of old obligations bearing rates from 4 1/2 to 6 per cent.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The fourth-place Indians kept spiraling downward today, losing their seventh straight game as the Senators topped them, 6 to 3.

Four new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. "The Little Foxes." Samuel Goldwyn's screen version of the Lillian Hellman drama, will have its world premiere at the Radio City Music Hall. Directed by William Wyler and prepared for the screen by Miss Heilman, the picture stars Bette Davis and includes Herbert, Marshall, Teresa Wright Patricia Collinge, Richard Carlson, Dan Duryea, Carl Benton Reid, Charles Dingle and Jesse Grayson among its supporting players.

SELLERSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 20 -- The United States Gauge Company, where recording instruments required for airplanes, submarines and warships are manufactured, was brought to a standstill today by a walkout of about 1,400 employes in sympathy with a strike called earlier by a hundred workers in the foundry department.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Reviewing construction that has taken place here since last Fall in the expansion of Fort Dix from one of the smallest to the largest military post in the metropolitan area, Lieut. Col. Frederick H. Richardson, construction quartermaster, said today $25,000,000 will have been spent when present building projects are completed.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 20 -- A German bomber, invading Iceland for the first time since American forces occupied this island on July 7, was driven off today by American-built Tomahawk fighters before it could drop any bombs.

The Dnieper River dam, completed in 1932 after day and night work for five years, was looked upon as a symbol of the new Russia in her drive toward industrialization and the wide distribution of electric power.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Arnold Denker of New York brought Reuben Fine's winning streak to a halt today by playing the open champion to a draw in the fifth round of the New York State title chess tournament. Nevertheless, after six rounds of play Fine still tops the list of masters with a score of 41/2-1/2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A report from the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, published today, that the British North Atlantic Air Service was competing with the American transatlanthe service, operated by Pan American Airways, was denied today in a statement issued by the British Information Service.

Theatrical business took an unexpected spurt at the ten Broadway matinees yesterday, reflecting the stronger trade first noticeable over the last week-end. The consensus was that New York was enjoying its usual late Summer influx of tourists and that the Rialto houses were reaping their share of the alien coin.
A decided spurt in apartment renting activity was evidenced yesterday by the large volume of contracts for residential quarters reported by brokers.

Luigi Antonini, chairman, and Alex Rose, secretary of the State committee of the American Labor party and leaders of the right wing group, issued a statement yesterday rejecting a "united front" with the left-wing faction, which withdrew most of its candidates for party nominations but continued a fight for the election of members of the party's county committees in the five counties of the city.

Supplementing the results made known during the progress of the recent U.S. Atlantic tuna tournament at Belmar, N.J., the judges announced many special awards, following the task of re-checking their statistics.

Stimulated by reports from Washington that opposition was growing in Congress to the establishment of ceiling prices on farm products, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday rallied sharply, and closed with net gains of 36 to 37 points, or $1.80 to $1.85 a bale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The National Photographic Dealers Association, at the final business session of its eighth annual convention here today, asked the government to give all relief possible, consistent with defense needs, to manufacturers of photographic accessories and supplies who are now facing partial or complete shut-downs because of lack of basic manufacturing materials.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- A neutral diplomat said today that the important German port of Hamburg, which he left a fortnight ago, had taken "such a smashing from the R.A.F. that its people were consoling themselves by saying 'Well, it's not as bad here as it is in Bremen.' "

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- John M. (100 per cent) Nichols, president of the First National Bank of Englewood, a South Side community, announced today that he was retiring from the banking business for the "duration of the Roosevelt concocted emergency."
The two four-story tenements at 258-62 Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, were sold by Vogel Rotkin, operators, to a client of Wilfred S. Stachenfeld, attorney, through L. V. Hoffman Co., Inc., brokers.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Several luncheon parties were given today. Mrs. Kimball G. Colby entertained with, a luncheon and bridge at the Meadow Club, followed by a tea at the same clubhouse. Among her guests were Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mrs. Edward van Ingen, Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell, Mrs. Charles Tracy Barney and Miss Candace Stimson.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Frank Stranahan, 18-year-old star from Toledo, Ohio, will battle it out over 36 holes tomorrow for the Great Lakes amateur golf championship.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Many luncheon parties were given today at the Club House Restaurant at the race track. Among those entertaining were Mr. and Mrs. Charles Freeman Shelden Jr., George D. Widener, Mrs. E. du Pont Weir, Henry J. Topping, Mr. and Mrs. William Dineen, Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Lunger and Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. LaMontagne.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- Thousands of Catholics went to the Vatican Grottoes today to pray before the tomb of Pope Pius X, who died twenty-seven years ago. In this connection, the Vatican authorities stated this morning that the cause for the beatification of Pope Pius X was well begun.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The "men without a country" manning the thirty-nine Danish ships acquired by the United States under the Ship Requisition Act, who are said to have become the objects of pressure by the Nazi-controlled government of Denmark, were urged by the Maritime Commission today to "serve the cause of democracy" by continuing to man their vessels.

A syndicate of thirty-eight underwriting houses headed by Dillon, Read Co. will offer today two new issues of securities of the Standard Oil Company of California, aggregating $40,000,000. One, an issue of $25,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent debentures, due on Aug. 1, 1966, will be offered at 102 1/2 and accrued interest.

The Petroleum Marketing Committee for the Eastern seaboard met in closed session at the Texas Company office in the Chrysler Building yesterday to formulate recommendations as to procedure in the gasoline curtailment plan.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a veteran of the so-called "War to Make the World Safe for Democracy," I am somewhat amused at the report of low morale in the training camps.

"I HAVE stopped believing," the French lieutenant told Hans Habe. This was in the town of Verrieres, on a night in June, 1940. For days the defeated French Army had been streaming south along the roads from the Meuse and the Argonne.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey reported yesterday that the combined gross revenues of its subsidiary companies in the twelve months ended on July 31 were $146,301,827, compared with $137,777,182 in the preceding twelve months.

AT SEA WITH THE ATLANTIC FLEET -- The United States Fleet is largely engaged today in operations designed to keep the Atlantic Ocean from becoming another No Man's Land of war. It is the spearhead of the defense program to which the country is attempting to gear unprecedented operations involving its men and machines.

A NORTHERN BRITISH AIRPORT, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- A conference of British Empire Premiers may be held as a sequel to the RooseveltChurchill meeting at sea, it was reported today after the arrival here of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- With Joe DiMaggio out of action, nursing a sprained ankle which he suffered in yesterday's double-header, the Yankees today had occasion to make some first-hand observations on how important Jolting Joe's powerful bludgeon has been to them all year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Allocations and commitments for the defense program topped $51,000,000,000 today. A prospective second lease-lend request may raise the total to more than $55,000,000,000.

Seat Sale Yesterday, reflecting a succession of 400,000-share days, a seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold for $28,000, down $7,000 from the high of the year, which was registered in January and earlier this month.

According to information received from the Far East yesterday, observers there are anxiously watching the progress of Japanese internal politics, well knowing that in the next few weeks lies the possibility of a decision of the question of war or peace in the entire Pacific, Siberia and the tropical jungle.

At a time when the local burlap trade was hoping that Calcutta burlap prices would start to ease off as a result of the establishment of price ceilings on goods here, cables were received yesterday advising of a 30 to 40 point jump in price.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The eighteenth annual world championship Star boat series headed into a deadlock tonight as the defending Wench of Los Angeles scored a brilliant victory and earned a point tie with Myron Lehman's Scout III of Newport Beach, Calif.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final adjustments.

Trading continued fairly active in the locally dressed wholesale meat markets yesterday, with all classes selling steady to higher. Steer hinds and ribs were strong from 50 cents to $1 higher. Cow beef sold mostly 50 cents higher. Bull beef was steady to strong. Pork cuts were uneven, with loins and regular picnics $1 higher.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday was one signed by the Packard Federal Corporation for the entire first floor, comprising 20,000 square feet of space in the building at 211-225 West Sixty-first Street. Daniel W. Blumenthal, trustee for Series N-80 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, is the lessor.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Aug. 20 -- After a lower opening a rally developed on the Boerse, but it was followed by a reaction at the close. The leading issues generally were considerably lower and the reaction was regarded as technical and good resistance was met at the lower levels.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Prices of grains and soy beans were on the upgrade today on a broad wave of general buying which found its incentive in reports that President Roosevelt would sign the bill that would freeze government-owned stocks of cotton and wheat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A demonstration how sound devices are used by some combatant nations to accentuate the normal noises of battle and thus induce a fear psychosis in the opposing forces was part of a preview of Army training films given tonight by the War Department.

Described by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn at the "foremost automobile thief in the country's history," Nicholas Pugliese, 48 years, old, of 450 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, admitted to the prosecutor last night that he had stolen 500 automobiles in Brooklyn in the past five years, most of them being disposed of in foreign countries.

While it was conceded anything might happen in women's fashions, leaders in the dress industry did not hold out much hope yesterday that women's dresses could be further shortened to help alleviate the rayon fabric shortage. A suggestion that at least 10 per cent in fabric yardage could be saved by shorter dresses had been made the day before at a meeting of the National Women's Undergarment Association.
BERLIN, Aug. 21 (AP) -- D.N.B., the official German news agency, quoting German military quarters,

The President's brief message to Congress yesterday incorporates, "for the record," the joint declaration of policy made by him and by Mr. Churchill in the name of their two Governments when they met on the high seas. To the eight points listed in that declaration the President adds two others which he believes were "of necessity" implied and included as part of the original eight:

The American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday a revision of its figures on steel and iron productive capacity on June 30 as a result of an increase of almost 2,000,000 net tons in capacity for steel-ingot production in the first half of the year.

Two months ago today, without warning or ultimatum, the German armies smashed through the Soviet frontiers and started on the mammoth drive that has taken them to the gates of Leningrad and Odessa and devastated a great part of European Russia. Two years ago tomorrow, with loud trumpetings of triumph, Adolf Hitler announced the famous Nazi-Soviet Pact that was to confound the western Powers and guarantee peace to the east.

Taking pictures of youthful "kings" and "queens" is an old story to the city's news photographers. A girl has ridden to royalty on the strength of her cooking or a crown has been placed on the head of a boy marble champion. Their first moments of new-found glory have to be recorded on film as a light touch for posterity.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 22 -- The German Army thrust forward in the central sector yesterday and captured the city of Gomel following fierce fighting, it was admitted this morning in the late communique of the Soviet High Command. Gomel is on the Sozh River, one of the tributaries of the upper Dnieper, and is east of the main course of that river.

VICHY, France, Aug. 21 -- Executions of two alleged Communists, mass arrests and severe sanctions against railway workers were among the drastic measures taken by the French authorities to check the outbreaks of disorders and sabotage reported from Paris in the past few days.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Among the comments with which President Roosevelt's message was received in Congress today were the following:
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Red Sox today ended the White Sox winning streak at nine games and put a stop to a run of thirty-two consecutive shut-out innings by Chicago hurlers. Boston won, 8 to 5.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Cecil Smith's Texas riders gave evidence of the need of more play together before they will be ready for the national open polo championship next month, in dropping an 8-to-4 verdict to Aknusti today on Phipps Field in Old Westbury.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The formation of an interstate defense committee representing Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Massachusetts is essential if adequate arrangements are to be made for the evacuation of civilians from New York City, defense officials of Westchester County and Southern Connecticut said "today after long study of the problem.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- The Grosse Ile naval air training base, which faces Canada across the Detroit River, became today the first naval base in the United States to be turned over to the British Government for the exclusive training of Royal Air Force naval fliers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A reduction of 26.6 per cent in passenger automobile production for August, September, October and November was ordered today by the Office of Production Management and the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supplies.

Twenty-five physically handicapped children from St. Charles Hospital, 211 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, toured Bronx Zoo yesterday in a bus. The children, 4 to 14 years old, were guests of Allyn R. Jennings, director of the Zoo. They were supervised by five Sisters of the Daughters of Wisdom.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Scott E. Leslie, a handwriting expert who helped terminate a number of criminal careers and enterprises, was killed here today and his wife, Katherine, was injured critically when their automobile collided head-on with a New Jersey State Highway Department truck.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 16 totaled 890,374 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,825 cars or 1.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 147,324 cars or 19.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 220,581 cars or 32.9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. James M. Robbins had an 83 for the best gross in the weekly one-day tournament of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today at the Round Hill Club. The consistent Mount Kisco performer was one of nine among the thirty who turned in cards of 90 or better.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Ten past State commanders of the Veterans of Foreign Wars retired behind locked doors tonight to judge the patriotism of Earl Southard, suspended commander of the organization in Illinois.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- A jury of nine men and three women began at 7:11 o'clock tonight its deliberations in the case of J. Warren Davis, retired senior judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, and Morgan S. Kaufman of Scranton, an attorney, both of whom, were tried on a charge of conspiring to obstruct justice and defraud the government.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 22 -- Reiterating his repudiation of charges that Americans and British are kept as hostages in Japan, Koh Ishii, the Foreign Office spokesman, at today's press conference declared that "our civilization is too proud to take hostages."

In the haste begotten of overwork the War Department proposed to erect an immense office building on a site across the Potomac near the gates of Arlington National Cemetery. The Federal Art Commission was quick to point out the injury to the beauty of Washington, the obstruction of one of its most majestic views that would result if this immense disfigurement of the Potomac waterfront were to be allowed.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A pair of $2,000 claiming races, both at six furlongs and carrying $1,300 purses, were the co-features at Narragansett Park today. Mrs. H.G. Good's All Heels, 22 to 1, annexed the two-year-old event and W. Drees's Tony Weaver took the sprint for older horses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A program for increasing production of alumina in Arkansas by 600,000,000 pounds a year by using low-grade bauxite ores was approved today by the Office of Production Management. It approved also a plan to build an experimental plant in Utah for extracting alumina from alunite and other aluminous clays.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- With negotiators continuing in deadlock and the Detroit Street Railways strike threatening to paralyze municipal transportation in this industrial defense center for a third day tomorrow, Mayor Edward J. Jeffries sought to find a peace formula in conferences tonight with strike leaders.

Stimulated by increased business activity the volume of bank transactions at all major cities in the week ended on Wednesday showed sharp gains over the similar week a year ago, the advance for all cities being the widest recorded for more than a decade.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Elmer E. Lucas, 31-year-old gas station operator from Peebles, Ohio, who has missed 110 targets out of 500 from sixteen yards this year to build a .780 average, broke 99 out of 100 today from eighteen yards to head the biggest field in history in the preliminary handicap, second most important event on the forty-second Grand American trapshoot program.

Attention is called by The London Economist to the notable rise of highgrade securities on that market. The British Government's 2 1/2 per cent console, for instance, which had brought 68 3/8 at the end of 1939 and 76 7/8 at the end of 1940, had risen last month to 82 1/2.

A point that has been widely overlooked in discussions of a broader tax base is the fact that lowered exemptions would not merely bring in new taxpayers but would substantially add to the levy on existing taxpayers. A reduction in the exemption for married persons from $2,000 to $1,500, as proposed by Secretary Morgenthau, would add $500 to the taxable income of all in this class who pay income taxes.

KENDAIA, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The 9,600-acre Seneca ordnance depot, the $8,000,000 defense projest for the storage of aerial bombs for protection of the northeast Atlantic seaboard, became a military reservation today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Miss Jessica Stonor, niece of Lady Camoys, will exhibit her drawings, executed in London between September, 1940, and January, 1941, during and after air raids, at a cocktail party to be held at the British war relief headquarters here on Tuesday afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday revealed today a contraction in note circulation of u2,802,000 to u665,375,000, the first drop in twelve weeks. Contrary to normal procedure the bank's circulation continued to rise after the August bank holiday spending.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The American Institute of Accountants recommended to the Senate Finance Committee today that "all personal exemptions be eliminated and that the normal income tax be withheld at the source on all payments to individuals, partnerships and trusts of salaries, wages, dividends, interest and other fixed or determinable income."

A further increase in the earning assets of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City took place in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase was $86,000,000, the largest since the week ended on May 28.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The low morale of National Guardsmen and draftees, commented upon by various writers who have visited the training camps, and the general lack of public support for the nation's defense efforts, as reflected by the close vote in Congress on the bill extending the service term, should occasion no surprise.

After three associations of dress manufacturers and jobbers had agreed to a 10 per cent wage increase for 85,000 union dressmakers in this city, two contractor associations jeopardized the agreement last night by threatening to close down their shops next Tuesday unless the jobbers granted the contactors an increase comparable to that won by the workers.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Germany was reported tonight, by travelers arriving from Sofia, to be massing forces along the Bulgarian-Turkish frontier in readiness for a possible drive across Turkey toward Iran and India.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on his recent conference with Prime Minister Churchill was as follows:

The stout defense by the Red armies -- the failure or success of which is still to be judged by the history of the next few weeks -- is in considerable measure attributable to the large number of tanks the Russians possess and the manner in which they use them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt warned Congress and the American people today that to accept a peace permitting Germany to hold conquered nations in subjection would merely give the Nazis a breathing space to prepare for a second war for the purpose of extending Nazi control "over Europe and Asia to the American Hemisphere itself."

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The grain markets lost ground today, with trading unusually slow. Pressure on wheat came mainly from professional traders who had bought the previous day. There also was some hedging against the Northwestern movement, but it was too small to be a market influence of consequence.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- One of the principal events of the social racing season here was the eleventh annual dinner of the New York Turf Writers Association held tonight at Arrowhead Inn. Many racing enthusiasts and members of society were hosts and hostesses at the event.

A hundred service men forgot the restraints of military life last night as they danced and sang at a block party held in the shadow of Queensboro Bridge at Sutton Place and Fifty-seventh Street under the sponsorship of the New York Defense Recreation Committee.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 22 -- For the second time within forty-eight hours direct negotiations for a settlement of the strike of C.I.O. ship workers at the Federal Ship-building and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, N.J., collapsed early this morning.

Advertising is essential during the defense emergency, Dr. Kenneth Dameron of Ohio State University and the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, Inc., declared yesterday. He said that information about goods and services is essential to national defense and that advertising is one of the chief means of imparting such information to the consumer.

William Harris Jr. said yesterday that he would close his producing offices in the Empire Theatre Building at the end of next week and that he had no definite plans for the Hollywood comedy written by Zoe Atkins and entitled "Babylonian Lullaby," which he controls until October.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt's reference to freedom of religion in all countries in his message to Congress today led Catholic leaders here to suggest that he use his influence to induce the Mexican Government to eliminate the anti-clerical provisions of the Constitution, which restrict the activities of the Catholic Church.
BERLIN, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The German High Command's communique today follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., for six years a star but never a winner in national amateur competition, gave his golf game a smooth tune-up today for next week's national amateur classic at Omaha by winning the first Great Lakes amateur championship at the Knollwood Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Panhandle Easter Pipe Line Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval of the purchase for $10,842,000 from the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation of the stock and indebtedness of the Michigan Gas Transmission Corporation and the Indiana Gas Distribution Corporation, and the purchase for $355,191 of some gas pipe lines from the Ohio Fuel Gas Company.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- Although the German drive in Russia appears again to be gathering momentum, and in spite of the tremendous losses said to have already been dealt the enemy, informed quarters here frankly asserted this afternoon that the Reich was anticipating that the campaign would continue throughout the Winter.

Residential buildings were involved in most of the realty deals reported in the New Jersey section close to New York yesterday. The Fidelity Union Trust Company sold the five-story apartment building at the northwest corner of Lincoln and Highland Avenues, in Orange, containing 168 rooms divided into fifty-two suites, to a client of Edward M. Bratter, of the firm of Marshall, Bratter Seligson.

There was no joy in Flatbush last night. The Dodgers were beaten by the Cubs, 6 -- 2, at Ebbets Field in the afternoon and in a manner that reflected no credit upon a majority of the playing personnel of the Brooklyn pennant aspirants.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We, the undersigned citizens of the United States, after a study of conditions in Peru and other countries of South America, wish to record our disagreement with the picture of IberoAmerican Catholicism submitted by your correspondent Harold Callender in THE NEW YORK TIMES Aug. 3.

Much that is discouraging is in store for shoppers when they set forth to do their week-end buying. Meat, the Consumer's Service Bureau of the Department of Markets reports, has in many cases advanced, in some maintained the status quo and in only the most isolated of instances declined in price.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES'S editorial of Aug. 16, "Anti-Inflation Taxes," commenting upon Secretary Morgenthau's statement of Aug. 14 that the Treasury is studying the question of higher social security taxes on a broader base, reveals your usual fairness and keen understanding of social security questions.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- In a long memorandum to the United States, Great Britain Has formally denied reports that American lease-lend supplies have been misused.

Prospective purchasers of Treasury tax-anticipation notes were warned yesterday by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, that if they delayed until the last few days of this month they may not be able to purchase any of the August issue of these notes and will have to take the September issue, which costs more.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged at 89.6 per cent of the 1926 average during the week ended on Aug. 16, it was announced today.

VICHY, France, Aug. 21 (AP) -- French and German police in Paris were reported tonight to be continuing the new drive of a series of arrests that have brought to 150,000 the number of persons deprived of their liberty throughout France because they were Jews, foreigners or political suspects.
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 21 -- Minister of the Navy W.M. Hughes today urged Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies to go to London despite Labor party opposition.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 "The Ballerina from Brighton," a photoplay by Lucille Prumbs, has been scheduled as a vehicle for Claudette Colbert, Paramount announced today. Miss Prumbs is preparing the scenario from her own story, which deals with the adventures of a ballet troupe stranded in England because of the war.

CAMP POLK, La., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Krueger, commanding general of the Third Army, in a blistering criticism of the handling of troops thus far in manoeuvres here, said today that there had been a stupid disregard of the danger of air attacks.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The third German offensive against Russia appeared to be nearing a close today, with big German advances on both the Ukrainian and Leningrad fronts, and authoritative quarters in London made no attempt to hide what they regarded as the gravity of the Russian position.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- After dropping the first game of a double-header by 11 to 3, the Athletics blanked the Browns, 12 to 0, behind Tommy Ferrick in the nightcap today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Department store sales for the week ended Aug. 16 were up 40 per cent over the sales of the corresponding period of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The sales for the week ended Aug. 9 were up 46 per cent, compared with the similar period a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 20:
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Refusal by Iran of British-Russian requests to throw German "tourists" and fifth columnists out of that country was forecast here tonight.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 21 -- The War Department was asked today to take over maintenance of bulkheads, jetties and stone breakwaters that protect the thin land strip on the New Jersey coast, between the Shrewsbury River and the Atlantic Ocean, from the ravages of storms.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- Mark R. Bacon, who as a member of the United States Congress in 1917 voted against the war resolution and the Selective Draft Act, had been in ill health for the last two years.

The list of known dead in the $2,000,000 fire that destroyed Pier 27, Brooklyn, and the New York Cuba Mail Line freighter Panuco last Monday stood at nineteen last night, with the recovery yesterday of six more bodies from the East River near the scene of the catastrophe.

Uncertainty over developments in Washington and adverse war news from Russia resulted yesterday in cotton futures losing approximately one-half of the gains of the previous day. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange, after a slight opening bulge, declined steadily and closed with losses of 18 to 24 points.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- A message from President Roosevelt to the national convention of Young Democrats, tonight, said that "against naked force the only possible weapon is naked force" and the defense of democracy must be fought on the aggressor's terms

HEMPSTEAD, L.I, Aug. 21 -- Bud Kroeger and Jack Weir of St. Albans, who beat the field to the tee this morning, also headed the list when the day's returns were in. Their card of 38, 35 -- 73 withstood the challenge of seventeen other teams to take the gross honors in the Long Island Golf Association's invitation amateur bestball handicap tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- While Reuben Fine, open champion of the United States Chess Federation, was idle because of a bye caused by Edward Lasker's withdrawal, Anthony E. Santasiere of New York gained an additional point today in the New York State chess championship on the Colgate University campus.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $10,300,909. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 31 cents a share on the 12,223,256 shares of common stock outstanding; it compares with $14,163,832, or 63 cents a common share, in the previous twelve months.

Speaking at the America First meeting on Wednesday evening, Mr. John T. Flynn threw in one remark that needs a footnote. "They've been looking for a hero," he said, "preferably a flier, and they got one, a transatlantic flier who fell into the ocean." Unmistakably he referred to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, who had argued at the Madison Square Garden meeting on Tuesday that slavery is worse than war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Following charges today by three New England Senators that an "unnecessary" diversion of oil tankers to the British was causing the oil and gasoline shortage on the Eastern seaboard, Ralph K. Davies, deputy petroleum coordinator, characterized such accusations as wholly unfounded.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 12 (delayed) -- This newest base established for American armed forces, which are being brought here in increasing numbers, has put American arms side by side with British in an odd collaboration which finds one force actually at war and the other technically at peace.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Employment of women in defense industries where shortages of male labor are becoming apparent was urged today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 21 -- As a step toward controlling inflation the Federal Reserve Board will shortly issue the first of a set of regulations to control buying on the installment plan. The immediate objective is to curb purchases of such goods as autos, refrigerators, washing machines, vacuum cleaners, etc., thus releasing metals for defense.

Specifications charging 3,409 cases of forgery in the designating petitions filed for John R. Davies candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor against Mayor La Guardia, were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections by Louis J. Lefkowitz and A. David Benjamin, chairmen of the law committees of the New York and Kings County Republican organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt sent a message to Congress concerning his meeting with Prime Minister Winston Churchill. He also sent a request for a supplemental appropriation of $18,988,435 for Coast Guard vessels.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Sid Hudson and Emil (Dutch) Leonard of the Senators teamed for six-hit pitching performances today, beating the Tigers in a double-header, 9 to 0 and 6 to 3.
BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- Considerable gains in all sectors of the Russian front are claimed by the German High Command today.

Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Ronald Ransom, vice chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, will address the fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, John D. Hospelhorn, president of the association, announced yesterday.

The Johns-Manville Corporation, maker of building materials; the Sherwin-Williams Company, paint manufacturer, and the York Ice Machinery Corporation, refrigeration-equipment and air-conditioning producer, entered yesterday into contracts for the construction of shell-loading plants and production of artillery for the United States Army.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Robert L. Riggs Jr. and Gene Mako narrowly escaped disaster, and two favored pairs in the women's tournament were eliminated today in the national tennis doubles championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.

Broadway will offer no new films today, as "Charley's Aunt" starts its fourth and final week at the Roxy, while "Bad Men of Missouri" begins its second and last week at the Strand.... Off Broadway, revivals of the Russian film, "Lenin in 1918"; the French picture, "Marseillaise," and the documentary, "China Strikes Back," open a week's engagement today at the Irving Place Theatre.

Supplies of locally dressed meats were light to moderate for yesterday's trading. Demand for traefer meats was fair to good and the market had a generally firm undertone. Thursday being an off-day in the kosher markets, little trading was done up to mid-day. The market was steady to strong, however, on steer chucks and plates, as well as veal and lamb foresaddles.

Yankee Films in Japan There is nothing new or surprising in the Japanese Government's announcement that it will no longer permit the importation of American motion pictures described as "gang thrillers, ultra-torrid romances and those depicting 'wasteful extravagance.' "

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Alaking, a colt that has been chasing Whirlaway, War Relic and such top-notchers, drove home winner of the Gnome Purse, in what might be termed his own class today, with many of the 11,304 present taking another horse.

Claims of fountain pen manufacturers concerning the durability of their products came under attack here yesterday in the second of a series of three hearings on Federal Trade Commission complaints charging misrepresentation and unfair competition against Parker Pen Company of Janesville, Wis.; W.A. Scheaffer Pen Company of Fort Madison.

It is a discouraging picture that Senator Byrd has painted of the present state of our preparedness. After two years of war he describes our tank production as "practically negligible." He asserts that only about a dozen of the 90-millimeter anti-aircraft guns have been delivered, and that the program provides for an average monthly delivery of only four such guns for the four remaining months this year.

Maurice Van Robays, who does a commendable job gathering in flies for Frankie Frisch, crashed a single off the bare hand of Fiddler Bill McGee last night at the Polo grounds, and, before a gathering of 11,845 fans, started the Pirates on the way to a victory over the Giants.

AT SEA WITH THE ATLANTIC FLEET -- An individual force of the United States Navy engaged in security duty is an infinitely enlarged policeman carrying out to the nth degree the duties of a "beat" on a section of the ocean.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The co-medalists, Joseph Mendes, home club champion, and Douglas Ford Of Green Valley, Westchester junior champion, were eliminated as the field reached the semi-final round of the twenty-eighth metropolitan junior golf championship over the narrow terrain of the Bonnie Briar Country Club course today.

Apartment leasing activity for the Fall season continued to hold the center of the stage in the realty world yesterday as new tenants were listed for many Manhattan buildings. Nearly all sections of the borough figured in the rental reports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Registrations of securities under the Securities Act in July amounted to $648,401,000, of which $290,785,000 was proposed for sale for the account of issuers, against $149,233,000 in the preceding month and $195,286,000 in July, last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Bucky Walters collected his sixteenth victory of the season today and gave the Reds their eleventh triumph in their last twelve starts as they defeated the Braves, 8 -- 5.

The high bidder yesterday for the new issue of $4,050,000 State of Minnesota rural-credit and deficiency-fund certificates was a syndicate composed of the National City Bank of New York, the First National Bank of New York, the Northern Trust Company of Chicago and the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

As the Petroleum Marketing Committee of the Eastern seaboard ended two days of deliberations yesterday on the gasoline situation and prepared to forward its findings to Washington, the report of a survey of actual sales by 109 filling stations in the Atlantic seaboard States indicated the voluntary rationing measures already initiated might be having the desired effect.

Coincident with the announcement of operating results for the first half of this year, the American Potash and Chemical Corporation yesterday advised stockholders of the election of F. Cecil Baker as president. He succeeds H.S. Emlaw, who resigned but will continue as a director and a member of the executive committee.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Teachers, A.F. of L., heard a plea for reconciliation today from leaders of three ousted locals, but took no action toward healing the breach which has split the federation.

Enlarged Scope For two weeks representatives of the New York Stock Exchange and of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms have been holding almost daily meetings. The subject has been the suggestion made by Emil Schram, new president of the Exchange, in his address in the Waldorf-Astoria before taking office:

H.C. Beaver, president of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, in a letter mailed yesterday to stockholders, reported that unfilled orders on June 30, last, were $58,856,065 against $11,980,950 a year earlier.

VICHY, France, Aug. 21 -- Marshal Henri Phllippe Petain this evening presided over a meeting of Ministers -- an unusual event in midweek. Normally such meetings occur on Saturdays. Last week, however, there was no gathering and this may explain why the Ministers met today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Despite the loss of its fifth column, that is, a lone cadet who, disguised as a fisherman, concealed a machine gun in his fishing rowboat, force "A" of the Corps of Cadets successfully effected a river crossing on Lake Tomahawk today on the fourth day of the Military Academy's annual field exercises.

Inactivity in price changes ruled yesterday in the stock market as operations repeated the dullness of last Friday, and closing quotations showed the day's business to be as near a stand-off as it has been at any time in the recent stalemated sessions.

Several leases of commercial space in the Park Avenue, Madison Avenue and Broadway districts were included in the lists of rentals reported by brokers yesterday. A number of firms were reported to have expanded their quarters.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21 (AP) -- After coming from behind to win the first tilt, 7 -- 6, the league-leading Bears were defeated by the Red Wings today in the nightcap of a twin bill, 3 to 1, and their six-game victory streak was ended. With Montreal beating Jersey City, Newark's first-place margin thus was reduced to seven and a half games, with twenty to play.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The newspaper Allgemeine Zeitung reported today that German troops had occupied the manganese deposits at Nikopol, on the Dnieper River about fifty miles below Zaporozhe and east of Krivoy Rog.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Russian attempts to blow up the $100,000,000 Dnieper River Dam and block the German offensive across the Ukraine were frustrated by a swift advance of Nazi artillery, it was asserted in German quarters today.

As appliance manufacturers start preparing for the production of 1942 models next month, the question of the curtailment proposed by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply is still completely up in the air and no official order has yet been issued, manufacturers reported yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:
Favorable opinions were expressed by many yesterday regarding the 1941 hunting regulations on migratory game birds.

Despite threats of rationing of oil supplies along the East Coast, executives of leading oil companies are inclined to the opinion that any drastic restriction scheme is unnecessary unless Washington intends to transfer additional tankers to the British war effort or to earmark a sizable part of the gasoline supplies on the East Coast for national defense purposes.
Traffic in the Port of New York is steadily increasing and reached a new record for the year during the month of July, figures compiled at the Custom House at Bowling Green revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- With hundreds of silk workers already out of work and more layoffs expected, the Office of Production Management announced today that a conference of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization textile union leaders has recommended a four-point program to alleviate the effects of the shutdown of silk imports.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 22 -- Large formations of Royal Air Force bombers, sometimes escorted by hundreds of fighter planes, made heavy attacks on German-occupied Netherlands and France during daylight yesterday, the Air Ministry reported.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 20 -- Resolutions endorsing the national defense program and expressing the hope that the United States might "be spared the devastating horrors of war," were approved today at the concluding session of the fifty-ninth international convention of the Supreme Council, Knights of Columbus.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Aug. 21 -- A strong rally developed on the Bourse today after a weak opening and prices at the close were the best of the day and not much lower than yesterday. A.K.U. was steady, Philips lost 3 1/4 to 245, Unilever rose 4 1/8 to 146 7/8, Royal Dutch lost 2 5/8 to 270 1/8, Amsterdam rubber 2 1/2 to 292 1/4, and Amsterdam Trading 1 1/2 to 453 1/2.

Because of Hitler's great losses in war material, and his expenditures of oil and other strategic raw materials in the invasion of Russia and previous campaigns, he is now "on the down grade," and this Summer "quite definitely marks the turning point of the war," Douglas Miller declares in an article in the September issue of The Atlantic Monthly.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 21 -- Unanimous approval of the eight-point war-aim program proclaimed by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill at their recent meeting in the Atlantic was voted by the State Federation of "Labor at the final session of its convention today.

Credit Collections Up 0.69% Retail credit collections showed an increase of 0.69 per cent in July, according to the twenty local store index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 47.56, against 46.87 in July, 1940.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 21 -- New Zealand came through the first year of the war with fewer industrial disturbances than in the last year of peace, a Labor Department report revealed today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The last-place Phils staged a three-hit ninth-inning onslaught which yielded two runs tonight to edge out the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 4.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 21 -- Large forces of Italians are reported to be pouring into Northern Croatia to put down grave disorders that have broken out in that puppet kingdom in the last twenty-four hours, according to reports broadcast in Croat over the Moscow radio late this evening.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 -- The Yankees, who had been expected to finish the job of pulverizing the American League within the next few weeks, apparently have decided to make this a good-will tour instead.

The arrests and executions in France evoke scenes from the Paris Commune of 1871 and the Reign of Terror of a century and a half ago. The very place names mentioned in today's dispatches, the Eleventh Arondissement, lying just beyond the Place Bastille, impel comparison of the old with this new Reign of Terror.

The Duke of Kent, youngest brother of King George VI of England, who has been visiting Canada for several weeks on an official mission as an Air Commodore on the Inspector General's staff of the Royal Air Force, will pass through New York City this afternoon on the way to spend the week-end with President RooseVelt.
The gasoline situation in the Eastern States is, to put it mildly, confused. The extent of the confusion is deeply underscored by several events of the past few days.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Whirlaway has a chance tomorrow to take the sting out of his greatest failure -- his flop in the Arlington Classic a month ago.

VICHY, France, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Germany was reported angered at the French Government tonight for its failure to halt the wave of sabotage against the French railroad system, threatening the German rear during the Russian campaign.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- The establishment of a "special institute for vitamin research" by decree of Reichsfuehrer Hitler, announced in Berlin, emphasizes the conspicuous role that vitamin preparations are playing in the present war.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In reply to the rather revolutionary remarks of Solon Gartenlaub concerning the desirability of having the two major leagues play each other during the season, I would like to observe that this would be distinctly unfair unless each team from one league played each team from the other league the same number of times (preferably once).

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- The battle for Leningrad promises to develop into one of the bloodiest of this second World War, and, according to all reports emanating from that city, the population is determined to defend it in a heroic spirit.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The $12 hog reappeared today as prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, reflecting increased dressed trade prices which lifted top light loins to 28 cents a pound, up a cent to the highest level since September, 1936. Cattle were firm and lambs were weak to 25 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Donald McNeill and Frank Parker, the national tennis singles champions on grass and clay, and Gardnar Mulloy and Wayne Sabin gained the two remaining brackets in the semi-final round of the national doubles tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today, leaving the four top-favored teams in possession of the field.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 21:

Taking untold liberties with the script and borrowing two dozen popular songs as an answer to all problems of plot, twenty-five Lower East Side youngsters yesterday put on their version of "Show Boat". Their theatre was the roof garden of the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, where sunlight put the spotlight on the audience.

PEEKSKILL, Aug. 22 -- Completing a week of intensive training at Camp Smith, 200 officers of the State Guard will break camp tomorrow, following a review by Major Gen. William Ottman, commander of the guard.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 22 -- In preparation for leaving Fort Ethan Alien early next week for Camp Devens to participate in the Sixth Array Corps manoeuvres, members of the 185th and 187th Regiments of the Seventy-first Field Artillery Brigade, formerly the New York National Guard, staged a review on Wednesday at which Colonel Carl A. Baehr, Brigade Commander, awarded citations for bravery and exceptional performance of duty to eighty-five members of the brigade.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- The increase In demand for shares today on the Boerse could not be covered because of the extreme narrowness of the market. Colonials were weak, but other groups were steady to strong, particularly specialties, which gained between 2 and 3 per cent and in some instances more.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- The American Ryder Cup team, prevented by the war from showing what it could do against the British two years ago, will have another chance to prove its worth tomorrow. The P.G.A. force is going to tackle a team of fellow-pros in a match for the benefit of the United Service Organizations.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Iran delivered to the British Minister today a formal answer to demands for expulsion of German technicians, and informed sources said the reply was substantially the same as an oral one that the British had called unsatisfactory.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- Foreshadowing a final refusal tomorrow to seat representatives of Locals 5 and 537 of New York and 192 of Philadelphia, the credentials committee of the American Federation of Teachers rejected today the credentials presented by the presidents and delegates of these locals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Extension of the cotton gray goods price ceiling schedule to cover combed lawns, dimities, voile and high-grade combed broadcloths was announced today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supplies.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner and chairman of Governor Lehman's committee on discrimination in employment, reported yesterday that job discrimination by New York State employers on the basis of race, creed or color was steadily decreasing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The War Department announced today that a fifth armored division would be created about Oct. 1 at Fort Knox, Ky., and would be ready for training about two weeks later.

Horace K. Corbin, president of the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, N.J., was elected chairman of the special committee to study that city's debt structure, at the organization meeting of the committee yesterday. Appointments to the committee were made recently by Mayor Vincent J. Murphy of Newark.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Several hundred persons attended tonight's dinner dance at the Devon Yacht Club on Gardiner's Bay. Officers and judges for tomorrow's sixteenth annual Horse Show at the Riding Club of East Hampton were guests of honor at a large dinner.

The feel of climax is in the air. High tension at half a dozen different points at once indicates that we are nearing another explosive point in the war. During the long pause between the Polish campaign and the attack on France a high Nazi official told the writer in Berlin that this struggle would be marked by spurts and Pulls, alternating periods of intense activity and exhaustion.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Stanley Caldar of Montclair, 20-year-old Dartmouth junior, became the 1941 metropolitan junior golf champion today as he defeated Billy Rohrey of Norwood, 5 and 4, in the 18-hole final over the Bonnie Briar course.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Britain's leaders considered tonight what they termed the desperate urgency of a war situation that may send British and Russian troops into Iran to guard the Asia Minor oil shed in a common land front against Germany's rush toward the southeast.

Samuel Goldwyn's "The Little Foxes" was seen by 22,163 persons on Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall, thereby setting an all-time attendance mark for a normal opening day at that theatre, the management reported yesterday. Due to the unprecedented business, the theatre will open at 9 A.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Here is a list of the articles covered by the regulations issued by the Federal Reserve Board in regard to installment buying, with the maximum maturity and the maximum credit value in each case:

The bodies of twelve more victims of the fire that last Monday destroyed the New York and Cuba Mail Line freighter Panuco and Pier 27, Brooklyn, were taken from the waters of the East River yesterday, bringing to thirty-one the total of known dead in the disaster.

VINCENT SHEEAN'S new novel, "Bird of Y the Wilderness,"* is a slow-burning fuse through most of its pages, but there is a bombshell at the end. What begins in a Tarkingtonian mood and continues along much of its course through a world and a time Sinclair Lewis's Carol Kennicott also knew, ends with an astonishing and implausible episode out of Greek tragedy.

Vichy's Ambassador to the United States, M. Gaston Henry-Haye, ought to know this country and its ways, for he has been visiting us off and on for about thirty-five years. In his youth he is said to have traveled America on foot and on a bicycle, as well as by less tiring means.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Regulations for the restriction of installment credit on a large number of consumer goods were issued by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System today.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The tragic death of a young boxer as a result of injuries suffered in a contest at Fort Hamilton last week indicates that there is need for additional reform in our ring rules.
