An outbreak of price-cutting disturbed the liquor market here yesterday but gave consumers an opportunity to buy trade-marked brands of domestic whiskies, and some scotches, at prices ranging from 35 cents to $1 a quart below levels specified in distillers' price-maintenance contracts.

The Pirates specialized in hitting for extra bases yesterday at the Polo Grounds. What is more, they concentrated their fire in two big innings. The result was another Giant reverse, spoiling the first start Bob Bowman made in the interests of Colonel Bill Terry's jaded ball players since last May.
ROME, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

To Sports Editor of The New York Times; In analyzing the success of the Brooklyn Dodgers this year, the thing that strikes me most forcibly about the Ebbets Field team is its exceptional balance and reserve strength. With other teams it is usually possible to point to one player as the key man, e. g., DiMaggio of the Yankees, Feller of the Indians, Walters of the Reds, Greenberg of the Tigers, etc.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 22 --A visitor to the New York State Con servatlon office today found considerable interest attached to the dedication of the Conservation Exhibits Building at the State Fall on Wednesday at Syracuse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Private home builders are beginning to feel the pinch of defense priorities.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 23 -- A three-day seashore vacation for 750 enlisted troops of this anti-aircraft post during Labor Day week-end has been planned by Major William Oliver Smith, morale officer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Wheal showed a stubbornly strong undertone much of today, although the range of quotations was narrow. Increased offerings were met, however, before the close, which caused a setback from the top. The close on the Board of Trade here was unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel higher.

A Hand for the Hen The country is hearing from the hen this year as never before. While another of our national birds watches with piercing eye the horizon east and west, the hen enlists in the battle of production in a big way.

Financing New Pipe Line Although no definite arrangements have been made for the financing of the proposed oil pipe line from East Texas via St, Louis to New York and Philadelphia, it is understood that considerable exploratory work has been done.

A repetition of the balancing act of Thursday was staged yesterday by the stock market as prices again held to a narrow groove. Adverse war news from the Russian front was again the order of the day. Although the share list exhibited no definite trend in either direction and trading was the lowest since the first of July, an orderly and firm undertone was maintained.

A perfect mark of 100 per cent in arithmetic tests is the passing grade for pupils in the work-study classes of some of the city high schools, it was disclosed yesterday in the annual report of the Board of Education's division of cooperative education.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 -- The Yankees, just to show they are not entirely dependent upon the devastating bludgeon of their incapacitated Joe DiMaggio, ended a two-day scoring drought today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We of the Republican party in this city are getting much advice these days from outsiders as to what we should do in our primary election, which, of course, is limited solely to the registered Republicans.

An accelerated expansion of plant facilities to meet the increasing demand for electric power in the nation's capital was announced yesterday by A.G. Neal, president of the Potomac Electric Power Company. The company, serving Washington, D.C., and surrounding territory, will spend more than $30,000,000 by 1943 for the installation of new generating facilities and the expansion and improvement of transmission and distribution systems.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The high morale of the Russian troops and the efficiency with which a Russian division that he watched carried out a successful attack are emphasized in a report by Lieut. Gen. F.N. Mason MacFarlane, chief of the British military mission to Moscow, that was made public by the War Office today.

BERLIN, Saturday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The German Air Force is smashing in great force at airfields and roads around Leningrad to soften Soviet opposition for approaching German armies while new and bitter encirclement battles are developing on the central front, it was reported here today.
CAIRO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following, communique today:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Resolutions touching on national defense were introduced today before the resolutions committee of the Young Democratic Clubs of America, including one that the, government, if necessary, should obtain, defense bases In Dakar, Cape Verde Islands, Siberia (opposite Alaska), Singapore and "other strategic points considered necessary by military and naval leaders."

ABOUT ten years ago a man bought a horse for $100 and, just for that, he now has a race track on his hands. A big track; a fancy track. Beautiful Hialeah. This tourist ran into the new master of Hialeah under the elms at Saratoga and asked him how it all came about.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- With Joe Dobson shading Buck Ross on the mound, the Red Sox made it two straight over the White Sox before a ladies' day crowd of 15,011 today. The score was 2 to 1. Boston, climbed to within a game and a half of the second place Chicagoans.

Although movements in the cotton futures market continued slightly erratic yesterday, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange managed to close at net gains of 5 to 11 points, thus erasing part of their losses of the previous session. The demand was stimulated by further reports of weevil infestation in the Southeast and less favorable weather outlook for the entire belt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Threats of economic difficulties in the Philippines disappeared today and an uninterrupted flow of sugar and strategic materials was assured through the addition of six vessels to the Philippine service and cancellation of plans to divert twenty-five ships from that run to the Atlantic.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 23 -- The Red Banner Baltic Fleet struck a sharp blow at the Germans yesterday, attacking a convoy of five transport vessels, crammed with soldiers and material, and after breaking up an escorting patrol of war vessels sank two of the transports, sent the three others aground and also sank two fast cutters of the protecting flotilla, the late Soviet communique announced today.
FORT DEC, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf's 114th Infantry Regiment left here tonight, increasing the number of Forty-fourth Division regiments training away from their home station.

Sales Here Rise 30% in Week Retail trade here continued active this week, with substantial volume gains noted for most stores. Average department store volume was estimated as probably better than 30 per cent ahead of last year, with home furnishings, furs and domestics faring particularly well.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -- Recognizing the existence in American prisons of "a potential army of defense workers that needs only mobilization to become effective," Sam A. Lewisohn of New York proposed to the American Prison Congress here today the organization of a "division M" in every prison in the country.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Prices of cheese were increased today for the fourth week by the Gouverneur Dairy Board. Wash curds were raised one-half cent a pound to 22 1/4 cents and State brand to 22 3/4 cents. The prices are the highest in fifteen years and 8 1/2 cents above quotations a year ago.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 22 -- Upon completion of its first eleven months of Federal Service, the 244th Coast Artillery has been selected as "best National Guard regiment" in the Third Coast Artillery District for the period April 1 to July 31. The district comprises Fort Story, Fort Mohroe, Fort Wool and Camp Pendleton.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Ministries said today:

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- President Roosevelt went on the offensive today against Congressional critics of the defense program, reeling off figures to support a statement that production generally was abreast of schedules and would increase tremendously in a matter of months.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, was held to a draw by Isaac I. Kashdan in the ninth round today, while Reuben Fine, national open ruler, strengthened his hold on first place by defeating Harold Evans of Binghamton in the New York State Chess Association tournament.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Montreal made it three straight over Jersey City in the four-game series, taking both ends of a double-header before a crowd of 4,068 tonight, by scores of 1-0 and 7-1. The twin setback stretched Jersey City's losing streak to five straight.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Jim Tobin snapped the Braves' fivegame losing streak and chalked up his tenth victory of the campaign today as he beat the Reds, 9 -- 1. The loss was Cincinnati's second in its last thirteen games.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Aug. 23 -- While the Russian troops continued today to hold successfully on the Novgorod and Gomel fronts, despite intensive pressure from German thrusts, the late Soviet High Command communique in referring to actions on the southern front announced the evacuation of Nikopol, about fifty miles east of Krivoy Rog on the west bank of the Dnieper River.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 9 amounted to 3,393,230 shares, compared with 4,859,080 shares in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 22 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies announced at a joint meeting of ministerial parties this afternoon that he had sent a letter to the leader of the Labor Opposition, John Curtin, again suggesting the formation of a national government, the leader of which would be elected, if necessary, by the united Australia Country and Labor parties jointly.
Residential properties in scattered sections of the borough figured largely in the Brooklyn realty transactions reported yesterday.

Motorists in the Eastern States who have had no favorite filling station at which they have regularly filled their tanks were finding it increasingly difficult yesterday to buy all the gasoline they wanted at any one place as the 10 per cent cut in supplies ordered by Washington began to be more widely felt.

OSWEGO, Aug. 21 -- War Department orders received this week will take the 369th Coast Artillery Regiment, Negro, from Fort Ontario to Camp Edwards. The Harlem soldiers will leave the Army post on Sept. 3 and will be succeeded here by the 198th Coast Artillery Regiment, which, will come from Camp Edwards.
BERLIN, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A special communique from Adolf Hitler's Field Headquarters today said:

The shortages of various popular cloths, which hampered retail advertising on men's clothing during the Spring and Summer, will probably toe absent in the Fall season, local store executives reported here yesterday. Deliveries of Fall styles have been pouring into local stores in good volume for the last month, and while retailers are cautious in their optimism, they are reasonably confident that they will have sufficient stocks to do a brisk business this Fall.
BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say to- morrow:

Installment furniture sales in the second quarter showed an increase of 33.39 per cent over the corresponding period of 1940, which in turn was 12.4 per cent over 1939, Arthur Fertig Co., retail advisory service, reported yesterday. This brought the gain for the first half to 35 per cent compared with an increase of 14 per cent in 1940 over 1939.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Herman Triplett's home run with a man on base gave the Cardinals a 4-2 victory over the Phillies today in a ten-inning battle. Triplett's homer was inside the park.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 22 -- Two initial steps were outlined by Dr. Judah Leib Magnes, president of the Hebrew University, in a statement here amplifying his pronouncement concerning Arab-Jewish, understanding efforts that ha gave to THE NEW YORK TIMES July 18.

Before the burgeoning season of 1941-42 is allowed to grow much older the League of New York Theatres will tackle a number of problems presented by Actors Equity, Chorus Equity, Scenic Artists and the Treasurers Unions at a general membership meeting next Wednesday, starting at 2:30 P.M., at the league's headquarters, 234 West Forty-fourth Street.

The resumption by the Bank of France of regular publication of its weekly statement of condition affords one more view of the world's monetary picture -- a picture that shows in all directions a rising tide of money in circulation. The bank's latest statement Shows note circulation at 239,500,000,000 francs, contrasted with 140,000,000,000 francs just before the start of the war and 174,000,000,000 francs at the time of the armistice last year.

A new national executive committee for the pulp writers' section of the Authors League of America was announced yesterday by Oscar Schisgall, chairman. The committee, elected by a ballot of writers throughout the country, is made up of Arthur Leo Zagat, treasurer; Robert Carse, secretary; Frederick Faust (Max Brand), Erie Stanley Gardner, Frederick C. Painton and Albert R. Wetjen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- President Roosevelt has signed the naval works authorization bill which will add about $225,000,000 of shore and island facilities to support the Navy in any task which it may have to meet.

VICHY, France, Aug. 22 -- Drastic changes are expected in the very near future in two internal organizations that closely affect the life of the country -- the service of supplies and professional committees.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Mrs. F. Skiddy von Stade of Westbury, L.I., has joined Mr. von Stade at their Summer home for several days at the races. They entertained with a luncheon today for Mr. and Mrs. F. Skiddy von Stade Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Carleton P. Burke, Miss Sara W. Clucas and her fiance Charles S. von Stade; Mrs. Renouf Russell of Boston, Robert Kelly, James Ryan and John Armstrong.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Electric Bond and Share Company and its subsidiary, American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., had filed an application under the Holding Company Act regarding the proposed issuance by the subsidiary of $15,500,000 of 3 per cent notes in exchange for a like unpaid principal amount of its notes held by banks and the parent company.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 22 -- The American Federation of Labor Street Car Men's Union tonight rejected a proposal made by Mayor Edward J. Jeffries to settle the three-day city-wide transportation strike.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22 -- A $9,000 payroll and $250 in petty cash were stolen today from the office here of Sigmund Eisner Company, manufacturers of uniforms, during a hold-up by six armed and masked bandits, who escaped in a waiting automobile.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 -- Divided seven to five and declaring its inability to reach an agreement, the jury of nine men and three women in the second trial of J. Warren Davis, retired senior judge of the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, and Morgan S. Kaufman of Scranton, an attorney, was discharged at 5:57 P.M. today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 22 -- The weakness of Italy's Navy and Air Force, coupled with the preoccupation of the Nazi Air Fleet in Russia, is swinging the balance of power in the Mediterranean more and more in Britain's favor.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- President Roosevelt issued today an Executive order extending to the full eighteen additional months authorized by law the military service of all selectees and members of the Army and National Guard, except those past 28 years old, those whose dependents would suffer unduly and those who could be spared.

Savings and loan associations in this State made about 2,500 mortgage loans in July, aggregating about $8,390,000, an increase of 40 per cent in mortgage volume and a gain of 13 per cent in the number of loans over July, 1940, it was announced yesterday by Zebulon V. Woodard, executive vice president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.
This is the third of a series of articles by a member of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, now cruising with a naval unit.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Sacket Harbor's historic post, Madison Barracks, forced to take a backseat since activation of the Fourth Armored Division at Pine Camp, recaptured the news spot-light this past week, when the 258th Field Artillery, 1,100 strong, was ordered from the post to Fort Devens, Mass.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In a letter published in THE TIMES last Saturday Carl Peterson of Chicago bemoaned the fact that no team in baseball today emphasizes place-hitting. He is not altogether 'correct in this assertion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Contracts totaling $4,582,947, were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug, 22 -- President Roosevelt today took a severe blow at the Japanese fishing industry, one of the most important, and far-flung enterprises of the empire, when he raised the tariff on crab meat from 15 to 22 1/2 per cent ad valorem.

Returning to his home at 136 West Ninety-second Street at 4:30 A.M. yesterday after a tour of duty at the Twenty-fourth Precinct station house, Patrolman Harold King was shot and killed by two men he apparently had surprised attempting to break into an automobile parked next door.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 8 the following headline and excerpts appeared:

The five-story flat at 913-915 Garden Street, Hoboken, N.J., assessed for $29,800, has been sold by the Pole Realty Company to the D.R. Realty Company, for $5,000 above a first mortgage of $26,000 held by the Hoboken Bank for Savings.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press) -- A net profit of $291,000 was shown in the 272d annual report of the Hudson's Bay Company for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1941, mailed today to shareholders. The profit is $60,000 below the previous year.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuter) -- Regulations have been introduced by the Bank of England bringing dealings between Uruguay and other neutral countries financed through London in United States dollars into line with existing comparable arrangements applying to other Latin-American countries.

OMAHA. Aug. 22 (AP) -- The starting field for the forty-fifth national amateur golf championship, which opens Monday at the Field Club, was reduced to 147 today with the announcement of three withdrawals by Joseph C. Dey Jr., United States Golf Association executive secretary.

While taxpayers generally seek every loophole to ease their tax burden, members of the First Avenue Association have recently assumed a voluntary "tax" to help pay for resurfacing a large section of their thoroughfare. They admit they are entirely willing to tax themselves in order to bury the avenue's "noisy" cobblestones.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics, who were fourth on Aug. 8, barely averted dropping into the American League cellar today by nosing out the eighth-place Browns, 5 to 4.

Beginning Monday, the Board of Elections will begin to hold hearings on objections to the validity of designating petitions of candidates for party nominations and a large number of candidates for the Democratic Comity Committee in New York County in a series of Tammany Assembly district leadership contests and for the Republican County Committee in Bronx County in the fight of a group of insurgent Republicans against the leadership of John J. Knewitz.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A survey of idle tank cars ready to be pressed into service to bring oil to the East Coast region where a gasoline shortage impends was asked today by Ralph K. Davies, Acting Petroleum Coordinator.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- On the second anniversary of the day Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, departed for Moscow to sign a ten-year non-aggression pact with Russia. Authoritative military quarters in Berlin asserted this evening that there were numerous indications of an impending crisis in the Russian defense.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A seven-point program to place, in defense or other jobs about 100,000 workers displaced by the 26.6 per cent automobile production cut has been proposed by the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers of America and accepted by automobile managements.

A list of ten commodities on which navicert quotas for Switzerland have been exhausted for the third and fourth quarters of this year and four commodities on which the quotas for Portugal have been filled was made public yesterday by the British Consulate.

A net profit of $1,869,497 was reported yesterday by the American Chain and Cable Company, Inc., and domestic and Canadian subsidiaries for the six months ended on June 30, last. Charges against the net include depreciation, amortization, Federal and excess profits taxes and other deductions.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 22 -- Finnish forces tonight were reported driving on the Karelian Isthmus town of Kiviniemi, less than fifty miles north of Leningrad, after capturing the railroad center of Kaekisalmi and destroying or routing five Russian divisions.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- A vanguard of Army nurses arrived today at the post hospital, which has been completely remodeled. Lieutenant Jean I. Mullen, veteran of eighteen years in the Army Nurse Corps, was placed in charge of the young women, most of whom were graduated recently from hospital nursing schools.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin) -- Aug. 22 -- The Bourse was very firm today with most of the leading issues showing gains. Unilever and Royal Dutch were in the foreground. A.K.U. moved up 2 3/8 to 149 1-3, Philips 5 1/2 to 250 1/2, Unilever 6 3/8 to 153 1/4, Royal Dutch 6 to 276, Amsterdam Rubber 2 1/2 to 295 3/4 and Amsterdam Trading 6 1/2 to 460.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Direct negotiations for settlement of the fifteen-day-old strike at the Kearny (N. J.) yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Corporation broke down again early today and the case was shunted back to President Roosevelt, who said at a press conference in Hyde Park, N.Y., that the government did not want to take over the company's yard if it could help it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Under a change of plans announced today by John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank board, only one instead of several agencies under the board's supervision will be moved to New York. The organization which will move is the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command announced tonight that its forces had broken the defenses the Russians had erected on the ruins of Finland's former Mannerheim Line.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Although playing erratic golf, Miss Jean Bauer, the Providence star, scored an 82 for a thirty-six-hole total of 166 today to gain a stroke lead on Mrs. Walter Acuff Jr. of Philadelphia at the two-thirds stage in the women's invitation tournament at Ekwanok.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 23 -- The Japanese press continued today to denounce United States oil shipments to Russia via Vladivostok as a deliberate provocation of Japan, emphasizing the statement of a government spokesman yesterday that it was a matter that could not be viewed from "a legal standpoint alone."

Issuing the first interim report on sales it ever has made owing to provisions of the Securities Act, the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday net sales and gross revenues from non-steel operations amounting: to $1,445,337,152 for the twelve months ended on June 30, compared with $1,145,607,886 reported for the calendar year 1940.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Priscilla Lane and Richard Whorf were named today by Warners for the leading roles in "Remember Tomorrow," a photoplay of international intrigue by Marion Parsonnet, which will go before the cameras Sept. 2.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 22 -- Warrants for the detention of thirty-six Germans, described as "the general staff of Nazi penetration in Argentina," were issued today by Federal Judge Ramon Vazquez. They had been indicted on charges of misusing public funds and forming an illicit association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated today that Japan had agreed to a gradual repatriation of American citizens, while President Roosevelt at Hyde Park took a sharp blow at the Japanese fishing industry by raising the tariff on crab meat from 15 to 221/2 per cent ad valorem.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- In the face of President Roosevelt's assertions at Hyde Park that American military production was measuring up, on the average, to advance expectations, Senator Byrd reiterated today his charges that the industrial preparedness program for national defense and aid to the non-Axis Allies was woefully inadequate.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

The average-sized man carries in his arteries, veins, capillaries and heart-chambers about ten pints of blood. Of this he can, if in good health, easily spare a pint at a time. Hence the feasibility of blood transfusions to the operative patient, of donations to hospital "blood banks" and of contributions to the store of blood plasma which our armed forces are accumulating.

HATTIESBURG, Miss, Aug. 22 -- Reports from the troops on manoeuvres in Louisiana and the attitude of men left at Camp Shelby indicated this week that extensive use of weapons and war tactics react favorably on soldier morale.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The text of President Roosevelt's proclamation increasing the duty on imported crab meat follows:

Word was received here this week from the British and Foreign Bible Society that the premises of its bindery, situated in the south of London, had been "almost destroye through enemy action." The Amer lean Bible Society, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, an nounced the news yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Extension, of the rule of selection to promotion lists for all grades of Army officers was ordered today by the War Department.

Fire of undetermined origin started shortly after 3 A.M. yesterday aboard the war-stranded Finnish freighter Aurora in the upper Hudson River, resulting in the death of the ship's chief officer and injuries to the captain. Sixteen crew members escaped unharmed.

Light to moderate supplies were a price-supporting Influence In yesterday's locally dressed market. Demand was fair to good. The market on traefer steer cuts was strong to higher. Hind and rib prices were up 50 cents, short loin prices advanced $1-$2, while rail chucks, ribs, top sirloins and lull hips were mostly $1 higher.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Miss Nancy McClave crashed into the winner's circle in Women's New Jersey Golf Association oneday tournament competition today when she scored an 81 over the Shackamaxon Country Club course.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- In the most "nervous" shoot-off in Grand American Handicap history, Walter L. Tulburt, 52-yearold Detroit furnace salesman, won trapshooting's blue ribbon event today by beating Del Bundschuh, 28-year-old Freemont, Ohio, machinist, 23 to 22.

VICHY, France, Aug. 22 -- Following the measures taken in Paris to check Communist activities and the mass arrests of Jews, there were raids reported today from Paris and from a large number of centers of the occupied zone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Mohammed Schayesteh, the Iran Minister, called on Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to deny reports from abroad that Nazi fifth-column activities threatened Iranian independence of action. He even denied that there were any fifth columnists in his country.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Most of the soldiers of Massachusetts' two large cantonments are concentrated at this fort. More than 40,000 of them brought about 5,000 motor vehicles. The 10,000 men of the 26th (Yankee) Division settled in their wide tenting area today after a trip on foot and by truck from Cape Cod which left most of them almost exhausted.
NEW YORK Mrs. John Henry Clews of the Plaza is returning today from Jasper National Park, Alberta.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Rochester scored twice in the thirteenth, inning tonight to defeat the league-leading Newark Bears, 6 -- 4, in a game that lasted 3 hours and 30 minutes.
Two new ships in the Maritime Commission's long-range replacement program will go down the ways today, bringing the total of launchings to 126.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Patent Office has been given a new role in tightening the nation's defenses as the result of the signing today by President Roosevelt of a bill which would plug loopholes through which inventions made in this country, particularly those important to national defense, might leak out to foreign nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Imposition of a "withholding tax" of 10 per cent, deducted on all incomes at the source, was advocated today before the Senate Finance Committee by Professor Harley L. Lutz of Princeton University, who said the levy would raise $7,000,000,000, or twice the $3,236,700,000 defense tax bill as approved by the House.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A fiverun ninth-inning rally gave the Tigers a 5-to-4 victory over the Senators today and handed Alejandro Carrasquel his first defeat in seven starts.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A. Finnish Supreme Command communique said tonight:

In spite of the upward trend of food prices, bargains are to be found by the knowing shopper. The semi-monthly issue of Consumer Prices, published by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, suggests that we balance our budgets with the fresh vegetables that are expected to continue in abundance through September.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22 -- A controversy developed here today over the action of Sheriff Henry Young Jr. of Essex County in accepting a check for $1,219 from the Curtiss-Wright Propeller Division in Caldwell Township for distribution to forty-five deputies who did strike duty at the plant earlier this month.

Two and possibly three rare paintings by old masters went up in the smoke of an outdoor oven in the rear of a Summer cottage in Hampton Bays, L.I., because of a maid's pique at the routine order of her employer and her desire to "hurt him," it was disclosed yesterday by Police Headquarters.

Worrying three pitchers with a dozen assorted hits and sending one hurler, Tot Pressnell, to the hospital, the Dodgers yesterday toppled the Cubs, 8-5, at Ebbets Field before a ladies' day crowd of 28,468. The Durocher clan's lead of a game and a half over the Cardinals remained unchanged.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. George P. Ryan gave their last large party of the season at their home, Vaucluse, tonight, when they entertained at dinner for forty guests. About 100 other persons came in later for dancing from other parties.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, landed at an air base near London today after a flight across the Atlantic in a bomber plane. He was accompanied by four United States naval officers -- Captain William J. Larson, Commander Clyde Lovelace, Commander Ernest W. Litch and Captain J.L. Schwartz -- and by Charles Peake, of the British Foreign Office staff.

How to justify the ways of war to religion will be discussed by many clergymen in the pulpits of the city tomorrow. Worshippers will be urged to cooperate in the effort to maintain recreational and rest centers for men in the defense service. There will be many visiting preachera, including a number from the Pacific Coast.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Fenelon and Big Pebble, the two who had the keen battle in the Whitney Stakes, are among the five named for the Saratoga Handicap, main feature here tomorrow as the Saratoga Racing Association concludes its fourth week of racing.

New bond flotations offered to the public this week by investment bankers amounted to $62,627,000, the largest total for three weeks. Comprising industrial, railroad and State and municipal issues, the amount compared with $4,393,000 last week and with $33,750,000 in the corresponding week last year.

TOKYO, Aug. 22 -- According to Domei news agency dispatches from Saigon, Indo-China, the joint commission organized by Japan, Thailand and French Indo-China for the demarcation of the new borders of Thailand and IndoChina will supervise demilitarization of the territory Indo-China ceded to Thailand.

VICHY, France, Saturday, Aug. 23 -- All Frenchmen arrested by or for German authorities in France will be held as hostages for the assassination of a high German officer two days ago, it was decreed in a German military order effective today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Men, women and children among Leningrad's population of more than 2,000,000 today threw up barricades in the streets of Russia's most magnificent city.

Sixty-nine municipalities will be in the market next week with new issues. Only one of the issues, however, is sizable. The total of new securities will drop to $8,333,178 from $13,444,311 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $35,494,691.

-- PILOT CHURCHILL The American people have wondered aloud at the costume Winston Churchill wore at his meeting with President Roosevelt -- a tight, high-buttoned jacket, a bow tie, a dark sea-going cap with a shiny visor.

LONDON. FOUR months after her tragic death there Has appeared Virginia Woolf's last novel, "Between the Acts," after being prepared for the press by her husband. Most of her admirers have found in it a further justification for their high appreciation of her work.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23 -- More than 500 Summer colonists from various parts of Mount Desert Island attended the annual nautical and costume ball which was given at the Bar Harbor Club tonight for the benefit of the Mount Desert Island Hospital.

An analysis of the elective subjects chosen by candidates for the entering freshman class of Fordham College discloses that the objectives of high school graduates are oriented more to a long-range attitude on the basic values of their college careers than they were a year ago.

THE musical riches of South America, particularly its treasures of folk material, are still partially and imperfectly known by most North Americans. One album of records -- or even a dozen albums -- cannot bring us the enlightenment we should like, but each new release adds a little more concrete knowledge.

The arguments of the advocates of peace at any price seem to rest upon three main premises. These are (1) that if Hitler subdues Russia he will be content with the conquest of half a world, (2) that no matter how great the material aid we give to Great Britain, she is doomed to defeat, and (3) that in organizing ourselves to preserve freedom abroad we will lose our own democracy at home.

WITH completion next January of the reconstruction of eleven miles of the Hutchinson River Parkway in Westchester County a bottleneck and many hazards on a main route between New York City and New England will have been eliminated.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 23 -- The historic Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, scene of hundreds of memorable tournaments since its establishment more than half a century ago, is the setting this week-end for a round robin mixed doubles tourney which serves a double purpose as regards the active interest and participation of the club members.

THE International Dance Festival at Jacob's Pillow, near Lee, Mass., will give its next to the last pair of week-end programs on Friday and Saturday afternoons at 4:45. The dancer on this occasion will be Barton Mumaw, and his program will consist of the following numbers: "Where-e'er You Walk" (Handel), "Serenade" (Scarlatti).

Strong efforts to relieve financial burdens of Brooklyn College students during the last year were made by the Faculty-Student Committee on Employment and Financial Aid, according to the committee's report made public yesterday by Harry D. Gideonse, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- An Agriculture Department inventory of the country's food supplies, both, on hand and now being grown or processed, indicated today that with a few possible exceptions there should be plenty for the next twelve months.

President Roosevelt's recent order blocking many types of transactions in which certain foreign countries or their nations are interested covers real estate deals, and brokers are watching with interest the effect of this executive action on future property transactions.

HOLLYWOOD. THE short, stocky one with the open-minded face is Lou Costello. The tall one with the pair of loaded dice in his pocket is Bud Abbott. Put the two together -- as destiny, fortunately, did -- and you have Hollywood's best-selling double feature, the zany comedy team now running second only to Bank Night in luring Mr. and Mrs. Public into the nation's movie houses.

A new women's world mark for the Swiss match, a small bore rifle event, was set by Miss Eleanor Dunn of New York City, Connecticut State women's champion, at the Poughkeepsie Rifle Club range. Miss Dunn scored twenty-three consecutive bull's-eyes, breaking the record of twenty held by Mrs. John R. Cole of Minnesota.

Trading in cotton was extremely quiet in the short session yesterday, with the list generally reflecting a reactionary trend. In the first hour of trading, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange established their low marks for the day with net recessions of 10 to 16 points, but the list subsequently steadied and closed at net declines of 2 to 9 points for the session.

THERE is no doubt about the attitude of most of the citizens at large on one important issue now before the nation. High and low, far and near, rich and poor, doctor, lawyer and Indian chief are for Larry MacPhail, Lippy Leo Durocher and the Dauntless Dodgers to win that National League pennant. Down with those Cardinals! Durocher's Dandies are The People's Choice.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Bears lost a battle of home runs to Rochester today, 5 to 3, but with second-place Montreal bowing Newark's lead of six games was unchanged.

BUFFALO, Aug. 23 -- The University of Buffalo's library science course, established over 20 years ago, will resume on a reorganized basis when the university opens next month. The course, given in collaboration with the Grosvenor and Buffalo Public Libraries, is under the leadership of Joseph B. Rounds, recently appointed director of the course as successor to the late Dr. Augustus H. Shearer, who established it in 1919.

Ben Fidd, the veteran watchman of the Chelsea piers, who sailed the seas that washed the shores in all parts of the world, paid a visit to the Battery sea wall yesterday accompanied by his grandson, Ben Fidd 3d, who usually accompanies him on his rambles.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- Great Britain took two steps today to help China in resistance to Japan. The Government of Burma was urged to abolish its 1 per cent ad valorem tax on goods for China crossing Burma. The Board of Trade moved to control trade between Britain and Japanese-occupied China.

AT SEA WITH THE ATLANTIC FLEET -- Life aboard a man of war in the current emergency runs the full range from battle-station alerts to the homely habits of men trained to live at sea, interspersed with traditions which date from frigate days.

TRENTON, N.J -- In the northern part of New Jersey is Stokes Forest, a vacation spot situated on the edge of the Kittatinny Mountains. Beneath the shade of its hardwoods and conifers run sparkling brooks and small streams.

500,000 JOBS: One of Washington's busiest executives is the white-haired handsome Federal Security Administrator, Paul V. McNutt. The agencies under his wing handle the important program of training defense workers, analyzing the labor market, finding jobs for those displaced by priority demands, the silk shortage, etc.

PANAMA, R.P. -- After more than five weeks of operation it is now possible to begin to measure some of the effects of the American "Black List" in Latin America, and it is evident that thus far the benfits exceed the disadvantages. It may be "The Proclaimed List" officially, but south of the Rio Grande it is the "Lista Negra Americana," and the inconvenience of being on it is the same regardless of the name.

FOR a moment Paul and Grace Hartman just waited, listening to the water slapping briskly against their stone pier down below. Then Grace began to describe the new house they were going to build off King's Point on Long Island Sound.

OMAHA, Aug. 23 -- Since the passage of the lease-lend and parity loan bills, the farmers' relative position in the national economy has been growing rapidly better. So far his contribution to national defense and aid to Britain has been one of profit rather than sacrifice.

LONDON, Aug. 1 NOW that the Polish documentary film, "The White Eagle" (made in London for our first ally under the working title, "A Nation in Exile"), has let the cat out of the bag, it seems futile to deny that the studio in which "Goodbye Mr. Chips" and "Major Barbara" was made has had its share of attention from our German visitors.

VICHY, France, Aug. 23 -- While in the occupied zone measures have been announced by both the French and occupying authorities to stamp out Communist disorders, there was an obvious effort to tighten police regulations and to check in this zone outbreaks of violence of another sort.

After your maid has finished that trying business of removing the Summer chintz and getting the Winter furniture covers out of the moth balls she may feel more like putting up with you for another six months or so if her uniform wardrobe is refurbished.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 23 -- The African Meteor, costing about $4,500,000, was launched today at the yard of the Ingalls Shipbuilding Company at Pascagoula, Miss. When outfitted, the vessel will be one of the most luxurious afloat.

What is all this talk about a "crisis in modern education"? From all sides we hear criticism of schools and colleges, as though the problems of our time called for aims and methods in education different from those of the past and for either new habits of mind or new knowledge.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Resolutions commending President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull for "their courageous attitude in the conduct of our foreign affairs" were adopted today by the Young Democratic Clubs of America.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- This city, fifth largest municipality in the State, is preparing for residential, industrial and commercial expansion in line with indications of increased realty activity, Thomas S. Burke, president of the Yonkers Chapter of the Westchester County Realty Board, declared today.

MANY fine restaurants build their reputations about a "specialite de la maison" -- one food which they prepare superbly well. And a specialite for your own maison is a practically sure-fire means of giving your menus for bang-up occasions a personality all their own, and of creating both for yourself and your parties an atmosphere -- that precious but indefinable something for which women cheerfully spend their all.

IT would be hard to discover questions more deserving of the well-worn epithet "vexed" than those which Chard Powers Smith has chosen as the central theme of this big, line novel; fine both in the colloquial and in the strictly critical sense and richly big in its wide-embracing humanity.

BIRD of the Wilderness," Vincent Sheean's new novel, might easily be a chapter out of "Personal History." This doesn't mean that it is an autobiographical book -- it may be or may not be -- but its mood and its content are those of a man looking back upon his own youth.

Alfred E. Smith will head a national committee of grandparents, to be known as "Esteemed Grandparents," who are sponsoring a plan to mobilize the nation's grandfathers and grandmothers to assist in child war refugee work in China, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president of the United China Relief, 1790 Broadway.

WARRENTON, Va., Aug. 23 -- Show ring enthusiasts from New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington and districts throughout the State will gather here next Saturday and on Labor Day for the two-day Warrenton Horse Show, often designated "the hunter show of America," which on this occasion will be the forty-second annual exhibition in the long series.

IN the decorating field there is probably nothing else quite so much fun as doing a child's room. The thought of soft bright colors, storybook designs and small-scale furniture makes most adults dissolve in a wave of pixie sentiment. But the trouble is this may not be what the child in question wants at all.

KITCHENER, Ont. -- An American who knows our own Pennsylvania "Dutch" country around Lancaster, Allentown and Harrisburg has an odd sensation as he enters Kitchener, here in the central section of Western Ontario.
There were 13,578 Brooklyn rooters at Ebbets Field yesterday and every one of them was cheering Doc Prothro's cellar-dwelling Phillies.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- Lefty Lee Grissom, an erratic southpaw, who until he downed the Giants a week ago couldn't beat any one this year, did a good job on the Cardinals at Shibe Park today, even though he needed relief in the ninth.

The current buying spree by consumers in durable goods is the prelude to still larger gains in soft goods lines during the remaining four months of this year, according to views expressed in important distribution quarters last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Rear Admiral H.G. Bowen, technical aide to Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, was designated today by Colonel Knox to take possession of the plant of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company and to proceed at once to the resumption of the construction of ships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Two domestic beet sugar organizations urged the Committee for Reciprocity Information today to grant no concessions to Cuban sugar producers in a contemplated supplementary trade agreement between the island and this country.

C.S. ARCHER, an Englishman who knows China and flying, has fashioned from his knowledge, of both a tale of adventure and mystery, spiced with humor and mild irony. Written in unpretentious prose, the narrative is swift and vivid, seldom permitting interest to flag.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Dissolution of a half-billion dollar intermediate holding company in the $3,000,0000,000 system of the Electric Bond and Share Company was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the "death sentence" provision of the Holding Company Act.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- In contrast to the former motorized blitz campaigns fought by the German armies in this war, the Russian campaign is proving to be essentially a "war of masses." In this war the mysterious "Soviet Mensch," or "Soviet Man," is putting up a fierce and tenacious resistance that has surprised not only the Germans themselves but foreign observers as well.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) -- It is costing two Southern California aircraft manufacturers from half a million dollars a year to nearly eight times that much to build airplanes for the government, they told a Senate committee investigating the national defense program.

LAST week in these pages we reported the details of the fifth annual Mozart Festival to be given in Asheville, N.C., from Thursday to next Sunday. In the fourth paragraph we mentioned a production in English of "Die Entfuehrung aus dem Serail."

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Mr. R.L. Duffus, in his otherwise generous review of "Diary and Letters of Josiah Gregg" (July 20, 1941), seems to attribute to me, instead of to the editor, Maurice Garland Fulton, the gathering of all the new Gregg materials which make this an important book.

Home owners, amateur gardeners, professional men and advanced students in horticulture will have opportunities to take courses in planning, planting and caring for gardens in the New York Botanical Garden's Fall and Winter studies, several of which are being given here for the first time.

OF all the works in Martha Graham's repertoire, "Punch and The Judy," which she created for the recent Bennington Festival, tops the list for sheer charm. Ordinarily, in these days, that is a serious accusation to make against a work of art, for like whimsy and fantasy, charm in the arts has acquired reprehensible connotations.

Augustin Huneeus, general representative of the Chilean Line in the United States, announced yesterday that because of the growth of passenger trade between the United States and South America the line would expand its office facilities here and open a new headquarters devoted exclusively to passenger business.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Hartwick College has taken steps to bring into more general use the resources of its Willard E. Yager Museum of the Indian of the Upper Susquehanna Valley. Beginning next year all students majoring in history will be required to take a course to "The Civilization of Early Man."

The Army of the United States now numbers 1,572,000 officers and troops. Among the men in olive drab are 693,000 trainees and 258,000 National Guardsmen. Last week the War Department announced that 200,000 of those trainees and guardsmen would be released by Christmas and that the rest of. them, depending on how the world crisis shaped up, would be allowed to go home after fourteen to eighteen months in the camps.

An authentic feature of the old-fashioned American way of life -- of which much is being heard today -- is the rocking chair. Recently revived, it ranks with other native home furnishings, such as the Windsor chair, the highboy and the butterfly table, as a typically American expression.

This story of modern Greece, told with a quiet charm, gains in significance from the times, for though there is nothing in the book about the war, the place names are those we have read in the headlines, and the author has preserved in her pages a picture of the peaceful life of simple country folk as it existed before the horror of the recent campaigns.

Continuing its policy adopted three years ago of exploring the vocational values of the various fields within the traditional liberal arts curriculum and seeking to make those values practically available to the students, the New York University Washington Square College of Arts and Science will inaugurate three new curricula this Fall, it was revealed by Dean Charles Maxwell McConn in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase made public yesterday.

Much more significant than the eleven-year record established by United States exports in the first half of 1941, or even than the fact that the six-month total exceeded that of 1940 by only 1.6 per cent, is the degree to which American export trade is becoming dependent upon war materials exported to a relatively few markets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A plan of major eastern petroleum distributors to provide the public with all the gasoline it wants for the Labor Day week-end, without interfering with the 10 per cent curtailment of gasoline consumption on the Eastern Seaboard ordered by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, was announced today by Ralph K. Davies, Acting Petroleum Coordinator for national defense.

A total of 106 new local housing authorities were established during the first six months of 1941, bringing the aggregate number of such bodies empowered to conduct slum clearance and low-rent housing programs under the supervision of the USHA on July 1 to 623.

IN his efforts to make the American people understand what a Nazi victory in this war could mean the President might well take a few minutes of one of his press conferences to recommend two books as must reading.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mixed cheers, boos and hand clapping greeted Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada today as he arrived at a sports stadium where 10,000 Canadian troops were assembled for a field day and inspection.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: THE commendable interest which several of your contributors have lately shown in Basic English leads us to remark that -- Professor Ogden's auxiliary language is not nearly basic enough.
A NEW bureau to further the careers of young American singers and players, the Record Concerts Corporation, has been formed.

DURING the past few years there have appeared a surprisingly large number of popular outlines of "the law," and if we assume that their publication was in response to a public demand for enlightenment as to our legal system, it would offer reassuring evidence that "the law" is, at least in this country, still taken seriously and as something of consequence in the everyday affairs of life.

AS the armies of Hitler and the defenders of Leningrad face each other in a deadly struggle for survival, a young musician of that city, rather famous has put into rehearsal at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow his new version of that greatest of Russian operas, which seems curiously destined to raise its voice in time Of national crisis -- Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff."

JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 -- Legislative action taken in Syria and Lebanon recently in conformity with the British-Free French authorities, has now had the effect of placing those countries on the same economic basis as Palestine, British officials said here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Since the war started two years ago it has become increasingly apparent that only machines can defeat machines, and United States policy in consequence has been predicated upon the assumption that this country eventually can produce more airplanes, tanks and other instruments of battle than Germany.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- A tentative settlement of the four-day strike which has crippled this city's street car and bus transportation system, was arranged today through the direct intervention of W.D. Mahon, 80-year-old international president of the A.F. of L.'s Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes.

Lloyd Harbor laces one of its biggest week-ends of the Summer over the coming Labor Day period. In addition to the scores of veteran cruiser skippers who over the years have been cutting grooves in Long Island Sound by their voyages back and forth to Lloyd's, two club fleets have scheduled three day rendezvous there.

Progress is reported by the soldier-artists' exhibition committee. Miss Emily A. Francis, director of Contemporary Arts and Collectors of American Art, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street, has announced that the first show made up of work by artists now in the Army and Navy will open in the galleries at this address on Sept. 15, continuing through the remainder of the month.

TO raise funds to aid persons suffering from consumption, "Lucha Antituberculosa" (Fight Against Tuberculosis) and the double-barred cross which is the universal anti-tuberculosis symbol have been overprinted, variously in blue or black or red, on Spanish Morocco pictorial postage and air-mail stamps which, so far as is known here, have not yet been released without the overprinting.
IT seems timely to comment on a matter which has bad comparatively little public discussion, and which is close to the interest of our emerging cultural pattern.

"THE VILLAGE THAT LEARNED TO READ" is not just one more book about boys and girls in another part of the world, described against an authentic background. It is a spontaneous, unforced story of natural children in an interesting and picturesque country, a story which the author has quite evidently enjoyed writing.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Whatever developments have occurred on the Eastern front in the past twenty-four hours have not been revealed by the German Supreme Command. Today's communique had the familiar phrase, "The operations are proceeding' satisfactorily on the Eastern front."

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity advanced moderately last week. The index rose to 130.9 for the week ended Aug. 16 from 130.6 (revised) for the week previous. It stood at 108.4 for the week ended Aug. 17, 1940.

ROCKPORT, Mass. IT'S a subject about which experts in mass recreation compile no statistics. It's a matter unconsidered by family physicians who prescribe a little change of some sea air. But the one-time Summer boarding house of the New England coast has had its face lifted, its glands tuned up and has taken on the whole alphabet of vitamins.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Haltal, from the Woodvale Farm, sprang something of a surprise by winning the thirty-ninth Saratoga Handicap today, driving home first by a head on the post, with the Circle M Ranch's Big Pebble striding powerfully but unavailingly alongside.

Miss Helene Rains of the Women's Swimming Association and Mike Priano of the Flatbush Boys Club shared the spotlight in the big swimming meet sponsored by the Department of Parks in the Flushing Meadow Amphitheatre last nigrht.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 23 -- Philip Mallory, with his International Class sloop Mystic Jr., and Freeman Meinertz, with his Atlanta Bobkat. came through a squall to win today in the Riverside Yacht Club's annual regatta, the sixteenth of the Yacht Racing Association series on the Sound.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 23 -- While the Mexican telephone strike has been declared legal and therefore subject to official mediation, the prospect of a series of strikes in all the industries of Mexico was raised today by a statement of the Mexican Federation of Labor that it would ask the Ministry of Economy to intervene for a revision of all labor contracts in the country.

BUENOS AIRES -- The dedication of the equestrian statue of Julio Argentino Roca (1843-1914), twice Argentina's President, has now definitely been set for Oct. 19 under a governmental decree just signed, and the 5-centavos stamp in commemoration is expected to be released on that date.

A package full of zoo-educational tour, behind-the-scene investigations, animal rides and the handling of some of the snakes and smaller mammals -- designed to attract children and their teachers to the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx, will be offered with the opening of school this Fall.

In a list of cash prices for thirty-one commodities published daily in this paper, only one shows a lower price today than a year ago. Most are steeply higher. Cotton, which is burdened with a huge surplus, is nearly double what it was a year ago; wheat, another surplus commodity, is up 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Senate Finance Committee closed hearings today on the $3,226,000,000 revenue bill with indications that its members favored a lowering of the income tax exemptions for individuals.

JUST inside the door, one absorbed little girl, dark braids tied with pink, kept wiping a patch of floor with a wet rag, then squeezing the rag into a toy washtub; near by two children busily snipped scraps of brown paper into a saucer -- "To feed the cow," they explained (as any intelligent person might have known, seeing their barnyard of blocks stocked with toy animals).

TUCSON, Ariz. -- Indian and Mexican school children -- they thickly populate Arizona's rural schools -- know about the dime stores but they can't get to them because distances are so great. And if they did they couldn't afford to buy the trinkets so dear to their child hearts.

Reorders exceeded expectations in the wholesale markets last week, running considerably ahead of the corresponding week last year, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.
BOSTON, Aug 23 (AP) -- The Reds, who refuse to be counted out in their long-shot bid for the National League pennant, today walloped the Braves, 7 to 2, for their twelfth victory in fourteen games.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 22 -- One of the most important problems in the rebuilding of the post-war world will be the application of the newest developments in scientific knowledge to the everyday affairs of man, said Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, in a statement issued today in connection with the opening of the institute tomorrow night on the Williams College campus.

More courses in Latin-American and Canadian history and culture are suggested in Director Broderick Cohen's report on the evening and extension division of Hunter College for the scholastic year 1940-41. The courses recommended would be part of a comprehensive program of timely studies, including meteorology, climatology, maps and map interpretation, bacteriology, blood chemistry, clinical pathology and foreign languages, including Portuguese.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Consolidation of the Tarrytown and Dobbs Ferry Hospitals and the development of a new plant on the former David Luke Estate here were proposed yesterday in a prospectus prepared for the boards of the two institutions by Edwin A. Salmon of New York, a hospital architect and member of the New York City Planning Commission.

FIFTEEN 1942 models -- five in each of the Nash "600," Ambassador Eight and Ambassador Six lines -- were introduced last week in Hot Springs, Va., at a convention of Nash distributors, who sold all 1941 cars the company was able to build.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 23 -- Organization of an anti-aircraft searchlight battalion, utilizing the combined strength of sixty 800,000,000 candlepower lights and capable of spotting airplanes over a 600-square-mile sector, was disclosed today as four searchlight batteries from anti-aircraft coast artillery regiments garrisoned here were ordered on special duty for experimental work.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 23 -- President Winfred G. Leutner of Western Reserve University announced today the establishment in Cleveland College of the Personnel Research Institute, made possible by its partial subvention by the Thomas H. White Fund and the aid of business firms and industries which, will make use of the institute's services.

"THE Monroe Doctrine and the Growth of the Western Hemisphere Solidarity" is reprinted by the H. W. Wilson Company ($1.25). Dr. Richard K. Showman, Graduate Assistant in History, University of Wisconsin, is listed as compiler and Dr. Lyman S. Judson, head of the Department of Speech, Kalamazoo College, as compiler and editor.

ABOUT the only time non-flying people think of airplane landing gears is when the newspapers recount how Pilot So-and-So was forced to make a "belly landing" when his landing gear was damaged while taking off, or his wheels locked while retracted. Otherwise, landing gears, like the next breath, are taken for granted.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Three months have passed since the Germans seized Crete, but deadly and stealthy warfare still is being waged on that rugged Mediterranean island by a lost legion of Australians, New Zealanders and Britons --men who didn't catch the boats when the British withdrew.

IN "Country Schoolma'am" Mrs. Lutes draws again on the reminiscences'so delightfully set forth in "A Country Kitchen" and "Home Grown," this time the story of her first year of teaching in the country schools of Michigan at the end of the Eighties.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- An output of Army tanks which will equal the value of $1,000,000,000 in 1942 is called for in a plan made known today by the Office of Production Management.

Practically any market report of the last two weeks would serve for yesterday. Shares on the New York Stock Exchange were firm, dull and mixed and showed no disposition to go anywhere. Volume for the two-hour session was 150,560 shares, and of the 425 issues traded, 162 rose, 143 fell and 120 did neither.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Still another sensational speed-boat accomplishment was added by George Schrafft of Westbury, L.I., today to his long string since the regatta season began. The 21-year-old Harvard graduate who, a week ago, won the national sweepstakes at Red Bank, brought his cream-colored Chrissie IV here and, in winning the 225 event, also gained the John Charles Thomas Trophy for 1941.

TO this day "the Jules Verne story" stands as something apart in the lingo of publishers, despite the bold inventions of the earlier ,H.G. Wells and the sensational crudities of Edgar Rice Burroughs. Yet Verne was by no means an innovator in the literary exploration of the fantastic and the scientific.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- Informed observers said tonight that the tension between Britain and Iran had reached a critical point and predicted Axis military intervention, if ,the tension reached the breaking point.

A full day devoted to basketball brought the fourth annual Eastern Coaching School clinic to a close at Manhattan Beach yesterday. Clair Bee, the director of the school, termed it "the biggest ever" and called it an unqualified success."

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today at the close of a general advance for the week that was sharpest in the lamb trade and carried hogs back to the four-year peak levels established in July.

LABOR DAY instead of sounding the knell of vacations, has become the tocsin for more holidays -- Fall holidays. Increasingly of late years has this season been growing in favor among those who wish to avoid the crowds of early August, or plan a special sort of trip.

ARECITAL by John Charles Thomas Saturday will conclude the Chautauqua Institution's annual music season. Other events in the final week will be a performance of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" by the Nine o'clock Singers and a concert by the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra, with Mischa Mischakoff, violinist, as soloist, and Albert Stoessel as conductor.

Mrs. Maine's Guests Mrs. Abigail Maine is sleeping on a cot in her kitchen this Summer, and mighty glad she is to do it, for the rooms of her twin white cottage are profitably rented to Summer people.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 23 -- Sixty men and women with professional interests in inter-American relations and affairs have just completed a nine-weeks Summer institute for Intensive training in Portuguese and Spanish at the University of Wyoming.

HYDE PARK. IF a pell-mell driver in a small touring car scoots up the Albany Post Road through Hyde Park these sunny Summer days it may be the President. If his vehicle is hotly pursued by a long, open automobile with intent, panamaed men draped over either side, eyes boring straight ahead -- it is the President.

Investigation of the causes of the fire that wrecked the super-structure of the war-stranded Finnish freighter Aurora in the upper Hudson River early Friday morning was being continued yesterday by FBI agents and other Federal and city officials pending the official inquiry at the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, 45 Broadway, at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Escorted by six tanks and 1,000 cavalrymen, the body of Major Gen. Adna Romanza. Chaffee was carried into Arlington National, Cemetery today on a flag-draped artillery caisson and buried beside the grave of General Chaffee's father, Lieut. Gen. Adna R. Chaffee, who once was Chief of Staff of the Army.

BASEBALL The Cubs downed the Dodgers, 7-1, but Brooklyn still tops the National League by a game and a half because the second-place Cardinals also were beaten, falling before the Phils, 4-2. The Giants defeated the Pirates, 5-3, then bowed, 4-3.

The cause has been the familiar one in past years, but not recently, namely, the use of non-stock parts.

Although the C.I.O. national convention is still more than two months off, its approach has brought wide speculation in labor circles about the possibility that John L. Lewis and the left-wing elements in the C.I.O. will come to a parting of the ways at the convention after a two-year alliance based on common opposition to President Roosevelt's foreign and domestic policies.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 23 -- While the co-medalists were eliminated in the opening round, John Dolan of Crestmont, Myron Friedman of Jumping Brook, Robert Linehan of Norwood and Roger O'Connor of Crestmont advanced to the semi-final round of the Jersey shore invitation golf tournament at the Norwood Country Club today.

Sales of Manhattan real estate during July in the open market numbered 285, the largest number for any single month since the Real Estate Board of New York began compiling statistics about seven years ago. These properties had a sales value of $12,982,890.

Citing facts and figures revealing the overcrowded conditions in Washington, Stephen F. Voorhees, first vice president of the Merchants Association of New York, urged over the radio last week "a decentralization of government agencies."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Calvin C. Laney, father of the Rochester parks system, died today at the age of 91. He retired as Commissioner of Parks in 1928 after forty years of constant service in which he was associated with the late John Dunbar, horticulturist.

HYDE PARK, N.Y. Aug. 23 -- The Duke of Kent, youngest brother of King George VI, in the United States on a visit symbolical of Anglo-American friendship, was the guest of President and Mrs. Roosevelt at the temporary White House tonight.

MANCHESTER, VT. THE Southern Vermont Artists' opened their fifteenth annual exhibition yesterday at the Burr and Burton Gymnasium in Manchester. It will continue through Labor Day. The exhibition this year is somewhat smaller than usual.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Bill Harris, 41-year-old pitcher-coach, outlasted 19-year-old Chet Kehn, Montreal's freshman mound star, in a pitchers' battle today to give Jersey City a 4-to-2 victory over the Royals.
HOLLYWOOD. ERNEST HEMINGWAY'S "For Whom the Bell Tolls" will reach the screen as a classic love story without political implications, Louis Bromfield, who is adapting it, disclosed this week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology which pioneered in advanced education in the field of weather forecasting in this country announced today the creation of a separate department of meteorology in the graduate school and plans for the offering of basic courses in the undergraduate division.

PLAINFIELD, Vt., Aug. 23 -- After three years of operating in its present location and under its present educational philosophy, Goddard College was found to be carrying out its aims in practically all particulars, according to a survey made available to the trustees at their annual August meeting.

It is a puzzle to figure out whether the author takes his youthful musicians seriously or not. His title sounds as if he might be poking a little fun at them, and it would be nice to think that he knows what a silly bunch of adolescents they are, from Beginning to end.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 23 -- The fatal shooting of Private Theodore J. Mazur, 23 years old, of 71 Hope Avenue, Passaic, one of seven soldiers who escaped from the Fort Dix guard house, is being investigated by civil police authorities.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S announcement last week that Pan American Airways would operate a ferry service between the United States and the Middle East is a good, if somewhat spectacular, example of the value of commercial airlines in time of war.

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Champion Pillicoc Reverie, black standard poodle bitch owned by the Pilicoc Kennels of Mrs. Milton Erlanger of Elberon, N.J., annexed her sixth best-in-show title today in the eighth annual exhibition of the North Shore Kennel Club at the Myopia Hunt Club.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Long-term measures providing the best defense of Syracuse or any other city, are, surprisingly enough, the same required for a sound city plan, according to conclusions arrived at in "A Study of the Theory of Defense Planning for the City of Syracuse" completed by three graduate students in the department of architecture of the College of Fine Arts, Syracuse University.

"Free France" is often referred to as a loose political movement more or less successfully taking shape for the definite purpose of supporting the British Empire in its fight with Germany and redeeming France from Nazi control. That description is accurate to this extent: All Frenchmen aware that the liberation of France can only be secured through a British victory naturally turn toward General Charles de Gaulle.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Browns won their eleventh game in the last sixteen, excluding two ties, by defeating Philadelphia today, 6 to 1, but remained in the cellar.

Reporting that the fascist party holds firm control over an Italy suffering increasing hardships of war, Malcolm Hooper, Second Secretary and Commercial Attache at the American Embassy in Rome, arrived at La Guardia Field aboard the Atlantic Clipper at 3:40 P.M. yesterday for a two-month visit before going back to his post.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- More than 1,000 persons are expected to attend the outdoor boxing carnival to be held here Friday evening on the grounds of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club for the benefit of the William Carey Camp of the Boys Club of New York.

WITH sales totals still topping last year's figures by wide margins, retail interests at the close of the week were weighing the possible effects of the installment credit regulations issued by the Federal Reserve Board.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- As the British filed into their motion-picture houses by the thousands this week and saw the pictures of the historic sea meeting between Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Roosevelt many pf the more thoughtful ones began to realize that they had to reappraise the entire question of Anglo-American relations.
Urban real estate foreclosures continued their steady downward trend during the first six months of this year, establishing for that period a new low record for the past fifteen years.

Lyman S. Hess, 63-year-old securities salesman and former lawyer, with a record of having swindled many elderly persons of their savings, was held by the police again yesterday, this time charged with a $66000 stock fraud committed seven years ago in a small New England city.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 23 -- The French House at Smith College is intended to become a cultural center preserving the elements of the life, art and tradition of France that remain of permanent value to the world, following the establishment of the house in 1939 for students unable to spend their junior year studying in France because of the international situation.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- The sixteenth annual Horse Show held today at the Riding Club of East Hampton was an outstanding event of the season. Southampton and East Hampton riding enthusiasts joined forces, since there is no show at Southampton this year.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Reuben Fine of New York City gained a draw in his last-round game with Dr. Walter Cruz of Rochester tonight and thereby captured the New York State Chess Association championship with a score of 8-2.

From Maine to Virginia the country auction sales of antiques reach their annual peak this month, catching the city vacationist trade coming and going. BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- In the fastest and nearest approximation of first-class tennis doubles of the week Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and Wayne Sabin of Reno, Nev., turned the tables on Donald McNeill of Oklahoma City and Frank Parker of Spring Lake today to gain the final of the national championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.

WESTBURY, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Forbes Direct, veteran pacer owned by Mrs. Fred J. Gross of Auburn, Me., made his first start of the late Summer meeting at Roosevelt Raceway a successful one tonight when he captured the first half of the $1,000 Whirlaway before 12,320 harness-horse fans.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Two new courses in religion have been added to the curriculum at Princeton University, bringing the total number of studies in religious instruction to six, according to an announcement made today.

ASUNCION -- On the occasion of the arrival of Brazil's President Getulio Vargas here on Aug. 1, Paraguay overprinted "Visita al Paraguay Agosto de 1941" (Visit to Paraguay August of 1941) on the 6-pesos postage stamp in the 1939 series which commemorated the settlement of the Chaco territorial controversy.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Win Pederson, former Minnesota star, booted a place kick with fifteen seconds of play left to give the New York Giants a 17-to-17 tie with the Green Bay Packers in a stirring exhibition, game tonight between the National Football League rivals.

Lou Nova will have to wait ten days longer for his chance to win the heavyweight championship of the world. EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- William Steinkraus of Scarsdala took the horsemanship championship as well as the open jumper rosette at the Bast Hampton Riding Club's sixteenth annual horse show today. Young Steinkraua triumphed with the big chestnut gelding, Salmo, capturing four jumping events and an equitation class for youngsters under 18 before going on to top honors.

AMENDS: President Roosevelt confessed last week to a "crime" that should keep him out of the gates of Heaven. The apparatus, according to the latest count, totals 825 pieces of land equipment and ten fireboats.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I, Aug. 23 -- Many of the members of the Summer colony and their out-of-town guests attended the large costume dinner at Woodhull House, the home of Mrs. Rodgers Denckla, for ths benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Administration lieutenants disclosed today that the new lease-lend appropriation to be asked of Congress will approximate $5,000,000,000 and will provide no funds for Soviet Russia.

BONNEVILLE, Ore., Aug. 23 -- A final settlement is near in the long controversy over whether the huge government dams on the Columbia River should be managed by an Independent agency patterned after the Tennessee Valley Authority or by a bureau in the Department of the Interior.

MEDDYBEMPS, Me., Aug. 23 -- A new kind of camp and youth project is under way here in the deep Maine woods, a few miles from the Canadian border. LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 24 -- British bomber squadrons attacked the Rhineland industrial city of Mannheim and other big Royal Air Force planes bombed docks at Havre, Dunkerque and Ostend through Friday night with destructive results, the Air Ministry reported.

Retail trade in the New York area continued active last week. Department store sales averaged more than 30 per cent ahead of a year ago. Most stores had substantial volume increases, especially in the home furnishings, fur and domestics departments.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- The season's height at White Mountain resorts was reached this weekend when hundreds of visitors arrived to remain over Labor Day.
