CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Johnny Humphries, a big blond Virginian who received his diploma from a long-term course in the bullpen, pitched his third consecutive shutout for the White Sox today as he smothered the Red Sox, 3 to 0.

Lake resort communities in the metropolitan region report the most active Summer season during the present vacation period in many years. WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- If the Vichy Government undertakes to permit German control of Martinique or any other territory in the Western Hemisphere the United States will seize and hold such territory by armed force, Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, declared in a broadcast over the Columbia system tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A thermometer may be utilized to detect the presence of deadly carbonmonoxide gas in manholes, cable vaults, excavations and other confined spaces, according to a patent (No. 2,253,187) awarded to Adolph Z. Mample of Glen Rock, N.J. The patent is assigned to the Western Union Telegraph Company, New York City.

ONE of the most important new products announced at the national photographic convention in Chicago last week was a Graflex flash synchronizer. Engineered for the Speed Graphic and similar cameras, the synchronizer, tests by the Army have proved, will operate efficiently with Supermatic and Compur-type shutters long after the point when aging batteries or low temperatures would ordinarily affect speed and timing.

Lewis C. Fralick, staff officer of the United States Customs Service and chief of the boarding division for the last three years, went through the halls of the government barge office at South Ferry last Friday saying good-bye to Customs and Immigration Department colleagues with whom he had met incoming passenger liners for many years.

LOS ANGELES, Calif -- No sooner has Santa Barbara observed the Old Spanish Days which constitute its annual August fiesta, than Los Angeles prepares to observe its birthday. It is a special occasion this year -- Los Angeles will be 160 years old.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- The twenty-fifth annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers completed by an overwhelming voice vote today the expulsion from the organization of Locals 5 and 537 of New York and 192 of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Army pointed the way today to conservation of rubber and large economies for motorists by stating that retreading and recapping of worn automobile tires had been perfected to a degree which made these processes thoroughly acceptable.

DETROIT -- Despite the fact that the plastic-body car, as typified by the recently exhibited Ford model, is still in the experimental stage, authoritative sources here express confidence that another twelve months will see the introduction of a small, low-priced automobile made of plastic substances.

ALFREDO SALMAGGI, who seldom pauses from his efforts to give New York opera of one kind or another in some theatre or other, promises a new season of "grand opera at erstwhile historical Hippodrome prices" at the Jolson Theatre beginning next Saturday evening.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 23 The government took possession tonight of the plant of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, N.J., where construction of vital naval and merchant vessels has been held up by a protracted strike.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Finns reported today that the port of Viborg was near encirclement by victorious Finnish troops, smashing southward across the Karelian Isthmus, and that an "avalanche offensive" now was being directed against its Red Army defenses.

An exceptionally brisk early Fall rental season for apartments in the New York Central residential zone in the Park Avenue area from Forty-seventh to Fifty-sixth Street is attributed by realty agents operating there to their anticipation several months ago of a trend to suites of five, six and seven rooms.

Throughout the nation's vitally important industrial plants the need for skilled men is growing daily as the tempo of defense production increases. It is estimated that by the time war-defense output reaches its peak in late 1942 some 1,000,000 trainees, ranging in age from 18 to 30 years, will be handling "skilled" jobs in America's "arsenal of democracy."

SEVERAL, years ago Judith Kelly published a mannered, supersensitive but definitely intelligent first novel which was called rather preciously "It Won't Be Flowers." Her heroine was a well-bred youngr Bostonian, sheltered and rich, who, despite a happy marriage and all the perquisites of fortune, was tormented by a social conscience.

A very good influence has hit the shoe and handbag manufacturers this year. Maybe they want to use their leather to the best advantage, maybe they want to play, safe and steer clear of questionable trimmings, or perhaps they are not in a frivolous frame of mind.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission instituted today a proceeding against the International Utilities Corporation and three subsidiary companies to show cause on Sept. 16 why they should not be prohibited from, fulfilling certain salary contracts with three individuals.

As the two-week "stop-gap" program for the full-fashioned hosiery industry came to an end yesterday, knitting mill executives expressed themselves as very much dissatisfied with the conditions surrounding the allocation of rayon yarn to the industry.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- With a diversified program of festivities and outdoor events in prospect for the next several weeks, members of society here are preparing for a busy late Summer and Autumn season. Immediate interest centers in the "Gay Nineties" dinner dance to be given at the Tuxedo Club swimming pool on Sept. 6, and the annual Tuxedo Dog Show to be held the same day on the local horse show grounds.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- Behind the dramatic fighting facade of the gigantic Russo-German War a series of diplomatic events has been taking place that, while certainly not so sensational or breath-taking as the development of the operations on the far-flung battle front, may in the end count at least as much in the final outcome of the combat with Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

AT the Estelle Newman Gallery, 66 West Fifty-fifth Street, may be seen, until Sept. 4, the final group show in the rotating Summer series. Thirteen artists are represented, in most instances by several canvases or water-colors.

LIFE'S values cannot be measured by money, nor by the criterion of power, nor by war. For years the author of this book has known this, and a more important secret that every American should cherish, if we had but the wit.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Whirlaway convincingly demonstrated his undisputed hold on the 3-year-old championship of the American turf today by galloping, with amazing ease, to victory in the $60,900 American Derby at Washington Park.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Trading in soy beans was the feature in the grain markets here today, with prices moving up to new seasonal high levels on commission-house and professional buying which disclosed a lack of pressure. The reduction in the prospective yield of corn, as indicated by a report in the Department of Agriculture on Thursday, has caused some apprehension that a downward revision in estimates on soy beans may be necessary.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 23 -- The return of Winston F.C. Guest, nine-goal star, to competition marked the continuation of test matches for the national open polo championship on the Meadow Brook Club's Belmont Field today.

THE announcement that for the first time it is now possible to produce direct, full-color, photographic prints from color transparencies has come as a surprise to many photographers. While it was well known that research into the problem had been under way for the past five years, few realized the process had been perfected and a color-printing service was about to start.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Convinced that the art of communication by writing is becoming increasingly important in the daily work of college graduates, the College of Arts and Sciences of the University of Newark will offer a new course this Fall to be called Professional Writing.

DURING and for several months after the close of the first World War a shortage of man power existed in the Pennsylvania and West Virginia steel industry. Attracted by wages of $4 a day, Southern farm Negroes moved North to enter the steel mills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Emphasizing the importance to Americans of wider and more effective teaching of all foreign languages in this country, a concerted educational campaign is getting under way on a nation-wide basis, according to an announcement by Dean Henry Grattan Doyle of The George Washington University.

The successor to Billy Conn as the light-heavyweight champion of the world will be named on Tuesday night when Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J., engages Tami Mauriello, Bronx youngster, in the star bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden.

HERMAN SHUMLIN apparently is not one to let good things get away from him. According to his general manager, Kermit Bloomgarden, the producer has signed Paul Lukas, Lucile Watson and Mady Christians, the three principal players in "Watch On the Rhine," to contracts which do not expire until May 31, 1943.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Players from Florida and the Pacific Coast led a field of seventy-eight into the third round of the twenty-fourth United States girls' lawn tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Writing in your Aug. 16 issue, A.D. Wallace emphasizes the importance of mathematics in general and of algebra in particular as a preparation in supporting our way of life. This point cannot be too strongly emphasized.

READERS of THE TIMES may already be familiar with General Sir Archibald Wavell's lectures as published in a condensed version in the Magazine section some time ago. The signal importance of the theories and views set forth in these lectures, now appearing for the first time in book form, has perhaps been made clearest by Sir John Dill, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, in his foreword to the study.

Nervous Rats It seems that the celebrated Pied Piper was right in using a shrill musical instrument to lure the rats out of Hamelin. A research report just published in Science by Clifford Morgan and James Gould of the Biological Laboratories of Harvard University reveals that while rats are practically deaf to low notes they are highly receptive to shrill ones.

IT comes as no revelation that the new season is just about ready to burst on the networks. Not with rumor and report thick in the air of new shows and new people, while the grapevine whispers darkly of certain changes in the personnel of some of radio's older favorites.

THIS is no "sealed room" murder, but something much trickier. A man is stabbed to death in the presence of three witnesses, all of whose stories agree in every particular, and each of whom admits that what he or she saw could not possibly have happened.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- The clubhouse at Bailey's Beach was a center of festivity for members of the Summer colony tonight when another in the series of subscription dances was given there. The majority of subscribers attended many dinner parties beforehand.

DELMAR, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- If any deer hunter is in the vicinity of the New York State Game Research Center at Delmar during the closed season it is respectfully suggested that he drop in and ask for Supervisor Robert Darrow.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Refugee students at Mount Holyoke College -- young women of high scholarship to whom the universities of Europe have been closed -- are proving the truth of a forecast that they would be "Europe's gift to Mount Holyoke" rather than merely the recipients of the benefactions of the college.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- The first unit in a four-part expansion plan to provide shelf space for thirty years to come, the new rare-book library of Harvard University will be ready soon for the transfer of some 100,000 of,the world's most precious volumes from their present place in the Treasure Room of Widener Library.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Ministry of Information disclosed today that the convoy that Prime Minister Winston Churchill passed and reviewed en route home from his sea meeting with President Roosevelt was making "one of the biggest deliveries of American arms and food ever sent to Britain."

AFTER the bustle of the opening performance had subsided last April, quite a number of Gotham play-goers regarded Lillian Hellman's "Watch on the Rhine" as the foremost theatrical achievement of the season.

While the policy of barring trade association executives from certain activities in the defense program set-up has drawn criticism from some of them, others are beginning to believe that, from the standpoint of self-protection, trade group officials should endorse this rule.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- Bernard Samuel, 61-year-old Republican President of the City Council, became Acting Mayor of Philadelphia today, succeeding Robert E. Lamberton, who died last night at his Summer home in Loganport, N.J.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Aug. 24 -- Red Army troops under General I.A. Koneff, striving to retake the town of Gomel, are "bringing to a successful conclusion" one of the biggest counter-attacks yet undertaken by the Russians, according to Soviet reports.

The "greatest battle in history" yesterday closed its ninth week. On a front almost a thousand miles long, from Leningrad on the Baltic to Odessa on the Black Sea, perhaps 9,000,000 men were locked in sanguinary struggle. The troops of Adolf Hitler were still pushing forward in the third phase of the invasion launched last June.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 23 -- A big step toward solution of the Argentine shipping shortage has been taken with purchase of sixteen Italian merchantmen, totaling more than 88,000 tons, at present laid up in Argentine ports.

ONE of the direct manifestations of the Italian Renaissance was the inordinate rush to publish the atlas of the celebrated Alexandrian, Claudius Ptolemy. In the Middle Ages this work had come to be looked upon as the final authority on geography.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Two public utterances this week -- one by President Roosevelt and the other by William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management -- amounted to official acknowledgment of a growing concern within the Administration of the lackadaisical attitude among the American people regarding their stake in the European war.

The solution of income tax problems arising from transactions in capital assets not infrequently turns upon one's concept of the operation under review. IT takes a major world event like the Roosevelt-Churchill meeting to rouse the warring radio waves to oratorical heights. A day or two before the ocean conference was made known, things were growing stale on short waves. There wasn't any snap to the talks from Europe.

Predictions are being made by Long Island developers that the Fall demand for small homes will be fully as large as has been shown during the Summer season in all of the popular residential centers in Queens and Nassau Counties. Builders in those localities are also predicting that the buying and building volume of homes throughout Long Island for the present year will exceed all former records.

Two men, one of whom is believed to be the leader of a ring of hotel robbers, were held by police yesterday, charged with robbing the Hotel Berkshire, 21 East Fifty-second Street, on Friday and the Hotel Earle, 103 Waverly Place, on July 31.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- It is said here by competent neutral observers that the campaign in Russia has halted once again. The primary German purpose today seems to be to prevent stabilization of the front; the Russians' purpose, as is natural, lies in the very opposite direction.

A special Scottish express pulled into London's busy Kings Cross station last Tuesday morning. Out stepped a stocky sunburned man wearing a blue nautical uniform and a peaked yachting cap. A crowd of Cabinet Ministers, generals, admirals, reporters and others rushed toward him.

Dr. Bowman, whose "Tales From a Finnish Tupa" is one of the most delightful folk tale collections published in recent years, has now woven together the legends of the five Great Nations of the Iroquois Indians in a continuous narrative.

DESPITE the talk about American composers, last season fewer works by native-born composers were played by the country's principal symphony orchestras than were performed by those orchestras during the season before.

Prices of cotton futures were erratic in day-to-day trading last week. Gains made in the early part of the period, however, more than offset the losses registered later, and, at the end of the session on Saturday, prices of active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange had made net advances of 27 to 35 points for the period.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- The German radio tonight bitterly attacked Russia for jamming its German language news transmissions by filling in pauses between news items with heckling on the same wave lengths and promised "fitting counter-measures."

Trends of production and corporation earnings before taxes must be examined to throw light on prospects of dividends as defense work and lease-lend transactions proceed, according to the current issue of The Exchange, magazine of the New York Stock Exchange.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 24 -- A seven-point program to strengthen the democratic form of government was presented by District Attorney Dewey of New York City tonight before the opening session of the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations.

Declaring that the destruction of a church could be compared to the interment of a person, the Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard celebrated a service for the dead yesterday morning in the chapel of the French Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit, 229 East Sixty-first Street.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 -- The youngest team in history to win the men's national doubles tennis championship today became the first to carry off the title a second year in succession since George Lott and Lester Stoefen repeated in 1934.
Reviewing the latest returns of current fishing contests reflects to some degree the activity along the coast of our salt water contingent.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The Board of Trade's index of commodity prices in July, based on 1930 as 100, stood at 153.2, compared with 152.4 in June, 139.7 a year ago and 98.1 in July, 1939.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 25 -- Although, the Japanese press continues to expatiate on the alleged Anglo-American manoeuvres to "encircle" Japan with the "ABCDS alliance" -- meaning American, British, Chinese, Dutch and Soviet -- the main attention this morning is concentrated, for the moment, on Saturday's conference in Washington between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Ambassador Kichisaburo Nomura.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- Promulgated as a law this week-end, the Palestine income tax ordinance will come into force on Sept. 1. Inhabitants will be liable to pay on a graduated scale that rises to about 30 per cent for incomes over u3,000 annually.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The stock markets have just finished an erratic and unexciting week. Starting off on a confident note, they gradualy succumbed to the shadow of the Russian war.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- One by one the "few" remaining Soviet bridgeheads over the Dnieper in the Southern Ukraine were being destroyed by the might of German arms, according to official German reports tonight.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, that "there is a sort of nostalgia today for a more Christian way of life."

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24 -- Trade and speculative buying of cotton expanded from time to time last week, induced mainly by spread of inflationary ideas and on mid-week rumors that the President would sign the freezing bill contrary to general expectations.

Campbell, had some beautiful broiled brook trout for luncheon, and Mort Mahony, the master of the mutuels, was helping him to destroy the trout. Between them was Francis P. Dunne, the assistant to the Racing Secretary. Somehow he had fished in the platter and landed the largest of the trout on his plate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Americans were warned to expect changes in the order of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System restricting installment credit, in a statement today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Second thoughts on the Roosevelt-Churchill conference have not changed financial London's opinion that more important decisions were reached than those covered in the eight-point declaration. The propaganda value of the declaration of war aims is undeniable, but it is secondary to the actions that must be taken to win the war.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- The street car and bus strike which halted service on the city-owned street railway system at 4 A.M. Wednesday ended at 4 P.M. today after the A.F. of L. Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America had ratified an agreement for a system-wide election Tuesday among the 5,500 employes.

The completion of a comprehensive plan for the Manhattan approaches of the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel was announced yesterday by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs. Traffic will enter and leave the new tube with a minimum of interference with normal surface traffic in the congested riverfront areas.

VICHY, France, Aug. 24 -- While in Vichy Pierre Pucheu, Minister of the Interior, was accusing Communists "under the cover of patriotism of provoking incidents between the civilian population and the German authority in the occupied zone," news came from Paris of another anti-Nazi act.
I AM pained to think of what nice people in Newport, Providence and the general Narragansett Bay area are going to say about Christopher La Farge and his new novel, "The Wilsons."*

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, instructed local draft boards today to be ready to see that soldiers who are released from active duty this Autumn get their old jobs as promised, and that others are placed as soon as possible.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- Reorganization of the State Employment Advisory Council was announced today by Frieda S. Miller, industrial commissioner. The reorganization of the council, in existence since 1933 was necessary, Miss Miller said, because many of the members resigned from previous boards because of personal burdens.

AMSTERDAM, (via Berlin), Aug. 24 -- Continental European stock markets, despite temporary setbacks, showed last week a continued strong undertone, this being mainly due to great liquidity and to curtailed investment and speculative horizons.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. MacCracken's speech at the America First rally last Wednesday night illustrates clearly the fundamental illusions of the isolationists. He condemned having America committed to the destruction of Nazi tyranny, because he said that would mean war for us.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- With a southwesterly breeze that sprang up over Long Island Sound as if made to order, eighty craft competed today in the special regatta of the Echo Bay Yacht Club.

Life's best values are those that may be most freely and widely shared with our fellowmen, the Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker, pastor of Baptist Temple, Los Angeles, said yesterday in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Aug. 24 -- Accompanied by the Duke of Kent, President Roosevelt is on his way tonight to Washington after moving today to relieve the British shipping stringency and the Eastern oil shortage, and arranging to meet legislative leaders tomorrow morning for what it was reported would be a final conference before the introduction of another lease-lend bill running to from $5,000,000,000 to $10,000,000,000.

WITH THE FINNISH FORCES, on the Onega Front, Aug. 24 -- That the fronts are again rolling forward and new events are imminent is the impression one gets from a journey to the foremost Finnish lines during recent days.

Training of seamen at the New York State Merchant Marine Academy is to continue without Interruption because of its importance to the defense program. The Bronx Board of Trade announced yesterday that it had received assurances from the Maritime Commission that the government did not plan to take over the Fort Schuyler Military Reservation, on which the academy stands, and that the training would continue.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- German assault troops have broken through a heavy concrete and steel defense line south of Leningrad, capturing a railroad center twenty-seven miles from the city, and may soon lay down a devastating artillery barage on the Soviet defenders, it was reported tonight.

The Rev. Robert R. Wicks, dean of Princeton University Chapel, asserted in a sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church that "it is a familiar delusion of American people that man was born to happiness."

WALDWICK, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Seven persons were killed tonight when a southbound bus, en route from Albany to New York City, crashed into the rear car of a line of automobiles waiting for a traffic light on Route 2 near here.

It was exactly one year ago last Wednesday that Winston Churchill, reporting to the House of Commons on the transfer of American destroyers for British air and sea bases in the Western Hemisphere, predicted that the affairs of the British Empire and the United States would have to be "somewhat mixed up," for mutual and general advantage.

It is regrettable that the strike at the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, N.J., should have ended in Government seizure of the plant. Imperative as it was to get the plant going again, this particular method could have been averted. The President, no doubt, could hardly have repudiated the recommendations of the Administration's own National Defense Mediation Board.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- What the British failed to do in three years, Bobby Jones's Ryder Cup "challengers" accomplished in less than seven hours today.

It is getting dark earlier these evenings, and the air has a crispness and sparkle that betoken Autumn. Soon there will be an acrid aroma of burning leaves in the parks, and the lights along Broadway will burn brighter in celebration of another season's openings.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 -- While steel customers were rapidly lining up information to be submitted on a special government form covering all unfilled tonnage, and while steel companies were endeavoring so to schedule operations as to assure a minimum of conflict, new orders last week continued to reach mills at a level higher than, either production or shipments.

Motion picture exhibitors in the past have laid too much stress upon the buying of pictures and not enough upon the merchandising of films to the ticket-buying patrons, according to Arthur W. Kelly, vice president and general manager in charge of distribution for United Artists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- According to authoritative sources, the War Department will reduce drastically the ten-year court-martial sentence imposed on John Habinyak, 26-year-old Pennsylvania selectee, for repeated disobedience of orders.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- The American people stand ready to surrender "some of their liberties and some of their freedoms temporarily to the government in order that they may not be compelled to surrender them permanently to Hitler and Nazism," Senator Barkley declared here this afternoons.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday Aug. 25 -- The Russian counter-attack in the Gomel region of the central sector is proceeding "according to plan," with German forces retreating in disorder north and south of Gomel, Soviet sources reported today.
Save for the terrific wear and tear on nerves, the situation on the National League pennant front today remains unchanged.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Joe DiMaggio brought his sprained ankle from Detroit to Chicago today, rested it carefully on the bench and, by his mere presence, appeared to have a highly beneficial influence upon his fellow Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Administration supporters tonight applauded Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech -- particularly the warning to Japan -- but isolationist leader Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, charged that it was "designed to frighten the United States into the idea that we have got to get into the war now or else Hitler will get us."

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- One week has passed since the signing of the Anglo-Russian trade agreement, yet few details of its contents are yet available. Cash and clearing are to provide the basis for dealings but as a heavy Russian import surplus is expected, the British Government has granted the Soviets a L10,000,000 credit to be supplemented after its exhaustion.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- An ultimatum to the Iranian Government is expected from London, the British Legation said today, as tension over the continued presence of German specialists in this country grew near the breaking point.

John R. Davies, candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor against Mayor La Guardia, charged yesterday that the attempt to have his designating petitions declared invalid was for the purpose of preventing enrolled Republicans from voting approval or disapproval of a third-term nomination for an enrolled member of the American Labor party on the Republican ticket.

Changes in the economic situation and outlook in the United States have been so sweeping at the end of two years of war in Europe that this country now finds itself in an economic position not unlike that of a nation actually at war, according to the Guaranty Survey, monthly publication of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

WARWICK, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Open revolt against the isolationist stand of Representative Hamilton Fish has been started here by four hundred of his constituents. He has answered it with a challenge to a debate in this village which they have accepted.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- The danger of totalitarianism to education was emphasized today at the convention of the American Federation of Teachers by representatives of the United States, Great Britain, Free France, Czecho-Slovakia and the Ukraine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The country's 15,000 banks are the "financial sleuths" mainly relied upon by the Federal Government to enforce the freezing order which prevent the use of Axis funds in the United States, Treasury officials said today.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 24 -- The Mardormere Kennels' whippet, Champion Flornell Glamorous, handled by Percy Roberts, racked up another best-in-show triumph in the annual Framingnam District Kennel Club exhibition on the Raceland estate of John R. Macomber today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Adams Kissam gave a buffet supper tonight at The Shallows for members of their week-end house party, Mr. and Mrs. Russell L. Gilbert, Miss Jane Gilbert and George L. Bagby.

ROME, Aug. 24 -- The controversy in American Catholic circles over Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy's speech and the whole question of the attitude of American Catholics toward the war against Russia is being watched with the keenest interest, it is revealed here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A special Icelandic Government trade delegation announced here tonight that it would open negotiations immediately with the United States over "various questions of finance, trade and shipping which are of vital importance to Iceland."

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The larger Chicago manufacturers of men's clothing are in fairly good shape as to wool goods inventories because of early buying, M. Kestnbaum, president of Hart Schaffner Marx, said here today. Expressing the belief that the experiences of his house were typical, Mr. Kestnbaum said that deliveries by the mills had come through in good shape until recently, when some delays in receiving goods on order have developed.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- A decree making certain significant changes in the wartime taxation of business, and the issuance of a new series of 3 1/2 per cent treasury notes are last week's outstanding developments in Reich war financing.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill used blunt words tonight in telling the Japanese Government that in the event of trouble in the Far East "we shall, of course, range ourselves unhesitatingly at the side of the United States."

Except for one day's uprush in prices for wheat and cotton, last week's markets hardly moved. On only two days did Stock Exchange transactions reach 400,000 shares. Even the Labor Bureau's weekly commodity price average stood still.
BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Bob Klinger won his eighth consecutive game for the Pirates, 7 to 3, today after a twelve-inning opener in which the Braves twice came from behind to snatch a 4-to-3 decision.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Patrolman John McHugh, a member of the Landsdowne, Pa., police force, has been released under $1,000 ball on a charge of involuntary manslaughter in connection with the shooting of Private Theodore Mazur, 23 years old, of Company H, 113th Infantry, one of seven soldiers who escaped from the Fort Dix guardhouse Friday morning.

The American Smelting and Refining Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $6,768,818 in the first six months of 1941 after all charges and estimated income and corporate taxes of $7,038,739, according to the semiannual report of Simon Guggenheim, president, issued for publication today.
BERLIN, Aug. 24 (AP) -- German headquarters issued the following today:

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- This war has been replete with almost incredible stories of the adventures of guerrilla bands and isolated units fighting their way back to the main lines, but one of the most astonishing tales told so far has just been heard by your correspondent.

South of the Thames lies the metropolitan borough of London whose name has become synonymous with the precise measurement of time and space. Greenwich Time is the standard traditionally used by astronomers of all nations. Longitude, all around the globe, is measured as so many degrees east or west of Greenwich.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Thirteen ships from a British convoy arrived here today and crew members said that apparently nine ships, including a destroyer, were sunk during an attack three days ago off the Spanish coast.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Hope for a peaceful settlement of Iran's dispute with Great Britain and Russia over an Allied demand for expulsion of German agents was declared by competent foreign sources here today to be virtually abandoned.

Three chess players ranging in age from 16 to 64 won championships in their respective classes yesterday in the finals of the annual tournament sponsored by the Department of Parks. The matches were played in the Heckscher Playground in Central Park.

The Pied Piper Robert Browning's famous ballad did not specify what sort of pipe was employed in the celebrated rat-drowning exploit of the Pied Piper of Hamelin. Nor can we find further elucidation in the legendry on which the poem was based.

NEWARK, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Behind masterful pitching by Tommy Byrne and Johnny Lindell, league-leading Newark conquered Jersey City today, 4 -- 0 and 4 -- 2, before a crowd of 7,615. The Bears increased their lead over Montreal to six and a half games, with sixteen to play.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- About 5,333,000 persons were employed by Federal, State, county and local governments in January of this year, according to a report by the Census Bureau.
ATLANTA, Aug. 24 -- Lured by the bait of $100 for each gooseegg inning he hurled, Chattanooga's big Buck Marrow blanked the Atlanta Crackers in six frames today, but alack, he lost the game, 4 to 1.

A group of religious leaders and educators, headed by Dr. Henry Sloan Coffin of the Union Theological Seminary, yesterday issued a statement applauding the Roosevelt-Churchill Eight-Point declaration of aims, particularly as it dealt with the peace to follow the war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Maximum time charter rates for tankers have been set by the Maritime Commission.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- While Prime Minister Winston Churchill was still speaking to the world by radio tonight the Germans issued a special communique from Adolf Hitler's Field Headquarters in which they asserted that twenty-five merchant vessels, totaling 148,000 tons, had been sunk by U-boats and surface craft, twenty-one of them from a heavily guarded enemy convoy en route from the British Isles to Gibraltar.

ROME, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Virglnio Gayda, the editor, professed amusement today at suggestions, alleged to be appearing in the Anglo-American press, that an attack should be made on the Italian mainland.
Awed, no doubt, in the presence of last year's world champions, the Giants submitted quietly to a double beating by the Reds yesterday at the Polo Grounds before a gathering of 22,860.

Take it from no less an authority than Leland Stanford (Laughing Larry) MacPhail, 200,000 persons would have seen the Dodgers and the Cardinals launch their crucial series yesterday at Ebbets Field if there were room. The crowd -- 31,523 -- that filed into the Flatbush ball park, however, fell far short of the all-time high of 41,109, but there were extenuating circumstances.

Realty dealing in Manhattan and the Bronx continues to show coniderable activity. On the East Side the nine-story apartment house at 125 East Ninety-third Street fronting 50 feet between Park and Lexington Avenues, was purchased by Herman Knepper, operator, for his investing associates from the Jonel Realty Corporation.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 25 -- Apparently halted by tenacious Russian resistance in their efforts to crush through to Leningrad from the south, the invaders yesterday renewed the attack on the Karelian Isthmus in the vicinity of Kaekisalmi, seeking to embarrass the defenders by closing in from the north.
MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique early today:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23 (Delayed) -- Vessels that are camouflaged, and therefore are in striking contrast to other ships entering the blue waters of Beirut harbor, continue to arrive at regular intervals. They are French and proudly fly the national colors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Aug. 24 -- With "The Male Animal" scheduled to go before the cameras tomorrow, Warner Brothers named Olivia de Havilland to replace Priscilla Lane in the feminine lead opposite Henry Fonda. The reason for the switch, Warners said, was that Miss Lane will be engaged in "Remember Tomorrow" with Richard Whorf.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Big AI Benton, yanked out of the relief class this year, hurled his ninth victory today as the Tigers defeated the Athletics, 7 to 4.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- In a move to have California voters pass on the new State statute outlawing the "hot cargo" and "secondary boycott" as labor's weapons during the defense emergency, union forces have filed referendum petitions in counties throughout the State bearing about 300,000 names.

The thirty-five-acre estate in Rumson, N.J., owned by Nicholas G. Rutgers Jr., has been purchased by Edward Folker of this city. The colonial-type residence contains twenty-four rooms and six baths. There are also twelve wood-burning fireplaces.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices continued to advance from 96.7 to another new high of 97.0. Largely responsible for the new high of 100.7 in the finished goods index and the 1.0 per cent gain in the foodstuffs index was the sharp rise in the price of beef.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A rising tide of complaints that small industries are being cut off from essential materials generated bipartisan support today for a proposed Congressional investigation of the government's system of defense priorities.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The revitalized Browns vaulted from the cellar into sixth place ahead of Washington and the Athletics today by squeezing out a 4-to-3 victory over the Senators in the tenth inning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Defying the normal seasonal trend, the volume of revenue freight transported by motor truck in July increased 2.3 per cent over June and almost equaled the record set in May, the American Trucking Association reported today.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 24 -- With none of the drama that surrounded the seizure of the North American Aviation Company plant, the Navy Department occupied the strike-bound yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here this afternoon and speeded preparations for the resumption of operations at 7:30 A.M. Tuesday.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The sporadic booing which at times was more voluminous than handclapping and cheering during the appearance of Canadian Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King yesterday at a sports meet of Canadian troops was written off generally today as a soldier-like lark.

Continued price increases in the wholesale markets during the past week had little effect on buying action. Reorder activity was especially brisk. Deliveries became easier in some lines but still remained a major consideration. Stores throughout the country reported early buying on Fall dresses.

John Simes Jr., six-day bicycle rider and winner of a bicycle derby, went out for a joy ride in a big flushing truck of the Department of Sanitation yesterday and drove all the way to Hartford, after pausing long enough in White Plains to give that city a free sprinkling of New York City water.

An invitation to attend the National Defense Clinic which will be held in Grand Central Palace next month was extended yesterday to all small manufacturers in the East whose facilities are available for defense work. In issuing the invitation, W.O. Crabtree, district manager of the defense contract service, Office of Production Management, declared that the clinic would play an important part in OPM's new policy of pressing vigorously to spread defense production.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Indians climbed past Boston into third place today by inflicting upon the Red Sox a double defeat, 4 to 3 and 5 to 2, in their first twin, killing since July 13 against the same team.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Prices of corn held last week within relatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade here and averaged somewhat lower than in the preceding week despite a mid-month crop estimate made by the Department of Agriculture which reduced the prospective yield about 108,000,000 bushels, compared with Aug. 1.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The revitalized Browns vaulted from the cellar into sixth place ahead of Washington and the Athletics today by squeezing out a 4-to-3 victory over the Senators in the tenth inning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Defying the normal seasonal trend, the volume of revenue freight transported by motor truck in July increased 2.3 per cent over June and almost equaled the record set in May, the American Trucking Association reported today.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 24 -- With none of the drama that surrounded the seizure of the North American Aviation Company plant, the Navy Department occupied the strike-bound yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here this afternoon and speeded preparations for the resumption of operations at 7:30 A.M. Tuesday.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The sporadic booing which at times was more voluminous than handclapping and cheering during the appearance of Canadian Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King yesterday at a sports meet of Canadian troops was written off generally today as a soldier-like lark.
NEW YORK Sir George and Lady Bettesworth-Piggott are returning from Lenox, Mass., this week and will be at the Plaza.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Phillies, still in last place but currently playing like wild fire, unleashed two styles of baseball today to sweep a double-header from the Cubs, 8 to 5 and 7 to 6.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Low production levels in armament industries were denounced today as a "first rate national scandal" by delegates from 195 armament factories meeting in London to discuss ways and means to speed output.

Passengers arriving yesterday on the Spanish liner Magallanes from Spain via Havana said there had been a near-riot on the pier at the Cuban port when thirtythree refugees were ordered back on the ship to be returned to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The American Automobile Association tonight asked Congress to investigate the gasoline situation in the East and to set up machinery for "an orderly handling and apportionment of available motor fuel with due regard for the rights of all users" if Federal control is deemed necessary.

VICHY, France, Aug. 24 -- Publication of the Bank of France's statement of position, recently resumed, still is "a month late because of the difficulties of coordinating the accounting facilities of the branches in the two zones. The July 24 statement shows a slight increase in discounts, amounting to 80,000,000 francs, but, on the other hand, the advances on treasury bonds declined by 155,000,000 while advances on securities were unchanged.

Moral and intellectual softness were condemned yesterday by the Rev. Francis X. Shea in his sermon at the 11 o'clock solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. He said that the footprints left by the Son of Man, who is God, are the footprints of a Man who taught a clear-cut code of faith and an equally clear-cut code of morality.

Sixty-two leading rabbis, representing twenty-four States, made public yesterday a statement approving the food relief plan proposed by Herbert Hoover through the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies, 420 Lexington Avenue.

WESTBURY, L.I, Aug. 24 -- Two games today provided practice for the players preparing for the national polo championship. At Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club, Aknusti started slowly but turned back Mike Phipps's Gulf Stream team, 7 to 5, and at Bostwick Field in Old Westbury, Stew Iglehart went very well to pull Westbury through against Long Island, 6 to 4.
LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- Racing against the threat of German intervention, British and Russian armies paced by bombers today fought their way into Iran in a five-pronged invasion.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 25 -- The concentric attack launched against Viborg up to tonight had reached a point where -- even if the word encircling may not yet apply -- one may speak of simultaneous and fierce attack on the city from the west, north and even from the east.

James B. Schafer, self-pro-claimed "master metaphysician" who, according to the authorities, now describes himself merely as a "teacher", with mediocre scholastic training, was arrested yesterday on a nine-count grand larceny indictment in the so-called "sanctuary" of his "Church of the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians" at 152 West Fifty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Continued broad cattle marketings failed to break the higher price level of beef offerings reached last week and the trade was generally steady to strong, while hogs went at steady to strong values, both reflecting continued good dressed trade demand. Spring lambs were off mostly 25 cents.

Department store sales in the Second Federal Reserve District last month showed main-store increases averaging 21 per cent over July, 1940, bringing the gain for the seven-month period to 10 per cent over last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Glore, Forgan Co., won today the award of $30,000,000 of Wisconsin Power and Light Company 3 1/4 per cent bonds due on Aug. 1, 1971, on a bid of 105.5897.

Iran's history is one of the oldest of antiquity. Until 1906 its government was an absolute monarchy, but in that year Mohammed Ali Shah signed a constitution that set up a national consultative body, and the present ruler, Riza Shah Pahlevi, governs with the assistance of a Council of Ministers.

Harry R. Bridges, the West Coast C.I.O. leader who is the subject of pending legislation and proceedings looking to his deportation for subversive activity, yesterday accused the Federal Bureau of Investigation of tapping the telephone wire of his room at the Hotel Edison.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 25 -- The establishment of a non-political national economic council for the study of post-war problems, with particular attention to the development of a plan to prevent future unemployment, was urged tonight by Howard Coonley, chairman of the legislative committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Survivors of fourteen British merchantmen voiced thanks in this neutral port today to a lone American-made plane for their survival out of a convoy of twenty ships and a tug harassed by a four-day running attack by German planes and U-boats off Spain.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- The unwillingness of civilians to make real sacrifices in the interest of national defense was blamed tonight by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, for any lessening of the morale of the Army.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- Officially the Germans revealed nothing new from the Eastern Front today. The communique of the Supreme Command tersely declared "Operations in the East are making good progress everywhere."

In Santa Barbara, Calif., David O. Selznick reported to a scout for this column the other day that "Lottie Dundass," Enid Bagnold's murder play with psychological overtones, which had its world premiere there last Thursday night, is definitely slated for Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The application of the Atlas Corporation, the American Company, the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, the Keith-Albee-Orpheum Corporation and Michael J. Meehan for approval of a plan of reorganization of Keith-Albee-Orpheum was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The defense Supplies Corporation set up an office in the quarters of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at 33 Liberty Street yesterday for the purchase of an estimated 100,000 bales of raw silk frozen under order of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, but bought no silk.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph. F. Thorning, Professor of Sociology at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg, Md., and director of the first Catholic Sign Seminar to South America, returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Elena with twenty members after three months at the University of San Marcos, Lima, Peru.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- On his way home to New Zealand after spending several weeks in Britain conferring with the British War Cabinet and other high officials, Prime Minister Peter Fraser of New Zealand arrived here today for a two-week stop-off.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States expects to supply, in increasing quantities, the defense materials urgently needed from this country by Latin-American governments, Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State, declared tonight in a nationally broadcast radio speech that was rebroadcast by short-wave in Spanish.

In the field of grand strategy, in which Hitler has hitherto enjoyed the initiative, the first spectacular result of Russia's participation in the war is the march of British and Soviet forces into the mountain-walled kingdom of Iran. Two considerations of the utmost importance predetermined this move.
The Anglo-Russian invasion of Iran tends to consolidate, at least temporarily, what has heretofore been a precarious British hold upon the Middle East.

Two boys reported missing since Saturday from their Summer home on Staten Island turned up last night at their home in the Bronx, eager for a night's rest after sleeping the woods for two nights and hiking through the New Jersey hurricane yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Congressional experts tonight gave out this table showing taxes which would be paid by a single man with no dependents under rates approved by the Senate Finance Committee, those provided under the tax bill approved by the House and those levied under existing law:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Darkness stopped the second St. Louis-Washington game today with the score tied at 3-all after ten innings, but the Browns won the first, 6 to 3. to strengthen their grip on sixth place.

The State of California awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,691,425 of its general-fund registered warrants to the Mercnants National Bank of Sacramento, whose bid topped a field of three other bidders. The bank bid par, plus a premium of $1.452, naming the interest rate as half of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt vetoed today the bill requiring the government to withhold from the market during the national emeergency its large stocks of wheat and cotton acquired over the last few years as a means of stabilizing prices for these crops.

Speculation over whether or not the government will establish price ceilings on a variety of canned foodstuffs and what steps it may take to insure delivery of canned goods in the quantities it desires, occupied the wholesale food market here yesterday.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 25 -- The Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company yard here, which has been strike-bound since Aug. 7, tying up $493,000,000 worth of Navy and Maritime Commission construction, was made ready today for full operation under Navy control tomorrow at 7:30 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States received the first tip that Germany was about to attack Russia and that Japan intended to occupy Indo-China through the operation of its newest intelligence adjunct, the foreign broadcast monitoring service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A preview of suggested practical but snappy togs for the well-dressed milkmaid, farmerette and defense factory-ette was given at Mrs. Roosevelt's press conference at the White House today. There was also a display of the latest in cotton stockings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National Defense Mediation Board, declared today that its decisions were guided by the principle that "the emergency should not be used to build up or tear down unions."

A fire that damaged the Finnish freighter Aurora last Friday, causing the death of Conrad Freese, the first officer, started amidships on the starboard side, not far from the pantry, according to testimony given yesterday at the hearing before a two-man board of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation.

Acting Governor Charles Poletti's action in barring a birth-control exhibit from the New York State Fair at Syracuse was assailed yesterday by officials of the New York State Federation for Planned Parenthood, sponsors of the project, but Mr. Poletti refused to reconsider his stand.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 -- Pending the receipt of the text and a careful study of it, official quarters were silent today on Prime Minister Winston Churchill's broadcast. The press observed a like caution, in the main.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight entertained the Duke of Kent at what was described as an informal dinner in the State Dining Room of the White House, as the climax of a day in which the royal visitor, younger brother of King George VI of England, flew to Norfolk and inspected the naval base.

While the sale of credit coupons, bonds, etc., by retail stores on the installment plan is not specifically considered in the installment regulations issued by the Federal Reserve Board, the National Retail Dry Goods Association expressed the opinion yesterday that to accept such credit coupons as down payments or installments on installment purchases would amount to a subterfuge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted, 10 to 6, today to raise $303,000,000 more from individual income taxes in the pending defense revenue bill by reducing exemptions from $2,000 to $1,500 for married couples and from $800 to $750 for single persons.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Cold Spring Harbor, champion of Long Island Sound, led the competition for the national junior sailing championship as the Eastern Yacht Club opened the twenty-first series for the Sears Cup, given by Commodore Herbert M. Sears in 1921.

VICHY, France, Aug. 25 -- Armored cars and squads of German soldiers tonight were reported patroling the streets of Paris to quell a series of demonstrations in the downtown section and a wave of sabotage that has caused two new train wrecks on major railroads.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States gave tacit approval today to the Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran when Secretary of State Cordell Hull said in his press is conference that he understood the issue there was between the Germans on one hand and the British and Russians on the other.

SHANGHAI. Aug. 25 -- Speculation and conjecture were rife in Shanghai today regarding possible Japanese moves when the first United States tankers enter Far Eastern waters bound for Vladivostok with precious oil cargoes.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Japanese charged today that Prime Minister Winston Churchill had lied about British and United States efforts to keep peace with Japan, and defiantly declared that nothing would halt the southward course of this Asiatic empire.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 25 -- The Turkish press and radio, particularly suspicious of Russia's intentions, denounced tonight the British-Soviet attack on Iran as "aggression" and urged another attempt to settle the conflict by means of negotiation.

Patrolman Patrick Coyle, a veteran of fifteen years on a Bowery post, was absolved yesterday after a rigid Police Department investigation of any breach of the rules and regulations in 'letting the cat out of the bag."

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's disclosure that the United States was trying to obtain a settlement with Japan stirred Chinese fears of an Asiatic appeasement, possibly at China's expense.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that it had distributed approximately 640,000 copies of various series of form TFR-300, which covers all foreign accounts in this country. These forms, in nine series, designed for individuals, banks, safe-deposit companies, insurance companies and business corporations, are to be filled out and turned in to the Reserve Bank by Sept. 30.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The text of a Royal Air force communique:

A quiet cotton market was enlivened temporarily yesterday when news of President Roosevelt's veto of the bill freezing cotton and wheat in the government loan reached traders. Prices on the Xew York Cotton Exchange, which had moved narrowly all morning, last 11 to 14 points on the veto announcement, then recovered and closed unchanged to 3 points lower than Saturday's final quotations.
Heavy rain and high wind slashed erratically up the eastern seaboard from Maryland to Maine yesterday, leaving two men dead, more than 100 persons injured and property damage that neared $1,000,000.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Aug. 26 -- After days of stubborn resistance Russian troops have evacuated the city of Novgorod, north of Lake Ilmen, it was acknowledged in today's Soviet communique. It appears that the Soviet forces, fighting strong rearguard actions, merely withdrew from the city itself and still hold strategically important heights on the western bank of a river to the north, from which their heavy artillery commands all approaches.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 25 -- The death toll of Bergen County's worst traffic mishap mounted to eight today when William Bason, 31 years old, of 128 Stevens Avenue, Jersey City, died in Hackensack Hospital. He was injured shortly after 8 P.M. Sunday night when an Albany-New York Greyhound bus caromed into a traffic line on Route 2 at Waldwick.

JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The divorce of Anne Gould Elsbury, 28-year-old great-granddaughter of the railroad magnate, Jay Gould, from her cowboy husband and her third marriage, to a Wyoming ranch neighbor, were disclosed today.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Aug. 25 -- Strong Royal Air Force groups, Indian infantry and artillery units and a 306-man medical detachment landed today to reinforce Britain's already formidable Malayan bases, emphasizing a declaration by Prime Minister Winston Churchill that Japanese aggression "has got to stop."

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Joseph Rosentover, president of the American Football Association, announced today a four-man corporation headed by Thomas Bradley, Manhattan insurance executive and polo player, had purchased the Jersey City professional football franchise from the association.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The text of the Foreign Office statement announcing the Russo-British decision to march into Iran toos as follows:
A gain in the volume of insured mortgages accepted by the FHA on new homes during the first half of the present year is reported in thirty-eight of the forty-eight States in the Union.

Refugee passengers and Americans returning from Europe yesterday on the American Export liner Excalibur declared that disillusionment was growing in German military and police ranks, and reported instances of German officers actually seeking an opportunity to listen to British radio broadcasts and other news "from the outside."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After fifteen months of intensive defense effort, with unlimited sums of money placed at the Army's disposal, Major Gen. McNair reports that there is not a single division ready for service: the War Department applies to Congress for permission to retire or dismiss out of hand the many incompetent officers it says that it has on the rolls;

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

In vetoing the bill to freeze Government stocks of cotton and wheat for the duration of the war President Roosevelt has acted with courage and wisdom. The effect of the bill would have been to prevent the Government from disposing during the present period of rising prices of any of the surplus cotton and wheat which it had acquired through price-supporting loans in past periods of depressed prices.

The National Anthem Several of the larger motion picture theatres have adopted the British custom of playing the National Anthem at the close of their performances. It is a happy innovation, providing as it does a moment in which audiences can pay homage to their country and all it stands for, and it serves as a musical reminder that they live in a land where the theatre, like the press, is free.
The twelve-story apartment house at 927 Fifth Avenue, corner of Seventy-fourth Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms to the Bowery Savings Bank, the plaintiff.

The two-story mill building on a nine and one-half acre plot on Warren Street, Phillipsburg, N.J., has been leased by the Phillipsburg Textile Mills Company to the Musicraft Manufacturing Corporation, manufacturers of phonograph records, albums and record racks.

Mayor La Guardia called Grover A. Whalen to Summer City Hall yesterday and assigned him to the task of drawing up a plan to conserve gasoline "without disturbing the business life and without causing undue inconvenience in the social and family life of our community."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Acting with speed, the War Department today slashed Private John Habinyak's sentence for insubordination from ten years and nine months, to three years.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- Winners of $25,000 in prizes for scholarships in any schools they may select were announced tonight at the annual award dinner of the Ford Good Drivers League. More than 170,000 boys and girls in all the States have competed in the contest.

Parker Pen Company will use 124 newspapers, seventeen radio stations, 169 college papers and sixteen magazines to promote its Fall line, D. R. Dayhoff, Eastern sales manager, told a group of dealers and salespeople at the opening of a regional sales meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

One of the most significant aspects of the Government seizure of the Kearny, N.J., plant of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company is that it implies a still further abridgment of management's right to manage. It is instructive to trace the history of governmental policy on this in recent years, particularly as it relates to the employer's power to hire, promote or discharge workers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies, addressing the Economic Society today, said he believed that never before had a community of 7,000,000 persons attempted and achieved so much in a war as Australia has. If every Australian could survey what is being done, all would be vastly proud, he declared.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Aug. 25 -- The Bourse opened very firm, but there was some reaction later on profit-taking. The leading domestic industrials and shippings were in the foreground. A.K.U. was unchanged, Unilever rose 6 1/8 to 159 3/8, Philips 4 3/4 to 255 1/4, Royal Dutch 3 1/2 to 279 1/2, Amsterdam Rubber 3 to 298 3/4 and Amsterdam Trading 2 1/2 to 462 1/2.

It is a fairly common assumption that one way to "beat inflation" is to take on increased debts which can later be paid off in "depreciated money." Leaving aside for the moment the folly of assuming that it is ever possible to "beat inflation," it is certain that one way to bring on inflation is for every one to increase his debts.

INWOOD, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Wretched weather marred the weekly one-day Long Island P.G. A. amateur-pro golf tournament on the water-logged Inwood Country Club course today. Only eleven teams of a starting field of twenty-five posted scores.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Complying with an order of Price Administrator Leon Henderson, the Joseph Seep Purchasing Agency of the South Penn Oil Company announced today a reduction of 23 to 25 cents a barrel in the price of Pennsylvania grade crude oil.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 25 -- A board of Army officers convened today to investigate the death of Private Theodore J. Mazur, Passaic, N.J., of the 113th Infantry. At the same time Patrolman John McHugh of Lansdowne, Pa., made a formal appearance before Prosecutor Daniel Lichtenthal in Mount Holly and was released in $1,000 bail on a charge of involuntary homicide to appear before the September term of the Burlington County grand jury.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Red Sox moved within half a game of third-place Cleveland tonight by beating the Indians, 1 to 0, on Charley Wagner's four-hit pitching. Bob Feller also allowed four blows in losing his eleventh game against twenty-one victories.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- Tie Russian note as broadcast by the Moscow radio said:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A reorganization plan for the Wabash Railway Company which would enable the Pennsylvania Railroad to acquire stock control was approved today by Federal Judge Charles B. Davis. He requested the receivers to place the plan in operation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt signed into law today the First Supplemental National Defense Appropriation Bill of 1942, making available to the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission more than $7,500,000,000 in cash and contract authority for urgently needed armament and defense works.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- RKO today took over the longpending deal for Lewis Milestone and William Hawks to participate in an autonomous production unit at Twentieth Century-Fox, signing both the producer and director to film John Steinbeck's "The Red Pony," which was to have been their first Fox picture.

SAN FRANCISCO., Aug. 25 -- Alfred Duff Cooper, former British Minister of Information, and Senator Johnson, foe of intervention, arrived from the East on the same train today, but they refused to exchange greetings.

The light-heavyweight championship of the world will be the prize when Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J., opposes Tami Mauriello, youthful Bronx warrior, in a fifteen-round bout in Madison Square Garden tonight. Neither boxer is regarded as the titleholder by the New York State Athletic Commission, but Lesnevich is recognized by the National Boxing Association.

With Frank Leahy, successor to Elmer Layden as head football coach and athletic director at Notre Dame, as the speaker, the seventh annual New York Herald Tribune Football Coaching School opened yesterday in the auditorium of the newspaper.
The air war on the Western Front between Britain and Germany has been only on a minor scale during the last twenty-four hours, each side making comparatively small raids against the other.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the outdoor amateur boxing carnival in behalf of the William Carey Camp of the Boys Club of New York, which will be held on Friday night under a large circus tent to be pitched near the club house of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- With the British-Soviet invasion of Iran, the economic encirclement of German in the east may be considered as complete, observers here remarked today. Although German trade with Iran had been greatly reduced since September, 1939, and especially since the outbreak of the Russo-German war, some Iranian goods were still reaching Germany via Turkey, according to reports published in the German press.

Space has been leased in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, by Emery Reves, international publisher, for offices of the Cooperation Publishing Company, which for many years syndicated the political writings of European statesmen. The concern had its offices in Paris until the German occupation, when they were transferred to London, only to be destroyed in an air raid.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Sales of reporting stores in the National Retail Furniture Association monthly survey soared 32 per cent above 1940 during July "for the highest gain registered in many months," John R. Trost, secretary of the control and management division said today.

Rayon greige goods were not offered yesterday. Buyers were not surprised, because the bulk of offerings in the last several weeks had come from second hands, who were quoting, and getting, prices well above mill quotations and far above the ceiling levels announced at the week-end by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

The stock market indicated anew yesterday that it was awaiting a clarification of the progress of the war and domestic political controls, for the trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, also influenced by the August lull, dropped to the smallest since early in June.

Representatives of the United Better Dress Manufacturers Association and the United Popular Dress Manufacturers Association, the two major contractors' associations in New York's dress industry, responsible for nearly 75 per cent of the industry's production, voted unanimously last night to shut down their factories, beginning today, until the jobbers' associations agree to a "more satisfactory adjustment" of the amounts to be paid to the contractors to cover overhead and operating costs.

DETROIT. Mich., Aug. 25 -- The American Federation of Teachers in annual convention tonight amended its constitution to exclude from membership any applicant whose actions are subject to totalitarian control, such as Communist, Nazi or Fascist."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Officers of the C.I.O.'s United Mine Workers of America reported today that the union's members had approved by 151,857 to 87,388 a referendum proposal for a continuing series of 50-cent monthly assessments from now until the union's next convention in October, 1942, to build up a union "war chest" to meet a probable post-emergency threat to the union's security, wage standards and working conditions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Aug. 20, 1941, aggregated $10,039,000,000.

A middle-aged man in midtown Manhattan boasts inside information about the beauty secrets of the lithe young women who appear each Sunday in the rotogravure sections, slender and lovely in trim tennis dresses and brief bathing suits.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- Unsuccessful in their efforts to modify the arrangements for tomorrow's election among 5,500 employes of the municipally owned Detroit Street Railways, leaders or the Congress of Industrial Organizations decided today to enter the balloting precincts under protest.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 -- With Vice Premier Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma still sick in bed suffering from an assassin's bullets, the Criminal Court of Tokyo today passed sentence on nine conspirators who were charged with having made preparations for the assassination of Japan's older and conservative statesmen who were suspected of pro-British leanings in July, 1939.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- More than half a dozen Decatur manufacturing companies have banded together to seek rearmament contracts by cooperation.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Tall Trees Stable's Ball Player -- the horse that won by 21 lengths in his previous start in the mud a week ago-scored a six-and-one-half-length victory over Mrs. Harry Barnett's Harp Weaver today on a fast track at Narragansett Park.

A powerful, 30-year-old seaman was arraigned in Federal Court here yesterday on the first charge of murder on the high seas to come before the court in more than seven years. The prisoner, Marco James Falcone, a native of San Pedro, Calif., was accused of stabbing Arthur Woodrow Evans, a fellow member of the crew of the Malamton, freighter of the Marine Transport Company lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Commonwealth Telephone Company of Madison, Wis., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 16,071 shares of $5 cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Brig. Gen. John C. McDonnell, in command of the First Interceptor Force, announced today that the air forces would test the permanent air defense system in part of the Northeast from Oct. 9 to 16 in the largest air manoeuvres of their kind in our history.

Consolidated operations of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the half-year ended on Aug. 2, last, resulted in an estimated net profit of $525,000 after all charges including $375,000 provision for Federal taxes. This is in contrast to the net loss of $45,000 reported for the corresponding period of the preceding year, after tax deductions of $70,000.

Mrs. Margaret Riker Whipple, daughter of Mrs. Julian Van Ness Whipple, gave a tea yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother in Hewlett, L.I., for members of the debutante and junior committees assisting in plans for the moonlight cruise, which will take place on the evening of Sept. 4 for the benefit of the British War Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Solicitor General Francis Biddle, who has been acting Attorney General since the elevation of Robert H. Jackson to the Supreme Court, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to succeed Mr. Jackson.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Racing at its rainiest was seen today as the Saratoga Association began the final week of its thirty-day meeting, with driving rain prevailing from morning until night, and with only three horses in the featured Marine Purse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The War Department has awarded contracts totaling $109,880,640, it was announced here today. Firms in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- The Turkish radio reported today that about 150,000 British and Russian troops were engaged in the invasion of Iran. Particularly heavy fighting was reported under way in the resistance of Iranian troops to British spearheads advancing into Iran along the main road from Baghdad.

This is a very unfortunate story -- the saga of Postman Posner, the Brooklyn Diogenes, who was too honest to keep the nickel he found on the street six months ago. The story has a moral, all right, but the moral is a bad one, for it strikes a blow at that most cherished of copybook maxims: "Honesty Is the Best Policy."
A number of leases for quarters in buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues were among the contracts for residential space reported yesterday by brokers throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared today that conversations with Japan have been purely informal and emphasized that any settlement of difficulties with Japan would have to be based upon the fundamental principles he enunciated in 1937.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Official German spokesmen tonight angrily denounced the British-Russian invasion of Iran as an unjustified "treacherous attack on a small nation," but said that thus far they knew of no diplomatic "or other steps" planned by Germany in connection with, the Anglo-Soviet move.

Twenty-thousand troops of the Sixth Army Corps one of the three corps comprising the First Army, will start a week of field manoeuvres today over a 440-square-mile area on the New Hampshire and Massachusetts border.

Donald McNeill, the nation's top ranking player, who experienced rough going during his recent campaign through the Eastern grass court circuit, dropped to the third rung in the seedings as the draw for the men's national tennis singles championship was made at the Hotel Vanderbilt yesterday.

Slaughter of most classes of livestock was normal yesterday. Trading in general was fair to good. Steer hind and rib prices were little changed from last week's close but other steer cull were strong to higher. The lamb market was sharply higher, veal and fresh pork cuts mostly unchanged. The kosher markets opened steady with last Friday's close.

Store Sales Here Up 26% Department store sales in New York and Brooklyn last week were 26 per cent ahead of a year ago, according to the flash report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. Sales in the previous week had run 40 per cent ahead.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- An agreement imposing on the employer the obligation to provide health insurance for his workers was adopted today by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Philadelphia Waist and Dress Manufacturers Association.

ANOTHER American journalist has returned from a long stay inside Germany with an interesting report and encouraging news. He is Joseph C. Harsch, graduate of Williams College and member of The Christian Science Monitor staff, who went to Berlin in the Autumn of 1939 and left in the Spring of 1941.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 25 -- After the roughest opening qualifying round in the forty-five-year history of the United States amateur golf championship, Stewart M. (Skip) Alexander of Burlington, N.C., tonight stands at the head of the class.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Teheran radio said today that Iranian Premier Ali Khan Mansur told an extraordinary session of the Parliament that Iranian authorities "have taken all necessary measures to face" an attack by British land, sea and air forces.
