A drizzle that turned into a downpour yesterday took some of the heat off the torrid National League pennant race by washing out the third game of the series between the first-place Dodgers and the second-place Cardinals at Ebbets Field.
Week-end reports furnished a silver lining to a gloomy Monday that left many fishing centers guessing as to the effect of yesterday's storm upon conditions for the next few days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Office of Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense ordered today that all "blending agents of petroleum origin" used in creating high-test gasoline be conserved solely for production of the type of fuel used in airplanes and tanks.
Among the projects for which plans were filed yesterday were groups of small dwellings in Brooklyn and Queens. The details of these and other plans follow:

Three City College teachers were dismissed late last night by the Board of Higher Education, meeting in special session at Hunter College, on trial committee findings that they had engaged in subversive activities and one of then also in indoctrinating his student with Communist theory.

ROME, Aug. 25 -- Great indignation is being displayed by the press today over the invasion of Iran by Britain and Russia. Although they say they are not surprised. Italian commentators assert that this new development of the war proves once more the extent of British "hypocrisy and greed," as well as London's "premeditated plan of conquest."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- By a standing vote, rarely used in the Senate, the nomination of Rexford Guy Tugwell to be Governor of Puerto Rico was confirmed today by what some reporters got as a tally of 11 to 9.

The railroads have set Sept. 28 as the date when train schedules will be revised to conform with the Federal Government's request that passenger services be reduced to release cars for military purposes, but their plans will be dislocated if the usual change from daylight to standard time is not made at the end of next month, it became known yesterday.

The designating petitions of John Cashmore, Democratic Borough President of Brooklyn, in the Republican primaries were sent yesterday by the Board of Elections to District Attorney William O'Dwyer for investigation after Paul Windels, representing the Brooklyn Republican Law Committee, charged that they were "permeated with criminal fraud and forgery."

Cut prices on liquor still prevailed in central shopping districts of the city yesterday, but the reductions, which were first made on Friday, had not spread to neighborhood shops up to last night. The small storekeepers marked time on price cutting at the instance of leaders of the package store trade associations, who assured their members that distillers will take action to enforce contracts within the next few days.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 26 -- As dawn broke yesterday morning British and Russian troops made simultaneous advances into Iran, it was announced here. Their purpose was to throw an accumulation of German technicians out of the country and occupy it until such time as the two nations became convinced there was no danger that the Germans would occupy Iran by invasion or fifth column tactics or a combination of both.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 26 -- The Red Army has abandoned the city of Novgorod, it was announced early today by the Soviet High Command. This was the first signal advance toward Leningrad from the south that the German Army has been able to register since the main phase of the battle for that Baltic seaport began.

Steel production this week is scheduled at 96.5 per cent of the theoretical annual productive capacity of 86,148,700 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, comparing with a revised rate of 96.2 per cent for last week, for which a rate of 98.2 per cent had been indicated, based on a capacity of 84,152,292 net tons.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 25 -- The indictment of German Ambassador Edmund von Thermann on charges of misuse of public funds and other similar malpractices became an immediate possibility today when Attorney General Raul Munilla Lacasa instructed Judge Roman Vasquez, who has been investigating Nazi activities in Argentina, to turn over all evidence he had gathered to the Supreme Court for whatever action that body might decide to take.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- The Yankees again were victims of some rearguard sniping today as the White Sox, with their left-handed Edgar Smith on the firing line, made a bit of a mess of the Bronx bombers' evacuation of the city.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- British and Russian troops entered Iran early this morning following a series of protests to the Teheran government concerning German intrigues in that country. Thus direct hand contact between the Allies was established for the first time and three key routes for the transport of American and British supplies to the Soviet Union were secured against Axis sabotage or diplomatic pressure.

Currency Hoarding The Federal Reserve authorities, it appears, are making a fairly detailed study of the steadily expanding volume of money in circulation. Increased employment and heavy contraseasonal trade volume have accounted for part of the currency increase, to be sure, but they do not account for the increased demand for bills of large denomination.

In the Fall of 1939 members of the faculty of Swarthmore College were trying to decide between two things -- a bagful of golf clubs and a set of rare sixteenth-century travelogues. Dr. Frank Aydelotte had just announced his resignation as president to become director of the Institute for Advanced Study and his colleagues sought an appropriate departing gift.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 25 -- In a brief and simple ceremony today Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu and Marine Minister Rear Admiral Mario Fincati, for Argentina, and Italian Ambassador Rafaele Boscarelli for Italy, signed the final papers whereby Argentina purchases sixteen Italian ships laid up hi Argentine ports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- FBI officials here gave further details today concerning the case of Frank Christy Davis, notorious confidence man, who is being held in the Hudson County jail in Jersey City on a charge of transporting in interstate commerce a sum of money in excess of $5,000 in violation of the national Stolen Property Act.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 26 -- With the agony of qualifying rounds for the national amateur golf championship over, the record established by Tom Sheehan, former Notre Dame captain, at North Shore in 1939 is still intact.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Roosevelt today branded as vicious rumor, distortion of fact or falsehood published reports of misuse of lease-lend funds and materials by or on behalf of nations benefiting under the American policy of "all out" help to the non-Axis Allies.

Reporting production, shipments and earnings at new highs in the first half of 1941, Thomas A. Morgan, president of the Sperry Corporation, informed stockholders yesterday that the management had taken twofold action to cushion the effects of any slump or drastic readjustment which might accompany a post-emergency period.

An apartment of ten rooms and four baths at 375 Park Avenue has been leased to J. Robinson-Duff, head of the stock brokerage firm bearing his name, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents, and Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Lady Louis Mountbatten called on Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, today to express the gratitude of the British people for the $25,000,000 worth of medical supplies, clothing and first-aid kits sent in their hour of need.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Though he had not been summoned to testify tomorrow, when the State Highway Department investigation will switch to a land deal in which he acted as negotiator for the department, Arthur H. Sweeney of Merchantville killed himself this morning.
Trading in Manhattan realty yesterday ranged from the Washington Heights area to the lower East Side and largely involved residential properties.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Newark boosted its lead in the International League by taking both ends of a double-header from the Syracuse Chiefs tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Charles H. Schweppe, well-known investment banker and civic leader, was found dead of a bullet wound in bed today at his home in Lake Forest. A coroner's jury of neighbors found that he ended his life while in ill health.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The six-year term of Edwin S. Smith as a member of the National Labor Relations Board ended today. It was generally assumed in Washington that he would not be reappointed, although there was no direct word from the White House.

The Woman's Suffrage Amendment was 21 years old yesterday. Those who fought for the vote expressed themselves as pleased with the progress made, although the date coincided with a spread of war to new areas, and world peace, so often bracketed with "votes for women," seemed as remote as ever.
ROME, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- The American Federation of Teachers at the final session of its annual convention today attacked the work of the Rapp-Coudert committee in New York and resolved to work with labor and educational forces in Georgia to protect that State from violations of academic freedom.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- House members predicted today that no attempt would be made to override President Roosevelt's sharply worded veto of legislation to freeze government loan stocks of wheat and cotton and to relax penalties for producing above-quota wheat.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Frank Erickson, New York gambler, and three others were indicted by the Morris County grand jury late today on charges of assault and battery and atrocious assault and battery as a result of the stabbing of Milton F. Untermeyer, New York stock broker, at the latter's home in Kinnelon in the early morning of May 25.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 26 -- The Labor party today unanimously rejected the offer of Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies to form an all-party government and declared that in view of the Prime Minister's indication of his inability to give Australia a stable government he ought to resign.

Thursday, Sept. 4, has been set by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a hearing on the modification of Rule X-10-b-2 necessary for operation of the New York Curb Exchange's "dealer market" plan. The announcement coincided with the revelation that the SEC had previously declined to make such changes.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- The curtain was lifted here today by the Chrysler Corporation on what it will mean to the United States, as the arsenal of democracy, to have the automobile industry pass from the "make-ready" stage to production of tanks, bombers, anti-aircraft guns and military trucks.

An underwriting syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co. of Chicago was the highest bidder yesterday on a $4,000,000 issue of City of Tacoma, Wash., light and power revenue bonds. The group paid 100.002 for the bonds in two series, offering an interest cost basis of 1.7488 per cent.

Buyer Registrations Up in Week Buyers arriving in the New York market during the week ended yesterday totaled 899, which compared with 856 in the previous week and 810 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Leases on and near Madison and Park Avenues in the retail area of the Fifties and upper Forties continue to feature the business leasing activity.

The first specific charges that a foreign agent had attempted to furnish precise information on the strength and location of units of the United States Army to a foreign government were revealed here yesterday. Kurt Frederick Ludwig, who, though born in this country, was said to be of German extraction and to have spent most of his life in Germany, was named as the alleged agent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In view of the proposals that are being made for the dispatch of an American expeditionary force to foreign parts, it is well that the country should be made to understand what this will mean.

The North American Company, which has been cited tentatively by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the integration, or so-called "death sentence," provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act., reduced further yesterday its investment in the Detroit Edison Company, a statutory subsidiary.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 -- Mayor La Guardia, as Federal Director of Civilian Defense, warned the convention of Veterans of Foreign Wars today that war with Hitler would be the price of laxity in arming the nation. He argued that only by keeping the stream of war supplies to our Army and to Great Britain flowing without interruption could the United States hope to ward off hostilities from the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Duke of Kent, brother of King George VI, declared today that Britain was confident of victory in the war against Hitlerism and emphasized that "the more you can give us, the quicker we shall win."

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Iranian Government was continuing conversations with Great Britain and Russia tonight despite the invasion of Iran by British and Russian forces this morning.

VICHY, France, Aug. 26 -- It was understood tonight that the status of Senators and Deputies was still under consideration and that, although their salaries and other privileges expire on Sept. 30, this action, should not be interpreted as the dissolution of Parliament.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, each of whom is a New Jersey State champion, captured the husband-and-wife championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today by scoring 40, 38 -- 78 on the Crestmont Country Club course.

Many surf casters will tell you of the long wait they have had before catching a striped bass. Perhaps it will be of interest to them to know that off Montauk Point the surfmen have been having a run of luck, judging from the fish being weighed at Frank Tuma's station recently.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Senate Finance Committee joined the House today in backing the alternative methods of computing corporation excess profits in the defense tax bill, ruling out the recommendation made by President Roosevelt and the Treasury Department for permitting only the capital gains method.

An investigation of advertisements in foreign language newspapers published here revealed yesterday that as much as $200 a month may be sent to non-Americans in Hungary or Slovakia, but no commercial concern has yet been been authorized by the Treasury Department to ship food packages to any of the Axis countries or European territory that it dominates.

An agreement to end the "stoppage" by dress contractors involving 60,000 workers and 1,300 shops in the New York industry was reached by representatives of the groups concerned at a conference yesterday afternoon.

Data by Petroleum Institute The figures of the American Petroleum Institute show that gasoline stocks on the East Coast dropped last week 699,000 barrels to 20,094,000. Since some lease-lend supplies previously had been reported as part of the East Coast's supply, the drop was not so great as is indicated.

On the basis of a resolution of the Board of Higher Education approving discontinuance of Townsend Harris High School, Frederick vP. Bryan. Acting Corporation Counsel, announced that the city would apply soon for reconsideration of a Supreme Court decision demanding restoration of $100,000 to the 1941-42 budget for the continued operation of the school.

Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J., became the undisputed light-heavyweight champion of the world by defeating Tami Mauriello, youthful Bronx warrior, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. But for a moment, at least, the crowd thought Mauriello had got the decision because of a misinterpretation applied to the time-honored custom of introducing a new titleholder with the description:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Three home runs in the opener and a sixteen-hit attack topped by Dom Dallessandro's homer with the bases loaded in the nightcap gave the Cubs both ends of a double-header with the Phillies today, 5 to 4 and 11 to 3.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Plans for the construction of 566 additional cargo ships to carry war supplies for the democracies entered the contract phase today.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 27 -- Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, announced early this morning that a possible tie-up of telephone systems throughout the country had been averted by an agreement reached between the Western Electric Company and the Association of Communications and Equipment Workers, an independent union.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 26 -- The investigation of Nazi activities in Argentina took a dramatic turn today with the precipitate flight by air to Brazil of Gottfried Sandstede, officially listed as head of the Press Office of the German Embassy, but suspected of being head of the Gestapo and Heinrich Himmler's confidential agent in Argentina.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- The Air Ministry announced today that British planes sank two German ships and set fire to two more in widespread daylight operations yesterday that included raids on convoys in the North Sea and airdromes in France and Belgium.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 26 -- With British air-borne troops paving the way and occupying Iranian oil centers to protect British nationals, the columns of Imperial troops that entered the Middle Eastern country yesterday made considerable progress in less than twenty-four hours, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A new plan for reorganization of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company was proposed today by an examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission. The original plan of the commission was rejected by the Federal District Court in Denver and returned to the I.C.C. for further proceedings.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Lord Beaverbrook, the Minister of Supply, who returned from the United States on Sunday, said today in an interview that he wished to see the United States come into the war, but added that it was a matter for the American people to decide for themselves.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The British and Russian troops entering Iran in at least four places apparently are encountering little opposition, according to reports received here today. In fact, it would appear that so far the Anglo-Russian forces had met virtually no resistance.
THAT book published the other day about a 10-year-old boy and a yearling horse on a Wyoming ranch -- "My Friend Flicka,"* by Mary O'Hara -- is as good as every one says it is.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

It is becoming increasingly clear that the National Defense Mediation Board has injured its own prestige and usefulness by its timidity and vacillation, and that it made a particularly serious blunder in its decision in the Federal Shipbuilding case.
That crucial series at Ebbets Field ended in almost pitch darkness at 6:35 yesterday evening with the Dodgers still holding their game-and-a-half lead over the second-place Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- To China, engaged in a death struggle with Japan, the United States within two weeks will dispatch a military mission to arrange increased lease-lend aid and assist and advise the Chinese Army, President Roosevelt announced today.

As the Defense Tax Bill passed the House it had two main defects. The first was that it fell $300,000,000 short of the minimum goal of $3,500,000,000 which had been set by the Treasury. The second was that it failed to provide the broadening of the tax base which virtually all authorities had come to regard as an essential element in any program to guard against inflation.

Grover A. Whalen, who was appointed by Mayor La Guardia Monday to draw up a gasoline conservation plan for New York, will come face to face with some of the most difficult phases of the problem today in conferences with representatives of labor, of taxicab drivers and possibly of filling station owners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Complete reorganization of the set-up of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation's public-utility system appeared to be foreshadowed today by a long order by the Securities and Exchange Commission setting several questions concerning the system down for consideration on Sept. 16 under the "death-sentence," corporate simplification and other sections of the Holding Company Act.

TOKYO, Aug. 26 -- The international situation confronting Japan was discussed today by the Cabinet on the basis of a detailed report submitted by the Foreign Minister, Vice Admiral Teijiro Toyoda, which precipitated what the press refers to as a "brisk" debate among the members.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The slugging Red Sox regained third place from Cleveland today with a 9-to-4 triumph pegged on Boston's thirteen-hit attack and three errors by the Indians' outfielder Roy Weatherly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Roosevelt asserted in his press conference today that he had decided that the new War Depart-Building should be located south of the Arlington experimental farm where a quartermaster depot is being built.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 26 -- Increased profits of public utilities resulting from capacity production during the national emergency should be used as a "rainy day" stake by being added to inadequate depreciation reserves, Basil Manly, a member of the Federal Power Commission, said here today in an address at the fifty-third annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.

Reflecting reports of intensified weevil activity throughout the cotton belt and intimations from Washington that the government did not intend to release loan holdings immediately, the cotton market made yesterday its best recovery since late in July.

A stout cardboard container conceals a honey as flattering to the eye as it is appealing to the taste. Its attractive appearance resembles heavy cream whipped to a foamy froth and tinted the shade of cafeau-lait, and its sweet fragrance is like the scent of broad, sundrenched meadows.

WITH THE FINNISH FORCES, on the Karelian Front, Aug. 26 -- While all thoughts in Finland today are directed toward Viborg, the ancient Karelian capital that now seems to be within reach of the latest Finnish offensive, it might be of some interest to study the opening movements of the Karelian campaign.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The War Department today awarded contracts totaling $20,351,310. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and other high ranking officials paid honor yesterday morning at the Police Department's funeral for Harold J. King, the 30-year-old traffic patrolman who was shot dead last Friday when he stopped outside his home at 136 West 92d Street to question two men who were tampering with a car.

Mrs. Charles Poletti, wife of the Acting Governor, joined her husband yesterday in declining to view the exhibit of the New York State Federation for Planned Parenthood, a birth-control group, which Mr. Poletti had ruled might not exhibit at the State Fair in Syracuse.

If Dniepropetrovsk, the Zaporozhe power plant and the Dnieprostroy Dam had fallen into enemy hands in 1935 when the dam was completed, all Soviet Russia would have mourned the event as a national calamity. The mighty power project was then the prime symbol of industrialization and the coming of Russia's Iron Age.

The arrest of Michael Bowers, 39-year-old father of two children and a resident of Queens, as a suspect in a Stroudsburg, Pa., bank hold-up, was revealed here yesterday by B.E. Sackett, local chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The advance guard of the Russian Winter -- snow and rain and the chilliness of late August nights -- is now engaging the Germans in their battle against time on the Russian front.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 26 -- With 97 per cent of the regular force ready and eager to return to work this morning, operation of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company yards here resumed today under government operation.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 27 -- The Soviet Government has advised Japan that any effort to interfere with normal trade relations between Soviet Russia and the United States through Far Eastern ports would be considered an unfriendly act, it was announced in an official Foreign Office statement early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- New Zealand will "cooperate fully" with the United States and Great Britain if the war spreads to the Pacific, Peter Fraser, Laborite Prime Minister of that British dominion, said today.

The fifty-family apartment house at 10-20 North Avenue, Elizabeth, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to the Elizabeth-North Realty Corporation. Hood, Lafferty Emerson were the attorneys for the seller. Jerome C. Eisenberg represented the purchaser.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Estimates of continued broad marketings for later in the week took the edge off a generally steady to strong cattle market today and the closing trade was slow at steady prices. Steady to 10-cent lower values prevailed in the hog trade and Spring lambs closed steady to 15 cents lower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Warnings that serious shortages are developing rapidly in some important raw materials needed for defense, and that the civilian population will soon begin to feel a fuller impact of the "all out" rearmament program were voiced today by Edward R. Stettinius, Director of Priorities, and other officials of the Office of Production Management.
NEW YORK Mme. Dushan Simovitch, wife of the Premier of Yugoslavia, is at the New Weston.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today it would purchase apples from the 1941 crop under a program designed to offset the price-depressing effect of the loss of export markets. Purchases are to be made from growers, associations of growers and their agents at prices subject to change from time to time in accordance with market conditions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Soy beans continued today to pace the grain markets and advanced to new seasonal high prices for the fourth straight day. Closing sales on the Board of Trade here were near the top with gains of 2 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Roosevelt was reported today to be considering appointment of a super priorities board, including Vice President Wallace, to coordinate the allocation of materials and supplies for military, lease-lend, civilian and export needs.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Japanese Army is determined to continue its policies in the Far East -- policies that British Prime Minister Churchill said must stop -- Lieut. Col. Kunio Akiyama, spokesman for the Japanese forces in China, said today.

Falcons as Fighters The first news that falcons were to be trained as anti-parachute fighters injected a note of medieval color into a grim war. Later dispatches are of a character to baffle the interested but inexpert fans of falconry.

Plans for a nation-wide campaign to collect scrap iron are expected to be discussed today at a meeting of dealers and mill and foundry executives with top officials of the Office of Production Management and the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply in Washington, scrap iron dealers reported here yesterday.

Sir Thomas Beecham, the British conductor, has been engaged to conduct next season at the Metropolitan Opera House. He has signed a contract with General Manager Edward Johnson for six weeks and will conduct at least ten and perhaps as many as fifteen performances.

Mr. Roosevelt has been a little slow to appoint Francis Biddle, who has been Solicitor General, Assistant Attorney General and Acting Attorney General, to the office for which he has had so much experience and high qualifications. He has been a member of the bar for almost thirty years.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Aug. 27 -- The southern arm of the Red Army's pincers movement in the Gomel sector of Russia made some progress yesterday as a large section of the eastern bank of the Sozh River in the neighborhood of Guta, about twenty miles south of Gomel, was cleared of the Germans, according to Soviet reports received today.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Athletics, making their final appearance of the season here, moved into sixth place in the American League race by sweeping both ends of a bargain bill with the Tigers today, 9 to 1 and 2 to 1.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard, Washington's knuckle-ball pitcher, allowed the Browns ten hits today, but mastered every threat to safeguard a 3-to-0 victory.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- A record-breaking afternoon round gave Mike Turnesa, one of the six Turnesa brothers whose golfing exploits are familiar to all links followers, a topheavy lead for the Westchester open championship today at the ancient Apawamis Club.

Some national advertisers are becoming annoyed at the readership claims of a few magazines as contrasted with their actual circulation because magazine promotion leads dealers to expect greater response from advertising in such publications than they can possibly get.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 26 -- A lasting post-war world peace will be achieved only through a reconstituted League of Nations and an end to American isolationism, the Rev. Dr. Walter W. Van Kirk, secretary of the department of international justice and good will of the Federal Council of Churches, and Carlton J.H. Hayes, Professor of History at Columbia University, asserted at the 1941 Institute of Human Relations session tonight on the campus of Williams College.

The apartment house at 169-71 Court Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Seamen's Bank for Savings to the Horton Management Corporation, Harris Fein, president. The structure is on a plot 50 by 100 feet, and was sold for cash above a $20,500 mortgage.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Taking both heats decisively, Colby Hanover equaled his record of 2:04 1/4 in capturing the $6,000 Noyes Stake for 2-year-old trotters at the opening of the State Fair's Grand Circuit meeting today.

There has just been published in England a book entitled "America Chooses!" It is made up mainly of the utterances of President Roosevelt, from June, 1940, to June of this year, from his denunciation of Italy's entrance into the war to the statement on the sinking of the Robin Moor and the report on the workings of the lease-lend act.
BERLIN, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Headquarters today issued this communique :

Republican organization attacks on petitions entering John R. Davies in their primaries as a candidate for Mayor and John Cashmore for Borough President of Brooklyn shifted yesterday from the Board of Elections to the Supreme Court amid charges that Mayor La Guardia's Republican designating petitions were suffused with fraud.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Strikes during the first seven months of 1941 cost 15,750,000 man days, five times more than in the corresponding period of last year and 44 per cent above the average during the corresponding months of the five-year period from 1935 through 1939, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Fiction's fabulous sleuth, Sherlock Holmes, provided the inspiration yesterday for a collegiate fashion note.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- An investigation of the East Coast fuel shortage was unanimously approved today by the Senate Commerce Committee, on motion of Senator Maloney of Connecticut, after three Senate opponents of the President's foreign policies had challenged the Administration to prove that the shortage was real and not just an attempt to bolster the war spirit.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 25:

A greater understanding on the part of the public about the value of vitamins and of health foods generally is necessary before consumer response to such products attains the volume it should, Dr. Walter R. Eddy, Professor Emeritus of Physiological Chemistry at Columbia University, told members of the National Health Foods Association, in convention at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,975,450 barrels daily, a new record and 22,150 over the 3,953,300 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 35,450 barrels more than the calculation of 3,940,000 daily for August by the Bureau of Mines.
Moore-McCormack Lines announced yesterday that three freighters now operating on the Pacific Coast would be shifted to New York because of the demand for space in the New York-South American trade.

The appointment of a planning committee to define a broad program of action for the Central Good Neighbor Committee in its efforts to strengthen civilian morale and preserve American democratic ideals in local neighborhoods throughout the country was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Elliott, chairman of the main unit.

Maurice Evans will bring his next Shakespearean revival, "Macbeth," to the National on Nov. 10. Judith Anderson will be co-starred with the actor-producer. To make way for "Macbeth," the current tenant at the National, "The Corn Is Green," will be transferred to the Royale on Sept. 9.

In view of the Government's persistent effort to bid up the price of cotton -- by fixing imaginary "parities" with other goods, by outright subsidy, or by the Congressional attempt to forbid the Government to sell, at the high prevailing prices, cotton previously bought by the Government to relieve the farmers -- the bulletin by the Department of Agriculture on the world's requirements is interesting.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the extensive comment on the alliance of Soviet Russia with England much emphasis has been placed on the similarity between the Soviets and Nazi Germany; and, of course, it is true that the Stalin government, with its secret police and arbitrary methods, has much in common with that of Hitler.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Aug. 26 -- The City Council refused today to allow use of the municipal auditorium for a speech by Charles A. Lindbergh Friday night under the auspices of the America First Committee.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- Today's Soviet communique said that Red Army troops had continued to fight stubbornly all along the front. Yesterday Soviet reports told of a concerted infantry, cavalry, tank and plane assault in which the Russians stormed and recaptured an unidentified city in the central sector.

The taxpayer containing five stores and four three-room apartments at 65 West Boardwalk, Long Beach, L.I., was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of James C. McCormick, Inc., broker. The structure is on a plot 80 by 181 feet and was sold for cash above a $51,000 purchase money mortgage.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Reports received here tonight said that Yoshitsugu Tatekawa, the Japanese Ambassador to Moscow, had notified the Soviet Government that Japan would not allow shipments of American war materials to reach Russia by way of the Pacific.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Two hundred and five New York trainees, the first to be inducted here under the present draft, took the oath today in the newly opened induction section of the Recruit Reception Center, where 64,000 men have been "processed" since the first draft call just nine months ago.

The taxpayer containing five stores and four three-room apartments at 65 West Boardwalk, Long Beach, L.I., was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of James C. McCormick, Inc., broker. The structure is on a plot 80 by 181 feet and was sold for cash above a $51,000 purchase money mortgage.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Ilona Massey, Brian Donlevy and Preston Foster were signed today by Edward Small for the leading roles in "Heliotrope Harry," formerly "A Whiff of Heliotrope, which deals with international jewel thievery.

The wild rush of the Reds to get into the private fight between the Dodgers and the Cards for the National League pennant was rudely checked by those casual bystanders, the Giants, at the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the New Yorkers halted the world champions, 7 to 4, in the opening fray of a double-header.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- After the veteran Jim Tobin gained his eleventh victory for the Braves by limiting the Pirates to four hits for a 4-3 decision, the visitors clouted three of his battery-mates for a 6-1 triumph to divide today's double-header.

A syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will make today an offering of $30,000,000 of first mortgage, Series A, 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company. The bonds, which will mature on Aug. 1, 1971, will be offered at 106 7/8 and accrued interest.

Mike McGinty, 40-year-old temporary watchman on the IRT division of the city subway, who lives in a furnished room at 114 East Eighty-seventh Street and has worked at his present job for five months, was in considerable difficulty yesterday over the use he had made of his life savings of $1,000.

Bound for London, where he will make a full report to officials of the Belgian Government-in-Exile on efforts to recover from French funds in this country $230,000,000 in gold deposited with the Bank of France in 1939 and 1940 for safekeeping, Hubert J.N. Ansiaux, an inspector for the National Bank of Belgium, left here yesterday morning aboard the Atlantic Clipper.

Trading in beef and lamb was fair to good yesterday. Other classes of locally dressed meats moved only fair to slow. Veal and calf were barely steady. Fresh pork cuts were about steady and other classes of traefer meats steady. Early demand for kosher meats was slow and prices were barely steady to weak.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Professor Casimir Bartel, former Prime Minister of Poland and an eminent scientist, has been shot by the Gestapo in Lwow, according to news received by the Polish Government here.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- After the veteran Jim Tobin gained his eleventh victory for the Braves by limiting the Pirates to four hits for a 4-3 decision, the visitors clouted three of his battery-mates for a 6-1 triumph to divide today's double-header.

A syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will make today an offering of $30,000,000 of first mortgage, Series A, 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company. The bonds, which will mature on Aug. 1, 1971, will be offered at 106 7/8 and accrued interest.

Mike McGinty, 40-year-old temporary watchman on the IRT division of the city subway, who lives in a furnished room at 114 East Eighty-seventh Street and has worked at his present job for five months, was in considerable difficulty yesterday over the use he had made of his life savings of $1,000.

Bound for London, where he will make a full report to officials of the Belgian Government-in-Exile on efforts to recover from French funds in this country $230,000,000 in gold deposited with the Bank of France in 1939 and 1940 for safekeeping, Hubert J.N. Ansiaux, an inspector for the National Bank of Belgium, left here yesterday morning aboard the Atlantic Clipper.

Trading in beef and lamb was fair to good yesterday. Other classes of locally dressed meats moved only fair to slow. Veal and calf were barely steady. Fresh pork cuts were about steady and other classes of traefer meats steady. Early demand for kosher meats was slow and prices were barely steady to weak.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion, Metro's remake of the comedy-melodrama, "Whistling In The Dark," will be the newcomer. Red Skelton is starred in the picture, which includes Conrad Veidt, Ann Rutherford, Rags Ragland, Eve Arden, Henry O'Neill and Paul Stanton in its supporting roles....

James B. Schafer, head of the "Church of the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians," in West Fifty-fourth Street, pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions to the theft of $9,000 in the last three years from one of his women followers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was with great interest that I read in your Sunday edition the useful article by Turner Catledge on the various causes of American apathy toward our defense efforts, but there is one point he brought up which calls for further exposition.

In the best stock market in almost a week, prices made a moderate advance and interest was spread liberally throughout the share list, while volume increased. There was little news to account for the mild upswing, but buyers found an oversold condition in stocks, and small orders brought ready improvement in values.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Rosetown made it a stern chase and a long one for all the others in the Diana Handicap, run through mud today, and at the end of a mile and a furlong she still was on the head end to score by a halt length.

President Roosevelt's veto of the bill which would have frozen government holdings of cotton and wheat was welcomed in Worth Street yesterday, both as an indication that the power of the farm bloc to impede anti-inflation measures was waning and as a promise that raw cotton would not be permitted to advance to levels which would further restrict mill offerings of fabrics on which ceilings have been imposed.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- Soviet troops invading Iran have occupied Tabriz, second city of the country, and Ardebil, according to a broadcast Tass report received here from Moscow. The broadcast said the information came from Tiflis, Russia.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26 -- The United Mine Workers and the mine operators will present a united front in seeking permission of the Federal Price Control Administrator, Leon Henderson, for a minimum wholesale price of $6.75 a ton for domestic nut coal and larger sizes of anthracite.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- About 5,000 out of 5,694 eligible employes of the Detroit Street Railways had voted this evening in the city-supervised election to decide whether they want the American Federation of Labor or the Congress of Industrial Organizations to be the sole bargaining agent for all workers on the bus and street car system.

A 2.13-inch downpour of rain accompanying a severe thunderstorm that passed directly over mid-Manhattan last evening drenched thousands of homeward-bound New Yorkers and caused a tie-up of the Independent Subway line in Brooklyn and Queens, and delays on the city's other subways.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Riza Shah Pahlevi of Iran saw the British and Russian Ministers this morning. Following their meeting, there was perhaps reason to believe that the Shah was bowing to the inevitable and that the Allied advance would not be resisted with any strength.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- With complete cooperation from everything but the weather, Coach Jim Crowley began to put the pressure on his Eastern Football All-Stars, 1941 edition, this afternoon.
BERLIN, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- German mechanized forces pounding upon Leningrad were reported officially today to have seized the city of Luga within the outer defense ring of the former czarist capital.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Creation of a military subdivision to be known as the East African Command, with Lieut. Gen. Sir William Platt as general officer commanding in chief, was announced here today. The new command will be directly under the War Office and will include all territories between the southern borders of the Anglo-Egyptian Command and the northern frontier of Southern Rhodesia.
The Broadway theatrical season will have its formal start next week with the premiere of one drama and the resumption of the engagements of two musicals.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Conservation leaders gathered at the State Fair today to dedicate the new Conservation Building in a ceremony that is expected to mark a new era in the progress of conservation in this State.

VERSAILLES, German-occupied France, Thursday, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Pierre Laval and his faithful follower, Marcel Deat, were shot here yesterday by Paul Collette, French assassin posing as a volunteer in the French legion recruited to fight Russia.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- Japanese reports and implications that Soviet-Chinese discussions have been going on, presumably to cement still closer the relations between the two governments, was again denied here yesterday after the Foreign Commissar, Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, had a forty-five-minute conference with the Japanese Ambassador, Yoshitsugu Tatekawa.

Negotiations for a new wage and working agreement between the National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute, representing ship-owners, will be opened early next month, probably on Sept. 9, at the institute offices at 11 Broadway, it was reported yesterday.

Protesting the ousting of 106 swimming teachers, Morris Shapiro, vice president of the United Parents Associations, urged the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday to rescind its action and restore these teachers in the "interests of safety."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- To keep defense production going, most of the steel workers in the Pittsburgh district will work Labor Day.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- Once more the Soviet Government proclaimed today its reassurances to the Iranian people, stating that their independence could be considered completely safeguarded and that Anglo-Russian action had forestalled Axis attempts to involve Iran in anti-Allied schemes.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Herbert F. Kroeger of St. Albans and his son, Arthur, won low gross honors in the eighteenth annual father and son tournament held under the auspices of the Long Island Golf Association today, touring the Cherry Valley Club course in 43, 38 -- 81.

There are probably cynics of the district clubhouse school who still say Mike McGinty merely got hold of the wrong guy. But there is more to it than that. Mike is the temporary subway watchman who wanted a permanent job. In a letter to William J. Daly, secretary of the Board of Transportation, he expressed the polite hope that one might come his way.

A good share of the apartment leasing activity reported yesterday covered residential quarters in East Side houses, with many buildings on Park Avenue and in the Fifties and Seventies appearing frequently in the lists.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- Dismissal of Secretary Perkins as head of the Department of Labor because she has demonstrated "her lack of ability" was requested of President Roosevelt today by the Veterans of Foreign Wars in a resolution adopted at the national encampment.

Men's Wear Promotions Pull Men's wear stores did well this week, particularly where cut-price promotions were featured. August overcoat sales drew an excellent response, medium-weight suit offerings moved well and furnishings promotions received attention.

DURING the past four or five Summers and Winters, while the Misses A, B, C, D, E, F and G (and H) of the several sovereign States in the Union have been turning out their huge and patriotic historical novels, Miss Margaret Leech (Mrs. Ralph Pulitzer) has been busily at work on a volume of non-fiction that is, in effect, one of the best historical novels in years.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 28 -- Intense air activity was maintained yesterday over the Channel and German-occupied territory after a night in which aircraft of the Bomber Command had attacked industrial areas of Cologne and the docks at Havre and Boulogne in force and fighters had attended to airdromes in Northern France.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Muffin Man, 8-year-old chestnut gelding owned by the Bryn Du Farms of Mrs. Sallie Jones-Sexton of Granville, Ohio, and piloted by Miss Elinor Leh of Johnstown, Pa., today won the Johnston L. Redmond Trophy, leading jumping event of the initial program of the Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair Horse Show.

Principal railroads serving New York City completed preparations yesterday for what they believe will be one of the largest holiday travel crowds in many years. They estimated that travel by railroad into and out of New York City over the labor Day week-end would exceed last year's figures by 20 per cent, and will be even larger than the travel on the Fourth of July of this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is a happy circumstance that permitted Lowell Mellett to bestow high praise upon the press associations and the American radio for the standard they have set of truthful reporting, as described in a recent dispatch from Boston in THE TIMES.

Fears of a possible short crop because of heavy insect damage again dominated the cotton market here yesterday. After opening strong at overnight gains of 9 to 14 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to show moderate strength, and closed at net advances of 14 to 18 points for the day.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 27 -- Answering William Perry, president of the New Zealand World War Veterans, who had asserted in the Legislative Council that an open conflict with Japan was inevitable, the Japanese Consulate issued a general statement today saying that, while no one should underestimate the tension in the Far East, exaggerated alarms were deplorable.

William Mitchell Kendall, senior member of the architectural firm of McKim, Mead White, designers of the Municipal Building, the Pennsylvania Station, the old Madison Square Garden and many other famous buildings and monuments here and abroad, who died at Bar Harbor, Me., on June 29, at the age of 85, named several public institutions as legatees in his will, filed for probate yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 26 contains a report of your Berlin correspondent about the way the Russians are now jamming the official German news broadcasts by heckling whenever the German announcer pauses for a moment.

A fifty-family apartment house it 10-20 North Avenue, near North Broad Street, Elizabeth, N.J., has been purchased by the Elizabeth-North Realty Corporation of Newark for cash above a new mortgage for $112,500 by the Home Life Insurance Company.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- A stern warning against the complacency of a section of the British public that feels United States deliveries of planes, tanks and other supplies, will win the war for Britain, coupled with an explanation of the limited powers actually held by President Roosevelt, who is almost universally looked on in this country as the savior of Britain, is contained in a striking letter printed in this morning's issue of The Times.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Aug. 27 -- The Boerse opened heavy today and fluctuations were wide owing to the withdrawal of the tax on blocked marks and the announcement of the introduction of a tax on dividends. After a weak opening there was a sharp rally in the leading issues.

Showing an increase of 55 per cent over a year ago, Charleston, S.C., led other cities in percentage of retail sales gains during July, according to the monthly report issued by the Federal Reserve Board. For the seven months, Norfolk, Va., was in the lead with a rise of 41 per cent over the corresponding period of 1940.

Although tax charges were two and a half times larger than those of the corresponding period a year ago, earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year were only $1,000,000 less than in the first six months of 1940, according to the semi-annual report issued for publication today.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The methodical march of British and Russian troops -- almost unopposed -- into Iran was the most effective answer today to a proposal by Riza Shah Pahlevi that the invasion should be called off upon his promise to throw German technicians and tourists representing a potential fifth column out of his country.

In spite of the astonishing fact that Ernie Lombardi actually stole a, base, the world champion Reds were no great problem for the pen nant-hungry Dodgers in the final night game of the season at Ebbets Field last night.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Iran was reliably reported today to have delivered to the British and Russian Ministers a plea that the Iranian war be ended and a guarantee that all Germans save a few in the indispensable technical posts would be ousted within a week.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Aug. 27 -- Forty thousand men of the Sixth Army Corps received tactical instructions tonight for the opening problem tomorrow in New England's largest peacetime manoeuvres and prepared to move out of camp.
The war against Iran enabled the British to clean up the Iranian ports of Italian and German ships that took refuge in the neutral Iranian ports after the outbreak of the war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Contracts totaling $12,975,403 were awarded by the War Department today. Firms in New York State receiving awards were as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) Paced by Arky Vaughan, the Pirates fired a 21-hit barrage against the Phillies today to scuttle the cellar occupants, 12 to 2.
Byers (A.M.) Company The A.M. Byers Company voted a dividend of $1.75 plus interest of 27 cents on the preferred stock. This makes the eighth 51.75 payment with interest thus far this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Senate Finance Committee eliminated from the defense tax bill today the excise taxes on radio broadcasting stations and outdoor advertising, and drove to within comparatively easy striking distance of completion of the measure.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) --The National Safety Council, acting on a request by President Roosevelt, planned today to mobilize an Army of safety-minded citizens for a campaign to halt accidents hampering the defense program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- An editorial in the new issue of Army Ordnance, official publication of the Army Ordnance Association, out today, advocated immediate appointment of a single directing head for the armament program. It declared this lack to be the first weakness in the defense program.

The stock market exhibited yesterday even a better brand of confidence in the international picture and defense policies than it had shown recently, but a slightly slower pace of trading kept prices from forging ahead more than major fractions in the main body of issues.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The conference between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill focused the attention of the world on the peace aims of the democracies. What actual steps will be taken by the democracies to overcome Hitler have been left to our imagination.

Many miles from home, fourteen Girl Guides from American republics and twenty-nine visiting Venezuelan Boy Scouts met yesterday at Inter-American House at 11 West Fifty-fourth Street. They were outnumbered by the hundred New York Boy and Girl Scouts who were their hosts, but they lost no time in turning a quiet afternoon into a gay fete with authentic South American flavor.

Even before Winston Churchill disclosed in his world-wide broadcast that "practical arrangements" already were being put in motion to accomplish the downfall of Nazi tyranny, it had been generally understood that the historic meeting at sea with President Roosevelt accomplished more than the mere expression of pious hopes.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- The self-contained Red Army of the Caucasus continued its rapid penetration of North Iran's highlands today, working down the Tabriz-Teheran highway, and this evening its vanguard was considerably less than 300 miles from Teheran.

Besides broadening the tax base by lowering personal exemptions, the most important decisions made by the Senate Finance Committee with respect to the tax bill have been approval of the basic features of the excess profits tax as passed by the House and the adoption of measures simplifying the calculation of income taxes.

MARBLEHEAD NECK, Mass., Aug. 27 -- With Captain Bobby Coulson and his Eastern crew making a comeback from an apparently hopeless position, the twentieth, national junior sailing championship for the Sears Cup was virtually deadlocked among three crews after the sixth and seventh races today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from Sidney Weinberg THE TIMES of Aug. 21, "Sight Requirement Handicap," is very interesting and should be answered for the benefit of the thousands of young Americans who are willing to serve in the Air Forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A Federal tax yield of $10,000,000,000, or about three times the $3,509,000,000 estimated yield from the tax bill now before Congress, was urged today by the National Economy League as the only alternative to inflation or a "totalitarian" system of price control.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Thursday, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- The entire city of Tallinn, besieged capital of Estonia and most beautiful city of the Baltic States, was being devoured by flames early today in a devastating application of Russian "scorched earth" tactics, according to reports reaching Stockholm.

SOUTH BEND, Aug. 27 -- In a round-table forum conducted here today at the Studebaker Corporation's proving grounds by Paul G. Hoffman, president and automobile editor, optimism was expressed as to both the outlook of the automobile industry and the cars to be offered to the public.

Acting on information obtained by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, who has been investigating charges of police protection of organized gambling rings in Brooklyn, a special detail raided late yesterday a Brooklyn rooming house where four men and a woman allegedly were operating a "numbers racket" that had 250,000 plays a day and averaged $3,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, declared tonight that he was more apprehensive of war with Japan than in Europe, and he contended that if war with Japain eventuated, "we will be preserving the British domination of Asia rather than helping the Unite States."

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- All day yesterday and throughout the night the battle for Leningrad continued without a break. The Germans, hurling everything they have at the Soviet line between points northeast of Kingisepp and north of Novgorod, have not been able to dent the defenses, according to the Russians.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- The Chicago Bears, champions of the professional football world, turn their explosive Model T attack against the Collegiate All-Stars tomorrow night before the season's first sellout crowd.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of commercial and cultural elections between the American Republics, told tonight how development of the interests of the two Americas could serve in the ceaenting of closer relations within the hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Certification of communities and industries for government aid in remedying labor displacement caused by defense curtailment of supplies will be based on surveys now being made by the labor division of the Office of Production Management, according to a statement today by Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of OPM.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Eight insurance companies and an individual who dissented from the plan of recapitalization and merger of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation petitioned the Allegheny Common Pleas Court today to name appraisers to determine the value of 7 per cent preferred stock which they declined to exchange for new preferred and common stocks.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 -- The Yankees, traveling all by themselves in the American League flag race, appeared in an extraordinarily vengeful mood tonight, belting the Browns into submission by 11 to 1 and with one full swoop bringing about a series of wholesale mathematical eliminations.
OMASA, Neb., Aug. 27 -- After what happened in the national amateur championship today it will be necessary to start compiling a new "Who's Who" in golf.

Tanker Control Board No opposition was voiced here yesterday by leading oil executives to the creation of a control board for tankers of United States registry in an effort to help assure adequate supplies of petroleum for the Atlantic Coast Since the Maritime Commission in May commandeered fifty tankers of United States registry to move oil for the British it has been realized that the creation of some such board was necessary.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- The American Federation of Labor's streetcar affiliate won exclusive bargaining rights today on the Detroit Street Railways System over the State, County and Municipal Workers Union (C.I.O.) by a vote of 3,076 to 1,925.

A Molyneux collection, highly selective and numbering only fifteen models, was presented yesterday morning by Bonwit Teller. This offering gave proof that a secret can be kept in the fashion world if need be. The suits and dresses were designed by Captain Molyneux when he was in the United States last April.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Bill Poland, New York battler just starting up the heavyweight trail, knocked out rugged Eddie Blunt, New York Negro, tonight in the fourth of a scheduled twenty-five-round bout. Poland floored Blunt twice before a straight right to the jaw sent the Negro to the canvas for the count.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Consumers of iron and steel scrap and dealers in these commodities were told today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, that rigid enforcement of the OPACS iron and steel price schedule would be started on Tuesday.

The Slavonic Committee for Democracy, Inc., 50 Pine Street, an anti-Communist organization, urged immediate American participation in the war as essential to defeat totalitarianism, in a statement issued yesterday by Andrew Kalpaschnikoff, general chairman.

CEDARHURST, L.L., Aug. 27 -- The national champions in singles and doubles were beaten at the Rockaway Hunting Club today in a tennis match between the International Lawn Tennis Club of the United States and a guest team.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Starting the final round with a twelvestroke edge over the field, Mike Turnesa, Fairview professional, romped off with the Westchester open golf championship at Apawamis today. Mike added a brilliant 68 this morning to his 71 and record-breaking 66 of yesterday, and with the knowledge that only a complete collapse would displace him toured the final eighteen in 70.

Returning to this city after settlement in Washington of the dispute between the Western Electric Company and the Association of Communications Equipment Workers, Henry Mayer, counsel for the independent union, disclosed yesterday that the organization had given up its demand for a "maintenance of membership" clause at the suggestion of Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Aug. 27 -- Tne Army's first tank destroyer battalion gave a demonstration here today of the tactics developed to stop the sweep of Panzer units such as might be employed by an invader.

VICHY, France, Aug. 27 -- The coal shortage in France is such that consumer families may expect for domestic purposes -- both cooking and heat -- not more than 500 kilograms [about 1,100 pounds] of coal for the five Winter months from November to March.

Jacques de Sieyes, representative in the United States of General de Gaulle and of the Free French Government, has taken offices for immediate occupancy on the fifth floor of the International Building, Rockefeller Center. For several months the New York offices of the Free French movement have been at 730 Fifth Avenue.

John Day announces that manufacturing difficulties have held up the new book by Nehru of India, but that the book should be ready by January. It is a large book called "Glimpses of History" and, like the author's autobiography, "Toward Freedom," was written in jail.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- All manufacturers and producers are required under a regulation issued today to accept defense orders, subject to a few specific limitations, even if this will prevent or delay deliveries on non-defense orders, or defense orders with lower preference ratings.

TOKYO, Aug. 27 -- Raising a direct issue with the United States and Russia, the Japanese Government has made formal representations to Washington and Moscow against the shipment of high octane gasoline from America to the Soviet Union through Vladivostok, it was officially announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- President Roosevelt moved today to plug leaks by which military equipment, munitions and machine tools could filter through the Philippine Islands to Axis and non-democratic countries. He issued a proclamation subjecting to full export control all such materials which had not been previously placed under such control.
BERLIN, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The regular High Command communique from the Fuehrer's Headquarters said today:

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Rialto, RKO's "Parachute Battalion" will have its local premiere. Officers and men of the 501st Parachute Battalion stationed at Fort Benning, Ga., participated in the making of the film which deals with the new arm of the air service.

The United States Maritime Commission will dedicate its first Pacific Coast training station for apprentice seamen on Saturday at Port Hueneme, Calif., it was announced yesterday. The commission has expended $750,000 on the station in its nation-wide program to provide seamen for the merchant marine.

Directors of the Associated Electric Company at a meeting held yesterday in Wilmington, Del., elected A.F. Tegen president. He also was elected a director, along with Willard L. Thorp, co-trustee of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation.

VICHY, France, Aug. 27 -- The first anniversary tomorrow of the formation of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's French Legion -- composed of the veterans of two wars -- will be marked throughout the unoccupied zone and the maining' colonies by the beginning of a four-day demonstration for a show of unity behind the aged Chief of State.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- On the basis of an authoritative military statement made here today, the German forces that reportedly have established bridgeheads across the lower Dnieper and are deployed east of that river appear to have taken Zaporozhe, an important Russian city on the eastern bank.

Why is Japan bent on making a dangerous issue out of the delivery of American supplies to the Soviet Union ? This is the most puzzling aspect of the crisis arising out of the representations made by Tokyo against the shipment of aviation oil from the United States to Vladivostok.

VICHY, France, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- A Communist plot to stir up strife between French civilians and the German occupation forces was alleged in an official statement today to have been responsible for sabotage of railroads, murder of a German naval officer and three terrorist demonstrations in Paris.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Kathryn Grayson and Ann Sothern were named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading roles in "Very Warm for May," which has been scheduled for Fall production. Miss Grayson will be seen as May Graham, the role played by Grace MacDonald on Broadway two seasons ago, while Miss Sothern has been cast as Winnie Spofford, Eve Arden's stage character.

VICHY, France, Thursday, Aug. 28 -- Pierre Laval and Marcel Deat, outstanding champions of French "collaboration" with Germany, were seriously wounded at Versailles yesterday morning by a young Frenchman, who fired bullets into each of the two men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Following is the tank wagon price for "regular" gasoline in some Eastern cities and the schedule of fair maximum retail service station prices issued today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator:

BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- Charlie Root, who was 42 last St. Patrick's Day, hung his 200th major-league triumph on the walls of baseball's Hall of Fame today as he set down the Braves, 6 to 4, in the second half of a twin bill.

The ratio of advertising expenditures to production value, sales volume and national income this year will be unusually low, as a result of the sharp spurt in these factors, compared with the minor gains in advertising. The ratio may well compare with the depths of the depression, when advertising and selling expenses were slashed to the bone, and is substantially smaller than the year 1929, when advertising volume reached an all-time high.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- While Russian troops moved on southward in Iran from the Caucasus today the British share in the joint campaign was a steady move northward from the Persian Gulf and eastward from Iraq.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- December and May wheat and all deliveries of soy beans and oats sold today at the highest prices since 1937 on the Board of Trade here, with soy beans pacing the advance. The latter closed around the top at gains of 4 to 4 1/2 cents a bushel, making the fifth straight day that the market has gone into new high ground.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Fingerprinting of all the people in the United States as an identification aid in case of air raids and appointment of a special attache to the Embassy in London to represent the civilian defense effort of this country were among recommendations made today to Mayor La-Guardia by the Civil Defense Mission of the Office of Civilian Defense, which recently returned from London

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Mrs. George H. Bostwick, general chairman of the committee arranging the polo match to be played here at Bostwick Field on Sunday afternoon for the benefit of the Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund, will give a luncheon preceding the game, for some of the young women who have been assisting her in plans for the event.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Immediate preparation to provide for emergency medical service for civilian casualties in case the United States is attacked was stressed today by the Office of Civilian Defense as a fundamental part of its program.

Finland's Landlocked Navy Dispatches from Finland tell how an improvised navy, composed of fishing trawlers and speedboats, operating in Lake Ladoga, assisted in the encirclement of Sortavala and Kaekisalmi, by occupying the islands in the archipelago off those cities and mounting artillery there.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- The fact that sections of the German public are speculating whether Nazi leaders have not underestimated the strength and staying power of Soviet Russia is admitted and an attempt to put an end to the conjecture is made by the Schwarze Korps, organ of Heinrich Himmler, the head of the political police.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- The Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran continues to inspire copious hostile comment in the German press. One German commentator says that the "sham arguments advanced by the aggressors of Iran in defense of their action have failed to impress the world as justification for the aggression."

A plan to revise the operating methods of New York's 12,000 taxicabs. designed to save 18,000,000 gallons of gasoline annually, was presented yesterday to Grover A. Whalen, who is preparing a program of gasoline conservation for Mayor La Guardia.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Led by Outfielder Jeff Heath, who drove home seven runs with two homers and a triple, the Indians gained an 11-to-4 victory over the Athletics today.

The pamphlet report of the Keystone Steel and Wire Company covering the fiscal year to June 30 shows a net profit of $1,618,376 after depreciation, interest. Federal income and excess-profit taxes. This is equal to $2.13 each on Keystone's 757,632 shares of capital stock, compared with $1.87 a share, or $1,418,221, a year before.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Kearny decision has been made. Last week I said in a private communication:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Acting Governor Charles Poletti and Howard E. Babcock, New York State Grange official, took opposing points of view tonight on the attitude of labor toward defense. They spoke at the annual farm dinner given at the Onondaga Country Club by Jerome D. Barurn, publisher of The Syracuse Post-Standard.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 27 -- Declaring that Joseph J. Mascuch, president of Breeze Corporations, Inc. of Newark, aircraft accessories manufacturer, had robbed and exploited the corporation for his own benefit, Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder, culminating a stockholders' suit pending for more than a year, ordered today the appointment of a receiver and the return to the corporation by five other officers and directors of corporation stock, cash and other assets totaling $2,000,000 in value.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- German and Hungarian forces were said in a Budapest communique, confirmed in Berlin today, to have stormed across the Dnieper and into the Eastern Ukraine after breaking Marshal Semyon Budenny's defense lines along the eastern bank.

Senator Gerald P. Nye charged last night at an America First rally before 10,000 persons in Breinlinger's Park, the Bronx, that where patriotic Americans were giving the government their aluminum pots and pans to aid defense effort, the government arsenal at Rock Island, Ill., was asking junk dealers to bid on scrap aluminum.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) -- An out-of-doors site accommodating 10,000 persons was assured today for speeches of Charles A. Lindbergh and Senator Wheeler here Friday night, the America First Committee announced.

Fresh frozen strawberries, luxuriant and lovely with their brightly blushing cheeks and that indefinable, familiar fragrance, are a nostalgic reminder of the waning Summer. They are welcome to Winter, too, for the frosty fruit that has just appeared in the markets of this city brings the promise of fine, fat berries all through the cold months to come.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 26:

MTNEOLA, L.I., Aug. 27 -- District Court Judge Leslie J. Ekenberg today fixed Oct. 15 as the last date for the prosecution and defense counsel to file briefs in the trial of Theodore H. Zittel of Northport, L.I., who on Aug. 2 picketed Jones Beach restaurants in a motor boat equipped with a portable loudspeaker in alleged violations of a State park ordinance.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Nearness of the Labor Day holiday together with reduced receipts and firmness in the dressed-trade market drew buyers into the hog market actively today for the accumulation of fresh supplies at prices 10 to 25 cents higher than yesterday, but cattle prices weakened under pressure of continued large marketings.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Even though shut off as late as the head of the stretch, Romping Home overcame all difficulty and decisively scored in the $5,725 Adirondack Handicap, run for the thirty-ninth time before 9,928 persons today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Japanese efforts to discourage American shipments of war supplies to Russia by way of the Pacific and Vladivostok were met by an assertion from Secretary of State Cordell Hull today that the United States would insist upon the policy of the freedom of the seas in the Pacific.

For six innings at the Polo Grounds last night the Cardinals acted as if they still were battling the Dodgers, but then they discovered that it was only the harmless Giants they were facing and so smashed over six runs for a spectacular 8-5 victory that was not too displeasing to a gathering Of 19,622.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Tigers, after dropping their last two games, juggled their line-up for today's opener with the Red Sox and, coupled with the wildness of Jack Wilson, the move paid off with a 6-to-3 victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Secretary of the Navy Knox said today the Administration would decide "in a very short time" on procedure involved in government operation of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company shipyard at Kearny, N.J.
NEW YORK Arthur Bliss Lane, United States Minister to Yugoslavia, and Mrs. Lane have arrived from Washington and are at the Ambassador.

Efforts to develop a series of schedules for reduction of chlorine consumption by manufacturers of various types of paper have been undertaken by trade groups and it was expected yesterday that a detailed program would be ready for presentation to the Office of Production Management by about the middle of next month.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Twenty-seven thousand workers in the glass industry have received almost $3,000,000 in wage increases at conferences between union leaders and manufacturers that started here July 22 and ended tonight.

There is little labor trouble to hamper New Zealand's war efforts, as strikes have been forbidden by the government for the duration of the war, Peter Fraser, Prime Minister of New Zealand, said yesterday.

Trading in steer beef, though fair, was not as active yesterday as earlier this week. Cow beef was active. Veal, calf and fresh pork cuts moved only fair and lamb carcasses showed signs of slowing up. The markets, though somewhat uneven, were mostly steady. Kosher beef opened steady today, kosher veal weak, lamb lower.
Apartment structures along Central Park South, Central Park West and in Greenwich Village drew many of the new tenancies announced yesterday.

The six-year term of Edwin S. Smith as a member of the National Labor Relations Board is ended. It is generally assumed that he will not be reappointed, though there has been no direct word from the President. Representatives of C.I.O. unions have urged his reappointment, while the American Federation of Labor Executive Council has opposed it.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 27 -- Ground warfare has flared briefly again in Ethiopia, where a small British detachment, cooperating with Ethiopian patriots and aided by the Royal and South African Air Forces, has captured an Italian fort in the Uolchefit area, just north of Debarech, which is about fortyfive miles north of Gondar, British headquarters here announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Seven manufacturers of bolt, nut, rivet and screw-machine products who do 41.5 per cent of this kind of business in the United States made in 1939 an average profit of 5.2 per cent on stockholders' investment, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 -- Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice opened his Summer home, Marimar, this afternoon for the annual book week tea in behalf of the American Merchant Marine Library Association. The party was arranged by Mrs. Lebrun Rhinelander, chairman of book week, and her committee.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A three-run splurge in the eighth inning enabled Syracuse to beat Newark in its final appearance in the local ball park tonight, 9 to 7. John Bottarini's double with the bases loaded scored two of the runs that broke a 6-to-6 tie.

Featuring as its theme the five-dress wardrobe for women "who want that New York look," first consumer copy in the $1,000,000 national advertising campaign of the New York Dress Institute made its appearance yesterday. The initial advertisement pictures and quotes Mrs. W. Palmer Dixon of 400 Park Avenue on the choosing of "striking Fall New York creations."
