A Brooklyn mother, apparently suffering from a delusion that her family was infected with an incurable disease, slashed the throats of four of her sleeping children, killing three, clubbed her husband, a former patrolman, and committed suicide shortly after dawn yesterday.

Charging bad faith and the breaking of promises made last June when a strike of operating employes of the city's unified transit lines was averted, officials of the Transport Workers Union C.I.O. affiliate, rejected yesterday a revised and standardized schedule of wages and hours adopted in their presence by the Board of Transportation at a special meeting held in its offices at 250 Hudson Street.

A plan of reorganization for Warren Brothers Company, a paving concern, has been filed in the Federal Court at Springfield, Mass., and the week of Sept. 16 has been set tentatively for a hearing on the plan by Federal Judge Elisha H. Brewster, who has taken it under advisement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Marx Dormoy, who was the French Minister of the Interior under Leon Blum, was killed on July 27. Today, Aug. 27, Pierre Laval falls, severely wounded.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Leaders of higher education in the Far West recommended today at a conference at Stanford University that a unified draft deferment policy be sought which would enable the nation's colleges and universities to retain instructors of draft age whose work lay in training students in subjects essential to national defense.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The tail-end Senators cut loose with a barrage of extra-base hits today to defeat the second-place White Sox, 11 to 3.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Jersey City and Baltimore divided a double-header tonight, the Little Giants taking the seven-inning opener, 1 to 0, and the Orioles coming back to notch, the nightcap. 9 to 6.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Mrs. Edgar A. Eyre gave a dinner with dancing tonight in the Tropical Room of the Seven Ponds Inn for her daughter, Miss Marjorie Meacham. Among the guests were the Misses Joan Faber Downey, Josephine A. Herbert, Jeanne Marie Schley, Janet Adams, Jane Murray and Audrey Carey; Paul Abbott Jr., John W. Herbert Jr., Claude Cartier, William Fleming, Orson D. Munn Jr., Thomas Murray 2d, and Winslow Lovejoy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- After a short period of some stability in the first half of August, wholesale commodity prices resumed their upward movement and advanced 0.4 point in the week ended on Aug. 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

The opening-day schedule for the national tennis singles championships, which will get under way at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills tomorrow afternoon, was announced by the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday.
The Giants got their first look at the left-handed Howard Pollet yesterday at the Polo Grounds and it was unanimously agreed if they never see him again it will be too soon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- During the week ended Aug. 27 member bank reserve balances decreased $39,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $59,000,000 in money in circulation in part by increases of $9,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $6,000,000 in gold stock and by a decrease of $13,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Two steps to require budgetary control of non-defense items were unanimously approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.

With a defense industry advisory committee scheduled to be appointed for the waste-material field next week, the first step in integrating the industry into a solid whole for defense purposes, instead of treating it as a group of individual supplying sources for other major industries, will be taken by the government, dealers reported here yesterday.

SOUTH KENT, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Two hundred and fifty-four carefree youngsters returning to New York and New Jersey from vacations passed in three Summer camps in the Berkshire Mountains escaped death or injury today when a six-car special train of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was derailed on a curve here, the engine and the first three coaches plunging into Hatch Pond.

WOE, woe, unutterable woe! The dreadful news from Omaha was that a flock of logical contenders had been pitched (or putted) out of the national amateur golf championship now raging over the course of the Omaha Field Club. In the very first round, too! Hardly were they in, adjusting their feet for their stances, when they were tossed out on their ears.

Fourteenth Street near Fifth Avenue looked like a revolving stage yesterday morning as Hearn's Department Store opened its 114th anniversary celebration. Modern traffic made way for hansom cabs and Victorias in a pageant depicting early shopping days, when family purchasing was a whole day's spree.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- Germany soon may demand freedom to use Turkey's Black Sea territorial waters but has no further designs on this strategically placed country at the crossroads of Europe and Asia, well-informed Axis sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Followvng are the texts of President Roosevelt's executive order establishing the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board and his statement outlining the duties of the new agency:
The Torrington Company and subsidiaries, excluding English subsidiaries, reported yesterday
BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles reached Russ Christopher for twelve hits, including Art Graham's home run, and downed the Newark Bears, 5 to 4, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today for modification of the commission's reorganization plan for the carrier to give present stockholders approximately $20,000,000 in new common stock.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, manufacturer of newsprint, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that in the quarter ended on July 31 they had made a slight improvement in earnings despite higher labor and material costs and increased taxes.

Of all issues which Japan might have chosen on which to base a protest to the United States, she has chosen the weakest in international law and the most illogical. One could understand her protesting our aid to China, whether in the form of loans, war material or our sending of a military mission there, for China is a country with which Japan is at war.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 28 -- For the last two days Viborg has not been mentioned in the official Finnish reports, but Finland is full of anticipation -- especially the Karelians, of whom half a million were transferred to other parts of Finland after the Moscow peace of March, 1940.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 28 -- United States citizenship was denied today to Henry Horst Heide, literary editor of the New York Staats-Zeitung, German-language newspaper, by Common Pleas Judge Walter L. Hetfield in Union County Naturalization Court here, on the ground that he had approved in part of certain Nazi principles and had described Nazism as "democratic to some extent."

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, naval manager of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, announced today that the Navy's $13,000,000 battle cruiser Atlanta would be launched Sept. 6 at 10:37 A.M.

Showings of Spring lines of foundation garments will be held during the week of Dec. 1, an advance of six weeks as compared with the date of the market week a year ago, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the Corset and Brassiere Association of America at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

After a display of strength throughout most of the session, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange in the late dealings yesterday reacted sharply to increased Southern selling, profit-taking and some hedging operations, and closed at 4 to 8 points under Wednesday's final quotations.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose 43.6 per cent over the total for the corresponding period last year and exceeded last week's ten-year record. The total for the twenty-three major cities of the country was $6,013,502,000 compared with $4,187,504,000 last year, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A declaration that now is the time, if ever, to begin, that cooperation with the British peoples for the maintenance of international order of which the Churchill-Roosevelt declaration was the first step is contained in a pamphlet on "United States Cooperation With British Nations," published today by the National Planning Association.

Advantages of the traditional banker of a corporation have not been ended by the competitive bidding rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Robert E. Healy, a member of the commission, declared before the annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Securities Commissioners in St. Paul, Minn., yesterday.

The Mineola Fair, which will run from September 9 to 13, yesterday followed the lead set by Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti in barring a birth control exhibit from the Syracuse State Fair. The Mineola exhibit had been planned by the Nassau and Suffolk Counties Committees on Mothers Health Centers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Hogs extended their sharp advance with gains of 10 cents a hundred pounds today, lifting the top to a four-year peak of $12.15, but then turned about and lost most of the advance, while cattle continued to weaken. Spring lambs, however, sold at steady to strong levels with some natives up 10 to 20 cents.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 28 -- A dozen golf professionals took the long, tough Hershey Country Club layout apart today, and leading in the $5,000 Hershey open championship at the end of the first round firing was a quartet of topnotchers tied at 69, four under par.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Paul Robeson will return to the American screen after a five-year absence in "Tales of Manhattan," which Boris Morros will produce this Fall for Paramount. Robeson was signed today by the producer at a reported salary of $10,000 to appear in a Harlem sequence in the picture.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Representatives of the twenty-one American republics agreed today to put into operation about eighty German, Italian and Danish ships immobilized in Western Hemisphere ports.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 28 -- Judging by present appearances, two veterans are apt to be finalists in the forty-fifth national amateur golf championship when the final is played on the Omaha Field Club course the day after tomorrow.

Two new films will appear in Broadway houses this morning. "Dive Bomber," a Warner Brothers aviation drama, will open at the Strand. The picture, which was filmed in Technicolor, and stars Errol Flynn and Fred MacMurray, was made with the cooperation of the United States Navy.
As the German campaign in Russia lengthens into its third month and a Winter campaign becomes more probable, the meaning of a "two-front" war becomes of greater importance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Colonel Per Zilliacus, military attache of the Finnish Legation, said today that Russian resistance appeared to be diminishing all along the Russo-Finnish frontier; but he expressed the opinion that the Eastern war would "undoubtedly continue" well into the coming Winter.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The brown gelding Battle Day, owned by Frederick M. Warburg of White Plains, N.Y., today annexed the President's Cup, emblematic of the championship of the twenty-second annual Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair horse show.

The Electric Bond and Share Company had a net income of $10,983,060, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, for the twelve months ended on June 30, according to the report to shareholders made public yesterday by S.W. Murphy, president.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Southpaw Thornton Lee made his seventeenth victory a four-single shutout of the Senators today as the second-place White Sox closed their long home stand with a 4-0 triumph.
SIMLA, India, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A British communique today:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Prince and Princess Francis J.M. Windisch-Graetz entertained with a luncheon today at Rosemore, their home in Great Plains Road. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston and A. Hamilton S. Post of Baltimore, who is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Livingston at Old Trees, their place in First Neck Lane; Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Wagner, Countess Mercati, Mrs. Stuart Duncan Preston and Colonel and Mrs. Jnatham Ralston Reed.

It has been reported in information from South American countries that seventy-five vessels totaling about 400,000 gross tons were immobilized in ports of Central and South America following the spread of war in the Spring and Summer of 1940.
BERLIN, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 23 shows the following changes compared with that of July 31, in thousands of Reichsmark:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Resumption on a substantial scale of the policy of making loans to Latin-American countries will soon be announced, it is understood, by Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator.
Sales of an apartment house in New Rochelle, a business property in White Plains and a store and apartment building in Mamaroneck featured the Westchester realty trading yesterday.

Negotiations for a settlement of the strike of Gimbel Brothers department store employes were resumed last night in Washington. The joint meeting, the first since the first day of the strike, Aug. 19, was called by Allan S. Haywood, national director of organization for the C.I.O.
BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- German forces advancing on Leningrad from the south, southeast and west are in some sectors only thirty miles from that city, authoritative quarters in Berlin asserted tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Contracts totaling $185,411,487 were awarded by the War Department today. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:
NEW YORK Mrs. A. Mitchell Palmer has arrived from Washington and is at the Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A warning that "sinister and planned" sabotage might motivate those who attempt to create confusion and dissension regarding the gasoline situation was expressed today by Ralph K. Davies, deputy petroleum coordinator, as he testified on the reasons for the Eastern gasoline shortage at the opening of a Senate investigation.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 29 -- With Vladivostok now the center of Japanese attention as a result of its projected use as a port of entry for United States war supplies to Russia, an official spokesman asserted today that Japan was concidering the question of extending the limits of her territorial waters.
The exodus from New York City for the Labor Day week-end will hit its full stride today, with the influx of out-of-town visitors not due to reach its height until tomorrow.
DANNEMORA, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The clear tones of two great bells ringing out over the walls of grim Clinton State Prison this morning signalled no "break" by any of the 2,419 inmates.

Stockholders of the Pacific Western Oil Corporation have been told by William G. Skelly, president, that because of the company's close relationship with George F. Getty, Inc., and the similarity of the two businesses, the officers for some time have been giving consideration to the advisability of acquiring all outstanding capital stock of the Getty company in exchange for the common shares of Pacific Western Oil.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Navy, in its biggest peacetime bid for man power, set its recruiting objective today at 13,000 men a month for the rest of the year and 15,000 monthly thereafter.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- For eight innings today Ike Pearson, Phillies righthander, had a shutout victory, but the Pirates exploded in the ninth to score three runs with, two out for a 3-to-2 victory.

An official Finnish "blue-white book," Finland's presentation of the facts leading to her involvement in the war, has been transmitted to this country and the documentary material will be made public as soon as possible in book form.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Aug. 28 -- The Bourse was firm today on the withdrawal of the tax on blocked marks. There was active trading in the domestic industrials and headed by Unilever they were considerably higher. The Dutch Indies closed lower and the tobaccos were weak.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Rudy York, whose recent batting slump was attributed to a broken wrist about which he kept silent, slammed a home run into the left field stands with the bases filled in the seventh inning today to give the Detroit Tigers an 8-to-7 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

Excess Reserves Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City dropped $35,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday as actual reserve balances declined $29,000,000 and reserve requirement increased $6,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 27:

LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Note circulation declined for the second consecutive week, the statement of the Bank of England reported today for the week ended on Aug. 27. Before the drop of a week ago, circulation had risen steadily for twelve weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Direct conversations were undertaken by President Roosevelt today with Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the Japanese Ambassador, at the instance of Prince Fumimaro Konoye, the Japanese Premier. The talks are expected to cover the whole range of questions entering into the relations of the two countries.
WITH THE SECOND ARMY IN ARKANSAS, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear warned the soldiers of the Second Army tonight against the subversive activities of foreign agents.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Headquarters of the Forty-fourth Division announced today that a survey would start tomorrow of its 16,600 enlisted men to determine their eligibility for release from military service under priorities announced recently by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Drastic changes in the old-age insurance system to provide a minimum of $30 a month to all persons past 60 who are not gainfully employed was recommended to the Senate today by the special committee to investigate this system.

VICHY, Friday, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- A merciless purge of anti-Nazi elements swept over all France today in the wake of the attempted assassinations of Pierre Laval and Marcel Deat, vhose names, according to Paris police, stood at the top of a list of fifty prominent Frenchmen marked for death.

Elimination of the proposed tax on radio and billboards from the revenue measure by the Senate Finance Committee was highly encouraging to the advertising field because it was one of the few times that the entire profession, including advertisers, agencies and media, was able to organize a really effective protest against some proposed governmental action regarded as detrimental.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 -- The American League's simmering pennant race, which fried itself to a frazzle weeks ago when the Yankees practically burned up the loop, moved a step nearer to total extinction today as the Bronx Bombers polished off the Browns in ten innings.

Manufacturers' new orders, shipments, inventories and unfilled orders advanced sharply during July, according to data compiled by the National Industrial Conference Board's division of Industrial economics. The board's index of new orders reached a new high at 268, based on 1935-1939 as 100, more than recovering its loss in June.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would give "very careful consideration" to the complaints made by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, against the new wage and hour schedules adopted by the Board of Transportation on Wednesday, adding about $6,000,000 to the annual operating expenses of the city's unified transit system.

In what is believed to have been the first case of its kind in this country, a trainee honorably discharged from the Army has been returned to the position he held at the time of his induction, although he was discharged by his employer after having been rehired for a period of three weeks.

"Viva O'Brien," the musical show with a Latin-American theme, is announced to arrive at the Majestic Theatre, opening Oct. 9. A preliminary engagement will begin at the Shubert, Boston, on Sept. 25. One scene in the musical is comparable to an "indoor aquacade" in which a dozen swimmers will disport themselves.

After advancing for seventeen consecutive weeks, commercial loans of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City declined $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,375,000,000.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- An order signed by Judge Lewis B. Eastmead in Orphans Court here today, approving a settlement between the administrator and the Pan American Airways Company for $4,000, closed the case of Watson Choy, prosperous Chinese restaurateur who was one of six passengers and crew of nine who disappeared with the Hawaiian Clipper in the Pacific on July 28, 1938.

WITH THE SIXTH ARMY CORPS IN THE FIELD, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Under the cover of darkness, the defending and invading forces in New England's biggest army manoeuvres slipped into new positions tonight to battle for control of the Nashua River Valley.

TOKTO, Friday, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- Japan is making a strong final diplomatic effort to settle her differences with the United States and if the effort fails the Japanese people "must be prepared for the worst," newspaper commentators said today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Maas., Aug. 28 -- America will emerge as the strongest single power in the world as the result of the world war, Adolph A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, asserted tonight at the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations.

Benjamin J. Brotman, president of Leo Elwyn Co., dealers in antiques and jewelry, has leased an apartment in the building at 875 Fifth Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and Win. A. White Sons.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 28 -- For the fourth time this season a women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament went to Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of Round Hill today when she returned a card of 38, 45 -- 83 on the Wee Burn course.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that, because of unprecedented expansion of its business in the last two years, due principally to the growing demands of the national defense program, it would seek $60,000,000 of new capital to provide for further plant expansion and other corporate purposes.

BUFFALO, Aug. 28 -- Professor James H. Sheldon, chairman of the board of directors of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, told the Jewish War Veterans of the United States today that the America First Committee was "a front for Adolf Hitler."

Slaughter of most classes of livestock so far this week has exceeded last week's kill and, compared with the last five-year seasonal average, the cow kill has been liberal, steer and calf slaughter fairly liberal, bulls moderate, lambs slightly below normal hogs fully normal.

It was announced officially in Moscow yesterday by a spokesman for the Soviets that the great Lenin-Dnieper dam, which took 30,000 Russian laborers five years to build under the direction of an American engineer, had been destroyed by Marshal Semyon Budenny, whose army is now digging itself in to the east of the Dnieper River.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 28 -- After a momentous day of negotiations, Robert G. Menzies tonight announced his resignation as Prime Minister, first to the cabinet and subsequently to a joint meeting of the government parties. These groupings, the United Australia party and the Country party, unanimously elected Treasurer A.W. Fadden, 46-year-old leader of the Country Party, to succeed Mr. Menzies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- An eight-year vacancy in the office of Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air was filled today by President Roosevelt with the appointment of Artemus L. Gates of Locust Valley, L.I., to the post.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- About 500 tanks have been delivered thus far to the British by American manufacturers and others are becoming available at an increasing rate, it was learned to day from an authoritative source.

Securities and cash in New York City's sinking funds at the close of the 1940-41 fiscal year on June 30 were $4,045,680 in excess of legal requirements, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick informed the Board of Estimate yesterday in his annual report on the operations of the sinking funds.

The sale by Dr. Edward M. Colie Jr. of his residence at 177 East Sixty-fourth Street to an investor was announced yesterday. The property consists of a four-story and basement building containing nine rooms, three baths and a doctor's office, on a lot 16 by 100.5 feet.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is remarkable that a generation schooled in the horrors of modern war should have forgotten so soon the grim lessons of "What Price Glory?" and the photographs of bloody battlefields and corpses on barbed wire brought out, a few years ago, by Laurence Stallings in his "First World War."

A tract of more than thirty-eight lots on the south side of Pople Avenue and the north side of Avery Avenue, just north of Lawrence Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Edwin E. and Frank M. Zittel to the Field Holding Corporation for immediate improvement with a group of two-family dwellings.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 28 -- The basic pay of a buck private in the Army draft camps would be raised an extra $30 a month after one year's service if the American public had the power to determine the Army wage scale. That fact is revealed in a nation-wide survey of public opinion by the institute.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Soy beans again dominated the grain markets today, advancing more than 4 cents a bushel at one time and going into new seasonal high ground for the sixth straight day. Trading was featured by short covering in the "old" October contract, trading in which will cease at the close on Saturday except for the liquidation of outstanding contracts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Roosevelt created today a seven-member Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, headed by Vice President Wallace, and shifted key defense officials to other posts, all in an effort to speed up the production of arms for the United States, Great Britain, China, Russia and other nations resisting Axis aggression.

Maria Markan, a soprano from Iceland, has been engaged for next season by the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was announced yesterday. She has a number of dramatic parts in her repertoire, and it is believed likely that she will be among those groomed to fill the roles of Kirsten Flag who will not return from Norway next season.

Week-end holiday influences began yesterday to appear in the stock markets as traders held to light commitments, but the improved tempo in prices was extended slightly. It was the the third consecutive session of rising values and selectivity of issues still was practiced.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 28 -- A panorama of German organization in Argentina, as widespread as it is thorough and including political, labor and military aspects, is offered in a preliminary report that the Congressional committee investigating anti-Argentine activities will submit to the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow.

Death Announced Battalion Chief William R. Lanahan, 52d Battalion, died Aug. 27. The funeral will take place from Skelton's Funeral Parlor, 86-08 Broadway, Elmhurst, Queens, at 11 A.M., Saturday, Aug. 30. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

Arrow Shirt Prices to Hold Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., will maintain present prices and quality of its white and fancy Arrow shirts for the balance of 1941, C.R. Palmer, president, announced yesterday. Manhattan Shirt Company earlier this week reported an advance in the price of its whites from $2 to $2.25.

Canvassers employed by Simeon J. Beckerman, professional petition circulator, to obtain signatures for petitions entering John R. Davies in the Republican primaries as a candidate for Mayor were questioned yesterday before Justice Ferdinand Pecora in Supreme Court as the New York and Kings County Republican organizations sought to invalidate the designation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent Alfred Baker Lewis, commenting on Dr. MacCracken's address, which he says "illustrates clearly the fundamental illusions of the isolationists," himself illustrates, as does your leading editorial of this morning, the fundamental illusions of the interventionists.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- An announcement that the new Iranian Government, formed yesterday, had issued orders to its forces to "cease fire" was received simultaneously in London and other European capitals today via the Teheran radio, and was regarded here as most welcome.

The younger generation, it seems, has taken hold of the good neighbor policy idea with a zest. Given plenty of colorful costumes, a wealth of bright-hued crepe paper and all the music they want, they can bring Latin America right into their back yard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 23 totaled 899,750 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,376 cars or 1.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 138,642 cars or 18.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 215,844 cars or 31.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The Atlantic Coast District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association will meet in New York on Sept. 8 for a wage scale conference prior to the opening of negotiations with ship operators for a new contract, it was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the A.F. of L. union.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- The German Army in cracking the obstinate Soviet bridgeheads on the western bank of the Dnieper employed what is virtually a new weapon -- mighty, low-slung, swift "storm cannon" -- according to eyewitness accounts of the fighting in the Ukraine reaching Berlin.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Brilliant forward passing by Sid Luckman, late of Columbia, enabled the Chicago Bears, monarchs of the professional football world, to triumph over the Collegiate All-Stars, 37 to 13, before a record crowd of 98,200 in floodlighted Soldier Field tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 28 -- The French-bred Saguenay II, now carrying the colors of Mrs. Ella K. Bryson, sprang a mild surprise today by winning the featured King Hanover purse as this month-long racing session drew toward its close.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Tom Earley's two-hit pitching gave him a slight edge in a stirring hurling duel with Vallie Eaves of the Cubs today, enabling the Braves to take a 2-1 verdict and the rubber tilt of their three-game series.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Further progress toward perfecting their offense and defense was made by the Eastern College All-Stars today during a two-hour scrimmage in preparation for their Fresh Air Fund benefit game with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 27 tells in a few words and figures why America is being held in contempt by totalitarian leaders, both in Europe and the Orient. And in each of two articles the onus is put on misguided unionists.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28 -- The East Hampton branch of the British War Relief Society, Inc., of which Mrs. Nelson C. Osborne is chairman, held an open house this afternoon. Tea was served by Mrs. Julian S. Myrick, and Mrs. Ormond Lawson-Johnson spoke.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Setting a season's record for 3-year-old trotters, when he went the second mile in 2:03, Bill Strang's His Excellency scored one of the year's biggest Grand Circuit upsets when he shut out the Hambletonian winner, Bill Gallon, in all three heats of the $6,000 Governor's Stake, before a grand stand crowd of 10,000 today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 -- Axis ships in Brazilian ports will soon be taken over by the government, it is indicated by two developments here. First, government ship inspectors have been sent to Bahia and Recife to look over Axis ships interned there.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 28 -- The Middle East is losing one of its most picturesque characters and also one of its most capable commanders in the transfer announced today of Air Commodore Raymond Collishaw, who has been Field Commander of the Air Force in Egypt through all the desert campaigning.

A sad discovery lies in store for enthusiastic shoppers setting out to market for their holiday dinners. The Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets reports that dairy product prices have taken still another step upward and every cut of meat, with the single exception of smoked hams, shows an average increase of 1 to 4 cents.

Like previous Washington "suggestions" on gasoline conservation, the "fair" price scale announced by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply met with a mixed reception yesterday from gasoline dealers in the East. A spokesman for a major New York City chain thought it would have a "good leveling effect."

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- German Ambassador Franz von Papen, delaying his scheduled departure for Berlin, today submitted to President Ismet Inonu "Germany's views" on the British-Soviet occupation of Iran, whence German nationals fled into Turkey throughout the day.
Red rugs rolled down the runway leading to the Twentieth Century Limited for the last time yesterday for passenger conductor Thomas Gullen.

The four-family house at 1408 Bronx River Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Rose Asher to Frances Sinatra through Benjamin Malina, broker, who also sold for the Balsam Realty Corporation to Bella Chutroo the four-family building at 1252 Noble Avenue.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued the following communique today:
BERLIN, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The communique issued today from Reichs-fuehrer Hitler's field headquarters:

Five hundred officers and trustees of savings banks are expected to attend the forty-eighth annual convention of the Mutual Savings Banks Association of the State of New York at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., Oct. 20 to 22, it was announced yesterday by Henry Bruere, president of the association.

Children Who Wriggle The school children who twist, wriggle and squirm are the hope of the world, says Dr. Elbert K. Fretwell of Columbia, lecturing at the University of Oklahoma. But don't they all ?

By a vote of fourteen to two, the Board of Estimate approved late yesterday two county reform bills backed by the Democratic organizations of the five boroughs after petitions calling for a referendum on the measures had been filed with H. Warren Hubbard, the City Clerk.

THE biographical vignettes of Jefferson, Roger Williams, Franklin, Sam Adams, Joel Barlow, Hugh Henry Brackenridge and their times that John Dos Passos has written for "The Ground We Stand On"* are considerably more genial than the biographical vignettes of William Jennings Bryan, Carnegie, Theodore Roosevelt, President Wilson, Herry Ford and Henry Winslow Taylor that he wrote for "The 42nd Parallel," "Nineteen Nineteen" and "The Big Money."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- The national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars after a stormy session today refused by a vote of 2,225 to 261 to seat as a delegate Earl Southard, court-martialed commander of the Department of Illinois, who has been accused of disloyalty through his activities as secretary of the Keep America Out of War Committee.

Most recent reports of the Governor Charles Edison salt-water fishing tournament in New Jersey are devoted to the standings of the women anglers participating. In the tuna division, for instance, Mrs. Thelma M. Mathis of Toms River is at present in second place, with a tuna of 153 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Officials of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply were warned, today by representatives of the sugar refining industry that a developing sugar shortage might force the closing of all refineries by Oct. 15.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 28 -- Once Riza Shah Pahlevi, ruler of Iran, comes to terms with Britain and Russia only Saudi Arabia and Afghanistan will remain among the nations of the Middle East not committed to either side in the war, it was declared here tonight.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 29 -- The enormous Dnieper Dam, which contained and controlled the flow of the Ukraine's greatest river, supplying power through its hydroelectric system to many of that region's industrial centers, and by its blocking of the stream bed established an important inland navigation system, has been blown up, and completely destroyed by Russian engineers, it has been confirmed in an official announcement.

There need be no surprise at the loud protests made by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, over the new schedule of pay and hour adjustments adopted by the Board of Transportation. The reaction on Mr. Quill's part was probably automatic, and might have been expected even if the schedule had been far more generous.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 28 -- William Remsen of the home club, 19-year-old Dartmouth student, won the qualifying medal in the eighteenth annual Long Island junior golf championship by carding 40, 37 -- 77 on the tricky Cherry Valley course today.

Faced with the extinction of several hundred relatively small rayon cloth converting concerns with an aggregate annual volume in excess of $150,000,000, a group of such converters met at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday and drafted tentative plans for seeking official action designed to release greige goods to these companies.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28 -- The Misses Anton and June Dunn, daughters of Edward D. Dunn of New York, gave a pierrot dinner dance at the Clambake Club tonight for their brothers, Edward D. Dunn Jr. and Eric W. Dunn. It was the first costume dance of the season and the clubhouse was gayly decorated with flowers.

VICHY, France, Friday, Aug. 29 -- Following the shooting at Versailles Wednesday of Pierre Laval, former Premier, and Marcel Deat, Paris editor, all signs pointed today to immediate repression of Communist and cognate activities throughout France, especially in the occupied zone.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- As the German military machine penetrates farther into Russia and takes over more and more territory the British are becoming more concerned over the whole problem of Allied and United States production.
Fears that supplies of scrap iron and steel may be difficult to procure next month, as a result of strict order of the Office of Price
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Department store sales for the week ended Aug. 23 were up 29 per cent above those of the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan succeeded yesterday in blocking temporarily any official approval by the Board of Estimate of Park Commissioner Robert Moses' plan to transfer the Aquarium from Battery Park to the Bronx Zoo.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Three walks in a row by Al Milnar, Cleveland pitcher, and a single by Dick Siebert produced three seventh-inning runs for the Athletics today to help them to a 5-to-3 victory over the Indians.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 28 -- Still champion of the nation's junior skippers, Captain Robert Coulson of the Eastern Yacht Club outsailed his two chief rivals, Tommy Platt of Cold Spring Harbor and Art Pounds of Westhampton, to break a deadlock and win the twenty-first annual series for the historic Sears Cup in the final race today.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Captain Lord Louis Mountbatten, cousin of King George VI, assumed command today of the aircraft carrier Illustrious at this port where she is undergoing repairs.

Talk of freezing furniture designs, with view to making possible the establishment of price ceilings, is now being given more consideration in Washington than when the idea was first proposed several weeks ago, according to reports reaching leaders of the industry here.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 29 -- An Axis convoy of four merchantmen and four escorting destroyers was bombed off the Libyan coast early yesterday by planes of the Fleet Air Arm, British officials reported today. An 8,000-ton ship was set afire and explosions were seen.

VICHY, France, Aug. 29 -- The permanent officers of Parliament are ordered by a law promulgated in the Journal Officiel this morning to remove their headquarters to Chatelguyon-les-Bains, "the nearest watering place to Vichy." Possibly there is no connection, but the waters of Chatelguyon are reputed to cure intestinal troubles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 - Announcement that trading in lard and cotton seed oil would be suspended on the Board of Trade as a result of an order of the Office of Price Administration banning operations in fats and oils, threw the grain and soy-bean markets into confusion at the opening today.

Aided considerably by the mild weather, the annual Labor Day week-end departure and influx of vacationists got under way in New York City yesterday, with every indication pointing to a record turn- , over for the last long week-end of the Summer.

ROME, Aug. 29 -- Premier Mussolini and Adolf Hitler have been together on the Russian front for five days, it was officially announced here this evening in a communique that laid down a challenge to the Roosevelt-Churchill eight-point declaration.
FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Reports of poor morale in the Federalized National Guard were discounted today by Representative Robert W. Kean of Livingston, N.J., after an inspection tour today.

One of the strangest of all fish in the marine world, the climbing perch that can walk on land and climb trees, will be part of the annual exhibition of the New York Aquarium Society, which opens today in Education Hall at the American Museum of Natural History.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The NEW YORK TIMES reported that the Slavonic Committee for Democracy urged the United States to enter into open conflict with the totalitarian powers. Andrew Kalpaschnikof, general chairman of the committee, outlined a plan for the future welfare of Europe.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Men and fighting equipment of the Fourth Armored Division went on display this week as detachments exhibited at the New York State Fair in Syracuse and the Jefferson County Fair in Watertown. Another unit toured southward for a Labor Day parade at Wierton, W. Va.
SIMLA, India, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A British communique on operations in Iran said today:

Week-end holiday influences were present in full force yesterday in the stock market as financial circles prepared for the twoand-one-half-day shut-down. Except for a show of strength in the aircraft manufacturing and transportation issues, the share list presented a limp and mixed appearance, and trading fell to the smallest amount since Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Here is a list of the major changes made by the Senate Finance Committee from the House-approved revenue bill:

Although Rex O'Malley had been signed under a run-of-the-play contract for the resumption of "Lady in the Dark" to fill the role vacated by Danny Kaye, there will be another actor in the part when the show gets under way again on Monday.

ROME, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini piloted Adolf Hitler's heavy airplane back from one section of the German-Russian front during their visit, Italian correspondents reported tonight in lengthy dispatches on the meeting.

Simeon J. Beckerman, professional petition circulator, who obtained about 5,000 signatures for petitions designating John R. Davies as a candidate for Mayor in the Republican primaries, had two warrants calling for his arrest served upon him yesterday in a corridor of the Supreme Court, where the Davies designation is under attack from the regular Republican organizations of New York and Kings Counties.

THE annual invitation to attend the Timonium Fair has arrived on official stationery of the "Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society of Baltimore County" decorated with a colored illustration showing exhibition tents, two cows, two horses, one pig, four chickens, assorted vegetables and jars of evidently home-made preserves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Michael F. Widman Jr., associate director of organization of the C.I.O., today completed a series of conferences with spokesmen for the United Wholesale and Retail Workers Union and of Gimbel Brothers, New York, in an endeavor to end the strike called in the department store last week.

Realizing that the old Europe of pre-war days never can be restored, Great Britain and all the interallied governments-in-exile in England are devoting serious consideration to problems of post-war reconstruction, former Prime Minister Paul van Zeeland of Belgium, who recently arrived in this country after spending two months in London, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The United States will obtain use of twenty-six tankers out of the eighty Axis vessels immobilized in Latin-American waters, which will about half solve the Eastern gasoline shortage problem, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, testified today before the special Senate committee investigating the petroleum situation.
There's a bit of romance, slightly flavored with corn, hiding behind the blank brick wall of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-third Street.

MILLBURN, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Two 15-year-old schoolboys here, who copied an extortion plan from a story in a detective magazine, got results last night that were wholly different from those in the story. The magazine extortionist eluded the law for years, but the boys were caught red-handed by a cordon of local policemen and FBI agents.
The new cargo vessel Exceller, the first of four sister ships designed for the India service of the American Export Line, will sail today on her maiden voyage, in command of Captain Hugh L. Switzer.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Fort Slocum's most vexing shortcoming, an inadequate supply of doughnuts, has been overcome by the installation of an electrically operated doughnut-making machine. Major Leon V. Chaplin, mess officer, said the soldiers averaged four doughnuts each at breakfast, a total of 12,000.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered toy dealers.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- A special communique from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters this morning announced that German troops, assisted by naval and air units, had captured Tallinn, former capital of Estonia, and Baltic Port, thirty-eight miles west of it, yesterday.

Irregularity marked the movement of the cotton futures market here yesterday. After opening 5 to 10 points up, near the high levels for the session, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped quickly to net losses of 13 to 20 points.

Trade Here Up About 25% Retail trade continued active here this week. Department store sales were estimated as about 25 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year, a rate of gain about equal to that of the preceding week.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the filing of a registration statement by the Missouri Utilities Company, Cape Girardeau, Mo., covering $3,150,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds, series A, due 1971; 14,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, and 125,000 shares of common stock, $1 par value.

Julio C. Berrizbeitia, 19-year-old Venezuelan Boy Scout, sailed yesterday for his home town of Puerto Cabello, which he left in the Fall of 1937 to start on a 20,000-mile walking tour that took him across Northern South America, Central America, Mexico and forty-seven of the forty-eight States of the Union.

A three-alarm fire in the Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, which spread rapidly through several onestory frame buildings, yesterday caused injuries to five firemen and killed several thousand mice, guinea pigs and other small animals.

VICHY, France, Aug. 29 -- Surgeons reserve their prognoses regarding both Pierre Laval and Marcel Deat, who were shot at Versailles on Wednesday by Paul Colette, ostensibly a volunteer hi the French Legion against bolshevism but whose real object, it is alleged, was "to bring down collaborators with Germany."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- W. Averell Harriman, Minister to London and lease-lend expert, will head the United States delegation to the three-power conference to be held in Moscow shortly, President Roosevelt announced today.

Tax-Anticipation Notes Estimates made some time ago in banking circles that August sales of the government's tax-anticipation notes, which first went on sale on Aug. 1, will run between $750,000,000 and $1,000,000,000, still hold good.

Catholic, Protestant and Jewish women will be organized this Fall into groups to give aid to China under the auspices of the Greater New York Women's Committee of the United China Relief, with headquarters at 285 Madison Avenue. Arrangements for the campaign will be outlined at an interfaith luncheon rally to be held Oct. 15 at a place to be announced later.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Whirlaway, Warren Wright's champion thoroughbred of 1941, will race in California this Winter along with the entire Calumet Farm string, Mr. Wright confirmed here today. The horse acknowledged to be the 3-year-old champion early this year is now in Chicago and will be continued in training during the New York season, this Fall.

By his wise order ending resistance to Russian and British troops eighty hours after they crossed Iran's borders, Riza Shah Pahlevi has spared his people needless bloodshed in a hopeless struggle against superior force. While his country is occupied by foreign troops, he and his countrymen have cause to give thanks that it was the Allies rather than the Nazis who got there first.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Johnfritz Achelis have come from their Summer home in Rumsqn, N.J., and are at the St. Regis before going to their home at 33 East Seventieth Street for the Autumn and Winter.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 30 -- Indicating that the strained relations between Japan and the United States had reached a decisive stage the Cabinet held an emergency session this afternoon at which the Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, explained recent developments, especially his message to President Roosevelt.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 29 -- More than 300 Summer colonists and their guests for the holiday week-end attended the circus party at the Dunes Club tonight. The spacious ocean-fronting veranda was decorated to simulate a huge "big top" and the adjoining club room was converted into a sawdust ring.

The appearance of the first public-utility financing in eight weeks accounted for most of the new bond offerings made this week. Two new loans in this category were placed on the market for an aggregate of $32,125,000, which, with $6,366,000 of new tax-exempt loans, lifted the total new offerings of the week to $38,491,000.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 29 -- Business, the church, schools, colleges and youth groups were urged today to join in a concerted attack on discrimination and intolerance, the final session of the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations receiving reports giving the recommendations of six round tables which have met daily for five days.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 29 -- After nearly six months of community programs all over the State, this little capital city began tonight the all-Vermont sesquicentennial celebration. Tomorrow's events will be the climax of the observance of the 150th anniversary of admission to the Union of the State, noted for green mountains, granite and Republicanism.

Assignments Revoked The assignment of Assistant Chief of Department Arthur B. Wright to command the Fire College, also his assignments as a member Board of Apparatus and Board of Hazardous Trades are revoked, effective 12:01 A.M. Sept. 1. In addition to his other duties, Assistant Chief of Department Arthur B. Wright shall perform duty under the direction of Assistant Chief of Department, in Command, John J. McCarthy (2).

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Could you, through your Mr. Allison Danzig, kindly inform Frank Kovacs that hundreds of tennis fans are sorely disappointed in him for the unbecoming dignity which he has lately displayed on the court?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Sales of independent retailers in July were 24 per cent higher than in the same month last year on the basis of reports from 23,357 firms in most kinds of business except department stores, the Census Bureau announced today.

VICHY, Saturday, Aug. 30 -- Eight more persons have been executed in Paris, dispatches from Paris reported today, bringing to eleven the number executed since the attempted assassination of Pierre Laval and Marcel Deat on Wednesday.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., Aug. 29 -- Half the garrison of this post, numbering slightly more than 30,000 men, jammed trains, buses and highways tonight, headed home for a three-day holiday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29 -- More than five hundred members of the Summer colonies here and in adjacent resorts, with their holiday, house guests, attended the outdoor amateur boxing carnival for the benefit of the William Carey Camp of the Boys' Club of New York, which was held tonight under a large tent near the clubhouse of the Shlnnecock Hills Golf Club.

The Consolidated Aircraft Corporation of San Diego, Calif., has called a special meeting of its stockholders for Sept. 15 to vote on proposals that would permit the declaration of a 100 per cent stock dividend by the directors, it was announced yesterday.
The national amateur tennis championships will start today at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, with a wide-open race for the titles in prospect in both the men's and women's singles.

Two openings in Broadway theatres this morning will complete the new film offerings for the week. 'I Give My Life" will be the newcomer at the Central. The melodrama, which features Danielle Darrieux and Anton Walbrook, was produced in France and has English dialogue.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 29 -- Robert Gordon Menzies tendered his resignation as Prime Minister of Australia this morning and Lord Gowrie, Governor General, immediately commissioned Arthur William Fadden as his successor. Mr. Fadden was sworn in this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Trading in lard futures on the Board of Trade here was suspended temporarily today while officials of the Exchange sought clarification of a ruling by Price Control Administrator Leon Henderson relative to speculative trading in fats and oils.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 29 -- Harry H. Channell, 49 years old, a Baltimorean with a long police record here and in other cities, was picked up by detectives last night at the Oriole Ball Park and held for Connecticut authorities in connection with a $42,000 burglary in Greenwich.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The people throughout occupied France and to only a slightly less extent throughout unoccupied France are strongly pro-British, and there is considerable passive resistance against the German occupation of France, according to Andre Diethelm, formerly first secretary in the Colonial Ministry.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A special German communique said today:

President Edward G. Barrow of the Yankees announced yesterday the club would accept applications for world series tickets commencing Tuesday. He revealed he has returned requests which have flooded the Yankee offices practically throughout the Summer.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Aug. 29 -- The Bourse was active today. The opening was firm but there was a sharp reaction later which was followed by a rally at the close, which was generally higher. Government bonds continued firm.
JANESVILLE, Wis., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Voters in the Wisconsin First Congressional District elected an opponent of President Roosevelt's foreign policies to the House of Representatives today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Expenditures for defense made through the Treasury this month already have exceeded $1,000,000,000, the first time since the World War that they have reached such a sum in such a period. With three business days of the month yet to mark up, the Treasury said expenditures from Aug. 1 through Aug. 27 for defense amounted to $1,001,446,512.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Spencer Tracy's next film at Metro, after the current "Woman of the Year" with Katharine Hepburn, will be "This Strange Adventure," based on a novel by Clyde Brion Davis, the studio announced today.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Office employes of the Navy-operated Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company are waiting reaction to a telegram sent to President Roosevelt early today urging a secret vote at the plant to determine whether reversion to private operation is possible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The following table gives the estimated revenue from the tax bill as passed by the House on Aug. 4, and the revenue from the bill as tentatively agreed to by the Senate Finance Committee:

Telegrams endorsing Senator Byrd's proposal for a budgetary control of non-defense items were sent to various Administration leaders yesterday by the New York Credit Men's Association. The proposal, calling for a series of estimates by the Bureau of the Budget on how to save $1,000,000,000, $1,500,000,000 and $2,000,000,000, and for setting up a committee to make studies of saving on non-defense expenditures, passed the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 29 -- Finland is still waiting. Tonight's only news from the Karelian front is that the city of Viborg is burning. Big fires can be seen as far as Appeenranta, some forty miles from Viborg on the new frontier with Russia, long ago passed by the Finnish troops, who are now reported almost everywhere nearing the pre-Winter war border.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: A few days ago a prejudiced Brooklynite wrote that Brooklyn was a perfectly balanced team. I am a Chicagoan visiting the East and have reason to dislike the St. Louis Cardinals. But I want to be fair and did a little checking up to find out really which of the two pennant contenders has the better balanced team.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Senate indicated its concern today over the morale problems of the United States Army by postponing action on the appointment of Frederick Osborn of New York as brigadier general in charge of morale.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, Hershey Country Club professional playing before the home folks, added a brilliant 67 to his first-round 69 today for a total of 136 and a two-stroke lead over Lloyd Mangrum, the slender man from Monterey Park, Calif., at the halfway mark of the 72-hole $5,000 Hershey open championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt announced at his press conference today that he would send a reply to the personal letter he had received from Prince Fumimaro Konoye, the Japanese Premier, in connection with the conversations that seek an improvement in relations between the United States and Japan.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Vincent Raskopf of the Garden City Country Club, a 17-year-old high school senior, will oppose Robert Baxter of South Bay, 20-year-old Holy Cross graduate, in the eighteen-hole final of the Long Island junior golf championship on the Cherry Valley course tomorrow morning.

On the Brenner they towered, magnified because they stood on the heights of Europe and dominated the familiar stage on which the drama of Western history has been enacted. But on the Eastern Front the figures of Hitler and Mussolini become small and shadowy. The immense spaces of Russia swallow them up.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt hinted today that he might make an important statement on international affairs in his Labor Day broadcast Monday. The speech may give some inkling of his negotiations with Japanese authorities and may touch upon his sea parleys with Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 30 -- An almost continuous twenty-fourhour offensive by the Royal Air Force over the Nazi-occupied Low Countries and France and into Germany was reported by British officials last night.

"Many people don't know what we have to offer in New York State when it comes to muskellunge fishing," said Roy Norton, superintendent of the Bemus Point muskie hatchery on Chautauqua Lake, in the western part of the State, not far from Lake Erie.

The ultimate test for the new board to promote defense production will not be what it looks like on paper, but how it is going to work. Organization does not exist for its own sake, but to promote special ends. The chief criteria for judging any defense organization are whether it enables us to reach prompt decisions and whether it enables us to reach the most intelligent and informed decisions.

It will cost Chester B. Duryea $22,500 for the legal services of James D.C. Murray in obtaining his release from the State Hospital for the Criminal Insane at Matteawan, N.Y., where he had been confined for twenty-six years on a charge of murdering his father, Brig. Gen. Hiram Duryea, Civil War hero honored by President Lincoln.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- New regulations to provide for the temporary promotion of about 3,700 officers of the Regular Army and the Reserve Corps were promulgated today by the War Department.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's forces have opened an offensive at forty points west of Shanghai along a 150-mile line, a Japanese army spokesman acknowledged today.

Explorers flying over Chiapas, in Southern Mexico, report another lost Mayan city: "a really impressive mass of ruins almost hidden by thick vegetation." They may be right. Such cities have been found, or traces of them, in Central America, in South America, in Arabia, in Africa," in Eastern Asia.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 29 -- The Chinese War Ministry said today that Chinese vanguards had reached the outskirts of two Japanese-occupied provincial capitals in counter-attacks that started Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The famous case of the United States against the Northern Pacific Railway Company, which has involved litigation and Congressional investigation since Civil War days, has been settled under the terms of a decree handed down in the Federal Court for the Eastern District of Washington, Attorney General Francis Biddle announced today.
FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Aug. 29 -- Blood typing and tetanus toxoid inoculations are under way for the entire personnel of the Twenty-ninth Division.

Mainbocher, the dress designer, is one of three new lessees of residential quarters in the recently remodeled building at 37 East Sixty-third Street, according to Hicker-nell-Romeyn, Inc., the agents, who report that units also have been rented to L. Douglas Pollars, who is associated with Mainbocher, Inc., and Morton Freund, of the Morton Freund Advertising Company.
The high-flying Dodgers once again are 4 game and a half ahead in the National League pennant drive.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Speculation in futures in fats and oils is not forbidden by the order of the Office of Price Administration on such trading, officials explained today.

Unless a second postponement is granted, the Federal Communications Commission's sweeping new rules affecting chain broadcasting will become effective Sept. 16. Under them the National Broadcasting Company will be compelled to dispose of its Blue network, while all radio stations throughout the country will be compelled to make drastic changes in their contracts with the networks.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Jersey City and Syracuse split a double-header tonight, the Chiefs winning the thirteen-inning opener 2 -- 1, and the Little Giants taking the nightcap, 6 -- 5.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- Earl Southard, suspended commander of the Illinois Department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, who was found guilty of disloyalty by a court-martial because of his work as secretary of the "Keep America Out of War" committee, was reinstated today at the national encampment with a reprimand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Jarvis Catoe, 36-year-old Negro confessed today that he had assaulted and killed seven women here and in New York and that he had assaulted four others and attempted to attack two more Police said tonight that a check of all details tended to corroborate the confession.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 29 (AP) -- John Lindell hurled his twenty-second victory of the season as he held Baltimore to nine hits tonight. Newark won by 11 to 2. It was Lindell's twenty-first complete game.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Four selectees, all sergeants in the classification section of the 122d Reception Center here, have been chosen to undergo eight months of training to become second lieutenants in the adjutant general's department, Colonel C.W. Baird, commanding officer, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Yankees, upon their arrival tonight from their final Western trip, staged a boisterous, impromptu celebration in honor of Joe Di-Maggio. The celebration was held to demonstrate the players' appreciation of the services of the star outfielder, who is universally credited with having provided the vital spark in the drive toward the American League pennant.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Eight have been named for the $42,000 Hopeful and five for the $13,000 Saratoga Cup; these being the closing-day features tomorrow of the month-long Saratoga meeting, which is sure to set new betting and attendance records.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The fall of long-isolated Tallinn, which completed the Nazi conquest of the Baltic buffer States laboriously won by the Soviet in the last two years, was accompanied by a fierce and continuing action in the Gulf of Finland against the surviving forces in flight from the flaming city In dozens of troop ships and fighting craft, according to reports received here.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Jewish War Veterans of the United States recommended tonight at their annual convention a broad physical education program for schools and colleges to prepare youth for "any emergency that may arise in the future."

Most of the life insurance companies doing business in New York State have asked the State Insurance Department to approve "war risk" clauses to be appended to their policies written hereafter, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, disclosed yesterday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Aug. 29 -- The United States and Germany are "the two and only two great and natural air powers in the world at this time," Charles A. Lindbergh declared tonight in an address before an America First Committee rally here.

John R. Davies, former president of the National Republican Club, who is opposing Mayor La Guardia for the Republican nomination for Mayor, drew first place on the primary election ballot at the drawings conducted yesterday by the Board of Elections.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In relation to your recent editorial "Food for War Prisoners" may I explain more fully our program on behalf of prisoners of war.

WITH THE SIXTH ARMY CORPS IN THE FIELD, Aug. 29 -- The men of the Red and Blue armies moved wearily back into Fort Devens this afternoon, the first manoeuvre of the Sixth Corps war games completed, and looked forward to long week-end leaves.

PANAMA, Aug. 29 -- The strength of military aviation in the Caribbean defense sector is greater than generally believed and is constantly growing, according to members of a special subcommittee of the House Military Affairs Committee, now touring the Caribbean zone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A plan for reorganization of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway, which would sharply reduce its capitalization and fixed-intereat charges, was proposed to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by one of the commission's examiners.

That the Board of Education may come in conflict with the policy of the United States Government in regard to the discharge of men in the military service developed at school headquarters yesterday. The problem has been caused by the ousting of 106 swimming teachers, to take effect tomorrow.

Hoping to obtain enough information to lay out a concrete program for oil conservation in the metropolitan area, or at least get a clear picture of the situation as it is today, Grover Whalen, City Oil Conservation Director, conferred yesterday with representatives of both the big companies and the dealers.

Annual "Labor Sunday" will be observed in the churches tomorrow and annual "Labor Sabbath" will be observed in the synagogues this morning since Monday is Labor Day. In churches and in synagogues prayers will be offered that strikes will cease in the United States and that the government will not have to take over any more commercial plants where defense materials are being manufactured.

C.S. Forester, the English author of "Captain Horatio Hornblower" and other historical novels, has just completed his first children's book, according to word from San Francisco. The author, who usually writes his books in longhand, dictated this one at his Berkeley home in the midst of his work on the current best seller, "The Captain From Connecticut."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Children's Day at the State Fair brought the young fry out by legions and boosted attendance records today at a rate that made officials glow. Both as performers and "on the loose" the youngsters stirred things up on the far-flung acreage where the 101st such exposition is in progress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Total civil non-agricultural employment in July was 39,240,000, an all-time peak, according to Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, who announced today that the figure represented an increase of 3,785,000 workers over July, 1940, and 380,000 in July.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Overriding the objections of Governor Charles Edison, a fellow-Democrat Attorney General David T. Wilentz decided today to petition the Court of Chancery for review of the railroad tax compromise legislation enacted recently.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- About 200,000 men will be released by the Army before the end of the year under regulations issued today by the War Department.
OMAHA, Aug. 29 -- As was an ticipated early in the week, Marvin (Bud) Ward, Spokane club manager, today went into the final round of the national amateur golf championship.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: After reading the rather pointed remarks of Richard Kohler in last Saturday's TIMES, may I be permitted to say something concerning the so-called "yoga" of which Lou Nova is an exponent?

Under a wartime act in England no issue arising from a civil proceeding can be tried by a jury save by the con- sent of the judge. Thus "right" has given way to "favor." Apparently nobody has protested. In criminal cases the jury still obtains, though summary prosecution is working against it there as well as here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 16 was 2,320,470 shares, compared with 3,393,230 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 29 -- A preliminary report by the Chamber investigating committee, in which the charge is made that various Nazi associations organized upon semi-military lines counted in Argentina alone well over 60,000 members who had taken an oath of blind obedience to Reichsfuehrer Hitler, was delivered to the presidency of the Chamber today.

The exodus of General Sessions and Special Sessions from the old Criminal Courts Building, on the west side of Centre Street between Franklin and White Streets, to the new seventeen-story court house across the street was completed yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 29 -- For the first time this year twelvemeter racing yachts were out today. Two of them appeared for the New York Yacht Club's Fall regatta, which was held out on Long Island Sound. They were the Seven Seas, under charter to George Nichols, and Clinton H. Crane's Gleam.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 30 -- During the most intense week of aerial battles since the first week of the war, the Soviet Air Force destroyed 500 German planes against a loss of a little more than half this number -- 262 -- it was announced in the midnight communique as fighting continued along the entire front and the Wehrmacht maintained enormous pressure on Leningrad without succeeding in breaking through the Red Army's defenses.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 28:

Millions of years ago in a shadowy age, volcanic eruptions in the section that is now North- western America coursed down high mountains into rock-walled little valleys. There deposits of lava formed a fine, firm foundation for fertile soil, rich in minerals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Senate Finance Committee completed today the draft of the largest revenue bill in United States history. In its present form it is estimated by the Treasury Department that it would yield $3,672,400,000 and would bring the nation's revenues to about $13,000,000,000 during the taxable year.

Shaw Sticks to It In a world that has changed so much since George Bernard Shaw was a stripling of 25, it is comforting to get word that he, at least, has not changed. It is sixty years, according to his own reckoning, since G.B.S. became a vegetarian; and the doctor's dilemma, as one of our caption writers pertly called him a few Sundaya ago, is still an abstainer from flesh.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 -- Twenty-eight boats started late today in the Stamford Yacht Club's annual race to the Vineyard, which will take them 232 miles around Vineyard Sound Lightship before the finish between the breakwaters at the entrance to Stamford Harbor, probably on Sunday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Savings deposits in Canadian chartered banks totaled $1,488,738,000 on July 31, compared with $1,466,936,000 on June 30 and with $1,612,549,000 on July 31, 1940, the Finance Department reported today in its monthly statement.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 29 -- New York City soldiers featured a special entertainment program given to troops at Fort Du Pont this week. Lieutenant Charles "Todd" Goodwin of Bellaire, Pa., post athletic officer and former University of West Virginia football star, arranged the program, which was in the form of a "jam session."

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its consolidated subsidiaries showed a net profit of $22,844,060 for the first half of this year, according to the preliminary semi-annual statement mailed yesterday to stockholders. The consolidated net profit for the first six months of 1940 was $17,549,546.

The traditional banker relationship between the 55,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company system and the House of Morgan -- dating back to 1906 -- was severed yesterday with the disclosure by Walter S. GIfford, president of A.T. T., that the Bell System would resort to competitive bidding in a forthcoming $95,000,000 financing operation.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 29 -- Champion Biene v ElbeBogen Se Sumbula, beautiful brindle bitch, flashed back from temporary retirement to take best-in-show honors at the first annual specialty event of the New England Boxer Club held here today.
NEWPORT R.I., Aug. 29 -- Mrs. John H. Prentice gave a dinner at Belmede, with many other guests coming in later for dancing.

Hiram Walker's new blend, Imperial, will be introduced to the metropolitan, area with an extensive campaign in newspapers, billboards and car cards, Carleton Healy, advertising manager of the company, announced last night at a meeting of the New York and New Jersey sales force at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- The following communique on the HitlerMussolini meeting was issued today:

FLORHAM PARK, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Miss Nancy McClave of Maplewood scored her second consecutive victory in the weekly one-day competitions of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association by posting 43, 41 -- 84 at the Braidburn Country Club today. Women's par for the long course is 40, 41 -- 81.

Yielding to pleas for additional pay rises for city transit employes in the lower brackets, the Board of Transportation added $251,500 yesterday to the $5,999,128 of increases contained in the new wage and hour schedules adopted on Wednesday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Dr. and Mrs. E. Terry Smith entertained with a luncheon today at the Gideon Putnam for George H. Bull, racing association president, and the latter's house guests, John A. Morris, secretarytreasurer; Mrs. E. Elkins Wetherill, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Stoller, Mr. and Mrs. Melville E. Stone, Mrs. Arthur Brooks Lapsley, Mrs. Philip G. Birckhead, Miss Elizabeth Rumsey, Carter Bowie, Cortright Wetherill, Roland T. Slingluff and Addison W. Kelley.

Trading yesterday was not active for a Friday, most interests having been supplied for the holiday week-end. Steer hinds and ribs were lower, and lower grades of veal and calf hindsaddles were sharply lower. Other classes showed little price changes from Thursday. Excepting lower grades of veal and calf hindsaddles and some accumulations of beef short loins, pork loins and regular trimmings, supplies were cleaning up fairly well.

Those falcons about which things have been heard lately in connection with the Army Signal Corps -- they are being trained to destroy enemy carrier pigeons -- made their first public appearance yesterday. They posed in Times Square near the Police Information Booth from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., attracting the attention of thousands of strollers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The world's record for trotters in a four-heat race was broken in the featured Messenger Stake of the Grand Circuit harness races over the track at the New York State Fair today.

Shortages of materials acted as a brake on expansion of both production and wholesale sales this week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Retail trade, however, responded briskly to seasonal demand. Prices moved higher to new peak levels.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Excellent relief pitching by Joe Haynes came too late for the White Sox today. The Browns scored five runs off Buck Ross in the first three innings to gain a 5-to-2 victory.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Thirty minutes after a formation of four Soviet warplanes dropped six bombs on a Teheran suburb today, orders by the new government of Premier All Furanghi went into effect for Iranian troops to cease resisting the invading British and Russian forces.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Prices of hogs and sows broke 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight today after a steady to strong market on weights under 240 pounds had lifted top values to a new four-year peak of $12.25. Steer trade dragged at a weak level and Spring lambs held steady.
