BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- Three weeks after the conference at sea of the leaders of the world's two most powerful democracies, Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini, as their authoritarian counterparts, held a five-day conference and inspection trip of their own in the Eastern Front, according to a special communique released from Herr Hitler's Field Headquarters this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, said today that he expected a speed-up in defense production to result from the latest reorganization, but warned that "we can't fight a war on a limited week or limited supply basis."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of Aug. 19, "What Causes Inflation," you Imply that the government's borrowing of bank-created demand deposits is responsible for the present price upswing, and that we are in for considerable unpleasantness unless Washington mends its ways.

Less resistance will be shown by consumers to the price advances on men's clothing going into effect for Fall on Tuesday than at any time since the first abortive attempt to increase levels substantially in the NRA days, manufacturers and retailers predicted yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The Eastern College All-Stars polished off their teamwork and the Long Island Indians in the same motion at Wilson Field today in their final tune-up for their battle with the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The resumption today of trading in lard futures induced the development of Independent strength in soy beans and the losses of yesterday, when the lard market was closed, were more than erased. Closing quotations of futures on the Board of Trade here were at about the top for the session, except on the old October position, the gains ranging from 1 1/2 to 2 5/8 cents a bushel.

TRIPS to the dentist, hair-cuts, new shoes belong to the wind-up in back-to-school preparations this week, and so do decisions about the schoolbag Howard's 8-year-old heart is set on-one like a brief case, not one with a strap. We've been rounding up expert opinion on these and a few other items.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 30 -- Ben Hogan, riding the crest of a great par-busting streak, shot a smart 69 in the third round of the $5,000 Hershey open golf tournament today for a total of 205 and a three-stroke lead over Lloyd Mangrum of Monterey, Calif.

T.D. Webb, vice chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, declares that the Treasury Department's new "tax saving's plan" has made a valuable contribution to the future financial stability of the average American citizen.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 30 -- Appreciation of Iran's wisdom in deciding to cease resistance against Anglo-Russian forces is feeing widely expressed in Arab circles here. The local Arabic attitude is that Britain's assurances of good intentions toward Iran prior to the campaign represent the best possible guarantee that no harm will befall the integrity and independence of the Kingdom if vital Allied interests there are maintained.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The government program for reducing the number of styles, colors and models of many household goods will be extended rapidly. Donald M. Nelson said today, in an effort to increase armament production.

The American Federation of Teachers, being an organization of intelligent people, demonstrated last week in its convention in Detroit that it was capable within its membership of that attribute of intelligence, self-criticism. On the major issue of the convention, the expulsion of local unions in New York and Philadelphia, the sense of the meeting was sharply shown.

THE little man with the banjo eyes will be back on the air next Wednesday night, and, though it is probably treading on dangerous ground to say so, it is hereby said that the new radio season will start then. The adherents of distinguished performers who have been working straight through the Summer will doubtless take umbrage -- and pen in hand -- at this pronouncement, asking plaintively, "What do you mean, a new season?

CARELESS driving of many operators results in destruction of one tire in every five. This extremely high ratio is entirely unnecessary, though modern driving conditions are not geared to obtaining the utmost mileage that manufacturers "build" into tires.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Flornell Rare-Bit of Twin Ponds, sound and pert Welsh terrier, owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., captured best-in-show honors at the annual exhibition of the Lenox Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the Foxhollow School for Girls today.

HYDE PARK, Aug. 30 -- Expressing fear that danger to the United States had increased, President Roosevelt said today that, although Americans pray they can remain at peace, the final decision might not be theirs.

MAESTRO: A short, dark, stocky man with a Van Dyke beard was conducting a concert of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra in January, 1928. After one number he walked off the podium with tiny mincing steps.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Mr, and Mrs. Barclay K. Douglas entertained with a large supper dance tonight at Sans Souci, their home in First Neck Lane, for her daughter, Miss Nuala O'Donnell. Multi-colored lights and lanterns illuminated the grounds and silhouetted the driveway and porches.

MONTPELIER, Vt, Aug. 30 -- Governor Stassen of Minnesota supplied a climax for Vermont's sesquicentennial celebration tonight with an address scoring "the overlapping and confusion" of defense agencies, suggesting one "director of defense" and asserting that the new seven-man board headed by Vice President Wallace failed to solve the problem.

Representative Stephen A. Day of Illinois announced yesterday that a poll taken by him of the persons listed in Who's Who in America showed only 42.8 per cent flatly in favor of our entering the war now. Those against were 57.2 per cent, he declared.

SUBSTANTIAL, progress toward uniformity of truck size and weight limits in harmony with the recommendations of organized highway officials was made during the 1941 legislative year when nineteen States changed their laws, the National Highway Users Conference discloses.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Despite distance racing, final holiday cruising and the distance here from the western end of Long Island Sound, 118 craft started today in the sixty-ninth Fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

PRESS confidently on, reader, from this novel's too-general title: you will find a quite particular originality beguiling you unfailingly from page 1. Even before you meet any of the strangely clustered denizens of the Citadel of San Liguori you know that this book which begins and ends with an earthquake is going to offer the prime entertainment of a brilliantly contrived tale.

The suggestion that Railway tank cars be used to alleviate the gasoline shortage in the Eastern States, with the extra expense of rail over water transport spread evenly over all gasoline retailed, was made yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his role as National Director of Civilian Defense.

THE railroads have stepped up their operating efficiency to a high peak. Never before have they offered so much in the way of safety, speed and fine equipment at so little cost to the traveler. Such is the conclusion reached after a 10,000-mile tour of the country on fourteen roads and twenty-seven trains, which included stops in twenty-three cities and many talks with employes from brakeman to president.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Aug. 29:

Changing from their recent irregular movements, price on the New York Cotton Exchange rose steadily yesterday to close at net gains of 13 to 21 points, with the most strength in the distant positions. Final quotations were only a few points below the best levels of the short session.

SOME of the best of recent historical novels have been built upon incidents whose details are virtually unknown. Beyond the fact that they are thought to have happened, there is little for the novelist to work with except his imagination.

THE press agents must be slipping. Otherwise there would be no accounting for the fact that a burgeoning star with the shining prospects of Dorothy Comingore should descend out of the sky with the coming of dawn over La Guardia Field, after an all-night flight from Omaha, without even a hint from the drumbeaters of RKO.

Article I in the credo of those who write historical fiction about the American Revolution appears to be that the Continental dollar started slipping as soon as it was issued and went steadily downhill. This is, however, not true. The colonists, especially those in the Middle Atlantic States, had had happy experiences with a managed paper currency which had no bullion backing.

Pierre Laval is said to have told a group of acquaintances in Paris two months ago that he knew 95 per cent of the French people were opposed to collaboration with the Germans, but that nevertheless he was convinced that along that path lay the best prospects for France and that was why he would continue to work in that direction.

A suggestion is made by the committee on urban land use of the American Institute of Architects that cities should set up a corporate real estate agency to deal constructively with tax-delinquent properties. Such an agency, it is held, could sell properties for which there is no anticipated public use.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Bobby Baxter, 20-year-old Holy Cross graduate, became the Long Island junior golf champion today by routing Vinnie Raskopf, a senior at Garden City High School, 5 and 4, in the eighteen-hole final at Cherry Valley.

Concern over the fate of the Irish freighter Leda, which left here in mid-July with a cargo of wheat and other essentials for Eire, is growing among Irish circles in the city. Members of the American Friends of Irish Neutrality said yesterday that they were anxious about the ship and had been unable to obtain any information as to her whereabouts.
MEXICO CITY. A THOUGH concerts of the Mexican Symphony Orchestra have been superb in past years, none has been as history-making as those of the season which will come to a close Aug. 31.

JOHN DOS PASSOS is 45, and in his brief time he has tried his hand at most of the forms of writing art. That means that to his credit are novels, which are the basis of his reputation, plays, verse, essays and now, in "The Ground We Stand On," history.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Aug. 31 -- Russian forces have inflicted heavy losses on German troops driving against Leningrad from the northwest and southwest, according to late Soviet reports. In one engagement alone the Germans lost eighty tanks and sixty-two planes, it was asserted.
SIMLA, India, Aug. 30 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

Westchester County brokers report rising interest in the sale of homes and the renting of apartments in well located sections. In many of the residential development centers construction work is going on to meet the expected Fall demand, and an active realty market is looked for during the coming months.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- An idyllic wonderland of cascading waterfalls and virgin timberland, two famous shrines and a series of expanded parks are soon to join the sights worth seeing in scenic and historic Pennsylvania, a State which has become increasingly popular with vacationists in recent years.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Attired in costumes revivifying modes of a half century ago, members of society here will gather at the swimming pool adjoining the clubhouse of the Tuxedo Club next Saturday night for a gala Gay Nineties dinner dance arranged as a benefit for the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Office of Production Management said today that a campaign to increase the junking of wornout automobiles would be extended next week to the Chicago, St. Louis and Kansas City areas.

MANILA, Aug. 30 -- Reports to Manila indicate Japan is rapidly reverting to the medieval period when foreign travel was rigidly restricted. Even Japanese domestic journeyings are subjected to closest scrutiny.
The writer of the following letter is Professor of Law at New York University and was formerly professor at the Academy of International Law at The Hague.

The single-story dwelling inspected by many thousand visitors at the recent World's Fair and known as No. 1 in the World's Fair Town of Tomorrow has been moved to Huntington, L.I., and re-erected in its original form by J. Franklin Bradley, realty operator, on a tract of twenty-eight acres which he is preparing to develop as a medium-priced home community.

Announcing the completion of its report on the realty and housing conditions in Milwaukee, Wis., the Urban Land Institute said that the general situation represented many of the factors presented in the studies previously completed of New York, Boston and Cincinnati.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug. 30 -- Growth of the annual orientation period for new college students, from a disconnected series of lectures on the general theme "How to Be a Success in College" to a carefully planned program involving personnel and counseling techniques, is traced in a study just made by Dr. Charles M. Bond, who this Fall will complete fifteen years as director of Bucknell University's Freshman Week activities.
DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- Henry Ford expects to build Consolidated B-24D bomber plane assemblies long before the $47,000,000 factory now under construction near Ypsilanti is completed.

Limitations imposed by the city budget for 1941-1942 will not permit the pay rises granted by the Board of Transportation to the 27,480 employes in the operating and maintenance departments of the unified transit lines to be retroactive to July 1, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at the Summer City Hall in Queens.

Another fleet making Lloyd Harbor a busy place this week-end is that of the Harlem Y.C., from City Island. Games on the beach near the lighthouse are scheduled for this afternoon after which, because the week-end is known officially as the "commodore's cruise," Commodore E.G. Baker will be host at a cocktail party.

Boys from England's well-known public (preparatory) schools have received training this Summer as tractor drivers to enable them, during their holidays, to be of help to farmers, according to recent reports from London.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- In a special communique issued from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters at the conclusion of the tenth week of the Russian invasion today the Supreme German Command recapitulated the exceptionally heavy shipping losses that it said had been inflicted upon the Soviet forces when they sought to evacuate encircled Tallinn before its fall.

"I'm afraid it's all over -- the blackout beat us." James Sanger, descendant of the man who founded England's famous circus, thus announced last week that his show was going out of business. The war's restrictions on bright lights, he explained, had caused a dwindling of patrons.

EMPORIA, Kan., Aug. 30 -- The first week of September marks the second anniversary of World War II. Also, it marks the fourth year of a, definite foreign policy outlined by President Roosevelt in his Chicago speech in the early Autumn of 1937, when he declared that free people should "quarantine against the aggressor."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Three leaders of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, sponsors of the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, which ended a five-day session yesterday on the Williams College Campus, called today for united action on the part of Protestants, Catholics and Jews in America to meet the problems of the present crisis and of the post-war period.

The fact that lass than half of the home owners in five States for which the United States Census Bureau so far has completed details in regard to housing conditions, possession and occupancy, have debts on their homes is hailed by the home building and home owning committee of the United States Savings and Loan League as one of the most reassuring facts revealed by the 1940 census.
Nearly 100,000 new small homes have been financed and constructed under the FHA program since the first of this year, according to Federal Housing Administrator Abner H. Ferguson.

With growing air power, England has begun to turn the tables on Germany and plans to bomb Berlin in night-long raids next Winter as the Luftwaffe hammered British cities last Winter, aviation experts arriving from Europe on the Atlantic Clipper said yesterday at La Guardia Field.

VICHY, France, Aug. 30 -- Interest in both zones of Prance was divided today between the condition of Pierre Laval and Marcel Deal after the shooting at Versaille on Wednesday by Paul Colette and the measures of repression taken to prevent the recurrence of such deeds.

An extensive exhibition of work by Henri Julien Rousseau, including paintings, drawings and prints, will open at the Chicago Art Institute on Jan. 22 and continue until Feb. 23. It will be held at the Museum of Modern Arts also, from March 18 through May 15.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth, believed to be the first woman in this country to hold an engineering professorship, has been appoinetd chairman of the Department of Personnel Relations at Newark College of Engineering, Dr. Allan R. Cullimore, president of the college, announced today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command announced today that Viborg, ancient symbol of Finland's struggle against invasion, had been recaptured from the Russians, but it soon appeared that all the Finns were getting back was a mere shell of the Karelian capital.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- Japan has made representations both in Moscow and Washington against the shipment of war materials to Russia via Vladivostok, and she has made cessation of such shipments a question of her national prestige. She is now considering the limits of her territorial waters.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 -- Buck Newsom limited the punchless Indians to seven hits today to give Detroit a 7-to-3 triumph in the series opener.

OMAHA, Aug. 30 -- In burning heat, borne on the wings of a 45-mile-per-hour gale and in the presence of one of the most partisan galleries ever to watch a golf match, Marvin (Bud) Ward, 28-year-old secretary of a Spokane "Boosters" Club, today annexe his second national amateur go championship.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- For the first time in the history of the Hopeful Stakes, all three places were swept by an entry today when Devil Diver, Shut Out and Amphitheatre finished as named in this $41,450 renewal of the famous juvenile fixture which is the high point of Saratoga's closing day each year.

In writing her historical story of the third expedition from Pan- ama to Peru, which was led by Marshal de Almagro and Francisco de Pizarro in 1532, the author has made the Marshal's young son, Diego, the central figure. The story as told by Miss Desmond is complicated and not always easy to follow.

Daytime and evening courses, which may be taken individually or as a group leading to the Certificate of Proficiency in Landscape Architecture, will begin at Columbia University on Sept. 25 under the direction of Professor Hugh Findlay.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is just possible that some of your readers will get false impression regarding the nature of the Portuguese State from the recent letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES by M. R. Madden.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug -- 29 Adoption of a plan to create an armored spearhead for New Zealand's fighting forces has been revealed by Defense Minister M. F. Jones with announcement of the creation of an army tank brigade for operations abroad.

Two of this country's most important farm products, wheat and cotton, may virtually disappear from the export markets unless they are disposed of through leaselend activities. The sharp rise in recent weeks in these commodities, partly the result of governmental activities, has placed them farther from an export basis.

In a telegram addressed to "Honorable Fiorello H. La Guardia, Civilian Defense Administrator, 2000 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C.," John R. Davies yesterday called upon the Mayor to remove Paul J. Kern as chairman of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.
Well ahead of the opening of the new art season, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has completed the redecorating and rehanging, begun last Spring, of twenty-four galleries of paintings.

The possibility that large-scale conflict may spread to the Far East draws attention to Japan's armed strength and particularly to the Japanese air arm, which presumably would be called upon to play an important part in any show-down among the powers.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, French Indo-China, Aug. 30 (AP) -- In the weird rites of a lost empire the body of the late King of Cambodia was cremated and enshrined yesterday. The monarch, Prea Bat Samdach Prea Sisowath Monivong, died last April 23.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 30 -- In high Catholic quarters it was learned today churchmen here believe the long conflict in Mexico between Church and State to be "about over." Anti-church laws are still on the books they remark, but everybody knows they are not enforced.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- A mass evacuation of British subjects from the Japanese Empire was indicated today in a British Embassy announcement that it had arranged for a ship to come to Japan to remove all British nationals desiring to leave.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Mrs. Norman K. Toerge of Locust Valley today retired the Fallowfield Challenge Cup emblematic of the hunter championship of the thirtysecond annual Smithtown Horse Show, held today for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

JUNE BURN and her husband, Farrar, if we are to judge from the story of their adventuring, do not possess the proverbial ounce of sporting blood. They have quarts of it; in fact, it appears that they have no other kind.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of firmness in the hog and cattle markets that reflected satisfactory dressed-meat trade and slightly diminished receipts. An insufficient run of animals was put up for sale today to really test the market.

A year ago the Eastern All-Stars handed the New York Football Giants a shock from which they did not recover all season. Seven times in the previous ten years the pupils of Stout Steve Owen had bowled over various picked elevens without overexerting themselves to any great extent, but the All-Stars vanquished the Giants, 16 to 7, and the New Yorkers went on from there to a rather indifferent campaign.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Ted Williams, still keeping his batting average above 400, got two hits, one a homer, in three trips to the plate today as the Red Sox scored a 12-3 victory over the Athletics.

About 4,500 are expected to enroll in the fiftieth session of the Evening and Extension Division of Hunter College, beginning Sept. 15, it was announced yesterday. Registration will start Monday, Sept. 8, and continue through Thursday, Sept. 11, from 2 to 4 P.M. and from 7 to 9:30 P.M. daily.

THE original title of the "Golden Legend" was "Legenda Sanctorum," meaning literally "readings from the saints." The word "legenda" is here the equivalent of "lectio," the prescribed reading about the saints in the Breviary.

ROME, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The official news agency Stefani quoted Foreign Minister Lorkovic of Croatia tonight as charging the former United States Consul at Zagreb with "illegal activity" in support of the enemies of Germany and Italy.

ALTHOUGH election day is some two months off, no Gallup poll is necessary to predict who will be New York's next District Attorney. That was decided when the principal political parties agreed, for the first time in the history of the city, upon the same candidate for the county's prosecuting officer.

SINCE the Axis occupation of Yugoslavia at least thirty-seven, provisional have been in circulation, according to information reaching New York last week. Eleven values in the 1939-40 series with portrait of King Peter II were overprinted "Serbien" and possibly the entire series was so treated.

HOLMES, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Mayor La Guardia, congratulating the sweepers and drivers of the Sanitation Department and Commissioner William F. Carey for finally establishing their vacation camp here after failing at other localities because of the "snobbishness or greed" of local people, disclosed yesterday that President Roosevelt had once assured him that "Carey and his men would be welcome up our way" in Dutchess County if they could not find a place.
JULIEN LEVY has left New York on an extended trip through the United States, where he will open exhibitions in various cities of work by artists identified with his gallery.

THAT a radio production is rarely better than its script is an accepted maxim among the industry's showmen. Occasionally an outstanding actor or director concerned with a program may lift an inferior script from the depths of its mediocrity, but the services of such people are not always available.

Traders in a number of lines who were in Washington during the week came back with the notion that major changes in the principles under which the ceiling system of the Office of Price Administration is operated may be in the offing.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30 -- The Maidstone Club's 1891 Barn Dance tonight brought to a close the season's series of Saturday dinner dances and the special program of events celebrating the club's fiftieth anniversary. The festivities were enlivened by a fiddler "calling the figures" for country dances, and by several "Gay Nineties" games.

Orders, deliveries and profits of the aircraft industry continued their wage-engendered boom in the first half of this year establishing new records in all three departments for the period. Profits after Federal tax provisions dipped moderately from the second half of 1940, owing to the sharply higher rates of taxation which will apply to 1941 earnings, but were well in excess of profits in the first half of 1940 and all prior quarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 30 -- President Roosevelt filled what has been regarded generally here as a long-felt need for centralized planning when he established this week a Supply Priorities and Allocations Board.

THE years following the mauve decade haven't settled down historically to a fast color of their own. As Josie Turner describes them, they might rate an apple-green or a golden to typify their halcyonhue; but probably a rosy pink would be best.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Without minimizing the importance or the seriousness of the diplomatic conversations with Japan that were marked by the delivery to President Roosevelt of the personal letter of Prince Fumimaro Konoye, the Japanese Premier, Secretary of State Cordell Hull made clear at his press conference today that the conversations were only in the preliminary stage and that fro definite conclusions had been reached or were yet possible.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- In accepting the chairmanship of a California organizing committee of the Fight for Freedom, President Robert G. Sproul of the University of California declared in a nationwide radio address tonight that until Hitler was defeated nothing else mattered.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Russell Sage College is planning to celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary Oct. 5 to 12. The major part of its anniversary program will be dedicated to the cause of friendship, understanding and good-will among the twenty-one American republics.

THERE are perhaps no more than 3,000 professional tournament directors in the United States, and the publication of technical literature for their use has proved generally unprofitable to publishers because of its limited sale.

IT looks as if the American public is expected to have a Gargantuan appetite for Russian Ballet in the season just ahead, for no less than four companies are to be in the field, two of them frankly calling themselves Ballets Russes and the other two, in spite of names under which they were organized in earlier seasons, now leaning heavily upon the same tradition.

DETROITERS visiting here last week said their Aug. 20-24 transit strike failed to stop or upset production schedules in any leading defense plant in the area. One small defense manufacturer suffered for a half day. In other words, Detroit factory workers are so thoroughly "motorized" that their cars absorbed the added burden.

RIO DE JANEIRO. Brazil. Aug. 30-Warren L. Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank, is here again, but as usual he is jealously guarding his mission. He would not state what brought him here, but it is conjectured that his special job will carry him to Minas Geraes to look into new sources of strategic war material and to speed up production of material already contracted for.

It seems there has been a revolution, in a quiet way, in the girdle, corselette and brassiere field. The design of these undergarments has been advanced through the introduction of nylon fabrics and nylon elastic net, which in many cases replace silks and combinations of silks, rayons and cottons.
In return for past favors granted in other hot pennant races -- notably 1934 -- the Giants knocked the Dodgers right out of the National league lead yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- It was announced officially today that Marshal Semyon Budenny's large southern army had escaped encirclement by the Germans in the "Battle of the Dnieper Bulge," and there were persistent reports that Soviet troops had crossed the Dnieper in a westerly direction at several points south of Kiev in a series of counter-attacks.

PURCHASES made to "beat the gun" on the new installment terms combined with "back to college" promotions to lift retail sales before the holiday. Gains over last year, therefore, were fairly well maintained, but retailers are anxious to see how comparisons will work out on the regular business that starts in now that the Summer is over.

ROME, Aug. 30 -- Every newspaper commentator in Italy tried his hardest today to explain and clarify the Axis answer to the eight-point declaration given out after the Hitler-Mussolini encounter. The comments were chiefly interesting for their failure to throw any light upon the subject.

AS dealers receive cars for display, Plymouth now is announcing locally throughout the nation its 1942 models. With noticeable changes in appearance and power, the new cars make use of optional materials replacing those required for national defense.

CAMP POLK, La., Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- Six members of the House Military Affairs Subcommittee, investigating Army camp construction, said that the $21,000,000 which Camp Polk cost was justified, although it is the most costly camp they have visited.

HANOVER, N.H., Aug. 30 -- A positive effort to strengthen the democratic faith of college youth will be undertaken at Dartmouth this Fall by twelve faculty members who will teach a new course entitled "Components of Democratic Thought."

Earnings of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., are indicated at $747,218 for the six months ended on June 30, before provision for Federal income and excess profits tax, according to a report issued for publication today.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The average German is probably more conscious of the semi-luxuries and amenities of life of which he has been deprived by the British blockade than of the deeper and therefore less conspicuous and spectacular effects which the cessation of overseas exports has had on his standard of living.

OLD BROOKVILLB, L.I., Aug. 30 -- The American Theatre Wing and the Nassau County Committee of the British War Relief Society are sponsoring the "Thumbs Up" garden party which will be held here on the evening of Sept. 13 on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage.

THE House of Ullstein, founded in Berlin in 1877. grew to be the largest publishing house in the world. It issued four dally newspapers, half a dozen magazines and a huge list of books. The story of its fall is told by Herman Ullstein, senior member of the firm, in the Aug. 25 issue of The Saturday Review of Literature.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 30 -- In authoritative quarters here it was said today that the Mexican Government was much impressed with the good-will shown in the negotiations under way in Washington and was hopeful of an early settlement of some of the major outstanding issues, including oil claims.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Police of many cities besieged Washington officials today for information whether unsolved sex crimes in their localities could be attributed to Jarvis R. Catoe, 36-year-old Negro and confessed murderer of ten women.
The Citizens Peace Petition Committee announced yesterday that 3 per cent of the first 15,000 signers of its petition for an American peace offensive were clergymen.

TORONTO. CANADIANS have been fortunate in recent months in seeing in person more leading American stage, screen and radio stars than in any similar previous period. There has been a heavier run of stage productions than for some years and wartime charities and government financing campaigns have brought big names of the American entertainment world to Canada as participants.

To the Art Editor: AS director of the Research Studio, Maitland, Fla., the run of letters that have followed your provocative articles have been of great interest to me. I have already written to Mr. Kootz to congratulate him on his

An 11-year-old boy who had been playing about the corner of 103d Street and Third Avenue was struck in the right leg at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon by a bullet fired by a policeman who was trying to halt a fight in front of Hantman's Bar and Grill at 1868 Third Avenue, across the street.

FORT DBC, N.J., Aug. 30 -- The Forty-fourth Division instituted a "survey within a survey" today to determine the number of specialists who will require raplacing as a result of the War Department's proposal to release 200,000 enlisted men from the Army by Dec. 10.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- Faced with the prospect of a long and bitter war, the economic system of the Soviet Union is now busily adjusting itself to the condition resulting from the German invasion and the initial German successes, including the conquest of certain extremely rich areas like White Russia and the Southern and Western Ukraine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Farmers are riding the crest of a price wave, due in part to the effect of the lease-lend and defense effort upon-the whole economy, the like of which they have not experienced in a decade, the Department of Agriculture said today.

SUMMER has long been regarded as the season when nature interferes most with radio. Now, high-power broadcasting has decreased the petty noises of manmade static, but when storms of major proportions strike, nature's barrage of lightning blots out reception.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: About last call for planting Bearded Irises if they are to become well established before Winter... . Keeping faded flowers of annuals removed, to prevent formation of seed, will prolong the season of bloom. Species which withstand some frost, such as Sweet Alyssum and verbenas, can be trimmed back now to present a neater appearance for the balance of the season.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- With the installation of new machinery and equipment from the United States, Nicaragua's gold output is expected to increase appreciably, the Commerce Department reports.

NO one who has ever visited an island sea-bird colony, seen the wheeling and circling of countless thousands of wings and heard the clamor of innumerable voices drowning out the sound of the waves will ever forget the experience.

There has been complaint, and some of it very specific complaint such as that of Senator Byrd, concerning deficiencies in our defense production. Unquestionably there are points at which it has lagged, due to a variety of causes, among which are insufficient concentration of planning authority, delays in material delivery, component bottlenecks and labor stoppages.

WITH an estimated $35,000,000 tied up in England due to wartime currency restrictions, American film producers are busily hatching ways and means to put as much as possible of this money into immediate use.

To convince a reader of superlative genius or superlative beauty is about as difficult a task as the writer can set himself -- in this case, herself -- in the way of characterization. Mrs. Burt has made a good job of it.

Only the United States can define the goals of the war, for England is consumed by resistance and its sole war aim can only be the defeat of Hitler, Dr. Max Ascoli, professor of political science in the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research, writes in an article, "War Aims and America's Aims," made public yesterday.
An analysis of the best-in-show awards at the leading exhibitions throughout the United States during the first six months of the year reveals some interesting facts regaarding judges and judging.
As usual, Labor Day finds sundry significant matters on the air, the outstanding events scheduled for tomorrow being as follows (all times EDS):

If the stockholder of a corporation sails his stock to the corporation, his gain on the sale may be either a capital or an ordinary gain. Since a capital gain is subject to a lesser tax, the stockholder will naturally seek to effect the sale as a capital transaction.

BATAVIA -- A charity series and four defense stamps will be issued by Netherlands Indies (philately's Dutch Indies) in the Fall, it is announced by L.A.L.J. Kusters of the Department of Posts, Telegraphs and Telephones.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced yesterday the names of eighteen members who will constitute the Federal Savings and Loan advisory council for the 1941-42 fiscal year.

The experienced vegetable gardener, far from resting inert in the shade of his favorite tree during late August and the heat of early September, welcomes the dog days for their longer nights, their heavy dews and their thunder showers. The Autumn is upon him.

The Country Club of Brookline, Mass., will be the scene of the forty-fifth women's amateur golf championship of the United States, held under the auspices of the U.S.G.A., from Sept. 8 to 13, inclusive.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Steve Peek turned back Baltimore today with a three-hit mound job, while Newark fashioned a 4-to-1 victory. Then Peek left for Washington rejoin the Yankees tonight.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to your correspondent Leonard W. Cronkhite, there were no serious economic causes for the present war.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Trapped in the cabin of the forty-foot tuna fishing schooner Schula after it had capsized early this evening when struck by a mountainous wave in Jones Beach Inlet, three of the eight persons aboard were drowned and two others injured. The survivors were rescued by the Coast Guard.

THE Society for the Publication of American Chamber Music will examine works for any combination of not more than six instruments, but the works it is most interested in publishing this year are sonatas for string and piano, piano trios and string and woodwind combinations.

Eager to extend the benefits of its free lunch program to needy children of pre-school age, the Surplus Marketing Administration will permit settlement houses, orphanages and day nurseries to participate in the program this year for the first time, Louis L. Horch, district supervisor of the SMA, announced yesterday.

Industriously American engineers have been tackling the new problem of building construction made graphic by the wholesale bombing of cities in the war across the seas. One of the major controversial points has been whether to erect panels which are bonded and anchored securely to the structural frame or panels with planes of weakness along the edges that will fall under high blast pressures so that the ultimate damage will be at a minimum.

MONTREAL -- Wartime Canada, grim with determination to stand shoulder to shoulder with the mother country in the battle against Hitlerism, is more eager than ever to welcome and to please American tourists.

Alfredo Salmaggi's New York La Scala Grand Opera Company, which presented nine productions at the Jolson Theatre in the Spring, returned there to begin an Autumn season last night. The opening work was Verdi's "Rigoletto" and the top price was 99 cents Instead of the $1.50 charged at the first stand at the theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- National morale is not as good as it should be today to conduct a huge armament program or, if necessary, a war effort That is the opinion of politicians, business men, labor leaders, observers and tourists from many walks of life pouring into the nation's capital from ail parts of the country.

"IF you love New York you can find beauty everywhere," Andre de Dienes reported enthusiastically. "There isn't a corner or a wall which doesn't have its photogenic aspects. Why, only this afternoon, while taking pictures on East Eighty-ninth Street, I saw an ancient junk shop which was a beautiful subject.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in August was around the dullest of the year and the turnover of 10,875,370 shares, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was the second smallest for an August in twenty-three years, or since 1918.

KATIE is leaving, as you may have heard. Everywhere feminine conversation is down to its topical bedrock, "the help." now that the household worker is making another wartime exit: this time, as in the World War, because she is getting a job in industry or because her husband is getting one.

The attitude of authorities at Vichy and Paris being what it was, the shooting of Laval, whose pro-German sympathies had been notorious, was bound to result in an excited official demonstration against all possible enemies of the existing regime. It is not at all strange that this week's cables should have reflected an atmosphere of something like official panic.

Aircraft shares led the stock market into moderately higher ground yesterday. Dealings of 231,600 shares on the Stock Exchange were the largest for a Saturday since Aug. 9 and compared with 150,560 on the preceding Saturday.

BROADWAY has not been exactly devastated by the two versions of the ice show that has been running at the capacious Center Theatre with one interruption since last October. No clangorous superlatives have crashed through the evening air of this brassy town, urging every one to come rushing to the box office without delay.
AIKEN, S.C., Aug. 30 -- Crisp nights and bright days for riding, golf and tennis are attracting members of society for the early season here, which begins on Monday.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- Official quarters continued their silence regarding the negotiations between President Roosevelt and Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the Japanese Ambassador. Though the Berlin radio announcement that an agreement had been reached with Washington was declared to be "premature" there was a notable change in the atmosphere, which is now registering subdued optimism.

TRAVEL as a means of keeping Americans fit for patriotic duty is urged by Defense Recreation Coordinator Paul V. McNutt in a recent article on the nation's health during the present national defense emergency.

A problem that has been annoying up-State sportsmen appears to be on the way to solution. Duck hunters at Oneida and Cross Lakes have found many difficulties arising over the setting of temporary and permanent blinds and complaints were also registered by property owners alleging acts of infringement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A plan to increase the price of milk and cream paid to producers in the New York metropolitan milk shed, based upon the record of public hearings held in New York State during the first half of August, was announced today by Secretary Wickard for immediate submission to producers and handlers.

CASTLETON, Vt., Aug. 30 -- Grandpa's Knob has been the scene of great activity in the past few days as steel workers removed the rigging used in construction of the Smith-Putnam wind turbine, said to be the largest windmill in the world, in preparation for its first tests.

COMPENSATION for the disappearance of the berries, peaches and melons which make Summer a joyful season for fruit addicts is the arrival of three Autumn stalwarts -- apples, grapes and pears. This Fall threesome floods into market as Summer houses close, bathing suits go into moth balls and disgruntled youngsters trudge back to school.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 30 -- Imperatrice, W.H. Laboyteaux's 3-year-old filly that never has been out of the money, kept her record clear today with a length and a quarter victory in the $10,000 added New England Oaks, mile and a sixteenth feature at Narragansett Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- At the start of the third year of the war, Washington is able to agree on at least one proposition: that Britain's chances of a tie or a victory are immeasurably better than they were a year ago. Even the isolationists who were willing to abandon the British in September, 1940, now admit that John Bull is a better bet today.

Dr. Mal Stevens has learned to take football injuries in season quite philosophically, but when one of his players tries to rush the calendar and gets himself damaged ahead of time, one could hardly begrudge the good doctor a spell of profound pique.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The four most influential newspapers in Buenos Aires chorused a demand today that Acting President Ramon S. Castillo scrap his policy of "strict neutrality toward all," for which he was criticized, and throw Argentina's weight into the fight against Nazi influence in the New World.

The report of Poor Co. for the first six months of the current year indicates a net profit of $481,000, after depreciation and Federal income and excess-profits taxes, equal to $3 each on 160,000 shares of outstanding Class A stock, on which there are dividend arrears.

THE American Philatelic Society at its recent convention in Baltimore adopted a resolution that the rules of its sales department be changed so as to provide that any stamps found in the sales books to have been repaired, reperforated or regummed shall be indelibly marked, on the reverse side, to that effect.

The mild weather, an influx of more than 20,000 soldiers, home on furlough from Southern Army camps, and the traditional departure and arrival of thousands of vacationists combined yesterday to give New York City the largest Labor Day week-end travel crowd in many years.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 30 -- One of outboarding's most prized perpetual trophies, the Stone Harbor Gold Cup, which has been in competition for a dozen years, will go to the engravers next week to have a new name added below the imposing list of prior winners.

It is characteristic of the financial community in this city, particularly that part of it which is concerned primarily with the underwriting and distribution of new securities, to look upon the Labor Day week-end as the line of demarcation between "Summer dullness" and the "Fall revival of activity."
SHANGHAI, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A report of mounting nervousness and anxiety in Japan was brought here today by fifty-nine Americans who arrived from Japan aboard the Japanese liner Tatuta Maru.

AMENIA, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- In a revival of old-fashioned town meeting democracy tonight, the dairy farming people of this village attended a debate in which Representative Hamilton Fish declared that America should stay out of war while continuing aid to Great Britain and Lewis Mumford demanded an immediate declaration of war against Germany.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden called today for redoubled production efforts by British workers in a speech in which he reviewed recent foreign policy, promised food for the Iranians, praised the progress of Anglo-Soviet diplomacy and enlarged the Roosevelt-Churchill declaration into a world pledge of peace and prosperity in the postwar era.

JOHN A. LOMAX has travels some 300,000 miles in his many journeys up and down and across the United States. He has poked into corners where probably only tax collectors go, and he has brought together an immense body of American folksongs, writing them down and recording them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Labor summarizes this Labor Day a year of fruitful employment gains and payroll accretions with a sense of satisfaction mingled with some doubts.

CANBERRA, Aug. 30 -- The new Prime Minister, A.W. Fadden announced at his first press conference today that while he would retain the present proportions of United Australia and Country party Ministers, he would personally select all Ministers instead of choosing from the panel submitted by United Australia party as had previously been done by a Country party Premier in coalition governments.

A three-year course in occupational therapy will be offered for the first time this year by Columbia University Extension, according to an announcement by Professor James C. Egbert, director. Scientific and medical studies, together with courses in arts and crafts, will comprise the first two years, followed by nine months of clinical training in hospitals in the metropolitan area.

THE International Dance Festival at Jacob's Pillow, near Lee, Mass., will close with a pair of performances on Friday and Saturday afternoons at 4:45, which will be in the nature of a gala. On the bill will be Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin, directors of the festival, Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Aug. 30 -- During the last two weeks of the sixteenth session of the Bread Loaf Writers Conference, held here annually on Bread Loaf Mountain under the auspices of Middlebury College, the question of whether such a conference should emphasize the commercial, the educational, the critical, the literary and the social, has been discussed repeatedly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The House Committee Investigating National Defense Migration will hold hearings in Detroit Sept. 23 to 25 to study the effect on communities and individual workers of the shift from non-defense to defense production.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -- A vocational education wavelet of the future crested here last week in connection with a display arranged for the national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity edged forward slightly in the week ended Aug. 23. It was 131.1, compared with 130.9 for the previous week and 109.0 for the corresponding week of last year.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- As a climax to the season a buffet dinner and dance for the benefit jointly of the British War Belief Society and the Soldiers' Guest House at Fort H.G. Wright here took place at the Fishers Island Country Club this evening, The members of the colony and their week-end guests provided a capacity attendance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The health, safety and welfare of America's 30,000,000 pupils in public and private schools are perennially prime concerns of State Legislatures and of local boards of education. Several new statutes touching these matters directly were enacted by the State law-making bodies convened during 1941.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 30 -- A lively controversy has been aroused in Switzerland, and notably in the German-speaking territories, by the action of the director of the Swiss Cinema Chamber in signing recently in Berlin an agreement that is viewed as curtailing the freedom of action of movie projection concerns in this country.

Charles A. Lindbergh's statement that England before the war ends "may turn against us, as she has turned against France and Finland," made in a speech Friday night in Oklahoma City, Okla., was characterized yesterday by Clark M. Eichelberger, national director of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, as "probably the most striking illustration of the perverted and twisted thinking of some of the isolationists."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A further tightening of restrictions on petroleum shipments to Japan is under study by export control authorities, it was learned in informed quarters today, despite Japanese overtures designed to achieve a peaceful solution of the critical situation in the Far East.

One of the cardinal principles involved in the passage of the Public Holding Company Act wag the effective regulation of financial practices and transactions of utility holding companies and their controlled subsidiaries. In passing the law, Congress vested specifically in the Securities and Exchange Commission powers of jurisdiction over holding-company systems in an effort to end activities which were rampant in the halcyon Twenties.

ON a dark Winter morning early in 1861 the sleepy folk of a Southern town were roused in terror by the noise of drum-taps; they were wide awake before they realized that this was not revolution but reveille. YORK HARBOR, Me., Aug. 30 -- Charles Hallam Keep, retired New York banker who served as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under President Theodore Roosevelt from 1903 to 1907, died today at his Summer home here. His age was 80.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- Teheran's 500,000 population drowsed through the Moslem Sabbath today, oblivious of the next steps of the British-Russion occupation of their country.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- A German spokesman said today that the Axis post-war program framed by Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini at their Eastern Front meeting called for the elimination of British and United States influence from the European Continent.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A collision between two horses, in which both drivers were thrown but escaped uninjured, marked the closing day of the Grand Circuit meeting at the New York State Fair today, and provided an unscheduled rodeo touch.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Sweeping Irresistibly onward, the Yankees today shelled Bucky Harris's Senators into submission, 8 to 1, and in the process eliminated what you might call one more "mythical contender" in the American League pennant race.

NORMAN BEL GEDDES, who hasn't been active in production for the Broadway theatre since "Siege," in 1937, was saying the other day that he expects this season to offer two works. DEER ISLE, Me. -- Deer Isle is "peeved" and considers it has good reason for being so. SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Much entertaining marked the closing of the 1941 racing season here today. Luncheon parties crowded the clubhouse terrace restaurant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- With the demand for trucks increasing because of defense requirements, the Office of Production Management set a high priorities rating today so that makers would be able to obtain supplies of steel, copper and other materials in order to turn out some 1,189,000 trucks in the model year ending July 31.

Manufacturers had difficulty filling orders in the wholesale market last week as the result of shortages in a great number of lines, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

RADIO'S part in war and defense will be demonstrated on Wednesday when, the National Broadcasting Company presents an hour-long program marking the second anniversary of World War II, Significantly titled "Two Years of War," the broadcast is scheduled to begin at 10 P.M. over WJZ, with a short talk by Niles Trammell, NBC president, outlining the industry's role in national defense.

LONDON. LONDON playgoers last week had the unusual experience of watching a magazine story come true. Firth Shepherd put on a new big-scale revue, "Fun and Games," at the Princess. It had four stars -- that notable band of comedians: Arthur Riscom, Sydney Howard, Richard Hearne and Vera Pearce -- who had built up a success in a previous show at this theatre, "Shepherd's Pie."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Aug. 23 were 248,910,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, this representing a decrease of 2,103,000 barrels, reflecting contractions of 1,354,000 and 749,000 barrels, respectively, in domestic and foreign oil on hand.

BALBOA, C.Z., Aug. 30 -- Three Panama Canal tugs completed the tow of the 23,000-ton Italian liner Conte Biancamano from Cristobal to Balboa today. HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 30 -- Packed aboard the small Spanish freighter Navemar with normal accommodations for fifteen passengers, about 1,200 European refugees are vicariously sampling the New World freedom from the crowded deck of the vessel alongside the Hamilton docks.

RIGHT off, we want you to know that this is not going to be the usual Sunday artide. But it is going to be a plain and (we trust) informative discussion of a matter on which every theatregoer should be brought up to date.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 31 -- The German industrial districts of Frankfort-on-the-Main and Mannheim were bombed over Friday night by many Royal Air Force planes, and during daylight yesterday an R.A.F. fighter squadron, using cannon and machine guns, set two German ships afire off the French coast, the Air Ministry reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The "all-out" defense production program to which the United States has set itself has reached the point where it soon will mean far-reaching and easily recognizable dislocation to civil life in this country, and the Washington Administration, acutely aware of the present apathetic state of public opinion toward the war, is very apprehensive as to what may follow in the next few weeks.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Following is an official transcript of President Roosevelt's informal remarks today to members of the Roosevelt Home Club:

PREDICTIONS that all of the nation's flying space in control of the Civil Aeronautics Authority will shortly be intricately "zoned" both horizontally and vertically have been prompted by recent promulgation of the new "3,500 foot ceiling rule."

The word "priority" has been often spoken since the rearmament drive got under way. The reason has been the government's policy of placing "first things first" to make certain that de- fense requirements are filled before all others. The meaning of priorities was brought home to American industry last February when the government decreed that defense demands for aluminum be filled before civilian needs.

To help teachers master the latest techniques and theories of modern education, the Board of Superintendents is offering the record number of 300 free courses this Fall for the 38,000 members of the New York City school staff, Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent in charge of personnel, announces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A radioactive spark plug for auto engines, which is said to reduce gasoline consumption, give quicker starting, smoother operation and more power, is offered in a patent (No. 2,254,169) granted to John H. Dillon of Akron, Ohio.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- With little respect for Johnny Humphries, the Browns knocked him out of the box today and decisively walloped the second-place White Sox, 10 to 1. Humphries made it thirty-five scoreless innings in a row by blanking St. Louis in its first time at bat, but Chet Laabs broke his string with, a home run in the second inning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30 -- One of the largest gatherings of weekend visitors to have come here this season is now at the resort and many luncheons, cocktail parties, dinners and dances are the order for the holiday period.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 30 -- On the shores of Switzerland's beautiful lake of Lucerne, the Fourth International Music Week was held this week in Lucerne's new art museum, despite war and the fact that there are only a few foreign visitors.

BY way of London comes word from India that Idar, the principal Rajput state of the Mahi Kantha Agency In Bombay, has entered the philatelic family of governments. The first stamp, a half-anna green, presents a portrait of the Maharajah, Dhiraj Shree Himmat Singhji.

THE coins of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg during the twentieth century have ranged from nickel and bronze during the reign of Adolphe and William IV to zinc and iron during the reign of Marie Adelaide, and silver, nickel, bronze and iron during the reign of Grand Duchess Charlotte.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 30 -- In a renewed government effort to set up a system of free medical care, Health Minister Arthur H. Nordmeyer conferred today with representatives of the National Medical Association and sought the physicians cooperation in the administering of a new State plan.

Gilbert F. Coyle, assistant freight traffic manager of the Grace Line, has been made freight traffic manger, succeeding James E. Magner, who was recently named vice presdent in charge of passenger affairs, it was announced yesterday by R.R. Adams, executive vice president of the line.
BERLIN, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

THE Germans, like every one else, share our common humanity and have minds remarkably similar to those of people in the United States. Yet there is such a thing as a slight difference in inherited traits which sets one race apart from another. That is to say, a tiny German baby brought up in a foreign country would probably still have certain characteristics which would show his particular heritage.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Climbing steadily for the third successive year, enrollment in introductory sociology courses will reach 231 this Fall at New Jersey College for Women as contrasted with 171 a year ago and 147 two years ago, according to Dr. Francis W. Hopkins, head of the Department of Economics and Sociology.

Price increases on store supplies ranging from 10 to 35 per cent or more over a year ago represent an important phase of the rising expense problem now facing retailers. These higher costs tie in directly with a widespread trend in many communities toward retailer adoption of the plan of making a charge for costly gift wrappings.

A dinner for the Americas, the first large benefit of the Autumn season here for Bundles for Britain, Inc., will be held on the evening of Oct. 2 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Robert Livingston Clarkson, is being given in recognition of the work now going on in many Pan American countries on behalf of the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Roosevelt declared in a Labor Day message tonight that management and labor "realize now, and I am sure will continue to realize, that there must be full and uninterrupted production of the weapons and materials needed for our protection and needed also by the nations engaged in opposing those who would do away with the liberty and happiness of free peoples all over the world."
Chairman, Committee on Inter-American Relations of the NEA Department of Secondary Teachers

HOLLYWOOD. "LOUISIANA PURCHASE," at which Washington politicians laughed as heartily as any one during its long Broadway run, has escaped by a hair's breadth threatened censorship and will appear on the screen in substantially the same form as it did on the stage.

DETROIT -- What will the government's curtailment program for automobile production mean to factories, dealers, labor, motorists and the public at large? First apparent is that the policy of gradual reductions will permit an adjustment period during which most of those persons affected will have time to prepare for the worst.

WHEN Marjorie Lawrence, Metropolitan Opera soprano, set off for Mexico in June there was no hint of any trouble. Less than three months before she had been married to Thomas M. King and her career was definitely in the ascendant.

A definite curtailment of the forward buying policies of both the military services and private industry will be necessary to avoid completely chaotic situation in vital defense materials in coming months and a severe curtailment in the production of consumer durable goods, according to opinions expressed by business executives and purchasing agents last week.

To the Music Editor: IT was extremely gratifying to read Francis Marquis's letter of the 20th on Prokofieff's score for "Aleksandr Nevsky." The scores for motion pictures are too seldom accorded due attention. This is strange when such prominent composers as Milhaud, Korn-gold, Honegger, Prokofieff, Hagemann, Gruenberg and many others are engaged to write music by film companies.

With daffodils taking the leae among Spring flowering bulbs for American gardens -- owing to the comparative scarcity of tulips -- the home gardener this year will pay more attention than ever before to using them in such a way as to get the maximum garden effect.

The tournament without a standout for the national tennis championship got under way at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday and, appropriately enough, there was a marked tendency among the lesser lights to look the elect in the eye rather than to submit quiescently in the customary opening-day processional.

Although the Importation of lily bulbs has fallen off, almost to the vanishing point, American production is increasing rapidly, and fortunately no extended shortage of the bulbs is in prospect. Nevertheless, they are not plentiful enough to be wasted, and any garidener planting them, this Fall should give them every chance to grow successfully.

The appointment of Barrett H. Clark, author and drama critic, as a lecturer in English at Queens College was announced yesterday at the Board of Higher Education. Mr. Clark will teach play-writing during the Fall semester, filling a vacancy created by the unexpected resignation of Assistant Professor Harold Whitehall to become associate professor at the University of Indiana.

THREE months in Great Britain in 1940 and 1941 cover the whole of Mr. Pyle's war background for this book, but he made gratrfyingly good use of his time and skill as an observer. And the manner in which he sets down his findings, observations and emotional reactions is as effective as it is unassuming.

WESTBURY, L.L. Aug. 30 -- Stewart Iglehart's Westbury polo team almost lost the services of a valuable man today when Mike White came down from his pony half-way through the third period of a test match on Whitney Field with a mallet cut over his left eye that required stitching.

William Kenny, 41 -- year-old laborer, of 432 East Thirty-fourth Street, who, according to an agent of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, makes a business of catching pigeons and selling them to Chinese for 25 cents each, pleaded guilty to a charge of cruelty to animals yesterday in week-end court before Magistrate Raphael P. Koenig.

The bond readjustment plan of the Alleghany Corporation has been completed, according to Robert R. Young, chairman. Assent to the plan, he said yesterday, had been received from 6,357 holders of the company's $47,581,000 par value of bonds outstanding.

To the Radio Editor: IT is important that participants in "forum" discussions over the radio should realize that "freedom of speech" is a precious privilege that is at the same time a not-to-be-slighted responsibility.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (U.P) -- Detailed accounts of Odessa's heroic resistance published today by Red Star, the army newspaper, and Izvestia, said the Russians were entrenched firmly and well-supplied with provisions and arms. Women and children were said to be under evacuation, protected by the Red Banner Black Sea Fleet.

THE Hungarian short - wave station at Budapest is clearer now that Summer is waning, and odd bits of news from the NaziBalkan front flash westward into American evening skies. Early last week Budapest was broadcasting English news at 8:50, and at 9 o'clock special English Hungarian war sidelights were spilling from waves of "Radio Budapest."

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Aug. 30 -- Enlargement of the music faculty of the University of Virginia makes possible the offering of a revised program of courses in musical theory and composition and in the history and literature of music for the session which begins Sept. 18.
Deaths and injuries in automobile accidents mounted steadily yesterday as unusually heavy Labor Day week-end traffic jammed the highways in and out of the metropolitan area.

Alvar M. Tondo, formerly of the French Line, has joined the staff of the Chilean Line in New York and has been named passenger traffic manager, it was announced yesterday by Agustin Huneeus, general representative in the United States.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30 -- Any man who'll sit on a jagged rock at night peering into the gloom through a telescope in the hope of seeing a ghostly sail slide by is a hero. If, moreover, he'll do it without compensation or hope of glory, he's a rara avis indeed.

LONDON. MILLIONS of books have been burned by German firebombs, but a phoenix has arisen from the ashes. That is the cheerful conclusion of Walter G. Harrap, the president of the Publishers Association, as he surveys the announcements of new books to appear in the Fall.

IN England we are learning, in some bitterness of spirit, to call the years from 1919 to 1939 the Armistice period in international relations. This leads us naturally to conduct investigations in various other spheres of human activity, as to the achievement, history and characteristics of the activity in question during these last two decades.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Aug. 20 you printed a statement on birth control by the Rev. Hubert Seller, spiritual director of the St. Gerard Maternity Guild of the New York local branch of the National Catholic Women's Union.

LONDON -- "Thank God you are safely here!" said Premier Churchill recently speaking in Downing Street to three American Red Cross nurses who had been picked up in the Atlantic after being torpedoed on the crossing. In spite of the torpedoes, forty or more of the fifty-five who were selected from those who volunteered for the service have arrived and are on the job.

RESIGNED: Robert Gordon Menzies, who was the youngest man to serve as Australia's Prime Minister when he took office in 1939, resigned last week and was succeeded by Treasurer Arthur W. Fadden. On May 24 Mr. Menzies returned home after a four months' absence during which he represented Australia in London.
Editor The New York Times Book Review: ON page 280 of Louis Fischer's book "Men and Politics." (Duell, Sloan Pearce, New York, 1941), I found the following statement:

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. ONLY in the heroic past of our country, only on the Red Man's side of the old frontier, one would say, could there be hundreds of square miles of centuries-old virgin forest, a wilderness almost uninhabited. Only in the dreams of Daniel Boone in his grave could elk be so free, so familiar that they passed you by in innocent confidence, in unhurried dignity.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Paul Erickson, 23-year-old rookie recently graduated to starting assignments, pitched six-hit ball today as the Cubs defeated the Pirates. 4 to 1, in the series opener.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Anti-aircraft guns threw up a heavy barrage today when two Iranian planes and a Russian bomber appeared over the city, and the drum, of falling shrapnel led to the belief that bombs had been dropped.

ONE of the most comprehensive invitation photographic exhibitions ever assembled will be opened for the benefit of British War Relief at the society's headquarters, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Wednesday. The exhibition is sponsored by the Manhattan Camera Club, in cooperation with British War Relief.

Threshold of Pain With India ink the doctor painted a black spot on the department's reportorial brow. Then he asked us to sit behind a screen and press the blackened area against an opening in the frame. A 1,000-watt electric bulb went on.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Clare Boothe's first screen story, "Six From Coventry" has been purchased by Paramount at a reported price of $25,000. An option on a second story by Miss Boothe, "Wedding Day," was acquired as part of the deal.

Investors have acquired a property in Harlem where they purchased from the McKee estate the row of three five-story tenement houses on a plot 74 by 74 feet at 255, 257 and 259 East 125th Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- American, labor will start tomorrow's holiday with official congratulations on its past year's record in national defense and with appeals from its own leaders to make new efforts on behalf of the United States and its own cause.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The Anglo-Russian entry into Iran was the dominating influence last week in the stock markets here.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- Germany's war communique today came from "the Fuehrer's headquarters," indicating that Reichsfuehrer Hitler was spending the second anniversary of the Reich's last day of peace at an Eastern Front encampment surrounded by barbed wire and camouflaged so as to be completely invisible from the air.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- After two years of war the center of power, both economic and military, of the forces opposing the Axis has shifted to the United States, according to experts who reviewed the war's course and consequences today on the University of Chicago's round-table broadcast.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

A "deal" between Mayor La Guardia and Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, to bring about a 10-cent fare on the city transit system with presumably further pay increases for the transit workers, was charged yesterday by John R. Davies, who is opposing Mr. La Guardia for the Mayoralty nomination.

MARSEILLE, France, Aug. 31 -- Varian M. Fry, an American resident of Marseille, was taken yesterday to Cerbere at the Spanish frontier after having been notified that the French Government had ordered his expulsion from the country.

Simon Schuster is planning a special edition of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" that will contain a number of unusual editorial and typographical features, including "parallel maps" and book markers illuminating the historical background.

Trustees of the estate of Edwin H. Raynolds, who planned to demolish the residence of the late paint manufacturer at Alien and Norwood Avenues, Allenhurst, N.J., have sold it to James J. Kelly of Elizabeth, through the Walter Reid Agency, broker.

Labor Day has often been been marked by subsequent quickening of activity from the dull Summer markets. Last year, despite the discouraging war uncertainties, stock market averages, after a brief decline, rose steadily from 93:43 early in September to 100.19 at the beginning of October.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 -- A mass demonstration of Mexican labor today represented qualified support of the Manuel Avila Camacho government, but slogans and placards denounced both the President's brother -- who seeks a Cabinet post with Conservative backing -- and Jorge Cerdan, Governor of the State of Veracruz.

Winning his second title in two days, Mike Priano, Flatbush Boys Club sensation, highlighted the opening session of the senior men's metropolitan A.A.U. swimming championships at Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn yesterday by defeating seven rivals in the 800-meter free-style race.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Political considerations continue to dominate the action of the wheat market here, but inflation talk also is reported to be exerting" a strong influence in the shaping of Pitsentiment. The President's veto of the bill to "freeze" government-owned stocks of wheat drew but little attention in the trade and following a minor break, the market soared to new high prices for the season and went into new ground since 1937.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Sept. 1 -- Late Russian reports tell of German efforts to push across the Dnieper River at two points, at one of which the Germans lost 1,500 men and seventeen tanks. One of the efforts was said to have been made in the neighborhood of Tulianova, south of Dniepropetrovsk.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- The discovery of so-called espionage material in the American Consulate in Zagreb is exploited today by the Italian press for propaganda purposes in order to prove what it termed "American intrigues" against the Axis.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A campaign to make the British public realize that "The Yanks Are Not Coming" marked the front pages of newspapers here today.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 31 -- Growing concentrations of Italian forces on islands close to the Turkish coast and in Greek Macedonia and Thrace near the Turkish frontier were reported here today.

CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 31 -- The only alternative to Hitler's new order based on conquest is the establishment of some sort of a federal union of free people to give political implementation to the principles embodied in the Roosevelt-Churchill declaration, Dr. Irving Fisher, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy of Yale University, declared here today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Iranian Government announced today the expectation that British-Russian military operations would stop and "the cause for the people's anxiety will soon be removed" as a result of talks with Allied representatives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- By way of cheering their bed-ridden leader, Joe McCarthy, whom they had to leave behind in a hospital, the Yankees gave the Senators a final thrashing today, 5 to 2, and then went roaring up the Atlantic seaboard like a tropical twister to demolish what's left of the American League.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Pirates came from behind today to defeat the Cubs, 4 to 3, for an even break in the two-game series. Elbie Fletcher drove in two runs with his tenth home run and tripled in the eighth to pave the way for the winning tally.

THE man behind the mutuel machines at most of the big tracks in the East is Mort Mahony, a thin, medium-sized, silver-haired gent of quiet demeanor. He supervises the great gadget and all its works. He hires the workers. He handles all the money. He has to be complete boss or he will not stay around the place.

New securities offered to the public here in August declined sharply from recent preceding months, with stock flotations the smallest since January and bond emissions the smallest since May, 1940. The total of both classes of securities was the smallest for any August since 1937.

With twelve named for the $12,000 Aqueduct Handicap and sixteen for the $7,000 Woodmere Claiming Stakes, the fifteen-day Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will get under way at Aqueduct today, marking the return of the thoroughbreds to the metropolitan area.

Vehemently denouncing as "false and shameful" charges that the motion picture industry is engaged in war-mongering, Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., made public yesterday a letter he sent to Senator D. Worth Clark, Democrat of Idaho, chairman of a Senate subcommittee appointed at the behest of isolationists to investigate alleged "war propaganda" in motion pictures.

A strong undertone was sustained in the cotton futures market last week and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange reflected net gains of 61 to 75 points for the period at the close on Saturday. In the previous week, prices had registered advances of 27 to 35 points.
