EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Lieutenant Edward Coe Embury, U.S.A., and Mrs. Embury are here spending a few days with Lieutenant Embury's father, Aymar Embury 2d and Mrs. Embury, at Third House. Lieutenant Embury just has returned from two years in Santo Domingo and is now stationed in Washington, D.C. Mr. and Mrs. Embury gave a dinner for them at the Maidstone Club.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Mainly through the device of passing Ted Williams intentionally three times, Phil Marchildon tossed a three-hitter at the Red Sox today to gain a 3-2 decision and an even break for the Athletics after Boston had taken a 5-3 decision in the first half of a twin bill.

Dividends declared in August amounted to $384,970,340 for 978 corporations, including $4,378,275 for fifty-three banks and insurance companies. It was the largest amount for any August since 1937, when $389,022,270 was voted by 880 concerns, of which $4,243,769 was for forty-one banks and insurance institutions.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, farmhands of the Yankees, assured themselves of no worse than a tie for the International League pennant today by walloping the Baltimore Orioles twice, 7 to 6 and 15 to 2.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Aug. 19 at 106.4, compared with 105.8 a fortnight before, 105.4 a month before, 97.1 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The whole of the Spanish Mole at Tripoli was left aflame after a heavy British raid Friday night in which twenty-five tons of bombs were dropped, the R.A.F. announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- On the basis of new steel-ingot capacity figures as issued by the American Iron and Steel Institute, raw steel output last week held at 97 percent, as good as unchanged from a revised rate of 97 per cent in the preceding week.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- The closing of the Manchukuoan-North China border to foreigners is concealing tremendous Japanese movements in Manchukuo. Shanghai diplomatic quarters believe that the Japanese and Russians are engaged in a diplomatic struggle that approaches in intensity the Japanese-United States "war of nerves."

Dr. Samuel Trexler, head of the United Lutheran Synod of New York and president of the Board of Foreign Missions of his church, returned yesterday from an extended inspection of Lutheran establishments in South America. As a result, he will recommend increased missionary activities there.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- Noel C. Scaffa, former New York private detective, noted for his sensational recoveries of stolen gems, died shortly before noon today in Hahnemann Hospital, a few hours after he had been stricken with a heart attack.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 31 -- A record fleet of 121 boats sailed today in the Bellport Bay Yacht Club race series that started yesterday. The course was a leeward and windward one. An ebb tide accompanied a brisk southwester.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- As the Battle of Russia entered its eleventh week, the government newspaper Izvestia predicted today the "complete collapse" of the original plans of Reichsfuehrer Hitler, who sent his armies into Poland two years ago tomorrow to touch off the second great war in a generation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Criticizing President Roosevelt's veto of legislation to freeze government stocks of cotton and wheat, Chairman Smith of the Senate Agriculture Committee said today that he would attempt to attach the measure to any price-fixing legislation coming before the Senate.

VICHY, France, Aug. 31 -- Several decisions affecting the economic welfare of the State were taken last week by the Council of Ministers. Among the resultant official announcements was one that the professional organization committees set up by the government have experienced extreme difficulties and, further, have not always satisfactorily performed their task.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 31 -- Despite undoubted reverses -- and serious ones -- Russian resistance continues stubborn. This is the main point underlined by competent neutral observers here as the war on the Eastern Front enters its eleventh week.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31 -- Members of the Summer colony were present at the Casino Theatre tonight for the dance recital given by Miss Theodora Roosevelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald B. Roosevelt of Cold Springs Harbor, L.I. Miss Roosevelt performed with her instructor, Alexander Tolas.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- As the war that began with Germany's demands for the restoration of Danzig to the Reich and the abolition of the Polish Corridor swings into the third year, German hopes of a victorious conclusion for the Axis Powers were asserted here today in confident accents.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- The American people now have offered to them an unprecedented opportunity for world leadership, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, declared tonight in his annual lecture at the Parrish Memorial Art Museum here.
NEW YORK Sir George and Lady Bettes-worth-Piggott, who are at the Plaza, will leave today for Atlantic City.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Passage by Friday or Saturday of the Senate's $3,672,400,000 tax bill was predicted tonight by leaders.

The narrow escape of Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, top-ranking player in women's singles, and a two-hour struggle between John Kramer of Montebello, Calif., and William Talbert of Cincinnati were the exciting episodes of the second day of competition in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday.

Boxing terminology was used by the Rev. E. Walter Helsel in his sermon yesterday to depict the psychological results of the consciousness of guilt. Mr. Helsel preached at the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street, of which he is assistant pastor, on the topic, "When Life Gets You Down."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Archaeologists of the Trailside Museum finished six weeks of intensive digging at an Indian shelter here today and revealed that they had found evidence of three civilizations going back 1,500 years.

SIMLA, India, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- Unofficial but reliable reports circulated at Britisn General Headquarters today that Anglo-Soviet terms for an Iranian armistice would include a demand that Iran facilitate the transit of war supplies to Russia.

PANAMA, Aug. 31 -- An exodus of Japanese from Panama appears to be under way following Tokyo's suspension of commercial relations with this country after the temporary closing of the canal several weeks ago.

Units of the Army's mechanized fighting equipment will be assembled at Fort Jay, Governors Island, Thursday and Friday for a military exhibition in conjunction with Army Relief Day on Saturday, the Army Information Service announced yesterday.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 31 -- Champion Pillicoc Reverie, homebred black standard poodle bitch from the Pillicoc Kennels of Mrs. Milton Erlanger, won her seventh best-in-show prize in the Great Barrington Kennel Club fixture today.

Columns by astrologers who profess to see some order in this topsy-turvy world are an important feature of almost every popular Sunday newspaper published in London. According to The New Statesman and Nation, the London weekly, two-thirds of the adult population of the British Isles read these predictions, and "about four out of ten" have some interest or belief, however slight, in the astral forecasts of the journalistic seers.

"Pal Joey" resumes its Broadway engagement this afternoon at the Shubert Theatre after a vacation of two weeks. Gene Kelly, Vivienne Segal and Anne Blair head the company. The John O'Hara-Richard Rodgers-Lorenz Hart musical, which closed at the Barrymore after 270 performances, is being offered at reduced prices for a limited run.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- Marshal Semyon Budenny, Russian commander on the Ukrainian Front, appealed today to the German, Rumanian, Hungarian and Slovak Armies to revolt against Hitlerism and join the Red forces in the "fight to the final destruction of the Fascist rulers, enemies of humanity."
SIMLA, India, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A British communique said today:

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 31 -- Ben Hogan, Hershey Country Club professional, uncorked a last-round 70 today to win the $5,000 Hershey open golf championship with 275, five shots under the tournament record established in 1937 by Henry Picard.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 25 -- For years the Government of Brazil was losing approximately $20,000,000 annually on the sale of its chief commodity, coffee. Then one day there walked into the President's office a young man from New York who said:

The days of dictators are numbered and "the whole philosophy of totalitarianism is doomed" in the face of cosmic forces at work, declared the Rev. Dr. Charles Henry Campbell of the First Reformed Church, Flushing, in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Congregational Church of Flushing, Bovme Street and Thirty-eighth Avenue, Queens.

The declarations made by arrivals from abroad have decreased 70 per cent in value since 1939 when the European war began, according to officials who have been examining baggage on the steamship piers in New York for many years.

Convinced that the Dodgers had reached the crossroads and that drastic measures were necessary if the Flatbush Fusileers were to be kept in the National League pennant hunt, Leo Durocher took himself off the coaching lines yesterday for the first time in a month and subjected his line-up to a violent shake-up.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 31 -- The faster that aircraft fly the sooner some new and stronger material must be found to take the place of the present aluminum alloy which is used in construction of all-metal planes, in the opinion of Dr. John E. Younger, aeronautical engineer and winner this year of aviation's coveted award, the Spirit of St. Louis gold medal.
MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Russian forces have broken up repeated German efforts to force a crossing of the Dnieper River, it was reported today.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- South Carolina's Democratic voters will nominate Tuesday a candidate for the Senate to fill the unexpired term of James F. Brynes, recently appointed an associate justice of the Supreme Court.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Art Gallagher of Philadelphia's Penn A.C. carried off major individual honors in the fiftieth Middle States regatta on the Cooper River course today with a two and one-half-length victory over Joe Angyal, New York City fireman, in the championship one-mile event.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 1 -- Soviet fighter-plane squadrons destroyed 125 German aircraft on Friday, while losing only twenty-four machines, it was announced in today's communique, which also said that fighting had continued along the entire front.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Bayard S. Litchfield's Victory Class sloop Flapper was established as the winner in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's twenty-second annual Stratford Shoal race today.

Labor Day has the gay, festive mood that goes with picnics and parties. But out on Long Island -- playground for work-worn city dwellers -- there is one group of men who fail today to fit into the carefree scene. These are the toilers who belong to the oyster industry, and for them Sept. 1, 1941, is not a holiday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The lard market fluctuated erratically last week, with no trading on Friday, as the result of an obscure order issued by the Civilian Supply Division of the Office of Production Management. The order aimed at suppressing unauthorized operations in cash fats and oils, but was so worded as to indicate that trading in futures on organized Exchanges also was prohibited.
New York City played host yesterday to a record crowd of out-of-towners who flocked into the metropolis to celebrate the annual Labor Day vacation, the last long Summer week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A program for the education of perhaps a million aliens in the privileges and obligations of American citizenship will be worked out in a two-day conference of educators and government officials here this week.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 1 -- Japan today observed the double anniversary of the outbreak of the European war and the great earthquake of 1923, which cost 100,000 lives, by attempting to draw lessons from these catastrophes for the future.
Three British leaders, in messages yesterday and last night to workmen in the United States, sounded Labor Day keynotes of support for democracy and of additional effort for defense.

Nation on Wheels We look at the vast expanse of the Russian front and wonder how the rival commanders ever get their millions of men from place to place. Yet here in the peaceful United States we move even greater numbers and think nothing of it. No population in the world is so mobile as ours.

WEEK ENDED AUG. 30, 1941 Interest in the foreign exchange market last week centered in the sharp grains registered by the Canadian dollar and Shanghai yuan, and a firm undertone in the free pound sterling.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Syracuse downed Jersey City, 3 -- 1, today in the opening game of a double-header. The second game was called because of darkness after nine innings with the teams deadlocked at 3 -- 3.

The Rev. Thomas J. Bigham. Jr., of the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, who was guest preacher yesterday at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, opposed legislation to prohibit strikes in defense industries.

As if enough profoundly discouraging actions had not been taken in Congress in the last year, a Senate committee, headed by Senator Downey of California, has chosen this time to plump for minimum pensions of $30 a month to all persons over 60 who are not gainfully employed, whether or not they have previously been employed and made contributions to a pension fund and whether or not they are actually in need.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 1 -- Royal Air Force fighter and bomber pilots put in one of their busiest days of the war yesterday. From dawn until after dark they made almost ceaseless raids over hostile territory on the other side of the Channel.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- President Roosevelt today accepted the resignation of George Stewart Brown of New York as Judge of the Customs Court in a letter which contained a tribute to the judge's many years of "devoted service" on the bench.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 31 -- At Four Brooks Farm, Tyringham, Dr. and Mrs. Walter W. Palmer gave a dance last night for their debutante daughter, Miss Hylie F.G. Palmer. Earlier Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Mason DuBois entertained with a dinner for Miss Palmer at Riverside.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is a disgrace to the nation that the fomenting and continuation of strikes is tolerated. Whether in the matter of the defense program or pertaining to other industries, the C.I.O. and A.F. of L. continue to carry on in a manner offensive to the American tradition of fair play.

ABOARD U.S.A. NORTH CAROLINA AT SEA -- The addition of the North Carolina, which has just finished her structural firing tests, and her sister ship the Washington to the United States Fleet gives this nation more battleships in commission than any other power.

The gravity of the international situation, the necessity for furnishing all-out aid to the opponents of Hitlerism and the urgent need of achieving national unity to preserve democracy and establish a better economic order at home were stressed by religious, labor and educational leaders in Labor Day messages made public yesterday.

The Federal government's labor policies in the present national emergency are "little short of chaotic," Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared yesterday in calling on American business men to oppose government policies or recommendations that "would enslave labor and amount to an abdication of the functions and duties of private management."

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Trading in corn last week was somewhat larger than it had been, but a part of the business represented liquidation in September position by scattered longs, while cash interests bought the September and sold the deferred months.

From the Russian viewpoint both Viborg and Tallinn were "insurance" cities, occupied as outposts in the defense of Leningrad. Each stands on the Gulf of Finland, Viborg at the northern approaches to Czar Peter's capital, and Tallinn flanking the water lanes which lead from the southwest to the great Soviet naval base at Kronstadt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The War Department announced today that, where practicable, it will release reserve officers who have completed a year of extended active duty and who do not desire to continue in active service.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, asserted tonight that the nation's task was "to see that the discordant elements forget their short-sighted views of their own rights and privileges and take the long view of what is necessary for the national welfare."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Until radio announcers and commentators stop saying haRASS and laMEN-table and ba-seez which is the plural of basis, not of base, I suppose we'll all have to suffer.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- President Roosevelt worked today upon his Labor Day speech which will be broadcast tomorrow upon the second anniversary of the start of the war. This is expected to include an appeal for all Americans to make sacrifices to meet the threat to the security of the United States growing out of Nazi Germany's campaign of conquest.

Those who find it difficult to restrain their impatience to get out with a gun will be rising early this morning to shoot rails on the flooding tide in several areas of New Jersey and Connecticut, for the season on rails and gallinules opens today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A communique of the Middle East R.A.F. command, said today:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At last high authority, in the person of the President himself, has taken note again of the fact that we are killing more than forty thousand persons, injuring more than one and a half million, incurring a monetary loss of more than two billion each year through automobile accidents.
POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Aug. 31 -- All Pompton Lakes was buzzing with gossip today about how the chief of police raided the volunteer firemen's carnival last night and took away the wheels of chance.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 31 -- A dozen resolutions endorsing aid to the democracies in their war against fascism will be offered at the international convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O. which opens here tomorrow morning.

There is no sense in expecting God to give mankind "peace, happiness and ease on a gold platter, with no effort on our part," said the Rev. George Yetter Flint, the assistant pastor, in his sermon yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

The Rivoli Theatre will open today for the new season with the local premiere of "Unfinished Business," co-starring Irene Dunne and Robert Montgomery. The film is a comedy, produced by Gregory La Cava for Universal release, and numbers among its supporting players Preston Foster, Eugene Pallette, Walter Catlett and Samuel S. Hinds.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 -- The Cardinals turned back a ninthinning bid by the Reds today to win their fifth straight, 6 to 3, and keep the National League lead by 2 percentage points.

STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 -- The Dodgers romped to a 34-0 victory over Albie Booth's Stratford Rams in an exhibition football game before 4,000 at Longbrook Park today. The weather was so warm that Brooklyn used more than three teams.

BASRA, Iraq, Aug. 27 (Delayed) -- British, Indian and Australian motorized infantry and naval units, sweeping across the Shatt-al-Arab River and from the scorching Persian Gulf, and then in a forced march across Iranian wastes upon Muhammereh, have seized Iran's most vital southern points and oil bases, including the great Abadan refinery.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Scattered showers and locally heavy rains accompanied by cool weather have brought about improvement in the outlook for the new corn crop in some sections of the main producing areas, but there was a large area that failed to receive sufficient moisture to be of any material benefit and further deterioration is claimed. The corn crop this year is unusually spotted, according to official returns.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Ten pitchers paraded to the mound today as Cleveland and Detroit split a double bill, the Tigers winning the opener, 7 to 5, and the Indians the nightcap, 7 to 4.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- A ship's commander can hardly be expected to take effective shooting action at something he cannot see except in case of a submerged submarine, where he relies upon asdic, his underwater eye. [Asdic is the name of an instrument that can detect submarines under water at a considerable distance.]

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 1 -- Russian-initiated peace negotiations with Finland, in which John G. Winant, United States Ambassador to London, is the central figure, were reported under way today by the Stockholm correspondent of The Daily Mail.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Fire Island, that isolated Eden just off the Long Island shore, which for years has boasted proudly that "there are no automobiles" within its highway-less domain, was awfully embarrassed today when the news leaked out that the State troopers had been asked to investigate an auto theft.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- German officials acknowledged tonight that the Russians had made heavy counter-assaults, involving "new armies," in the central sector west of Moscow and along the Dnieper River in the Ukraine, but insisted that each Soviet attack had been crushed.
Several leases of apartments in buildings on Park Avenue were announced over the week-end by renting agents.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A double victory over the White Sox today, by 12 to 8 and 5 to 4, gave the peppy Browns a sweep of their four-game series and sole possession of sixth place. The result dropped Chicago, which came here in second place, to third behind Boston.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- In the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, held out on Long Island Sound today as a forerunner of its Labor Day event tomorrow, there were eighty-eight starters, despite squall threats all around that did not make up to the bursting point.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- While last week's military events contributed to the remarkable strength in the bond market here the general monetary situation has been the predominant influence for most of this year.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- Richard G. Casey, the Australian Minister, asserted today that his homeland chose war two years ago because it was convinced Germany was bent on world domination, and hinted that the United States faced a similar decision.

Describing religion as "a powerful practical tool" that "must be taken into account by all politicians and public men," the Rev. Thomas Kirkland Thompson of Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, at McDonough Street, Brooklyn, in his sermon yesterday morning urged the avoidance of "this-worldly religion" and "other-worldly religion."

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- Several factors concurred in depressing the tone of the Boerse in the earlier part of last week. The principal one was an increase of 25 per cent in the rate of corporate income tax. Furthermore the ending of the Netherlands tax on the sale of Netherlands-owned German stocks to the Reich, which becomes effective on Sept. 1, was expected to result in large offerings of German shares for Netherlands accounts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Eleven producers and distributors of tracing cloths, blueprint papers and various other supplies and equipment used by the engineering, drafting and building professions were ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to "cease and desist" from an alleged combination and conspiracy to fix and maintain prices for their products.

American defense needs and "business as usual" came to a parting of the ways last night as steel priorities and new credit restrictions, intended to slow the demand for non-defense durable goods whose manufacture must be curtailed, went into effect.

VICHY, France, Aug. 31 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today broadcast his decision to extend the membership in the French Legion from the Veterans of Two Wars to include in addition all those ready to volunteer their services for the National Revolution.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 -- Reports of boll weevil infestation accounted for late gains of about $2 a bale in cotton futures here last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Braves and the Phillies split a double-header today, Boston winning the first game, 8 to 3, and Philadelphia taking the second, 8 to 5. Both clubs owed their victories to five-run fifth-inning uprisings.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill gave a dinner, with dancing, tonight at The Orchard, their place in Hill Street. Many additional guests came in later from dinner parties throughout the colony for supper and dancing

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 97.0 to another new peak of 97.7. The sharp gain of 1.3 per cent in the raw materials index reflected the price rises in coal, cotton, eggs, grains, livestock and potatoes.

A juvenile edition of the forthcoming Mardi Gras will be held Sept. 3 when P.A.L. Day is celebrated at Coney Island, it was announced yesterday. Closing the Summer recreation program of the Police Athletic League, 3,500 Pals will march at noon in the parade along Surf Avenue, that will include the Police Department Band, sixteen P.A.L. fife, drum and bugle corps and many floats.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The meeting of the Interallied Council, originally planned for last week, was postponed at the last minute to an unspecified date in the first half of September. The reason for the postponement appears to be purely technical, although the delay allows better preparation for the meetings background.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Two distinguished naval careers ended today with the retirement of Rear Admiral Joseph K. Taussig, a hero of the Peking Relief Expedition, and Rear Admiral Hayne Ellis, former commander of the Atlantic Squadron.

Distress signal flares shooting skyward from South Brother Island in the East River off the Lower Bronx last night brought a police launch rushing to the scene, to find that an absent-minded husband had left his wife, three children and two friends stranded on the island where he had taken them early in the morning.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Representatives of 55,000 dairymen determined today to draft promptly a "course of action" on the government's recommended price of $3.11 a hundredweight for Class 1 fluid milk in the New York city market -- a proposed price already criticized as "entirely too low."

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- An advance of 63 per cent in the level of stock prices and 6 per cent in that of bonds indicates the trend of the German security markets in the first two years of the war. From the end of August, 1939, to Aug. 29, 1941, the share price index rose from 133.05 to 217.20.

DOWN around Mott Street, Pell Street and the Bowery, according to Carl Glick, almost any stranger ought to be able to find, if he looks hard enough, a tasty and wonder-working drink called Fu Kwat, or tiger-bone wine. Also another drink, quite as tasty though not as powerful, called Gop Guy, or spotted-lizard wine.

Despite Mayor La Guardia's declaration that the new wage and hour schedules for the 27,000 employes in the operating and maintenance departments of the city's unified transit system cannot be made retroactive to July 1, as demanded by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, the union will continue to press for that concession, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Two distinguished naval careers ended today with the retirement of Rear Admiral Joseph K. Taussig, a hero of the Peking Relief Expedition, and Rear Admiral Hayne Ellis, former commander of the Atlantic Squadron.

Distress signal flares shooting skyward from South Brother Island in the East River off the Lower Bronx last night brought a police launch rushing to the scene, to find that an absent-minded husband had left his wife, three children and two friends stranded on the island where he had taken them early in the morning.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- In a reply, to President Roosevelt's address of today Senator Wheeler declared tonight that American faith in democracy was being poisoned by "broken promises." He spoke before a Labor Day assembly at St. Charles, III. His speech was sponsored by the America First Committee and was broadcast over the Mutual network.

Playing twenty-one innings of what at times was great baseball and at other times was something vastly different, the Dodgers yesterday contrived to win only one game, but did not lose any of their twin bill with the Braves at Ebbets Field.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Metals and other material shortages and lack of shipping facilities cut Into July wholesale home furnishing sales by groups but left the general average 43.1 per cent above the 1940 dollar totals and 40.8 per cent above those of June, 1941, the monthly survey of the Merchandise Mart showed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Roosevelt's warning to labor that it has an extraordinary stake in this country's defense program won general approval among the handful of Congressmen who spent Labor Day in the capital. Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, Republican isolationist, sounded one of the few critical notes.
AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 1 -- The stock exchange here was exceedingly firm today in face of the new dividend-restriction announcement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Official Washington maintained strict silence today on the mission of forty-seven Russians who have arrived in two flying boats at Nome, Alaska.

BRIELLE, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Disappointment was the lot of the majority of the surfcasters we met today, touching beaches from Atlantic Highlands to North Point of Barnegat, and this disappointment was greater in that it was shared by so many.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- President Roosevelt's call to the nation today to subordinate all private interests to the rearmament effort and the destruction of Hitlerism drew an enthusiastic response from nearly all available members of Congress, Republicans and Democrats alike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie., 1940 Republican Presidential candidate, has been retained to defend motion picture producers against charges, soon to be brought before a Senate interstate commerce subcommittee, that they are producing war propaganda movies, it was disclosed tonight.

It would be hard to imagine a more productive field in which to stress the importance and the rewards of safe driving than that encompassed in the Ford Good Drivers League. This organization, of which Edsel Ford is president, has grown by leaps and bounds.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 1 (London Times Dispatch) -- The topic today in Ankara and Istanbul is the impending departure of Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador, for German Army headquarters, where he will see Adolf Hitler, and afterward go to Vienna for reasons of health.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Employers were asked today by the Selective Service Administration to cooperate in returning to jobs the 200,000 soldiers to be released from, military service before the year-end.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 -- The Congress of Industrial Organization has made "a brilliant record of progress" In the last year "in the face of the most determined opposition on the part of reactionary financial interests and their political agents," Allan S. Haywood, director of organization for the C.I.O., said here today in an address over the Blue network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Fruits with a tropical taste are being imported from Cuba for Manhattanites with exotic inclinations. Mamey en Almibar is a rich, fragrant fruit resembling the coconut, and said to grow in lush profusion in the interior of Cuba. Sliced and packed in a heavy syrup, it may be served as a sauce or garnish, or lend its strange and fascinating flavor to a fruit cup or salad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Summing up its reports made in the year on. 780 corporations operating in seventy-six selected industries, the Federal Trade Commission announced today that their average total investment in 1939 was $28138,187,401, their sales were $24932,624,668, and their combined net income, after deducting interest charges and all taxes, was $2,127,475,966. This combined net income represented an average rate of return of 7.56 per cent on the average capital employed in 1939.

The opening guns already fired, the Fall publishing season begins in earnest this month. September last year yielded more than 700 books, 150 fiction titles alone. The publishers' schedules for the weeks ahead show full quotas in almost every category -- in light fiction, mysteries, biography, novels, books on the war, books described as "not on the war."
Two years ago yesterday -- Sept. 1, 1939 -- the "Total War" began.

A vigorous protest against the lack of a lawyers' room in the new Criminal Court Building, which opens officially today, was made yesterday in a statement by Robert Daru, chairman of the board of directors and former president of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Launching ten days of pre-season training, Head Coach Herb Kopf sent thirty-five candidates for Manhattan's 1941 varsity football team through five hours of virgorous practice at La Salle Military Academy today.

Formation of a new group called United Youth for Defense, with its leadership composed entirely of men and women under 35 years old, was announced yesterday. Its purpose is to rally youth not engaged in military service for other national defense needs.

VICHY, France, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petaln's announcement of a new government party, the Legion of War Veterans and Volunteers of the National Revolution, was censored out of the German-controlled Paris press today -- an Indication that the totalitarian-style movement was trouble-bound.

Miss Anne Carroll Moore will retire today after having served thirty-five years as superintendent of work with children in the New York Public Library. She will be succeeded by Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayres, who comes from the faculty of the Graduate School of Librarianship of the University of California.

A sharp drop in industrial and public utility bond retirements caused the total of bonds called before maturity for redemption in August to fall to $74,602,000, the smallest amount for any month since December, 1939, when $73,781,000 were redeemed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Loans, discounts and deposits as reported by the 13,423 commercial banks insured with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation established new high records at the end of June, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the FDIC, made known today in a report.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- The Yankees toiled long and laboriously today, but in the end clinched nothing but their teeth. To the delight of 25,121 onlookers, the onrushing Bronx Bombers were unexpectedly caught by their coattails and held to an even break by the Athletics.
VICHY, France, Sept. 1 -- The second anniversary of the opening of the war finds France in a position of which no one would have dreamed on Sept. 1, 1939.

To maintain the position it has held for many years in better-class grocery and department stores in this country, Huntley Palmers, one of England's oldest and largest biscuit manufacturers, will soon start what is believed to be the first British consumer good-will campaign here since the war started.

Ponty, a 10-to-1 shot, captured the $11,400 Aqueduct Handicap yesterday as thoroughbred racing returned to the metropolitan district. New track marks were set for betting and attendance, as well as minor records that followed in the wake of a turnout of 39,968 persons.

VAN HORNESVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP) --Representatives of 55,000 dairymen serving1 the New York City milk market termed the government's proposed increase in the class one fluid milk price unsatisfactory today but advised acceptance of the figure "as a temporary but not a final readjustment."

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A British mechanized column, after an overnight contact with the Red Army at Kazvin, ninety miles northwest of Teheran, retired today in the direction of Aveh Pass, on the Hamadan road.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- A Soviet communique' describing spreading anti-Nazi disorders and German reprisals in France today said that many Catholic priests had been arrested and thrown Into prison or concentration camps in the Nazi-held zone.
HYDE PARK, Sept. 1 -- "We shall do everything' in our power to crush Hitler and his Nazi forces," President Roosevelt pledged today on the second anniversary of the start of war in Europe.

The appointments mada by Mayor La Guardia to the Board of Education and the Board of Higher Education were attacks yesterday by John R. Davies, candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor against Mr. La Guardia.

Not an Indian has whooped on Bear Mountain for years, but the shade of the redskin rose again yesterday to remind contemporary man of the mystery that envelops the origin of the first American -- a mystery to whose solution will be contributed the findings of the Trailside Museum at Bear Mountain.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British welcomed President Roosevelt's speech today, particularly those parts of it that referred to the necessity of increasing United States production and of seeing to it that the increased production got to Britain.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Bears mathematically clinched the 1941 International League pennant today by defeating Jersey City in the first game of a double-header, 4 to 3. The Little Giants turned the tables in the nightcap, winning by the same score.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Twenty thousand soldiers poured into Fort Dix tonight, returning from two-and-one-half-day holiday week-ends, for a week of routine small-unit training in preparation for two months of large scale manoeuvres starting next month in North Carolina.
Realty transactions involving loft and industrial properties, as well as several residential parcels, were reported yesterday in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A new method of diagnosing the Chances of recovering the use of muscles damaged by infantile paralysis was demonstrated today to the American Congress of Physical Therapy.

One month ahead of schedule workmen in the Brooklyn Navy Yard have topped out in fortyeight working days a new sixteenstory storehouse and office building costing more than $4,000,000, which will add twenty-one acres of floor space to the yard's facilities.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A heavy morning rain forced postponement until tomorrow of the $6,500 Horseman Futurity, feature of the program opening the fiveday Grand Circuit meeting at the Indiana State Fair today, but three other events were staged on the muddy track.

Passenger traffic between the East Coast of the United States and the East Coast of South America by the American Republics Line, which has risen steadily in the last two years, continued to rise in the first eight months of this year, according to Leo E. Archer, general traffic manager of the company.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Firmness ruled on the Stock Exchange today, with an exception, however, In the home railways, as wardamage uncertainties checked the ardor of the bulls. Profit-taking caused a general reaction among the carriers, especially in the junior stocks, where losses ran from 3/8 to 1 point.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Night air raids on Germany both from the west and the east [evidently the combined effort of British and Russian air forces] were reported by the High Command today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Longrange planning of municipal or State public improvements as part of a program to build a reserve of public works for post-war use has been begun by fifty-two cities, including New York, and nineteen States, including New York, it was announced today by the National Resources Planning Board.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Opening an active autumnal month of sailing, the Larchmont Yacht Club today held its fifty-fourth Fall regatta on Long Island Sound. It attracted 106 owners and their craft, against 122 last year.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 21 -- A Portuguese mission has just left Brazil. It attracted little attention elsewhere. Seemingly this was a gesture to repay a similar courtesy on the part of Brazil when she sent a mission to Portugal for the celebration of her centennial.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Hailed as a "truly American" example of the use of private wealth, for the public welfare, a brick-and-shingle firehouse, part of a new early colonial type shopping center, first unit of the Melville restoration project that will create a "Long Island Williamsburg" in this little village, was dedicated this afternoon before a cheering crowd of 5,000.

In his youth Adolf Hitler longed to be an artist, and when he failed to make the grade for enrollment in the Academy of Arts in Vienna, his ambitions turned to architecture. For years he labored, making the careful little architectural sketches and drawings owhich can now be seen in Munich.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES The public has a right to know more about the essential facts of the Eastern seaboard shortage of gasoline.

VICHY, France, Sept. 1 -- Efforts to make possible a definite accord between France and Germany are being made, according to a statement to the American press representatives in Paris today by Fernand de Brinon, the Vichy delegate with the occupying forces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- When he addressed labor today and called for a speed-up in armament production, the President once more conceded that "our American effort is not enough," that "our enemies know it" and, "unless we step up the total of our production and more greatly safeguard it on its journeys to the battlefields, these enemies will take heart in pushing their attacks in old fields and new."

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Big Pebdle, bidding for the 1941 handicap championship, swept to victory in the $33,100 Washington Park Handicap today before 38,000 fans, the largest crowd of the Washington Park meeting.

Under a broiling sun that sent the thermometer up to a most uncomfortable 89, the Fordham football squad reported for its inaugural practice at Fordham Field yesterday. Donning light equipment, the thirty-four candidates went through their paces in good spirits.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 1 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged today in a Labor Day address broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company that labor's rights had been imperilled by the activities of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- With the Russian invasion in its eleventh week and the war in its third year, the Germans today released little official information of importance about operations on the Eastern Front. On the basis of assertions in informed quarters, however, it appeared that the Russians were taking the initiative in counter-attacks both in the Ukraine and in the sector east of Gomel.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The question of the removal of the Aquarium from its present ancient location is beginning to seethe. Mr. Moses thinks it's about time it should go; contra, Mr. Isaacs.

The mass migration of city folk townward from vacation land has begun. The annual yearning to get away from getting away from, it all is setting in. In July the impulse to get away from it all seizes most of us. By September "it all" has taken on a rosier hue and seems endurable, if not actually attractive.

USING a hydrometer, hygrometer, fluoroscope or something similar, one might be able to determine precisely how much of Eugene Lyons's new book, "The Red Decade,"* is sound, reasonable and true. I have no such instrument at hand. I have good reason, however, for believing that parts are perfectly sound, reasonable and true.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- More men and women are employed today, and at better wages and under better working conditions, than at any time in the history of the United States, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, said tonight in a Labor Day address broadcast by the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 1 -- An unequivocal statement that the modern bombing plane has made the American coast "impregnable to invasion" is made by Lieut. Col. Thomas R. Phillips of the Army General Staff in an article to be published tomorrow in Army Ordnance, organ of the Army Ordnance Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1-- A "Small Business Section" of the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice has been established, and Guy Holcomb of Atlanta, president of the Georgia Association of Petroleum Retailers, has been made its chief.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The text of a Royal Air Force communique:

SHAHABAD, Iran, With the British and Indian Armies, Aug. 28 (Delayed) -- The hostilities against Iran, entered into for the purpose of ridding the country of German agents whose activity was believed to be threatening British security in the Middle East, ended this morning at 10 o'clock.

as Segura nailed the rising ball from deep court or volleyed it murderously from far back. The Atlantan mixed his spin, alternately chopping and coming over the ball and incessantly played wide to the backhand.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The new installment-buying restrictions and some tax proposals of the Senate Finance Committee are assailed in the Economic Outlook, the monthly survey issued by the C.I.O. Economic Division as bearing more heavily on the poor than the rich.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: General Marshall reported some weeks ago that Army morale was good; and more recently that, if it was not good, it was no more than could be expected as a result of civilian opposition to the Extended Service Law. Within the last few days the War Department announced that desertions had reached an alarming point.

LONDON, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- British and Russian columns in Iran have made their first contact of the war at Sinneh, cutting off Iran from Turkey, it was reported today in a British communique from Simla, India.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Army fliers released from military service and holding the status of civilians probably will help Pan American Airways operate its new plane ferry and air transport service across the Atlantic and Africa to British forces in the Near East, it was learned today.

With gasoline deliveries back on a restricted basis after the unlimited Labor Day week-end rationing holiday, the filling station dealers made plans yesterday to demand representation on the Petroleum Coordinator's regional advisory boards.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Cardinals ran their latest winning streak to seven games in a row and took a firmer grip on first place in the National League by sweeping a pair with the Pirates today, 5 to 3 and 6 to 3. The victories placed the Cards a half-game ahead of the Dodgers.
Lillian Gish, stage and screen actress, announced here yesterday that she had resigned as a member of the America First Committee, which is opposed to America's intervention in the war.

How adept Detectives John Sheridan and Ralph Lucoli of the Brooklyn headquarters squad are at the rhumba was a point on which the police were silent yesterday. In announcing the arrest of two ex-convicts for burglary.

American labor stands firm and united "against Hitler and against all he means," Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, declared yesterday during the "Salute to Labor" broadcast over the red and blue networks of the National Broadcasting Company.

KINGS PARK, L.I., Sept. 1 -- State Senator George L. Thompson, oldest member of the State Legislature, died of a heart attack at his home here today. He was 76 years old. He had gone out for his usual morning walk, and on his return complained of dizziness.

Land Of the Aryans It must be a source of peculiar annoyance to the Nazis that the very country from which their conception of Aryan world dominance springs is now under the control of Russian and British troops.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Japanese Army's chief spokesman, Colonel Hayto Mabuchi, chief of the army press section of Imperial Headquarters, told the nation in a broadcast last night that soldiers should not be used uselessly, adding that, therefore, diplomatic efforts should be pushed as long as possible, but that "peaceful means will not be allowed to be dragged along forever."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 1 -- A further step toward removing the last remaining restrictions on Argentine imports was taken today when Finance Minister Pedro Groppo announced the suppression of quotas that hitherto limited the number of motor vehicles that could enter the country.

Their determined bid to knock the Dodgers out of the National League pennant race laid aside for future reference, the Giants yesterday started doing something about climbing out of the second division before a crowd of 8,248 at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The largest drop in America's school population ever recorded was predicted today by the United States Office of Education for the term about to open, and the agency traced the cause to the low birth rate during the depression era.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Senator Bankhead of Alabama advised farmers today to withhold their cottonseed from the markets until prices reached $60 a ton, about $15 above recent averages.

Perhaps no generation, in American history has had a harder time finding and justifying its beliefs than that which was old enough to fight in the World War and is now too old to do-front-line service in any future war. Professor Charles R. Bagley of Dartmouth College has recently stated the case for those among them who are convinced American action against Hitler must be early and vigorous.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The German armies were declared today to have beaten back two Red Army counter-assaults, one a persistent series of efforts to recross the Dnieper River in the lower Ukraine and the other in an undisclosed sector of the front where eighty-six Russian tanks were reported smashed by a Nazi corps.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Senator Byrd of Virginia called tonight for "fundamental replanning and basic reorganization of the defense program." He renewed his charges that production of military supplies was lagging.

WASHINGTON, Sept 1 -- A survey disclosed today that President Roosevelt has brought about 95 per cent of all exports, about $4,000,000,000 worth of goods annually, under the export control licensing system.

The dislocations in peacetime industries due to the shifts to defense production may be severe in some instances, but should be offset in the aggregate by the defense expansion, according to the current review of economic and business conditions by the National City Bank.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Repudiating the isolationist stand of John L. Lewis, former president of the C.I.O., the national officers of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America called upon the union's seventh national convention today to support a policy of all-out aid to Great Britain and Soviet Russia.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- President Roosevelt's Labor Day speech has been heard by Italian Fascisti with relief since it contained no announcement of any advance toward intervention. That is the one thing that the leaders here are overwhelmingly interested in, and they are more than ever convinced tonight that Mr. Roosevelt's hands are tied and the United States will stay out of the war, at least through the Autumn and Winter.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 2 -- Declaring that an American, British, Chinese and Netherland encirclement movement was strangling Japan economically and that Japan must break it without delay, by diplomacy if possible, by force if necessary, Colonel Hayto Mabuchi, chief of the Japanese Army press section of Imperial Headquarters, last night attacked the United States and Britain for their "unpardonable crimes."

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Tigers, batting as of old in their drive toward a first-division berth, exploded thirty-five hits for sixty bases in twice walloping the Browns today, 9 to 5 and 16 to 8, before 22,180.

NOME, Alaska, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Anton N. Fedetoff, attache at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, arrived by plane tonight to confer with forty-seven emissaries who arrived in two flying boats yesterday after a mysterious flight across the top of the world.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A Finnish battle leader, taking cognizance of speculation over the possibility of an early Moscow-Helsinki peace, emphasized old territorial demands upon Soviet Russia today and declared, "Our fight is not finished."

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Sept. 2 -- As the third year of the war begins, German troops are for the first time in retreat toward a secondary line of defenses, according to a Russian military commentator who broadcast from Moscow last night.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- With Ted Williams clouting three homers, to boost his season's total to thirty-four, the Red Sox swept a double-header with the Senators, 13 -- 9 and 10 -- 2, before 22,577 fans today.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The White Sox kept on the heels of second-place Boston by sweeping a double-header with the Indians today.
NEW YORK Colonel and Mrs. Arthur W. Little, who have been spending the season in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., will return to Mayfair House next week.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Today's High Command communique, issued from "the Fuehrer's Headquarters," said:

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- In an address that reiterated Mexico's desire to cooperate with the United States for collective Pan-American defense, President Manuel Avila Camacho, at the opening of Congress today, said negotiations for a general settlement of outstanding questions with the United States, including oil claims, were on the point of satisfactory solution.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Cubs rallied to score a 5-to-4 victory in the tenth inning today after the Reds had beaten them, 2 to 1, in the first game of a double-header before 25,107.

BELLPORT, L.I., Sept. 1 -- The R Class yacht Hurricane, sailed by James J, Topping of the Point o' Woods Yacht Club, won the annual special race for the Queen of the Day Cup conducted today as a feature of the three-day Labor Day invitation regatta of the local yacht club, in which a total of 121 boats participated.

Registering their first goal in less than three minutes, the New York Americans repulsed the Puentes Grandes football club at Starlight Park in the Bronx yesterday, 3 to 2. The game was the first of a tour of the United States scheduled for the losers, who are the national soccer champions of Cuba.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Economic cooperation between the United States and Mexico was highlighted today with the announcement that the State Department in Washington had given Class A-3 priority to 1,000 railroad boxcars ordered by the Mexican National Railways, despite the fact that United States railways face a shortage of rolling stock.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 2 -- The air war between Britain and Germany was intensified over Sunday night when the Royal Air Force stepped up its offensive in attacks on the industrial Ruhr and Rhineland areas, smashing at targets in Essen and Cologne, and the Nazi Air Fleet carried out a sharp attack on Hull.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Lady Edward Spencer-Churchill was fatally injured today in an automobile accident near Cobham, Surrey. Her daughter, the Viscountess Cowdray, was seriously injured.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 2 -- For the fifth consecutive day the Soviet High Command communique does not mention any change in the fighting sectors. The Red Army appears to be holding firm on a line following the Dnieper River from its Black Sea mouth to north of Kiev, then going eastward around Gomel and Smolensk, northward to the Lake Ilmen area and northwestward past Kingisepp to the Baltic.
There never has been a Labor Day week-end like it.

This Summer there has been one successful winged invasion of Britain. From the European Continent a host of clouded yellow butterflies have made the overwater journey and settled down in Lancashire and Cheshire. The editors of the British scientific journal Nature, in reporting the phenomenon as "one of the most interesting entomological features of the Summer of 1941," abstain in all their dignity from any timely comparisons.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Ella Boole of Brooklyn, N.Y., 83-year-old president of the world's Woman's Christian Temperance Union, said tonight that "despite the fog of censorship now covering the globe" sufficient news has trickled through to indicate that white ribbon organizations are "carrying on despite bombings and suppressions."
Three new plays will come to Broadway next week, at the current writing the list reading like this:

Broadway motion-picture theatres enjoyed one of the biggest Labor Day week-ends in recent history when approximately 450,000 persons jammed the major first-run houses over the holiday period, according to reports from theatre managements yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Two American pilots, believed to be the first to receive the Distinguished Flying Cross in this war, were honored today for "outstanding services" in attacks on German objectives.

Eight men, leaders of as many nations that have been overrun by German and Italian troops, chose yesterday, the second anniversary of the war, as an occasion to broadcast from London their contempt of Nazism and Fascism and to vow that their peoples, though brutally oppressed, were still fighting back and would continue the struggle until Hitlerism was overthrown with the aid of the United States.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1 -- Neutral diplomatic quarters here are watching with grave anxiety the development of events in Bulgaro-Turkish relations. The situation in that region is considered to be particularly serious, especially in view of the possible military implications that any "amicable" arrangement might have on the development of the German campaign against Russia.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Eleven soldiers escaped early this morning from the guardhouse at Fort Slocum, a garrison on Davids Island a mile off shore from here, by smashing the lock of their cell block and sawing through one-inch steel bars that covered a window.
Property loss in Britain through air raids in the first two years of the war is estimated at $480,000,000 by The Economist, British financial journal.

Now that Finland's armies have reconquererd nearly all the territory lost to Russia in last year's war, logic and good sense dictate the immediate conclusion of a separate peace with Moscow. All reports agree that this is the profound desire of the Finnish people, who are exhausted by two desperate campaigns and have no interest in fighting by the side of Germany when their own land is restored to them.
Following are the texts of the Labor Day addresses of President Roosevelt and Ernest Bevin, British Minister of Labor, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Proclaiming the readiness of the American Federation of Labor to do its full part, George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the A.F. of L. appealed here today for the restoration of unity in the labor movement in this country.

The Brazilian National Coffee Department has put forward a plan for the liquidation, from time to time, of coffee pledged as security for outstanding sterling and dollar bonds of the State of San Paulo 7 per cent Coffee Realization Loan of 1930.

Reorders continued to come In at a steady pace in the wholesale markets last week, despite the heavy Fall purchases made by stores earlier In the season. While shipments are slow, stores generally have substantial stocks for the Fall season.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 1 (U.P) -- George Gibson, president, opening the seventy-third Trades Union Congress today, pledged the fullest possible support from Britain's workshops to Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

The OPM is "reliably tinderstood" to have prepared secretly a list of more than forty Industries, embracing thousands of business concerns, that face drastic retrenchment or complete shutdown as a result of "raw material starvation" under the national defense program, Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, Inc., yesterday told the institute's one hundred district managers at the opening of a four-day meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Lack of sound Spanish translations of technical handbooks, textbooks and other literature produced in this country for the use of Latin-American engineers is a serious handicap to the development of closer commercial relationships between this country and the Southern republics, George W. Warner, general manager of the Armco International Corporation, contended last week in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Mike Priano, Erasmus Hall High School senior, continued to dominate the men's local swimming picture by scoring a double yesterday as the two-day senior metropolitan A.A.U. championships came to a close at Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 1 -- Heavy British bombers continued early yesterday the blasting of Tripoli, major Axis supply base in Libya, Royal Air Force headquarters here reported today.

VICHY, France, Sept. 1 -- The Petain government has persuaded German authorities in Paris to abandon their plans for "mass execution" of Jewish hostages in reprisal for anti-Nazi terrorism, it was announced today by Pernand de Brinon.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Thirty-three City College football players arrived at the New Concord Hotel late this afternoon to open their 1941 training campaign. Equipment was distributed and Coach Benny Friedman held a brief blackboard session.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Heavy Finnish attacks against Russian troop concentrations and supply bases on the Karelian Isthmus today gave prompt support to the declaration of a Finnish battle leader that the war against Russia "is not finished."

The New York State Labor Relations Board decision in the case of the Germaine Stores, Inc., operators of a department store at 550 fifth Avenue, which was reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 31, did not make clear that the board, in reversing the trial examiner's findings, cleared the company of all charges of engaging in unfair labor practices except one.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The construction of ships of both fighting and cargo-carrying types is the third front in the Battle of the Atlantic.

Harry Hurst, Toronto lightweight, defeated George Zengaras of the East Side in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. The Canadian battler, flashing a two-fisted body attack, wore down Zengras in the early sessions.

ROME, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- British planes, bombing and machine-gunning Southern Italy, Sicily and the Libyan Coast, have killed thirteen persons and wounded many more, a High Command communique said today.
The unfinished passenger liner Rio Parana will be brought here today or tomorrow from Chester, Pa., and assigned to a New York dockyard for conversion into an auxiliary, it was disclosed yesterday.

Ball Player, the 3-year-old chestnut gelding from the Tall Trees Stable of Mrs. Frank Navin, widow of the former owner of the Detroit Tigers, flashed home first in the $2,500 Damask Purse at Aqueduct yesterday. Mrs. Navin was present for the race.
LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Howard Osterhout, acting manager of the pre-primary campaign headquarters for John R. Davies, bought 5,200 petition signatures from Simeon J. Beekerman, veteran petition-gatherer, a few hours before the deadline for the filing of primary petitions, according to testimony given yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Forty-five children from Germany, Austria and other European nations under German domination arrived yesterday on the Portuguese passenger liner Mouzinho under the auspices of the United States Committee for the Care of European Children.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Treasury Department announced today that $1,037,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes had been bought during August by individuals and corporations to provide for payment of Federal income levies due next year.

One of the Axis spokesmen says of the President's Labor Day speech that "Mr. Roosevelt used the language of the head of a state at war." If he means that Mr. Roosevelt spoke as the leader of a nation which has chosen sides and taken a hand in the battle, he is right.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 3 -- Following up the speech of Colonel Hayao Mabuchi, chief of the Japanese Army Press section of Imperial Headquarters, in which he stated Japan must break "American, British, Chinese and Dutch encirclement" either by diplomacy or by force or face economic strangulation, the Great Japan and Asia Development League yesterday submitted to Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye, who is its president, a four-point program that calls for:

Despite the high record level of industrial production, net profits of large industrial corporations as a group declined between the first and second quarters of this year owing to higher labor and material costs and increased provision for taxes, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review of credit and business conditions.
BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- German spearheads advancing toward Leningrad have arrived at Krasnoe Selo, some twenty miles southwest of the former Russian capital, authorized quarters in Berlin reported today.
SHIPPENSBURG, Pa., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Robert Bridges, former editor of Scribner's Magazine and contributor to many publications, died today at his home here, at the age of 83.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2 -- President Roosevelt said today in a message to the sixteenth Biennial Convention of the National Federation of Federal Employes that assurance of government workers that they would accept all responsibilities in a spirit of service "is heartening to me."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Contracts totaling $14,890,988 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

Add to the list of films opening this week "Frightened Lady," which will arrive at the Globe tomorrow. The mystery drama, which was produced in England, is released by Arthur Ziehm and distributed by Hoffberg Productions, Inc.

Campaign headquarters for Mayor La Guardia, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, and Newbold Morris, Council President, were opened informally yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt, with a formal opening scheduled for tomorrow afternoon when all candidates except the Mayor will be present.

The season of 1941-42 will be ushered in tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre with the unveiling of a new play, "Village Green," which will bring together once more Frank Craven (pere) and John Craven (fils) in the same attraction. Carl Allensworth is the author and he has chosen for his theme the political turmoil of a small New Hampshire town.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Thirteen horses have been named for the eighth annual Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase on Saturday and as usual the owners include some of the best-known names in the sport.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Three children were fatally burned here today when a flaming pilotless Army P39 Airacobra pursuit ship plummeted to the lawn of the Hempstead Reformed Church at Jerusalem and Florence Avenues and exploded, showering ignited gasoline and engine parts and shattering plateglass windows of near-by stores.

Affected by the Labor Day statement of President Roosevelt implying more conflict and also developments on Saturday when the parity price of cotton was raised 25 points, the market for the staple held strong yesterday as quotations approached closely their best levels since 1930.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The first of Great Britain's big United States-made Fortress bombers to be tackled by German interceptors came through a seven-plane assault, battered and smoking, some of the crew dead and others wounded, and returned to Britain with its mission fulfilled.

To meet the menace of the growing fuel shortage in the East, railroad traffic officers from all over the country are to confer tomorrow in Washington with officials of oil companies on proposals to reduce the rates for shipments of petroleum and its products by rail.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 2 -- The Bulgarian Parliament has been summoned to a special session for noon tomorrow following a surprise meeting of the Cabinet which lasted from 5 o'clock this afternoon to shortly after 11 this evening.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Bill Gallon stepped the first heat of the Horseman Futurity in 2:01 today for a new mile record in the 34-year-old race for 3-year-old trotters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- General Charles de Gaulle left Brazzaville, the capital of Free French Africa, four days ago and is expected to engage in an important talk with Prime Minister Winston Churchill. The agreement reached a year ago between the British Prime Minister and the Free French leader calls for adaptation to new circumstances.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Marking time for the start of the Governors' Cup play-offs, the champion Bears fashioned a 7-to-3 victory over Jersey City tonight mathematically to eliminate the Little Giants from consideration for a first-division berth and the play-offs.

Trading was only fair following the Labor Day holiday. The lamb market was slightly lower but other classes were little changed from last week's closing markets. Early demand for kosher meats was slow but opening prices were steady on all classes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Joel McCrea will play the male lead opposite Claudette Colbert in Preston Sturges's next picture at Paramount, a marital comedy-drama, the studio announced today. Sturges is writing the scenario, for which no title has been announced, and he will direct the picture, starting Nov. 10.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Suspension of market activities yesterday, with moderate receipts and a strong dressed market today, failed to bring much competition, as hog prices sagged 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight, while beef cattle sold at prices steady to 15 cents lower than at the previous close.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The nation's railroads and petroleum companies moved today toward joint action to ease the Eastern gasoline shortage by greater utilization of tank cars.

Both customers and retailers here took the new installment credit regulations in their stride yesterday, the first business day since the restrictions became effective. Business continued at the active pace of recent weeks, and the consensus was that the rules were put into effect without a hitch.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- For the eighth year Dr. Marvin Allen Stevens is beginning on the shore of Lake Sebago the construction of a New York University football team. In none of the years since he went to New York from Yale has the quiet, frankly spoken coach had an easy job on his hands, but this year, with only thirty-two men on hand so far, his task seems harder than ever.

A ticklish problem without precedent, the possibility of moving the world series out of the park of one of the participating teams, will be considered today at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt called by Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The power of any city to enter into contracts with labor unions and the right of city employes to strike to enforce such agreements are strongly denied in a survey made public today by the National Institute of Municipal Law Officers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The United States, it was learned today, will make a large loan to Mexico, as part of a comprehensive agreement under which Mexico is expected to cooperate with the United States in the economic and military defence of the hemisphere, guarantee to keep all strategic war materials away from the Axis powers, and make a final cash settlement with American companies whose Mexican oil properties were seized in 1938.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- Premier Benito Mussolini's newspaper asserted today that he and Adolf Hitler, in their five-day conference on the Russian front last week, had decided on the unification of Europe in one Axis-dominated State.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 2 -- In the midst of a discussion on a resolution to give all possible support to the Russian war effort -- which means redoubled efforts by the already weary workers -- the Trades Union Congress was thrown into turmoil today by the charge that Lieut. Col. John T.C. Moore-Brabazon, Minister of Aircraft Production, believed the Russians and Germans should be allowed to exterminate themselves, thus giving the British continental dominance.

Wall Street returned to work yesterday after the holiday weekend in a more bullish frame of mind, and as trading in stocks on the Stock Exchange crossed the half-million share mark for the first time in three weeks, prices edged forward further.

The demand of Eastern seaboard gasoline retailers for representation on the Eastern Marketing Committee appeared yesterday to be running into the complication that there are no vacancies on that committee.

Prices on Southern canned tomatoes moved up to 82 1/2 cents a dozen for No. 2s in the wholesale market here yesterday, the highest price registered for a new tomato pack in ten years. Despite the rise, buyers were eager to place commitments for both immediate and future delivery.

To the permanent residents in a thousand towns it means that the speed boats will be put to bed; the bathing beaches abandoned to almost primeval quiet; the Summer cottages boarded up with signs warning against trespass; the Summer stores gone southward; the roads safer for the contemplative driver; the high trails empty of their shouting youngsters and plodding oldsters.

A steady increase in the amount of rayon yarns available to the hosiery industry may be expected on the basis of orders already issued and arrangements now pending with yarn manufacturers, according to a summary of the supply situation to date issued yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

PANAMA, R.P., Sept. 2 -- The formation of a Panamanian Commission of the Inter-American Development Commission was reported here today by Rafael Oreamuno, vice chairman of the parent body located in Washington. He has been organizing similar commissions in each capital in Latin America for nine months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Captain Sherwood Picking, distinguished submarine expert and recently appointed Assistant Naval Attache to the United States Embassy in London, was killed in a recent crash of a Royal Air Force Ferry Command plane, the Navy announced here today.
Two years ago today Britain and France declared war upon Germany.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Hungry and footsore after hiding in woods and tramping back roads for twenty-six hours, the last five of the eleven soldiers who escaped yesterday from the Fort Slocum guard house on Davids Island were ambushed and captured early today by Scarsdale police ten miles from the fort.
A Junior Davis Cup match between New York and Boston at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday was won by the New England players, 6 to 3.

The two great island outposts for the defense of the Western Hemisphere against attack from across the Atlantic are Iceland on the north and the Azores on the south. American forces are now in firm occupation of Iceland. It is reassuring to learn from a Rio de Janeiro dispatch to THE TIMES that protection for the Azores may be arranged through the good offices of Brazil, acting as a friendly neutral.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Vice President Wallace, speaking for the newly-created Supplies Priorities and Allocation Board, said today that defense officials would stop the sapping by less essential industries of material, labor and machinery resources necessary for an all-out defense program so that "every available man and machine" may be employed on defense requirements or at work essential to the civilian economy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Aug. 27, 1941, aggregated $9,405,000,000.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 2 -- By a vote of 382 to 5, delegates to the seventh national convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., approved today President Roosevelt's policy of aid to Great Britain, Soviet Russia, China and all other nations resisting Hitlerism.

Another figure, former captain of a charter boat in Miami, Fla., was added yesterday to the growing group accused by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa of supplying to a foreign power information on the current strength and present geographical distribution of the Army.

The $3,672,000,000 Defense Tax Bill as revised by the Senate Finance Committee is undoubtedly far from perfect. The magnitude of the burden it imposes, and the large number of tax-payers it covers, must mean inevitably that it will produce many individual hardships.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Sept. 3 -- The pressure that the Russians have maintained against German positions finally is bearing fruit and according to Russian reports, the Germans now are on the defensive at many points on the Eastern Front, although they continue stubborn resistance against the Soviet counter-attacks.

Noting that builders are running into shortages and "price corners" in some materials and equipment needed to complete their home construction contracts, the American Builder, in its September issue, urges priority for home building.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Officials of the Big Five operating railroad brotherhoods and of the fourteen non-operating unions were busy today tabulating the results of a strike vote taken among their 1,140,000 members. The outcome is expected to be announced on Friday.

Condemnation of the use of "influence," political or otherwise, in our courts became the theme yesterday at the opening of the Court of General Sessions in the new $20,000,000 Criminal Courts Building, facing Centre Street, between Leonard and White Streets.
A self-styled "unconfirmed diffident bachelor" was accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of having used the mails to defraud a "certain class of persons, to wit, unmarried females."
VICHY, France, Sept. 2 -- A series of laws and decrees issued today completes measures already taken by the Petain government for the reform of public education.

Hosts of Labor Day week-enders, some of whom had been unable to obtain transportation Monday night during the record travel rush, were returning to their homes yesterday as services of the city's various transportation agencies gradually returned to normal.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following:
