LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The hills of the United Kingdom's West Coast today claimed a transatlantic transport plane, which crashed with the loss of ten lives, including two Americans.

Cannot Be Told Once upon a time there was a modern young school teacher who had a message she wished to convey to her little boys and girls. She wanted them to know that if by any chance they came across a small blue bottle marked Arsenic or Cyanide of Potassium they had better refrain from putting the contents into their mouth.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Charley Root, veteran Cubs' right-hander, went to work on his third set of 100 pitching victories today, notching the two hundred and first triumph of his major league career by beating the Reds, 3 to 1, in the final game of the series.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The opening of the Fall trout season in New Jersey passed almost unnoticed in the Labor Day excitement, especially in the central counties, but this morning we found about fifty anglers in the northern and western areas.

DENVER, Sept. 2 -- The establishment of a National Opinion Research Center at the University of Denver was announced here tonight. It is being sponsored jointly by the university and the (Marshall) Field Foundation, Inc., of New York.

Near the end of an uneventful session of competition that had caused hardly a ripple of excitement, two favorites were eliminated from the national singles championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday, marking the first inroads in the established order.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Governor Burnet R. Maybank piled up a big lead over his two opponents for the Senate in a special democratic primary today but on the face of incomplete returns he lacked the majority which would give him the nomination.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Five Russian officials were in San Diego today negotiating with the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation to buy giant bombing planes.
ROME, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

Fifteen inconspicuous looking trucks carried the entire gold reserve of Poland, totaling $75,000,000, on a bizarre tour through Europe before the metal was brought to a temporary place of safety from the Nazis, Ignacy Matuszewski, former Polish Finance Minister, disclosed here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES today reports the recommendation made by the Jewish War Veterans in favor of "a broad physical education program for schools and colleges to prepare youth for any emergency that may arise in the future," because "the experience of the selective service boards reveals physical disability to the extent of 35-40 per cent."

The simple words "cinnamon toast," however softly whispered in the ear of the Older Generation, invariably evoke a wave of reminiscences through which Autumnal foliage, bright copper tea kettles and open fires float in a dreamy blur.

Retail Sales Here Up 16% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 16 per cent for the week ended Aug. 30, in comparison with the same week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

For the first time since she enterea service between New York and Lisbon in July, 1940, the American Export liner Excambion arrived here yesterday without a capacity list of passengers aboard. Although normally she carries 165 passengers and has brought more than 200 on some crossings, only 118 were on the ship yesterday.

VICHY, France, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- The Nazi-controlled Paris press alleged today that mysterious "American tourists" were infiltrating into African territories, including the Dakar region, where British and Free French forces have been concentrating for threatened attacks.

It now seems clear that a real Russian counter-offensive is developing on the central fighting front. What the Germans describe as "new armies" are attacking heavily on the 175-mile sector between the deep Nazi penetrations at Smolensk and Gomel. If Swedish reports of the recapture of the towns of Rogachev and Zhlobin are correct, the Russians are back again on the banks of the upper Dnieper.

LEIPZIG, Germany, Sept. 2 -- To contribute its part in building up the new economic order in a Europe consolidated under German hegemony rather than to satisfy immediate consumer demands -- such is the official slogan of the fourth wartime Leipzig Autumn Fair now in progress.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 3 -- There were persistent reports today that Red Army counter-attacks in the central sector were pushing back the Germans toward Smolensk, Zhlobin, Rogachev, Bobruisk and Gomel.

Directors of the Celanese Corporation of America yesterday authorized a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 30 to holders of record of Sept. 16. This disbursement will lift cash dividends authorized to date this year to $1.50 a share.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted yesterday the highest bid for an issue of $500,000 of city of Portland, Ore., water-system bonds, naming an interest cost basis of 1.4037 per cent. The firm bid 100.04 for $350,000 as 1 1/2s and $150,000 as 1/4s.

Sixty-three hundred aliens who have formally declared their intention of becoming citizens of the United States are serving in the Army as selectees but none are permitted to enter training for officerships or even to enlist voluntarily in the regular forces of the Army, Navy or Marine Corps, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Four more members of the German spy ring rounded up early in July appeared yesterday before Federal Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Brooklyn and entered pleas of guilty to one count of the indictment against them and pleas of not guilty to the other count.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue, and sell, $5,800,000 of equipment-trust serial certificates.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1 (Delayed) -- The Red Army and the British Indian Command rushed the massive task of consolidation of liaison across hundreds of square miles of Iran's vast mountains, deserts and plateaus today, following the historic junction made yesterday by the two Allied armies at Kazvin, ninety miles northwest of Teheran, closing the gateway to India against an attack from the Caucasus and providing a supply line to Russia from the Persian Gulf.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The 1941 tax bill, hailed by some as a potential source of more revenue than the $3,672,400,000 estimated by the Treasury Department, was ordered reported to the Senate today by the Finance Committee.

To meet the need for art to interest children, the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has conducted a survey throughout the country, to determine children's taste in art, and yesterday announced a competition among America's artists to supply the sort of pictures children want.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Plans have been completed for the annual rummage sale in behalf of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children, which will be held on Thursday afternoon in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

Representative Samuel Dickstein sent a telegram, last night to Representative Martin Dies, asking him to investigate the America First Committee, Inc. Mr. Dickstein charged that the committee "acts as a sort of front" for anti-Americans, pro-Nazis and other groups that have fascistic tendencies.

Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday the Democratic reform bill which abolishes the offices of Commissioner of Records in New York and Kings Counties and transfers their duties to the respective County Clerks. The law takes effect Jan. 1.

A group of thirty-three one-family houses in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, is called for by one of the building plans filed yesterday. The project is estimated to cost about $185,700 by the Trump Brighton Corporation, owner, and Isaac Kallich, the architect.

Telephone Financing The decision announced late last week by officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to sell its forthcoming $95,000,000 refunding issue by competitive bidding was the signal for an enthusiastic revival of activity yesterday throughout the underwriting community.

Only once in ten years has an All-Star team beaten the New York Football Giants, but another picked collection of collegians has hopes of starting the Giants off on the wrong foot in a second decade tonight when the Eastern College All-Stars clash with the professionals in the sixth annual benefit game at the Polo Grounds.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- In declarations of policy released here today, battle lines were drawn between the advocates and the opponents of the Westchester County charter amendment that would abolish the Board of Supervisors and create a small legislative board.

The rising cost of men's clothing was demonstrated yesterday when the popular-price chains put into effect price advances ranging from 10 to 13 per cent over the Spring levels. The Howard Clothing chains lifted prices from $22.50 to $24.75, while Crawford's advanced quotations from $19.95 to $22.50 on its base lines and from $24.95 to $27.50 on its higher-price line.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Jack Sabol, pro at Westchester Hills, and Louis Barbaro, young Hummocks pro, gained the major share of the honors in the one-day golf tournament staged by the Westchester division of the P.G.A. at the Hudson River Country Club today.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- For eighty tense minutes Lieutenant Woodward Burke, chief test pilot of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, flying a new type of dive bomber, circled over Newark Airport this afternoon with a jammed landing gear while fire engines, a police emergency truck and an ambulance waited below for a crash landing.

Keen competition in bidding for the forthcoming $95,000,000 issue of American Telephone and Telegraph Company long-term debenture bonds was promised yesterday with disclosure that at least three major underwriting syndicates had been formed to participate in the first "open house" financing by the company in thirty-five years.

ALTHOUGH the farming community of Elm, Moss County, Iowa, doesn't show in any atlas that I know of, it is on the map as a result of Paul Corey's long chronicle of the family of the late Christopher Mantz. This chronicle began with "Three Miles Square" two Autumns ago. It was continued in "The Road Returns," which appeared last Autumn.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The War Department released the following orders to day, dated Aug. 30:

For 1,000,000 New York City school children the ten-week Summer vacation is just about over. School opens officially Monday morning, although the 40,000 teachers and supervisors must return to their classrooms this week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- American military planes are becoming laboratories for psychologists, who have found that perception is more important than muscular coordination in flying, it was reported today to the American Association for Applied Psychology.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force reported tonight that British bombers had carried out a heavy attack upon shipping and munitions plants at Crotone, Italy.

Beginning yesterday the Fall openings of Uptown Retail Guild stores presenting original designs got under way. Six in all will take place during the course of a week's time. Yesterday's showings were held by Jay Thorpe and Bergdorf Goodman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Defense construction projects at Atlantic bases and at Army air fields involve a total cost of almost $1,000,000,000, it became known today in connection with proposed legislation to combine the operation of the Army Corps of Engineers and the Quartermaster Corps' construction division.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- The Italian press today minimized and ridiculed President Roosevelt's Labor Day speech which the commentators did not profess to take seriously. However, it was to be noted that the brief and distorted Stefani summary, given to the press as a news item from Washington, contained one outstanding inaccuracy upon which part of the comments were based.

In chronological order Kirby Higbe lost his no-hitter, his shutout and his poise in the sixth inning of yesterday's game between the Dodgers and Braves at Ebbets Field. He couldn't, of course, regain the first two, but item No. 3 returned almost immediately and the Brooklyn right-hander coasted to a 9-2 victory.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Sparkling Gem, a 2-year-old gelding owned by Harry Sandrock, scored his third victory in three starts at Narragansett Park today when he won the Nantucket purse at six furlongs.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- "Rivers of blood are flowing" all over Yugoslavia and waves of violence threaten to destroy the Serbian people's unity and existence, the newspaper Pest today quoted General Milan Neditch, Serbian leader and former War Minister, as saying.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, said today that he would protest to the State Department about newspaper articles charging that representatives of the French Embassy here were working in collaboration with the Nazi Germans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Additional billions of dollars will be mobilized to increase the size of this country's already vast armaments program and assist in the effort "to crush Hitler." President Roosevelt announced today.

THE advertisements and advance literature put out by Promoter-for-a-Night Rufus Stanley Woodward state that the football game to be played this evening at the Polo Grounds will be between Johnny Mara's Giants and the "Eastern College All-Stars" for the benefit of the Tribune Fresh Air Fund. A man takes his life in his hands when he mixes in these football scrimmages and Mr. Woodward is about to find that out.

Despite the restrictions on consumers' durable goods, advertising volume for the balance of the year is expected to maintain its present rate of gain over 1940, which is about 4 to 5 per cent. In the last month or two manufacturers of consumers' durable goods have been giving a preview of what will actually happen to advertising when production is curtailed, by cutting down on their expenditures even though their sales have held up.
LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 3 -- Around the clock operations, now being carried on by the Royal Air Force whenever the weather permits, had a varied schedule in the last twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- From the time in 1940 when the President summoned William S. Knudsen and his associates to Washington, and began to appoint other specialists from business and finance to defense posts in the regular Federal departments -- from that time until last week the veteran New Deal government group felt it was being subordinated in the rearmament effort.

Stockholders of the International Mercantile Marine Company, at a meeting in Hoboken, N.J., yesterday, approved steps providing for a simplification of the capital structure of the United States Lines Company, its principal subsidiary, and for part payment of the I.M.M. bond maturity on Oct. 1.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The Aknusti and Gulf Stream polo combinations turned in victories today as test matches for the national open championship continued at the Meadow Brook Club. Aknusti prevailed over the Pelicans, 13 to 10, on Waterbury Field, and Gulf Stream turned back Texas, 9 to 8, on Whitney Field.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- The German High Command has been compelled by its enormous continuing losses to rush reserves from occupied Europe, in some cases leaving wounded men to hold invaded areas, the Soviet General Staff declared today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- Representatives of more than 100,000 independent gasoline retail dealers in seventeen Eastern seaboard States came to Philadelphia tonight for a special conference which they prefaced with a 10-point statement of objectives, challenging the government's contention that a shortage of gasoline existed and demanding a full measure of recognition in any steps to curtail the sale of petroleum products.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla said in a press interview tonight that he considered Mexico's relations with Britain already restored in everything but the technicality of protocol.
NEW YORK Admiral and Mrs. Henry B. Wilson have arrived from Washington and will be at the Vanderbilt for the Autumn and Winter.

Since "Lady in the Dark" closed last June, four members of the original company have gone on to higher and more expensive things. Not Gertrude Lawrence, of course: she will not go on to anything higher, please God! for many years to come, and she can scarcely be more expensive to any earth-bound management than she is right now.

The four-story apartment house on a plot 89 by 100 feet at 462-66 Woodcliff Avenue, northeast corner of Hamilton Avenue, North Bergen, N.J., assessed for $57,600, has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee for the mortgage certificate holders of the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company, to Frank Mescia for a stated consideration of $64,500.

A ten-year-old girl in Port Washington, L.I., has been drying "miles and miles of dishes" so that children in the bombed cities of Britain may be evacuated to the comparatively safe Scottish highlands.

Mayor La Guardia appeared unexpectedly yesterday afternoon at exercises marking the moving of the contagious disease unit of Willard Parker Hospital, but despite all pleas violated one of the traditions of an election year. He posed for photographers, joked with reporters and waved his hat in greeting to the several hundred persons present at the ceremony -- but he refused to make a speech.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3 --It seems certain that Mexico will get financial help from the United States to support her currency and to complete the Pan-American Highway to Guatemala and that each loan or credit accompanying an oil settlement will be earmarked for a specific purpose.

WITH THE RUSSIAN ARMY, on the Central Front, Sept. 3 -- For several days I have been at the most active sector of the Western Front. The word front, which in the first month of the war was used only conditionally, now has a definite meaning. There is much here that reminds one of the first World War-trenches, barbed wire, and above all a certain amount of stability.

Premier Konoye did not overstate the case when he told the Japanese people yesterday that they face the gravest crisis in their history. They stand alone in the Far East. Their German and Italian allies, lacking control of the seas, cannot aid them. Their trade has gone to smash.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- An upturn of 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight brought the S12 hog back to the Chicago market today, while Spring lambs soared 25 to 35 cents in an active market. Beef cattle were steady to a shade higher than yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Soviet-British-Iranian negotiations are continuing and may continue for some days, it was said here today. The British say there is no cause for apprehension regarding the future status of the German Legation or other legations under Axis control.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- The government sued Al Capone and fourteen officers of his one-time $20,000,000 crime syndicate today for $250,000 in taxes and penalties on bee Federal agents confiscated from the syndicate's stocks during prohibition.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Undoubtedly there is a sincerity back of the various polls being taken to determine the American mind, but one factor is self-evident: there is a midway group who believe it is impossible to decide for or against war at this time simply because the issue is not clear cut and cannot be squeezed into a dichotomous logical answer.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- What the Royal Air Force is accomplishing in the Battle of the Atlantic was indicated today by Sir Archibald Sinclair, the Secretary for Air, speaking at a luncheon of the National Defense Public Interest Committee.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- Concerned over an adverse trade balance and noting that nine-tenths of Mexico's foreign trade is now with the United States, Mexican authorities suggest that Washington might help this country's economy by removing the tariff on the sixteen major imports from Mexico, including eleven strategic minerals sold exclusively to the United States.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces removed from Foochow are "heading in a new direction for the purpose of continuing" the campaign against China," a joint statement of the Japanese Army and Navy said today. Lieut. Col. Haru- shige Iwasaki, chief of the Press Bureau of the Japanese Expeditionary Forces, said the occupation of Indo-China and the effective Chinese coastal blockade made the garrisoning of Foochow unnecessary, because "Indo-China and Foochow are closely linked.
BERLIN, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The German High Command communique, issued from "the Fuehrer's Headquarters," said today:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- To cope with rationing imposed by Washington and with other trade difficulties resulting from the gasoline shipping shortage, filling station proprietors of the Eastern Seaboard formed a permanent organization here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Plans for increasing the collection of scarce scrap materials by 20 per cent to fill the mounting demands of the defense program were outlined by defense officials today at a meeting of eighty representatives of dealers in non-ferrous metals, iron and steel scrap, wool rags, cotton rags and scrap rubber.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Sept. 4 -- German resistance to Russian attacks in the area of the central sector between Smolensk and Gomel has been broken at many points and is crumbling at others, according to a Moscow commentator.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Washington mustered five runs in the ninth inning today to hand the Athletics a 9-8 defeat after Philadelphia had produced five runs with two out in the eighth inning.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 (AP) -- R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:
ROME, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

Donald McNeill, the defending champion from Oklahoma, and Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., qualified yesterday to meet in the semi-final round of the national tennis tournament at Forest Hills, and Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles and Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco gained the penultimate brackets in the lower half of the women's singles.

HELSINKI, Finland, Thursday, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command reported early today that Russian troops fighting on the Karelian Isthmus had been "decisively beaten" and that Finland had regained all the soil lost to the Soviet in the 1939-40 war.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent Zoltan Havas, in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, published in your edition of Aug. 30, takes issue with the Slavonic Committee for Democracy's objective of a Slavonic commonwealth, saying that "such a plan would meet with complete failure" because of territorial differences.

Harold K. Guinzburg, head of the Viking Press, sold yesterday the four-story residence with garden at 152 East Sixty-third Street, which he bought in 1927. The house adjoins the residence of Samuel Seabury and was sold through Warren Marks Associates, brokers, who recently sold 163-5 East Sixty-third Street to Edward L. Bernays, public relations counsel.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 -- William Cameron Forbes, former Ambassador to Japan and a former Governor of the Philippines, will be a week-end guest of Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice. He is to speak at the Art Association on Saturday morning on "Some Aspects of the Philippine Problem."

A survey of steel requirements for all purposes in 1941 just completed by the committee on commercial research of the American Iron and Steel Institute places at 80,000,000 net tons of steel ingots the total demand that will be placed upon the industry.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3George Montgomery and Alice Faye will play the leads in Twentieth Century-Fox's "My Gal Sal," Theodore Dreiser's screen adaptation of his own work, "My Brother Paul," the studio announced today. The picture is scheduled to go before the cameras Oct. 6, and Montgomery will play Paul Dreiser, Dreiser's brother, who was the subject of "My Brother Paul."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was glad to read in THE TIMES the story from Santiago, Chile, quoting Benjamin Claro Velasco to the effect that good-will envoys sent by this country are hindering rather than helping the Good Neighbor policey of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A broad program to aid construction of strategic roads in the United States, the Inter-American Highway and two militarily important roads in Panama through the granting of high preference ratings which help in getting materials was outlined today by the Priorities Division of the Office of Production Management.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 3 (AP) -- With the favored Wise Bee wheeling and eliminating himself right at the start, Anthony Pupino's Charm Bracelet, a 4-to-l shot, went on today to win Narragansett Park's Mattapoisett Purse.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Hurtled into an overtime struggle on the wings of Tommy Henrich's twenty-seventh homer, the Yankees jammed through another tally in the eleventh inning to vanquish the Red Sox, 2 to 1, today and advanced to a position from which they may clinch the American League pennant within the next twenty-four hours.

The trial of sixteen members of an alleged German spy ring was begun yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn before Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury of nine men and three women. To the surprise of all, the jury, with two alternates, was completed in three hours and twenty-five minutes.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

The Buffalo Forge Company of Buffalo, N.Y., announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 115,120 shares of common stock. The shares, to be sold by the company and some of its large stockholders, will amount to approximately 35 per cent of the 324,786 shares to be outstanding upon completion of the financing.

Serious attention deserves to be paid to the medical phase of the civilian defense program. The plan announced by Dr. George Baehr, Chief Medical Officer of the Office of Civilian Defense, depends on the voluntary cooperation of State agencies, local public health services and the privately endowed hospitals.
After two years of war political, economic and psychological factors give certain advantages to both sides.

The cotton futures market had an erratic session yesterday as prices on the New York Cotton Exchange, establishing both their high and low marks early in the day, eased off and closed with net gains of 12 to 16 points in the active months.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- A "strongish" formation of British bombers attacked Berlin last night, drawing terrific anti-aircraft fire which shook buildings, rattled windows and all but drowned out the roar of the motors over the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Expansion of the civilian defense program to afford scope for the activities of every man and woman in the country was predicted by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at her press conference today.

The New York Giants were loaded to the gunwales for the Eastern College All-Stars in the sixth edition of The Tribune Fresh Air Fund football game at the Polo Grounds last night. Beaten a year ago and smarting under that setback for twelve long months, the professionals made the 1941 collegians pay heavily for the indignities that the 1940 heroes handed them.

Advertising linage in eight New York newspapers made the best gain of the year last month, when the total rose 8.1 per cent over the like 1940 month, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Six papers registered increases while two had small losses.

The Brock Pemberton office announced yesterday the postponement to an indefinite date of the opening of the new Parker W. Fennelly comedy, "Two Story House." A spokesman for Mr. Pemberton said the premiere, scheduled for next Tuesday at the Morosco, would be delayed "at least a week."

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Spiteful, a game 4-year-old filly owned by T.B. McGrath of Chicago, was a handy winner of the $2,500 added two-mile and a half Great Western Handicap at Washington Park today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- A proposed 1942 budget for White Plains that would be $34,594 below the 1941 appropriation and provide a substantial reduction in taxes on residences was announced today by city officials. Most of the reduction in taxes, however, would result from a $7,797,662 cut in assessed valuations already effected.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has leased from 60 Wall Tower, Inc., two entire floors in the building at 70 Pine Street, comprising about 50,000 square feet of floor space, through Horace S. Ely Co.

Four boys and two young men were accused yesterday by Brooklyn police of having conducted such a profitable burglary business during the last three months that they were able to hire a truck at $9 a night to transport them from crime to crime, piling up their loot and disposing of it for cash.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Married men, men with higher education, those who are religious and others who hold office in several organizations and whose work is teaching, writing, selling or executive are better equipped to maintain morale in time of economic stress, according to Professor Goodwin Watson of Teachers College, Columbia University.
Favorites came home at Aqueduct yesterday in almost routine fashion, six of them scoring in the eight races, including the featured Black Maria Purse, where Petrify was first.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Skippers of the home club carried off a full measure of the first day's honors as a fleet of seventy-seven took part in the opening of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's ninth annual Fall race series today.

Fall openings of Uptown Retail Guild stores presenting original designs continued yesterday with showings by Bonwit Teller and Milgrim. Today Saks Fifth Avenue will present its collection. Hattie Carnegie will show on Monday.

A good share of the apartment leasing reported yesterday covered suites in West Side buildings. Eighty new tenants were added to the roster of Castle Village, several of them former residents of New York suburbs.

What Kerensky Did Berlin now calls President Roosevelt another "Kerensky" whose mission it is to prepare the way for bolshevism, in the United States. But there was a time when Berlin and bolshevism were working hand in hand against a real Kerensky.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 3 -- James B. Carey, national secretary of the C.I.O., was ousted from the presidency of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America today, after delegates to the organization's seventh national convention had rejected his appeal for condemnation of communism, nazism and fascism.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- A prediction by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that wheat prices might advance 10 cents a bushel further as a result of the large volume of cash grain that is going into the Federal loan stock had an emphatic reflection in the market here today and all deliveries on the Board of Trade advanced to new high marks for the season, with the close at about the top for the day.

Thanks to Carl Allensworth's "Village Green," which opened at Henry Miller's last evening, a new theatrical season has begun and Frank Craven is back on Broadway. Although a new theatrical season is worth counting among life's frugal blessings, it does not outrank the best pants-pocket actor in the business.

OXFORD UNIVERSITY PRESS publishes this morning what looks like and doubtless is, Hands down, the soundest and most valuable single volume of its particular nature ever issued: "The Oxford Companion to American Literature,"* by James D. Hart of the English Department of the University of California.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- So successful was the inaugural husband-and-wife championship sponsored by the Westchester Golf Association at the Bonnie Briar Club today that husbands and wives were clamoring for more when the event was concluded.

Attorney General John J. Bennett began an investigation yesterday into the affairs of five men, three of them with criminal records, who operated from suites in fashionable hotels during the last two months, to commit alleged stock frauds.

Two new pictures will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's "When Ladies Meet" will be the newcomer at the Capitol. The remake of the Rachel Crothers comedy-drama features Joan Crawford, Robert Taylor, Greer Garson, Herbert Marshall and Spring Byington . . .

"I'll believe what I hear about a letter to me from President Roosevelt when I see the letter," said 73-year-old Sam Coher. of the Bronx yesterday. "I think it's wonderful he should write to me now when he has so many other troubles to think about, but I only know what my children have told me."

LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Britons were told authoritatively today that the Battle of the Atlantic "is not going too badly" for them, and that Germany's campaign against Soviet Russia had closed the largest gap in the British blockade of the Continent.

The Football Rules Committee's decision last Winter to allow unlimited substitutions presented to Steve Owen, the stout fellow who coaches the New York Giants, an opportunity that will not come up again, once the gridiron campaign gets under way.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge Baltzell today held George A. Ball, financier, of Muncie, Ind., and his co-defendants liable in a $6,000,000 damage suit entered by Rodney P. Lien, Ohio's Bank Superintendent and liquidating agent of the Union Trust Company of Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Roosevelt named a five-man mission today to represent the United States in a three-power conference at Moscow to implement the program to "crush Hitler" by providing Anglo-American aid to Russia.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 3 (AP ) -- Johnny Lindelt, ace Newark righthander, chalked up his twelfth straight and his twenty-third triumph of the season tonight as the Newark Bears defeated Jersey City, 4 -- 2, in the final home appearance of the season for the Little Giants.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Sept. 3 -- While Europe is locked in a death struggle and Japan and America are bandying platitudes Japan's Kwantung Army in Manchukuo is rushing preparations for what seems likely to be all-out war against Soviet Siberian forces.

Americans who want to defeat totalitarianism but who refuse to buy defense bonds because they dislike the Administration's fiscal policy were warned yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie that circumstances much more disastrous than being in debt might arise if the defense program was delayed.

Small rayon converters were assured last night that the Office of Price Administration is not only interested in their inability to obtain rayon greige goods, but also is prepared to take action to remedy the situation.
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 3 -- Firmness continued on the Stock Exchange here today after some initial hesitancy, but with an increasing turnover.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 4 -- Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye warned his countrymen yesterday that Japan "faces the gravest emergency in her history." He made this admonition in a statement read to a meeting of Cabinet Ministers and financial and industrial leaders held under auspices of the Imperial Rule Assistance Association to promote closer collaboration between government and business.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The N.Y.U. football squad had its first taste of contact work in a three-hour drill today which also included assaults on the charging machine and tackling dummy. In the afternoon the group practiced punting, forward passing and new formations.

Thousands of shoppers at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street yesterday at 1:20 P.M. were horrified when a young woman secretary leaped to her death from the twelfth floor of 1 West Forty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- American shipyards will turn out 130 to 134 merchant ships this year, or 25 per cent more than was estimated as possible in May, according to figures made public today by Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission.

The stock market's greeting to September at its advent, which many in Wall Street had felt would find further reflection in volume and price enhancement, proved yesterday to be a one-day affair, for the share list returned to its familiar narrow movements.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Two of the six scheduled races to decide the national women's sailing championship were held today by the American Yacht Club and the Riverside Club's Long Island Sound representative crew won both of them.

Sales of fur skins by members of the American Fur Merchants Association totaled $40,033,546 for the first eight months of the present wholesale season (through July), compared with $27,148,510 in the same period of last year, an increase of 47 per cent, according to figures issued yesterday by the association.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Nearly 13,000 enlisted men of the Forty-fourth Division's total of 16,600 are eligible for release from Federal service by Dec. 31 under the War Department's recent priority rulings, according to results of a survey, announced at division headquarters today.

Fall Clothing Sells Well A brisk response to the new Fall lines of men's clothing this week was reported yesterday by retail store executives. Specialty shops reported particularly good activity, with school clothing, of course, providing a major share of the business.

Soldiers and sailors on leave in this area are making greater use of the recreational and information service provided by special committees, it was announced yesterday during a broadcast in which volunteer civilian and Army and Navy officials participated.

Chilean economy is being affected crucially by United States enforcement of its "blacklist," according to Maximiano Errazuriz, conservative Chilean Senator, who arrived here yesterday on the liner Copiapo of the Chilean Line. Senator Errazuriz said he would be here two months and expected to confer with United States authorities to seek reconsideration of the enforcement.

Representative Hamilton Fish, isolationist leader, declared yesterday that he did not believe there was any reason for an Eastern seaboard shortage of petroleum products, characterizing it as "phony" and "a part of the program to spread war hysteria."

General Eleazar Lopez Contreras, who was President of Venezuela from 1936 until May of this year after succeeding Juan Vicente Gomez, dictator of his country for twenty-six years, arrived here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Paula to study United States defense measures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Three minutes after hearing nearly six hours' of testimony, aiming to prove Francis Biddle as Acting Attorney General responsible for the alleged tapping of Harry Bridges's telephone in a Newport hotel, the Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of Mr. Biddle as Attorney General.

Dandelion greens -- those unsung heroes of the world of food -- have recently made a revolutionary appearance in the grocery department of a dignified city store, neatly packaged in tins that bear the label of a distinguished Back Bay Boston firm of gentlemen grocers.
VICHY, France, Sept. 3 -- The Ministry of Supplies is still wrestling with the problem of equitable distribution of foodstuffs and repression of Black Markets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Senate began, consideration today of the defense tax bill estimated to yield $3,679,800,000 and bring the nation's tax revenue to a record total of $13,305,330,000 annually by adopting numerous noncontroversial amendments proposed by the Senate Finance Committee, but deferring action on other changes made in the House version of the measure.

In Robert Bridges, a kind of historical figure makes its exit from the literary stage of New York, a little dimmed because his generation is mostly gone. To the surviving elders who remember his work in the youth of Life in the hands of John Ames Mitchell and Edward S. Martin, he is an old-friend lost.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Dairy Farmers Union, after long debate, today endorsed in part a declaration of principles under which five producer groups concurred last Monday in a government-proposed price increase for milk shipped to the New York City market.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will open a three-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on Oct. 9, S. Hurok, manager of the company, announced yesterday. Contrary to custom, matinees will be given only on Saturdays but there will be performances every evening including Sundays.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Miss Edna Morton of Shelter Rock successfully defended her metropolitan junior girls' golf championship today by carding nines of 42 and 41 for an 83 on the hilly Essex Fells Country Club course.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, the British Ambassador, today told the Russian people that their "magnificent successes" of the past ten weeks had shattered Adolf Hitler's hopes of a swift victory paving the way for a conquest of Britain and the United States.

The Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., announced yesterday that it had asked twelve national business leaders to "lead a nationwide campaign unifying a spirit of high morale between civilians and the armed forces of the United States."

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Phillips Lounsbery, stockbroker associated with the firm of Gude, Winmill Co., 1 Wall Street, New York, was found dead this morning on the lawn beside his home on Succabone Road here, killed by the discharge of a shotgun that was near his body.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (U.P) -- The United States is engaged in negotiating currency stabilization agreements with Mexico, Colombia and Ecuador as part of the economic war against Germany, authoritative quarters disclosed tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 -- Johnny Lanning tonight set back the Reds with one really damaging blow, a seventh-inning homer by Ernie Lombardi with a mate on base, as the Pirates beat Cincinnati, 3 to 2, in the opening game of a crucial series with third place jin the National League standings at stake.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So much is currently said about preserving "the American way of life" that I have wondered if some one could define this popular phrase so that the world may know just what it is we desire to preserve.

Russia is inquiring for large tonnages of almost all types of American steel, and barrel stock for Russian oil drums has received an A-l-A priority. This material, allocated to several sheet mills in the United States, constitutes a "rush shipment," according to the magazine Iron Age, which notes that steel producers are endeavoring to move sufficient steel to meet requirements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Contracts totaling $3,462,153 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

The United States Government is spending about $2,000,000 daily for foods for shipment to Britain under the lease-lend legislation and, with the record for safe arrival thus far unexpectedly good, greatly increased food supplies are likely to be asked by Britain, according to an analysis of the lend-lease food situation prepared by the American Institute of Food Distribution from confidential sources.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Navy Department reported today that in the eight months since Jan. 1 "a total of 213 vessels of all classes were completed or placed in active service," in its progress toward a two-ocean fleet.

So far retailers throughout the country have not experienced freight congestion or embargoes, but the real test of the shipping situation will probably come next month when the peak of holiday shipments to the stores is reached, according to reports yesterday in retail traffic circles.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- The bridge, tea and fashion show given this afternoon at the Maidstone Club for the benefit of the East Hampton Settlement House brought several hundred people to the clubhouse on the dunes. Mrs. William Tod Helmuth Jr. headed the committee planning the affair.

Trading was uneven with certain cuts exceptionally active and others slow. Prices were irregular. Steer hinds and ribs were barely steady. Veal and calf hindsaddles were steady and some salesmen were asking higher prices. Lamb carcasses were unchanged in price but some lamb cuts were higher and others lower.

Arrival here yesterday of approximately $500,000 of gold bars from Chile was reported unofficially. The metal, which arrived on the passenger ship Copiapo of the Chilean Line, was one of the largest single shipments from Chile in recent months, although Chile has shipped gold here frequently.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 2:

Federal Reserve Expansion It appears that the steadily expanding "wartime" activities of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York have made necessary the acquisition of more office space than is available in the massive Federal Reserve Building in Liberty Street and in the bank's annex at 95 Maiden Lane.

Philosophers would have us know that education, within reasonable bounds, is a great thing, and there must be a lot in what they say, for here it is two weeks since the United States Fish and Wildlife Service made public its 1941 rules and regulations for duck shooting, and hardly a complaint has arrived on our desk.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- The Women's Christian Temperance Union, pledging continuance of its fight to outlaw liquor, asked the Army and Congress today to ban the sale of beer in the Army camps.

The sale of $1,037,000,000 of taxanticipation notes in August, the first month in which they were offered, marks a striking success for this new type of Treasury offering. On the basis of this experience it is calculated that the Treasury may take in as much as $6,000,000,000 to $8,000,000,000 through this means in the current fiscal year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Mr. Terzian was recognized as an outstanding authority on the production of carbureted and blue water gas, and spent nearly thirty years in operation and development work in the gas industry.

Although the American oil companies have not been officially informed concerning the proposed liquidation of their claims against the Mexican Government, they have learned that the tentative agreement provides that they receive a token payment of $9,000,000 in cash.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 -- Although most observers fail to read any deep significance into the desultory patrolling, raiding and artillery fighting now going on around Tobruk and the Cyrenaican border, they agree that there is at least one more really big battle due in the Western Desert.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "For Skeptical Youth" opened up one of the widest possible fields for discussion -- the youth question. However, since TIMES space is limited, I, as a young American, would like to answer two points.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- For the first time since the invasion of Russia began on June 22, it is possible in Berlin tonight to construct from German reports a composite picture of the approximate status of the operations on the extensive Eastern Front south of Lake Ladoga.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 4 -- Tensely awaiting the approach of a United States tanker with gasoline for Russia, the Japanese nation heard a solemn warning from Premier Prince Konoye tonight. It was the first public statement of the Premier since July 30 and came as leaders of Tohokai, extreme nationalist political group, threw their support to proposals for establishment of an ocean safety zone around Japan.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Edwin F. Smith, Jersey City lawyer, died here today in his Summer home after a three-month illness. Mr. Smith also had a home at 88 Bentley Avenue, Jersey City. He was a member there of the law firm of Edwards, Smith Dawson, 1 Exchange Place.

HAVANA, Sept. 3 -- Cuban sugar circles here today reported that Cuba had only a little over 100,000 tons of sugar available from, this year's crop after a Presidential decree releasing sufficient sugar to cover an increase in quota allotment granted to Cuba last week by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Describing the means by which the Administration Building at La Guardia Field is being prevented from sinking into the "filled" soil that comprises a large part of the airport, Major Elmer Haslett, director of the airport, and Chief Engineer Joseph A. Meehan declared yesterday that they were unable to predict when the building would become stable.

Lester V. Berrey and Melvin Van den Bark have completed after many years of work their "American Thesaurus of Slang." It will be published in November by Crowell, which originally published in this country "Roget's International Thesaurus."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Roosevelt created today the Office of Health Defense and Welfare Services in the Office for Emergency Management. He issued a proclamation detailing the functions of the agency. Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, was named as director.

A mounting list of alleged forgeries on primary petitions for John R. Davies, opponent of Mayor La Guardia for the Republican nomination, was revealed yesterday by the third handwriting expert called at hearings before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora in the action brought by the New York and Kings County Republican Committees to rule Mr. Davies off the ballot.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 4 -- Berlin rocked under the impact of British bombs Tuesday night when squadrons of the most powerful Royal Air Force craft dropped tons of high explosives through gaps in the clouds on the German capital.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Governor Charles Edison disclosed at the Little White House here today that an extensive investigation of the entire tax structure in New Jersey has been under way at his behest for several months. Recent enactment of the railroad tax compromise laws, which are about to receive a court test of their constitutionality, was only one result of the inquiry into the complicated State tax problem.

In what was generally regarded as the last month of practically "unhampered" production in the major electrical appliance field, sales of refrigerators and ranges in July continued their substantial gains over 1940, passing even the average increase for the first six months of the year.

Investigators who have found themselves involved in the precise dilemmas they set out to study and solve for the USO-Y.W.C.A. program, will pool their experiences during the next two days at national headquarters of the Y.W.C.A., 600 Lexington Avenue, where seven women from both coasts will meet to map their future course.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Securities carried at $410,042,996 on the balance sheet of the Electric Bond and Share Company on June 30 had a market value on that date of only $59,500,000. Despite this, however, the preferred stock of the company still has a coverage of cash and cash items amounting to about $140 a share, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Charges that an American citizen of German descent and education had come to this country a year and a half ago and formed a compact but highly efficient military espionage agency for the German Government were made by a Federal grand jury here yesterday and were admitted immediately by the three young persons accused of helping the "master spy."

COME what may in the National League race, Larry MacPhail made the "beau geste" of baseball yesterday when interested parties were sitting around Judge Landis, planning for a world series in October. If the Dodgers bob up as the opponents of the Yankees, the home games of the Brooklyn club will be played on Brooklyn soil.

Representatives of the leading fuel oil companies in New York suggested to Grover A. Whalen yesterday that heating oil be conserved by cutting the temperature of homes, offices and factories from 70 to 65 degrees and by prolonging Christmas and Easter vacations in the public schools, at the same time lengthening daily school hours.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Five thousand manufacturers in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine have Been invited by the Massachusetts Committee for National Defense to attend an all-day defense subcontracting clinic at Worcester, Mass., on Sept. 18.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 4 -- Maintaining their unremitting pressure on the central battle front, troops of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's western army continued advances in certain salients -- which unconfirmed reports situate between the Gomel and Smolensk regions -- driving back the Nazis more than thirty miles at one point.

In the Battle for Britain and the Battle of the Atlantic the British have been fighting a defensive action. Lacking numerical parity with Goering's Luftwaffe, or sufficient small patrol vessels to protect their convoys properly, about all they could hope for was to keep their sea lanes open and war industries going.

UNITED STATES Washington, D.C. MEDICAL, OFFICER, ASSOCIATE MEDICAL OFFICER, SENIOR MEDICAL OFFICER, $3,200 to $4,600 a year. While graduation from a Class A medical school and completion of interneship are general requirements for the associate grade, under the terms of the new announcement persons who are now serving their interneship may apply.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Splitting double-headers with the cellar tenants of the National League makes for exactly no progress, and that's what Leo Durocher's pennant-chasing Dodgers did today with the Phillies. Thus, with the first-place Cardinals rained out, the runner-up Brooks lost a bit of ground and now are four points out of the lead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The civilian use of crude rubber in the United States probably will be restricted until the situation in the Pacific is clarified, and, meanwhile, a shortage of domestic supplies is expected to be felt this month for the first time, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week again reached a new high figure of 4,004,700 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was an increase of 29.250 barrels over the 3,975,450 daily in the previous week.

With the American League pennant all but clinched by the Yankees, the inaugural game of the 1941 world series will be played at the Stadium Wednesday afternoon, Oct. 1. This was determined officially yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt, presided over by Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Thousands of civilians along the Eastern coast will be called on next month to scan the skies for "enemy" aircraft when the Air Force Combat Command tests its defenses against air raids.
