While graduation from a Class A medical school and completion of interneship are general requirements for the associate grade, under the terms of the new announcement persons who are now serving their interneship may apply.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Splitting double-headers with the cellar tenants of the National League makes for exactly no progress, and that's what Leo Durocher's pennant-chasing Dodgers did today with the Phillies. Thus, with the first-place Cardinals rained out, the runner-up Brooks lost a bit of ground and now are four points out of the lead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The civilian use of crude rubber in the United States probably will be restricted until the situation in the Pacific is clarified, and, meanwhile, a shortage of domestic supplies is expected to be felt this month for the first time, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week again reached a new high figure of 4,004,700 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was an increase of 29.250 barrels over the 3,975,450 daily in the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Thousands of civilians along the Eastern coast will be called on next month to scan the skies for "enemy" aircraft when the Air Force Combat Command tests its defenses against air raids.
NEW YORK Mrs. Leland Harrison, wife of the United States Minister to Switzerland, is at the Plaza.

Whether Townsend Harris High School, ordered liquidated by Mayor La Guardia, would admit entering students this Fall remained in doubt yesterday as Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga reserved decision on a motion brought by a group of parents of prospective students and by teachers of the school to hold the Board of Higher Education in contempt.
For the second time in the National League's feverish pennant race this season the Dodgers have been rained into first place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Led by marked increases in prices for farm products and processed foods, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' commodity index of nearly 900 wholesale price series advanced 0.7 per cent in the last week in August.

Grim, but Normal In the matter of holiday fatalities we have not been quite fair to Labor Day, 1941, and in particular to the Labor Day automobile. Not every reader who saw the figure of 576 holiday deaths in his newspaper went on to that part of the story which gave 385 as the number of automobile fatalities.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Playing most of the day in a drenching rain, members of the New York Stock Exchange Golf Association held today their forty-fifth annual golf tournament and outing at the Glen Oaks Club here. Despite the weather, some good scores were posted,
Fall openings of stores presenting original designs continued for the third day yesterday with showings by Saks Fifth Avenue and Henri Bendel.

Floyd B. Odlum, chosen yesterday by President Roosevelt to direct the new Defense Contracts Distribution Division, heads as president of the Atlas Corporation, the largest investment company in the United States, with assets of more than $100,000,000 and interests in utilities, banking, transportation, real estate, retailing, the amusements and many manufactures.
The eleventh week of the Russian campaign comes to an end this week-end, with three to four weeks remaining before snow may commence to fall with some frequency along the northern battlefront.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The War Department awarded contracts totaling $11,024,524, it was announced today. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Senate voted by 43 to 23 today to approve the amendment of its Finance Committee to the defense tax bill lowering the personal income exemption from $2,000 to $1,500 for married persons and from $800 to $750 for single persons.
A twelve-room suite in the building at 1035 Fifth Avenue has been leased by Mrs. Donald B. Tansill through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Miss Lois Maclntyre of the Riverside Yacht Club, Long1 Island representative in the women's national sailing championship, retained the lead tonight in the series off the American Yacht Club, but only because the fourth race was declared no contest.

Nobody at the Hester Stables, one of the few remaining horse-for-hire places on the lower Bast Side, could offer any explanation for Willie's strange behavior yesterday morning. Cornelius Lyon, stable foreman, was positive Willie's genealogical tree showed no fire-horse relation.

High prelates of the Roman Catholic Church, several hundred priests and members of religious orders joined yesterday with 1,000 of the laity in commemorating the third anniversary of the death of Patrick Cardinal Hayes.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the dance recital given by Miss Theodora Roosevelt, granddaughter of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, and her partner, Alexander Iolas, tonight at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng in Halsey Neck Lane.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 4 -- A year ago it took three men to give Manhattan the equivalent of a triple-threat back. This season Herb Kopf has three triple-threats in the same backfield. So things are perking up for the Jaspers as they labor twice a day on the spacious fields of La Salle Military Academy.

A corporation headed by Abraham Fishkin has purchased from Mrs. Minna G. Werdermann the property known as 1235 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, improved with a one-family dwelling on a plot 260 by 150 feet, owned by the seller's family for more than forty years, according to Leicher Heney, Inc., who arranged the transaction.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Coach Mal Stevens had hoped for a respite today from the heat which engulfed the N.Y.U. football camp in the past four days, but he was hardly prepared for the heavy showers that washed out the afternoon drill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Pleasure was expressed today by Secretary Morgenthau over the action of the Senate in approving the establishment of a joint Congressional committee to study the reduction of non-defense expenditures.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate reduced income-tax exemptions:
BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 4 -- Since the campaign in Russia opened at the end of June there have been so many revisions of military judgments that additions to the list should not surprise.

Bank clearings for the last three weeks have been at a rate approximately two-fifths above the volume for the corresponding period a year ago. Heavy payments and settlements incident to the end of the month were largely responsible for keeping the volume for the week ended on Wednesday at a high level despite the Labor Day interruption.

The bond department of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company, St. Louis, has announced the appointment of Robert B. Ewin as Southwestern representative. His territory will include Southern Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Kansas.

Wendell L. Willkie has been nominated for one of six new directors of the Lehman Corporation to be elected at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on Oct. 15, it was announced yesterday by Robert Lehman, president of the investment trust.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A strong tone prevailed generally in the entire livestock market today. Hogs opened strong to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, but eased to steady to strong trading. Beef cattle were strong and in some instances 10 to 15 cents higher than yesterday. Spring lambs were strong to 15 cents up.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- The German High Command asserted today that in two years of war 13,088,283 tons of British shipping and shipping in the service of Great Britain had been sunk by the German Navy and Air Force. Included in this figure were the claims on British losses for last month, which the Germans set at 537,200 tons.

Guy Pearce Jones, author of the recently published "Two Survived" (Random House), sends word that he has heard from Robert Tapscott. Tapscott is today the sole living member of Mr. Jones's true sea story. With Wilbert Widdicombe, Tapscott spent seventy days in an open boat some months ago after their British freighter had been sunk by a German raider.

HARRISON, N.J., Sept. 4 -- The Atha plant of the Crucible Steel Company, which has about 4,000 employes and has been working on $5,000,000 worth of orders for steel casings and guns for the Army, Navy and British, was forced to shut down almost completely today by a walkout of about 600 crane operators, electricians and maintenance men.

Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday, after a public hearing at the Summer City Hall in Queens, the two Democrat-sponsored bills abolishing the offices of county Sheriff and county Register, effective Jan. 1, 1942. His action paved the way to have the bills submitted to a referendum vote at the November election.
LONDON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Operations of Merck Co. and subsidiaries in the first six months of this year resulted in net earnings of $4,775,407 before allowances for taxes and other adjustments, according to the report issued for publication today. After allowance for income and excess-profits taxes and other special reserves, net income was $1,591,073, equal to $1.45 a share on the outstanding common stock.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- Bulgaria has rejected German demands that she declare war on Russia but has declared her readiness to fight for Germany on any other front, diplomatic quarters said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Deliveries of military planes by manufacturers reached a peak of 1,854 in August, an increase of 394 airplanes in one month and more than three times the rate of delivery in August, 1940.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: New Yorkers will warmly applaud Borough President Isaacs's request for a public hearing on the demolition of the Aquarium at the Battery because of its proximity to the Manhattan terminus of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4 -- John Garfield and Warner Brother agreed on an armistice to their Summer-long fight today, and Garfield accepted the leading role in "Remember Tomorrow," for which Richard Whorf had previously been announced.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Senate non-interventionists said tonight that they did not consider the attack on the U.S.S. Greer likely to lead to war, but Senator McCarran commented:

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Rapid Robert Feller finally caught up with, his twenty-second pitching victory today by cashing in on a three-run tenth inning as the Indians defeated the Tigers, 7 to 6.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The validity of public opinion polls was challenged today before the American Psychological Association, meetingA at Northwestern University.
Trading in locally dressed meats was fair yesterday, steer beef was weak to lower; lamb, stronger, and fresh pork cuts steady to slightly higher. Other classes were steady.

GREENPORT, L.I., Sept. 4 -- A three-masted schooner, fugitive of the war, arrived here late last night after two years of fleeing from one European port to another to avoid possible bombing and destruction.

The cotton futures market continued its advance yesterday, although the rise was not so steep as that which marked sessions earlier this week. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange opened at their best levels for the day, with overnight gains of 6 to 9 points, and closed at net gains of 3 to 5 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- A submarine of undetermined nationality attacked the United States destroyer Greer this morning in the Atlantic on the way to Iceland, the Navy Department stated tonight. Torpedoes were fired at the vessel.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- New York City has been collecting taxes for forty years on twenty-four lots that actually are just across the city boundary line and in Mount Vernon, officials of this city contended today. The tax payments have amounted to $12,000 and the Mount Vernon officials said they intended to retrieve that amount from New York and do the future collecting of the taxes from the property owners.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- More than 700 Germans in the German legation compound at suburban Shimran today threatened bitter resistance against any attempt to seize them "contrary to international law."

By a 14-to-4 vote the Board of Higher Education adopted at a special meeting yesterday a resolution to abolish Townsend Harris High School. In this way, it was hoped, the contempt action brought against the board by a group of parents of prospective students and by teachers of the school would be halted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- By a signed pledge, eleven leading oil companies promised tonight to ask for and to utilize all available railroad tank cars in an effort to alleviate the gasoline and fuel shortage in the Atlantic States.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "Sun Valley Serenade," starring Sonja Henie, which arrives at the Roxy, will be this morning's sole film newcomer to Broadway. The iceskating musical features Milton Berle, Lynn Bari, Joan Davis, the Nicholas Brothers and Glenn Miller and his orchestra....

BERLIN, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A German submarine commander said today that widespread patrol of the Atlantic by airplanes and British submarine chasers was making successful German submarine operations difficult.

G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, polo-playing steeplechase star, suffered a blow at Aqueduct yesterday, but it was a zephyr tap compared to the shock to the form players who backed the entry of Cottesmore and Sussex to odds-on and then saw them finish far back of Bath, who captured the 53,775 Harbor Hill Steeplechase in record time for the track.

Republican organization leaders of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Richmond turned out in force yesterday afternoon for the formal opening of the campaign headquarters for the renomination of Mayor La Guardia, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, at the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The pennant-pursuing Cardinals were knocked out of the National League leadership today when they dropped a pair of heartbreaking games to the Cubs, 3 to 0, and 4 to 3. The second game went eleven innings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The plan of George P. Rea, president of the New York Curb Exchange, for erecting dealer markets on the existing stock exchanges, was presented formally today to the Securities and Exchange Commission at the request of its proponent after the plan had been discussed at previous conferences with members of the commission's staff.

A considerable division of opinion still exists among producers with respect to advancing the $4.75 dress range to $5.50, despite the move toward adoption of the higher quotation some two weeks ago, it was indicated yesterday following a meeting of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Jooss Ballet, after an absence from Manhattan since the Spring of 1938, will open a limited engagement at the Maxine Elliott Theatre on Sept. 22, it was announced yesterday by the company's manager, Rombout van Reemsdyke of All Arts Productions, Inc. After the first week there will be no Monday evening performances, the troupe appearing on Sunday evenings instead.

Antipathies between the permanent populations in towns that overnight have become focal points for military or defense concentrations and the influx of newcomers who may be munitions workers, trainees or trainees, families, are being slowly dispelled -- but there still is need for a vast amount of reconciliation work in that field.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

On the Chicago grain market, wheat for September delivery rose yesterday to $1.16 per bushel. This was the highest price reached since July, 1937, when four years of short wheat crops had brought the country's unsold surplus to the lowest in ten years. This price of wheat compared with 73 1/4 cents in February; yet the present year's crop is estimated the third largest in the country's history.

Argentina has hopes of retaining its newly developed market for cheese in the United States and of expanding its sales considerably in the future, Dr. Enrique L. Yalour, director of the dairy division of the Argentine Ministry of Agriculture, advised importers here yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Argentine-American Chamber of Commerce at India House.
VICHY, France, Sept. 4 -- A German Army sergeant was shot at in Paris last night near the Gare de I'Est. He suffered only a superficial wound in the shoulder. He was unable to identify his assailant.

An over-all plan looking toward corporate simplification and geographic rearrangement of the Laclede Gas Light Company's system was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Missouri Public Service Commission by Laclede's parent, the Ogden Corporation, successor organization to the defunct Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

Colors Lead Coat Reorders The trend toward colors is now gaming marked headway in reorders for cloth coats, which are running well over last year at this time. The favor for colors is unusual for so early in the season, as black ordinarily has a strong lead.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, today extended to the United States Congress an invitation for any of its members who are critical of the use being made of lease-lend material sent to Britain or any other Americans interested to come here and see for themselves.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The text of President Roosevelt's explanation of the new OPM Division of Contract Distribution and his Executive Order establishing it were as follows:

Senator D. Worth Clark of Idaho, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee which is to investigate alleged war propaganda in the motion pictures, has denied that the inquiry is a witch hunt. Perhaps that is the wrong term. But the circumstances surrounding the setting up of this inquiry are such that it can make no pretense of being unprejudiced.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Joseph E. Widener's Jezebel II led practically all the way in the Yo Tambien purse at Washington Park today to win the mile race for 3-year-olds in the sharp time of 1:36 3-5.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- All deliveries of grain and soy beans, except September corn, sold today at new seasonal high prices as a result of general buying by commission houses. While the markets were called upon to absorb liberal profit-taking and some hedging sales, grains finished well toward the top.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $1,000,000 of construction bonds of the Chicago, Ill., Sanitary District on a bid of 102.029 for 2 1/4 s. The bonds, dated Sept. 1, 1941, and maturing on July 1, 1961, but callable from Jan. 1, 1943 to 1961, were reoffered at prices to yield 0.50 to 2.10 per cent, according to the call dates.

The big British war transport Empress of Asia docked here yesterday with 393 passengers from the battlefronts of the Near East, the first ship of her kind to come here from Suez since the war spread to that part of the world.

If the banking fraternity does its job well and maintains the ideal of making public service an integral part of private enterprise, public opinion will insist that banking remain a private enterprise, Leston P. Faneuf, assistant vice president of the Marine Midland Group, Inc., of Buffalo, told members of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the chapter's annual Consuls Dinner last night at the Hotel Abbey, 149 West Fifty-first Street.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 3 -- On the second anniversary of the war House of Representatives today renewed New Zealand's pledges to Britain to make all efforts to aid in the defeat of the forces ranged against free peoples and expressed admiration for the achievements of New Zealand's air, land and sea forces.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Following are excerpts from the text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech today at the Lord Mayor's luncheon in honor of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada:
ROME, Sept. 4 -- The last legal access the Italians had to foreign news was closed today when the Italian Government barred all foreign newspapers from Italy.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $5,800,000 of New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad equipment trust certificates, receiving the award on their bid of 100.389 for 2 1/8 s, an interest-cost basis to the railroad of 2.05 per cent.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Texas and the Pelicans are to open play a week from Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club in the season's major polo event, the national open tournament. This became known tonight as rain washed away the test matches scheduled for teams preparing for the championship.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Professional golf's story-telling "gamboleer" -- fast-shooting, fast-talking Leonard Dodson of Kansas City -- did a record-smashing job as he stole the show today in the opening act of the year's richest tournament -- the $11,000 Tam O'Shanter open.

Class I Railways Reports for June of 137 Class I railways to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed an aggregate net income of $52,800,181, against $7,617,507 in June, 1940. This was after charges, which, in the case of railroads in receivership or bankruptcy, are not being paid and as a result of reorganization will not be paid.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- With another demonstration of their versatility in smashing records, the "riddled' Yankees completed the task of riddling the remainder of the American League today by vanquishing the Red Sox, 6 to 3, and thereby clinching the 1941 pennant of the Will Harridge loop.

New York City dress contractors will receive increases in "floor cost" payments retroactive to Aug. 20 of from one cent on garments wholesaling at $2.87 or less, up to 13 per cent on garments selling from $16.75 up, under a decision made yesterday by Harry Uviller, impartial chairman of the dress industry.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., New York, yesterday was named defendant in the first of a series of price maintenance actions through, which William Jameson Co., Inc., distributors of House of Lords and King's Ransom Scotches, expects to enforce observance of a uniform resale price level in the metropolitan market.

WASHINGTON Sept. 4 -- A high Administration source indicated tonight that Congress would be asked "within the next three months" to amend the Neutrality Act to permit United States merchant vessels to enter the ports of belligerent nations.

Price restrictions on the $30,000,000 issue of 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company were removed at the close of business yesterday by Glore, Forgan Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., who together headed the underwriting, syndicate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt authorized today the first lease-lend aid to the Polish government-in-exile, declaring that the "gallant resistance" of Polish forces was "vital to the defense of the United States."

The centennial season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society will open on Thursday night, Oct. 9, with Leopold Stokowski conducting a program featuring Reethoven's Fifth symphony, which was the chief number of the orchestra's initial concert on Dec. 7, 1842.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The American tanker L.P. St. Clair, with the first cargo of gasoline destined for the Soviet Union under the program of aid for Russia, has arrived safely at Vladivostok, the State Department was advised today.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Following are excerpts from the text of Canadian Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King's address at the Lord Mayor's luncheon in his honor today:

Characterizing the Supreme Court of the United States during the first four years of his Administration as "a dead hand" laid upon his whole program of progress, President Rooseevlt in the issue of Collier's out today explains his attempt to enlarge the court, asserting that up to 1937 the court had not permitted the Federal Government to function as the people had voted for it to function.

Now that the hardwoods are beginning to show a slight change in color, a number of hunters seem to be getting that ailment known as "itching feet," and, according to several letters just received, the only cure for this ailment is a trip to some spot where there is no subway.

Use of a section of the Lehigh Valley Railroad pier at Claremont Terminal, N.J., for loading of explosives on ships has been approved by the government and loading already is under way there, it was learned yesterday from Captain John S. Baylis of the Coast Guard, who is Captain of the Port.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Much of the South's cotton is reported to be going into government loans although borrowing values now are under the rising market quotations. Farmers who believe the staple will go well above parity price by next Spring will take advantage of the loan offer, A.L. Roberts, government cotton economist, said today.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 4 -- President Fulgrencia Batista, celebrating the eighth anniversary of the "sergeants' revolt" that placed him in command of Cuba's armed forces, today reviewed the work of his government since its inauguration last October.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Young Ho Kown, 37-year-old Chinese cook, of 633 West 155th Street, dished up an aeronautical potpourri here today, an "aircraft-dirigible-helicopter." Nothing like it has been seen here since Bonnie's Gull, with flapping wings, crashed ten years ago, killing its inventor.

An encouraging report of actual savings in gasoline already made by one company, with the prospect of possible further reductions, was presented to Grover Whalen yesterday by representatives of New York City's 11,809 taxicabs.

IN THE FIELD WITH THE SIXTH ARMY CORPS, Sept. 4 -- Forty thousand Sixth Army Corps troops were occupying defensive positions tonight after an afternoon of intensive reconnaissance by land and air units as the third phase of New England's largest war games neared a climax.
FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Setting up of another air unit to be stationed at Fort Dix was announced here today upon receipt of orders from the War Department.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Anti-Communist forces in the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., suffered a new rebuff at the union's seventh national convention today when they sought unsuccessfully to have the organization's official publication, The UE News, censored as "communistic."

THE pendulum swings widely in two of the books we have been reading this week. Guglielmo Ferrero's "The Reconstruction of Europe," which will be reviewed here tomorrow, D.V., elaborates a theory about Talleyrand's work and its importance for our day, that is somewhat at variance with the usual historic conception of that man of many devices.

Fifty children gave their version of a corn-husking contest on the garden rooftop of the Children's Aid Society West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, at an old-fashioned Harvest Festival yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The War Department soon will ask Congress for a supplemental appropriation of about $1,000,000,000 to finance new contracts for the production of tanks, anti-tank weapons and anti-aircraft equipment.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- A new world order based on freedom can be effected only through the wholehearted cooperation of the British Commonwealth and the United States, Premier W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada declared today at a luncheon given in his honor by the Lord Mayor of the City of London and attended by Prime Minister Winston Churchill of the United Kingdom.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current emergency requires increased national revenue. Most of the proposals in the current revenue bill involve greater burdens upon the taxpayer. However, there is one exception. It concerns the capital gains tax, which could produce an additional one hundred million to four hundred million dollars.

Cotton will have the greatest promotional fund in its history in 1942, as a result of pledges from companies handling more than 90 per cent of the nation's crop to contribute 5 cents a bale to the National Cotton Council's budget, Oscar Johnston, president of the council, announced yesterday.

KINGS PARK, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Legislators, State officials, county and town officials of Suffolk and Nassau Counties, hundreds altogether, as well as most of the villagers of Kings Park, paid final tribute to State Senator George L. Thompson this afternoon in the Methodist Church here at a funeral service conducted by the pastor, the Rev. Noel H. Cardwell, and the rector of St. James Episcopal Church, the Rev. Joseph Mills.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 3:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt's recent reorganization of the nation's defense machinery through creation of the Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board was described today as "a faltering step forward" by Bernard M. Baruch, chairman of the War Industries Board of the first World War.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- New teeth were put in the Administration's price control moves today when Mayor La Guardia, as president of the United States Conference of Mayors, appealed to municipal executives throughout the country to revoke municipal business licenses of firms which persistently violate price control ceilings as fixed by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Army set an arbitrary "age ceiling" today for officers of all ranks serving in the field with troops in a further step to revitalize its forces in keeping with the physical demands made on men By modern warfare.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William M.V. Hoffman of Tuxedo Park are at the St. Regis.

Consolation for budget watchers is to be found in the market places this week-end. A halt has been called -- at least for the time being -- in the advance of many food prices and most cuts of meat are still wearing their last week's price tags.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- With old surpluses melting away under increasing domestic and British demands, the Department of Agriculture will announce in a few days details of a 1942 farm program which is designed to provide the country with the largest supply of food ever produced in a single year.

A client of Smith Isaacs, attorneys, has purchased from Betty Kucharsky and Sarah Chertok the five-story walk-up apartment house at 1567 Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, paying cash above mortgages of $43,000. There are 122 rooms in the house, which is divided into twenty suites producing an annual rental of about $11,200.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 4 -- Stock trading here showed a divided aspect today; Netherlands Indians were firm, industrials were depressed. A general reaction set in toward the close. Royal Dutch was active at 2 3/4 points higher at 299 1/4; Amsterdam Rubber gained 2 to 301 1/2; Amsterdam Trading 2 to 465.

From the spectators' view, at least, the Football Rules Committee has done the gridiron game no favor in changing the official college code to permit unlimited substituting. This was painfully apparent in Wednesday night's contest between the New York Giants and the Eastern College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds.

Although the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange topped the half-million-share mark yesterday, eclipsing the Tuesday's total, the stick market was sluggish, with sufficient offerings on the trading floor to offset the continued leadership of the aviation issues.
CHICAGO, Sept 4 -- A collapse of the efforts to settle the wage dispute between the railroads and their 1,200,000 employes was predicted tonight in rail labor circles.

Myron C. Taylor departed for Rome yesterday aboard the Yankee Clipper to resume his post as President Roosevelt's personal representative at the Vatican, from which he returned several months ago because of a serious illness. Before leaving he issued a prepared statement in which he termed the President and Pope Pius XII "two symbols of civilization at its best."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Pirates, aided by rain, beat the Reds and Cincinnati's ace pitcher, Bucky Walters, today, 4 to 0, to move within one-half game of third place, now occupied by their opponents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Capitol Hill showed very little interest today in the British Information Minister's invitation to visit England to observe what was being done with lease-lend materials.

OTTAWA, Sept. 4 -- The extension of lease-lend facilities to Poland, announced at Washington today, is expected to be of immediate and important aid to the nucleus army that country is building in Canada. In that army every one is a volunteer and the number of men is steadily mounting.

John R. Davies, opponent of Mayor La Guardia for the Republican nomination, testified in Supreme Court yesterday that he had nothing to do with designating petitions in his behalf and disclaimed any responsibility for alleged forgeries among the signatures, as charged by the objectors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- The United States is letting Spain have large quantities of petroleum products as part of an effort to prevent Spain's entrance into the war on the side of the Axis, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- An official survey disclosed today that only about half of the plants catalogued in the original Army-Navy industrial mobilization plans are working on munitions orders.
A dwelling and several apartment properties along the West Side passed to new hands in transactions announced yesterday.

Professor Goodwin Watson of Columbia reports to the American Psychological Association the results of a study of 539 unemployed men in the first two months of 1934. Whose morale held out best? Those who had a religious belief, the strongest source of patience and hope.

German-Occupied Countries Apparently enheartened by the recent developments in the war, which are interpreted as placing increasing burdens upon the aggressor nations, the dollar obligations of German-occupied countries advanced yesterday as much as 6 1/2 points in early trading here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The dictionary describes a changeling as "one that is left or taken, often secretly, in the place of another, especially in place of something genuine or natural; specifically, a child secretly exchanged for another in infancy or supposed, in popular superstition, to have been exchanged for another by fairies or elves."

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The news from Russia kept the stock markets here quiet today. The gilt edge issues, however, provided one exception, continuing to feel the benefit of the weight of money available and of the disbursements made on Sept. 1.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 4 -- A fierce surprise attack by the Fleet Air Army on an Axis convoy in the Mediterranean early yesterday threw the ship crews into near panic and resulted in the destruction of one large merchantman and damage to another large ship and two smaller ones, according to a British communique.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some Americans feel that if we never participate in this war as active belligerents we will come out with superior moral strength and influence with the nations of the world, and will be a tremendous power in making the peace.
Into each national tennis championship tournament some rain must fall and they finally got out the tarpaulins at Forest Hills yesterday after five days of clear weather.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Virtually no authentic information is available about the conference that Adolf Hitler and Benlto Mussolini had a fortnight ago. But reports received from Turkey throw some light upon preparations begun in Bulgaria by the German High Command for eventually transporting by sea troops and material to Batum, on the east shore of the Black Sea, and other districts close to the Caucasus.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Milestone, a bay gelding owned by Joseph A. Neville of Delaware, Ohio, hung up a new record today for the $1,500 L.S. Ayres Co. 2:08 trot at the Indiana State Fair Grand Circuit harness racing meet. He stepped the first mile in two minutes.

Brokers' loans of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City increased $137,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday in its weekly statistical summary.

THE committee that sponsored the Defense Bond Day in the baseball parks missed a trick when it didn't have the Stevens peanut, popcorn and "all-hot" vendors going through the aisles hawking the certificates with the proper cry: "Herey'are! Here y'are! Get your red hot Defense Bonds!"

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- The iron ring about Leningrad has now been sealed, it was indicated by information made available here tonight. Excepting the still open avenue of retreat across Lake Ladoga, this information suggested, all the Russian forces in the Leningrad area are trapped and face eventual starvation, destruction or capitulation.

Marking an important departure in its merchandising policy, Bonwit Teller Co. today will open a new department devoted to decorative homewares accessories, it was announced yesterday by William Holmes, president of the Fifth Avenue specialty store.
ROME, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Italian communique today follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- An order issued tonight by the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding the Associated Gas and Electric Company was viewed here as foreshadowing the paring from that huge public-utility system under the "death sentence" clause of the holding company act of a substantial number of the 175 subsidiaries which it controls in twenty-five States ranging from Maine to Florida and from Connecticut to Arizona.

In return for canceling the run-of-the-play contract he held for "Lady in the Dark," Rex O'Malley will receive a substantial sum equivalent to ten weeks' salary from the management. Previously, Mr. O'Malley turned down an offer to settle on the basis of four weeks' pay.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 5 -- The atmosphere in Tokyo, which had turned to subdued optimism following Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye's message to President Roosevelt, was again registering increasing tension today.

September and October are months in which the capacity of the railways to handle promptly the freight delivered to them receives its maximum test. With the present great activity of trade, some doubt has been expressed as to what will be the results in these months this year; but the doubts have not been shared by the railways themselves.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Sept. 5 -- While Russian forces on the central front continued to pound retreating German units east of the Dnieper River in the Pripet region, Soviet units between Gomel and Smolensk, a Moscow commentator declared this morning, had crossed the Dnieper at another point near its junction with the Berezina River [northwest of Gomel] and were pushing northward toward Bobruisk.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 5 -- New Russian counter-attacks on the central front, in the vicinity of Kiev, and southward in the Ukraine were reported last night as it was officially announced that Leningrad was neither encircled nor cut off from communication with the interior.

Purchase by an operator of loft property assessed at $405,000 featured realty activity on the East Side yesterday. The deal involved 126-28 Fifth Avenue, a fifteen-story structure on a plot 60 by 115 feet at the southwest corner of Eighteenth Street, which was purchased by David S. Meister from the Mutual Life Insurance Company.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt ordered today a wider geographical and corporate distribution of defense orders to speed up the production of arms and prevent the extinction of small business and alleviate "priorities unemployment."

BERLIN, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- The official D.N.B. news agency said today that the Russians had tried to land on a German-occupied sector of the Black Sea coast, only to be frustrated by German coastal patrols.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Mrs. James M. Robbins carded 42, 40 -- 82 to win the low-gross prize in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association in rain at the Mount Kisco Country Club today.

The attempt of an enemy submarine to sink the United States destroyer Greer on the Iceland run brings us squarely up against the whole question of using the Navy's guns to protect American ships and cargoes on the high seas. That question has been hanging fire for too long a time.

Supreme Court Justice Edwin L. Garvin yesterday ordered the attorneys representing the Republican and Democratic organizations in the court fight over the Republican petitions for Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic candidate, to complete their case today so that the Appellate Division could hear arguments on his decision on Monday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- Russian, forces were reported by the official Hungarian Government newspaper tonight to have launched heavy counter-attacks on the central front aimed at the Berezina River. The newspaper Magyar Orszag did not place the location of the Russian attacks, believed to be somewhere in the vicinity of Gomel, which lies about twenty miles east of the Berezina.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Major General Henry W. Baird's Fourth Armored Division was a reduced force tonight, with nearly 50 per cent of its complement on furlough and more than 1,000 officers and men contributed as a nucleus for the Fifth Armored Division, soon to be activated in Arkansas or California.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 5 -- With quieter trade, the Bourse was irregular today, small fluctuations appearing generally. Sugar and rubber shares continued active, however, and mostly were firm. Amsterdam Trading rose 4 1/2 points to 469 1/2, while Amsterdam Rubber was unchanged at 301 1/2 and Royal Dutch was slightly lower at 298 1/2.

George S. Kaufman will step out as a producer in his own right tonight when Hartford witnesses the mystery-comedy, "Mr. Big," written by Arthur Sheekman and Margaret Shane and directed by Mr. Kaufman. Advance reports say it is filled to the brim with all sorts of hare-brained capers in the typical Kaufman style.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- Germany's virtual coal monopoly in Western Europe, resulting from the conquests of 1939 and 1940, has enabled her to obtain a steady flow of supplies of essential foodstuffs and raw materials from allied, occupied and non-occupied countries.

Several years ago in New York's lower East Side a boy of 17 killed his mother. The boy was committed to the State asylum. There he was examined by Dr. Frederic Wertham, a psychiatrist, who became unusually interested in the circumstances of the case.

Belair Stud, one of the most powerful stables in the country, will try with both barrels for the $12,000 Edgemere Handicap, today's big feature at Aqueduct, for both Foxbrough and Fenelon are among the ten entered for the ninefurlong run.
HATTIESBURG, Miss., Sept. 5 -- Camp Shelby soldiers, when they return late this month from manoeuvres, will find extensive improvements on the reservation.

VICHY, France, Sept. 5 -- More blood was shed in Paris last night when Marcel Gitton, who was elected to the Chamber of Deputies in 1936 as a Communist but left his party when war was declared in 1939, was shot by a man on a bicycle in the working-class quarters of Les Lilas when he was returning home.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- What amounts to a press campaign was under way here today to make Italians realize that the war against Russia is an extremely difficult matter. The newspaper tell of rain, the approaching Winter, the efficiency of the Soviet guerrillas and the high quality of the Russian soldiers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Sept. 6 -- Three main battles are raging on the Eastern Front, according to reports from Moscow early today. Two of them -- between Dernovichi and Gomel, in the south-central sector, and between Dukhovshina and the Kholm sector -- are said to continue to turn in the Russians' favor.

All but the October futures contract touched new eleven-year high records on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as the market advanced for the sixth consecutive trading session. After being under pressure for most of the session the staple developed sudden strength near the close and final quotations showed net gains of 4 to 7 points.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- The champion Newark Bears, preparing for the opening of the playoffs on Tuesday night, registered a 4-to-3 victory over Syracuse tonight before a crowd of 8,183.

The appointment of twenty-six priests to the faculty of the new Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School for Boys at 153d Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was announced yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman. The Very Rev. Philip J. Furlong already had been named principal of the school, which will be formally dedicated Monday.

Edward Levine, owner of the Brass Rail restaurant at Seventh Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, agreed yesterday to meet with Mayor La Guardia Monday in an attempt to settle a strike of waiters, kitchen help and chefs which started in January, 1939.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

AN old ivory hunter brought in word that George Vierheller was sighted on safari yesterday in the wilds of Brooklyn, cautiously beating his way toward Ebbets Field. He had a native guide. This may be significant.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 5 -- Pledges that labor on both sides of the Atlantic would cooperate in the destruction of Hitlerism were exchanged today by James B. Carrey, retiring president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., And Jack Tanner, president of the Amalgamated Engineering Union of England, in a two-way radio broadcast 'arranged in connection with the convention of Mr. Carey's union here.

Two men were arrested last night charged with swindling an elderly spinster of securities valued at $10,000. They were taken into custody by Lieutenant James McCoy at the office of Attorney General John J. Bennett, later being locked up in Police Headquarters to await a hearing on extradition to New Jersey, where the larceny allegedly occurred three weeks ago.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- Although Japan remains firm in rejecting any "third power" -- meaning American -- mediation in China, Iichi Kishi, deputy spokesman of the Cabinet Information Board, declared today that if Wang Ching-wei and Chiang Kai-shek were to negotiate a settlement, "that would be an affair between two Chinese regimes."

Investment Market At least another week will pass before activity in investment banking circles will be transformed into actual public offerings of new securities, according to present plans. Except for a relatively small railroad equipment-trust issue ($1,260,000 of one-to-ten-year or $1,500,000 of one-to-fifteen-year certificates of Denver Rio Grande Western) slated for sale on Wednesday, corporate bond financing promises to remain at a standstill.
NEW YORK Sir William and Lady Garthwaite returned yesterday from Narragansett, R.I., and are at the Plaza.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Heavy field guns and Army trucks rumbled through the streets of New York yesterday as the final train of military supplies and equipment arrived at Governors Island to go on public view today in connection with Army Relief Day, held annually to raise funds for the relief of widows and dependents of officers and men of the Regular Army.

Reporting to stockholders on operations of the parent company in the first six months of this year Standish Backus, president of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company, announced yesterday a net profit of $2,180,744 after all charges including depreciation and $1,325,000 provision for Federal normal income and excess profits taxes.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Higher charges, a threatened scarcity of vans and crews and a heavier migration of families from one home to another led moving men and warehouse operators yesterday to forecast that the peak of the Fall season in New York would find conditions this year reminiscent of 1929.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Sept. 5 -- About 1,000 tanks, light and medium, and half-track armored scout cars were loaded on twenty trains of flat cars yesterday and today for shipment to the Louisiana manoeuvre area. The Armored Force vehicles are part of the First Armored Division which left here 12,700 strong Monday and Tuesday.
BERLIN, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Some Germans here indicated today that if Leningrad's resistance continued, the Nazi armies would undertake to pound it to pieces.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- David Johnsen of Washington, who was graduated from George Washington University last June, defeated second-seeded Gene Mako of Los Angeles in the Eastern New Jersey clay courts tennis tournament today, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 6 -- Although bad weather curbed activity on the Western air front Thursday night, coastal command planes of the Royal Air Force operated over occupied France, the Air Ministry reported.

VICHY, France, Sept. 5 -- There is such a big illicit trade in ration cards that citizens have been warned that whenever a death is registered the first formality is to surrender the dead person's food and clothing coupons.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Groping their way out around Long Island Sound today the crews in the women's national championship completed their three final races and the series at the American Yacht Club, with Miss Lois MacIntyre of the Riverside Yacht Club capturing the title and the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup.

Joe Louis and Lou Nova had a brief meeting yesterday at the New York State Athletic Commission, where the heavyweight champion of the world and his challenger signed formal contracts for their meeting at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 29.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- The $11,000 Tam O'Shanter open tournament -- current drama on the professional golf circuit -- went through its second act today with the leading role still in the capable hands of that surprising young man from the Ozarks, Leonard Dodson.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt approved yesterday two model market baskets prepared by the Camp Fire Girls as evidence that in spite of the rising cost of foods a $1 bill would provide an adequate meal for a family of four.

Patrolman Dominic Paolo, attached to the Police Technical Laboratory as a fingerprint, typewriter and forgery expert, fatally wounded himself with a police service revolver at 10:15 A.M. yesterday in the home of his sister-in-law at 1304 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx.

Several rayon greige goods weaving mills have begun to enter the finished goods business, either through subsidiary or other connections with converters, or by establishing converting departments, it was reported in Worth Street.

British advertising has definitely contributed to civilian morale during the two years of the war by financing the continued existence of newspapers and their freedom of expression and license to criticize within reason, W.B.B. Fergusson, managing director of Lord Thomas, Ltd., London, writes in a letter to the New York office, released yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 5 -- Ray Peeney and George Brenner of the Hopewell Valley Country Club, staged a blazing finish to steal the show from some of the State's better-known golfers today as firing in the New Jersey partners' bestball tournament got under way at the Trenton Country Club links.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, announced today that he had called two meetings next week to discuss imposition of ceiling prices on carded cotton yarn and the extension of the cotton gray goods price schedules to cover the remaining important constructions.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Rain helped the Pirates gain an even split with the Reds today before a crowd of 4,897. A storm broke in the seventh inning of the nightcap with the Bucs leading, 1 to 0. The Reds took the opener, 10 to 4, by overcoming a three-run lead with eight runs in the eighth.

Although the volume of business in the New York Stock Exchange held yesterday above the half million share mark, the market was again highly selective, with the aircraft issues the main medium of trading. The mixed status at the close offered little choice for these either bullishly or bearishly inclined.

VICHY, France, Sept. 5 -- Accusations in the American press concerning the activities of Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador, to Washington, and members of his staff have been followed by a protest from the Vichy Government to the United States Government.

One hour before the printing concern he had headed for the last thirty years was to be sold at auction, 65-year-old Paul Overhage plunged to death yesterday morning from a fire-escape shaft on the tenth floor at 229 West Twenty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Submarines of the British Mediterranean Fleet have torpedoed an Italian 10,000-ton cruiser and a liner believed to be carrying troops to Africa, as well as a tanker and two supply vessels, the Admiralty announced today. The liner was believed to be the 23,635-ton Duilio.

WITH ANGLO-AMERICAN FORCES IN ICELAND, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Soldiers, sailors and airmen of the United States and Great Britain, have turned this windswept island into a Gibraltar of the North safeguarding a vital link in British-American communications.

Given sufficient supplies, the Chinese Government could defeat the Japanese, Dr. Wei Tao-ming, newly appointed Chinese Ambassador to the Vichy Government, declared yesterday. He said that the Japanese morale was at its lowest ebb, while that of his country was higher than it had ever been.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- The Japan News Week, which often reflects the view of the Foreign Office, published strongly anti-Axis editorial comment today, and several hours after it had appeared on newsstands it had not been suppressed by the police.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Stanley Ogilvy's Star Spirit, Howard Seymour's Atlantic Mutiny, Bud Moxham's International Maid of Honour and Glenn McNary's Victory Allouette were leading in their classes for race week championships at the end of the third day of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual Fall series today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Francis Biddle, the Solicitor General who has been Acting Attorney General since the elevation of Robert H. Jackson to the Supreme Court, was confirmed by the Senate today as Attorney General, and some hours later received his commission from President Roosevelt at the White House.

Although Great Britain's bombed children can "take it" as well as, if not better than, adults, extensive construction of residential nurseries is needed in England and Scotland to care for the children, particularly those of mothers employed in war industries, former Governor Henry J. Allen of Kansas said yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Field from Lisbon on the Atlantic Clipper.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Straight-heat victories were the order of the day in the closing program today of the Grand Circuit harness-racing program at the Indiana State Fair.

The first government-approved advertising campaign for the reclamation of waste paper needed for the manufacture of corrugated boxes started yesterday in thirty-two key cities throughout the country. Radio spot announcements, amounting to $2,000 a week in New York alone, began yesterday with extensive newspaper and magazine advertising scheduled for next week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The vote by which the Senate approved the $3,583,900,000 tax bill was as follows:
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Evidence hat vitamin B1 mignt have a salutary effect on the brain was reported today at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association at Northwestern University.

The spreading of defense contracts among smaller manufacturers so as to increase production and relieve "priorities unemployment" has now been recognized as a major problem of the defense program. The new Division of Contract Distribution which has been created under the direction of Floyd B. Odlum is to take equal rank with the other divisions of the Office of Production Management.

The Republic of Haiti, by its action yesterday in announcing that full service would be resumed on its outstanding dollar bonds on Oct. 1, the next interest payment date, is believed to have set a record, at least for Latin-American nations, in respect to the speedy rectifying of a situation encountered last March when the republic found it necessary to reduce its external debt service by one-third of the contractual rate.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederic Byers entertained with a dinner tonight at Sandymount, their place on the ocean, for Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Rogers and Mr. and Mrs. Eric Loder who have joined Mr. and Mrs. Byers for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The United States Fleet is searching the Atlantic with orders from President Roosevelt to "eliminate" the submarine which yesterday tried to sink the American destroyer Greer while the ship was on the way to Iceland with mail.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Several hundred younger members of society, representing communities through the county, attended the third annual Westchester Cotillion tonight at the Apawamis Club here. The dance served to introduce some forty girls, the majority of whom were feted at cocktail parties, receptions and dinners given in conjunction with the cotillion.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 5 -- Although the wild rice was too high and the tide too low, we had one of the best days of rail shooting in our experience today, and in the future no one will be able to tell us that these birds are scarce on the lower Housatonic.

"Willful waste makes woeful want" is an ancient adage that has an especially appropriate application in these days of shortages and rising prices. Stopping unnecessary food wastes at home has become much more than a matter of family thrift, according to a recent bulletin published by the Bureau of Home Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture.

East and West Sides participated almost equally in the apartment rentals announced yesterday. Included in the units rented were several duplexes. The midtown section was especially popular with new tenants.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Sept. 5 -- While authorities at this post were explaining the crash of the flaming Army fighter in Hempstead Tuesday, in which three children playing near their homes were fatally burned, a repetition of the tragedy was narrowly averted today a short distance away.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Contracts totaling $35,321,819 were awarded today by the War Department. Companies in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The gasoline and fuel oil situation in the Eastern States contains a real threat to the nation's security that should be met in the speediest possible fashion, the Senate Oil Investigating Committee was told today by Leon Henderson.

When Robert Frost told the Bread Loaf Writers Conference the other day that he would as soon play tennis with the net down as write free verse, he stirred up hardly a ripple of comment in the land. Time was when such a pronouncement from a major poet would have set tongues to wagging from coast to coast.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times:

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 5 -- The seventh national convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., closed today after voting down a constitutional interpretation intended to give locals the right to bar Communists from office.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- A preinduction examination plan will be tried out in this State beginning Oct. 6 to prevent possible hardship on registrants who may be unable to pass the physical tests demanded by the Army.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 5 -- At the end of its second report to Congress, presented today, the Chamber investigating committee, after detailing how Nazi propaganda in Argentina is financed, announces that at an early date it will recommend some action by Congress as a result of the German Embassy's activities.

In drawing a balance sheet of the eleven weeks of the Russian campaign, the material factors -- casualties in men and materiel in both armies, conquest of territory, and economic gains and losses -- are of major importance.

Charging that the gold reserves of the Central Bank of Poland that were transported to France just ahead of the German invasion of Warsaw later were permitted to fall into the hands of the Nazis, the Polish bank has obtained a writ of attachment against $64,050,641 of the vast store of French gold here, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the New York State Mediation Board, recommended today that the National Defense Mediation Board make a further attempt to mediate the controversy between the Consolidated Edison Company, the Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes and Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, American Federation of Labor.

Asserting that Mayor La Guardia had strong organization and independent support for re-election, William M. Chadbourne, chairman of the committee for renomination of Mayor La Guardia; Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Newbold Morris, President of the City Council on the Republican ticket, announced yesterday the appointment of four county chairmen and the opening of headquarters in the five boroughs of the city.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, has no intention of retiring at the federation's annual convention next month.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- Fierce Russian counter-attacks south of Leningrad succeeded in annihilating a German artillery division, driving back the Nazis and recapturing strategically important points previously occupied by the invaders, it was reported today as the tremendous onslaught all along the front continued to be met by stiff resistance.

Floyd B. Odium, who has taken a temporary leave of absence as president of the Atlas Corporation to accept the appointment by President Roosevelt as head of the new Division of Contract Distribution in the office of the OPM, yesterday said that the White House statement concerning the division "seems both clear and complete."

Lessons of the first two years of the war with special reference to its effect on religion in the countries concerned will be cited by clergymen in their sermons tomorrow in the churches of the New York area. Opinions on the Labor Day broadcast of President Roosevelt will be expressed in some pulpits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Great Britain, it was disclosed tonight, is about to undertake with the help of the United States Government a campaign to employ thousands of American technicians for service in England repairing vital equipment used by the British armed forces.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Although most of the qualifying field competed today, the score of 33, 36 -- 69 shot by Reginald G. Narelle and Edmond Overton of Pelham over the Labor Day week-end took medal honors in the first annual member-guest invitation golf tournament of the North Hempstead Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Jessie Woolworth Donahue of New York City gave away 20,000 shares of F.W. Woolworth Company capital stock, worth more than $500,000 at current market prices and sold 10,000 shares in July, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

President Roosevelt has given the Navy the only orders that could properly follow the attack on the destroyer Greer. Those orders are to track down the submarine that made the attack and to "eliminate" it if it is found. The circumstances of the case leave no doubt that the attack was deliberate.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., Sept. 5 -- The modern slang of the American soldier today is replacing code language formerly used by the United States Army for sending military messages by radio or telephone while in the field.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Tokyo press, including early editions of Saturday's papers, had not mentioned up to tonight the arrival of the American oil tanker L.P. St. Clair at Vladivostok, announced in Washington yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- By a vote of 67 to 5 the Senate adopted late today the 1941 revenue bill which calls for the record increase of $3,583,900,000 in taxes to help meet the costs of the defense program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today he was wondering what had happened to the exploratory conversations President Roosevelt was supposed to be conducting with the Japanese.

Five British merchant seamen, all of whom gave their status as "D.B.S." (Distressed British Seaman), who arrived here on the Empress of Asia on Thursday, acted as spokesmen yesterday for fifty men in the same category who they said were aboard the ship, and told of some of the difficulties they faced.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- Long-range German artillery batteries have already begun the bombardment of the city of Leningrad. This was the only announcement of importance in regard to the German operations on the Eastern Front in today's communique of the Supreme Command.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Elden Auker pitched five-hit ball as the St. Louis Browns defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 1, before 22.691 persons tonight. The loss dropped the White Sox back into a second-place tie with, the idle Boston Red Sox.

Shipments of United States currency to foreign countries in August amounted to $1,543,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday. Of this amount, $1,000,000 was shipped to Cuba, including many large denomination bills; $200,000 to the Dominican Republic, $240,000 to other Caribbean nations and $103,000 to Canada.
BUFFALO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs outlined today a seven-point civil defense program to guide its membership for "whatever emergency the future may bring."
ROME, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique follows:

The three-story warehouse property on the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Mortgage Corporation of New York, trustee for the certificate holders, to the Aronka Realty Corporation for cash above a first mortgage of $22,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Reduced marketing brought a strong tone to the hog market today, while beef cattle held fully steady and lambs eased 25 to 35 cents per 100 pounds in later trade, wiping out part of the gains made earlier in the week. The strong tone of the hog market, also reflecting fair demand in the dressed trade at steady prices, developed on all weights as well as sows.

Britain's financial journal, The Economist, has calculated that the total property loss in Britain through air raids in the first two years of the war has amounted to $480,000,000. Large as this sum is, it is equal to only 2 per cent of the total $24,000,000,000 of estimated real estate values in the country.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, will deliver an address in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine tomorrow at the 4 o'clock evening prayer service. The message by Mr. Woll will take the place of the usual sermon.

With Jim Crowley on hand for the first time since practice started last Monday, the forty-two candidates for the Fordham eleven went through a double session yesterday on Rose Hill. Because of the sultry weather contact work was put off until Monday.

The vacation period is over for the rampant Dodgers. Today they turn once again to the serious business of winning that National League pennant for Flatbush, and Manager Leo Durocher is ready for the homestretch drive.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Four of Camp Upton's officers will depart this month to attend officers' schools, Colonel C.W. Baird, commanding officer, announced today. Two other officers recently returned from similar training.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5. (AP) -- Jersey City and the Orioles divided an abbreviated double-header tonight, Baltimore winning the opener, 5 to 4, the Little Giants the nightcap, 3 to 1. Rain stopped the second game after five innings.

Trade Here Up 25 to 30% Retail trade here widened its percentage of gain over a year ago. Department store volume was estimated as running 25 to 30 per cent ahead of 1940, compared with a rise of 18 per cent in the preceding week.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Members of the Interstate Poodle Club and the Dalmatian Club of America held joint specialty exhibitions today on the Tuxedo Park horse show grounds, with an excellent attendance of fanciers of the two breeds.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following:
To Sports Editor of The New York Times:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- RKO today purchased "China Sky," a novel by Pearl S. Buck which has appeared as a magazine serial and will be published this Fall in book form. The story deals with two American doctors, a man and a woman, who operate a hospital in a small Chinese town under Japanese bombardment.

The board of directors of the Food Machinery Corporation declared yesterday a special dividend of 35 cents and a quarterly dividend of 35 cents a share on the common stock, bringing to $1.40 the dividends declared thus far in 1941, compared with $1.25 ordered in the same period of 1940.

The men's national tennis championship resolved itself into a proposition concerning the big four of the seeded group yesterday as Robert L. Riggs and Ted Schroeder joined Donald McNeill and Frank Kovacs in the semi-finals at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

WITH THE RUSSIAN ARMY, on the Central Front, Sept. 5 -- I found Marshal Semyon Timoshenko, Commander in Chief of the Russian forces in the west and defender of Moscow, if and when it is attacked, in the small room of a log cabin behind the lines.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- The railroad wage dispute involving about 1,200,000 workers was headed today toward President Roosevelt for settlement. As had been indicated, the National Railway Mediation Board, which for three weeks had been trying to bring about an amicable settlement, announced that its efforts had failed.

FORT DIX, Sept. 5 -- A possibility that 25 per cent of the Fortyfourth Division's 941 officers might be relieved from duty in the near future was seen here today, following two War Department announcements, one setting age limits for all Army officers and the other stating that 50 per cent of the Reserve officers on active duty would be released.

A legendary figure from Mongaup Valley came reluctantly to town yesterday in the person of a ruddy-cheeked, bristly-haired, rotund man named Philip L.E. Del Fungo Giera, according to his own statement, and Peter Brenner, according to the Federal authorities.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- Extensive military training -- including lessons in tactics and staff work, marching drill, gunnery and grenade throwing and the art of using terrain effectively -- is to be instituted in all Soviet schools for the last three classes.

OTTAWA, Sept. 5 -- Canada can now fully equip an infantry division with tanks, guns, rifles, transport and everything else down to boots and bonnets, in six weeks, Munitions Minister C.D. Howe said today at a press conference.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Grain and soy bean futures soared for the second straight day to new high prices since 1937 as public and professional buying came into all pits on the Board of Trade. While liberal profit-taking was attracted by the advance, closing sales were only slightly under the top.

Yesterday was moving day for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was giving up the apartment she has used as a town residence during the last few years at 20 East Eleventh Street. In its stead, she will utilize this Winter a suite of rooms in the family home at 49 East Sixty-fifth Street, which has stood unoccupied for most of the period since her husband went to the White House in 1933.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 6 -- Some British newspapers today interpreted the submarine attack on the U.S.S. Greer as the first direct challenge to the United States by Germany, and commented that the "U-boat" commander "provided the reminder that America needed that the war was near her shores."

"Soviet Power," which will arrive at the Central this morning, will round out the week's new film offerings. The picture includes five factual films produced in Russia, "Citizens of Tomorrow," "The Soviet Woman." "Armenia, Land of Joy," and two of the first Russian newsreels of the current Russo-German war, titled, "Russia's Millions Mobilize" and "Report From the Front."
Margaret Mitchell, the tiny author of the giant "Gone With the Wind," has forsaken the manipulation of words for the operation of a heavy machine used in making surgical dressings.

The elimination of a monopolistic combination in the drug industry that will actually benefit the former monopolists and free them from unwanted contacts with Germany was announced yesterday by Acting Attorney General Francis Biddle.

SOMEWHERE IN FINNISH KARELIA, Sept. 5 -- The city of Viborg, once known as Finland's gayest metropolis, is a dead and blasted ruin. Two wars in two years have smashed its houses and burned them out, leaving only skeleton walls pocked with empty windows.

MONTEVIDEO, Aug. 25 -- There has arrived here a copy of the text of the pastoral letter of the Catholic hierarchy of the Netherlands in which is reaffirmed the prohibition, against Catholics giving their support to either national socialism or communism on pain of being denied the last sacrament at time of death.

Approximately 60 per cent of the output of the General Electric Company is going directly into defense channels, Charles E. Wilson, president, said yesterday at a press conference following a meeting of the board of directors. Total billings by the company this year, Mr. Wilson estimated, will run between $600,000,000 and $650,000,000, while earnings for the third quarter will not show much change from previous quarters this year.

The jump of military airplane production to a new high record is cheering news. The 1,854 military airplanes delivered by American manufacturers in August is not only the greatest number achieved for any single month, and more than three times the rate of August a year ago, but the increase of 394 planes over the preceding month is itself the greatest single gain ever recorded in such a period.

Mrs. Helen Pauline Mayer, 25-year-old resident in a German community of Ridgewood, Queens, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents yesterday and charged with conspiracy with Kurt Frederick Ludwig in collecting data on the United States Army for transmission to Germany in violation of the espionage law.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times:

The five-story building at 12 Gramercy Park South, which was the Rhinelander residence before being converted into apartments, has been sold by Philip Rhinelander and others to Mrs. Abbey G. Zolnay and Mrs. Margaret Zolnay Newcomb.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Bernard M. Baruch, 1918 chairman of the War Industries Board, conferred with Donald M. Nelson for two hours today and told reporters later that Mr. Nelson, the executive director of the new Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board, might furnish in himself "the solution of the need for one-man control of defense under the President."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Maritime Commission invoked today for the first time its new authority to take over idle ships in American ports for defense service, when it assumed possession of the Danish vessel African Reefer.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A German spokesman took the view today that the submarine attack on the United States destroyer Greer was just what advocates of American intervention in the war had been wanting.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 5 -- The men of the United States destroyer Greer, which was attacked by a submarine on the way to Iceland, said on their arrival here today that the Greer's depth charges might well have sunk the undersea vessel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Shortage troubles of Mid Western hardware retailers have been aggravated by a strike at a large wholesale house and by the tendency of jobbers generally to ration heavy household appliances, but sales nevertheless are running substantially ahead of last year, it was reported today at the headquarters of the Illinois Retail Hardware Association.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times:

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Sept. 5 -- With the proceeds going to buy recreational equipment for the 18,000 men of the Twenty-ninth Division here, the musical extravanganza "Snap It Up Again" is entering its final week of rehearsals before the premiere next Thursday at the Maryland Theatre in Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Shortage troubles of Mid Western hardware retailers have been aggravated by a strike at a large wholesale house and by the tendency of jobbers generally to ration heavy household appliances, but sales nevertheless are running substantially ahead of last year, it was reported today at the headquarters of the Illinois Retail Hardware Association.
