FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Sept. 5 -- With the proceeds going to buy recreational equipment for the 18,000 men of the Twenty-ninth Division here, the musical extravanganza "Snap It Up Again" is entering its final week of rehearsals before the premiere next Thursday at the Maryland Theatre in Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 30 totaled 912,720 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 12,970 cars or 1.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 143,945 cars or 18.7 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 196,323 cars, or 27.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Battling through a strong group of terriers and then forging to the top among the six finalists, the grand little Welsh terrier Flornell Rare Bit of Twin Ponds, owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., and handled by John Goudie, was named best of nearly 700 dogs today in the twenty-third annual exhibition of the Tuxedo Kennel Club held on the horse show grounds.

Faced with a growing list of priorities on basic chemicals and the problem of supplying these and other chemicals to defense contractors who have priority ratings, sales offices of major chemical companies have been thrown into confusion from which there is little hope of any early extrication, according to comment of sales managers last week.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 -- Vines DiMaggio's nineteenth, homer of the season, hit with two out and Elbie Fletcher on second base in the second inning, gave the Pittsburgh Pirates an early lead today as they defeated the Cubs, 6 to 4.
HYDE PARK, Sept. 6 -- President Roosevelt will make a speech of "major importance" from the White House at 9 o'clock, Eastern standard time, Monday night.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that the city and the Consolidated Edison Company had settled with his approval all litigation arising from cumulative increases of $936,725,250 in real estate valuations over the last six and one-half years.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Refugee King Peter II of Yugoslavia, a tall, slim, shy youth, celebrated his eighteenth birthday anniversary today convinced that the time is ripe for a British invasion of Italy.

HOLLYWOOD. IN spite of a steady and unending flow of both published and "original" stories into Hollywood the industry continues to display an insatiable appetite for material. Whether it is a small independent interested only in a completed shooting script for $250 or a major that will pay $100,000 for the synopsis of a yarn on which bidding is brisk, a writer with a good story is in an enviable position.

The stage is being set and the battle lines drawn for the first open clash between at least two powerful underwriting groups for one of the nation's most prized investments -- an issue of about $94,500,000 of debentures of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The author of the following letter has been Professor of Philosophy at Harvard since 1913 and is a former president of the American Philosophical Association. He is the author of many books and is chairman of American Defense Harvard Group.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- By providing part-time Jobs, the National Youth Administration will enable about 450,000 different students to continue their education during the 1941-42 academic year, it was announced today by the NYA Administrator, Aubrey Williams.

The cotton futures market yesterday continued its upward trend, making the seventh consecutive session in which it has recorded advances. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange again established new eleven-year highs and registered net gains of 8 to 13 points for the two-hour session.

DON'T ever let any one tell you that Milton Berle isn't a very careful guy. "Cozy" might be the word. The news had reached this corner that he was going to team up with Charles Laughton for a WOR variety show scheduled to make its initial appearance on the network Friday at 9:30 P.M. So what could be more natural than, a desire to see Mr. Berle to get the inside on this impending event?

While reports last week agreed that the new installment regulations went into effect smoothly and with general compliance on the larger down payments and shorter terms, the question of possible illadvised attempts to evade the restrictions received attention in the retail field.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 6 -- Charles A. Stillman, last of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company officials who joined the company when the New York banking house of Dillon, Read Co. reorganized it twenty years ago, died today at the age of 68. He had been ill for several months.

There isn't any other time of year, except Christmas time perhaps, when the stores are so full of young fry as they are right now. It is back-to-school clothes that they are after, and they and their mothers are spending afternoons looking.

KEARNY, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Two new light cruisers, whose unusual designs and secret installations make them the Navy's newest "mystery ships," slid down the ways today with the launching here of the Atlanta and the launching in Quincy, Mass., of a sister ship, the San Juan, as the Navy Department intensified its already unprecedented shipbuilding program.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Sept. 6 -- A Curtiss P-40 Army pursuit plane, piloted by Second Lieutenant G. Marshall Walker, 23 years old, of Easton, Pa., crashed at Mitchel Field this morning and he was injured.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Two leading questions of the day in Britain are, first, what exactly has been the effect of the Royal Air Force offensive against the Reich, and, second, when, where and in what strength will the Luftwaffe retaliate ?
LAFCADIO HEARN said that poetry in Japan was as universal as air; felt by everybody, read by everybody and composed by almost everybody -- irrespective of class or condition.

EVERY so often, articles appear, written by some, top-notch decorator, describing how you can furnish an apartment for "practically nothing." But if you start from scratch (and you are not content to sit around on packing crates), "nothing" almost invariably turns out to be quite a tidy sum.
A DEMONSTRATION of general portraiture by Helene Sanders will tie given at the Miniature Camera Club, Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, tomorrow at 8 P.M.

MODERNIZING a mausoleum isn't the easiest task in the world, but Director Taylor has made progress toward that end at the Metropolitan. Whether the pretentious Fifth Avenue facade will ever have its face lifted -- eliminating the dreary flight of steps and providing ingress right from street level -- seems at present less than even a remote possibility.

The hero is a circus clown, and what a clown! You wouldn't believe that the thing's he does are possible -- not even if you saw them. He calls himself Bibobi, but that is not his real name, and he is more than a clown. He is a spy working in the interest of England but strictly on his own.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- More than 500,000 Germans, organized as Storm Troopers, are scattered strategically through South America in a campaign for "Nazification" of the continent, Raul Damonte Taborda, Chairman of the Congressional Committee Investigating Anti-Argentine Activities, charged today.

The building industry is experiencing more activity this year than in any previous year since 1929 and this condition is expected to continue until the Spring of 1942, according to a recent survey completed by L. Seth Schnitman, consulting economist, and Myron L. Matthews.

Bundles for Britain, Inc., announced yesterday its plans for a national campaign to expand relief to British children war sufferers. The organization, which has headquarters at 745 Fifth Avenue, will undertake to supply on a larger scale sweaters and other warm, knitted garments for which there is expected to be desperate need next Winter.

The executive council of the American Friends of Lafayette yesterday, on the 184th anniversary of Lafayette's birth, adopted a resolution endorsing the principles of the Free French following of General Charles de Gaulle and urging the President and Congress to recognize and assist the de Gaulle regime to the utmost.

ASHIP is a live thing. It breasts the seas, thrusting them aside, taking them over the bow, rolling in them as plates creak and groan. Down below the engines pulse tirelessly, the faint vibration running from the stern forward, to fade out before the impact of the waves.

Two new social science courses, born directly of this country's national defense effort and its concomitant attempt to unify the Americas, will be introduced at St. John's College, Brooklyn, with the opening on Sept. 22 of the seventy-first academic year, it was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Edward J. Walsh, president of the university.

FOR, THE COMING WEEK: The Fall clean-up is begun -- annuals and vegetables left beyond their period of usefulness merely waste plant food. . . . If All waste material (except that which, may contain weed seeds or disease spores) is best used on the compost Heap, where it will make valuable humus; if there's no compost heap, now's a good time to start one.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs scored their first victory in ten tries in Ruppert Stadium today by pushing across a run in the ninth inning to defeat the champion Newark Bears, 6 to 5. It was Syracuse's fifth triumph in twenty meetings so far with Newark.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The American woman's "recognition of the fact that she has a unique moral and social job in the defense of democracy" has been shown by early registrations in the Newark and New Brunswick divisions of Rutgers University College, in which women are expected to "turn out for evening classes in significant numbers," Dean Norman C. Miller said today.

FIRST MILITARY AREA Major George L. Robinson, Infantry, will proceed, on or about Sept. 16. from Utica, N.Y., to Oneonta, N.Y., on temporary duty in connection with the training of the Organized Reserves.

PHILADELHPIA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Athletics maintained their two-and-a-half-game hold on seventh place in the American League by dividing a double bill with the last-place Senators today, winning the opener, 8 to 3, but going down before Emil Leonard in the nightcap, 8 to 4.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- President Roosevelt has again instructed the heads of all government departments and agencies to hire employes without regard to "creed, race or religion" and, particularly, to give the Negroes an opportunity to get their fair share of Federal jobs, including those related to defense.

FOR those genuinely interested in the defense of democracy, a. more important and timelier book could hardly be published than Eugene Lyons's complete survey, of the Stalinist infiltration in the United States.

A conflict developed yesterday between Mayor La Guardia and Sol A. Herzog, counsel to the Eastern States Gasoline Retailers Conference, over the Mayor's recent "crack-down" move against filling station proprietors who disobey the price ceiling set by the Federal Price Administrator.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Boykin Cabell Wright and their sons, Boykin C. Wright Jr. and Alan Harriman Wright, have returned to their country home in Syosset, L.I. from a fishing trip in northern New Brunswick, Canada.
With the open, P.G.A., and amateur championships out of the way, only one major tournament remains to be played before the 1941 golf season is turned over to the historians.

The Increasing volume of national defense orders undertaken by the automobile and railroad equipment industries added to the record-breaking sales of passenger cars and trucks in the 1941 model year have permitted these companies to make an unusually favorable showing to date this year in the face of sharply higher taxes.

VICHY, France, Sept. 6 -- Measures of repression were directed today by both German and French authorities against acts of violence of various origins that have been multiplying in France in recent days.

DRING the four months October through January the John Day Company will publish five novels. For most publishers that would not be an excessive number, but John Day has, during the past few years, confined itself to one fiction title per season, and sometimes there have been none.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Aug. 30 amounted to 249,413,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 503,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 291,000 and 212,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude respectively.

IT seems only logical that Whitman should follow Poe in the series of monographs issued by the "Index to Early American Periodical Literature." Virtually all the principal American writers of the nineteenth century were contributors to magazines, but none was more dependent upon them than Poe for an audience.

Experts in home decoration always have much to say about the selection and placing of pictures. Not so long ago professionals advised practically doing without them, on the plea that bare walls were more restful. Now they are saying that larger pictures are easier to assimilate into a room's decoration;

The renovation work on the "Gilbert Hall of Science" at 1 West Twenty-fifth Street has been completed and the modernized structure will be formally dedicated Sept. 17. The designing and alteration of the six-story building was directed by Harry Preble Jr., industrial designer.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 6 -- The proposal made last June by the Uruguayan Foreign Minister, Alberto Guani, that any American republic at war with an extracontinental power should be regarded as a non-belligerent by its sister republics, is as convenient a gauge as any for measuring how far the governments of this hemisphere are ready to cooperate in the policy of effective continental solidarity.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Germany was declared by a foreign observer here today to have planned a combined land and sea campaign "before the end of October" against the Baku oil fields and the new British-Russian supply line through Iran.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- American participation in the war, limited and "non-belligerent" as it still remains, is none the less creating a problem of post-war planning which in recent weeks has drawn an increasing amount of study. Now this problem emerges as one perhaps as large, if not larger in the long-range life of the nation, as the war question itself.

The Radio City Music Hall Glee Club may seem only the somewhat uniteresting masculine act that fills up the time between the Ballet and the Rockettes. But there has probably never been a singing organization in the world quite like it, and Irving Landau, its 30-year-old director, provides another case history for the study of what happens to composition, students when they find it impossible to earn a living by composing.

Summer and all-year houses, country estates, business and residential buildings and sites for apartments and stores are included in the long list of properties to be offered under the hammer in the annual Nassau County public auction starting on sept. 27.

IT is the Jooss Ballet, back in New York after two seasons in South America, that will open the local dance season. The theatre will be Maxine Elliott's and the date Sept. 22, considerably earlier than any dance season has opened in a number of years.

HOLLYWOOD. ANY ONE wishing to indulge a baronial complex and acquire a complete Welsh village, with a row of stone cottages, shops, a pub, tobacconist's and market-place, also a grim Nonconformist chapel, will find it ready for him a cannonshot out of Hollywood.

To the Art Editor: YOUR editorial synthesis of Aug. 24 contained a paragraph, with one important error, which happens to completely demolish my principal point. My point of "disagreement" was definitely not, as you have it, that "Mr. Kootz had wasted his time looking in the wrong places."

This is the time when the major symphony orchestras start revealing the details of their regular subscription series. From the announcements that came in last week we culled the following news items: The Detroit Symphony and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra are going to continue for a second season without regular conductors.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article by Anne O'Hare McCormick, headed "Iran Is the Old Meeting Place of Britain and Russia," brought to my mind an incident which, had it been successful, would have altered radically the history of British prestige and authority in the Middle East.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The management of Allied Mills, Inc., succeeded today in electing four of its slate of five directors in a battle of proxies at the annual stockholders' meeting.
First place in the National League still belongs to the Dodgers.

President Roosevelt has supplied a text for education this year. It is no less valid because of the emphasis placed upon vocational training by the war. The President spoke his text in a message to the American College Publicity Association.
Five thousand New Yorkers, attending the annual Army Relief Day ceremonies yesterday at Governors Island, got their first good look at the Army's latest modern war equipment,

IN China music is as necessary as rice, and no more adorned. Were the common people -- coolies, stevedores, ricksha pullers, soldiers, barbers, professional mourners, farmers, knife grinders, guerrillas and all the others of the great masses forced to carry on their work without musical sounds, it would be an impossible and drab kind of life.

Growing scarcity of supplies has caused a sharp increase in the number of potential customers for wholesalers of dry goods and general merchandise, and it was predicted last week that relations built up with many customers during this emergency period might well lead to a broader post-war field for the wholesalers.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora threw out the entire primary petition for John R. Davies, opponent of Mayor La Guardia for the Republican Mayoralty nomination, at 9:10 o'clock "last night on the ground that the petitions that had been circulated for the former president of the National Republican Club were "saturated with fraud."

Dean Thorndike Saville of the New York University College of Engineering, who has been in the forefront of those warning against the danger of Federal encroachment upon engineering schools through the subsidization of defense courses, declared yesterday in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase that the present crisis should temper criticism of national policy in this field.

Fall courses begin this week at the city's two botanical gardens. Miss Hester M. Rusk, instructor, will conduct a course in "Fall Wild Flowers in the Garden" on Tuesdays at 10:45 A. M. and in "Native Ferns in the Garden" Monday evenings, from 6:30 to 7:30, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

American cities, long suffering from the handicaps of ill-advised planning, misdirected and overambitious suburban expansion and hit-or-miss traffic systems, need a new approach to the problem of future development and major operations to remove the cancerous growth of blighted areas before they can offer to their residents all the amenities which urban families now require for gracious living.

Following a hearing that began a week ago Friday during which night sessions were held, Justice Edwin L. Garvin, in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday ruled valid the petition of John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, which seeks for Mr. Cashmore a place on the Republican ballot in the primaries to be held Sept. 16. Mr. Cashmore is already the designee of the Democratic party to succeed himself.

In a recent study of crying in young children (reviewed in this column) the biggest group of situations which sent the-youngsters into tears involved the "establishment of health routines." There were seven categories in this group, starting with eating, going to bed and dressing.

SOMETHING new is promised by Helen Hayes for the radio theatre she will bring to the wave lengths for a second run Oct. 5 at 8 P.M. on WABC's local stage. Having had her fling last season in presenting those established plays or stories in which she always had wanted to act, her plan now is to book original dramas written expressly for her show as well.

HERE is a text for the times, a brief novel depicting the opening phases of an Axis-United States war commencing with simultaneous actions between our Pacific fleet and the Japanese navy near Guam and a series of encounters between the Atlantic fleet and a German-Italian force in the Caribbean.

WHEN Summer visitors pack off to the city with their children, their suntans and a new crop of reminiscences, vacation time begins for hard-worked members of art colonies scattered from semi-suburban Westport to the jigsaw-puzzle coastline of Maine.

Polo staged a preview of its coming national championship within the shadows of Manhattan's sky-scrapers yesterday as Texas and a picked Long Island team played on Governors Island for the benefit of the Army Relief Fund.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- For the third straight day grain and soy bean futures sold today at the highest prices in four years, with persistent buying by commission houses a factor. Brokers said public interest was increasing steadily.

MOST contestants in national bridge tournaments use the same bidding system, though they have various names for it. The American Contract Bridge League for some years has barred other bidding systems unless their users can explain them to each set of opponents without unreasonably delaying the game.

BOLTING their breakfasts, snatching their books, five mornings a week children dash out of the house and off to school. What can harried mothers do about it, this column is asked, and how much breakfast does a school child need?

VIENNA, va. THE Autumn sun shines down upon ripe fields. The silk on the tasseled corn is dry. Beans lie in the soya pods. The grass in the meadow nods its bloom. Acres of orchard trees are full bent, branches laden with late pears and apples, yellow and red.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- The Soviet High Command, in a Communique early today, described a stone-wall stand by the Red Army all along the front in fighting marked by aerial combats and heavy artillery fire.

On a World Front The shadow of the world's lengthening war hung most heavily last week over the bloody Russian battleground, where uncounted legions of men have perished in eleven weeks of unrelenting conflict. The military machine with which Adolf Hitler has conquered almost all Europe moved forward, but slowly and apparently at high cost.

TRAVEL LINES: Young hikers will find ten youth, hostels between Calgary and Banff where food and lodging are inexpensive. Ranches, lakes, fishing, forests, farms, offer diversion on the 150-mile hike. . . . Recreation, travel and fun in our national parks are being enjoyed by 20,000,000 people annually, thanks to the hard work of the National Park Service, which is celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of its establishment. . . .

The American Friends of Czecho-Slovakia issued a statement yesterday asserting that German families who had moved to Bohemia and Moravia by the thousands to escape British bombings had begun returning home at the end of July.

The Canary Islands, like all of Spain, are today desolate and barren. Trade has died and communication with the outside world has practically ceased. Only once a week does an almost empty steamer ply between the islands and Barcelona.

EIGHT exhibitions will open this week in local galleries, museums and other institutions. Knoedler's will place on view tomorrow, in the second floor gallery, water-colors executed by Arthur B. Davies in 1927, the year before his death.

Formal articles of consolidation creating the new Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., through the merger of a group of subsidiaries of the Midland United Company of Chicago, once an Insullcontrolled property, were filed yesterday with the Secretary of State of Indiana.

WHEN this war's history is written the air mail is certain to receive honorable mention for having blazed new routes to maintain oceanic and continental communications that otherwise would have been delayed or interrupted.

BAGHDAD, Sept. 6 -- As if by prearranged signal, a series of isolated revolts and organized rebellions against Axis rule is igniting Southeastern Europe. Something approaching a revolution threatens the German and Italian front and rear at a period which historians may cite as the turning point of the second World War.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Sept. 6 -- Wild Root, a mule whose name has become a legend in the United States Army, was retired from service today with all the pomp and circumstance that could be contrived by the officers and men of the Fourth Field Artillery.

PULSE beats of the New York art world quickened a bit last week with, the opening of a half dozen exhibitions, premonitory of the Fall season. Several institutions and galleries were among the early Autumn, 1941, trail breakers.

NIAGARA FALLS -- Only two and a half years after the collapse of the Honeymoon Bridge here a new structure, known as the Rainbow Arch, will be opened to traffic late this month. Formal dedication ceremonies, which President Roosevelt is expected to attend, will probably take place on Oct. 7.

BOSTON, Sept. 6 -- A flood tide of spending is under way in New England. Only the thoughtful minority think of the swelling wave as the result of an artificial business boom. The masses, finding themselves in possession of an abundance of money to spend, seem ignorant of, or indifferent to, the danger of inflation.

Culminating a series of tests made under all kinds of weather conditions and employing two airplanes and a two-way radioequpiped police sedan, the Police Department has set up a plan whereby, in the event of a threat to the city's safety under enemy attack, each of the department's more than 1,000 vehicles will be spotted and directed from the air, it was learned at Police Headquarters yesterday.

Statisticians would have to unearth some musty records to find a session on the stock market as completely stalemated as that of yesterday, for, although the volume of trading was the heaviest for a Saturday in about a month, more issues closed unchanged than showed price variations.

Gardeners with a scientific turn, of mind may be interested to know that a common, vacuum-cleaner can easily be rigged to rid greenhouses of moths responsible for the leaf tyer and leaf roller grubs. These moths usually enter greenhouses from outdoors and start laying eggs (500 to 700 eggs in three weeks per moth!) from which hatch grubs that do serious damage.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the Spring of 1941 a friend asked whether Germany's spectacular successes were not due to the fact that she might be a superior race biologically. My answer was that there was nothing from what one read or heard to indicate any characteristics that might be associated with biological superiority.

Although the white marlin have almost ceased to show an interest in the baits presented by the anglers off Ocean City, Md., a substitute has made an appearance, for during the past week some of the offshore anglers have brought in as many as 150 bluefish.

A squad of forty-five will report to Coach Lou Little tomorrow morning at Baker Field to begin training for Columbia's sixty-first year of intercollegiate gridiron competition, a year which will be marked by one of the most difficult schedules the Light Blue forces have ever encountered.

THE New York Grand Opera Company will inaugurate a season of popular-priced opera at the Ambassador Theatre Thursday night. "Carmen" is announced as the opening opera, to be followed Friday by "La Boheme."

SWISS RATION: For three days last week the sale of cheese was banned in Switzerland as a prelude to rationing that cut consumption by 50 per cent. Last year the little neutral nation had the world's largest per capita consumption of cheese -- nineteen-and-three-quarter pounds.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Daylight assaults by American-built Flying Fortresses and Britain's new four-motor bombers have snarled German communications from Norway to France and caused havoc in the Reich's war industries, the Air Ministry reported today.

As America's colleges and universities prepare to open this Fall, the shadow of war and defense still obscures their immediate program. It is fair to assume that of the nearly 1,500,000 young men and women who will return to the campuses, few will escape some of the war's effects.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 6 -- To keep "the human touch" with 11,000 students is the task facing the University of Texas, which in a decade has almost doubled its enrollment and has shot into the upper brackets among the country's large higher educational institutions.
BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- President Roosevelt was openly accused in official quarters today of an attempt to precipitate an incident at sea for the purpose of bringing the United States into the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A waste paper conservation program, which started this week in New York, Chicago and Milwaukee, soon will be enlarged to include thirty other major cities, reaching a population of some 40,000,000. This was announced today by the Offices of Production Management and Price Administration.

Trying conditions prevailed for the fleet of forty-seven craft that participated in the opening heat of the two-day national canoe sailing championships which opened yesterday off the City Island Yacht Club. A tweiity-five-mile wind that made the surf extremely choppy prevented all except seventeen boats from crossing the finish line.

MORE than 1,250,000 boys and girls are entering the senior class this month in the high schools of the United States. Another 1,000.000 who started with them in high school have fallen by the wayside. Of six entering junior high only three finish senior high and of the three who are graduated only one goes on with formal schooling.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued the following communique today:

Editor The New York Times Book Review: THE "objective scholarship" which Mr. John Cournos finds in Professor Hearnshaw's "Germany, the Aggressor Through the Ages" (New York Times BOOK REVIEW, Aug. 23, 1941) cannot fail to impress the reader.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Believing that the average citizen needs a better understanding of the problems America would face if threatened by invasion, Colgate University has added a course in "Geographic Defenses of the United States" to its curriculum for the 123d year opening Sept. 24.

BERLIN, Sunday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Germans reported today that they had penetrated the defenses of Leningrad in at least one place after attacks by strong German Air Force units and long-range artillery bombardment.

HARRY HOPKENS returned from London a few weeks ago without his hat. It was a famous hat. What made it famous was its banged-up and slouched-down appearance. It was generally worn turned up in front and flopped down at the sides. It attracted attention from the English at once, for in the England of happier days only a duke could afford the solid comfort of a battered old felt hat.

One of the outstanding features of the Summer season in the buying and building activities on Long Island has been the increasing attention directed toward Nassau County, especially in the old established home centers near the Queens County line.

"THERE'S rosemary, that's for remembrance," said gentle Ophelia. But rosemary is for seasoning, too, and for many centuries the tiny curled leaves have seasoned the soups of Central Europe, where the plants grow wild. Rosemary and rue perfumed the cozy kitchen of Ann Hathaway's little cottage and found their way, doubtless, into some succulent Shakespearean stew.

The colorful Puentes Grandes team of Havana, champion soccer eleven of Cuba, will meet a combined Brooklyn Hispano and St. Mary's Celtic squad at Starlight Park today in the feature contest of a double-header. The New York Americans will tackle Brookhattan in the curtain raiser, scheduled for 1 P.M.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 6 -- Jessie Gladys, claimed for $3,000 on Wednesday after she had run three times at Saratoga in claiming race with no takers, brought her new owner $5,090 today by winning the Mary Dyer Handicap at Narragansett Park.

Fordham University will reach the climax of its year-long commemoration of its 100th anniversary with a three-day celebration on Sept. 15,16 and 17, witft ceremonies scheduled on the campus In the Bronx and in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The triduum celebration will be directed by the Rev. Gustave Dumas, dean of the Graduate School of Fordham and general chairman of the university's centenary committee.

The President has hinted that a request for a new lease-lend appropriation will go to Congress tomorrow or the next day, and that additional requests will also be made for the domestic armaments program. In reply to a question at his press conference last week, he replied that "present plans were simply to spend more money and turn out more war materials."

All denominations attempt to teach the principles of religion, but they vary with regard to the method they use. The time when and the place where religious instruction is given are important with, respect to this matter. Protestantism believes that the church building and the morning worship are the place and the occasion most fit for the impartation of information, about religious truths, but Catholicism is of a different opinion.

One year ago the United States advanced its strategic frontiers 700 to 1,000 miles into the Atlantic as Britain, in exchange for fifty destroyers, granted us eight base sites from Newfoundland to British Guiana.

RICHMOND, Va. -- The scenic and recreational attractions of Virginia make it one of the most popular vacation and touring areas in the East. Thousands come here in the Spring, particularly during Garden Week, when many of the historic old mansions and gardens are open to the public, and each Fall additional thousands discover in Virginia the place for a perfect vacation.

To the Art Editor: I AM quite sure that no real bomb dropped even by the R.A.F. could so successfully have hit its target. And the artists' letters quoted in your article of Aug. 24 most successfully brought to light the situation of the unknown experimental artist in America.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- College men, who in a few more days will be headed back to their campuses, outnumbered other competitors this hot but windy afternoon on the Schuylkill in the amateur events of the Eastern divisional and American Power Boat Association outboard championships, and this naturally gave Prank Desmond another spot in the lime-light.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- Because a little girl kept a lemonade tend in Western Springs and four of her playmates came down with infantile paralysis, scientists have truck the hottest trail of the virus in the history of epidemiology.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 6 -- Next month hundreds of students will register for the ninety-ninth academic year of Villanova College.

NERVE ELECTRICITY -- It long has been known that nerves carry their messages by electro chemical means, but the exact relation between the electricity and the chemistry is still a subject of intensive study. The latest finding, reported in Science, concerns the autonomic nervous system which, without intervention by the conscious mind, regulates such matters as blood circulation, sweating and the dilatation of the pupil of the eye.

THE National Symphony Orchestra will open the first series of "Pop" concerts in its history, Sept. 22, at the Riverside Stadium, Washington, D.C. The concerts will be given on Monday and Thursday nights during a three-week season.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Hunters owned and shown by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Aubrey Hale of Greenwich, Conn., were prominent during the second annual Helping Hand horse show held under a cloudless sky today at Brighthome Farm.

A number of solemn thoughts of one sort and another run through one's mind at the announcement that the Berlin branch of the Russian Travel Bureau has been reopened. It takes one back to the hopeful Twenties, when Utopia in actual operation could be seen by travelers who didn't stray from their Soviet guides.
BOSTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Tommy Livingston's pinch-hit single in the ninth inning gave the Phillies a 4-3 victory over the Braves today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States has requested banks In the Far East to cooperate fully with the newly created Stabilization Board of China, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced today. He said the British Government would make a similar request.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial under the heading "An Old Right Suspended" might, despite your care, lead a careless reader to believe that the decline in the number of English jury trials, in civil cases, is a rather recent development.

-- OYSTER'S RETURN The ancient Greeks called them "the perfect prelude to a meal" and the Romans deemed them "dainty manna from the sea." Colchester in England has signaled the opening of the new oyster season for 900 years with a special ritual.

A pitched pistol duel between three policemen and five armed robbers in a bar and grill at 455 East 114th Street, near the East River, resulted at 11 o'clock last night in the death of a woman, the serious wounding of a lieuten ant of detectives and injury of a man customer.
ANOTED eighteenth century composer once remarked that he had learned to judge the worth of a new musical work by the audience's reaction when the music was performed for the first time.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after oll charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- British military quarters report tonight that evidence is accumulating of strain on German forces and increasing Nazi casualties, and say that unless the army can capture Leningrad before the bitter northern Winter sets in these difficulties will grow.

Charles E. Murphy, former president of the Advertising Club of New York, has been selected to direct the campaign of the three city-wide Democratic candidates, District Attorney William O'Dwyer, candidate for Mayor; Justice Lloyd Church, candidate for Controller, and M. Maldwin Fertig, candidate for President of the City Council.
SO far as new productions are concerned, last week was Russian Week and London had the chance to compare the theatres of the Czar and the Soviets on consecutive days.

THE function of Miss Maud Silver in this crime novel reminds one of that of the chorus in a Greek tragedy. She is a commentator and an interpreter of events rather than an investigator, although she is a private investigator by profession.

AFTER attending the theatre regularly for a good many years a man is likely to get stage - struck. This silly thought popped into my head last Tuesday evening at the reopening of Moss Hart's "Lady in the Dark." Any constant playgoer ought to grow accustomed to the luster and magic of the professional musical stage, which has been passing miracles for a long time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- Authoritative defense quarters disclosed today that Russia had requested aluminum supplies from the United States to offset losses in productive capacity caused by "scorched-earth" destruction of facilities at the Dniepropetrovsk dam and disruption at Leningrad.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- Contributions from members of the Presbyterian Church in the United States for the year ending' March 31 were $42,200,443, the largest amount in more than nine years, according to a church report today.

TWIN FALLS, Idaho -- One of my favorite diversions is to drive downtown, park the car in a busy spot and watch the people. Plots for short stories and articles have come to me while I was parked downtown -- material that found a ready market.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 6 -- Within the next two weeks about sixty students of Wesleyan University, now living in dormitories and fraternities on the campus, will leave Summer jobs in manufacturing and construction concerns working for national defense and return to their classes.

THERE aren't many people who would undertake writing, directing and producing a program in a foreign language like, for instance, Portuguese. Even a master director, Earle McGill, has never been faced with such an assignment, or so he says.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment has been halted in its work by lack of funds and will appeal to Governor Lehman and the legislative leaders to sign certificates of consent making funds available pending appropriation by the next Legislature.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 6 -- Since the beginning of the German-Russian, war and the simultaneous increase in the Intensity of British bombings, the morale of the German home front has substantially weakened. Such is the unanimous conviction of objective and qualified observers in Stockholm.

THEY lived quietly and well in Holland, slow-moving but energetic, rooted in old dignities, yet lusty and free. Mevrouw Haming kept her shop in the big house on the canal, near the quays of what had once been a busy port on that Zuyder Zee now golden with wheatfields.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 6 -- With more than $350,000,000 in defense orders, ranging from ships, shells, smokeless powder and aluminum to underwear, Alabama is experiencing the biggest boom in history. The spending and employing are reflected in lines of depositors at the banks, compounded crowding at the five and ten cent stores, day-long attacks on department store counters, where sales are about 33 per cent over a year ago.

IN his new novel, "County Seat," Paul Corey again uses the Iowa countryside as background and the members of the Mantz family as his main characters. It may be he is planning a saga of the Mantzes, that is, if the word "saga" can be used to describe a group so little illumined by any spark of grandeur.

CAVEMEN: Amid the woods of Bear Mountain, overlooking the Hudson River about fifty miles north of midtown Manhattan, lie the fieldstone buildings of the Trailside Museum. The most popular exhibits of the museum are the live animals.

SEATTLE, Sept. 6 -- A newest bomber in the B-17 line of Flying Fortresses was ready for service today following its successful completion of air tests. Known as the B-17E model, the ship bristles with guns and is equipped for super-charged, high-altitude flying.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: News travels slowly to this diminutive hamlet on the east coast of Nantucket, and I have only just heard of the death two weeks ago of my friend Julius Holz, publisher of the German language daily, The Newyorker Herold.

SOME like it hot, some like ill cold, but many motorists like brisk Fall weather as the perfect background for short trips. With gasoline saving now almost mandatory, these trips must indeed be short. Sharp sunlight flooding country roads and warming the air's sting is a suitable sauce for picnics, football games, hunting and mountain drives.

THE centenary of the birth of W. H. Hudson has been celebrated by several literary tributes to his work, as well as by more than one B. B. C. broadcast. The Times Literary Supplement devotes to him a full-page biographical and critical article and also an editorial.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 -- Defense spending in St. Louis and cities of the general area has brought with it a business bonanza of sizable proportions, but nothing as fantastic as the boom orgy of the late Twenties. There is no tendency here to view the pyramiding sales and big pay jobs as endless economic manna, but there is a definite spending splurge.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 6 -- With a west-northwest breeze that blew up to seventeen knots at the finish, 134 craft took part today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's championship series regatta out on Long Island Sound.

CONGRESS is looking around for new sources of revenue in order to put the finishing touches to the biggest tax bill in our history. As it is, life is already an ambush of little hidden taxes. You fill out no tax-form and sign no check when you pay 16 cents for twenty cigarettes.
At the quarterly meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club to be held Tuesday a proposed amendment to the rules applying to registration and field trials will be presented.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood, in a speech in Edinburgh, Scotland, today, called upon the British people to make even greater savings and pledged unlimited financial assistance to Russia.

To its large collection of views of old New York the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth. Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, recently added an original drawing that helps to visualize hotel life here 100 years ago.

Widely divergent procedures are being employed by various companies in the consumer durable goods fields to reorganize their selling and advertising staffs as a result of production curtailment, reports here last week indicated. They range from wholesale firings to no changes at this time, although there is no assurance that companies which so far have maintained their staffs will do so.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 -- This area is in the midst of a defense boom in which contracts held by the shipyards and aircraft factories are the major elements in the greatly stepped-up industrial production. Airplane manufacturers have orders, both British and American, that total some $1,500,000,000, and the shipbuilders are at work on approximately $300,000,000 worth of contracts.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- With the laying of the keel of the 10,000 ton cruiser Wilkes-Barre, the 111-year-old Cramp shipyard in Kensington was formally reopened today and the Delaware River basin brought to a high station in the naval rearmament program.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Mal Stevens's doubts concerning the availability of two keymen for next season have been cleared up sooner than he expected, but not in a manner to cause the N Y.U. coach, much joy.

ON another page of this issue there appears a review of Mr. Eugene Lyons's "The Red Decade." As Mr. Eastman remarks in the course of his comment on the book, the facts therein contained are fabulous. The case history of the American fellow-traveler is one of the most comi-tragic clinical footnotes to American history.

Several hundred retailers from, all sections of the country will attend the dinner to be held at the Mayflower Hotel, Washington, on Sept. 15, marking the opening of "Retailers-for-Defense Week," it was learned yesterday. Donald M. Nelson, executive director of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, will be the guest of honor and chief speaker at the dinner.

Quietly, without any unusual fanfare or excitement, 1,000,000 boys and girls will return to their classrooms tomorrow morning, as the New York City school system opens another academic year. The pleasant ten-week Summer vacation will soon become even more delightful in nostalgic retrospect.

TUXEDO PARK. N.Y., Sept. 6 -- A Gay Nineties dinner dance, one of the most novel parties given here in several years, took place tonight in the clubhouse of the Tuxedo Club. The fete drew an attendance of more than 200 club members and their guests -- all attired in costumes reminiscent of the dernier cri in fashion a half-century ago.

THIS first novel is a crisp and incisive sketch of the late hours in the working day of a mismanaged and overmanaged advertising department in a big department store. It fairly tingles with tense nerves, muted mutiny and jangling purposes, all vibrant under the pressure of a rapidly approaching deadline.
DURHAM, N. H., Sept. 6 -- Federally sponsored defense training courses today were credited for doing a "great job" in opening the doors of industry to American boys and girls.
THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined slightly in the week ended Aug. 30. It was 130.5, compared with 130.8 for the previous week and 109.1 for the week ended Aug. 31, 1940.

The office of Coordinator of Ship Repair and Conversion, which was opened here two months ago to serve the Maritime Commission and the Navy in the important job of returning ships to sea duty as quickly as possible, is already functioning at top speed and the national repair situation is "well in hand," according to John E. Otterson, the coordinator.

THE Indian Is no longer the "vanishing American." The "domesticated" Redskins who do "old war dances" for tourists at holiday resorts are not the last sad remnants of their race. The trend toward extinction has been stopped;
THE Yankees have knocked more baseballs out of the parks and brought more spectators into the parks than any other club in the two big leagues. One thing led to another in that case.

A plan to establish a separate company which would handle the repair and maintenance of electrical appliances under the new program of the Consolidated Edison System, companies will be presented to dealers by E.F. Jeffe, vice president, at a meeting at the company's headquarters on Tuesday.

HERE is a biography written with a zest and an enthusiasm that are contagious. Those who love the Uncle Remus stories -- and who does not? -- will thoroughly enjoy discovering the modest, retiring and original personality responsible for the appearance in print of Br'er Rabbit, Br'er Fox, Br'er B'ar, Sis Cow and all the rest.

To the Radio Editor: THIS letter is being written in defense of the nation's networks' radio announcers and is meant to straighten out people that fall into Mr. Fred C. Kelly's category. His letter is printed in today's TIMES and your caption "Back to School, Boys" does a grave injustice to the men who play so vital a part in our vast radio industry.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- As the German invasion of Russia enters its twelfth week Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine, and Leningrad, according to Berlin sources, appear to be faced with capitulation or annihilation soon.

MEXICO ON PARADE" is the slogan for next month when that country puts on its most brilliant regalia for the second Inter-American Travel Congress opening in Mexico City on Sept. 15. The business sessions of the congress, which will draw travel officials from all the Americas, will be interspersed with a social program continuing the nine days of the conference.

No limit lower than $7,500 should be placed on new one-family houses in the New York City or Long Island areas and two-family houses should be proportionately higher if any priority order is issued concerning such construction, declares Frank Fox, president of Realty Associates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Diversion of materials from normal channels to the defense program appeared to be having an increasingly critical effect today as Floyd B. Odium, head of the newly created Division of Contract Distribution, prepared to tackle President Roosevelt's assignment to keep small industries functioning by bringing them into the defense effort.

THE reader who wants a first-hand factual picture of Germany at war, cool, objective and unbiased, cannot afford to overlook this report of an American newspaper man who left Berlin a few months ago. Both the physical details of wartime Germany and the mentality which the German people have developed under the impact of the war are described vividly and convincingly.

With the time for replanning and replanting now approaching, any gardener who is thinking of remodeling -- indeed, the maker of a new garden, for that matter -- may well investigate the advantages of a real woodland for one or more of the boundaries of his property.

WILLIAM ROGERS DEERING and Alexander Kirkland -- they produced "Out of the Frying Pan" last season -- plan to begin this semester with Walter Hackett's new play, "Thirteen o'clock" (temporary title), nee "News of the World."

TO point out the uses of historical novels is an adventure, this English scholar says. He begins his diverting enterprise with a brief consideration of the novel in general and the historical novel in particular; and the latter, he notes, must be more than informative if it is to be really good:

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Three sharp-shooters of big-money golf -- Ben Hogan, Byron Nelson and Sam Snead -- closed in today on that surprising fairways sniper from the Ozarks, Leonard Dodson, laying the groundwork for a wide-open final round tomorrow in the $11,000 Tam O'Shanter championship.

Should the pledge of the oil companies to use "surplus" tank cars as much as possible to prevent a shortage of fuel in the East Fact to lessen the possibility of more pipe lines being constructed, railroad managements will be relieved greatly.

MANILA, Sept. 6 -- The United States Army's vigilance against military surprise in the Philippines has been augmented by rooftop patrols in half a dozen strategic Manila spots guarding against the unheralded approach of strange airplanes or unexpected developments of whatever nature.

Despite occasional reports to the contrary, by and large the morale of the men in the Army camps is high, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, declared yesterday in his sermon. Rabbi Rosenblum has just returned from a month of special service as chaplain with the United States Army at Camp Edwards.

Denouncing the "savage and bestial might" by which Germany seeks to challenge America's freedom of the seas, Wendell L. Willkie, asserting that he voiced "the overwhelming sentiment of my fellow Americans," urged President Roosevelt yesterday to meet the Nazi threat "with determination and force."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The following Foreign Service changes since Aug. 30 were announced today by the State Department: Dudley G. Dwyre of Fort Collins, Col., First Secretary of the American Legation and consul general at San Jose, Costa Rica, designated First Secretary of Legation at Guatemala.

About 51,000 students will register for the Fall semester this week in the city's four colleges, including 3,830 selected high school graduates as entering freshmen. Unlike most private colleges throughout the country, enrollment in the municipal system of higher education will suffer no decrease because of the war and the Selective Service Act.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 6 -- A Plainfield twosome and three teams representing the home club put together plenty of pars and birdies to gain, the semi-final round of the New Jersey State Golf Association partners' best-ball tournament at the Trenton Country Club today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox came back to capture the second game of a double-header today, 7 to 1, after dropping the decision to the St. Louis Browns in the opener, 3 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Defense officials and British supply officers here were cheered on several counts this week by the announcement from OPM that military aircraft deliveries by United States manufacturers in August reached an all-time high of 1,854, an increase of 394 over the preceding month and of 1,268 planes over August, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Great Britain is developing in the United States a wartime army of diplomats, technicians, propagandists and civil servants that is unprecedented in Anglo-American, relations. There are now 4,626 persons on the payroll of the British Government in this country, 4,407 more than there were at the outbreak of the war.

THOUSANDS of books must have been written about the placer-mining days in California, hundreds must still be accessible in the larger libraries and there have been many reprints and modern reappraisals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- An attachment for cameras which, automatically feeds photo-flash lamps successively into place for taking the next picture, as bullets are fed to firearms, is the invention for which a patent (No. 2,254,888) was issued to Michael J. Neumann de Margitta of New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The New Jersey State Building and Construction Trades Council, A. F. of L., meeting at the Hotel Ritz Carlton, at its thirty-eighth annual convention, rejected today a resolution demanding a 25 per cent increase.

Dealing a sweeping setback to the Board of Higher Education, Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga ruled yesterday that Townsend Harris High School, a preparatory school operated in conjunction with City College, must continue in existence and accept new students for the Fall term starting Sept. 15.

THOUGH Congress has not yet got around to enacting anticipated legislation which would bar Axis propaganda, pictures from this country, German films have already felt the pressure of more stringent enforcement of existing laws governing the import of foreign films.

Self-registration of almost 3,000 Hunter College juniors and seniors this week is another step toward the development of self-reliance in Hunter girls, according to Professor Mary Belden James Lenn, registrar.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- A German submarine fired two torpedoes at the United States destroyer Greer, a German communique acknowledged today, but it declared that the American warship was the aggressor and acted on orders of President Roosevelt.

Donald McNeill's one-year reign as national tennis champion was brought to an end yesterday by Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., and Robert L. Riggs, the 1939 title-holder, barely eked out victory in the fifth set over Frederick Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., in the semifinals of the national tournament at Forest Hills.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- Odessa, capital of the Soviet Union's "Riviera," still is holding out stoutly, altnougli it has been besieged almost a month. On the land approaches to the city new Russian fortifications form a great horseshoe. The city is continually supplied by the Red Banner Black Sea Fleet, which is shuttling convoys back and forth.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The Field Day and Pet Show to be held on the afternoon of Sept. 20 on the Polo Field at Woodlands, the estate here of Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, will be the last garden event of the season for the benefit of the Westchester Children's Association.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read the letter of John Cudahy which appeared recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which he suggests that President Roosevelt should intervene in the interests of peace. In his opinion, neither the President nor Winston Churchill could venture to disregard a proposition which would have such powerful backing.

Professional football crashed into the sports-consciousness of the New York fans last week when the New York Giants polished off the Eastern College All-Stars. This week it will deliver a triple blow at them.

The first meeting in the FHA's campaign to enlist the support of private capital in the defense housing movement in the New York City area will be Held tomorrow night at the Hempstead Golf Club, Hempstead, L.I., announces Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director.

Retail trade continued unusually active here last week. Department store volume was estimated as showing an increase of 25 to 30 per cent over a year ago, a substantially larger percentage increase than occurred in the preceding week. Active consumer interest was reported in Fall apparel, which helped both the department stores and specialty shops.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Members of society who follow polo are enthusiastically cheering, almost every day at one of the geven fields of the Meadew Brook Club, here, the players on the teams competing for the major polo events this month -- the national open tournament which starts next Saturday and the Monty Waterbury Cup matches which will follow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Alsab, biggest bargain in horse flesh in ten years, scored his fifth successive stake victory today, increasing his earnings as the nation's leading money-winning juvenile to $72,180.

Proceeding on the theory that "youth can best be served by a college which enters fully and helpfully into the life of its community," Queens College announced today the opening of extension courses for the Fall semester.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Superior children may come from homes in any economic level, but the, chances are that they will be found in middle-class homes, Dr. W. Drayton Lewis, assistant professor of psychology at Murray State Teachers College, Murray, Ky., told the National Convention of the American Psychological Association today as the session ended.
BERLIN, Sept. 6 (U.P) -- All Jews over 6 years of age were ordered by the secret police today to wear a large yellow star of David with the black superscription "Jew."

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Soldiers in the Forty-fourth. Division's recently organized anti-tank battalion have a "chaplain's fund" from which they can borrow money when they become financially embarrassed, it was revealed here today.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A heavy wind that churned treacherous waves in Lake Erie today damaged one sailboat, capsized three and forced withdrawal of eleven others entered in the national Comet Class regatta, but the Sea Robin rode out the waves to capture the second race.

These late Summer and early Autumn, days yield a rich harvest in the home defense garden. The grower is so justly proud of her great crimson tomatoes, crisp string beans, luscious limas and sweet golden, corn, that it is a temptation to give away the late season surplus of garden produce to appreciative friends.

The Chilean Line announced yesterday that it had taken a lease on Pier 1, at the foot of Columbia Street, Brooklyn, and that all passenger and freight vessels of the line, with a few exceptions, would operate from the pier in the future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Overcrowded school facilities in booming defense centers, together with an impending shortage of teachers, is presenting to educators a major problem which they are hopeful of solving with government help.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were nominally steady today after a week of irregular advance, which was strongest in the sheep market. Not enough animals were put up for sale to test values today but the hog top held at $12.10 a hundredweight, or only slightly below the four-year peak.

PREPARING to lend a note of realism hitherto unknown in United States Army manoeuvres, between 800 and 1,000 military aircraft of the Army, Navy and Marine Corps have taken or are taking positions in Louisiana and Texas for the largest mockwar action in the history of this country.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 6 -- Carborundum, one of the hardest abrasives known, is the basis of a new source of artificial light which'may revolutionize electrical lighting. The carborundum light is the subject of a patent (No. 2,254,957) granted to Zoltan Bay of Ujpest, and Gyorgy Szigeti of Budapest, Hungary.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Seven housewives were arrested late this afternoon on gambling charges in a raid on an apartment at 93 Avon Avenue, in the Clinton Hill residential district, after a young woman had telephoned the police of the Fourth Precinct and complained that her mother was losing $20 a day at poker games in the apartment.

WITH the development of aircraft engines of high horsepower for the "stinging" pursuits and big bombers of the Air Corps, it becomes evident that new propellers must be designed which can absorb the full power of these engines.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 6 -- Corrigan, imported as a colt from Ireland by Carroll K. Bassett, triumphed in the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase over the difficult three-mile nineteen-jump course before a crowd of 10,000 today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 -- The Cardinals didn't have a chance against Johnny Vander Meer's two-hit pitching today as they dropped a 2-to-O decision to the Reds and fell two games behind Brooklyn.

With a weapon concealed from his superiors after they had forced him to relinquish his two service revolvers, Patrolman John F. Kehoe, ill of a nervous disorder for two years, shot and fatally wounded himself yesterday in the bathroom of his apartment at 2,105 Burr Avenue, the Bronx.

They stood In little knots about the bare ballroom of the Hotel Biltmore, somewhat embarrassed, but anxious to please; concerned mainly that they should let out no information that might be useful to Britain's enemies.

The developers of the Packanack Lake community in Passaic County, N.J., west of Paterson, have commissioned Cross Roads, Inc., to open a new section on the western shore of the lake for immediate construction of fifty homes for all-year occupancy.

The thirteenth, biennial convention of the American Pilots Association, nation-wide organization of State pilot groups serving thirty-three United States ports, will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania beginning Thursday, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- German reports admitted today that terrific Red Army counter-attacks were being hurled against Nazi lines at a dozen points along the eastern front, particularly along the lower Dnieper River.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A mighty new long-range, high-altitude bomber, believed by authorities here to be one of the world's most powerful aerial weapons, was ordered into mass production by the War Department today with awards of contracts totaling $347,156,674.

THE new installment terms were introduced smoothly in the week and retailers reported that trade continued at a normal pace. Some instances were related of attempts to dodge the credit regulations through one device or another.

THE Pinkertons have been writing for thirty years, have turned out enormous quantities of fiction for the pulp paper magazines, but always until just recently "we wrote to live: our pleasure was in building houses, varnishing boats, exploring country that was new to us.

BERNE, Switzerland (By Telephone). THE German soldier was born in the bitterness of the World War, bred in the strife and revolutions of the years that followed, and trained in the iron school of Nazi discipline. Today for the first time he is fighting an enemy who matches his offensive fire with a defensive fanaticism backed by the same power from which the German draws his strength -- a revolutionary ideal.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- Marshal Klementy E. Voroshiloff's army defending Leningrad has made another series of stiff counter-attacks to the south, driving back German forces seeking to close about the city, it was reported today as the entire front remained active and new Nazi thrusts at Kiev were beaten off.
Middle-age conquered youth in a special checker contest conducted yesterday by the City Park Department.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After reading the article in THE TIMES in which Professor Irving Fisher's address to the World Fellowship at Conway, N.H., was quoted, I cannot see how any open-minded individual can disagree with the idea of world union which he advocates, or can longer hold on to the theory of isolationism.

As a result of the signing by President Roosevelt of the bill to increase by $200,000,000 the FHA's authorization to insure loans financing privately built defense housing in vital areas, Administrator Abner H. Ferguson declares that financing facilities will be assured for the construction of about 60,000 additional dwelling units under Title VI of the National Housing Act.

Marvin Ereuer stepped forth, blithely in a bid for his tenth victory yesterday as the new American League champions returned to the Stadium before a gathering of 10,286 fans, but the Red Sox sneaked in three runs before he was fully alive to what was happening and Joe Cronin's men romped off with the ball game, 8 to 1.

WELLESLEY, Mass., sept, 6 -- Students returning to Wellesley College this month will find construction of the new wing to Simpson Infirmary well under way. This addition, which is considerably bigger than the original infirmary, was begun last Spring and will be ready for use during the second semester of the coming academic year.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 6 -- The National Sugar Institute sold today 275,863 long tons out of the 400,000 tons of its surplus sugar, financed by the Export-Import Bank of Washington, Senator Jose Manuel Casanova, president of the institute, said tonight.

A RECAPITULATION of the stamps issued during the two years of the war shows that a minimum of 1,245 major and minor varieties appeared, attributed directly to conditions caused by the conflict. Releasing of scores of other warcaused postage items has been reported, and it seems probable that still more were issued of which collectors have not yet been informed.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The Admiralty today announced that two more Italian ships had been sunk by British submarines in the Mediterranean. One of them, was the liner Esperia, of 11,398 tons, torpedoed off Tripoli, and the other was identified as a ship of the Ramb class which have 4,000 tons displacement and a good turn of speed.

IT isn't every night I get around to seeing a play. Unless you go to every opening, hot to cold, there is a set of rules to follow. First you read the notices to learn if you want to see the play at all. After that you ask the wife If she wants to see it. If she does, the two of you sit down and decide upon the night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 5:

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 6 -- None of the craft in the Riverside Yacht Club's race for the New Rochelle Cornfield Light Vessel Challenge Cup had finished as darkness fell over Long Island Sound today and the committee was prepared to spend the rest of the night anchored off Greenwich Point aboard F.A. Merrill's yawl Ariadne waiting for them.

With, vivid memories of their 1940 experiences and with a number of new wrinkles and altered plans, a group of Northern yachtsmen, mostly New Yorkers, have begun getting their boats ship-shape for the second annual "Southward Ho" cruise to Miami.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The United States is expected to protest to Germany about the attack on the destroyer Greer in view of the official Nazi admission today that one of their U-boats fired on an "unidentified destroyer" off the coast of Iceland Thursday.

Hyman Sehorenstein, Commissioner of Records for Kings County, whose ability to read and write has been a moot point during his twenty-six years in public office, made public yesterday an open letter to Mayor La Guardia. The letter was by way of reply to a remark made by the Mayor last Monday in signing the bill abolishing the office of Commissioner of Records in New York and Kings Counties.

To the Art Editor: MR. KOOTZ speaks of American art as a spectator who has haunted the galleries in a negative, critical frame of mind for a decade. He has become so bored with his habitual reactions that he new demands "a bright, white hope" and "a new method of painting."

The attack made last week on the United States Destroyer Greer, admittedly by a German submarine, cannot properly be regarded as an isolated "incident." It is part and parcel of a deliberate campaign which has as its objective the closing of the sea lanes of the North Atlantic.

Few Into Many Polls of public opinion were severely handled by a speaker at the Chicago meeting of American psychologists. He did not quarrel, however, with the very small samples which the new scientific polls employ.

Another episode in the intense baseball rivalry between the Police and Sanitation Departments is scheduled for the Polo Grounds today, when their teams are to clash in their fifth annual benefit game, starting at 2:30 o'clock.

If Chief Justice Richard Morris had not become reconciled to his son-in-law, William H. Popham back in the eighteenth century, the real-estate history of Scarsdale Westchester, might have been different, according to Richard S. White, resident manager of the Scarsdale Chateaux.

AFTER six years of preliminaries and delays, the establishment of Big Bend National Park seemingly was assured recently when Governor W. Lee O'Daniel of Texas -- now United States Senator -- signel the bill appropriating $1,500,000 for the acquisition of the necessary lands.

FOR the sixth time since the Civilian Pilot Training Program of the CAA got under way in 1939, insurance rates for the student pilots have been voluntarily reduced by the insurance companies, Donald H. Connolly, administrator of the government agency, announced last week.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Jersey City broke even with the Baltimore Orioles in today's double bill, winning the opener, 11 to 3, but dropping the nightcap, 2 to 1.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6 -- Yale football losses because of the draft will be fewer than has been feared. Manager Ed Carpenter of the eleven said today that of the list of about seventy-five candidates invited to report here Wednesday sixty-five have agreed to be present.

HOLLYWOOD WHAT the town has considered the major miscasting of the year, the placing of Hedy Lamarr in the role of an efficient American business woman in an advertising agency, has been explained away by King Vidor, who made the assignment and who is directing "H. M. Pulham, Esq.," for Metro - Goldwyn - Mayor.

THAT fellow who, every so often, plops himself into the chair beside our desk and starts slamming questions at us in a rudely truculent tone was around the other day. He was blazing like a torch. Something he had read -- or eaten -- had agitated his spleen, and he scarcely had himself seated before his jaw was wagging darkly in our face.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Sept. 7 -- Russian marines succeeded shortly after dawn yesterday in making a surprise attack on the German-occupied coast west of Odessa, during which they inflicted heavy casualties on the German division and Rumanian regiment assigned to hold the area, Soviet sources reported early today.

Unions representing unlicensed personnel aboard United States merchant ships are expected to reject a plan for payment of war bonuses on a formula based on ship hull insurance rates when it is submitted to them by the United States Maritime Commission.

While striking employes of Gimbel Brothers department store conducted a mass picketing demonstration outside the store, a dozen bees, released from a paper bag, routed women shoppers from the jewelry counter on the street floor shortly after noon yesterday.

BASEBALL By downing the Giants, 4 -- 1, while the Cardinals were being beaten by the Reds, Brooklyn's Dodgers increased their lead to two games in the National League pennant race. The second-place Cards were baffled by Pitcher Johnny Vander Meer, who struck out fourteen and gave only two hits as the Reds won, 2 -- 0.
The USHA has earmarked Sl,000,000 for the construction of low-rent farm homes in Texas and another $550,000 for the same purpose in Florida, the Federal Works Agency revealed yesterday.

The largest single private wire system in the country is not operated by the Western Union Telegraph Company, as might generally be supposed, but by the United States Steel Corporation. To keep pace with the increasing tempo of defense production United States Steel and its subsidiaries have expanded their private leased wire system to a point where it is handling more than 11,000 messages daily.

THE war has begun to create mechanical problems for the recording companies. The chief difficulty is an impending shortage of materials, but it is not yet serious. Research staffs have been working busily in an effort to develop substitutes, and the indications are that they will succeed.

THIS is a book of American democracy as seen and felt by intelligent newcomers who have chosen the United States to be their country. It had its origin in broadcasts given on a program prepared by the Immigration and Naturalization Service of the United States Department of Justice.

LONDON, RUMMAGING through our old files the other day in search of some triviality or other we came across a review of "Midshipman Easy" 'dated December, 1933 -- a faded, slip, which brings back nostalgic memories of the week before Christmas, a small cinema now dark, a dirty Winter twilight, and the snow falling.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- Buck Newsom and Al Benton gave a total of eleven hits in pitching the Tigers to a double victory over Cleveland today, 7 to 2 and 6 to 2. As a result, Detroit climbed to a game and a half behind the fourth-place Indians.

If the liberal arts college is to withstand the strain of social changes ahead of us, it must get down to the simple basis of education, says Dean Charles Harold Gray of Bard College, Columbia University's residential and undergraduate unit at Annandale-on-Hudson, N. Y., in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) --The presence of large liners in Italian convoys recently attacked in the Mediterranean "undoubtedly" indicates that the Axis is attempting to reinforce its armies in North Africa, one well-informed observer said tonight, adding that it was reasonable to assume that "some of them are getting through since it is impossible to sink every ship that sets out."

Live oak timbers, believed to have been intended for building Civil War wooden naval vessels, have been uncovered in dredging operations at the Navy Yard, Brooklyn, and will now be used in connection with the construction of modern fighting ships, Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the yard, announced yesterday.

One of the theories of what Messrs. Hitler and Mussolini call the system of "capitalistic exploitation" is that goods and ideas compete with each other on their merits. There have been countless indications of what the "fruitful, peaceful and harmonious collaboration" which these two dictators propose to introduce will be like.

James J. Lyons, borough president of the Bronx, with Mayor La Guardia and Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, will speak tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at the dedication of the new $3,000,000 Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School for Boys, Grand Concourse and 153d Street, the Bronx.

PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Superb golf under pressure enabled Reginald G. Narelle and Edmond B. Overton of Pelham, winners of the medal, to lead the way into the semi-finals in the first annual member-guest invitation tournament at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 6 -- The annual member-guest golf tournament at the Tamarack Country Club today was distinguished by a brilliant 66 that was turned in by Neil White of the home club, one-time Southern amateur champion.

On our Science in the News page today is a collection of strange diagrams. They show the structures as the chemist conceives them of certain molecules known to produce cancer. It was for his brilliant fundamental study of these structures that Professor Louis Frederick Fieser of Harvard's chemistry department merited the Katherine Berkan Judd $1,000 prize of The Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases.
