Cancer-Causing Chemicals Professor Louis Frederick Fieser, to whom Memorial Hospital last week awarded a prize at $1,000 for his original work on cancer-producing chemicals, is something of a legend around Harvard, where since 1930 he has taught organic chemistry and pushed forward the boundaries of chemical knowledge.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- In the front rank among Fall attractions of New England's seacoast, off Long Island's Montauk and along New Jersey's northern shore is that lighting fish of roaming habits, the striped bass, familiarly known as the "striper."

MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 6 -- Suncastle, a 10-to-1 shot ridden by a member of the R.A.F., turned on a surprising burst of stretch speed to score a head victory in the 165th running of the historic St. Leger Stakes for 3-year-olds today.

Copies of a resolution pledging solidarity with the trade unions of Great Britain and the Soviet "Union were sent yesterday by the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., to the Ambassadors of both countries in Washington.

KITTERY POINT, Me. TO report on Army camp entertainments from the standpoint of a buck private is not without certain difficulties. Inhibitions of a peculiarly military kind keep crowding in on free critical faculties.

General Milan Neditch, Serbian leader who was once War Minister of Yugoslavia, spoke thus last week over the Belgrade radio to his defeated countrymen. The general was quoted by a pro-Axis Hungarian source, which implied that he was appealing for order in the land overrun by last April's Balkan Blitzkrieg.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6-Chairman Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said "the Nazis might as well learn now that we are going to defend our ships and our citizens."

OTTAWA, Sept. 6 -- Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King's visit to London has had repercussions that seem likely to provoke a new liveliness in the conduct of the war. He himself has obviously been stirred up, his compatriots think, by his contact with the leaders and people of Britain and, incidentally, by the physical fact of his air trip across the North Atlantic in a single night.

Many Manhattan apartment tenants already are comfortably settled in new suites for the coming year and have been able to avoid the troubles of last-minute moving because quite a few of the new buildings in the borough have been completed ahead of the traditional Oct, 1 leasing date.

Active leasing in the new Georgian-style garden-type apartment house, which will be ready for October occupancy, at 310 West Fifty-fifth Street, is reported by O.A. Robertson, Inc., agents. Arthur Weiser is the architect.

Many of the leading mortgage experts in the country will be among the speakers at the forth-coming annual convention in this city of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, Oct. 1 to 3, inclusive. Dean R. Hill, president, announces that one entire day will be devoted to urban mortgage banking problems and the position of the "conventional" loan in present real estate financing.

WILLIAMSBURG, VA. TWO graying men in their fifties met on a street corner in Williamsburg in 1926. One was John D. Rockefeller Jr., who had a great fortune. The other was the Rev. W.A.R. Goodwin, rector of Williamsburg's Episcopal Church, who had the idea of restoring the town to its eighteenth-century appearance and wanted to tell Mr. Rockefeller about it.

The massing of Bulgarian troops on Turkey's European frontier is once more causing anxiety in Kemal Ataturk's cubist concrete capital at Ankara. Bulgarian troop movements, concentrations and decrees of mobilization have long been a main interest of Turkish observers and a principal fear of the ever-sensitive, nervous, rumormongering Istanbul, glittering on the shores of the blue-watered Bosporus.

TO point out that the practice of a high and uniform degree of thrift, not to mention frugality, has never seen the distinguishing national characteristic of the American people is not to do them an injustice. Rather it is another way of saying that our country is unbelievably rich and wide and not yet fully developed.

DETROIT -- Automotive opinion is still sharply divided over the salability of new cars during the coming model year. There is no dispute over the salability, or fitness, of the 1942 cars which are commencing to reach the showrooms of dealers throughout the country.

As amended by the 1941 revenue bill (HR5417), passed last Friday by the United States Senate, the excess-profits tax is estimated by the Division of Research and Statistics of the Treasury Department to create tax liabilities for the calendar year 1941 of $2,157,000,000, as follows:

SKANEATLES, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Although Howard Siddon of Island Heights, N.J., representing the Barnegat Bay fleet, skippered his Beth across the finish line first in all three races of the National Lightning Class championship regatta, he lost the title today to John M. Stern from the Buffalo Canoa Club.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 6 -- Gratified with the achievements of its experimental Summer session, Brown University will continue its defense education program in applied mechanics during the coming academic year, according to plans disclosed today by Dean Roland G. D. Richardson of the Graduate School.

The current curtailment in so-called non-essential industries is approximating the pattern of the first European War, making allowance, of course, for the obvious differences in the type of industrial and consumer goods production in the two periods.

The biographies of musicians -- Mozart, Haydn, Schubert and others -- by Opal Wheeler and Sybyl Deucher, have been popular with child readers from 8 to 11 ever since they appeared. In "Curtain Calls for Franz Schubert" (and its predecessor, "Curtain Calls for Mozart") the authors present dramatic scenes from the life of the composer, with selections from his work.

ALTHOUGH Sir James Barrie, Bart., O.M., lived his filial quarter of a century in genteel seclusion, there are no secrets from the prying world now. In 736 closely printed pages, his official biographer, Denis Mackail, has exhausted the subject and worn the reader down.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Workers, children and bomb-snocked neurotics were led into dark and cold bomb-like vaults in London today and, in one of the most horrible experiments of the war, were exposed to an artificial Blitz bombing calculated to be just exactly as terrifying as the real thing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Some 499,000 defense and non-defense jobs were filled during July, a month in which job placements generally decline, it was announced today by Paul V. McNutt. Federal security administrator.

Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of the President, was not only the "Gracious Lady" revealed in a recent biography, but a gallant and spirited lady who knew how to enjoy her life as fully as she made it useful. "Mrs. James," as she preferred to be called, was always a figure in her own right and did not require her son's elevation to the Presidency to stamp her as a definite and forceful character.

At the request of Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District, "junk boats" operating in New York Harbor will be prohibited, beginning Nov. 1, as a means of curbing possible espionage or sabotage, License Commissioner Paul Moss announced yesterday.

The short interest at the close of business on Aug. 29 was 470,002 shares, according to a compilation by the New York Stock Exchange from reports submitted by members and member firms. This compares with 487,169 shares short on July 31. Both totals, however, do not include the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced from 97.7 to 97.9. This rise was chiefly the result of price increases in agricultural raw materials. The major raw materials index rose by 0.8 per cent, while the farm products group rose by 0.9 per cent, as higher prices for cotton, grains, and some livestock items more than offset lower prices for apples, oranges, and other livestock items.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The British Government's anti-inflationary price policy received a serious shock last week "when the Trades Union Congress rejected proposals for wage stabilization laid down in a "White Paper" published in July.

Two big innings, in each of which it scored four runs, enabled the Department of Sanitation baseball team to clean up the Police Department nine in their charity game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. While a crowd of 45,000 looked on, the Sanitation athletes tallied four times in the second inning and four in the sixth to cement an 11-to-7 triumph over the forces of law and order.

WEEK ENDED SEPT. 6, 1941 Continued strength in the Canadian dollar, which climbed to the highest price in two years, was the only development of significance in the foreign exchange market last week. Elsewhere the free pound sterling alone now of the European currencies, and the Chinese descriptions in the Eastern group, still traded, remained unchanged.

VICHY, France, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Cri du Peuple, published by Jacques Doriot, head of the anti-Communist French Populist Party, said today that scores of anti-Communists had received letters bearing the hammer and sickle seal -- the Communist insignia -- threatening them with the fate of Marcel Gitton, a former Communist Deputy turned collaborationist who was assassinated in Paris on Friday.

NO doubt these days ex-Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh has weighty matters occupying his time and mind, but if he could spare a few odd hours, he might learn something from a book published this morning: "No Other Road to Freedom,"* by Leland Stowe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Senate's recent authorization of a committee to recommend reductions of "non-defense expenditures" has focused attention on a problem which has been puzzling government experts ever since the term non-defense expenditure first became popular.

WITH BRITISH AND INDIAN ARMIES in Iran, Sept. 5 (Delayed) -- The Iranian campaign having come to a sudden and satisfactory end, the Indian soldiers in this theatre, many of whom were recruited not more than four months ago, have been robbed of an opportunity of proving their worth actually as warriors in General Sir Archibald Wavell's command.

Speaking at a Labor Sunday service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, stressed the common interest of labor and religion in the task of overthrowing Hitlerism.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- After fifty-five minutes of a nonchalant display of the fundamental plays of their T formation, the Chicago Bears, professional football champions, passed and ran 53 yards for the touchdown that defeated the New York Giants, 14 to 8, in an exhibition game today.
BERLIN, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Hundreds of German combat planes and divebombers attacked the defenders of Leningrad yesterday in the area south of Lake Ladoga, D.N.B. reported tonight.

From authoritative sources comes increasing recognition of the revolutionary change in strategical concepts that the airplane has now brought about. Writing in Army Ordnance, organ of the Army Ordnance Association, Lieut. Col. Thomas R. Phillips of the Army General Staff contends that the modern bombing plane has made the North American coast practically "impregnable to invasion."
BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Braves went on their biggest hitting spree of the year today to whip the Phillies twice, 17 to 6 and 10 to 1.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 7 -- According to a communique issued might by the Finnish High Comland, the Finnish troops north of Lake Ladoga have reached the River Svir, often mentioned in disussions concerning the so-called strategical border of Finland.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- There was continued silence today in official German quarters regarding the progress of operations on the Eastern Front. The High Command asserted tersely that the operations were following a "planned course." Other Berlin sources were slightly more" voluble. Leningrad apparently is still being bombarded by long-range German artillery.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A count of noses of Hollywood personalities enrolled in the Navy today revealed enough to make a feature production.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- A bull market was on in wheat last week, all deliveries of that grain selling in new ground since 1937, with the top figures of the season reached yesterday, despite liberal profit-taking sales and week-end evening up.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Sept. 8 -- As the twelfth week of the Russo-German war began Moscow military spokesmen said yesterday that Russian forces west and southwest of Leningrad had yielded very slightly. With the Germans pouring in elite troops and their newest material, every inch of ground gained by them can be considered dangerous.

Placing upon the shoulders of understanding Christian men and women the task of reconstructing civilization after the conflict is over, the Rev. Edmund A. Bosch declared yesterday that those with vision, assurance and courageous patience must put together the shattered fragments of the world and rebuild it anew.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen, N.J., has amassed more points than any other pilot in the country in a dozen seasons of speed-boat racing. Five times he has won the national high point championship, and his commanding lead again this Summer will undoubtedly bring him a sixth title.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Maritime Commission announced today that in allocating vessels in a given trade route it would give preference to American steamship owners and operators who have cooperated in the development of the American merchant marine by owning or operating United States flag vessels.
Thousands of persons witnessed rescues of occupants of two small sailing craft that capsized in near-by waters yesterday afternoon.

The Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer told members of Calvary Baptist Church 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning that "we are forced by the facts to agree with those who say that much of our national government is being operated by subterfuge and deception."
Mayor La Guardia said that "New York City mourns the passing of a typical American mother."

Fifty French sailors from crews of French ships still in the port of New York, together with a number of sailors serving as volunteers on British ships as part of the Free French Forces, attended yesterday a special solemn high mass for all French sailors who died in the war.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 8 -- The Japanese press today, despite the German version, insists that the real circumstances of the Greer incident remain obscure.

MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- Slashing Russian counter-attacks have succeeded in routing the Germans in pitched battles in the Karelian Isthmus forests north of Leningrad and in the bitterly contested Gomel area of the central sector, it was reported today as Nazi efforts to advance were repulsed all along the line.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Moving daintily and with that superb action characteristic of the hound species, Champion Flornell Glamorous padded softly and speedily across the turf late today to claim the judges' attention and impress herself on the minds of the spectators.

Two British mothers departed for Europe with their children yesterday aboard the American Clipper, which left La Guardia Field at 11:28 A.M., carrying thirteen other Lisbon-bound passengers, among whom were John Dos Passes and Thornton Wilder, both novelists and playwrights.

No American need hesitate in choosing between the word of our own Navy Department and the word of the professional liars of the Nazi Government as to who fired the first shot in the battle off Iceland. But we will make a mistake if we put the whole emphasis of our interest on this one point, to the exclusion of all others.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 -- The Reds jolted the second place Cardinals' fading pennant hopes again today, scoring a 5-to-2 triumph in the second game of a twin bill called because of darkness after eight innings.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The last-place Senators climbed within a half game of seventh place in the American League today by sweeping a double-header with the Athletics, 3 to 2 and 4 to 2.

It was a great day for the masculine ego at the Bronx Zoo yesterday. The heart of the dominant male must have swelled with pride and the ardent feminist must have flushed with resentment as Oka and Makoko, a pair of mountain gorilla babies, took up residence in their new cage and promptly gave a convincing demonstration of who's boss.
NEW YORK Truman H. Newberry, former Secretary of the Navy, and Mrs. Newberry will leave their Summer home in Watch Hill, R.I., on Wednesday and will be at the Plaza.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Jersey City ended the season today by taking both ends of a double-header from Baltimore, 10 to 5 and 7 to 4.

Five million pounds of metals vital to defense needs, including enough aluminum, to build 275 fighter planes or half as many bombers, will be saved this year by the Bell Telephone System through the substitution of other materials, according to announcement yesterday by the New York Telephone Company.
Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he was hopeful that the nightly gasoline curfew in the East Coast States would be rescinded "very soon."

HAVANA, Sept. 7 -- Former President Mario Garcia Menocal y Deop, one of Cuba's most famous political figures, died here in his home at Twenty-first and N Streets in the Vedado residential district this morning after a week's illness. His age was 74.

NIANTIC, Conn., Sept. 7 -- The feeding habits of the striped bass in the Niantic River continue to be unpredictable, and the experience of several anglers today disproved the theory that success rewards the one who is at the right place with the right bait at the right time.
HAVANA, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- General Menocal died of liver, kidney and circulatory ailments.

PANAMA, Sept. 7 -- In view of the tremendous number of merchant ships sunk in the present war, plus the shortage of tankers to haul oil from the United States Eastern seaboard to Russia and England, significance is seen in a recent announcement by the government of Panama that today 270 vessels, totaling approximately 1,175,000 tons, are registered in the nation's merchant marine, sixth largest in the world.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last week there appeared in news columns an item to the effect that certain workers at the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's yard at Kearny, N.J., had sent a telegram to President Roosevelt urging him to order a secret vote of the company's employes to determine whether the yard should be returned to the company or should continue to be administered by the Navy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Deliveries of about 33,000,000 pounds of cash lard all but wiped out last week the open interest in that delivery on the Board of Trade, but the liquidation by holders of September contract spread to the October future and was in sufficient volume to hold the market in check.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- With the crop-growing season for corn rapidly nearing an end, the trade is commencing to pay more attention to the possible government loan on the 1941 crop. On the basis of the parity price on Aug. 15 the prospective loan would be about 73 3/4 cents a bushel, or 12 3/4 cents more than on the harvest of the preceding season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Ida Lupino's next assignment a1 Warners will be "Juke Girl," the story of a nickel phonograph operator in the beer halls of the Florida back country. The yam was suggested by a magazine article by Theodore Pratt, and Pratt prepared a screen treatment from which Ken Garnet arid A.I. Bezzerides are writing the scenario.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- George Fox, former well-to-do coal operator of Chicora, Pa., who became a Detroit alley cleaner thirteen years ago, and was declared legally dead by a Pennsylvania court several years ago, died Saturday night in Receiving Hospital here.

With most of the Broadway theatres continuing their current attractions for second weeks or more, only three new films are scheduled for local theatres this week. The first arrival will be "Badlands of Dakota," which opens this morning at the Rialto.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The pennant-winning Newark Bears closed their International League campaign today by dividing a double-header with Syracuse before 5,000. They lost the opener, 7 -- 2, but came back with a 5-3 decision for their 100th victory.
Labor unions representing longshoremen and seamen will meet here this week to discuss changes in their present contracts, which expire Sept. 30.

The record-breaking Defense Tax Bill, having been approved by the Senate with remarkable speed, is now at the final and critical stage of its five months' career. It is to be sent to conference for agreement between the members of the two houses preparatory to final enactment. There ought to be no hesitation on the part of the conferees in agreeing upon the Senate version of the bill.

BURGER MOUNTAIN, N.C., Sept. 7 -- Today, 3,432 years after Moses showed the tablets bearing the Ten Commandments on Mount Sinai, the 76-year-old overseer of the Church of God walked up Burfer Mountain bearing a reproduction of these tablets on one arm and on the other a copy of the Beatitudes of the Sermon on the Mount.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Something new under the sun was unveiled today when the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and the Fort Hill fleet got together to run a benefit yacht race.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- Although, almost buried beneath an avalanche of forms and paper work necessary to classify the tremendous volume of unfilled steel tonnage, the industry last week was nevertheless able to retain a sufficiency of perception to be able to discern quite emphatically that difficult days are ahead for such consumers as are unable to produce priority ratings with their orders.
C.S. Forester, British author of "Captain Horatio Hornblower" and other novels, said on Saturday that he would start work immediately for the British Embassy in New York.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The tragedy that occurred a short distance from here in which three small children were burned to death due to the crash of an Army plane has caused a great deal of anxiety among all parents in this vicinity. My own children passed the spot only a short time after-ward.

In an open letter to Congress, made public here yesterday by Fight for Freedom, Inc., 1270 Sixth Avenue, a group of sixty-three persons charged that the coming hearings before a Senate subcommittee on allegations that the radio and motion-picture industries put out propaganda designed to get the country into war represented "the most barefaced attempt at censorship and racial persecution which has ever been tried in this country."

A plea for a religious vocabulary and an edition of the Bible that can be understood by all the people was made by the Rev. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Aug. 30 to Sept. 5 are given in the following tabulation: The Senate On the committee amendment to lower personal income-tax exemptions, adopted 43 to 23:

Their ten-week Summer vacation nothing more than a treasured memory, the city's legion of school children, an estimated 1,010,670 strong, must tumble regretfully out of bed this morning, gulp their milk and cereal and trudge off to continue where they left off last June, or start a totally new phase in their lives. School opens today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine gave a large supper party with music tonight at Valmay Cottage, her place in First Neck Lane. The occasion marked the birthday of the hostess. Mrs. Valentine's house party includes her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine Jr.; her sister, Mrs. William Vernon Booth, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Foster of Chicago and Edward Purcell Mellon of New York.

Reorders in the wholesale market during the past week reflected active buying in the retail field. Prices continued to rise in a great number of lines and early deliveries were at a premium on some merchandise. Reorders were heavy on back-to-school wear, crepe dresses and costume suits.

Smaller Turkeys Promised Rays of cheery news slip through the war-cloud pall now and then. One of these pleasant glimmerings of hope is the tip from the Farm Research Division of the North Carolina State College that a small turkey is being developed for the market.
An innovation in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's work with children and important changes in its educational program for adults will go into effect early this Fall.

Mayor La Guardia, acting in his official capacity as president of the United States Conference of Mayors, announced here yesterday the setting up of a four-man board that will represent the Mayors conference in discussions with Federal priorities officials in Washington in an attempt to evolve a formula on priorities for the normal needs of cities and government agencies.

Acting Detective Lieutenant Elmer Mason was in a critical condition in Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital last night from bullet wounds received when he and two plainclothes patrolmen fought a pistol duel with, five men late Saturday night in a bar and grill operated by brothers of Joey Rao, notorious Harlem, gangster on parole.

The American Flying Service Foundation, Inc., 60 East Forty-second Street, organized last February to help the Army and Navy recruit cadets for their schools and stimulate interest in American aviation, put on an allday show yesterday at Manhattan Beach to help along its campaign.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- It is becoming even harder to get into the Army than it is to try to avoid service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Price Controller Leon Henderson, four of his principal subordinates and an employe of the Office of Production Management were accused today by Chairman Martin Dies of the House Committee on Un-American Activities of Communist sympathies or affiliations, past or present.

The average salary paid to women senior stenographers in Pittsburgh is higher than that in any other city in the country, with New York second, according to a survey by the National Office Management Association. The study, covering the period from March to May, includes data obtained from more than 250 companies in twenty-four cities, and covers a total of 21,417 employes who fall into fairly rigid classifications.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Robert J. Watt, who was the American Labor representative in the International Office before the war and is now a Special Organizer of the A.F. of L., has criticized sharply the failure of the government to use more representatives of labor, in addition to the representatives of business and government, in the mobilization of industry for defense production.

The premiere of "The More the Merrier," the Frank. Gabrielson-Irvin Pincus farce, was postponed yesterday from next Thursday until next Monday. After last week's tryout in Baltimore the producers, Otto L. Preminger and Norman Pincus, decided the script needed revision.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- A birdie 4 on the 465-yard par 5 home hole by Eddie Kringle, former Manhattan College fullback, playing from Shelter Rock, enabled him and Kenneth Dillenbeck to defeat Wellsworth W. Carroll and Ray Torgerson, Lakeville, 1 up, in the final of the first annual member-guest tournament of the North Hempstead Country Club today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 -- Fairly bullish private crop estimates along with more persistent reports of damage by weevils and worms bolstered cotton futures last week, resulting in the establishment of new highs for the season. Reopening after Labor Day with a dollarabale upturn when nervous longs reinstated their contracts as weather conditions remained unfavorable, trading slowed down at the mid-week in the shadow of the approaching September bureau report due on Monday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to an Associated Press dispatch of Aug. 29, Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, has proposed the construction of one hundred concrete, oil-carrying barges as an, expedient means of relieving the tanker shortage.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Stewart Iglehart and Mike Phipps led their teams to victory today in the test matches played at Meadow Brook and Bostwick Field among teams preparing for Saturday's national championship. These last hard workouts saw Iglehart's Westbury outfit turn back Cocie Rathborne's Pelicans, 9 to 6, on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club, while at Bostwick Field, Phipps's Gulf Stream four defeated Ebby Gerry's Aknusti side, 12 to 9.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Neil White and Bill Weeks of White Plains, N.Y., won the fifth annual member-and-guest golf tournament of the Tamarack Country Club today, rallying to defeat the 1940 winners, Roger Feacock of the Indian Springs (Md.) Country Club and Larry Elliott, his host, in the eighteen-hole final.
As the month, of September approaches the autumnal equinox, the extension of the present campaign in Russia into the Winter months appears more and more likely with each passing day.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Major league players who are honored with a "day" often take a drubbing from the opposition, but Tommy Bridges did not let his admirers down today.
BERLIN, Monday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A squadron of British bombers reached Berlin in the course of attacks on North and Northwest Germany during the night, it was stated officially today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 7 -- Striking the keynote of "Pan-Americanism" on the 119th anniversary of Brazil's national independence, President Getulio Vargas declared today that "any aggression from whatever source will find us the greatest block' of varied nationalities ever got together in any defensive alliance."

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- Although Dutch holdings of German shares are estimated at about 1,000,000,000 marks, the Dutch holders do not seem to be inclined to part with their stocks, especially as after the abrogation of the tax the lower Amsterdam prices rose quickly to the level of stock prices in the Reich.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The candy industry has experienced good business, is looking for further increases in sales this Fall and Winter, and is keeping its fingers crossed on possible priorities developments, an interview with Philip P. Gott, president of the National Confectioners Association, indicated today.
CAIRO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East communique said:

A graphic description of the battle with sand and flies in the Middle East War zone was contained in a letter received yesterday from Cairo from Alan R. Stuyvesant, secretary to former Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan, who formed a unit of the American Field Service with the Free French in Syria.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Sept. 7 -- The government has introduced a new bill for national free medical care in the House of Representatives. It provides that every doctor giving service to any patient after Oct. 1 will be entitled to a fee from the social security fund.

VICHY, Sept. 7 -- A central fund to facilitate the deposit and transfer of securities, and where all obligations bought on the Bourse but not in the name of the holder must remain, has been set up for operation.

The 102d meeting of the American Chemical Society, which opens in Atlantic City today, will command more than ordinary interest. Many of the 5,000 chemists and chemical engineers in attendance are in a strategic position in the drive to adapt American industry to the exigencies of national defense.

VICHY, France, Sept. 7 -- Measures seeking to establish a modified form, of prohibition in France are expected in the near future. Dr. Serge Huard, the newly appointed Minister of Health, is understood to be working on the details.
ROME, Sept. 7 -- Rome had one of its rare air-raid alarms last night starting at 10 o'clock and lasting less than a half hour, but the war bulletin subsequently indicated that it was a false alarm.

In July, the last month in which silk hosiery was readily available before the freezing of trade with Japan, hosiery mills in the United States shipped 11.4 per cent more women's silk full-fashioned hosiery than in the corresponding month of last year, according to figures issued over the week-end by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Rookie Vallie Eaves and Babe Dahlgren joined forces today in the Cubs' 3-to-1 victory over the Pirates in the last contest of the season between the clubs. Pittsburgh won thirteen of the twenty-two contests.

Cotton futures prices last week advanced to the highest levels since 1929-30. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains on the week of 48 to 57 points, following grains of 61 to 75 points in the previous week.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- President Roosevelt decided today, because of the sudden death of his mother, to defer from tomorrow night to Thursday night his speech on the international situation. This is expected to give time for developments growing out of the battle of a German submarine and the United States destroyer Greer to crystallize.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Roosevelt declared in a radio message to Brazil tonight on the occasion of Brazilian Independence Day that "never was the world more in need of a re-establishment of the ideals of peace and justice for which Brazil has so constantly stood."
Maine is famous for lobster, Vermont is known for maple sugar, while California is renowned for Valencia oranges. And many believe that the finest blueberries in the world come from New Jersey.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Two convoys will leave here tomorrow morning to prepare for the arrival of other troops from Fort Dix in the North Carolina manoeuvre area and a third convoy will depart for a week of combat firing practice at Indiantown Gap, Pa.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Ever regal, ever serene, Sara Delano Roosevelt affected furs, orchids and a gold lorgnette for the sake of dignity and tradition, but she always had time for a laugh. Behind the lorgnette were a pair of merry brown eyes which could sparkle with efficiency one moment and twinkle with humor the next.

BY a sheer stroke of luck the following letters were preserved as they arrived. Circumstances that arose later now give them added interest and even a pitiful touch. They are testimony to the sad turns that fate sometimes takes in the boxing game. Two were signed by James Joy Johnston, the little man from Liverpool with the brassbound vocal cords and long experience as a fight manager.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Parker Hall pitched a 10-yard touchdown pass to End Paul McDonough to give the Cleveland Rams a 17-to-14 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today in the opening game of the National Football League season.

They are testimony to the sad turns that fate sometimes takes in the boxing game. Two were signed by James Joy Johnston, the little man from Liverpool with the brassbound vocal cords and long experience as a fight manager.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Parker Hall pitched a 10-yard touchdown pass to End Paul McDonough to give the Cleveland Rams a 17-to-14 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today in the opening game of the National Football League season.

Turning on a full head of steam as dusk was descending on a bottle-throwing, paper-tossing crowd of 34.361 at Ebbets Field yesterday, the dauntless Dodgers pushed across the winning run in the tenth inning of the nightcap for a 4-3 triumph and a clean sweep of the vital three-game series with the Giants.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The convention of the Zionist Organization of America endorsed late today a declaration calling upon Great Britain and the world's democracies "to proclaim establishment of the Jewish Commonwealth of Palestine as an integral and essential part of a democratic world order" when peace is restored.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 7 -- The University Student Council today considered the six-point reform program for the University of Puerto Rico submitted by Rexford Guy Tugwell, pending announcement of the student assembly's decision on his taking a leave of absence as chancellor to serve as Governor.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Add these observations to the national round table on "Why Is American Morale Low?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Congressional sources said today that large quantities of 4.5-inch anti-aircraft guns, the weapon used by most British air defense units and heavier than the Army's newest 90-millimeter gun, were being manufactured in this country.

It is quite possible that the Yankees, who have nothing more exciting in prospect than to wait for October's world series to roll around, would have spent another afternoon of ease and comfort at the Stadium yesterday, letting the chips and base hits fall where they might.

Terming the general health situation in Belgium alarming, Dr. Edouard J. Bigwood, technical adviser to the Belgian Government in London, declared in a report made public yesterday that "it seems inevitable that the health of several generations will be irretrievably impaired If nothing is done."

VICHY, France, Sept. 7 -- Shots were fired at two Germans -- one a civilian and the other a soldier -- in different parts of Paris last night. There is no evidence available today to indicate whether these shootings represented counter-reprisals for the execution of three alleged Communists yesterday for the wounding of a German sergeant last Wednesday

Commenting on Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora's decision invalidating the petitions designating him for the Republican nomination for Mayor, John R. Davies said yesterday that he had just begun to fight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Playing before the greatest gallery in American golf history, Byron Nelson of Toledo fired three straight, birdies in a brilliant final round today to win the $11,000 Tarn O'Shanter open championship with a 72-hole total of 278 strokes, 10 under par.

Robert L. Riggs of Clinton, S.C., is back on the national tennis throne, and for the first time since 1908 -- unbelievable as it may seem -- a native of the East reigns as women's champion in the person of Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke of New York.

WITH THE THIRD ARMY IN LOUISIANA, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Sixteen thousand civilians in Southwestern Louisiana and East Texas were drafted today to take part in the gigantic manoeuvres that start next week between the Second and Third Armies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Browns continued in their late-season jinx role for the White Sox as the two teams met today for the last time this season. St. Louis scored two runs in the ninth to give Dennis Galehouse a 3-to-1 decision over Ted Lyons.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 8 -- In a sweeping move designed to obviate permanently any dangers of a fifth-column movement in the Volga German Republic, which has housed hundreds of thousands of Germans since the latter part of the eighteenth century, when Catherine the Great invited in settlers from South Germany, the Soviet Supreme Council has signed a decree ordering the resettlement of that population in Siberia.

Six men accused of having kidnapped the drivers and helpers of three trucks in the last year and hijacking their loads of fur valued at more than $40,500 were arrested simultaneously in various sections of Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday by local F.B.I. agents.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Playing before the greatest gallery in American golf history, Byron Nelson of Toledo fired three straight, birdies in a brilliant final round today to win the $11,000 Tarn O'Shanter open championship with a 72-hole total of 278 strokes, 10 under par.

Robert L. Riggs of Clinton, S.C., is back on the national tennis throne, and for the first time since 1908 -- unbelievable as it may seem -- a native of the East reigns as women's champion in the person of Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke of New York.

WITH THE THIRD ARMY IN LOUISIANA, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Sixteen thousand civilians in Southwestern Louisiana and East Texas were drafted today to take part in the gigantic manoeuvres that start next week between the Second and Third Armies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Browns continued in their late-season jinx role for the White Sox as the two teams met today for the last time this season. St. Louis scored two runs in the ninth to give Dennis Galehouse a 3-to-1 decision over Ted Lyons.

ALBANY, Sep. 8 -- Representatives of thirty women's organizations in the State met in the Capitol today and promised to do all in their power to aid the civilian defense program outlined by Governor Lehman as chairman of the State Defense Council.
BERLIN, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A German High Command communique, issued today from "the Fuehrer's headquarters":
Fall openings of stores presenting original designs continued yesterday with showings by Hattie Carnegie, Lord Taylor and Chez Ninon.

Professional football, which has gained in stature and popularity with each succeeding season, will make its 1941 bow at Ebbetts Field tonight, when the Brooklyn Dodgers oppose the champion Chicago Bears in an exhibition. The Bears have played three games, winning all, but the Dodgers have met only an independent Connecticut outfit, which was repulsed easily.

Samuel Goldwyn's "The Little Foxes," wHich has been seen by 416,405 persons in its first eighteen days at the Radio City Music Hall, will become on Thursday the seventh film in the eight-year history of the theatre to play more than three weeks there, the management announced yesterday.... "Sun Valley Serenade," at the Roxy," played to 61,856 patrons for a gross of $37,178 for its first three days ending Sunday.

JUST the other day a gentleman with a courtly Southern accent phoned Mr. Bill Brandt, the "stout fella" who is the head of the National League Service Bureau, and asked for service. The caller said he was an old subscriber or veteran, rooter on the National League side and wanted to put in an order for world series tickets on that side.

DOVER, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- A humane society spokesman revealed today that the society had been forced to send an attendant to the rescue of sixty-four animals, left foodless on Honeymoon Ranch, the Bald Mountain farm of Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d, when a caretaker allegedly quit while Mr. Rogers was off on a yachting trip.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Last night's R.A.F. raid on Berlin was by every account a thrust of mighty power sharply illustrating how Britain's aerial arm, strengthened by American-built planes, has grown from a year ago to take the offensive, where it once fought desperately only to protect this island.
NEW YORK Countess Andre M.A. de Limur of Washington, D.C., and Santa Barbara, Calif., is at the SherryNetherland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., of St. Louis, Mo., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 30,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible (until Sept. 15, 1950) preferred stock of $50 par value, 66,666 shares of common stock of $2 par value for conversion of the preferred and an indeterminate amount of common stock scrip also for the conversion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Major Gen. Julian L. Schley, chief of Army engineers, believes the proposed $285,000,000 St. Lawrence seaway might result in diversion of some commerce from New York's barge canal system, but predicted the latter's, tonnage would increase substantially in future years because of the highly industrialized and populous area it serves.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My brother, about 30, was inducted into the Army four months ago. Strangely, our regular correspondence had not touched on current Army morale until I recently asked him his observations on that subject. I think his comments are interesting and, knowing him as I do, pretty accurate.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 8 -- Trading on the Bourse here today was quiet and the volume of transactions smaller than recently. Bids were slack, resulting in slight losses in Royal Dutch, down 4 points to 292; Amsterdam Rubber, 4 to 297 1/2, and Amsterdam Trading, 3 off at 462.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 9 -- British, Canadian and Norwegian troops, acting under Canadian command, have accomplished a bloodless landing on Spitsbergen, Norwegian islands on the roof of the world, with valuable coal mines, which, according to British officials, the Nazis had planned to use for their dwindling supplies of fuel.

Gains of 30 to 35 per cent in the Christmas holiday trade of drug stores were forecast yesterday by H.C. Naylor, of the Lane Drug Stores, Inc., Atlanta, Ga., who was elected president of the Associated Chain Drug Stores, at its semiannual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Many candidates for public office have sued in Supreme Court here to force the printing of their names on election ballots, but Samuel Sloan Duryee of Garrison became today the first plaintiff to demand the removal of his name, contending that the Democratic committee of Putnam County was unlawfully running him for Putnam's combination office of County Judge, Surrogate and Children's Court Judge.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The N.Y.U. football squad presented a study in frustration during a supervised scrimmage today. Coach Mal Stevens tested two teams in a series of line plays, but as soon as any one broke away from the scrimmage line seeking touchdown territory, a shrill command from Mal's whistle stopped him.

Formal announcement of the selection of Charles E. Murphy, former President of the Advertising Club of New York, as campaign manager for the Democratic city ticket was made yesterday at a luncheon attended by Mr. Murphy; William O'Dwyer, the candidate for Mayor; Justice Lloyd C. Church, candidate for Controller, and M. Maldwin Fertig, nominee for President of the City Council.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- A strong bull market ruled in both the soy bean and the grain markets today with beans being run up the permissible 8-cent limit for a day's trading. This carried prices to a new record high level since trading in futures was inaugurated on the Board of Trade in 1936.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- One of Philadelphia's quietest primary campaigns drew to a close tonight, with fewer than half the qualified voters expected to go to the polls tomorrow to determine Republican and Democratic candidates for a variety of city and State offices.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- A tracking test under the auspices of the Port Chester Obedience Training Club was held today on the Lincoln Avenue estate of Hugh D. Chisholm. It was the final event of the first annual licensed trials of this organization, the other classes having been contested yesterday in connection with the bench show of the Westchester Kennel Club at Rye.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- A strange story of the sea came to light today when the Admiralty and the Air Ministry issued a joint communique telling how a United States-made bomber had captured a U-boat and how warships had brought it to port. The battle opened when the aircraft dropped a depth bomb that caused damage to the submarine and forced it to the surface.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- After taking a savage beating during the first three rounds, Bob Montgomery cut loose in the closing rounds tonight to gain a ten-round decision over Mike Kaplan of Boston before 12,000 at Shibe Park.

Joseph Priestley, one of the great pioneers of chemistry, was an Englishman by birth and career, but he died in Northumberland, Pa., a refugee from the wrath of eighteenth century England against his sympathy for the French Revolution. He was that rare combination, a philosophical and a practical man.

For some years the National Medical Association of New Zealand has been waging a pitched battle with the Government on the socialization of medicine. Undeterred by a threatened "strike" of doctors, the Health Minister has now sponsored a bill which has no counterpart in any democratic country and which provides for free medical care.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 9 -- The British Royal Air Force over Sunday night made its heaviest raid on Berlin since the war began.

The bronze lion above the football gridiron at Baker Field woke from his Summer slumbers yesterday, aroused by the booming bass of one of the most famous voices in football. Deeply tanned from a Summer on Cape Cod and full of energy, Lou Little began his twelfth season as builder of Columbia teams.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Louis Barbaro, youthful Hummocks pro, and Fred Fiore, former N.Y.U. gridiron star, finished with a 64 over the Metropolis Country Club course today to capture the Westchester Golf Association's weekly pro-amateur bestball tournament.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A trainee in an encampment has rebelled against soldiering under what unionism terms "unfair" conditions. He complains that the workman in the factory is receiving $100 a week while he receives but $21 a month for his task.

Serving of subpoenas by the antitrust division of the Department of Justice on drug trade associations and buying groups, requiring the production of records and letters on fair trade activities as far back as 1933, stirred widespread interest in the drug trade here yesterday.
Demolition, of the Fifth Avenue elevated structure in Brooklyn will start next Monday, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 9 -- Japan's relations with the "United States are the most important issue facing the Japanese Government, Koh Ishii, the Cabinet spokesman, told a press conference today. They are more important than the outcome of the Greer incident, he declared, but added that he was unable to say anything about them.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- Aided by a full moon the British launched during the night one of their severest air raids against Palermo, Sicily, killing sixteen and wounding twenty-five civilians. Slight damage was caused, according to today's war communique.
With many of the off-shore bottom fishing boats coming in this week-end with large catches of blackfish, pollock and cod, the skippers are satisfied that the Summer is over.
VICHY, France, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- The Paris press today lashed out in a vicious attack on Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Premier Joseph Stalin and President Roosevelt.

Lippy Leo Durocher, whose ability to voice consonants and vowels at a terrific pace has earned him the undisputed title as the Loquacious One, had nothing to say yesterday as he led the Dodgers out of Brooklyn for their final tour of the West, a trip that either will make or break their pennant chances.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 9 -- Eight German divisions, which have been routed on the Western front following a terrific series of counter-attacks by Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's armies, are now retreating hastily, it was announced in a Soviet communique early today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Defense officials predicted today that American war supplies would be flowing in greatly increased amounts to Axis opponents all over the world in another six months.

A victory by Olympus in the $2,500 Strathmeath Purse and a triumph by Henry Knight, a 46-1 shot, in his initial start, were highlights at Aqueduct yesterday on an afternoon that saw favorites fail in six of the eight races.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- United States exports to the United Kingdom in the first half of the current year were 74 per cent greater than in the first six months of last year, while exports to Japan dropped 50 per cent, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Despite a government crop estimate indicating a yield of about 200,000 bales more than the trade generally had expected, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday their upward movement for the eighth consecutive session and again touched new twelve-year high records.

Remarking that the municipal airport was a city in itself, Mayor La Guardia officially opened an airport banking office at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when he became the first depositor of the Empire Trust Company's new branch at La Guardia Field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Bank debits, as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Sept. 3, 1941, aggregated $9,076,000,000.

Fat round bon bon boxes, circusscarlet, hold five whole pounds of Viennese fruit candies of the sort that delights the heart of the very young and is probably eyed with shy approval by not-so-very-young men with a weakness for sweets. These are really rather undignified candies, hard and rainbowhued and more than likely to find their surreptitious way into the capacious pockets of small boys with ambitious appetites.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The State Department was informed tonight that the American freighter Steel Seafarer was sunk by an airplane in the Red Sea yesterday, second United States merchantman to be sent to the bottom since the start of the European war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Contracts totaling $884,060 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

TRENTON, Sept. 8 -- A committee of four Republican Senators was appointed today by I. Grant Scott, president of the New Jersey Senate, to investigate various branches of the State government. The group is headed by Senator Frank S. Farley of Atlantic County and includes Senator Robert C. Hendrickson of Gloucester, Senator Lloyd L. Schroeder of Bergen and Senator Howard Eastwood of Burlington.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 23 was 2,294,050 shares, compared with 2,320,470 shares in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Top-grade hogs established a new four-year price peak of $12.30 a hundredweight today, gains for the day being 15 to 25 cents. Beef cattle were steady to 15 cents off, and Spring lambs dipped 35 to 50 cents.

That Parker W. Fennelly "shudder comedy," "Two Story House," originally announced to open tonight at the Morosco, is expected to arrive on Saturday or Sunday. The exact date will be determined soon. When the thriller finally makes its delayed bow, made necessary by additional tinkering, the attraction will be referred to under another title -- "Cuckoos on the Hearth."
Cures for Optimism A person tries to be measurably cheerful about the state of the nation, and he quotes figures which seem to justify such a frame of mind, but people won't let him.

The St. Paul Union Depot Company, controlled jointly by several railroads, will enter the market on Sept. 16 with $14,737,000 of refunding bonds. Adhering to the principle which has prevailed in recent terminal financing, the company will offer the proposed issue in competitive bidding.
Striking evidence that the apartment renting season is getting into full swing is contained in the long lists of residential contracts reported yesterday by brokers.
The problem of oil is again assuming considerable significance in the picture of the war.

The new $3,000,000 Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School at Grand Concourse and 153d Street, the Bronx, was formally dedicated "to God and country" yesterday afternoon by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.

Trading opened only fair in the wholesale markets today. Dressed beef prices were little changed from last week's close. Veal and calf hindsaddles were strong to higher. Lamb carcasses were strong and lamb cuts strong to higher. Fresh pork cuts were steady to slightly higher. Kosher lamb opened higher and other kosher meats steady to slightly stronger.

First place in the opening race of the Star sloop series for the Atlantic Coast championship was taken yesterday by W. Whitney Stueck's boat named Peace, It's Wonderful, of the Eastern Long Island Sound fleet. The craft hails from Saybrook, Conn.

ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- Supreme Court Justice Bergan gave orders today to Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers Building and Common Laborers' Union to hold an election of officers and also account for the moneys it has received and expended since 1937.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Emperor Hirohito will receive the Privy Council tomorrow to hear it recommendations on important matters of state, after which, it is understood, Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye will make an "important public announcement."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Hugh Jackson Reber's justifiable affection for Iran seems to have got a bit the better of his judgment in his letter to THE TIMES.

At this moment in Berlin groups of experts are anxiously reckoning the expenditures of the German armies in munitions, in civilian supplies and in lives and are realizing that these losses cannot be replaced, Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, declared last night in an address in the McMillin Academic Theatre of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Acting as counsel for the motion-picture industry, Wendell L. Willkie questioned today the legality of a Senate subcommittee investigation of interventionist propaganda in films, scheduled to begin tomorrow. He said the industry's witnesses would appear under protest.

The British Government's anti-inflationary price policy has received a serious shock in the rejection by the Trades Union Congress of proposals for wage stabilization laid down in a "White Paper" published in July. The proposals are described in a dispatch to this newspaper as "extremely mild."
ROME, Sept. 8 (AP) -- An Italian High Command communique today:

Junior Hadassah, the Young Women's Zionist Organization of America, announced last night that it had ordered the planting of a group of trees in the George Washington Forest, near Nazareth in Palestine in memory of Mrs. Sarah Delano Roosevelt.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Sept. 8 -- The thousands of craters on the moon were not formed by the impact of huge meteors but by volcanic action, according to Dr. Roy K. Marshall of the Fels Planetarium, Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Income payments to individuals in July were $7,442,000,000, a figure lower than the June aggregate of $7,661,000,000, but which with seasonal adjustment represented an increase of 1.5 per cent over June.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Bette Davis's next picture at Warners', following the current "Man Who Came to Dinner," will be "In This Our Life," a novel by Ellen Glasgow which the studio bought last February for a reported $40,000. Casey Robinson is preparing the scenario, and the photoplay is scheduled to go before the cameras early in October.
BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 8 -- The fate of the world, at least for several generations to come, is probably being decided in Russia in a triangle marked by the cities of Smolensk, Gomel and Bryansk.

DENVER, Sept. 8 -- A Chicago hiker collapsed of exhaustion and barely escaped with his life in the Mountain West's earliest widespread snowstorm on record, which ranged down the Rockies today from Montana to Southern Colorado.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Under the guidance of a young woman who returned recently after eighteen-months of defense work in the bombed areas of England, 300 housewives and business men of Westchester County and Southern Connecticut began studying tonight the duties of home defense wardens.

The report of First National Stores, Inc., issued yesterday, for the quarter ended on June 28, disclosed a net profit of $679,767 after depreciation, Federal normal income taxes of $291,176 based on proposed 1941 law and Federal excess-profits taxes of $206,581.

Ground-breaking ceremonies were held yesterday at Naugatuck, Conn., for New England's first great plant to help supply the nation with synthetic rubber. F.B. Davis Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, which will operate the plant, and Kenneth Goodyear, a descendant of Charles Goodyear, who discovered the process of vulcanization, turned the first spade of earth.

Manufacturers of women's fullfashioned hosiery indicated yesterday that they will make every effort to provide sufficient quantities of saleable merchandise to meet the needs of retailers in the holiday season. Some were relying upon their present stocks of raw silk and hosiery in work and allotted all-silk hosiery for the next month to their customers on the basis of customers' takings over specific periods.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- All ordinary applications for preference ratings and mail inquiries may be expected to be handled within forty-eight hours of the time they reach the Division of Priorities, Donald M. Nelson, director, said today as he outlined new methods of dealing with priority problems.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 6:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today this year's cotton crop at 10,710,000 bales, based on conditions on Sept. 1, compared with 10,817,000 forecast a month ago, 12,566,000 produced last year and an average of 13,246,000 in the ten years 1930-39.

The Appellate Division of the Second Department, sitting in Brooklyn, handed down last night a decision reversing Supreme Court Justice Edwin L. Garvin, who held Saturday that the petition placing John Cashmore, Democratic Borough President, in the Republican primary was valid.

Utility Financing The list of prospective public-utility refunding operations continued to grow yesterday when reports were circulated that the Arkansas Power and Light Company, an Electric Bond and Share property, was contemplating the early refunding of its outstanding $35,000,000 of 5 per cent first and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 1956.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A program to make farm production in 1942 the largest ever attained in the United States, so as to improve nutrition at home "and meet the needs of nations that still stand between this country and Hitler," was announced today by Secretary Wickard.

WITH chastened mien and respectful attention I have just been reading a scholarly volume by Howard Haycraft, New York publisher, editor and bibliographer. It is called "Murder for Pleasure,"* and is a history (pp. xviii + 410, illustrated and indexed) of that solace and joy of Presidents, Prime Ministers and people in general, including pinheads: the police novel, or whodunit, or detective story.

A million and a quarter youngsters -- more than one-seventh of the city's population -- had the blues yesterday. It was the first day of school again, and classroom windows drained the sunshine of its brightness for 1,010,680 boys and girls who sat at their desks at 9 A.M. in the 700 public schools of the five boroughs, facing the prospect of a ten-month grind.
Plans for a number of one and two-family dwellings, including a group of eighteen in Bayside, were filed in Queens and the Bronx yesterday. The list follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Extraction from more than fifty species of tropical and subtropical plants of the genus erythrina of a series of new powerful paralyzing drugs that promise to be of therapeutic value in the treatment of insanity and for the alleviation of spasms due to nervous disorders was reported here today before the opening sessions of the annual Autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 8 -- Continuing its relentless war on Axis shipping, the Mediterranean Fleet Air Arm early yesterday attacked a convoy of three medium-sized merchantmen and three destroyers and badly damaged two vessels, it was reported here today.

Dr. Philip C. Jessup, Professor of International Law at Columbia University, who was decorated by the Brazilian Government with its highest honor, the Order of the Southern Cross, for making his way through the jungle for more than fifteen miles on Aug. 18 to summon aid for fellow-victims of a plane crash, arrived here yesterday on the American Republics liner Brazil.

WITH THE CANADIAN SPITSBERGEN EXPEDITION, Tuesday, Sept. 9 -- Canadian troops, supported by British and Norwegian detachments, have occupied Spitsbergen in the Arctic Seas without enemy interference in a daring 2,500-mile expedition from Britain.

Using a large four-column advertisement in Boston newspapers a group of sixteen Stock Exchange firms with offices in that city for the first time in history have joined in calling public attention to important facts favorable to certain types of stocks.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The automobile industry has a tentative production program of 2,147,000 passenger cars and 1,189,000 trucks for the 1942 model year, but there is a growing belief in trade quarters that further revisions of the passenger vehicle schedule will be made.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- As in previous defense creations, the President gave to no member or officer of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, the SPAB, that full delegation of authority without the full and competent exercise of which most observers are convinced the rearmament-British aid program cannot successfully be carried out.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Labor will be riding for a fall if it adopts the attitude that everything it is seeking is right, without regard for capital, Albert W. Hawkes, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, warned here today.

A thin man from Berlin and a plump man from Rome announced on Aug. 29 that they were planning for a "fruitful, peaceful and harmonious collaboration by all the peoples of the European Continent in the political as well as in the economic and cultural spheres." Down to that date, in one occupied country alone -- namely, France -- 150,000 political arrests had been made within three months.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Americans are better informed about war news than any other people, members of the New York State Publishers Association were told today by Charles E. Honce, general news editor of The Associated Press.

The secret of the Norden bombsight, this country's most jealously guarded air defense weapon, has been in the hands of the German Government since 1938, United States Attorney Harold M. Kennedy charged yesterday in his opening statement at the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government, specifically Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The American Automobile Association urged a Senate investigating committee today to recommend discontinuance of the night-time ban on gasoline sales in Eastern States, but a spokesman for filling-station operators asked its continuance.

By way of celebrating its tenth anniversary, the A.C.A. Gallery has just reopened in new quarters at 26 West Eighth Street. Removal from the old place at No. 52 edges the A.C.A. about a block along toward the Whitney Museum, which is at 10 West Eighth.

Department Store Sales Up 9% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 9 per cent for the week ended Sept. 6, in comparison with the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- German motorized units, assisted by their air force, were reported in an announcement from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Headquarters tonight to have reached the Neva River on a wide front and to have taken Schluesselburg by storm.

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks in the United States and Canada, including exports, last month amounted to 29,268 units, or 21.4 per cent more than the 24,019 figure for August, 1940, while sales for the first eight months of this year totaled 1,695,813, or 37.5 per cent more than the 1,233,465 units sold during the same period of 1940, the company announced yesterday.

Macmillan will issue a week from today the first volume of the "Cambridge Economic History of Europe," a study that as a whole will deal with the economic history of the world as it affected Europe from the days of the Roman Empire to the present.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Twelve cargo ships will be launched on Sept. 27 in celebration of "Liberty Fleet Day."

Premium buyers are concentrating their attention this year on glassware and articles of paper and wood, because of the scarcity of other materials occasioned by defense needs, it was evident yesterday at the opening of the seventh annual Atlantic Coast Premium Buyers' Exposition at the Hotel Commodore.

VICHY, France, Sept. 8 -- Paris was reported to have been quiet today, without any recurrence of incidents between the French and the Germans. But the occupying authority arrested some hundred leading Jews, mostly belonging to the liberal professions.

Reversing the restrictive policies of the past eight years, the Department of Agriculture has announced a farm program for 1942 calling for "the largest production in the history of American agriculture." The increases are to be chiefly in foodstuffs -- eggs, milk, and other dairy products, meat, vegetables and other things needed by people in the war-torn countries of the world who are defending themselves against Axis aggression.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Expenditures of the Federal Government for national defense reached a new high mark of $1,172,000,000 in August, an increase of 9.5 per cent over the $1,070,000,000 in July.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 -- Establishment of a finance division in the new national defense set-up, staffed by "practical experts," was recommended here today by Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association. He made the principal address at the opening session of the national convention of the Financial Advertisers Association.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The War Office issued the following communique today:

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- A number of distilleries soon will swing into the production of alcohol for use in the manufacture of smokeless powder, Howard T. Jones, director of the Distilled Spirits Institute, advised State liquor control officials here today.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- The German press ended tonight three days of editorial silence about the Greer incident with a volley of invective, seldom equaled in intensity, against United States foreign policy in general and President Roosevelt in particular.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 8 -- For the first time since 1931 four players tied for the medal in the qualifying round of the forty-fifth women's national golf championship at The Country Club today. This development and the elimination of Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S.C., last year's runner-up, were the highlights of the opening day's play.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Admiralty and the Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- Twenty-seven persons were killed and many others injured in the raid of a formation of British bombers on Berlin last night, the communique today said. It said damage caused was principally in residential sections of the capital.

To some it may have seemed just another Sunday afternoon. But consider it from the Dodger-fan standpoint. Brooklyn is a city of homes. There had been a good, substantial dinner. Thirty-four thousand citizens had then repaired to Ebbets Field. The New York Giants were the guest stars, and were to be treated with as little as possible of the loving kindness due to guests.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Soy beans closed 8 cents a bushel higher today, the permissible limit, with sellers temporarily withdrawn from the market. At the finish prices were 38 5/8 to 38 7/8 cents a bushel higher than the low point of about two weeks ago and the October was up 89 5/8 cents from the inside price of March 31.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Royal Canadian engineers in the Canadian raid on Spitsbergen wrecked the island's coal mines and set fire to vast coal and oil dumps, starting the greatest fires this correspondent has ever seen.

Fines totaling $47,000 were levied in Federal Court yesterday against the General Electric Company, Corning Glass Works and N. V. Philips Gloeilampenfabriken of Eindhoven, the Netherlands, with several of the officials of General Electric and the Netherlands concern.
BERLIN, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- The last possibility of Russian escape from besieged Leningrad across Lake Ladoga has been cut off, authorized German sources reported tonight.

The miracle of quantity production of defense materials achieved by American industry was described to several hundred members of the International Student Service Conference here yesterday by Howard Coonley, chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Joseph E. McWilliams, twice convicted of disorderly conduct for utterances in political speeches in Yorkville in July, 1940, was freed under suspended sentence yesterday by Magistrate William W. Hoppin in Uptown Traffic Court on his promise not to repeat the offense.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Iranian Parliament acceded in full today to the demands of victorious Britain and Russia after hearing sick and aged Premier Ali Furanghi express "the grief of our people over the events that have befallen us."

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 9 -- This was Williamstown visitation day for the Richmond Garden Club, and members inspected gardens of Mrs. Edward Crosby Doughty, Mrs. William Cook Hart, Mrs. Alvah K. Lawrie and Mrs. Charles D. Make-peace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Rookie Arnold Anderson was effective with runners on the bases tonight and the Senators defeated the White Sox, 7 to 2, climbing out of the American League cellar.

Trading in locally dressed meats was only fair to slow today. Steer hinds and ribs were mostly 50 cents lower. The cow beef market was 25 to 50 cents lower, other classes of traefer meats steady. The kosher markets opened steady with Monday's close.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The "Big Five" railroad brotherhoods have set Sept. 15 at 6 A.M. as the time for a strike, it was announced here tonight by Alexander F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen. A telegram was sent to the National Mediation Board, which failed to adjust the dispute between the unions and the carriers.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- The Germans warned again tonight that all ships in war zones prescribed by the Axis are subject to attack "regardless of nationality," and indicated that either an Italian or German plane sank the American freighter Steel Seafarer in the Red Sea Friday night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 9 -- From a usually reliable source it is learned here that the Germans are applying great pressure on the Finnish Government to make it order the Finnish troops to participate in the final assault on Leningrad.

Of the two vessels sunk by Axis attacks, the Sessa was among thirty-nine Danish-flag freighters taken over by the United States this year following long idleness in American ports. She left New York Aug. 7 for Reykjavik, Iceland, with 2,200 tons of general cargo the nature of which the operators here refused to disclose.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 9 -- Since the reported Finnish advance to the Svir River and the capture by the Germans of Schluesselburg, there is now a distance of only ninety-three miles between the most advanced German and Finnish troops in the area south of Lake Ladoga, it was asserted here tonight.

Smaller percentage increases In retail trade during recent weeks suggest that some of the "fright" buying stimulated by fear of higher prices and prospective shortages has disappeared, and that volume is now tending to strike a more rational gait, according to comment in retail quarters here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- A charge by Brig. Gen. Robert E. Wood, head of the America First Committee, that the American Legion was "affirmatively pledged to military convoys and active war in behalf of Great Britain," met a denial today from Milo J. Warner, national commander of the Legion.

The Canadian-led expedition to Spitsbergen has turned out to be a raid accompanied by great destruction, but it may lead also to an occupation as permanent as that of Iceland. Yesterday Winston Churchill described these islands as the northeastern tip of the British front, swinging in a vast crescent from the Arctic Ocean through the Atlantic and into the Mediterranean at beleaguered Tobruk.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 9 -- Urging banks making consumer credit loans to comply fully with the spirit as well as the letter of the Federal Reserve Board's regulations curbing excessive expansion of consumer credit, Walter B. French, deputy manager of the American Bankers Association, in an address at a meeting of the Iowa Bankers Association here today declared that the board was the best qualified of all governmental agencies to handle the matter.

The question whether freedom of speech and of the press should be limited to prevent their abuse by those who would utilize them to overthrow the whole system of civil rights provoked a sharp debate yesterday at the second annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Relation to the Democratic Way of Life, in the McMillin Academic Theatre of Columbia University.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Thompson Automatic Arms Corporation has been called for Oct. 9 to consider a merger of the company into a subsidiary, the Auto-Ordnance Corporation. The latter would acquire all the assets and assume all the liabilities of Thompson Automatic Arms, which would be dissolved and liquidated.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The Dodgers might have been able to whip the Cubs, or vice versa, but neither team, could compete with the weather at Wrigley Field today, although a valiant effort was made to play the game, which started forty-eight minutes late because of the heavy rain.
ROME, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Italian High Command, issued the following communique today:
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 9 -- General firmness returned to the stock market here today, thus dissipating the tendency to irregularity which characterized yesterday's session.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 -- Labor must have a voice in the peace conferences at the end of the present war, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared here today as he disclosed plans for a meeting of world labor leaders to bring this about.
After offering a military costume as a contemporary gesture, the Fall and Winter fashion collection displayed yesterday by Stein Blaine veered back into the Victorian period.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 -- The Giants inaugurated their reconstruction period and their last Western trip simultaneously today at Forbes Field with a ten-inning victory over Frankie Frisch's Pirates. The score was 4 to 2, thanks to a couple of majestic home-run drives by Babe Young.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 9 -- "A Song of Bernadette," a new novel by Franz Werfel dealing with the miracles of Lourdes, was purchased today by the International Artists unit at RKO for a reputed $75,000, plus 10 per cent of the picture profits.
