LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The German Legation at Teheran will be closed and all Nazis within Iran turned over to the British and Russian authorities there, under the Anglo-Russian agreement, the terms of which were announced here today.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Sept. 9 -- Pilots of stratosphere planes and flying fortresses may be able to determine their positions at night instantaneously by using an instrument described here today by Dr. N. Wyman Storer of the University of Kansas.
CHICAGO, Sept 9 (AP) -- Both the hog and lamb markets were generally steady today. Cattle sold steady to 15 cents off.
Crafts from the Long Island bays rushed to the fore yesterday in the second race of the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship, being held by the Eastchester Bay Yacht Racing Association.

Steel production in August totaled 7,000,957 net tons, the third seven-million-ton output thus far in steel history and the best August on record, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This compares with 6,821,682 net tons produced in July and with 6,186,383 tons produced in August, 1940, and is an increase of 13 per cent over a year ago.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Sept. 9 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association resolved today to obtain "the necessary legal and physical evidence" to break the practice of "monopolistic control which ensnares all fighters of prominence and makes them subject to a single promoter."

Fear that "labor priorities" may soon be established in non-essential industries was expressed yesterday by speakers at a round-table discussion held as part of the seventh annual Atlantic Coast Premium Buyers Exposition at the Hotel Commodore.

Filling station operators, having decided after four and a half weeks of the 7 P.M.-7 A.M. curfew on gasoline sales that it is an excellent innovation, protested vigorously yesterday against any move to do away with it.

Responding to President Roosevelt's recent proclamation calling for a nationwide emergency safety program to halt the rising accident rate, which is causing a loss of man-hours in defense production "many times" that caused by strikes, representatives of 125 national organizations, with millions of members, adopted a program of specific emergency measures at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday for "the greatest mass attack on accidents in the history of safety."

Rosetown, a Jamestown filly that had been running with colts and beating- them at that, was dropped into the Chacolet Purse with those of her sex yesterday at Aqueduct, and she had an easy time scoring.

Low-priced issues monopolized activity yesterday on the stock market, and the demand was so heavy that the volume on the Stock Exchange exceeded three-quarters of a million shares. Gains in most of the session were moderate, however, and uneasiness over the sinking of another American-controlled merchant ship brought out sustained profit-taking in the final hour.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 9 -- After spending the first eight days or practice on defense against a tentative varsity eleven, Manhattan's reserve corps had a chance to show its strength today in an offensive session against the first-stringers that occupied the whole afternoon.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The German High Command announced today the loss of the German artillery cadet ship Bremse after a short and fierce fight with British units in northern waters. The warship was on convoy duty, supplying German troops in the extreme north, a communique said.

Eager to take advantage of the fine condition of one of the most promising Columbia football squads in recent years, Coach Lou Little lost no time yesterday in getting down to serious work. The second day of practice at Baker Field was marked by a spirited two-hour contact drill which saw the tentative first and second Lion elevens run through almost every play in Little's varied and deceptive repertoire.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Not being of an age to associate with admirals, I must remain silent before F.K. Berrien's opinion of the top ranking officers of the Navy recently expressed in your columns. To his criticism of the "kind of training dispensed at Annapolis,"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 --The United States and Great Britain have reached a comprehensive agreement under which the British Government has agreed to drastic reductions in its export trade for the duration of the war. Details are expected to be announced simultaneously in London and Washington tomorrow.

READING, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Saratoga, a bay colt by His Majesty, scored a straight-heat victory over eight other starters today to become the first horse in the history of the Reading Fair Grand Circuit meets to win two Futurity trophies.

The sinking of the American freighter Steel Seafarer makes it increasingly clear that we are headed for a showdown with Nazi Germany on a question of fundamental importance to both countries. That question is whether we intend to yield control of the high seas to a Government which has described itself as the sworn enemy of our democratic system.

Paramount's "West Point Widow," which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is today's lone film newcomer. Anne Shirley and Richard Carlson head the cast of the drama, which also includes Richard Denning, Frances Gifford and Janet Beecher in supporting roles.

Among the business leases reported yesterday was one signed by the WPA for ground floor space, comprising more than 20,000 square feet, in the building occupying the block front on the south side of Bridge Plaza, from Twenty-third to Twenty-fourth Streets, Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Supply Priorities and Allocation Board rejected tonight a proposal by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, for high priorities on 480,000 to 700,000 tons of steel plates for speedy construction of a 1,500-mile petroleum pipeline from the Texas oil fields to the New York refining area at a cost of $70,000,000.

As a result of a suit brought by members of the union, Supreme Court Justice Bergan at Albany has ordered Local 17 of the International Hod-Carriers Building and Common Laborers Union to hold an election of officers and also account for the moneys it has received and expended since 1937.

That pennant fever in Brooklyn apparently is catching. The Football Dodgers treated the champion Chicago Bears with rude disdain for all but the final thirty-seven seconds of an exhibition thriller before 27,103 howling fans at Ebbets Field last night.
NEW YORK Rear Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Yarnell arrived yesterday from Maine and are at the Commodore.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Disregarding the advice of political leaders and entering a controversy many officials had avoided, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach of Westchester declared today his opposition to the adoption in November of the County Charter Amendment that would abolish the Board of Supervisors and create a small legislative board representing new districts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The motion-picture industry now finds itself in the position many other citizens have occupied: inquisition by an unfriendly committee of Congress. Individual employers and associations, and especially the utility managers, have been through it;

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 9 -- Trade negotiations between Turkey and Germany began formally here yesterday immediately after the arrival of Dr. Karl Clodius, leading German trade expert, and the rest of his delegation.

TOKYO, Sept. 9 -- In line with the agreement with Britain, according to which a British ship is scheduled to arrive at Yokohama to evacuate Britons from Japan Sept. 24, the Japanese Government has decided to dispatch three passenger ships to evacuate Japanese from British territories.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Little Dom DiMaggio provided more batting support than Dick Newsome needed today as the Red Sox rookie right-hander shut out the Tigers, 6 to 0, for his seventeenth victory.

The two and three-story apartment building on the southeast corner of Thirty-fifth Avenue and 167th Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the Nassau-Suf-folk Bond and Mortgage Corporation to Norwood Apartments, Inc., through Hosinger Bode, Inc., brokers.

Although many oil companies have complied with the request of Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold for all data on advertising, including cost, mediums used, advertising copy and script used in radio programs for the eighteen months ended on July 1, several companies have not been able to comply with the request, largely because of the huge task involved in assemblying the data.
A four-point credo of democracy in the present world crisis was offered yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, in a message to New York City's 35,000 school teachers.
The five-story structure known as the Fuller Building, on the southwest corner of Montgomery and Hudson Streets, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by Bertram A. Levine to the Fuller Building Corporation.
An anonymous telephone call led the police last night to the top floor of a six-story tenement at 534 East Eighteenth Street where they found four children clad in rags and sobbing because of hunger.
SUEZ, Egypt, Sept. 9 -- Twentyfour survivors of the American freighter Steel Seafarer, sunk in the Red Sea Friday night by a warplane's missles, were landed here tonight. None were injured.
BERLIN, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The communique from the German High Command said today:
The parade of new Fall fashions continued yesterday with showing that included the collections of Mainbocher and Russeks.

A growing trend toward merchandising basic lines will feature the retail drug trade as the defense program reduces the available supplies of novelties and gadgets, B. Harry Badanes, vice president of McKesson Robbins, said yesterday at the semi-annual convention of the Associated Chain Drug Stores at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Nathan Cummings, who has been president of the C.D. Kenny Company of Baltimore City since 1939, has become the sole stockholder of a new concern which has acquired all the assets and assumed all the liabilities of the corporation, titled the C.D. Kenny Company. The new concern will make no change in policies, management or personnel of the old company, and will have capital and surplus in excess of $1,000,000.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 9 -- Indications that salary increases would be granted Lutheran clergymen were seen as presidents of thirty-one of the thirty-two synods of the United Lutheran Church in America conferred here tonight on need of higher pay to meet the rising cost of living.

The partly completed Kingsborough housing project at Pacific Street and Buffalo Avenue, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who told several hundred tenants they must not forget to "put a little ribbon on the curtains and a little flower on the dresser" in their new homes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Senator Nye in his testimony on alleged movie propaganda said he had been informed of a "demand" by "some agent of the government" that motion picture studios produce "propaganda" films.

Reversing Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, the Appellate Division in a four-to-one decision yesterday ordered the Board of Elections to restore John R. Davies to the Republican ballot as a candidate for the nomination for Mayor in next Tuesday's primaries. His opponent will be Mayor La Guardia, whose designating petitions have not been challenged.

Petey Scalzo, West Side warrior, who once held the world feather-weight championship, knocked out Jimmy Gilligan of Buffalo in the fifth round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Queensboro Arena last night, before 2,500 fans.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Into William Ullman's interesting account of the proposed Big Bend International Park an unintended error has crept. Mr. Ullman writes: "The Spaniards called it the Rio Bravo del Norte -- Brave River of the North." As a matter of fact, the Spaniards called the river the Rio Grande -- which we take as our usage.

A scarcity of contracts continued to govern the course of the cotton market yesterday, as prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, advancing for the ninth consecutive session, registered net gains of 21 to 26 points, or $1.05 to $1.30 a bale.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opens to the public today two exhibitions both of which are to remain current for approximately a month. They have bee ninstalled in connecting galleries on the second floor. One of these exhibitions is concerned with domestic architecture -- its theme, "The Wooden House in America."

Gasoline stocks along the East Coast, where a shortage is threatened because of the diversion of tankers to Great Britain, declined 458,000 barrels last week to 19,803,000, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 9 -- For a day that started out to be just another one of those dull, matter-of-fact-occasions, characteristic of first match-play rounds in championships, this one at The Country Club, where the women are holding their forty-fifth national golf classic, certainly turned out to be a whiz-bang.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In announcing that the decrease in the number of children registering for the new school term would necessitate the consolidation of classes, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, City Superintendent of Schools, indicated that the same would result in a reduction of 863 teaching posts this Fall.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- In the seclusion which it had longed for but hardly dared hope to achieve, the nation's first family took leave today of its matriarch, Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt Brevity and dignity marked the service that committed the mother of the President to her grave in St. James's church yard this afternoon, beside the husband who had preceded her in death by forty years.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 9 -- German Ambassador Baron Edmund von Thermann called on the Foreign Office today for the ostensible purpose of announcing the imminent arrival here of Captain Fritz Wiedemann, recently ousted Nazi Consul General in San Francisco, but actually to protest against the latest report of the Congressional committee investigating anti-Argentine activities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Tense relations between Germany and the United States over the issue of freedom of the seas were further aggravated by an announcement of the State Department today that the steamship Sessa, an American-owned and operated former Danish vessel of Panamanian registry, had been sunk near Iceland by a torpedo and an American member of the crew lost.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 -- A 20-millimeter anti-aircraft gun which is able to call its shots on dive bombers when they swoop down to discharge their loads is being produced in the completed parts of the $20,000,000 naval ordnance plant being built at Centerline, Mich., near here, by the Hudson Motor Car Company.

HAS any one ever discovered how much truth there is to the report that the Germans tried to invade England last Fall? The story has been "divulged" here and "denied" there for a good many months, and now further hints appear in a wartime diary kept by Margaret Kennedy, distinguished tinguished EnglishIrish author of "Escape Me Never" and "The Constant Nymph."

There was a "what of it? " air about the Stadium yesterday when the Yankees and Browns clashed for the last time. Only 3,006 fans were on hand to see the new champions take a 1-0 thriller. Time, it has been said, makes quite a difference, and that was apparent, for despite the tenseness of the struggle, the customers found it difficult to stifle yawns.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in August showed the largest increase over a year ago of any month this year, according to a compilation by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The August gain amounted to 29.8 per cent, compared with 25.7 in July and 16.9 in June.

Colorado Fuel and Iron The directors of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company declared a special dividend of 25 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share, compared with three dividends of 25 cents each in the preceding quarters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- An application by the United Light and Power Company and its subsidiary, the United Light and Railways Company, for permission to sell to the public 355,250 shares of common stock of the Northern Natural Gas Company which, they own was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Some of those who are planning Fall surfcasting expeditions to North Carolina beaches will have an opportunity to get in some shooting also, for the deer season is now open in Cumberland, Hoke and Moore Counties and according to reports such game is very plentiful this year.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Draft officials moved world heavyweight champion Joe Louis closer to the Army today.

Today's Fleeting Crowns Joe Louis and the New York Yankees are the outstanding continuators of a great tradition -- the age of the superchampions. Today tennis champion makes way for tennis champion every year, but in the decade after 1920 Tilden stood first seven times out of ten.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 10 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Red Army troops, smashing fifteen miles into the weakened German center, have already mopped up 250 square miles of territory around recaptured Elnya, which the Nazis had converted into a stronghold and base for a future offensive, according to Soviet reports.

VICHY, France, Sept. 9 -- Admiral William D. Leahy, the American Ambassador, returned to Vichy tonight from Barcelona, Spain, where he met Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, on his arrival from the United States.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 9 -- A survey of the Forty-fourth Division's 941 officers completed today disclosed that 130, or nearly 14 per cent, are over age in grade. In the group are three colonels in command of regiments and eight lieutenant colonels, including battalion, commanders, division staff officers and the commander of special troops.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- British communiques today said that in the Murmansk area one German destroyer, one armed trawler and another vessel were sunk, while in the English Channel at least three ships were "probably sunk" and others damaged by British warships.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- Rarely has the Italian press evidenced so great an interest in a forthcoming Roosevelt speech as today. Since Italian correspondents in the United States have cabled to their newspapers that the President is expected to do away with the Neutrality Law altogether and announce the convoying of merchantmen, the Italian people are being prepared for a worsening of the already grave situation obtaining between the Axis and Washington.

Final details of a deal under which E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will buy up the outside interest in the du Pont Film Manufacturing Corporation were agreed on last night and will be submitted on Oct. 1 to a special meeting of the shareholders of the Pathe Film Corporation.

IN THE WESTERN EGYPTIAN DESERT, Sept. 9 -- It is a pity that Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini cannot pay a visit to the Western Desert today. It would give them many sleepless nights if they could see the strength of the British defenses here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today that Adolf Hitler was bound to give fresh impetus to the struggle in the Atlantic and that, being increasingly hampered by the United States patrols in the north, he had to develop his malice in the south.

Negotiations for a new wage agreement and working contract affecting 30,000 unlicensed seamen on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts were started yesterday between the National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute at the latter's offices, 11 Broadway.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The British Admiralty issued the following today:

Officials of Rockville Centre, L.I., yesterday received sixteen bids for an issue of $225,000 of electric light system bonds and awarded the bonds to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicaigo and Tilney Co. of this city.

The inquiry into radio and film propaganda which was opened in Washington yesterday by Senator Clark's subcommittee of Senator Wheeler's Interstate Commerce Committee was at times comic. But the inquiry has its sinister aspects, as Wendell L. Willkie, speaking as counsel for the motion picture industry, abundantly demonstrated.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Cushioned by two runs in the second and six in the third, the Reds withstood a last-minute four-run uprising by the Braves today to win, 9 to 7, in an extra-base fray marked by twenty-nine hits and seven errors.

THE moguls of the National Boxing Association, whose authority is recognized in about forty States, gathered in convention down in Winston-Salem, N.C., one of the centers of the tobacco industry, and apparently smoke got in their eyes. It was advertised as the smoke of battle by President Joseph Triner of Chicago, whose term of office was running out, but to this distant observer it looked more like smoke from a concealed pipe of peace.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- The planning of an advertising budget for a financial institution requires an understanding of banking problems, a knowledge of general conditions nationally and locally and the belief that advertising expenditures are an investment in the future.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- An insurgent attempt to take over control of the Republican organization in Philadelphia was turned back by large majorities today as a listless primary attracted to the polls far less than half the qualified voters of the State.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Nine Red Cross stations scattered throughout Dutchess County cared today for more than 2,000 "refugees" in an evacuation day drill. The "refugees" made their way through, the highways in cars, trucks and buses and received food, shelter and first-aid treatment.

VICHY, France, Sept. 9 -- With the object of striking swiftly to repress violence wherever it occurs and prosecuting not only the actual perpetrators of crime but the instigators behind them, a new State tribunal will be instituted by laws to be published tomorrow, it was announced today.

Newspaper, magazine and radio advertising campaigns are essential for the success of any premium offer, according to Howard W. Dunk, secretary of the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc., who is in charge of arrangements at this week's Premium Buyers' Exposition, in the Hotel Commodore.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- Not only beleaguered Leningrad, but also the Russian naval base at Kronstadt, lies under the fire of German long-range field artillery batteries, authorized German military quarters declared tonight. In addition German bombers, including Stukas, are said to have attacked Leningrad yesterday and last night.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Bard of Athlone, from the Midwest stables of Duquoin, 111., set a 1941 record for 3-year-old trotters on half-mile tracks at the opening grand circuit program of the Kentucky State Fair today.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- A veiled warning to the United States that while Adolf Hitler would like to "finish off Russia and Great Britain before coming to close quarters with the United States," he might be forced to change his tactics in consequence of American patrols in the North Atlantic, was contained in Winston Churchill's review of the war today at the resumption of Parliament after a Summer recess.

Last November President John Stewart Bryan of William and Mary College announced that one of its friends had enabled its Institute of Foreign Policy to offer prizes of $4,050 for the best essays by selected students on "The Next Decade of American Foreign Policy."

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9 -- High government officials here said today that although they expect a stabilization and credit agreement to be announced soon by Washington, possibly this week, they consider that the Mexican peso already is stabilized, de facto, and that this nation has no intention of altering the exchange rate that recently has been maintained by the Bank of Mexico.

While a panel of cotton-textile men was discussing with the Office of Price Administration proposals for upward revision of gray goods ceilings, a movement spread through Worth Street yesterday for establishment also of raw cotton ceilings, since it was held that higher cloth ceilings would be of little use in stimulating the movement of goods unless mills have some assurance that their cotton costs would not be rising.

Two hundred and fifty members of the newly organized Inter-Union Institute for Labor and Defense, representing A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions with 5,000,000 membership, meeting at the City Club last night, ate a modified version of the "blitz" dinners served to wartime British workers on their ration cards.

Watermelon turns translucent and assumes a lovely shade of pale moss green or chartreuse when it is transformed into a sweet, spiced pickle, and it seems ineffably appealing in its clear glass jar with small, shiny black cloves and a brown curl of cinnamon to keep it company.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- The United States faces an imminent threat of currency inflation, Secretary Morgenthau told the Advertising Club of Boston at its dinner tonight. He pledged that the Federal Goverment would do everything that could be done to prevent such a disaster.

For sixteen months the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been in constant communication with the Nazi secret service in Hamburg, Germany, by means of a short-wave station on Long Island, exchanging worthless "information" about the American defense program for accurate reports on the activities of Nazi spies in this country, it was disclosed yesterday at the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign power.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Members of the mixed force of British, Canadians and Norwegians who made the raid on Spitsbergen told how they had fired huge dumps of coal and wrecked mines to such an extent that they reckoned it would be years before the pits could be operated again.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Excerpts from Prime Minister Churchill's House of Commons speech today follow:

The two apartment houses at 463 and 468 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, have been sold by George M. Mayer to a client of George M. Strype, broker, and will be rehabilitated by the new owners. The five-story building at No. 466 contains twenty apartments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Charges that a small group of motion picture producers, "all born abroad and animated by the persecutions and hatreds of the Old World," have been injecting prowar propaganda into American films, both for financially selfish and "non-American" reasons, were voiced before a Senate inquiry group today by Senator Gerald P. Nye, Republican, of North Dakota.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Malay coastal defense area bordering on the South China Sea was extended today to a point more than 200 miles north of Singapore.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Stock market sentiment, already good at the opening today strengthened further after Mr. Churchill's review of the war situation.

Mrs. Joseph McBride of the home club captured the low-net prize in the one-day handicap tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association with 89 -- 20 -- 69, after matching cards with Mrs. Francis J. Klaess of Rockville at the North Hills Golf Club course in Douglaston yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 9 -- Myron C. Taylor arrived late this afternoon by Italian plane from Barcelona, Spain, bringing a message from President Roosevelt to Pope Pius.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following Companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits Taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The vessel on which four American recruits for the Royal Air Force were killed recently was trailed for more than a day by the attacking submarine, one of the seven survivors disclosed here tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9 -- Gerontology, a new branch of chemical science probing into the chemical processes that make our bodies grow old, promises to usher in an age of "chemical Methuselahs" in whicn centenarian "youngsters" will retain the vigor and resistance to disease of 10-year-olds, according to reports presented here today at a symposium on the chemistry of aging at the annual Autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Investment Market The transition from the traditional negotiated financing operation to the modern competitive bidding principle of new-security distribution has been almost phenomenal. The battle against compulsory bidding was long, yet today, viewing what is slated to come on the market within the next month or so, the absence of a "negotiated deal" is striking.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 9 -- For the first time in the memory of Navy Department officials women were present today when the regiment of midshipmen at the Naval Academy marched in to take their places at table.

A scheme through which the National Safety Bank and Trust Company was made to pay $60,000 of the gambling debts of two conspirators was charged yesterday in Federal court. The suspects were arraigned before Isaac Platt, United States Commissioner, by Raymond Ickes, assistant United States attorney, after their surrender to agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A new plan to keep defense and essential civilian industries going at full speed was announced today by Donald M. Nelson, Priorities Director of the Office of Production Management.

Billy the Kid, of whom something has been heard recently in the motion pictures, will make a book appearance too Nelson Nye of Chicago says he could not find an authentic account of the outlaw so he wrote one under the title "Pistols for Hire: A Tale of the Lincoln County War and West's Most Desperate Outlaw, William (Billy the Kid) Bonney."

The last group of a total of 4,583 candidates for the Fire Department who had passed the written examination participated yesterday in the final day of competitive physical tests, held at the New York University athletic field in the Bronx, closing what was described by Chief Examiner Paul M. Brennan as "probably the most difficult physical test ever devised for a job anywhere, and certainly in the civil service."
Archbishop Francis J. Spellman stressed yesterday the importance of nursing in the world crisis when he addressed the graduates of the School of Nursing of St. Vincent's Hospital.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 10 -- The Germans treated Britain warily early today following smashing Royal Air Force raids on Kassel and Muenster in Germany and Cherbourg in German - occupied France. Early this morning no attacking planes had been reported anywhere over Britain.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Bob Feller chalked up victory No. 23 with little difficulty today as the Indians coupled thirteen hits and four walks with five Philadelphia errors to trounce the Athletics, 13 to 7.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- Following is the text of the address prepared for delivery by Secretary Morgenthau before the Advertising Club of Boston tonight:

There were six new cases of infantile paralysis in New York in the twenty-four hours ended at 9 A.M. yesterday, according to Dr. Samuel Frant, epidemiologist of the Health Department. So far this week there have been twenty cases of the disease.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 8:

The rate of American defense production will be doubled in September and October, John Biggers, former director of the production division of the Office of Production Management, recently appointed Minister to London in charge of synchronizing British and American defense production, asserted yesterday when he left La Guardia Field aboard Pan American Airways' Dixie Clipper bound for Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- To what extent a man living in one part of the country should be permitted to sit on boards of railroads which operate in remote parts of the nation will be debated in connection with a petition today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by W.H. Coverdale of Coverdale Colpitts, consulting engineers, of New York City.

John E. Bierwirth, a vice president of the New York Trust Company twelve years, was elected yesterday president of the institution by the board of trustees. He succeeded Artemus L. Gates, who resigned last week to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Aeronautics.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Spitsbergen expedition provided the basis today for new calls in the British press for an invasion of the European Continent.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- President Roosevelt ordered his special train tonight and prepared to leave tomorrow for Washington to deal with urgent matters of state, including the sinking of an American ship in the Red Sea and an American-operated ship off Iceland.

It is less than a week to the primaries, and, as usual, petitions are attacked for their invalidity, the courts are busy ruling on charges of fraud, and uncertainty and suspicion attach more or less to the whole process. The cases of candidates for conspicuous offices naturally bear the most attention, yet to the ingenuous inquirer it looks queer that aspirants to district leadership, seasoned politicians, are having trouble with their petitions.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew has had twelve conferences with the Foreign Minister, Vice Admiral Teijiro Toyoda, in the last seven days, it was revealed last night, and informed Japanese quarters said today that "developments of the greatest importance" in the field of Japanese-American relations were possible within the next few days.

Leopold Stokowski, noted orchestra conductor, has been engaged by the National Broadcasting Company to undertake the leadership of the NBC Symphony Orchestra for the 1941-42 season, it was announced here yesterday by Niles Trammell, president of the NBC.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9 (AP) -- The pennant-winning Newark Bears got off on the right track in the semi-final round of the International League's Governors' Cup play-off series tonight by beating the fourth-place Rochester Red Wings, 9 to 8, in a wild contest before a crowd of 6,430.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Working more on team combination play and pony workouts than on the actual score, the five teams entered in the national open polo championship which starts Saturday rode through practice matches at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Widespread uncertainty over what items should be included in the listing of assets in which foreigners hold an interest troubled exporters here yesterday as they sought to compile information for the special form TFR-300, which must be turned into the United States Treasury Department by Sept. 30.

WITH THE SIXTH ARMY CORPS IN THE FIELD, Sept. 9 -- Six regiments, two battalions, one company and one battery have been commended by Major Gen. Karl Truesdell, Sixth Army Corps commander, for their efficiency and display of good training technique during manoeuvres.

Buyer Registrations Up in Week Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market last week numbered 1,201, as against 559 in the previous week and 1,246 in the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The courage and determination of Great Britain in her present struggle for existence are exemplified in the leading character of the Frederick Hazlitt Brennan play, "The Wookey," opening tonight at the Plymouth.

A group headed by Lehman Brothers and Goldman, Sachs Co. will offer today to the public 50,000 shares of Jewel Tea Company, Inc., 4 1/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value. The stock will be priced at $105 a share, involving new financing in the amount of $5,250,000.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Middle East General Headquarters issued the following:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The German announcement of the encirclement of Leningrad is accepted here as more or less factually correct, though it is pointed out that Leningrad is probably capable of a prolonged defense.

TOKYO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Admiral Seizo Kobayashi, former Governor General of Formosa, said in a newspaper article today that the South Seas had become a matter of life and death for Japan, but he dismissed any idea that Japan was bent upon monopolizing that area.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 10 -- Events in Norway totally over-shadowed today even the reports of the operations on the Finnish front and around Leningrad. News from Oslo was given to the public under big headlines on the front pages of all evening newspapers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Top grade hogs were bid to a new 4-year peak of $12.35 today in a strong market, with extreme gaias at 10 cents. Beef cattle and Spring lambs sold steady to 15 cents off.

Using a new sound amplification system to give added appeal to its lectures, the American Museum of Natural History opened yesterday its annual education program. Last year, 326,775 persons, mostly children, attended the museum's education series.
WASHINGTON, Sept., 10 (AP) -- Thornton Lee chalked up his nineteenth victory as the White Sox slaughtered the Senators, 12 to 4, today to gain an even break in the two-game series.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- The Battle of Leningrad raged with "undiminished fury" today, accompanied by perhaps the greatest mass slaughter of the war. However, a spokesman cautioned a press conference that, despite German encirclement, the time required for capture of the former Czarist capital still was uncertain.

Taking time out for a moment, from his task of directing world series arrangements -- an unenviable job, by the way -- President Edward G. Barrow of the Yankees announced yesterday the acquisition of four minor league players for delivery next Spring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A demand that Senate investigators of charges of pro-war propaganda in movie films actually view the films alleged to contain such propaganda before going into possible motives on the part of the producers was laid before the investigating group today by Wendell L. Willkie, counsel for the producers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 10 -- Major Gen. George H. Brett, chief of the United States Army Air Corps and a member of the war supply mission to Russia, accompanied by five other American officers, arrived at a Middle East airdrome this afternoon in a huge Consolidated Liberator plane.

An NBC television fashion show yesterday of knitted wear for British children served notice that Bundles for Britain plans to turn young people all through the United States loose with knitting needles within the next few weeks.

The major oil companies that have banded together to build a pipeline from the Texas oil fields to the New York refining area are going ahead with their plans despite the refusal of the Supply Priorities and Allocation Board to grant them priority on the needed steel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Topics of The Times in the issue of Sept. 3 takes exception to Dartmouth College's new course in "Components of Democratic Thought," which was described in THE TIMES of Aug. 31. It appears that he disapproves of the course's intention to be "never a vehicle for indoctrination."

A new American standard of body sizes for boys' garments; covering the range from kindergarten to junior high school, was introduced to the trade yesterday by the American Standards Association at a meeting in the Hotel Governor Clinton.

Sixty South American students, ranging in age from 8 to 21 years, arrived here yesterday from Venezuela and Colombia on the Grace liner Santa Rosa to enter schools and colleges throughout the United States.

An underground steam main blast tore a thirty-foot crater in Seventh Avenue at Perry Street, in one of the busiest sections of Greenwich Village, at 10:30 o'clock last night, with a thunderous explosion that sent a geyser 150 feet into the air.

Several thousand Americans have been stranded in the British Isles because of the Neutrality Act, which prohibits their traveling" on ships of belligerent nations and at the same time forbids American ships to enter the war zone to fetch them home. Fortunately, the law gave the State Department discretionary powers to relax the former prohibition and this power has been used at last.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The British expedition to Spitsbergen, a minor odyssey in a gigantic struggle, is, nevertheless, a smallscale example of the type of raiding operations that the German campaign in Russia has made possible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Establishment of a capital issues committee is believed to have been foreshadowed by the statement last night in Boston by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau that it might be necessary "to extend general controls over bank credit and create controls over selected capital expenditures."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- The injury-harassed Cardinals, counted out of the pennant race early in the week even by some of their faithful followers, leaped within one game of Brooklyn by winning a doubleheader from Philadelphia today, 3 to 2 and 1 to 0, while the Dodgers dropped a pair to the Cubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Recurring reports, particularly in Tokyo, that a preliminary agreement looking to an adjustment of relations between the United States and Japan was to be expected momentarily were regarded as premature today in view of a brief oral reply made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull to questions at his press conference today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The value of products manufactured by twelve textile machinery and sewing-machine manufacturing companies in 1939 was $122,982,870, according to the Federal Trade Commission.

A BRITISH AIRPORT IN EGYPT, Sept. 10 -- British heavy bombers again raided the Corinth Canal, between Peloponne is and the Greek mainland, and pilots report they caused more slides that will delay German attempts to reopen the waterway to traffic.

Flippant twists to Fall wardrobes for the young were displayed yesterday by Lanz of Salzburg, 668 Fifth Avenue, with adaptations of the carefree flower-strewn dirndl fashions. From gay Tyrolese flowers of felt used as a back trim on soft sport hats, to skirt pockets of crocheted net, the styles scoffed at things prim with a persuasive insistence upon fun and comfort.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- More than 1,200 British planes have been destroyed by the German Air Force since the beginning" of the war in Russia, according to a tabulation issued here tonight with the aim of proving that the eastern conflict had not detracted from the German air arm's force on the two other fronts.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 -- A Giant pitching experiment mired today on rain-soaked Forbes Field as the Pirates subjected the Terrymen to a 10-7 defeat in the New Yorkers' final appearance of the campaign here.

It is too bad that the issue between Fiorello H. La Guardia and John R. Davies, as candidates for the Republican nomination for Mayor, should have been confused by irregularities on Mr. Davies's designating petitions, and by consequent action in the courts. However, Mr. Davies is obviously a victim of a poor method of collecting names for such petitions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Navy has organized a force within the Marine Corps which will be trained and equipped with every modern device for lightning attacks on enemy shores.
NEW YORK Captain Vyvyan O. Drury, aide to the Duke of Windsor, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Drury Lodge, Newport, home of his father, F. Saxham E. Drury.

Van Wyck Brooks coupled a appeal for revival of the true American classics with an outspoken condemnation of what he called the "coterie writers" -- T.S. Eliot, James Joyce, Marcel Proust, Paul Valery and Gertrude Stein -- in an address yesterday before the second annual conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion, in the McMillin Academic Theatre o Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- While the State Department approved an Anglo-American agreement regulating Britain's use of lease-lend materials and President Roosevelt prepared to send to Congress his second report on expenditures under the first lease-lend bill, government officials put the final touches today on a second lend-lease bill calling for an appropriation of nearly $6,000,000,000.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, spent one hour and ten minutes with Pope Pius and one hour and fifty minutes with Luigi Cardinal Maglione, Papal Secretary of State, today in an exchange of information and ideas that may have a great bearing on the ideological development of the war.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Newark Bears gained a 2-0 advantage in their International League Governors' Cup series tonight as young Russ Christopher pitched a masterful four-hit shutout against the Rochester Red Wings, 7 to 0.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Major Gen. William N. Porter, Chief of the Chemical Warfare Service, in an address tonight before the annual Autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society, warned that while poison gas warfare has so far Been absent from the battlefields of Europe and Asia, Hitler is likely to use it "at any moment."

Mrs. Ruth Pratt, member of the Republican National Committee, who supported Joseph V. McKee for Mayor on the Recovery party ticket in 1933, announced yesterday her support of Mayor La Guardia and accepted the vicechairmanship of the Republican Primary Committee for the Renomination of La Guardia, MoGoldrick and Morris.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Samuel Sloan Duryee of Garrison, an attorney and banker in New York and head of the War Department's Board of Tax Amortization Review, must remain on the Sept. 16 primary ballot in Putnam County as the Democratic candidate for the combination job of County Judge, Surrogate and Children's Court Judge despite his protest, Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A joint conference committee worked today to adjust Senate-House differences in the record-breaking revenue bill, but ended the meeting without agreeing on any of the major controversies.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Spread-eagling the fleet yesterday in the third race of the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship series on Eastchester Bay, Paul V. Shields won his second consecutive contest with his boat, Spitfire. He won by 4 minutes 6 seconds from the second craft, Horace G. Brown's Blue Stardust.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Reds and the Braves put on a marathon game today and it was Boston that panted to victory in the fifteenth inning, 4 to 1.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of President Roosevelt, bequeathed the bulk of her estate to her son, according to a will filed today for probate in the office of Surrogate Daniel J. Gleason.

One hates to quote that moldy saying of Charles Dudley Warner's so regularly laid on Mark Twain's threshold, but it remains bitterly true that all we can do about the weather is to talk about it. But what poisonous and excoriating speech can come within a mile of doing justice and execution to yesterday's weather?

Following a meeting at the War Department in Washington on Tuesday, at which consideration was given to the question of presenting free, commercially sponsored shows at Army and Navy camps, Lawrence Phillips, executive director of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., announced yesterday that ten of the largest advertising agencies were seriously considering recommending such programs to their clients.

Busy Chinese children in native costumes were aided by yesterday's torrid weather as they dispensed cooling drinks of iced tea and shrilly hawked the packaged product from which their beverage was brewed at the city's main intersections.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Chairman Maloney of the special Senate committee suggested today that a price increase of less than 1 cent a gallon would remedy all threats of gasoline shortage.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The White Paper on the Lease-Lend Act published simultaneously in the United States and London today is a government effort to make a bridge between the business men of Great Britain, South America and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Contracts totaling $17,089,805 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

The International Longshoremen's Association decided yesterday to ask employers in port of the Atlantic Coast for a 25-cent hourly wage increase above the present scale of $1.10, and a 40-cent increase in overtime pay, which is now $1.65.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Today's Middle East R.A.F. communique said:

The right wing of the American Labor party, which controls the party organization in Brooklyn, has denied renomination to City Councilman Harry W. Laidler, it was learned yesterday and Dr. Laidler has been designated for reelection by the City Fusion party.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed late yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement and prospectus covering a proposed issue of $90,000,000 of thirty-five-year 23/4 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1976, thereby revealing for the first time the terms of the proposed financing for which two large underwriting syndicates are prepared to bid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Secretary Hull has authorized the Consul General in London to permit at his discretion Americans in the British Isles to return to this country in urgent cases on British or other belligerent ships, if no other passage can be found.

For the first time in ten days the cotton market yesterday suffered a downward reaction. Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau's address in Boston on Tuesday night, in which he warned against inflationary tendencies and advised that the government free its stocks of wheat and cotton, threw the trade here into a state of nervousness.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- Although the remarriage of widows has always, been frowned upon in Japan, as in most Asiatic areas, the substantial Japanese losses in the China "af- fair" have brought the question of remarriage of war widows to the forefront of public discussion.

DAVID O. WOODBURY'S "Colorado Conquest"* tells a story that has never, apparently, been set out in such detail for popular consumption before. It has to be read with fingers crossed and eyes wide open and also with due regard for the author's particular political notions, but there seems to be no better general book on the subject, and the subject is colorful almost to the point of being gaudy.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Long-hitting Herman Barren of White Plains, Fenway Country Club pro, added a par-71 round to a morning 68 to win the first annual $500 Green Valley open golf championship by four strokes, with 139, today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 10 -- The dramatic struggle between the Norwegian people and the German occupation authorities reached a climax when at 5 A.M. today the German Commissar for Norway, Josef Terboven, proclaimed a state of "civilian emergency," automatically invoking martial law in Oslo, the rest of Aker Province and the adjoining districts of Asker and Baerum.

READING, Pa., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Brilliant stretch drives in the last two heats gave Lucy Hanover, speedy bay filly, top honors in the $5,000 3-year-old Futurity trot in today's Grand Circuit racing at the Reading Fair.

By unanimous vote the Board of Education, at its regular meeting yesterday, dismissed Ingram Bander, a history teacher in the Bronx Vocational High School, on charges of being a Communist and of having given "untruthful and evasive" testimony.

Some one once declared that if a monkey persisted at punching the keys of a typewriter he would eventually write a Shakespearean sonnet, and it might also be stated, with as little fear of contradiction, that the surfcaster who perseveres will eventually snare a big striped bass.

Electric power production declined last week by less than the usual amount for the holiday week, and the adjusted index rose to 121.0 from 120.5 for the week ended Aug. 30. It stood at 105.2 for the week ended Sept. 7, 1940. It is now the highest on record except for the week ended Aug. 2, when it stood at 121.3.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Speculative traders beat a hasty retreat in the markets for farm commodities today, with lower prices recorded for butter, eggs, cotton, wool, grains and sugar. Sales showed a sharp drop from the preceding day, when the rush to buy vast quantities of American-grown produce for future delivery raised the daily turnover to new high records.

Bicycle manufacturers are making a determined effort to comply with the recent request of the Conservation Bureau of the OPM urging them to reduce voluntarily the number of models, designs and materials, it was learned yesterday. The request, in the form of a letter signed by Robert E. McConnell, chief of the Conservation Bureau of OPM, sent to eleven manufacturers, was the first industry-wide program for such reductions issued.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Dean Wayne L. Morse of the University of Wisconsin Law School has been named as chairman of the fiveman emergency board created by President Roosevelt to investigate the dispute between the Class I railroads and the nineteen standard railway unions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- An inspection of the public history of the petroleum-shortage scare in the East leads to one of these conclusions:

Cone Denims Raised 1/2 Cent Cone Export and Commission Company announced yesterday that a card basis price of 18 cents had been named on denims for use in computing values of irregulars. The company has no regular goods on sale, having sold up November production in a single day last week.
Realty activity in Manhattan was featured yesterday by deals in which savings banks disposed of loft buildings. Operators bought and sold houses on the West Side.

WITH THE RUSSIAN ARMY, on the Central Front, Sept. 10 -- An Adjutant reported to Lieut. Gen. Ivan Stepanovich Koneff, commander of the Russian forces in the Smolensk zone, that an attack was being launched, and we climbed into his car and drove toward the front through forests, ravines and small hills.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 9:

Dr. John T. Madden, dean of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, announced yesterday the appointment of Spencer Miller Jr., secretary and director of the Workers Education Bureau of America, to conduct a course in collective bargaining.

With industrial users of ethyl alcohol facing an aggregate shortage of 3,000,000 gallons from now to the end of the year, considerable concern has developed in the toilet goods industry with respect to the outlook for supplies during the current heavy production period.

POSSIBLY George Halas of Chicago has the right tackle slant on football. He conditions his Great Bears by tossing them into football games and letting nature take its course. Four games in eight days! That's a tough schedule for young gents wearing all that heavy upholstery but, when last glimpsed in action, the Bears were romping through it laughingly.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 (By courier to Baghdad) -- The Iranian capital and the southwestern provinces were reporteed on the brink of revolution this morning, and violent anti-Shah feeling was said to be sweeping Iran.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 10 -- Relations between Argentina and Germany enter into a critical phase tomorrow when the Chamber of Deputies begins discussion of the behavior of the German Ambassador, Baron Edmund von Thermann, and of the measures that should be taken to counter Nazi activities.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Following is the text of the memorandum by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Minister, as made public here:

It was in April, 1940, as a preliminary to the attack on France and Britain, that the Nazi legions suddenly marched into Denmark and Norway. These were the first of the "neutrals" to be invaded and occupied. The Norwegians put up a valiant fight, but they were overpowered by the might of an enemy that first betrayed a friendly neighbor and then systematically ravaged the land Hitler had sworn to respect.

Republican and Democratic lawyers were still wrangling last night before Supreme Court Justice Edwin L. Garvin, in Brooklyn, over the validity of the Republican petition designating Borough President John Cashmore in the opposition primary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that, despite drought conditions in August, aggregate crop production this year was expected to be nearly 2 per cent larger than in any previous season except 1937.

In his speech at Boston Secretary Morgenthau discussed various antidotes to inflation, but put chief emphasis on what is at once the simplest, most obvious, and yet, as he said, "the most effective way to prevent a damaging rise in prices." This is to increase the supply of available goods wherever possible by releasing surpluses from storage.

VICHY, France, Sept. 10 -- Although no further violent developments were reported from Paris today, the situation remained tense, with the Paris press a fairly trustworthy barometer. For the moment it is stressing internal affairs rather than "collaboration" with Germany, although, of course; the two cannot be separated.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- It is not possible to interpret satisfactorily in Berlin the continued silence of the Supreme German Command and authorized spokesmen here relative to developments on the Eastern Front. The 1,500-mile battle zone was disposed of in four German words in today's communique, which said: "In the East there were steady successes in the attack."

Four and a half hours of peristent cross examination by counsel for the defense failed yesterday to alter materially the testimony of William G. Sebold, 42year-old naturalized American citizen, about the activities of an alleged Nazi spy ring here, as the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government continued before Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

The so-called Battle of Fifth Avenue with interventionist and non-interventionist groups pleading their respective causes against the traffic's din was still in progress last night and promises to go on until Winter weather drives the speakers indoors.

Mr. Brennan does not have much to say about freedom in his gusty war play, "The Wookey," which was acted at the Plymouth last evening. But he illustrates it with great relish in the absurd and indomitable figure of a Cockney tugboat skipper, and freedom seems like a vital thing.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Sept. 11 -- German forces in the central sector of the Russian front, in the immediate vicinity of Smolensk, were reported today to be in full retreat after having suffered heavy casualties at the hands of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's crack forces now driving in to encircle Smolensk from the north and southeast.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 11 -- Following up their drive "into the weakened German center, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's armies have mopped up the region southeast of Smolensk and are pushing new counter-attacks toward that important but ruined city and toward the White Russian city of Gomel, according to Soviet reports.

The new Supply Priorities and Allocations Board has taken an aggressive and encouraging step forward in its decision announced last night to make a sweeping survey of the nation's requirements for its entire defense effort. This important study will cover military, lease-lend and civilian needs-exactly the sort of overfall, long-range analysis that should have been attempted long since, as soon as the magnitude of our task became apparent.

The glow of Autumn ruled the style review that De Pinna held yesterday at the breakfast hour. Here are some of the tints this store believes smart women will like: Plumberry, crushed amethyst, green gold, police-gazette pink, emerald green, wine, dark brown and an occasional shadowy gray.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Her victory over Miss Betty Jameson, the defending titleholder, still acting as a stimulant, Miss Janet Younker of Elmsford, N.Y., today continued to play the leading role in the women's national golf championship at The Country Club.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Jimmy Wilson's Cubs are "Indian givers." Last Thursday they gave the Dodgers possession of first place in the National League by beating the Cardinals twice.
The first year of development of a tree nursery for the city on Rikers Island, which was a garbage dump for the previous ten years, has just been completed, the Park Department announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A statement that the Sessa was torpedoed and shelled without warning at night and sunk in two minutes by a submarine presumed to be German was issued today by the State Department.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- A Cornell football squad of sixty-six -- one of the largest in recent years -- reported to Coach Carl Snavely today. Sixty had been invited and the others came on their own.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederic Du Bois gave a supper dance tonight at their home in Clapboard Ridge Road here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Diane Du Bois.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Athens dispatches to the German newspaper Donauw Zeitung of Belgrade today reported the imposition of death sentences on five Greeks and the confiscation of the properties of former Greek statesmen and all their relatives to the second degree.

The basic Nazi aim is to conquer the generation now in its childhood and its youth and to create a world that to liberty-loving people would be a "debased and dreadful parody of life," Archibald MacLeish declared last night at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria opening a campaign to raise $503,800 for the United States Committee for the Care of European Children.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- Subscriptions for a new issue of the 5 per cent nine-year Treasury bonds, exactly similar to the issues of last February and of February, 1940, will be opened on Monday, it was officially announced today. Banks have been canvassing their clients the past week regarding this issue, which, indeed, has been expected for some time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- "It's Written in the Stars," a screen comedy by Steven Vas, was purchased today by Paramount for a reported $10,000 as a probable vehicle for Fred MacMurray. The yarn is an astrological story, and will be filmed under the title "The Crystal Ball."

More aggressive action to protect their own interests was urged upon foreign traders yesterday during an informal discussion Which featured the regular monthly meeting of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- The impression of a setback in the Washington negotiations was created here today by a sudden suspension of the optimism that had been emanating from official quarters for several weeks.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- What happens to money earned when a nation is at war and restrictions are placed on purchases is shown by the figures for excise receipts for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1941, as against the year of 19391940.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The British Government is pressing Teheran for swift fulfillment of the terms of the agreement announced yesterday. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said in the House of Commons today that Britain had advised the Iranians that she wanted them to waste no time in handing over members of the German community in their country -- including those who have sought refuge at the German Legation.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Some reasons why the Red Army's artillery functions as successfully as it does were indicated to foreign correspondents today when they were permitted to visit Moscow's crack school for artillery cadets.

Two thousand employes of the day shift of the Third Avenue Railway System authorized their leaders last night at a mass meeting in the headquarters of the Transport Workers Union, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, to take any action, including a strike, to bring about a new working agreement.

Inauguration, of a labeling campaign under government auspices, designating certain types of products as patriotic and the use of others as unpatriotic, in order to conserve materials, was predicted yesterday by Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, at the closing session of the semi-annual convention of the Associated Chain Drug Stores at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 10 -- With the approach of the end of the first year of Federal service for the Forty-fourth Division, it was announced today at division headquarters that plans were beingmade to discharge 1,800 men who enlisted for one year soon after the Forty-fourth's Federal induction last Sept. 16.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Hearings of a special Senate committee into the gasoline shortage on the Eastern seaboard were recessed today for a period of "watchful waiting" as Senator Maloney, the chairman, called upon the public to "take seriously the conservation of petroleum products and all other fuels."

The 1,272 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with a par value of $56,100,967,060 on Aug. 30, had a market value of $53,216,867,646, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of July 31 there were 1,271 issues with a $56,041,115,610 par value and market value of $53,259,696,637.

Production of coke pig iron in August reached a new high record of 4,791,432 net tons, compared with 4,770,778 in July, according to reports to The Iron Age. Output on a daily basis increased slightly from 153,896 tons a day in July to 154,562 in August.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The team of Mrs. Robert Beard of Knollwood and Mrs. Harold Minott of Mount Kisco scored a 79 today in the Women's WestChester and Fairfield Golf Association best-ball foursomes championship at the Knollwood Country Club.

TOKYO, Sept. 10 -- Despite the silence maintained by both sides regarding the negotiations between President Roosevelt and Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, Japanese Ambassador, it is believed some progress has been made, and the prospect of avoiding a spreading of the war to the Pacific is brightening again.

A basic formula for settlement of the three-week-old strike of Gimbel Brothers department store employes was worked out yesterday at a conference in Washington, but difficulties encountered by the negotiators in reducing details of the agreement to writing made it uncertain whether a full accord would be reached in time to permit the strikers to return to work tomorrow.
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 10 -- A strong tone and keen demand dominated the Bourse here today with activity on a broad scale.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Arrangements for the construction for just under $72,000,000 of two more magnesium and an additional aluminum plant and their leasing by the Defense Plant Corporation to three companies for the production of 108,000,000 pounds of magnesium and 30,000,000 pounds of aluminum annually were announced today by Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator.

Driving on powerfully on the outside of one of the biggest fields of the meeting, William L. Brann's Pictor yesterday captured the $10,175 Bay Shore Handicap at Aqueduct before 12,066 persons, who pretty well neglected him in the betting.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Rookie Fred Caliguiri, late of the Wilmington, Del., Class B team, pitched the Athletics to a 6-4 victory over the Indians today.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- A new trend in N.Y.U. football is in the process of development at the Violet Summer training camp. The players directly involved are the backs, but even they are incidental to a pair of coaches largely responsible for exploiting the innovation to its fullest -- Nat Machlowitz and Bill Galu, new assistant backfield tutors.

LASHIO, North Burma, Sept. 10 -- The Burma Road is a going concern. This correspondent has just traveled its tortuous 600 mile length from Kunming to Burma's border and found the road taking the heavy wet season traffic at its capacity.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 -- It seems strange to think that hardly two months have elapsed since British Imperial and Free French troops entered Syria and Lebanon after the collapse of Vichy resistance, and yet the country has not only resumed complete economic normality but is even enjoying a period of prosperity that may develop into a more permanent form if all goes well.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -- The creation of a special labor committee to facilitate the transfer of workers from curtailed nonemergency industries to defense jobs was urged here today by Joseph Keenan, coordinator of the Office of Production Management.

The American Institute of Graphic Arts will hold from Oct. 29 to Nov. 12 an exhibition of books "made for children." A call has been issued to publishers to send any of their books manufactured and designed in the United States and Canada from 1937 through this year. The exhibit will be held at the institute's headquarters at 115 East Fortieth Street.

Speeding up of the priority system and the creation of the new division of contract distribution of the Office of Production Management are two moves of the last week which are being lauded by steel consumers, particularly small metalworking plants, according to Iron Age.

Trading In the wholesale meat markets continued slow on most classes. Bull beef and fresh pork cuts were steady to tower. The lamb market was steady to fully 50 cents lower and other classes of traefer meats were mostly steady. Kosher steer beef, as well as veal and calf, were steady. Kosher lamb ioresaddtes opened weak to 50 cents lower.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- J. M. Mehl, chief of the Commodity Exchange Administration, told produce and grain brokerage men tonight that governmental regulation of futures trading was designed so that these markets might remain open.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- Bank leposita in this country are relitively trifling compared with the total value of securities outstanding, E.A. Pierce of Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane of New York asserted today in an address at the annual convention of the Financial Advertisers Association in the Hotel Statler here.

Charles Paris, 44 years old, who gave up midget-auto racing for the security of working in a garage, returned to his first love early yesterday morning in breakneck pursuit of a hold-up couple. At 70 miles an hour, he showed up well over a twisting six-mile course of Brooklyn streets.

Ignorance In Cleveland yesterday E.A. Pierce told the story of a customer who entered a bank a year or so ago with a batch of Liberty bonds from which not a single coupon had been cut. Business had been pretty good and at long last he felt able to pay his interest to the government.

Securities representing the foreign public utility properties owned directly or indirectly by the Compania Hispano-Americana de Electricidad, S.A., known as "Chade," have been placed beyond the reach of Nazi invaders until the end of the war, it was learned here yesterday.

While the New York area sweltered under near-record temperatures yesterday and the second successive day of abnormal humidity helped to make it one of the most uncomfortable of 1941's fading Summer, reports reaching here from the Midwest told of fine football weather that was chilling the population of Illinois and surrounding States.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 10 -- The Chinese Government "hopes and believes" that, while China is continuing her fight against Japan, the United States and other countries friendly to China will intensify their economic pressure upon Tokyo, or at least not relax it in any way, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek told The United Press in an interview today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- In an address before about 15,000 persons at a Defense Day rally in the Coliseum tonight Mayor La Guardia of New York predicted that if Great Britain should be defeated and Nazi Germany was victorious in the European war the enormous cost of national defense in the United States would be continued for twenty-five years.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 75 by 85 feet at 6611-15 Broadway, southwest corner of Sixty-seventh Street, West New York, N.J., was purchased by Lothar Rosenfelder from the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company, in liquidation.

We were once subjected, rather unwillingly, to a pseudo-psychology test that inquired quite pointedly into our preferences as to music, literature, pursuits and persons. Our answers were vague and stumbling, and we could see the words "arrested development" forming themselves in the mind of our examiner as he posed his last question.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 --An over-all study of the lease-lend, defense and civilian requirements from America's productive machine was ordered today by the Supply Priorities and Allocation Board in what was regarded as one of the most important steps taken in fifteen months by a defense agency.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President has set our national policy on a very positive course -- a course committing the American people to gigantic effort and great risks, but one that is imperative for the preservation of world freedom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Richard T. Frankensteen, director of the Aircraft Division of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., threatened today to call a strike of 16,000 West Coast aircraft workers, but agreed that he would favor putting the dispute before the National Defense Mediation Board if direct parleys failed to break the deadlock.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- Automobiles and instruments of war were displayed side by side today as General Motors Corporation showed how it has changed its productive capacity to meet the needs of defense.

An entire floor in the building at 270 Madison Avenue has been leased by the Federal Government for offices for the Coordinator of Information. The lease was arranged by Butler Baldwin, Inc. and the Cross Brown Company.

Orson Welles's "Citizen Kane" will return to Broadway this morning to begin a popular-priced engagement at the Palace, where it opened last May as a road-show attraction at increased admissions. The film also will be shown at the RKO Albee in Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- With 16, 200,000 radio sets in the Reich, including the protectorate and the newly annexed Polish and French provinces, on April 1, 1941, Germany claims second place among the world's most "radio-minded" nations, following the United States with its 28,700,000 radio listeners, according to the Reich Statistical Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Roosevelt arrived in Washington at 9:15 (E.D.T.) tonight and held a two-hour conference at the White House with key officials to discuss final plans for ordering the Navy to take whatever steps may be necessary to protect American, shipping on the seas, and to convoke Congress Monday or Tuesday to ask for repeal of the Neutrality Act.

Donning his 8-year-old sister's clothes after his mother hid his own, 5-year-old John Schierenbeck of 422 aBy Ridge Avenue, Brooklyn, ran away Tuesday for the fifteenth time to visit his friends, the soldiers, at the Army Base, foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, the police revealed yesterday.

Agents of apartment buildings throughout the city and in suburban areas continue to report leasing in heavy volume. Recently completed buildings and others in the course of construction are drawing many of the home-seekers. One house which is not yet ready for occupancy is reported 85 per cent rented.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Continuance of the rise among the giltedge listings is having a general brightening influence on the Stock Exchange here. All-round price increases again were the rule today.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Sinking of the Sessa and the Steel Seafarer and the encounter of a U-boat with the United States destroyer Greer were described in British newspapers today as a German challenge to the United States.

Elimination or Communists, Nazis and fascists from positions of influence in the State C.I.O. will be asked in a resolution to be submitted to the C.I.O. convention in Utica on Sept. 26 and 27 by representatives of the New York joint council of the United Retail Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, it became known yesterday.

Wholly About Food Americans are growing familiar with short rations in symbolic form. "We have had Public dinners in behalf of China relief where the guests ate the kind of meal provided for Chinese famine sufferers.

Charles R. Rogers, free lance film producer, will be Georgie Hale's partner in the production of "The Lady Comes Across," a new title for the musical most recently known as "Listen, Lady!" The show will star Jessie Matthews, who also will make a series of pictures under Mr. Rogers's auspices. Other prominent roles may oe taken by Jack Haley and Tony Martin, Mr. Hale said last night.

7WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Information available here -- though filtered through the haze of distance and distorted by unofficial claims -- does not present the optimistic picture painted in the news dispatches from Russia.

DES MOINES, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Charles A. Lindbergh charged tonight that "the three most important groups which have been pressing this country toward war, are the British, the Jewish, and the Roosevelt Administration."

Christianity knows nothing of the rights of individuals and groups over against the community as a whole, but demands complete concern and responsibility from every Christian and the Christian fellowship for all men in all their necessary relations, Professor Nels F. S. Ferre of the Andover Newton Theological School said yesterday at the second annual conference on science, philosophy and religion.

Evidence that the German Government sought to learn vital American defense secrets, particularly in airplane production, and the amount and type of exports to the. democracies abroad, was read into the record yesterday at the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 11 (AP) -- New officers for three top subholding companies of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation were announced today as another step in reorganization of the big utility concern.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 11 -- Strong disapproval of any policy of appeasement in the dealings of the United States with the Axis powers was expressed today in the report of the foreign relations committee of the American Legion, which denounced the totalitarian governments as "international bandits."

It was an all-out day of optimistic news for the stock market yesterday and traders quickly reacted by briskly bidding up a variety of issues from fractions to 2 points. First as an antidote for the depressing news budget of the previous day was the advance notice from, the White House that President Roosevelt's radio address on the nation's position in the international picture would leave no questions unanswered.
