The two-family residence at 3211 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Eva Greenberg to Sara B. Cohn for cash above a first mortgage of $15,000, according to the City Title Insurance Corporation, which insured the title. The property is valued for taxes at $21,000, of which $8,300 is on the land, a plot 60 by 100 feet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Indians turned back the last-place Senators twice today, 8 to 5 and 3 to 2, behind Al Smith's shaky hurling in the opener and Al Milnar's five-hit pitching in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Roosevelt conferred for an hour and a half today with Constantine A. Oumansky, the Soviet Ambassador, apparently on problems of supplies for the Russian Army. Secretary of State Cordell Hull was present throughout the interview, which was sought by the Ambassador.

Although the total of loans and investments of the sixteen reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City showed a net decline of $11,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $12,259,000,000, there was a sharp increase in commercial loana. The rise was $35,000,000, the largest in four weeks, and carried the total to $2,428,000,000, a new high for ten years.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 -- A giant air battleship, the largest flying boat in the world, was shown to the public for the first time today at the Middle River plant of the Glenn L. Martin Company.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Lou Abree, 33-year-old clerk, hurled the forty-ninth no-hit game of his career today to give his Peoria (Ill.) team-mates a 4-0 victory over the Rochester (N.Y.) Kodak Parks, 1940 champions, in the Amateur Softball Association's national tournament.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- All classes of livestock weakened today, with prices declining as much as 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Continued advances in prices of agricultural products and cotton and woolen textiles brought the general level of the wholesale commodity prices to the highest point since early 1930, Acting Commissioner Hinrichs of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Central Buying Agency To prevent prices in foreign markets from getting out of hand, it is considered quite likely that the United States Government may establish a central buying: agency for some of its most essential products, especially in the metal group.

The annual report of the International Agricultural Corporation covering the fiscal year ended on June 30 last, issued by Louis Ware, president, for release today, reveals a net profit of $402,522 after all charges. This is equal to $4.02 a share on the 100,000 shares of 7 per cent $100 par prior preference cumulative stock outstanding.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Pirates split a double-header with the Braves today, annexing the first game, 7 to 5, and dropping the nightcap, 10 to 0, but managed to pick up a half-game on the Reds, whom they now trail by a half-game in their third-place battle.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Applications of six stockholders to block a proposed merger of the Celluloid Corporation and the Celanese Corporation of America were taken under advisement here today by Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein in three simultaneous suits in Chancery Court.
BERNE, Sept. 11 -- On the Russian front at present the situation may be summed up thus: Two sieges and a "battle of destruction."

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- The Reich military expenditure during the first two years of the war approximated 100,000,000,000 marks, financial experts here estimated today from data given in an article by Fritz Reinhardt, assistant minister of finance, published in the current issue of the leading Nazi economic weekly, Deutsch Volkswirtschaft.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The American motion-picture industry is loading its feature and newsreel films with "pro-war propaganda" because it is "controlled by four or five men who cannot possibly have an American point of view," John T. Flynn, economics writer and America First Committee leader, today told the Senate subcommittee looking into charges that such pro-war propaganda was being disseminated.
Marketing this week end will not prove to be an unalloyed joy for the thrifty housewife with one eye on her budget.

In his report to the House of Commons on the progress of the war, Prime Minister Winston Churchill indicated that the "acoustic mine," that finest flowering of the German genius for contriving mechanical methods of spreading destruction, is being mastered by British science and organization.
BERLIN, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today from Adolf Hitler's Headquarters:

A fire of undetermined origin but believed by Fire Marshal Thomas P.Brophy to have been accidental did $25,000 damage yesterday to the New York Central Railroad's Pier D, North River at Sixty-second Street, and hung a black pall of smoke over the near-by waterfront and the West Side Highway for over an hour.

VICHY, France, Sept. 11 -- Prisoners of war, national relief, food and raw material distribution, transport and social and economic problems are among the topics listed for discussion by the new Commission of the National Council, that opens its session here tomorrow.

The boys and girls in the New York City school system are going to participate in this country's "all-out" defense program. Starting next week, thousands of cotton and woolen garments will be made by the pupils, to be sent in a steady stream to the children of Great Britain.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Par received rude treatment today as the first annual amateur-pro championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association started over the windswept Lakeville Club course. Fourteen pairs beat regulation figures in the best-ball qualifying round, and scores were so low that six teams that carded 75s had to play off for three places in the championship flight of thirty-two.
OSLO, Norway (via Berlin), Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- Fear that German authorities would extend the state of emergency from the Oslo area to other parts of Norway prevailed Here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Release of government-held surpluses of farm products and the dropping of quotas on Canadian wheat were advocated by Secretary Morgenthau today as anti-inflation measures.

Overriding the objections of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs and the protests of spokesmen for organizations interested in the preservation of the city's historic landmarks, the Board of Estimate paved the way yesterday for closing the Aquarium in Battery Park on Oct. 1 and removing most of its exhibits to a temporary home in the Bronx Zoo.

Acceleration of the campaign to save waste paper, by which, it is hoped to reverse the present percentage of 72 per cent waste and remove a small but important deficiency in the American defense effort, was announced yesterday by the Waste Paper Consuming Industries.

The strike of Gimbel Brothers department store employes ended at 6:40 P.M. yesterday when 1,000 strikers, meeting at the Hotel Diplomat, voted to call off their picket lines and march back to work this morning.

Although long since shorn of their league championship, the Tigers still seem able to do a lot of scratching and clawing. They gave the Yankees so much of both in 2 hours and 42 minutes at the Stadium yesterday that the vaunted Bombers breathed a sigh of relief when Del Baker's scrappy Bengals jammed a run across in the twelfth inning.

In a clear, dry northwest wind that piped up from a low of eighteen miles an hour to more than thirty, Bill Picken, with his sloop Fo-Fo of the Great South Bay fleet, regained the point lead yesterday in the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Henry Ford said today that the Ford Motor Company would continue to make airplanes when the war had ended and predicted that thousands of aircraft would be needed for peacetime pursuits when the fighting had stopped.
NEW YORK Mrs. Dwight F. Davis has returned to the Ritz Tower from Southampton, where she had been visiting for a few weeks.
The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- Scoring five runs in the fifth inning after a grounder rolled between Bill Werber's legs, the Giants gained a 6-0 victory today at Crosley Field as they opened their farewell series against the Reds.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Hundreds of British-built fighter aircraft are even now being sent to Russia, Prime Minister Winston Churchill declared today in a vigorous speech in the House of Commons in defense of his Minister for Aircraft Production, Colonel J. T. C. Moore-Brabazon.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 12 -- British response to President Roosevelt's address is just beginning this morning. Official circles are waiting for Prime Minister Churchill to speak the first authoritative word, but a few of the newspapers are welcoming the President's pronouncement in glowing terms.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 11 -- Probing deep into the mystery of living processes, a group of world authorities, gathered at the University of Wisconsin for a three-day symposium on the mechanism of respiration, presented a new picture on the way the body cells use hydrogen and oxygen to keep the life going at a steady pace.
TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 11 -- Alfred M. Landon, 1936 Presidential candidate, said tonight that he had expected the President's statements.

Although the increase over a year ago was the smallest in ten weeks, check transactions for the last week showed a gain of 17.8 per cent over the corresponding period last year. The total for twenty-three leading cities of the nation was $5,689,802,000, compared with 54,831,423,000 for the 1940 week, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., issued yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- The Italian press prepared its public today for an important step toward war which was to be announced by President Roosevelt's speech. As it will be 4 o'clock in the morning here when the President begins to talk, the people will learn nothing of the contents until the afternoon papers tomorrow.

President Roosevelt spoke last night the words which we believe the country was waiting to hear. There will be no yielding to Hitler's threats. There will be no surrender of American rights on the high seas. The time has come to tell the aggressors "you shall go no further."
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.
Death Announced Fireman 1st Grade Robert Mahl. Engine Co. 161, died Sept, 9. In the performance of duty at New Dorp, Richmond.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The conferees on the 1941 revenue bill were reported to have reached almost complete agreement today in ironing out the differences between the House and Senate versions, with the lowered personal income tax base imposed by the Senate said to have been retained.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 11 -- After holding the spotlight for the last two days as a result of their brilliant accomplishments during the first three rounds of the women's national golf championship, New York's three representatives, Miss Janet Younker of Century, Mrs. Sylva Leichner of Fresh Meadow and Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Lakeville, all went tumbling out in today's quarter-finals.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 11 -- A sizable majority of wage and salary earners interviewed in a nation-wide survey are ready to have the government fix wage and salary rates at the present level if the government also freezes prices to prevent the cost of living from going any higher.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Sept. 11 -- Stars which are sometimes fort million times as bright as the sun and stars no larger than the earth, but with temperatures on their surfaces of 150,000 degrees centigrade, were declared to be related, in a discussion on "supernovae" by a Mount Wilson astronomer here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The War Department released the following orders, dated Sept. 10:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Roosevelt conferred early today at the White House with Republican and Democratic leaders of Congress to give them an advance outline of his speech which Stephen Early, White House secretary, stated "would leave no unanswered questions."

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- As the hour for President Roosevelt's speech neared tonight the violence of German press attacks on the President -- steadily intensified for the past two days -- makes the high point in front-page head lines, such as that of the Voelkischer Beobachter, which asserts "war-monger Roosevelt needs corpses for provocation -- American citizens must perish on ships of warring States to bring about the longed for incident".

Schools and Democracy Arthur Greenwood, a member of the Churchill Cabinet, writes in the current New Leader of the part which educational opportunity must play in the reconstruction of British life after the war.

The March of Time's documentary feature film dealing with the Papal State, "The Story of the Vatican," will have its local premiere at the Belmont Theatre on Friday night, Sept. 19. The picture will be shown on a continuous-run basis . . .

Sidney Homer Jr., acting chairman of the Associated Leagues for a Declared War, with headquarters in Westport, Conn., made public yesterday a telegram sent to President Roosevelt by the organization asking him to urge upon Congress the immediate declaration of war on Nazi Germany.

"Brother Cain," a drama dealing with, the social and economic problems of a Polish mining family of Pennsylvania, by Michael Kallesser and Richard Norcross (nom de plume of Lawrence B. Wallis, English and drama instructor of Mount Holyoke College), opens tonight at the Golden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The special Senate committee investigating the reports of a gasoline shortage on the Eastern seaboard reported today that not only was there no shortage but that "had an adequate analysis been made by those to whom the responsibility of coordination was delegated the confusion of the past few months might have been avoided."

Vehicular traffic continued to be rerouted all through yesterday at Perry Street and Seventh Avenue, where on Wednesday night an underground steam main exploded and shattered scores of windows in several apartment houses in that neighborhood, and a twenty-inch water main in the vicinity burst, tying up the IRT subway service from Canal Street to the Pennsylvania Station for several hours.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 12 -- The War Office announced yesterday the creation of a new General Defense Headquarters under direct command of the Emperor, which will be responsible for the defense of Japan proper, Korea, Formosa and Sakhalin.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- A German plane that crashed in Belgium, on Jan. 10, 1940, contained two German staff officers who had with them documents foreshadowing the air invasion of Belgium, it was revealed in an official account of Belgium's part in the war made public by the Belgian Government in London today.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A sharp upturn in non-defense as well as defense industries in New York brought last month the year's biggest rise in employment and payrolls.

With four Americans assigned to wartime posts in London among its passengers, the Atlantic Clipper left La Guardia Field at 10:45 A.M. yesterday for Lisbon. Arriving today, Pan American Airways announced, will be fifty-three passengers from Europe on the American and Dixie Cloppers, scheduled to land at 1:45 and 2:45 P.M.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Arcturus Stable's Smacked, one of the most consistent sprinters in the country, ran to his fifth straight triumph when he was the odds-on winner of the Esposa Purse at Hawthorne today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Ralph Budd, Defense Transportation Commissioner, warned today that the railroad car-building program was 20,000 cars behind schedule and called upon shippers to give full cooperation, to insure efficient utilization of existing equipment to meet transportation demands in the coming peak period.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The bombing and fighting planes which the Army will test in mass formations in the manoeuvres starting in Louisiana on Monday are "the finest air force in the world" from the point of view of quality. Robert A. Lovett, Assistant Secretary of War for Air, declared today.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 12 -- The junior Axis partner, Italy, came in for a pounding by the Royal Air Force over Wednesday night when the new British four-engined bombers switched their offensive from industrial targets in Germany to those at Turin.

Honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws will be awarded to Nelson A. Rockefeller, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, Governor Lehman and Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, at exercises next Wednesday concluding a three-day celebration of the centenary of Fordham University, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Soviet Russia formally accused Bulgaria tonight of acting as a full-scale base for German-Italian land, sea and air attacks upon the Soviet Union and strongly intimated that Russian reprisals would be swift and stern.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- Police today arrested nine more Germans and one German-born Chilean in a round-up of suspected Nazi elements, bringing to thirteen the number held in custody.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The American freighter Steel Seafarer was attacked by a low-flying airplane bomber in the Red Sea on the night of Sept. 5 under conditions, of excellent visibility and sank quickly as the result of well-placed bombs, according to an affidavit of Captain J. H. Halliday, the master, received by the State Department today from the American vice consulat Suez.

Commenting on the refusal of American Labor party leaders to renominate him for City Councilman because of their belief that he is an isolationist, Harry W. Laidler said yesterday that, while he believed renomination should depend entirely on his record in the Council, he was not an isolationist.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- The Court of Appeals, at the end of an eleven-hour session devoted entirely to election cases, decided tonight by a 5-to-2 vote that the name of John R. Davies shall stay on the ballot for the Republican Mayoralty nomination in the primary election next Tuesday.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 11 -- The suggestion in published reports yesterday that the dilapidated Summer estate of Mrs. James J. Coogan on Catherine Street and Rhode Island Avenue, this city, be cleared and made into a park to be known as the Coogan Memorial Park has failed to move the members of the family, as have other appeals made in the past.
Frederick Warner Seymour, utilities executive, died on Wednesday in the French Hospital after a short illness. He was 54 years old and resided at 356 Forest Road, South Orange, N.J.
LARAMIE, Wyo., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Elysabeth C. Carrere Barbour has obtained a divorce from United States Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey, a check of court records disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Roosevelt has ordered the Navy to destroy on sight any Grerman or Italian submarines or raiders entering waters "the protection of which is necessary for American defense." Not only shall American shipping be thus protected, but British and Allied shipping as well.

Daniel Arnstein, former Chicago cab driver who for three months has been trouble-shooting the Burma Road for the United States Government and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday brimming with enthusiasm for "the road," for Chinese truck drivers, and for the Chinese cause in general.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 11 -- The first clinical evidence that a vitamin recently observed to restore the original color to the fur of prematurely gray animals may produce a similar result in human beings was presented here today before the annual Autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Partly as a result of its incursion into manufacturing in this country, the International Telephone and Telegraph. Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $73,760 in the first six months of 1941, against a net loss of $126,977 in the same period last year.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 -- The cast that presented the patriotic moral-rearmament revue, "You Can Defend America," at the Casino Theatre tonight before a large audience of Summer residents were for the most part guests in various Summer homes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 11 -- There were no disturbances today in the Oslo district affected by yesterday's proclamation of martial law by Reich Commissar Josef Terboven. [Strikes in Oslo's iron and shipbuilding industries ended yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Hungarian Regent, paid a three-day visit to Reichsfuehrer Hitler at the Fuehrer's headquarters this week, according to an official communique issued tonight.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Clem Dreisewerd ended Newark's domination of the Red Wings in their International League playoff series by shutting out the Bears tonight, 2 -- 0, on six hits. Newark won the first two games of the best-of-seven series.

A parcel of vacant land in the Journal Square area of Jersey City, N. J., which that city acquired last July at foreclosure, has just been sold by the municipality for a small fraction of its assessed valuation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- V. Thor, chairman of the Icelandic government Trade Commission, said today that the 1,215-ton Icelandic vessel Hekla was sunk in late June by a submarine while en route from Iceland to Canada.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The officers of the Russian Air Force who arrived here last week after a flight from Moscow via Alaska were quite recently in the midst of the struggle with the Germans. They are described as outstanding experts in aerial and mechanized warfare.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Ebby Gerry's Aknusti team loomed as a title prospect this afternoon as players and ponies went through their last workouts in preparation for Saturday's opening of the national polo championships at the Meadow Brook Club.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- The government's Information Board spokesman said today the United States and Russia had not yet replied to Japan's second representations protesting shipments of gasoline to the Soviet port of Vladivostok.

Ten sea-going ships of 83,944 gross tons were completed in shipyards of the United States during August and delivered to their owners, according to a survey of ship construction in the current Bulletin of the American Bureau of Shipping.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Capital reaction to President Roosevelt's address tonight ranged from the assertion of Senator McCarran that it was "nothing short of an unauthorized declaration of war" to a statement of Senator Thomas of Utah that "driving pirates off or out of the seas is not war."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Charles P. Luckey of Mount Kisco and Mrs. S. Hinman Bird of Whippoorwill carried off the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association best-ball four-somes crown today at the Knollwood Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Plans for the expansion of the steel industry by 10,000,000 tons at a cost of about $1,250,000,000 are nearing completion by experts of the Office of Production Management and may be ready for submission Tuesday to the new Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Flora Hanover, a Down East mare, trotted to a ding-dong victory in the Governor's Cup race at the Kentucky State Fair Grand Circuit meet today over stiff competition from the Hanover (Pa.) Shoe Farm's Little Lie.

The city of Utica, N. Y., awarded yesterday to Dick Merle-Smith an issue of $740,987 of various-purpose bonds on a bid of 100.5599 for 1 per-cent obligations. The bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1941, and maturing serially from Oct. 1, 1942, to 1961, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.15 to 1.25 per cent according to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- A new kind of "brain trust," to protect President Roosevelt and his aides from false information reaching this country from foreign sources, has been created by Colonel William J. Donovan, Coordinator of Defense Information.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- If Reichsfuehrer Hitler's motorized forces were to follow the timetable of the unmotorized troops of Napoleon Bonaparte, they would enter Moscow tomorrow. According to authorized military quarters in Berlin, however, the German front line in the central sector is around forty-five miles east of Smolensk and more than forty-five mile east of Gomel.

The anglers who put away their off-shore fishing tackle on Labor Day are missing quite a bit of sport, according to reports from several of the Long Island and New Jersey fishing centers, for the school tuna are still plentiful and just as large as they were in August.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two things stand out in the investigation of the motion-picture industry by a Senate subcommittee which mark it as wholly opposed to every tradition of the American form of democratic government.

A unit of about 25,000 square feet of space, comprising the fifth, sixth and part of the seventh floors in the Commerce Building at 155 East Forty-fourth Street has been leased for executive and general offices by Girl Scouts, Inc., and the New York Girls Scouts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- "In the past year the country has experienced the most rapid increase in the volume of bank credit during its history," the Federal Reserve Board declared in its September bulletin issued today. "Loans of commercial banks have expanded by nearly three billions and their holdings of United States Government obligations by about $3,600,000,000."
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command mand issued the following commiinique today:

With a ruling by the OPM anxiously awaited on whether the slide-fastener industry will be granted supplies of metal to continue operations, one of the companies in this field reported yesterday it had laid off between 400 and 500 of its 1,700 employes because of inability to get copper, nickel silver, zinc and replacement tools and machinery.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 11 -- Shouts of "he must leave the country" were heard repeatedly in the Chamber of Deputies tonight when it began discussing the resolution of the investigating committee that German Ambassador Baron Edmund von Thermann had exceeded his diplomatic duties and made improper use of his position.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 11 -- Conceding that the point has been reached in the defense program where all business must be prepared to make real sacrifices, trade associations representing widely varied fields frankly expressed disappointment and disapproval of the policy of some defense agencies in attempting to go over the heads of associations directly to industry for the solution of problems which cannot be handled adequately without full and complete data.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- The "resettlement" in Serbia of the Volga Germans, announced by Moscow, is merely a pretext for the extermination of 400,000 peasants of German origin -- such is the German reaction to this Soviet measure, as reflected in the daily press.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions, figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.
Lumber output declined by more than the usual seasonal amount last week, and the adjusted index fell to 118.9 from 121.8 for the week ended Aug. 30. It stood at 94.0 for the week ended Sept. 7, 1940.

Assessment reductions totaling $554.100 for the tax periods 1937 to 1940-41 have been granted by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin on the theatre and office building property at 1697 Broadway and 203-5 West Fifty-third Street.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 -- Communique No. 1 from this vital sector of the major league baseball front should read pleasantly to the folks back in Flatbush.

Paul J. Sampliner, president of the Independent News Service, has leased an apartment of elever rooms and five baths in the building at 895 Park Avenue through Pease Elliman, Inc., and Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. Mr. Sampliner has been a resident of Scarsdale.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11 -- What was regarded as a move by President Manuel Avila Camacho away from the influence of former President Lazaro Cardenas was announced tonight in the appointment of Octavio Bejar Vazquez, a moderate in politics, as Minister of Education.

Three men were convicted in Federal court yesterday on the first charge to be made in this district of tampering with the Selective Service Administration. The conviction, which was obtained less than four months after the three defendants had tried unsuccessfully to bribe a draft law investigator, was immediately stressed by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa as a warning and an assurance that all such attempts would be prosecuted vigorously.

In the first definite move by an industry in the clothing field to meet present rising costs through organized action, the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers at a meeting yesterday appointed special committees to develop simpler garments and establish a code of fair trade practices.

The Curtis Publishing Company has decided not to go through with its plan of withdrawing the 2 per cent discount for cash after Feb. 1, 1942. Walter D. Fuller, president, confirmed this change of plan yesterday by telephone from Philadelphia.

Acting at the request of Mayor La Guardia, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to authorize Dock Commissioner John McKenzie to establish a reduced round-trip rate for motor vehicles on the municipal ferryboats between the Battery and St. George, S. I.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, National Football League champions, overwhelmed the College All-Stars, 23-6, tonight before a throng of 38,000 in the Crosscup-Pishon American Legion Post's annual charity game at Fenway Park.

Amplitude of fur is the slogan of Gunther for this Winter's furs. While there is insistence on good tailoring, ease of silhouette is stressed. All of which means greater luxury in appearance. Only in the long-haired furs is the bulky look acceptable.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES :

Bay Dean, an 8-year-old jumper who never has made any great pretentions to being at the top of the division, won handsomely again yesterday at Aqueduct in the $5,850 Glendale Steeplechase Handicap and once more made it clear that Arthur White is a keen trainer.
LONDON, Sept. 11 UP) - The Bank of England's statement today showed a rise in note circulation of u2,146,000 to a high record of u669,404,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Southpaw Herman Besse celebrated his return from the Toronto farm today by pitching the Athletics to a six-hit victory over the White Sox. The score was 2 to 1.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 12 -- John D. Biggers of the Office of Production Management reached Great Britain today by plane on a mission to see how the productive facilities of this country and the United States could best be synchronized. He will remain here five to six weeks.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 11 -- Sicily's famous volcano is not erupting now, but Royal Air Force bombers kindled their own Etna in the Citadel section at Messina in a raid carried out Tuesday night and early yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- Jessie Matthews, English screen actress, arrived in Hollywood today by plane to make her first American film appearance in "This Changing World," cooperative British war charities picture which RKO will release.

Despite a unanimous offer by the faculty to save the school by accepting reductions and deferments in salaries, the New York Law School, founded fifty years ago, will suspend operations this Fall because of economic conditions and steadily decreasing enrollments, aggravated by the draft, and will be absorbed by St. John's University School of Law in Brooklyn.

Two publishers have quickly added books on Russia to their Fall lists. For Doubleday, Doran (Sept. 26) Maurice Hindus has written "Hitler Cannot Conquer Russia." Anna Louise Strong calls her book (Dial Press, Oct. 25) "The Soviets Expected It."

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Sept. 12 -- The German wedge through Smolensk is now surrounded on three sides, according to the latest reports from Moscow, which also tell of fierce fighting nearly eighty miles west of Smolensk it-self -- in the area around Oryekhovno in the lake region south of Polotsk.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- The wheat market showed today a bouyant undertone, reversing its action of the previous day, with professional and Eastern traders rushing to replace lines sold out the previous days as a result of Secretary Morgenthau's proposal that the government release its holding's of surplus commodities and lift the ban on imports of Canadian wheat into this country.

With the President's historic declaration of last night the era of evasions, head hiding and half measures is over; this nation is now firmly facing the fundamentals of its policy ana the actualities of the times. It is leaving its destiny neither to accidents, "incidents" nor tne convenience of the Hitler time-table.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- By invading Russia, Reiehsfuehrer Hitler adopted a, policy that had the effect of completing the Allied blockade of Germany and of German-dominated Europe, the Department of Commerce reporter today.
BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- A German military expert was quoted by the Dienst aus Deutschland today as having stated:

The recently formed New York Grand Opera Company, under the direction of Amadeo Passeri, opened its season at the Ambassador Theatre last night with a performance in French of Bizet's "Carmen." Nearly all of the 1,100 seats in the intimate auditorium were filled at this initial presentation, which was well received, with curtain calls for the principals after each of the acts.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 11 --A rank and file revolt of anthracite miners against increased union dues and assessments stepped up its tempo tonight as nearly 4,000 angry men shouted down efforts of a leader of the United Mine Workers (C.I.O.) to end their strike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Loading's of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 6, which included a holiday, amounted to 797,740 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 114,980 cars, or 12.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 102,646 cars, or 14.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 135,383 cars, or 20.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Burnet Hershey, dramatist, radio commentator and president of the Overseas Press Club, said yesterday that Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, one of the chief inquisitors in the current Senate subcommittee investigation of pro-war propaganda in the movies, had himself sponsored a film now being used as anti-war propaganda by the isolationist America First Committee.

The cotton market yesterday, after the unsettlement of the previous session which had been caused by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau's advocacy of release of government-held stocks of cotton and wheat, resumed the advance that had been uninterrupted for nine sessions until Wednesday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial "To Protect Workers" encourages me to call attention to H. R. 5149, introduced June 24 by Representative Wesley E. Disney of Oklahoma, which would withdraw from a labor union the protection and right of the National Labor Relations Act if, among other things, the union did not issue to each member an annual financial statement in a form prescribed by the Secretary of Labor.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current Senate subcommittee investigation of the motion-picture industry is directed against all propaganda in films. The Senators who are leading the inquiry present an indiscriminate list of anti-Nazi films. These pictures can be divided into three groups.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Secretary Stimson told reporters at a press conference today that he thought that the morale of troops In the Army was "not half as bad as you might think from the things said by critics." It would be improved, he said, with the imminent weeding out of unfit officers and with gradual supplying of full equipment.

NOT that it makes much difference to him this year, but Bing Miller was discussing the world series that is up ahead. His roommate on the swings around the American League circuit, Mervyn Shea, was chipping in remarks, too. Being Detroit coaches, they were in on the big party last year. Their club finished second to the Cincinnati Reds in that October scramble.

ARCHIBALD MACLEISH has written the preface for "I Am an American," a remarkably varied and interesting collection of testaments by such well-known naturalized citizens as William Knudsen, Igor Sikorski, Senator Wagner, Dr. Damrosch, Ludwig Bemelmans, Judge Pecora, Emil Ludwig, Claudette Colbert, Dr. Einstein, Tony Sarg, Luise Rainer, Giuseppe Bellanca, Elissa Landi, Louis Adamic and Thomas Mann.

VICHY, Sept. 11 (U.P.) --Two militant Communists were condemned to death and two others were sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor today by a military tribunal at Clermont-Ferrand in unoccupied France.

A distribution of $6,274,710 in Canadian funds will be made on Oct. 15 to the holders of first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company as a result of a decision by a master for the Supreme Court of Ontario fixing this as the date for crediting a payment of 15 per cent on account of principal on the bonds, or $130 for each $1,000 face amount of bonds.
READING, Pa., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Little Pat, champion pacer over a half-mile track, today won his fifth successive free-for-all trophy at the Reading Fair Grand Circuit meeting.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Port Washington's war-inspired emergency organization, some 1,500 men, women and children, will be tested tomorrow night in a mock air raid on the Sands Point School, with persons from all walks of life participating in guard and first-aid duties.

The Philip Rhinelander estate, which has been disposing of its realty holdings in this city, sold another parcel yesterday when Pauline Rosenthal of Harmon, N. Y., bought from the heirs the four-story brownstone house on a lot 16.8 by 75 feet at 113 East Nineteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Wendell L. Willkie, Republican candidate for President in 1940, called upon all Americans today to rally to the support of President Roosevelt in the policy enunciated in his radio address. Mr. Willkie declared that, while no man could say that the naval action ordered by the President "will involve us in war, any thoughtful person knows that if the President Were less firm, disastrous war would be inevitable."

Formation of a women's committee to support Mayor La Guardia and his running mates was announced yesterday by William M. Chadbourne, chairman of the Republican Primary Committee for La Guardia, McGoldrick and Morris.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Department store sales for the week ended Sept. 6 were up 12 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve reported today. The sales for the week ended Aug. 30 were up 30 per cent.

Twenty-five thousand post wardens and building control directors of the New York City Air-Raid Protection Services -- a quarter of the army of 100,000 citizens who have volunteered their services to defend the city in case enemy aircraft should ever attempt to bomb it -- will start on Monday a five-day training course to familiarize themselves with the latest methods of fighting an aerial "Blitzkrieg," Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday.

The Columbia football squad suffered its first casualty of the 1941 campaign when it was learned yesterday that Leo Blanton, a sophomore, would be out of action at least three weeks, possibly for the rest of the season. A torn ligament in his right knee, a recurrence of an old injury, will keep the Waco, Texas, youngster on the sidelines.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Thornton Wilder, addressing the opening session of the seventeenth international P.E.N. congress at the Institut Francais in South Kensington, bade playwrights, poets, essayists, editors and novelists of the thirty nations represented to "be patient."

To the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: In reading THE TIMES of Sept. 10 I was struck by an odd coincidence. In the listing of the best fighters of each division by the National Boxing Association, the flyweight class had a predominance of English fighters, which was just the reverse of the case in every other group.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Sept. 12 -- The new "tow targets" outfit, which includes about seventy men from New York City In its personnel of 350, got its first redesigned Martin B-10 bomber into the air this week with a forty-foot target streaming 7,000 feet behind it.

At a luncheon yesterday at the Century Club members of this year's Carnegie Institute jury, in whose honor the luncheon was given, informally discussed the results attained thus far in the task of selecting pictures for the annual exhibition that will open in Pittsburgh Oct. 23.

The Football Giants will get another look at the T formation tonight, but it will not be the Chicago Bears that are operating it. The completely reorganized Philadelphia Eagles, now the property of the millionaire sportsman, Alexis Thompson, will join the pupils of Stout Steve Owen for their first game of the National Football League season in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, established today price differentials for all grades and classifications of domestic hides with a top limit of 15 1/2 cents a pound for the four top grades, but said that the revision of a previous price order "does not justify any change in the price of leather or leather products."

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 12 -- On the lookout for a punter to succeed Frank Reagan, who was graduated, Head Coach George Munger put the Pennsylvania backs and Johnny Creamer, end, through a long kicking drill today in the opening practice.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- President Roosevelt's speech was widely hailed today as just the tonic needed to pick up the lagging spirits of those here who have had a growing belief in the last few weeks that the United States was getting further away from the war.

The stock market took yesterday President Roosevelt's sea-defense warning to the Axis powers with utter calm and, while the volume of business contracted, the list closed steady but mixed. It was again in the commodity futures that the real gyrations took place, as prices jumped at the opening in reaction to the President's radio address, then lost ground in a flurry of profit-taking and selling influenced by reports of coming Federal brakes on inflation.

Replying to reports from London that the international P.E.N. congress seeks the dissolution of the European P.E.N. in America on the grounds that it is a "spurious" organization, Jules Romains, French novelist, who heads the European group here said yesterday that the congress had no right to pass judgment on his new organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- A spokesman for the eight major anthracite producers informed Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, today that the companies "cannot accede to any arbitrary price ceiling" which would hamper the industry's present wage structure and reduction of operating deficits.

Germany's absorbing Interest in all phases of this country's activities during 1940 and the first half of 1941, from airplane production and shipbuilding facilities to weather conditions along the Atlantic seaboard, was pictured in graphic detail yesterday at the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government, specifically, Germany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The first step in the Army's release of officers considered unfit for duty was taken today with a recommendation that 170 be withdrawn.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 12 -- The President's "shoot-on-sight and convoy" policy means that the United States has at length entered a "shooting war" with all that that implies.

Three British labor leaders, the advance guard of a delegation which will represent labor and industry on a tour of American defense industry as guests of the Office of Production Management, arrived from Lisbon yesterday aboard the Dixie Clipper.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The British Admiralty issued this communique today:

The two-family dwelling at 1079 Astor Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Mutual Housing Corporation to William Chasin, who paid a cash consideration above the first mortgage of $10,500. The parcel is valued for taxation at $18,500.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 12 -- Discovery and isolation in pure form of two new enzymes of life, providing two important missing links in our knowledge of the mechanism of respiration, and pushing farther our understanding of the mystery how life carries on with oxygen, was reported here today at the symposium on the respiratory enzymes and the biological action of the vitamins at the University of Wisconsin.

The disappearance last July of four paintings valued at $10,000 from W. J. Sloane, 575 Fifth Avenue, was believed solved last night when the police arrested Charles Russell Perkins, 24-year-old Negro laborer who said he had no home.
BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Joe Dobson of the Red Sox blanked the Browns today, 5 to 0, for his sixth consecutive victory.

Despite the rising cost of living, the New York joint board of the Millinery Workers Union, A.F. of L., has decided not to seek higher wages for its 20,000 members for fear of driving factories out of the metropolitan area, Nathaniel Spector, general manager of the joint board, announced last night.

Lincoln Filene, chairman of the Federated Department Stores, Inc., reported yesterday for the six months ended on July 31 an estimated net profit of $829,737 after provision for all charges, including depreciation and taxes, and after deducting profit applicable to minority interests in preferred and common stocks of subsidiary companies.
Loft buildings in the fur district attracted investors in deals announced yesterday by brokers.

After dutifully listening to three acts of "Brother Cain," which was acted at the John Golden last evening, a thinking man is likely to give up any idea he may have had about adopting coal mining as a career. For "Brother Cain" insists that coal mining is dangerous, coal miners are hot-headed and stupid and coal mining companies are heartless.

VICHY, France, Sept. 12 -- A translation into French of the complete text of President Roosevelt's radio broadcast was handed to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today by United States Ambassador Admiral William D. Leahy when he was received in audience by the Chief of the French State today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept 12 -- With the Administration's Price Control Bill scheduled for early consideration in Congress, two outstanding facts about the attitude of farmers toward price control are revealed in a nation-wide institute survey of farm sentiment.

The heavier load carried by many industries engaged in defense production presages an increase in stream, pollution in New York State, it was stated yesterday by Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne at the annual State convention of the Izaak Walton League in Cortland.

The Second Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of life, closing a four-day session at Columbia University, declared yesterday that the common factor in the varied viewpoints expressed by its membership of scientists, philosophers, theologians, artists and critics was an insistence on "the dignity and worth of the human personality."
VICHY, France, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The French announced tonight that work was being rushed to transform Abidjan on Africa's Ivory Coast into "one of the most secure natural harbors in the world."

Investment Market Railroads and their agencies promise to continue to be the principal borrowers in the bond market at least for a week or so. This week has been the dullest period of new financing in more than a year, and the only sign of a pickup in activity in the immediate future is in the carrier field, where two new loans will be offered for sale in competitive bidding next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The master of the Montana was M. Knudsen, a 41-year-old Dane. The address of his wife, Mrs. Lilly Knudsen, was given as 9100 Second Avenue, North Bergen, N. J. The second mate was Niels G. Aarre, also a Dane.

"Badlands of Dakota," which has been playing to capacity audiences at the Rialto, according to an announcement by the management, will begin a second and final week on Monday. . . The Forty-eighth Street Theatre will inaugurate its Swedish film season today with the first local showing of "Min Van Klock-Johan."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Johnny Humphries's four-hit pitching and his teammates' timely hitting gave the White Sox a 2-to-0 victory over the Athletics today. It was Humphries's fourth shut-out victory of the year. Chicago made eight hits off Phil Marchildon.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 12 -- The rebellion of rank and file members of the United Mine Workers of America against an increase in their union dues and assessments spread into the Mahanoy City area today with the closing of two collieries there and the increase in the number of idle men to an estimated 20,000 or more.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Phils blasted three Cub pitchers today to win the opener of a two-game series, 5 to 3. Tom Hughes was returned the victor, although he allowed nine hits, three by Lou Novikoff, recently returned from Milwaukee.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Sept. 12 -- On a faultlessly groomed gridiron in sylvan setting of majestic peacefulness and beauty, fifty-nine young men garbed in all colors of the rainbow kicked and threw around footballs the morning and afternoon long today.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 13 -- Bomber Command planes of the Royal Air Force went on a new mission Thursday night when they made their first raid on Rostock, important German naval base on the Baltic Sea that is being used by the Nazis in their war against the Russians.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 12 -- After three and a half hours of speeches in which Deputies of all shades of opinion denounced Nazi activities in Argentina, the Chamber of Deputies adjourned tonight until Monday without approving a resolution proposed by its investigating committee, in which German Ambassador Edmund von Thermann is censured for exceeding his diplomatic duties and violating his privileges.

Many areas of the city participated in the apartment leasing covered by the reports received yesterday from brokers and agents. The volume was somewhat less than was current earlier hi the week, but calls for quarters in new buildings and in old houses which have been renovated still are said to be heavy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 11:
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Taft 2d have returned from Murray Bay, Quebec, and are now in their new home at 44 Bast Sixty-seventh Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: By way of making it respectable and putting it to our own uses the term "propaganda" is carefully dissected in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 7 by Dr. Ralph Barton Perry. He divides it into good and bad propaganda according as it deals with truth or falsehood and thereby trips into a common error.

The first comment in Berlin on the President's address is that Germany and not the United States will determine "what happens next." That is true, up to a point; but not beyond that point. It is true in the sense that German action, or inaction, will determine what happens on the sea lanes in the immediate future.

Clergymen of New York and vicinity will comment in their sermons tomorrow on the radio address delivered by President Roosevelt Thursday evening. In churches tomorrow and in synagogues this morning prayers will be offered for the President and his family for comfort in their sorrow at the death of Mrs. James Roosevelt.

The Loyal Americans of German Descent, an anti-Nazi organization with headquarters at 285 Madison Avenue, sent to President Roosevelt and Charles A. Lindbergh yesterday telegrams commenting on their addresses of Thursday night.

A buying wave which carried the cotton market in the first hour yesterday to new twelve-year peaks subsided quickly, taking quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange as much as 42 points below their best levels for the session.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 -- The police investigation of Nazi activities in Chile extended into the provinces today after the arrest yesterday of thirteen prominent Germans. Many additional arrests were made in southern cities, and centers of totalitarian organizations were raided in a search for documents revealing a complete set-up of militarized groups and plans of action.
