There is nothing in the structure of a healthy young man to indicate that his organs and tissues will degenerate and that he will go the way of all flesh. What is the process? Can it be prolonged, so that a hundred and even a hundred and fifty years will become the span of life?

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Sept 12 -- Fresh from instruction in the armored-force replacement schools at Fort Knox, Ky., 770 selectees arrived Wednesday afternoon to fill vacancies left by 900 men transferred Sunday from Major Gen. Henry W. Baird's Fourth Armored Division to form a cadre for the Fifth Armored Division soon to be activated in the West.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Out of the effort which the automobile industry in general and his own company are putting into building swiftly the tools of national defense will come great benefits to the passenger automobile and the commercial vehicle of the future, George W. Mason, president of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, told about 3,000 distributors, dealers and salesmen and members of the automotive press gathered here today for a new-car convention at the Hotel Stevens.

CAMP PENDLETON, Sept. 12 -- A new intensive training program designed to prepare it for field artillery work occupied the 244th Coast Artillery this week as it awaited final word on manoeuvres. The regiment will send an advance party to South Carolina next week, if it receives final announcement that it will go on the two-month tests.

By placing fifth yesterday in the final race of the Star Class series held by the Eastchester Bay Yacht Racing Association, William H. Picken Jr. of Bay Shore, L.I., won the Atlantic Coast class championship with his craft Fo-Fo.

Stewart Holbrook's new book is "Murder Out Yonder," an informal account of certain "classic" back-country crimes. The author spent months investigating nearly 100 cases, traveling 11,000 miles in running down records, newspaper accounts and in interviewing -- the murderer in one instance.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept 12 (AP) -- The Germans are resorting to mass arrests in an attempt to forestall a threatened gigantic conflict within the next few days, border advices said tonight. Angered by repressive measures to block a

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Prices of anthracite coal were frozen today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, who moved to prevent an at-the-mine increase of 15 cents a ton on domestic sizes which producers had announced for Monday.

The three-story factory building at 67-73 Winthrop Street, Newark, N.J., has been purchased in an expansion move by Rangertone, Inc., Richard H. Ranger, president, from the A.M.S. Realty Company, in a deal arranged by Edwin C. Butler, broker.

Addressing a distinguished gathering of civilians and officers of the United States and British navies at the New York Yacht Club yesterday, Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Commandant of the Third Naval District, forecast shooting in the Atlantic "in the near future" and said that "every American officer ought to be proud to be there to take it and give it back to them in good measure."

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 12 -- Large Netherlands and German buying orders, due to the more favorable comments on the position in the Far East, considerably raised prices here today of Netherlands Indies shares, Royal Dutch advancing 10 3/4 points to 321 5/8 in a heavy volume.

Just to make certain that the Tigers would not gain the distinction of being the only club in the American League to win their season's series with the Yankees, the Bronx Bombers entertained a ladies' day crowd of 5,500 at the Stadium yesterday by routing the retiring champions, 8 to 2, in the second game of the current set.

PORT WASHINGTON, L., I., Sept. 12 -- In a remarkable demonstration of community team-work, Port Washington, where the Deutsche Lufthansa transatlantic flying boats used to make practice landings in peaceful pre-war days, blacked out its lights for seven minutes tonight in a complete dress rehearsal for air raids and disasters.

The defense obligations assumed or under negotiation by the General Motors Corporation now amount to $1,200,000,000, covering a broad field of projects, according to a letter addressed to stockholders yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the company.

VICHY, France, Sept. 12 -- Another German Army officer has been injured in Paris by an Unidentified assailant, according to reports received here tonight. No action of reprisal has as yet been announced.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Colonel Glair W. Baird, who completed today his first year in command of this post, was honored this afternoon and evening by his fellow officers and soldiers in events combining anniversary and farewell felicitations.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- H.G. Wells, British author, will be elected international president of P.E.N. tomorrow at the concluding session of the seventeenth congress, held at the Institute Francais in South Kensington, London. He will succeed Jules Romains, chosen in Prague, Czecho-Slovakia, in 1938 (pre-Munich).

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 13 -- The Russian High Command announced today that the Red Army had withdrawn from Chernigov, on the western bank of the Desna River, after a series of bitter battles. Stiff fighting continued along the entire front and Soviet troops persisted in counter-attacks in the central sector.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The United States mission, to the three-power supply conference in Moscow was directed by President Roosevelt today to work out an allocation of American war materials to Russia for the most effective use toward defeating German aggression.

With general and automotive the only classifications showing a decline, advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records registered an increase of 4 per cent for August. This brought the increase for the first eight months of the year to 3.6 per cent.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 12 -- The halting until after the war of the government's plan for mobilization of the country's remaining doctors in a system of free medical care was sought by the Opposition when the measure was debated in the House of Representatives last night.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- Adolf Hitler, proclaiming the start of the ninth German Winter relief campaign, called on the German people today to make sacrifices for the armed forces that are engaged in a "gigantic struggle for the existence or non-existence of the German nation."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Earl Wynn, a recruit from Springfield in the Eastern League, held Cleveland to eight blows while his mates were collecting thirteen as the Senators trimmed the Indians, 7 to 4, today.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, New York's leading Roman Catholic layman, Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of the Free Synagogue, one of the outstanding Jewish leaders of New York, expressed strong approval yesterday of President Roosevelt's Thursday night address.

Two men were killed and seven other persons, including two small boys, were injured shortly after 3:30 P.M. yesterday in an explosion and fire at the factory of the Charles Comerford Shellac Company, 509 Third Avenue, near Twelfth Street, Brooklyn.

The Spanish freighter Navemar, packed like a cattle boat with refugees from Germany and Nazi-dominated lands of Europe, docked in Brooklyn late yesterday at the end of one of the war's strangest voyages, an odyssey in reverse.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 12 -- The secret landing field in Colombia threatening Panama Canal, which was mentioned by President Roosevelt in his broadcast last night, is seventeen miles from the Caribbean port of Cartagena, according to a reliable report here.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 -- Last night Lippy Leo Durocher was unshaven but happy. Tonight he will be shaven but unhappy, for he had vowed not to remove his whiskers if his Dodgers won again today. They lost, and the Cardinals no are only one game out of the lead, with a chance to take it by winning the final tomorrow.

Returning to work after a three-week strike, C.I.O. members employed in Gimbel Brothers department store voted yesterday to take a five-day, forty-hour week, with no immediate increase in pay, instead of a five-and-one-half-day, forty-two-hour week, with a weekly wage rise of $1.50.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Pirates and Braves today split a double-header for the second straight day. Pittsburgh won the first game, 6 to 3, for Lloyd Dietz's seventh victory of the year and Al Javery blanked the Bucs in the second, 5 to 0.

Mr. Andrews of Florida has made a point in the Senate that is so eminently reasonable that it will strike a responsive chord in every human heart. The upper chamber needs more light. "Sometimes," says Mr. Andrews, "it is hard to determine whether your wife is sitting in the gallery or not, because you can't see."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. Sept. 12 (AP) -- Old Man Par was given a thorough going-over today in the first round of the $5,000 Greater Atlantic City open golf tournament at the Country Club of Atlantic City.

Edgar S. Auchincloss, 32 years old, a great-grandson of the late Samuel Sloan, D.L. W. Railroad president, pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions to an indictment accusing him of being criminally negligent on the night of Aug. 20 when the automobile he was driving killed Thomas S. Cooke.

Sixteen, including the leaders in the division, have been named for today's running at Aqueduct of the $20,000 Beldame Handicap, which will be the companion piece to the 513,000 Cowdin, formerly the Junior Champion. A third stake, the $3,000 Bushwick hurdles, makes the day's distribution the biggest of the meeting for the Queens County Jockey Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In spite of the British blockade, Germany is today the only European nation that is comfortably fed; the condition of the people in the conquered countries is appalling. Since the blockade is unable to keep food from Germans, why should it be applied to our friends the Belgians and the people of the other conquered nations?

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Francis Jebb Alien of Khakum Wood, this place, gave a supper dance tonight at their home here for their debutante daughter, Miss Ellen Jebb Alien, The debutante received with her parents in the living room, which was banked with yellow chrysanthemums and other Autumn flowers.

Robert Erskine Ely, director emeritus of Town Hall, who laid the foundation for its nation-wide forums, was honored by his associates in that institution and the Economic Club yesterday on the eve of his eightieth birthday. Many of the leaders in civic, educational and cultural fields who took part in programs under Mr. Ely's direction were among the 500 men and women attending the testimonial luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- A new high record for soy beau futures was established today on the Board of Trade, with the May running up more than 4 cents to a high of $2.02 a bushel, the first time that figure has been quoted on the Exchange since trading began in 1936.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 12 -- The Morris County grand jury indicted today two persons on charges of jury tampering, the allegation being that they tried to influence two members of the grand jury while it was considering indictments against Frank Erickson, New York bookmaker, and others accused of assaulting Milton F. Untermeyer, New York stock broker, at his home in Kinnelon, N.J., last May 25.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 12 -- Keeping herself in the match by holing a fifteen-foot downhill putt on the home hole at The Country Club, Mrs. Frank Neweli of Long Beach, Calif., reached the final round of the women's national golf championship today by eliminating Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N.C., with a birdie 4 on the nineteenth.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 12 -- About 1,500 officers and enlisted men, comprising the Forty-fourth Division's advance detachment, are scheduled to leave here tomorrow morning in 142 vehicles for Wadesboro, N.C., site of the division's base camp during the First Army manoeuvres in October and November.

Trade Gain Here Under 10% While retail trade here continued active this week, percentage gains over a year ago were likely to be smaller than in recent weeks, reports yesterday indicated. Estimates put department store volume at probably under 10 per cent better than a year ago.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept 12 -- Only three horses were entered today to run against Whirlaway in the $25,000 Narragansett Special, and it appeared that Warren Wright's 3-year-old champion would go to the post tomorrow favored at 1 to 2.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The doors of three strikebound packing plants at the Chicago Stockyards were opened today after Judge George Fred Rush of the Cook County Circuit Court had granted a sweeping injunction limiting the number of pickets.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Alan B. Plaunt, one of Canada's leading exponents of public control and operation of radio and a former member of the Board of Governors of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, died today at the age of 37 after a long illness.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 13 -- The first Japanese reaction to President Roosevelt's speech was one of relief that he had again omitted any direct mention of Japan, which was taken to indicate that the Washington conversations based on Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye's "peace message" were continuing, with the prospect of favorable results."

The fireproof industrial building at 9-20 Thirty-eighth Avenue, Long Island City, has been purchased by the 9 - 20 Thirty-eighth Avenue Corp., Valentine Ling, president, a client of Pokart Pokart, attorneys, and in turn leased for a chemical manufacturing plant to the Purocaine Chemical Co., Inc., Julius Bolyog, president.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Soldiers, policemen and civilians from forty States, Canada, Mexico and Central America participated today in the opening matches here of the first annual Empire State National Revolver and Pistol Tournament, held to perfect marksmen for community and hemispheric defense.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 12 -- The issue arising from failure of defense agencies, in particular the Office of Price Administration to rely upon trade associations probably will be resolved by effort at rapprochement on the initiative of the trade association men themselves, it was predicted unofficially here this afternoon.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Sept. 13 -- The Russian High Command acknowledged in a communique early today that the German threat to Kiev from the north had been increased and that Soviet troops had been forced to evacuate Chernigov.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Doubtless few fight fans know that Lou Nova spent the Summer in Northern Maine. Bunny Pierce, the sports leader of that area and storekeeper at Bingham, took technicolor movies of Lou In action. He was signing autographs for the village kids.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Judge Ernest A. Inglis in Superior Court handed down a decision today holding the Most Rev. Maurice F. McAuliffe, Roman Catholic Bishop of the Hartford Diocese, controls the property of St. John's Greek Catholic Church here, cathedral church of the Right Rev, Orestes Chornock, Bishop of the Carpatho-Russian Greek Catholic Diocese in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The American-owned cargo ship Montana was torpedoed midway between Iceland and Greenland yesterday, shortly before President Roosevelt warned Germany and Italy that their war vessels henceforth would be shot on sight in United States defense waters, the State Department said today.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- John Biggers, United States lease-lend director in London, said today the combined efforts of the present programs of the United States and Great Britain, "properly synchronized, will outdo Axis production by the middle of 1943."
MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Prices of hogs were steady today, with those for sows strong to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. Beef cattle held in line with yesterday's close, but Spring lambs were off 15 to 25 cents.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Each time a bottle-throwing exhibition occurs at a local ball park the newspapers take a mild slap at the rowdies responsible for it and the matter is forgotten until it hapens again.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- The German High Command complained of bad weather and terrain difficulties on the Eastern Front today as it was reported that the Red Army had undertaken two counter-attacks south of Leningrad, in addition to the strong Central Front offensives that the Russians have been pressing for more than a week.

Mrs. Alice Richmond has purchased from the Troy Savings Bank through Herbert L. Williams, Inc., brokers, the two-story colonial residence at 90 Taymil Road, New Rochelle, Westchester, valued for taxation at $17,105. The house contains eight rooms and three baths.

Although the people of the United States have done their part in contributing generously to the USO and President Roosevelt is the organization's "best friend," not one building for the use of service men has been erected with government funds as provided for in the original contract, Walter Hoving, former USO president and now chairman of the board, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- President Roosevelt was reliably reported today to have had reasonable assurance of peace in the Pacific before he ordered United States planes and warships to shoot on sight any Axis submarines found in the defensive waters of the United States.

Ada-May, once of the musical stage, has been engaged for the featured role in "Western Union, Please," the Frances Goodrich-Albert Hackett comedy which the firm of Aldrich Myers is producing. She will appear opposite Charles Butterworth.

CAMP STEWART, Sept. 12 -- With the departure this week of the Eighty-sixth Quartermaster Battalion for Hoffman, N.C., additional troops from this post's six regiments and three separate battalions will leave here on Monday for the scene of the Fall war games of the First Army.

Business activity increased only slightly this week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The mild rise that took place from the existing high levels was smaller than the increase that usually occurs in early September. Business barometers again reflected an irregularity in trend, due partly to last week's holiday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Hygrade Sylvania Corporation of Salem, Mass., manufacturer of electric incandescent lamp bulbs, radio receiving tubes, fluorescent lamps and fixtures and related products, today filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 100,000 shares of common stock of no par value.

Open hearings before a joint committee of the New York State Legislature on permitting life insurance companies to make investments in common stock have been tentatively set for Oct. 20 and 21, Murray L. Watt, counsel for the committee, announced yesterday.

Results of a nation-wide field survey among women, believed the first of its kind ever made and ranked highly important as a dress merchandising and sales tool, will be disclosed to members of the New York Dress Institute at a series of two meetings to be held next Tuesday and Wednesday.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- A decided decrease in the number of firms reporting better business, higher commodity prices and larger in ventories is noted in the August business survey report released to day by the New England Purchasing Agents Association.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Newark took a 3-1 lead over the Red Wings in the semi-final round of the International League play-offs tonight, staging a four-run rally in the ninth inning for a 9 -- 6 victory.

Mackerel in white wine sauce is as traditional a dish in the fishermen's cottages of Brittany as baked beans with brown bread in the red brick houses of Boston's Back Bay. And in less turbulent times, before the war put a halt to European imports, this Gallic delicacy of firm-fleshed mackerel in its spicy sauce used to arrive on these shores, tidily tinned, in sizable shipments.

An effort "to unify the work of all agencies, in order to gain greater effectiveness in the Far East" will be made at a special meeting next Friday, Saturday and Sunday of the Board of Strategy of the Protestant Foreign Missions Conference of North America at the Gramatan Hotel in Bronxville.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The British and Russian envoys protested to the Iranian Government today against an editorial in the government-controlled newspaper Ettelaat which attacked the British-Russian treatment of Iran. The editorial asserted that Iran would maintain political relations with the Axis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -- "Pied Piper," new novel by Nevil Shute, was purchased today by Twentieth Century-Fox for Winter production. The story deals with an elderly Englishman who escapes from wartime France with a group of small children.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 12 -- Eight Southern California aircraft plants moved today to increase wages many millions of dollars.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The following communique was issued by the State Information Bureau tonight:

With his place on the primary election ballot assured by the decision of the Court of Appeals, John R. Davies disclosed yesterday in an interview that at a conference with Mayor La Guardia on Aug. 8 at the Admiral Club he offered to withdraw as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor if Mr. La Guardia would promise not to campaign against the next Republican candidates for Governor and President.
A half-hour scrimmage brought Fordham's football practice to a close yesterday afternoon after the Rams had run through morning and afternoon drills on Fordham Field.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 -- Colonel Bill Terry got a look at his rookie material in wholesale lots today at Crosley Field.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- President Roosevelt's speech is considered here as a step toward war, but it is already clear that it will not be taken as open intervention. Events will be allowed to develop but for the time being the Axis will take no decision.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Fifty-seven candidates for the Princeton football team answered Coach Tad Wieman's call to start practice and went through a two-and-a-half-hour workout on fundamentals on university field today.

The new-issue market in respect to bonds this week came the nearest to a complete standstill that it has in more than a year. Offering's to the public fell to a total of only $2,789,987, the smallest volume since early June, 1940, compared with $7,841,825 last week.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 12 -- Premier Arthur W. Fadden, commenting on President Roosevelt's broadcast, said today, that it would be a tonic for the people of the United Kingdom and a rallying cry for the peoples of the Americas.

Trading in locally dressed meats was only fair to slow yesterday and price trends of traefer meats were weak to lower. Kosher beef opened strong to slightly higher, veal sharply higher and kosher lamb strong.

Members of the Seafarers International Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate, will go on strike at noon today for increased war bonus payments, it was announced here yesterday by John Hawk, secretary of the organization.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- The country's small business men joined with labor and civic leaders tonight in what was called "a back-to-the-wall" campaign against threatened wide-scale dislocation of employment and production due to defense priorities.

Members of the Seafarers International Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate, will go on strike at noon today for increased war bonus payments, it was announced here yesterday by John Hawk, secretary of the organization.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- Germany will seize and hold the initiative in German-American relations from now on and "the responsibility for the consequences will rest entirely with Roosevelt," an authorized German spokesman said tonight in the first official comment on President Roosevelt's speech of Thursday night.

Polo's national championship tournament will get under way this afternon at 3:30, when Cocie Rathbone's Pelicans face Cecil Smith's Texas four on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I., in the opening round of the year's most important event.

Not Very Plain The strange thing about the literature of "the coteries" so sharply assailed by Van Wyck Brooks the other day is that it should also have become in such large measure the literature of proletarian revolt.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an admirer of the quantitative theory of money and a firm believer in its soundness, I feel constrained to call Robert K. Pepper's attention to the fact that the statement which he takes from a Federal Reserve leaflet and uses in his letter to THE TIMES does not, as he appears to think, prove the unsoundness of the aforesaid theory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The White House today compared Charles A. Lindbergh's speech, at Des Moines with the recent "outpourings of Berlin." The fresh White House criticism of Mr. Lindbergh resulted from the aviator's address, delivered under America First Committee sponsorship, soon after the President's radio address.
RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 12 -- British military strength in Burma and civilian defense preparations are rapidly being brought to the level of those in other British teritories in the Far East.

THE college football rosters are coming in by the bundle. The compilers of these brochures are optimists on a large scale. They must believe that the newspapers and the public yearn not only for the vital statistics but the detailed life histories of all the prospective gridiron heroes on their squads. They are broad-minded about it, too.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., Sept. 12 -- A provisional regiment from Fort Hancock returned to the post today after a surprise trip to West Point, to take part in a mimic warfare training program. With no advance notice, the soldiers were turned out from their bunks in full marching equipment Wednesday morning and sent to West Point on the Army steamer Brig. Gen. Yates.

TORONTO, Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Premier Mitchell Hepburn made public tonight a letter he had sent to Oliva Dionne in which he said that the Ontario Government had "accepted in principle" the suggestions the father of the quintuplets made in a letter to Mr. Hepburn Aug. 7.
ROME, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Italian High Command said today:

New State and municipal financing scheduled for sale next week by fifty-eight municipalities and local housing authorities aggregates $11,202,416, compared with $3,789,194 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $33,103,906.

Whenever it was heard, and that was almost everywhere, the President's speech was recognized for what it was -- a historic pronouncement marking the turning point in the Battle of the Atlantic and perhaps in the war itself. Naturally, the reaction to it varied according to the point of view and interest of the countries concerned, but nowhere was there any doubt about its significance or importance.

Despite persistent publicity concerning the spread of infantile paralysis, figures compiled by the United States Public Health Service from data throughout the country show the incidence this year running only about 15 per cent higher than last year, when the case load was unusually low.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Par-shattering strokes rained incessantly over the Lakeville Club links again today as eight of the thirty-two qualifying pairs survived the initial two rounds of match play in the Metropolitan Golf Association's first amateur-pro best-ball championship.

"There will be no shooting war unless Germany continues to seek it," said the President in his historic broadcast, and on that point, at least, the first official comment from Berlin seems to be in complete agreement. "What happens now," declares the spokesman of Whilhelmstrasse, "will in no way be determined by Mr. Roosevelt but by us."

THOSE who still suffer from what might be called bigbillthompsonitis and see redcoats under every bed will find very little to console them in "Victoria's Heir,"* for though the book traces in considerable, detail the forces that shaped modern Britain during the past century, it also shows the strange growth of Germany's forever hopeful and forever thwarted little efforts to enslave the world.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 12 -- There is comparatively little news today from Norway, which is silenced behind tightly closed doors as befits a prison or an immense concentration camp.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Since President Roosevelt told the world last night that the American Navy would shoot on sight to protect this country's "waters of self-defense," every White House move today indicated that henceforth for the President action will be the keystone of United States foreign policy.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept 12 -- Arriving at Camp Smith today in a motor convoy, 150 West Point cadets, commanded by Major Nelson I. Fooks, will begin four days of rifle practice with stationary and moving silhouette targets.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- Today's press continues sharp criticism of Bulgaria's present role in international affairs voiced in the note presented two days ago by Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff to the Bulgarian envoy.

By a vote of 5 to 2 the Court of Appeals has sustained the decision of the Appellate Division, First Department, reversing that of Judge Pecora of the Supreme Court, Special Term, of this county, removing the name of Mr. John R. Davies as a candidate for Mayor on the Republican ticket in the primary election next Tuesday.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 13 -- Germany probably lost the war at sea this week as President Roosevelt, denouncing what he described as Nazi "piracy," ordered the Navy to convoy and to shoot at sight.

Out of the present Japanese-American negotiations it is possible that a truce in the Far Eastern conflict may come, but not peace. The fact is that Japan and America never have been nearer war than now. For ten years there has been a steady progression toward that point, with a few deceptive interludes of apparent concord.

THE new footman lingered in the empty hall, when a blast of melody preceded the news broadcast, and did a few steps to "Boomps-a-Daisy." So he became a maker and breaker of alibis when murder brought a not illogical climax to the hostilities of Jonathan Royal's house party.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Aug. 31 appeared a letter from a young Iowan, Herald Beckjorden, who analyzes America's relation to the current world struggle and concludes that there is no reason why our country should become involved.

HERE with no trimmings is the Royal Navy in action in this war -- fourteen stories of the "fleet in being" done with comprehension, authenticity and sharp-cut atmospheric suspense. Many of the fourteen -- and the best of them -- are quick, deft, impression pieces of the mode of life in various branches of the service.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 13 -- Two prominent legionnaires, one a past national commander, accused President Roosevelt tonight, on the eve of the American Legion's national convention here, of deliberately attempting to force America into an undeclared war.

River Edge House, the twelve-story terrace apartment dwelling under erection at 33 East End Avenue, at Eighty-first Street, will be completed for Dec. 1 occupancy, it was announced yesterday by Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., newly appointed agent for the structure.
F.D.R. Orders Whoever believes he will be able to help England must definitely know one thing: Every ship, whether with or without a convoy, that comes before our torpedo tubes will be torpedoed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Another armed ship bill, and another desperate congressional battle over it, appeared in the offing today with a promise of further embittering relations between the supporters and opponents of President Roosevelt's foreign policy.
LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Admiralty report on the loss of eight ships in a convoy bound for Britain:

A two-year series of diplomatic steps have brought "effective elimination" of German-dominated airlines from the entire western side of South America and their replacement by Pan American-Grace Airways, the line announced here yesterday.

Delegations of nationals of virtually all the Nazi-occupied nations and other nations fighting for their independence, many in their colorful national costumes, will take part in the Victory Parade on Broadway on Wednesday night, it was announced yesterday by Bundles for Britain, Inc., 745 Fifth Avenue, sponsor of the parade.

The primary contest between Mayor La Guardia and John R. Davies for the Republican Mayoralty nomination will highlight Tuesday's primary elections, when the registered voters of the Republican, Democratic and American Labor party go to the polls throughout the city to select their city-wide and county tickets for the November municipal elections.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This war, like all other conflicts in human thought, will be won by character and morale and not purely by material means.

The Danish freighter African Reefer, latest foreign vessel to be requisitioned by the United States Government for use in a defense route, is to be placed under the American flag, it was disclosed here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: American invention is surging against a wall of prejudice. I am not going to recount the many evidences of a hostile attitude toward invention in general, but only those directed against military invention.

THE city of Angouleme, France, has a population of 38,000 in normal times. Just before the collapse of the French Army the refugees from the Moselle began to arrive, and in six weeks' time there were more than 300,000 people in the city.

New Nibelung Ring Another title for this entrancing tale might be Houdini-in-Reverse. It is Ring the story of a man who made it his life's ambition to put iron rings around another people and who ended up himself in an iron ring consisting of pretty nearly everybody in the world outside of himself.

A system of hospitality for visitors from Latin America has been developed in the last few months at Inter-America House, a center that has become a cultural meeting place for Americans and our Southern neighbors and an important factor in the strengthening of the good-neighbor idea.

RETAILERS stage their National Demonstration this week under the slogan "Retailers for Defense" with conditions that have rapidly returned to normal after the soaring increases of the Summer. Panic buying has dwindled and it remains to be seen what higher prices, priority unemployment and the recent stocking up by the public will mean in trade results over the coming weeks.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The Bedford Golf and Tennis Club here was the setting tonight for a dance given jointly by Mr. and Mrs. H. Bartow Farr of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Dr. and Mrs. William Barclay Parsons of New York and Ridgefield, Conn., to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Mary Blair Farr and Miss Rose P. Parsons.

THE Museum of Modern Art opened last week two new exhibitions, one of which, called "The Wooden House in America," is a traveling show. It has already been about quite a bit and will journey on from here next month.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 14 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's central army continued its counter-attacks on two salients, recapturing the small town of Setolovo in the Smolensk region and advancing ten more miles beyond Trubchevsk, below Bryansk, the Russians reported yesterday.
They practiced "Dunkerque" on the peaceful Hudson River yesterday.

HAMMOND, Ind., Sept. 13 -- Seven members of one family were killed today when their car was struck by the Grand Trunk Railroad's Maple Leaf Limited at the Kennedy Avenue crossing in Highland, seven miles southeast of Hammond.

IMMEDIATELY after Labor Day came a week of much fashion reviewing. Seven outstanding houses having custom-made departments carrying original designs conducted their Fall openings. These houses which made contributions to fashion history are: Henri Bendel, Bergdorf Goodman, Bonwit Teller, Hattie Carnegie, Milgrim's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Jay Thorpe.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Will there be an end to the sacrifice of thousands of lives? Yes! An end to this awful tragedy of human suffering could be brought about and an era of peace and security established for all if some of the earnest and humane leaders of the world would once more make a special effort in that direction.

WITH the trend toward expansion of cultural opportunities, a number of public libraries have extended their service in an effort to make good music as available as good reading. They are lending phonograph records without charge to cardholders.

SINCE the appearance of "Place of Hawks" a relatively short time ago, August Derleth has written so much and so exhaustively about one small Wisconsin town that his publishers can speak with some justice of the "Sac Prairie Saga."

The Columbia gridiron squad, ending its first week of practice yesterday, ran roughshod over Rutgers in the first intercollegiate scrimmage of the year to be held at Baker Field. No score was kept, but the first-string Lion eleven racked up three rapid touchdowns while holding the Scarlet behind its own 40-yard stripe.

More than 250 prime contractors will set up offices for three days to participate with 6,000 to 8,000 subcontractors in a defense production clinic on a national scale at the Grand Central Palace beginning Sept. 22. The clinic will be held in connection with the Civilian National Defense Exposition, which will open next Saturday.

Coming up with four runs after two of their number had been retired in the ninth inning at the Stadium yesterday, the truculent Tigers, dethroned American League champions, shot a farewell broadside into the Yankees that probably will rankle the Bronx Bombers throughout the Winter.

Governor Lehman pledged the State of New York last night to a continuing effort to place every available facility at the disposal of the national defense program, on the ground that the country is now racing against time to re-arm.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Expanded facilities for research and instruction in new fields as well as a general strengthening of the faculty are listed among the innovations in program as Princeton enters the 195th year of its existence.

THE war situation having put a great deal of money into circulation and created a more than ordinary need for mental and emotional refreshment, would seem to have set the stage for a busy and prosperous dance season.

DETROIT -- Adoption by one large car maker of a 1942-model pricing plan, whereby the dealers will set the retail price of the coming season's cars, may result in the sale of most of the industry's new cars on a regional price basis instead of on a factory-delivered price basis.

BLACK MOUNTAIN, N.C., Sept. 13 -- In beginning its ninth year on Sept. 22, Black Mountain College will also begin its first year on its new property at Lake Eden, near Black Mountain, in buildings constructed and renovated by its own students and teachers during the last year.

WITH Major Paul Pleiss, formerly of the United States Army, I have just completed a five-month motor-car expedition through all the South American republics with the exception of Paraguay. It was an amazing trip through tropical jungles, over the Andes, through modern capitals and primiative Indian villages, and across the roadless Patagonian pampas to the Strait of Magellan.

CREDIT where credit is due. Radio has turned the trick of bringing good music into hamlets where previously only the occasional tootling of a local fife and drum corps had been heard.

ELECTRIC FENCE -- Electric fences for livestock are in themselves nothing new, but new is an improvement made by Charles F. Dalziel and James R. Burch of the University of California. Their fence is based on the "single-impulse" principle, which means that it shocks just once when it is touched.

ALBAN BERG, who died at the end of 1935, wrote relatively few compositions, and only two or three have received performances here that would suffice to make them reasonably known. One recalls his opera, "Wozzeck," which made something of a sensation when it was done by Leopold Stokowski, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the League of Composers.

Both the home makers who do their own decorating and those who avail themselves of skilled advice can well take advantage of every opportunity to see what professionals are doing. A visit to the Decorators Club Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, is therefore worth while; there photographs, colored sketches, swatches of upholstery, curtain fabrics, carpets and wall colors help to visualize some of the recent achievements of leaders in interior decorating.

THERE are probably a few old timers in remote places who lean back in their rickety chairs, squint at the sky and refuse to predict the weather, declaring that only "scatter-brains" and "greenhorns" would dare to forecast rain, snow or sunny skies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13 -- Enrollment of engineering students in non-technical courses such as literature, history, economics and the social studies is expected to reach a new high this year at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology despite the general emphasis on scientific education, according to Dr. Robert G. Caldwell, dean of humanities and chairman of the Division of Cultural Relations with South American Republics.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13 -- Next week-end, the class of 1945 will arrive at Radcliffe, to open the college's first freshman orientation program. For three days before the opening of college, Sept. 19 to 21, freshmen will have an opportunity to become acquainted with Cambridge, the college, and each other, under the guidance of upper classmen.

Conducted by four authorities on world affairs, a new course in current events, based on "The Future of the Democracies," will open Town Hall's short course season this year on Oct. 13, it was announced yesterday by Chester D. Snell, vice president.

ALTHOUGH "Village Green" was not written for Frank Craven, he is in it. That is the fact of most important about the first new play of the season. For Mr. Craven is an immensely likable and entertaining fellow in the vein of Yankee neighbor.

Manhattan foreclosures showed a decline both in number and in the dollar volume of liens involved during August as compared with the same month of last year, according to the monthly survey of forced transfers by the Real Estate Board of New York.

THE Eastman Kodak Company has announced a new Bantam Special, equipped with a Kodak Ektar f:2 lens and Supermatic shutter. Aberrations are said to be virtually nonexistent in the new lens, which is particularly well suited for Kodachrome photography.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The American freighter Arkansan was hit by shell fragments and some of her plates were pierced during a heavy raid on the port of Suez on the night of Sept. 11, the State Department announced today on the basis of a report from the legation in Cairo.

With the coming of Autumn rains and cooler weather, the gardener's "second Spring" arrives -- a busy season for planning, planting and replanting, that offers just as great an opportunity for garden improvement as does the generally recognized Spring planting season.

Life insurance companies increased their holdings of FHA mortgages by $107,463,000 during the first six months of this year, bringing the value of their small home mortgages in this category to $601,262,000, it was announced yesterday by the Institute of Life Insurance.

Savings and loan associations carrying insurance under the Federal Savings and Loan Corporation increased their resources by $450, 000,000 during the fiscal year ending June 30 last, according to report issued yesterday by Oscar R. Kreutz, general manager of the corporation.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The next to last chapter in the story of a youthful attempt to fly the Atlantic behind a four-cylinder motor has been unfolded in the wilds of Newfoundland with discovery of the wreckage of Thomas H. Smith's baby Clipper.

NEXT Tuesday evening a civic banquet will bring to a climax the celebration marking the hundreth anniversary of the founding of Fordham University. The President of the United States will be represented and both the Governor of the State and the Mayor of the city will add their words of appreciation for an institution which has aided in the cultural advancement of the country.
NEW YORK Colonel and Mrs. Olin F. Harvey will give a dinner with dancing at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 27 to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Anne Woodin Harvey.

CONTINUING to be funny for a living -- at least that is the intention -- Frank Fay will lead a new troupe into WEAF'S Radio City studios Oct. 23 at 10:30 P.M. Seventy-six stations strung from coast to coast are to carry the program, which will take up thirty minutes' air time once a week.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 13 -- A great shout went up from the crowd of 43,400 gathered today for the eighth running of the Narragansett Special as Whirlaway, the 3-year-old champion, thundered down the stretch, but the famous son of Blenheim II-Dustwhirl could not overtake the fleet-moving War Relic.

RIVER BEND was the northern end of a thousand-mile trail from Texas and the shipping point for the cattle herds driven up over that trail. It was reputed to be the most sinful town west of the Missouri.

Certificates of registration are being awarded to 100 new homes comprising an entire residential development at Hingham, Mass., about eighteen miles from Boston announces David Ford, assistant governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- German reaction to President Roosevelt's broadcast today lacked some of the recriminatory vehemence that marked early comment, and the speech was frankly evaluated as a further stage in the interventionistic and aggressive policy of the White House.

SALISBURY, Conn., Sept. 13 -- A new course in animal husbandry, including breeding of Guernsey cows and sheep, will be offered to young farmers and farmerettes at Hillcrest School this Fall by Orville Engst, director, when the new term opens Sept. 22.

Fordham's football team will quit the Rose Hill campus tonight to journey to Keyser Island, in Long Island Sound off South Norwalk, Conn., where the Rams will work out for three days. They will return to the campus in time for a drill Thursday morning.

AS THESE words are being written, the ominous rumble of the opening guns in the Senatorial rump investigation of alleged pro-war propaganda in American films is heard on the breeze from Washington. Wendell L. Willkie, who is serving as counsel for the badgered industry, has fired a frank and reasoned letter at Senator D. Worth Clark, the chairman of the willful subcommittee which has assumed responsibility for conducting the initial quiz.
CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Sept. 13 -- Changes and developments designed to intensify the effectiveness of the liberal arts way of education on many fronts are forecast for the coming year at Wilson College.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- While the world's attention is concentrated on the war in Russia, there is a certain danger of forgetting other fronts, notably the Middle East.

IT was ninety years ago. Soft breezes of an autumnal night blew through the open windows of an unfinished building on New York's Nassau Street. Candles in makeshift holders guttered on the rickety tables where men sat writing, their pens scratching out copy that in the morning, Sept. 18, 1851, would be read in the four-page first issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Experience in music acquired this Summer at the Norfolk Music School of Yale University will be reflected during the Fall in at least eleven States, from New England to California, from which came the fifty-two students who have completed a six weeks course.

Real-estate difficulties, after a long period of quietude, are again confronting the former William Waldorf Astor property on the west side of Madison Avenue between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets. The twenty-five-story building erected there in 1926 several years after the death in 1919 of Lord Astor, as he was better known in later years, is to be sold at foreclosure on Sept. 23 in the Vesey Street rooms to satisfy liens exceeding $5,500,000.

THE tremendous scope of the national defense work being done by the automobile industry is not generally grasped by the public, although newspaper reporters from day to day have chronicled the war orders received by the makers of pleasure cars and commericial trucks.

Plans for the rehabilitation of between 800,000 and 1,000,000 Polish civilians exiled at the beginning of the European war to communities scattered over Russia proper and Siberia were outlined last week by Sylwin Strakacz, delegate of the Polish Red Cross to the United States, and Francis X. Swietlick, head of the Polish National Council, in an interview at the former's apartment at the Hotel Buckingham.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 13 -- Macalester College, after two years of experimentation, has announced that the core of its curricula for all students will henceforth be a sequence of courses in citizenship.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- District Attorney Dewey in addressing the annual meeting of the Federation of Bar Associations of Western New York here this afternoon counseled all lawyers to offer "unselfish and open-minded leadership in a changing world."

The Paderewski Testimonial Fund, Inc., Mrs. Vernon Kellogg, chairman, made remittances amounting to $9,925 and was in receipt of $10,922 during July and August, according to a statement released from the organization's national headquarters in this city.

Retail trade in the New York area continued active last week, but failed to show the pronounced percentage increases over a year ago that marked August, due in part to the fact that in September last year several large establishments put on large promotions not being staged this year.

MEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 13 -- Plans for the establishing of a study-habit "clinic" in connection with the Tufts College educational guidance center during the coming school year were announced today by Dr. Nils T. Wessell, dean of men in the School of Liberal Arts.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 13 -- A volunteer truckman for the British War Relief Society was under arrest today, charged by the Englewood police with rifling scores of packages placed in his care and selling the contents to secondhand clothing merchants in New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Senators tied the ball game in the ninth inning then went on to defeat Cleveland, 6 to 5, in the eleventh today to gain an even break in a four-game series with the Indians.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Sept. 13 (Router) -- News reached here today that Jonkheer Hugo Loudon died on Sept. 6 in the occupied Netherlands. His age was 81.

The Autumn season of outdoor sports will be off to an auspicious start for members of society on Thursday when Belmont Park on Long Island will open for the annual Fall race meeting held under the auspices of the Westchester Racing Association; of which Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt is president.

Publication last week of the agreement covering England's use of materials shipped her under the lease-lend act was considered by exporters yesterday to have removed threats of further friction between English and American business interests over competition in this market and abroad.

THE Theatre Guild expects the script of the new Philip Barry play this week. It was not written especially for Katharine Hepburn, Mr. Barry emphasized to the Guild, but if she wants to play in it the Guild will offer its blessing.

Dr. Samuel W. Patterson, Associate Professor of Education at Hunter College since 1930, will serve as acting director of the Evening and Extension Division during Director Broderick Cohen's sabbatical leave, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON. THE latest problem on the mechanical side of book production arises from a shortage of binding materials, which it is feared may soon become even more serious than the shortage of paper.

Several large leases consummated in the city last week emphasized the important part which expansion of government agencies for defense purposes is playing in reducing the amount of surplus office space here.

Some home owners design their gardens for the enjoyment of the public, but the majority think of their places as quiet retreats where they may putter to their heart's content and visit informally with friends. ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Twenty-six-year-old Lloyd Mangrum, youngest member of the Monterey Beach (Calif.) golfing family, loomed as the man to beat today as the second round of the $5,000 Greater Atlantic City golf tournament ended.

PORTLAND, ORE. THE Fall run of Chinook salmon, king of the Pacific fisheries, is under way in the Columbia River. In a sense, this is the most important run since white men came to this coast, for on its success or failure may depend the future of Columbia River salmon fishing, a $10,000,000 industry.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 13 -- The possibility that the A.B.C. arrangement between Argentina, Brazil and Chile may be revised into a military alliance against foreign aggression is indicated by the conversations that the Argentine Minister of War, General Juan N. Tonazzi, had last month in Rio de Janeiro with Brazilian military chiefs, and the similar talks now under way in Santiago, Chile.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Nazi reports said tonight that planes had enveloped Leningrad's defenses in "a hurricane of fire" and hinted that huge new "pockets" of Soviet forces might be building up in the Kiev-Konotop-Kharkov triangle in a German advance toward the rich Don basin.

Thrusting along the rail in a terrific final drive at Aqueduct, the Foxcatcher Farm's Fairy Chant yesterday won the $19,700 Beldame Handicap, which the chestnut daughter of Chance Shot also had taken last year. The track was fast and conditions ideal as 23,701 persons watched jockey Irving Anderson find his way between the rail and the field to lance through the hole beyond which victory beckoned.

Some of the metropolitan district players who received a share of the spotlight during the women's national golf championship at Brookline, Mass., will be rivals in an intersectional team match to be Staged two weeks from tomorrow.

In the New York area there are thousands and throughout the country probably hundreds of thousands of landlubbers who are making friends with yachtsmen because of their new excitement about navigation and small-boat handling. WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A partial report of new laws affecting higher education enacted by the State Legislatures of 1941 reveals several changes and innovations, some of which may prove to be of major significance.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 13 -- As a step toward stimulating scientific exchange among nations of the Western Hemisphere, the University of California has sent by air to Lima, Peru, small shipments of radium-like phosphorus produced in the institution's atom-smashing cyclotron.

CARMEL, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Russell Stewart, the Albany lad with a long string of successes in a short career, added to his laurels today when he won the jumper championship in the fourth annual horse show of the Gypsy Trail Club.

THE Long Island Bridge League's masters' pair tournament will be played in two sessions on Wednesday nights, Sept. 17 and 24. Play will take place in the Plaza Hotel in Brooklyn.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined further during the week ended Sept. 6. It dropped to 129.3 from 130.5 for the week ended Aug. 30 and 130.8 for the week ended Aug. 23. It stood at 108.6 for the week ended Sept. 7, 1940.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- Plans for the semicentennial of the Drexel Institute of Technology have been completed, and the celebration will open formally on Oct. 24 under the chairmanship of Dr. L.D. Stratton, dean of men, according to an announcement made today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the recent debates in Congress over the extension of the draft act the question of Canada's war effort became a matter of acrimonious discussion in which Canada was charged with forbidding conscription for overseas service, while United States citizens had to face such a possibility.

The appalling conditions under which some 3,000,000 Polish Jews must struggle to live in 300 ghettos throughout Nazi-dominated Poland are revealed by authoritative statistics received in the United States and made public here yesterday by Dr. Henry Szoszkies.

SLOVAKIA has issued a three-stamp series which Czech officials in New York interpret as an expression of unrest under German rule and which they expect will have a short life postally. The stamps, 50-haleru olive, 1-koruna blue and 2k black-brown, are inscribed "Memorandum Slovenskeho Naroda" (Memorandum of the Slovak Nation), and each bears portraits of Stefan M. Daxner (1823-1892) and Stefan Moyses (1797-1869) between the letter "M" (for Memorandum), and the dates 1861-1941.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 14 -- The story of a continuous attack on a convoy bound for Britain was told today in official statements. The combined efforts of German submarines and airplanes caused the loss of eight ships. Three were sunk by torpedoes, four by bombs and the eighth damaged by attack, later foundered in a gale.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 12:

The College Art Association of America plans to begin publishing next month a new art periodical, to be known as The College Art Journal. This is to be devoted primarily to problems of teaching, in contrast to the association's present periodical, The Art Bulletin, which will continue the publication of scholarly studies in the history of art.

REGISTRATION for Fall courses at the Manhattan School of Music begins tomorrow. Principal members of the faculty include Janet D. Schenck, director, who heads the piano department; Hugo Kortschak, head of the string department, who will give a course in conducting; Hugh Ross, who directs the chorus and heads the voice department, and Vittorio Giannini, who teaches composition, scoring and arranging.

Opening the season for New York city's clubwomen, a defense ball will be given on Wednesday evening at the Hotel Astor, with representatives of more than two hundred clubs attending. The dance will open the administration of Mrs. Guy Percy Trulock, president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, and its proceeds will be used to start a fund to purchase civilian defense equipment for the Second Corps Area.

WHITE HORSE, Pa., Sept. 13 -- The 25th annual Bryn Mawr Hound Show was held today at the Radnor Hunt Club, a new site for this event. More than 400 hounds of eight breeds were entered, with the foxhounds and beagles having the largest entries.

IN the Autumn of 1939, Leland Stowe -- or Lee as his intimates call him -- was 39 years old. He had spent eighteen years of his life as a reporter, most of them in Europe, many of them as head of the Paris bureau of a big New York newspaper.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Whether or not the United States sends an armed force to Europe's battlegrounds, at least one type of American uniform will see action on foreign soil through the efforts of the South Orange Chapter of Bundles for Britain.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Food rationing in Britain will be relaxed during the coming Winter months if German raids become as intense as they were last year, Lord Woolton, Food Minister, said today, speaking in Watford, Hertfordshire.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The curtailment of silk supplies offers many possibilities in the way of using substitutes for silk in the ribbons traditionally used by the State Department on treaties, and in the regimental colors which are the pride of Army units, the Department of Commerce said today.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 13 -- Under terms of a decree affirmed today all property in the Netherlands of United States citizens and of residents in America, likewise of corporate bodies with domicile in the United States, must be declared before Oct. 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- Wilson Lindsley Gill, educator and engineer whose method of teaching civics in public schools was widely adopted, died here yesterday in the Women's Homeopathic Hospital on his ninetieth birthday. He resided in Mount Airy.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Atlantic Hanover, a brown gelding owned by the Hanover Shoe Farms of Hanover, Pa., and driven by Henry Thomas, won the opening heat of the $750-free-for-all pace in 2:03 1/4, fastest mile of the Grand Circuit meeting here, and then went on to capture the other heats in convincing fashion today at the Kentucky State Fair.

Members of the fourth class of Naval Reserve midshipmen to be graduated from the Midshipmen Training School aboard the U.S.S. Prairie State at 136th Street and the Hudson River will receive ensigns' commissions at a graduation ceremony Tuesday morning.

ON her way to where she is now, which is the program called "College Humor," heard Tuesday evenings over WEAF, Miss Mary Ann Mercer has had sundry vocal adventures indicating that if you start young enough and are bright enough you may possibly get somewhere.

News of the imposition of import restrictions by the Union of South Africa, effective at midnight tonight, after which no goods not already in transit from non-sterling countries will be allowed to enter that country without a permit from the government, was received in New York City yesterday. South Africa is the last of the British dominions to adopt such a measure.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- H.G. Wells, who was elected international president of the P.E.N. organization at the closing session of the seventeenth congress today, promptly declined the honor on the ground that no Briton should hold that office lest it become a British monopoly.

Urgent need for skilled laborers at the United States naval base under construction at Bermuda forced two contracting concerns to book all available space on three Pan American Airways transatlantic Clippers to carry workmen to Bermuda, it was learned yesterday at La Guardia Field.

Two days of this week-end are needed by the Englewood Basin Y.C. to bring its season to an adequate close with a grand and gala finale of events. This morning a ball game is to be played between the North and South, meaning those skippers who moor their cruisers north and south of the basin's entrance to the Hudson.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Indicating a trend in American education, a new curriculum in "American Culture and Institutions" will be offered by the University of California at Los Angeles when classes begin Monday, according to President Robert Gordon Sproul.
Criticism of Charles A. Lindbergh for his Des Moines speech, attacking the British, Jews and adherents of President Roosevelt, was sharp here yesterday.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 13 -- A grand Scottish terrier added to his brilliant record today when Champion Relgalf Ribbon Raider received the best-in-show title in the final event of the thirteenth annual all-breed exhibition of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club on the fair grounds.

AMERICA'S radio industry is in the midst of an all-time high. In 1940 more than 11,800,000 sets were sold, but this year the total is expected to top 12,000,000. In the whole history of radio receiver production, figures have never been greater than now -- a 20 to 30 per cent gain over last year's peak.

Upward of 100,000 retail merchants in cities and towns throughout the country will participate in "Retailers for Defense Week," which begins tomorrow and represents the fourth annual National Retail Demonstration. Launched as a nation-wide effort to bring retailing into closer cooperation with the consuming public, the demonstration this year will feature the role of distribution in offering both direct and indirect assistance to the national defense program.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 13 -- Mexican banking circles, consulted today, expressed optimism about a loan from the United States. One banker said that arrangements for it were 99 per cent completed. Starting with a motion picture in color showing scenes and activities at the New York Botanical Garden throughout the year, a series of free Saturday afternoon lectures will be presented in the Museum Building beginning Sept. 20 at 3 P.M.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 13 -- If German departments want to survive in American colleges they must look about for new ways by which they can be of special service to the arts and sciences in the curriculum, according to Dr. Emil L. Jordan, head of the German department at New Jersey College for Women.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The following Foreign Service changes since Sept. 6 were announced by the State Department today: The assignment of Carol H. Foster of Annapolis, Md., as Consul General at Johannesburg, Union of South Africa, has been canceled and he has been assigned for duty in the Department of State.

Single, twin and multi-engine aircraft will roar over Newark Airport this afternoon as part of the largest air carnival ever held in the Middle Atlantic States area, according to final plans announced yesterday by the Newark Air Show.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Senate subcommittee investigating alleged dissemination of war propaganda in films subpoenaed Charles Chaplin today for testimony Oct. 6 on his picture, "The Great Dictator."

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 13 -- Looking ahead to a year when the comprehension of world events will challenge the newspaper reader, Mount Holyoke College has announced an expanded series of public assemblies scheduled every Thursday evening and open to the community as well as the college.
