The robbery of his bank in Ox Bow hit old Tom Arnold pretty hard. So he decided to give up his great Cross T Ranch for the benefit of the depositors and take his 4,000 head of cattle north for a new start. He got a contract for 3,000 head of beef for the reservation Indians to be delivered at Ogallala and planned to take his own stuff on to Wyoming.

PRETORIA -- The Postmaster General of the Union of South Africa has begun release of a series of stamps "depicting typical illustrations of South Africa's war effort." The first value, an oblong 3-pence blue, appeared on Aug. 1, and the others, "to be issued at regular intervals," are: Half-penny, the Infantry; 1p, Nursing Services; 1 1/2 P, Air Force; 2p, Seaward Defense; 4p, Artillery; 6p, War Production; 1-shilling, Merchandise Units.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Two contests for public office nominations and thirty-eight contests for election to county political committees will confront the enrolled voters of Westchester County in Tuesday's primary election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- To help the marketing of Southern tobacco and Maine potato crops, the OPM Civilian Supply Division and the Federal Petroleum Coordinator arranged today to increase September gasoline supplies by 10 per cent in some areas of Maine, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia.

The reading public soon may have to pay slightly higher prices for books. As the Fall books come from the presses and hundreds of new titles reach bookstore shelves and counters there is evidence that scattered increases already are in effect.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- British trade circles regard the British Government's publication of the memorandum on the handling of lease-lend materials as a political rather than a commercial move. Anti-British allegations in this respect, though believed to have been largely deliberate, required prompt refutation.

ART books published since the last semi-annual round-up in January nave not accumulated in any embarrassing abundance. But today I should like glancingly to refer to our current shelf. As in past surveys, the list here submitted isn't inclusive, embracing, as it does, only those books on art that have come to the writer's attention.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 13 -- The College of William and Mary will institute a new system of counseling for students as one of the features of its 249th session, whicn commences Monday. The step, follows a six-month study of counseling needs by a faculty committee.

The question whether "Inflation" can be headed off by such means as increased taxation, larger sales of defense savings bonds, a system of price controls and priorities on basic materials, or whether stricter controls of bank credit must be brought into play, is now squarely before the financial community.

The United States Office of Education has received a request from the President which it considers extremely important. It is a request for the development and operation of a nation-wide program of public discussion. It is urged that the program be put into effect by the Office of Education with the cooperation of colleges and public school systems.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- The attacks on President Roosevelt's speech in the Italian press gained in intensity and violence today, with Virginio Gayda going so far as to say that the new policy was a de facto declaration of war. For Giovanni Ansaldo, who had his first chance to comment this morning, there was no appropriate answer but "naked force."

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 -- A large-scale process of reclassification and retirement of the Army's officer personnel, which, may affect many thousand Regulars, National Guardsmen and Reserves, is now starting.

IN that more deeply integrated American culture which Emerson first foreshadowed in "The American Scholar" and which we may some day fully realize, two races other than the white will have played a contributing part.

Yesterday, the 127th anniversary of the writing of the national anthem by Francis Scott Key, was "Star-Spangled Banner Day," by proclamation of Mayor La Guardia as Civilian Defense Director. In commemoration, 5,000 persons, including several city officials and representatives of patriotic organizations, gathered at Central Park Mall for a community sing, led by Lucy Monroe, soprano, and accompanied by the band of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.G.

The increasing availability of jobs in defense industries had little effect on the total number of applications for admission to Cooper Union this year, it was announced yesterday. Only in the Night School of Engineering, where six-year courses are given for men already in industry, was the number of applicants found to be lower than during a normal year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The additional naval activity announced by President Roosevelt in his speech Thursday night posed the question, in view of the discussion of a gasoline "shortage" on the East coast, whether the Atlantic fleet has sufficient petroleum supplies on the Atlantic Seaboard to combat the Nazi "rattlesnakes," as the U-boats were termed by the President.

To the Screen Editor: State censorship is an onerous task and it is quite within the bounds of experience that an officially appointed censorship body should commit a grave error of judgment. But the commission of the error is as nothing compared with a stubborn refusal to realize that a mistake has been made.

Experienced planters, in creating their garden pictures, put much dependence on shrubs, not only for a display of bloom but also as backgrounds. Beginners in the art, following the lead, often complain about the paucity of color among shrubs after the flush of the Spring season passes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 13 -- The Philadelphia Eagles winged forth tonight with a new owner, a new coach and a new team. But they looked like the old Eagles to the New York football Giants who hit them with both barrels for a smashing 24-0 victory, the largest margin between the two clubs in eight years.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 13 -- At the Devon Yacht Club tonight a harvest dance closed the season of dinner dances. The club closes tomorrow. Commodore Harry L. Jefferys and Mrs. Jefferys gave a dinner. Vice Commodore Dickson B. Potter and Mrs. Potter, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rice, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Scheerer, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Connick, Mr. and Mrs. Jorge Zalles and Mr. and Mrs. N.A. Campbell were among others with guests.

HOLLINS, Va., Sept. 13 -- Entering upon the one hundredth, year its history, Hollins College will open the current session next Friday with a capacity enrollment of 330 students from thirty-two States and several foreign countries.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Reading courses, to be offered to normal and better-than-average readers as well as to those who are found to be below normal, will be given for the first time at Stevens Institute of Technology this year.

LAKELAND, Fla. RISING sixty feet out of a sixty-two-acre citrus grove on a slope overlooking Lake Hollingsworth, in Lakeland, is a building unlike any other structure in the world. The grove is the campus of Florida Southern College and the building is a chapel designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, upon whom the King George medal for architecture recently was conferred.

Frank Graham Thomson of Brookmeade Farm, Devon, Pa., Philadelphia financier and philanthropist, died here yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital, Ninth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, of pneumonia following an injury he sustained three weeks ago from a fall.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 -- Many Argentines were most unpleasantly surprised when they saw recently in a newsreel the launching in Rio de Janeiro of a destroyer built in Brazilian yards by Brazilian labor. They were driven to the unhappy reflection that Argentina was in no position to match such an achievement, for she possesses neither the industrial equipment, the skilled craftsmen nor the necessary materials to produce anything so ambitious as a warship.

With the passage last Tuesday by the delegates to the American Kennel Club of the amendment to the rules applying to field trials the way was cleared for the formation of an organization for the purpose of holding a national open all-age retriever stake.

During the convention sessions of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Detroit an important meeting of the Institute of Real Estate Management will be held Nov. 6 and 7, announces J. William Markeim, president of the institute.

Completing its third week of operation here, the Army Exchange Service buying office for 2,500 post exchange units operating in Army camps through the nation already has listed more than a thousand items of several score manufacturers and contracted for more than $500,000 worth of cigarettes, candy, soft drinks and other products retailed to soldiers through their camp stores.

Stocks were firm and closed irregularly higher after a dull session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Sales were 230,060 shares and covered 495 issues, of which 173 rose, 140 fell and 182 were unchanged.

What to plant for satisfactory bloom in the small garden after the iris season closes is a bit of a puzzler to most growers. Some have used gladioli, but this entails the planting of corms in late Spring, digging them up in the Fall and storing them in the cellar over the Winter.

When the 1,000,000 boys and girls returned to the New York City public schools last week they found, among other things, a completely new course in mathematics, designed to make the subject more meaningful and less distasteful to the average student.

AN invisible net has been flung across the skies of North America as the newest weapon in the defense of our national security. Through its fine meshes are filtered thousands of radio messages and programs daily -- all the radio communications of whatever kind that flash into our ether from any part of the world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Soy beans continue to dominate the action of the markets on the Board of Trade, and price fluctuations were erratic. Beans were under pressure from the start and at one time showed a decline of about 4 1/2 cents a bushel from Friday's finish, with the May selling at 14 cents under the recent high point before sufficient short-covering and reinstating of sold-out lines developed to bring about a sustained rally.

RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Miss Marion Dryden Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newcombe Chandler Baker of this community, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at the Rumson Country Club. The debutante attended the Westover School, Middlebury, Conn., and Miss Hewitt's Classes in New York.

Dr. Henry J. Masson, director of the evening division of the College of Engineering at New York University, described yesterday in an-interview how the cultural activities of the students are being broadened, and the role of the college in aiding students to advance in the position in which they are employed.

Mayor La Guardia will open the Civilian and National Defense Exposition at Grand Central Palace at noon next Saturday. Designed to show the public the latest military, industrial and commercial activity in the defense program, the exposition will be open daily from 10:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. for thirty days, closing Oct. 18.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Creation of a Civilian Defense Volunteer Division was announced today by Mayor La Guardia, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13 -- The Harvard Graduate School of Education will inaugurate this Fall a new degree program of studies in elementary school administration, Dean Francis T. Spaulding announced today. The new program will be under the supervision of Dr. William H. Burton, director of apprenticeship and lecturer on the principles of teaching.
With the soil thoroughly moistened by recent rains, and cooler weather ahead, conditions are ideal for the planting of the broadleaved evergreens, such as rhododendrons and azaleas.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 -- A patriotic note is always added to the speed-boat regatta programs at the Maryland Yacht Club, because it was only a few cable lengths to the eastward that Francis Scott Key wrote what has become the country's national anthem.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Charles Whitehead of Plainfield and Lloyd G. Beatty, winners last year, and the team of Karl Kellerman of Rock Spring and Sam Cowen, club champion, tied for the lead at the end of the first eighteen holes in the annual Glen Ridge Club member-guest invitation golf tournament today.

THIS new "companion" is a reference book whose purpose is considerably broader than that of a mere encyclopedia of literary titles and names. Its author has worked from the realization that, as he puts it, "the understanding of works of literature depends upon the informed knowledge of the entire social atmosphere of their time and place."

Two stately mansions on Fifth Avenue soon will go into the hands of wreckers to make way for an apartment building representing an investment of about $5,000,000, it was learned yesterday, when the town houses of the late Edward H. Harriman and Adolph E. Lewisohn and adjoining realty, at Sixtyninth Street, were purchased by builders.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Five officers of the Norwegian merchant marine who outwitted the Vichy French authorities at Dakar, French West Africa, and escaped after fourteen months of internment have arrived in London. The men belonged to two vessels taken over by the authorities at Dakar after the fall of France.

The hospitality offered by America to English children may prove in time to be one of the most important factors in the future relationship of the two nations, but in the meantime it offers a theme to writers on which many variations may be played.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Treasury took another important step today to tie the hands of Axis interests seeking to capitalize in this country on the sale of securities looted from Nazi-invaded countries.
THE conductor's pot has begun to boil, with effects which presage important changes in the concert and operatic life of the city.

In his annual certification to the City Planning Commission, made public yesterday, Mayor La Guardia instructed that body to allow no more than $1 for new projects in its capital outlay budget for 1942. Thus the Mayor followed the example set by himself in his message to the commission with regard to the 1941 budget.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Two new champions were crowned today in the national outboard motorboat championships on Lake Austin -- Dick McFayden of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Jack Henckels of Fort Worth.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 -- A low-flying line drive in the eighth inning that missed Johnny Rucker's desperate bid for a shoestring catch and rolled for a double brought defeat to Hugh East, rookie right-hander, and to the Giants in their farewell appearance of the campaign against the champion Reds at Crosley Field today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Prices of livestock steadied today after a week of irregular movements, due largely to government purchases of pork and lard, lagging wholesale demand for meats and a sharp increase in supplies.

Possibilities that the international situation may become more tense over the week-end forced potential buyers of cotton futures to adopt a correspondingly cautious attitude yesterday. The brisk demand which carried a run-up of the prices of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to their best levels of the day early in the two-hour session evaporated quickly, and the market receded to register net losses of 1 to 6 points at the close.

VICHY, France, Sept. 13 -- A notice published in the Paris press today, signed by General Heinrich von Stuelpnagel, the German military commander for France, recalls that the possession of firearms or explosives is punishable by death and warns that those found with them can henceforth expect the death sentence.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 13 -- Although Lafayette College is preparing to open its 110th academic year by carrying on the normal work of the college uninterruptedly and calmly, national defense is to play a leading role in the program during the year.

WITH THE SECOND ARMY IN LOUISIANA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A race for the Red River was expected to start the Second Army's deployment against the Third Army when the nation's greatest war games start at midnight tomorrow.

PROPHET: In Atlantic City last week a 50-year-old scientist seated in a wheel chair gave a lecture before the annual Autumn meeting of the Ameri- can Chemical Society. He was Dr. Thomas Midgley Jr., who since last September has been suffering from infantile paralysis but has kept up chemical experiments.

Many exceptions can doubtless be cited to the thesis set forth before the American Psychological Association by Dr. Harvey C. Lehman, that the greatest philosophers of the last 500 years "most often experienced their deepest insights at not later than ages 35 to 39 inclusive."

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 13 -- On the theory that the next Presidential election in the United States will be a wide-open affair -- especially where the Democratic party is concerned -- political experts have already begun to scan the horizon for "Presidential timber."

Activity continued at a steady pace in the wholesale market last week and price changes and delivery delays remained the major problems, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Four Latin-American countries were moving rapidly tonight to smash Nazi influence within their borders.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- The German High Command now claims that U-boats have sunk twenty-eight merchantmen out of a single British convoy of forty vessels in the North Atlantic, which prompted an authorized naval spokesman here to hint that German submarines are applying a new method of attack in the Atlantic.

While we cannot afford to be complacent about the progress of our defense program, there are grounds for real satisfaction in the evidence that this production is at last on the march. It cannot be measured by appropriations, but it can to some extent be measured by the actual amount of cash currently paid out by the Government.

A five-point program for providing job security for workers in automobile and automotive equipment industries, transferred temporarily to defense production, has been worked out at a series of conferences between the OPM's labor supplies division and management and union leaders in the fields concerned, and OPM will issue a definite order covering these points within the next two weeks, it was learned here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Dick Fowler, 20-year-old rookie right-hander, pitched the Athletics to a 3-1 victory over the White Sox today in his major league debut.

A HISTORY of the American lumber industry which contains only one mention of Paul Bunyan is something of an achievement, but Mr. Holbrook's ordered and clear account is so full of facts and data that one scarcely misses that roisterer, for here is the background which produced him, and here are the men who spun his legends out of their own feats -- a true saga which kindles the imagination as much as the myth.

Pointing out that uncertainty over deliveries of materials and over priority ratings which may be given to home construction has delayed work on new housing even in vital defense areas, builders throughout the nation are urging that Federal agencies handling this branch of the emergency program take "definite action" as soon as possible to set up regulations in this field and the machinery to administer them.

BEFORE the Civil Aeronautics Authority launched its civilian pilot-training program and the war in Europe got going under a full head of steam, there were about 20,000 private and commercial airplane pilots in the United States.

The British War Relief Society's downtown committee is arranging a benefit party entitled the "Downtown Hop," to be held on the night of Sept. 26 in the ballroom of the Hotel Astor. The guests of honor for the occasion will include Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister at Washington, and Lady Campbell, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas S. Cole, Sardar and Sardani Hardit Singh Malik and Mr. and Mrs. Emil F. Horn.

Formation of a committee of lawyers to support Mayor La Guardia for renomination was announced yesterday by William M. Chadbourne, chairman of the Republican Primary Committee for the Renomination of La Guardia, McGoldrick and Morris.

Use of tests and personal history ratings in the selection of salesmen is rapidly growing in favor, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by the American Management Association, 330 West Forty-second Street. Half of the reporting companies said the tests had been successful in reducing turnover, and more than half said they had contributed to higher volume per salesman.

NASH MOTORS division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation last week presented fifteen new 1942 models in three series of five models each, including the low-priced Ambassador "600," the medium-priced Ambassador Six and the Ambassador Eight.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 13 -- Diminutive Paul Runyan, whose comparative lack of distance off the tees makes it imperative that he work overtime with his irons and putter, turned in two magnificent rounds and, together with his youthful partner, Jack Dreyfus Jr., progressed to the final in the first annual Metropolitan Golf Association amateur-professional four-ball championship at Lakeville today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Newark Bears gained the final round of the International League Governors Cup play-offs by eliminating the fourth place Rochester Red Wings tonight.

This book should be good for hours of leisure for busy mothers after the first reading if they themselves can keep their hands off it. Less a story than a recreation, it tells of Mr. Luke, pop-eyed, bewhiskered keeper of a zoo, whose charges, Trunko, the elephant, Spotty, the leopard, and six other brightly colored beasts are duly introduced to us as being safely behind bars.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- In a move to improve student morale at Cornell University, a coordinated program of guidance and counseling, including emphasis on health and recreation, will be put in operation for the first time at the seventy-fourth opening of the university on Sept. 22.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The farmers of the United States have been called upon to undertake an all-out wartime production program that will grow more food in 1942 than was ever raised in a single year upon the farms of this country.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, director of the seminar in South, America sponsored by editors of The Sign, national Catholic magazine published by the Passionist Fathers, Union City, N.J., the first Catholic seminar established in South America, has recommended expansion of the magazine's cultural program for next Summer, it was announced yesterday.

THE long magnetic storm which swooped down across the European short-wave paths recently blanketed most of the German and English broadcasts to the United States for three successive evenings, so that the South American stations which usually double in volume during such storms provided the clearest entertainment.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 13 -- A powerful, new, natural substance in the living tissues of plants and animals, which acts as a general distributing agent of the vital materials that go into the making of living matter and at the same time acts as a regulator to keep growth within normal bounds, was described here today before a symposium at the University of Wisconsin on the respiratory enzymes and the biological action of the vitamins.

To the Art Editor: I TOO should like to ask Mr. Kootz to come and look. I am a painter and I feel that I too have the answer to all his worries. I have had the same difficulty in spreading my new ideas about and in seeing the inside of a gallery.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Sept. 13 -- Two hard-hitting 2-year-olds, Mrs. Albert Sabath's Alsab and R. Sterling Clark's Colchis, raced to a dead heat today in the $10,000-added Eastern Shore Handicap.

Perched on the running board of a speeding automobile, a policeman chased a youthful automobile thief more than two miles through crowded Upper East Side avenues yesterday, finally cornering him at Seventy-eighth Street and York Avenue and hilling him with his pistol.

ANNOUNCEMENT has already been made of the forthcoming publication, in October, by Oxford University Press of "Laval," by Henry Torres. The original French version of this book is now available here under the imprint of Brentano's.

IN the year 1772 Henry William Stiegel made a last and princely gift to his town of Manheim in Pennsylvania. He had founded the town himself, naming it for his beloved Manheim in Germany, putting up his great new Glass House, whose products were to rival for texture and clarity the finest lead glass imported from Europe.

Without doubt, there is something of a revival of interest these days in the growing of small fruits in the home garden. Not only do they provide delicious dishes and desserts during their different seasons, but much material for canning and preserving for Winter -- a matter now being given more attention than it has received for a long time.

THE Fall cruise season is taking shape. Ship lines, furbishing up for busy days ahead, announce good bookings and plenty of diversion in port towns they touch. Spring is on the way in South America where flowers fill plazas and parks from October to December, to be followed by the season of crowded beach resorts and outdoor sports.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- After tying the score twice today, the Cubs defeated the Phillies, 5 to 4, in the eleventh inning when Rufus Melton walked Bill Nicholson with the bases full and nobody out.

Three ships loaded with important government cargoes for West Indies bases were strick-bound in New York yesterday, and other vessels were threatened when the Seafarers International Union took action to force the shipping industry's hand on war bonuses for unlicensed seamen.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 13 -- "Tell the American people how deeply grateful we are for the assistance. Tell them how we value their attitude, their courageous facing of the problem with us. Tell them we'll ultimately triumph."

With four teams already away from the barrier, three more will enter the National Football League race this week, when two games are scheduled. The Cleveland Rams and the Pittsburgh Steelers started operations a week ago and the New York Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles last night.

As a memorial to President Roosevelt's mother and in commemoration of its seventh anniversary, ceremonies were held yesterday afternoon at the Sara Delano Roosevelt Playground, Delancey and Rivington Streets, at which Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court declared that the improvements made in the Lower East Side are typical of the way in which Americans have become conscious of each other's welfare.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Nick Strincevich came through for the Pirates today, giving only four hits after he had replaced Dick Conger in the second to shut out the Braves, 1 -- 0.

Fleets of stubby little ships, almost unnoticeable in their gray, grim Navy war paint, are daily sweeping New York Harbor for mines as the Navy increases to full wartime intensity its ready vigilance against any threats by sea to the metropolis, it was learned here last week during a day's trip aboard one of the doughty vessels.

There is no other time during the entire year when conditions are so favorable for lawn making and restoration as they are in early Fall. The cool, moist weather that normally prevails at this period is particularly conducive to the growth of grass -- especially to root development.

STANLEY MORISON of London, the learned typographer and historiographer of calligraphy, is now an air warden. The other day, watching on the roof of a building during a raid, he saw a bomb drop some blocks away on the offices of the Monotoype Company, where all his reference books were stored, as well as the manuscript of the definitive history of calligraphy upon which he had been working for ten years.

Making "homes as safe as possible" is the main principle beingenforced by the Federal Works Administration in the construction and management of more than 90,000 dwelling units for families of enlisted and civilian personnel in the Army and Navy and of other workers in national defense industries.

IN 1908 Maggie Owen of Castle Rea, Ireland, was "a virgin 12 years of age," a wild, eager soul who answered, if she did not approve of it, to the name of Maggie Flibberty-Gobberty, and who complained that no one took her seriously through "there is great depth to me."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Military deferment for school teachers of vocational, physical and health education was proposed today by Dr. Francis J. Brown, consultant for the American Council of Education, to meet a short- age of instructors in those subjects.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- The C.I.O. United Mine Workers of America tonight ordered a six-State walkout of at least 40,000 coal miners employed in the so-called "captive" mines of the nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Reporting that Wendell L. Willkie has decided to take an active part in the off-year elections of 1942, associates of the 1940 Republican Presidential nominee said today that he would work and speak for those Republican candidates who have backed President Roosevelt's foreign policy.

Here is a series of 200 short practical chapters; each topic treated so briefly that it could be presented in a classroom or school assembly. Writing out of a long experience in dealing with thousands of boys in a large city high school, the author understands the problems which confront those who are starting in life and looking for jobs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The first contributions of the new Supply Priorities and Allocation Board to the progress of the defense program have been more psychological than physical, but their importance is not discounted here despite the universal feeling that it is only with more tanks, more airplanes, more ships and more of every other implement of war that the democracies shall ultimately be able to defeat the Axis powers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- What is said to be an improved and simplified converter which can be hooked up with present radio receivers so that they can be used to pick up FM (frequency modulation) radio programs is revealed in a patent (No. 2,255,668) granted to Winfield R. Koch of Haddonfield, N.J.

IN Joss Elvin Mr. Freeman has brought to life a character by no means rare in the English countryside but rare enough in fiction. Joss is a person who wants but little here below, but that little he must have. His one ambition is to have a place he could call his own, a place in which he could be his own master.

Russia Besieged Since men first went to war the stories of great sieges have filled chapters of legend and history. Homer tells how the Greeks besieged Troy for ten years. In 1429 Joan of Arc raised the seven-month British siege of Orleans and saved the throne of France.

CHUNGKING. JUST before the last war a little almond-eyed Chinese girl went up to Wellesley from Macon, Ga., where she had been attending high school. She was very young and she babbled like a running brook. When she was enrolled as a freshman at Wellesley she startled her new classmates by burbling in the softly slurred English of the Deep South, "I do not think I shall stay here very long."

The Puentes Grandes soccer team of Cuba is scheduled to make its last appearance at Starlight Park today. The Havana booters are slated to oppose Brookhaven in the feature contest of a double-header. The New York Americans and Brooklyn Hispano will meet in the first game at 1:30 P.M.

Spokesmen for unions representing officers employed in the deck departments of United States merchant ships disagree on reports that there is a shortage of such men available for service, a survey conducted here last week indicated.

STRIKE DEFERRED: President Roosevelt last week appointed a five-man fact-finding board to investigate the threatened strike of 1,250,000 employes of the Class I railroads of the country. His action, under the terms of the Railway Labor Act, postpones the strike for a period of sixty days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A special crew of workmen under the direction of David Lynn, architect of the Capitol, has recently been wrestling with the problem of removing one of the large paintings from the Capitol Building and replacing it with another.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- On the basis of President Roosevelt's Thursday night speech and the militant German reaction thereto, relations between the United States of America and the Third Reich have unquestionably reached their nadir. The tension between both countries has scarcely, since February, 1917, reached a point which boded so ominously for the future.

-- BUFFALO BILL The ranch that William Frederick Cody, better known as Buffalo Bill, homesteaded when he was 50 has been sold and his original cabin, long maintained as a museum, will be preserved by the new owner.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 13 -- High officials in the anthracite section of the United Mine Workers of America voted today to command rank-and-file members of District 7 to end their uprising against increased dues and assessments and return to work Monday, but a spokesman for the Insurrectionists said that the order would fall on deaf ears.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have been puzzled for some time over a method of reasoning which is brought to our attention again by L.W. Cronkhite in THE TIMES of Aug. 24. The general subject is the unjustifiability of Germany's discontent and resulting action since the last war.

THE second Chicago Festival of Ancient Music will be held Sundays, Oct. 5, 12 and 19, at the Goodman Theatre, Chicago, under the sponsorship and direction of Philip Manuel and Gavin Williamson, harpsichordists. Mr. Manuel and Mr. Williamson will head an ensemble comprising further Dorothy Lane, harpsichord; Leonard Sorkin and Oscar Chasow, violins; Milton Preves, viola, and Dudley Powers, 'cello.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Sept. 6 totaled 247,528,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 1,885,000 barrels in the week, comprising declines of 1,576,000 and 309,000 barrels, respectively, in domestic and foreign supplies.

Negotiations for a rapprochement between John L. Lewis and the left-wing forces in the C.I.O. have been started with a view to welding a united front of Lewis supporters and leftists at the national C.I.O. convention, tentatively scheduled to open in Detroit Nov. 17.

TWENTY years ago John Corey had graduated from the New England college where he is now Professor of English Literature. That Summer he had met Jessica Pindar, young bride of Nathaniel Pindar, the banker, crisp, baldish, fifteen years older.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 13 -- Competent observers here expressed the belief today that in the near future there would be increased activity by German raiders on the Pacific trade routes, especially the lanes touching Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, the Philippines, Hawaii and the American West Coast.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross will dedicate Friday a new headquarters for its blood-donor campaign at 139 East Thirty-sixth Street, where the drive to secure the New York City quota of the 200,000 blood units needed by the United States Army and Navy will be directed.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Eighty Nazis left on special trains for war-time internment in India and Siberia today, after twenty-four hours of delaying tactics by the German Legation had been ended by the threat of the Iranian police and army to "take measures" against the legation compound.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Last year's statistics are not necessarily an indication of this year's performances -- at least this is the hope of the N.Y.U. football team, now training here, for the Violet made a poor record in 1940 and is committed to nine games this year with opponents who were great last Fall by arithmetical comparison.

KIAMESHA, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Despite the number of talented sophomores on the City College football squad, a week and a half of practice has indicated that two veterans are to be the key men in Benny Friedman's 1941 varsity line-up.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Their spars bending under the breeze-filled weight of their big parachutes, which they carried off to leeward, three 12-meter racers swept to the finish line of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's regatta today, and most of those who saw them wondered whether the built-up sticks of spruce and glue would survive to the end.

A record enrollment of more than 800 students and the addition of five new courses to the curriculum will mark the third year of the existence of the Division of Public Service Training of City College, it was announced this week by Dr. Robert Jahrling, acting director.

Owing to a large increase in the volume of business as the result of national defense requirements, the chemical industry is likely to set a new high record for net profits this year, despite the sharp increases in Federal taxes. Earnings before taxes will be definitely higher than in any previous year.

Inventory for Defense The man who has been called the New Deal's favorite business executive is Donald M. Nelson, the portly, bespectacled vice president of Sears, Roebuck, who came to Washington seven years ago as assistant coordinator of an NRA code.

THE filling-station man tacks up the sign "Open 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. Only" and becomes suddenly, conspicuous. The public, after years of taking him for granted along with freedom street lighting and such-like blessings, is acutely aware of him at last.

ARTHUR D. DIVINE, the South African who writes under the pseudonym of David Rame, has, ever since his college days in Grahamstown, been both man of action and man of the pen. Before he set out, at the age of 22, to see the world and its people by working in almost every kind of seacraft he had won his spurs in South African journalism.

An effort to coordinate all women's club activities in relation to Chinese relief will take concrete form on Thursday, when club representatives meet at a tea in the home of Mrs. Maurice T. Moore, 1,000 Park Avenue. As chairman of the Greater New York Women's Division of the United China Relief, Mrs. Moore has formed a committee whose purpose is the linking together of diverse women's activities for her relief organization.

MARGARET LEECH spent five years writing "Reveille in Washington," the story of the capital during the Civil War. She said that one cheerful aspect of all this work was that she always could break up those conversations that start: "To fight Hitlerism we'll have to give up the very freedom that we're fighting for we'll have to form a totalitarian State as tough as his, so what's the use of fighting?

RECENT work mingled with some that has been seen before in most of the exhibitions that opened last week. At Macbeth's, oils and water-colors by artists associated with the gallery make up a sprightly early season show.
VICHY, France, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Paris radio reported today that "about 1,000" persons were arrested yesterday at La Rochelle in mass police raids on cafes and restaurants.

IN a very short time now New Yorkers will be playing their annual frantic game of musical chairs -- moving from one apartment to another almost identical. In the meantime the weary hunt is on and, on almost any residential street, you can see harassed people studying a real estate list and hopefully ringing doorbells.

A SERIES to be entitled "Mental Hospital," suggested by an attendant at an insane asylum, in which entertainment would be furnished by the inmates; a religious amateur hour, featuring amateur choristers, clergymen just out of the seminary, etc., and a series devoted to reading dogs' horoscopes, are a few suggested radio programs actually submitted to the networks each year by listeners.

Man's wear buyers arriving this week to cover 1942 Spring lines and, incidentally, to replenish Fall and Christmas stocks rapidly diminishing because of the defense boom, are finding prices on furnishings up 25 to 33 1-3 per cent above the last Spring season.

An appropriation of $1,250,000 from which first allocations of funds were made last week has given the impetus of governmental authority to meeting the recently stated need for 30,000 registered nurses in the defense program. During the week hospital schools of nursing have initiated courses to attract new recruits, for which this sum was mainly designated.

AT the outbreak of the Amercan Revolutionary War an anonymous two-volume novel was published in London with the title "Adventures of Alonso: Containing Some Striking Anecdotes of the present Prime Minister of Portugal."

BOSTON. BOSTON has a long list of new shows in prospect for the Autumn but none of them is likely to bear much resemblance to "Mr. Big," which romped into the Plymouth Theatre Monday after a brief preliminary engagement at Hartford.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 -- Pitching under the most terrific pressure he has had to bear all season, John Whitlow Wyatt made good when the chips were down by shutting out the fighting Cardinals with three hits as the pennant-bound Dodgers took the vital finale of the series today, 1 -- 0.

FOR the second time William Grant Still, composer, and Katherine Garrison Chapin, poet (in private life Mrs. Francis Biddle, wife of the new United States Attorney General), have collaborated on a strong and challenging American work.

DAVID SELZNICK'S celebrated search for Scarlett O'Hara probably will seem like a mere nothing by the time Paramount gets around to making up its mind about who's going to play who in the picturization of Ernest Hemingway's "For Whom the Bell Tolls."

ALTHOUGH the radio is alleged to be an impersonal medium whose addicts commune with art in the detachment afforded by distance, it isn't always so. The higher life, or existence among the kilocycles, need not be so lonely, if you care to stir about a bit and seek out a program at its source.

MR. MAUGHAM here tells of tragedy that is outside the range of his art and very nearly outside the range of his life. It is improbable that the full significance of the events with which he now deals can be realized for many years.
"FAYE'S FOLLY" has an interesting background in the rich black farmlands of Illinois during the last two

A MAN who refused to be a king enters philately's gallery on a Brazilian 400-reis stamp which commemorates an episode three centuries ago when Spain and Portugal and the Netherlands were struggling for possession of Brazil.

TRAVEL LINES: The Nassau Legislature will meet next week "to consider a proposal by the Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., for a New York-Miami-Nassau service of sixteen weeks between December and April with twenty-four trips between New York and Nassau."

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 13 -- Significant shifts in defense policy, largely as a result of creation of the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board, are rapidly shaping up and the result will very shortly be a much more smoothly operating transition from the effort at guns and butter economy to a wholly defense economy, in the view of trade association executives who completed their annual convention here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The capital is finally convinced that Franklin D. Roosevelt is in earnest. The so-called great debate has been shelved for the moment. The attempt to win the war without fighting it has been abandoned. The general feeling here this week-end is that for the eighth time in her history and the second time this century the United States of America is at war.

The inauguration of Dr. Rexford Guy Tugwell as Governor of Puerto Rico on Sept. 19 will be an event of unusual significance to American education. Within a month after arriving in the island to serve as the newly appointed chancellor of the University of Puerto Rico this former member of the original New Deal group was nominated by the President and confirmed by Congress for this important post.
CLINTON, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- With an enrollment of 450, the limit fixed by its board of trustees, and with every dormitory room filled, Hamilton College will open Thursday for its 130th academic year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Group hospital plans are approved by the Federal Office of Defense, Health ano Welfare Services, which said today that participation of employers and employes in such pre-payment plans would protect the health and productive capacity of the nation "as well as conserve American resources for defense activities."

The publication by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service of Daniel Merriman's fine report on the striped bass of the Atlantic Coast gives sportsmen, and conservation groups a longer lever with which to pry increased protection measures for this fish in the various coastal States.

LONDON -- The watchful British Government that seems to know all the tricks has crabbed the motorist in practicing almost the last of his beloved wartime "wangles." Officially, a wangle is a "skillful intrigue."

Science made this world of telephones, radio, railways, automobiles, electric lights, synthetics, mass production. In every civilized country it has changed the environment, on the whole for the better. Yet every advance has been accompanied by abuses. If we have rayon stockings we also have new and more deadly explosives.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 13 -- A War Department announcement said today that Brig. Gen. Edward C. Rose of Harmony Hall, Harbourton, near Trenton, will be relieved of duty as commander of the Sixty-ninth Field Artillery and as Forty-fourth Division artillery officer, effective next Wednesday.

IF Times Square "looks like the most wonderful Christmas tree we ever saw" to Bebe Daniels and Ben Lyon, call it the awestruck reaction of a couple of expatriates just back home after more than two years in a blacked-out and war-scarred London.

Bach: Italian Concerto in F. Artur Schnabel, piano. (Victor, two twelve-inch records, $2.50.) Mr. Schnabel, we understand, does not like to be labeled a Beethoven expert to the exclusion of other composers, and here-he shows, if proof be needed, that his field is wider than Beethoven.

THIS anthology, which has some excellent writing to recommend it, is edited in the belief that a "revival of poetry" as Mr. Williams puts it "is now on." Probably this means nothing more than that a great deal of poetry is being published, which is true.
ROME, Sept. 13 -- Wars are fought not only with airplanes and submarines, cannons and tanks. All those things in superabundance do not explain the developments of recent weeks.
AFTER long hours of reading Hermann Rauschning's latest book, with its mixture of autobiography, politics, sociology, economics and philosophy, there comes to mind the lament of Dr. Faust:
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 13 -- The long harness racing meet of the Old Country Trotting Association closed tonight with the usual eight events staged under the floodlights at Roosevelt Raceway.

"Handsome is as handsome does" may be all very well. Just the same, many a plain woman full of good works feels privately that she would have been happier had she been up front when the Good Fairy came around, and many pretty women think they will scream if they have to look at the same old face much longer.

Assistant United States Commissioner for Vocational Education Although vocational education is today occupied with the task of training nearly 4,000,000 persons for defense industries it is not too early to look beyond the current crisis.
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor in 1938, announced yesterday his support of Mayor La Guardia for renomination in the Republican primary election on Tuesday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 13 -- Listing a program of seventy-six classes, the thirty-ninth annual Piping Rock Horse Show to be held here on Oct. 2, 3 and 4 is expected to be one of the most notable show ring exhibitions in the long history of these Piping Rock events.

Two dining and dancing rendezvous which have been popular with members of society for several years -- the Persian Room of the Plaza and the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria -- will mark their formal openings for the Autumn and Winter season with benefit dinner-dances.

The work of bringing the manifold problems of defense before members of the General Federation of Women's Clubs will be set in motion this week, as outlines and other material prepared by fourteen recently created divisions are being made ready for the printer.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Seven championship awards tonight high-lighted the closing session of the annual two-day New Brunswick horse show as an enthusiastic throng jammed the grandstand, bleachers and ringside at Johnson Park.

Women's apparel and accessory markets hare continue in the throes of price adjustments that entail major price line changes, increases on many individual items, and the elimination from manufacturers' lines of styles which cannot be made to fit into specified brackets either because of higher production costs or price resistance on the part of buyers.

Small-home building under the FHA program reached a new peak in August with about 5,600 new homes started each week, Federal Housing Administrator Abner H. Ferguson announced yesterday. This compares with the previous high mark of 5,500 homes a week in July and with a weekly average of 3,800 homes started under FHA inspection during August, 1940.

Mayor La Guardia, as director of the Office of Civilian Defense, announced yesterday the appointment of Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, wife of the President, as an assistant director of civilian defense. The announcement was made in the city's office at La Guardia Field.

The proposed $80,000,000 pips line from Texas to New York and Philadelphia, details of which have been worked out by government and oil executives in the last four months, is expected to be abandoned. The only hope for the project now -- considered to be very slight in oil circles -- rests with President Roosevelt.

To the Art Editor: AMONG the interesting revelations of the Kootz controversy on the whereabouts of a vital American art is your observation that "artist after artist directs the searching eye not to the galleries but rather to the studios." Apparently these artists have not only lost confidence in the galleries of dealers but also those of museums.

THE Fall exhibition season, co inciding with the renewal of camera club lecture activities, has made an auspicious start. Two shows, both of which are well worth seeing, are now in town. A third will open late this week, and at least two others may be expected shortly.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Signs of moderation in Japanese policies multiplied today after a week in which Emperor Hirohito exerted his personal influence to curb army extremists and support Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye's Cabinet.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Sept. 14 -- Striking down from the northern side of the Smolensk-Bryansk road, at a point somewhere near Alesega, and in a northeasterly direction from the town of Poceps, on the Bryansk-Gomel road, Russian forces have launched a heavy offensive along a twenty-five-mile front and forced Nazi mechanized spearheads into retreat, according to a Moscow radio report broadcast early today.

Every American ought to realize that we are not, and could not be, brought closer to war with Nazi Germany by President Roosevelt's Thursday evening radio address. It is the war that has come closer to us, and the President so reported. Our Government has done, is doing, and under the new announcement of policy will continue to do, all that can be done to keep it at a distance.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 13 -- Carrying far heavier golfing armament than did her opponent and with, just as much grit and determination in her make-up, Mrs. Frank Newell, little 20-year-old Californian, today added her name to the list of those who have gained fame by winning the women's national championship.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 13 -- In a striking gesture of continental solidarity, Brazil will permit American banks of deposit to continue functioning. A decree soon will be issued that any bank duly incorporated and owned by citizens of any country of the Americas will be free to operate in Brazil, thus canceling a decree issued last April 9 calling on foreign banks of deposit either to nationalize or cease operations in July, 1946.

IN Professor Butler's introduction to this first good biography of an extraordinary poet we find the frank statement that "the subject of this study is still a mystery to me." This is not a silly or hypocritical remark.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- Seigo Nakano, president of the Fascist party -- Tohokai -- told a mass meeting in Hibiya Hall today that time was running short and that unless the United States and Britain accepted Japan's terms soon Japan and Germany would have to blast their way to Singapore and the Persian Gulf to establish contact with each other.

Plans for mutual war defense aid among the Fire Departments of New York City and Westchester and Nassau Counties have been almost completed, according to a statement just issued by Assistant Chief of Department John J. McCarthy, recently designated by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh to head fire defense activities in the city.

Quartermaster Corps' Robots In these days when large bodies of troops are shifted from one section of the country to another the Quartermaster General must know what supplies are available at dozens of destinations. He relies on "mechanical men" who will never smell powder or hear the bursting of shells.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 13 -- German armed forces today were reported resorting to drastic measures to crush anti-Nazi and guerrilla outbreaks in Norway, Hungary, Yugoslavia, the Netherlands and Rumania.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 13 -- Enthusiastic demonstrations for Britain and the British airmen brought down by the Germans during an attack on Oslo on Saturday, Sept. 6, was one of the causes that precipitated the introduction of a state of civilian emergency in Oslo, it was learned here today.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, is declared by Roberto Farinacci in this mornings Regime Fascista to have come to Rome to get Pope Pius's approval of the President's war plans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The President in his latest radio address greatly extended the traditional concept of "the freedom of the seas." The degree to which Hitler resists this new definition will determine the degree of belligerency which may arise between the United States and Germany, whether or not a formal declaration of a state of war shall ever follow.

Dr. John P. Conroy, who retired in 1931 as a district superintendent of schools after forty-nine years in the school system of the city, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 167 West Ninety-fourth Street. He was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Navy Department confirmed today the news of the death yesterday in Rio de Janeiro of Commander John James Patterson 3d. His wife, Mrs. Rhueybelle Alter Patterson, was with him. Two children, John James Patterson 4th and Gay Isabelle Patterson, also survive.

The difficulties inherent in international holdings in times of war have become apparent to officials and security holders of the Italian Superpower Corporation, organized in 1928 by Bonbright Co., Inc., Field, Glore Co. and the Banca Commerciale Italian Trust Company, New York.

VICHY, Prance, Sept. 14 -- Potatoes will supplement the insufficient supplies of meat and bread in France this Winter, Paul Gharbin, Secretary of State for Supplies, promised in a broadcast to the nation tonight.

Tonight's opening will be that of a farce by Frank Gabrielson and Irvin Pincus called "The More the Merrier." It is the story of a wealthy man with ambitions toward the Governorship of Colorado. The producers are Otto L. Preminger and Norman Pincus, brother of Irvin.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The general tendency continues upward and strong on the Stock Exchange amid an optimism which almost every one hopes will be justified by the course of events. However, there is another school of thought which holds that the current bullishness may be overdone.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Fairfield Osborn, who are spending a few days with Mr. and Mrs. Owen Johnson at Ingleside, Stockbridge, were the honor guests at a dinner given tonight by their hosts. Mrs. Osborn's mother, Mrs. Felix Lamond, who is staying at the Martin Inn, was among the guests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Federal Trade Commission in a complaint issued today charged the Linen Supply Board of Trade of New Jersey, its officers, directors and member companies, all operating in the Newark and New York area, with "combinations and conspiracies to fix uniform minimum prices and discounts and other practices in restraint of trade."

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 14 -- The fierce tribes of Southwestern Iran are rising in revolt against the present Teheran regime and, with increasing signs of insurgency within the Iranian Army, civil war is expected by many leading foreign observers and Iranians within two or three weeks unless the regime of Riza Shah Pahlevi is overthrown or deposed in the meantime.

Cotton prices continued to move into new high ground last week and reached the highest levels since 1929. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 38 to 47 points.

A group of leading liberals and trade union leaders issued an appeal yesterday to the 150,000 enrolled members of the American Labor party in New York City to vote in Tuesday's primary election for the right-wing slate of candidates for public office and to members of the party's county committees "to keep the party free of control and eventual disintegration at the hands of the Communists."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- The Giants failed to aid the Dodgers today in their stirring bid for the National League pennant. And they didn't do their own cause any good in the obscure battle for fifth place.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 14 -- The Packers opened their National Football League campaign today with a 23-to-0 victory over the Detroit Lions. Green Bay added two touchdowns in the last seven minutes to three field goals scored previously.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 14 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The government must clearly define its policies on wages, hours, the closed shop and profits and the economic implications of our defense effort must be clearly understood if the defense labor problem is to be solved, the Foreign Policy Association asserted today.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 14 -- The presence of an Axis commerce raider in the waters of the Pacific approaches to the Panama Canal has been known for two weeks by marine authorities and shipping circles here, it was revealed today by a reliable source. Vessels arriving from the Pacific nave reported picking up radio messages from other ships, advising that they were being attacked by the raider.

JUST the other day President E.G. Barrow of the Yankee ball club was looking up at a picture on his office wall. It was a picture of a world championship baseball team. But not a Yankee team. It was a picture of the Red Sox of 1918 who beat the Chicago Cubs in the world series of that year. Ed Barrow managed that Red Sox team.
Banks disposed of several properties in Brooklyn over the weekend to investors.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 -- The flow of orders to steel mills last week, as well as the avalanche of special forms PD-73 covering tonnage booked before Sept. 1, was rapidly approaching the status of a routine nature.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 14 -- The American Legion was asked by one of its standing committees today to request Congress to lift restrictions which prevent the rise of selective service men or former National Guardsmen outside the Western Hemisphere.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN ENGLAND, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Thousands of motorized British troops, participating in a mock battle of invasion, pushed the last remnants of numerically superior "German" forces into the sea today after a struggle that had raged in the counties of Devon and Cornwall for nearly a week.

Unless the barriers of race distinction can be broken down, "our democracy is doomed," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in his sermon in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The people of America, he said, have much to learn from the inhabitants of the Hawaiian Islands where, he said, "race differences are dissolving."

LONDON, Sept 14 -- The City received President Roosevelt's speech with greater satisfaction than any of his previous declarations. The financial markets expressed their opinion with a display of buoyancy not experienced in a long time.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 97.9 to 98.4. In the major raw materials index, which rose 1.4 per cent to a new high of 92.7, agricultural items such at cotton, eggs, fruits, grains, livestock, and potatoes continued to show the greatest price increases.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There seems to be a great deal of confusion of thought among many exporters and others regarding British efforts to win this war and regarding the British efforts to retain a few shreds of its pre-war export business.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Iran Government ordered police today to remove 400 Nazi males from the German Legation compound to barracks in Teheran for transfer to India and Russia, where they will be interned for the duration of the war.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 14 -- It isn't often that an 18-month-old youngster receives the highest award in an all-breed dog show, especially when he is untried and unknown, against specimens that have earned notable triumphs in stiff competitions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With regard to the letters from Leland de Langley and W.J. Postman concerning French opinion of Petain, it seems necessary to point out that French opinion is confused and divided. I was there throughout the war and long before the war, and have only just returned, and I can assure you that it is possible to find every sort of opinion except that which is pro-German.

L.C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., and subsidiaries had a net profit of $1,035,041 for the fiscal year ended on June 30, according to the annual report of the company released for publication today by H.W. Smith, president. Federal income and excess-profits taxes are allowed for in the net result, which was equal to $3.46 each on 276,237 shares of outstanding common stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The questioned ability of American railroads to handle smoothly the growing defense traffic will get its severest test so far next month when the period of peak carloadings for the year is expected to be reached.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- A complete wing of the Royal Air Force -- planes, pilots and ground maintenance crews-has arrived in Russia, the Air Ministry announced tonight. Presumably this force will go into action soon.

ROME, Sept. 14 -- The Axis will await further American moves and will not provoke the United States to war, Virginio Gayda writes today in an editorial that sums up the Italian reaction to President Roosevelt's speech. He says Washington was disappointed when the Axis reacted calmly.

The church was described by the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams as a "social laboratory in which we learn to live together," in his sermon yesterday morning at the Prospect Avenue Methodist Church, at Greenwood Avenue, Brooklyn.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- The story of how three men on a raft, victims of a submarine's torpedo in the chill waters off Iceland, buried three comrades at sea was told today by one of the survivors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Because the Finnish. Army in its war with Russia has nearly reached a line that it will be able to defend "it seems logical to us to stop the war with Russia," a spokesman at the legation of Finland said tonight.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- Meeting ferocious Soviet resistance along every yard of their advance, German troops advancing from the south-west are believed in Nazi quarters to be less than fifteen miles from the metropolitan boundaries of Leningrad.

One of the pleasures of life most often mentioned in connection with the Everything-I-Like-Is-Fattening school of thought is breakfast cereal. A bowl of crisp breakfast cereal is commonly considered as a solace and a comfort that is categorically denied to those unfortunate souls who are "watching their waistlines."

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Mike Phipps's Gulf Stream four galloped to the final round of the national polo championship today, turning back Stewart Iglehart's Westbury team, 7 -- 4, before 8,000 in the big stands of Meadow Brook's International Field.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Sept. 14 -- Advance detachments of New York's 102d Coast Artillery Anti-Aircraft Brigade, including elements from three regiments, will leave here at 5:30 o'clock tomorrow morning on a 300-mile convoy to North Carolina, scene of forthcoming Army manoeuvres.

Sept. 14. Memo for City Desk: Bill Cully, head keeper at the Bronx Zoo, called up this afternoon to say that Mandy, a female otter, had escaped from her cage sometime during the night and had taken refuge in the wild-fowl pond.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 15 -- The Russian High Command announced today the abandonment of Kremenchug, about ninety miles northwest of Dniepropetrovsk on the eastern bank of the Dnieper River. The Soviet withdrawal came after fierce fighting lasting many days, it was said.

VICHY, France, Sept. 14 -- Considerable results already have been obtained through the government's efforts to restore and reorganize the country's economy. The task is, however, far from being accomplished. One of the most urgent problems is that of the reconstruction of buildings destroyed during the recent military operations.

When 6,000 male students return to the main center of City College on Thursday they will find that the invasion of the fair sex that began two years ago will have doubled -- from six to twelve. There will now be 500 men to every girl.

Although Belgium lies helpless under the heel of the Nazi conqueror and King Leopold III is a prisoner of war in his Laeken Castle, refusing to take part in political affairs, Belgium continues, nevertheless, to play the part of an active belligerent in the war against Germany to an extent not appreciated by the anti-Nazi world.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- The British Admiralty today finally told the full story of the submarine Triumph twenty-one months after it returned through mine-infested waters to Britain with its bow blown partly off and a gaping hole in its hull.

While there was a slight let-up in activity in some lines during the past week, reorders continued to pour into other departments in the wholesale market. Dress purchases for early September have not come up to expectations, and action on coats and suits slowed somewhat.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Sept. 2 at 106.7, compared with 106.4 a fortnight before, 105.8 a month before, 98.4 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

The appointment of Ralph E. Samuel as chairman of the 1941 merged fund-raising campaign for 116 medical and social welfare agencies affiliated with the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities was announced yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of last year's joint drive.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 14 -- An official British report today said the Fleet Air Arm had virtually administered the eoup-de-grace Friday night and early yesterday to an Axis convoy that the R.A.F. and the Air Arm broke up in the Central Mediterranean en the previous night. At least three merchantmen were sunk or halted and the others were damaged.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- Robert Preston has been named for a leading role with Veronica Lake and Alan Ladd in Paramount's "This Gun for Hire," which Frank Tuttle will direst starting in three weeks. W.R. Burnett and Tuttle have prepared the scenario from a story by Grahame Green, owned by the studio since 1936.

Experts of the Office of Production Management are nearing completion of plans which are said to call for the expansion of the steel industry by 10,000,000 tons, and are to submit these plans this week to the new Supply Priorities and Allocation Board.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 14 -- The discovery that Vitamin C, essential for the prevention of scurvy and for the maintenance of healthy gums, teeth and capillaries, also plays a vital role in reproduction was announced today at the University of Wisconsin, following a three-day symposium on the respiratory enzymes.
PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 14 -- The Paterson Panthers defeated the Long Island Indians in the American Football Association opener at Hinchliffe Stadium today, 23 -- 0.

With a system of British "aircerts" like navicerts certifying non-contraband, Pan American Airways announced yesterday the first transatlantic air express service by clipper plane between New York and Lisbon, via Bermuda. Shipments will start Sept. 25 on regular schedules.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14 -- The biggest crowd ever to assemble in the history of Newark poured out today for the mammoth air show marking the official rededication of Newark Airport, now back in the running as a rival of New York's La Guardia Field.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 14 -- Lloyd Mangrum, the Monterey Beach, Calif., star, carried off the $5,000 Greater Atlantic City open golf tournament honors today. The former Texan posted a final round score of 72, which gave him a total of 275 and first-prize money of $1,200.

The complete rebuilding and modernization of "bedraggled" old Corlears Hook Park, which now forms a link in the East River Park that makes a continuous mile-and-a-half unit of parks fronting on the East River, is announced by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, in a pictorial report submitted yesterday to Mayor La Guardia.

TOKYO, Sept. 14 -- A further indication that conversations in Washington hold out hope for peace in the Pacific was seen here today in the announcement that Kaname Wakasugi would leave for the United States tomorrow afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- Racketeering and the question of itemized accounting of millions of dollars of income since 1911 will be among the major issues to be raised at the first convention in thirty years of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, which will open here tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Prices of corn and oats, while affected by altogether the same influences as wheat, are not dependent on export demand, and with most of the production consumed through domestic channels, these two markets are less likely to be affected by the closing of Continental Europe to the buying of this country's surplus grains.

With John R. Davies, former president of the National Republican Club, attempting to make President Roosevelt's foreign policy the issue in his contest with Mayor La Guardia for the Republican nomination for Mayor at the primary election tomorrow, supporters of the Mayor countered yesterday with assertions that the sole issues were continuance of good municipal government and prevention of the return of Tammany control.

Losing to Brookhattan by the score of 3 to 1, the Puentes Grandes football club of Havana made its final appearance at Starlight Park yesterday without having recorded a single victory against local clubs.

HEADQUARTERS, THIRD ARMY, LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 14 -- Weather, arbiter of military history, threatened tonight to influence the start of "the greatest field exercise the Army has ever staged, the biggest it probably ever will stage," as a tropical storm curved in toward the Gulf coast.

WOODMERE, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Fewer than one-twelfth of the 1,200 candidates for County Committeeman in the Democratic and Republican primaries in Nassau County have subscribed to the isolationist pledge demanded by the recently formed "Committee for the Restoration of Representative Government," which has headquarters in Mineola.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept, 14 -- Reports circulating in foreign diplomatic circles here tonight say that the Rumanian General Ciupercu had been executed upon orders of the Rumanian High Command.

The fifty-four children selected for the seven-year experimental program in the education of gifted children will start school "for real" today in the Hunter College Elementary School kindergarten. The group represents the upper 18 per cent of the 300 applicants for the new program, approved by the Board of Higher Education last Spring, and the ages range from 3 1/2 to 5 1/2 years.

The Tax Foundation, a non-profit organization that has offices at 30 Rockefeller Plaza and seeks to coordinate the work of taxpayer groups throughout the country, issued yesterday an eighty-page booklet called "Tax Facts and Figures," which is intended to be an annual publication.

THE unfortunate part-time lunatic who was England's King for a full sixty years was for part of those sixty years America's King as well. His Majesty George III, of course. It may seem as though nothing more could be said about this particular Royal George, but a unique and exceptionally interesting biography comes out this morning: "America's Last King,"* by Manfred S. Guttmacher, psychiatrist, neurologist and Chief Medical Officer of the Supreme Bench of Baltimore.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Patrick T. Fagan, district president of the United Mine Workers (C.I.O.), said tonight that about 38,000 soft-coal miners in six States would go on strike tomorrow at "captive" mines of seven steel corporations on the sole demand that the companies grant a union shop.

A proposal that the pay of Navy Yard draftsmen be increased 25 per cent has been submitted to Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox by the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, a C.I.O. affiliate, through its international president, Lewis Alan Berne, it was announced here yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- The Bulgarian currency is now virtually based on the Reichsmark, and the last discount at which the Reichsmark was formerly quoted in Serbia has been abolished. These two facts are cited by the influertial German Mining Gazette published at Duesseldorf as convincing evidence of the increased strength of the Reichsmark in Southeastern Europe.
ZAGREB, Croatia (Via Berlin), Sept. 14 -- Four time-bombs exploded in Zagreb's central telephone exchange today, injuring a German major and at least thirteen other persons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Revised regulations simplifying in some cases the requirements under which 350,000 employers keep records concerning more than 15,500,000 workers and in other cases calling for additional information were announced today by Brig. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, administrator of the Wages and Hours Division.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Yale University will begin its 241st year on Sept. 22 with the largest entering class in its history, about 980, or 125 more than last year's enrollment.

The strike called Saturday on three ships in New York loaded with important cargoes for United States bases in the West Indies was extended yesterday to two other vessels here, two in Mobile and two In New Orleans by the Seafarers International Union.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Events since the publication of my letter in your issue of Aug. 27 lead me again to address you. I do this in the prayerful hope that some heed in high places will be paid to a note of warning from one who in the last World War had intimately to do with that of which he now speaks.

If Christianity is to make an impression upon society in these confused days it becomes necessary for every Christian to practice the principles of his faith in every act of his daily life, the Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday in his sermon at the cathedral.

The flares of revolt blazing up at one point after another on the darkened horizon of Europe do not reveal anything new. That the iron lid clamped down on the Continent by the occupying armies cannot now be screwed down tight enough to prevent the watched pot from boiling over signifies a change in the balance, but not in the basic situation.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14 -- In a seesaw battle during which both teams fought the umpires with almost as much fervor as they fought each other, the Dodgers finally came through with a 7-5 triumph over the Reds today.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Sixteen hundred selective service men will be received by the Forty-fourth Division to replace in part the 2,000 soldiers who will be released from the service in the next few weeks, it was announced here today.

Thirty-two scholarships aggregating $71,200, including twenty honor grants to entering students at Columbia College and twelve Pulitzer free scholarships to outstanding graduates of New York City public high schools, have been announced by Frank H. Bowles, director of admissions at Columbia University.

UPPER DARBY, Pa., Sept. 13 (AP) -- To provide more milk under the defense program and offset foreign shipments, the Farm Security Administration announced today an increase of 100,000,000 pounds in 1942 milk quotas for eleven Northeastern States.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 14 -- Captain Fritz Wiedemann arrived at the Quilmes Airport near Buenos Aires this afternoon by a Condor airline plane from Rio de Janeiro and was welcomed by German Ambassador Baron Edmund von Thermann and Counselor of the German Embassy Erich Otto Neyen.
Eight new films will arrive at midtown theatres during the week. The openings follow:

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 14 -- Costa Rica will celebrate the 120th anniversary of independence from Spain tomorrow with a vast pro-democratic and anti-totalitarian demonstration here sponsored by the National Anti-Nazi Front composed of all organizations opposed to the Axis and its subordinates.

A unified religion, with 700,000,000 Christians scattered over the earth healing their divisive creeds and basing themselves on Christ's Golden Rule, could create a Christianity that would "transform the world from a bedlam and hell into the vestibule of heaven and happiness," the Rev. Dr. Henry R. Rose declared yesterday morning.

A world civilization built without consideration of God can lead only to failure, declared the Rev. Dr. Teunis E. Gouwens, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church of Louisville, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO. Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- General Robert E.
