Wood, national chairman of the America First Committee, announced tonight that an "independent group" of fiftyeight "prominent Americans" had united in a public condemnation of President Roosevelt's address last Thursday as a "grave threat to democratic principles of majority rule."

GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Thomas E. Dewey declared here today that Charles A. Lindbergh had been guilty of "an inexcusable abuse of the right of freedom of speech" in his address at an America First Committee rally at Des Moines on last Thursday.

Illustrating his sermon with the Gospel story of Christ's miraculous resurrection of the son of the widow, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at the 11 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral that Christ wished us to draw spiritual significance from His words and actions.

HAZLBTON, Pa., Sept. 14 -- A showdown on the strike which thousands of anthracite miners in this region have joined as a protest against increased union dues and assessments and the check-off. system, is scheduled for tomorrow morning, set as the deadline for the strikers to return to work.

With the consolidation of the powers of the airways traffic control division of the Civil Aeronautic Administration and the locally hired operators of airport control towers, the direction of private and commercial air traffic will be brought more directly under the supervision of the Federal Government, it was learned at La Guardia Field yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept 14 -- There was an evening of music at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Maxim Karolik tonight under the patronage of many members of the Summer colony. The artists were Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead, Boston pianist, who spent the week-end with Mr. and Mrs. Karolik, and Mrs. Edmund S.R. Brandt of this city, vocalist.
Incredible as it may have seemed to 38,851 onlookers, Cleveland's forlorn and downtrodden Indians still appear to have some fight left in them.
NEW YORK Henry Rogers Benjamin will give a supper-dance on Dec. 27 at his home, 2 East Eighty-seventh Street, to introduce his daughter, Miss Ann Rogers Benjamin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Congress, its individual minds, like those of most American citizens, preoccupied with the implications and possible results of President Roosevelt's order to the Navy to shoot first when it encounters Nazi or Italian war craft on the seas, will resume active sessions tomorrow with several specific and important problems before it.

Lippincott has signed an agreement with Ann Watkins, literary agent, for the autobiography of William Seabrook. The book, provisionally entitled "My Brother Charlie," is planned for publication in the Fall of 1942.

The transformation of our East River front has been so gradual that the public has failed to grasp how remarkable and far-reaching it has been. Section after section has been rescued from its dismal dwellings, its shabby factories and its dead-end docks. Eventually it will sweep in an unbroken ribbon of renovation from the Bronx to Battery Park.
Mayor La Guardia, in his dual capacity as national Director of Civilian Defense and chief executive of the city, placed the medical facilities of the metropolis on an emergency basis yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Strength in surrounding markets such as soy beans and cottonseed oil, was largely responsible last week for further advances in the lard market on the Board of Trade, with the distant deliveries moving into the highest ground since 1937.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 14 -- Finland has "good hopes of peace in the nearest future," it was announced tonight by a government spokesman who declared Finland was Germany's ally "only by accident and will not continue the war any longer than Finnish interests demand."
ASTORIA, Ore., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Columbia River fishermen deluged canning factories today with the largest catch of Chinook salmon in thirty years.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- The 9-year-old bay gelding My Play Boy captured the jumper crown today to supply one of the high spots of the eleventh annual Lawrence Farms Hunt Club horse show. My Play Boy followed his championship performance at yesterday's Gypsy Trail Club exhibition in Carmel by placing in all four of the division's major events here.

Citizen Ponders Situation John Smith, U.S.A., looks around, listens here and there, reads the Letters - to - the - Editor columns every day, and wonders how devoted to their democratic institutions the American people are, himself included.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique said today:

RANGOON, Burma, Sept., 14 -- Although the growing threat of the Japanese in Indo-China has recently caused an increase in British defense preparations in Burma, most Burmans continue to oppose cooperation with Britain in the European war.

Lists of new apartment rentals issued by brokers and renting agents over the week-end indicated a continuance of the demand for rooms in the rush of the Fall renting season. The activity extended over wide areas of Manhattan and was a factor in the filling up of buildings in the East and West Side sections.

Nathan Gelfer, head of the Gasoline Station Council of Metropolitan New York, representing gasoline dealers in Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan and the Bronx, predicted yesterday that unless there was a lessening of the restrictions on gasoline deliveries a fourth of the 8,000 stations in the four boroughs would either have to close before Oct. 1 or resort again to drastic rationing of their customers.

The architectural design for the exterior of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel mid-river ventilation building adjacent to Governors Island was made public yesterday by the New York City Tunnel Authority, which announced that McKim, Mead White had won first prize of $2,000 in the Authority's competition for the best design for the structure.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Col. Gen. Eugen Ritter von Schobert, commander of a German Army on the Eastern Front and one of the nation's most distinguished military leaders since World War days, was killed in action last Friday, the High Command announced today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Cuba walloped the Braves, 10 to 3, after absorbing a 6-to-8 defeat, in a double-header today before 14,752 fans.

The modern German concept of war is rapid movement. The Blitzkrieg must be kept in motion or it ceases to be a Blitzkrieg. Nevertheless, over the long term, the German offensive has tended to lose pace. New weapons and better strategy have helped opposing forces to slow it down.

While preaching his weekly sermon at the Nostrand-DeKalb Methodist Church, Nostrand Avenue and Quincy Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, the Rev. Carl A. Bergsten announced that an all-night "prayer vigil" for the President, his Cabinet and Congress would be held at the church starting at 9:30 P.M., Oct. 1, and ending at 7:30 A.M., the following day.

For a long time Adolf Hitler and his Nazi hordes were feared even more than they were hated in the lands they had overrun. Now there are clear indications that hatred for their conquerors is overcoming fear in Norway, in France, the Netherlands and all the other hapless countries where the swastika has been raised.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 15 -- Brest was heavily attacked Saturday night by a large force of British aircraft that raked the docks there with "a great weight of bombs," some of which, it was hoped, further damaged the Nazi battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau, the Air Ministry announced last night.

Doctors, dentists and hospitals throughout the country were asked yesterday by the Duchess of Leinster, executive director of the surgical instruments division of Bundles for Britain, 745 Fifth Avenue, to contribute their surplus medical and surgical equipment to England.

In its semi-annual, unaudited report to stockholders issued today, R.H. Macy Co., Inc., reports for the six-month period ended Aug. 2 total sales of $62,947,024 and an indicated profit of $507,137, compared with sales of $56,135,116 and a loss of $391,063 for the comparable six-month, period of 1940.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Red Sox swept a double-header from the White Sox today, 9 -- 2 and 5 -- 1, to increase their second-place lead over the Chicagoans to five full games.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Pirates were in a virtual tie for third place for about ten minutes today, but the Phils took them right out again with a five-run rally in the ninth inning which won the second game of a double-header, 6 to 3.

An investigation intended to remove persons holding subversive views from jobs in the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department is being conducted by Dr. Godfrey P. Schmidt, Deputy Industrial Commissioner, it became known yesterday.

As part of its campaign against "gyp" installment houses, the New York Furniture Merchants Association plans to devise an emblem for use by members which will certify that the stores' prices and merchandise are right. While no definite program has been formulated, tentative plans for consumer promotion of the emblem include both newspaper and radio advertising.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A four-hit pitching performance by Right-hander Sid Hudson and a lightning-fast triple play by the Washington infield gave the Senators a 2-0 triumph over the Tigers in a series opener today.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 14 -- The smaller Continental European stock markets continued bullish last week, almost wholly disregarding the yield factor, high taxation and a renewal of semiofficial warnings against excessive speculative activities.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- The third of the four special regattas of the season at the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club was held today under splendid sailing conditions, a good south-southwest breeze making fast and lively going.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Thanks to an early lead, Paul Runyan and Jack Dreyfus Jr. of Metropolis defeated Al Collins and Jess Sweetser of Sleepy Hollow in the thirty-six hole final for the Metropolitan Golf Association professional-amateur four-ball championship at the Lakeville Club today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 14 -- With Thailand at present the focal point of rivalry between AngloAmerican and Japanese-Axis interests in the Far East, the arrival here yesterday of Willys R. Peck from Washington to assume the post of United States Minister, succeeding Hugh Gladney Grant, is expected to signalize an important improvement in Thai-American relations.

Fordham University, the largest Catholic university in the United States and the largest Jesuit university in the world, will close the year-long commemoration of its one-hundredth anniversary with a three-day celebration starting this morning on the Fordham campus in the Bronx and continuing through Wednesday.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14 -- The Brooklyn Dodgers scored three touchdowns in the second period and defeated the Churchills, 35 to 0, in an exhibition football game today before 7,500 fans.
According to a letter just received from Tom Fearing of Manteo, N.C., the sailfish, marlin and dolphin are more plentiful off Hatters than they have been in years.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 15 -- More than 20,000 miners, most of them openly defying a command by their union leaders to return to work, were idle today in a stay-away revolt which forced a shutdown of every mine and colliery in District 7 of the United Mine Workers.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15 -- Following is the text of the address by Secretary Knox today before the convention of the American Legion:

The second of the Summer theatre tryouts to reach Broadway this season is "Cuckoos on the Hearth," formerly known as "Two Story House." Its premiere, set back from last Tuesday, will take place this evening at the Morosco under the auspices of Brock Pemberton.
NEW YORK Countess Robert van der Straten-Ponthoz, wife of the Belgian Ambassador, has arrived from Washington and is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Traders in cotton futures held yesterday to the cautious policy which had marked Saturday's session. As a result, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange receded steadily in a quiet market to close at the lows of the day with net losses of 18 to 21 points.

In an effort to assist bankers in this State in carrying out the Federal Reserve Board's consumer credit regulation and to aid the banks in filling out Form TFR-300, which, covers mandatory reports on foreign-owned property in the United States, the New York State Bankers Association, in cooperation with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will conduct a series of conferences in six key cities.

Americans have not lost their sympathy and admiration for the Finns. We hope, as the former Foreign Minister intimated on Sunday, that their war is nearly over. Twice the victim of the double turn in Russo-German relations, Finland has lost more than half her man power in two campaigns fought on the margins of a world conflict that has sucked one little nation after another into the whirlpool.

Should Auld Acquaintance? Friends of John L. Lewis are working hard to find a formula of reconciliation with the Left Wing. The twain until recently were like that to each other, but Mr. Lewis is a bit of a rover on his own account.

AMSTERDAM, via Berlin, Sept. 15 -- Large buying orders competed today on the Bourse with considerable liquidation and the market closed highly irregular. Royal Dutch rose 4 3/4 to 334 1/4, but Amsterdam Trading dropped 7 3/4 to 495 1/4.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 15 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Third Army, Lake Charles, La., Sept. 15 -- Beneath lowering gray skies and in intermittent downpours of rain, the Second and Third Armies, more than 400,000 strong, clashed today in the start of the greatest manoeuvre in the country's history.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Hogs and Spring lambs turned higher today, hogs rising 5 to 15 cents a hundred pounds and Spring lambs trading at strong to 25 cents higher. Beef cattle were mixed, steers losing ground yearlings holding steady and heifers showing some gain.

Trade Here Up 2% in Week Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 2 per cent for the week ended Sept. 13, in comparison with the corresponding week of 1940, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Realty deals in which business properties changed hands featured the Manhattan trading reported yesterday.

After a meeting lasting nearly six hours, members of the Seafarers International Union, A.F. of L., which has called a strike affecting ten ships along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, decided early today to reject a Maritime Commission proposal to sail seven of the vessels on the condition that a retroactive agreement be reached with the shipowners within two weeks.

A high-tension switch grounded at 8:35 A.M. yesterday in the eight-story B.M.T. powerhouse at 500 Kent Avenue in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn. There was a sharp flash, steam gushed from the top-floor windows, and one of the giant generators in the plant went dead.

In the cold and perilous waters off Iceland swim codfish of such noble proportions and such supreme palatability that the aristocratic cod of Boston dinner tables seems to pale by comparison. In an Icelandic fishery, the firm flesh is expertly lifted from the bones and the fillets are precisely packed in cellophane-lined tins to be shipped southward to New York City.

Fifteen hundred barbers and manicurists met at the Hotel Diplomat, 108 West Forty-third Street, last night and approved a call for a general strike, effective this morning, in 3,000 barber shops throughout Manhattan. According to Adolph Rosenbaum, strike chairman, the walkout will affect 7,000 barbers and 1,000 manicurists, more than half of whom he said were members of Local 1 of the Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union, C.I.O., which will direct the strike.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Senators made five hits and as many runs in the first two innings off Hal Newhouser today and defeated the Tigers, 8 to 5.

Willard F. Rockwell, chairman of the board of the Timken-Detroit Axle Company, informed stockholders in a report issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30, last, that sales were at record levels. He attributed this to an increased demand from regular customers and a larger participation in the National Defense Program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Contracts totaling $8,605,824 were awarded by the War Department today. Firms in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- A vitamin that prevents and cures a certain type of blindness in both animals and man, and also has been found to be one of the essential food factors which protect rats against a chemical causing cancer of the liver, was among the principal topics today at the symposium on the biological action of the vitamins at the University of Chicago.

An American religious mission consisting of a Protestant minister, a Roman Catholic priest and a Jewish rabbi has just arrived in London after a flight across the Atlantic to study and report on the religious and social trends among the organized religious groups in England and Ireland, it was announced yesterday.

WITH THE THIRD ARMY IN LOUISIANA, Sept. 15 -- Four soldiers, including a captain, were killed in pre-dawn traffic accidents in blackouts as thousands of troop-carrying vehicles, armored cars and tanks rumbled into No-Man's Land in west central Louisiana.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Roosevelt's lease-lend report showed that upward of a dozen nations have been getting some measure of lease-lend assistance.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 15 -- By 78 votes to 1, the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon approved a resolution censuring the German Ambassador, Baron Edmund von Thermann, "for overstepping the functions of his office and abusing his diplomatic privileges."
ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 15 -- Five teams cracked par by two strokes to deadlock at 68 in the weekly amateur-pro competition of the Long Island P.G.A. over the Shelter Rock Country Club course today.

Allowances amounting to about $1,500,000 were asked in Federal court yesterday by attorneys who aided in the recently completed reorganization of McKesson Robbins, Inc. The drug company entered voluntary proceedings under the Federal bankruptcy laws on Dec. 8, 1938, following the disclosure that its then president, F. Donald Coster, was in reality Philip Musica, an ex-convict.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -- The Navy is ready as never before to carry out President Roosevelt's order to blast Axis warcraft out of United States defense waters, Rear Admiral John W. Greenslade, commandant of the Twelfth Naval District, told the Pacific Trade Conference today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Release of the pool of rayon yarn built up to relieve "undue hardship" cases among manufacturers, whose operations have been affected by the silk-freezing order, was announced by the silk substitution section of the OPM today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The 48.4 per cent reduction In passenger automobile production for December which was ordered by the Office of Production Management today led some government sources to predict that an even deeper slash might be expected for January and succeeding months of 1942.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- For the first time this season the Red Sox ran a winning streak to seven consecutive games today as they swept the three-game series with the White Sox. They won by 6 to 1.

Trading in the wholesale meat markets yesterday opened slow on most classes of traefer meats. Steer hinds and ribs and veal were steady: other classes weak to lower. Kosher beef opened higher and veal foresaddles steady. Kosher lamb opened steady to strong.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- Maxwell Andersen's "Candle in the Wind," starring Helen Hayes, opened at the Colonial Theatre this evening. The warmth of the evening was no deterrent to a packed house that waited until the close of a by-no-means short play to cheer the cast and give a handsome ovation to Miss Hayes.

The stock market went through a balancing act yesterday, with the additions just about offset by those issues which declined or closed unchanged. Trading in the afternoon, in particular, was lifeless, as traders backed away from entering orders.

The primary election campaign came to an end last night, with Mayor La Guardia still the favorite to win the principal contest -- that between himself and John R. Davies for the Republican nomination for Mayor -- but with a number of factors leaving observers in some doubt as to the result of the voting today.

The Sweets Company of America has called a special meeting of stockholders on Sept. 16 to consider a decrease in the authorized capital stock to $1,250,000 from $5,000,000 and changing the par value of the common stock to $12.50 from $50 a share, each present share to be exchanged for one new share.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15 -- Secretary Knox brought the American Legion Convention to its feet cheering today with a speech in which he revealed that "beginning tomorrow" the Navy would "provide protection as adequate as we can make it for ships of every flag carrying lend-aid supplies between the American continent and the waters adjacent to Iceland."

Paul H. Davis Co. head a banking syndicate which will offer today to the public a new issue of 41,439 shares of common stock of the Snap-On Tools Corporation of Kenosha, Wis. The stock is to be priced at $12 a share.

The initial exhibition of the new season at the Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street, will open to the public today. It consists of 200 water-colors selected by the Section of Fine Arts and was first shown at the National Gallery in Washington last May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Twenty-three manufacturers of drugs and medicines whose combined output furnishes most of such products used in the United States had a net income in 1939 on average corporate net worth investment, after providing for income taxes, of 20.7 per cent on the average stockholders' investment, the Federal Trade Commission made known in a summary issued today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Sept. 10 aggregated $8,891,000,000.

A plan for establishment of local gasoline rationing boards to curtail consumption more equitably than is possible under the present blanket rationing system will be discussed next week at a meeting of the executive committee of the Eastern States Gasoline Retailers Conference and then presented to the government, Sol Herzog, counsel for the group, said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial declaration that "Judge Pecora held that only about one in thirteen of the signatures on Mr. Davies's petition was genuine" is a grave distortion of fact and an editorial admission of its falsity should be made with equal prominence.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Assets of the Radio Corporation of America have been depleted by an alleged conspiracy that has benefited individual officers of the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, according to charges in a stockholders' suit on file here today in the Westchester County Clerk's office.

The contest between Mayor La Guardia and John R. Davies for the Republican nomination for the chief magistracy of this city has brought some unusual features into today's primary election. Mr. La Guardia, though he doubtless knows what has been going on, has largely ignored it.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique:

The convention of the New York State Industrial Union Council, the largest State C.I.O. unit in the country, scheduled to have been held in Utica Sept. 26 and 27, was indefinitely postponed yesterday by a ruling of Thomas Kennedy, national C.I.O. administrator for the State Industrial Council.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 15 -- The tension that prevailed in Thailand in the first weeks after the Japanese occupied Southern Indo-China has subsided. The possibility that Thailand might be involved in war as a result of the threatened continuation of Japan's southward drive from Indo-China has greatly diminished, authoritative observers here said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed in August amounted to 874,113 bales of lint and 131,314 bales of linters, compared with 928,943 of lint and 134,006 of linters in July this year, and 650,888 of lint and 86,819 of linters in August last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Roosevelt's letter to Congress, transmitting his second report on the $7,000,000,000 lend-lease program, follows:

And Now, Form TFEL-2 If you own a bond or debenture or similar security of any of the thirty-two foreign countries whose accounts have been "frozen" in the United States send immediately to the Federal Reserve Bank for Form TFEL-2, fill it out, file the return with the bank, wait for approval and the formal request to bring in the security.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 15 -- The Germans sent two columns of tanks thirty-five miles into Egyptian territory yesterday, but the Axis forces withdrew after a sharp engagement with British tanks and planes in the desert about thirty miles south of Sofafi Pass.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 -- Dr. Albert C. Haring, Indiana University Professor of Marketing, criticized today regulations imposed by the Federal Reserve System on installment buying as discriminatory against the low-income groups.

Beginning this morning, "the American Navy will provide protection as adequate as we can make it for ships of every flag carrying lend-aid supplies between the American continent and the waters adjacent to Iceland." This announcement, made yesterday by Secretary Knox in an address before the national convention of the American Legion, is a plain statement of the policy on which the United States has now embarked.
A bill to add a month to each end of the present period of daylight saving time in the city is to be introduced in the City Council today by Newbold Morris, President of the Council.
Apartment leasing activity continued unabated yesterday, with brokers reporting demands for space in buildings In many residential sections of the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Driving to conserve materials for national defense, the Office of Production Management ordered a reduction today in the December production of passenger automobiles of 48.4 per cent below December, 1940.

Replacement problems created by the defense program were uppermost in the minds of more than 1,500 beauty and barber shop owners and manufacturers and distributors of supplies and equipment who took part in the opening of the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Beauty and Barber Shop Supply Institute, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Sept. 10 Arthur Upham Pope takes issue with me for my article on Sept. 7 referring to the situation of the Turki-speaking minority in Iran. I referred to "the 600,000 unhappy, oppressed Turki-speaking folk of that area who had been impressed by the Shah into abandoning their nomad life and set to work on his estates beside the Caspian Sea."
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 15 -- A year ago it was Dave Allerdice. This time it is Captain Bob Peters on whom Princeton is largely pinning its hopes for the success of its football season.

One hundred and ninety-one freshmen were registered at Townsend Harris High School, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, yesterday afternoon after the Board of Higher Education had adopted a resolution authorizing enrollment of an entering class at the school.

When the Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion, after four days of discussion by eminent authorities in all three fields, emerged with a reassertion of "the dignity and worth of the human personality as the basis for civilized life," it said nothing startling, nothing that the man in the American street would not say in fewer syllables and with less deliberation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Viewed by itself as a narrative and catalogue of American achievement, the President's second report to Congress of lease-lend activities could properly be used to awaken pride for this country's genius, where pride may have been extinguished, and stimulate it in breast where it has flickered low.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The trustees of the Erie, Nypano and Cleveland Mahoning Valley Railroads applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of purchase by the Erie of the properties of the other two roads and for authority to issue and sell 18,000,000 of Ohio Division first mortgage bonds.

Although the Dodgers have not yet clinched the pennant, applications for box and reserved seats for the world series at Ebbets Field will be accepted by the Brooklyn club, it was announced yesterday. For the present only requests made by mail will receive consideration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Extra styles, "frills and trimmings," decorations and ornaments made from materials urgently needed for national defense, are "only waste" and must disappear during the emergency, Donald M. Nelson, Director of Priorities of the Office of Production Management, told the National Retail Dry Goods Association at a "retailers for defense" dinner here tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman rushed into conferences with the British tonight to find out how many United States guns, tanks and planes they would spare to Russia before the American delegation he heads hurries on to Moscow for three-power meetings to complete a plan of deliveries.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) Several hundred C.I.O. workers at the Waverly terminal plant of the Breeze Corporation, Inc., which has 518,000,000 worth of contracts for airplane armor, went on strike today in what they said was a protest over drawn-out wage negotiations.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- Despite the fact that the business curve in this city shows some signs of flattening out, as more plants reach capacity, inventories last month ncreased their gains over preceding months, according to the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit.

Two-year prison, term were imposed yesterday on Daniel J. Houlihan, former local draft board chairman, and Francis O'Connell, whom he tried to help bribe his way out of military service under the Selective Service Act. James O'Connell, 62-year-old father of Francis, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison and fined $5,000.

The Treasury Department's new regulations requiring that all bonds of the thirty-two foreign countries whose accounts are "frozen" be accompanied by a Treasury "clearance certificate" went into effect yesterday. Hundreds of bondholders, or their representatives, visited the Federal Reserve Bank for copies of Form TFEL-2, which covers the situation.

The government's efforts so far to control prices have been inadequate and inflation cannot be averted unless the "pressure of powerful political groups seeking to escape their share of the defense program's burdens is resisted," Charles J. Walsh, Professor of Economics at Fordham, declared yesterday at the first of three days of exercises commemorating the close of Fordham University's centenary year.

Frederick Jubert Duquesne, described as a veteran espionage agent whose activities go back more than forty years, was pictured yesterday as a central figure in a Nazi spy ring entrusted with the task of uncovering the secrets of American war machines of a revolutionary nature, as the trial of sixteen persons accused of espi-onage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government entered its second week.
ROME, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Supply, in a telegram addressed today to all factories where tanks are being made in Britain announced that every tank and tank part made in Britain next week was going to be sent straight to the front lines defending Leningrad, Kiev and Odessa.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 16 -- Despite several outward manifestations of Japan's "immutable policy," the main interest in all Japanese quarters today continued to be centered in the Washington conversations being held on the basis of Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye's "peace message" to President Roosevelt.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Secretary Wickard has called upon the nation's farmers for record production in 1942, to improve nutrition at home and to include the necessary 8 to 10 per cent of our output earmarked for British and Allied uses.

Export permits for shipment of silk from China were suspended yesterday by the Japanese military except where foreign exporters there are able to arrange for military account wheat, oil, gasoline and other essential materials, according to a cable from the Foreign Silk Association of Shanghai to Raw Silk Importers, Inc., here.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Johnny Zaleski, assistant professional at Cedar Ridge, and Tom Morley, that club's amateur champion, today captured the Long Branch Trophy given by Mayor Alton Evans as the top prize in, the annual Old Orchard Country Club pro-amateur golf tournament.

PITTSBURGH. Sept. 15 (AP) -- A C.I.O. strike for a union shop today closed more than thirty "captive" mines operated by seven big steel companies, cutting off coal supplies to mills which have been running full blast producing steel for tanks, ships, guns and other war materials.
Scoring her sixth triumph in seven starts, James Cox Brady's filly, Oasis, swept off with the Bonnie Maginn Purse at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of 12,098.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today an application by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey for an order declaring it not to be a subsidiary of the United Gas Improvement Company or the United Corporation.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 16 -- The sinking of seven German vessels, including five troop-jammed transports, in the repulse of a Nazi landing attempt at the Baltic island of Oesel and in a clash in Arctic waters was announced today by the Russians.

MASKINONGE, Que., Sept. 15 -- Osiace Adam, who after vaulting the language barrier had agreed to conduct us on a duck shooting expedition along the shores of Lac St. Pierre, was a joyful man at daybreak.

VICHY, France, Sept. 15 -- Contending that the most urgent problem of the twentieth century is not the new European order of peace between continents, but the problem of the church pastor, Marc Boegner, writing in the Figaro today, appeals for an "inter-ecclesiastical truce of Christian churches."
The Cuba Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net loss of $161,932 after taxes, interest, amortization, depreciation and profit and loss charges and credits.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The plight of 1,000 Paterson silk and rayon workers who are unemployed or on part-time work as a result of the silk freezing order was studied here today at conferences arranged by the labor division of the OPM, and a program was begun to re-employ or retrain these workers, preferably for defense work.

If Olsen and Johnson had not already earmarked "Crazy House" as a title. Frank Gabrielson and Irvin Pincus would have just the right caption for their new farce, "The More the Merrier," which was slammed around the stage of the Cort last evening.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 15 -- Major Vidkun Quisling's official organ, Fritt Folk, today threatens Sweden with strong reprisals because the Swedish Trade Unions Congress dared to express its sympathy and solidarity with the court-martialed Norwegians.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to add my little word of comment concerning this ridiculous and wildcat so-called investigation into war propaganda. Because of the clear-cut issues of morality and decency involved, I think it would be physically impossible for the movies to make too many anti-Nazi films or for the papers to stress these truths too greatly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here was relatively low to day with operators inclined to act with caution pending further developments in Washington. Prices fluctuated erratically within a moderate range.

James W. Gerard, chairman of a campaign to raise $110,000 this Fall for the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, announced a preliminary donation of $10,000 from Marshall Field at the first meeting of the campaign's executive committee at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday, the 110th anniversary of the founding of the society.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- House and Senate conferees officially approved the revised tax bill today, and leaders planned to bring it up in the House tomorrow and in the Senate Wednesday so that it would be on President Roosevelt's desk late Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- As deposits of insured banks have increased more than 36 per cent since Sept. 21, 1938, when the banks last were asked to report the extent of insurance coverage, they have been requested by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to report as of Sept. 24 next the proportion of their deposits protected under the FDIC's $5,000 individual insurance limitation.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has instructed the realty firm of Pease Elliman, Inc., to place on the market the dual-residence building at 47-49 East Sixty-fifth Street, which was the town home of the late Mrs. James Roosevelt and of President Roosevelt and his family.

The four-story flat at 335 Randolph Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Summit Building and Loan Association to Anna Lutz. The purchaser turned in shares with a book value of $11,504 in payment.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Six Americans fighting with the Royal Air Force were included in a casualty list issued today by the British Air Ministry. They were:
Good old necessity with its unending influence on modern invention produced a revolutionary innovation yesterday that should alleviate a lot of headaches among members of the fairer sex.
Showings of new hats by Franklin Simon and of frocks, suits and coats by Carrie Munn Couture continued yesterday the display of fashions for Fall and Winter.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15 -- Associate Justice John Crawford Crosby, retired, of the Massachusetts Supreme Court and Mrs. Crosby entertained at dinner in their home here tonight the other members of the bench. Dinners have been given annually for twenty-eight years.

ROME, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A burst of activity in Africa, in which Hill 146 was captured by Axis forces in a lightning attack east of Tobruk, Libya, and a British formation routed in Ethiopia by Italian cavalry and hand-grenade attacks, was reported officially today.

CALIFORNIA' coyotes and the Southern California Edisoa Company may not seem to have much in common, but they both figure in an odd and interesting book written, by Lila Lofberg with the assistance of David Malcolmson: "Sierra Outpost."*

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- "Present trends in the grocery industry of the country appear to be generally consistent with public policy as expressed in the antitrust laws," Corwin Edwards, chief economist, United States Department of Justice, told members of the Super-Market Institute here at the Hotel Bellevue-Stratford at the opening of the fifth annual convention of the organization today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- As the International Hod Carriers', Building and Common Laborers' Union of America opened its first convention in thirty years here today the insurgent group indicated that it would carry its anti-racketeering fight to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who is scheduled to address the delegates tomorrow.

LISBON, Sept. 15 (Reuter) -- Rudolf Hilferding, German Finance Minister in 1928, has died in a German prison, it was reported here today. He was a political refugee in France at the time of the occupation and was taken off a boat at Marseille when he was on the point of leaving for the United States.
BERLIN, Sept. 15 -- Large-scale attacking operations are "progressing successfully" in both the Leningrad area and the Ukraine, authorized German sources declared tonight.

With the reminder that they face dangerous and "heroic" days, thirty-six graduates of engineering schools throughout the country who had taken a special twelve-week course at the New York University College of Engineering for commissions as ensigns in the Naval Reserve, participated in commencement exercises yesterday morning in the Gould Memorial Library auditorium, on the N.Y.U. campus in the Bronx.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 15 -- As the first four of 1,800 soldiers to be released from the Forty-fourth Division prior to its departure for manoeuvres Sept. 26 received their discharge papers this afternoon the Seventy-first Infantry of New York City held a review honoring 600 of its members who will be discharged soon upon completion of their enlistments.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- Negotiations were opened today by RKO for Daphne Du Maurier's new novel, "French Man," as a vehicle for Charles Boyer. The story has been approved tentatively by Joseph I. Breen and Sol Lesser, it is understood, and an offer for the work has been made.
With the aid of Norman Branch, Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, the singular southpaw of the Yankees, scored his fifteenth victory of the campaign at the Stadium yesterday.

Restoration of the 2 per cent cash discount by the Curtis Publishing Company and the McGrawHill Publishing Company, coupled with acceptance of the discount principle, by the radio networks, are important contributions to the financial soundness and general welfare of the advertising business, Frederic R. Gamble, managing director of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, said yesterday.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- N.Y. U.'s final week at its football training camp will be given over to rest and contemplation, if today's activities are any indication. Coach Mal Stevens devoted the morning and afternoon drills to instruction in fundamentals and a review of the past fortnight's work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Criticism by newspaper columnists of the Senate's inquiry into alleged war propaganda in motion pictures has reached the proportions of "a mass attack" and "smacks of conspiracy," it was asserted at the hearing today by Senator Clark of Idaho, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Subcommittee conducting the inquiry.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 15 -- A substantial number of 1,500 circulars sent through, the mail by George N. McKendry, Republican town chairman, and his town committee to Republican voters in a bitter party caucus fight last week wound up in the town incinerator today, some of them unopened, and Mr. McKendry speedily demanded an explanation from James T. Kelley, the town's Democratic postmaster.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A tenth-inning single off Pitcher Fred Caliguiri's glove gave the Browns their third straight triumph over the Athletics today, 4 to 3.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- Scoring all their runs in the seventeenth inning, which was played in dusk so deep that the players seemed only shadows on Crosley Field, the Dodgers today toppled the Reds, 5 -- 1, and by this des perate venture moved back to a two-game lead over the second place Cardinals in the torrid National League race.

Official word yesterday from Philadelphia indicated that the city will be in the market on Oct. 10 with an issue of $14,100,000 of refunding and water bonds. The securities will mature serially from Jan. 1, 1943 to 1967. Further details of this operation, which has been expected for some time, will be made known at a later date.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The way has been legally cleared for shipment aboard American merchant vessels manned by American crews of munitions and other articles of war to such key British points as Hong Kong, Burma and Suez, the State Department revealed today in making public an opinion on the Neutrality Act by Attorney General Biddle.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 15 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 13:

Loew's Criterion will bring in "Dr. Kildare's Wedding Day" tomorrow in place of the previously scheduled "Ice-Capades." No new date has yet been set for the latter film. Lew Ayres, Laraine Day and Lionel Barrymore continue their customary roles in the new "Kildare" release....

The Procurement Division of the Treasury Department has leased a floor comprising about 23,000 square feet in the A. Finkenberg Sons, Inc., warehouse building at 112-28 Willow Avenue, the Bronx, for supplies for refugees in unoccupied foreign countries, it was revealed yesterday by Arthur Eckstein, Inc., brokers.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 15 -- The establishment of a new constitutional government at Teheran is considered tonight in highest foreign diplomatic circles here and elsewhere in the Near East to be only a matter of days, perhaps hours.

Polo's national open championship will stage the second of its semi-finals at Meadow Brook in Westbury today. At 3:30 P.M., on Hitchcock Field, Cocie Rathborne's Pelicans will try to continue the pace that brought them through against Texas and Cecil Smith Saturday, when, the championship started.

The Columbia football squad felt the aftermath yesterday of last Saturday's scrimmage with Rutgers when Ken Germann, alternate varsity left halfback, failed to appear in uniform for either the morning or afternoon drills at Baker Field.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Two teams tied for best-ball honors in the Westchester County Golf Association's final one-day pro-amateur event of the season at the Wykagyl Country Club today.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The stock market opened quiet today, last week's activity having reached a point where a speculative shake out was to be expected and the markets were more vulnerable to the latest news from Russia.

Operators of small concerns and other business men in this area who have been perplexed by the methods of procedure required to continue operations under defense regulations may now seek information and guidance at an expanded local office of the priorities field service of OPM, it was announced yesterday at the opening of the new office, 25 Broadway.

Robert Moses told the Republican voters of the city last night, in an address, that even though Mayor La Guardia has been contemptuous of the Republican party, and would do better staying away from fires and leaving them to the fire engines, the Republican party had no choice but to nominate him for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Defense Mediation Board called upon striking soft-coal miners in "captive" coal mines of five States today to resume production immediately pending a hearing by the board starting here on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A program of military censorship involving official control over international communications while leaving the press unrestricted is being developed in collaboration between the Army and the Navy, James V. Forrestal, Acting Secretary of the Navy, said today.

Demand for most classes of fresh meats has been quiet for the first two days of the current week. Supplies of pork cuts were moderate and cow beef was rather liberal for trade requirements. All other classes of traefer meats were fully normal. Prices on veal hindsaddles were about steady and calf weak.
Some highly placed Americans who have just returned here from Rome, where they had lived for several years, paint this picture of Italy today:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 17 (UP) -- A German expeditionary force that set out by air and sea to invade the Baltic island of Oesel has been annihilated by the Russians, with a Nazi loss of four heavily loaded transports, one destroyer, ten launches, many small craft and thousands of soldiers, including parachutists, according to today's communique.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 15:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Contests for public office nominations and political committee memberships in Westchester County were won in today's primary in most instances by party regulars, according to returns tonight.

The 6,185-ton passenger liner Acadia will be requisitioned by the government to use in connection with the projected airplane ferry service between the United States and the Near East, it was reported here last night.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 16 -- The Committee for the Restoration of Representative Government, an anti-war group, was beaten decisively in an attempted retaliatory write-in vote against County Committeemen who had refused to sign its isolationist pledge, according to returns tonight in the Nassau County primary.

An extremely light vote was cast in the New Jersey primaries yesterday. No State-wide offices were at stake and misunderstandings caused by the introduction of permanent registration in some counties, was a factor. The apathy spread even to Hudson County, where outpourings of Democratic voters usually are engineered by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and his organization.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Harold Brooks entertained at their home tonight and Mrs. James B. Duke entertained at Rough Point this afternoon.
BERLIN, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A special communique from the headquarters of Adolf Hitler said today:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The "two-ocean" Navy which will give the United States the greatest fleet ever built by any country reached the point today where every contract involved has been awarded.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The independence of Syria was proclaimed today by the occupying Free French authorities and Sheik Tajeddine Hassani was named the first President of the Republic.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 16 -- Ginger Rogers was signed today by Twentieth Century-Fox for the leading' role in "Roxie Hart," formerly "Chicago," which William Wellan will direct.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Earl Blaik, the trouble-shooter, has come back home to do a job.

The newly established Gallery of Modern Art, 18 East Fifty-seventh Street, is now open to the public -- the walls hung with an assortment of oils, water-colors, gouaches and drawings by European and American artists, most of whom are contemporary.

Despite a record volume of sales for the year representing a gain of 35 per cent over the preceding twelve months, earnings of the Motor Wheel Corporation for the fiscal year ended on June 30 were slightly less than for the twelve months ended on June 30, 1940, due to an increase in Federal taxes of approximately $1,443,000, H. F. Harper, president, informed stockholders yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Wednesday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- This city of 400,000 was blacked out by a strike of employes of the Kansas City Power and Light Company at midnight.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. George Emlen Roosevelt have come from Gracewood, their place in Oyster Bay, and are at the Ambassador before going to their home at 1,001 Park Avenue.

Grass and Concrete At the beginning of the century, when Corlears Hook Park in the south-east corner of Manhattan Island came into being, a city park was a combination of asphalt walks, benches and greensward, with or without trees.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your editorial "The End of Neutrality" is an unbecomingly weak bit of apologia for the Administration's entire immoral course. These sentences, in particular, are tissue-thin:

Mayor La Guardia defeated John R. Davies, running as an anti-war and anti-New Deal candidate, for the Republican nomination for Mayor in yesterday's primary election by an indicated majority of about 18,000 in a surprisingly light vote.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 17 -- Hamburg caught it heavily again Monday night, when a strong force of British bombers methodically dropped high explosives on shipyards, factories and railway sidings "hour after hour," the Air Ministry said today.

The visitor in Scandinavia is always surprised when he gets there to discover the differences between the three nations inhabiting Europe's biggest peninsula. Perhaps because its connection is watery and tenuous, so that it is not firmly anchored to the Continent, but swing's out and away into the empty northern seas, it has developed a life and character of its own, as distinct from the rest of Europe as is life in the British Isles.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 16 (AP) -- A quarrel believed to have developed over small tips given hotel employes was blamed by officers today for the bizarre acts of a naval Medical Reserve lieutenant who beat his bride of three days with a sword and fatally wounded himself with the weapon.

Since the American people have at no time been neutral in their feelings about this war, and since their Government, represented both by the President and Congress, has long since taken action which makes us the open ally of democratic Britain and the open enemy of Nazi Germany, we find fresh assurance in the reports from Washington that the Administration will seek repeal of the Neutrality Act at the present session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Six statements of policy, designed to cushion the impact of passenger car curtailment orders on the automobile industry's labor force and provide an orderly method of transferring workers from non-defense to defense work, were issued today by Sidney Hillman OPM associate director general.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Moving to avert a bankruptcy action for the Colorado Southern Railway, Edward Flynn, executive vice president, today asked holders of $20,000,000 of general mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due on May 1, 1989, to agree to a voluntary interest reduction.
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 16 -- A sharp reaction developed on the Bourse today on the expectation that firm steps would be taken to halt the boom in stocks. Heavy liquidation was in evidence.

The cost of many foods continues to rise steadily. Between July 15 and Aug. 12 retail prices advanced 1.2 per cent to reach the highest level in ten years, and for the last part of August preliminary reports from eighteen cities in the country indicate that this advance has continued.

The British passenger liner Modasa arrived here yesterday after a long voyage across the Atlantic during which she and other vessels in a big convoy successfully dodged a nest of Axis submarines that later attacked an eastbound convoy.

The Allied Stores Corporation and subsidiaries had a consolidated net profit of $496.173 in the three months ended on July 31, according to the quarterly statement issued for publication today. The profit is after $360,000 provision for estimated Federal taxes based upon tax legislation now pending, $245,000 excess profits tax and $400,000 appropriation for inventory valuation reserve.

Good Lord, we're surrounded! On Monday night "The More the Merrier" hit murder over the head with a funny-bone at the Cort Theatre. Last evening "Cuckoos on the Hearth" played a few pranks on crime at the Morosco Theatre.

Industrial purchasing agents were urged yesterday to face the fact that if their plants were not operating on defense work their chances of getting preference ratings on scarce materials were very slim and they might be forced to suspend operations temporarily.

The Book-of-the-Month Club has made a dual selection for December -- "Language in Action," by S. I. Hayakawa, and "Storm," a novel by George R. Stewart. The former, a Harcourt, Brace publication, is described as a guide to accurate speaking and thinking.

Months before United States armed forces occupied Greenland and Iceland, Germany sought to learn this country's intentions with regard to these island defense outposts, it was disclosed yesterday at the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government, specificially Germany.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 16 -- Mexico's Independence Day ceremonies culminated today in a big parade lasting over two hours and watched by crowds on heavily packed streets leading to the main square, where it was reviewed by the President from the balcony of the palace.
Emphasis on past fashions in history was featured in the Fall and Winter style show presented yesterday by Arnold Constable as the opening event in the store's 116th anniversary celebration.

The veteran trainer Max Hirsch and Jockey Wendell Eads, who lost the mount on Whirlaway this season, occupied the spotlight at Aqueduct yesterday when Hirsch saddled the winners of the two best races and Eads scored with three mounts.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Former National Singles Champion Don McNeill of Oklahoma City met defeat in a surprising reversal of form today in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Herbert Hoover predicted tonight the collapse of the Hitler regime, even though the Nazis suffer no military defeat, and at the same time urged a course which, he said, would lead to national unity. He spoke from Chicago in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Three thousand miles across the continent the sun-kissed shores of California beckoned to a 7-year-old girl and a 10-year-old boy in Brooklyn. Yesterday in the misty hour before dawn the youngsters stole out of their home and started on the first leg of their journey -- on tricycles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Navy is patrolling the Atlantic sea lanes with orders to shoot at any German or Italian submarines and sea raiders but will not escort groups of American, British and other merchant vessels in groups as a customary practice.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 16 -- The sudden abdication today of Riza Shah Pahlevi of Iran and his flight from Teheran before the advancing Anglo-Russian forces concludes the first major phase of the Allies' struggle to safeguard the Indian frontier and the back door to the Middle East, and, in the opinion of Iranian experts here, climaxes the eleven-week crisis that pushed Iran to the verge of revolution and civil war.

Once more the extraordinary record for safety of the civilian pilot training program under the Civil Aeronautics Administration has received tangible endorsement by a reduction in premium rates covering life and accident insurance for student pilots. This is the sixth time since the program was initiated in 1939 that voluntary reduction in premiums has been made.
Many store leases were included in the lists of commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday.

A double-handful of brass chains and padlocks, a roll of adhesive tape, a toy typewriter, and two crude black cloth hoods were placed in evidence in Federal court yesterday as the paraphernalia assembled for a series of kidnappings that never occurred.

A recommendation that shoe styles be simplified, in order to reduce the number of patterns and lasts required, was offered by the women's style committee of the National Shoe Retailers Association at a style conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Discontinuance of the practice of the New York City school system of segregating slow children In special classes was recommended yesterday in a Board of Education report on the five-year Speyer School experiment with bright and dull pupils, completed last Spring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt will give an informal luncheon Sept. 25 at the White House for the Duke of Windsor and his American Duchess, the former Wallis Warfield Simpson. It will be the first time the Duchess has met the President, but the Duke has known Mr. Roosevelt a long time.

One of the largest long-distance moving jobs on record got under way yesterday as workmen in Washington, D. C., began loading vans with the office equipment, furnishings and records of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, whose headquarters are being transferred to New York.

Francis J. Thompson, instructor in public speaking at City College, was suspended yesterday by Acting President Harry N. Wright following charges of "conduct unbecoming a member of the staff and neglect of duty," made against the teacher by the conduct committee of the Board of Higher Education.

A possibility that West Coast seamen may join the strike for increased war bonuses now in effect in Atlantic and Gulf ports arose yesterday when the Sailors Union of the Pacific announced it would seek "immediate adjustment" of such payments and threatened "drastic action" if demands were not considered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Roosevelt has accepted a gorilla, "the largest and most ferocious" ever sent out of Africa, as a gift from Free French forces, it was revealed at the White House today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A total commitment of $3,902,952,578 had been made to Sept. 13 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for reserves of rubbery metals and other strategic and critical materials and supplies, the construction of defense plants, the acquisition of equipment, and loans to manufacturers to carry out contracts with the government for defense materials.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 Disturbed over curtailment of shipping services from Pacific Coast ports during the national emergency, commercial leaders of the Far West proposed today that the Maritime Commission consider diverting to this coast lease-lend tonnage now being shipped from Atlantic seaboard ports to the Red Sea.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept.16 -- Investigation of a fire early this morning that caused fatal injuries to a man and his wife culminated this afternoon with a confession, according to the police, by Edward Mulvaney, 26 years old, an unemployed laborer, of 560 First Street, that he had set that fire and five others since Aug. 29, two of them this morning.

The police, protection against possible election frauds yesterday was the most complete in the history of the city, with Police Commissioner Valentine ordering 1,100 detectives to don uniforms which many of them had not worn for years to carry out Mayor La Guardia's orders for n honest election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Roosevelt stated today that neither he nor, to his knowledge, any of his aides, had exerted pressure on the motion picture industry for the production of "propaganda" movies. Incidentally, he ridiculed the Senate investigation of war propaganda in films.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, THIRD ARMY, LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 16 -- "The Battle of the Red River" still hung in the balance scales of war tonight as more than 400,000 men struggled through the cypress swamps and tangled pine thickets of Louisiana on the second day of a manoeuvre unprecedented in size in American history.

Students beginning the new academic year at Cornell Medical College were informed yesterday that the curriculum they were about to undertake or resume was insufficient in that it would fail to teach them the increasingly important social relations of medicine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Supply Priorities and Allocation Board called today for "expanded production of every critical material" and instructed its executive director, Donald M. Nelson, "to leave no stone unturned by any agency of government in the drive to bring production of the nation's basic materials up to maximum defense and essential civilian needs."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation announced tonight that a sit-down strike at its key by-products plant in near-by Clairton ended at 7:30 P.M. after seriously hampering operations in several other mills.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Bulgarian Government today rejected a Soviet note protesting that Bulgaria was permitting Germany and Italy to mass warships in her harbors for an attack on the Russian Black Sea coast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The House by a voice vote approved and sent to the Senate today the conference report on the record $3,553,400,000 revenue bill.
Seven new cases of infantile paralysis were reported in New York yesterday, according to Dr. Samuel Frant, epidemiologist of the city Health Department.

Assuming that the earth's center is liquid and contains radio-active matter, the end of the world could be brought about 2,000,000,000 years from now by liquefaction, Dr. Victor F. Hess, Professor of Physics at Fordham University and recipient of the Nobel Prize for physics in 1936, suggested yesterday at one of the panel discussions being conducted during the three-day celebration of Fordham's centenary that closes today.
The underwriting community became "competitive-bidding minded" yesterday when nine banking syndicates sought two new issues of railroad-terminal bonds aggregating $16,837,000.

Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers in the New York market last week totaled 1,043, which compared with 1,201 in the previous week and 1,050 in the corresponding period of 1940, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

In addition to the many records they always seem to be breaking, the Yankees set a new mark in salesmanship yesterday when President Edward Grant Barrow announced that every one of the 41,000 reserved seats had been sold for the world series opening at the Stadium on Oct. 1.

Stocks of gasoline along the East Coast last week declined 665,000 barrels to 19,238,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks of light fuel oil, however, were up 747,000 barrels to 16,418,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks gained 743,000 to 10,241,000.

Advertisers and agencies here were seriously concerned yesterday by reports that the Export Control Administration, was considering a ban on export of printing plates, such as half-tones, electrotypes and nickeltypes, to Canada, in order to conserve vital metals, such as copper, zinc and nickel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The discovery of a new member of the ever-growing family of the B vitamins, known collectively as the Vitamin B Complex, was announced here today at the symposium on the biological action of the vitamins at the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Legislation to increase the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's borrowing power by $1,500,000,000 was approved by the House Banking Committee today amid inconclusive discussion of the RFC's present lending capacity.

Two thousand barbers and 400 manicurists in the area between the Battery and Fifty-ninth Street -- with the exception of lower East Side -- yesterday responded to the strike call of Locals 1 and 3 of the Barbers and Beauty Culturista Union, C.I.O., according to union officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- In a major move to expedite the transport of American planes, tanks and guns to the war fronts, the United States and Norway are throwing fifty to 150 additional merchantmen Into the enlarged Atlantic convoys now moving with increased protection of United States warships.

A resolution was unanimously passed by the City Council yesterday urging that the start of the world series be postponed from Oct. 1 to Oct. 2 because the scheduled opening date coincides with the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

Two large city projects were filed with the Department of Buildings yesterday. In Manhattan plans were submitted for a $300,000 six-story apartment in the Dyckman area and in Brooklyn for a $305,000 development of thirty-two two-family dwellings.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Sale of the insolvent Central States Life Insurance Company to the newly formed Mutual Savings Life Insurance Company of St. Louis was recommended to court today by Ray B. Lucas, retiring Missouri State Insurance Superintendent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Roosevelt today made Edward R. Stettinius Jr. his special assistant and delegated to him greatly expanded powers to administer the lease-lend program, a move calculated to speed the transfer of war supplies to Great Britain and her allies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Officials are seriously considering asking Congress for the authority to extend a munitions-purchase loan of several hundred millions to Russia, presumably out of the funds of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Serge Semenenko, chairman of the reorganization managers of the Brown Company, maker of high-grade and specialized pulps, announced yesterday that, owing to a substantial increase in working capital, the company will borrow only $6,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation instead of the $10,000,000 permitted by the plan of reorganization.

ROME, Sept. 16 -- The Pope today gave Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, his reply to the President's message, and it appears on good Vatican authority to have been a polite "no."

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Cleveland Rams scored a touchdown, converted the point and added a field goal in the second period tonight to defeat the Chicago Cardinals, 10 to 6, in a National Football League game in Comiskey Park.

THERE seems to be a feeling that the Boys in Blue, meaning the umpires, made a mistake in letting that Monday ball game in Cincinnati run on so long that the dauntless Dodgers eventually made off with it under cover of darkness. President Ford Frick of the National League yesterday denounced the late proceedings and warned all concerned against indulging in any more of the same.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- The Cardinals picked up half a game on the Dodgers by playing a 1-1 tie with the Giants in ten innings today, but the outcome was a distinct disappointment to them. Going into the ninth with a 1-0 lead, the Redbirds held high hopes of making the pennant race even closer until the New Yorkers dashed them with a tying rally.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- Axis planes bombed this capital of Egypt and holy city of the Moslems last night, killing thirty-nine persons, injuring ninety-three others and touching off speculation as to whether Home would be raided in reprisal.

Mrs. Preston Davie has been appointed vice president of the American Women's Voluntary Services and director of its Region 2, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Isabella Greenway King, chairman of the organization's board of directors.

Without mentioning Charles A. Lindbergh's recent speech, in which he charged the British, Jewish and Roosevelt Administration groups with leading this country into war, Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Governor Lehman united last night in denouncing anti-Jewish and anti-religious propaganda of all kinds as a grave threat to American democracy and the democratic world order that is hoped for after the war.

For the third successive session the cotton market yesterday was under pressure. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange touched their best levels of the day in the first hour of trading, then receded as much as 31 points near midday and closed with net losses of 14 to 17 points.

Organization of the American Council of Christian Churches in opposition to the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America was announced yesterday after a meeting of Fundamentalists at headquarters of the new organization at 340 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Macy has a way of presenting a fashion show that is as tidy as a prize package, giving a complete idea of what is being promoted in costume and accessories. Yesterday's show represents the merchandise found in the Little Shop -- everything down to the tiniest bauble we gather was brought together from that department.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Riza Shah Pahlevi of Iran abdicated today, "on account of failing health," as British and Russian forces came within a few miles of Teheran in moves converging upon that capital The Shah is succeeded by his son, 21-year-old Crown Prince Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

The real impact of the defense program will develop in the next six months and will challenge the fashion industries to see "how much can be done with how little," Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, told the ready-to-wear and fabric division of the Fashion Group at a meeting at the Murray Hill Hotel.

LONDON, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- American technicians and mechanics already are at work in Russia, W. Averell Harriman revealed today amid a brisk round Of conferences on how Britain and the United States Can Best support the Soviet war against the Germans.

MASKINONGE, Que., Sept. 16 -- Most American duck shooters agree upon only one thing concerning their favorite sport -- that it is almost impossible to be comfortable and at the same time get good shooting. However, the hunter who tries the lakes and rivers of Quebec during the first two weeks of the season is in a position to scout this theory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Nineteen textile and dyeing and finishing corporations (except woolen worsted) in 1939 had a combined net income of $5,137,138 before deduction of interest on long-term borrowings and income taxes, which represented a rate of return of 7.1 per cent on the total employed capital of $72,100,313, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The number of "fighting planes" that the United States and Great Britain have agreed to supply monthly to Russia as soon as possible -- announced in London today as "several hundred" -- is at least 500. Such was the information that reached the Supply Priorities and Allocation Board, the SPAB, at its meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Loans and securities of domestic banks are probably of higher average quality than ever before, but the capital ratios of the banks are too low and some banks continue to exhibit undesirable management practices, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation informed Congress today in its annual report for 1940.

An organized movement among manufacturers of beauty and barber shop equipment to form their own trade association started here yesterday at the Hotel Commodore where manufacturers are exhibiting their products in connection with the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Beauty and Barber Shop Supply Institute.

The opening group show of the season at the Midtown Galleries, 605 Madison Avenue, just above Fifty-seventh Street, got under way yesterday. In it may be reencountered many of the artists whose work is regularly seen there.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

VTCHY, France, Sept. 16 -- Several sensational developments in the tense internal situation of France were made public here today. The German military authorities announced the names of ten hostages who had been executed in reprisal for acts of terrorism, against the German troops of occupation and reports were received of two more attempted shootings on the streets of Paris.

Belated support entered the stock market in the final hour of trading yesterday and enabled the general list to show a moderately higher closing. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was heightened considerably, although this was due to heavy dealings in some low-priced shares, particularly a block of 45,000 shares of Commonwealth and Southern which was transferred in the last hour although the price unchanged.

Immediate severance of diplomatic relations with Germany, combined with "positive action" in cooperation with the British Navy to deliver supplies and munitions to their destination are among the demands made upon the Administration in Washington by the Committee to Defend America in its new ten-point statement of basic policy released here last night.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communigud today:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Chet Laabs's twelfth-inning home run, his second of the game, gave the Browns a 9-8 victory over the Athletics today. It gave them a sweep of the four-game series and their second extra-inning conquest in two days.

Michael Todd is recruiting quite a company for his forthcoming musical comedy, "And So to Bedlam," formerly labeled "Viva McKeever." Mr. Todd said yesterday he had signed Ned Sparks, Jed Prouty, Gypsy Rose Lee, Carrie Finnell, the Nonchalants and Milt Britton's band.

Furniture buyers for department stores here denied yesterday that public misunderstanding of the new installment regulations had caused a sharp drop in sales, as reported by W.S. Cheyney, vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, in Atlantic City on Monday at the group's Eastern convention.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 16 -- The will of the Argentine people to permit no foreign agent to undermine their sovereignty or democratic institutions and to demand prompt measures against any one who engages in such activities was overwhelmingly expressed this afternoon.
Havre de Grace Results HAVRE DE GRACE, MD. By The Associated Press. FIRST RACE -- Purse $1,000; claiming; 2-year-olds; six furlongs.

In his second ninety-day report on the progress of lease-lend aid President Roosevelt announced that, out of the $7,000,000,000 appropriated by Congress, more than $6,250,000,000 had been allocated and over $3,500,000,000 of legal contracts had been made. Through August the total dollar value of defense articles transferred and defense services rendered, plus expenditures for other lease-lend purposes, amounted to $487,000,000.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Miss Kathleen Byrne of the Rye Country Club, Westchester medal-play champion, won low-gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the south course of the Westchester Country Club with a four-over-par 41, 36 -- 77 today.

Nearly all the nations dominated by the Nazis as well as those fighting for their freedom will be represented among the 15,000 marchers in the Victory Parade to be held Saturday night under the sponsorship of Bundles for Britain, Inc., 745 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.
Barrett Herrick, head of the investment firm of Barrett Herrick Co., Inc., has been elected a director of W.C. Lipe, Inc., of Syracuse, N.Y., manufacturer of machine tools and automotive clutches.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Soy beans were on the downgrade today, with the October breaking 6 7/8 cents a bushel at one time as a result of scattered liquidation and stop-loss selling.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- After weeks of virtual silence on specific operations on the Eastern Front, the German High Command today released information suggesting that the Russian forces face critical situations in two of the three major theatres.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 -- Bill Werber's line single off Hugh Casey in the eleventh inning scored Eddie Joost from second base and broke up a ball game today that had as many bizarre late inning happenings as yesterday's unprecedented seventeen-inning affair between the Reds and the Dodgers.

Four hundred and twenty-nine young officers, In Summer uniforms of white and gold, received ''emergency" commissions as Naval Reserve ensigns yesterday morning at graduation ceremonies aboard the U.S.S. Prairie State at 136th Street and the Hudson River.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Braves unloosed a 15-hit attack today to defeat the Cubs, 8 to 5, in the final meeting of the teams this season. The Cubs got 12 hits off Al Javery, but he kept them well scattered.
