Democratic primary voters in twenty-five election districts in Queens were turned away from the polls for lack of appropriate ballots yesterday afternoon between the time the polls opened and 7 P.M., when rush work rectified the error.

Jaded residents of Williamsburg in the lunch-hour crowd along Throop Avenue, near Gerry Street, Brooklyn, rubbed their eyes yesterday at the sight of an armored truck, with three pistol-bearing guards in the front seat, bouncing casually over the cobblestones while money bags clattered into the gutter through the back doors.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Don L. Moore, 1939 champion and runner-up last year, assumed the lead today in the annual New Jersey State seniors' golf championship when he toured the Essex Fells Country Club course, his home layout, in 76.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- The Government of Panama ordered Francisco Villalaz Castillo, its Minister to Germany, today to protest against the torpedoing of the steamships Sessa and Montana and to present a claim for indemnity.

Railroad Financing Some nine banking groups had opportunity yesterday to express publicly their views on the value of two issues of railway terminal bonds. The views proved to be unusually interesting, especially in the case of the $14,737,000 St. Paul Union Depot issue, which produced rather wide differences of opinion among the underwriters -- a fact perhaps due to some extent to the schedule of redemptions.

If the British "get Hitler on the run" he will renew his assault an England, using bacteriological warfare and several new methods of destruction, it was predicted yesterday by A. Beverly Baxter, a member of the British Parliament who arrived at La Guardia Fileld aboard the Yankee Clipper from Lisbon.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 -- The American Legion, average age 48 years, paraded today in memory of the war from which it sprang. For the duration of that parade, the twenty-third annual convention of the Legion forgot about the world conflict that has made it necessary for many sons of Legionnaires also to put on Army and Navy uniforms.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- There are 10,100 food and grocery supermarkets now in business, the rate of growth has not as yet been checked and operators of this new type of retailing must be on the watch for over-expansion and loose business methods during the war period of emergency, John Guernsey, distribution economist of the Department of Commerce, told delegates to the fifth annual convention of the Supermarket Institute today.

A bin making unlawful any discrimination in employment on city contracts because of race, color or creed was introduced in the City Council yesterday by Councilman Anthony J. Digiovanna, Brooklyn Democrat. The proposed local law, which would amend the administrative code, was referred to the Committee on General Welfare.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- William Green, president of the American federation of Labor, appeared before a turbulent session of the convention of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union today and warmly praised the top union officials, who had just been accused by anti-administration delegates of "railroading" the adoption of a set of rules in "undemocratic fashion."

A NOTHER traveling North American author has traveled around the fringes of South America and come home to reveal in book form some of the sights and secrets of that continent. Carl Crow, late of China and the 400,000,000 customers, now urges us to "Meet the South Americans."*

The Newark Bears, junior edition said farm team of the New York Yankees, will clash with the Montreal Royals at Ruppert Stadium in Newark tonight, in the opening game of the final Governors' Cup series, the International League play-offs.

Today's openings: "Our Wife," a marital comedy starring Melvyn Douglas, Ruth Hussey and Ellen Drew, with Charles Coburn and John Hubbard, at the Paramount; "Dr. Kildare's Wedding Day," featuring Lew Ayres, Lionel Barrymore, Laraine Day and Richard (Red) Skelton, at Loew's Criterion.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 16 -- Jim Crowley sent his Fordham football squad through morning and afternoon drills today at the Rams' Keyser Island retreat in Long Island Sound, where the team is staying for three days. An hour long scrimmage, in which a tentative first-string eleven worked on the attack against the scrubs, brought the day's practice to a close.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Tigers made their blows count for runs as they defeated the Senators by 4 to 2 today behind the effective hurling of Schoolboy Rowe and Buck Newsom.

An informal campaign was bagun yesterday by members of the Park Association of New York City to call the city's attention to the need for acquiring land around historic Conference House at the southern tip of Staten Island, where the final statement of determination to secure their independence was made by the American Colonies to the British.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- With the prices of basic agricultural commodities increased by 50 per cent since the outbreak of the war, both the Government and the food industry should be seriously worried at the prospect of continued and possible inflationary increases in the prices of these products, Dr. A.C. Hoffman of the Office of Price Administration told members of the Super Market Institute here today.

In the $3,553,000,000 Defense Tax Bill which now goes to the President there is ground for satisfaction. It is by far the heaviest and most broadly based tax levy ever adopted by this country, yet there can be little question that it meets with wide public approval. In the five months during which the bill was being shaped, public discussion showed a wide and progressive understanding of the problem of defense financing.

On recommendation of the reorganization managers, trustees of the Erie Railroad have decided to throw open to competitive bidding the proposed issue of $18,000,000 of the system's Ohio Division bonds, it was learned yesterday.

Five members of the Interstate Sepitation Commission from Connecticut joined officially yesterday In a tripartite compact with representatives of New York and New Jersey to continue "the control of future pollution and the abatement of existing pollution in the tidal and coastal waters" of the metropolitan area bounded by the three States.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Edward Washer, 35, amateur art collector who does research for the WPA, was told today that a painting he purchased for $25, which he had to borrow because he was out of a job, is a valuable work.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Russian parachute troops and strong mechanized forces occupied the strategic outskirts of Teheran today, and both Russian and British staff officers entered the capital to forestall any friction with the Iranians.

Although Axis planes have bombed Cairo, holy city of the Moslem world, it is as unlikely as it is unthinkable that the British, or for that matter the Russians, will be led into the error of bombing Rome. Even from a purely material standpoint, Great Britain has everything to lose and nothing to gain by adopting Nazi tactics for the purpose of avenging an act of barbarism against the holy city of the Moslems.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The death of Alanson B. Houghton, former Ambassador to Berlin and London, deprives us of a really great American and one of the wisest and most farsighted statesmen I have ever encountered in my four decades of dealing with public men here and abroad.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 16 (delayed) -- Bulgaria in a formal note has requested permission for eight Bulgarian destroyers, a submarine, three E-boats and a torpedo boat to pass through the Dardanelles into the Black Sea, it was revealed tonight.

Fall fashions shown yesterday at John Wanamaker indicate that smart sports ensembles will blend as one right down to the gay shades of new lisle hose. After the games, it is indicated, bright contrasts became the mode for afternoon street wear and evening returns to matching colors with peplums and slit skirts dominating fashionable models.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Unseeded George Richards of Montebello, Calif., eliminated Hal Surface of Kansas City, 6 -- 1, 8 -- 10, 9 -- 7, in a singles match that lasted 2 hours 20 minutes today in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament. Richards, who defeated Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., yesterday, staved off three match points in the deciding set to enter the semifinal round opposite Frank Kovacs.

Professor Alvin H. Hansen of Harvard University, consultant of the Federal Reserve System, and Professor Luther H. Gulick of Columbia University, consultant of the National Resources Planning Board, will leave on the Atlantic Clipper today to attend the International Conference on Science and the World Order in London from Sept. 26 to 28.
LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The British Air Ministry today issued the following:

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Frank R. Ryan of the home club set the pace in the opening round of the annual 36-hole senior championship of the Long Island Golf Association with a 37, 38 -- 75 at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

After a primary there is always sorrowful surprise at the "light vote." What would be surprising is a heavy vote. The unfortunate fact is that most people are too lazy to vote at two elections. So the September rehearsal is always thinly attended. A temperature of 87 Tuesday was no additional inducement.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 17 -- Bulgarian mobilization is being accelerated and army manoeuvres will start shortly in Eastern Bulgaria, with 350,000 to 400,000 men under arms, it was reported by foreign military sources here this evening.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 17 -- Thirty-one Swedish sailors lost their lives, twelve were injured and three destroyers went to the bottom at 9:45 A.M. today in the worst catastrophe in the history of the Swedish Fleet. The explosion, the cause of which has not yet been determined, started aboard the destroyer Goeteborg, lying in Haorsfjaerdens Naval Yard in the Stockholm Archipelago.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon's generosity with bases on balls and a two-run error by Sam Chapman gave the Tigers a 3-to-2 victory over the Athletics today. The defeat was the fifth in a row for the Mackmen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The War Department announced that it had awarded contracts totaling $150,242,213 today. These included a contract to the Vega Aircraft Company of Burbank, Calif., for airplanes and equipment to the value of $147,790,500.

Columbia's football squad took the measure of Manhattan yesterday, scoring four touchdowns to the Green's two in the second informal scrimmage of the year at Baker Field. The Lion varsity tallied twice against Coach Herb Kopf's first-stringers in the first twenty minutes and in the closing minutes of the three-hour duel pushed another score across, while the seconds got one touchdown.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Founded under an umbrella, The Yale Review will celebrate its thirtieth birthday tomorrow. Its founder, editor for the first quarter century and its all-time guiding spirit, former Governor Wilbur Lucius Cross, writes in its celebration issue:

ROME, Sept. 17 -- With cold weather approaching on the Eastern Front, the press today publishes editorials purporting to reassure the Italians that operations of the Axis forces against Russia will suffer no slackening because of the forthcoming snow and freezing temperatures.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 17 -- Holding that "our present national objective is the defeat of Hitler and what he stands for," the American Legion convention today gave wholehearted support to the Roosevelt foreign policy, even to the extent of beating down a determined effort from the floor to put through a resolution opposing aid to Soviet Russia.

"Hellzapoppin" plays its 1,292 performance tonight, thereby passing the Broadway long-run record of "Lightnin'" and becoming runner-up to "Tobacco Road" and "Abie's Irish Rose." On Monday the revue begins "its fourth year on Broadway.

Mayor La Guardia's victory over John R. Davies for the Republican nomination for Mayor in Tuesday's primary election found his leading supporters yesterday publicly jubilant but privately somewhat apprehensive because of the smallness of the vote.

The conferring of fifteen honorary degrees by Fordham University and the dedication of its future efforts to a restoration of old wisdom as well as to increasing knowledge marked the close yesterday of three days of exercises celebrating the centenary of the largest Catholic university in the United States and the largest Jesuit university in the world.

Formal interpretation of Section 43 of the Uniform Practice Code of the National Association of Securities Dealers, dealing with "when, as and if issued" trading in the securities of railroad companies under reorganization plans, was made public yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia said yesterday, after his victory over John R. Davies in the Republican primary, by a margin of 19,820 votes, that he would conduct an active campaign for re-election.

Another New York Curb membership was marked for retirement yesterday, when the board of governors authorized the Exchange to buy the seat of Luis J. Francke Jr. for $1,000, effective after notice has been posted seven days. The present market for Curb seats is $1,000 bid (by the Exchange) and $1,400 asked.

Following the current movement uptown of many old-time jewelry and diamond firms long-established in the Maiden Lane district, the Diamond Dealers Club, Inc., an association of 500 members whose functions and purposes are similar to those of the stock exchanges, has taken an entire floor in 36-38 West Forty-seventh Street for its new headquarters.

In an address delivered at the opening exercises of Cornell University Medical College, Dr. Samuel Z. Levine stressed the social responsibilities of the physician. There is no doubt that our medical schools stand high and that in them the best instruction in the world is now given in various branches of medicine.

One of the chief assets of the Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading on advertisers and agencies is a gradual change in the type of national copy being run in papers, it was pointed out yesterday by agency men. While the trend is not too obvious as yet, an effort is being made to develop a newsy type of ad with both price and place of purchase indicated.

A heavy volume of trading was reported in the Bronx yesterday, when a number of small apartments and other residential properties went into new hands. The upper part of the borough figured largely in the activity.

Officials of sixteen local housing authorities were hi the market yesterday for long-term funds and made awards of 4,549,000 of Series A bonds. Except for a few of the smaller liens, the bonds are to mature serially from April 1, 1942 to 1961.

TOKTO, Sept. 17 -- Orders to the United States Navy to shoot on sight in defensive waters and the American move to increase arms shipments across the Pacific are treated in Japan with the utmost reticence so far. The general tenor is illustrated by an editorial in Asahi which says:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 17 -- Raul Damonte Taborda, president of the Chamber Investigating Committee, at today's session of the Chamber of Deputies, dared German Ambassador Edmund von Thermann to challenge him to a duel if he considered himself insulted by the committee's denunciation of his conduct as Ambassador and as, at the same time, leader of the German penetration in Argentina.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The power to decide whether there be war or peace is not vested primarily or exclusively in Congress, but chiefly in the enemy, and next to the enemy in the President as the Chief Executive and as Commander of our Army and Navy as head of foreign relations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, today revoked a price-ceiling schedule on anthracite coal after conferring with leading Pennsylvania hard-coal producers who had ignored his order of last Friday forbidding a 15-cent-a-ton increase which became effective Monday.

An investor has bought from Henry Goelet, operator, the twelve-story loft building on a plot 50 by 110 feet at 30-2 West Fifteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. There are fourteen lofts and one store in the building, which is assessed at $150,000.

African and other business interests in this country have requested the government of the Union of South Africa to delay the imposition of its new import restrictions to permit shippers and shipping lines to adjust their affairs to the new situation, it was disclosed here yesterday.

VICHY, France, Sept. 17 -- Further economic accords are expected to result from the conference of twenty-five presidents of chambers of commerce in France and Germany that opened in Paris last Monday and will continue until next Thursday.

The Yankees took their last look at a Western club this year yesterday unless -- if you will pardon so heretical a thought -- they tangle with the Cardinals in the world series. They grazed at the White Sox and promptly flattened them at the Stadium, 5 to 3.

TRENTON, Sept. 17 -- Verbal clashes between Roger Hinds, chief of the Governor's staff investigating the New Jersey Highway Department, and Benjamin C. Van Tine, head of the department's legal staff, marked today's hearing on the department's dealings with the Lincoln Oil Company of Paulsboro.

The United States Maritime Commission has notified the Seafarers International Union and shipowners whose vessels are involved in a strike called last Saturday by the union that unless arbitration proceeding's are begun today the ships will be requisitioned and placed under government operation.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Tommy Goodwin, one of the leading amateurs of the district, closed the Metropolitan Golf Association seeason of one-day tournaments today by capturing the low gross honors with a sparkling par 71 over the Woodway Country Club course.

The Socohy Vacuum Oil Company has purchased from the Neipp estate the property on the northeast corner of Sunrise Highway and Morris Avenue, Rockville Centre, Nassau County, and will erect a large gasoline service station.
MANILA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Japanese control of French Indo-China has reached a point where the French colony is well on the "road to becoming a Japanese preserve, according to travelers arriving here.

WASHINGTON, sept, 17 (AP) -- Counsel for the Interstate Commerce Commission contended today that "misleading statements of fact amounting to misrepresentation" were made to the commission in connection with the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company's acquisition of stock control of the Denver Salt Lake Railway.

After threatening to call out all studio bands on the Mutual Broadcasting System network, whose New York outlet is WOR, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, deferred yesterday the strike deadline until 3 P.M. today.

VICHY, France, Sept. 17 -- The German authorities in Paris served notice today that if and when acts of violence continued an increasingly large number of hostages would be executed in reprisal. The notice was placarded on walls and published in newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The radio policies and practices of William Randolph Hearst were explored today by the Federal Communications Commission on the resumption of its investigation of newspaper-owned broadcasting stations, for the purpose of determining whether special policies should be adopted in regard to the ownership and operation of stations by newspapers.

Replying to the address delivered in Chicago Tuesday evening by former President Herbert Hoover, in which he urged that this country adopt a waiting policy and let Hitler Germany destroy itself, Wendell L. Willkie assailed Mr. Hoover's policy as based upon a "wholly unrealistic doctrine" and charged that American isolationism bears a great responsibility for the condition of the world today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 17 -- British, Indian and Russian motorized columns entered the suburbs of Teheran shortly after 1 o'clock this afternoon, according to reports from foreign diplomatic and military sources here, completing the Allied occupation of strategic Iranian cities and bases begun in the early morning of Aug. 25 when the Allied troops crossed the frontiers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Florida Power and Light Company of Miami filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering issue and sale of $45,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1971, $10,000,000 of sinking fund debentures due in 1956 and 140,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

Lashing at "arm-chair technicians who think they know more than the War Department about what needs to be done," Colonel F.J. Pearson of the Army Information Service addressed members of Pro-America at their first luncheon meeting of the season in Town Hall yesterday, "to counteract some of the subversive propaganda being put out by various organizations concerning conditions in Army camps."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- An offer to buy the Phillies was mailed to Gerry Nugent today by Jack Kelly, national director of the Civilian Physical Training Program, on behalf of a syndicate he heads. Nugent is with the Phillies at Cincinnati.

Upsets within Tammany Hall and the American Labor party marked the contests for party positions settled at Tuesday's primary election. In the Republican ranks the incumbents won with ease in the county-wide contest for the Bronx leadership and in three district leadership fights in Manhattan.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Trainer Frank A. Bonsal Jr. stole the spotlight here this warm and humid afternoon. Bonsal showed three winners in the first five races and not one was favored.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, wealthy Summer residents here, reported to the police that jewelry valued at $30,000 was stolen at 4 A.M. today from their shore-front showplace, Nid de Papillon, by a burglar who escaped through a main door.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Oscar Blomquist, missing from N.Y.U.'s training camp the past three weeks, dropped in today, but only to tell Mal Stevens, his coach, that he couldn't stay. This was what Mal had expected right along, so his failure to bid Oscar remain constituted no breach of hospitality.

VTCHY, France, Sept. 17 -- Colonial affairs have been uppermost in Vichy in the past few days as revealed by the visits in rapid succession of General August Nogues, Governor General of Morocco; Admiral Jean Esteva, Resident General of Tunisia; Governor General Pierre Boisson of Dakar and finally, General Henri Dentz, the former High Commissioner of Syria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The National Defense Mediation Board appealed today to strikers to return to their jobs at the Kansas City Power and Light Company. It declared that in a time of national emergency union members were obligated to follow the orderly procedure of the Wagner act in seeking bargaining rights instead of resorting to direct action.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, said today he had asked Larry MacPhail, president of the Brooklyn club, for an explanation of the additional 25-cent charge on strips of world series tickets.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Virtually duplicating his performance of last year, August F. Kammer of Baitusrol came through with a rush on his second round today to apparently retain his New Jersey State seniors' golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, C.I.O., proposed today a plan under which production would be resumed of bituminous in thirty "captive" mines, essential to steel production. However, details of the plan were not made public as coal operators and members of the National Defense Mediation Board studied it.

VICHY, Thursday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The German conquerors last night warned all Parisians that they were liable to be shot as hostages unless attacks on Nazi soldiers ceased, and the police in the occupied zone early today pressed house-to-house searches for hidden arsenals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The $3,553,400,000 Revenue Bill which received the final approval of Congress today will affect, directly or indirectly, virtually every citizen and will bring an estimated 4,930,000 additional persons under the income tax structure by lowering exemptions from $2,000 to $1,500 for married persons and from $800 to $750 for single individuals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Three straight singles in the tenth inning brought the Senators a 9-8 victory over the Browns today. Washington combed, three St. Louis hurlers for 20 blows.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- Postmaster Peter F. Tague of Boston, a former Representative in Congress, died of a heart attack today while attending the annual convention of the National Association of Postmasters at the Statler Hotel. His death occurred just two hours after James W. O'Hare, superintendent of the Belmont branch of the Boston Postoffice, died at his office of a similar ailment.

At exercises opening the second century of the New York University School of Medicine, which was founded in 1841, 200 incoming students heard a warning against the danger of institutionalized medical practice and were told to be wary of "schemes and plans for medical service."

It was a carefully edited collection that Nicole de Paris invited the press to see yesterday morning. She selected some twenty-five gowns out of her well-stocked establishment as representing the highlights of what she considers the trends for the grande dame this season -- in her custom-made department Mme. Nicole does not pretend to cater to the young girl with budget limitations.

OTTAWA, Sept. 17 -- By an Order in Council adopted last night by the Federal Cabinet, strikes in war industries, including defense construction projects, have been outlawed except when a majority of the workers vote in favor of a strike.

Fifty-three per cent of American women expect the most stylish dresses to come from New York, while only 26 per cent give the lead to Hollywood and 14 per cent to Paris, according to a nation-wide survey made for the New York Dress Institute by the J. Walter Thompson Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Vice President Wallace, in his new role of super-defense chief, reported today two steps toward coordinating and amplifying the program of economic warfare against Hitlerism.

Racing at Belmont Park will begin today, with fourteen named for the Fall Highweight Handicap, while that at Aqueduct ended yesterday when three competed in the Stony Brook Claiming Stakes as the Queens County Jockey Club concluded the most successful session in its history.

Pleas for and against further extension of the mortgage moratorium law, which by its terms will expire July 1, 1943, were heard yesterday by the special joint legislative committee on mortgage moratorium, at a public hearing in the Council chamber at City Hall.

Four members of United States armed forces will present a closeup of the defense effort in a book that Lippincott has added to its Fall list. The four contributors to "America's Defense Primer" will portray the roles of the Army, Navy, industry, labor and the plans for civilian defense, Lieut. Col. Robert Ginsburgh, U.S.A.; Major John T. Winterich, U.S.A.; Lieutenant Victor F. Blakeslee, U.S.N., and Lieutenant Hartley E. Howe, U.S.N.R., are the authors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Negotiations are under way for further additions to the aluminum and steel-making capacity of the United States, Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, told a press conference today.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Authorized German military spokesmen tonight predicted spectacular new successes soon by the southern armies of Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt. Unofficial sources followed up with broad hints of a Blitzkrieg tide engulfing whole Soviet armies.
HERSHEY, Pa., Sept 17 -- Pennsylvanians looking back to the good old days need focus no farther back than 1940 in lifting a highball at nightfall to legendary deeds of their football heroes.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Egypt today protested vigorously to Germany and Italy against Monday night's air raid on Cairo.

The government resorted yesterday to the use of motion pictures in open court to buttress its case against Frederick Joubert Duquesne, described as a veteran espionage agent of more than forty years' experience, as the trial of Duquesne and fifteen others accused of espionage continued before Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

New York City was proclaimed the men's wear style center of the world yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. Speaking to an audience of about 600 men's wear merchants and manufacturers from all sections of the country who were attending a fashion show and merchandising clinic at the Hotel Waldorf - Astoria, the Mayor warned, however, of restrictions on the industry likely to come because of defense priorities.

VINCENNES, Ind., Sept. 17 -- Historic old Vincennes took its place today in the nation's retail merchandise world with the arrival from New York of Ellis A. Gimbel, son of Adam Gimbel; Bernard F. Gimbel, a grandson, and Bruce Gimbel, a great-grandson.

Last month the number of subcontracts negotiated by the New York office of the Division of Contract Distribution was double that of the previous month, W.O. Crabtree, district manager, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Vacancy surveys now being completed show that in most up-State defense and industrial centers there is an "acute shortage" of homes for workers, and "prompt action is necessary to meet this situation if serious interference with defense production is to be avoided," Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing, reported yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Staging one uprising that produced four runs in the seventh inning and another that settled the issue in the ninth, the Newark Bears conquered the Montreal Royals, 6 -- 5, in the first game of the final round of the International League's Governors' Cup play-offs at Ruppert Stadium tonight.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 17 -- Japan is said to be shipping gold to Thailand for the purchase of rice, rubber, tin and other products. This report conflicts with the recent announcement that Japan had received a large credit and would not ship gold.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 18 -- Following attacks on Karlsruhe and other objectives in Western Germany carried out by aircraft of the Bomber Command Tuesday night, squadrons of Bristol Blenheims, guarded by more than 300 fighter planes, blasted an importan power plant at Mazingarbe near Bethune, France, during daylight yesterday.

Today is the ninetieth anniversary of the birth of THE NEW YORK TIMES, which made its first appearance as a newspaper with three editions -- morning, evening, and weekly -- under the editorship of Henry J. Raymond.

Purveyors of lewd pictures and literature have engaged in a racket to dispose of them at prices from $1 to $5 through young girls at near-by Army camps, it was asserted yesterday in testimony at a General Sessions trial, where Benjamin Babitsky was found guilty of having 15,000 copies of obscene cartoons, pictures and books in his second-hand book store at 75 Third Avenue.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 17 -- Prime Minister Arthur W. Fadden, reviewing the war situation in the House of Representatives today, said Russia's position was serious and that Australia's security was imperiled as never before.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Lieut. Col. Cuthbert P. Newton, Forty-fourth Division chaplain, has been transferred to the station complement of Fort Dix, division headquarters announced today. As ranking chaplain of the post, it is expected that Colonel Newton will become post chaplain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox revealed today that the Navy Department was operating the Kearny, N.J., shipyard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, at least temporarily, in accord with recommendations of the National Defense Mediation Board, under which members of the C.I.O.'s Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers must remain in good standing as a condition of employment.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 -- Adjusting themselves to both the ridiculous and the sublime, the Cardinals annexed a double-header from the Braves at Sportsman's Park today to cut half a game from Brooklyn's lead in the torrid National League pennant fight and advance to within one length of the Dodgers.

Styles as Waste The next time a person is tempted to laugh at the plush albums and scrollwork verandas of the grandfathers, he might bethink himself of what Donald Nelson, Director of Priorities, has just said to the dry goods merchants.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- As viewed from Berlin tonight, the drives of the German forces into Soviet Russia appear to be in acceleration after weeks of arduous fighting in which advances have been slow and costly.

President Roosevelt's radio address announcing orders to the Navy to shoot on sight to protect American defense waters also meant the "elimination of Congress," Senator Charles W. Tobey, isolationist of New Hampshire, declared at a meeting in Carnegie Hall of the America First Committee last night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Continued trimming of dressed pork prices pulled live hog values down as much as 15 cents a hundredweight today while beet cattle turned higher. Spring lambs were weak to 10 cents off.

The New York City nonpartisan committee of the American Federation of Labor, headed by Thomas J. Lyons, president of the State Federation of Labor, announced last night its support of Mayor La Guardia for a third term.

The third annual series of popular-priced symphony concerts by the WPA New York City Symphony Orchestra will be presented by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project, beginning Oct. 19, in Carnegie Hall. This series of Sunday night concerts will be divided into two groups, the first continuing through Dec. 14 and the second running from Jan. 4 through March 13.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 16:

A firmer tone prevailed in the cotton market yesterday and prices registered their first advances since last Friday. After showing gains of as much as $1.35 a bale soon after midday, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange eased in quiet trading and closed at net gains of 16 to 21 points.

The local heat wave yesterday seemed to have affected consumer demand, and fresh meats were hard to move. Steer hinds and ribs were lower, and the lamb market was weak to lower. Fresh pork cuts sold unevenly. Veal hindsaddles were steady, calf and cow beef weak. Demand for kosher meats was good.

MASKINONGE, Quebec, Sept. 17 -- Just to prove that she could be contrary, Dame Nature gave us a taste of weather today that would be the average duck hunter's conception of a perfect day for ducks, then she sent most of the ducks far out on Lac St. Pierre and allowed only an occasional flight to stir the gunner's blood.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 17 -- Emergency crews at the Kansas City Power and Light Company plants maintained essential services today after a surprise strike called by a local of the A.F. of L.'s International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers had darkened this area in a blackout for four hours beginning last midnight.
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) Sept. 17 -- Following some weakness in the early trades, buying reappeared on the Bourse here today, but the close was on an irregular note.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Far more important than consumer shortages in Germany are the signs that wear and tear is not being taken care of in such vital industrial plants as the Krupp Works in Essen, the British Ministry of Economic Warfare announced today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Holding the view that isolationism endangered this country's future, 176 active or emeritus members of the Stanford University faculty issued a statement today supporting "a more dynamic policy of action" as our best protection against the totalitarian menace.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Reds took a twin bill from the Phillies today. A hit batsman with the bases full decided the second game, 3 to 2, after Johnny Vander Meer had yielded only three hits and fanned eleven to win, 1 to 0.

After charging that city school officials were engaging in a "witch hunt," Representative Vito Marcantonio, representing a New York City teacher accused of being a Communist, stalked angrily out of a departmental trial at its opening yesterday.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A new world two-heat trotting record for 2-year-old colts traveling over a half-mile track was set in the $2,500 Delaware Gazette event today when Cannon Ball beat the favorite, Colby Hanover, in the opening Grand Circuit feature.

At last the Battle of Paris is being fought. It was not fought on that bleak day in June, 1940, when the German tanks rolled down the Champs Elysees. The French prized their capital so highly that in order to save it from destruction they permitted the conquerors to take it without firing a shot.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Soy beans made a strong start and a weak finish today. A statement by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that the price of cottonseed oil this season might be the highest in twenty years was a factor in inducing buying at the start, but the upturn of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel was lost quickly on scattered liquidation, and hedging pressure appeared.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Red Army troops smashed the German Panzer forces of Col. Gen. Heinz Guderian in the recent fighting near Bryansk, southeast of Smolensk, the Russians reported today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Labor spokesmen started their arguments today for increased pay and vacations with pay for members of the fourteen non - operating unions. They presented their case to the five members of the Presidential fact-finding commission, headed by Wayne L. Morse, dean of the University of Oregon Law School.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 -- Twenty-eight alleged leaders of Nazi activities in Chile, associated with the Landesgruppen, Blockgruppen and Ortsgruppen, who have been arrested in various cities in a sweeping police campaign, are to be questioned in the inquiry begun five weeks ago in Valdivia under Appeals Court Judge Humberto Mewes, it was announced here today.

THE General's manners, they complained, were "despotic." His judgment, they went on, was "feeble, infirm and full of prejudice." His temper was "irascible and violent." His language was "indecent and abusive." Rather than "reprehending the dissolute and cultivating the meritorious officer, he makes no distinctions but in favor of his tools, spies and toad-eaters."

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- If the Cubs eventually finish ahead of the Giants -- as they well might do since they are now only a half game away from the Giants' fifth-place position -- Vern Olsen ought to rate a bonus from the house of Wrigley.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- With the signing today of Tim Holt, Western actor, for the role of George Amberson Minafer, Orson Welles announced that the long-delayed "The Magnificent Ambersons" will go before the cameras at RKO on Oct. 1.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- Germany's third war Winter will bring with it the rationing of potatoes, the only food product that had not been formally rationed during the first two years of the war and one that has become a mainstay of the German diet.

On the site of Federal Hall, where the Congress of the Confederation authorized the meeting of the Constitutional Convention in 1787 and where, two years later, George Washington took the oath of office as the first President of the Republic, ceremonies were held yesterday commemorating the 154th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution of the United States.

With the traditional rental season in its final fortnight, brokers and agents continue to report a heavy volume of apartment leasing. Agents of several buildings say all past records have been broken by the activity in recent days and that they are rapidly approaching 100 per cent occupancy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Convoying of merchant ships by American war vessels in the "defensive areas" of the oceans deemed necessary to American security was listed today by Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, as being among "all methods" now being used to implement the more aggressive defensive policy recently enunciated by President Roosevelt.

Despite heavy losses in international operations as a result of the war and the preceding period of unsettlement, Sir Douglas Alexander, president of the Singer Manufacturing Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in 140 Broadway that "we have confidence that after the war we shall be confronted with the greatest demand ever experienced; a long-term rise in installment buying of sewing machines is in prospect when peace returns."
The Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union, C.I.O., doesn't want the public to stop patronizing the small independent barber shops, against which the union is conducting a strike in midtown Manhattan.

The one-story blockfront business building at 1213 East New York Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, has been acquired by interests connected with Simon Ackerman Clothes, Inc., through Riker Co., Inc., brokers.
NEW YORK Frank P. Corrigan, United States Ambassador to Venezuela, Mrs. Corrigan and their son, Edward Corrigan, who arrived on the Santa Paula, are at Essex House.

Jules Romains, French novelist and former international president of the writers' organization, P.E.N., issued a statement yesterday declaring that charges made against him at the recent congress of the organization in London were "grotesque."
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 17 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Basic commodity prices have risen 17 per cent in the past year, and the country is now in a stage of "mild inflation," Leon Henderson, director of the Office of Price Administration, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Matching women's par, Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Lakeville won low-gross honors in a Long Island Women's Golf Association one-day tournament with a score of 40, 39 -- 79 on the long and difficult Deepdale course today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- Still sticking to their nerve-jangling habit of doing everything the hard way in the desperate drive for the first Brooklyn pennant in twenty-one years, the Dodgers today blasted their way from apparent defeat to a 6-4 triumph over the Pirate by scoring five times in the ninth inning.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Third Army, Lake Charles, La., Sept. 17 -- The influence of air power upon war again made itself felt today in the greatest manoeuvres in the country's history as parachute troops participated in an American tactical exercise for the first time and bombers of both sides blasted air fields, bridges and highway nets.

The stock market broke out of Its mediocre course yesterday with a bulge not duplicated in almost two months. The rally, all jammed Into the final hour, raised values 1 to 2 points all along the line under the heaviest buying wave since late July.

East Coast Oil Supplies With the heavy gasoline-consuming season nearing its end, indications are that there is little danger of an acute oil shortage developing along the East Coast next Winter, except possibly in heavy fuel oil.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- On the eve of President Roosevelt's expected request to Congress tomorrow for a new appropriation of from $4,000,000,000 to $6,000,000,000 for lease-lend aid to non-Axis allies, the Administration moved today to make up to $100,000,000 cash available to Russia for the purchase of war supplies in this country.

The hats reviewed yesterday afternoon at Mme. Pauline's gave the impression that this expert milliner must have mastered the Oriental's art of wrapping a turban. She has long been wedded to the draped, towering, swathed headgear of the East, and has had a particular knack of adapting it to the Occidental woman's physiognomy.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Red Sox, surging from behind with a two-run ninth-inning rally, extended their victory string to eight straight today as they defeated the Indians and former team-mate Jim Bagby, 3 -- 2.

Now that the wise heads at MGM have promoted Laraine Day to newer and more exacting chores, they have tried to extricate her as gracefully as possible from the clinical duties of the Dr. Kildare series. In "Dr. Kildare's Wedding Day," now at the Criterion, they probably have made the best of a bad job.

You'd think that monstrous wiverns, harpies and cockatrices darkly sprouting from heraldic projections in Old Criminal Court might give a child nightmares, but Charlie Quinlan insisted last night that he raised his whole family in the gloomy old court building and never once heard a child scream.

TRENTON, Sept. 17 -- With the most listless primary election in years now a matter of record, the Democratic and Republican organizations in New Jersey looked forward today to the party conventions next Tuesday, and there was no prospect of a serious disruption of intra-party harmony.

The change of seasons always sets us to looking backward nostalgically, exactly like Mrs. Lot. The other day we got to reminiscing over all the wonderfully good things that have made their appearance on the gastronomical horizon during the Summer -- many of them far too fine to be forgotten as that last rose fades from sight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Final Congressional approval was given today to the greatest tax bill in history, and the measure was sent to the White House with every indication that President Roosevelt would sign it in a day or two.

Credit Collections Up 0.69% Retail credit collections showed an increase of 0.69 per cent in August, according to the twenty-local-store index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 42.09, compared with 41.40 in August, 1940.

ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Police disclosed today that Mrs. Antoinette Farnsworth Drew, 75, an artist whose paintings hang in many galleries, had been bludgeoned to death in her studio apartment in a house owned by her.

Nearly 2,000 marchers, many of them colorfully costumed in native dress to represent nations conquered by Hitler or still struggling in defense of their independence, paraded last night from Madison Square up Broadway to Greeley Square, where they formed in the triangle there a mammoth V, the symbol of victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- An executive order was issued by President Roosevelt today designed to prevent the diversion to the United States of coffee shipped from the producing countries under their quotas for exports to markets outside the United States.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Bob Feller marked up his twenty-fourth victory of the season today, snapping a Red Sox victory string which had run to eight games as his Cleveland Indians battered three Boston pitchers for a 6-1 decision.

TOKYO, Sept. 18 -- The Japanese Foreign Office announced today that, as a result of the sinking of a Korean sailing vessel by Soviet-made floating mines off Nishisuira Promontory on Sept. 1, Japan had filed a categoric protest with the Soviet Government and demanded adequate measures to preserve peace and tranquillity in the Sea of Japan.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The National Contract Hardware Association today urged its members to ask their representatives in Congress for measures to provide materials to the industry.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Russian troops trapped in a ring thrown about Smolensk and the zone east of it are under incessant attack by squadrons of dive bombers, military dispatches reported tonight.

Brooklyn's twin population won recognition yesterday at a fashion show staged by the borough's Oppenheim Collins store. Identical styles were shown in diversified color combinations and many afternoon and dinner frocks varied only in the length of the skirts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- An appeal for prompt termination of House Banking and Currency Committee hearings on the Administration's price-control bill because of the danger to consumers of rapidly rising prices was expressed in committee today by Representative Kopplemann of Connecticut.
VALLEJO, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Army officials expressed keen interest today in a strange-looking, radio-controlled aerial torpedo developed by an engineer at the Mare Island Navy Yard.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn stores showed an increase of 26 per cent during August, while inventories at the end of the month were 25 per cent higher than a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Choice lightweight hogs backed down further today in a steady to 10-cent lower market as light pork loins in the dressed market declined. Heavier hogs and sows held steady again, however.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The House Ways and Means Committee, after originating the largest revenue bill in history, will soon start work on other tax measures.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Four world records were set in today's Grand Circuit harness races, with Spencer Scott, 1940 Hambletonian winner, owned by C. W. Phellis of Greenwich, Conn., clipping two.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 18 -- British official sources announced here today that ten German tanks were captured by Britons and South Africans during last Sunday's foray by two Nazi tank columns in the Egyptian desert. The British reported the loss of one armored car.

THAT Dodger-Cardinal razzle-dazzle race may go right on down to the last out of the National League season, which is not due to come until about dusk on Sept. 28. Nobody can hold his breath that long. A glance over the boxing situation will provide a breathing spell.

Ray Robinson, undefeated Harlem lightweight, will face the sternest test of his career when he tackles Maxie Shapiro, experienced and able warrior from the East Side, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Contracts for the construction of a great pipeline from the oil fields to the East Coast are "signed, sealed and delivered and certainly represent a splendid example of the industry-government cooperation to meet an emergency," Ralph K. Davies, Deputy Petroleum Coordinator, told the annual meeting of the National Petroleum Association today, but lack of the necessary priorities prevents the work from going ahead.

National advertising In newspapers last month was lower than at any time during the depression, while automotive was also below figures of the eleven years, with the exception of August, 1938, an analysis of Media Records figures reveals.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Peace Haven, until recently the retreat at Oakdale, L.I., of the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians, was sold today for $22,000 at a foreclosure auction on the steps of the Suffolk County Court House. Besides the 110-room house, which is said to have cost $2,500,000 to build and furnish, twenty-four acres were included in the sale.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. De Forest Grant have returned to 962 Fifth Avenue from Reverie Cove, their Summer home at Bar Harbor.

TRENTON, Sept. 18 -- Testifying as a witness today in the Gubernatorial investigation of the State Highway Department, Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commander of the Forty-fourth Division at Fort Dix and formerly State Senator from Burlington Comity, declared that the $25,000 paid by the department to the Lincoln Oil Company of Paulsboro, N.J., to settle a damage claim was inadequate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Mass production of a revolutionary type of light ocean freighter driven by a battery of gasoline engines and known as the "Sea Otter" entered the defense program today.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- After making their getaway from German-occupied France, five French youths whose ages range from 16 to 19 completed today a daring trip across the English Channel in two small Canadian canoes and landed safely at Eastbourne, exhausted but little the worse for their experience.

Charging breach of contract, misrepresentation and negligence, thirty-three of the more than 700 passengers who arrived at this port on the Spanish steamer Navemar last Friday filed suit yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to recover a total of $676,500 in damages plus the price paid by each for transportation across the Atlantic Ocean from Spain.

Sun spots and the aurora borealis yesterday and last night played havoc with radio communications, but treated New York and the Eastern Seaboard as far south as Virginia to a display of light unparalleled in recent years.

Another move in this city's campaign to become the fashion center of the world was taken yesterday when the first commercial fashion show was televised at Radio City through the National Broadcasting Company's television station, WNBT.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : It would make for easier understanding if we would qualify inflation whenever the word is used. It is indiscriminately used now to mean five or more different things.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Cirrhosis of the liver and degeneration of the kidney are now being established as deficiency diseases due to the absence of choline, a fat-consuming substance present particularly in the brain and nerve tissue and in the yolks of eggs.

A 22-year-old aerial photographer in the Army air forces took the witness stand yesterday in an effort by the government to link Edmund Carl Heine, former foreign agent for the Ford and Chrysler Motor Companies, with a German spy ring that operated in this country until the arrest of thirty-three suspects last June.

Five sets of books dedicated to "Children in the Courts," each containing 382 volumes designed to be helpful and inspirational to problem children, were dedicated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who had written a letter signed "Fiorello" that brought a $5,000 check from an anonymous philanthropist, making the project possible.

Asserting it to be his duty to continue liberalism in our government and to maintain the Democratic party as the liberal party in American politics, President Roosevelt, in the issue of Collier's appearing today, explained that he had participated directly in the 1938 primaries to check defections among Democrats in Congress that threatened eventually to jeopardize the Administration's whole liberal program.

When Federal insurance of bank deposits was started in 1934 a good many bankers regarded it as a highly dubious experiment, calculated to put a premium on unsound banking. Today the overwhelming majority of bankers approves the operations of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

The American Legion's 1,000,000 members have not been noted for grinding any axe but their own. Drawn impartially from all the various social and economic strata of the nation, they are representative of no particular section, political party or special interest. One thing they have in common -- that nearly a quarter of a century ago they all were their country's uniform.

Paul Bartholet is to resign as vice president and treasurer of the five investment companies in the Tri-Continental group to become executive director of a new permament organization of investment companies, according to an anouncement yesterday by the National Committee of Investment Companies.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- An ominous warning that Russia must have a swift flood-tide of war supplies or face military disaster, and perhaps capitulation, came tonight from a London source in a position to speak with authority.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- News of the reprisal arrests of Chileans in Germany arrived here today almost simultaneously with a cable from Adolf Hitler congratulating President Pedro Agulrre Cerda on Chile's Independence Day.

C. Raymond Everitt of Little, Brown confirmed yesterday the report that Ellery Queen in the future will be published by his concern. The mystery author, who is in reality a writing team composed of Frederic Dannay and Manfred B. Lee, has been published for many years by Stokes, the house recently acquired by the Philadelphia firm of Lippincott.

To Make Most Toy Deliveries While curtailment of output due to metal priorities has developed on some plaything's, most toy deliveries are being made for the forthcoming holiday season, it was reported here yesterday. This month will probably see peak shipments to the stores.

Mrs. Ida N. Pickings, a Baltimore lawyer, who told the Special Sessions clerk her age is "21, plus," entered not-guilty pleas yesterday for her husband, Guy W. Pickings, 42, and herself on charges of desecrating the American flag last Nov. 1 by using it for advertising purposes on their car.

In addition to further price advances and sustained buyer demand, activity in the raw skin branch of the fur industry here was featured by an unusual event yesterday -- both fur auction companies here held sales of the same type of furs on the same day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, established ceiling prices today on by-product foundry coke and by-product furnace coke, effective Oct. 1. He said that quotations were frozen at about the levels now prevailing.

Revision of rayon greige goods ceilings probably will be made in the reasonably near future despite Wednesday's statement by the Office of Price Administration that a rise in yarn prices was not high enough to justify an increase in ceilings. This prediction was made yesterday by greige goods traders who were in close touch with Washington.

TRENTON, Sept.18 (AP) -- A man booked as Victor Pershing Werder, 23 years old, of Deal, N.J., who referred to himself as a suspended member of the German-American Bund, was held today by United States Commissioner Marvin A. Spaulding on a charge of "falsely wearing the uniform of the armed forces of the United States."

Plans are now under way for the building of a high-tension electric power line from Millwood, N.Y., to the Sherman Creek plant of the Consolidated Edison Company at the foot of Dyckman Street, it became known yesterday. The project is intended to make available surplus power from steam-generating plants in this city for defense industries up-State, where a power shortage is threatened.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 18 -- Russian leaders in the Far East are frankly apprehensive of an invasion by Japan in event the military situation in Europe should go badly for the Soviet Union, but they are confident they will be able to repel it.
BERLIN, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- An undisclosed number of Chileans have been arrested in Germany in retaliation for the arrest of German residents in Chile, authorized sources disclosed today.

Cotton Export Plan The new plan announced by the Department of Agriculture for the sale of cotton to Canada marks a further entrance of the United States Government into the export markets. In previous export plans for cotton and cereals, the subsidy was paid by the government to the exporters, who could buy the commodities from any source they wished.

Bank transactions for all reporting cities in the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest level since the week ended on March 17, 1937. Excluding New York City, clearings for the remaining twenty-two outside centers were the largest for any week since the period ended on July 3, 1930.

J. Theus Munds, senior partner in the brokerage firm of Munds, Winslow Potter, 40 Wall Street, and society figure here and at Newport, who died on April 18, 1938, left a gross estate of $18,214, his partnership in the brokerage business, which is now being liquidated and the value of which is not yet determined, and general claims against his estate totaling $379,832.

With all the dash and sparkle for which it is noted, Belmont Park opened its Fall meeting yesterday, and in the feature of the day Joseph E. Widener's Roman equaled the track record for six furlongs, as he smashed home first in 1:10 flat despite the top weight of 140 pounds.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 -- America, "at peace technically," actually is fighting a war of production with the greatest industrial army in the world, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told the American Legion Convention today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- An implied threat to call 330,000 soft-coal miners in the Appalachian area out on strike for the second time this year today came from John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, in an effort to put more pressure on operators of "captive" mines to grant the union shop and on Alabama coal operators to advance wages 40 cents a day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A joint management-labor mission from Great Britain had luncheon today with officials of the Office of Production Management and told reporters later that the British people now believe that Germany will not be able to conquer Russia and are anxious to do their bit to relieve pressure on the Russians.
Mayor La Guardia condemned Charles A. Lindbergh's attack on Jews yesterday with the declaration that the Lindbergh statement was "a carbon copy of a Nazi paper."

Officials of North Arlington, N.J., announced yesterday that they will consider tenders on Sept. 26 on an issue of $731,000 of general refunding bonds, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1941, will mature serially on Oct. 1, 1942 to 1959.

Because they were asked about methods of preventing a nosebleed, the round in which Joe Louis knocked out Arturo Godoy and whether it is possible to predetermine the sex of a cat, New York City high school teachers are up in arms and have staged a minor revolt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Federal Communications Commission, which is investigating the press-radio policies and practices of newspaper-owned broadcasting stations, completed today its examination of Hearst Radio, Inc., and began an iquiry into the "general situation" in Kansas City, dealing with the ownership by The Kansas City Star of station WDAF, one of the city's six broadcasting stations.
YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Patrick F. Kenny, a plumbing and general contractor of New York, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 65.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Flames which destroyed four Boston and Maine Railroad freight sheds, forced the evacuation of near-by tenements and finally crept almost to the State Prison walls, were controlled tonight after a two-hour battle by hundreds of fire fighters.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, renewed his efforts yesterday to organize the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the only major non-union band in the country, by ruling that Efrem Zimbalist and Joseph Szigeti, violinists, could not play scheduled dates with the orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- An increase in industrial activity in August and the first part of September with which sales to consumers and an advance in prices more than kept pace was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, 3D ARMY, LAKE CHARLES, Sept. 18 -- The Second and Third Armies of the United States, engaged in the largest manoeuvres in the nation's history, met in headlong collision today as both sides sent tanks, planes and men against the other's lines in a smashing frontal assault.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Iran's new Shah has decided to cede all the possessions of his fabulously rich father as a gift to the nation, the government announced today.

Although both loans and investments of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City showed substantial declines in the week ended on Wednesday, commercial or business loans continued their uninterrupted advance to the highest level recorded in more than ten years.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 19 -- While Russian-German armies are locked in a death struggle in Europe, Far Eastern Soviet armies are closely guarding the Siberian-Manchurian border against any possibility of an attack by Japanese legions, and Soviet naval bases in icy northern seas are being steadily strengthened.

Fashion observers at Belmont Park yesterday had a "double entry" to watch -- the clothes of the smart opening day crowd and those worn by the manikins in a style show put on by the New York Dress Institute and a group of the city's milliners.

There is a close connection between the accelerating drive on the Southern Russian front and the suspended but inevitable battle for the Near East and the great bridgeheads of the Mediterranean. This is the contest underlying all the action in this war like an intermittent but recurrent drumbeat.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

YOSEMITE VALLEY, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Procedure before the Federal administrative tribunals is by no means so complicated as many lawyers apparently believe, Ganson Pursell, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told the State bar of California, meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Roosevelt today asked Congress for an appropriation of $5,985,000,000 with which to finance aid to the non-Axis allies under the lend-lease program through June 30, 1943.

Long Lived Trade Young men starting out in life and looking about for a business with an assured future should try publishing and printing. Out of seventy-five advertisers in the first number of THE NEW YORK TIMES, ninety years ago yesterday, those in existence today are nine, including THE TIMES itself.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- In both the Southern Ukraine and around beleaguered Leningrad the Germans claimed continued successes today. These claims, however, were couched in general terms in the High Command's communique. Other Berlin sources of military information have become silent in the last twenty-four hours, suggesting that another period of reticence relative to the course of operations has been ordered.

Riotous Autumn colors in the gardens of the Turf and Field Club and Autumn-tinted costumes worn by members of society who attended the opening of the fifteen-day Fall race meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon marked this sporting and society fixture as one of the gayest inaugurals in many years.

As the consequences emerge, it becomes increasingly clear that the National Defense Mediation Board made a serious blunder in its decision in the Federal Shipbuilding case. The sole stumbling block to acceptance of the decision by the company was the demand of the board that the management must discharge, regardless of his record, any employe who failed to pay his dues or otherwise to maintain his union membership "in good standing."

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Soviet military dispatches said today that defenders of Leningrad, freshly reinforced with the city's best citizens and soldiers, had driven the Germans back nearly ten miles and recaptured three villages in a series of counter-attacks.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 -- Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York and a former Director of the Budget of the United States, declared today before the convention of the National Association of Life Underwriters in Taft Auditorium here that "the protection we devise for our dependents will prove as fragile as an empty egg-shell unless Hitler is defeated."
Burnham B. Woodford has been appointed general sales manager of the Eisemann Magneto Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 --The Army will begin in three weeks experimental training of its first "infantry air-borne battalion," a complete ground-fighting unit of 500 men who will be carried with all their equipment in transport airplanes.

John S. Fleek, a partner in the investment banking firm of Hayden, Miller Co. of Cleveland, Ohio, has been nominated for the presidency of the Investment Bankers Association of America, it was announced yesterday by Emmett F. Connely of Detroit, president of the association.

Shippers and steamship lines were informed yesterday that the restrictions recently imposed by the South African Government on imports had been eased to mitigate hardships and inconvenience foreseen by the industry here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's lend-lease letter to Speaker Rayburn, together with the text of the budget director's letter on the same subject:

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Wheat showed an easy undertone in early trading today in sympathy with a break in soy beans and scattered liquidation, but later short covering got under way on news that a large new appropriation for lease-lend purposes had been asked of Congress.

A country fair covering three city blocks, with games of skill, fortune-telling and all the trimmings, where customers couldn't even spend the customary "tenth part of a dollar," was open to New Yorkers yesterday. Five hundred children who Have worked throughout the Summer in the Children's Gardens, York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, advanced this as their idea of a real harvest celebration and the way fairs should be held.

With deliveries of cigarettes, cigars, smoking tobacco and candy to thousands of New York stores at a standstill, the State Mediation Board announced last night that it would endeavor to effect an early settlement of a strike of 1,000 A.F. of L. workers in the wholesale candy and tobacco distributing field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced at a press conference today that on Aug. 15 he had granted Soviet Russia an advance of $10,000,000 against future deliveries of Russian gold.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement issued today revealed another record top for notes in circulation of u669,739,000, an increase of u335,000 in the week. Decreases were shown in private deposits and government securities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- With continued broad gains in wholesale markets for domestic agricultural commodities and sharp increases in prices for certain chemicals, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of approximately 900 price series rose 0.7 per cent more in the week ended on Sept. 13.

The United States Government seized three American-flag freighters in Weehawken, N.J., late yesterday afternoon to break a weekold strike called by an American Federation of Labor sea union to enforce its war bonus demands.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Sept. I8 -- President Roosevelt received today from his new Attorney General, Francis Biddle, a virtual carte blanche, from historical and legal points of view, to deal as vigorously and drastically with problems arising from the present world crisis as he believed the situation required.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, established in June, 1937, "for the promotion and encouragement of art and education in art and the enlightenment of the public especially in the field of art," will show this afternoon from 5 to 7 o'clock to those who have recently applied for tickets of admission that part of the Guggenheim collection which is housed in the Guggenheim apartment at the Hotel Plaza.

"Navy Blues," a Warner Brothers musical, featuring Ann Sheridan, Jack Oakie, Martha Raye and Jack Haley, will open this morning at the Strand. Also arriving this morning is the Russian historical drama, "General Suvorov," at the Stanley Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The allocation of $305,000 among eleven organizations engaged largely in aiding the peoples of war-stricken countries in Europe was announced today by the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union at the final session of its convention.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The role assigned to the farmers of the Middle West for achieving "the mightiest farm production effort ever made in the upper Mississippi Valley" was described today by Secretary Wickard.

VICHY, France, Friday, Sept. 19 -- German authorities have ordered a 9 P.M. curfew in Paris as a result of attacks on Nazi military officials in the occupied capital under cover of darkness, the morning newspapers announced today.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., had a consolidated net profit of $1,988,792 in the six months ended on June 30 after interest provision for Federal taxes and other charges, according to the pamphlet report mailed to stockholders yesterday by W.J. Murray Jr., president, which set forth in detail the condition of the business as of July 1, when the company formally emerged from reorganization.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber dismissed yesterday as against the Texas Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Texaco Development Corporation, one part of allegations in a stockholder's derivative action charging "siphoning" of the assets of the Indian Refining Company, which is owned 91 per cent by the Texas Corporation.

Grief-stricken over the report that Dr. Rudolf Hilferding, German Social Democratic Finance Minister in the Stresemann and Mueller Cabinets, had been found hanged in his prison cell in occupied France, his wife, Frau Rose Hilferding, told yesterday the story that lies behind the tragedy of her husband's death.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 -- At Its final session today, the American Legion Convention beat down a resolution that would have called for immediate legislation to conscript capital, labor and industry in time of war or national emergency on the same basis that "fighting man power" is now drafted.

MASKINONGE, Que., Sept. 18 -- You may call the duck a teal or a sarcelle, as they are known up here, but under any name they are hardy birds, for the wind that drove the black ducks out of Lac St. Pierre today left the teal in scattered rafts amid the white-caps, and there they remained.

KANSAS CITY, Friday, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Union electrical workers voted early today to accept their officials' plea to end a strike against the Kansas City Power and Light Company and agreed to return to work at 7 A.M., central time.

Formation of the National Beauty Products Association, a trade group comprising about 200 beauty and barber shop equipment and supply manufacturers, was announced last night following a meeting at the Hotel Commodore, where the producers are exhibiting in connection with the annual convention of the Beauty and Barber Shop Supply Institute.

Asserting that the word "attack" should be substituted for "defense" in American thinking, Marshall Field declared yesterday that he did not know what was going to happen to his money in the emergency ahead, "and I don't give a damn."
LONDON, Friday, Sept. 19 -- Powerful new blows against Nazi shipping and objectives on land in the Royal Air Force's continuing offensive were reported by the Air Ministry early today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Oliver Lyttleton, recently appointed British Minister of State and sent to Cairo to deal with all political problems in the Near East, is hard at work trying to lay the foundation for the time-honored federation of Arab States that haunted the late Colonel T.E. Lawrence a generation ago.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 18 (AP) -- The French Lick Springs Stables' Briar Rose today won Narragansett Park's featured Walpole Purse, a six-furlong sprint for $2,000 juvenile platers, by four lengths from Mrs. Ed Haughton's Portable.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The "Welles Plan" to cripple the Axis war effort by cornering all strategic war materials in this hemisphere is making excellent progress. This became known tonight when it was learned that the United States had virtually concluded a new war-trade agreement with Peru and had obtained important priorities on several essential metals from Chile, Bolivia and Argentina.

Notables in sports, journalism and business are among the latest renters of apartments. Lists of rentals announced yesterday by brokers and renting agents include the names of many new tenants taking apartments in Manhattan, where most of the activity was on the East Side.

The late rally of Wednesday in prices of shares on the New York Stock Exchange proved to be just a flash in the pan, for yesterday traders who have had to be content with profits seldom larger than fractions, cashed in on the dollar additions.

There is no intention now of sending "Pal Joey" on tour, beginning Sept. 29, as had been announced previously, because the musical has profited from a lower scale since it reopened at the Shubert on Sept. 1. It will remain there until Oct. 11, an order already having been placed for tickets until then.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Department store sales for the week ended Sept. 13 were 8 per cent higher than for the corresponding period of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. For the week ended Sept. 6 sales were up 12 per cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Unless the American Government is to make itself ridiculous or commit one of the most disastrous blunders in years, the negotiations with Japan (if there really are any) should be dropped at once. What earthly sense can there be in negotiations? At the best they can only be futile, at the worst calamitous.

Operators of ocean-going ships under contract to the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F. of L., inforced the union yesterday that because of the uncertain movement of vessels they could not consider the I.L.A. proposal for a forty-hour week.

Joseph Pell Disbrow, operator of the first garage and automobile agency in Jamaica, died Wednesday at his home, 117-09 Eighty-fourth Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens, after an illness of several months. His age was 69.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 18 -- The Newark pitching was remarkably consistent tonight. All of it was bad.

Increased hedging operations resulting from heavy sales of spot cotton in the South and uncertainty over the plan of the Department of Agriculture to sell government-held cotton at a discount for shipment abroad caused yesterday losses in the cotton futures market.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- An astounding piece of pitching by Hugh Casey today led directly to the Dodgers' defeat by the Pirates, 6 -- 5, as well as another violent argument with an umpire and the banishment of Manager Leo Durocher by George Magerkurth.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- An authoritative source said today that reports had been received of an Italian attempt to pass warships through the Turkish-controlled Dardanelles under the Bulgarian flag and that Sir Hughe M. Knatchbull-Hugessen, British Ambassador to Ankara, "probably" had made representations against this proposal to the Turkish Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 13 totaled 913,952 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
