This was 116,212 cars or 14.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, which included a holiday; 109,687 cars or 13.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 113,521 cars, or 14.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 18 -- The popular Dixiana Stable silks of Charles T. Fisher of Detroit were carried to victory for the first time at the Havre de Grace meeting today when Night Glow raced to a hairline triumph in the six-furlong Mount Pleasant Purse, the feature event.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Federal Petroleum Coordinator, reported today that consumption of gasoline on the Atlantic seaboard continues to proceed ahead of new supplies, and asserted that it would be "stupid" to end the gasoline service station 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. closing or to lift the order reducing deliveries to stations by 10 per cent below July levels.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 -- In stentorian tones opportunity called the Cardinals today at Sportsman's Park, but Billy Southworth's gang couldn't hear the call through the clatter of enemy home runs.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 18 -- In view of the presence of German raiders in the Pacific, Australia is keenly concerned over whether President Roosevelt's order to shoot at Nazi surface vessels and aircraft on sight applies to the South Pacific region.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Eleven Belgians have been sentenced to death by a German field court-martial for espionage, printing of pamphlets against Germany and "assisting the enemy," the German-language newspaper Brusseler Zeitung said today.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Because of wartime conditions Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England since 1920, will continue to hold that office despite the fact that on Sept. 6 he was 70 years old, which in recent years has been regarded as the normal retirement age for Bank of England officials.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Pitcher Island was anchored to the bottom of Lake Tiorati in the center of the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park tonight after two days of floating about the mile-long lake, much to the consternation of bass fishermen and passing motorists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture inaugurated today a new export subsidy program on American cotton designed to help make it competitive in the Canadian market with Brazilian cotton.
BERLIN, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The German High Command communique from the Fuehrer's Headquarters said today:

SHANGHAI, Friday, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- At least eight persons were killed and more than eighty-five wounded in widespread terrorist attacks Wednesday, on the eve of the tenth anniversary of the so-called Mukden Incident that was the beginning of the Japanese occupation of Manchuria, the Japanese Domei News Agency reported today.

As a step toward increasing defense production by reducing the number of man days lost through accidents and illness, the National Association of Manufacturers, through its committee on healthful working conditions, has called upon its 8,000 members to make a self-analysis of employe health in their own plants, Ernest Muehleck, committee chairman, announced yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Reds shut the season's book on Philadelphia with a double victory today, 5 to 0 and 9 to 2, and a sweep of the four-game series.

Glad tidings await week-end shoppers. From the butcher they'll hear the cheery news that meat shows a helpful drop in price and at the dairy counter they'll find that butter and eggs have halted their disheartening march into the upper reaches.

Larry MacPhail, up to his elbows in thousands of world series ticket applications, made an impassioned appeal to the press yesterday to co-operate with him in the trials and tribulations that are certain to await him should the Dodgers win the National League pennant.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Offensive action by Britain is urged in an editorial today by The Times of London, which bases its opinion on the present low ebb of German air activity over these islands -- pointing out that the lull is of a most deceptive nature.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Edward J. Brown, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, today telephoned local strike leaders at Kansas City asking them to send back to work the A.F.L. members who walked off their jobs at the Kansas City Power and Light Company plants.

In one of several business leasing transactions in and near Madison Avenue reported yesterday, The Pathe News took an entire floor, with about 30,000 square feet of space, in the Plaza Building, on the east side of the avenue, Fifty-eighth to Fifty-ninth Streets.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Although he slipped to 42, 42 -- 84, twelve strokes over par, in the second round today, Frank R. Ryan of the home club captured the annual senior championship of the Long Island Golf Association with a 75, 84 -- 159 score at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 17:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 -- Delegates seeking to make mandatory a convention of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America every five years were overwhelmingly defeated today, despite their protests that a referendum procedure was largely responsible for failure to convene from 1911 to 1941.
Dr. Charles Fama, member of the Medical Board of the New York City Employes Retirement System, issued a statement last night in reply to District Attorney O'Dwyer's address.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Eddie Albert was signed today by RKO for three pictures, the first of which will be "Hit the Deck," with Lucille Ball, Bert Lahr and Buddy Ebsen. Albert was brought to Hollywood in 1932 by Warners to repeat his stage role as Bing Edwards in "Brother Rat."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Senators defeated St. Louis, 9 to 8, today after halting a four-hit rally that produced a pair of Brown tallies in the ninth.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 18 -- Uncle Sam is going all out to build the finest two-ocean navy that ever rode the seas, and Major Emery E. (Swede) Larsen of the United States Marines has the same idea in mind.

A resolution endorsing Mayor La Guardia for a third term was declared adopted by a voice vote last night at an acrimonious three-hour meeting of the Central Trades and Labor Council, A.F. of L., in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street.
The acceptance speech of District Attorney O'Dwyer of Brooklyn, Democratic nominee for Mayor, follows:

In a speech accepting the Democratic nomination for Mayor, District Attorney William O'Dwyer endorsed last night President Roosevelt's defense policy and the policy of the President and Congress in giving aid to those countries that are resisting Nazi aggression.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Contracts totaling $7,422,493 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- The Soviet Union began assembling its almost illimitable man power today for the creation of the greatest reserve military force in history -- estimated unofficially at not fewer than 25,000,000 men -- while early Autumn fog and rain were declared to be swallowing Germany's last hope of quick and decisive victories.

The trading yesterday was generally slow and draggy on all classes of traefer meats, due in part to the unusually hot weather which had its effect on consumer demand. Steer hind and rib prices were about steady. Pork loins were weak to $1 lower. All other classes of traefer sold mostly steady. The kosher meats opened steady to strong.
ROME, Sept. 19 -- Beginning Oct. 1 restaurants, hotels and boarding houses may serve only standardized and severely restricted meals at fixed prices, it was announced today.

WARWICK, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- The home folk of this Orange County Republican township, many of whom have grown irked by Representative Hamilton Fish's isolationism, reverted tonight to an old-fashioned American custom. They called him home to meet an ardent anti-isolationist in debate in the high school auditorium on the issues of American participation in the war.

Emphasis upon the means of securing prime contracts for small concerns as well as upon methods for arranging subcontracts will toe a feature of the first nation-wide defense production clinic which will open at the Grand Central Palace on Monday in conjunction with the National Defense Exposition, it was announced at the OPM's office here yesterday.

Railroad terminal and local housing authority long-term financing featured the new investment market this week and accounted for most of the total of $21,611,000 in new bonds offered to the public. It marked a substantial increase from the $2,789,987 of bonds marketed last week, which was the smallest volume in more than a year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- A blistering six-under-par 64 gave Slammin' Sammy Snead of Hot Springs, Va., a one-stroke lead on a field of more than sixty of the nation's leading professional and amateur golfers after the first round of the 72-hole $7,500 Henry Hurst invitation tournament over the Torresdale-Frankford course today.

WELLINGTON, Del., Sept. 19 -- Final plans for the movement of 350 men of the 122d Coast Artillery to Trenton for demonstrations at the State Fair next week were completed by Major William J. Cleary of Jersey City, who will be in command.
Mayor La Guardia will supervise the rehearsal of the air-raid demonstration for the Fifth Annual Police Show in Madison Square Garden at 2:30 this afternoon, it was announced yesterday at City Hall.
Apartment buildings in Riverside Drive, West End Avenue and adjacent streets yesterday added many names to their tenant rosters. Four new tenants signed for apartments in the Beresford.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau today issued the following:
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- An authoritative source today quoted a rumor that a German raider had been destroyed in the Pacific after sinking several ships west of the Panama Canal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Roosevelt questioned the legality of the "maintenance of membership" clause recommended by the National Defense Mediation Board in the case of the strikebound Kearny (N.J.) yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company and was assured by the Mediation Board and Robert Watt, general counsel for the NLRB, that it did not conflict with the Wagner Act, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The National Defense Mediation Board won a thirty-day truce today in the "union shop" dispute between the United Mine Workers, C.I.O., and operators of "captive" mines in Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Kentucky, under which 43,000 striking miners will resume Monday "the production of coal indispensable to the national defense program."

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Considerable newspaper space was devoted to National League President Ford Frick's censure of both Cincinnati and Brooklyn for tactics used in last Monday's seventeen-inning game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, announced today plans to link price ceilings on cotton gray goods, combed cotton yarns and carded cotton yarns to the price of spot raw cotton on ten markets, with, automatic adjustments of maximum prices up or down as the price of cotton fluctuates.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, THIRD ARMY, LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 19 -- The Red Second Army, blasted and battered by Blue bombers and ground troops, was retreating precipitously this afternoon as the first phase of the greatest war game in the country's history ended.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported yesterday for the first eight months of 1941 net profit of $5,292,609 after Federal income and excess profits taxes based on the proposed tax legislation for 1941. The profit is equal to $2.81 a share on 1,882,240 common shares, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- The German High Command today recapitulated its casualties in Russia up to the end of August. The total casualties of the German Army, including the Elite Corps and air force, were reported to have been 402,865. Naval casualties were not mentioned.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Douglas Ford of Green Valley, one of the brighter stars of the younger crop of linksmen, and Fred Bohling registered a one-under-par 71 to win medal honors in the qualifying round of the member-guest best-ball tournament at the Plandome Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- With the new $5,985,000,000 lend-lease appropriation due for early consideration by Congress, Administration leaders gave increasing attention today to another important move to implement President Roosevelt's foreign policy, namely, repeal or substantial modification of the remnants of the Neutrality Law.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 19 -- The Bourse developed a quieter tone today although still fluctuating considerably. The close showed some sharp gains. Royal Dutch rose 2 to 316 3/8 and Amsterdam Rubber 5 1/4 to 313 1/4. Amsterdam Trading was steady at 482 1/2, but Philips was 2 1/4 better at 276 3/4.

A reception aboard a Staten Island ferryboat on April 26, 1934, to fifty relatives and friends attending the funeral of Mrs. Alice Claypool Vanderbilt, widow of Cornelius Vanderbilt, cost her estate $78.

Ray Robinson had little more than a brisk workout in his scheduled ten-round bout with Maxie Shapiro of the Bast Side at Madison Square Garden last night. The Harlem Negro, a professional boxer a little less than a year, stopped his veteran opponent in 2:04 of the third round after having had him on the canvas four times.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- One British battleship, two aircraft carriers and four cruisers are among a dozen British vessels named officially by the Navy Department today as being in American ports for repairs or service operations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Secretary Ickes, who said yesterday he would not withdraw gasoline consumption restrictions on the East Coast despite a Senate Committee finding that no shortage exists, today expressed gratification over a reduction of 11.4 per cent in gasoline deliveries to dealers and service stations in the week ending Sept. 12 from the preceding week.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Dr. George D. Stoddard, dean of the Graduate College of the University of Iowa, was named today State Commissioner of Education to succeed Dr. Ernest E. Cole, who will be 70 years old, the age for retirement, on Nov. 18. Dr. Cole, at the request of the Board of Regents, will remain as Commissioner until June 30, 1942.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : For many years THE TIMES has been a great and good friend of the city park system, whose support no park man can fail to acknowledge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Maritime Commission denounced today as an outlaw strike the stoppage of work that prompted it yesterday to take over the ships Alcoa Banner, Alcoa Trader and Alcoa Scout in New York Harbor.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 19 -- The release of enlisted men from the Forty-fourth Division will be speeded up, it was announced today, as a result of an order permitting the discharge of men physically deficient, through a waiver relieving the government of any responsibility.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Reinforcements for the Fourth Armored Division, three officers and thirty-one men, are due to arrive here from Fort Lewis, Wash., on Sept. 30 at 3 P.M. They started over the road across the continent last Wednesday.

The main purpose of the meeting of the President and Winston Churchill was to survey the world situation as it was changed by Russia's entrance into the war. This development brought unexpected reinforcements to the fight against Hitler. It was a free gift of time to gear up the arsenal.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: It's becoming almost humanly impossible to abide that species of humanity known as "Gowanus fanaticus" since the Dodgers have joined the ranks of the nouveaux riches. It is the unhappy lot of us Giant followers to be continually beset by a horde of screeching magpies who are quick to forget the days when the Dodgers were in rags.

The most modern military and noncombatant war equipment, as developed from experiences in Europe, will Be on display in Grand Central Palace at noon today when Mayor La Guardia opens the Civilian and National Defense Exposition.

Fordham, New York University and Manhattan will have 1,000 service men as guests at each of their home football games at the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium this season, the local institutions announced in a joint statement yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- On the ninetieth day of the German Invasion of Russia, the official silence was broken when four communiques issued from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters today reported several vitally important developments on the 1,500-mile Eastern Front.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 18:

The production of aluminum at Massena, N.Y., must be accelerated. Electric power is needed. If Canadian Quebec politics were not what they are, it could be obtained from Quebec's Beauharnois plant; and if our own Administration had not been so insistent on harnessing the St. Lawrence, it could have been developed by 1942 along the Ottawa River.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt, in Rosh ha-Shanah greetings to the Jews of America, issued yesterday through the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, expressed "the confident hope that the temporary darkness which appears to encompass the world shall not extinguish the light of liberty and the blessings of peace and freedom."

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- General liquidation developed in the grain markets today as the result of Bernard M. Baruch coming out strongly against paying farmers more than parity for agricultural products at a hearing before a House committee.

DON'T accept this tale as true. But it could have happened in Brooklyn. Almost anything can happen in Brooklyn. The name of the man who came back with the story will be concealed because, on his own bland statement, he is still a mild mental case. He put the blame on contagion. He attended the Montague Street seance, or Brooklyn conference on the disposal of ticket applications for world series seats at Ebbets Field.

Trade Here Even With Year Ago The pace of retail trade here this week was slower, reflectinug both, warm weather and a reaction after the heavy purchasing during August. Department store volume was estimated as about even with the corresponding week last year, with comment indicating that results today will tell the story of whether a gain or loss for the week is shown.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The recent death of Mickey Welch recalls a game unique in baseball history. It was between the New Yorks and Buffalos. Welch and Jimmy Galvin were the opposing pitchers and the score was New York 24, Buffalo 0.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19 -- The change from a defensive to an offensive psychology among the men and women of Britain is illustrated today in results of a nation-wide sampling of public opinion in the British Isles.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- The International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America adopted a resolution today condemning racketeers, but the convention refused to go on record as barring from office those found guilty of racketeering, embezzlement or larceny of funds.

Just before leaving by airplane for Cleveland, where he addressed the Municipal League of that city, Mayor La Guardia replied yesterday to the charge of District Attorney William O'Dwyer that his administration had been extravagant by saying that whoever supplied Mr. O'Dwyer with his figures didn't know the city government and what it had accomplished.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Exports from the United States in July were valued at $359,000,000, which the Department of Commerce described today as "at a higher level than in June or in the first six months of 1941." Comparisons were difficult because of late receipts of some shipping documents, the Department stated.
CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 19 -- The public and Parliament were stirred today by revelations of a government secret fund to combat "subversive activities" in Australia.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Two American Eagle Squadron pilots destroyed two German Messerschmitt-109 fighter planes in offensive patrols over France today during which German troops and supply trains were strafed and German shipping bombed, the Air Ministry said.

Small declines in number of stockholders are reported by both the United States Steel Corporation and the General Motors Corporation in the third quarter of 1941, but the shrinkages were smaller than the increases in the second quarter as reported by the two companies.

Edmund Carl Heine, suave, glibtongued former foreign manager for the Ford and Chrysler Motor Companies, was pictured yesterday by government witnesses as a professed tyro in aviation, who employed his alleged ignorance about airplanes to advantage in uncovering and transmitting to Germany vital information about American plane manufacture and production.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- President Roosevelt spent most of the day working among his naval books at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here. Aides indicated that he obtained a report from Secretary Hull on Russian reverses.

The American Communications Association, an affiliate of the C. I. O., announced yesterday that its Marine Department, a national organisation of marine radio officers, had opened negotiations with steamship operators for a standard agreement to replace the one expiring at the end of this month.

The American Jewish Committee and the Jewish tabor Committee, in a joint statement made public yesterday, denounced the "un-supported and unsupportable charge impugning the patriotism of Americans of the Jewish faith," contained in the Lindbergh speech in Des Moines on Sept. 11, and declared that "our interests and those of our country are one and indivisable."

A few spots turn up on the sun -- terrific hurricanes of incandescent gas. Bits of electricity flash across an abyss of 93,000,000 miles and strike the earth's upper rarefied air. The sky is aglow with an aurora seen as far south as Virginia. A century ago the phenomenon would have struck the world by its beauty, and men would have gone about their business with nothing but wonder in their hearts.
Herbert Hoover Roosevelt speaking:

JACKSON, Mich., Sept. 19 (AP) -- John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, said here today that the Germans have 300 divisions totaling nine to ten million men under arms and that perhaps 100 of these are yet to be thrown into the battle of Russia.
All cantaloupes are muskmelons but all muskmelons are not cantaloupes. And confusion lies in store for the curious consumer who tries to sift meaning from this devious definition.

Trading on the wholesale meat markets yesterday showed slight Improvement over Thursday. Steer hinds and ribs were steady, lamb steady to strong, veal and calf hind-saddles barely steady. Other classes of traefer meats were steady to firm. The kosher beef market opened steady. Lamb foresaddles were strong to sharply higher.

The stringent wartime economy that forces on every Briton his share of sacrifice forms a rough pattern on which the post-war British economic future may be cut, Charles Morgan, British author, declared here yesterday in an interview.

Farm-paper appropriations will be much larger next year and many advertisers will use this medium, for the first time, according to a survey of advertising agencies just completed by the Agricultural Publishers Association. According to V.F. Hayden, executive secretary of the association, the increased interest in farm publications is due to a combination of many favorable circumstances, not the least of which is the farm price parity law.

Senator Claude Pepper of Florida charged last night that John L. Lewis and Charles A. Lindbergh were representative of a small group of willful men in this country who were seeking to profit from the present critical period and who were "looking forward to the day when out of the nation's misery they can set up their own kind of dictatorship."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, National Civilian Defense Director, tonight called upon Herbert Hoover "to practice what you preach" in advocating exclusion of partisanship from discussions of the nation's foreign policy.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 19 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, attended a C.I.O. meeting incognito last night at Pontiac and went away greatly impressed with "the intelligence and patriotism of American workers."

Robert W. Cyner, 29 years old, of 2553 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, who teaches printing in Junior High School. 171 at 19 East 103d Street in Harlem, broke up a corridor scuffle at 11 A.M. yesterday.

Approximately 350,000 pounds of wastepaper, or 175 tons, have been collected in the city during the first week of the government-sponsored nation-wide drive to reclaim old newspapers and magazines for conversion into corrugated boxes in which to ship defense material, it was announced here yesterday by the committee for the local wastepaper industry, which has headquarters at 17 East Forty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Federal Bureau of Prisons revealed today that Martin Manton, former Federal Court judge in New York, who was sent to prison for judicial corruption, would be released Oct. 13.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho submitted to Congress today a bill to amend the penal code to empower the government to check espionage and foreign propaganda that hitherto did not conflict with the law.

VICHY, France, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Eight alleged Communists accused of terrorism and anti-German "manifestations" were executed in Paris today amid a new outbreak of sabotage in which ten men wrecked several German Army cars in a Paris garage and escaped.

In his speech accepting the Democratic nomination for the Mayoralty, District Attorney O'Dwyer helped to clear the air of false and irrelevant issues. For this he deserves the gratitude of citizens of every party.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Phosphorus, the element that shines in the dark and is therefore named (in Greek) the "light bringer," has come to the fore in modern investigations as the prime generator of energy in living organisms, including man, it was brought out at one of the scientific symposia held here in connection with the fiftieth anniversary celebration of the University of Chicago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Arnold Pressburger, United Artists produced, announced today two new photoplays to follow the current "Shanghai Gesture" on his schedule. They are "Valet-Maitre" and "Lady Paname" by Henri Unsan, the former story being a comedy and the latter a musical drama.
LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 20 -- The British Supply Mission headed by Lord Beaverbrook has left for Moscow, it became known today.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 20 -- The Red Army was reported today fighting desperately to stem a German tide sweeping through the Ukraine, and Russia acknowledged that her troops were hard pressed at Kiev, ancient Ukrainian capital.

The Maritime Commission carried through its threat yesterday to operate strike-bound ships and keep defense cargoes moving by signing on a crew for the loaded freighter Alcoa Banner and placing it aboard preparatory for departure at the earliest possible hour.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Royston Curtis, 7 years old, is a shy boy. Speaking rarely and then only in monosyllables, he is the most silent of the young victims of the Luftwaffe's bombing in a hospital in the Midlands.

Centralia, Ill. A group composed of Blyth Co., Inc., E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and Ballman Main has received the award of an issue of $723,000 of water revenue bonds of Centralia, Ill., on a bid of 100.027 for $183,000 as 3s and $540,000 as 2 1/4 s, or a net interest cost of 2.318.4 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- That battling spirit of the Dodgers, which has been flaming and crackling throughout the most eventful trip ever made by a Brooklyn team, exploded tonight when Manager Leo Durocher punched a, reporter:
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Air Ministry today issued this communique:

MASKINONGE, Que., Sept. 19 -- This is our last day, and in leaving here we will take with us some duck-shooting memories that are equaled only by the early experiences of Barnegat Bay, when the shooting hours were liberal and you could let go at any duck that came along and not be afraid of violating the law.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 19 -- Only a few hours after a hostile demonstration outside the German Embassy that included throwing two small bombs, Captain Fritz Wiedemann left here at 8 A. M. today aboard the Japanese ship Manil Maru en route to the Far East.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Several readers have taken issue with my statement in an article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine last Sunday that President Roosevelt was "more of a reformer" than Winston Churchill. Some cited authorities to prove that the British Prime Minister also is concerned with improving the lot of the common man of Great Britain. I would be the last to deny it.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- Ideologically, politically and economically Manchukuo is rapidly forging ahead of Japan, but needs America's capital and large-scale machinery for her development, Yoshisuke Aikawa, president of the Manchuria Industrial Development Corporation, told the Japanese public today.

Columbia's varsity football team lost a great fullback and the Army Air Corps gained an outstanding prospect as a flier yesterday when Leonard J. Will, one of the finest spin-buckers and all-around backs ever developed by Coach Lou Little, received orders to report for active duty as a flying cadet.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Winthrop Pennock is a civic leader who wants women to stay in their homes and learn to be better mothers and housewives -- and she is a government bureau head who doesn't want to "run" anything.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Testimony by Navy Department officials that a number of spy suspects were radio operators aboard American merchant vessels brought a volley of protests from maritime union spokesmen at a Senate hearing today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- New York City must adopt a more cooperative attitude if it expects Westchester County to build an airport that would be used largely for the air defense of the city and its far-flung watershed, the Westchester Board of Supervisors' committee on airport sites decided at a meeting here this afternoon.

On the basis of what is happening in Canada and England William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, predicted yesterday that "our economy, our industry, our common life are going to be very different, and I think quite completely revolutionized" as a result of the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Passage of a price-control bill is urgently necessary "not only to win the war but also the peace and to protect our people from unnecessary suffering and our American economic system from dissolution," Bernard M. Baruch told the House Banking and Currency Committee today.

Investment Market The market for railroad bonds promises to hold the spotlight in the new-issue market again next week when trustees for the Erie will consider bids on Tuesday for an issue of $18,000,000 of Ohio Division 3 1/4 per cent bonds.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Miss Janet Younker, who held the center of the stage for so many days in the recently played women's national golf championship at Brookline, seems unwilling to rest on her laurels.

Because only 350 women responded to Mayor La Guardia's call last month, a second appeal was made yesterday by the New York City Defense Council for 1,000 women to serve at the secret control center, built by the Army at an undisclosed point In Manhattan, for aerial operations during test manoeuvres from Oct. 9 to 16.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Every organized basic industry in the country and "a few strategically located labor unions" were accused here today by Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, of hampering national defense by restricting production by "some device or other."
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. D. Trowbridge Elliman have arrived from Charleston, S. C. and are at the Black-stone.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- The State Banking Department announced today its approval of an organization certificate of Morgan Cie., Inc., of 25 Wall Street, New York, with a capital of $150,000. An application for permission to open branch offices in Paris and ChatelGuyon, Puy-de-Dome, the latter in unoccupied France, also was granted.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Strong bids for the conformation hunter crown were launched today by the chestnut geldings, Chelsea Ruscus and Jitney Jingle, as the tenth annual Plainfield Horsa Show opened at Brookhollow Farm.

Adverse news from the Russian-German front, coupled with a slump in commodity futures, took its toll in stock prices yesterday and a steady decline prevailed throughout the session on the Stock Exchange. Final quotations were around the low points of the day, with losses fractional in most of the list, although values retreated a point or more in some of the pivotal issues.

Hopes that Charlie Keller, re-doubtable clouter of the Yankees, may get into the world series loomed brighter yesterday than at any time since the husky King Kong went out of action with a painful sprain and chip fracture in his right ankle.
Radio listeners heard some spicy and unscheduled telephone conversations yesterday and the trouble was laid to the current magnetic storm caused by sun spots.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, called upon the American citizenship tonight to take a more forceful interest in the affairs of government, chiefly through influencing Congress to cut non-defense expenditures now and to forego projects which should wait for the post-emergency period to absorb the inevitable unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Maximum prices for all grades of waste paper, effective Oct. 1, in the area east of the Rocky Mountains were established today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, who said that a "seriously disturbed price situation" had developed.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States continued to decline in August, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the bill market. The decline was the fourth consecutive monthly drop.

Twelve years ago Rosalie Stewart took her leave of Broadway after producing James Forbes's "Precious" and settled down on the Coast as an authors' agent. Yesterday Dwight Deere Wiman let it be known that Miss Stewart would be associated with him as co-producer of "Letters to Lucerne."
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The assault on Kiev has cost Germany at least four divisions, including' 30,000 men killed in the Golosoyev Forest alone, according to Soviet estimates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- After three years of transcendent success-the golden era of George-town football -- the Blue and Gray finds itself with only the remnants of the great aggregation that lost one regularly scheduled game in piling up 563 points to 89 for the opposition in twenty-five contests.

SASKATOON, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Dr. J.S. Fulton, director of the animal diseases laboratory at the University of Saskatchewan, announced today that laboratory research had established a definite link between the epidemic of human encephalitis, or sleeping sickness, and equine encephalomyelitis, or horse brain fever.

Should the decision of the board appointed by President Roosevelt to adjudicate the demands of railway unions for higher wages favor the unions, the managements likely will ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for increases in freight rates, Edward W. Scheer, president of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, declared yesterday at its annual meeting in Jersey City.

United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa, who in less than a year has brought about the conviction of Motion-Picture Producer Joseph M. Schenck and the indictment of George E. Browne, movie union president, announced yesterday that he is still investigating the film industry on a broad scale.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is refleeted in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

The semi-annual report of the American Cable and Radio Corporation and subsidiaries, announced yesterday, show net income of $624,127 for the first half of 1941 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, amortization, interest on income debentures and other charges.

Heavy hedging pressure, together with the testimony of Bernard M. Baruch before a House committee that a ceiling on commodity prices was necessary, resulted yesterday in virtually a steady decline in cotton prices. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed only a few points above their low levels for the session and at net losses of 25 to 32 points for the day.

Tomorrow will be observed as a rallying Sunday, marking the beginning of a new church year. Many churches will resume their evening services and the day will mark the resumption of sessions in many Sunday schools. The pastors of the five Collegiate Reformed Churches are among the clergymen to take up their work again tomorrow.

After attempting four days to get a jury to try Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and two co-defendants on a charge of first degree murder, Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor, the prosecution and defense attorneys late yesterday afternoon had one juror selected tentatively when sessions were adjourned until next Wednesday because of the intervening Jewish holy days.

In an attempt to Improve the speech of New York City school children, the Board of Education's speech department will make a survey this term of all pupils in the kindergarten grades, Dr. Letitia E. Raubicheck, director, disclosed yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The German press tonight began a strong editorial campaign against Argentina and said that anti-German agitation in that country could have "a reaction on diplomatic relations" between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., successor to the old partnership of J.P. Morgan Co., cannot serve as indenture trustee for securities underwritten by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., the Securities and Exchange Commission held in an opinion and order issued today.
BERLIN, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following today:

Tomorrow will be observed as a rallying Sunday, marking the beginning of a new church year. Many churches will resume their evening services and the day will mark the resumption of sessions in many Sunday schools. The pastors of the five Collegiate Reformed Churches are among the clergymen to take up their work again tomorrow.

ELLWOOD CITY, Pa., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Less than two hours after three gunmen robbed the First National Bank of Harrisville of nearly $3,350 this afternoon, one of them was slain here and the other two were critically wounded.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A.F.L. machinists reported tonight they had broken off wage negotiations with the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation, and were prepared to strike to enforce their demands.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 (U.P) -- The capture of Poltava, on an airline and only eighty miles from the terminus of the Caucasus oil pipeline, raised a grave threat to Kharkov, Rostov, at the mouth of the Don River, and to the entire Donets industrial basin, an authorized German spokesman said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Round-lot trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 6 amounted to 2,504,760 shares, compared with 2,349,990 the week before, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The "great fire" that destroyed the first of the three structures of Trinity Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street, occurred 165 years ago tomorrow, and the anniversary will be commemorated at the 11 A.M. service in the present edifice, now nearing its century of existence.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Sept. 19 -- New York's 207th. Coast Artillery of Manhattan and the 209th, of Buffalo and Rochester, elements of the 102d Coast Artillery, Brigade, will move out of this anti-aircraft training center Monday for the First Army war games in North Carolina.

An all-out pageant to promote the sale of defense stamps and bonds arose yesterday at 2:45 P.M. from the Sunken Plaza at Rockefeller Center to the view of 750 city onlookers and a coast-to-coast television audience.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Two more world records for the half-mile track were broken in today's Grand Circuit harness race program. Lucy Hanover trotted a mile in 2:05 1/4 to establish a new mark for 3-year-old fillies and Merwynna set a four-heat record for 3-year-olds.
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau said in a communique today:

VICHY, France, Sept. 19 -- Reviewing for the press today the events of the Syrian campaign, General Henri Fernand Dentz, High Commissioner of Syria, paid tribute to the fighting qualities of the Australians.

The new Blood Donor Center of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross was opened for inspection yesterday. The center, a converted six-story private home at 139 East Thirty-sixth Street, donated rent-free by its owner, Miss Susan Pringle, is equipped for making appointments with volunteer donors and for conducting the phlebotomy, which formerly was performed at the Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center.

It will be Whirlaway under 126 pounds, giving fourteen pounds to each of the others against him, in the long mile and five-eighths of the Lawrence Realization today at Belmont Park, where 30,000 persons are likely to turn out for the return of the champion to the metropolitan area.

C.C. Moskowitz, vice president of Loew's, Inc., confirmed a report yesterday that Loew moving picture theatres in Jersey City had been threatened with a boycott by the Hudson County chapter of the America First Committee if they did not stop showing alleged pro-war propaganda movies and newsreels.

FORT DEVENS, Sept. 19 -- The New England war games of the Sixth Army Corps were only a prelude to the real thing in the South, officers have informed their commands as the various units prepare for the long truck-trek.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A plan of priorities to facilitate construction of 200,000 privately financed defense housing units to cost not more than $6,000 or rent for not more than $50 per month was announced today by Donald M. Nelson, OPM Priorities Director, who said that it had been approved by the OPM Council and would become effective Monday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. followed their annual custom of sending an anniversary sale bargain booklet to their mail order customers today, but the range of merchandise featured showed clearly the impact of consumer goods restrictions and priorities on the company's business.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 -- It was said in informed circles here today that Mexico's desire for funds for economic development and the United States' desire to strengthen defenses of the hemisphere had been reconciled by a formula that earmarks approximately half of the United States credits to Mexico for each, of these purposes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- During the last six months the Department of Agriculture has bought from American farmers more than a million tons of concentrated foods for Great Britain.

The Modern Library announced yesterday that it would add four volumes to the series on Oct. 1 -- "The Grapes of Wrath," by John Steinbeck; Plato's "The Republic"; "My War With the United States," by Ludwig Bemelmans, and Van Wyck Brooks's "The Flowering of New England."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Dec. 15 will be a date of great significance to the American people, marking as it does the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Bill of Rights. These ten amendments to the Constitution provide the very cornerstone upon which American principles of freedom, tolerance and equality rest.

Theodore Hoffman, president of the Steuben Society of America, was urged yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, national chairman of the Legion for American Unity, to invite a speaker to present an opposite viewpoint of that of Senator Gerald P. Nye, who is scheduled to address the annual Steuben Day dinner of the organization tonight at the Hotel Biltmore.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 19 -- The imminent rupture of Soviet diplomatic relations with Bulgaria is confidently expected by leading diplomatic sources at Ankara and qualified military experts here foreses an almost immediate German effort to drive Bulgaria into war.

Attended by representatives of nearly 100 stores, the Spring: buying convention of Affiliated Clothiers, Inc., resident office, at the Hotel New Yorker this week, experienced a volume of buying reported as "the greatest in years." The convention, at which about forty men's and boys' wear manufacturers displayed their products, was the thirty-fourth semi-annual session, of the buying organization.

MONTREAL, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals forged a game ahead of the Newark Bears in the final round of the Governors' Cup play-offs tonight by taking the third game of the best-of-seven series, 6 -- 4.

Gasoline stations and garages in New York City that had been facet with the prospect of dry pumps by next week if they were held strictly to their September quotas, which are 15 per cent below July sales, apparently are to be allowed enough supplies by the oil companies to keep them, in some sort of operation until Oct. 1.

BUTCHERS are a gay race of men -- fat, friendly and loquacious. They will discuss with gusto your new Fall hat, the International situation or the Dodgers. Anything, in fact, except meat. And so the young homemaker, eager for information about her marketing problems, leaves her favorite meat counter amid a burst of cheerful witticisms, no wiser than when she arrived.

OTTAWA, Sept. 20 -- With the active aid of the United States Government and over the opposition of Customs and Foreign Exchange Control Board officers here, "Bull" Fielding, a well-known character in Windsor, Ont., has succeeded in obtaining permission to import slot-machine devices, the duties on which amount to about $11,000.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 20 -- For many years before the war the idea of a northern federation or union was vigorously championed in various Scandinavian circles. Despite political differences and certain economic incompatibility there was naturally a profound feeling of unity, a unity created by common cultural inheritances; a similar social order and similar sympathies and antipathies.

The 166-year-old Dutch-Colonial cottage known as the "Jesse Cook House" at Durham Center, the picturesque Connecticut Valley village which held its tercentenary celebration several years ago, has been chosen by the Williams-Harter Corporation, as the second of a series of early American dwellings to be re-created at New Salem, Port Washington Boulevard and Hawthorne Road, Port Washington, L.I.

JOSEPH WITTLIN, whose "Saga of the Patient Foot-soldier" has been named by the Polish P.E.N. Club as its candidate for the Nobel Prize, was born in Dmitrov, Poland, on Aug. 17, 1896, where his family had lived for generations.

DOWN in Greenwich Village's Commerce Street, Al Casazza, the groceryman, and Mr. Brown, the locality mayor, stood aghast the other night. CALIFORNIANS, during the summertime, devise numerous festivals of one kind or another, but the one that took place out In the San Joactuin Valley last Labor Day was something new. As a matter of fact, Californians were not responsible for it at all; the "Okies" and the "Arkies" thought it up.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Sept. 20 -- Major Edward S. Shattuck of Washington, counsel for the Selective Service Administration, told members of the State Bar of California at their annual convention today that it might be almost time to alter what he termed the "liberal policy" of draft boards in favor of registrants.

With only a partial representation of the blue ribbon foot racers on hand, it remained for the towering men of muscle to provide the most noteworthy results in the annual Fall handicap track and field meet of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island yesterday.

Share trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was dull and directionless. Closing prices in a market which traded 251,430 shares were fractionally lower and the tone was moderately easier than on Friday. Of the 542 issues traded, 301 fell, 88 rose and 153 were unchanged.

A special preview opening of the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for the Autumn and Winter season will take place on the night of Oct. 8 with a benefit party for the Musicians Emergency Fund, which for several years has been the beneficiary of the opening celebrations in both the Iridium Room and the Viennese Roof.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Representatives from more than 300 colleges, universities, learned societies and other institutions have accepted invitations to participate in the celebration of the 175th anniversary of Rutgers University, to be held on Oct. 9, 10 and 11.
Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5702, will be ushered in today at sunset with religious services in synagogues and temples in all parts of the world where freedom of religion still prevails.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (A.P.) -- Livestock prices were steady today alter a week of downward drift that was checked principally by a curtailment of receipts. Stockmen attributed the market's weakness principally to sluggishness in the wholesale dressed meat trade, which may be a reflection of some backing away of consumers.
Foreclosures on properties held by the Home Owners Loan Corporation have reached a new low point in a downward trend that has prevailed since September, 1940.

Club women, enthusiastic about the interest shown in flower arrangement in recent years, invite tie women of their communities to enter arrangements in local flower shows, even though they may be inexperienced at the art. But of the many who make this brave effort, only a small minority attract favorable attention front the highly critical out-of-town judges.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- Until a Spell of wildness overcame Charley Wagner in the eighth inning today the Yankees and Red Sox had quite a struggle at Fenway Park before 12,014 fans. When the next-to-last stanza started the McCarthymen were in front by 2 -- 1.

Defense material rationing may affect half of the nation's manufacturers, some even "fatally," with hundreds of thousands of persons thrown out of work as a result, Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, predicted yesterday.

NOW is a good season to witness that modest wonder of the heavens -- the Milky Way. Modest -- for although at this time of year the Milky Way is the outstanding feature of the sky, it is not easy for city people to see. Neon lights, incandescent lamps, the beam of a passing automobile: any of these can blind our eyes to the faint light of the Milky Way.

This year marks the twenty-fifth, anniversary of the Child Education Foundation, 535 East Eighty-fourth Street, which fulfills the four-fold purpose of training nursery school and primary grade teachers, maintaining a nursery school of its own, assisting in the establishment of similar schools throughout the country and guiding parents with their problems through a Parents' Forum.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- Robert (Bobby) Crawford, business manager for Al Jolson, producer and former millionaire music publisher widely known in theatrical and song writing circles, died today of a heart attack at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The following Foreign Service changes since Sept. 13 were announced today by the State Department: Baynard B. Barnes of Vinton, Iowa, now serving in the Dept. of State, designated First Secretary of the Legation and Consul at Reykjavik Iceland.

The transition taking place in the method of distributing new securities is unprecedented in financial history, both in speed and extent. The traditional method of banker-borrower negotiation in security underwriting is being abandoned in favor of the new procedure (in corporate financing) of opening the field to all comers -- competitive bidding.

SWEET BRIAR, Va., Sept. 20 -- Nearly a third of the students returning to Sweet Briar College this year have elected for study courses pertaining to national defense. Sophomores, juniors and seniors have registered for the four new courses offered for the 1941-42 session, designed to clarify for them the present world situation.

Sex Changed to Order C. Donnell Turner, research endocrinologist at Northwestern University, finds that permanent alterations of sex in rats may be produced simply by an overdose of estrogen (female sex hormone).
MR. KOOTZ, while not pulling his punches, is doing a bit of shadow boxing. His statements are partly correct, but his emphases are muddled and his conclusions faulty.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Schooled in the tradition of the horse and taught to sit in a basket saddle as soon as the highchair, children of society in the North Shore estates have, this season, developed their interest and knowledge of the pony and horsemanship to a point where they are giving their own horse shows.

To encourage additional housing facilities for defense workers the FHA announced yesterday a reduction in the maximum financing charge on loans it insures above $2,500 for the remodeling of homes designed for more than one family.

One of the hostages shot by the Germans in Paris last week was a youth of 19. Another was a man of 72. So far at least twenty-five hostages have been slaughtered in Paris. None of them was guilty of any crime. None was accused of a crime. None was tried by any process of law, not even by a court-martial.

A RECENT ruling of the United States Golf Association to limit the distance-carrying feature of golf balls is expected to go far toward standardizing the ancient Scottish game as played in the United States.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The Royal Air Force swung into one of its biggest daylight operations since the war began today when squadrons of bombers, many of them protected by clouds of fighters, attacked the enemy in Norway, Germany, the Netherlands and France.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 -- Arabic peoples regard three British statements of the past three months as not only unequivocal official declarations that guarantee Arab independence but also as foundation stones for Arabian unity.

BY way of footnote to Mr. Strunsky's review of "The Democratic Spirit" on the front page of this issue the occupant of this corner is prompted to quote from Bernard Smith's introduction to the excellent and timely volume he has edited.

The college football season, which opened without fanfare yesterday, will get under way in full fury during the coming week-end with major games from coast to coast. A remarkably, fine card is scheduled for the first big day of the campaign despite the absence of such top-flight teams as Army, Columbia.

There is always the chance, of course, that they are either too busy in their own field, as Mr. Evans is at the moment with his "Macbeth," or that perhaps they just wouldn't be interested.

A article by Winthrop Sargent in The American Mercury entitled "The Sterility of Modern Music," is worth reading. It is shrewdly reasoned and is highly suggestive in its analysis of the influences which have affected musical composition in the Immediate past and its possible future course.

At this season householders are discovering-some with pleasure and some with dismay -- that there is a cricket on the hearth, or somewhere near it.

On the sunny afternoon of last March 11, in Washington, D.C., a courier carrying a leather brief case arrived at the White House after a hurried trip from the Capitol. He hastened to a desk in the Executive mansion at which the President waited. "While cameras recorded the scene, the nation's leader received and signed "an act to promote the defense of the United States."

As a belated birthday present for Queen Elizabeth of England, a hand-made afghan fashioned by Mrs. Mary Whiteford of 777 Avenue E, Bayonne, N.J., president of the Bundles for Britain branch in the New Jersey community, will be flown across the Atlantic aboard the Pan American Airways' Dixie Clipper next Thursday morning.

THE United States Navy is at war. From the northern latitudes of the Western Ocean, where the pack ice presses around the Greenland fjords, to the doldrums, where the burning sun makes the pitch bubble in the teak deck seams; from the China Coast to the Golden Gate, the Navy has assumed new and world-wide obligations.

"General Apathy," pictured in old-time political cartoons as a somnolent person in a shabby uniform, seems to be the chief enemy that Mayor La Guardia will have to face in his campaign for re-election to a third term.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 20 -- The warlike Southwest has been sobered by the entry of the United States into what most of its residents consider a shooting war, but has not changed one whit its desire to have this nation go the limit in overcoming the Axis powers.

While many Long Island builders and developers admit that difficulty is being experienced in obtaining necessary materials for construction and home equipment, a number of operators prepared for the emergency several months ago and new work in many localities is continuing at a reasonable volume.

THE season opens with a fanfare tomorrow evening when the Jooss Ballet begins its first New York engagement in three years at the Maxine Elliott Theatre. During its first week it will present two programs, the first one consisting of the pick of its old familiar repertoire, and the second, of two works new to Broadway.

SIX new lines of Buick motor cars covering a wide price range from the lower to the upper medium brackets, and embodying outstanding mechanical as well as appearance improvements, are announced today by the Buick Division of General Motors Corporation.

The recommendation of a special Senate committee that the Federal old-age insurance program be revised to provide a minimum pension of $30 a month for all persons over 60 was denounced yesterday by the American Association for Social Security as a "reckless proposal which for brazen irresponsibility and shameless disregard for the welfare of the nation and the aged will remain unparalleled for many years."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Slammin" Sam Snead, first-round leader in the $7,500 Hurst invitation golf tournament, blew him self to a four-over-par 74 today to slip into a three-way tie at 138 with two Ohioans -- Billy Burke of Cleveland and Tony Penna of Dayton -- at the thirty-six-hole halfway mark.

HOLLYWOOD. "WILL any one who has had any circus experience please see Walt?" That particular question, posted on the Walt Disney studio bulletin board some months ago, brought forth a miscellaneous assortment of Disney-ites who (1) had once been in a circus (2), who wanted to work in a circus if Disney was going to start one (3), who came in to see what all the excitement was about.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity recovered somewhat during the week ended Sept. 13 from the previous holiday week, but was still below the week ended Aug. 30. It stood at 130.2 for the week ended Sept. 13, compared with 129.3 for the week ended Sept. 6, 130.5 for the week ended Aug. 30 and 110.6 for the week ended Sept 14, 1940.

At its national convention in Detroit last month, the American Federation of Teachers recognized two new locals in this city, one in the college and the other in the public school field. LAST May the National Gallery at Washington held its first loan exhibition; an exhibition made up of 200 water-colors that are ultimately to be placed in rooms and wards of the United States Marine Hospital at Carville, La.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Douglas of White Oak Shade Road, this community, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mercier Douglas, to Ensign Sheldon H. Kinney, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Sheldon Kinney of Pasadena, Calif.

BUFFALO, Sept. 20 -- In an effort to meet specific nursing needs brought to the forefront by the national defense program, the School of Nursing of the University of Buffalo this year will place special emphasis on three courses newly accredited -- public health nursing, physical therapy and school nursing. The university will open Monday for its ninety-sixth year.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 20 -- Mort Stuart's Watch Over, a $5,000 selling plater a few months ago, boosted his year's earnings to $14,630 today by winning the $5,000 added James C. Thornton Memorial Handicap at Narragansett Park.

Brooklyn's football Dodgers will start a pennant quest of their own today just as their baseball namesakes are battling feverishly to finish their season successfully. The Brooks, surprisingly strong as was evidenced by their brilliant struggle against the Bears, will face Detroit at Ebbets Field this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock.

One of the most delightful projects of the interior decorator is to recapture the fascination of an old house. Through skill and knowledge the beauty of other days can be made to live again in its pristine quaintness and simplicity. The city dweller with a flair for decoration can now gain ideas for projects of his own by visiting an exhibition of water-color pictures of old-time rooms with their old furnishings intact.

While waiting for a court decision on the question of petitions for county reorganization, the New York City League of Women Voters is wasting no time preparing for its busiest season of the year with pre-election activities. AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) Sept. 20 -- Renewed strength of almost boom proportions ruled throughout the session on the Stock Exchange here today. The buying was engendered principally by expectations of a relaxation of the tension in political affairs in the Far East.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 20 -- A milestone in the history of higher education for women in Rhode Island will be marked this year as Brown University celebrates the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Pembroke College. The celebration will begin on Wednesday with the academic year.

Watriss and his second wife, the late Mrs. Helen Barney Watriss, in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here today.

RANGOON, Sept. 20 -- Chung-king, from where this writer has just come after a five months' stay, is optimistic. Inspite of severe economic difficulties, damaging Japanese air raids, threat of serious monetary inflation and the drain on the energy of the people caused by four years of bitterly hard wartime living, the capital of Free China confidently believes the Chinese position by and large favorable and today looks forward to ultimate victory.

Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, who will see Pope Pius XII tomorrow before leaving Monday for the United States, will take with him an autographed photograph of the Pope bearing a cordial message for the President, it was stated today in well-informed Vatican quarters.
