The annual White Elephant Cocktail Party, an event which for the last few years has proved to be one of the most popular benefit fetes of its kind, will take place this Autumn on the afternoon of Oct. 9 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 20 -- A testimonial dinner, arranged by the up-State Democrats in a manner which indicated a boom for James A. Farley for Governor next year, was turned tonight by Mr. Farley into a rally dedicated to party unity in which the former national chairman gave the strongest support to President Roosevelt and his foreign policy.

With the horse show season now at its peak and early Autumn weather proving conducive to show ring exhibitions, polo matches and race meetings, members of society on the North Shore of Long Island are actively participating in an extensive program of outdoor events of interest to all horse-lovers.

The British passenger liner Madura, carrying sixty-five passengers from Glasgow, arrived at Pier 4, Hoboken, at 5 P.M. yesterday. Two hundred other passengers who made the Atlantic crossing left the ship at a Canadian port.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 (AP) - A United States of Europe was envisaged today as an outcome of the present war by Vaino A. Tanner, Finnish Trade Minister, who is visiting Germany at the invitation of the Reich Government.

WORKS by Mozart, Schubert, Mendelssohn and Dvorak will be presented by the New Friends of Music at its chamber music concerts to be given in two subscription series of eight programs each, this season, in Town Hall.

With October almost here, the interest in shooting has reached its usual fever pitch, and there have been several inquiries for a summary on the New York State hunting seasons with their "do's and don't's," so we'll run right through the list.

CONFISCATION: The property of the House of Orange-Nassau, the royal family headed by exiled Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands, was confiscated last week by German occupation authorities. The Queen had excluded herself from the community of "New Europe," according to the Reich Commissar, by remaining on what was termed the bolshevistic-capitalistic front and by encouraging violence against German forces.

Post-war building in the United States, says the Agricultural Forum magazine in its current issue, must work according to a definite plan. This plan, it is explained, must be broad enough to include the nation, minute enough to cover all its political subdivisions, bold enough to inspire respect and realistic enough to produce action.

MONTREAL, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals moved within one victory of the International League's Governors' Cup tonight with a 5-2 triumph over the pennant-winning Newark Bears behind the seven-hit pitching of 19-year-old Chet Kehn.

Developers in several residential communities in Bergen County, N.J., announce that as a result of the active selling market during the Summer months it has been necessary to open new home site sections for immediate improvement with houses for Fall occupancy.

MUCH has already been written about London, and all Britain, under the bombs; of the Britain of the Summer's terrible and pregnant pause less is known. It is this latter Britain which is here revealed, in insight and integrity, by the author of "The Constant Nymph."

All factions in the C.I.O. will support Philip Murray for re-election as national president, a survey indicated yesterday. Mr. Murray, who has just recovered from a two-month illness, has made no public announcement of his intentions, but persons in his confidence say he will be a candidate to succeed himself at the forthcoming C.I.O. convention.

BALTIMORE lies nearly 200 miles from the ocean, "but it is a salt tide which laves the docks and piers which line its nearly 100 miles of foreshore." It's a salt tide which ebbs and flows through its history from the first tobacco wharves through the great days of those fine-drawn schooners that gave privateering so rich a zest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today criticized the Administration's price-control bill as "sweeping," lacking in administrative standards and having purposes "far beyond accomplishments through price control."
GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 20 -- As has happened in almost every tournament of consequence this year, form today went haywire in the Cedar Creek Club's mixed foursomes event.

News that British fighter planes to as large a number as 300 escorted British bombers in last week's day-light raids on German targets in occupied France indicates a considerable accession to British air strength and perhaps something more. There may conceivably be read into it the possibility that a solution has been found to the long-range fighter problem.

AFTER many years of tentative, inching progress toward the inevitable development of large-scale express and freight shipments by airplanes, it appears likely now that the war may furnish the impetus to carry the plan to fruition.

MYSTIC: A new French language journal appeared last week on New York City's newsstands. The paper, "La Voix de France," expressed a strong anti - Vichy policy. "The flame of French culture," its lead editorial declared, "has not been extinguished, A cloud has passed over it.

SOMETIMES the realistic truth is caught most completely in a romantic scuffle. Take, for example, the case of Frederick Hazlitt Brennan's "The Wookey," which has brought a whiff of London's ordeal into the Plymouth Theatre.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington has accepted its first example of nineteenth century French painting for its permanent collection. It is a canvas by HonorS Daumier, entitled "Advice to a Young Artist," and was presented by Duncan Phillips, director of the Phillips Memorial Gallery in Washington and also a director of the National Gallery.

MR. CLARKE always has the most engagingly different characters in his books, and they are not only different from the people ordinarily met in books, or in real life, for that matter, but they vary pleasantly from one book to another.

PITTSBURGH, Sept 20 (AP) -- A highly touted Duquesne University football eleven, which flashed only moments of the power and deception expected of it, was hard put to win, 14-to-2, today over a game but inexperienced Waynesburg College team.
LOADED with "safety" gadgets devised by well-meaning inventors, a car would look like an overburdened tinker's wagon and would be unsafe as a high school boy's home-built racer.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Asserting problems immediately ahead and confusion during the next few years would exceed in magnitude "the expectations of any of us," Nugent Fallon, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, said today that home owners would have an advantage.

SAN FRANCISCO. AT a bare minimum, 30,000 trained cooks are needed to make the bread, roast the meat, turn out the pies, make the coffee and otherwise provide 1,500,000 men in Uncle Sam's new Army with the most varied and tastiest menus ever placed before any army in the history of the world.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The record tax bill intended to raise $3,553,400,000 to pay part of the cost of the country's vast rearmament and lend-lease programs was signed at 12:15 P.M. Eastern Standard Time today by President Roosevelt in the presence of a few photographers in the study of his Hyde Park home.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept 20 -- Aiming to introduce students not to any specific subject as such, but rather to the humanities in general, previous courses in history and English given in the freshman year will be replaced this semester with a new course, "Introduction to the Humanities," at Stevens Institute of Technology.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Dick Watts raced 63 yards for a touchdown in the final period tonight to help North Carolina State College score a 14-7 victory over Richmond in the first Southern Conference game of the season, played before 12,000 fans.

THE professional football season is getting under way on the stagger plan. The Cleveland Rams and the Pittsburgh Steelers started off ahead, possibly because they were supposed to be a little bit lame and could use a headstart on the big league scrimmaging field.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Negotiations with Japan looking toward a settlement of Japanese-American relations have reached a virtual standstill, although they are being kept open in the hope of effecting an eventual settlement, it was reported on good authority today.

ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The Institute for Economic Education recently established at Bard College, and which is working under a grant from, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, has just gathered the results of a preproduction audience test for a film on Latin America.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, addressing a conference at the Hotel Roosevelt sponsored by the New York Fight for Freedom Committee to Defend America, yesterday criticized former President Herbert Hoover for counseling against full aid to Soviet Russia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Use of radio, sound trucks, posters, newspapers and other publicizing methods for recruiting youths into the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration was forbidden today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: In a letter to the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review on Aug. 31, 1941, Dr. Eugenio Morreale protests against Louis Fischer's assertion in his book "Men and Politics" that he, Morreale, "Mussolini's agent in Vienna," inspired the attack of the Austrian Government on the "beautiful modern apartment house settlements of the Socialist party in Vienna."

In addition to training young men and women for positions in journalism, the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, which maintains the university's journalism department, will this year inaugurate a program of journalism specialization, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. John T. Madden, dean of the school.
NOTWITHSTANDING the war, the U.S.S.R. continues issuing commemorative postal paper. One series in two denominations marks the centenary of the death of Mikhail Yurevich Lermontoff, poet and novelist.
Commodora Chester Beritley's A.P.B.A. "southward Ho" cruise to Miami is taking on a national complexion although it starts at Flushing Bay and was expected to attract New Yorkers mainly.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Seven, hundred persons contributed $2,500 to the Westchester County Children's Association at its benefit field day and pet show this afternoon at Woodlands, the Central Avenue estate of Mrs. Felix Warburg.

The encouragement of private corporations under public supervision to enter into the field of "neighborhood redevelopment" is commended by the Federal Home Loan Bank. Attention is called to the fact that New York, Michigan and Illinois have passed laws permitting such urban improvements upon compliance with certain regulations.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 20 -- It took Stewart Iglehart and Westbury just "a little less than a minute of overtime today to win the opening match of the Monty Waterbury Cup polo tournament, the most important handicap event of the year.

ELIMINATION of harmonics from the gadgets and circuits used to reproduce tone has long been an engineering ideal in broadcasting. Harmonics, to a radio man, means an unwanted something added to the original vibrations of voice or musical instrument, called "distortion."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Food prices and the cost of living have reached their highest point in ten years under the impact of the armament effort, but an accompanying rise in weekly earnings of factory workers has more than kept pace with climbing prices, government economists say.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Numerous officials of this government are beginning to wonder whether, in their recent endeavor to show great progress for the lend-lease program and thus to smooth the legislative ways for a new Allied-aid appropriation, they have not done much to obscure for the American public the real measure of help which the "arsenal of democracy" is giving to the non-Axis front.
BERLIN, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20 -- So bitter is the dispute between leading isolationists and leading interventionists that some political observers have predicted that -- if America is not in a shooting war next Summer -- there may be a full-fledged "Keep - Out - of - War" party, in the Congressional elections, under the direction of men like Charles A. Lindbergh, Senator Wheeler and Senator Nye.

An Important step in contributing to the cleanliness and health-fulness of American cities has just been taken by Pittsburgh, points out Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in the enactment of an ordinance requiring that soft coal be burned with mechanical combustion equipment or that smokeless fuel be used.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Coast Guard Academy's powerful football team routed Rhode Island State today, 38 -- 0, in the opening game for the two institutions. The cadets put the game on ice as early as the first period when they scored three times.

This is a mystery story which sensible parents can safely recommend to 8 to 12 year olds. It is intelligent and deftly knit, as one would expect from the author or authors whose name it bears, and though the tougher-minded of young mystery fans may regret that there is not even a smidgen of gore, there is danger enough and plenty of clues to pique the curiosity.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A qualified source declared today that Russia's situation in the Ukraine was more precarious than ever in the face of German claims of a juncture of Nazi columns behind Kiev, the capture of Poltava far to the southeast and a drive across the Perekop Isthmus to isolate Crimea.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 20 -- "The highest commendation we can make on what we have seen here today is that we are confident for the future," said Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey after a review of the Forty-fourth Division this morning.

With Don Snavely and Ken Germann, varsity center and left halfback respectively, still benched because of injuries, and Len Will gone to join the Army Air Corps, Columbia's football forces had difficulty yesterday in holding a slight edge over Lafayette.

Edward R. Stettmius Jr. will be 41 years old one month from tomorrow. Compressed into this brief span of life has been one of the most improbable careers in the annals of American business and, more recently, of government. Last week, the only one of the dollar-a-year men to whom has been delegated full administrative control over his assigned duties, he rose to a status previously held by only Harry L. Hopkins.

TO THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Hungarian political weekly Az Ember (The Man) has published a letter written by a Hungarian journalist in Budapest which was smuggled out of that country. This letter reveals for the first time the internal chaos, political and economic, which exists in Hungary.

The organization this Fall of twenty-one workshops for teachers by the New York City Board of Education has again focused attention on this plan of teacher education. To the workshops teachers bring problems which have arisen in their regular daily classrooms for group discussion under the leadership of an authority in the field.

Heavy last-minute payments of tax arrears are serving to reduce appreciably the potential offerings of properties in Nassau and Suffolk Counties which might otherwise be placed on the auction block by officials of the two counties.

William T. Fetherston announced yesterday his retirement as Democratic County Chairman in Richmond, a post he has held since 1934. Although Mr. Fetherston's only explanation for his decision not to continue as county leader was that it was for "the best interests of the party," his withdrawal was due to the strong opposition to his leadership made evident in the primary election last Tuesday.

The disinclination of various defense agencies to deal directly with trade association executives in consideration and formulation of various policies as to prices, allocation of materials, etc., was traced last week to the arrangement between the Office of Production Management and the Department of Justice which was worked out to avoid anti-trust prosecution for defense cooperation.

In painting radiators and pipes never before painted it is advised that the surface should first be cleaned thoroughly with wire brushes to remove all traces of rust, dirt and grease. A priming coat of a good red lead should then be applied.

Hazing for the present "freshies" at Hunter College will begin on Monday, Sept. 29, and continue through Friday, Oct. 3, Aline Kaplan, chairman of the Freshman Advisory Committee, announced yesterday. The committee will give a tea for lower freshmen this coming Friday, in preparation for Hazing Week.

THOSE who are familiar with Mrs. Hewes's fine novels for young people, "Swords on the Sea," "The Codfish Musket," and others, know that she is a past master at presenting with drama and vision the influence of trade upon the course of history.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Railroad management was praised today by a spokesman, for railroad labor for its "intelligent leadership" and criticized as "socially backward in the matter of wages."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Science and Society" you ask scientists for their interpretation of what is wrong with science, citing that every advance has been accompanied by abuses.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept 20 -- New England and Midwestern exhibitors garnered the principal awards as the tenth annual two-day Plainfield horse show closed today before a large throng of enthusiastic onlookers at Brookhollow Farm.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: IN THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of Aug. 31 Dr. Eugeaio Morreale takes exception to Louis Fischer's charge -- from the tatter's book "Men and Politics" -- that Dr. Morreale, on behalf of the Italian Government, inspired Dr. Dolfuss's attack of Feb. 12, 1934, on the Austrian Social-Democratic party.

Label Means Little Herbert Morrison, British labor leader, formerly in the MacDonald Cabinet, now in the Churchill Cabinet, for many years the moving spirit in the London County Council's progressive activities, was once accused in the House of Commons of sponsoring a socialistic bill.

FOR her first novel, a distinguished one, Miss Isabel Currier has taken the most difficult imaginable theme it is possible for a novelist to take. It is a real tribute to Miss Currier to say that it almost comes off.

WITH important issues constantly developing in the international scene and at home, the new season promises to be a fertile one for radio's discussion forums. There certainly should be enough material to go around.

That the erection of cellarless homes on Long Island is practicable has been proven by W.R. Gibson, president of the Gibson Corporation, Long Island builder, who cites the experience of his firm in its development known as Nantucket Homes in the Gibson section of Valley Stream, L.I.

With the "hysterical" phase of consumer purchasing over for the time being at least, merchants were inclined to ease somewhat on purchases lest they be caught "holding the bag," according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 20 -- Publication of the first volume of a monthly journal devoted to experimental research in speech was announced at Massachusetts State College today. It is edited by Clyde W. Dow, in charge of oral English at the college, and published in cooperation with the Department of Languages and Literature.

The State Power Authority protested yesterday against reported plans of private utility companies to build power transmission lines through Van Cortlandt Park and Westchester County to carry electricity to up-State defense factories.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A communique issued today by the Soviet Information Bureau said:
An extensive renovation program was completed at Cooper Union in Cooper Square during the Summer.

THROUGH this story of English middle class family life runs a theme of conflict between two fundamental human instincts, the self-protective and the adventurous. Material success may be attained by an individual dominated by either of these instincts, but, implies the young English author of this first novel, happiness is most often attained by those who know how to guide them.

Columbia University will begin its 188th year on Thursday faced with unparalleled responsibilities in upholding "the university ideal and the university influence," according to President Nicholas Murray Butler.

Conditions under which college students other than those pursuing technical studies in fields related to national defense might obtain postponement of induction under Selective Service were explained yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service.

The approval given by President Roosevelt last week to the promotions of three Naval Reserve officers gave Captain Albert B. Randall, retired commodore of the United States Lines, the distinction of being the first merchant marine officer ever to receive the high rank of rear admiral.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Permitting a total of seven hits, the two aces of Leo Durocher's staff, Whitlow Wyatt and Kirby Higbe, hurled the Dodgers to a twin triumph over the dungeon-dwelling Phillies today before 17,794 paying patrons, the biggest crowd to see the Phils play at Shibe Park this year.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Sept. 20 -- the community of Ancon on the Peninsula of Santa Elena is mystified and concerned by the washing ashore of twenty-three dead whales there. Removal of the carcasses is a stupendous task, and the problem may have to be solved by temporary evacuation of residents of the vicinity.

This Fall, for the first time, Brooklyn College is offering to adults interested in special fields but not in obtaining degrees a series of nine non-credit courses as part of the evening session curriculum, it has been announced by Professor James W. Park, director of the evening session.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In replying to Mr. Cronkhite's letter In THE NEW YORK TIMES George A Lundberg seems to have omitted con sideration of a very important factor frequently ignored when the former German colonies are under discussion.

Theories of social service which they studied in a series of lectures at the Carroll Club are being put into practice by a group of young business women, organized as the Genevieve Brady Volunteers, and named in honor of the founder of their clubhouse at 120 Madison Avenue.

Donald. M. Nelson, executive director of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board and honorary chairman of "Retailers for Defense Week," has telegraphed his congratulations to Major Benjamin H. Namm, national chairman, on the success of the campaign.

BUENOS AIRES. Argentina, Sept. 20 -- Rupture of relations between Argentina and Germany is now viewed as an imminent possibility as a result on the one hand of the resolution voted by the Chamber of Deputies Monday implicitly demanding expulsion of Ambassador Baron Edmund von Thermann, and on the other of the German Government's attitude as manifested by an anti-Argentine press campaign under way in the Reich.

That the erection of cellarless homes on Long Island is practicable has been proven by W.R. Gibson, president of the Gibson Corporation, Long Island builder, who cites the experience of his firm in its development known as Nantucket Homes in the Gibson section of Valley Stream, L.I.

Three years ago today a Caribbean hurricane ravaged Long Island and New England. In the four hours of its passage from the sea to Canada it took hundreds of lives, left thousands of families homeless, caused property loss incalculable. The impact of its abnormal tide registered as an earthquake shock on the seismographs.

FRAGMENTARY reports of what took place in the way of overprinting in Yugoslavia following its conquest by the Axis have been reaching New York. A few of the stamps so treated have arrived and have been illustrated in these columns in recent weeks, but there is no knowing what facts the censorship has concealed.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 20 -- The powerful Boston College Eagles, despite some ragged play now and then, rolled up a 78-0 score against little St. Anselm today to launch Denny Myers's head coachship with the most one-sided triumph in their long football history.

WITH his usual fine disregard for high-flown terms and phrases, Charles F. Kettering, inventor of the automobile self-starter and head of General Motors research, recently observed that motorized warfare, which has been glorified as Blitzkrieg, is really only "plain old ordinary horsepower."

The writer of the following letter is the author of numerous books, plays and essays and has been editor of various literary publications here and abroad. He was secretary of the Foreign Ministry of the Hankow Government and dean of the Peking Women's Normal University.

STORRS, Conn., Sept. 20 -- A continuation of the wide expansion which has been taking place at the University of Connecticut for five years was evident this Fall as the school began its sixty-first year.

THE cast for "Cosi Fan Tutte," first work to be presented by the New York Opera Company, which begins its season on Oct. 14, at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, will include Ina Souez as Fiordiligi, Pauline Pierce as Dorabella, Andzial Kuzak as Despina, Eugene Conley as Ferrando and Waldeman Schroeder as Guglielmo.

THIS novel should have an unsettling effect upon Anne Parrish's admirers. In fact, I really cannot imagine what they will make of it. For "Pray for a Tomorrow" is no deft and glib social comedy, meticulously fashioned, nor does it glitter with the kind of feline wit which marked its author's earlier satires.

The development of personality and social skills through the medium of increased student participation and control of activities is the objective of the greatly expanded Student Guidance Program at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, Mrs. Ruth C. Wright and Dr. Frank K. Shuttleworth, directors of the program, disclosed last week.

CHARMING, frightened, lonely young Jacklin is running in horror from her cousin's dead body when the curtain rises on this second thriller by a not-very-well-known author. And prospective readers must be at once warned and stimulated by the assurance that it is an expert and dreadful tale.

ITHACA, N.T., Sept 21 -- Gifts and bequests to Cornell University during the fiscal year ended July 1 totaled $2,261,037, Provost H.W. Peters announced today. Of this amount, $1,054,330 was added to the university's permanent endowment.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The diplomatic correspondent of The Sunday Dispatch said today that King Boris of Bulgaria had decided to take his country into the war on the side of the Axis. British news dispatches from Turkey said that the Bulgarian radio had announced the declaration of a state of emergency in the Balkan kingdom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- While Senator Tom Connally of Texas was predicting repeal or modification of the Neutrality Act "within a few months," Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, Mr. Connally's predecessor as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today urged the Administration to place "the ultimate decision" of war or peace before the American people.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A propeller - less airplane driven through the skies like a rocket is described in a patent (No. 2,256,198) awarded here to Max Hahn of Seestadt Rostock, Germany. It is assigned to Ernst Heinkel of Warnemunde, Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The estate of Alfred I. du Pont, engaged in a legal battle with a group of banks and insurance companies for control of the reorganized Florida East Coast Railway, filed exceptions today to a report by an examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission which closely followed the reorganization suggestions of the "bankers' plan."

Senator Gerald P. Nye appealed last night to "all loyal Americans" to oppose President Roosevelt's foreign, policy program of all-out aid to nations fighting against Nazi Germany on the ground that it represented a deliberate attempt by the President and British leaders to involve this country against its will in the war.

An attempt at a more economical use of materials and labor in the erection of housing for defense workers is being made at Indian Head, Md., where the Public Buildings Administration of the Federal Works Agency is providing homes for the influx of new workers at a Naval powder factory.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Reds took a four-and-a-half game lead over Pittsburgh in the battle for third place today by defeating the Pirates in both ends of a double-header, 2 to 1 and 7 to 3, on the tight pitching of Bucky Walters and Paul Derringer.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 20 -- No Influential voice in New England has yet demanded that the United States shall formally enter the war as a belligerent. A thousand voices are eloquent in the advocacy of all possible measures for the national defense, and only a small minority of these expresses any dissent from the measures taken by the Administration to date.

DEADLY SOUND -- Dr. A.P. Krueger and E.J. Scribner (University of California) have focused high-pitched sound on bacteria that cause carbuncles and on viruses and killed them. It was found that the sound not only destroys the germs but inactivates the mother substance.

While commending the campaign proposed by the FHA to stimulate conversion of single family houses in defense areas for use as boarding and rooming houses, the National Real Estate Journal sounds a warning that any remodeling plans need careful consideration.

The sounds of rattling machine guns, zooming planes, exploding bombs and anti-aircraft fire filled Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The mock raid lasted twenty minutes and judging from the applause of the audience of experts, ranking police and fire officials, Mayor La Guardia's Air Raid Warden Service showed its ability to cope with such an emergency.

ROME, Sept. 20 -- With the verbosity that he displays only when discussing questions of vital importance to Italy, Virginio Gayda has written a seven-column editorial to prove that President Roosevelt has deceived the American people by slowly dragging them into war in contradiction of his pre-election promises.

In the final step that will establish it as the complete counterpart of the War Industries Board of 1917, the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board will within the next few months dispense almost entirely with preference ratings and priorities and adopt a system of rationing as the best means of speeding the defense program, purchasing agents and others in close touch with Washington declared last week.

The largest revenue measure In United States history was sent last week to the White House for Presidential signature. The bill called for the addition of $3,553,400,000 to the nation's tax load. It had won Congressional approval after six months of consideration on Capitol-Hill.

That there is a real and growing desire to understand the direction in which events are moving nations and the relation of those events to the direction is indicated by the multiplication of school and college courses intended to illuminate the world crisis.
LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 20 -- The first snows of Winter have covered the tundra and the forests of the Soviet north, but for the Allies the Winter's prospects are not cheerful.
More than $67,000,000 in defense contracts and subcontracts have been allotted to Bronx industries since the defense program started, the Bronx Board of Trade reported yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Two Italian motor ships transporting troops to Libya were torpedoed and sunk off Tripoli, but nearly all the soldiers and seamen on board the vessels were saved, the Italian High Command reported today.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- Surrender of the Kiev garrison, mopping up operations in the Ukrainian capital and progress in liquidation of 200,000 Russians trapped in the triangle between Kiev, Priluki and Kremenchug to the east were featured in today's German Supreme Command coaununique.

TROY, Sept. 20 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's Department of English reported to President Hotchkiss today that as a result of an experiment last year students had learned how to increase their time for study by an hour and fifteen minutes a day, without cutting their average of eight hours for sleeping or curtailing other important activities.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 20 -- Despite the heavy pressure of German propaganda trying to persuade Sweden of the necessity of joining the "crusade against bolshevism," Swedish Prime Minister Per Albin Hanssen declared today that Sweden was firmly resolved not to let herself be dragged into it.

WASHINGTON. WHEN Francis fiddle of Philadelphia was sworn in by President Roosevelt early this month as the fifty-eighth Attorney General of the United States a neat though probably fictitious bit of prophecy was consummated.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William Stuart Forbes will leave the Carlyle today for Hamilton, Mass.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Sophomore Hugh Cox stole the spotlight today as North Carolina crushed Lenoir-Rhyne, 42 to 6, in its opening game.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

For the sixty-sixth annual all-breed show of the Westminster Kennel Club to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12, the entry will be limited to dogs which have won a first prize at an A.K.C. licensed or member club show and to puppies.

Vital questions regarding effective rehabilitation of decaying business and residential sections in many cities of the country in addition to better planning methods will be discussed at a conference of the Urban Land Institute Oct. 15 to 17 inclusive at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20 -- His contribution, to the knowledge concerning estrogens, female sex hormones, has won for Professor Edgar Alien, chairman of the Department of Anatomy of the Yale School of Medicine, the Baly Medal of the Royal College of Physicians of London, it was announced here today.

While total manufacturing operations continue to increase as new plants or additions to old ones spring up, smaller industries are being hit by the growing scarcity of essential supplies, the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday in the monthly report of its business survey committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Applications for export priority should carry as detailed information as the exporter can provide concerning the need for his merchandise in a particular market and the uses to which it will be put, Milo Perkins, executive director of the newly created Economic Defense Board, asserted here today.

Setting up of joint committees of retailers and manufacturers in consumer goods industries was seen here last week as a necessary step for speeding up the simplification of merchandise which Donald M. Nelson, executive director of the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board, has declared is essential to the defense program.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- Surrender by the Reich of its controlling interests in two big German shipping companies, the Hamburg-American Line and North German Lloyd, is announced in a communique' that states that shares in those companies have been sold to "suitable private circles."

HOLLYWOOD. HONTY Woolley loves Hollywodd and Warner Brothers. He regards Bette Davis with enthusiasm both as an actress and as an individual; he is appreciative of Ann Sheridan's beauty and histrionic skill; he says Jimmy Durante is 2 splendid fellow and an excellent actor.

One of the first large philanthropically conceived dances of the early Autumn will be the R.A.F. Midnight Military Ball to be given Friday night in the rotunda of the Roxy Theatre immediately after the premiere of the new film, "A Yank in the R.A.F."

DENVER, Col., Sept. 20 -- A strong sentiment against the United States entering the current European war as an actual participant still is in evidence in Colorado and other States of the Rocky Mountain region, although virtually the entire populace is definitely in favor of supplying all possible material aid to England and Russia in their battle.

FOR almost half a dozen years now, whenever life threatened to become a shade stodgy in the theatre, in the films or on the radio, Orson Welles has been up to something new, and of course this is all to the good.

AS the Spanish saying would put it, it is raining books on Latin America, and no signs of clearing up yet. Most of these books are strictly personal impressions, and should have remained just what they are: travel diaries containing the sort of exciting banalities youthful travelers are tempted to scribble on pink or azure paper, only to relegate them to the bottom of the trunk long before reaching home.

Only food supplies from the outside world can save 2,000,000 children in Greece from death by starvation this Winter, Laird Archer, foreign director of the Near East Foundation, warns in a report on a survey conducted recently with the help of Charles L. House, who remains in Greece as head of the American Farm School in Salonika.

Having been trounced six straight times by the ferocious western clubs, the Giants greeted the Braves with enthusiasm at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The New Yorkers bowled over the Bostonians in both ends of a double-header, 4 to 3 and 7 to 3, thereby blithely leaping over the Cubs into fifth place.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 20 -- The coming out party Tennessee staged today for John Barnhill as head coach of a Southeastern Conference team was definitely a success, the big Orange eleven handing him a 32-to-6 victory over a rugged Furman machine from the Southern Conference.

GETTING mixed up with other people's lives is often an extremely troublesome business. Frequently it proves the most difficult and most troublesome part of a biographer's job, especially if his victim, or perhaps one should say subject, is but recently dead and has surviving relations.

THE first annual exhibition of prints from the permanent collection at the Brooklyn Museum is now on display. Some sixty-five prints are included in the show, which will last through Oct. 19. All of the photographs all standard press accessories, such as flashgun, range finder, etc., it possesses a telescopic eye level view finder adjustable for correction of parallax on close-ups, and has double extension bellows.

NO reader of American fiction needs to be told that Ben Ames Williams is an experienced and highly qualified professional writer. When "Come Spring" was issued early last year it seemed merely one of the more distinguished achievements of a varied and colorful writing career.

MOSCOW (By Wireless). NEARLY three months of war have done little to alter the fundamental aspects of life in this city which Napoleon described as "Moscow, Asiatic capital of this great empire, Holy City of the peoples of Alexander; Moscow with its innumerable churches in the form of Chinese pagodas."

The Introduction of the new large-fruiting blueberries, the first of which were developed by the United States Department of Agriculture, has interested many gardeners in attempting to grow these luscious fruits for themselves.

The snuffbox was the only treasure which Nancy and Robin Martin had saved when they escaped from a slave rebellion in Barbados and fled to Newport in the days when Rhode Island was still a colony. To these homeless children of the West Indies sun the little gray town didn't seem so cold and cheerless as at first after they had been taken under the kindly wing of good Mrs. Bathsheba.

Recreation as a defense measure and its importance to the welfare of the country in the war emergency as well as in normal times will be the outstanding theme of the twenty-sixth annual National Recreation Congress, which opens in Baltimore on Sept. 29.

Apartment buildings in Manhattan and the adjoining boroughs ire filling up rapidly for the Fall season, and brokers and landlords now are busy showing their available suites to last-minute prospects who for various reasons have been unable to make their choice of new living quarters ahead of time.

AGNES SLIGH TURNBULL, author of "The Rolling Years" and "Remember the End," began this informal diary as an outlet from more serious writing -- a record of small daily events in her life and those of her family and friends, her home and work and her personal philosophy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The mechanism by which the anti-hemorrhagic Vitamin K performs its function in coagulating the blood In case of injury was elucidated at one of the symposia held here this week in connection with the fiftieth anniversary of the University of Chicago.

IT may come as a shock but it's a fact that there are thousands of female officers in the United States Army. They are not out on the drill grounds giving orders; they are the nurses in our expanding military forces, now 5,695 strong, with 3,000 more needed by next June.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has awarded three prizes and three honorable mentions in its contest, held during the Summer, for photographs of the Cloisters, the branch of the museum in Fort Tryon Park devoted to medieval art.

FROM the soaring increases of mid-Summer, retail gains have been cut down to margins which do not represent much more than the average price advance over last year. In other words, unit sales may be running a little under a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Declaring that "it is unfortunate that Mr. Wendell Willkie should attempt to read out of the party those who disagree with him on foreign policy," Senator Taft said today that he saw no reason for Republicans to make an issue of international policies in the off-year elections of 1942.

Department store sales in the New York area last week were about the same as a year ago. The expansion of apparel demand was checked by the hot weather in the early part of the week, but picked up with cooler weather Friday; men's wear sales for the week averaged about even with 1940.

The National Defense Expositor conceived and promoted by New York City officials and citizen through a non-profit corporation opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace for a month's run. Its name appeared to be somewhat of a misnomer, since Mayor La Guardia remarked in his short talk officially opening it at noon that it was full of "offensive atmosphere."

NORTHFIELD, Vt., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Influenced by the large corps of Dartmouth, observers on the scene, the Norwich Cadets adhered strictly to straight football today while defeating a tenacious Montclair (N.J.) Teachers College team, 27 -- 6. Norwich plays the Indians next.
An extensive renovation program was completed at Cooper Union in Cooper Square during the Summer.

Issuance of priority rules giving preference to dwelling units costing $6,000 or less within commuting distance of defense centers may serve to speed up construction on low-priced homes in many parts of the metropolitan area, but will have an adverse effect on the programs of the average residential developer here.
Several of the courses which the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is offering adults this Fall will begin this week. On Wednesday the special course in gardening has its opening lesson at 3:30 P.M.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 20 -- Boston Man, a bay son of Bostonian and Candy May, outran Lou Tufano's favored Market Wise and eight other 3-year-olds today to win the $10,000 added Potomac Handicap before an overflow crowd of 18,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Administration is seriously considering plans to request of Congress the repeal of the Neutrality Act, which it regards as placing abnormal fetters upon a realistic American foreign policy, just as did the original Neutrality Law adopted in 1935.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Frank warning that many private colleges and universities face "financial and educational" bankruptcy if present conditions continue is made in the annual report of 1941 just just released by President Alan Valentine of the University of Rochester.

THE business of drinking in pictures, like the business of drinking any place else, is one upon which certain people are forever casting critical frowns. Let an actor so much as quaff a nourishing libation, and thereafter give evidence of its stimulating effect upon him, and many substantial burghers are sure to take heated offense.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, asserted today complaints had reached his office that "unscrupulous" landlords in some defense areas were evicting tenants who appealed to government-sponsored Fair Rent Committees against advances in the cost of living quarters.

Having been passed by both houses of the Congress, the new tax bill, known, as Revenue Act of 1941, was signed yesterday by President Roosevelt and became law. Not in itself a complete revenue measure, this is the second bill to be enacted this year containing amendments to the Excess Profits Tax of 1940; the first, designated "Excess Profits Tax Amendments of 1941," was signed by the President on March 7.

TO THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just read THE TIMES announcement that on Sept. 18 your great newspaper will celebrate its ninetieth anniversary. That is surely an event in American life, in which THE TIMES holds so pre-eminent a place.

September and October bring rich reward to any gardener who has been even moderately faithful in caring for his roses throughout the Summer. Beetles are now sufficiently reduced in numbers so that flowers may safely be allowed to open in the garden.

New York City's career girls have taken on a new job in which fun outweighs duty. They also have found themselves thrust back to adolescent days, when lectures by mother preceded their first grown-up parties.

An attempt at a more economical use of materials and labor in the erection of housing for defense workers is being made at Indian Head, Md., where the Public Buildings Administration of the Federal Works Agency is providing homes for the influx of new workers at a Naval powder factory.

While commending the campaign proposed by the FHA to stimulate conversion of single family houses in defense areas for use as boarding and rooming houses, the National Real Estate Journal sounds a warning that any remodeling plans need careful consideration.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The English-language publication Moscow News, in the first Russian press comment upon the forthcoming United States-British-Russian conference, called it today "the turning point in the present gigantic struggle, opening new perspectives for those combating Hitler."

Under pressure of increased hedging and liquidation, the cotton futures market lost ground yesterday for the third consecutive session. Opening 4 to 9 points lower, quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped sharply. The Close showed losses of 22 to 33 points.

The panda, the newest darling of the zoos, has a face and figure and a manner too which have endeared him to a public without age limits. In this unusual picture-book, imported from England, Joan Kiddell-Monroe proves that he is as decorative as he is fetching.

A VOLUME of nearly a thousand pages drawn from one hundred American writers over a period of three hundred years may seem to constitute a rather elaborate definition for a single word, even if that word is "demorcacy."

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Led by a group of three craft in the large handicap class, with the sloop Larikin under charter to Jack Shethar racing against them on time under the cruising rule measurement, a fleet of ninety-nine set forth today in the American Yacht Club regatta.

Although metal shortages so far have not been felt much by the public, because manufacturers of metal products have accumulated large inventories shortages are already serious in a number of metals vital for defense and used by civilians in everyday life.

ENTERPRISE, Ore. IN these early Autumn days, when leaves are falling and the woods are drying, the Forest Ranger keeps a keener watch on his domain. He is a jack-of-all-trades and a master of many crafts. His duties are the most varied among Uncle Sam's millions of employes.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- D.N.B., the official news agency, tonight announced the arrest of nine Chileans in Berlin, Paris and Vienna during the past few days, subjecting German relations with South American nations to new strains. It had been reported earlier in the week that an undisclosed number of Chileans had been arrested, apparently in retaliation for the arrest in Chile of twenty-eight persons on charges of engaging in Nazi activities.

The government-operated freighter Alcoa Banner, laden with important cargo for American bases in the West Indies, sailed from her Weehawken pier at 3 P.M. yesterday, the first of three seized vessels to get under way as the Maritime Commission moved to break a week-old strike.

"I BOUGHT A MOUNTAIN" is the record of seven years on a sheep farm in North Wales. Thomas Firbank, a Canadian educated in England, at the age of 21 undertook the adventure of buying 2,400 unfenced acres, a house on a mountainside and a flock of 1,300 sheep "tied to their own mountain by a heredity which is many times as strong as the best fence."

HYDE PARK, Sept. 20 -- When President Roosevelt today signed the $3,553,400,000 tax bill, he approved a measure which, in one way or another, will touch virtually every citizen. It will require an estimated 22,000,000 persons to file Income tax returns, of whom about 4,900,000 will be making out returns for the first time, and it will impose numerous excise, or "nuisance" taxes.

BECAUSE waste paper is used in the making of ammunition and for other vital needs its collection is now an essential industry. The point was emphasized in a letter sent recently by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, to Mayor Kelly of Chicago asking that waste paper be collected in fashionable districts from which collectors had been banned.

Because of the "busyness" of national defense industries in other cities throughout the country, a new record will have been set in the metropolitan area at the end of the calendar year 1941 when $80,000,000 worth of mail shall have been handled by the New York Postoffice, it was predicted yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman.
SIR THOMAS BEECHAM, who returns this afternoon as guest conductor of the Columbia Broadcasting Symphony, is, as any of his musical colleagues will tell you, a fabulous figure.

A report just issued by the Home Owners Loan Corporation shows that during the past years the sum of $166,000,000 was spent for repairs on 550,000 homes under, the agency's direction. The largest proportionate share went for painting involving $52,000,000 of which $33,800,000 went for labor and $18,200,000 for materials.

An Important step in contributing to the cleanliness and health-fulness of American cities has just been taken by Pittsburgh, points out Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in the enactment of an ordinance requiring that soft coal be burned with mechanical combustion equipment or that smokeless fuel be used.

Attacking the policy of isolation, Bertrand Russell, British philosopher, declared yesterday at a conference on "War Aims and Peace Terms" that no nation can secure peace for itself through this method. He admitted that during the last World War he had been an isolationist, but confessed that he had been wrong.

ADMIRERS of Wagner had better prepare themselves for toad news this morning. The report is that the Metropolitan Opera will not present "Tristan und Isolde" this season, Yes, "Tristan und Isolde"! The opera's best seller in recent years! It appears that the decision to leave it out of the repertory has been taken -- with sorrow.

Combined net profits of 112 producers of consumer goods in the first half of 1941 amounted to $165,734,689 after all tax provisions and other charges, compared with $141,260,170 in the same period last year, reflecting better gains after taxes than most of the heavy industry groups thus far reviewed for the period.

With the opening of the first study course of the season next Tuesday afternoon -- a new course in garden management -- the New York Botanical Garden is initiating a greatly expanded program of adult education, particularly in gardening.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Scoring all their runs in the last two innings, the White Sox stuck in the fight to hold their third-place berth today with a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, THIRD ARMY, Lake Charles, La., Sept. 20 -- More than 400,000 soldiers slept on their arms or moved to new concentration areas across the congested roads of Louisiana and East Texas today as the Second and Third Armies of the United States prepared for another phase of the greatest war game in the nation's history.

Many interesting facts about Manhattan in earlier days, particularly the Twenty-third Street area, are contained in an unpublished autobiography of the late Samuel B. Goodale, who founded in 1866 the present firm of Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, Inc.

TRAVEL LINES: For travelers visiting Cuba, "Havana Manana," by Consuelo Hermer and Marjorie May, offers data on island manners and customs . . . A new pasteurization plant at Aguadulce, Republic of Panama, is at present producing 1,500 quarts of Grade "A" milk a day, of which a thousand quarts axe consumed by men working on United States defense projects in the Canal Zone.

THE New Jersey State mixed team-of-four tournament will be played next Sunday. There will be two sessions, the first beginning at 1:30 P.M. and the second at 7:30. Play will take place in the Douglas Hotel in Newark.

Calling attention to the present emphasis on new housing construction, C. Armel Nutter, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards says that prospective purchasers and investors should not lose sight of the advantages of older dwellings.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 20 -- Reports from foreign diplomatic circles in Ankara tonight indicated that the new Shah of Iran was making a desperate but probably unsuccessful attempt to retain his throne by a series of sweeping declarations and decrees designed to implement constitutional reforms and wipe out the corruptness of his father's reign.

THE annual Report of the Custodian of the Chapin Library at Williams College describes, as usual, progress in cataloguing, services to scholarship and other good works, as well as the year's exhibitions.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Douglas Ford and Fred Bohling, the medalists, reached the semi-final round of the Plandome Golf Club's first annual member-guest tournament today by winning two matches, one of them decisively, 7 and 6, from Clem O'Malley and Jim Nammack.

CLEMSON, S.C., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Clemson's defending champions of the Southern Conference defeated Presbyterian College, 41 -- 12, today with the aid of Booty Payne's passing, Joe Blalock's receiving and Charlie Timmons's plunging.

UNION, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Declaring that the principles of the Selective Service Act "have, through pressure groups, been debased to the point that just and fair classification of registrants is impossible," the three members of Draft Board 2 in the Union-Springfield area sent a letter of resignation to Governor Charles Edison today.

Charges of swindling more than a dozen bondholders of the bankrupt Associated Gas and Electric Company system in four States of several thousand dollars were made against a stock salesman yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of New York and Attorney General David T. Wilentz of New Jersey.
ROME, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- The club that knocked the Cardinals out of the National League lead on Sept. 3 delivered what may prove to be the finishing blow to St. Louis pennant hopes at Sportsman's Park today.

The two-story business structure to be known as the Village Square Building on the site of the former village hall in Bronxville, West-Chester County, will be ready for occupancy Oct. 1, according to Hart Burtnett, renting agents.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 21 -- A "savage life-and-death struggle" is still raging about Kiev, the Russians reported today. The Germans have lost about 150,000 men and are hurling a quarter of a million more of their best troops into the great battle, Russian dispatches declared.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A.F.L. machinists will vote a second time on Monday on whether to strike to enforce their wage demands upon the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation, holder of $750,000,000 in defense orders.

HOW Sandy will turn out, what he will do next, what effect his unpredictable behavior will have on his nice wife and three adorable children and on Angela and the other literary personages interested in his genius -- these are the lively interests in Miss Clements's third novel.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 20 -- Soviet-Bulgarian diplomatic relations were strained to the breaking point tonight, according to reports to high foreign diplomatic sources here, and, in the light of Sofia's strong new protest to Moscow and the unexplained sinking of a Bulgarian vessel in the Black Sea, authoritative foreign circles in Ankara declared that only a miracle now could prevent open warfare between the two powers.

Next Saturday will be "Defend America Day" for 12,000 members of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L. The union painters, relaxing an ironclad rule against Saturday work, will take up their brushes as "a weapon against Hitlerism" and will contribute their earnings to organizations engaged in promoting national defense and in distributing relief to the victims of Nazi oppression.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- With only a few minutes to spare before expiration of their time limit at 7 P.M., the International Class sloops finished today their next to last Sunday race of the season for the Royal Bermuda Trophy, and Corny Shields brought in his Aileen the winner to take the lead in the series by three boats.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 -- The volume of steel business which was accompanied by priority ratings increased somewhat last week in the steel industry, owing to the fact that several priority orders recently have been assigned preference rating symbols to material, the consumption of which is considered to be included in the national defense effort.

Gazzarra Brothers, builders, have purchased a plot of lots on the south side of Blossom Avenue, between Main and Saull Streets, Flushing, L.I., for improvement with twentyfive homes. Construction work on several of the units has started, according to the Halleran Agency, broker in the sale.

As an introduction to the mock air-raid that will form the climax of the Fifth Annual Police Show at Madison Square Garden, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would address the country on "The Police and Civilian Defense" on a coast-to-coast broadcast on Wednesday evening at 10:30 o'clock.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- The question of whether Turkey will be permitted to pursue her present neutral course or whether an attempt will be made to force her definitely to choose sides was declared today by well-informed circles to be under discussion in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Final regulations were issued today by General Philip B. Fleming, administrator of the wage and hour division of the Department of Labor, for the employment of learners at less than the 40-cent minimum, under two wage orders to go into effect on Sept 29 for the manufacture of men's cotton garments and single pants of any material and for the women's apparel industry.

Denouncing the tendency to rationalize the Christian doctrine, the Very Rev. James P. De Wolf e declared yesterday that the place of theology in the modern world is of "gravest importance," that there is no need to "adjust truth to twentieth century learning," and that the first step for real Christians today is to "dare believe."

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 20 (Delayed) -- Both the American Red Cross and the British Army have sent food, clothing and medical supplies to Lebanon and Syria, but so precarious at best is the economy of these little countries that they are unlikely to recover quickly from Vichy rule and the ravages of war.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Uruguay, which has promised the United States the use of her seaports and other facilities in the event of war, will begin construction soon of a huge naval air base on the Atlantic coast, informed sources reported today.

If your new Fall dress looks snugger than it should, and you wince at the sight of a full-length mirror, a certain city store will find you consolation in the form of a cracker. It is a cracker that can be eaten with a clear conscience, and -- which is still more astounding -- with genuine enjoyment.

Special, as well as general hospitals, are now handicapped by a shortage of graduate registered nurses occasioned by the war and defense program, it was disclosed yesterday at Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street.

Christian religion eventually will be restored to new power and influence in both Russia and Germany, Suffragan Bishop J.I. Blair Larned of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island predicted in a sermon yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Senator Clark, Democrat, of Idaho, an opponent of Administration foreign policies, said today that Congress probably would be asked to write into the pending $5,985,000,000 lend-lease appropriation a prohibition against aid to Russia, but Senator George said this would be a fatal mistake.

Continuing their mad marathon to nowhere, the Giants and Braves engaged in the second of three successive double-headers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. To the puzzlement of 9,839 onlookers, the revitalized forces of Colonel Bill Terry again bagged a pair of victories, tightening their grip on fifth place.

A preliminary study of the virtual economic blockade of Japan by the United States and the British Commonwealth through the stoppage of trade gives an indication that if this blockade is maintained beyond six months Japan will have "to plead for an economic truce with America and Britain and sue for a military armistice with China."
VICHY, France, Sept. 21 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain tonight exerted his personal influence to put a check to the series of aggressions against the German troops of occupation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 21 -- As was foreseen, the lifting of the state of emergency has not changed the actual situation in Norway, where mass arrests continue unrelentingly and where the latest decrees of Josef Terboven, Commissioner for Reich-held areas in Norway, have had the effect of extending a slightly modified form of martial law, including courtmartial, to the entire country.

New designs in furniture, fabrics and lighting to meet today's home needs will go on public exhibition or Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, after more than a year's preparation.

Stress upon the efficacy of newspaper advertising, and defense against "the unwarranted attacks on advertising emanating from. Washington" will play important parts in the $1,000,000 promotion program planned for National Newspaper Week, Oct. 1 to 8, according to the National Newspaper Week Committee of Newspaper Association Managers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Washington scored twin victories over the Athletics, 6 to 5 and 6 to 2, today and moved into undisputed possession of sixth place.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Darkness halted a fourteen-inning 1-1 deadlock today after the Tigers had captured the first game of a double-header with the White Sox, 6 to 3, before 12,536 spectators.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Sept. 22 -- The Russian High Command announced today that Kiev had been evacuated. Thus the Germans have attained one of their three major objectives, the two others being Moscow and Leningrad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Approval of the $285,000,000 St. Lawrence seaway project for inclusion in an omnibus rivers and harbors bill has resulted in no appreciable change in sentiment among House members, a majority of whom oppose the proposal, a survey shows.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Sept. 21 -- On the eve of the departure of two regiments of New York's Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft) brigades for Fall manoeuvres, Brig. Gen. Nathaniel Eggleston emphasized tonight that the exercises "should result in the attainment of a high state of combat efficiency by the individual soldier and units of this brigade."

If Bulgaria declares war on Russia it will be for the same reason she adhered to the Rome-Berlin-Tokyo compact last March -- because Adolf Hitler ordered it. Then he demanded and received permission to march Nazi armies across the little Balkan country in order to attack Greece, which was successfully resisting the Italian assault.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Freedom of the seas is essential to the national defense and political freedom of the United States, Dr. William Y. Elliott, former chairman of the Department of Government at Harvard University, said tonight in a debate with Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican, of New York, who charged that "the whole issue of freedom of the seas is filled with the rankest kind of hypocrisy, quibbling and hair-splitting."

ROME, Sept. 21 -- His mission completed, Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, this morning tool leave of Pope Pius XII in a private audience which lasted fifty minutes. He and Mrs. Taylor will leave early tomorrow by plane for Lisbon.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- President Roosevelt spent at his home here one of the most quiet week-ends he has enjoyed in months. While he had the usual routine work to handle, including the signing of a $3,500,000,000 tax bill, he was able for the most part to do just what he pleased.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from Helen S.K. Willcox draws attention once again to the dairy industry. Any dairy farmer appreciates that neither reason nor economic considerations have a sufficient influence upon milk price or milk marketing practice, and that the farmer usually occupies the position of a poor second.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices continued its advance into new high ground by rising fractionally from 98.4 to 98.5. Whereas much of the rise in the all-commodity index in recent months has been in the prices of raw material, especially agricultural, last week's rise was brought about chiefly by commodities in the semi-manufactured and finished products groups.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Food as a "fifth column" working for peace in Europe was discussed today by Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard in the University of Chicago round-table broadcast.

Some reciprocal dealing, not necessarily relevant, between an author and her husband has come to light through several sources. It seems that the title of Anne Parrish's new novel, "Pray For a Tomorrow," published last week by Harper, came from a forthcoming volume of verse by her husband, Josiah Titzell.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- Apprehension that official circles might lose patience with the "booming" Boerse and might at last act on the warning against speculative excesses as given by Walther Funk, president of the Reichsbank, early last March, was responsible for the complete reversal of the tendency of the stock market here last week.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- In impressive ceremonies at the Shrine of Our Lady of Martyrs, Auriesville, today, the gold medallion awarded each year by the Catholic Affairs Committee of the Knights of Columbus of New York State was presented to Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine of New York City.

While we were upon Lac St. Pierre worrying the waterfowl the anglers in this general area seem to have struck some excellent striped bass fishing and, according to several letters received on our return, both Montauk and the Rockaways have been producing very well.

Many buyers were in the wholesale market last week to place orders for holiday and Spring merchandise. Deliveries in the majority of lines caused greater concern than rising prices. Dresses were in demand in women's sizes. Activity was brisk on evening dresses, and dinner types were preferred to the more formal gowns.

In a rearmament economy some form of price fixing is inescapable. But the fixing of ceilings is only one way to control prices. As the hearings on the pending price bill have brought out, price-fixing is enormously difficult, clumsy and productive of hardship. The most efficient form of price control is control of the factors which are pushing up the general price level.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 -- The largest crowd ever to watch an International League game in Montreal -- 24,732 fans-saw Newark defeat Montreal, 4 -- 3, today to remain in the Governors' Cup hunt. The victory left the pennant-winnig Bears trailing, 3 -- 2, in the four-out-of-seven final series.

With a view to providing more adequate recreational facilities for the people of Harlem, the Department of Parks and the WPA are engaged in large-scale reconstruction work in the northeast part of Central Park, the department announced yesterday.

Hopes and fears over the Russian-German campaign made a two-headed structure last week of the stock market, for after prices had pushed ahead to the best points since July the list retreated after Wednesday's outburst and closed practically unchanged on the week.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Qualified London observers, studying Bulgaria's declaration of a state of emergency issued yesterday, termed it flatly tonight a forerunner of a new German diplomatic offensive against Turkey, with an attack upon the Dardanelles to follow shortly if persuasion failed.
ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- A job for every New York man discharged from the Army is the goal of a State plan announced today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State director of selective service.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for August, based on 1930 as 100, was 153.2, compared with the same figure for July, with 140.1 a year ago and 98.1 for August, 1939.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, held in check for two periods by a stubborn Cleveland football team turned on the power in the first and fourth quarters to crush the Rams in a National League football game today before 20,000 by 24 to 7.

ABOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S TRAIN, Sept. 21 -- President Roosevelt will arrive in Washington early tomorrow from Hyde Park prepared to do his utmost to have the new $5,985,000,000 lend-lease appropriation approved by Congress as quickly as possible.
BERLIN, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A special communique from Adolf Hitler's field headquarters said:

LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 21 -- Hurricane warnings flew along parts of the Gulf Coast today as 350,000 troops of the Second and Third Armies shifted to new concentration areas in preparation for the final phase of the greatest war games in the country's history.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Warner Brothers borrowed Betty Field from Paramount to play the controversial role of Cassandra Tower in "Kings Row," for which half a dozen other actresses have been discussed during the ten weeks the film has been before the cameras.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Dr. Rudolf Schoenheimer, Associate Professor of Biological Chemistry at Columbia University and an outstanding research worker in the field of biochemistry, was found dead of poisoning at his home at 115 Wickes Avenue here on Sept. 11, it became known today.
All the current officeholders in the Metropolitan Association A.A. U. were retained for another year at the organization's annual meeting at the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday.

A TRUE (well-er-partially true, anyway) copy of the minutes of a meeting of a subcommittee of the Joint Army and Navy Committee on Welfare and Recreation leading up to a broadcast that will come out of the Blue (network) at 9 P.M. (daylight) this evening:

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 21 (AP) -- President Manuel Avila Camacho has bluntly ordered Mexico's 80,000 school teachers to abandon all political activity as of Sept. 30, and thereafter to dedicate themselves exclusively to teaching.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The extreme difficulty the Quartermaster Corps is encountering in some instances in having suppliers make direct bids to the Army on canned fruits and vegetables for the coming year was disclosed in a bulletin released today by the War Department.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- A tropical storm of "hurricane or near hurricane" intensity tonight roared over the Gulf of Mexico toward the Louisiana coast and residents of low-lying areas south of here were evacuated from their homes.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- With a wide margin over all other contenders, the imported brown thoroughbred gelding Dalchoolin, owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll of New York and jumped by his owner and Gordon Wright, won the conformation, hunter championship of the fifth annual Pocantieo Hills horse show on the grounds of the Sleepy Hollow Farm Stables today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- To the green-shirted riders of Gulf Stream went the highest honors of American polo today, when they came on through the last two periods of the most stubbornly contested national championship final in years to turn back Aknusti, 10 to 6.

One reason that people are frustrated and bewildered by life today is that they have forgotten that "the most powerful forces in the universe are not always the most vocal," the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A 43-yard place-kick by Quarterback Len Barnum of Philadelphia in the second quarter and a 27-yard touchdown run by Halfback Lou Tomasetti in the third gave the Eagles a 10-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today in a National League football game.

In some respects the United States, between the collapse of France and the President's announcement following the attack by a German submarine on the destroyer Greer, might be compared to Great Britain between the Munich agreement and the Nazi invasion of Poland.

The Daniel Guggenheim Medal, created to honor persons who make notable achievements in the advancement of aeronautics, has been awarded for 1941 to Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways System, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Sam Snead spreadeagled the field in the $7,000 Hurst invitation golf tournament today to win by nine strokes -- widest margin of victory in a major tournament this year.

A message that will lift the chins of stout-hearted folk everywhere has been flashed from the garrison of Tobruk to the defenders of Odessa. "From our African fortress," say the British soldiers holed up in their desert sand-pit, "we follow with admiration your struggle and wish you all luck."

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The widespread forward sweep in the stock markets of the last several weeks has been brought to a halt. In any case, it was felt that securities were due for a reaction as a result of the good profits that are available after the enthusiastic speculative advance that has lifted almost all the major groups.

Brussels danced on the eve of Waterloo, Vernon Castle set New York to footing the one-step in the World War, and now, with battles again raging in many lands, the Victory Dance is a marked feature of ballroom floors in diversion centers of the United States.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Governor Charles Edison announced today that he had ordered an immediate investigation into charges by the three resigned members of Draft Board 2 of Union County that deferments had been granted without justification by the appeals board of their district and by State and national draft headquarters.

Three Dodger passes went for touchdowns at Ebbets Field yesterday, two for Brooklyn and one for the Detroit Lions as the Brooks opened their National Football League season with a 14-to-7 victory before a gathering of 19,269.

An appeal to Bundles for Britain, Inc., 745 Fifth Avenue, to meet the immediate needs for Army woolens estimated at a minimum of 105,000 garments has just been received in a letter from Lady Kemsley, director of distribution of knitted garments for Bundles for Britain and chairman of The Daily Sketch War Relief Fund.
NEW YORK Mrs. Joseph S. House is expected at the Plaza today from Whitefield, N.H.

Registration at the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music opens today, to continue through next Monday. New students will be enrolled from Thursday on. Scholarship auditions are slated from tomorrow until Wednesday.
MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's communique, in announcing the loss of Kiev, said: "After many days of fierce fighting our troops evacuated Kiev."

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- All efforts to estimate the course of Great Britain's foreign trade at the present time are frustrated by the statistical "blackout." In the early days of the war every effort was made to keep exports going in order to provide the foreign balances needed to obtain essential supplies.

For those who stayed at home yesterday to listen to the Dodgers, this is the story of what happened at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park, where the asters and the dahlias are now in full bloom.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Russian transports bearing reinforcements and supplies are slipping into besieged Odessa night after night, a German war reporter, Karl Sedlatzek, reported today in a dispatch describing hard fighting for the Soviet Black Sea port.

After advancing substantially in each of the four preceding weeks, cotton prices last week lost ground sharply. With the exception of a temporary strengthening on Wednesday, day-to-day net price changes were to lower levels. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts at the close on Saturday reflected net losses of 87 to 92 points for the week, in contrast to net grains of 38 to 47 points in the previous week.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Bedlam broke out last night at an internment camp for Fascists near Peel on the Isle of Man when 600 to 700 of them pelted their guards with bottles and brickbats because three internees who had escaped and been recaptured were refused permission to return to that camp.
Garden in Fall Autumn finds the flower garden disorganized on the phlox front, hard-pressed in the gladiolus sector and generally looking seedy and worn, yet carrying on with great gallantry.
