CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Uncertainty as to developments in price controls which will be brought up soon in Congress for discussion resulted last week in a reduction in speculative interest in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Sales of 139,645,000 bushels of all grain futures showed a decrease of 112,863,000, compared with the preceding week, but they were about double the amount of 70,094,000 bushels traded in the corresponding period last year.

III for the last year, Mehmet Ali Yukselen, 51 years old, Turkish Consul General in New York City for four years, strangled himself with two neckties in his bed in the Consular residence, 50 Central Park West, yesterday. He had suffered from a painful heart condition and had brooded about it, his associates said.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The Dodgers made history for the lowly Phillies today by drawing 35,909 fans through the Shibe Park turnstiles. It was the largest gathering before which the Phils have played a home game in all their years in the National League.

Hundreds of wide-eyed children accompanied by their more seriously minded parents, flocked yesterday to the National Defense Exposition at Grand Central Palace to get a first-hand glimpse of a cross-section of the nation's defense program.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Elmer Riddle pitched his fourth shutout of the season for Cincinnati today to beat Pittsburgh, 2-0, and gain his eighteenth victory against four defeats -- the best pitching record in the National League.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Long-range hitting, a trick usually reserved for the Bronx Bombers, brought the Red Sox a 4-1 victory over the Yankees today. Beating the McCarthymen these days can't be done with mirrors, so the Red Sox resorted to homers, which accounted for every Boston tally.

Civic organizations, business leaders and Mayors of many cities and villages in New York State are cooperating in a movement to have the State income tax law amended to allow the deduction of Federal income tax payments, it was announced yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street.

Leading supporters of Mayor La Guardia were reported yesterday to have approved a second independent nomination for the Mayor in addition to that of the City Fusion party, to give New Deal Democrats opportunity to vote under their own emblem and to give him one more line on the voting machines.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 22 -- The Royal Air Force kept up an unremitting offensive on the Western Front over the week-end, pounding at Berlin, Frankfort and Ostend early yesterday and making heavy daylight sweeps over German-occupied France yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- Plans for some form of compulsory "mixed investment" and more drastic taxation of stock exchange profits were under consideration at a meeting last week in the Reichsbank, according to informed financial circles here.

Governor Lehman announced yesterday his authorization of a 20 per cent increase in the strength of the New York Guard. The increase will bring the aggregate strength of the Guard to 17,000 officers and men as soon as they can be equipped, it was disclosed by the Governor's announcement, released here through the New York State Defense Information Committee, 80 Centre Street.

Numerous rentals of apartments in buildings in the Greenwich Village area were reported by brokers and renting agents over the weekend. Most of the other late Fall renting was done on the East Side, where houses on Park Avenue figured prominently in the activity.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 21 -- Wilmington opened its American Football Association season today but the Clippers lost, 13 to 6, to the Long Island Indians. A crowd of 6,000 saw the game. It was Long Island's second league fray and first victory.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 21 -- Brown University's Committee on Scholarships announced today the winners of six Horace Mann scholarships and ten Benjamin Ide Wheeler Scholarships, awarded to outstanding members of the freshman class for the coming academic year.

There can be no stability, peace or progress in this war-ridden, struggling world until God is placed first and in its center, the Rev. James A. Brimelow, pastor of the Grace Methodist Church, 135 West 104th Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Controversy within the Senate over the investigation of the movies approached a step nearer a showdown today when Senator Clark of Idaho signed vouchers for $552.04 in expenditures by the Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee inquiring into alleged war propaganda.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The slender, silvery crescent of the Moslem year's ninth moon appeared over Egypt this evening, signaling the start of the Holy Month of Ramadan.

Sixty-one volunteers of the Fire Department Emergency Auxiliary Corps who have been, studying firefighting in the fire houses of the Third Division, between Fourteenth, and Fifty-ninth Streets, held a rehearsal for two hours and a half yesterday morning at Twenty-seventh Street and the Hudson River.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Russian mines were blamed today for the sinking of two Bulgarian ships in the Black Sea.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Justice Department has been asked to take action under the anti-trust laws against "priority profiteers," who have raised prices of some chemicals from 100 to 400 per cent.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- The German High Command, after three months of war in Russia, announced today that heavy losses had been inflicted on the four armies of Marshal Semyon Budenny reported encircled east of captured Kiev, and that the Crimean Peninsula had been cut off from the rest of the Soviet Union.

WANTED -- A falcon in reasonably good condition. Must be willing to settle down as the mascot of a regiment. Experience in falconry not necessary. Apply 101st Cavalry, 6th Army Corps, Fort Devens, Ayer, Mass.

With the death of Rudolf Schoenheimer, biological chemistry has lost one of its commanding figures. Before he began his researches, already classic, no physiologist could say that he knew exactly how the body converts a mouthful of beefsteak or a pat of butter into tissue.
WITH THE SECOND ARMY IN LOUISIANA, Sept. 21 -- Army officials will see tomorrow what Army planes can do to tanks with live bombs.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 21 -- If at first you don't succeed, try, try again. That is a schoolday motto Miss Jean Bauer of Providence and Chris Brinke of Detroit must have learned well.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, in an address at the official opening of the university this afternoon, called on American citizens to relinquish all ideas of passive defense and turn the full strength of national power against the Axis forces.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Herbert L. Bowman, Nassau County defense director, announced today that the communications program of the Nassau County Defense Council and subordinate units would be tested on Friday night, Oct. 10, with sectional blackouts and other civilian - defense problems.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While it is valuable to distinguish between the various uses of the term inflation, I believe that A.W. Warner, in his letter published Sept. 19, introduces undue complications by saying that the word is used to mean five or more different things.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Soviet Ambassador Ivan Maisky issued a special appeal to British workers today on the eve of "Tanks for Russia Week," during which every tank produced in the United Kingdom will be delivered to Russia. Beginning tomorrow, Mr. Maisky will visit factories turning out machines of war.
VICHY, France, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the speech Marshal Henri Philippe Petain addressed to "Frenchmen of the occupied zone" today:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- Fighting desperately to remain in the Naional League pennant race with the Dodgers, Billy Southworth's Cardinals beat the Cubs today in both ends of a double-header that marked their farewell appearance of the championship season at Sportsmans Park. St. Louis thus cut a game off Brooklyn's two-game lead.

Seamen on three more ships arriving in United States ports went on strike yesterday as the Seafarers International Union, A.F. of L., denounced as "intimidation" the action of the government in seizing three other vessels and sailing two of them under Maritime Commission operation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Not much has been heard lately about the British children -- nearly four thousand of them -- who were sent to the United States when the Nazi raids on Britain were at their worst.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- Fighting desperately to remain in the Naional League pennant race with the Dodgers, Billy Southworth's Cardinals beat the Cubs today in both ends of a double-header that marked their farewell appearance of the championship season at Sportsmans Park. St. Louis thus cut a game off Brooklyn's two-game lead.

Seamen on three more ships arriving in United States ports went on strike yesterday as the Seafarers International Union, A.F. of L., denounced as "intimidation" the action of the government in seizing three other vessels and sailing two of them under Maritime Commission operation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Not much has been heard lately about the British children -- nearly four thousand of them -- who were sent to the United States when the Nazi raids on Britain were at their worst.

With their three small children looking on, Mrs. Blanche Tannraillo, 21 years old, shot and killed her husband, Andrew, also 21, in their fourth-floor apartment at 677 East 137th Street, the Bronx, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- Subscriptions for the Issue of the 5 per cent nine-year treasury bonds which opened on Sept. 15 totalled 9,882,000,000 lire in the first five days, the Voce d'Italia announced today. That sum, the newspaper stressed, was considerably higher than the one obtained in corresponding periods during previous state loans.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Cleveland and St. Louis traded shut-outs today, the Indians grabbing the opener, 14 to 0, and the Browns taking the nightcap, 3 to 0.
At least six new films will arrive at Broadway theatres this week. The program follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A private at Chanute Field, Rantoul, Ill., thinks life in Army camps is "heaven" and he has written President Roosevelt to assure him so and to make a number of suggestions for speeding national defense. He also pleaded for sacrifices and an end of strikes in aircraft factories.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 21 -- Some of Syria's leading nationalist politicians, who were outstanding during two decades of negotiations for independence under republican France, have been included in the new Syrian Government that Prime Minister Hassan Bey Kakin announced late Saturday night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Prices of corn were affected last week by the same factors that influenced wheat and ranged lower. Another unsettling factor was the receipt of the first car of new corn of the season which graded No. 4 yellow and sold at 12 1/4 cents a bushel under the December.

Rosh ha-Shanah sermons and addresses marking the 5702d year of the Jewish calendar, which began at sunset last night, placed emphasis yesterday on the moral aspects of the present world crisis and repudiated efforts to drive a wedge between American Christians and Jews on issues of foreign policy.

A strike that would tie up work on millions of dollars In Navy contracts at the Long Island City plants of the Ford Instrument Company was authorized yesterday by members of the United Instrument Workers, Local 425, of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 21 -- Errol Flynn, the stalwart movie hero, and Jimmie Fidler, movie columnist, engaged early today in another of those one-punch Hollywood battles -- this time over the current Senate movie investigation -- and the ending had a new and unhappy theme from the usual Flynn curtain.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 21 -- Important influences connected with local economic and financial developments and with European capital movements continue to affect the stock markets of the smaller Continental European countries.

The premiere of "The Distant City" -- Broadway's only theatrical event this week-takes place tonight at the Longacre Theatre. The author, Edwin B. Self, has written of the love of a mother for her son, who is involved in a murder.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Forty-fourth Division headquar ters announced today plans for the division's 690-mile trip to Wadesboro, N.C., for two months of manoeuvres with First Army troops. Unlike previous motor movements of the division, this trip will be made by daylight and will require four days of actual traveling for the 2,000 vehicles and 15,000 men.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21 -- The New York Giants scored in every period to defeat the Churchill pros, 41 to 0, in an exhibition football game today before a crowd of 4,000. George Franck, the all-America back from Minnesota; Len Eshmont of Fordham, Frank Reagan of Penn, Red McClain of Southern Methodist and Jim Poole, veteran end, scored the touch-downs, Franck getting two.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- War Department supply contract awards announced yesterday for the Air Corps, Ordnance Department and Quartermaster Corps amounted to $7,913,318.98, and Included the following awards to concerns with headquarters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The university of Chicago will begin tomorrow morning its fiftieth anniversary week, in commemoration of its first years of "new frontiers in education and research," with a program of scientific symposia and academic festivities.

Under a banner, "Welcome Soldiers and Sailors-New York Labor Is With You," 2,000 service men and 1,000 "picked" girls enjoyed a carefree evening last night at the Gay Blades, Fifty-second Street west of Broadway, where roller skates had given way to the tunes of the rumba and conga.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Changes in sentiment were unusually rapid last week in regard to the immediate trend of the wheat market and speculators who were aggressive buyers in the preceding week generally went out of their holdings in the last few days.

ELIZABETHTOWN, Ky., Sept. 21 (AP) -- A mother who was visiting her soldier son at Fort Knox, a man who kidnapped her and another civilian were killed in a head-on auto collision near here early today.

MODERN Britain is "simply toiling with change." So says Allan Nevins, who recently returned to New York after six months in England as Harmsworth Professor of American History at Oxford. British cities have changed. The British countryside has changed. British society is being transformed from "top to bottom."
Hymenoptera to Gestapo Scientists gathered for the University of Chicago semi-centennial will seek for the origins of totalitarianism and the leadership principle in a study of lower forms of life.

Since Italy entered the war the harbor at Gibraltar has not been of much use to the British fleet. While the fortress on "the rock" itself is believed to be impregnable from the sea or air, the 440-acre harbor is too vulnerable to aerial bombardment to serve as a naval base.
WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22 -- In perfect weather, ninety-nine, players tried for places in the New Jersey State women's golf championship over the perfectly groomed Echo Lake course today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Secretary Hull indicated today that he favored drastic modification of the Neutrality Act. He asserted that since 1935 both President Roosevelt and he have felt that the measure was quite as likely to get the United States into war as to keep it out.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- British bombers swarmed across the southeast coast today, resuming their bombardment of occupied Europe after bad weather had interrupted a forty-four-hour week-end offensive believed to have been the heaviest and most sustained yet undertaken by the Royal Air Forces.

The path of United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa's broad inquiry into the motion-picture industry was cleared of one possible obstacle yesterday in Federal court when Judge John W. Holland sustained a subpoena served on George E. Browne, movie union president.

Fifty years ago the late John D. Rockefeller and the late Dr. William R. Harper, then a young professor at Yale, heaved a rock into the educational pond. The splash has subsided, but the waves will always wash up on distant shores. With a handsome donation from Mr. Rockefeller, Dr. Harper founded a great institution.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Officials and members of the headquarters staff of the National Confectioners Association met here today as a preliminary to a survey to reduce the packaging requirements of the industry by an estimated 25 per cent.
NEW YORK Mrs. Frederick W. Drury and Miss Frances Sands Drury have returned to 18 East Sixtieth Street for the Winter.

ROME, Sept. 22 -- In a daring raid that carried them right into the center of Gibraltar's harbor, Italian naval units claim to have destroyed three British merchant ships and gravely damaged a fourth. Official bulletins describing the raid, issued today, say it occurred on Saturday.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that an inventory had been completed and specifications drawn to equip the civilian population with gas masks. He spoke at a luncheon of the Young Men's Board of Trade in Longchamps Restaurant at 253 Broadway.

The strange path of Sidney Greenberg's "romance" came to light in the Tombs yesterday when the Bond Clothing Company discovered that the checks he had given for an outfit in which to get married were not so good as cash. The district attorney's office decided the checks were bad enough to constitute grand larceny, and the grand jury agreed.

Paddy Jr., an aristicratic but tolerant border terrier, took a back seat yesterday morning with good grace. Only a few refined sniffs indicated an inner conviction that ancestry in dogdom evidently did not count for much these days.

Salvatore Baccaloni, Metropolitan Opera basso comique who made his New York debut last season, arrived yesterday on the American Republics liner Uruguay from engagements in South American cities with Bruno Landi, Metropolitan tenor.

Sales of national defense stamps practically doubled in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn as a result of the celebration last week of "Retailers for Defense Week," it was stated yesterday by Major B.H. Namm, national chairman of the week, and chairman of the retail advisory committee of the United States Treasury.

" Cape Cod Ballads" was published in 1902. Since then Joseph C. Lincoln has written thirty-five novels, three volumes of short stories, three books of sketches and two of verse -- not to mention three novels done in collaboration with his son, Freeman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Sept. 13 amounted to 246,164,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 1,364,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decrease of 1,673,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude but an increase of 309,000 in stocks of foreign crude.

The defense program with its far-reaching social and economic implications is giving Americans the opportunity to become acquainted with each other, Mrs. Isabella Greenway King, chairman of the board of directors of the American Women's Voluntary Services, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, predicted today that longer working hours and a lower standard of living were just ahead for America under the national rearmament program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 20:

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Local operations dominated the action of the wheat market today. Prices fluctuated in a nervous manner within a maximum range of about 1 1/2 cents a bushel, but ran into scattered selling on the bulges and buying on the breaks, without the market getting anywhere.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The House passed by a voice vote today a resolution changing the Defense Plant Amortization Act to allow six months instead of sixty days after the beginning of defense plant construction or expansion, within which applications for necessity certificates must be filed in Order to obtain tax credit for amortization purposes.

John R. Davies, who contested the Republican Mayoralty nomination with Mayor La Guardia, arrived here yesterday after a five-day vacation, still uncertain whether he will run as an independent in the general election.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 22 -- Chile is ready to impose measures "to safeguard her sovereignty and dignity if Chilean citizens arrested in Germany have been taken in reprisal for the arrest of Nazi leaders here," emphatically declared Foreign Minister Juan Bautista Rossetti this morning when questioned regarding repeated reports from abroad, unconfirmed officially, that nine Chileans have been detained by police authorities in Berlin, Vienna and Paris.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- With four Russian armies trapped east of Kiev, the Baltic island of Oesel for all practical purposes already in their hands, Leningrad beleaguered, Crimea cut off from land connection with the rest of Russia and being invaded and strong motorized forces driving toward Kharkov and the Donets Basin, according to their accounts, the Germans yesterday and today intensified their activities against the Soviet Navy and merchant marine.

A high-pressure campaign to move millions of gallons of whisky to consumers before new Federal taxes adding $1 a gallon become effective Oct. 1, was developing in the retail, wholesale and distilling divisions of the industry here yesterday. Outside New York the campaign has already gotten underway with special advertising and solicitations of consumers by retailers.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (delayed for reasons that will become apparent) -- A sham attack was made before dawn today on the Ministry of Information building, and the men who handle the war dispatches are unable to agree as to who won the battle.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 22 -- J.W.Y. Martin's Abrasion, after a disappointing campaign in the New England sector, crashed the winners' circle for the first time since the Summer meeting at Delaware Park when he sprinted to an easy triumph in the Susquehanna Handicap today.

If there is anything in omens, we are in for a brilliant dance season, for the Jooss Ballet officially raised the curtain last night with an altogether beautiful performance. The program promised no novelties, consisting as it did of four works which have been seen here more than once, but there is no other novelty quite equal to that of becoming reacquainted with the essential qualities of living art.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In view of the fact that this country is becoming more and more interested in things military and government policy, isn't it about time the public be led into the way of proper thinking by the press in matters concerning things military?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- "Gold Importage," a novel of Alaskan adventure by Robert Ormond Case, published last year, was bought today by Republic as a vehicle for Ray Middleton. Middleton recently completed "Mercy Island" with Gloria Dickson, whom the studio has signed for three more pictures, and it is expected that she will appear again with him in "Gold Importage."

A new addition to the week's openings is "This Woman Is Mine," with Franchot Tone, Walter Brennan, Carol Bruce, John Carroll and Nigel Bruce, which the Rivoli will present on Saturday. The film was directed and produced by Frank Lloyd from the Gilbert Gabriel novel, "I, James Lewis."

HONOLULU, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Martin R. Connelly, aged 26, an Army Air Corps officer at Syracuse, N.Y., was shot and killed in an argument with a Customs guard today at the pier where the steamship President Cleveland en route to San Francisco from Manila was docked.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses will open at 3 o'clock this afternoon a new playground and observation terrace on Fort Washington Avenue at 190th Street on land that was donated recently to the city by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 22 -- Germany confronted Bulgaria with a virtual ultimatum during the week-end, demanding Bulgaria's prompt entry into war against Russia on threat of complete occupation of Bulgaria by the German Army, this correspondent learned from trusted foreign diplomatic sources this evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- An explanation of its present position relative to a proposed defensive, political and economic alliance between Sweden and Finland has been received at the Swedish Legation from the Swedish Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The United States is working on an armament program that will reach a total of more than $66,000,000,000 if the request for a new lend-lease appropriation is approved by Congress in its present form, according to Office of Production Management figures disclosed today.
William Selden Miles, 79-year-old Negro, was honored yesterday by members of the Union League Club at the completion of sixty years of service for the club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Francois H. Charles-Roux, nephew of the former French Ambassador of the same name to the Vatican, has resigned as deputy consul of the Vichy government in New York to go over to the Free French cause, it was learned today.
ROME, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- A Stefani (Italian) News Agency dispatch from the "zone of operations" said today that German motorized columns had advanced thirty-one miles into Egypt beyond Solum.

GARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Now that the primary is over and he is the unwilling nominee of the Democratic party for Putnam County's highest office, Samuel Sloan Duryee said today that his principles as a loyal Democrat required that he stop his street-corner and commuter-train campaigning for his Republican opponent, but that he still hoped he would lose in the November election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- That President Roosevelt's foreign and defense policies will be endorsed at the fourth annual convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was the expectation reported here today following a conference of C.I.O. division chiefs with President Philip Murray.

VICHY, France, Sept. 22 -- On the eve of the anniversary of the defense of Dakar on Sept. 23 to 25 a year ago Governor General Pierre Boisson of that West African colony received the French, German and other foreign press in Vichy to declare that all West Africa was solidly behind Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and in a better position for defense than ever.

Just to prove that there are still large salmon in the Southwest Miramichi, up in New Brunswick, R.W. Harrison of New York City went out on his birthday and came back with a 30-pounder, reported to be the largest salmon taken from that water in many years.
PORT ARTHUR, Texas, Sept. 22 -- A Gulf storm, with winds of more than seventy-five miles an hour, was headed inland tonight and expected to strike between Port Arthur and Port O'Connor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22-- At a legislative strategy conference held soon after he returned today from Hyde Park, President Roosevelt received assurances from Democratic Congressional leaders of the speediest possible passage of the $5,985,000,000 lend-lease appropriation.

WITH THE RED ARMY on the Central Front, Sept. 20 (Delayed) -- Having broken the spine of the Germans' powerful initial drive toward Moscow, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's troops now are grinding slowly forward through the lacerated forests, tank-torn fields and burned-out villages of the rolling upper Dnieper Valley.

Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, has put on, as the new season's opening attraction there, two exhibitions -- related in that both are addressed to the same general theme. One of these, composed of engravings, is entitled "Children of Britain"; the other, "Pictures of Children," most of them oils, and in the main by French artists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Even if the Nazi forces occupy all the Ukraine or even all European Russia they will still find themselves with a war on their hands on the Eastern front, although it may be a different character from the present struggle, the Commerce Department reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- In objecting to Westchester County's proposed use of the Rye Lake site in Purchase for an airport, New York City is attempting to obstruct the normal growth of the county by establishing precedent of dictation over the development of areas surrounding the city's vast reservoirs, the Westchester Board of Supervisors' committee on airport sites asserted today in a 3,000-word letter to Mayor La Guardia.

Charleston, S.C., with a gain of 67 per cent over 1940, and Phoenix, Arizona, with a rise of 61 per cent, led in department store sales increases by cities during August, according to the report issued by the Federal Reserve Board. Norfolk, Va., with an upswing of 46 per cent over 1940, made the best comparative showing for the first eight months of this year.

Promotion of better understanding and friendlier relations among industry, advertising and the public will be the aim of this year's program proposed for its affiliated advertising club by the Advertising Federation of America, James A. Welch, vice president, Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Three British battleships and nine other vessels were revealed by the Navy Department today as having visited American ports and departed after being repaired or serviced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The National Defense Mediation Board called today for "complete resumption of construction work" on the $5,000,000 propeller plant of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation at Beaver, Pa., tied up since Sept. 10 by a strike of twenty-nine A.F. of L. building trades unions because of a jurisdictional dispute with an independent union.

A high official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration testified yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial that he had been approached in the Spring of 1940 with a request to furnish information on United States airplane shipments to the Allies to members of an alleged German spy ring.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- A danger besetting the preservation of learning was laid before the annual conference of the New York Library Association tonight by William Warner Bishop, librarian of the University of Michigan.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Justice Bernard L. Shientag of the Supreme Court, First Judicial District, who leased a penthouse at 944 Park Avenue through Wm. A. White Sons, agents, and Francis R. Jaffin, broker.

Education and merchandising are the keynotes of the plan to make a national trade body of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, which was released to the public yesterday. The proposal, already approved by the board of governors, is to go before the membership on Oct. 7.

For the fourth consecutive session the cotton market yesterday declined under pressure of increased hedge selling and liquidation. Prices of futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, after a momentary rally around midday, dropped sharply in active trading.

A new system of gas rationing for October for the seventeen Eastern States, where the government says a shortage exists, has been suggested to the Petroleum Coordinator's office in Washington by the Eastern Petroleum Marketing Committee, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Testimony designed to show that wage rates of railroad workers have lagged behind those of workers in other industries was presented today to the Presidential fact-finding commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- William A. McClurg, a Republican politician in Chester, Pa., was sentenced today to one to two years in County Prison by Judge Edwin O. Lewis in Quarter Sessions Court after he had pleaded guilty to a charge of conspiracy to bribe a public official.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Taking up where she had left off one year ago, Mrs. William R. Kirkland, representing Silver Springs, today annexed qualifying honors in the tri-county (Westchester, Putnam and Fairfield) golf championship, which got under way at the Century Club.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The morning communique of the Soviet Bureau of Information said today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Selective service headquarters today authorized local boards to defer the induction of college students into the Army when immediate induction would cause "undue hardship" because of interference with their work.

Funds are in the hands of the National City Bank, as fiscal agent, to pay at maturity on Oct. 1 the twenty-year 7 per cent external dollar bonds of the State of Queensland, Australia, it was learned yesterday. The issue is the first Australian loan and, in fact, the first dollar bond issue flotation of Great Britain or any of the dominions, to fall due since the beginning of the war on Sept. 3, 1939.
PHIADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- An editorial today in The Daily Pennsylvanian, undergraduate newspaper of the University of Pennsylvania, urged the United States to enter the war at once.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Sept. 17 aggregated $11,664,000,000.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Plans are being made for public sale of a large block of shares of Marshall Field Co. owned by several of the large stockholders, it was learned today.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, which last June bought $35,393,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds due in 1971 of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation in what originally was designed to be the first compulsory competitive sale of utility securities under Rule U-50 of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has sold a block of $10,000,000 of the issue, it was learned yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Nathaniel Peffer's letter to THE TIMES, in which he opposes a rapprochement between the United States and Japan, will make pleasant reading for those whose only idea of Far Eastern policy is embodied in the words Delenda est Cipango.

Expressing the fear that in the event of sudden air attack on America by a foreign enemy panic would cause more damage than the bombs, Mayor La Guardia last night emphasized the importance of trained emergency services that could be provided by women's organizations.

ROME, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- A Navy Ministry announcement today of the Italian raid on Gibraltar harbor said the British could not hope to keep the attack secret because "the explosions and disappearance of four steamers occurred before the eyes of the Spanish."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull was asked today in his press conference whether he thought there was undue pessimism over the situation in Russia.

Plans are being completed for the anniversary ball to be held Oct. 1 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in celebration of the tenth anniversary of the opening of the hotel. A benefit for the United Service Organizations, the ball and its decorations and entertainment program will follow a patriotic theme.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ex-President Hoover has discovered that the United States needs national unity. How attain it? He finds that the isolationists are wrong; so are the interventionists. So what to do? Be neutral? No. Be belligerent? No. What then?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Five insurance companies which own first mortgage bonds of the Florida East Coast Railway Company have filed exceptions to several of the findings and recommendations in the report of Ralph H. Jewell, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, on a reorganization plan for the road.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson of Buffalo, commander of the Fifty-seventh Infantry Brigade, has received orders reassigning him for duty with Second Corps Area headquarters at Governors Island, it was learned today.

The stock market managed to retain its balance yesterday despite the continued depressing news from the Russian war front, and reports from Washington that the Administration already is working on another tax bill. Under the proposed new legislation the alternative methods of calculating excess-profits taxes would be eliminated and the average earnings option would be wiped out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Representative Hamilton Fish of New York said tonight he would place before Congress next week a resolution to declare war against Germany and predicted its defeat in the House by more than 2 to 1.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Five French youths who escaped from France last week by crossing the English Channel in two canoes drank champagne today with Prime Minister and Mrs. Churchill at 10 Downing Street. Mr. Churchill raised his glass to them with the toast "Vive la France!"

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Development of a simple and economical mass production method for preparing potent vaccines against the various strains of typhus was described today at one of the symposia being held here in connection with the fiftieth anniversary of the University of Chicago.

Peter Gerald Lehman, 24-year-old air-minded son of Governor Lehman, refused to have his military flying hopes frustrated after the Army and Navy turned him down because he was married, and he has volunteered for service in the Royal Canadian Air Force.

With a warning from Mayor La Guardia that what American industry is now producing in war materials "is not enough if we are going to win this war," OPM's first National Defense Clinic opened a three-day session yesterday on the fourth floor of Grand Central Palace.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Winds of full gale velocity sweeping out of the Wasatch Mountain canyons on a 300-mile storm front, left Ogden, Utah's second city, isolated and without power or communication facilities today.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Genevieve McKinney Toomey Teal Paddleford Howells Fawcett, 58, one-time Broadway beauty and international adventuress, died in the State pentientiary Friday, it was revealed today.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities, included in each group is given.

THE trials and tribulations of Emile Gauvreau, the ex-Macfadden, ex-Hearst and ex-Annenberg newspaper editor, have been very great. I have known, or known of, various newspaper editors, tabloid or otherwise, but I never heard of another whose case quite matches Mr. Gauvreau's.

An average of twenty-four New Yorkers an hour experienced yesterday the sensation at the National Defense Exposition of walking through a gas-filled chamber wearing one of the Martianlike transformations known as a gas mask.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Authorizations designed to improve the oil and gas situation in the Eastern States, and to prevent development of a shortage of supplies on the Pacific Coast in consequence of the diversion of tankers to transport aviation gasoline to Russia, were issued today by Secretary Ickes.

Prices on waste paper have been cut so sharply under the new ceilings issued at the close of last week by the Office of Price Administration that stoppage in the flow of material to the mills is bound to ensue after Oct. 1, when the maximums become effective, dealers said here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from Martin Flavin published by you on Sept. 2 sought to explain the poor morale of the draftees on three main grounds: that the method of drafting men indiscriminately was wrong, that the Army was poorly officered and that it was deficient in essential fighting equipment.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Joseph Berlinger and Frank Stuhler of the North Shore Country Club teamed to win the one-day woman-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. with a 79 -- 8 -- 71 score over the Garden City Country Club course today.

"As You Lake It" will open Oct. 22 at the Mansfield Theatre, it was announced yesterday by Eugene S. Bryden and Ben Boyar, producers. Rehearsals begin today under Mr. Bryden's direction. Pete Cusanelli, Murvyn Vye, James O'Neill, Kenneth Tobey and Randolph Echols complete the cast.

A good deal of mystery has surrounded the discussions which have been in progress for several weeks between the United States and Japan. "This was inevitable in the circumstances. On the initiative of Prince Konoye the two Governments have been exploring the possibilities of a better understanding, and conversations of this kind can only be carried on in confidence.

One thousand vessels are under construction or under contract to fee built to American Bureau of Shipping standards, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the classification committee of the bureau, reported yesterday at the semi-monthly meeting of the committee.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Indians slipped into a tie for fourth place with the Tigers today by dropping a 5-to-0 decision to the Browns in their final home game. Only about 1,500 fans were in the stands as St. Louis handed Bob Feller his thirteenth defeat and the tribe its second straight shut-out.

While "The Distant City" was dragging one foot after the other at the Longacre last evening, a reviewer could hardly help asking himself, "How did this one ever jump all the hazards and actually get on the stage?" Probably because it carries a message.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 22 -- The Japanese southward advance has struck a snag in Thailand. It is evident in Bangkok, from where the writer has just arrived after a ten-day visit, that the Japanese have not succeeded in making Thailand an economic, political or military tributary of Tokyo.

Sooner or later Turkey must make up her mind which side she is on in the struggle raging all around her. The return of the German Ambassador to Ankara, after his conferences with Adolf Hitler, may precipitate that decision. No doubt he will bring tempting inducements for closer collaboration between Turkey and the Reich, and dire threats in the event the Turks prove difficult to convince.

Don Snavely, varsity center, and Ken Germann, alternate first-string tailback, returned to action at Baker Field yesterday as the Columbia football squad entered its third week of training. The former has been recuperating from a leg bruise and Germann from a shoulder sprain.

Hygrade Sylvania A banking group headed by Jackson Curtis will offer today 100,000 shares of Hygrade Sylvania Corporation common stock, priced at $19 3/8 a share. Proceeds of this financing will be used to increase the company's working capital, as the result of expansion of business in the fluorescent lighting and radio-tube fields.

New Lease on Life Plans to use a pulmotor on the Association of Stock Exchange firms are so general in their phraseology that they must be judged as symptoms of a state of mind rather than as promises for fulfillment.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Lippy Leo Durocher's equanimity was partially restored today as he watched the calm and efficient Curt Davis shut out the Phillies or half a dozen hits while his determined Dodgers belted Rube Melton for eight to turn in a 5-0 triumph.

Studies of twenty common stocks and ten preferred stocks have been made by the statisticians of the New York Stock Exchange at the request of the joint committee of the New York State Legislature which is investigating the possibility of broadening the investment territory in which life insurance companies may operate.

Trading opened fair in the wholesale markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to 50 cents higher. The lamb market was strong with some in-between sales 50 cents higher. Other classes of fresh meats were steady. Due to the Jewish holidays there were no kosher markets. Of the classes generally killed "kosher," only a light supply of lambs was slaughtered today and these were intended solely for the traefer trade.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Although a little more optimistic over the steel supply situation as a result of advices from Washington, the members of the National Contract Hardware Association and the American Society of Architectural Hardware Consultants prepared last week for a last-ditch fight to keep the builders' hardware business alive during the defense program.
The fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks will open tomorrow in St. Paul, Minn., with 200 delegates and guests in attendance.

Nearly 3,000,000 employes in small non-defense manufacturing plants throughout the country face loss of employment within six months unless the Federal system of priorities for national defense needs is revised to permit allocation of a small percentage of raw materials to these plants, Walter B. Weisenburger, executive vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said here yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Sept. 23 -- Although the Soviet position on the Ukrainian front remains grave, Russian forces have succeeded in turning back German spearheads driving into the Donets Basin south of Kharkov, according to a Moscow military spokesman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A House subcommittee, beginning tomorrow to examine the President's new lend-lease budget, will doubtless show some critical interest in the record made under the first lend-lease appropriation of six months ago. This Mr. Roosevelt recently summarized in a message to Congress.

With a gathering of 22,590 wagering $1,043,429 on the seven races at Belmont Park yesterday, the afternoon developed into a tedious one for the form players, who had to wait until the finale to see a favorite romp home in front.
BERLIN, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The German High Command communique from "the Fuehrer's Headquarters" said today:

TOKYO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Japan, under economic pressure by the United States and Britain, tightened her belt another notch today with drastic reductions of steel and iron goods production and looked anew to diplomatic discussions in Washington to produce a possible key to accord.

SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 22 -- After two years of unprecedented industrial effort at a cost of billions of dollars, the United States Army is beginning to acquire first-class planes in considerable and increasing quantity.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 22 -- It was revealed here today that sixty Russian sailors, whose internment in Sweden was announced last night, arrived in two armed tugs, probably from the island of Dagoe, which, according to the Russian radio, quoted by the newspaper Aftonbladet, was attacked last night by German naval forces.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Moscow Radio reported tonight that the British and United States delegations for the three-power conference, including the Soviet Government, have arrived in Moscow by plane. There had been no announcement here that the American delegation, headed by W. Averell Harriman, had left London, but officials said that "for reasons of security" none was to be expected until the Americans reached their destination safely.

There was speculation in the Bronx yesterday as to whether a sleepwalker could dress without waking, hide a cooking kit under his jacket and then set forth on an expedition still sound asleep. This poser was put by the story of 11-year-old Richard E. Hoffman of 1541 West Farms Road, the Bronx, who figured in a bizarre bit of somnambulism over the week-end.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Last November a Holy Cross football team with the poorest record of any to wear the Purple in recent years threatened for fifty-seven minutes to ruin the season of the Boston College eleven that humbled Tennessee in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on New Year's Day.
The responsibilities of the Jewish people in the present world crisis were emphasized in Rosh ha-Shanah sermons throughout the city yesterday.
The Giants burled their 1941 season at the Polo Grounds yesterday and just missed burying Casey Stengel's Braves under the wreckage.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The refreshed Cardinals, still nipping at the heels of Brooklyn in the mad fight for the National League pennant, departed tonight for their last-ditch stand against Pittsburgh and Chicago.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- Twenty-five inhabitants of the Belgian town of Tournai are being held by the German military police as hostages and may be shot as a reprisal for the slaying of two German police officials in Tournai last Wednesday night, it was announced by Lieut. Gen. Baron Alexander von Falkenhausen, German Military Commander for Belgium and Northern France today.

LONDON, Sept 22 -- Two Italian liners of about 24,000 tons each were torpedoed and sunk last Thursday by British submarines operating in the Central Mediterranean, the Admiralty announced today. A third vessel estimated to have been as large as the others was said probably to have been damaged.

Although expressing their earnest desire to cooperate with the Office of Price Administration and other government agencies, speakers at the thirty-second general conference of the Quality Bakers of America, at the Hotel Pennsylvania, yesterday, generally asserted that many of the trade practices which have come under government scrutiny are the result of competitive market conditions.

WASHINGTON, Sept 22 -- The United States Government-owned freighter Pink Star was sunk between Greenland and Iceland on Friday, the State Department announced tonight. It was the first American-owned ship sunk since President Roosevelt issued orders to the United States Navy to shoot on sight at German and Italian raiders in defense waters.

To insure against the possibility of a sweep by the Cardinals of their six remaining games, the Dodgers must win the four left on their schedule to capture the National League pennant. Should both teams take all their remaining contests, Brooklyn would have an advantage of one game in the "won" column, the St. Louis disadvantage being in the fact that last week the Cards were held to a tie that cannot be played off.

It is difficult to see any justification for the strike of the Seafarers International Union, an A.F. of L. subsidiary, which has now involved some twenty ships. This strike has been called on ships loaded with defense supplies urgently required at some of the United States defense bases in the Caribbean, and on ships required for the transport of bauxite (the basic ore from which aluminum is made) to this country.

LONDON, Sept 22 -- Soviet Ambassador Ivan Maisky and his wife visited tank factories in the Midlands today and at one where the workers paused for ten minutes the first of the tanks they had made in "Tanks for Russia Week" was presented to him.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 22 -- With an assist from the elements, the Newark Bears defeated the Montreal Royals, 5 -- 4, in an eleven-inning thriller that deadlocked the final International League Governors' Cup series at 3-all tonight at Ruppert Stadium.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Making a last-minute fight for a first division berth, the Tigers climbed into a fourth-place tie with Cleveland today with an 11-to-0 victory over the White Sox.

The national headquarters staff of the Home Owners Loan Corporation reported for work yesterday morning at 2 Park Avenue to find that everything was in readiness for them to continue where they left off last week when movers took possession of the offices the Federal agency then occupied at First Street and Indiana Avenue, Washington, D.C.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) -- Sept. 22 -- The Bourse opened today with a hesitant tone and a small trade, although at the close a keen demand developed. Royal Dutch was up 1 point net to 322 1/2; Amsterdam Trading was 1 higher at 494; A.K. U.2 at 152 3/8.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines has estimated the October market demand for domestic crude oil at 124,400,000 barrels, or 4,012,900 daily. This is 52,900 barrels more than the estimated daily demand for September and 11 per cent above the actual demand for October a year ago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- With receipts higher than last Monday and with several local packers still out of the market as a result of labor trouble, hogs were barely steady to 10 cents lower in today's livestock transactions.

A blanket priority covering repairs and replacements will be sought by the paper industry at the meeting today with the OPM in Washington, it was learned here yesterday following a conference of officials of the American Paper and Pulp Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

United States Senator Gerald P. Nye, addressing an America First rally in the Brooklyn Academy of Music with 500 policemen on guard against disorder, charged last night that he and other non-interventionists were being "smeared" with the issue of anti-Semitism.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau early today issued the following communique:

A call for immediate settlement of the A.F. of L. seamen's strike that has tied up twenty-three ships in United States ports was issued from Washington last night by the Maritime Commission as members of the Seafarers International Union met in fourteen cities to discuss a general strike.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Japan is rushing masses of additional troops to Manchukuo as a result of mounting confidence in Tokyo over German victories against the Red Army, foreign military observers reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Opposition to the blanket price control plan offered to the House Banking and Currency Committee on Friday by Bernard M. Baruch was voiced before the committee today by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, who spent much of the twelfth day he has been under questioning explaining why he thinks the administration's piecemeal control plan is better.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 22 -- An attempt by the revolting miners of District 7, United Mine Workers of America, C.I.O., to spread their revolt against increased dues and assessments met with indifferent success in District 1 today even as their fellow-workers were engaged in meetings designed to end a stoppage of activity at forty-two anthracite workings which has put 20,000 men out of work.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- John A. Herrmann of the Century Country Club, who hasn't played competitive golf outside of his home club events in three years, re-entered competition at Fenway today and teamed with Dan Galgano, Woodway pro, to win the Westchester P.G.A. one-day best-ball event by two strokes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 22 -- The biggest pro-German newspaper in Finland, the Helsingin Sanomat, publishes an editorial today violently supporting Field Marshal Baron Carl Mannerheim's bid for Soviet Karelia.

"Cheese is a man's food, and this is a man's cheese," said a stern saleswoman who stood guard over the small, wrapped-in-cellophane cylinders that we were regarding so wistfully. Like the sturdy country sausages that Alpine shepherd boys carry with them to lunch on in the cold mountain air, these golden cheeses are long and round and firmly wrapped in a casing tied at either end with a knot of cord.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Secretary Knox, appealing for speed in every defense operation, told 12,000 United Aircraft Workers today that "it is hard for you to realize that American sailormen are today at sea fighting dictatorships.
LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 22 -- Army officers who settle claims for damage done in the Louisiana manoeuvres, are praising the patriotism of farmers making cash sacrifices for their government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Prevention of the concentration of radio control and stimulation of diversification are the primary objectives of the Federal Communications Commission, Chairman James L. Fly, told the National Independent Broadcasters' Association today at the opening session of its national convention.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Five months to a day since he left his stricken country, King George II of the Hellenes, accompanied by his brother, Crown Prince Paul, and high officials of the Greek Government arrived today in London.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 22 -- Indictment of German Ambassador Baron von Thermann and at least two other members of the German Embassy on charges of "reiterated frauds" is among the immediate steps that the Chamber of Deputies Investigating Committee intends to take to counteract German infiltration in Argentina, according to a statement made to the press this morning by the committee's president, Raoul Taborda.

The American Car and Foundry Company announced yesterday that it would defer a dividend of $1 a share on its common stock, which was to have been paid on Oct. 1, because of a suit brought against the company.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 22 -- The United States cannot disassociate itself from the distressing conditions in the world today and lock itself in ivory towers and be untouched by everything that is occurring, President Lewis of Lafayette College said today in an address to the faculty and undergraduates at the beginning of the academic year.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Thirty-five provisions on the required wearing of the Star of David by Jews have been communicated to the Jewish Central Council to clear up uncertainties as to when and how the star, first required last Friday, must be displayed.

VICHY, France, Sept. 22 -- While Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, welcomed today with an ovation in Savoy, was pleading for all Frenchmen to stand together behind him for the safety of the nation Paris was going through its third and last night of curfew regulations ordered in punishment for assaults on the troops of occupation.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick promulgated yesterday an amendment to the sales tax regulation eliminating a double taxation threat that would have taken a substantial sum from residents of New York City after the new Federal excise taxes become effective next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A two-run uprising in the ninth brought Washington a 4-3 decision over Boston today for the Senators' sixth straight victory.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Camp Polk, La., Sept. 23 -- Deficiencies in small unit training and inadequate officer leadership were described by Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair today as the principal weaknesses revealed by the first phase of the Army Manoeuvres just ended.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Russians, gravely concerned by the growing German threat to the vital Donets Basin industrial area, have counter-attacked against Nazi forces along hundreds of miles of the front in a determined effort to relieve pressure on Soviet armies in the south.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor reached Miami by chartered plane today on the first leg of a six-week vacation tour of the United States and Canada and were greeted by the cheers of several thousand persons.

Faith in the ultimate victory of democracy over dictatorship was expressed by rabbis here in sermons yesterday, the second day of Rosh Ha-Shanah, the Jewish year 5702. Calli upon American Jews to continue their unswerving patriotism and loyalty, the speakers deplored anti-Semitism as a Nazi method of weakening the nation.

An interesting house closely associated with the life of the Gramercy Park neighborhood back in the days when all of that section of Manhattan was given over to private residences, figures in a realty sale just made to an investing group.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Nicholas Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., which controls Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, told a Senate subcommittee today he would consider it "the worst kind of a crime" for a group of companies to "get together" to prevent another company from doing business.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 23 -- With a majority described by union officials as "overwhelming," members of the machinists' union of the American Federation of Labor in secret ballotting last night and today authorized a strike against the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation, builder of long-range bombers, which holds defense orders exceeding $750,000,000.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Sept. 24 -- Driving along a front stretching from Poltava to Krasnograd, about sixty miles southwest of Kharkov, a Russian force greatly strengthened by new units from the northeast and by immense quantities of materiel salvaged from the defeat at Kiev has checked the German thrust from Kremenchug toward Kharkov, Soviet sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Senator Norris, Independent, asserted today that repeal of the Neutrality Act would mean war and he voiced his doubts that Congress would approve a declaration, of war at the present time.

Warning of the danger of a two-ocean attack by Germany and Japan against the United States and Canada if the Nazis conquer Russia and Great Britain, Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn of Ontario last night denounced strikes in war industries as disloyal and called for drastic measures against radical agitators who promote them.

With but one week remaining of the apartment rental season, yesterday's leasing reports showed little diminution from the volume that has been current for several weeks. Among the latest lessees were several executives and employes of rubber and oil companies.
HOUSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A tropical hurricane hurled winds of 90 and 100 miles an hour against the Texas coast today from Freeport to Matagorda.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Light-weight hogs, which are coming upon the livestock market in greater numbers, dropped today 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. Heavier butchers hogs and sows held steady to 10 cents down. A reported lag in consumer demand for dressed pork acted as a depressing influence on live hog prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board, in a move to combat inflation, will increase reserve requirements of member banks by about one-seventh, or to the present statutory limit, on Nov. 1. It said that the funds affected would amount to $1,200,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of Sept. 20 you have endorsed the too-little, too-late policy of sending the bulk of lease-lend supplies to England and some leftover help to Russia "for special needs." But --

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 23 -- Eighteen hundred soldiers of the 174th Infantry, from Western New York, held a farewell review this afternoon for Colonel Joseph W. Becker, who was relieved of the command of the regiment yesterday because he is two years over the new 55-year age limit for colonels.

There will be a solemn mass of thanksgiving this morning in the chapel at the French Hospital for Sister Mary of St. Eudoxie, who has rounded out sixty years of religious life and fifty-three in service to the sick. This afternoon she will receive good wishes from the nurses' alumnae at a reception in honor of their oldest member still on duty.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 23 -- Vice Chancellor James E. Fielder restrained today consummation of a plan for an exchange of stock proposed by directors of the Pacific Western Oil Company, a Delaware corporation with offices at 15 Exchange Place, Jersey City, pending final hearing in the litigation started by Sylvia Wirklich of the Bronx, N.Y., a stockholder.

Mayor La Guardia's frequent absences from the city in connection with his defense post were defended yesterday by Acting Mayor Newbold Morris, who said any other Mayor of New York City would have been drafted, too, "if he was a good Mayor."

Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Republican-Fusion-Labor candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, opened his election campaign last night by asserting that the cleaning out of "political barnacles" from an "abounding number of costly sinecures" begun four years ago, in that office, had led to a program of public improvements which must be continued in the next four years.

Members of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, had a preview last night of the new furniture and furnishings that have resulted from the inter-American design competition held by the museum's department of industrial design.

Bank Reserve Requirements The Federal Reserve Board took last night the long awaited and anticipated step of lifting member bank reserve requirements by the full limit of the law, effective on Nov. 1. The immediate effect of this action will be to reduce excess reserves -- the alleged basis for credit inflation -- by about $1,200,000,000 to around $4,000,000,000.

Two seamen were held on a charge of homicide yesterday following the death of Plainclothes Patrolman James A. Schowers, 40 years old, of 244 East 196th Street, the Bronx, who was injured when he plunged fifteen feet into an areaway from the high, narrow stoop of an old-fashioned brown-stone house at 2032 Fifth Avenue, with, most of the stone and metal railing falling on him and crushing his head.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23 -- The fates that had smiled so sweetly on the Bears last night had a change of heart tonight. For under the same lights at Ruppert Stadium, the breaks -- with the pennant winners in the previous game -- went the opposite way in this one and led to a thrilling 4-to-3 victory for the Montreal Royals.

The familiar deep-throated bark of the seven sea lions in the central pool under the big dome at the Aquarium was missing yesterday. The thirty-seven-foot pool was empty even of the blue-green water in which the sea lions frolicked, and in its place was a large yellow and-black sign, that read:

ROME, Sept 23 -- The German controlled Croat Government has executed fifty men described as "Communists and Jews" as "intellectual instigators" of the recent bomb explosions in the Zagreb central telephone exchange, in which a German major, twelve German soldiers and several Croats were wounded, according to dispatches from Zagreb printed in the Italian press today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 23 Alfred M. Morris of the Scarsdale Golf Club, Westchester seniors' champion, repeated the victory he scored in the title event at Westchester Hills a few months ago by winning the annual Fall tournament of the association at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today.

A demand that the United States Department of Agriculture and the New York City Board of Education take steps to reinstate the sale of penny-a-glass milk in all Queens schools was made yesterday by George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens.
BERLIN, Sept. 23 -- From German-occupied Belgium today came reports of five new death sentences -- three against Communists and two for "favoring the enemy."

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept 23 -- How an instrument of war was made out of the peace library of the League of Nations was told tonight by Miss Marie Ginsberg to members of the State Library Association, gathered in annual conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Sept. 16 amounted to 2,093,414 running bales, including 131 round bales counted as half bales and excluding linters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Opening the Administration's drive for the quickest possible enactment of the new $6,000,000,000 lease-lend and defense appropriation, Secretary Wickard told a subcommittee of the Appropriation Committee of the House today that the United States must send $1,000,000,000 of foodstuffs to Great Britain in the next five months or else the latter might lose the war.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 23 -- Moscow's flat rejection of Sofia's new protest against alleged operations of Red Army parachutists in the Bulgarian Dobruja is viewed in leading foreign diplomatic and military circles at Ankara tonight as the penultimate or perhaps even final step before a rupture of the diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Bulgaria.

After weeks of uncertainty concerning the fate of goods they had aboard the Japanese steamers Asamu Maru and Nako Maru which turned back in mid-ocean when the freezing order against Japanese assets went into effect here, importers learned yesterday that the cargoes have been discharged at the ports of origin.

TRENTON, Sept. 23 -- Sounding the keynote for the November election campaign, Governor Charles Edison told the Democratic State Convention here today that the party had a capital issue in the "sorry record" of the Republican-controlled Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A debate over the St. Lawrence seaway developed in the House today after Representative Ploeser of Missouri asserted that the actual cost of the project would exceed $1,000,000,000.

MANILA, Sept. 23 -- Apparently working on the assumption that the United States Congress will make available $54,000,000 for Philippine defenses, President Manuel Quezon and Lieut. Gen. Douglas MacArthur, chief of the Far Eastern Command, have determined at a series of conferences on plans for incorporating all the Philippine reserve forces into the United States Army by the end of the year.

A soldier assigned to typing official documents at Fort Jay, Governors Island, was arrested yesterday as the sixth person involved in a Nazi spy ring that allegedly specialized in assembling military information for Chancellor Hitler. The suspect, Rene Charles Froehlieh, was drafted into the Army last February by Local Board 175, Brooklyn, despite his open connection with a Nazi propaganda agency at that time.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Central Front, Sept. 21 (Delayed) -- The enormous central front, defended by Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's armies, may now be considered stabilized, but although a lull is setting in, counter-attacking Russians continue to advance on some salients.

The American Oil Company, a marketing corporation, controlled by the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, which in turn is controlled by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, started last week the movement of from sixty to eighty tank cars daily of gasoline from its refinery at Texas City, Texas, principally into the Southeastern States, according to an announcement made yesterday by R.E. Wilson, president of Pan American.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Closing its two-day convention in Chicago, the National Independent Broadcasters Association, representing 200 independent stations, took steps in its final session today toward reorganization and the changing of its rules and regulations governing its connection with the National Association of Broadcasters in effect Since 1939.

In behalf of the National Dunking Association of this city, its vice president has referred to Mr. Paul McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, a nice question of language. According to him, in some States, and notably in Pennsylvania, round doughnuts with the hole are called "crullers," while in some other States that name is restricted to doughnuts in the shape of a twist.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Formation of a Free French National Council of eight or nine members, to be in effect a provisional government, with political as well as military aims, was announced today.

Holiday Cut Buyers' Total Due to the religious holiday the number of visiting buyers registered in town for the week ended yesterday totaled only 508, against 1,043 in the previous week and 933 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

As the American Petroluem Institute was releasing figures yesterday showing increases in the last week in the stocks of gasoline and light fuel oils on hand in the Eastern seaboard, several filling stations in Northern New Jersey that had exhausted their September quotas were forced to close down and others tried to conserve their supplies by half-day shutdowns or by restricting sales.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Governor Van Wagoner of Michigan told a Congressional investigating committee here today that "the nation will see economic chaos within three months" unless national defense priorities on materials and labor are lightened in favor of industrial production for civilian use.
ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Sept. 23 -- A new plastics-and-mahogany airplane, susceptible of mass production from materials not now on priorities lists, is being successfully flown by test pilots here.

Women interested in serving the national defense program were urged by the War Department yesterday to concentrate on 'a campaign to quell "rumors propagated by Axis governments and their agents in this country."

While new taxes, effective on Oct. 1, apply to a variety of industries, apparently only the liquor field is in a position with ample stocks to take advantage of a "buy now" advertising campaign. This week several distillers and retailers have started extensive campaigns, urging the public to stock up now, but other industries, such as the household equipment, radio and tire fields, are unable to use this theme because of currently low stocks.

An underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation received yesterday the award of a new issue of $18,000,000 of Erie Railroad Company, Ohio division, first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1971, on a bid of 101,0959, representing an interest cost to the road of 3.19 per cent.

The famous Norden bombsight, believed to have been this country's most closely guarded aerial defense secret, figured again in the testimony yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial as the government opened its case against Herman Lang, accused with fifteen others of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) -- National Open Champion Craig Wood and his partner, Byron Nelson, the sick man from Toledo, took a commanding five-hole lead today over the hitherto invincible Ben Hogan and Jimmy Demaret at the half-way mark of their $2,000 36-hole best-ball match.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, disclosed yesterday that the $1,000,000,000 utility system had taken steps to comply with the Securities and Exchange Commission's attitude toward interlocking directorates and officers in a holding company-service organization set-up.

Confidence in the victory of democracy over the fascist aggressors is expressed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in an article, "There Will Come a Better Day," published in the first issue of the international magazine, Free World, out today.

Two new films are listed for today. "Ice-Capades," starring Dorothy Lewis, Jerry Colonna and James Ellison and featuring several skating specialists, at Loew's Criterion; "Unexpected Uncle" with Anne Shirley, James Craig, Charles Coburn and Ernest Truex, at the Palace, along with the second-run Abbott and Costello comedy, "Hold That Ghost."

A syndicate composed of the Union Securities Corporation, Hemphill, Noyes Co. and G. M.P. Murphy Co. received the award yesterday of $500,000 of road bonds of the State of West Virginia on a bid of 100.001 for $55,000 as 4s and $445,000 as 1 1/4s, or a net interest cost of 1.2846 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- An estimate, agreed to today by responsible government as well as industrial experts of the defense aircraft program, is that the jurisdictional and unionization strikes and disturbances in the plants of the propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation have already had these effects:

The sinking of still another Ameri can-owned merchant ship -- this time the Pink Star, sailing under the registry of Panama but owned by the United States Maritime Commission -- emphasizes again the crucial point of conflict between our Government and Hitler, so far as the highways of the North Atlantic are concerned.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The following is the Maritime Commission's partial list of the crew of the steamship Pink Star:

The race program at Belmont Park yesterday, including as it did several famous stakes, brought out a large number of members of society from many parts of the East, and the Turf and Field Club and auxiliary dining room near the track and all the lawn spaces were reserved for luncheon.

One hundred and fifty tons or coal had to be removed from the port side bunker of the Greek freighter O'dysseus off Bedloes Island last night in order that friemen could reach the source of a blaze that started on the craft shortly after 3 P.M. yesterday.

For guidance in their cold-blooded murder of innocent hostages the Nazis have set up what appears to be a grim sort of international currency, with the individual Nazi taken as the standard of value -- the gold brick of the New Order. At least five hostages are to be killed for any Nazi slain in any occupied country.

A public offering of 147,597 shares of the $10-par-value common stock of the Lukens Steel Company is being made today by an underwriting syndicate headed by E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Pistell, Wright Co., Ltd., and Alien Co. for the account of seven stockholders.

Miss Pauline Alderman, associate professor of music at the University of Southern California, and Miss Evelyn West, until recently an executive of the California Federal Art Project, both of Los Angeles, won $500 each yesterday in a competition sponsored by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, for the best amateur musical play of the year.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Dennis Edward Myers came into the crowded dressing room of the Boston College football coaches with the sour look of a man who had eaten something that had disagreed with him. He had just awakened from a post-prandial doze, following a lunch of hot lemonade and aspirin -- the doctor's order for a cold he contracted recently.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Tigers staged a rally in the tenth inning today to defeat the Browns, 4 -- 1, and move from a fourth-place deadlock with the idle Indians into a third-place tie with the White Sox.

THERE was a piece in the paper last week about the record Fall catch of chinook salmon in the Columbia River -- 5,000,000 pounds, more or less, taken in the space of three days, the greatest haul in thirty years. Who says that the new dams at Bonneville and elsewhere have ruined the salmon industry along the river?

Barring any geological complications that might arise in the next 5,000 years, the population of the year 6939 should have no difficulty in locating the Time Capsule, a record of our times, at Flushing Meadow Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The National Wholesale Hardware Association, Philadelphia, its officers, executive committee, advisory board, member companies and several cooperating companies have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 --The United States Sugar Corporation of Clewiston, Fla., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 200,000 shares of 6.4 per cent cumulative participating convertible preferred stock, Series A, $25 par value, and 562,500 shares of common stock of $1 par value.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- A revival today of reports that Congress would give favorable consideration to proposals to establish a ceiling of parity prices or better on agricultural products under the terms of the price-control bill revived the spirits of traders who had been working for higher prices.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23 -- An outright declaration of war on the Axis powers was urged today by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, at the opening chapel service in the Harvard Memorial Church today.
