Announcement was made yesterday by the National Horse Show that two new divisions had been added to the prize list for the annual exhibition at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 5 to 12, inclusive.

Gasoline stocks along the East Coast increased 156,000 barrels last week to a total of 19,394,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks were up 1,227,000 barrels to 17,645,000, but heavy fuel oil stocks declined 199,000 to 10,042,000.

One hundred and twenty-nine USO club building projects have been cleared through government agencies, seventy more will be cleared within ten days and contractors are being asked to submit bids on the service centers, it was disclosed yesterday.

Petitions were placed in circulation last night naming William J. Goodwin of Queens as an independent candidate for Mayor. Mr. Goodwin's supporters must gather 7,500 valid signatures by Oct. 7, to get his name on the ballot.

Early American art, especially primitive work by artists most of whom will probably never be personally identified, invites considerable attention as the new season gets under way. Next week the New York Historical Society will open an exhibition of textiles (printed cottons, linens and silks) containing American scenes and events, this material ranging from 1777 through to the present year.

Wendell L. Willkie will speak at "Fun to Be Free," the big show which the stage, screen, radio and arts division of Fight for Freedom, Inc., will present at Madison Square Garden on the night of Oct. 5 under the sponsorship of the Fight for Freedom Committee to Defend America and the American Labor Committee to Aid British Labor.

The extent to which the plastics industry has contributed to national defense and relieved the shortages created in many industries by the diversion of vital metals to armament manufacturing was revealed yesterday in a preview of the sixth annual plastics competition, sponsored by Modern Plastics Magazine at the Chanin Building.

Following closely the pattern set on Monday, the stock market yesterday had some good price enhancements in the morning, only to give way a bit in the afternoon. But, at that, the close was irregularly net higher after a session of selective activity.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 23 -- Argentine troops occupied the nation's two most important military airdromes today and were reported moving fast into all the air bases in the country to forestall any surprise move by Nazi conspirators.

QUOGUE, L.I., Sept. 23 -- A twentieth-century caravan, mechanized for national defense, was driven by women between Orange, N.J. and Quogue, L.I., today. The trucks carried members of one of the nation's top-ranking Red Cross Motor Corps divisions on the 108-mile journey, which was climaxed this evening by a demonstration of emergency driving under blackout conditions.

Dr. Donald D. Van Slyke of the Rockefeller Institute threw a bombshell among the chemists gathered at the University of Chicago's fiftieth anniversary celebration when he told them that raw egg white is not the most easily digested of proteins, as we have believed these many years, and that we would do well to boil eggs hard and chop them up before eating them.

QUINCY, Mass., Sept. 23 -- Secretary Knox, speaking at ceremonies today following the launching of the 35,000-ton battleship Massachusetts seven months ahead of schedule, demanded repeal of our Neutrality Act without delay, asserted that "our Army must be used wherever and whenever it is needed" and warned that the day might come when we should have to fight Hitler on our own soil.

CINCINNATI, Sept 23 (AP) -- Taking advantage of a jittery defense that committted four errors, the Cubs routed Johnny Vander Meer in a four-run second inning today and went on to defeat the Reds, 5 to 1, behind Bill Lee's eight-hit hurling.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- A decrease of more than 30 per cent in orders booked during August by the Massachusetts textile industry, most of which loss has been suffered by the woolen mills, is noted in the monthly index of orders released today by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts.
Active leasing of stores and office space in the midtown section was a feature of the commercial rental lists given out by brokers yesterday.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Joe Louis caused Promoter Mike Jacobs some concern today as the Brown Bomber went through training for his heavyweight championship defense against Lou Nova at the Polo Grounds on Monday night.

An ultra-modern version of the old American "market place" was held on a grand scale at Grand Central Palace from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. yesterday as big and little producers and consumers of industrial defense goods assembled to exchange their wares and services on the second day of the OPM's three-day National Defense Clinic.

Youth Discovers Home An editorial in the University of Pennsylvania undergraduate newspaper calls for our immediate entry into the war. The student editors say it is a decision arrived at after careful deliberation "by some of those who will do the fighting."

"The Distant City," Edwin B. Self's drama, starring Gladys George, closed after last night's performance at the Longacre. It opened Monday night and only gave a total of two performances. Previously it had a three-day try-out engagement in New Haven.

In spite of unexpectedly large ginnings from the new crop the cotton market made a minor recovery yesterday from the losses of the four preceding sessions, largely on trade buying. The market, however, was somewhat nervous.

Red Ruffing was a fetter batter than pitcher at the Stadium yesterday. He hammered a home run, triple and single, batted in three runs and scored two. But the veteran redhead of the Yankees was the victim of his own lackluster performance on the mound and even more so of the fielding ineffectiveness of his mates.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- The Giants, who have been throwing recruit pitchers at the opposition for the past two weeks, were up against a pair of new Phillie hurlers today themselves, and split even, dropping the first game, 8 to 2, and then winning, 8 to 6.

Easing the hard routine of preparations for Manhattan's opener with St. Bonaventure Saturday at Randalls Island, Coach Herb Kopf yesterday sent the Jasper eleven through a two-hour dummy scrimmage. The Kelly-Green polished its offense and worked on a defense for the strong attack anticipated from the husky and seasoned up-State combination.

PURCHASE. N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Although the announcement that the first-flighters in the second annual tri-county (Westchester, Putnam and Fairfield) golf championship would have to play two rounds today met with considerable opposition when it was made after yesterday's qualifying round, several contestants did not stop even after thirty-six holes at the Century Club today.

The Germans claim to have sealed up the western gates of Russia, but the far northern ports are still open to traffic over the Atlantic route. American tankers are en route to Archangel and British planes and ships continue to reach the Soviet Union by way of Murmansk.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) Sept. 23 -- There was a renewal today of the keen demand which developed at the close yesterday on the Bourse. It centered mainly on the Dutch Indians and shippings which showed gains up to 12 points.

The large building at 112-6 East Twenty-third Street, running through the block to 121-5 East Twenty-second Street, which formerly was occupied as the Madison Square postoffice branch, has been acquired by the Charles Bruning Company from the Mutual Life Insurance Company.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 -- Soldiers guarding the home of President Manuel Avila Camacho at Chapultepec Heights fired on a crowd representing the Union of Munition Workers this afternoon, killing eight and wounding twenty-four, according to reports from hospitals.

The American Superpower Corporation announced yesterday an offer to exchange its holdings of certain public utility stocks, including shares of the United Corporation, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and the American Gas and Electric Company, against tenders of its own $6 first preferred stock, for the purpose of retirement.

A solution of the eleven-day shipping strike appeared imminent for the first time yesterday as President Roosevelt gave the tie-up his personal attention and warned that further delay would not be countenanced.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Germany has lost 3,000,000 men since she began war against Russia, but the Nazi military machine is still strong, Ivan M. Maisky, the Russian Ambassador to London, told the American Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon meeting today.

Congress faces an exceedingly difficult decision in determining whether the pending price-control bill should follow the blanket plan advocated by Bernard M. Baruch or the selective plan proposed by the Administration. Mr. Baruch argues that, since every price is a resultant of other prices, it is unjust and impractical to regulate some without regulating all.

Fenelon captured the Manhattan Handicap, Dogpatch toppled some of the leading 2-year-olds and Alsab won the special match with Requested in a day of racing at Belmont Park yesterday that heartily pleased 22,381 persons who wagered $1,204,640 on the eight-event program.

TRENTON, Sept. 23 -- Although endorsing President Roosevelt's foreign policy and asking national unity in its support, Representative Charles A. Eaton charged before the Republican State Convention here today that the Chief Executive was responsible for the confusion of public opinion over America's course with regard to the war.

Now, at last, comes the exciting season when tennis racquets are screwed tightly up in their presses and stored away, when overloaded station wagons travel slowly in to the busy city and the mothballs are shaken out of Autumn tweeds. And everywhere eager eyes -- young and old -- are scanning the sports pages for announcements of football games at favorite colleges.

Trading was fair yesterday In the locally dressed meat markets. Prices generally were steady to strong and supplies of most classes were light. Because of the Jewish New Year holidays, the slaughter of those classes usually dressed as kosher was confined to small number of lambs for the traefer trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Defense chieftains decided today that American economy must be kept in good running order for the post-war emergency and that repair parts should be supplied to all industries, essential and non-essential, in return for definite pledges against hoarding of materials and promises to follow practices of conservation, simplification and substitution.

Summer seemed uncertain yesterday whether it was coming or going, but astronomical and meteorological authorities stepped up with assurances that, despite the warmth, it really was the first day of Fall.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Physiological studies of the dwellers of the Andes Mountain in South America have revealed the existence of an entirely new human being, best described as "the stratosphere man," who constitutes a biological entity radically different in several respects from other branches of mankind.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Arming of United States merchant ships and the supplying of arms for the vessels of other American republics is to be this government's answer to the German U-boat campaign in the North Atlantic. President Roosevelt made this clear today.

The death of Lee F. Hartman is a loss that will be felt by many writers and by a far wider circle of readers. Under his vigorous editorship, extending over the last decade, Harper's Magazine was a periodical in which one found unfailing liveliness and intellectual stimulation.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 23 -- The first round of match play in the New Jersey women's State golf championship found all favorites advancing today, although Miss Nancy McClave of Maplewood, who tied for the medal yesterday with a fine 79, was carried to the eighteenth green of the Echo Lake Country Club.

The editors of Simon Schuster explain how a book of collected Peter Arno cartoons such as that brought out yesterday is put together. Faced with the problem, they said, of choosing the best from the best, "we solved the dilemma by collaring half a dozen aficionados from the thousands of Arno admirers."

Government agencies should assume a greater share in the task of educating the consumer in the health value of vitamin-enriched bread, it was asserted by bakers at the second day of the thirty-second general conference of the Quality Bakers of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- "Nothing Ventured," a screen comedy by Ian McLellan Hunter and Aileen Hamilton, was purchased today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Lana Turner. Pandro Berman will produce the film, and Hunter has been engaged to write the scenario, which deals with a small-town ten-cent-store clerk who feigns amnesia and goes to New York to seek her fortune.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Major William Dwight Whitney, W. Averell Harriman's personal assistant in London, told the English Speaking Union today that if the British expect "decisive action" from Americans it is necessary to give them a full picture of the war situation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Roosevelt established today the United States National Commission of the Permanent American Aeronautical Commission.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Baseball, like politics, makes strange bedfellows. Today the Dodgers, painfully pennant-conscious, were voicing unstinted admiration of and gratitude to Onkel Franz Frisch's Pirates, whose collective ears they were trying to "bat down" only five days ago.

Home rule is little by little being sold by the municipalities for cash just as centuries ago they bought it from the kings of England for cash, David M. Wood, municipal finance expert and senior partner in Thomson, Wood Hoffman, attorneys, declared yesterday at the annual convention of the National Security Traders Association in New Orleans.

A series of new compositions and others rarely performed have been placed on the programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for its centennial season which opens on Oct. 9 at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra management announced yesterday the novelties and highlights for the first half of the season.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington and Miss Madeleine Huntington, who had been at the Savoy-Plaza, have gone to Palm Beach.

BERLIN, Sept. 23 -- Ten days after the reported encirclement of four entire Russian armies east of Kiev, the German High Command announced in a special communique from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters today that these trapped forces were in dissolution, that fifty Soviet divisions had been destroyed and that 380,000 prisoners had been taken.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 -- The Cardinals' pennant chances, already hanging by a slender thread, became even more precarious today as Billy Southworth's hardpressed St. Louisans could do no better than break even in a double-header that opened their four-game series with the Pirates.
New York's Fall fashion openings continued yesterday with the collection of Zoe De Salle, inspired by the American desert country, and Dein-Bacher's showing of new styles in fur.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 22:

A large dinner dance for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club was given last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza as a preview opening of the room for the Autumn and Winter season. The official opening of the Persian Room will take place tonight.
Today, if the wind does not whistle and howl as it did three years ago during the perigee, this will be the best day of the season for the rail-bird shooters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The storm in the Atlantic Ocean, the Weather Bureau said today, may be expected to pass about 175 miles southeast of Nantucket Island tomorrow morning. The bureau issued this report:
BERLIN, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The following special communique was issued today from German headquarters:
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Today's Soviet Information Bureau communique follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If Dr. Raubicheck were a baseball fan, she would know how ill-timed were her strictures on Brooklyn pronunciation. Delivered at a moment when Durocher's persuasive speech had failed to soften an umpire's heart, her remarks could only serve to fray the already frazzled nerves of loyal Brooklyn rooters and incite them to employ a type of cheer usually associated with another borough.

The Army Engineer Corps and the Realty Mortgagee Corporation, in leases arranged by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., have taken full floors in the building at 150 Broadway. Each of the units contains about 13,000 square feet of floor space.
ROME, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- House restrictions on the Administration's Property Seizure Bill were accepted by a joint Senate-House conference committee today and the action cleared the way for a final Congressional vote.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Without waiting for a formal request from President Roosevelt to Congress for authority to arm American merchant ships, Administration leaders at the Capitol began preliminary moves today looking to repeal of the prohibitory provisions of the Neutrality Act.

Following the fortunes of the Yankees these days becomes, more than ever, a task for a qualified statistician. With the pennant in the proverbial bag, virtually all interest is centered in the records that the record-conscious McCarthymen are in line to achieve.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 24 -- After serving for six years on the staff of Dick Harlow at Harvard, Neil (Skip) Stahley finds himself in command of varsity football and burdened with the cares and responsibilities of a head coach in an ivy institution of learning.

Organization of American women for defense is proceeding as rapidly as possible in Washington, Miss Eloise Davison, Assistant Director of Civilian Defense, said yesterday at a tea and cocktail party at the New York Newspaper Women's Club, at which she was guest of honor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Hogs extended their decline today. The close showed losses ranging from 20 cents. Heavy butchers resisted the downward trend but light weights, representing the Spring pig crop, were under pressure.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 24 -- With assurances of full support from the national C.I.O., the biennial convention of the State, county and municipal workers of America set in motion today a nation-wide campaign aiming to extend to 5,000,000 government workers all the collective bargaining rights enjoyed by employes in private industry.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- Determined to play out their string to the bitter and, Billy Southworth's doughty Cardinals thrashed the Pirates, 4 to 0, today and then retired to their dressing room to hear the disheartening news from Boston, which all but sounded the death knell to their pennant hopes tonight.

Hearings at which evidence intended to clarify the relative positions of securities of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and its top subsidiary, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, will be presented, were opened yesterday before Frederick E. Crane, sitting as a special master, in the Federal Court House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The first "test" cases of certified "priorities unemployment" in the aluminum goods manufacturing industry were alleviated today with the award of about $2,000,000 in Army orders, and Floyd B. Odlum, new director of the Contract Distribution Division of the Office of Production Management appealed to the holders of the bulk of defense orders to assign their "ablest executives" to handle subcontracting for him.

To meet the "urgent psychological need" to repair the mutilated faces and bodies of civilian and military victims of aerial warfare in Britain as quickly as possible, a campaign to obtain $200,000 in this country for plastic surgery equipment was opened yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Plaza.

Alfred David, head of a chain of tipless haircutting shops, disclosed yesterday that he had appealed to Governor Lehman for protection as a result of a beating last Friday that he attributed to a union dispute. A copy of Mr. David's appeal was sent to District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn, but not to Mayor La Guardia.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda, head of the Chamber committee investigating anti-Argentine activity, charged today that a subversive plot by members of the Army Air Force, smashed by the government last night, was "another Nazi attempt to seize control of the Argentine Government through Quislings."

Detailed testimony relating to, the famous Norden bombsignt, believed to have been this country's most jealously guarded aerial defense weapon, was barred yesterday as being "inimical to the interests of the United States" as the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government continued before Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Red Sox walloped Washington twice, 7 -- 2 and 5 -- 4, today as Charley Wagner gave a four-hit hurling performance in the first game and Heber Newsome scattered twelve blows in the nightcap to pitch his nineteenth victory.

"Newcomers of 1941," a variety revue, will open tomorrow night at the Ambassador Theatre under the auspices of the veteran showman Will Morrissey, who also will head the cast, Mr. Morrissey has been rehearsing his show for several weeks without any of the usual fanfare and decided yesterday that his efforts were ready for Broadway presentation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The prepared text of Secretary Morgenthau's statement on price control legislation today before the House Banking and Currency Committee was as follows:

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The Air Ministry made public today the first confirmed reports of activity by British planes flying in Russia, Patrols were said to have been carried out under unfavorable weather conditions, and during them several successful encounters took place.

Hundreds of Democratic party leaders and workers crowded the seventh floor of the Chanin Building yesterday to hear William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor; Lloyd C. Church, nominee for Controller, and M. Maldwin Fertig, candidate for President of the Council, predict victory for the Democratic city ticket in the Fall election.
Fifty-five families, most of whom came from outmoded tenements in various parts of the city, moved into their bright new homes in Clason Point Gardens in the East Bronx yesterday.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Central Front, Sept 22 (Delayed) -- Three parachutists are swinging down against the setting sun as the last plane taxies to rest and the ground crew covers it with pine boughs. These are only practice leaps, the officer explains.

The American Committee for Democracy and Intellectual Freedom made public yesterday an open letter to the Board of Education and the Board of Higher Education, protesting the RappCoudert legislative committee's investigation of subversive elements in New York City schools and colleges and urging the educational authorities to stop dismissing teachers on the basis of the investigating committee's disclosures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Legislation to provide Federal assistance to cities against air attacks was asked of Congress today by the Director of Civilian Defense, Mayor LaGuardia of New York. Mr. LaGuardia requested prompt consideration of a bill permitting the loan of equipment to cities "susceptible to bombing attacks" which cannot themselves provide the equipment.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 24 -- This tourist turned into Dr. Bier's training ground here on the trail of the "cosmic punch" with which Lou Nova plans to annoy J. Shufflin' Louis come next Monday night at the Polo Grounds. Nova with the light brown hair was asleep. The camp followers claim that Lou has set a new sleeping record at these training quarters, which is no mean feat in itself.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Denying charges that Charles A. Lindbergh is anti-Semitic, officials of the America First Committee Issued a statement today deploring "the injection of the race issue into the discussion of war or peace."

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- Dixie Walker gave himself and the Dodgers a grand birthday present in the seventh inning today when he belted a lofty triple to left field with the bases filled to bring the Brooks from behind and send them on their way to a 4-2 triumph over the Braves.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Honorably discharged from the Army because of family dependents, Ben Kish, veteran Brooklyn Football Dodgers quarterback, joined the team here today as it continued preparations for its National League contest with the Philadelphia Eagles at Shibe Park, Philadelphia, Saturday night.
TOKYO, Sept. 24 -- To free all available funds, labor and materials for national defense the Japanese Cabinet today slashed the budget by 1,323,000,000 yen.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- Aknusti rode into another of polo's important final rounds today, triumphing pretty much as it pleased over Westbury in the first semifinal match of the Waterbury Cup tournament. The score was 10 to 4, and of the Westbury goals, two were on the board as handicap before the start.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 24 -- W.G. Chudleigh, president of Aeronautical Mechanics Local 1,125, A.F. of L., said today that 98.9 per cent of the members who participated in a secret poll at the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation's plant had voted in favor of a strike.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Apprentice Milton Briggs rode five winners, four of them in successive races, at Narragansett Park today. They were Unbuttoned, paying $6.30 for $2, in the third event; Kleig Light, $16.10, in the fourth; Hicomb, $7.20, in the fifth; Speedy Way, $14.60, in the sixth; and Sun High, $9.60, in the eighth.
Harold G. Hesse sold the dwelling at 173 Engle Street, Tenafly, N.J., to Robert N. Mann through the office of Helen B. Marshall, broker.

The Indian rupee rose here yesterday in the foreign exchange market from 30.33 to 30.37 cents, to reflect cabled advices of a lowering of the official India buying rate on United States dollars. Par value of the rupee, before the dollar-relation change, was 61.7978 cents.

As a result of the cancellation of the annual automobile show here, special show sections will not be run by any New York newspapers and a sharp drop from last year's linage is expected in the coming weeks. Expectations are that linage may be as much as 30 to 40 per cent under the corresponding 1940 period.

The action of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System in ordering an increase of one-seventh in the amount of reserves which member banks are required to keep against their deposits does not so much restrict existing bank credit as reduce the potentialities of future credit expansion.

A solution to the problem of the dwindling supply and rising prices of imported rabbit fur for men's and women's felt hats was announced yesterday by the Hat Corporation of America, makers of Knox, Dobbs, Dunlap, Knapp, Byron and Berg hats.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The 1940 world champion Reds sewed up third place in the National League pennant race today, Bucky Walters blanking the Cubs, 2 to 0, for his nineteenth victory as St. Louis crowded Pittsburgh out of the running.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Nathaniel Peffer's comment on Japan's position is for the most part unanswerable. It is improbable that any result can come of the negotiations with Japan, since the Japanese Government cannot at present make terms that the United States could approve.

The action of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System in lifting the reserve requirements of member banks by about one-seventh to the statutory limit, effective on Nov. 1, caused yesterday little more than a ripple in the money market and in the market for government securities.
NEW YORK Rear Admiral and Mrs. Frederick G. Pyne have come from the Chevy Chase Club, Washington, and are at the Vanderbilt.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 24 -- The following message from General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck, British Commander in Chief in the Middle East, for troops in the Middle East was written for publication in the troops official magazine, issued at Cairo:

The Lehigh Valley Railroad proposes to buy l,000 coal cars in addition to 1,050 already on order, R.W. Brown, president, made known yesterday in Philadelphia. Fewer than 2 per cent of the road's freight cars are in disrepair, and a sufficient number of locomotives was described as being available to move the traffic offered.

Water Supply Forwarded to all Division Commanders is a copy of all auxiliary sources of water supply in each division, exclusive of natural supplies available from rivers, streams, lakes and ponds. In each instance a complete check on these supplies shall be made for the purpose of verifying the Quantities of water indicated.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Soviet troops smashed a new German offensive against the icefree Arctic port of Murmansk and fought back stubbornly along the whole front, the Russians reported today.

Weary footsteps echoed yesterday afternoon up and down the stairways of the fifty-eight-story building at 500 Fifth Avenue at Forty-second Street and the adjoining thirty-story Salmon Tower Building, 11 West Forty-second Street, as a strike of elevator operators and other maintenance help cut the buildings' service to a minimum.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- Having released a plethora of special communiques over the last week-end announcing successes of its forces on the Eastern Front, the German High Command has again retired behind a protective screen of silence.

Favorable operating results for the six months ended on July 31 last were reported yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. The company, directly or through subsidiaries, operates the Gimbel stores in New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Milwaukee, the Saks Thirty-fourth Street store in New York and the Saks Fifth Avenue stores in New York, Chicago, Detroit, Beverly Hills, Miami Beach and Palm Beach.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Muskrats Up 50% Over April Muskrats showed a 50 per cent advance over the April levels at the sale of Hudson's Bay Company furs held yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. The high was $3.15, and 100 per cent of the offering of 300,000 pelts was sold.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Johnny Kinder, New Jersey open golf titleholder, and Charley Whitehead of Plainfield scored a sensational nine-under-par 62 to win the pro-amateur medal-play championship, annually a prelude to the New Jersey open tournament, on the hilly, wind-swept Forest Hill Field Club course today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Enough evidence of a serious labor shortage in Germany is accumulating to indicate that her pressure on Bulgaria may be directed less at getting that nation into the war against Russia than at winning help in the war against lagging Axis production.

Details of a $75,000,000 program which will expand the annual pig iron producing capacity of the Republic Steel Corporation by 35 per cent were announced yesterday by the company at Cleveland. The program has been approved by the Defense Plant Corporation, the announcement said.

The twelve-day shipping strike ended yesterday when the unions involved accepted the proposal of the National Defense Mediation Board that the strikers return to work pending a negotiation conference under the board's auspices next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A White House luncheon scheduled for tomorrow in honor of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor was postponed tonight because of the serious illness of G. Hall Roosevelt, President Roosevelt's brother-in-law. The announcement was made by the State Department, which said:

Proposals to curb excess profits further, even to the extent of limiting earnings to a 6 per cent return on invested capital during the present Emergency, produced yesterday a decided reaction in the stock market where prices weakened 1 to 2 points from the morning highs in the final hour.

It appears that the best way to win a regular line post on the N.Y.U. football team is to report to Mal Stevens as a back and wait for the Violet coach to prove otherwise. This procedure has already netted Mal two fine forwards, both at positions which were open less than a month ago.

A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, announced last night that the company's board of directors had authorized the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a registration statement for the sale of 534,423 additional shares of common stock of $50 par value.

The first Fall open shooting dog stake of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association is scheduled for Oct. 11, and as it is open to any man who has a dog that can work pheasants, it should be of interest to those desiring to give their dogs some action before the opening of the upland game season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The United States endorsed in general terms the Allied conference in London mapping post-war problems and requested that it be informed concerning the exploratory discussions and consulted in regard to the plans that emerge from them in the statement read at the opening session today by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary.
Relatives of three of the crew of thirty-four aboard the Pink Star when it was sunk by a submarine continued here yesterday to await anxiously for word of the fate of the men.

One of the largest dinner parties at the formal opening of the Persian Room of the Plaza last evening was given by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Beinecke. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Murray Vernon, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney VereSmith, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Hillas, Mr. and Mrs. George E. Ruppert, Dr. and Mrs. John N. Robinson, Mrs. Walter B. Walker and Rollo K. Blanchard.
The American Women's Voluntary Services held a style preview yesterday of the new powder-gray, brass-buttoned uniform prescribed for its 80,000 members.

An underwriting group headed by Bond Goodwin, Inc., and including Craigmyle, Rogers Co. and the Whitney-Phoenix Company, Inc., will offer today to the public 30,000 shares of cumulative convertible preferred stock of Aeronca Aircraft Corporation.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept 24 -- An odd seagoing craft, intended by its inventor for quantity production in the national defense effort, rested today on the ways of an Orienta Point boatyard here and kept residents guessing as to what it was.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Volume production of medium and heavyweight Army tanks is planned by the Ford Motor Company.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Full adherence to the Atlantic Charter drawn up by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill was pledged today by the free governments of nine European countries, now in exile in London, and by the Soviet Union.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the A.F. of L. and chairman of the American Labor Committee to Aid British Labor, addressed an appeal yesterday to "every organized worker in the land" to contribute one hour's pay to help the workers in Great Britain and in all countries engaged in fighting Hitler or overrun by the Nazis.

In a one-day tourney of the Women's Long Island Golf Association that was productive of good scoring, Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Lakeville shot a 75 on the North Hills Golf Club course at Douglaston yesterday, to capture low gross honors by four strokes.

The women who have gathered in New York this week for the fourth annual training institute of the American Women's Voluntary Services have listened to some pretty plain speaking on the requirements for civilian defense work. There is nothing dramatic or spectacular about modern war, the Mayor warned them in his opening address.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 24 (AP) -- American railroads are "doing a better job just now than ever before in the history of transportation," R.V. Fletcher of Washington, vice president and general counsel of the Association of American Railroads, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Three million five hundred thousand more tons of iron and steel scrap will have to be found annually in the United States if its steel industry Is to meet the great demands made upon it by the defense effort, the Commerce Department stated today, predicting that a long-range scrap program must be inaugurated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Army's plans for removing from troop commands all officers who are older than limits set for field service in each rank will be applied only gradually and will not be completed until March 1. The purpose is to prevent disruption of the efficiency of troop units.

Twenty-five American women recently evacuated from Japan and China against their will met yesterday at the Parkside Hotel, Gramercy Square, to discuss methods of adapting themselves to community life in this country for the duration of the war.

The third biennial convention of the Transport Workers Union of America, C.I.O., began yesterday in Transport Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, with condemnation of the city's labor policy toward the 32,000 civil service employes of the unified transit lines, coupled with a strong hint of political reprisals in the November election.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- The grain markets showed a firm undertone today, with buying by houses with Eastern connections and the strength in cotton factors. Wheat advanced around 1 1/2 cents a bushel at the extreme before running into liberal profit-taking by professional traders and spreading operations between here and other markets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Contracts totaling $17,822,801 were awarded by the War Department today. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Fears that Connecticut is going to require New York State residents commuting to jobs in Connecticut defense industries to buy Connecticut license plates for their automobiles are unfounded, it developed here today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24 -- Officials of the Mexican Confederation of Labor, or C.T.M., indicated clearly today that their organization, which played a leading role in the late Cardenas administration, would not react in any decisive manner to the fatal shooting of several members of the Munitions Workers Union yesterday in front of the Presidential residence when troops were called to break up the demonstration.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 24 -- The journey of the Forty-fourth Division's 12,000 men and 2,000 vehicles from Fort Dix to Wadesboro, N.C., commencing tomorrow night will be controled entirely by radio, according to an announcement today from division headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A series of conferences were held today between Army and Navy officials and Thomas E. Dewey, national campaign chairman, of the United Service Organizations, and as a result Brig. Gen. Frederick H. Osborn will move to stimulate construction of buildings to house U.S.O. units.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Chairman Davis of the National Defense Mediation Board wrote a letter to Secretary of the Navy Knox, Aug. 13 last, disputing the contention of the company operating the Kearny, N.J., shipyards -- that the board's decision in the labor dispute there was tantamount to an order for a closed shop.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24 -- The two players who tied for the qualifying medal in the New Jersey State women's golf championship on Monday were eliminated today when Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood defeated Mrs. DeWitt Untermeyer of Hollywood, 1 up, and Mrs. Charles B. Harding of Rumson halted Miss Nancy McClave of Maplewood, 2 and 1, in the second round at the Echo Lake Country Club.

The three-day National Defense Clinic closed at the Grand Central Palace yesterday with representatives of large and small concerns expressing great satisfaction over the results of the special session.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial "Rome's Immunity" in THE TIMES of Sept. 18 confuses two things when it fails to distinguish between an aggressor's threat of reprisals unless his victim submits and the threat of retaliation made to an aggressor should the latter embark on a fresh aggression -- in this instance the bombing of Cairo, beloved of Moslems for its ancient mosques.

Premier Mitchell Frederick Hep-burn of Ontario was inducted into the Circus Saints and Sinners Club of America as the "fall guy" amid much fanfare and hilarity at their luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor. One thousand persons attended the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, today told a committee representing anthracite miners striking for a reduction of dues and assessments that his advice to them was to call off the strike and present their grievances to the international union's executive board.

And Vice Versa Science will stop at nothing in order to get results. It will apply a spectroscope to the star galaxies, and it will also stand on its head in an elevator. To study the effects of parachute jumping on the human system, Professor Ivy of Northwestern University stood on, his head in a rapidly descending elevator.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In criticism of your editorial today about the New England hurricane of Sept. 21, 1938, may I point out that it was never within 500 miles of the Caribbean Sea. Its entire course until it hit this coast was in the Atlantic Ocean.

A syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., received the award yesterday of an issue of $2,000,000 of Chicago's waterworks revenue certificates on a bid of 101.939 for 2 1/4 s. Dated May 1, 1941, and maturing on May 1, 1961, the obligations were reoffered by the underwriters at a price of 103 1/8, to yield 2.05 per cent.

Abe Schwartz, alias Abe Bibchik, professional dice player and policy game operator, 38 years old, of 9214 Avenue B, Brooklyn, was found shot dead yesterday in a coupe in front of an apartment house on Empire Boulevard off Albany Avenue in Brooklyn.

Julius Grossman, Inc., manufacturer and retailer of shoes, leased yesterday the store, mezzanine and basement at 415 Fifth Avenue, and as part of the same transaction subleased the six-story building it occupies at 11 West Thirty-sixth Street to Original Elbee Furriers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Secretary Morgenthau recommended today that all corporation profits over 6 per cent on invested capital be taxed away by the government for the period of the emergency, asserted that additional restrictions on bank credits might become necessary and opposed fixing by legislation of a price ceiling on wages.

LAKE MOHONK, Sept, 24 -- A general drop in the circulation of books, a notable increase in serious reading and a widespread demand for technical books are the three major reactions to the imminence of war as observed by the State's librarians. Members of the New York Library Association, who have stressed these trends in private conversations, are meeting here for their annual conference.

Home furniture and furnishings that have resulted from the inter-American design competition held by the Museum of Modern Art were placed on exhibition yesterday evening for an invitation audience at Bloomingdale's, where they will go on sale today.

Steel orders taken by various producers in September have run 30 to 45 per cent below the volume booked in August, but even at this reduced rate new business has equaled shipments, resulting in no reductions in backlogs, according to Iron Age.

William M. Chadbourne, who was chairman of the Republican Primary Committee for the renomination of Mayor La Guardia, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, announced yesterday the reorganization of this committee into a citizens committee to support these candidates for re-election.

The Maritime Commission will begin today to use its new powers under the ship warrant legislation Signed by President Roosevelt in July, through which it received far-reaching control said by ship operators to be unprecedented in American maritime history.

Declaring that we are as deeply in the war as if Congress had declared war, Donald D. Conn, executive vice president of the Transportation Association of America, told the finance division of the Association of American Railroads in Colorado Springs yesterday that the foremost obligation of every person and industry was to aid rearmament.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Buck Newsom held the Browns hitless the first three innings today, then lost his magic and St. Louis defeated the Tigers, 3 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, announced today that he would ask the Senate for $1,000,000 to study the problems of American small business through a special Senate committee which he heads.
Lou Nova will reach the end of the training trail today.

The cotton market continued yesterday in a quiet session to make an irregular recovery from its recent losses. After prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange had made gains of 23 to 27 points in the early trading, quotations eased off and closed with net gains of 9 to 13 points for the day.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 24 -- The Bourse was hesitant and irregular today, although good resistance to profit-taking developed. Amsterdam Trading lost 6% points at 495 and Amsterdam Rubber was off 1% at 319%, but Royal Dutch was 1% higher at 335% and Unilever 2% at 168%. Bonds were firm.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, outlined here tonight a set of fundamental laws as governing the diffusion of culture among the different peoples of the world and set forth reasons why Japan, of all the countries on the Asiatic continent, adopted the militarist aspect of Western civilization, whereas China chose instead to learn from Europe and America the ways of democracy and peace.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 24 -- While Swedish economic and financial circles do not conceal their dismay at the 100,000,000-krona clearing advance that the Swedes have been compelled to make to Germany to keep Swedish-German exchanges running, it appears today from information obtained in high neutral circles that the Germans had asked for an outright commercial credit of 250,000,000 kronor.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 24 -- The Japanese military position in Southern Indo-China is not yet powerful enough for major operations against Thailand, Malaya or Burma, according to observers in Thailand, where a close watch is being kept on the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Nicholas Schenck, president of Loew's Inc., denied before a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee today that motion picture makers had ever agreed among themselves on a policy of producing war propaganda pictures.
LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries said early today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Handicapped by two vacant judgeships and an unusual number of protracted trials, the Southern New York Federal Dstrict Court wound up the 1941 fiscal year with more cases pending than in the previous year, the Administrative Office of United States Courts has reported.

A client of Nathan Feingold, attorney, has purchased from the C.S.C. Operating Company in a transaction negotiated by David Kraus, broker, the five-story apartment house at 1047-9 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx. The building contains 100 rooms, divided into nineteen apartments.

A YOUNG dog named Ed and a young harpy named Veda would make a perfect pair, and by rights they should inhabit and infest the pages of the same volume. They do not, I am sorry to report. The latter is to be found in James M. Cain's latest novel, of which more. anon. The former dominates James T. Farrell's latest, called "Ellen Rogers."*

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 24 -- By occupying army air fields last night, the Argentine Government appears to have forestalled what might have developed into a dangerous military movement of seditious character. As a consequence of these measures, it is stated, calm reigns throughout Argentina.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- German official quarters and the Berlin press reject legal responsibility for the sinking of the Pink Star and brand President Roosevelt's hint that American merchantmen will be armed as "Roosevelt's will to deny the authority of international law and subject every country and every sea to plutocratic despotism."

In one chapter of his forthcoming book on Hollywood, Leo C. Rosten discusses the subject of war propaganda in the movies. His conclusion is that the producers, far from seeking to influence public opinion or guide it into any particular channel, try to give the public what it wants.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Refugees by the thousands returned tonight to the Gulf Coast homes they fled to escape a tropical storm which killed three persons and caused millions of dollars' damage to crops and property. The heaviest blow in years spent its violence as it moved northeastward before veering west into Texas again near Sulphur Springs.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters tonight issued the following communique:

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Dr. H.A. Bacus, research director for the railway clerks, stressed today increased railroad revenues as indicating ability to pay proposed wage increases of 30 cents an hour as asked by the fourteen railroad non-operating unions.

The Board of Estimate is scheduled to act at its meeting today on a request for $16,000 from WNYC, the city broadcasting station, which seeks a new frequency modulation station operating on a twenty-four-hour basis as an auxiliary to its present operation.

Swiss industry, already operating on closely rationed supplies, has been put into a precarious position by England's decision yesterday to block further shipments, foreign traders said here. Both exporters and importers interested in the Swiss market, however, were confident that the blockade would be temporary and that it was undertaken to compel a modification of the trade agreement recently concluded with Germany by the Swiss.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept, 24 -- Southpaw Tom Sunkel, last of the quintet of recruit pitchers introduced by Bill Terry this month, came within four putouts of a nohit game in the second contest of the double-header with the Phillies in Shibe Park today, but had to settle for a two-hit, 2-to-0 victory, with twelve strikeouts.

A.T. T. Financing The financial community is expressing keen interest in the forth-coming sale at competitive bidding of $90,000,000 of American Telephone and Telegraph Company 2 3/4 per cent thirty-five-year debentures. Bids on the issue, which is to be used for refunding, will be opened on Monday by Walter S. Gifford, A.T. T.'s president, at the company's headquarters, 195 Broadway.

VICHY, France, Sept, 24 -- The Vichy government is understood to have prepared a protest to Great Britain, to be transmitted through the United States State Department, alleging' bombing and sinking by British planes of the French freighter Monselet, near Sfax, Tunisia, last Saturday.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- The automobile industry was in effect put on trial before a Congressional investigating committee today on charges of having pursued a "business as usual" policy despite the national defense program, and of having contributed only "a negligible" share to that program.

Four thousand nine hundred and ninety-eight years from now, if all goes well, some strange-looking creatures in funny clothes will dig up the Time Capsule, which will be found some fifty feet deep either in Flushing Meadow Park or under one of the spots included in that park in what will then be extremely ancient times.

Trading in the wholesale markets yesterday was fair to slow. Quotations on lamb were strong, with some inbetween sales 50 cents higher wholesale and asking around $I higher for retail selections. Veal hindsaddle prices were steady to strong and calf hindsaddles were about steady. Cow beef sold mostly 50 cents higher and bull was steady to strong.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Thornton Lee pitched a two-hit game today for the White Sox to defeat the Indians, 2 to 1. It was the left-hander's twenty-first victory and enabled Chicago to take sole possession of third place, breaking a tie with the Tigers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 24 -- Asserting that the time-honored ten-to-one ratio of deposits to bank capital is no longer an adequate test of the measure of sufficiency of capital funds, John D. Hospelhorn told the fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks in his presidential address here today that sound bankable assets of good quality are a truer test for deposit protection.

In the second annual report of the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts there is a wealth of information with due accompaniment of chart and table about the Federal courts. In every circuit there are, or are to be, three law clerks allocated by the senior circuit judge to district judges upon a certificate of need.

Opposition to a Navy Dpartment proposal to supplement construction facilities at the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, by building two new piers and putting an extension on a third pier was expressed by local shipping and commercial interests yesterday at a hearing at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

The lone arrival on Broadway today is the Warners' mystery-comedy, "The Smiling Ghost," which opens at the Globe with a cast headed by Wayne Morris, Brenda Marshall and Alexis Smith. Meanwhile, at the Capitol, the management announces that "Lady Be Good" will be held over for another week beginning today.
ROME, Sept. 24 -- Advice on bringing up children was given by Pope Pius yesterday morning in a sermon to newlyweds.

Father John T.H. Joyce, a Maryknoll Missioner serving in China, recently faced a one-man Japanese firing squad and escaped without injury except the wear and tear on his nerves, the Maryknoll Fathers, Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, disclosed yesterday.

Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard brought his appeal for full mobilization of America's agriculture to the famers of the Northeastern area yesterday, urging them to contribute their share "in the greatest production effort American agriculture has ever made."

A "very tractable" marsh falcon named Placid, with some "irregular" military experience, was offered as a mascot to the 101st Cavalry, Sixth Army Corps, Fort Devens, Mass., which features a falcon on its regimental insignia, by Jacques Suzanne of Lake Placid, N.Y., artist, Arctic explorer and animal fancier, in a letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

A new chapter was written into the annals of shoe fashions yesterday morning at Saks Fifth Avenue. Sixty-five pairs of feet moved along a curtained runway so constructed that nothing could be seen of the manikins above their knees. Attention was focused on shoes and stockings.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- New submarine successes in the Mediterranean were announced today by the British Admiralty. An Italian mine layer and a transport were torpedoed and two supply ships of about 5,000 and 1,500 tons have been hit and a large schooner has been attacked.

An adequate supply of gasoline to keep all stations and garages supplied for the rest of the month seemed assured yesterday for the metropolitan area, although some of the major oil companies indicated they might not be willing to give additional gasoline to stations that have flagrantly violated the curfew and rationing regulations.

Alien Street Park on the lower Bast Side was playing host at 1:45 P.M. yesterday to several hundred persons, including a score of mothers and their children who were basking in the sun, when John, a docile 10-year-old horse, suddenly bolted on Alien Street, outside of the park, smashed the light truck he was hitched to against a Second Avenue Elevated pillar, before dashing into the park and causing a minor panic.
Books and magazine articles are coining from the presses in tribute, and there will be a luncheon today in its honor, for the detective story is celebrating its 100th anniversary.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, SECOND ARMY; SOMEWHERE IN LOUISIANA; Sept 24 -- The men and machine. 350,000 men, 50,000 vehicles, of the Second and Third Field Armies of the United States, were again locked in mimic war tonight over a manoeuvre area sodden with rain.

Running powerfully through the stretch, M.R. Ryan's Stimady, at 33 to 1, yesterday captured the seventy-second Jerome Handicap, which goes back to 1866 and the famous old days of the sport at Jerome Park. Renewed at Belmont Park, which had a crowd of 12,134, the mile run grossed $9,400, of which $6,825 went to Mr. Ryan.

Two New York City high school teachers were found guilty by the Board of Education yesterday of unbecoming conduct, one of them being dismissed for slapping a pupil and using profane language in the classroom. The other was accused of appearing at school intoxicated on several occasions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Gracie Allen will return to the screen after a two and a half year absence in Metro's "Mr. and Mrs. North," the studio announced today. She will play the vacuous Mrs. North, the role done on Broadway last Winter by Peggy Conklin. Miss Allen's last film was "The Gracie Allen Murder Case," produced by Paramount early in 1939.

Returning to its first place of exhibition after an absence of twenty-six years, the American Dahlia Society yesterday opened its twenty-seventh annual Fall Flower Show at the American Museum of Natural History. A year ago the society exhibited at the World's Fair and in other years in various hotel ballrooms.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 24 -- At Sedgwick Hall, Lenox, today, the Lenox Library Association, of which Grenville Lindall Winthrop is president, opened its twenty-second annual exhibition of arts, fancy work and handicraft. Mrs. Henry White and Giraud Foster lent palms and ferns for decorations.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Competition must be keener in Westchester, Fairfield and Putnam than it is elsewhere or else the field in the second annual tri-county golf championship now holding forth at the Century Country Club is better balanced than usual.

Old man Winter strode into the autumnal setting at Belmont Park at the luncheon hour yesterday when rich fur raps designed for cold days passed in review before the guests on the fashion terrace. Strangely incongrous were the high shakos of fur and the warm pelts that Revillon Freres offered against the glowing background of the Indian Summer foliage.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 24 -- The dual difficulty of controlled dollar buying and the United States defense program's curtailment of markets is causing increasing concern to local merchants.

Several months ago a versatile and cosmopolitan gentleman withdrew into the snug kitchen, where he has perfected the formula for many a delectable dish, and firmly announced that he was not "at home" to any one until he had solved the problem at hand.
Persons prominent in the social and business worlds figured in a number of the leading apartment rentals reported yesterday by brokers. Leases for large suites were a feature of the activity.

Speaking at the opening of the fifth, annual police show in Madison Square Garden last night, Mayor La Guardia told the crowd of 20,000 there and those listening to a nation-wide radio hook-up of the NBC that it was his intention to ask Congress for sufficient funds to provide every American city with the large amounts of specialized equipment needed for airraid defense.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Press-radio affiliation in Des Moines has been of benefit to broadcasting and the press, according to Luther B. Hill, manager of the Iowa Broadcasting Company, who testified at the resumption today of the Federal Communications Commission hearing on newspaper ownership of radio stations.

The Roosevelt-Churchill Atlantic Declaration is the direct and conclusive answer to "those who would continue to put their country in danger" by preferring a minority-inspired policy of "wait and see," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday at the opening exercises of Columbia's 188th academic year.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, commander of the British Indian Army, was revealed today to have been in London for secret conferences believed to have considered the possibility of sending British troops to Russia and the imminence of a new outbreak of war on the Egyptian-Libyan frontier.

WASHINGTON, Sept 24 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today informed the Niagara Falls Power Company that its continued emergency diversion of water from the Niagara River must be conditioned on acceptance by the company of a stipulation that an estimated $1,000,000 annual net profit from this defense operation should not be distributed to stockholders but used instead to reduce the company's investments in Niagara Falls Power facilities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Floyd B. Odlum, director of the Division of Contract Distribution of the Office of Production Management, made public today the letter he was sending to the fifty-six largest holders of defense contracts urging them to pick their ablest executives to handle subcontracting to avert widespread "priorities unemployment."

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Inaugurating the young hunter division a year ago, the North Shore horse show, which opened today to continue through Saturday, reaped handsomely from its earlier efforts, with a total of forty-seven young hunters listed, making up more than 50 per cent of the entry in the twelfth annual exhibition.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 25 -- The funeral of the nine victims of the shooting on Tuesday will take place at 11 A.M. tomorrow. It is awaited here with some anxiety. In the procession will be members of the Federation of Federal Employes, the Railway Union, Electrical Workers Union and a street-car workers' union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- One of the worst Fall droughts since the parched months of 1930 is developing throughout most of the East and Southeast, with pasture lands turning brown, water running low in reservoirs, power dams and rivers and Fall grain fields taking too hard for the plow under a bright sun.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 25 -- Germany has delivered a final warning to Bulgaria that she must send forces to the Russian front now or Germany will consider that Bulgaria has violated her pact with the Reich and thereupon will be occupied by the German Army, according to reports to high foreign diplomatic sources in Ankara and Istanbul tonight.

Volunteers from the ranks of business and professional women are needed for civilian defense work, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday at a luncheon of the New York Fashion Group in the Hotel Astor. At the same time he announced that a voluntary participation center under a woman director would be established within the next few days to enroll and train civilian defense workers.

Property owners in Forest Hills, Queens, won their fight yesterday in the Board of Estimate to bar apartment house construction from their section, which is predominantly devoted to one-family homes. The Board of Estimate voted unanimously to change the area bounded by a line 100 feet north of Sixty-sixth Road and by 110th Street, Sixty-seventh Road and 108th Street from a "D" zone to a "G" zone.

An executive committee of leaders in finance, business, agriculture, industry, labor and education, charged with the responsibility of directing a State-wide program of defense savings, was announced yesterday by Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the New York State Committee for the Sale of Defense Bonds and Stamps.

As a result of the lack of rain this month, forest fires are again prevalent in several sections of New York State, and officials of the Conservation Department report that unless conditions are improved before the opening of the Fall hunting season the woods will be as dry as they were last Spring.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 25 -- Profit-taking caused an initial reaction on the Bourse today, but a slight rally developed near the close. Royal Dutch was 3 1/2 lower at 331 3/4; Amsterdam Rubber, 2 1/4, at 317 1/4; Amsterdam Trading, 1 at 494, and Philips 1 3/4% at 282 1/2, but Unilever was 1 3/4%, higher at 170 1/2%.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Russians are throwing "great masses" of troops against German positions on the north central front, apparently to draw German strength away from Leningrad, dispatches from the front said tonight.

An exhibition of paintings and etchings of New York by an architect, Edward Shepard Hewitt, opened at the Harlow, Keppel Galleries yesterday afternoon with a preview, and will be open to the public today. Mr. Hewitt long has been a resident of Brooklyn Heights, from which he has depicted lower New York.

Sixty mothers of New York City selectees now receiving military training were served exactly the same meal their sons were eating in camp at lunchtime yesterday when they visited the National Defense Show in Grand Central Palace at the invitation of the Quartermaster Corps, Second Army Corps Area.

Appointment of Clyde F. Farmer, assistant to the president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, as vice president of traffic was announced yesterday. He was freight traffic manager of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad until he joined the Lackawanna on Aug. 1 last.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Leningrad Is still being shelled unremittingly by guns of many calibers from German field positions. Reich land forces are reported by the official news agency, D.N.B., to have tightened the noose about that beleaguered metropolis.

Special Notice Company commanders shall direct all members of the uniformed force when released from military duty to report at Room 1124, Municipal Building, Manhattan, with the documents issued to them at the time of their separation from military service.

Seymour Burg, a 20-year-old un-employed printer, who had been gaining access to social functions by misrepresenting himself as a NEW YORK TIMES reporter, pleaded guilty to unlawful entry before Magistrate Klapp in Felony Court yesterday and was held in $3,500 bail for Special Sessions.

Milk price increases equaling the record for the city appeared likely yesterday as a result of demands for higher prices from farmers and for higher wages by 14,000 union drivers and other employes of 120 milk companies in the metropolitan area.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At the last meeting of the City Council I introduced a resolution endorsed by other members of the Council minority urging the City Housing Authority to consider the advisability of undertaking public housing developments which would require no cash subsidies, and which would be available for low-income families now ineligible for tenancy in subsidized housing projects.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

SHANGHAI, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A large force of Japanese warplanes made a "devastating" raid on the Chinese capital of Chungking today, the Japanese announced, while both air and ground forces hammered against Chinese positions in Hunan Province.

Six thousand men and women gathered yesterday noon before the Subtreasury Building to cheer and applaud as prominent speakers warned dictators that Americans would never submit to any alien ideologies nor succumb to the blandishments of a "new order."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board suspended today for sixty days the commercial pilot certificate of Hugh C. Bobbins, who on April 6 flew a newspaper photographer over the British battleship Malaya in New York harbor.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) ---The Bank of England's statement issued today showed that note circulation was continuing an upward swing to another new high record of u671,393,000, an increase of more than u1,600,000 in the week. Both government securities and private deposits increased over the previous week and bullion figures were u100,000 higher.

Members of the bar were urged in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. John Hugh O'Donnell, president of the University of Notre Dame, to unite against attempts to undermine the foundations of jurisprudence in America.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- To the radio audience should be served better programs through the cooperation of those who know how to entertain and those who know how to educate, Kolin Hager told delegates to the New York Library Association's conference tonight.

Excess Reserves Following heavy increases in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System In the two preceding weeks, excess reserves in the week ended on Wednesday declined $50,000,000% it was disclosed yesterday, making the current total for the system $5,200,000,000.

State of California Kaiser Co. bought yesterday $2,281,830 of general fund registered warrants of the State of California at one-half of 1 per cent plus a premium of $1,726. The obligations, dated Sept. 30, 1941, are to be payable on or about Feb. 25, 1942.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Sept. 26 -- The long-expected German thrust in Crimea has been underway for more than twenty-four hours, it was acknowledged by the Russian spokesman in Moscow early today.
No longer will Lena gaze tolerantly at the fish in the Aquarium, roam at will along the Battery wall or sleep the hours away on its green lawn -- when not catching rats.

The John Hay Whitney racer Gramps, by the doughty Equipoise, but never noted as a stayer until Duval Headley got hold of him, won again yesterday at a mile and a half before 11,999 persons at Belmont Park. In his previous effort Gramps had figured in a dead heat with Iron Shot, also at a mile and a half.

No Clothing Resistance Yet Between the hot weather and the religious holidays, men's wear stores have not been able to decide yet whether higher prices are developing any consumer resistance. These two factors were responsible for a slowing down in sales this week and last.
BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- A new submarine attack on a British convoy in which eleven merchantmen were sunk was reported in a special High Command communique from the Reichsfuehrer's headquarters today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Agitation in Congress for American aid at the present time in feeding the European countries overrun by the German and Italian armies was countered today by Congressional leaders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Allan S. Haywood, director of organization of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared before the Federal Communications Commission today that newspaper-owned radio stations had repeatedly discriminated against the C.I.O.

Apartment leasing that extended into many areas of Manhattan marked the reports submitted yesterday by agents and brokers. A continued heavy volume of activity was indicated, despite the nearness of the traditional moving day, and some brokers declared that the current season was the best they had experienced in many years.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The two-hit hurling of Ray Starr, veteran, minor leaguer up from Indianapolis, gave the Reds their second consecutive shut-out over the Cubs today, 6 to 0, in the season's final home game.

Bruce Bliven, editor and president of The New Republic, has signed a contract with Duell, Sloan Pearce for a book entitled "Men Who Make the Future." Mr. Bliven will survey new achievements in divergent fields of science, basing the studies mainly on interviews with leading men in each field.

The cotton market lost yesterday almost all its gains of the two previous sessions under pressure from political developments and technical factors in the trade. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near their low levels for the session and at net losses of 11 to 16 points.

Civic and religious leaders in this city paid tribute yesterday to the late Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of the President, on the eighty-seventh anniversary of her birth at a special memorial service, held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- New regulations issued by the War Department today opened the door for National Guard and Reserve officers and men on active duty to run for public office despite normal regulations prohibiting such participation in politics.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 25 -- When the season's polo handicap title is started Sunday afternoon with the final of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup, it will bring together the same two teams that fought last week for the open title. Gulf Stream qualified to face Aknusti for the title by turning back Texas, 12 to 7, today.

Bank clearings of the twentythree principal cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,496,952,000, an increase of 24 per cent over the $5,239,102,000 reported for corresponding week the year before, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. said here today that "the most hopeful possible solution" to the serious problem now facing endowed institutions as a result of sharply curtailed incomes was to increase greatly the number of contributors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The War Department awarded contracts totaling $80,890,836 it was announced today. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

Defending the actions of the Rapp-Coudert investigating committee, of which he is chairman, Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., asserted yesterday that at no time had the committee attempted to smear any teacher who was innocent of subversive activities, and maintained that the hearings, both private and public, were conducted in an honest manner.

Going to market will be, on the whole, a cheery business this weekend, with several pleasant surprises in store for the thrifty homemaker. Pork has again slipped down the price scale into more approachable regions, the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets tells us, and loins are to be had in many stores for 6 cents less a pound than they cost at the first of the month.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Seigo Nakano, Japanese pro-German political leader, said in an interview last night that the Japanese people demand a firmer foreign policy and that if "Japan submits to the United States she will be destroyed."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Mystery clouded the fate of the disabled freighter Ethel Skakel and her twenty-eight-man crew tonight after the twenty-three-year-old vessel had radioed distress calls from the immediate vicinity of a severe storm in the Caribbean Sea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 John Lee Mahain has completed the "Tortilla Flat" photoplay for MGM in which Spencer Tracy will be seen as Pilon. Ruth Hussey was announced for the role of Dolores in 1940, but the studio declared today that no castings aside from Tracy are definite.

Samuel Wolchok, president of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, C.I.O., announced yesterday the suspension of Lowell Morris as business manager of the union's Local 3, composed of employes of Bloomingdale's.

The "freedom" silhouette, designed to allow its wearer maximum movement, was introduced yesterday by Milgrim's at a showing of Fall and Winter styles during luncheon hour at the Plaza Hotel. This was the first of a series of weekly style shows at the hotel.

Vacating the Cort Theatre after tomorrow night's performance is "The More Merrier," the Frank Gabrielson-Iron Pincus farce. It will have been presented sixteen times by Otto L. Preminger and Norman Pincus with a cast headed by Frank Albertson, Teddy Hart, Millard Mitchell, Louis Hector, Grace McDonald, Keenan Wynn, Will Geer and G. Albert Smith.
ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- An eight-month drought has sucked away the normal water supplies of a dozen New York State communities and today threatened to close the forests again.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Britain has embarked on a long-term program of tank production for Russia that will entail heavy sacrifices and great risks over a period at least through next Spring, it was learned here today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 25 -- First ballots returned in a nation-wide survey of public sentiment on the Administration's new "shoot on sight" policy indicate a sizable majority approving that policy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: From the days of the last war, there have been claims outstanding for the return of property sequestrated under the Trading With the Enemy Act, now held in various trusts by the United States Treasury. Payment, however, cannot be made because of Public Resolution No. 53 (Harrison resolution of 1934), forbidding payment to former enemy nationals, except by executive order of the President.
ROME, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Italian High Command today issued the following communique:

Another substantial increase in commercial loans of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City was shown yesterday in the figures announced by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the week ended for Wednesday.

A client of Prince Ripley, Inc., brokers, has purchased for cash, above a purchase money mortgage of $30,000, the business property at 39-41 Main Street, on the corner of Columbus Avenue, Tuckahoe, Westchester.

While the Secretary of Treasury made some sound and effective points in testifying before a Congressional committee on price-control legislation, the net effect of his testimony is profoundly disturbing. He declares, rightly, that if we hope to win the battle against inflation we must fight it courageously "on all fronts" -- and then immediately proceeds to find excuses for not fighting it on one of the most important fronts of all, that of wage-control.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Cheering crowds of men and women, many of whom had gathered before daylight, greeted the Duke and Duchess of Windsor at the Union Station on their arrival from Miami early this morning, and throughout the day the visitors ran into traffic jams wherever their crowded schedule took them.

Retail groups are becoming fearful that the public will place upon them the responsibility for the higher prices now developing in so many lines and are anxious that where the advances have been made solely by manufacturers the latter bear the burden.

August Zinsser, a trustee of the Central Savings Bank for more than a quarter of a century, vice chairman of the executive committee and president of the bank from 1926 to 1936, will retire tomorrow on his seventieth birthday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Following is the text of the Duke of Windsor's speech at the National Press Club this afternoon:

The Jooss Ballet last night made its first change of program at Maxine Elliott's Theatre, presenting "A Spring Tale" for the first time on Broadway, and "The Prodigal Son" in a version altogether different in choreography, cast and costume from that presented here by the same company several years ago.
