Fear of further prosecution prompted Gerald W. Tiffany, notorious bucket-shop swindler free on probation, to end his life yesterday by inhaling illuminating gas in the apartment of a friend on the ninth floor of 17 West Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commismission approved today a plan for the reorganization of the Federal Water Service Corporation, whose corporate structure had been found "repugnant" to the requirements of the Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Senate investigation into alleged war propaganda in the movies turned into a rough-and-tumble argument over foreign policy today, culminating in a shouted assertion from Wendell L. Willkie that Chairman Clark of Idaho had broadcast over the country "un qualified falsehoods" regarding his position in this matter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Bundles of franked envelopes used by members of Congress for their mail and discovered at the offices of the Make-Europe-Pay-War-Debts and Islands-for-War-Debts Committees, are part of the evidence considered in a grand jury investigation of Nazi agents in the United States, it was asserted today.

The American shipbuilding program is well ahead of the most hopeful expectations, but all elements involved in the unprecedented ship construction and ship operation plans of the government will have to achieve close cooperation to assure success of the national defense effort, according to Captain Howard L. Vickery, U.S.N., a member of the Maritime Commission.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- General Charles de Gaulle announced today the composition of the Free French National Council that will serve under his Presidency as a provisional government until they can hand over their functions to a constitutionally representative French Government.

The responsibility for continued high real estate assessments in New York City was ascribed last night to the La Guardla administration by Lloyd C. Church, Democratic nominee for city Controller, in his acceptance speech, delivered over WOR at 9:15 o'clock.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America (C.I.O.) struck out today at communism in two separate actions at its seventh national convention at the Hotel President.

President Roosevelt "goes to the record" in this week's article in Collier's Magazine to point the steps his Administration took in attempting to promote a better world order, head off the war, and the part he believes Congress's refusal to repeal the arms embargo in July, 1939, played in hastening the opening of hostilities.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Gottfried Feder, one of the oldest and leading members of the Nazi (National Socialist) party, died in Munich yesterday at the age of 58. He drew up the original twenty-five-point program on which the party was founded in 1922.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Socialist newspaper Critica charged today that the plot uncovered this week in Argentina was a Nazi conspiracy involving a military attack on Chile designed to prevent unity in the Americas.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- Aside from a minimum of replacements, the automobile drivers of the United States may have to struggle along during the war emergency with no more than a total of 30,000,000 cars which they now have.

The twenty-seventh annual Flower Show of the American Dahlia Society, which closed its two-day exhibition last night at the American Museum of Natural History was attended by about 25,000 persons and won high praise for its rare splendor and perfection.

The United Engineering and Foundry Company, makers of steel mill equipment, announced yesterday that the problem of producing electrolytic tin plate in strip form in commercial quantities had been solved by the company after three years of exeprimentation.

Headquarters for the Citizens' Committee for the Re-election of Mayor La Guardia, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, were opened yesterday in the Hotel Astor, increasing the committee and organizations supporting the Mayor for re-election to a third term to an unprecedented number.

ROME, Sept. 25 -- Coincident with word that 1,500,000 Serbs still oppose the Axis-sponsored regime in Croatia -- thousands of them roaming in guerrilla bands with torch, bomb and machine gun -- Italy proclaimed today she had secured her Adriatic flanlk by reoccupation of a Croatian demilitarized zone.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Loading's of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 20 totaled 907,969 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,983 cars, or 0.7 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 84,640 cars, or 11.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 98,-217 cars, or 12.1 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 25 -- General Angel Maria Zuloaga, Commander of Army Aviation, was relieved of his command today by order of the executive because his position had been rendered untenable by Tuesday's seditious military movement that was largely confined to the flying branch of the service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Three hundred additions were made to the blacklist of Latin-American concerns and individuals believed to be acting in the interest of Germany and Italy in a supplemental list issued tonight by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 -- In one of the most impressive play rehearsals this observer has looked upon, the Harvard football varsity went through its full repertory of fakes and hidden-ball manoeuvres at top speed this afternoon while Dick Harlow and his staff whippet up a fever of enthusiasm among the men until they were functionIng letter perfect in the execution of their individual assignments.

The passenger liner Evangeline, the first ship affected by the sea-men's strike which began on Sept. 13 and ended Wednesday night as a result of Federal mediation, will sail today at 5 P.M. for the West Indies, officials of the Alcoa Line announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (U.P.) -- Aldo (Buff) Donelli, football coach at Duquesne University, today took on the additional job of coaching the professional Pittsburgh Steelers, the first man ever to coach a college and pro team at the same time.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Japanese conversations with the United States are compatible with the spirit of the Tripartite Alliance, Saburo Kurusu, Japan's Ambassador in Berlin when the pact was signed, declared in an interview published yesterday.

Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, disclosed yesterday that he had information that Abe Bebohick, Brooklyn policy banker mysteriously slain Wednesday, had paid gambling-protection money to policemen and that as a result twenty plainclothes patrolmen had been questioned before the two extraordinary grand juries investigating official corruption.
Thirteen days after the completely un-American speech which Charles A. Lindbergh delivered at Des Monies on Sept. 11 the America First Committee has issued a statement in which it says:

United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., in the year ended with June, had a consolidated net profit of 12,623,132, equivalent to $4.37 each on the 600,000 shares of issued common stock, according to the annual report of J.W. Schwab, president, for publication today.

Establishment of a professional repertory theatre for high school audiences, which would present six plays a season, chosen from those being studied in English classes, at prices from 25 to 35 cents, is being planned, it became known yesterday.

THIS heavyweight championship fight is a hard one to figure. Who can tell how much J. Shufflin' Louis has slipped, if at all? Lou Nova says he thinks the champion is as good as ever, but it isn't worrying him at all because --

TORONTO, Sept. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Whipping up to near-hurricane velocity in some sections, a roaring September storm fanned out to sweep along the coast of Lake Ontario east from Toronto tonight. At least three persons were killed, many others were injured and first reports of property loss indicated thousands of dollars' damage.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Lou Nova, Alameda, Calif., challenger for the world heavyweight title, will have no complaint to make on his physical condition if he loses to Champion Joe Louis on Monday night in the ring at the Polo Grounds.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 25 -- By a voted of 183 to 7, the biennial convention of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C.I.O., adopted today a resolution defining the military defeat of Hitlerism as the primary task confronting the United States and calling for a "torrent" of supplies from this country to Great Britain, Soviet Russia and China.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx was defeated yesterday in a move to forestall the closing of the Aquarium on Oct. 1 when a majority of the Board of Estimate refused to reconsider its original decision on the closing date.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Russian lines before Leningrad again swung out in a series of vigorous counter-attacks yesterday and Soviet accounts declared that the great battle was at least momentarily turning against the invaders.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF SECOND ARMY, SOMEWHERE IN LOUISIANA, Sept. 25 -- A major reorganization of the armored divisions of the United States Army to provide greater hitting power and more tactical flexibility has been planned and tentatively approved, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Department store sales for the week ended Sept. 20 were 12 per cent higher than for the corresponding period of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales in the week ended Sept. 13 were up 8 per cent.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, informed a meeting of the American Women's Voluntary Services last night that he had set up a staff committee to study the role of volunteer aides in his department should it be called upon to provide communal kitchens, evacuate bombed areas and rehouse the homeless in the event of a military emergency in New York City.

The Brooklyn Dodgers won the 1941 National League baseball pennant yesterday. They beat the Braves at Boston, 6 to 0, while the St. Louis Cardinals gasped out their last hope in Pittsburgh, 3 to 1. It was Brooklyn's first pennant since 1920.

An effort by the State Mediation Board to intervene yesterday in the strike of elevator operators and other building: service employes in the thirty-two-story Salmon Tower Building, 11 West Forty-second Street, and the sixty-two-story office building at 500 Fifth Avenue, as the strike entered upon its second day, failed when the Walter J. Salmon interests, operators of the building, rejected mediation by the board.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 (U.P.)Nazi informants said today that Germany had assigned about 2,000 troops to help the army of General Milan Neditch, Serbian Premier, to stamp out disorders in Serbia, which were ascribed here to "unrest whipped up by the Moscow radio."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A longer work week was advocated today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of Price Control, as one way of taking up the slack in defense production.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- Signalizing the opening of a nation-wide Dinner-for-a-Dollar Day program of the Camp Fire Girls, three Trenton members of the organization served a meal to Governor Charles Edison at the State Fair here this afternoon.

An ugly rumor has been going around the country. People say that the Marx Brothers have broken up their slap-stick team. Rialto Gossip, which hears all evil and tells a good part of it, printed a melancholy confirmation of the rumor signed by Groucho Marx a fortnight ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Securities amounting to $108,230,000 became effective under the Securities Act in August, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
Prince Serge Obolensky gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Mrs. Harrisen Williams, Mrs. Hugh McLeod Fenwick, Mrs. Cameron Clark, Alan Lennox-Boyd and Jay Rutherfurd.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- Fraud, incompetence and malfeasance were attributed to the State Highway Department today by Harold H. Fisher of the Governor's investigating staff as the hearing on land acquisition cases went into its sixteenth day.
NEW YORK Dr. Joao Antonio de Bianchi, the Portuguese Minister, and Mrs. de Bianchi have arrived from Washington and are at the RitzCarlton.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- One of the season's major golf upsets took place in the semi-final round of the tri-county championship at the Century Club today when Mrs. William R. Kirkland, former metropolitan champion and still regarded as one of the district's foremost linkswomen, lost to Mrs. Archie McLave, a four-handicap golfer from Westchester Hills.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Roosevelt Administration is facing a dilemma as the result of the National Defense Mediation Board's policy of recommending the closed shop and "maintenance of membership."

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

A total of 102 passengers from Lisbon and Bermuda arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard two clippers, the Atlantic and the Dixie, giving Pan American Airways its largest number of incoming passengers in one day since the transatlantic service was started more than two years ago.

With only twenty of its 250 delegates dissenting, the third biennial convention of the Transport Workers Union of America, C.I.O., voted yesterday a strong endorsement of President Roosevelt's foreign policy and pledged the "support, patriotism and loyalty" of the union and its members to a program of all-out aid to Britain, Russia, China and all other nations opposed to Hitlerism.

In the company of a group of close friends and well-wishers, the detective story formally celebrated its 100th anniversary yesterday. Congratulated and eulogized for having come a long way since Poe's "The Murders in the Rue Morgue," the guest of honor was at the same time reminded of its responsibilities and warned of incipient diseases and infirmities that might set in during its second century of literary life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Congressional drive to modify or repeal the Neutrality Act and return American merchant ships to full freedom of the seas took more definite form today with the introduction of an outright repealer by Senator McKellar of Tennessee.

Grover A. Whalen reported to Mayor La Guardia yesterday that there was "a real and serious" shortage of gasoline and fuel oil along the Eastern seaboard. To meet it he recommended a tenpoint conservation program which he estimated would save New York City car and home owners $25,000,000 annually through the elimination of existing wastes.

Holding that "food will win the war and write the peace," Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard revealed here yesterday that during the next twelve months the Federal Government, through its all-out aid program to England, expected to supply at least one-fourth of the food consumed in the British Isles.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- Leo Durocher's battling Dodgers today ended their grueling, season-long race with the Cardinals and became the 1941 National League champions by beating the Braves, 6 -- 0, while the courageous Southworth crew was losing to the Pirates in Pittsburgh.

Trading in wholesale meat markets here yesterday was mostly fair. Fresh pork cuts sold strong to a shade higher. Other classes were mostly unchanged. All kosher meats were lower Wednesday and yesterday's market opened weak with only a fair to alow demand.

A property in the garment area that had been in the Wendel estate for about a century passed to new control yesterday when the twelve-story loft building at 584-90 Eighth Avenue, between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Street, was sold by the Wendel Foundation to David S. Meister, operator.

Manhattan's starting eleven for tomorrow's opener with St. Bonaventure, named yesterday by Coach Herb Kopf, is made up of seven seniors, three juniors and a sophomore. The designation of the first team for 1941 came at the close of a two-and-one-half-hour non-contact drill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A reaction in agricultural markets brought the Bureau of Labor statistics index of wholesale prices of nearly 900 series down 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Sept. 20. At 91.5 per cent of the 1926 average the general level of commodity prices in wholesale markets was 1.7 per cent higher than last month and 17.8 per cent above the year before.
BERLIN, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- Perhaps it was never in the Cards for the outcome to be otherwise, and a few minutes after 5 o'clock this afternoon St. Louis bowed to the inevitable as Billy Southworth's grim Redbirds went down to a 3-1 defeat in their series finale with the Pirates.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Plans for the new Chicago morning newspaper being backed by Marshall Field are progressing satisfactorily, Mr. Field said today in Chicago.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- Although ignoring the railroad tax laws enacted at Governor Charles Edison's urging, and which caused Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, for a quarter century the party's State leader, to "abdicate," the Democratic platform for the coming general election calls for the overthrow of the Republican majority in the Legislature to assure support of Mr. Edison's administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 24:

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division moved out of their quarters this afternoon, loaded their equipment in more than 2,000 vehicles, ate supper from mobile field kitchens and at midnight began a 700-mile journey to the First Army "war" in North Carolina.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Central Front, Sept. 23 (Delayed) -- This village, which is called Ushakovo, has lost one of its three dimensions. Now it has only length and breadth; there are no vertical elements save a couple of gateposts and a small wooden obelisk on a mass grave.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently a young man from one of our up-State New York counties received the highest grade in a technical examination in competition with 200 other applicants. In recognition of this he was awarded an important defense position in a great electrical company near here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Administration's approach to the question of price controls is political at two major points: farm products and wages. This is generally accepted in Washington as explaining the exemption of these two great cost factors in the pending price-limitations bill.

"A Yank in the R.A.F.," starring Tyrone Power, and Betty Grable, will have its premiere this morning at the Roxy. Produced by Twentieth Century-Fox under the supervision of Darryl F. Zanuck, the film features John Sutton, Reginald Gardiner, Donald Stuart and John Wilde.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, the defending champion, and Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol advanced to the final of the nineteenth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship on the Echo Lake course today.

VICHY, France, Sept. 25 -- Jews permitted to practice the profession of architecture are limited, according to a decree issued today, to 2 per cent of the architects listed in a district, but in no case can they be more numerous than they were on June 25, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Treasry experts are preparing a bill embodying Secretary Morgenthau's proposal that corporation profits be limited to 6 per cent on invested capital for the duration of the emergency as an anti-inflationary measure, the Secretary stated today.

It would be hard to find a heartier centenarian than the detective story, whose first century was commemorated in this city yesterday. Poe was the father of a great race. Somebody has called our time the Golden Age of this form of fiction. From the statistics of literary crime we learn that in 1939 233 crime novels were published in the United States; in 1940, 283.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The first White House funeral service in five years will be held tomorrow afternoon in the East Room for G. Hall Roosevelt, only brother of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who died at 5 A.M., Eastern standard time, today in the Walter Reed Hospital at the age of 50.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Shattering all course and tournament records for the second nine holes, Tommy Harmon, Montclair GoLf Club professional, took the lead in the annual New Jersey State open, golf championship at The Forest Hill Field Club today when he went out in 39, three over par, and returned in 29, six under, for a 68.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed gold holdings and Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

The Europe that emerges from the dark agony of this war will present many new problems to the collective wisdom and humanity of the civilized world. But Hitler has brought at least one solution nearer; he has terribly simplified the complex and explosive problem of minorities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, seeking about $600,000,000 to replenish working capital to build additional plants and to repay bank loans necessitated by some $21,000,000 of expansion beyond plant facilities built and owned by the Federal Government, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 534,426 shares of common, stock, $50 par value, and subscription warrants evidencing the right to purchase such shares.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (U.P.) -- Senate and House tax experts predicted privately today that Congress would reject Secretary Morgentnau's proposal to limit corporation, profits to 6 per cent during the emergency.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Scientists, gathering here today in preparation for the opening of a three-day session on "Science and World Order," were told by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, that "they faced a future of struggle against hunger and slavery" in which they would have to fight against "suffering either of body or of spirit."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Plans to treble the output of 100-octane aviation gasoline by building fifty new refineries at a cost of $150,000,000 were announced by Secretary Ickes today.

With the introduction yesterday of Senator McKellar's resolution to repeal the Neutrality Act, there is additional reason to hope that this long-postponed issue will at last be brought squarely before Congress, where it belongs, and disposed of in the right way. Congress itself has already taken a series of steps which go part way toward repeal.

Tough Accent Persists People' are turning away from light fiction to serious books, at least in the State of New York. So the librarians in convention assembled at Lake Mohonk report. They attribute it to the war, from, which not everybody is apparently trying to find escape, or if they do seek escape they go to the movies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The government of Vichy is trying hard to solve the problem of its diplomatic representation in Washington. Notwithstanding a denial issued last week, nobody doubts that the days of Gaston Henry-Haye in the United States are numbered.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Daylight air-raid alarms were sounded in Germany for the first time in the war recently, a German military spokesman revealed today. The date was not revealed, but the spokesman said that the alert was sounded "in several towns in Central Germany."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- Pinch hitting with the bases full and the score tied in the ninth inning, Johnny McCarthy hoisted a puny fly that fell safely near the right-field foul line to send in the winning run of the Giants' 3-2 victory over the Phillies today.

The reorganization of the Republican County Committee's leadership, begun when Thomas J. Curran succeeded Kenneth F. Simpson as chairman, was completed last night at a meeting of the committee at the Manhattan Center on West Thirty-fourth Street.

The government yesterday opened its case against Axel Wheeler-Hill, accused with three others of operating a radio-sending set for the purpose of transmitting information on the sailings of ships from New York to Great Britain, as the trial of Wheeler-Hill and fifteen others charged with espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government continued before Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

Proud and happy Brooklyn baseball fans, 10,000 strong, jammed and transformed Grand Central Terminal into a bedlam last night as the victorious Dodgers came home from Boston with their first National Leaguepennantin twenty-one years.

Members of the advisory committee of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange were appointed yesterday by Emil Schram, its new president. They are to take their places on Oct. 1, when the institution is to change from the committee form of government to the corporate form.

Two price-fixing conspiracies, alleged to affect 25,000,000 pounds of cheese produced in this State annually, were charged yesterday to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the Kraft Cheese Company and ninety other defendants.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 26 -- The measures taken on the Berlin Boerse against the excessive prices of shares had a sharp repercussion here today with heavy liquidation developing and the volume increasing. The close showed some losses of 17 points.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Bank deposits here are the greatest on record and loans and discounts are the largest since Dec. 31, 1931, it was disclosed today in reports made in response to national and State bank calls for statements of condition as of Sept. 24.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Sad indeed is the feeling of disgust, of utter disgrace, which has overcome this rabid National League fan of thirteen years; for in this year of 1941 Brooklyn has taken the pennant of the senior circuit, which should, by all rights, be flying from the flagpole of Sportsman's Park in St. Louis.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Bobby Feller gave Cleveland a chance to finish in a tie for third place today by pitching a 1-hit victory over the Browns, 3 to 2, in the nightcap of a double-header after the Indians had lost the first game in 11 innings, 6 to 5.

Five others against Whirlaway in the $11,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup, and fourteen juveniles in the $80.000 Futurity, are the highlights of today's program at Belmont Park. Despite the long two miles of the Cup race, most Whirlaway admirers expect that the race will prove merely another step forward in the effort to establish the Warren Wright color-bearer as the world's leading money-winning thoroughbred.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Sept. 26 -- At the present rate of induction of selectees, New York bids fair to soon become the State with the largest representation in the Armored Force and the Armored Force Training Center.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- "Frenchman's Creek," Daphne du Maurier's new and unpublished novel of adventure during the Napoleonic era, was purchased today by Paramount for $125,000. Although the bidding was highly competitive, Miss du Maurier closed with Paramount because of the cast that studio has in view for the picture.

AN early arrival in what one ventures to prophesy will soon become a considerable covey (sharp trend ahead) of books about the Soviets and the war is Maurice Hiudus's "Hitler Cannot Conquer Russia,"* which reached us so hurriedly day before yesterday that it didn't even wear a jacket.

In connection with the observances of the 100th anniversary of the publication of Poe's "The Murders in the Rue Morgue" attention is called to a letter of Poe's dated Aug. 13, 1841, and addressed to his publishers. Poe wrote that he wished to publish a "new collection" of his tales.

TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- A floor fight at the closing session of the Republican State Convention here next Tuesday was indicated today when the resolutions committee of the convention made public a tentative platform and a minority report sharply criticizing the majority plank recommending revision of the State Constitution by amendments.

Formation of an International "Independent Hungary movement, with headquarters in New York City, to labor for Hungary's, liberation from Nazi domination and for a post-war peace based on genuine collaboration among the small nations of the Danube, was announced yesterday by Tibor Eckhardt, voluntarily exiled member of the Hungarian Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Amid a confusion of shouted charges and counter-charges, witnesses told the Senate movie investigating subcommittee today that persons of German, Jewish or South Irish ancestry were not wanted as employes at the British purchasing agency here.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 26 -- Despite the increased burdens the u322,000,000 budget presented yesterday is cheerfully accepted as the inevitable result of trebled expenditures in the last three years in which the cost of defense has risen from u14,000,000 to u217,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I venture to address this letter to you because, clearly enough, we have reached one of those periods of pause in the war in which a moral stocktaking is essential; and there is, I think, a real danger that the balance of forces may be wrongly estimated by a public which is still remote from the actual impact of conflict.

In a brochure entitled "John Doe Looks at Industry in War" the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company yesterday cited a number of reasons why oversold manufacturers should continue to advertise during the period of the emergency. The national program of curtailment, substitution and-simplification is creating many problems for manufacturers and questions in John Doe's mind, which should be answered, it was said.

Despite the conflicting reports read in the newspapers or heard on the radio, New York City's high school students have learned how to separate news from propaganda and possess a "very satisfactory" understanding of the world crisis and changing international events, a study made by the Board of Education's high school division disclosed yesterday.

CHATAIGNIER, La., Sept. 26 -- One hundred and thirty-one "men from Mars" in forest green, rubberized silk coveralls and plastic helmets dropped suddenly into a pasture in this Evangeline country of Louisiana today, frightened a herd of cows into bawling terror and proceeded methodically about the business of disrupting the Blue Third Army's communications and rear areas.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- On the eve of the first anniversary of the signing of the Tripartite Pact between Germany, Italy and Japan. Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, has returned to Berlin from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters, and it is expected here that commemorating ceremonies will be held in Berlin tomorrow.

Michael J. Quill was unanimously re - elected international president of the Transport Workers Union of America, C.I.O., for a third successive term of two years at the union's third biennial convention last night at Transport Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street.

The Protestant Digest, edited by Kenneth Leslie, made public yesterday a declaration of principle, attacking Charles A. Lindbergh's Des Moines speech as marking the beginning of an anti-Semitic campaign aimed at democracy, and listed the names of 700 Protestant churchmen from all parts of the country who signed the declaration.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Sept. 26 -- At a cost of $37,770, two regimental chapels will be built at once at this post of the Twenty-ninth Division. Work will be completed by Dec. 15, according to Captain Loren A. Wilson, the new construction, quartermaster here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that under the Holding Company Act the Central Illinois Public Service Company had filed an application covering $38,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, Series A, due on Oct. 1, 1971, and $9,000,000 of unsecured notes due on April 1, 1942, to Oct. 1, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A program designed to prevent a speculative boom in farm lands such as occurred in the World War was outlined to a group of leading farm mortgage lenders here today by A.G. Black, governor of the Farm Credit Administration. Representatives of more than 100 institutions and insurance companies which write about 75 per cent of the farm mortgage loans were invited to the conference.

There could be small comfort for any Dodger fans who strayed into the Stadium yesterday for a glance at the villains whom their heroes will meet in the world series. What they saw was disconcerting, to say the least.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- German forces smashing eastward toward the Caucasus and Russian oil were said authoritatively tonight to have hurled 70,000 men into a sickle-like sweep aimed at disposing of Crimea in passing.

FORT DEC, N.J., Sept. 26 -- This 25,000-acre reservation had all the earmarks of "a ghost city" today with, two-thirds of its 30,000 population headed south for manoeuvres and the remaining 10,000 so scattered that their presence was scarcely noticeable.

A second German-born, naturalized United States citizen who became a counter-espionage agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in order to trap members of an alleged Nazi spy ring took the witness stand yesterday at the trial of sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Shaving four strokes from the Forest Hill Field Club par of 71, Jack Mitchell, Spring Brook professional, today took the lead at the half-way point in the twenty-first annual New Jersey State open golf championship.

Although the surfcasting at Montauk has been rather unproductive during the week because of the unsettled weather and high surf, the prospects are excellent for this week-end, according to Frank Tuma of the Montauk Surf Fishing Club.

Reflecting the scramble for silk stockings last month, the hosiery department led all other sections of department stores in this Federal Reserve District with an increase of 134 per cent in August compared with the same month, last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The principal ceremony in the launching of fourteen cargo ships tomorrow will be at Baltimore when the Patrick Henry, the first. liberty ship, will be launched at 12:30 P.M. Eastern standard time. The Patrick Henry Is one of three ships of its type to be launched tomorrow out of 312 liberty ships now under construction.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The 198th Coast Artillery Regiment will move from Fort Ontario on Monday, Oct. 6, proceeding to Philadelphia, where the unit will take up positions to repel an "air attack." About 1,600 officers and men of the regiment will make the trip and have been assigned to stations at Fairmount Park and League Island and at an undetermined third site.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- General disapproval of Secretary Morgenthau's proposal to limit corporation profits to 6 per cent during the emergency was voiced today by members of Congress who were in the city, and any idea that such an enactment could be put through the legislative body was described as "fantastic."

ABOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Sept. 26 -- After a simple but impressive funeral at the White House this afternoon for G. Hall Roosevelt, who died yesterday, President and Mrs. Roosevelt were on the way tonight to Tivoli, N.Y., where the body will be buried in private ceremonies tomorrow morning.

Conservation of shipping containers through reuse, reduced thickness, decreased number of styles and sizes, less interior packing, fewer individual packages and greater use of bulk shipments, was recommended by speakers yesterday at a special shipping container conference held by the American Management Association at the request of the Office of Production Management at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Japanese Government has forbidden "unofficial" celebrations today of the first anniversary of Japan's treaty with the Axis Powers. The prohibition could not have been necessary. Nothing has come of Berlin's solemn recognition of the "New Order in Greater East Asia."

WELMINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Troops at Fort du Pont have been busy this week with intensive training. Almost every night there have been drills with searchlight batteries stationed several miles out the Newcastle Road north of the fort and similar batteries on the St. Georges Road south of the post, crisscrossing beams over the entire area.

MEXICO CITY, Sept 26 -- The peaceful passage through the center of Mexico City today of perhaps 20,000 workers in the funeral procession for the victims of Tuesday's shooting seemed to indicate that both sides desired to avoid a test of strength at present and preferred to allow the revolutionary tension of the last few days to die down.

A gala "Downtown Hop," presented under the auspices of the Downtown Committee of the British War Relief Society, took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor, drawing an attendance of more than 1,500 persons.

Chief Many Rains returned yesterday to the happy hunting grounds of his ancestors. The Chief, Patrolman James A. Schowers, who was killed Tuesday in Harlem in performance of duty, made known, through a letter written in 1938 and read at his request at his funeral, the simple but stirring emotions of a man willing to give his life for the things in which he believed.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- German troops storming the approaches to Crimea have been mowed down by the thousands, and Russian defenders still stand unbeaten outside Leningrad, Soviet war dispatches said today.

John J. Knewitz, who has been under fire for alleged friendliness with the Democratic organization headed by National Chairman Edward J. Flynn, was re-elected last night chairman of the Bronx County Republican Committee at a stormy meeting at the Winter Garden, Washington and East Tremont Avenues.

It is safe to assume that in the present emergency money rates will remain low and there is little likelihood that the Federal Government will permit them to rise disproportionately after the emergency, Dr. Marcus Nadler, professor of finance at New York University, said yesterday in an address at a luncheon of the Municipal Forum of New York in the Block Hall Luncheon Club, 23 South William Street.

The task of superstatemanship after this war is twofold: to find a solution of the problem of Germany, the crucial problem of the world's peace, and to work out a practical answer to the infinitely complex questions which have become more inflamed and confused than ever by the German occupation of Southeastern Europe.

Six Per Cent of What? Business men in general know that sacrifices are expected of them, of their workers and of their stockholders in the prosecution of the national defense, but they have one practical suggestion about the proposal that all corporation profits be limited to 6 per cent.

As in the case of nearly all the Edna Ferber-George S. Kaufman collaborations, among them "The Royal Family," "Dinner at Eight," and "Stage Door," the playwrights' latest effort also will have a goodsized cast. Twenty-seven principals have been engaged and commenced rehearsing yesterday.

A tribunal of four priests who will give full-time service to the work of the Curia of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has been constituted by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, it was announced yesterday at the Chancery Office, 477 Madison Avenue.

Next Tuesday is the deadline for written notice of entry by contestants wishing to qualify in the contest conducted by the American Newspaper Publishers Association, which is offering a cash prize of $500 for a medal design symbolizing "the advancement of the daily newspaper in public service."
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, speaking as national campaign chairman of the USO, warned yesterday against regimenting the service man's off-hour recreation.

Trade Here Up 8-9 Per Cent Retail trade here continued active this week, with increases over a year ago being maintained at about the pace of the preceding week. Department store sales up to yesterday were estimated as showing a gain of about 8 to 9 per cent. Cooler weather aided the apparel departments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Wholesale prices of eggs moved sharply higher today, the finer grades advancing as much as a full cent a dozen. To the consumer who is paying 45 to 50 cents or more a dozen for eggs at retail, this might be a warning that sharply higher prices are just ahead.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Japanese military announced today that their troops had entered the outskirts of Changsha, bitterly defended capital of Hunan Province, and that hand-to-hand fighting was raging.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The Fourth Armored Division at Pine Camp received the advance guard of the Ninety-first Observation Squadron, ending a transcontinental flight from Gray Air Field, Fort Lewis, Wash.

Under a continuous flow of Southern selling, prices of all active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange declined yesterday below the 17-cent level. After a brief rally around noon when quotations showed gains of as much as 6 points above Thursday's close, prices receded steadily to close with net losses of 16 to 19 points.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Lieut. Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, general officer commanding the Canadian Corps in Britain, told a group of visiting Canadian editors tonight that "there will have to be an invasion of the Continent."

VICHY, France, Sept. 26 (AP) -- French Indo-China authorities have protested vigorously to Japan, charging violation of French sovereignty as a result of sudden, widespread arrests of Chinese and Annamites by Japanese troops in the French colony, It was announced officially today.

Negotiations aimed at liberating $15,000,000 to $25,000,000 worth of general merchandise tied up in Japanese ports since the break in commercial relations betweeen this country and Japan are now under way between officials of the two governments, according to reports reaching foreign traders here from Washington yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Action of atomic bullets, catapulted from the 225-ton atom-smashing machine at the University of California with an energy of 96,000,000 volts, four times more powerful than the highest energies obtained before, was described today at a symposium of the fiftieth anniversary celebration of the University of Chicago, held jointly with the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: A clear-cut demonstration that the mutuel machines take more money from the players than the bookmakers ever thought of taking was seen last Tuesday at Belmont Park when Alsab, the 17-20 outsider, defeated a 7-10 shot.

Every citizen, including every member of a labor union, has a direct personal interest in the subject discussed by delegates to the convention of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America held this week at Lansing, Mich. The constitution of this organization of civil service employes now states that it shall not be its policy "to engage in strikes as a means of achieving its objectives."
The September list of 100 books recommended by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee for reading by members of the Roman Catholic Church was issued yesterday.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield captured the New Jersey State golf championship for the second year in succession when she defeated Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, 9 and 8, in the thirty-six-hole final on the Echo Lake course today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Captain Andy Tomasic supplied the spark that carried Temple to a 31-9 victory over the University of Kansas in the opening football game at the Owls' stadium tonight before 23,000 spectators.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 26 (U.P.) - The $55,000,000 bankruptcy case of William Fox, former motion-picture official, in litigation for the last five years, was virtually settled today.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer chalked up seven strikeouts today to push his seasons' total to 202 as Cincinnati downed Pittsburgh, 4 to 3.

The survey of gasoline and fuel oil conditions in this area which has just been completed by Grover A. Whalen confirms the fact that a shortage of transportation facilities owing to the transfer of eighty tankers from domestic use to Atlantic lease-lend service has made necessary a curtailment of domestic gasoline and oil consumption.

With the use of oil burners banned in the East for the 200,000 privately financed defense housing units which will get priority assistance, the burner industry is now looking to Midwestern markets to replace sales being lost along the Eastern seaboard, manufacturers reported yesterday.

IT was learned yesterday that Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants would not march in the victory parade through Brooklyn Monday. He said so himself, with gestures. He was wearing a gray suit, dark glasses and a very mournful countenance when he was interviewed.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- George Arliss, stage and screen star, was fined u4,500 today on a charge of failing to register with the Bank of England his United States and Canadian securities as required under the finance provisions of the defense regulations.

Resolutions setting forth the triple objectives of the toy industry in relation to the defense program were adopted yesterday at the conclusion of the twenty-fifth annual convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept 26 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Magyar Menzet reported today that ten alleged Communists were hanged Sept. 16 in the Serbian villages of Melence and Mokrin on charges of "pillaging and sabotage" and their bodies left suspended in the main squares of the villages for twenty-four hours.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- War Department contracts today totaled $7,108,297. Concerns in New York State receiving awards were as follows:

Hollywood and the country fair were intermingled in the Broadway area last night when more than 10,000 New Yorkers turned out for a combination carnival, movie premiere and military ball at the Roxy Theatre, Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Local gasoline distributors and dealers generally hailed yesterday as "a constructive step" the report of Grover A. Whalen to Mayor La Guardia in which he asserted that the Eastern seaboard was threatened with "a real and serious" shortage of gasoline and fuel oil and advanced a ten-point conservation program to remedy the situation.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept 26 -- Franz vqn Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey, will arrive in Ankara on Monday morning, it was disclosed tonight by foreign diplomatic circles in the Turkish capital.

VICHY, France, Sept. 26 -- Developments In Franco-German relations may be expected in the near future, it is stated. Negotiations have been quiescent virtually since the opening of hostilities against Russia, but now, according to an authorized source here, "the German Government is sufficiently relieved of preoccupations regarding the Eastern Front to be able to devote its attention again to relations with France."

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Sept. 27 -- Failing to force a passage through the Russian defenses on the Perekop isthmus, German forces in the third day of their battle for Crimea attempted large-scale parachutist operations against the Crimean peninsula yesterday in as widely separated points as Eupatoria, on the western shore, and Theodosia, on the eastern shore, near the narrow cape that forms the southwestern arm enclosing the Sea of Azov.

MONTREAL, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals, pounding three Columbus pitchers for fourteen hits, including three home runs, took the first game of the little world series tonight, 12 to 6, before 10,000 fans.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Joe Louis had one furious outburst when he resumed training today. George Fitch, his New Haven sparring partner, was unlucky enough to be in the ring with him at the time and had to be carried out.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Three men are missing from a Navy patrol bomber which, was forced down in the Caribbean Sea near St. Eustatius Island yesterday. Eleven others were reported 'safe.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Jan Valtin, author of "Out of the Night," and three book critics provided a climax for the New York Library Association's conference this evening in a half-hour broadcast discussion of his book. Those participating besides Mr. Valtin were Lewis Gannett and Irita Van Doren of The Herald Tribune and Rex Stout, author.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 26 -- The State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C.I.O. union of civil service employes, revised its constitution today to establish machinery for strikes in government departments and public and private hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Georgetown's Hoyas rolled over the Mississippi Rebels, 16 to 6, tonight in a football game highlighted by a pair of third-period Georgetown touchdowns resulting from intercepted passes. An estimated 25,000 spectators saw the opener for both schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Floyd Odium, Director of the OPM Contract Distribution Division, declared today he was enlisting "some of the best trains in the country" to overcome a delay of six to twelve months in establishing an adequate subcontracting program to spread the defense program into more factories and speed up the output of arms.

A German-appointed representative, in occupied territory, of a Netherlands corporation which has transferred its seat to one of the Dutch colonies cannot lay claim to deposits of the corporation here, Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter ruled yesterday.

In answer to the argument that steam plants can be built at strategic points, and this much more rapidly than the St. Lawrence project can be developed, the Administration argues that the manufacturers of steam turbines are flooded with orders, whereas the makers of waterwheels are not worked to capacity.

Negotiating committees of the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association, representing deep-sea operators, have reached an agreement for a new wage and working contract covering 50,000 dock men along the Atlantic coast, it was announced yesterday.

Over on Manhattan's West Side, Prince, a 3-year-old German shepherd dog, has become so fond of Skippy, an alley cat born eight weeks ago in Liverpool, England, that he carries Skippy with him wherever he goes.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Friendships launched during their service at Fort Monmouth will be continued by selectees drawn from, the movie industry when they return to their careers in Hollywood and New York, through formation of the Twentieth Signal Club.

Appeals of "a special wartime character" and the programs of social welfare organizations in Great Britain have received the support of The Pilgrim Trust during the past year, according to the tenth annual report of that organization, issued from its new headquarters in Harlech, North Wales.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- This is going to be a cold Winter, Italians learned today when the newspapers published a forecast of the restrictions of coal supplies and heating. This year heating in houses cannot begin before Dec. 1 in Northern Italy, Dec. 10 hi the center and Dec. 20 in the south, whereas last year it began everywhere on Nov. 15.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The contents of twelve mail bags, said to contain unaddressed envelopes bearing Congressional franks, which were subpoenaed from the offices of the America First Committee, were under examination today by government agents as a phase of the local Federal grand jury Investigation into alleged Nazi activities in the United States.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 26 -- One of the most-prized trophies of the North Shore horse show, the Frank Melville Jr. Memorial Challenge Trophy, today was captured by the Bryn Du Farm's chestnut gelding, Muffin Man. The victor was piloted over the outside course by Miss Eleanor Leh.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 26 -- Reports received in foreign diplomatic and military circles here and in Istanbul indicate there has been a new outbreak of demonstrations and a sharp decline in morale in Italy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Gifts of $9,200,000 to the University of Chicago fiftieth anniversary fund, out of a final goal of $12,000,000 to be raised within the next ten years, were reported tonight at a citizens' dinner at which 800 of Chicago's prominent citizens, alumni, educators, and leaders in other walks of life, joined in celebrating' the fiftieth anniversary of the university.

In a reply to the radio acceptance speech of former Justice Lloyd Church, Democratic nominee for Controller, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the principal issue of the campaign was whether the voters of New York City wanted an orderly handling of city finances or a return to the confusion and ineptitude of former Tammany administrations.

An inquiry board of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation began taking testimony yesterday on the crash of the tanker Robert E.Hopkins and the collier Jason in Ambrose Channel late Wednesday night.
TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- Tempers flared again today in the hearing into the land acquisition transactions of the State Highway Department, with a threat of fisticuffs punctuating the early proceedings.

Locally dressed meats showed little strength yesterday. Supplies appeared ample with the exception of veal, which was scarce. Steer hinds and ribs were weak to 50 cents lower, or about in line with last week's closing market. Pork cuts sold unevenly. Calf and lamb were steady to weak. Kosher beef market opened stronger.

LONDON. Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Former Mayor Paul Hartmann of Oslo, in German-occupied Norway, who reached England last week, said today that Norwegian factories were busy turning out skis for the German forces in Russia.

CAMP DAVIS, N.C., Sept. 28 -- While the nation's shipyards concern themselves with the job of building a "bridge of ships," the Camp Davis barrage balloon training center is going about the task of throwing up a wall of silken balloons and steel cables.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America (CIO), which claims 100,000 members, ended its annual convention today with a resolve to organize the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Fore River Shipyard at Quincy, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor ended a 30-hour visit to the capital early this afternoon, after the Duke, acting in his official capacity as Governor of the Bahamas, had conferred with highranking Army and Navy officials, including Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Full-scale American aid to Russia is being delayed by the difficulty of obtaining from the Moscow government "full knowledge" of the Russian position, which President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill insisted in their joint message to Premier Joseph Stalin was the prerequisite to the proper supplying of needs, several informed officials said today.
Sermons will be preached tomorrow in the churches of the New York area in celebration of annual Religious Education Week, a national observance, that will begin tomorrow.

Other Poe Stories No doubt Edgar Allan Poe is the father of the detective story and M. Dupin of "The Murders in the Rue Morgue" is the ancestor of Sherlock Holmes. But younger readers are in danger of being misled into thinking that the Rue Morgue story is the only one of the kind that Poe wrote.

LONDON, Sept 26 -- All-out aid of scientists to the Allied armed forces against the Nazis was advocated here today by United States Ambassador John G. Winant so that in the world to follow there would be greater scope for science in "the service of constructive civilization."

WASHINGTON, Sept 26 -- A projected major revision of the priorities system, under which defense industries will get specific allocations of raw materials instead of preference ratings, was outlined to the House Banking Committee today by Donald M. Nelson.

After more than a decade of staid attention to studies a spirit of "rah-rah" has returned to Columbia College. The renaissance of freshman hazing has taken place on the Morningside Heights campus, and beware the member of the class of 45 who does not wear his freshman cap and bow down to the sophomore baiter.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26 -- As the defense program gathers speed in United States cities and towns, Washington officials have come out almost daily to warn of a multitude of adjustments and sacrifices which may be necessary in the life of the average American citizen.

Knee deep in congratulatory telegrams and wearing the sort of smile that won't come off, Lippy Leo Durocher held court for local and visiting baseball writers in his suite at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday, but would not permit a photographer to get into the place.

Urging complete unity of purpose and full preparedness in defense of democracy, Governor Lehman declared yesterday that the American people might have to make "sacrifices of time and effort and money, and possibly lives," to preserve their freedom.

MONTGOMERY, Sept. 26 -- The Air Corps Reserve received 355 new commissioned officers today with, the graduation of the Southeast Air Corps Training Center's seventh class of aviation cadets. The cadets, who have completed a thirty-week training course, automatically were added to the Air Corps commissioned forces and were welcomed as second lieutenants in the reserve.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- Drastic measures intended to check the upward trend of stock prices were announced today in Berlin, causing the heaviest slump on the Berlin Boerse since the beginning of the war. Although this step had been expected for some time and did not take the market by surprise, its announcement resulted in an almost complete abstention of buying.

Brooklyn's biggest parade since the Fourteenth Zouaves and the Twenty-third Infantry came home from the wars in 1865 will be staged in the borough Monday afternoon in behalf of Brooklyn's Beloved Bums.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Howard O. Hunter, Works Projects Administrator, reported today that WPA employment dropped last week to the all-time low total of 1,034,629. He said it would go down still further during the month, but would rise again, and sharply, during the Winter due to the expected increase in non-defense unemployment occasioned by the shutting down or part-time operation of industries unable to get priority ratings.

Movement of freight appears to be slackening on several important railroads, according to members of the Association of American Railroads, who met yesterday in Washington. While freight is expected to increase in the next two or three weeks, the maximum volume is expected to be below previous expectations, with no likelihood of a shortage of cars.

Two rare Romanesque capitals from the collection of the late George Grey Barnard have been purchased by the Worcester, Mass., Art Museum through the Robinson Galleries, Inc., of this city, it was learned yesterday. This is the first major sale from the collection disclosed since announcement was made that the collection would be sold by individual pieces to museums and collectors.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 26 -- Departure of 42,000 troops for manoeuvres has left this post almost deserted. The week-end will see the post's population further depleted by the departure of 754 selective service men in process of being discharged from the Field Artillery Replacement Center.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Five New Yorkers and a Philadelphian were among thirteen men, promoters and salesmen in a fraudulent scheme to sell cemetery lots, who were sentenced to prison terms today by Federal Judge William H. Holly in Federal District Court.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 26 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 25:

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Big Al Benton, who usually comes to the rescue of his mates, got some assistance himself today as he pitched the Tigers into a tie for the American League's third place by defeating the White Sox, 4 to 3.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 26 -- Troops of the 186th and 187th Regiments of the Seventy-first Field Artillery Brigade, made up largely of National Guardsmen from Brooklyn, will leave Fort Ethan Alien early tomorrow morning en route to the Carolinas to take part in manoeuvres during the next two months.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dunkers of Washington Irving's day would, I think, have used a spoon to dunk the doughnut of that period. The delectable balls were small, probably not larger than a golf ball; otherwise, they would have been called "dumplings," not "nuts."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 13 was 3,664,950 shares, compared with 2,504,760 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Crown Princess Martha of Norway greeted ten Royal Norwegian Air Force fliers who arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday morning in five Douglas attack bombers from Washington on a two-day good-will flight from their training base at Little Norway, near Toronto, Canada.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 26 -- The National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, meeting here in its fortieth annual convention, today heard William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks, describe Federal regulation of consumer credit as preliminary to adoption of a "compulsory savings plan."

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Coast Guards took the forty-one-man crew off the 3,000-ton freighter Essex today, a few hours after she was beached on Southeast Light Shoals when battering seas threatened to sink her. The skipper is Captain Harold Andersen of Floral Park, L.I.
WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Central Front, Sept. 23 (Delayed) -- The Russian front looks like this. These are leaves from a notebook:

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- In a special communique from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters, the German High Command reported tonight that 574,000 Russians and "inestimable" quantities of materiel had been captured in the destruction of the four Soviet armies claimed to have been trapped east of Kiev since Sept. 13.

Newspapers in the United States are making many noteworthy contributions to the preservation and extension of freedom and democracy in America, according to articles by noted Americans appearing in a special supplement to Editor and Publisher, trade magazine, issued today.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 26 -- With the danger of Hitlerism confronting them, the people of the United States must unite in a total effort to preserve the security of this nation in a perilous hour, William O. Douglas, associate justice of the Supreme Court, warned the Clvitan Club of Atlanta today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- More than 600 members of the Seventh Infantry, State Guard, made up largely of veterans of the old Seventh Regiment of Manhattan, entered today the active training phase of a four-day tour of field duty here under command of Colonel Milton S. Bowman.

A strong combination of soma of the nation's leading insurance companies will enter on Monday bid at a sale of $90,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent debentures of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, it was learned in insurance circles yesterday.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- As was generally anticipated, Miss Kathryn Byrne of the Rye Country Club today won the second annual tri-county golf championship at the Century Club, but her victory was not as easily obtained as many thought it would be.
NEW YORK Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, is expected to come to the Savoy-Plaza today from Newport.

Abe Bebchick, Brooklyn "policy king," mysteriously slain Wednesday while being sought as the alleged payer of $3,000 a week to police for gambling protection, was met beside his parked car by two well-dressed men and drove away with them less than four hours before his body was found, according to a story related yesterday to police by Bebchick's part-time chauffeur, described only as "Zoo."
VICHY, France, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- In a land of plenty, which is harvesting a better than average crop, 40,000,000 Frenchmen are hungry today.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 26 -- After serving for fifteen years at Brown, one of the longest tenures enjoyed by an Eastern college football coach during the past generation, De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry has moved his lares and penates to Dartmouth as successor to Earl (Red) Blaik.

For the fourth consecutive week new bond financing in this market has been restricted to the railroad and tax-exempt fields. This week the combined offerings of those groups amounted to $23,811,000, compared with $21,611,000 last week and with $53,146,000 in this week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Office of Production Management enlisted the aid today of about 500 government employes, including representatives of four other departments and agencies, for the first nation-wide check of priorities violations.

NEAR ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Sept. 26 -- A base camp for use by the 244th Coast Artillery while engaged In First Army manoeuvres is expected to be completed this week-end by an advance detachment of 134 officers and men who came here Sept. 16.

An attempt to clear Actors Equity Association of Congressional charges that it was dominated by Communists, a problem that has agitated the membership for some time, came to the fore again yesterday afternoon at the first quarterly meeting of the season in the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A "factual survey" has shown only 5,192 tank cars available to haul oil to the East Coast, Secretary Ickes, oil coordinator, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the Army, Navy and the Maritime Commission, in radio speeches tonight, hailed this country's progress in providing merchant ships for the struggle against the Axis.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Increasing evidence is reaching Great Britain tending to show that the Germans are laying plans to continue their campaign against Russia into the Winter.

Arguing against wage control at the present time, Secretary Morgenthau declares that if we can "keep the cost of living from rising" and "impose adequate taxes on excessive profits, then we will have removed the major causes for demands for general wage increases."

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- A mixed squadron of the Fighter Command's new Hurricanes-12-gun, 4-cannon model-went into action today against four Nazi minesweepers protected by two "flak" ships. Two of the minesweepers were probably destroyed and one of the flak ships damaged, a communique reported.
Emerging diffidently amid the blare that accompanied the worldshaking feat of the Dodgers, a new football season starts on the trail down Autumn to Winter this weekend.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Secretary Morgenthau's proposal for 100 per cent taxation of all corporation profits above 6 per cent was described today by an influential member of the House Ways and Means Committee as "too preposterous for Congress to swallow."

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook dismissed yesterday as against the Chase National Bank an accounting suit charging waste or misappropriation of more than $50,000,000 assets, which was instituted against the bank and other defendants by the General Investment Corporation and some of its stockholders.

KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Two more warships for the United States Navy, the destroyers Hambleton and Rodman, slid down the ways at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here within ten minutes of each other this afternoon.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 26 -- Minister of War Juan N. Tonazzi announced today that Lieut. Col. Aristobulo Reyes, Chief of Staff of Aviation, had been placed temporarily in charge of the military, air arm. General Angel Maria Zuloaga was removed from that post yesterday as a consequence of the discovery Tuesday of a military plot.

That you can make your oldest dress devastating by wearing the right accessories Is an admonition often found in fashion columns. Whether a new scarlet pocketbook can achieve startling effects with an old black suit probably is matter for experiment, but ringing changes on the ancient and familiar is a good principle, which applies in the matter of meals.

For the first time in its history the Board of Education's retirement system has refused to permit a New York City school administrator, who was dismissed on charges of unbecoming conduct, to retire on a yearly pension. A precedent has been set which is now going to be decided in the civil courts.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- As the Rus- sian war progresses and the Germans penetrate deeper and deeper into Russia a whole new series of problems arises for the British to face.

RUTLAND, Vt. -- Here in the valley of Otter Creek, with the Green Mountains to the east and the Taconic Range and the Adirondacks rising to the south and west, lies this busy trading and manufacturing center of 18,000 people -- Vermont's second largest city and headquarters of the Rutland Railroad.

WHEN typhoid fever developed among more than 90 per cent of our volunteer regiments encamped for the Spanish-American War the proportion was considered excessive. But when disease in the Boer War killed nearly twice as many British soldiers as did the enemy's bullets, that was not really out of the way.

TRADE should be by definition a two-way affair. Still, on dealing with this matter, most people, including many business men, are wont to think only of more opportunities for the exportation of their products.

Our champion Dodgers were beaten at Ebbets Field yesterday by the dungeon dwellers of the National League, the Phillies, but all would have been sweetness and light, with nobody caring a whoop about the result, had it not been for an injury to Pete Reiser, the outstanding rookie of the circuit.

VEGETABLES are the problem children of American cooking. We have a great abundance of them, and we are a vegetable-minded folk who rarely give a grocery order without including a green or two on the list. But by the time they reach many of our tables most of the food value for which we paid has gone with the wind and their appeal to the appetite is definitely a thing of the past.

The Federal Works Agency, states John M. Carmody, administrator, is planning to erect 10,000 prefabricated demountable dwelling units out of a total of approximately 92,000 houses. All are being built for families of enlisted and civilian personnel in the Army and Navy and workers in defense industries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The National Defense Mediation Board today ruled against the demand of New York City's Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers for jurisdiction over electrical work on two new generating stations now in process of construction by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- It's going to take the last day of the season, tomorrow, to decide who is going to finish third, fourth, fifth, sixth and seventh in the American League.

Activity was spotty in the wholesale market last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. While business fell off in some lines, volume continued heavy in others.

The Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University will begin its twenty-ninth season on Wednesday, Oct. 15, with a reorganized program keyed to "the public's quickened interest in world affairs," it was announced yesterday by Dr. Russell Potter, director.

Realty Associates, Inc., will celebrate its fortieth anniversary Oct. 11 with an outing at the Cold Spring Golf Club, Huntington, on the site of the former Otto H. Kahn estate now being developed by the firm as a residential community.

THIS novel about a strikingly original psychological problem is so carefully and skillfully worked out that it makes as absorbing reading as a crack detective story. Its whole theme is the analysis of an arrestingly odd character, a pleasant personality with a sinister background; and the job is done with delicacy and distinction.
ROCHESTER. OVER sixteen years ago the Eastman School of Music inaugurated its American Composers' Concerts. During these years we have performed over 600 orchestral works by American composers.

Two hundred courses, covering fifteen fields of study dealing with national defense, war and peace aims, American institutions, international relations and a dozen issues growing out of the present world crisis, are being offered at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, whose twenty-third year begins tomorrow.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 27 -- Use of the camera to record art and music treasures of Mexico, broadcasting of radio programs to Mexico, holding a field school on the Texas-Mexico border in education of Spanish-speaking pupils -- these are a few of the "extra-curricular" activities of the University of Texas Institute of Latin-American Studies during its first year of operation.

IN soothing contrast to the drum-beating which for weeks usually precedes the return to the air of a harlequin or medicine man comes the unpretentious announcement stating simply that WABC's "Sunday Evening Hour" will open its eighth consecutive season tonight at 9.

THE Revival Series, as an idea and an ideal, is not new to The Theatre Guild. We have been thinking about it for quite some time, discussing the pros and cons, weighing the chances for its success. But recently I have had an increasingly strong conviction that the time was ripe now for the Guild once more to take the course of action it followed when it was first organized, and for the same reasons.
