It is now established that a girl can find very attractive ornaments for her clothes without spending exorbitant sums and also without compromising with a natural distaste for out-and-out fake and imitation. In some unlikely places you will find ornaments that are designed with a good deal of style and imagination.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Carnegie Tech, football champion of the East four seasons ago, was beaten by 19 to 13 today by little Westminster College.

CHILDREN, as subject, are to the fore just now. Knoedler's displays engravings, many of them particularly fine, after eight- eenth and nineteenth century British masters, as well as canvases, hung in an adjoining room, that range from polished storytellers, through Greuze and Renoir and Degas, to Derain.

Civilian home building and the preservation of small business interests will be among the important topics selected for discussion during the sessions of the forthing convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Detroit opening Nov. 4 and continuing through Nov. 7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Prices are going up. Housewives are complaining bitterly at what they have to pay for eggs and pork chops. They suspect volubly that some of the clothing they still buy at the pre-war prices is not of the same quality it used to be.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Members of society who follow the horses had the busiest program of the Fall calendar today, but with the aid of the automobile many of them were able to keep the engagements scheduled for the last Saturday in September.

LONDON. DURING past weeks my chronicles of the London theatre have made a monotonous success story. The audiences have been eager but the managers remained cautious. In such circumstances there was no likelihood of experiment and little risk of failure.

Another age-old boating tradition falls before the rushing program of national defense. Like the Detroit Gold Cup regatta and the Washington President's Cup regatta, which had to be abandoned last Summer until a more propitious time, the National Motor Boat Show will be omitted.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 27 -- The New Jersey College of Agriculture at Rutgers University will offer twelve-week courses in dairy farming, fruit growing, vegetable gardening, nursery practice and poultry husbandry commencing Monday, Oct. 27, Professor Frank G. Helyar, director of resident instruction at the college, announced here today.

Dr. John T. Madden, dean of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University, yesterday named ten leaders in industry and labor as participatnts in a new course on collective bargaining, described as the first of its kind in an American university.

The debated insurance formula, or index, which the Maritime Commission has been devising for its projected industry-wide settlement of the war bonus demands of seamen, is completed and probably will be offered for discussion tomorrow when the National Defense Mediation Board opens its conferences with ship owners and striking seamen in an attempt to mediate the strike that ended last Wednesday.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The heaviest offensive operations of the week were carried out today by the Royal Air Force. During the hours of darkness before dawn formations of British bombers attacked targets in Western Germany, including Cologne, and also Calais and Dunkerque, in the course of which one plane was lost, the Air Ministry reported.

PROPORTIONAL representation has always had a special charm for those modern crusaders who have set out to redress the wrongs of minorities and rectify electoral systems. "One can hardly help having a feeling of romance about it," Walter Bagehot wrote many years ago.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- Sliding down greased ways, two cargo vessels splashed into harbor waters today as Southern California joined the nation in the celebration of "Liberty Fleet Day."

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Kurdish sharpshooters hidden above mountain trails in the mutinous province of Kurdistan repulsed small Iranian Army patrols today, according to advices from the vest-pocket war front.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Luck and two substitute backfield players gave the University of Southern California victory over the Oregon State Beavers today -- a triumph registered in the final seventeen seconds of a bitterly contested Pacific Coast Conference game.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON. OUT of the confusion of agencies and personalities brought to the front by the nation's unlimited emergency the spotlight now falls on one month-old agency and one commanding personality. The agency is SPAB, more fully known as the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board.

Three members of the original freshman class of Queens College that graduated in June have returned to the Flushing campus as members of the faculty, President Paul Klapper disclosed yesterday with the announcement that nineteen new staff members were added this semester.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Fellow-hay fever sufferers who read Laszlo Rozsa's plaint in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES can imagine with the vividness of too-frequent experience that he wrote from the depths of despair after a restless night during which he gasped for breath propped high on pillows.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Believing that Congress is certain to be in session during a large part of the first semester, Colgate University has revised its Washington Study Program to enable the ten honor juniors in the group to work simultaneously on public administration and political control with special emphasis on activities related to national defense.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 27 -- A series of battles with Serbian guerrillas in which German dive bombers wiped out the Yugoslav town of Uzice was reported tonight in press dispatches to Budapest. Press reports of armed clashes or resistance, centering in the Serbian area, when 2,000 German troops were sent to aid pro-Nazi authorities, told of violence in which at least 360 deaths were recorded.

The City College Remedial Reading Clinic, created last year for the purpose of aiding elementary school children to overcome various reading defects, will again be in operation during the current semester, it was announced this week by Dr. Daniel J. Harris, supervisor.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Hard running by Fullback Johnny Grigas sparked Holy Cross to a 19-13 victory over Louisiana State University tonight before 25,000 spectators in a game featured by a multitude of passes and by a bit of fisticuffs just before the final whistle.

By dipping down into their bank reserves and concentrating on making profits from their own business enterprises, the Junior Leagues of the country have expended in the last fiscal year nearly half a million dollars in community service.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 27 -- The Naval Academy football team opened its campaign today with a 34 to 0 triumph over William and Mary before a capacity throng of 20,000 spectators.
ROME, Sept. 27 -- The first anniversary of the signing of the Three-Power Pact was celebrated today with manifestations designed to stress "the unshakable solidarity" of Rome, Berlin and Tokyo.

SOMERS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York dedicated and blessed this afternoon a $130,000 group of three new dormitory cottages on the 800-acre campus of Lincoln Hall, a Catholic protectory for boys at Lincolndale near here.

At the end of a bitterly run two miles, the inches that span the breadth of man's hand formed the margin of victory for Market Wise over Whirlaway at Belmont Park yesterday as 32,809 persons watched American racing history being made.

THIS novel has Steve and Irene Blyth as its central figures and the Cinderella blooming of marriage with its final pain and disillusion as the theme. They are young, singularly attractive -- and very happy -- at first.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 27 -- Minister of War General Juan N. Tonazzi gave clear proof of his determination to stamp out the last traces of disaffection in the army flying service when today he ordered Major Martin Cairo, described as the leader of the dissatisfied group of officers in the Military Aviation School at Cordoba, to report immediately and in person at the Ministry of War.

Kenneth McKellar, Tennessee's veteran Senator, was among the legislators on Capitol Hill who voted for the Neutrality Act of 1935. He voted also for the various amendments to it in 1936, 1937 and 1939. Last Thursday Mr. McKellar rose on the floor of the upper chamber.

KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Speaking at the launching of the steamship Louise Lykes this afternoon, Governor Edison, former Secretary of the Navy, declared that the American people were determined "to fight for freedom." He said that the American Navy intended to protect the safety of this and other American cargo ships carrying "bombers and other munitions to blast the home ports of Hitler's warcraft."

TAKING a leaf out of the defense program book, Hollywood has ordered a new burst of speed in the production of motion pictures. What effect this order will have remains to be seen; for the disheartening truth remains: Hollywood must make haste slowly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Fifteen committees, representing as many different "use" groups in the folding paper box industry, are at work at present, whittling down sizes, changing designs, testing smaller caliper board, and in other ways seeking to economize on the use of materials in response to the recent OPM request for a 25 per cent consumption cut, it was learned here today.

LITTLE, BROWN CO. report that three of their books. "Escape." "The Mortal Storm" and "Rogue Male," have been mentioned frequently in the current Senate subcommittee investigation. To prevent any misunderstanding. Little, Brown Co. wish to go on record as follows:

A sober survey yesterday of New York's better-known hotels, restaurants and bars failed to uncover a conclusive answer to the question whether the increased Federal taxes on spirituous liquors that go into effect Wednesday will mean an increase in the price of a drink over the bar.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- The Chicago Cardinals and the Detroit Lions, both seeking their initial National Football League victory of the season, fought to a 14-14 deadlock tonight before 17,458 spectators at Comiskey Park.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Watering, quite as important at this time as it is in the Summer season, is continued during the dry spell, now assuming a serious aspect in many sections. Watering of any newly planted trees or shrubs is particularly necessary... Roses should still be good for several weeks of bloom, so dusting and spraying is continued, but high nitrogen fertilizers, stimulating late soft growth, are avoided.

The Transport Workers Union of America, C.I.O. affiliate, voted yesterday to extend its jurisdiction, subject to the approval of the C.I.O. itself, to include employes of utility companies other than those operating rapid transit, street car and bus lines.

WRITERS for the Broadway theatre seem to be turning their attention to the world of the sym- phony and opera. Jerome Kern has taken his "Show Boat" music and turned it into a symphonic work. Now Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart have agreed to do an opera for Lily Pons.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- After winning the medal in the annual Meadow Brook Club's four-ball invitation golf tournament with a 67 yesterday, Howell Van Gerbig of the home club and P. Hal Sims of North Hills failed to survive the first round today, losing to Teddy Bassett and Bill Gurney of the Winged Foot Club 2 and 1.

WE are getting some good anthologies these days. Last week there was occasion to speak of Bernard Smith's "The Democratic Spirit"; today Mr. Rodman's stimulating collection called "The Poetry of Flight" is reviewed on the front page.

Members of the New York City League for a Declared War held their first meeting last week at the Hotel Commodore and unanimously adopted a resolution demanding an immediate declaration against Germany.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 27 -- Lehigh showed plenty of potential strength in its first football game of the season in Taylor Stadium today, holding a scrappy Hartwick College eleven, to a 13-13 stalemate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A plan designed to assign to every Republican worker a specific role in the 1942 Congressional campaigns was adopted today by party leaders from a dozen States. The new party organization move, which will be submitted to the Republican National Committee for approval, calls for a special organization set-up in every county in the United States and unifies the functions of the national, State and county committees.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- The extreme Right Wing newspaper Tevere demands the abolition of all Jewish associations in Italy which, it says, are merely hotbeds of anti-fascism, and defeatism. Many editorials in the past few days have charged that Jews as well as Free Masons, professing to be Fascists, were attempting to undermine Italian morale.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- New reports of political crimes in Germany and occupied countries tell of a raid by an armed French band on a German powder magazine, the exploding of a German Army railway train and a string of death sentences -- including the exceptional penalty of death for one German -- for listening to foreign radio broadcasts.

Two women's organizations have chosen new headquarters in the city in which their activities will be centered this season. The Women's City Club, now in its twenty-fifth year, has taken a floor at 55 West Forty-fourth Street, and plans are being made for an opening reception on the evening of Oct. 7.

Three additional provisions are asssential to complete the effectiveness of the Price Control Bill now before Congress, according to Dr. Julius Hirsch, head of Germany's Price Control Board during the latter part of the first World War and now in this country as a lecturer on business economics.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- Phonographic recordings of speeches made in Germany by leaders of the Weimar Republic and of the incipient Nazi movement during the period from 1928 until 1933 will be used at the University of Pennsylvania this year in a new departure in the teaching of modern European history.

CHUNGKING. THROUGHOUT the spiral development of China's awakening -- its advances, recessions and new forward movements on a higher level -- the position of writers, playwrights and publicists has been a reliable indication of the political weather in the country.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 27 -- Disorders have broken out at Tabriz, in Russian-occupied Northwestern Iran, and dissident Kurdish tribesmen and Armenian, irredentists are waging guerrilla warfare against Iranian authorities remaining in the Russian-occupied zone, it was reported here today by travelers from Iran.

IN the past year William McConnell and his staff have painted well over 500,000 square feet of art. It isn't in Michelangelo's class, but it has more utilitarian value than the works of all the old masters put together.

A series of weekly luncheons and fashion shows is now being arranged for the Autumn and Winter seasons in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The first of these fetes will take place on Oct. 9 and will be a benefit for the Opportunity Shop, of which Miss Ruth Vanderbilt Twombly heads the executive committee.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 27 -- Held to six points in the first half by a big, bruising Norwich team that was bursting with scrap and confidence, Dartmouth knocked the stalwart Vermont cadets into a state of helplessness and erupted in a scoring jamboree for a 35-0 victory in Memorial Stadium today.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Jack Jenkins, a 200-pound back from Texarkana, Ark., booted a field goal from the 20-yard line to give Vanderbilt a 3-to-0 decision over Purdue's Boilermakers before 17,000 spectators in warm sunshine today.

Changsha, whose name means "a long strip of sand along the river," is the capital of the mountainous province of Hunan in Southeastern China. Tourists interested in objets d'art knov Changsha for its local industry of making outline embroidery in black and white on silk and satin and for its white brassware and pewter pots.

Strength in railway securities gave a better tone to yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange and both bonds and stocks made moderate gains. The latter had a turnover of but 194,420 shares, which compared with 251,430 on the previous Saturday, and was the smallest for any day since Aug. 23.

A BRITISH AIR BASE IN EGYPT, Sept. 24 (Delayed) -- With the danger of Axis domination of Iraq, Syria and Iran removed and with the situation in the Western Desert static, the war in the Middle East has become, for the time being, a battle of supplies a battle as important as a major land offensive.

The Influx of industrial workers to expanding defense plants in Buffalo, N.Y., has caused such a dearth of low-rent dwellings that the United States Housing Authority has begun the task of selecting sites for 3,100 additional defense homes there, despite the fact that funds for erection of these houses have not yet been made available.

The USO will shortly have another club building operating for service men in the New York area, and, at the same time, the Soldiers and Sailors Club at 283 Lexingion Avenue will have its much-hoped-for expanded quarters. Mrs. Francis Rogers, founder of the latter organization, detailed yesterday architectural plans for renovating the residence adjoining the club on the north, which has been purchased through an allocation of the USO.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt were in retirement at their home here today after a motor trip back from Tivoli, N.Y., where they participated in the burial service for G. Hall Roosevelt, brother of the First Lady.
WYANDOTTE, Ind. -- The recently discovered fairyland of helictites and other rare onyx formations in Wyandotte Cave has been opened to the public.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Visitors from many sections of New York State, as well as from Connecticut and Long Island, will throng Hi-Esmaro, the estate of Mrs. H. Edward Manville here, on Wednesday and Thursday for the unique war relief benefit flower show to be held under the auspices of the Ninth District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State.

Members of the Turf and Field Club and their guests from many parts of the East and South, the Long Island society colonies and New York yesterday taxed to capacity the historic clubhouse at Belmont Park and its auxiliary restaurant near the tracks with luncheon parties planned long in advance to precede the race program, which included the Belmont Futurity, the richest stake of the season for 2-year-olds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 26:

MEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 27 -- In an effort to maintain interest in poetry and to encourage creative work among its undergraduates, Tufts College has established a new "poetry laboratory" which will function as an auxiliary to the regular classroom lectures and writing courses, Dr. Harold H. Blanchard, head of the English Department, announced today.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 27 -- A basis for a settlement of the uprising of rank and file members of District 7 of the United Mine Workers of America against increased dues and assessments was reached tonight at a conference attended by representatives of the insurgents, of John L. Lewis and of a group of coal operators.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Alumni of the University of Chicago, assembled in Rockefeller Memorial Chapel today, presented to the university $506,809 in appreciation of its half-century of service to the community, the nation and the world.

NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 27 -- New to the campus scene of the American college and university was a colorful matriculation ceremony inspired by President Joseph A. Brandt and held this week at the University of Oklahoma to honor 2,000 freshmen, first-year law and medical students and transfer students from other colleges and universities.

CHEVROLET demonstrates wide change in body design as it presents three lines of 1942 models. The "Fleetline" series, introduced in mid-season as a sedan, adds a new six-passenger "Aerosedan" and takes its place with the "Master De Luxe" and "Special De Luxe" lines.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Champions of the 1941 Summer season on Long Island Sound were settled today in the twenty-second and last title regatta of the Yacht Racing Association held by the Echo Bay Yacht Club. Some had been foregone conclusions, they were so far out in front of their competitors in the percentage standings.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- The Supreme German Command, in a special communique from Reichsfuehrer Hitler's field headquarters, reported today the successful conclusion east of Kiev of "the greatest battle of annihilation of this war and all history."

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuter) -- It is known that for some time plans have been held in readiness for a concerted uprising in each of the ten European countries conquered by the Germans, with the exception of Denmark, which is not represented at the Inter-Allied Conference in London.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Mrs. James M. Austin's Pekingese Che Le of Matson's Catawba triumphed at the annual all-breed fixture of the Ox Ridge Kennel Club today, taking his seventeenth best-in-show award. Handled by Mrs. Ruth Burnett Sayres, the Peke increased his group victory record to ninety-one and his breed list to ninety-five.

JOE LOUIS sat on the edge of his rubbing table up at his training camp at Greenwood Lake. He had only a towel across his lap. He leaned forward, his big hands resting lightly on the edge of the table, his head bent forward so that he looked at the floor. There wasn't a muscle ripple in his whole powerful body.
THERE are plenty of things musical of an unexpected nature that one finds in Eastern Canada. The latter we rather erroneously liken to our own Atlantic seaboard.

IT'S always seemed to me that legends and yarns and folktales are as much a part of the real history of a country as proclamations and provisos and constitutional amendments. The legends and the yarns get down to the roots of the people -- they tell a good deal about what people admire and want, about what sort of people they are.

The response to our recent mention of sea coot or scoter shooting has been large, varied and interesting, some wanting to know where to go for this shooting, others wanting to know whether these birds are now legal game in New York, and still others wanting to know the reason for shooting a bird that you can't eat.

A Pennsylvania Military College team whose chief assets included two or three hard-running backs, some deception and a plethora of gameness, helped New York University raise the curtain on its 1941 gridiron campaign yesterday at Ohio Field.

WASHINGTON. NOW comes Congress again. Ending a period of comparative inaction during which it declined to adjourn formally for fear something might happen behind its back. Congress is beginning to bestir itself once more. Members who sneaked away for vacations, unnoticed in the long series of three-day recesses, are returning.

SINCE the radio's schedule is incessant, around the clock and through the year, the law of averages says that it must spend a good deal of its time being -- or trying to be-funny. Even in midsummer you could tune in at almost any hour of day or night and hear people making jokes; and if the jokes were not always exactly uproarious, at least the spirit was there.
LANSING, Mich., Sept. 27 -- The State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C.I.O., closed its convention today after rejecting a proposal to bar Communists, Nazis and Fascists from union office.

A world free of war and tyranny, with scientists taking a more active part in political economy to prevent wars and to enable the mass of people to satisfy their physical wants, was pictured yesterday by scientists and science editors who discussed the present and future over the radio from London and New York.

Better understanding of problems arising in the United States because of war and preparation for defense through study of world news will be emphasized in lecture courses and in eduactional and vocational classes opening tomorrow at the New York Y.W.C.A.
The most potent factor in the "good neighbor" policy of the United States is not diplomacy, quasi-official committees or goodwill missions, but the humble coffee bean.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Elmer Riddle snared his nineteenth victory of the season against four defeats today as the Cincinnati Reds out-walloped the Pittsburgh Pirates, 15 to 9 -- but the sensational rookie wasn't around when the game ended.

THOUGH it is actually a light novel -- and, on the whole, a pretty romantic one -- "The World and Richard" has a curious, an interesting, and a very poignant theme. In terms bordering the clinical, Miss Corley tells the story of a young woman who adopted a crippled child -- a child whose psychological handicaps were more serious, even, than his physical ones.

Chagrined by St. Bonaventure's opening-half scoring success, Manhattan College's football forces roared back with a vengeance and shackled the Bonnies to attain a 20-to-13 verdict in their opening game yesterday at Triborough Studium, Randalls Island.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The text of a Royal Air Force communique:

ANY idea that makes good records cheaper deserves endorsement. Lower prices mean wider distribution, and the larger the public for records of better music the greater will be the following for the art itself. The reductions that cut record prices virtually in half last year had a salubrious effect on the market and on the growth of the American audience.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 27 -- A new era in Notre Dame football opened to the impressive blast of six touchdowns today as Coach Frank Leahy's initial Irish eleven routed the University of Arizona, 38 to 7 before 35,000 spectators.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York has bought 1,000 color slides of contemporary American paintings from the American Library of Color Slides, 274 Madison Avenue, for presentation as gifts to twenty-five institutions throughout the United States.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 27 -- Haverford College is starting a policy of gradual growth as it opens its 108th year. One hundred and six freshmen, constituting the largest class in the history of the Quaker school, assembled on the campus this week, swelling the total enrollment to 351.

IN the midst of war, two British students of world conditions have set down some of the facts of peace problems in the newest and most graphic way. This is, in other words, a book whose brief, succinct text is completed by modern picture-writing, with symbols, percentage-blocks and maps.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- With speeches at campaign tempo, Westchester County approached this week its November election amid charges that the entrenched Republican organization is permitting a "milk racket" to exist, that abolition of the Board of Supervisors would sound the death knell of home rule and that continuance of the board would merely perpetuate a costly system of colonial government.

The Alcoa liner Acadia, one of the twenty-six ships affected by the strike that ended last week, sailed at 4:30 P.M. yesterday for Bermuda, carrying 308 passengers. She had been scheduled to depart from Pier 18, Hudson River, at 3 P.M., but was delayed by the tardy arrival of passengers.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 -- A Tulane football team that showed crushing offensive power, vicious defensive play and, to the amazement of all, even a vigorous passing attack, upset Boston College's Sugar Bowl champions, 21 to 7, before 45,000 spectators today.

HERE it is October -- well, almost October -- and the prospects for Broadway during that month are pretty good. The other day Tecumseh -- he of the exacting eye -- took a look at what are called Almost Certainties, and therefrom made the following report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Sept. 20 amounted to 246,500 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 336,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 323,000 and 13,000 in stocks of domestic and foreign crude respectively.

WHOEVER Mr. Shearing really is his devoted following will recognize the master's touch on the first page in the name of his heroine, who, they will know, must be at least half a fiend in spite of that gentle appellation, Angelica.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- General Sir Archibald Wavell, it was revealed by an authoritative British source today, will confer with Soviet representatives at Teheran on "joint defense of that part of the world."

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 -- Most experienced observers believe that last Tuesday's fatal clash between troops and munitions workers in front of the Presidential residence is unlikely to weaken the Avila Camacho regime, which is carrying out a sort of political, economic and defensive rapprochement with the United States.

Failing to capitalize on a scoring chance late in the fourth quarter after getting a first down two feet from its Brooklyn opponent's roal line, John Adams High was held to a scoreless tie by Adelphi Academy at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

THAT sinewy-minded back-country chronicler, Stewart H. Holbrook, has long been of opinion that the most interesting American crimes have not been native to the big bad city against which peacefully rustic parents are supposed to warn the too adventurous young folks.

With the season for benefit theatre parties now under way, there are in prospect two special performances of "Candle in the Wind," Maxwell Anderson's new prose play starring Helen Hayes, at the Shubert Theatre. The performance on Election Eve, Nov. 3, has been taken over as the annual theatre party for the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry-on-Hudson and a preview performance on Oct. 14 will aid Bundles for Britain.

One of the city's leading real estate organizations will celebrate an anniversary on Wednesday, when Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., rounds out thirty years in business. The occasion, incidentally, will close the firm's most active leasing season since its establishment on Oct. 1, 1911.

As the climax of a Defend Amer- ica Day on which thousands of New York painters gave approximately $50,000 to national defense by contributing their day's wages, 5,000 persons thronged Manhattan Center last night for a rally at which Mayor La Guardia, the principal speaker, was cheered wildly when he promised that President Roosevelt never will "sit down at a table with an international scab."

Rolling slowly eastward across the plains of European Russia, the Nazi tide has already engulfed White Russia and two-thirds of the Ukraine. By these advances, the Germans have seized industrial areas of considerable importance and have taken up positions which threaten other Russian manufacturing and agricultural areas of the first magnitude.

Roy E. Larsen, president of Time Inc., and publisher of Life Magazine, who was chairman of the 1940 committee, has been reappointed head of the sixty-third annual city-wide appeal of the United Hospital Fund of New York, 370 Lexington Avenue, and committees have been organized to direct the activities of the more than 5,000 voluntary workers, it was announced yesterday by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president.

THROUGH the aperture of his periscope the submarine commander sees the top of a freighter's masts and a thin wisp of smoke about nine miles away. It is a lucky sight, for although submarines theoretically can see an enemy at eleven miles, nine is pretty good through that prismed tube above the wallowing sub, a tiny dot on the ocean, loafing along.

ROME. SOME years ago, certain personalities of the literary world -- professors, writers, critics -- were pleasantly impressed on reading a number of compositions gathered together by a girl less than 9 years old.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Al Tolley, playing with Ray Billows, New York State amateur champion from the Dutchess County Country Club, gained the semi-final round in the annual member-guest golf tournament of the Garden City Country Club today.

Hunter College Evening and Extension Division offers so far as is known the only cryptography and cryptanalytics courses open to the public in the United States, according to Rosario Candela, instructor. Mr. Candela first began the study of cryptography eleven years ago, when, as a New York architect, he learned of the accomplishments of the Army Signal Corps in the first World War.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of Mrs. Oswald B. Lord as Assistant Director of Civilian Defense for the Second Corps Area, comprising New York, New Jersey and Delaware.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Here comes Coxey's army," said my old Army buddy, as we watched draftees on leave shambling out of Grand Central. He had something there.

MORE than a year of effort by a part of the engineering staff of American Airlines and of a manufacturing company has produced results -- a new type of credit card exactly three and one-half inches long by two and a quarter inches wide.
GEORGETOWN, Md., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Three persons were killed and seven injured early tonight when an explosion ripped the 80-foot cruiser Koonyung as it lay docked in the Sassafras River.

Those who have an interest in the newest developments of modern design will find a visit to the current exhibition of Organic Design in Home Furnishings at the Museum of Modern Art an exciting experience. Here are strange-looking, form-fitting chairs, coffee tables with the outlines of abstract forms and units of furniture adjustable to an almost indefinite number of combinations.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Bill Terry's Giants were beaten today, 5 to 4, by the Braves. The game was played in the teeth of a piercing east wind from Massachusetts Bay.

ONE fine morning, not long ago, a bundle-laden woman emerged from a department store in New York and was startled to catch sight of a blond curl escaping from the cap of a driver who had just nudged a yellow cab along the curb.

Virtually every nonessential occupation and purchase will be subject to tax on and after next Wednesday, when the new Revenue Act of 1941 takes effect. Food, housing, basic clothing and transportation within commuting distances are not covered, but sports, amusements, travel for the sake of travel and luxury goods of all types will be made to bear part of the burden of national defense.

Fashions this season call for a "tapering" line, and women who have been careless of their figures during the Summer may be in for the shock of their lives when they see themselves in the new wrapped hip-lines and tunics. If the tapered line or reasonable facsimile thereof simply is not visible to the naked eye, perhaps a general slimming course is in the cards.

DICK HAMMERSLEY, son of an English pottery manufacturer, narrates his career, as full of disappointments and reversals of fortune as the most avid fancier of suffering heroes could desire. Yet he describes these staggering buffets of Fate with so little Christian resignation and so much zestful humor that one sheds no tears, confident of ministering ravens to come.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- While the Office of Production Management looks forward to increased emphasis on the direct allocation of basic defense materials to industry, the priority system will continue and must be strictly obeyed, Donald M. Nelson, OPM Director of Priorities, said today.

WITHOUT posing national problems and without probing regional conflicts, Hilda Morris succeeds in making her new novel, "Landmarks," a peculiarly American document. So subtly that it doesn't seem art -- but assuredly is -- she manages to endow her book with the essential characteristics and the feel of an American town.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The United States and Great Britain will begin discussing ways and means of implementing the Atlantic Charter next month when Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government, comes to Washington for a series of conferences with Vice President Wallace, chairman of the new Economic Defense Board.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Jack Mitchell of Spring Brook, leader at thirty-six holes with 138, added rounds of 72 and 71 today for a seventy-two-hole total of 281 and captured the New Jersey open golf championship at Forest Hills.

WHEN the dauntless Dodgers are about to precipitate themselves into a world series and a disciple of Yoga steps forth to challenge for the heavyweight boxing championship of the world, reason totters and chaos rules. A delightful feeling of dizziness pervades the mind. It's like a wonderful dream, too good to be true.
To the Art Editor: IN the absence of a better method, this is directed exclusively to the artists named below who have actually participated in the published "bombshell" discussion to date:

TRAVEL LINES: Tomorrow the Red Willow People of Taos Pueblo, N.M., perform their Sunset Dance, the beginning of a two-day celebration of thanksgiving for a bountiful harvest. Squash, melons, other fruit, loaves of bread and bags of cake are piled high for the feast that follows the second day of merrymaking.

MONTREAL, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Columbus Redbirds of the American Association squared the little world series at one game each tonight by beating the International League's Montreal Royals, 8 to 5. The Redbirds were aided considerably by six Montreal errors as Johnny Grodzicki set the Royals down with eight hits.

THE airmen are beginning a new chapter in the history of civilization. The only major task of our generation, wrote T.E. Lawrence before the war, is the conquest of the air. The airman, continues Mr. Rodman in his introduction, is "the world's freest man." Dependent on the most intricate scientific organization that the world has ever put together, he yet lives on the very margin of civilization, alone, above all this organization, in the sky.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- For some months now British merchantmen traveling alone or in convoys have been carrying on foredeck catapults Hurricane fighters prepared to take off against raiding FockeWulfs. Often for plane and pilot it is a suicide mission.

Tchaikovsky: Symphony No. 4, in F minor. Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos. (Columbia, five twelve-inch records, $5.50.) The Mitropoulos touch, which means a big line, dramatic contrasts and brilliant tone, makes this a spicy reading, and the up-to-date recording should recommend the album to those who seek replacements for disks that do not sound as brightly and fully or that are not complete.

HOLLYWOOD. FOR fifteen years the motion picture industry has tried in vain to film John Colton's play, "The Shanghai Gesture." Even in the lurid season of 1925-26 the drama startled Broadway sufficiently to run 155 days; since then thirty-two adaptations have failed to launder it to the taste of the screen censors.

THE Extavia, newest ship in the American Export Lines' service to India, is expected to sail within twenty days on her maiden voyage and the Examiner of the same lines will start her maiden voyage for the same ports within thirty to sixty days.

BATHS BANNED: Since early this month a drought has affected the Eastern section of the country. Lawns, shrubs and trees have felt the dryness. Last week the women students of Mount Holyoke College felt it, too. President Roswell G. Ham advised the undergraduates to use water "as if it were gold."

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Sept. 28 -- "The battle for Kiev can be considered ended," according to a statement received early today from Moscow. In this battle, it was said, fifteen Russian divisions were trapped by the Nazis after Marshal Semyon Budenny had withdrawn some of his forces.

Despite the sharp drop in enrollment experienced this term by the New York City school system, the vocational division has shown a substantial increase over previous years and now boasts of the highest attendance in its history.

Presidents of women's club federations in six States will discuss the foundations of democracy as one of the events of a three-day convention of the New England Conference of State Federations of Women's Clubs, opening tomorrow in Providence, R.I.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 27 -- Under the auspices of the New Orleans Philharmonic Society, the Newcomb-Tulane Festival Choir of Tulane University will provide the choral part of Beethoven's Ninth symphony in a concert presented by the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra in New Orleans on Jan. 26, Maynard Klein, director of musical activities on the campus, announced this week.

The decision of the National Defense Mediation Board in the Federal Ship-building case was a serious blunder, and the size of that blunder is becoming daily more evident. Though no such provision had previously existed, the board insisted that the company must discharge, regardless of his record, any employe who failed to maintain his union membership in good standing.

One of the outstanding features in the studies recently made of conditions in the four cities of New York, Boston, Cincinnati and Milwaukee is the basic unanimity regarding the urgent need for marked improvements in planning and zoning regulations.

RETAIL trade is winding up a month of business which has shown more moderate gains over last year's figures. It will enter October with several important influences on the side of further reduction in the margin.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Wendell Willkie's announcement that he will work for the nomination and election of Republicans who have backed the Roosevelt Administration's foreign policy -- in the nation-wide contests which begin next Spring -- has brought into the open one of the sharpest dilemmas now facing the G.O.P.

WALTER DUTRANTY once said that he believed folklore to be one of the keys to the character of a nation. Most of us do not feel competent to analyze the national and racial elements in a folk tale, but all of us, children and adults alike, take pleasure in noting characteristic details which distinguish the fairy and folk tales of one part of the world from those of another.

The launching of fourteen new ships of the American merchant marine yesterday in a nation-wide Liberty Fleet Day celebration in shipyards on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts was hailed by President Roosevelt as a "telling blow" at Hitler "and other aggressors of his ilk."

The European war will last "at least three more years," will be won on Middle Eastern battlegrounds and will include participation of an American Expeditionary Force, Demaree Bess, foreign correspondent for The Saturday Evening Post, said yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Field aboard the Yankee Clipper.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Production for defense has created in the nation's capital a vast and complicated organization. The executive and legislative branches of government are concerned. More specifically the tasks of defense production fall upon such bodies as the OPM and the SPAB.

THE Insurance Bridge League, which conducts tournaments for the employes of ninety different insurance companies, begins its annual season next Thursday evening. Only these employes are eligible to play in its games.

A special defense recreation conference will be held in Baltimore tomorrow in conjunction with the opening of the twenty-sixth National Recreation Congress which will continue through Friday. More than 1,500 delegates from all sections of the country, Canada and Hawaii will attend the congress.

WITH THE RED ARMY ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, Sept. 27 -- "This is a war of blitz grinding. On a large part of the front the German troops already are digging in. What lies ahead of them is trench warfare, the mud of Russlan roads and Winter."

To the Editor, The New York Times Magazine: A MAGAZINE section of a newspaper that provokes comment is presumably doing what it was intended to do. Wilford M. Alkin, labeled an educator, indubitably succeeded in provoking me.

THE photographic public has come to know the projected background from Hollywood and the advertising photograph. The idea is simplicity itself; one sets up a translucent screen at the back of the set and projects an appropriate lantern slide thereon, photographing the subject against it.

Pointing to the significant changes in society during the last decade, Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, announced yesterday that a faculty committee has been established to review the "strictly orthodox" liberal arts curriculum and recommend changes which will more aptly fit "new needs and possibilities."

THE philosopher of art is largely concerned with the traits common to the various arts. The men invited by Professor Centeno to turn philosopher reflect not on art but on a specific art, their own. And in this capacity they are concerned less with the common than with the distinctive characteristics of the arts.

FIVE is an age ripe for fantasy. Tall tales told by the young periodically crop up in the news. The latest of these, a saga related by a 5-year-old, included the capture of a runaway lion single-handed and the rout of a family of killers -- both incidental to his fifteenth bolt from home "to join the Army."

ENTERPRISING is too mild a word to describe the bustling, good-natured, redfaced little man who hurried breathlessly about London in mid-eighteenth century, intent on keeping "hot" his multifarious "irons."

THERE is of course no direct connection between the fact that this week will find (a) the world series disturbing the nervous system of the five boroughs and (b) Joe Louis's right hand encountering the cosmic system in the person of Lou Nova.

Somewhere in the Central Mediterranean torpedoes churned toward three 24,000-ton Italian liners shepherded by fast Fascist men-of-war. The "tin fish," loosed by British submarines, found their mark. Exploding torpedo warheads ripped open the plates of two of the merchantmen.

QUINCY, Mass., Sept. 27. -- As part of the Liberty Fleet Day program the Sinclair Refining Company launched today at 4:45 P.M. at the Fore River plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here the tanker S.S. Sinclair Superflame.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 27 (AP) -- The highly ranked Tar Heels of North Carolina were rudely upset today, 13 -- 7, by the South Carolina Gamecocks in general and a rookie back named Stan Stasica in particular. A crowd of 11,000 persons saw the Southern Conference game, played in shirt-sleeve weather.

VICHY, France, Sept. 27 -- Although the official report of today's Cabinet meeting mentioned only internal questions, there is reason to suppose that the relations between France and Germany were also under consideration if only in an informative sense.

AMONG the outstanding exhibitions of the early season may well be included that of recent water-colors by De Hirsh Margules, at the Ferargil Galleries. Shifting from the Hatteras, New York and Cape Cod scenes of other years, Margules has spent a profitable period on the Maine coast.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 27 -- A mild poliomyelitis epidemic, which a few weeks ago threatened to develop into an acute outbreak, has been brought under control by public health authorities through the cooperation of public and private groups, including civic, professional, business, religious and governmental agencies.

WATERVILLE, Me., Sept. 27 -- With a women's dormitory approaching completion this Fall seven of the eight most necessary buildings on the new campus of Colby College may be seen on Mayflower Hill, a 600-acre site two miles from the college's present city location.

Three thousand members of the National Maritime Union, at a membership meeting held in New York last week, went on record in favor of immediate repeal of the neutrality law and urged the arming of American ships carrying supplies to the enemies of Germany.
WATERVILLE, Me., Sept. 27 -- After Colby had scored twice in the first five minutes, City College roared back with a passing game today that was good for three touchdowns and victory by 20 to 16.

Though the Autumn poets mourn that "the melancholy days are come," the Autumn gardeners know better. This is their busiest season of the year and, in a way, their happiest. To them, even though their dahlias and chrysanthemums and hardy asters must soon curl up and disappear, these are cheerful, hopeful days, full of bright visions of the best Spring gardens ever -- next Spring's gardens, the perfect gardens of their lifelong dreams.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined last week to the lowest figure since June 7. The index dropped to 128.3 from 130.2 for the week ended Sept. 13. It stood at 111.5 for the week ended Sept 21, 1940.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -- Inferentially urging repeal of the Neutrality Act, Rear Admiral John W. Greenslade, commandant of the Twelfth Naval District, declared at Liberty Fleet launching ceremonies on San Francisco Bay today that the new cargo ships christened on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coasts should not be hamstrung by restrictive laws.

Hollanders and Holland-Americans will join with Americans of Polish, Belgian, French and Yugoslav extraction to demonstrate their unity with "the Allied opposition to Hitlerism" in a rally this afternoon and evening at Idlewild Park, West Paterson, N.J.

When murder behind the microphone is being investigated by the men from the homicide squad and the D.A.'s office a Centre Street stenographer looks around at the Radio City scene and says it is fascinating. It was an apt remark.
ALAN FISHER will judge the monthly print contest "Vacation Scene" at the Brooklyn Camera Club, 413 Avenue N, tomorrow at 8:30 P.M.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor were greeted by thousands of Chicagoans during a stay of two hours and forty-five minutes today. They arrived at 7:45 A.M. and left for St. Paul at 10:30. It was the Duke's first Visit to Chicago since 1924, when he was the Prince of Wales.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Sept. 21, Zoltan Havas relates certain conditions existing in Hungary. The object of the letter seems to acquit the Horthy regime of any wrongdoing.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Championship honors in the young hunter division of the twelfth annual North Shore horse show were awarded today to the chestnut gelding Glamor Man, owned by Mrs. Dorothy N. Lee of Middleburg, Va., and ridden throughout by Aubrey Fishback.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Integration of courses in several departments to give basic preparation for careers in public service is the primary aim of studies under the Division of Public Affairs established this year in the Yale Graduate School.

Newsreel cameras whirred and klieg lights burned last week in the picture gallery of London's bomb-scarred St. James's Palace, the historic room where the League of Nations once met. The cameras were recording the second meeting of the Council of Allied Governments.

DETROIT -- Despite sporadic interruptions due to short-ages of parts, production of 1942 cars and trucks is rapidly approaching the 100,000-per-week mark, where it is likely to remain for several weeks while car makers are stocking their dealer outlets.

"FOLLER this road until you ford this here crick three times," the hillman directed the strangers. "Then the first house you come to you turn left around their kitchen garden and foller the lane. Hit's rough, but you-all kin git through there all right if you jest take it slow."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: That in the present crisis morale will be the deciding factor is now almost a commonplace. In all wars that either by their length or severity place breaking strains on the contending parties, the "will to victory" counts most.

Good neighbors tugging at the wheels of production are about to challenge shoppers grown listless with curtailed manufacture of consumer material and dwindling supplies from the hapless doors of European exporters. Within a few weeks stores throughout the country will radiate a warm aura of Latin-American colors, with articles both strange and familiar attesting to the fact that this program is settling down to a mutually beneficial neighborliness.

LOUDEST of all morning waves received in this country is Australia's potent beam on 9.68 megacycles. Judging by the stentorian thunder of this wave the ABC has added the power to its stations promised last Summer.

THE Jooss Ballet unquestionably got off to a wonderful star last week at the opening of its sixth American season in Maxine Elliott's Theatre, and will attempt to continue the good work with the addition of a brand new ballet to its list on Thursday.
Mars will be the leading actor in next month's celestial show.

Makers of building materials, furnishings and appliances of every sort were able to show a substantial gain in the second quarter of this year over the previous three months and over the corresponding quarters of 1940, despite the sharply higher provisions for taxes.

THE beauty of most Fall country togs is that they can serve about as well in town. The town-and-country tweed is a classic these days. It requires different accessories for the different uses. A brimmed felt instead of a turban, a sweater to take the place of a silk shirt, stout oxfords substituting for pumps, knit gloves rather than suede, and the trick is done.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Soviet Ambassador Ivan Maisky and Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czech Government-in-Exile, presided over two sessions today of the International Conference on Science and the World Order that is being held here under auspices of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Ted Williams, striving to become the first major leaguer in eleven years to bat .400 for a season, made only one hit in four chances today and dropped just below .400 as the Red Sox defeated the Athletics, 5 to 1.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 27 -- Turkish Government circles radiated confidence tonight that Turkey would emerge from the coming critical week and the entire Autumn with existing alliances and ententes intact, preserving the republic's armed neutrality in the face of crises affecting Turkey, Southeastern Europe and the whole Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Picking off enemy airplanes at night will be much easier in the future if the claims made in a patent (No. 2,256,787) just awarded to Edward F. Lazar of New York City are substantiated.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- By a margin of fifteen lengths, William J. Clothier's Henchman, today won the forty-third running of the Meadow Brook Cup, the three and a half mile amateur steeplechase over timber on the estate of F. Ambrose Clark.

ACROSS a series of large semi-postals carrying designs beautifully executed, Belgium parades ten figures of European royalty of the centuries when Belgium was under the control of the Dukes of Burgundy, Spain and Austria.

Proof of men's regard for women's value in the recreational part of the national defense program is found in the announcement that for the first time in its history the Young Men's Christian Association has appointed three women to its national Army and Navy Department committee.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Colgate's Red Raiders rolled over gallant little St. Lawrence today, winning, 66 -- 0, with Indian Bill Geyer, Ed Phinney, Jules Yokopovich and Mike Micka breaking loose consistently for long gains.
LONDON. THOUGH it makes no direct contribution to the production of literature, the society entitled Friends of the National Libraries deserves well of every one who has literary interests.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Rutgers opened its football season today with a 34-to-0 victory over Alfred before 5,000 in the Rutgers Stadium.

THE full story of the part taken by aircraft in the present conflict must naturally await the termination of the war, when veils of secrecy will be lifted and all the facts may be collected, examined and weighed. But in the meantime there is a need for a dispassionate and readable presentation of available information, and that is what we find in "War in the Air."

AMSTERDAM (viaBerlin), Sept. 27 -- Trading on the Stock Exchange here today was at a somewhat slower pace than in recent sessions. Offerings continued to have the edge in the volume of transactions, but a good undertone of resistance was in evidence.

RELIGION is "the greatest single force in the life of man" -- especially, Henry James Forman adds definitely and by constant implication, in the life of the man who is "civilized," who is "modern," who must face the "realism" of the world today.

ASTRONOMERS and physicists, for more than 100 years, have observed striking relationships between the earth's magnetism and things that happen on the sun. For instance, decades ago it was found that when solar disturbances occurred, compass needles often fluctuated erratically and auroral streamers decked the sky far south of normal polar latitudes.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, Shreveport, La., Sept. 27 -- Shreveport, hot in the Southern sun, resembled a city under siege today as two field armies, participating in the greatest war games in American history, fought outside its gates and staff officers tried to solve the vexing problem of coordinating ground and air effort.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- In a rough National Football League battle where the only casualty was Referee Red Friesell, the Brooklyn Dodgers turned back the Philadelphia Eagles, 24 to 13, before a gathering of 16,341 under the Shibe Park floodlights tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an article published in your issue of Sept. 21, Pertinax, in commenting upon Communist resistance in France, states: "The trouble with the Communists, all their social ideas left aside, is that one always wonders what they will do next.

SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 27 -- After a year of expansion, most of the units of the United States Army are probably better trained than the men who fought the greatest battle in American military history -- the Meuse-Argonne offensive of 1918.

During the season when sunshine is at a premium the conservatory or garden room in the home so fortunate as to have one becomes the most sought-out spot. For here Summer lingers with a spirit that defies the Winter; here plants continue to grow vigorously and flowers bloom in unstinted abundance, even when outdoor gardens have turned bleak and brown.

IF the average newspaper reader were to thumb back through the bound volumes of THE NEW YORK TIMES he would be astonished to find how brief a span of years bridges back to the days when newspaper columns were unadorned with photographs.

THE presses of the nation are oiled and inked and ready to roar the praises of the hero of the 1941 World Series. When the umpires take their places and the man at the plate calls "Play ball!" every player on the field will be pray- ing that the divine lightning strikes him, that when the games are over his name will be first on the tongues of America.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 27 -- The fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks closed here to- night after members had heard a warning by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, that "ruinous inflation" must be forestalled.

FROM all parts of the country, from all walks of life, the "cream" of America's manhood is responding to the nation's call for men to fly the planes which are now coming off the production lines. Ex-sailors, farmers, oil field workers, Army enlisted men, lawyers and other white collar workers have entered Air Corps training schools to receive their coveted "wings" and commissions.

Seldom do Army men throw up their hands in despair, but the men of the 101st Cavalry at Fort Devens, Mass., have just about reached that point as the result of the response to their recent plea for a live falcon, the predominating feature of their regimental insignia.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt neared a final decision tonight on proposals to modify the Neutrality Act. His decision may bring a request to Congress to put guns on American merchant ships and open all combat zones to American vessels serving the British life-line.

DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Running wild in the first period on a four-touchdown scoring spree, the Duke Blue Devils overwhelmed the Wake Forest Deacons, 43 to 14, in their opening football game today. More than 10,000 spectators witnessed the contest.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- A Great Lakes steamer loaded with more than 100,000 bushels of wheat arrived here late today from Fort William, Ont., the consignment being, it is understood, the first of a series which will move 1,000,000 to 1,250,000 bushels of Canadian grain for transshipment via rail or barge to Gulf ports.

On Tuesday Mayor LaGuardia will lay the cornerstone of the Machine and Metal Trades High School, which will be used for training in defense industries as well as for regular vocational students, and the event points to figures brought out by Mr. Fine in an article on this page showing that there has been a 15 per cent increase in vocational students in the New York City school system in twelve months.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The six-day conference of the New York Library Association closed here today with several meetings of special interest to school librarians. The speakers on the program were Rita M. Cowan of the Division of Civic Education of the State Education Department; Carl E. Lewis of Poughkeepsie, and Fjeril Hess, author and editor.

Although a good deal of progress was made last week at the National Defense Production Clinic toward voluntary subcontracting, it was learned yesterday that the Office of Production Management, acting through the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board, is shaping plans to wield a club over prime contractors if the voluntary effort does not provide satisfactory results.

IT was dinner time on Sunday in the country. Everything was quiet. Every one was relaxed. The Pekingese was snoring, as usual. While the roast was being carved the telephone bell rang. "Los Angeles calling," the operator announced.

One of the outstanding events of the early season will take place Wednesday night when a gala anniversary ball will be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. A two-fold purpose envelops preparations for the event which have occupied the attention of several committees for weeks past.

BURLINGTON, Vt, Sept. 27 -- Following a hectic and uncertain year since the death of President Guy W. Bailey on Oct. 22, 1940, the University of Vermont has just opened its 151st year with prospects much brighter than seemed possible six months ago.
In this story Frances Kent Gere has drawn a careful, consistent and convincing picture of Rimmani, a 12-year-old boy of ancient Babylon, and his adventures in the reign of King Hammurabi.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 27 -- From this bastion of American defense, which Secretary Knox ranks next in importance in the battle of Atlantic to Iceland and Newfoundland, the head of the United States Navy fired another barrage last night against the Neutrality Act.

Although the problem of a prospective oil shortage along the Atlantic seaboard has not been solved fully, the oil companies, by using every transportation facility to the fullest extent, appear to have met rather effectively for the time being a situation, which two or three months ago seemed to indicate an acute problem of supply for the largest oil-consuming area of the country.

The longest column of Army trucks ever seen in New York City will pass through here on Tuesday morning en route from Camp Edwards, Mass., to the First Army manoeuvres m North Carolina. Police Department officials already are working on the traffic problems that the procession, consisting of 1,163 vehicles and carrying 9,000 officers and men of the Yankee Division, will present.

FOR some reason (probably climatic) New York in October is always fairly cracking with energy and the promise of gayety. People are delighted to run into friends, from whom they have had a rest all Summer, and full of ideas about seeing more of them. Even in the middle of a late heat wave many women have visions of themselves presiding at a cocktail party, a Winter dinner or Sunday tea.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Premier Emmanuel Tsouderos, who arrived in London a few days ago with King George and other officials of the Greek Government, said in an interview yesterday that the German troops in Greece were warweary and so ill-equipped with clothing that they had plundered clothing stores and that some of them even had taken women's underclothes to wear.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- The Council of Ministers today, upon Premier Mussolini's proposal, took the gravest of all rationing steps by ordering that each individual may have only 200 grams, or about 7 ounces, of bread daily, starting Oct. 1. Other important decrees of a political and financial nature were also sanctioned, making this one of the outstanding Ministerial meetings of the war.

The Yankees yesterday voted to divide their world series swag into thirty-one full shares and other smaller ones. Then they went out and cast a negative ballot in their game with the Senators at the Stadium.

TO describe certain novels as "strange books" might often be escape into some vague kind of criticism. But if we call Miss Green's novel strange we do so because the author quite obviously wanted to write a strange story.

A NEW kind of farmer festival invites the Autumn tourist. Sponsored as a rule by farm cooperatives, it usually centers about the cooperative growing, shipping and marketing of a single local product, the region's principal money crop.

The Department of Commerce recently estimated Germany's current national income to be 100,000,000,000 marks annually. Now come estimates from Germany, based on figures of the Reich's Assistant Minister of Finance, Fritz Reinhardt, which place the total of the Reich's military expenditures in the first two years of the war at that same figure, 100,000,000,000 marks.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 27 (AP) -- September was Italy's blackest month at sea since the Battle of Cape Matapan last March, with twenty-nine troop and supply ships sunk, thirty others damaged badly and the flow of Axis reinforcements across the Mediterranean to North Africa curtailed sharply, a compilation of British war bulletins showed tonight.

THE hundredth anniversary of the birth of the great Czech composer, Antonin Dvorak, is now being enthusiastically celebrated in London. The announcements of many Dvorak performances in concert halls here and Dr. Paul Stefan's book indicate that the same will be true in America.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 27 -- All-America Tom Harmon was no nearer than the radio booth today, but Michigan's football team effectively alternated two players in his position to defeat Michigan State, 19 to 7, before 67,079 spectators.

Through one of the coincidences that often occur in the various fields of science, Dr. George S. Oliver of California and Dr. Ehrenfried Pfeiffer of Holland have both been delving into the lives of earthworms. Their findings have amazing import for gardeners and farmers.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 -- Her prow's fresh gray paint glistening with champagne, the Patrick Henry, first of the 312 Liberty Fleet ships being constructed in American yards, backed down the ways into the middle branch of the Patapsco River today amid a din of whistles, bells and horns.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- The University of California gave a convincing demonstration of old-fashioned power football today, smashing out a 31-0 victory over St. Mary's in the Golden Bears' opening game before 50,000 fans.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- West of Philadelphia traffic rushes down Lancaster Pike (U.S. 30) and all that the driver has time to notice is the eddy of trucks and cars around him. As the garages, super-markets and antique shops slip by he may easily miss one of the sights of the region -- a kind of market seldom seen in the United States -- the Lancaster Farmers' Market.

With the Sea of Marmara and the Bosporus, the Dardanelles is part of the "Straits" -- 235 miles long and from one-half a mile to fifty miles wide -- linking the Aegean with the Black Sea.

ANKARA, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Diplomatic quarters reported tonight that Russia had rejected a Nazi "trial balloon" for a separate armistice modelled closely on the armistice signed by the Reich with France.

As the Autumn peak in railroad freight traffic approaches, the ability of the nation's systems to handle the largest volume of freight in eleven years is about to be tested. The car surplus -- the number of freight cars available but not actually in use -- has fallen sharply in recent months until it averaged but 44,000 in the week ended Sept. 13.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Stanford's Rose Bowl champions today opened their 1941 season with a shaky 19-15 victory over the University of Oregon in a Pacific Coast Conference game before a crowd of 35,000.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., -- A new appreciation of art courses, open to students in all four classes was added to the art department curriculum at Georgian Court College here this year. The new course is to be taught by Dr. Elizabeth H. Hajos.

HAVING obtained a temporary release from his United Artists contract Gabriel Pascal -- he who is "cinematically wedded to George Bernard Shaw" -- is about to sign a two year pact with RKO Radio Pictures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Senator George of Georgia, chairman of the Finance Committee, issued a statement today opposing Secretary Morgenthau's proposal to limit corporation profits to 6 per cent during the emergency.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Cubs came from behind today to beat the Cardinals, 6 to 5, after knocking Howard Pollet out in the eighth inning with a decisive 3-run rally.

Thirty-two leaders of industry, labor and professions have accepted appointments as associate and vice chairmen of the fifth merged fund-raising campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, it was announced yesterday by George Z. Medalie and Hugh Grant Straus, presidents of the two federations.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Amherst scored a convincing victory over Ducky Pond's Bates eleven today, 31-7. The Jeffs tallied a touchdown in the first half on a Bob Blood to Carey pass, picked up momentum in the second half and added 25 points.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. has suggested that corporate income of over 6 per cent of invested capital should be treated as excess profits and taxed during the emergency at the rate of 100 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Princeton University's unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps expanded to the largest size in its history this Fall, with a record total of freshmen inducted and some major changes in materiel and method.

The Masonite Corporation, which manufactures pressed wood hard boards and insulation materials, earned $2,010,886, or $3.54 a share on the common stock, in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, according to preliminary figures announced yesterday by Ben Alexander, president.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Opponents of the Administration's foreign policy are organizing for a fight against revision of the Neutrality Act, and Senator La Follette made it clear today that opposition Senators would resist any changes.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Members of the Oyster Bay Shop of the British War Relief Society are sponsoring a showing of British war motion pictures, which will take place Tuesday evening at Christ Church Parish Hall here. Proceeds from the showing, which will also include films of peace-time England, will be divided between the British War Relief Society and Young America Wants to Help, one of its divisions.

THE problem of how to estimate the value of United States covers which passed through the mails in the period from 1787, when the postal service was established, to 1847, when the government first made adhesive stamps, was approached in a systematic way by the late Edward S. Knapp, New York broker, whose collection of stamps, covers and related historical material was one of the best ever assembled.

As a fitting climax to as thrilling and dramatic a campaign as the game has known, Greater New York moves on the scene this week to provide the setting for baseball's greatest show on earth -- the world series -- and this time it promises to be even greater than ever.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 27 -- Following in the hoofprints of his great stablemate, Challedon, W. L. Brann's Pictor won the thirtieth running of the $15,000 added Havre de Grace Handicap before a closing-day crowd of 18,000 today.

The cotton market, moving within a narrow range, declined yesterday for the third consecutive session. After touching the low levels for the day in the first hour of trading, at losses of 7 to 10 points, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered moderately.

In answer to reports from members that pressure was being brought by labor organizations in the field of chemistry, the American Chemical Society issued a statement yesterday opposing the forcible enlistment of professional men in bargaining units dominated by non-professional groups.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Ohio State's Buckeyes kept their opening day victory string since 1894 intact today, beating Missouri's highly touted Tigers, 12 to 7, in a spine-tingling contest before 49,671 fans to give Coach Paul E. Brown, just up from the high school ranks, a rousing send-off on his big league career.
