CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Evolution of the universe, reaching back billions of years before the stars were formed and before "time" can be computed, was the subject of a symposium conducted jointly by the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the University of Chicago in the course of the latter's fiftieth anniversary celebration.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command issued the following communique today:

The fearsome features of a three-foot cannibal and the ferocious imagery of Jack-the-Giant-Killer's giant will dominate the third annual exhibit sponsored by puppet fanciers throughout the country to be held next week in Hearn's Auditorium, 20 West Fourteenth Street.

VETERAN and new owners of cars will reach deeper into their pockets next Wednesday and thereafter for automotive expenses under the new Federal tax act. On Oct. 1 a 7 per cent levy on new car wholesale prices doubles the previous tax.

Exasperated by what they term an increasing tendency of the U.S. Customs Bureau toward arbitrary enforcement of tariff regulations not connected with revenue production, importers here announced yesterday that they will send a delegation to Washington shortly to ask a more lenient official attitude on technical points.

OSCAR has been Oscar of the Waldorf since the old Waldorf, done in German Mooresque, opened in a glitter of glory and a prodigious downpour of rain on the night of March 14, 1893. Today he celebrates his seventy-fifth birthday, a legendary character of New York, as authentic as pegleg Peter Stuyvesant.

POLISHED to mirror-like brightness, a mahogany airplane that may revolutionize the private plane industry took to the air last week at Roosevelt Field. For almost an hour it circled the field, reflecting the sun like a piece of well-kept furniture as it banked and climbed, and then it landed.

"Flower Photography in Color" will be the subject of the free lecture on Saturday from 3 to 4 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden. Paul Rittenhouse, photographer, will illustrate a talk with projections of his own work, showing single flowers, compositional groups and garden scenes.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Reinhard Heydrich, German Chief of the Security Police and right-hand man to Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, was named by the Reichsfuehrer today to take over the job of Baron Constantin von Neurath at Prague as Reich Protector in Bohemia and Moravia.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 27 -- Reports today described the daylight raiding of roads and Axis positions deep in Libya for the second time this week. The attacks mentioned were carried out on the coast road east of Sirte and southwest of Bengazi.

In the spacious administration building of El Palomir, airport of Buenos Aires, soldiers of the Argentine Army last week stood guard. In the capital's police headquarters 3,000 uniformed men were held for emergency duty, while others patrolled the highways and kept check on suspicious persons.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 27 (AP) -- The University of Virginia's Captain Bill Dudley, 168 pounds of football dynamite, piloted his Cavaliers to a 25-to-0 triumph over Lafayette College today, shattering the Pennsylvanians eleven-game winning streak.

The Nazi Ring Tightens LENINGRAD: population 3,200,000; built on marshland and on "laborers' bones" by Peter the Great; capital of the Czars; cradle of the Red Revolution; Russia's second city and its window on the Baltic; home of former imperial palaces and of workers' tenements; center of shipbuilding, aircraft, munitions, machine tool and textile manufacture; producer of 10 per cent of Soviet industrial output; junction of railroads from Murmansk and Moscow.
THE hero of Mr. Kelland's latest novel might almost be classed as a denatured, American version of Bertie Wooster or one of the other Wodehouse Crumpets. The process by which this lukewarm and slow-

ROME, Sept. 27 -- Time may be working for one side or the other in this war, militarily speaking, but certainly it is working against the man in the street. Every week that passes the screw is turned a little tighter. He must eat less, wear less, buy less.

WASHINGTON, Sept 27 -- The United States Army, the largest occupational training agency in this country, gives credit for a good share of its present efficiency to the training received by service men in the days when they attended public school.

MOUTHPIECE: The editor of Rome's II Giornale d'Italia found a new word last week to describe the American people. They were "deluded," wrote Virginio Gayda in one of the articles widely accepted as reflecting the attitude of the Fascist government, in believing that Italian morale was low after two years of war.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 27 -- Turkey is arming furiously and playing fair diplomatically through the precarious Autumn and staking high hopes on the Spring.

Paul P. Rao, Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of customs, was nominated last night for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District, composed of Manhattan and the Bronx, at the Democratic judicial convention in Tammany Hall.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 27 -- Oberlin College students this Fall are obtaining information about the role their enlarged educational project in Szechwan Province is playing in the reconstruction of Free China.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 27 -- The giant steel mills of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company were closed tonight by a strike of members of the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- The first anniversary of the conclusion of the German-Italian-Japanese alliance was observed here today in what was officialy described as a "dignified" manner without any public demonstration, in keeping with the delicate International situation in which Japan finds herself.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 27 -- Brown opened Coach Skip Stahley's regime today by defeating Wesleyan, 20 to 6, before a crowd of 10,000 spectators.

GREENPORT, L.I., Sept. 27 -- The Greenport Basin and Construction Company, which has completed eight small boats for the Navy in its yards in the last ten months and is building or about to build six more, is prepared to proceed with operations Monday morning despite a strike called today by Local 47, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O.

Above the Courts Senator Coudert, it should be noted, was careful to qualify one statement in his reply Courts to the American Committee for Democracy and Intellectual Freedom. This body has just denounced the Coudert inquiry into subversive teaching as a peril to the schools.

THE disappointed mumblings of a half-crazed common trooper caused the title "Mad Anthony" to be attached to a great American. Washington Irving, who completely misunderstood the nickname, injudiciously concluded that it was given Wayne because of rashness, recklessness and unbridled daring.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 27 -- About 15,000 persons from rural sections of the country are expected to take part in the nineteenth annual convention of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, which opens here next Saturday and continues through the following Wednesday.

Has Joe Louis slipped? Has the Brown Bomber, the Dark Destroyer, the Alabama Assassin lost the power of lightning in the punch that has been one of the most destructive weapons in the history of the ring?

To the Art Editor: I FOR one believe Mr. Kootz is entirely in error in his dispar- agement of American art in the last decade. On the contrary, I believe the last ten years have been the most fruitful in our history. Moreover, there are more so-called "experimental" artists at work than ever before.

The attack on the La Guardia administration on the ground of continued overassessment and inequality of assessment of real estate in New York City broadcast in his acceptance address on Thursday night by Lloyd C. Church, Democratic nominee for Controller, was supported yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Whether the President formally requests Congress to revise or repeal the Neutrality Act, or Congress takes up the matter with his informal blessing, its participation in this decision follows the best-established American historical precedents. In the quasi-war with France in 1798, and in the war with the Barbary States for several years from 1801, the partnership of Congress was carefully obtained by the Executive in advance of offensive action.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A monetary conference participated in by the United States, Britain and China will be held in Hong Kong to study new means of bolstering Chinese currency, the Treasury Department announced today.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The White Sox regained sole possession of third place in the American League by beating the Tigers today, 10 to 6. John Rigney pitched the full distance for his thirteenth victory. Chicago scored eight times in the fourth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- WPA, political bone of contention for more than five years, has virtually faded from the scene, so far as controversy goes, in the face of the inexorable advance of the war effort and the consequent rise in employment levels in defense industries.

Some weeks ago the Germans announced that they had conquered an area in Russia which formerly supported 70,000,000 people. Since then they have widened their conquest. If they overrun the whole Eastern Ukraine, as they now threaten to do, they will add many millions to the civilian population at their mercy.

Department store sales in the New York area last week averaged about 8 per cent ahead of a year ago. Apparel lines were benefited by the cooler weather, although the religious holidays curtailed trade in the earlier part of the week.
Despite its heavy war losses the British Empire now has more ships than she had a year ago, while the merchant marine of the United States has declined.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to the newspapers, the German General Staff expects to be able to take the greater part of European Russia in 1941 and that their line of occupation will reach the Volga.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: I REGRET the necessity of writing, but I am afraid Miss Walton has unwittingly misrepresented my Sac Prairie Saga in her review of my new novel "Evening in Spring." The suggestion inherent in her last paragraph is that the books in the Saga are composed mainly of "wistful memories of * * * boyhood."

TWENTY radio transmitters, designed for ground-to-plane communication, are rolling off the assembly lines every week at the Kearny, N.J., plant of Western Electric. More than 300 of these radio transmitters will be delivered to Pan American Airways, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The 435-ton Panama motor ship Triniday, reported sunk in the Atlantic, was neither American-owned nor operated, as far as could be determined here today. No official report was received on the incident but at the State Department it was said that apparently there was no American interest in the ships.

The suggestion inherent in her last paragraph is that the books in the Saga are composed mainly of "wistful memories of * * * boyhood."

TWENTY radio transmitters, designed for ground-to-plane communication, are rolling off the assembly lines every week at the Kearny, N.J., plant of Western Electric. More than 300 of these radio transmitters will be delivered to Pan American Airways, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The 435-ton Panama motor ship Triniday, reported sunk in the Atlantic, was neither American-owned nor operated, as far as could be determined here today. No official report was received on the incident but at the State Department it was said that apparently there was no American interest in the ships.

SEATTLE, Sept. 27 -- The boy they have been touting at an All-America candidate, Bruce Smith, 193-pound halfback, lived up to advance notices today as he led Minnesota to a 14 -- 6 victory over the University of Washington football team before 43,000 spectators.

THIS is the story of a return home -- the intimate chronicle of a woman going back to the villages of her childhood in a land at war. It makes no pretense to comprehend an entire scene or survey a great nation's resources.

WOODSY trails beckon as the scarlet of maple and the gold of towering tulip trees suggest a foretaste of autumnal foliage glorious in color. The heat and humidity of Summer are at an end and, with cool days ahead, hikers in ever-increasing numbers are escaping from the metropolitan area and heading for the forests near by.
NEW YORK Mrs. Robert Walton Goelet and members of her family are expected at the Ritz-Carlton today from Newport.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- The first anniversary of the conclusion of the German-Italian-Japanese alliance was observed here today in what was officialy described as a "dignified" manner without any public demonstration, in keeping with the delicate International situation in which Japan finds herself.
ROME, Sept. 28 -- Italy and Britain are engaged in another of their great running battles between air and sea power in the Western Mediterranean, the Italian High Command announced succinctly today.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 28 -- The mighty Chicago Bears, world professional football champions, rolled over the Green Bay Packers today, 25 to 17, in a thrilling see-saw battle before a sell-out crowd of 24,876.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an interview in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 21 Attorney General Biddie is quoted as saying: "In so far as I can, I intend to see that civil liberties in this country are protected and we do not again fall into the disgraceful hysteria of witch-hunts, strike-breakings and minority persecutions which were such a dark chapter in our record of the last World War."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- In a struggle that teemed with dramatic moments, the New York Giants vanquished the Washington Redskins, 17 to 10, before a gathering of 35,677 in Griffith Stadium today and thus gained a mighty important victory in the Eastern Division race in the National Football League.
ANKARA, TurKey, Sept. 28 -- Franz von Papen, German Ambassador, crossed the Bosporus in his special motor launch tonight and boarded the Anatolia Express at Haydabpasha bound for Ankara.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- W. Averell Harriman and Lord Beaverbrook and their staffs and the Anglo-American delegations to the Tri-Power Economic Conference in Moscow arrived today on the eve of the opening sessions of talks designed to facilitate supplies for the Soviet fighting forces in the war against Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Germany and to add to the vast resources at the disposal of this country the reserves and manufacturing output of the English-speaking world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Wheat prices averaged higher last week, with much of the trading in futures feeing of a professional character. Outside interest was considerably curtailed by uncertainty over developments in Washington, especially in regard to price-control measures.
MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 29 -- In both the central and Leningrad sectors the Red Army has started fierce new counter-attacks and captured German advance positions, the Russians reported last night.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Featuring classes for junior riders, the annual Brookville Charity Horse Show was held here today on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Emanuel to raise funds for the upkeep of The Shelter, the home owned by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children of Nassau County.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Sept. 28 -- The Long Island Indians made their home debut a winning one today. Playing aggressive football from start to finish, the Indians turned back the Newark Bears, 10 -- 0, in an American Association contest on Memorial Field before a crowd of 5,000.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Sept. 28 -- Sir Robert Leslie Craigie, British Ambassador to Japan, after suddenly canceling all pending engagements at Tokyo, arrived here today with his wife and son, prepared to board the boat for Shanghai Tuesday morning, ostensibly on a three-month leave that will take him to the United States.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 28 -- Louis Barbaro, Mamaroneck, N.Y., fired his fourth consecutive subpar round this afternoon -- a 66 -- and with it won the City of Providence open golf championship at the Municipal Course.

If the Dodgers, who nave an important date with the Yankees on Wednesday, could discover a loophole in baseball law and put a Brooklyn uniform on Sid Hudson, their world series chances would be greatly enhanced.

Realizing a hope cherished for many years, the Actors Fund of America will dedicate on Sunday, Oct. 19, a lofty obelisk on its plot in Kensico Cemetery in Westchester as a memorial to the stage folk buried there.

Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti, as Coordinator of the New York State Council of Defense, declared yesterday that the health facilities of the State were rapidly being placed on an emergency defense basis to meet any possible crisis.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 28 -- Most of the secondary Continental European stock markets continued last week to reflect a generally strong undertone, with the principal trading interest being focused on the low-price and less active equities, since the more active shares have reached levels too comparatively high for the average operator.
Agents were kept busy over the week-end showing and renting apartments in the city to lessees whose names are being added to building rosters in the late Fall renting rush.

Outlining his reactions to what he heard and saw from a pew at the twenty-five church services he attended last Summer while on the West Coast, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale paid tribute yesterday morning to the ministers of America.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Transportation Ministry Issued new restrictions for Jews today and the newspaper Berliner Boersen Zeitung forecast additional stringent steps against the Jews, possibly including the ghetto.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- The mass of the German forces that were said to have trapped and defeated five Russian armies east of Kiev is now being manoeuvred into position for a new offensive in the Eastern Ukraine, it was reported here tonight.

The best friend of the Jew is the man who has the best acquaintance with Jesus Christ, for no man who knows Christ can hate anybody, the Rev. Francis K. Shepherd declared in his sermon yesterday morning at North Baptist Church, 232 West Eleventh Street.
NEW YORK Mrs. John A. Logan is expected to come to the Savoy-Plaza this week from Camden, Me.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- The sword of Damocles which had been hanging over the German Boerse for the last few months fell with a crash on Friday in the form of a long-delayed announcement of measures which the Reich Ministry of Economics intends to take with a view to checking definitely the "war boom" in the stock market.

There is no dispute in this country over the wisdom and justice of heavy taxation on corporation profits flowing out of the armament program. But the proposal of Secretary Morgenthau that profits of all corporations, whether arising from the rearmament effort or not, and regardless of size, be limited to 6 per cent of invested capital is a completely different proposition.

VICHY, France, Sept. 28 -- Xavier Vallat, Commissioner-General for Jewish Questions, is back in Vichy after a sojourn in Paris, and it is understood that new decrees regarding the status of Jews may be issued in the near future.

ONCE upon a time nobody had to hesitate in naming his choice when Shufflin' Joe Louis stepped into the ring. He was, as the boys say, a "mortal lock," a copper-riveted cinch. The Dark Destroyer couldn't miss. Or so it seemed. He did miss in the first Schmeling bout, but he more than made up for it the next time he ran into Herr Max.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The National Congress of Parents and Teachers said today that it was sending detailed instructions to 2,500,000 members to aid them in playing "an increasingly important role in the national defense."
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Gulf Stream and Aknusti played a repeat performance on International Field at Meadow Brook today and it was even tetter than last Sunday's national open polo final.

The Barnard College Occupation Bureau placed more students and graduates in jobs during the last academic year than ever before, Miss Katharine S. Doty, head of the bureau, reported yesterday to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve. Total earnings for the college year ending July 1 were $50,000 more than the year before.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- Italians had to tighten their belts today as the new regime of curtailed rations began to make itself felt. On the Via Vittorio Veneto, Rome's equivalent to Fifth Avenue or the Champs Elysees, fashionable morning strollers passed two bread queues, the first that Italy has seen since the previous World War.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The 21 per cent rise in wholesale prices which has occurred in two years is attributable chiefly to increases in farm products and to higher hourly wage rates, the Brookings Institution reported today. As a result, it said, the government's pending price control bill could exert no effective control over the price system as a whole and must be supplemented by stabilization of farm prices and wages in general.

Justice and peace will come to the world not because of our increasing aid to the Allies nor because of the gallant stand of Britain, but because of God, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in his sermon at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A communique issued today by the British Middle East Command said:
Principals -- Joe Louis, Detroit, champion. vs. Lou Nova, Alameda, Calif., challenger.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Sept. 16 at 106.9, compared with 106.7 a fortnight before, 106.4 a month before, 99.9 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

Opinions sharply divided along "isolationist" and "interventionist" lines were expressed yesterday afternoon by speakers commemorating the World War dead of the Seventy-seventh Division of the A.E.F. and honoring the survivors of the division's "Lost Battalion" and the Gold Star Mothers in a service at the Mall in Central Park.

A syndicate of investors headed by Stanley L. Ballin bought from the Mutual Life Insurance Company the twelve-story store and loft building at 6 East Thirty-ninth Street and 5 East Thirty-eighth Street for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $247,500 maturing in 1951.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- A steady volume of incoming steel specifications, the majority of which covered "rated requirements," the allocation of additional tonnages for the use of Great Britain, a slight increase in the production of steel ingots, and a further accentuation of the growing scrap shortage, were highlights in news of the steel industry last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- As a result of liquidation of United States securities by Great Gritain, Canada, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and Latin America, but chiefly by Great Britain and Canada, there was for the first time since 1934 a net outflow of capital from the United States in the first six months of this year, the Treasury reported today.

VICHY, France, Sept. 28 -- A development of importance in the financial field last week was a measure concerning the organization of banks. An order of the Finance Ministry stipulates that a bank must have a minimum capital of 5,000,000 francs when it is being organized into a company through the issuance of stock, and a minimum capital of 1,000,000 francs when organized without a corporate structure.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 28 -- A first-hand view of the battle of supplies, the part that heavy bombers are playing in it, and the general strategic situation forces upon one the conviction that the British are not out of the woods yet in the Eastern Mediterranean despite the respite given by Germany's invasion of Russia.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Governor Lehman will confer here Thursday afternoon with Federal, State and local defense officials on evacuation plans for New York City.

With registration for the general election Nov. 4 to begin a week from today, the five Democratic county organizations supporting the Democratic city ticket and the various parties and groups supporting Mayor La Guardia and his Fusion running mates will set up machinery this week to get voters to qualify for participation in the election.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 28 -- Bulgaria has received a temporary delay on entering the war, pending the outcome of German negotiations with Turkey, according to reports in foreign diplomatic circles.

"Ghost for Sale," a mystery comedy by Ronald Jeans, opens tonight at Daly's Sixty-third Street Theatre. The show, which will be seen for two weeks only, marks the first of Alex Cohen's stock company productions this season. London first saw the play in 1938, with A.E. Matthews in the leading part.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The War Department announced yesterday the award of miscellaneous supply contracts totaling $6,288,373, among which were the following for concerns in the New York area which have not been previously published:

VICHY, France, Sept. 28. -- Although there was no diplomatic activity today in Vichy, Franco-German relations loomed large in Lyon, where Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, arrived in the morning to open the trade fair, an annual institution that lapsed last year on account of the war.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Final returns in Britain's much publicized "Tanks for Russia Week" showed that the last seven days surpassed any similar period by nearly 20 per cent in production of all types of tanks. A considerable number of these actual machines will eventually find their way to Russia if the Eastern Front Is maintained for the three or four months needed to ship the tanks there.

WEST PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Several thousand persons representing groups originating in the Netherlands and other occupied nations of Europe staged a mass demonstration at Idlewild Park here today in support of "Allied opposition to Hitlerism" and to broadcast their belief that the countries now dominated by the Nazis soon would regain their freedom.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, will climb into the ring of the Polo Grounds tonight for the nineteenth defense of the title he won back in June, 1937, by knocking out James J. Braddock in eight rounds at Chicago. The Brown Bomber is to oppose Lou Nova, rock-ribbed, steel-jawed challenger from Alameda, Calif.

The American Association for Social Security yesterday made public the findings of a survey showing what the association termed widespread opposition on the part of the press to the proposal of Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. for the use of social security funds for defense purposes and for the purpose of curbing inflation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A boom in sales of farms -- the first such boom in about twenty years -- was attributed yesterday by government officials to the national defense and British aid programs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- The prospect that Harold Lloyd may remake a number of his own early vehicles with Kay Kyser as the star appeared today with the announcement by RKO that Kyser's next film will be "My Favorite Spy," which Lloyd will produce and in which he previously had declared he would appear.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fighters roamed over occupied France today attacking German troops and supply stations. Reports from the English coast tonight indicated that the raids continued after dark.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Ted Williams of the Red Sox today became the first American Leaguer to hit .400 or higher for a season since 1923, when Harry Heilmann batted .403 for Detroit. Bill Terry was the last National League player to turn the trick.

In comparing the Yankees and Dodgers on the defense one almost immediately becomes cognizant of a situation rather extraordinary though not exactly new, and one which might well hold the key to the outcome of the forthcoming world series struggle.

An atmosphere of delightful informally pervaded Ebbets Field yesterday as the champion Dodgers closed their National League season by beating the Phillies, 5 -- 1, in a game that put a Brooklyn team at the century mark in victories for the first time in the club's history.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The British Association meeting today adopted seven points constituting a charter of scientific principles by which they hoped that the men of the laboratories and their formulas would make their influence dominant in the brave new world of the future.

The current alcohol shortage will be alleviated, making drastic curtailments in its civilian use unnecessary, through arrangements made with the Commodity Credit Corporation to permit whisky distillers to convert 20,000,000 bushels of corn into alcohol for use by the Ordnance Department, according to a raw material survey by Ernest T. Trigg, president of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, released for publication today.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- It is notorious that Nazi Germany has made the persecution of Roman Catholics second only in intensity to the persecution of the Jews.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Sept. 28 -- The will to war against Japan is very strong in the Netherlands Indies, Singapore, Australia and New Zealand. The general feeling here is that the United States-Japanese talks in Washington are useless but are giving the United States time for defense and offensive preparations that are rapidly nearing completion in the Philippines.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Browns, whose chief claim to fame is the trouble they cause higher ranking teams, retained this form today by defeating the Indians, 5 to 4.

Some Spring business was placed in the wholesale market last week, but merchants generally were wary, of making large commitments at present high prices. Deliveries were better in many lines and stores received shipments in full on these items.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 98.5 to 98.7. The all-commodity index thus continued to enter new high ground, despite the fact that rather sharp declines were witnessed in agricultural raw material commodities, which have been responsible for much of this year's rise in the general index.

Increased prices with maintenance of present quality is favored by the largest group of restaurant patrons responding to a recent questionnaire of the Society of Restaurateurs, Inc., on what to do about the rising costs of foodstuffs and labor.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Corny Shields, with his sloop Aileen, won both the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy and the Frank Campbell prize for the best combined point score in championship and Sunday racing of the International Class, it was determined tonight after mathematicians had resorted to all but calculus to get the figures correct.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- How business on the London Stock Exchange was affected by the first full year of war is revealed in the annual report of the institution for the year ended on March 31.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Cardinals closed the season today with a 3-to-1 victory over the Cubs. Eddie Beazley, rookie pitcher from New Orleans, made a successful major league debut for St. Louis with a ten-hit performance.
NORTH PORTAL, Sask., Sept. 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, greeted by thousands of Canadians, made a triumphant entrance into the Dominion at this border town today.

Carder, associate minister of the Riverside Church, where the annual memorial service of the Police Square Club, Masonic organization of the department, was held.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 28 -- A deathblow to all of Norwegian economy has been delivered by the stoppage of all German imports into Norway, it is now learned.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- President Roosevelt, who will take up on his return to Washington Tuesday the fight for modification or repeal of the Neutrality Act, heard the Rev. Frank R. Wilson of St. James Episcopal Church here assert, today that the United States helped to upset the world situation.

Carrot colors are the keynote -- warm carrot yellow and gay carrot-leaf green -- for the shiny new shop that has just opened its doors and hung out its shingle in the busiest section of town. The sunny hues draw a throng of passers-by through the open door into the bright interior, where a series of green-and-silver stools stand primly before a diminutive bar.

A plea that Catholics all over the world pray during October for a peace that only God can give was made, both in Italian and English, by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday afternoon at a rally of the Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Societies, Italian-American branches, on the campus of Fordham University in the Bronx.

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept 28 -- A proposed peace agreement which would have meant resumption of work at closed collieries in this area tomorrow morning was rejected today by coal miners who have been on strike for nearly three weeks against increased union dues and assessments.

One of the most dramatic stories to come out of the war -- the capture by the Germans of Wing Commander Douglas Bader, legless British flying ace who parachuted from his disabled plane into enemy territory -- was further embellished yesterday in dispatches from Rome and Berlin that told of his attempted escape.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If Secretary Morgenthau would like to see a 6 per cent limitation on all profits during the emergency, he ought to have some economic or social purpose behind his proposal. What that purpose could be we do not profess to know, but we do know what purposes his proposal will not fulfill.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- The Giants finished their season today, beating the Braves, 2 -- 1, with Rookie Dave Koslo, southpaw from Milwaukee, pitching a six-hitter and farming seven. This was his first major league victory against one loss.

He was a member of the last two Cabinets in the republic and when Germany dismembered Czecho-Slovakia, creating the German Protectorate of Bolemia-Moravia in its stead, he was Minister of Transportation.

HOFFMAN, N.C., Sept. 28 -- As troops of New York's 102d Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft) Brigade completed their first week on field manoeuvres today, Lieut. Col. Roelif H. Brooks, Protestant chaplain of the 207th Coast Artillery Regiment, the old Seventh of New York, officiated at a service here before several hundred troops.
In its first change of ownership since 1888, the two-story dwelling at 318 East 156th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Ida E. Beck to Antonio Conty through P. C. D'Onofrio, broker.

A chart giving prices in both pounds and yards for numerous standard constructions of print cloths and broadcloths based on raw cotton at various levels from 14.71 to 19.42 cents per pound, under the system contemplated by the Office of Price Administration, has been prepared by Heineman Seidman, cotton goods brokers, 245 Church Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Of the four basic elements of life carbon and nitrogen comprise less than 1 per cent of the earth's weight, hydrogen, mostly in oceans, is 1 1/2 per cent and only oxygen exists in abundance, according to Professor Henry Norris Russell, the Princeton astronomer.

A message from General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, to officers and men of the Jewish faith was read over the radio yesterday in a broadcast sponsored by the Jewish Welfare Board at the approach of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, which begins at sundown tomorrow.

THREE new, fat, interesting anthologies have been published within the week. Each has its peculiar merits, as should appear this morning has the three are taken up in alphabetical order.* It is a tradition in the trade that no reviewer ever reviews an anthology without managing to suggest in the course of things how much better he could have done had be been in the editors shoes. I shall try to resist the temptation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Influenced by the curtailment measures of the National Defense program, factory sales of automobiles, including commercial cars and trucks, were only one-third as many in August as they were during July, the Census Bureau reported today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Monday, Sept. 29 -- A strike of 17,000 C.I.O. workers in plants of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company was settled yesterday when Governor Frank Dixon ordered Home Guardsmen withdrawn.

An offering will be made today by Dillon, Read Co. and associates of 14,000 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock, $100 par value, and 125,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value of the Missouri Utilities Company. The preferred stock will be priced at $99 a share, plus accrued dividends, and the common stock at $13.50 a share.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- With a further rise of u1,650,000 just reported, the Bank of England's circulation has reached a new high record of u671,400,000, and the movement is continuing against the usual seasonal trend.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Sept. 29 -- The fifteenth week of the Russo-German conflict, began yesterday with the Soviet forces fighting tenaciously along the entire length of the front. Late Soviet reports mentioned further gains in the central sector, where Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces continue to make progress above Elnya and toward Gomel.

In a new decorative setting the Greenwich Presbyterian Church, 145 West Thirteenth Street, reopened its doors yesterday after having been closed all summer during reconstruction work on the exterior and interior of the edifice.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The White Sox finished third in the American League standing today as Lefty Thornton Lee shut out the challenging Tigers, 3 to 0. However, thanks to the Browns' conquest of Cleveland, Detroit tied with the Indians for fourth.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Czech Government authorities in London said today that increasing sabotage in former Czecho-Slovakia had slowed arms factory output as much as 50 per cent, blown up a number of German troop trains and disorganized transportation.

Too much emphasis on freedom and not enough on discipline is the "failure and folly" of this generation, the Rev. Dr. Edwin McNeill Poteat of the Euclid Avenue Baptist Church, Cleveland, declared yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Five Homeward Bound Monsieur Dionne will get his wish at last. He is to have the Quintuplets at home with him: Yvonne, Annette, Cecile, Emilie and Marie, all five. After seven years of entrusting them to the kindly care of Dr. Dafoe and the government, he shoulders the responsibility and prepares to welcome them to the parental hearth.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The markets generally have fallen into a waiting attitude pending further development of the Russian situation, which it is recognized has reached a critical stage. There is no despondency, but it is clear that what happens in Russia in the near future will have considerable repercussions on the general military situation, although none on the final outcome.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Small manufacturers must receive a share of defense orders if the national defense effort is to proceed at top speed and financial ruin of the concerns is to be avoided, Bradley D. Nash, financial consultant to the contract division of the Office of Production Management, said here today at the preliminary sessions of the sixty-seventh annual convention of the American Bankers Association.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Owing to the absence of all the usual prewar statistical data, Great Britain's trade progress can only be indicated now along very general lines.
The upland shooting season will get under way in New York on Wednesday in the northern part of the State, when woodcock become legal game.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Efforts to create bullish enthusiasm in corn last week met little success, as outside interest was light. Reports of damage by frost in some sections failed to bring buying orders, and a report that a large quantity of government-owned grain would be converted into alcohol for making munitions also failed to attract much attention.
Graft was assailed yesterday by the Rev. Francis X. Shea of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral as a long-standing "cancer of American public life."

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Haggin Perry of Cobham, Va., who brought a string of hunters to Long Island for the Piping Rock exhibition this week dropped a number of entries into the Brookville charity horse show today and were rewarded by carrying off the hunter championship with their chestnut gelding Cornish Hills, whom Mrs. Perry jumped in the various classes.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt opened a new radio series of comments on current events yesterday with an attack on isolationists "who for personal and selfish reasons insist on being blind and advocate a course which would destroy us as a nation, and which seems to endorse the principles which hold sway in other nations because their leaders consider them necessary to their national life."

Although new orders received by manufacturers in August failed to rise in the usual seasonal proportion, they remained enough above shipments to cause a slight rise in the backlog of unfilled orders, according to data compiled by the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Ted Williams and Pete Reiser won the batting championships of the American and National Leagues, respectively, according to unofficial figures compiled yesterday by The Associated Press. Williams, the Red Sox slugger, hit .4057 and the Dodger youngster .343. They are the youngest pair ever to win these crowns in the same year.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 28 -- Miss Marion Miley, 27 years old, nationally known golf star, was killed and her mother, Mrs. Fred Miley, was critically wounded just before dawn today by two masked men who invaded the secluded Lexington Country Club.

The cotton market receded substantially last week from the declines of the previous period. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed, at the close of trading on Saturday, net losses of 58 to 63 points for the period, compared with declines of 87 to 92 points in the week preceding.

WASHINGTON, Sept 28 -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, indicated today that the Administration would not push for amendment of the Neutrality Act until after the second Lease-Lend Bill is passed.

Philip H. Willkie, son of Wendell L. Willkie, and William C. MacPhail, son of Larry MacPhail of the champion Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team, will be among the thirty young college graduates who will be inducted into the Naval Reserve V-7 Midshipmen School this morning.

Farm income, which is one of the most important factors in the general business outlook, is almost certain to reach the highest total since 1929 and may be the largest in more than twenty years, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, a monthly review of business and financial conditions.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 -- Two million spindles, or 20 per cent of Japan's total, are idle as a result of the cessation of cotton imports from the United States, India and elsewhere, according to the newspaper Osaka Jiji The same paper reports that Japanese plans to import cotton from China are opposed by the Federation of Cotton Spinning Companies in China as unfeasible.

The revolt in conquered Europe at first seemed no more than a symbol of desperate resistance to intolerable oppression, a sign that the human spirit would rebel even where defiance seemed hopeless. Now sabotage in the conquered countries has reached a point which indicates some organized underground direction.

By grace of the Constitution of New Hampshire the voters of that State are asked every seven years if a convention should be called to revise that document. Experience has shown that it is much easier to call a convention than to get the people to ratify the amendments it has proposed.

In a bitter attack on Lawrence B. Elliman, chairman of the Committee on Taxation of the Real Estate Board of New York, Mayor La Guardia denied yesterday Mr. Elliman's assertion that real estate in the city was overassessed. The charge was first made by Lloyd Church, Democratic nominee for Controller, in his acceptance speech and denied the following day by the Mayor.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Second Army, Shreveport, La., Sept. 28 -- As the hot Southern sun sank in a red blaze above the Texas plains tonight, the concluding phase of the greatest manoeuvres in the country's history ended with Shreveport almost ringed by "enemy" forces.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- For the outstanding triumph of his career, Ch. Merrie Dip of Pastorale, imported Old English sheepdog owned by Mrs. Helen Margery Lewis of Great Barrington, Mass., today captured premier honors in the Westbury Kennel Association's annual all-breed exhibition at the J.S. Phipps estate.

Business and financial circles had last week something more than war news to digest and in one instance at least the dish was not very palatable. The unsavory morsel was the proposal of Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau that profits of industry for the present emergency in excess of 6 per cent of invested capital be taxed 100 per cent and that no ceiling be placed on wages.

MONTREAL, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A seven-run rally in the sixth inning brought the Montreal Royals, International League champions, a 9-6 victory over the Columbus Redbirds of the American Association today in the third game of the little world series.

Saturday, as the President declared, was a memorable day in the emergency defense of the nation. From dawn to dark fourteen new ships of the American merchant marine were launched, among them the first "liberty ship," the Patrick Henry. It was the largest launching of ships in this country in one day since the World War.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Mark Stuart of Winged Foot and Don Grant of the Rockaway Hunting Club won the annual Meadow Brook invitation four-ball golf tourney today, defeating William Gurney and Ted Bassett, the Winged Foot pair who beat the medalists yesterday

A Renoir centennial loan exhibition, including some of the most famous of the artists's paintings, will be held during November at the Duveen Galleries, 730 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of Free French Relief. Governor Herbert H. Lehman is honorary patron of the exhibition.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Emphasizing that all transportation facilities available should be employed to relieve the petroleum shortage in the East, Ralph Budd said today that the fullest use of tank cars would not be made until some way had been found to reimbuse "those who could use the railways for transportation of oil and gasoline."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Administration forces appeared today to be moving for a quick showdown on repeal or modification of the Neutrality Law so that American ships, under their own protection, may deliver lease-lend material directly to belligerent ports or wherever else they may be most effective in stopping Axis aggression.

Control of wages is not included in the pending Price Control Bill because workers cannot sit idly by while their living costs go out of sight, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said here last night. He addressed 800 manufacturers from the New York and New Jersey industrial districts at a "Preparedness Conference" sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt reported for duty this morning at the Office of Civilian Defense and assumed her new post as assistant director, the first government job ever held by the wife of a President of the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- The decision in the Bridges case was described by the Bridges Defense Committee today as "a direct slap at the labor movement, particularly the Congress of Industrial Organizations and its 5,000,000 members."

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29 -- Although isolationists in the ranks of the American Bar Association have begun what promises to be a week-long battle for their ideas, supporters of President Roosevelt's foreign policy appeared to have matters well in hand as the annual convention of the association opened today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Professional buying gave a moderate lift to wheat prices on the Board of Trade here today, in the face of news of a character to cause hesitation and selling under normal conditions. Heavy rains fell in parts of the Southwest where most needed, putting the soil in that region in good condition, and earlysown grain is described developing to a good stand.

One thousand and eighty high school boys and girls, most of whom had never before seen a stage presentation, attended a special matinee performance of "Life With Father" yesterday at the Empire Theatre.
PEKISKO CREEK, Alberta, Sept. 29 (U.P.) -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived today at the red-roofed ranch that he once described as "the only home I ever owned."

Wall Street felt yesterday the first serious impact of insurance competition in the underwriting field when three of the nation's largest insurance concerns, acting as a combination, outbid two powerful investment banking syndicates for $90,000,000 of American Telephone and Telegraph Company 2 3/4 per cent thirty-five-year debentures.

An underwriting syndicate of seventeen members headed by Shields Co. will offer today to the public a new issue of 29,000 $100-par-value shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc. The shares will be priced at $101 each, plus accrued dividend from Sept. 1, involving a total market value of $2,929,000.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- Timing the greatest wave of air raids in this war to coincide with the psychological shock of bread rationing, the British last night attacked ten Italian cities all the way from Northern Italy, through Sicily to the Dodecanese Islands.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 30 -- Red Army troops counter-attacking in the central and southern sectors have succeeded in breaking up German tank concentrations southwest of Bryansk and routing two brigades of Rumanian infantry in the Ukraine, ...

Lou Nova had an advantage of four ounces over Joe Louis for their fight at the Polo Grounds last night. The challenger weighed 202 1/2 pounds and the champion 202 1/4. Arthur Donovan was the referee, and the judges were Charley Draycott and Bill Healy.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept 29 -- The word has gone around that Andy Kerr is right back where he started at Colgate in 1929.

Robert L. Stott, chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, has appointed a board of arbitration which is to serve, commencing tomorrow, in place of the present arbitration committee. The action was taken with the approval of the Exchange's governors.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Sept. 29 -- A very acute need exists for more ships and more commercial planes to connect the East Indies and the Philippines, The few ships in service are mostly westbound and proceed from Manila to Batavia and Singapore and thence to Bombay, Cape Town and New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Air Associates, Inc., of Bendix, N.J. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 50,000 shares of $1.37 1/2 cumulative convertible preferred stock of no-par value and a maximum of 100,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value, the latter to be reserved for issuance upon conversion of the former stock.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Colby Hanover, owned by Eugene Frey of York, Pa., and driven by Fred Egan, registered hard-pressed straight heat victories today in capturing the $3,500 Kentucky Futurity at the Lexington Grand Circuit meeting.

Up at the empty Stadium yesterday the Yankee Bombers were testing their bomb sights and the Brooklyn "Bums" were throwing Jethal rights and lefts in preparation for the sanguinary battle that will open there at 1:30 tomorrow afternoon.

Many parties were given at the luncheon and fashion show entitled "Autumn Hours," held yesterday for the benefit of the Mobile Kitchen Division of the American Women's Voluntary Services at the formal luncheon opening at Le Coq Rouge for this season.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 29 -- A reign of terror is under way in Bulgaria, where a wave of executions, mass arrests and trials before courts-martial over the weekend precipitated new disorders and fresh sabotage in Sofia and the provinces, according to reports tonight from foreign diplomatic and military quarters here.

SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 29 -- The Army is still six months to a year short of being ready for combat service, according to evidence given by the largest and most successful manoeuvers in the country's history, which were completed yesterday.

A number of leases calling for large apartments were among the contracts for residential space reported yesterday by brokers as having been signed for quarters in buildings throughout the metropolitan area.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Sept. 30 -- An attempted revolt by a Czech Army group seeking to throw off German rule and restore independence in dismembered Czecho-Slovakia was disclosed today with the announcement that twenty-four persons, including three former generals, had been shot in Bohemia-Moravia on order of a German court-martial.

An admission by one of the defendants that he transmitted to Germany information on the shipment of United States war cargoes to Great Britain was read into the record yesterday as the Brooklyn espionage trial entered its fourth week.

Largely as a result of the efforts of Mayor La Guardia, the Repub- licans and both left and right wings of the American Labor party united last night on a Supreme Court slate for the First Judicial District, which includes Manhattan and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A ceiling on wages and farm prices, more taxes, and an over-all agency with full authority to fix general prices, were advocated today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as measures needed to halt "runaway inflation."

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt will hold a White House conference with Secretary Hull on revision of the Neutrality Act tomorrow at 10 A.M., soon after arriving in Washington from Hyde Park.

BERLIN, Sept, 29 -- German forces driving toward the Donets Basin and Kharkov, in the Eastern Ukraine, have beaten back strong Soviet counter-attacks and destroyed three Red Army divisions in a new battle of encirclement, the German High Command announced today.

Current activities of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board will be continued without "interruption or modification," it was stated yesterday by officials of the organization in commenting upon the complaint charging monopolistic practices, price-fixing and restraint of trade issued against it by the Federal Trade Commission.

Mrs. Wallace P. Cohoe, a 61-year-old grandmother of Riverdale-on-Hudson who expects within a week to obtain a private license to pilot her pontoon-equipped light monoplane, yesterday morning became the pioneer member in the State of the Maltese Falcons, a group of civilian fliers offering their planes and services to the Civil Air Guard of the Office of Civilian Defense.

Two more men connected with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes were accused yesterday, as the result of investigations by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa, of extorting money from movie producers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Following is the text of Marriner S. Eccles's statement prepared for presentation before the House Banking and Currency Committee's hearing today on price control legislation:

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Sept. 30 -- German forces under Col. Gen. Karl von Rundstedt, attacking the approaches to the Crimean Peninsula, have suffered a major defeat on the Perekop Isthmus, it was reported from Moscow last night.

The Sept. 6 issue of The Times Literary Supplement, London which reached here yesterday, is the special Autumn and Export number and is devoted to the ''debate on the era after the war." The large-sized issue, surveying the new Fall books, also contains special articles by J.B. Priestley, Hermon Oulds and Sir Bernard Pares.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Scenes of academic splendor and medieval pageantry marked the closing of the fiftieth anniversary celebration of the Unievrsity of Chicago today, with ceremonies including the awarding of honorary degrees to thirty-five scientists and scholars at a convocation addressed by President Robert M. Hutchins.

Vladimir Padwa, a member of the First Piano Quartet, which plays regularly for the radio, and heretofore an accompanist at many concerts, last night gave his first solo recital at Town Hall. The event, the first serious piano recital of the season, was attended by an audience of 1,200.

ROME, Sept. 29--The Italian Government today blocked for ten days, beginning tomorrow, all textile goods and wearing apparel in Italy. The measure, as explained in an official communique read to all Italians in a nation-wide broadcast, is preliminary to rationing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Another stage in the long fight between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Transamerica Corporation, a Giannini enterprise, was reached today in the commission's announcement that, on receipt of new information from the corporation, it had struck from its pending proceeding against the corporation seven particulars in regard to which it had charged the corporation with false and misleading statements.

Captain George Fried, supervising inspector here of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, Department of Commerce, announced yesterday at the inquiry into the collision between the tanker Robert L. Hopkins and the collier Jason in Ambrose Channel last Wednesday, an indefinite adjournment to obtain additional witnesses.
LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

The "inevitability" of a serious depression in the United States following the war was challenged yesterday by Robert R. Nathan, chief of the bureau of research and statistics of the OPM, in an address at the opening of the tenth annual convention of the Controllers Institute of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

An undeniable air of excitement pervades the small, cozy market that has put a fine shine on the cream-colored enamel of its brand-new meat case and announced to an astonished city that it will sell "a leg of lamb for two."

A syndicate headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., has received the award of $731,000 of general refunding bonds of North Arlington, N.J., on an interest cost basis of 3.77 per cent. The bid was 98.75 for $42,000 as 3s, $279,000 as 3 1/2 s and $410,000 as 3 3/4 s.

VICHY, France, Sept. 29 -- How is the campaign in Russia faring? Manifestly the respective communique's do not answer the question with any degree of precision. They are as contradictory as ever and the figures of losses they adduce are too appalling.

"Bowery Blitzkrieg," featuring Leo Gorcey, Bobby Jordan and Huntz Hall, will be the new feature today at the Rialto. The supplementary program will offer a pictorial account of last night's battle between Joe Louis and Lou Nova and "We Americans," a short sponsored by the Federal Housing Administration and narrated by Frank Craven.

Axis armies wait in Libya for the signal to attack Egypt. Reinforcements have been reaching them steadily. Despite the combined efforts of the R.A.F. and the British Navy, it is estimated that only about one-fourth of the ships carrying men, machines and munitions from Italy to this outpost of Mussolini's shattered empire have been destroyed.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Gifford will return from their Summer home in Spring Lake, N.J., tomorrow, and will be at the Savoy-Plaza until they go to Miami Beach.

The Junior Leagues of America made public yesterday the results of a survey of the training, skills and availability of the league members for America's defense program. The results were announced by Mrs. George V. Ferguson, president of the association, at the annual meeting of the board of directors being held this week at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The unexpected resignation of Dr. Frank L. Babbott as president of the Long Island College of Medicine, a post he has held for the last ten years, was announced yesterday at the institution's exercises opening the 1941-42 academic year.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentine, Sept. 29 -- The War Ministry has appointed General Jorge A. Giovaneli, inspector of infantry and commander of the Buenos Aires garrison, to investigate the unsuccessful military coup discovered last Tuesday and prosecute any officers or men considered guilty of acts of disaffection or breaches of discipline.
TOKYO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A conference between United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew and Foreign Minister Admiral Teijiro Toyoda on Saturday was disclosed to- day.

The stock market drifted yesterday in light trading and through a narrow range of prices, with volume on the Stock Exchange at 397,960 shares, the smallest figure since Aug. 29. On last Friday, the previous full trading period, the turnover was 486,380 shares.

The big question at the start of the evening at the Polo Grounds was whether or not Nova and Louis could fight enough to keep everybody warm. The weather was as chilly as a Giant rooter receiving news of the Dodger world series plans.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota issued a "warning" last night to Lewis W. Douglas, official of the New York Committee to Defend America, declaring that if Mr. Douglas did not maintain silence on national defense policy he would be haled before a Senatorial investigation into the business concern he heads.

The rush to buy liquor, furs, jewelry and cosmetics before the new 10 per cent Federal excise tax becomes effective was comparable yesterday to that of the week before Christmas. The new tax goes into effect tomorrow.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 29 -- The New Jersey women's golf team of fifteen continued to reign as champion of the metropolitan district by garnering 18 points to 15 for Westchester and 12 for Long Island in the Fall intersectional matches for the Myra D. Patterson Trophy over the Upper Montclair course today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

Eros has struck the Wakefield Gallery at 64 East Fifty-fifth Street, where an exhibition called "Love in Art" opened yesterday. However, the little chap's aim, it is to be feared, was but glancing, for the result proves far less erotic than so piquant a title may have led one to anticipate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Deportation of Harry R. Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader, on the grounds of membership in and affiliation with the Communist party, was recommended to Attorney General Biddle by Judge Charles B. Sears today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At a meeting of Fight for Freedom at the Harvard Club recently Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, Adviser to the Secretary of War, made an able speech on the defense situation. One part of it especially impressed this writer.
Joe Louis will go into Uncle Sam's Army next month the fighting heavyweight champion of the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Gross earnings of $446,750,000 for the six months ended on June 30 were announced today by Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, for the 5,136 national banks in the United States and possessions. This was an increase of $20,742,000, or about 5 per cent, over the corresponding period last year.

Fight and baseball fans, together with vacationists here for the opening of football, night club and theatrical seasons, took over the city last night on a scale that spokesmen for the hotel industry declared had not been equaled since the convention of the American Legion.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Anton Bundsnann, New York stage director, was signed today by Paramount. His first picture will be "Doctor Broadway," by Borden Chase, which is expected to go before the cameras next month.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Britain has built an anti-Axis front reaching through Asia Minor to the left flank of the Russian armies of the Caucasus, it was announced officially today, and detailed arrangements for cooperation between empire forces there and in India have been worked out.

SOME of these Brooklyn rooters are too hot to handle, but this interested bystander came across a cool one yesterday. He gave the Yankees all the best of it on form, statistics and previous condition of servitude, but stuck calmly to his conclusion that Durocher's Dandies would run over the Yankees.

Under the stimulus of trade and mill buying, which was in more substantial volume than in the few preceding sessions, the cotton market yesterday erased some of its losses of last week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange touched their best levels around noon with net gains of 27 to 31 points, but the market subsequently quited down, and final quotations were at net advances of 18 to 26 points.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 30 -- The three-power conference of the United States, Britain and Russia, designed to facilitate material aid to Russia's armed forces in the war against Germany, opened here yesterday afternoon.

What They Dodged What is it that the Brooklyn Dodgers are supposed to dodge? Some of the younger people may be thinking that the Dodgers got their name from dodging pop bottles at Ebbets Field, victims of poor marksmanship.

The city trading reported yesterday indicated a continued interest in loft properties. Two such buildings changed hands, one in the textile district going to an investor and another on the fringe of Greenwich Village going to a group headed by an operator.

The New York Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms each received yesterday a telegram from A.W. Mansfield, chairman of the National Committee of Stock Exchange Partners, approving a plan to reorganize the association as a national trade body.
Brooklyn yesterday was a bor- ough of bedlam in an extraordinary hysterical victory parade for the Beloved Bums, winners of the 1941 National League baseball pennant.
Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that the city's low-cost housing program may be held up temporarily because of steel shortages caused by the national defense effort.

Whirlaway, regarded as the top horse of 1940, is almost certainly through for the season, although there is a faint possibility he will appear in a special race against War Relic on Friday, it was learned yesterday at Belmont Park, where 12,397 persons watched The Rhymer win the featured Martimas Purse.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Hugh Byas, in his plea for patience with Japan, says that the Japanese alliance with Germany "has been of little value to Hitler." Yet he points out that Singapore bristles with men and guns, planes and submarines, and that Japan cannot attack Russia "unless the Far Eastern Red Army is withdrawn."

HAZLETON, Pa., Sept. 29 -- With their ranks increased to 30,000, dues-striking members of the United Mine Workers of America, C.I.O., made plans tonight to pull the 70,000 other miners in the anthracite field from their jobs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Sept. 24 aggregated $10,061,000,000.

Trading in fresh meats was generally fair yesterday. Fresh pork cuts sold steady to lower. Other classes were generally steady. Demand for kosher meats was slow during the early hours but salesmen expected a reasonably active late market at steady prices. Because of the Jewish holiday tomorrow the slaughter of those classes usually dressed "kosher" was below normal.

When the American Export liner Excambion, carrying 134 passengers from Europe to the United States, was six hours out of Lisbon on Sept. 20, a huge four-motored Nazi bomber roared out of the north, circled the ship once and disappeared in the direction from which it had come, it was learned yesterday when the ship arrived here.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 29 -- German Ambassador Franz von Papen conferred for an hour and fifteen minutes this afternoon with Turkish Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu, the Foreign Affairs Under-Secretary, and Dr. Karl Clodius, the chief of Germany's trade mission to Ankara.

Henry Hof, operator, has returned to active participation in Manhattan realty trading with the purchase of the old Eimer Amend property on the east side of Third Avenue, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets, for close to a century the headquarters of the drug firm.

There has been no lack of urgent warnings from Administration spokesmen of the imminent dangers of inflation. But in nearly all these warnings inflation has been treated as though it were some natural calamity like a hurricane. The Administration wants the power to nail down certain sections of the price structure, but it resolutely ignores the primary causes of the storm and its own responsibility for them.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 29 -- If fascism comes to this country it will stem from the South, Dr. Malcolm Boyd Dana, president of Piedmont College, warned 200 New England women leaders in federated club work today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Efforts of consumers to forestall restrictions on installment sales and new taxes depleted retail stores and sent buyers into the Chicago wholesale market on a contraseasonal scale, the August survey of the Merchandise Mart showed today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 29 -- In the fourth report, to be presented to the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow, the investigating committee on foreign influences takes up the subject of foreign schools, pointing to the "insidious ability with which they are used by Nazis for influencing the minds of Argentine youth."
BERLIN, Sept. 29 (AP) -- This communique was issued today from headquarters of Reichsfuehrer Hitler:

BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- Six Czechs have already been executed under the "state of civilian emergency" decreed by Reinhard Heydrich, as Deputy Reich Protector of Bohemia-Moravia. It is and will continue difficult to judge from Berlin the extent of the anti-German uprising.

THE great mystery is at last beginning to come clear, the mystery of the fall of the French Republic. It is still difficult enough to understand and explain every item and detail, but witnesses are appearing one by one. The latest witness is Arthur Koestler, distinguished author of "Darkness at Noon." His shocking and absorbing report is called "Scum of the Earth."*

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Doctors strove tonight to save the life of Mrs. Elsa Ego Miley, 50 years old, wounded by two masked gunmen who killed her daughter, Marion, 27, nationally known golf star, as police pushed their thus far fruitless hunt for the slayers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Contracts totaling $5,188,699 were awarded today by the War Department. Firms in the New York and New Jersey areas receiving awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The private explanation given by candid defense chiefs for the failure of the administration to press for a true price control bill is cynical. Also, it is incompatible with the public demands on all citizen groups to sacrifice with a spirit worthy of the times and realistic as to the perilous alternative.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Receipts of cattle at twelve principal markets expanded to 102,700 head today, the largest in eleven months, compared with 99,000 a week ago, and 100,000 a year ago. Salable arrivals in Chicago were 17,000 head.
ROME, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this special communique today:

In comparing the Yankees and Dodgers on the offense and sizing up the managerial capabilities and general tactics of their respective pilots, one again finds these two world series rivals offsetting each other to a surprising degree. So much so that most of the experts seem unable to reconcile these facts with the manner in which the Yanks have been installed such overwhelming favorites.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen entertained at dinner at Wakehurst this evening for Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who leaves tomorrow for New York, closing Beaulieu.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Secretary Morgenthau told his press conference today that although his assistants were preparing a bill to limit corporation profits to 6 per cent on invested capital it would not be submitted to Congress before January and would not be made retroactive to apply to 1941 profits.

Competition It cannot be said that the underwriting community was taken by complete surprise yesterday when a small group of life insurance companies stepped in and purchased $90,000,000 of American Telephone and Telegraph Company 2 3/4 per cent debentures in competition with two investment banking groups, but it can be said that the full realization of what this trend means to the industry came as a stunning shock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Revision of entry visa regulations in the light of their operation since July 1, and especially of "Form K," which has been protested by lawyers as a reflection on the legal profession, is under consideration by the State Department.

Tonight, for the first time in his career, the name of George S. Kaufman will grace a theatrical program as a Broadway producer. The play is "Mr. Big," opening at the Lyceum, in which Mr. Kaufman also has a proprietary interest.

Two hundred women here volunteered yesterday to knit sweaters for men in the defense forces, bringing the number of volunteers for a knitting program started last week by the New York Red Cross chapter up to several thousand, according to the chapter's executive director, General Robert C. Davis.

The mail-order firm of Sears, Roebuck Co. is enlarging its quarters in the building at 345 Hudson Street by two floors, adding about 85,000 square feet to the floor space occupied there by their offices, stockroom and shipping departments.

A proposal of the Consumers Counsel that a maximum be established beyond which the Bituminous Coal Division of the Department of the Interior must not advance coal prices has met with wide support among industrial companies in the New York area, and it was indicated here yesterday that strong representations will be made in Washington backing the proposal.

VICHY, France, Sept. 29 -- There were no developments here today in regard to French-German "collaboration." Nor are there likely to be -- outwardly -- for some time. Yet it is manifest that relations between France and Germany once again dominate all other problems.

Yom Kippur, most solemn day in the Jewish year, will begin at sundown today and continue through sundown tomorrow. In temples and synagogues throughout the city thousands of worshipers will mark with appropriate prayer and meditation their Day of Atonement.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Asking for an end of the Republicans' forty-year control of Westchester County government Schuyler B. Patterson. Democratic candidate for County Executive charged tonight at the annual reorganization meeting of the County Democratic Committee that the Republicans had mismanaged county affairs and were issuing "utterly false figures" to conceal their alleged misdeeds.

Every one who had the foresight to bring a topcoat to the Polo Grounds last night aroused the envy of those who had neglected, willfully or otherwise, this little detail. It was cold, not unbearably, but cold. And besides the topcoats there were sweaters, extra vests, gloves and other warm articles of apparel to be seen everywhere in the crowd.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- A system of wage payments for the emergency which would involve wage dividends or profit-sharing or, as an alternative, supplemental compensation adjusted to the cost of living scale was proposed here today for the consideration of business and labor by Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Sept. 29 -- Quotations on the Bourse here today reflected a marked recovery from their relapse levels of last week.

Movement of motor traffic through Central Park was facilitated further yesterday when Stanley M. Isaacs, President of the Borough of Manhattan, formally opened two new spurs to the Ninety-seventh Street Transverse Road. One spur will serve as an entrance and the other as an exit, and both are designed to double the capacity of the transverse road.
The sea coot, or scoter, shooting off the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound is improving every day and, according to several observers along this area, the birds are increasing by the hour.

About three years after its London premiere, "Ghost for Sale" took up residence in the Sixtythird Street Theatre last evening as the first production of the Daly's Theatre Stock Company. A lot of bombs have fallen out of the sky since April 10, 1938.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 24 (Delayed) -- Captain J.C. Mackenzie of the torpedoed freighter Pink Star told today of the heroism of the Canadian second officer, J.L, "Jim" Cassidy, who gave up his life so as not to overcrowd a lifeboat.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Strong forces of Royal Air Force bombers, operating from bases in Britain, battered Genoa, Turin and other points in Northern Italy early today. An Air Ministry communique told of attacks on Genoa, Turin "and elsewhere in Northern Italy," but did not specify what places were meant by "elsewhere."

Buses will replace trolley cars on the Gates Avenue line in Brooklyn next Sunday, according to a Board of Transportation announcement yesterday. Motorization of this route means complete bus transportation on Fulton Street from Rockaway Avenue to Borough Hall.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has just acquired one of the most important paintings to come into its collection -- "The Starry Night," by the famous modern artist Vincent van Gogh.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- Three British cruisers and three merchant ships were sunk and nine other ships were damaged Saturday by torpedo-launching planes in one of the heaviest aero-naval battles of the war in the Mediterranean, a special communique announced this afternoon.

Store Sales Here 17% Higher Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 17 per cent for the week ended Sept. 20 over the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

There was plenty of action in the set of preliminary bouts supporting the championship event at the Polo Grounds last night. In the eight-round semi-final Lenny (Boom Boom) Mancini, 136 1/2, Youngstown, Ohio, gained the decision over Terry Young, 132, East Side.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Shotgun blasts within earshot of the village schoolyard ended the lives this morning of James Monte, a local business man, and Mrs. Doris Croyle, his bookkeeper and wife of a civilian employe at West Point.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 27:
ROME, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Today's regular communique of the Italian High Command follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Donald M.
