Nelson, Director of Priorities of the Office of Production Management, today issued an interpretation explaining how inventor ymaterials may be used to fill orders bearing preference ratings and under which preference ratings may be used by a supplier to obtain needed materials.

Joe Louis was his usual calm, patient self as he submitted to a flood of questions sent at him in his dressing room after his victory over Lou Nova at the Polo Grounds last night. Joe tried to answer all and did a pretty good job of it in his slow, matter-of-fact way.

With Adam Spiegel, wingback who broke his collarbone in scrimmage last Saturday, out for at least six weeks, and probably for the season, Columbia faced the problem of fashioning a backfield from five players yesterday at Baker Field.

In accepting the Democratic nomination for President of the City Council, Transit Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig last night rebuked Mayor La Guardia for his alleged use of personal vilification to besmirch those who criticize his administration and taxed Newbold Morris, the present President of the City Council, with slavish obedience to the Mayor's wishes.

BERLIN, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The British-American-Russian conferences now being held in Moscow, German spokesmen asserted today were hard pressed for time because of a growing realization that aid for Soviet Russia must be swift if it is to be effective.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 29 -- The British now face the possibility of war in the Pacific "without anxiety," Vice Admiral Sir Geoffrey Layton, Commander in Chief of the British fleet based on Singapore, told this correspondent today in an interview at his shore headquarters at the famous Singapore naval base.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt called today upon all professional and volunteer recreation workers and their agencies to strengthen their services in the emergency, declaring that the nation was no stronger than its morale.

Three years ago today Prime Minister Chamberlain was telling cheering crowds in Downing Street that he had "returned from Germany, bringing peace with honor." He had joined with Hitler in a solemn statement that "we regard the agreement signed last night and the Anglo-German naval agreement as symbolic of the desire of our two peoples never to go to war with one another again."

Captain Henry William Urquhart McCall, commander of the British light cruiser Dido, one of twelve British warships now being repaired in United States ports, for the first time gave a first-person story yesterday about his ship in action off the Island of Crete and also in other engagements including six months of convoy work, involving the safe delivery of hundreds of vessels loaded with freight for Great Britain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the editorial "Birds and Hard Winters" you mentioned that many of us cherish the belief that birds, muskrats, beavers and certain kinds of trees are able to predict the weather much farther ahead and better than the Weather Bureau.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill, speaking today on the committee stage of the supply vote of credit for L1,000,000,000 said to the House of Commons:

Jaeckel's presented its new collection of furs yesterday afternoon, with Tracy Jaeckel delivering the message of the new collection. We've kept our coats ultra-simple and minus all chi-chi as an antidote to the glitter of dresses," he announced.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey began yesterday the oral delivery of his ruling on whether, as the government has asked, the Aluminum Company of America will have to be broken up into several divisions.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 30 -- A twosome composed of Miss Grace Amory of Cedar Creek and Mrs. Alexander Cushing of Piping Rock took top honors in the third annual women's Long Island four-ball, best-ball match play tournament over the Cedar Creek course today.

There was quite a bit of excitement off Beach Haven, N.J., over the week-end and on Monday when several of the boats came in with larger catches of bluefish than have been taken in this area in many years.

Textiles, Inc. Textiles, Inc., which emerged from receivership last week, has declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the 4 per cent preferred stock, payable on Oct. 1 to holders of record of Sept. 30, and a dividend of 10 cents on the common stock, payable on Oct. 15 to stock of record of Oct. 8.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 -- Amid a heavy barrage of heckling questions at the end of his luncheon address before the Town Hall today Senator Wheeler told his critics "to go back to Europe and join the British Army and fight."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A 10,000,000-ton steel expansion program won today the approval of the Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board, new defense agency headed by Vice President Wallace.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- John Carmody, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, was confronted today with making a decision on which may hinge a general strike in Michigan of all mechanics in the American Federation of Labor building trades unions.

The poor wretch who prides himself on being realistic says that two gangs of mercenaries will meet this afternoon at the Yankee Stadium. What, he will inquire, glancing bitterly at the passing throngs, is Manhattan or Brooklyn to them? Aren't they bought and sold like horses?

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had notified Sheriff Daniel E. Finn Jr. of New York County to take action on a report by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, that embezzlements and alterations of official records had been found in the Sheriff's office.
Having successfully defended his world heavyweight title for the nineteenth time and exhausted the visible supply of worthy challengers, Joe Louis is looking forward to enjoying life in the Army.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Thirteen Italian aircraft were destroyed last Saturday when a force of Axis planes attacked a British convoy in the Central Mediterranean, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Commons today.

Before dawn yesterday 9,000 soldiers of the Twenty-sixth Division, bumping and jolting in 1,163 Army vehicles and trying to keep warm against the chill of early day, passed through the city en route from Camp Edwards, Mass., to the "wars" being held in the Carolinas by the First Army.

BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- Winter may hold up Germany's military operations on the Eastern Front, but the Reich's armies will be in a better position to live through the coming cold months than the Russians, it is asserted by Colonel Scherff of the German General Staff in an editorial article widely published in the German press today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Declaring that the increase of employment in the first year of the defense program has been of record-breaking proportions, Secretary of Labor Perkins reported today that total civil non-agricultural employment in August amounted to 39,542,000.

Speaking in the House of Commons yesterday on the progress of the war, Mr. Churchill said in effect that matters were proceeding so satisfactorily for the British cause that it would be criminal irresponsibility to tempt fate by undertaking any rash adventure on the Continent of Europe at this time.
MR. BIG, a "new comedy" by Arthur Sheekman and Margaret Shane. Setting by Donald Oenslager: staged and produced by George S. Kaufman. At the Lyceum Theatre.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is on the "threshold" of the final stage in the accomplishment of integration and simplification of pubic utility holding companies in accordance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, Robert H. O'Brien, director of the commission's utilities division, declared yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 30 -- John R. Fell proved his ability as a golfer as well as a polo player and an aviator today.
CAIRO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The R.A. F. Middle East Command communique today said:

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- A Department of Agriculture report showing a fairly general increase in the parity prices of grains between Aug. 15 and Sept. 15 had a minor effect on the markets early today, but the buying was mainly of a professional character, and when some of the buyers tried to secure profits they found support lacking.

The government's case against Josef August Klein, 37-year-old commercial photographer, who with fifteen others is accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government, opened yesterday with the reading of a statement purportedly made by Klein to government agents in which he admitted that the activities of several of his co-defendants had aroused his "suspicions" that they were violating the espionage laws of the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Price inflation, credit inflation, currency inflation, wage inflation, public-debt inflation, and so on may be different aspects of the same thing, as your correspondent Willard D. Arant contends. But as, the term inflation is loosely used, its several meanings are as far apart as the poles.

SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 30 -- Lack of discipline and effective command were cited today by Lieut.-General Lesley McNair as two of the major faults revealed by the second phase of the greatest war games in the nation's history.

A warning against "working with the 1 per cent of the student body" of City College that has caused the institution to be branded as "Red" was sounded yesterday to 900 freshmen by John R. Turner, dean of men.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Appointment of Mrs. Ethel P. Hasselkorn of Poughkeepsie as associate field representative of the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration in New York and New England was announced today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 1-- German raiders were spotted after dark last night over the northeast coast of England, where they dropped incendiary and explosive bombs, killing, some persons and injuring others, and destroying or damaging houses and other buidings.

Every resource at the command of the New York Zoological Society, "backed by the active collaboration of the Commissioner of Parks," was pledged toward the creation of an "impressive and beautiful" new aquarium yesterday by Fairfield Osborn, president of the society.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- Premier Joseph Stalin received W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the United States delegation, and Lord Beaverbrook, head of the British mission, for the third time last evening after the first full day of committee sessions on aid to Russia had concluded.

Prize lists for the National Horse Show to be held in Madison Square Garden Nov. 5 to 12, inclusive, were sent to exhibitors throughout the country yesterday. The program is made up of 119 competitive events for many types of show horses, including hunters, jumpers, saddle horses, hackneys, heavy harness horses and ponies.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the second largest of the year and the volume of 13,544,841 shares for September, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, compared with the 11,940,530 shares that were turned over in the corresponding month of last year (the dullest September since 1918) and with 10,375,370 shares traded in August.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Amendments relaxing, in the case of railroad reorganizations, its rules for the registration of unissued securities for "when issued" dealing on national securities exchanges were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Resignations of two of the public representatives on the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange were announced yesterday by Emil Schram, president, Curtis E. Calder and Roswell Magill both have found, they declared in letters to Mr. Schram, that they can no longer spare the time that the position demands.

Baseballs bounced around once again in empty stands at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the apparently carefree Dodgers an Yankees belted batting-practice pitches in their just-before-the battle workouts over a stretch of four hours.

"Best Foot Forward," the first new musical of the season, will be presented tonight by George Abbott at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. The book of the musical was written by John Cecil Holm and has to do with the visit of a Hollywood star, portrayed by Rosemary Lane, to a boys' preparatory school.

There will be 11.8 per cent more freight cars loaded in the last three months of 1941 than there were in the same period last year, according to an estimate by the thirteen Shippers' Advisory Boards issued yesterday. All the boards forecast increases for the period.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- D.N.B., official German news agency, said today that among those executed in Bohemia-Moravia were Professor Vladimir Groh of the University of Bruenn, Dr. Vojtec Jilek of Bruenn and numerous Jews -- all charged with preparation of high treason and sabotage.

TRENTON, Sept. 30 -- Soon after the Democratic State Convention adopted here today a platform calling for a constitutional convention to draft a new State constitution, as advocated by Governor Charles Edison, the Republican State Convention voted down, 86 to 23, a proposed Similar plank.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 -- Thirty-seven thousand automobile workers here were made idle today when wildcat strikes caused the closing of the main Dodge plant, the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation, and the Briggs Manufacturing Company's Mack Avenue plant.
Of seventeen minor league players chosen at the major league draft meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt last night, only two were picked by local clubs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull made an extended review of the international situation today.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The Battle of the Atlantic is definitely swinging in Britain's favor, Prime Minister Winston Churchill indicated today in an address to the House of Commons that was optimistic in its general tone.

President Roosevelt declared for the maintenance of a free press "against all assaults" as a "fundamental obligation" of American patriotism in a message yesterday in praise of National Newspaper Week, which begins today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Mindful of the physical afflictions that blighted his team's hopes a year ago, Ossie Solem might reasonably be absolved of any intent to deceive when he hesitates to commit himself on Syracuse's outlook this Fall.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- The Red Army, continuing strong counter-attacks on the northern front, has recaptured a strategically important city a considerable distance from Leningrad and has reoccupied several villages, it was reported today as the official spokesman, S.A. Lozovsky, said that the military situation around the former capital might be described as "improved."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- A recent forty-eight-hour sea battle in the North Atlantic, from which British warships emerged "successfully," was described in guarded language today by Captain Harold Drew, commander of the Manchester, a British cruiser of 9,400 tons, which has put in at the Philadelphia Navy Yard for refitting.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in September amounted to $219,772,000, compared with $74,602,000 in the preceding months and with $171,198,000 in September, 1940. Last month's total was the largest for any September since 1939, when $383,440,000 in bonds was retired.
BERLIN, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

R.L. Clause, president of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, in a letter to stockholders accompanying the dividend of $1 a share payable today, says that the company "is becoming increasingly affected by the national defense program, both from the growing scarcity of certain raw materials and rapidly rising taxes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The three major and challenging tasks now faced by the United States -- namely, speeding up of defense, the readjustment from nondefense to defense activities, and the avoidance and disruption of inflation -- have as their basis "the real problem, which is more political than economic," according to the report of the economic policy commission of the American Bankers Association delivered at the association's annual convention here today.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 30 -- As a preliminary to the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship, the organization's amateur-pro title golf tourney was staged today on the Rockville Country Club course.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 30 -- Americans are too dependent on the many luxuries which democracy has provided and are unwilling to give them up and work for a defense program which they believe may not be needed, Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, asserted here tonight.

In most parts of Europe today people who say things that governments, or friends of governments, don't like can be arrested, deprived of the necessities of life, tortured or shot. These measures quiet them. We don't think Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota would care to see the same measures applied here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Contracts totaling $7,017,815 were awarded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:
LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

In the dispute between Mayor La Guardia on the one hand and Justice Church and Mr. Elliman on the other over the assessed valuation of real estate in the city neither side has squarely met the arguments of the other. But the Mayor has certainly shown to least advantage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Fourteen of the largest associations of coat and suit manufacturers who do some 90 per cent of this trade in the United States, the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board to which they belong, and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with conspiracy to monopolize the sale of women's and children's clothing.

Mrs. Robert L. Gerry Jr., as a member of the general ball committee, and Miss Wendy Iglehart, chairman of the junior committee, are among the many young women of society who have been actively aiding preparations for the gala anniversary ball to be given tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the United Service Organizations.

The trading pace was slow yesterday. Because of the Jewish holiday a large number of the local sales coolers will close early today and will not be open again until tomorrow. The slaughter houses will finish kosher activity around noon and there will be no kosher kill today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 30 -- Italy will send three divisions, including four Blackshirt battalions, to the Russo-German front in a compromise on Germany's demand for ten divisions, according to disclosures this evening by high foreign diplomatic circles here.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 1 (AP) -- How British warships, including the damaged battleship Nelson, beat off wave after wave of Italian torpado planes in a furious battle lasting just an hour was related early today by a special correspondent of Reuter's news agency who was aboard the aircraft carrier Ark Royal.

Blase New York, which long since had come to regard itself as fully capable of taking a world series right in stride, found itself gripped last night in a baseball fever which threatened to reach alarming proportions.

Urging companies not to scuttle a major investment in salesmen for the sake of a few years of defense business, Robert E. Anderson, advertising and sales promotion manager of the National Gypsum Company, yesterday stressed the necessity of maintaining sales forces intact and of bolstering the morale of salesmen against the time when priorities are a thing of the past.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 30 -- Calling for repeal or modification of the Neutrality Act, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, asked tonight at a dinner of the American Bar Association whether the time had not come "to throw all our resources into the fight against Hitlerism."

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- A Polish Army is being formed east of the Ural Mountains by the new Polish High Command, working in collaboration with Soviet authorities. This army, which is expected to consist of several divisions plus reserves, is commanded by General Wladyslaw Anders, who was appointed to the task by Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski on Aug. 4.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Alice Silverthorne De Trafford, who figured in a shooting in a train compartment in Paris in 1927, was found shot to death today in her farmhouse at Gilgil, Kenya Colony. Precise circumstances of the death were not known here.

Buyer Registration Up in Week Out-of-town buyers registered in the market last week numbered 653, against 508 in the previous week and 800 in the same period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 212, which compared with 47 for a week ago.

Lord and Lady Halifax, who departed from Horta, the Azores, at 1:58 P.M. Eastern standard time yesterday, are scheduled to arrive at the seaplane base at La Guardia Field at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon aboard the Dixie Clipper, commanded by Captain William A. Winston, it was announced by Pan American Airways yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J, Sept. 30 -- As Administration forces in Congress prepare their drive to modify or repeal the Neutrality Act, there has been a sharp increase in public sentiment for allowing American merchant ships to carry war materials to Britain -- a step now prohibited by the act.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Eugene Phipps of Englewood, N.J., gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of their marriage. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hall, Mr. and Mrs. John I. Bentley, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Doherty, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Bomer and Mr. and Mrs. William Eldridge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Secretary Morgenthau's proposal to limit corporate profits to 6 per cent drew fresh opposition today from Senator Vandenberg, who called the plan "an attempt by indirection to repeal the capitalistic system."

The Ultimate Challenger On the eve of a fight in which Joe Louis defends his title the newspapers print at the head of a column the familiar conspectus. Once more it is shown how Louis compares with Nova in age, weight, height, and so on, through chest and biceps down to size of fist, thigh and ankle, to the extent of fifteen items.

The only hope for a lasting world peace is for the United States to start a peace offensive and negotiate a peace that would be founded on an association of all nations, John Cudahy, former United States Ambassador to Belgium, declared last night at a dinner of the Citizens Peace Petition Committee at the Town Hall Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The government ordered makers of household mechanical refrigerators today to cut production for the last five months of 1941 to a level of 43.2 per cent under the average monthly output for the year which ended June 30, and warned that reductions in 1942 would probably be greater.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Independent retail store sales, led by the durable goods lines, advanced 23 per cent during August over the corresponding month last year, the Census Bureau reported today on the basis of returns from 23,679 firms in 34 States, covering most kinds of business except department stores.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The average price of hogs fell below $11 a hundred pounds on die livestock market today as heavy receipts forced quotations down as much as 15 cents. Salable arrivals amounted to 15,000 head. which was 4,000 above advance estimates and constituted the second largest daily supply since early July.

AT last, after all these years, the Dodgers are in a world series again! The Anti-Noise drive in New York has been unofficially suspended for the duration. Brooklyn rooters are the loudest on the big league circuit. The Dodger club is magnificently vocal from President Larry MacPhail down to Babe Hamburger, the clubhouse protector of loose valuables.

A wife put in a one-minute long-distance phone call to her husband shortly after noon yesterday and as a result seventy-seven trailers were expected to be burning up the road to Seneca County soon to meet an acute housing shortage on a defense project.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- The major part of Italian consumer goods are under purchase and sales ban and will be rationed, Italians learned this morning when they read partial lists of restricted objects in the newspapers. [Here four lines were censored.]

After a two-hour secret practice yesterday, the second in two days, Jim Crowley named his first-string eleven for the 1941 Fordham gridiron season opener with S.M.U. here Saturday. The team is composed of two sophomores, three juniors and six seniors.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Sept. 30 -- The volume on the Bourse today was light and the market was steady to firm. Royal Dutch was comparatively active and rose 3 1/2 points to 324 1/4 and A.K.U. was up 2 to 143 1/8. Otherwise the changes were mostly fractional. The shipping shares were active. Bonds were firm with a keen demand.

President James M. Wood of Stephens College yesterday entered a blanket indictment against the system of education of American women. Or more precisely, against its inability to prepare the mothers of future generations to meet the problems of their own lives and to instruct their children how to live a rounded and useful existence.

Floods of mail have been pouring into the offices of The Exchange, publication of the New York Stock Exchange, since it published, in its most recent issue, a list of sixty-five stocks which have been paying dividends continuously for periods of twenty-five to forty years.
A Domestic Relations Court justice, several titled figures of European social and diplomatic circles and a number of stage notables were among the lessees of residential quarters listed yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 -- The need for improved health and morale, as basic factors of defense not only against external dangers but against economic insecurity within the country after the emergency, was impressed upon the National Recreation Congress at its session today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The issue of $5,000,000 of trustees' certificates by trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation to implement its recent tax-settlement operation with the Federal Government was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

"Beat-the-tax" buying of furs, jewelry and cosmetics, on which 10 per cent retail excise taxes go into effect today, spread yesterday into a general buying spree that carried department-store and other retail sales figures far above a year ago.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 30 -- German heavy artillery is shelling villages in Western Serbia as reprisals against Serbian guerrillas and in their attempts to smash the resistance of Serbian Chetnik warfare, according to reports from foreign military intelligence sources here this evening.

CONWAY, N.H., Sept. 30 -- The hunt for 5-year-old Pamela Hollingworth took a new turn tonight as a belief was expressed that the child might have been carried from the woods after she wandered from a family picnic on Sunday.

The municipal bond market, which has been more or less in the doldrums recently because of the scant supply of new issues, took on new life yesterday with an impressive demonstration of investor demand when a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. offered for sale a new issue of $9,000,000 of refunding and improvement bonds of the State Roads Commission of Maryland.

To analyze current attacks on advertising, to present sound answers to them and to determine a proper course to take, the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies will jointly sponsor a meeting to be held at the Homestead, Hot Springs, Va., on Nov. 13, 14 and 15, it was announced yesterday.

Sherry parties were as much a part of the comfortable and cozy post and pre-war scene in England as Mr. Chamberlain's umbrella and Her Majesty's hats. A happy compromise between the sometimes stuffy afternoon tea and the often indecorous cocktail party these convivial gatherings were particularly prevalent in the literary quarters of Soho and the academic confines of the great universities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Roosevelt plans to send a special message to Congress soon requesting that the social security program be enlarged to provide protection for a much greater number of individuals than are now covered.

MANILA, Sept. 30 -- As indications multiply that the tentative American-Japanese parleys in Washington will result in a stalemate, inner circles in Tokyo and other key centers in the Far East are already expecting another Japanese Cabinet overturn, with Prince Fumimaro Konoye probably surviving as Premier and with the reemergence of Yosuke Matsuoka and his adherents in places of high authority, backed by extremists.

The re-emergence of Italy into the news is a sure sign that the winds of war are blowing south. During the long Summer months, while the Germans were throwing their massed man power and air force into the endless morass of Russia, a strange quiet brooded over the Italian peninsula.

Asserting that "Hitler and the Axis powers are licked now," Mayor La Guardia yesterday urged 2,000 students and parents attending the cornerstone laying of the new Machine and Metal Trades High School to turn their attention to post-war problems.

Eighty-four million persons have visited the Aquarium at Battery Park since the New York Zoological Society took it under its wing -- or possibly one should say its fin -- in 1902. How many visited the site when it was Castle Garden, Castle Clinton and the Southwest Battery no one knows.

Mayor La Guardia virtually challenged the Democrats yesterday to get going in the Mayoralty race, with the promise that he would answer anything that the had to say. His declaration came several hours after a statement had been made at Democratic campaign headquarters that William O'Dwyer, the party's Mayoralty nominee, would make an important radio speech tonight.

Marshall Field's Up the Hill, a daughter of Jacopo and coupled in the betting with W.H. LaBoyteaux's Imperatrice, yesterday won the $17,050 Ladies Handicap, which had its seventy-first running at Belmont Park.

Low interest rates are "highly inflationary" and tend to defeat many of the government's objectives during the present emergency, Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University and chairman of the Citizen's Emergency Committee, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The New England Gas and Electric Association was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to answer the recent report of the commission's staff that its corporate structure is unduly and unnecessarily complicated, and a hearing was called for Oct. 29 to determine what steps should be taken to correct this condition.

Charges that Joseph Flaherty, assistant deputy sheriff, and members of his family voted in the Democratic primary election in the First Assembly Distict, although their residence was outside the district, were made yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer at the opening of court hearings in the contest between Carmine Di Sapio and Sheriff Daniel B. Finn over the Democratic leadership in the First Assembly District West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The 10 per cent cut in gasoline deliveries in the Atlantic Coast area was continued for October and made mandatory in an order issued today by the Office of Production Management. It was extended to apply for the first time to taxicabs and delivery trucks.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho in an interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES today said he would regard the expected settlement between Mexico and the United States as the touchstone of the Good Neighbor policy.

Offering's to the public of new securities in the New York market during September ran to a total of $104,248,000, the emissions consisting of $85,273,000 in forty-five bond issues and $18,975,000 in ten stock issues. This showing compares with $120,441,000 in the preceding month, when $114,417,000 was placed through twenty-seven bond issues and $6,024,000 in three stock offerings.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 30 -- Continuing the series of daylight raids that lately have taken a heavy toll of Axis supplies, equipment and personnel along the land and sea routes between Italy and the Libyan front, Royal Air Force bombers yesterday followed their night raid on Palermo, Sicily, with a fierce daytime foray against the airport and seaplane base there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A meeting of Governors and agriculture officials of all farm States was called today by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, chairman of a special Agriculture Subcommittee, to meet here Oct. 9 and 10 to discuss price control legislation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Murry Dickson, batted from the box in the third inning of the first game, came back tonight to pitch the Columbus Redbirds, American Association champions, to a 5-to-4 victory over the Montreal Royals, evening the little world series with the International League club at two victories each.
The formation by Hans Rott, former Austrian Cabinet member, of a Free Austrian National Council, with himself as President of Austria in exile, yesterday was denounced by Austrian groups here.

Gasoline stocks on the East Coast last week declined 522,000 barrels to 18,872,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks, however, were up 719,000 barrels to 18,364,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks rose 113,000 to 10,155,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Westchester County revenues and expenditures in the operation of its Playland Amusement Park have been kept in a manner typical of most public parks, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach, Republican, said today in answering charges made last night by Schuyler B. Patterson, Democratic candidate for County Executive.

Following closely on a sharp rise in the sugar market, in which prices of active world futures contracts advanced the trading limit of 25 points on Monday, the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, at a special meeting yesterday, voted to request the president of the Exchange to appoint a control committee to investigate fully the world, or No. 4, sugar contract.

A PURCHASING agent, says William G. Morse, is positively the lowest form, of animal life, next to a Wall Street banker. Mr. Morse ought to know, for he used to be, among other things, a bond salesman, and at present he is official purchasing agent for that old and respected New England institution known as Harvard.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement in the House of Commons on the conduct of the war brought a bit of strength to the New York Stock Exchange yesterday with the result that stocks improved moderately and closed with fractional gains, but the market remained dull.
Dividends declared in September, as through the preceding six months, again constituted the largest for any corresponding month since 1937.

Under the terms of a new agreement worked out between the city and New York University, the university yesterday named Dr. William Carson Von Glahn, former associate professor at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, to head the Department of Pathology and Laboratories at Bellevue Hospital, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissioner of Hospitals.

With most Yiddish theatres opening tonight after the conclusion of Yom Kippur, the Hebrew Actors Union announced yesterday morning that the outlook for the new season was better than that of a year ago. Six attractions are scheduled to be running by next Monday, the union noted.

Under the terms of a new agreement worked out between the city and New York University, the university yesterday named Dr. William Carson Von Glahn, former associate professor at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, to head the Department of Pathology and Laboratories at Bellevue Hospital, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissioner of Hospitals.

With most Yiddish theatres opening tonight after the conclusion of Yom Kippur, the Hebrew Actors Union announced yesterday morning that the outlook for the new season was better than that of a year ago. Six attractions are scheduled to be running by next Monday, the union noted.

Sleepy-eyed moving men closed their van doors and moved their trucks back into garages and warehouses late last night while members of some weary households went to sleep fitfully in the midst of a confused jumble of packing crates, boxes and furniture as the peak of another Fall moving season passed.
The faithful, the febrile and the fanatic shivered last night in thin lines outside the Yankee Stadium awaiting day and the start of the world series between the Yankees and the Dodgers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- "Daddies," a drawing-room comedy by John L. Hobble which David Belasco produced on Broadway in 1918 with Jeanne Eagles, George Abbott and Bruce McRae, has been revived by Warners as a vehicle for Gloria Warren and Patty Hale, the studio's two new juvenile acquisitions, to follow their debut in "Always in My Heart."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Thoug the United States Government has begun to wage economic warfare against the Axis and is making ready for physical war if that shall be the consequence of its foreign policy, in the theatre of militar planning it still retains the type of tactical organization that directed operations in the war between the States.

Through the real penitence that results in righteous action, men and the nations they comprise can build a better world in which love and freedom will replace force and oppression, rabbis declared in sermons at services here last night, beginning the observance of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the most sacred day in the Jewish religious calendar.

Production of aircraft equipment and of defense chemicals came to a halt yesterday in two vital New Jersey plants as strikes were started at Air Associates, Inc., in Bendix, and at the Calco Chemical Division of the American Cyanamid Company in Bound Brook.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Reports of revolt, terrorism and fierce reprisals reached here today from many parts of Europe in advance of a third and still blacker Winter of the war. They told of the destruction of whole rebellious Yugoslav towns by Italian planes and warships.

Times without number the America First Committee has drawn the picture of a reckless one-fifth of this country dragging a reluctant four-fifths into war. The material for this familiar picture is plainly derived from the finding by the Gallup survey that approximately 20 per cent of the American people favor our immediate formal entrance into the war, while 80 per cent oppose such action at the present time.
NEW YORK Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt returned to 640 Fifth Avenue yesterday from Newport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Treasury was busy today explaining, on the eve of the imposition of new excise taxes, that there was "no tax on cleanliness" and that umbrellas were jewelry if they had gold or silver handles or handles meant to look like gold or silver.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The report of Judge Charles B. Sears recommending the deportation of Harry R. Bridges to Australia was denounced today by Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, as an encouragement to the enemies of organized labor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Roosevelt declared today that the Constitution of Soviet Russia protects religion and the right to propagandize against it. He termed this virtually the same rule as that applying in the United States.

Post-war economic and social adjustment rather than the present war is the greatest problem confronting the United States, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday before the opening assembly of 200 students of the City College Division of Public Service Training in the Faculty Room of the college's main building, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.
The new Fall season has reached full proportions and will run into November at flood levels.

Among the building projects filed yesterday were a multi-family house to go up at 685-695 Second Avenue, Manhattan, at a cost of $160,000, and a similar structure costing $250,000 to be erected on Sixty-seventh Road, Forest Hills. The details of these and other plans follow:

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 30 -- The Turkish Government finally and categorically informed Germany today that Turkey would deliver no chrome to the Reich. It is also learned that Turkey will sell Germany no wheat, as the current crop is poor and reserves are below normal.

TRENTON, Sept. 30 -- The concluding session today of the Democratic State Convention was featured by the announcement by United States Senator William H. Smathers of his intention to seek re-election next year, and the adoption by the delegates of a platform pledging full support to the policies of Governor Charles Edison.

In response to the increase of 25 points to 16.99 cents a pound in the parity price of the staple as announced late Monday by the Department of Agriculture, cotton prices yesterday continued their upward trend. After advancing to as much as 24 points around midday, the quotations on active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yielded moderately and closed at net gains of 14 to 15 points.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 1 -- Governor Arthur H. James of Pennsylvania married Mrs. Emily Radcliffe Case, widow of Dr. Claude Case, today in picturesque Deep Run Presbyterian Church, where the bride worshiped as a girl.
MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- Lord Beaverbrook, chief of the British mission here, has never forgotten his Canadian origin and his North American tastes.

Wendell L. Willkie will be master of ceremonies for the serious side of the program arranged for the "China Calling" rally at Madison Square Garden tonight, while Eddie Cantor and Walter O'Keefe will be in charge of the variety entertainment, in which stars of the theatre, screen and radio will participate.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 -- A Methodist Bishop in Michigan telegraphed President Roosevelt today that support for his "emergency policies cannot be secured by ridiculous, unsupported propaganda," and charged that some of the statements in the Chief Executive's remarks yesterday concerning religious freedom in Russia were "utterly misleading" and "obviously untrue."

Extensive defense preparations for the protection of New York Harbor against potential enemy attempts to enter by the use of submarines, motor torpedo boats or any other type of fighting vessel have been completed and are ready now for instant functioning, it was disclosed yesterday by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District and commander of the North Atlantic Naval Coastal Frontier.

Yesterday saw a Christmas tree on Plaza Square spreading its branches in a message to the 1,500,000 Frenchmen still left in German prison camps. In nights to come, each lighted bulb will represent the acquisition of $1,000 toward $30,000 now being sought by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, on whose doorstep at 4 West Fifty-eighth Street the tree has been placed.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 1 -- After twelve days of bitter fighting Finnish troops today captured Petrozavodsk, the capital of Soviet Karelia, it was officially announced in Helsinki.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 1 -- The prepared text of Secretary Knox's address to the American Bar Association was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Controller General Warren reported to Congress today that the National Youth Administration had requested Army recruiting officers to refrain from contacting NYA youths in order to keep them on the NYA rolls and maintain a program which would justify Congressional appropriations.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 1 -- New Jersey's 97-year-old Constitution, often referred to as a "horse-and-buggy" document because of its many antiquated features, was taken for a ride literally and figuratively today.

After Day of Atonement sermons yesterday morning in which the nations of the world as well as individuals were called to penitence and were urged to build a new world order of peace and democracy, Yom Kipper, the holiest day in the Jewish religious year, came to an end at sunset last evening.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

The planet Mars, which has intrigued the human imagination for centuries, will afford to observers in the northern hemisphere their best view in seventeen years at 2 A.M. tomorrow. At that time, the ruddy globe will be 38,130,000 miles away, affording a rare opportunity for study of the planet by professional astronomers and amateur sky gazers.

Advises Tax Clause on Cosmetics Members of the Toilet Goods Association were advised by that organization yesterday to use a stamped notation on all orders covering sales to retailers operating beauty or barber shops. The notation reads: "This order for toilet preparations is given and accepted with the express understanding that a buyer will not use or resell the same in a beauty shop, barber shop or similar establishment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, who has been under fire in the press for alleged slowness in negotiating contracts for the expansion of aluminum, magnesium and steel-making capacity, said today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was already "about through" letting contracts which would expand magnesium production from its present level of 36,000,000 pounds to nearly 350,000,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Plans for protecting the lives of elementary and high school pupils should the United States be attacked were discussed today at a meeting of public, parochial and other private school administrators, headed by James Marshall, president of the New York Board of Education, under the auspices of the Office of Civilian Defense.
BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- It became apparent here today that the President of the Bohemian-Moravian protectorate, Dr. Emil Hacha, would

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Water Power and Control Commission is "without authority" to bring an action against the Niagara Falls Power Company to regulate water diversion on the American side of the Niagara River, the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, ruled today.

Columbia will face Brown in its opener at Baker Field Saturday with a starting eleven of six seniors and five juniors, Coach Lou Little announced yesterday as the rights were turned off at the up-down gridiron.

An increase in the newsstand price of national magazines looms as a possibility, as publishers started to struggle this week with the question of how they can compensate for rising costs, it was learned here yesterday. The decision must be made quickly, because national advertisers, beginning to prepare their 1942 budgets, are anxious to know whether advertising rates will be advanced for 1942.

The sixty-third annual appeal for funds on behalf of the United Hospital Fund and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn will be open on Oct. 14, it was announced yesterday by the United Hospital Campaign Committee.

The Yankees have become so accustomed to these world series conquests that the novelty long since has ceased to exist. The Bombers won the first game of the current classic and, in the slang of the day, "So what?"

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Miss Katherine Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass., ranking star who is seeded No. 1 in the Hot Springs Fall invitation tennis tournament, reached the women's semi-finals today by vanquishing Mrs. Barclay Douglas of Locust Valley, L.I., 6--3, 6--3.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Finnish Army communique said today:

The special message that the President plans to send to Congress recommending a huge extension of the social security program will raise some particularly difficult problems at this time. In principle there are strong grounds in favor of the main change that the President has in mind.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- As another step to reinforce defense of the Western Hemisphere, the United States today signed a lease-lend agreement with Brazil, the largest and most geographically strategic country of South America.

A local National Art Week Council has been set up in New York with Paul Manship as one of two co-chairmen. The other has not yet been designated. Audrey McMahon, director of the New York City WPA Art Project, has been made administrative vice chairman of the council.

The action by the Federal Reserve Board in increasing bank reserve requirements raises a basic question as to how far measures of this kind can be effective in controlling inflation under present conditions, according to the National City Bank of New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Although five of the six Harvard players who were injured yesterday reported in uniform for practice today, Coach Dick Harlow did not call for the lengthy scrimmage he had scheduled.
The fashion terrace at Belmont Park was packed yesterday at the luncheon hour, the occasion being the last of this season's fashion showings. The exhibitor was Russeks Fifth Avenue.
ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., Oct. 1 -- Jimmy Hines, Lakeville pro, today began the defense of his laurels as metropolitan P.G.A champion in a most auspicious manner.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Construction of a Westchester County Airport adjacent to the Rye Lake Reservoir of New York City's watershed in Purchase would not endanger the purity of the water in the reservoir if sanitation precautions were taken in building and operating the airport, high ranking Army officers from Washington told the County Board of Supervisors committee on airport sites today.

Today's openings: "It Started With Eve," co-starring Deanna Durbin and Charles Laughton, at the Radio City Music Hall; "Honky Tonk," featuring Clark Gable and Lana Turner, at the Capitol; "Great Guns," with Laurel and Hardy, at the Globe.

To open the musical comedy season, George Abbott has been good enough to assemble the freshman class and put them through some highly enjoyable paces. "Best Foot Forward," is what he calls the exercises, which were staged with professional skill at the Ethel Barrymore last evening.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 1 -- With the help of parachutists and glider trains towed by powerful transport planes, German forces under General Field Marshal Karl von Runstedt have broken through the northern defenses of the Perekop Isthmus, which joins Crimea and the Russian mainland.

A general buying movement, probably in response to reports of lower crop estimates, made itself felt in the cotton market after the first hour of trading yesterday and prices, as a result, were run up as much as $2.50 a bale. After holding within a narrow range early quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange thereafter rose steadily to close at their high marks for the season, reflecting net gains of 43 to 50 points.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement to the House of Commons evoked a note of commiseration in German quarters today and the speech was dismissed on the ground that the Prime Minister once again "felt the urge to speak" at a moment when the drift of military events and restive home sentiment called for a display of specious optimism.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 1 -- Japanese forces in Hunan Province are retreating in great disorder with heavy losses in "a debacle many times worse than 1939," Chinese military dispatches said tonight.

Brooklyn's dazzling Dodgers, whose dramatic National League pennant victory touched a new baseball high for mass hysteria, advanced upon the Yankee Stadium yesterday, brought with them legions of devout followers who helped set a world series attendance record of 68,540 and then unhappily got themselves lost in the vastness of the situation.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- After rising for fourteen months business activity in New England has declined 2.7 per cent in August as compared with July, the New England Council reported today. Three components of the council's business index showed increases, but these were below seasonal expectations.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) Oct. 1 -- The Bourse was less active and prices easier. Royal Dutch dropped 614 points to 318; Amsterdam Rubber 6 1/2 to 478 1/2; Amsterdam Trading 2 1/2 to 312 1/2; Philips 4 to 267 1/4; Unilever 1 1/2 to 162 7/8 and A.K.U. 1 to 142 1/8.
NEW YORK Dr. and Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor have returned to 950 Fifth Avenue from Denbigh, their Summer home at Sugar Hill, N.H.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Yale's football players today concluded the series of long and strenuous dally practices on Anthony Thompson field and will taper off gradually for their opening game of the season against Virginia here Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Roosevelt continued discussions with Secretary Hull today, preparatory to what is expected to be an open appeal for substantial modification, or practical repeal of the Neutrality Act of 1939.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Plans for making the Pacific Coast "substantially independent" of Eastern steel mills for strategic and economic reasons as well as to effect some decentralization of the steel industry westward were disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Trading in wheat was on a small scale today and mainly of a professional character, but while prices dipped slightly in the early trading due more to lack of demand than to any material selling, shorts found offerings light late in the session when they tried to cover and the close was only slightly under the best prices.

Carl Alfred Reuper, a former trusted employe of Air Associates, Inc., and the Westtnghouse Electric Company transmitted inconsequential information to Germany in return for past favors, but more than compensated for this by his contributions to the United States defense program, according to testimony yesterday in the Brooklyn espionage trial.

Baby bluefish arc given top billing in this week-end's report on fish conditions by the Fishery Council. In recent months there has been a distressing dearth of the delicate and popular fish, which has been available in quantity only for the last two weeks.

A school teacher enjoys no special privilege to lie under oath, Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. told the Kiwanis Club yesterday in a sharp reply to an attack on the legislative investigation of subversive activities in the city school system made last week by the American Committee to Defend Democracy and Intellectual Freedom, headed by Dr. Ned H. Dearborn, dean of the general education division of New York University.

BERLIN, Thursday, Oct. 2 -- Premier General Alois Elias, two retired generals and an unstated number of other Czechs fell before firing squads yesterday in the German Protectorate of Bohemia-Moravia, making a total of nearly 100 executions in four days.

Repeating the assertion made in his acceptance speech that there would be no room in his administration for "a Gerson or a Kern or any of their fellow-travelers," District Attorney William O'Dwyer challenged Mayor La Guardia last night to state his attitude toward Communists and particularly his attitude toward the left wing of the American Labor party, alleged by the State officers of that party to be dominated by Communists.

John R. Davies, running against Mayor La Guardia in the primaries last month, got considerably less than 6 per cent of the enrolled Republican vote. Mayor La Guardia received considerably more than 8 per cent. The evidence was strong that most New York City Republicans took Mayor La Guardia's renomination for granted and were not interested in Mr. Davies's candidacy.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 -- Recreation and play under the tension of present times are just as important as labor in the nation's defense effort, in the opinion of Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, who spoke tonight at the National Recreational Congress.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 1 -- Diving within a few feet of the target one at a time, a flight of R.A.F. heavy bombers early yesterday blasted a Tripoli truck park and started a fire so large that one British gunner described it as "like the setting sun."

In true mountain climbing fashion, Richard Allen Brown, 8 years old, began to ascend the cliffs of Fort Tryon Park, on Riverside Drive opposite Henshaw Street, shortly after 11 A.M. yesterday. But like many another amateur, he had to be rescued.

The six-story apartment house at 1440 Undercliff Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold for cash above a first mortgage of $139,120 by the Realty Freehold Corporation to Briarcliff Estates, Inc., David Walzer, president.

Bread and pastry deliveries to hotels and restaurants were halted yesterday when 3,000 members of the Bakery and Pastry Drivers and Helpers Union, Local 802, A. F. of L., went on strike in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, tying up operations of 174 companies in the affected area.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 -- Participants in the second "wildcat" strike in two days at the Briggs Manufacturing Company's Mack Avenue plant voted today to go back to work tomorrow morning, thus permitting the reopening of the big plant, closed because of the unauthorized strikes.

A newspaper which takes its responsibilities seriously, as we believe most American newspapers do, cannot regard National Newspaper Week, which opened yesterday, as an advertisement for a private business. As a private enterprise the newspaper must take its chances along with other enterprises producing goods or services for which the public is willing to pay.

VICHY, France, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- French police arrested seven persons accused of terrorism and seized a quantity of arms and explosives today in a house-to-house search of the Thirteenth Ward in the Austerlitz station area of Paris, reports from Paris said.

Interest in the opening game of the world series of baseball games was even greater than that evidenced in the stock market yesterday, and this, combined with a religious holiday, pushed activity on the New York Stock Exchange to the lowest level since late August.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Representative Thomas F. Ford, Democrat of California, stalked angrily from a House Banking and Currency Committee hearing on the Administration's price and rent control bill today after accusing his colleagues of "fiddling while Rome burns!"

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Redbirds spotted Montreal a three-run edge in the first frame tonight, and then combed three hurlers for sixteen hits, including four doubles and a home run, to win by 13 to 3 and capture a three-game-to-two advantage in the little world series.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarter communique said today:

A plea for assistance in bringing out of unoccupied France some of the refugee intellectuals "in whose hearts and in whose dreams there is the only hope for a free Europe tomorrow" has been made by Dr. Prank Kingdon, chairman of the Emergency Rescue Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The inter-allied conference here last week took the expected course but gave no indications of immediate action which would influence commodity markets. It threw no new light on the prospective working of the clause in the Atlantic Charter providing for raw materials, plans for which are obviously still in their earliest stages.

Insurance Competition Leaders of the investment banking industry expressed complete agreement with the remarks yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, in an address before the Mortgage Bankers Association.

Because of the Jewish holiday, Yom Kippur, there was no kosher kill yesterday and no kosher markets. Many wholesale coolers were closed and trading was light in those that were open. Prices were little changed from Tuesday's levels.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 1 -- A warning that Nazi mentality was "not necessarily confined to Germany" but had a way of coming to life "even in localities in the United States" was given to American educators today by Dr. Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, who spoke at Stanford University's fiftieth anniversary celebration.

VICHY, France, Oct. 1 -- At the instance of the Commissioner General for Jewish Questions, the Minister of the Interior has appointed "provisional managers" for numerous Jewish enterprises in the unoccupied zone. They include the Sudarsky clothing stores, with five branches in Lyon and business in Nice, Toulouse, Vichy and other towns south of the line of demarcation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 1 -- If youth has found it difficult to adjust to the "present national crisis, the blame rests with the parents, Dr. Lucius A. Whipple, president of Rhode Island College of Education, declared here today. He addressed the final session of the annual meeting of the New England Conference of State Federations of Women's Clubs.

VICHY, France, Oct. 1 -- Citizens examining their ration cards today for the month of October noted ruefully that they will receive one quarter of a pound less of fatty matter and nearly two ounces less of cheese. In compensation they will be entitled to buy a half pound of macaroni.

Business activity in September continued at the high rate which began with the national defense program, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, made public yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- James D. O'Neil, former C.I.O. publicity man on whose purported statements to Federal agents former Judge Charles B. Sears based in part his recommendation that Harry Bridges, California C.I.O. leader, be deported as an undesirable alien, went on trial for perjury in Federal court today before Judge Martin I. Welsh and a jury of five women and seven men.
Repeating a victory scored in this stake a year ago, Herbert M. Woolf's Joe Schenck closed with a rush to win the $5,000 added Vosburgh Handicap, seven-furlong feature at Belmont Park yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 1 -- Has the "go-slow" movement inaugurated in occupied countries already reached the German factories?
It was easy to tell which were the Yankee fans and which the Dodger rooters among the record crowd of 68,540 at the Stadium for the world series opener yesterday, The Yankee fans were the noisy ones.
BERLIN, Oct. 1 (AP) -- This communique was issued from Adolf Hitler's headquarters today:
ROME, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

A justice tempered with rectitude to offset the doctrine of might upheld by dictators throughout the world was advocated by leaders of the Roman Catholic clergy yesterday at the annual votive mass of the Holy Ghost, known as "The Red Mass."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Travelers from Rumania reported today that General Ion Antonescu had given up his military command on the Russian front as well as his Rumanian Premiership, and that German police were campaigning relentlessly against dissidence and sabotage in Rumania.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Champion of the Ivy League in 1938 and 1939 and ranked in the national upper crust until beaten by Dartmouth and Penn last year, the Big Red faces a new season with only the bare remnants of the great squad that revived the glories of the early Gil Dobean era of Cornell football.

In a cash deal, the two-family house at 89-91 Brighton Avenue, East Orange, N.J., has been sold by Howard J. Gardner to a client of Philip Mintz, attorney. M.I. Sientz was the broker. The building contains sixteen rooms and occupies a plot 84 by 120 feet.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Sales of wholesalers at $320,062,000 advanced 38 per cent in August over August of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The American Army under training today is very moderate in its size, compared with the population of the country, and represents the minimum necessary for its task, Secretary Stimson told a press conference today.

GLEN HEAD, L.I, Oct. 1 -- Miss Grace Amory of the home club and her partner, Mrs. Alexander Cushing of Piping Rock, continued to play great golf as they eliminated Mrs. Dudley Mills of Cedar Creek and Mrs. Bruce Brodie of Nassau, 4 and 2, in the first round of match play in the Long Island Women's Golf Association four-ball best-ball handicap tournament on the Cedar Creek course today.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A heavy British air raid last night on German coastal cities [Hamburg and Stettin] left dead and injured among the civilian population, the High Command announced today. The Reich curtailed evening activities in preparation for more frequent Fall and Winter attacks.

Continuing the trend shown in recent quarterly reports, many banks, including the largest institutions in this city, which will publish statements of condition today, show further expansion in their loans and discounts, lifting their advances to the highest point in several years.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Glad indeed are some of us to see once more on the editorial page matters of real import, such as "Crullers vs. Doughnuts."

The front behind the war front, the "sixth column," will issue its unofficial "communiques" in a book being prepared at Alliance for early November publication. Representatives of ten occupied countries have been gathering the reports that filter through from their Nazi-occupied countries and together they will attempt to give a picture of the secret battlefields of the war.

The new procedure of competitive bidding by insurance companies for securities issues was criticized yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, as involving serious economic dangers and as being likely to have an adverse effect on capital markets of the future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Replying to President Roosevelt's assertion that the Soviet Constitution protects religion and the right to propagandize against it, Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the House Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities, today wrote the Chief Executive that "freedom of religious worship is, and always has been, as non-existent in Soviet Russia as freedom of speech has been non-existent in Hitler's Reich."

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Great Britain's war expenditure has reached L13,000,000 a day, Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood told the House of Commons today. He declared the threat of inflation had been kept in check but remained a real danger and that the ceiling on the higher-bracket income tax had been reached.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 1 -- Conferences here between high British, military and civil authorities in the Far East have been devoted more to a general exchange of information and ideas than to the formation of policy, informed sources here said today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 1 -- Bolivia's political crisis was solved today with the appointment of a new Cabinet, which was sworn in tonight after a fortnight of political conferences. The most important change was the appointment of a civilian Minister of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- If one result of the conversations between the President and Secretary Hull shall be a move to arm our merchant ships, then the first real test of the efficacy of such armament against modern war craft will be at hand. Congress may be asked to authorize the arming specifically so as to associate the National Legislature in this new step of major foreign policy.
VICHY, France, Oct. 1 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, has left for Paris on one of his periodical visits.

After two weeks of indecision, John R. Davies, whom Mayor La Guardia defeated in the Republican primary, announced yesterday that he would run for Mayor independently as the candidate of the "All American" party on an anti-war and anti-New Deal platform.
Nobody was happy in the Dodger clubhouse after yesterday's loss of the world series opener to the Yankees, but neither was anybody in despair.

Royal Cortissoz has just reached the fifty-year milestone in his distinguished career as art critic of The New York Herald Tribune. The celebration of this event will mean much to thousands of friends, whether or not they are personally known to him. As for the length of span to date, that is indeed impressive.

Czechoslovakia will continue fighting against Germany until the last German agent is removed from its soil, Jan Lichner, Czech Minister of State, declared yesterday at his country's consulate, 1440 Broadway.
In sharp contrast to the hectic pace of the preceding two days, retail shopping here slowed considerably yesterday when the new Federal excise taxes became effective.

The action of certain manufacturers of silverware, watches and other merchandise now taxable under the new jewelry excise tax, in announcing new retail prices which include the tax and, "incidentally, increases in the prices of their goods," has disturbed many retailers, who are protesting against this move, it was announced yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- Roberto Farinacci, who returned a few days ago from a visit to Germany and a tour of the Eastern Front, told many thousands of Italian farmers yesterday in Cremona that the Russians had between 35,000 and 40,000 tanks and 35,000 planes, according to the Regime Fascists.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The banks of the nation have responded to the financial needs of this country in the current crisis and have affirmed their adequacy, according to P.D. Houston, president of the American Bankers Association, in an address today before delegates to the association's sixty-seventh annual convention.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- War Department contracts totaled $237,075,138 today. Concerns in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Senate committee investigating the East Coast petroleum products shortage situation, and J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, were the objects of sharp attacks today by Harold L. Ickes, petroleum defense coordinator, who appeared before the committee at his own request.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Two Americans and three others aboard a plane belonging to the Aramayo Mining Company were killed when the plane crashed in the Andean Challhuani Range, the Sub-Prefect of the town of Sorata reported today.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- Germany reported progress today at both ends of the Eastern Front, sharing her claims in the north with Finnish forces, which announced the capture of Petrozavodsk, and in the south with the Italians, who are bolstering the push across the Ukraine.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 2 -- The United States and Great Britain agreed to fill virtually every Soviet need for war supplies in exchange for "large quantities" of Russian raw materials at the concluding session last night of the three-power conference.
When the bleacher gates at Yankee Stadium were opened just after 8 A.M. yesterday the more earnest customers had been in line fourteen hours.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The American League White Sox got four runs on six hits in the ninth inning today to defeat the National League Cubs, 4 to 1, in the opening game of the city series at Wrigley Field.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 1 -- Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey, canceled his scheduled departure from the Turkish capital today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee today resumes its listing of week-end motion picture theatre programs for children between the ages of 8 and 16 years. Films listed by the committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of youngsters in local public and private elementary and high schools, will be shown tomorrow, through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Amid a flashing patriotic decor, a gala ball was given last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the dual purpose of advancing national defense projects and celebrating the tenth anniversary of the opening of the Waldorf on its present site.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Many extremely perplexing problems -- technical and otherwise -- involved in getting aid to Russia were outlined here today by Laurence Cadbury, a member of the economic mission that went to Moscow a few hours after Adolf Hitler launched the German invasion of Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Minister of Australia and Mrs. Richard G. Casey, Will Ashton, director of the National Gallery of New South Wales, and Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation, were the ranking guests at the opening today in the National Gallery of Art of the first exhibition of the art of Australia ever sent to this country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 30:
The New York Stock Exchange has authorized for listing, but will not admit to dealings until further notice, the following securities of the International Paper Company:
Samuel J. Foley, District Attorney of the Bronx, has taken an apartment in the Concourse Plaza Hotel at 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

The Park Department announced yesterday that work had been started on the construction of three new playgrounds, one in Manhattan at Park Avenue and East 108th Street, and two in Brooklyn at Shore Parkway and Homecrest Avenue, and at Third Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

A strong argument can be made and has been made for American aid to Russia, but this argument does not rest on the preposterous notion that Russia is a democracy. It rests, instead, on military grounds -- and on these grounds exclusively. Russia is fighting Hitler, and Hitler is the one great threat to our security.

LONDON, Thursday Oct. 2 -- While bombers of the Royal Air Force were attacking the German ports of Stettin and Hamburg for the second successive night between sundown Tuesday and dawn yesterday, the Luftwaffe carried out its sharpest raid on Great Britain in weeks.

Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, returning on the Dixie Clipper from a month's visit in England, declared yesterday that the two countries have a "great, new obligation" to give all possible help to Russia as quickly as they can and that if the public could know how much already has been sent "they would be astonished."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- The closed shop was branded as unsound and employers who accepted it were accused today by Thomas R. Jones, president of American Type Founders, Inc., of "double-crossing" their loyal employes.

The four-story property at 740-2 Eighth Avenue, of which the upper floors comprise the Hotel Fulton, and which has seven stores on the grade floor, has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to Imperial Equities, Inc., for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $254,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Manufacturers' inventories moved up sharply in August to reach a new all-time high of almost $13,500,000,000, according to the Commerce Department. Almost all of the estimated $300,000,000 increase during the month was accounted for by the durable goods industries.

"Ah, Wilderness!," the first play In the Theatre Guild's series of six revivals this season, opens tonight at the Guild Theatre. It was eight years ago this evening that the Guild first produced the Eugene O'Neill comedy. Harry Carey of the movies will be seen in the role created on Broadway by George M. Cohan.

Shortages of material are not serious yet in the printing and publishing fields but by the end of the year numerous difficulties will begin to crop up, suppliers pointed out yesterday. Paper, machinery and equipment and ink will offer the most serious problems, with copper and zinc also a source of dificulty.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 1 -- Although the United States has made defeat of the totalitarian powers a part of its national policy by both executive and legislative action, it is contributing as yet "only a part of our share" toward this end, Secretary Knox declared today before a general meeting of the American Bar Association holding its convention here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -- W. Somerset Maugham's "The Moon and Sixpence," a novel reputedly based on the life of Gauguin, was purchased today by David Loew and Albert Lewin as a vehicle for Paul Muni.

Miss Elizabeth Newton, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Newton of 150 East Seventy-second Street, will give a luncheon today at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for a group of debutantes assisting her in plans for the invitation preview Sunday night at the Heckscher Theatre of "Marco Polo," an operetta produced by Junior Programs, Inc.

OTTAWA, Oct. 1 -- Thirteen Canadian air squadrons, of which eleven are commanded by Canadian officers, are already formed and operating in Europe, Air Minister C.G. Power stated yesterday in a speech in Montreal and he added that shortly the number would be raised to twenty-five.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today that another $20,000,000 advance of the $50,000,000 promised had been made to Soviet Russia and added that he was in favor of including Russia in the second lease-lend bill.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In response to many requests of its members, the Municipal Art Society wishes to speak for citizens who are concerned over the removal of the present Aquarium building in Battery Park.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 17 (Delayed) -- A field force of the United States Army, infantry, artillery, and engineer, signal, ordnance and medical units, has arrived here with vast supplies of equipment and materials.

Excess profits due to defense production must be taxed at extraordinarily high rates during the national emergency, but it is equally important that normal non-defense profits must be fully protected if American industry is to survive the war, Ellsworth C. Alvord, Washington tax authority, said yesterday at the conclusion of the tenth annual convention of the Controllers Institute of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
