LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- After finishing last in the first heat of the $3,000 Poplar Hill purse on today's grand circuit program, Harry C. Fitzpatrick's Wilmington won the event with victories over On Time and Bell Boy in the final two whirls.

A strong indication that he might reject the charges of monopolization of the aluminum industry that form the main strength of the government's suit to break up the Aluminum Company of America was given yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

French Post-Mortems Reading the latest of Winston Churchill's masterful speeches a person finds himself thinking of France. Long ago a good many of us began to weary of the seemingly endless parade of books explaining how France inevitably fell for a seemingly endless number of reasons.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- Compulsory military training for all Russian men between the ages of 16 and 50 was instituted today as another and drastic step in the full mobilization of this country's vast fighting potential. The Red Army, fighting hard on all fronts, made local counter-attacks in the northern and southern sectors and beat back a sudden German thrust in the center.

TO the surprise of many Yankee fans, the Dodgers didn't look any funnier than any other team when they came on the field to start the series at the Stadium yesterday. But when Manager Durocher gazed around at the packed stands -- the greatest crowd that ever surrounded any Brooklyn team -- he leaped up and kissed Marse Joe McCarthy, the Yankee manager.

A wire has just been received from the Vermont Forest Service, reporting that the woods in that State will be closed to all hunting until there has been a sufficient rainfall to eliminate the present fire hazard.

A style show, entitled "Fashion Portraits," will be given for the benefit of the Masters School Day Nursery during the luncheon hour on Oct. 21 to mark the formal opening for this season of the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Mrs. Francis Robert Masters is president of the beneficiary, and Mrs. Bromwell Ault, first vice president of the organization, heads the committee in charge of the arrangements for the forthcoming benefit.

After the New York Public Library closes its doors at night it usually becomes a place of silence and shadows, but lights glowed last night in the building and the marble walls of the lobby echoed with the sounds of dancing.

WASHINGTON, Oct 1 -- A panel of the National Defense Mediation Board began consideration today of the war-bonus dispute involving seamen and steamship owners that resulted in the strike on Sept. 13 that was called off at the request of the board.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 1 -- A long official communique, issued at Veliki-Beckerek, in the Banat, tells of the activities of "Communists" in this area. The communique recalled that previous warnings to Communists provided that they return to their homes and turn in any arms they had in their possession.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- As new Federal excise taxes became effective today on hundreds of items, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, warned that "the threat to the general price structure if 'pyramiding'' of the new tax is resorted to by distributors of merchandise is real and dangerous."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- As new Federal excise taxes became effective today on hundreds of items, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, warned that "the threat to the general price structure if 'pyramiding'' of the new tax is resorted to by distributors of merchandise is real and dangerous."

ROME, Oct. 2 -- The huge sum of 24,000,000,000 lire has been placed at the disposal of the Ministry of War for "expenses consequent upon the state of war," it was learned today from a decree published in the Official Gazette. This is the largest of all the war outlays and, indeed, is the largest single budgetary provision in Italian history.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today: ...

Egg prices are up again, the consumers' division of the Department of Markets reports, adding that this essential food now has attained a high price level unprecedented in the bureau's annalswhich date to 1934. Grade A Whites are quoted at a city-wide average of 57 cents a dozen, as compared with last week's 55.
The play-by-play description of the second game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows:

Trading opened only fair in locally dressed meats yesterday. The lamb market was steady to 50c lower, with heavyweights showing the decline. Fresh pork cuts were irregular. Other classes were mostly unchanged. The kosher markets opened unevenly. Lamb was higher and other classes about steady.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- The man who taught the Southwest's young blood to draw a bead with an inflated pigskin instead of a six-shooter as the ringmaster of Southern Methodist's aerial circus came north by way of Vanderbilt last year to take charge of football at Temple.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- A continued slaughter of Czechs and Poles was reported tonight along with accounts of terrorism and reprisals throughout occupied Europe. The Germans shot fifteen more Czechs and hanged three who were Jews at Prague today, according to their own official announcements and Berlin and Prague radio broadcasts picked up here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a loan-and-purchase program for this year's rice crop, designed to aid orderly marketing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- While administrative authorities continued their study today of plans for removing the restrictions of the Neutrality acts on American shipping, Senator Pepper of Florida, forecaster of many foreign policy moves in the past, urged President Roosevelt to revoke the proclamations which had brought the act into force.
Recovering from a bad start Jose Coll Vidal's Paul Pry came from eighth and last place to win the $3,500 Class C Sorteado Handicap at one mile and a half at Belmont Park yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 -- It was said here tonight on high authority that the signing of the Washington accord between Mexico and the United States had been provisionally fixed for next Thursday.

Incredible as it may seem, the Yankees can be defeated in a world series game and, at a few minutes past 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Brooklyn's dazzling Dodgers completed the demonstration by pinning the mighty Bronx Bombers down on their own mat and keeping them there.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 2 -- Recreation was stressed as an essential part of life., particularly in an emergency period, before delegates today to the National Recreation Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- "Chain newspaper publishing has become a menace to democratic institutions Bind therefore has no place in a democracy, least of all when this country is facing the opposition and enmity of a rapidly expanding totalitarian world," Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania told the Senate today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Diedrich B. Gristede, vice president and treasurer of the chain grocery store firm of Gristede Brothers, hanged himself today with a trunk strap in the garage under his home at 12 Rectory Lane here.

Adoption of a limit of 6 per cent on profits as suggested by Secretary Morgenthau will work a severe hardship on many companies in the United States, according to H.C. Beaver, president of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 2 -- Craig Wood's attempt to add the metropolitan P.G.A. as a setting in the national open crown he annexed at Fort Worth, Texas, early this season came to naught today in the second round of to the district match-play championship.

The nine-acre property, formerly owned by the estate of Halsey Hammond, at Lincoln Park, N.J., has been purchased by J. Richard Hanna of New York, according to Previews, Inc. Three acres, landscaped with tall cedars and other trees, encircle the cobblestone residence of nine rooms and bath, with wide porches on two sides.

TRENTON, Oct. 2 -- New Jersey is experiencing its dryest Fall since 1930, State Fire Warden Leroy S. Fales said today, and he is preparing for the worst period of woodland fires in the department's history.

The State of Washingtoa Toll Bridge Authority has passed a resolution authorizing the trustee for the Tacoma Narrows bridge 3 and 3 11/4 per cent revenue bonds, due in I960, to accept tenders from holders and to make payment of principal and interest in full, it was learned yesterday.
"You fellows haven't come in here on a loser in a long time, have you?"

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- A plan for the redemption at 101 1/2 of the $16,000,000 of New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad 4 per cent collateral trust notes due in 1946 was announced today by the parent Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

While retail trade returned to normal proportions here yesterday with the elimination of "beat-the-tax" buying, some uncertainty continued with respect to items which may be taxable under the jewelry clause of the Revenue Act.

Greenpoint hillbilly laments and Canarsie anti-Yankee chants sweetened the Bedford Avenue air around Ebbets Field in Brooklyn last night as The Bums' rooters grimly waited for what one of them lyrically called "the dawn's oily light."

Citing the psychological problems of youth, that finds itself faced with war today in spite of education for peace and with regimentation after being schooled solely to the importance of individual freedom, Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham, president of the national board of the Y.W.C.A., proposed yesterday an intensification of recreation and art programs and directed discussion hours for young people.

A substantial decline in retail advertising linage, partly because last month had only four Sundays as against five in the corresponding 1940 period, and a sharp drop in the automotive classification, caused a 2.2 per cent decline in linage of the eight leading New York newspapers last month, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

Emil Camarda, general vice president for the Atlantic Coast district of the International Longshoremen's Association, was killed shortly before 4 P.M. yesterday in the offices of Sabbatino Co., Inc., general stevedores, at 52 Broadway.

The Tailored Woman opened its luncheon showing, held in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday, with a line-up of striking fur-trimmed woolen coats. They were the most exciting items presented. They demonstrated what New York's designers can do in the way of handling fine fabrics and furs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 27 amounted to 919,510 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,541 cars, or 1.3 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 97,076 cars, or 11.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 89,814 cars, or 10.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.
BLOWING ROCK, N.C., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Dr. Henry R. Linville of New York City was killed yesterday when an automobile dropped fifty feet from the Yonalohsee Trail.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 -- "Angel Face," a magazine short story by Jean Becket, will be Joan Carroll's second vehicle at RKO, the studio announced today. Young Miss Carroll, who was seen last season on Broadway in "Panama Hattie," recently completed "Obliging Young Lady" for RKO.

Tenseness, with a capital T, was written all over the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the drama of the second game in the world series was unfolded. It gripped the banner crowd of 66,248 fans to such an extent that when Dixie Walker circled under Tommy Henrich's game-ending fly to right in the ninth the riotous celebration that was expected from the many Dodger rooters was not forthcoming.

Arsenal Yields Eggs For the British people an egg a day will keep Hitler away. American aid to Britain makes a much better showing if we stop thinking in terms exclusively of tanks, planes and guns and begin to take note also of cheese and eggs and dried fruits.

Thirty thousand New York City school children will attend the released-time program of religious instruction this year, compared to 10,000 when it was started last February, the Rev. Dr. Warren M. Blodgett predicted yesterday at a conference for ministers, church workers and parents at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Approval of the new gasoline rationing system for the Eastern seaboard promulgated by the Office of Production Management, except as to some methods of administration, was expressed yesterday by the executive committee of the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Conference in session at the Hotel New Yorker.
One of the most imposing private homes remaining in the Upper East Side residential neighborhood between Fifth and Madison Avenues has just changed ownership in an "all cash" transaction.

When we received word recently that Maine had closed its woods to shooting, we expressed a belief that Merrymeeting Bay would be thronged with hunting traffic, and a wire from Earl Doucette proved that in this instance, at least, we were prophetic.

The trend of population to the suburbs and the possibility of "war boom" inflation are creating financing problems which must be studied closely by investment institutions to avoid economic pitfalls, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America was told yesterday at its annual convention.

Battle of Tank Gars The "battle of tank cars," which is going on between the Oil Coordinator's office and the Senate committee investigating the oil supply situation along the East Coast, appears to be no nearer a decision than when the issue first was raised.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Appearing before the Senate Oil Investigating Committee today to answer an attack made on him yesterday by Harold L. Ickes, defense oil coordinator, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, expanded his challenged assertion that more than 20,000 idle tank cars were available to meet the reported shortage of petroleum products in the Atlantic Coast States.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- German occupation forces have executed nearly 1,000 persons in Europe, in some cases shooting them by the carloads, in reprisal for a mounting tide of violence in the occupied countries, a compilation showed tonight.

THE second game started at 1:30 at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, but the fun didn't begin until 2:45 Brooklyn time. That was when the Dodgers came to life and their Flatbush followers came out of hiding.

Bundles for Britain honored the twenty republics of Latin America last night at a "Gala Dinner of the Americas" given In the Sert Room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in recognition of the Interest shown by Latin America In the American srar relief society.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (Reuter) -- All German radio stations tonight broadcast a warning by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, that death remains the penalty for listening to the British radio. The warning was contained in an article by the German propaganda chief in the Nazi periodical Das Reich, which was quoted by the announcer.

Eugene P. Connolly, leader of the left wing of the American Labor party in Manhattan, charged last night that District Attorney William O'Dwyer two months ago had sought the aid of left-wing labor politicians whom he now calls members of a "Communist group" supporting Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Fulmer bill, to refund and guarantee certain bonds of the Federal Land Bank System and to improve the functioning of the cooperative features of the system, is awaiting the completion of hearings before the House Committee on Agriculture.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- For the fifth consecutive week the Bank of England's statement, issued today, revealed a new high record for note circulation. The increase was more than L6,000,000, bringing the total to L677,774,000.

The steadily growing Bundles for Britain, Inc., which started as an American war relief organization, has already reached out as far as Australia, where thousands of volunteer workers have united as an affiliated chapter, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Paul White, executive director of branches, with headquarters at 745 Fifth Avenue.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Arrangements have already been made to speed up and amplify United States and British deliveries of war materials to Russia, and a staff of United States experts will remain here to supervise maintenance of United States-made equipment and give instruction in its use.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A statement issued at the White House today on behalf of President Roosevelt expressed hope that the way had been opened for developing full freedom of religion in Soviet Russia.

CHICAGO. Oct. 2 (AP) -- Prices of hogs were marked down today as much as 25 cents a hundredweight In a dull market after a fairly steady opening. While the early top was $11.50 buyers were unwilling to go above $11.25 in later dealings. Livestock men said hog prices normally slump at this time of year as the Spring pig crop appears on the market.

Richard J. Cullen, president of the International Paper and Power Company, announced yesterday that the existence of the company would be terminated at the close of business tomorrow, marking completion of the reorganization program approved by stockholders on Sept. 25.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Morris L. Ernst, New York lawyer, urged the Federal Communications Commission today to prohibit newspaper ownership of radio stations, and to include an appraisal of programs among the factors for consideration in deciding on renewal of station licenses.

The Maritime Commission has announced that the priority system placed in effect on westbound lumber shipments in the intercoastal steamship trade for the month of October would be dropped and that there would be no priorities in November on this commodity.

Promising its "full and complete support" to William O'Dwyer and his running mates on the Democratic ticket, the New York County Democratic Committee voted last night at'its statutory reorganization meeting in Tammany Hall to re-elect its retiring party officers and to seat three new Assembly District leaders.

Bayside National The Bayside National Bank, Bayside, Queens, reported as of Sept. 30 total deposits of $3,735,067 and total assets of $4,277,483, compared, respectively, with $3,643,064 and $4,123,388 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $833,762 against $856,401; holdings of United States Government securities to $576,241 against $576,565, and loans and discounts to $1,999,637 against $1,845,734.

Jackson of the Supreme Court said tonight at a dinner of the American Bar Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As reported to THE NEW YORK TIMES Oct. 1, President Roosevelt declared that the Constitution of Soviet Russia protects religion and the right of propaganda against it. He termed this essentially the same rule as applying in the United States.
Although the large gains of recent weeks were narrowed considerably, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday exceeded those of the preceding week and the corresponding week of 1940.

The appearance of a group of insurance companies as the successful bidders for the $90,000,000 offering of American Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures marked a new and significant development in the changing pattern of finance. The offering was the most important yet made under the new conditions of competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, Oct 2 -- Reports received in some foreign diplomatic circles from Moscow today were to the effect that Reichsfuehrer Hitler had made what was described as a liberal peace offer to Premier Stalin and that it had not yet been definitely rejected.

Appearing yesterday at the Sixth Division Police Offices, 229 West 123d Street, to testify about alleged police brutality in Harlem, forty witnesses, including representatives of teachers' unions, other labor groups and an observer for the American Civil Liberties Union, walked out indignantly when Deputy Inspector George W. Mulholland, who is conducting the hearing, said he would hear them individually and in private.

Dry Goods Ceilings Expected Dry goods wholesalers seeking to replenish their dwindling stocks of a wide variety of staples met further difficulty when it became apparent that mills were expecting ceilings on finished goods and therefore were not likely to sell more than spot goods whenever these become available.

Driving skill, knowledge of traffic regulations and sharpness of vision are not in themselves predetermining factors that make for safe driving, according to the results of a one-year study conducted at the New York University Center for Safety Education.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 -- Municipal transportation is not a luxury and cannot be subject to rationing, Mayor F.H. La Guardia of New York, who is National Director of Civilian Defense, said here today as he recommended creation of a transportation committee to confer with priorities authorities for maintenance of transportation equipment.
The problem of women in business is becoming serious when they start making feminists out of 14-month-olds.
VICHY, France, Oct. 2 -- Paul Collette, young Frenchman who attempted to assassinate Pierre Laval and Darcel Deat, "collaborationists," was sentenced to death by the Tribunal of State last night.

Asserting that the United States shares a "common danger and common aim" with China, Wendell L. Willkie, speaking last night before a cheering crowd of nearly 18,000 at Madison Square Garden, called on the American people to assure "the continuance of our own democracy" by aiding the Chinese in their struggle against totalitarianism.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, told the House of Commons today that a certain number of potential trouble-makers among British subjects with fascist leanings who had been interned on the Isle of Man under defense regulations had been ordered sent to prison in another part of Britain.

The luxurious furnishings of the Hangar Club, 36 East Sixty-third Street, were being catalogued for auction yesterday as the Missionary Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis prepared to take over the building as a business school for girls.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has authorized a group of holders of bonds of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway to intervene in the company's bankruptcy proceedings. The group is headed by Arthur Wiesenberger.

The arrival in Washington yesterday of Mexico's Finance Minister, Eduardo Suarez, coincides with reports that final agreement is near on the proposed credits to Mexico to strengthen hemisphere defense. Mexico, it is said, will receive a substantial loan, partly as a credit from the Export-Import Bank, the balance as a stabilization loan from the "United States Treasury.

Fordham's football forces had their last hard workout yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's meeting with Southern Methodist hi the Polo Grounds, a game that shapes up as the Rams' hardest opener in recent years. The squad worked from 3 o'clock until darkness forced Coach Jim Crowley to call a halt.

The new six-story apartment building erected by the Bank for Savings at the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street has been purchased by an investing client of Samuel Kronsky Co., brokers.

After a start which appeared to be a counterpart of Wednesday's trading, when prices rallied sharply, the cotton market yesterday ran into a selling wave and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at net losses of 12 to 16 points.

A luncheon was given by Decio Machado in the Ritz-Carlton Garden, yesterday for Mrs. Machado, who celebrated her birthday. The guests included Mrs. A. Perry Osborn, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Orland King, Countess Mercati, Mrs. Bennett Crocker, Mrs. James Thomas Lee, Mrs. Vivian Wooley Hart, Colonel Henry T. Blair, Henry Torres, George Bagby and Arthur Pope.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Final returns in a coast-to-coast check-up of public sentiment on President Roosevelt's "shoot at sight" order indicate that this measure is one of the most widely approved of all Administration steps yet taken to cope with the foreign crisis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Viscount Halifax, who returned yesterdal from London, conferred with President Roosevelt today on the war situation and the need for accelerating Anglo-American production for quick delivery at the fighting fronts.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and the Mellon Securities Corporation will offer today to the public a new issue of $4,000,000 Detroit, Toledo Ironton Railroad Company ten-year serial notes, priced at par and accrued interest, and due $400,000 on each Oct. 1 from 1942 to 1951, inclusive.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 2 -- The only player In a big field of seventy-one to break 90 was the winner of low-gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Tamarack Country Club today.

Secret instructions issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to manufacturers in defense industries on how to combat espionage and sabotage within their plants found their way into the hands of an alleged German espionage agent, who earmarked them for transmission to Germany, it was disclosed yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Pennsylvania today concluded its heavy work for the opening game with Harvard, but no bodily contact was permitted.

Within a few days President Roosevelt will send to Congress his recommendations for the repeal or modification of the Neutrality Act of 1939. We believe he will be wise if he makes no piecemeal proposals, but instead asks Congress to put an end to the whole outworn Jarce of American neutrality.

For the first time since the war started the Channel ports will be lighted this week-end. For a few hours warfare will cease while two hospital ships cross the narrow waters to carry wounded war prisoners from Germany to England and from England to Germany.

Talk of more and more taxes which, according to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, "will have to be a genuinely all-out bill, a genuine levy upon all in accordance with their ability to pay," chilled sentiment again yesterday In the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Secretary Hull observed his seventieth birthday today by working as usual. Correspondents assigned to the State Department, however, gave him a birthday cake at the noon press conference.

That admirable little troupe of dancing actors which calls itself the Jooss Ballet last night presented the world premiere of a new work by its first guest choreographer, Agnes de Mille; restored an old one, "Ballade," to the repertolre for the first time this season; gave another magnificent performance of that most stunning of dance dramas, "The Green Table," and repeated "A Ball in Old Vienna" for good measure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Amendment of the Communications Act to permit a merger of the domestic telegraph facilities of the nation and independent merger of American -owned international telegraph facilities was recommended today by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee after more than a year's hearings and study.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 2 -- Despite a protest, George Sylvester Viereck, who registered with the State Department last year as a propagandist for Germany, has been directed to appear tomorrow as a witness before the Federal grand jury investigating activities of Nazi agents in this country.

Lack of vital materials for production of disinfectants, insecticides, deodorants and fumigants has resulted in a sharp reduction in output of those products in the last few months, and further cuts in production are inevitable unless the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board gives the Industry recognition, according to trade spokesmen here yesterday.

Citing the almost phenomenal prosperity of numerous competitors of the Aluminum Company of America, Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey yesterday continued to dispose of the allegations on which the Department of Justice has attacked the $300,000,000 corporation as an illegal monopoly.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Secretary Morgenthau urged several thousand bankers here today to postpone loans for non-defense projects that would involve competition for materials urgently needed for the nation's defense effort. He asked them to take this action without waiting for the government's priorities list to become broader, in a speech at the concluding session of the American Bankers Association's convention.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The United States Rubber Company announced today the development of a new non-metallic material designed to displace sheet aluminum in many important uses.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- A generous increase in Britain's food rations was announced today in the House of Commons by Major Gwilym Lloyd George, Parliamentary Secretary to the Food Ministry, who said the extra allowances would be available Nov. 17.
NEW YORK Baroness de Villiers Terrage and Miss Jeanne Marie de Villiers Terrage have returned from Newport and are at the Savoy-Plaza.

For the first time in 100 years an anthology of work done in the classroom by New York City school children was issued yesterday in a brochure entitled "Moments of Enchantment." Specimens of poems, songs, compositions, graphic arts and paintings lend color and sprightliness to the attractive seventy-two-page book.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The War Department awarded contracts totaling $302,894,413, it was announced today. Firms in the New York area receiving awards were as follows:

LAKELAND, Ga., Oct. 2 (AP) -- A strange attack on former Governor E.D. Rivers and his wife late last night by a man identified as Horace W. Bikle, 38, a former school teacher, who later committed suicide, was believed by officers today to have been an abortive kidnap plot.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Oct. 3 -- Russian forces on the southeastern outskirts of Leningrad have broken the Nazi stranglehold around the former capital by smashing through the spearhead of the German lines, the authoritative military commentator in Moscow reported early today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The hostile public reception that greeted the President's approving citation Tuesday of Article 124 of the Soviet Constitution -- the so-called freedom-of-worship guarantee -- and the possible effects of that reception on United States aid to Russia in its war against the Nazis, have greatly disturbed those here who con centrate on the one objective of crush ing the Hitler regime.

The issue in the present municipal campaign is whether New York City should continue to be administered along the scientific lines followed under his administration or be turned bacK to the politicians, Mayor La Guardia told an audience of representatives of the architectural societies in the metropolitan area at the Architecturel League of New York Building, 115 East Fortieth Street, last night.

Reports of a heavy volume of apartment rentals continue to pour in from agents and brokers, despite the passing of the official "moving day." Realty men are hoping they can find a little respite after one of the Busiest rental seasons in recent years.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- German bombers last night and early today made their heaviest and most widespread attack on Britain in more than three months, and it was feared that casualties would be high in at least two towns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador; the Right Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Ready of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, James M. Cox, former Governor of Ohio; Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and transacted official business.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Russian troops have made more counterattacks in the northern sector, it was reported today, and in the vicinity of Staraya Russa have recaptured four villages and a strategically important hilltop, which was strongly defended by the Germans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- With further declines in market prices for agricultural commodities, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive wholesale price index of nearly 900 price series dropped 0.3 per cent in the last week of September. Prices for certain industrial goods continued to advance.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 2 (AP) -- With both Chinese and Japanese claiming a gigantic victory in the two-week campaign in Hunan Province, the Japanese today launched a new offensive 500 miles to the north, in Honan Province, apparently aimed, as was the other, at erasing the stigma of an old defeat.

An injunction to break the boycott established by Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., against the products of eleven major electrical manufacturers was recommended yesterday by John Kirkland Clark, special master, in a report filed in Federal court.

President Roosevelt warns in his latest article in Collier's Magazine that this country cannot afford, under modern conditions of warfare, to wait until it is physically attacked "before starting to shoot."

Katharine Cornell yesterday announced that she will appear in a new work by Henri Bernstein. Rehearsals are to start shortly after the conclusion of "The Doctor's Dilemma" tour, with Miss Cornell's husband, Guthrie McClintic, directing.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., Oct. 2 -- fin elaborate sham battle staged today by the Army to permit members of Congress and foreign military attaches to see every type of Army unit in operation, ended in the decisive defeat of a "Panzer" unit which tried to crush a force using the Army's newest defensive weapons.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 2 -- The battle of the Kiev pocket has made crucial the problem of aid to Russia. After more than three months of fighting the strategic situation in the Russian campaign is so much in the German favor that it now looks as if the Red Army cannot be maintained indefinitely as an effective fighting force without major materiel aid from outside Russia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Oct. 1:

A surprisingly good state of health among the children of Manhattan's tenement districts was disclosed yesterday in medical examinations at the five kindergartenage centers of the Children's Aid Society.
BERLIN, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The German navy and air force sank 683,400 tons of merchant snipping "in their successful battle against British" supply lines during September, the High Command said today.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- German comment on the Moscow conference, which closed yesterday, continued today to emphasize the contention that the problem of transportation would be the weak point in all efforts toward mutual help among Germany's enemies.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Alarmed at reports of the University of Virginia attack, headed by Captain Bill Dudley and Eddie Bryant, Yale's coaches held another session on defense against the Southerner's formations today.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- Nazis acknowledged today that the Russians were on the offensive at both Odessa and Leningrad, but they said that in the drive on the Donets industrial basin Axis armies had reached "an important railway junction" -- possibly Lozovaya, seventy-eight miles south of Kharkov.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 2 -- John Curtin, leader of the Labor Opposition, told the House of Representatives yesterday that Labor's main objections to the budget were compulsory loans, taxation of income down to L150 and "illiberal" treatment of service men and their dependents.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Miss Nancy McClave of Maplewood, medalist in the New Jersey State championship last week, teamed so well with Mrs. Arthur J. Stumpf of Crestmont today that their best-ball score of 37, 37-74 led a large field in the New Jersey Women's Golf Association fourball, best-ball tourney over the Essex Fells course.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Governor Lehman's announced call for a conference on Oct. 9 of representatives of Federal, State and local agencies, with respect to the problem of removing elements of the civilian population of New York City in event of air attack, is a logical step in preparation for defense.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 2 -- On the basis of a personal poll of the Stanford University faculty, Herbert Hoover concluded today that 60 per cent of the members did not agree with 176 professors, associate professors and assistant professors who, in a recent statement termed "fallacious" the idea that a passive defense was still possible for this country and called for "a more dynamic policy of action."

A 21-year-old boy and the 26-year-old father of a young son received prison terms of seventeen and a half years each yesterday in Federal court. They were Edward John Penn and Werner Fred Luck, who are serving State prison sentences for preying on the parents of the kidnapped and murdered Peter David Levine in 1938, and were found guilty of having conspired to kidnap other sons of wealthy Westchester County families.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 2 -- The opening program of the three day Piping Rock Horse Show brought out today a good-sized contingent of members of society who are real ring enthusiasts, and the breeding classes, shown during the forenoon, found the ringside surrounded by spectators who had left their cars to get a closer view of the entries.

Commercial loans of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City reached a new high level for the current movement in the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its statement for the week.

TOKYO, Oct. 2 -- With Washington conversations between the United States and Japan believed approaching a decisive stage, Colonel Hayao Mabuchi, director of the intelligence section of Imperial headquarters, today reiterated the Army's determination to finish the China incident" by armed force and again repudiated any peace based on the status quo ante as "suggested by countries hostile to Japan."

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- All hostilities over the English Channel, the war's most bitterly contested body of water, will cease for perhaps twenty-four hours this week-end while Great Britain and Germany exchange 3,000 wounded and disabled prisoners of war.

Discussions upon which determination of a major price-control policy will be based will begin in Washington today when representatives of the burlap industry take up with the Office of Price Administration the question of what can be done about the fact that burlap prices in Calcutta are quoted at levels higher than the ceiling prices established here by the OPA.

With both teams facing their first major testsof the campaign, Manhattan's football combination and powerful George Washington U. will meet tonight under the Polo Grounds lights. Upon the outcome of the battle, which should see sharp aerial and ground attacks, depends much of the future of the two elevens.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- While wheat showed stubborn resistance to selling pressure early today, outside buying failed to develop, and later many of the local element turned to the selling side when cotton started to react. Decided strength in Winnipeg, however, resulted in pressure being relatively light and closing trades on the Board of Trade showed losses of 3/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel.

Two prominent members of the Roosevelt Administration, A. A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, and Leland Olds, hairman of the Federal Power Commission, last night conferred the blessing of the New Deal on Mayor La Guardia's candidacy for re-election.

Some time in November Oxford University Press will issue "Bible for Today," an edition that when published in England had an advance sale of 25,000 copies. The forthcoming volume is the full authorized edition. The improvements are mainly typographical, with the text in paragraphs, with introductory commentaries, headlines and footnotes added.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Finnish Army correspondents reported today that a sudden break-through by Finnish troops in taking Petrozavodsk had forestalled Russian plans to destroy a large part of the city.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 3 -- German bombers blasted at five British towns and raked streets with machine-gun and aerial cannon fire in sharp attacks by the light of a harvest moon last night and early today.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Oct. 2 -- High-ranking favorites continued to display their mastery over the Cedar Creek Club links today and bagged well-earned decisive victories to survive the semi-finals in the Long Island Women's Golf Association four-ball, best-ball handicap tourney.
MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- The number of Czechs who have been executed by the Gestapo in connection with disorders in the protectorate of Bohemia-Moravia has now risen to 123 and still further shootings and hangings may be expected, according to well-informed German quarters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- National defense agencies are drafting a program to increase the present tank production goal of 1,000 tanks a month to 3,000 tanks a month by mid-year of 1942.

Not much doubt about it, the best play of the season so far is Eugene O'Neill's comedy of recollection, "Ah, Wilderness!" It was put on by the Theatre Guild in Fifty-second Street last evening, eight years to a day after the original performance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Henry W. Koeneke, president of the Security Bank of Ponca City, Ponca City, Okla., was elected today president of the American Bankers Association at the closing session of its annual convention. Mr. Koeneke was advanced from the post of first vice president.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- A protest against President Roosevelt's comment Tuesday that the Russian Constitution guarantees freedom of religion and propaganda against religion has been made by the spiritual director of the Holy Name Society here.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 2 -- Dedicated to the noted steeplechaser Good and Plenty, who starred in the first decade of the century, the thirty-ninth annual Piping Rock horse show opened today on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club.
Employes of three more New Jersey defense plants answered strike calls yesterday, bringing the number of work stoppages in this category to five.

Noel Coward's farce, "Blithe Spirit," will have its premiere at the Morosco on Nov. 5, thereby displacing the present occupant, "Cuckoos on the Hearth." Brock Pemberton, producer of "Cuckoos," said yesterday the "shudder comedy" would be transferred on Nov. 1 to a more permanent home not yet selected.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Forty days ago a station wagon bearing Rear Admiral H.G. Bowen drove through a picket line at the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company yard on the banks of the Hackensack River and the "blue ribbon" ship assembly yard of the East Coast was under control of the United States Navy.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 3 -- The 7,052-ton American-owned tanker I.C. White, flying the Panama flag, was torpedoed and sunk Sept. 27 in the South Atlantic, the freighter West Nilus reported today.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- The Nazi-controlled Czech press revealed today that the Mayor of Prague, Otakar Klapka, has been executed along with a number of members of the City Council. They were all said to have been in league with the former Premier, General Alois Elias, in an attempt to break off the Protectorate from the Reich by armed revolt.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3 -- War or no war, the average American still has an itch to do a little betting -- you might call it gambling -- now and then.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Roundlot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Sept. 20 was 3,756,160 shares, compared with 3,664,950 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Hats off to America, land of free thought and opinion, where every one exercises these privileges to their fullest extent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 2:

Civilian defense agencies here will get their first real test when the Army simulates an attackk on Fort Tilden on the Rockaway Peninsula the week of Oct. 9 to 16 to try the coastal defenses of New York Harbor.

The Greek maritime contribution to the Allied cause is now 200 deep-sea vessels of 1,000,000 tons, according to Stavros Theofanidies, Minister of Mercantile Marine of the Greek Government in exile, who arrived here yesterday.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 4 -- Germany's loss of three bombers for certain, and probably more, according to the Air Ministry, in the Nazi air attack in this country Thursday night occurred out of a force of not more than thirty or forty planes employed against the enemy's main target in Northeast England -- said by Berlin to be Newcastle -- British officials stated yesterday.

Concerned over the possibility that the new Federal liquor taxes would produce a wave of bootlegging in the city, Mayor La Guardia directed Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday to establish new alcohol squads in his department immediately.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- A wild flight in a Coast Guard plane that groped through fog-shrouded skies, had a brush with a tree-top in New Hackensack, N.Y., and was brought down to a one-wheel landing at Municipal Airport here ended safely tonight for Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.
Civilian morale in the present emergency is dependent to a large degree upon the state of health and welfare of every member in the community, Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Temple met a stubborn Virginia Military Institute eleven, but the Owls managed to score their second straight football victory tonight by beating the Southerners, 28 to 13, before 15,000 at Temple Stadium.

ROME, Oct. 3 -- The practice of sterilization, racial marriage laws and the "mania for divorce" were condemned by Pope Pius XII in an address inaugurating the new juridical year of the Sacred Roman Rota this morning.

Rain fell on New York yesterday for the first time since Sept. 4 and thereby ended the longest dry period -- twenty-eight days -- recorded by the local Weather Bureau since its establishment in 1871. Although the rain brought gloom to those who had intended to watch the third World Series game, farmers and forest fire wardens throughout the East were elated.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., Oct. 3 -- Camp Shelby, practically deserted for the last two months, was taking on new life today as troops trickled in from Louisiana where they participated in the nation's largest peacetime manoeuvres.
Bishop William T. Manning plans to open the entire length of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Sunday, Nov. 30, it was announced yesterday.

IN came Onkel Franz Frisch, the manager of the Pirates, and he was immediately put on the grill and questioned on the world series wrangling to date. Onkel Franz used to play in those things himself. He knows what it feels like to be in them -- and out of them, too, for that matter.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 -- According to the Domei news agency, the Japanese Government has lodged a vigorous protest with both Britain and Iran against the suspension of the diplomatic privileges of the Japanese Legation in Teheran, including immunity of mails and diplomatic pouches and the use of code messages.

Man's Other Garden Royal Cortissoz, looking Man's back over fifty years of art criticism, told the interviewer that at one period in his early newspaper Career there was a good chance of his becoming a music critic.

Market Wise, Shot Put an eleven others have been named for the $50,000 added New York Handicap to be run this afternoon on Belmont Park's getaway day, but what will be almost as intereating is the return meeting between Alsab and Requested in the Champagne Stakes, secondary feature.

The first report cards of the year will soon be brought home by the youngsters who trudged off hopefully to school early last month. And many anxious mothers, eagerly scanning them to learn if their young hopefuls have started the year in a blaze of glory or already have fallen behind, will be blissfully unaware that their young fry's success or failure is to a large extent determined right in their own kitchens.

NEWHAVEN, England, Oct. 3 -- British authorities called a sudden halt tonight to exchange under the protection of a mercy truce of some 3,000 German and British prisoners of war, although the crippled and blinded Germans already had been carried or led aboard one of two hospital ships in this harbor.

The cause of the crash between the tanker Robert E. Hopkins and the collier Jason on the night of Sept. 24 remained undisclosed yesterday following an official inquiry by the board of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation.

SACRAMENTO, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- A twin-motored Douglas B-18-A Army bomber with six men on board is missing and believed to have crashed somewhere between Needles, Calif., and Albuquerque, N.M., Lieutenant R.A. Butler, McClellan Field adjutant, said tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much publicity and recognition are rightly being given to the organization and activities of civil defense and other emergency agencies, such as the Air Raid Wardens, Auxiliary Firemen and Women's Volunteer Service. These organizations have been fortunate in the degree to which they have caught public interest and have thereby kindled the fires of patriotic enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Roosevelt said today that he was worried about the health of the people of the United States as the result of figures he had received showing that a high percentage of Army selectees had been rejected because of physical unfitness.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- The first employer-union agreement to offset the impact of priority unemployment in the automobile industry was signed here today by representatives of the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.).

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler returned to Berlin from his field headquarters today to broadcast from the Sportspalast a report of Germany's progress in Russia since June 22. He had left the front, he said, during operations of "gigantic dimensions" that had been in progress for forty-eight hours.

New bonds offered to the public this week were for the fifth consecutive period restricted to State and municipal and railroad issues. Together they aggregated $15,991,000, compared with $23,811,000 marketed last week, and with a total of $63,772,000 in new bonds offered in this week last year.

A SOUTHERN ENGLISH PORT, Oct. 3 -- Broken men, some of them with missing limbs, some of them sightless, all of them physically unfit for active duty again with Adolf Hitler's air, sea or land forces, boarded brilliantly lighted British Red Cross ships here tonight in anticipation of returning to their homes in Germany by way of Dieppe in Nazi-occupied France.

Greater New York's bitter inter-borough battle for the baseball supremacy of the universe remained in a state of suspended animation yesterday when rain washed out the scheduled third game of the Yankee-Dodger world series.

John Creighton Murray, 20-year-old violinist of this city, displayed superior talents for his chosen instrument at his recital in Town Hall last night. At this second New York appearance, Mr. Murray, who made his debut last season in the same auditorium, reinforced the favorable impression then made by his artistry.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 3 -- No gunner without a strong will and an equally strong conscience should indulge in any coot shooting off the Connecticut shore, as we learned yesterday, for the illegal broadbill and equally illegal blackduck flirt in and out of the coot decoys and offer temptations to an itching trigger finger.

All three city-wide Fusion candidates, Mayor La Guardia, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, will speak this afternoon at the formal opening in the Hotel Astor of the headquarters of the citizens' committee for their re-election.

Yesterday's postponement was the first because of weather that the world series has suffered since 1936, when the Yankees met the Giants. That year the series opened on Sept. 30, when Carl Hubbell vanquished Charlie Ruffing on a rain-soaked field at the Polo Grounds, 6 to 1.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- Japan's drive against two Chinese group armies in North Honan Province is gaining additional momentum and Japanese forces are expected to enter Chengchow, strategic junction point of the north-south Peiping-Hankow and east-west Lung-hai railways, during today, according to Japanese press dispatches from the front.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Contracts totaling $33,561,310 were awareded today by the War Department. Concerns in the New York area received the following awards:

Twenty-six young choristers, clad in gay costumes representing towns and provinces of the Netherlands, lifted their voices late yesterday afternoon in song to celebrate the Dutch victory over the Spanish Army at the siege of Leyden on Oct. 3, 1574.
In days to come, when Winter whines in the Canarsie eel grass and purls in the weeds in Sheeps-head Bay, the old folk will talk of the Night of the Big Wind and of The Flood.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 3 -- The Bourse maintained today a highly reserved attitude. A small reaction after a firm opening left the close irregular. Royal Dutch was steady at 323 1/2 after touching 328. Amsterdam Rubber was 3 points lower at 313 1/4 and Amsterdam Trading 2 1/4 better at 484 1/4.

The effect of national defense production on the output of civilian materials was thrown farther into bold relief yesterday with the disclosure by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company that approximately 1,000 workers would be laid off in its plant at Mansfield, Ohio.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- Major Gen. James Chaney of the United States, in company with other members of the American and British supply missions, visited a series of Soviet arms manufacturing plants this morning, and after his inspection tour told reporters that he was tremendously impressed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged the Crown Manufacturers Association of America, its officers and directors and fourteen corporations making crowns or closures for bottles and cans, and cork discs used in making such closures, with conspiracy to restrict and suppress competition in the interstate sale of these products.

Municipalities that fail to accumulate surplus funds by curtailing all but the most necessary expenditures in the present defense crisis will find themselves hard pressed to meet ordinary running expenses in the post-war period, T. Coleman Andrews, former State auditor of Virginia, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania attended by more than 250 municipal finance officers representing cities and towns in seven Eastern States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Railroad management opened today its fifteen days of argument before a Presidential fact-finding commission that the railroads are not in sufficiently strong financial position to meet the wage increases demanded by nearly 1,250,000 workers.

NEW WINDSOR, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Rejecting the proffered unity of Leftist groups, speakers attending the annual conference of the Teachers Guild Associates and the New York Teachers Guild declared that there could be no united front with Communist or other totalitarian groups in the teaching profession.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 3 -- The release of men under provisions of the Service Extension Act last week already has taken several key men from permanent personnel units of Camp Upton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Supporters of Administration foreign policy quickly seized tonight upon the sinking of the tanker I.C. White as new evidence that the Neutrality Act should be amended. Some of the President's critics, however, declared their positions vere not changed by the incident.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- "Tulip Time in Michigan," a screen story by Walter Reisch, was purchased today by Metro and added to Joe Pasternak's production schedule. The yarn, which deals with a Dutch-American tulip grower and his seven daughters, will provide roles for Kathryn Grayson, Ann Rutherford, Virginia Grey, Jackie Horner and three other young stock players.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 -- Contrary to reports from Washington that conversations between the United States and Japan had broken down, Spokesman Koh Ishii said today that the talks were continuing. At the same time the press was highly skeptical of the results of the Moscow conference, declaring neither side could trust the other.

Salvatore Sabbatino, vice president of Sabbatino Co., suppliers of stevedores, surrendered at District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office yesterday and was booked on a charge of homicide for the killing of Emil Camarda, an important leader in the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. of L.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 3 -- Japanese mining, trade and banking interests in British Malaya worth millions of dollars have virtually ceased to exist, at least temporarily, as a result of British freezing of Japanese assets on top of earlier war restrictions and the Chinese boycott.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Oct 3 -- Chill nights, as North Country temperatures dropped into the thirties this week, turned thoughts of the Fourth Armored Division to Winter training, one of the purposes for locating the mechanized force in this region.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Red-headed Al Brosch, who presides over the pro shop at the State's Bethpage Park golf courses, and Willie Goggin, successor to Benny Hogan at the Century Club in Westchester, will battle over the thirty-six-hole route at the Rockville Country Club tomorrow to see who will hold the metropolitan P. G.A. title.

When the President Grant of the American Presidents Line docked at Pier 5, Staten Island, yesterday after a four-month voyage around the world, she brought four former Yugoslav Government officials who fled from Belgrade April 15 to escape the German Army.

Remedial legislation intended to remove the necessity of competitive bidding and to remove other obstacles to the program of spreading defense orders among small contractors will soon be proposed to Congress by government agencies, Floyd B. Odium, director of the contract distribution division of OPM, declared last night.

Builders and mortgage men may expect in the post-war era a vast public and private construction program similar to that which followed the first World War, Charles F. Palmer, Defense Housing Coordinator, yesterday told the members of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Pan American Airways said tonight that a Miami-to-San Juan seaplane "water-looped' on landing at San Juan, Puerto Rico, today and that two babies were missing in the complement of twenty-one passengers.

A complex labor row resulted in the closing last night of all sixty-seven retail shops of the Hanscom Baking Corporation in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens. Nearly 1,000 bakers, drivers and clerks were affected by the suspension.

Dr. Joao Antonio de Bianchi, the Portuguese Minister, and Mme. de Bianchi gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Dr. Ruy E. Ulrich, former Ambassador from Portugal to London, and Mme. Ulrich, who are here for their first visit and are returning shortly to Portugal.

Yesterday's clouds, not content with washing out the world series ball game at Ebbets Field, tarried long enough last night to deny metropolitan observers an opportunity to spy on that neighboring world, Mars, in its closest approach to the earth until 1956.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 3 -- The Very Rev. Edmund A. Walsh, vice president of Georgetown University, today praised President Roosevelt's latest move to win religious liberty in Russia.

Investment Market The underwriting community, which is gradually shaking off the effects of its loss on last Monday in competition with insurance companies for $90,000,000 of American Telephone Telegraph 2 3/4 per cent debentures, is preparing to "try its luck" again in several competitive sales slated for next week.

MONROE, N.C., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Declaring that America was "faced with war under circumstances predicting the severest war test the nation has ever faced," Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding, told the officers of his First Army here today that "force, and superior force only, will save us in this national crisis."

As a result of the success of a consistent newspaper advertising campaign, the General Tire and Rubber Company will continue its newspaper advertising through the Fall months, L.A. McQueen, vice president in charge of sales, reported yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 3 -- The rationing of all products, including food, was advocated today by the press to eliminate hoarding, profiteeing and shortage.

While "beat-the-tax" buying of furs was notably heavy at retail in many cities throughout the country this week, reorders in the wholesale markets eased somewhat. Buyers and manufacturers reported that a reaction in September is normal, but volume last month was well above expectations.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 3 -- Maurice J. (Clipper) Smith, the original Rockne Watch Charm guard, knows a good football player when he sees one and when he talks about him the description has a graphic vividness that leaves an indelible stamp.

Jacob L. Webb, a great-great-grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, who was married after an airplane elopement last Sunday to Miss Lenore Lemmon of New York City, was arrested in his room at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday morning on a warrant charging him with issuing two worthless checks for $20 and $100 at the Hotel Pierre.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3 -- Turkey will sign her new trade pact with Germany next Tuesday, well-informed sources said this afternoon.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3 -- The revolt of the Yugoslavs has attained the proportions of warfare, and with new disorders in Croatia and large-scale daytime attacks by Serbian irregular army units in South and Central Serbia, the Reich and Italy actually are faced with a newly developing Balkan front, according to reports tonight from foreign military sources here.

The muted strains in Herr Hitler's performance in the Sportpalast yesterday were as striking as the loud crescendos. The grandiose claims of success on the Russian front contained no hint of when the slaughter might be expected to end. Except for an oblique suggestion in the reference to Britain's search for help, there was no mention of the part the United States is playing in the war.

Despite the repudiation of the promoting committees by Governor Lehman and other sponsors, the dinner forum on "Europe Today" will be held at the Hotel Biltmore next Thursday evening, it was announced last night by Lillian Hellman, who is co-chairman with Ernest Hemingway.

Accustomed as is Wall Street to the claims of the Nazi Chancellor in his public utterances, it was forced yesterday to strain its thinking powers in an attempt to find corroboration of his assertion that Russia had been broken "forever," for the statement did not dovetail with news dispatches at hand from other quarters.

The cultural section of Austrian Action, Inc., presented the first of a series of concerts last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, whereby artists from Austria have the opportunity accorded them of contributing to the cause of their native land.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The I.C. White was the eighth American-owned ship sunk since the outbreak of the war. Others were:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Exports of merchandise from the United States in July amounted to $354,649,000, compared with $316,669,000 in the same month last year, the Department of Commerce reported today in revised statistics based on geographical areas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Office of Price Administration today amended its pric ceiling record-keeping requirements affecting rayon greige goods to preserve trade secrets concerning the construction of new weaves of cloth.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 3 -- Mrs. W. Haggin Perry of Cobham, Va., riding Cornish Hills, today captured the Henry G. Vaughn Memorial Trophy, one of the most interesting events of the second program of the thirty-ninth annual Piping Rock horse show.

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 3 -- This reservation continued to display all week the aspects of a forgotten town. With more than 20,000 troops from here off to manoeuvres in the South, the few remaining units are performing routine guard functions. Nearly 1,000 buildings stand vacant.

Manhattan College's football team, showing speed and deception on the offense, alertness and strength on the defense, routed George Washington University, 23 -- 0, under the lights at the Polo Grounds last night. The smartly drilled Kelly Green eleven was in command throughout, never permitting the Colonials to advance beyond the 28-yard line.

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous decision yesterday, upheld the ruling of Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga that the Board of Higher Education was without power to abolish Townsend Harris High School, the preparatory school operated as an adjunct to City College, and that the school must be continued.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Brooklyn's move of making available a number of single-game reserved seat tickets for each of the world series games at Ebbets Field is one of the most constructive of the many progressive steps taken by the much-maligned Larry MacPhail.

The Citizens Union, through its secretary, George H. Hallett Jr., announced yesterday its opposition to the constitutional amendment to be voted on in the November elections that seeks to authorize the diversion of $60,000,000 of the State's grade crossing elimination funds for highway and parkway construction.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 3 -- Faith in the future of the privately endowed college, if it pursues the interests of higher education and subordinates those of institutional prosperity, was expressed today by Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, at the annual Founder's Day convocation at Lehigh University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Press-radio relationships and the relative merits and importance of newspapers and radio broadcasting in the presentation of news were discussed at today's hearing on newspaper ownership of stations before the Federal Communications Commission by Dr. Carl J. Friedrich and Dr. Zechariah Chafee Jr., both of Harvard.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- The nation-wide edict of Theatre Authority, Inc., that no more free shows may be put on for soldiers by union-controlled amusement folk, went into effect tonight.

VTCHY, France, Oct. 3 -- A new law is to be issued very soon regulating the consumption of alcoholic beverages in France. It will modify the law of Aug. 23, 1940, hailed at the time as definitely ending alcoholism.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The International Mercantile Marine Company will pay off at par its 6 per cent bonds due on Oct. 1, it was learned here tonight. The amount of the matured issue is $11,469,000.

The Whitney Museum will open on Tuesday an exhibition consisting of a selection of works from its permanent collection, including paintings, water-colors, drawings and prints. For the first time in its history the museum will present, in addition to this showing, work by a group of children who attended the Saturday art classes directed by August Peck.

"World-Wide Communion Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in churches of the Protestant faith in the New York area. Prayers will be offered for "a just peace." There will be not only holy communion at the 11 A.M. services of Protestant Episcopal, Methodist and other branches of Protestantism, as is the custom the first Sunday of each month, but in all houses of worship.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- It was Bach, Beethoven and Brahms at the opening of the forty-second season of the Philadelphia Orchestra at the Academy of Music this afternoon, but the "Star-Spangled Banner" for a few moments turned the concert into an old-fashioned community songfest.
BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- In his speech today Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler said:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 29 there appears an article by Hanson W. Baldwin under the caption "War Games Show Army Still Lags." The article speaks of Negro troops as a "big and dangerous exception to the general high standard of the American soldier."

Herr Hitler opened the third "Winter Relief Drive" yesterday at the Sportpalast in Berlin with the same boasts of Nazi victories and the same derision of his enemies that he used on the same occasion thirteen months ago. Last year he had conquered Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands, Belgium and France, and was about to order the all-out air attack which he thought would bring Britain to her knees.

Brooklyn Trust The Brooklyn Trust Company reported as of Sept. 30 total deposits of $140,345,635 and total assets of $155,804,086, compared respectively with $134,713,619 and $150,833,945 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $53,712,390, against $53,014,275; holdings of United States Government securities to $45,786,729, against $45,839,599, and loans and discounts to $35,957,250, against $34,318,532.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, undertook today the control of mill margins in the manufacture of carded cotton yarns by establishing a price ceiling schedule which automatically fluctuates 1/2 cent per pound with each upward or downward movement of 44 points in the "spot" price of raw cotton.

With at least two sizable issues scheduled to be sold, the total of new State and municipal offerings next week will be boosted to $21,846,732, compared with $11,130,657 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $31,532,989.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Roosevelt revealed today that he had instructed W. Averell Harriman, head of the United States delegation to the Moscow tripartite conference, to take up with the Stalin government the question of religious freedom in the Soviet Union.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Preparations for the testing of air defenses in parts of the Northeast and Middle Atlantic States next week are being completed here at the headquarters of the First Air Force and its component, the First Interceptor Command.

Trading was mostly fair In the wholesale markets yesterday. Fresh pork cuts were weak to lower and heavyweight lamb was lower. Lightweight lamb and other classes were mostly unchanged in price. The kosher markets were fairly active and prices were about steady with Thursday's markets.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 3 -- After only a month and four days in office, the Government of Premier Arthur W. Fadden fell today and the Labor leader, John Curtin, accepted a commission to form a new government. He is Australia's fifth Labor Prime Minister.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is refleeted in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

Paper Mill Rate at New High Paper mill operations in this country rose to a new high last week, when a figure of 105.2 per cent of capacity was reached, the American Paper and Pulp Association reported yesterday. The previous high was reached in the week ended Sept. 13, when a figure of 104.0 was reported.

FORT BENNING, Oct. 3 -- Instructions issued by the Fourth Army Corps have tentatively named Chester, S.C., as the main concentration area for the Fourth Motorized Division when it moves to the Carolinas for the First Army manoeuvres, November 3-30.

AT the end of June, last year, Arthur Gerald Donahue was piloting a cultivator in a green Minnesota cornfield, the Sinclair Lewis country, and at the beginning of August he was piloting a Spitfire in the Battle of Britain.

Denmark became Germany's first "Nordic Protectorate" through no fault of her own. Unlike Norway, France, Belgium and the Netherlands, she had no army and no means of resistance. When the Germans invaded her territory she had to succumb and the invader took possession almost without bloodshed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 3 -- Walter P. Armstrong of Memphis, chosen president today of the American Bar Association at the final session of its convention, appealed for loyal and unanimous support of the decisions of our government after they had been made, "without carping criticisms or partisan bickering."

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The use of the word "bums" when referring to the Brooklyn baseball team by sports writers and radio commentators seems to be an unfortunate choice of words. The writers and speakers evidently are not motivated by a desire to ridicule the club or reflect upon the characters of the players when employing the expression, yet certain damage is being done.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- There has been no further news of Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt's Ukrainian drive since the German occupation of Poltava was admitted early this week, but it was indicated here today that the Russians are organizing strong defenses to protect the Donets coal basin, which according to the newspaper Pravda is admittedly threatened.
Football has another of its opening days -- positively the last -- this afternoon, with all the big guns joining in the barrage due to last until New Year's.

As the special master, John Kirkland Clark, sets them forth in a report filed in Federal court, the facts are these: Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., established a boycott against the products of eleven major electrical manufacturers.

VICHY, France, Oct 3 -- Attempts to blow up seven synagogues were made in Paris during the hours between 1 A.M. and 5 A.M. today. In six instances they were successful, and the damage done was considerable, only the external walls of the structures remaining.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 3 -- Secretary Morgenthau disclosed plans today to borrow $1,000,000,000 or more next week in what may be the largest cash financing by the Treasury since the World War era.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Deftly-stroked iron shots were valuable weapons for Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Plandome and her Lakeville partner, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson, as they triumphed today in the final of the Long Island Women's Golf Association four-ball best-ball handicap tourney.

A substantial number of buying orders for cotton which came into the ring in the final hour yesterday held the market to moderate losses. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 11 points to up 1 point from Thursday's closing values.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3 -- A decrease in juvenile delinquency and vandalism in areas providing recreation facilities was noted by James Mulholland of the New York City Park Department in an address today before the National Recreation Congress.

President Roosevelt's historic meeting at sea with Prime Minister Winston Churchill was forecast last January by a self-confessed agent of the German espionage service, according to testimony yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial.

In his speech before the bankers' convention in Chicago Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau laid stronger emphasis than ever before upon the need for broadening the sale of Defense Savings Bonds. In the five months since the program started it has yielded $1,500,000,000 from 2,500,000 investors.

Making their first joint broadcast, President Roosevelt and Wendell Willkie called on the American people last night to give the fullest possible support to this year's campaign of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs as an expression of their determination to safeguard and perpetuate the democratic system.

An impasse between Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Education over the granting of sabbatical leaves to clerical employes was complicated further yesterday when City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio stopped payment on September checks issued to thirty-five library assistants, laboratory assistants and teacher clerks.
WASHINGTON, Oct 3 -- President Roosevelt expects to make known Tuesday to a bipartisan delegation of Senate leaders his proposals for revision of the Neutrality Act.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Oct. 4 -- German forces on the front southwest of Leningrad were reported by Moscow early today to be attempting in vain large-scale counter-attacks in a wide area with the aim of breaking the Russian line established yesterday when the city's defenders established contact with large tank divisions from the Valdai Heights for the first major change in the northern situation in four weeks.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 3 -- Charles A. Lindbergh tonight told a rally sponsored by the America First Committee that President Roosevelt was leading the United States along a road which, "not many steps ahead," might involve the suspension of the Congressional elections in 1942.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The German appeared tonight to be directing the mightiest of pressure against Kharkov and the industrially important Donets Basin, colliding head-on with counter-attacks in which the Russians used both tanks and armored trains.

Louis Waldman, former Socialist State chairman and former member of the State executive committee of the American Labor party, announced yesterday that he would support District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic nominee for Mayor, declaring that the prime issue of this campaign was whether New York City was to have "a Communist United Front administration for the next four years."

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3 -- Reports from Bulgaria to foreign news sources here tonight said that King Boris had issued a special order granting amnesty to nearly 300 Bulgarian political prisoners in an effort to end the disorders and spreading revolt in his country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The National Defense Mediation Board announced tonight an agreement to end the dispute between the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation, San Diego, Calif., and a local of the International Association of Machinists, A.F. of L.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- John C. Blackall, Commissioner of Insurance for Connecticut, asserted here today that the "greatest effect of the present war on insurance, as well as on every other business, is to create a very profound uncertainty that challenges the judgment of all of us."

A majority of the apartments taken in the "post-moving day" leasing reported yesterday were in East Side buildings, although the West Side came in for a good share. Many of the lessees favored houses in the Seventies and Eighties as well as in the avenues on both sides of the park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The first case in which the Office of Production Management is alleged to have been a party to coercion and a conspiracy with the American Federation of Labor to grant to the federation's building trade unions a monopoly of defense construction in violation of the antitrust laws is under investigation by Thurman Arnold, special assistant attorney general.
NEW YORK Mrs. Frederick A. Sterling, wife of the United States Minister to Sweden, has arrived from Newport and is at Hampshire House.
