ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3 -- Reports from Bulgaria to foreign news sources here tonight said that King Boris had issued a special order granting amnesty to nearly 300 Bulgarian political prisoners in an effort to end the disorders and spreading revolt in his country.

WHEN a child is physically handicapped, parents feel about him pretty much as they do about a normal child -- only more so. Wise or unwise, anxious or indifferent, protective or ambitious, whatever the attitude, the child's disability seems only to intensify it.

THE 1941 metropolitan championships will be played over an eight-day period beginning on Oct. 19 and ending on Oct. 26. This is the principal tournament held in New York during the Fall, and often attracts as strong a field as the Eastern championships in the Spring.

WHEN Mayor La Guardia, as head of the Office of Civilian Defense, named Alice Marble director of physical training for women, he chose a leader who is an example as well as an enthusiastic advocate of physical fitness. Miss Marble became national women's tennis champion the hard way, retired undefeated and has preached physical training all over the country.

The Yankees had to go to Flatbush to be overtaken by the spirit of celebration. They beat the Dodgers in the latters' backyard yesterday and the American League champions burst out in their first demonstration of jubilation since the start of the classic.

WHEN Virginia Woolf quietly wrote a farewell note to her husband, took her stick -- so fixed is habit -- and went on her favorite walk across the sum- mery meadows down to the Ouse to slip under the water, it was a sad hour for English letters.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 4 -- The last of the high goal polo matches of the season on Long Island will take place tomorrow afternoon on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club when two picked teams, fresh from triumphs in the National Open Championship and the Waterbury Cup matches, will compete in the annual contest for the Writers Cup.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey, continuing dictation in open court of his opinion in the government's anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America, again ruled yesterday against the government as he had on the previous ten of the twelve divisions into which the government's charges were organized.

WHO knows," the Shadow asked, "what evil lurks in the hearts of men?" The Shadow knew, as usual, while children from here to California trotted happily along to their nightmares, and, speaking of mayhem, Joe Louis cut down the Yogi man, Lou Nova, under a chilly Autumn sky.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the President's comparatively recent statement announcing the establishment of the new OPM Division of Contract Distribution, headed by Floyd B. Odlum, occurs this statement:

It was in this month three years ago that a certain radio dramatization frightened a good many Americans out of their wits. The Martians did not land in New Jersey. The "War of the Worlds," so convincingly broadcast, turned out to be merely the re-enactment of an old fantasy by that master of scientific fantasy, H.G. Wells.

Documentary motion pictures will be used to supplement classroom instruction and field trip observation in the second half of a required course on "Contemporary Civilization" in a "three-dimensional education" experiment at Columbia College.

IN the last month or so most women's stream of consciousness has been banging back persistently to just one topic -- money; how to run a home in the coming year with some degree of grace and pleasure and still keep within a possible budget.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- How a pilotless, radio-controlled airplane may be landed safely should the engine go dead, or the plane get out of range of the controlling radio signals is revealed in a patent (2,257,277) awarded to Walter H. Righter and Kenneth W. Case of Glendale, Calif.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 4 -- Duke exploded three touchdowns in the first half today to crush Tennessee, 19 to 0, before a homecoming crowd of 48,000 and gain sweet revenge for numerous losses inflicted by the Volunteers in recent years.

HAZLETON, Pa., Oct. 4 -- A revolt against increased union dues and assessments that had kept 20,000 men idle for twenty-six days in District 7 of the C.I.O. United Mine Workers ended today when leaders of the insurrection said they would make no attempt to thwart the expressed wish of a majority of the strikers to return to work.

EVEN before the words blitz, panzer, appeaser, fifth columnist and Quisling invaded our vocabularies we had at our command a rich assortment of language. The literacy test for new voters in New York State embraces 10,000 words; and Professor Edward L. Thorndike, the indefatigable word-counter of Columbia University's Teachers College, reports that readers encounter some 30,000 different words in such publications as THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine.

DUBLIN SOME months ago I wrote a pleasantly optimistic article on the renaissance the war was to cause in the Irish theatre. Since then Ireland has become (to parody the old classroom definition) a small body of land completely surrounded by war.
WITH 90-horsepower engines of either six or eight cylinders, the 1942 Ford cars feature new exterior lines and new styling within.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- Fresh hints that one consequence of the wave of anti-German activity in occupied Europe would be severe new measures against the Jews were seen today in comments of the Czech and German press. The Nazi-controlled press in the Bohemian Protectorate asserted the Jews were responsible for the "planned revolt" there, and one leading newspaper, the Narodni Politika, demanded the transportation of all Jews out of large Czech towns.

THE Curtis Institute of Music opens tomorrow for its eighteenth season. New faculty members include Richard Bonelli, Emanuel Feuermann, Mieczyslaw Munz and Gian-Carlo Menotti. The orchestration course given by Samuel Barber starts this Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor has announced the allotment of $100,000 additional Federal funds for the care and treatment of children afflicted with infantile paralysis in those States where epidemics of this disease have been encountered in recent weeks.
ALTHOUGH it did not seem possible at the zero hour when the moving men left, the apartments into which many New Yorkers moved last week are now gradually emerging from chaos to order.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 4 -- The college library and the seasoned professor can do much to teach freshmen good habits for living, according to officials at New Jersey College for Women. This year's freshmen are provided with a special collection of diversified reading material, designed to give advice on everything from the liberal arts to latest fashions, while faculty members stand by, ready to give assistance for college living.

ALL of Britain's "little men" have a single thought on the war -- it has got to be won, somehow. About Adolf Hitler there is one idea also -- he has got to be "deposed." But about the Germans themselves, investigation shows, there is a vast confusion of thought.

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 4 -- An immense improvement over mess halls, tents, theatres and open air arenas in which Fort Dix chaplains have been compelled to hold religious services for the last year are the twelve chapels just completed that will be formally accepted tomorrow morning.
The play-by-play description of the third game of the world series at Ebbets Field yesterday follows:

In the last few years there has been a noticeable increase in the use of fences by home owners. A fence not only serves certain definite practical purposes; it may also be one of the most decorative features of the home grounds. Building a fence is important because it is a permanent and important part of the total landscaping scheme -- something one will live with for years.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 4 -- The research of faculty members and students, larger enrollment in varied courses, lectures, programs and vacations all point to a strengthening of the interest at Wellesley College in the Latin-American countries.

Having thrown a searchlight on the children's hour, wherever one would be found on the air, the Radio Council on Children's ProTrams has found several things to criticize in both quantity and quality as well and has set them down or the record.

The Office of Production Management announced on Wednesday that it had taken immediate steps to carry out a decision of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board that a further 10,000,000-ton expansion of the nation's steel-making capacity was desirable.

IF there is such a thing as seasonal reading, Margaret Culkin Bantling's new novel, "A Week in New York," can be put in the warm weather category. It's the story of several people from Overland, a small city four or five hours' flying distance from New York, who find themselves, for various reasons, in the metropolis for a week.

Ebbets Field yesterday was a psychiatrist's nightmare come noisily to life and frenzied action. Hatless, coatless and shirtless Dodger fans, cooked and fried by ardent sun in the bleachers, roared themselves into advanced hoarseness in a noble but losing cause.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Hanson W. Baldwin's description of the low morale of the Army and its deficiencies in training in THE TIMES closes with these words: "Fundamentally, a tautening up all along the line, started by the War Department, is one of the greatest needs.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 4 -- It is axiomatic that in wartime the opposing sides in their various propaganda efforts attempt to annex to themselves the highest moral authorities, rising in boastful assertions to include in the final thrust the authority of Divinity.
Belmont Park's getaway day crowd of 26,996 came up all standing twice yesterday as crack thoroughbreds set records that doubtless will stand for many a year to come.

To some fortunate souls Autumn brings the joys of a cozy hearth, clear, cold, country nights, the lonesome fragrance of burning leaves; but to many homemakers it means that the painters move in and the householders temporarily move out -- if they are lucky.

A new series of lectures and courses at the Iranian Institute, 724 Fifth Avenue, will start tomorrow. Associated with the institute since its inception more than ten years ago under the directorship of Professor Arthur Upham Pope are a number of American and European authorities in the field of Persian and Near Eastern languages, art, architecture and history.

Wendell L. Willkie will give the principal address at a dinner Tuesday night in the Hotel Commodore, beginning the fifth merged campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, it was announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 4 -- "The Finnish Government has been awaiting the return from Germany of V.A. Tanner -- leader of the Social Democratic Party and Minister of Industry, who left Stockholm this morning by air for Helsinki -- before forwarding its reply to the British warning," a highly qualified neutral observer told this correspondent yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- German authorized sources maintained the closest secrecy concerning the vast new operations in Russia but Adolf Hitler's own newspaper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, said that the British and American conferees at the Russian aid conference would be well advised "to leave the Soviet capital in a hurry."

GAS: Odorizer Wanted We all know that thousands of people lose their lives because they fail to detect the odor of gas escaping from a gas jet. Surely there are plenty of substances, which at trifling cost, could be put in gas tanks and thus create such a distinctive smell that attention would at once be drawn to the fact that coal gas was filling the room.

A complaint accusing the Hanscom Baking Corporation of refusal to negotiate a contract with Local 50 of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, A.F. of L., was filed with the State Labor Relations Board yesterday by Herman E. Cooper, counsel for the union.

SEVERAL gallery shows opening last week have served to focus attention upon a form of art that has passed through some pretty violent vicissitudes in the last hundred years. We are asked to scrutinize and, if we can, to evaluate anew what has come to be called the story-telling picture.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- A crowd of 10,000 watched Army down The Citadel, 19 -- 6, today in the opening game of the West Pointers' football season. Seven hundred cadets from the Charleston, S.C., institution accompanied, their team, here, and a company of fifty put on a smart military drill on the field between the halves.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The national debate on the relation of wages to inflation is likely to increase in intensity, if not in bitterness, in the next months in view of the increasingly upward surge of hourly rates and average incomes of hourly paid workers.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 5 -- Along with an attack for the second night in succession on Brest -- haven, of the Nazi battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau -- British bombers through Friday night blasted at port works at Rotterdam, Antwerp and Dunkerque.

OF the two works to be conducted by Fritz Busch for the New Opera Company special interest will center in Verdi's "Macbeth," which, with Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte," also under his leadership, will form the Glyndebourne Festival offerings of the troupe's initial season, starting Oct. 14 at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 4 -- Sophomore Tom Kuzma and the veteran Bob Westfall pooled their talents today to blaze the way for the lone touchdown as Michigan's Wolverines triumphed, 6 to 0, over Iowa's Hawkeyes in the season's first Western Conference football game.

MR. MAGEE'S happily humorous novel concerns itself with a group of upperclass English people, all mildly unscrupulous and keen as Yankee horse-traders to take advantage of each other. Today they are all in a jam, but hoping and planning for the other kind of jam tomorrow.

THE State Department recently announced that the United States and India would soon exchange diplomatic representatives for the first time. With the title of United States Commissioner at Delhi, the American envoy will assume his duties some time this Fall.

War-relief projects of the English-Speaking Union here will receive aid from a benefit performance of "The Wookey" on the night of Nov. 6 at the Plymouth Theatre. Mrs. Carll Tucker is chairman and Mrs. Paul Moore and Mrs. William-Barton Eddison vice chairman of the benefit committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 -- Harry Bridges, State C.I.O. director, pledged full support to President Roosevelt in the fight to defeat nazism in a speech today at the State C.I.O. convention. He urged members of C.I.O. unions to do likewise.

In commenting on Mayor La Guardia's opening campaign speech, John R. Davies, whom the Mayor defeated for the Republican nomination and who is circulating independent nominating petitions, said last night that he agreed that the Mayor had "transformed" the city.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $487,613,470 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Sept. 30 was $28.02, compared with $28.32.

The most intensive music education program in the history of Queens College will begin this semester, it was indicated yesterday with the announcement that a students' music listening room will be opened on the Flushing campus.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 4 -- John J. McClure, Republican leader of Delaware County, was acquitted by a jury today of a charge that he fraudulently converted to his own use $85,000 paid him from the sale of the Chester Water Works to the Chester Municipal Authority.

RETURN: The chief resident of the red-brick British Embassy on Washington's Massachusetts Avenue returned last week after more than a months absence abroad. Lord Halifax had been in Britain to report to Prime Minister Churchill and other government leaders and to take a brief rest.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Since so much stress is now being laid on good English and spoken English Just now, please allow me to add a word Detlev W. Schumann of Brown University, in your issue of 7 September, says: "The most flagrant of all acts of aggression by the an- cient Germans: the invasion of Britain in the fifth century by the Angles and Saxons."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Immediate authorization of a study of post-war transportation facilities was urged today by Senator Mead of New York, as a step toward preventing economic dislocation after the war.

A discussion of probable conditions confronting the American merchant marine in world trade at the expiration of the emergency is expected to be one of the important features of the American Merchant Marine Conference and fifteenth annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States to ba held Oct. 21-24 at San Francisco.

CHARLES MORGAN has the casual charm of honesty that probably is inevitable in a poet who has survived the toughening training, starting at the age of twelve, that is a prelude for a career as a British naval officer.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Plans have been perfected for the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of Russell Sage College, and some 500 of the alumnae have indicated their intention of returning to the campus next week. They will find, however, not the usual academic festival but a program titled the Inter-American Week of Troy, dedicated to the larger service of national interests.
BERLIN, Oct. 4 (AP) -- This communique was issued today from Adolf Hitler's headquarters:
LONDON. ART and politics are seldom joined to good purpose, but the Dvorak centenary celebrations which have been held here lately have given satisfaction to both musician and politician.

Although the temperature stood at 84 degrees on the playing field, it took the players of Fordham and Southern Methodist University more than three periods of football to warm up yesterday. But when they finally did, they blazed all over the Polo Grounds gridiron.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Due to a combination of accelerated production of war supplies and inflated costs, the Administration raised its estimate today of defense expenditures for the current fiscal year to $18,000,000,000, as compared to a forecast of $10,811,000,000 when the 1942 budget was announced in January.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- With museums and other cultural institutions as study centers, a new form of decentralized adult education will get under way in Philadelphia on Tuesday. This unique movement, called The Junto, takes its name from the club of that name which Benjamin Franklin established in 1727 for the mutual exchange of knowledge among his young acquaintances.
THE title for Theodore Roethke's first book of poems, "Open House," derives from the first poem:

Fall is the time to watch football games and to plant roses. Like all other types of gardening, if one is to have a full measure of success he must plan several months ahead. This gives the plants on opportunity to become, thoroughly established before their normal blooming period arrives.

Definite action is expected to be taken this week by retailers on the request by Price Administrator Henderson that no mark-up be taken on manufacturers' excise taxes to avoid the threat to the price structure which "pyramiding" the tax would engender.

NORTON, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Wheaton College will introduce a course in civilian defense this week, according to the report of a faculty-student committee which has completed a method of procedure for the year.

THIS "Treasury of the World's Greatest Litter" (subtitle) contains thirty selections for quick reading, in the humorous mode with which "How to Lose Friends and Alienate People" has already acquainted a large public. But "Readers Digest Very Little" offers a wider variety of agile fun than did its predecessor.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 4 -- Seventeen more members of the crew of the torpedoed American-owned tanker I.C. White, flying the Panama flag, were picked up at sea today by the American freight and passenger steamer Delnorte.

THE Colorado of Mr. Woodbury's title is the river, not the State, Most of the book is devoted to the long battle to get enough of the river into the Imperial Valley for irrigation, and then to keep the rest of it out.

VICHY, France, Oct. 4 -- General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, Edouard Daladier, Leon Blum and other prisoners at Bourrasol near here will be transferred to internment in a fortified place until the end of the war, according to predictions in the Paris press today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Confronted by a surprise move of the Westchester County Republican Committee in pledging itself unanimously to oppose abolition of the County Board of Supervisors, taxpayers organizations and women's clubs fought on today for adoption of the November proposition that would substitute a board of eleven legislators for the present board of forty-four supervisors.

Two Columbia plays, identical in both conception and execution but differing only in yardage covered, gave the Lions a sparkling 13-to-6 victory over Brown before a gathering of 12,000 at Baker Field yesterday.

REGINALD Denham will be starting his season's activities next week, having recruited the services of Henry Hull for the leading role in the Edward Percy work, "Play With Fire." The play was seen in London under the name of "Beneath the Surface," with Robert Morley portraying the central character, a gentleman not averse to trading in stolen merchandise and the like.
THE NEW TORK TIMES index of business activity continued its decline last week. The index dropped to 128.2 from 128.3 for the week ended Sept. 20. It stood at 111.7 for the week ended Sept. 28, 1940.

IT is a happy event that this second volume in the Sovereign States series chances to deal with North Carolina, and that Mr. Daniels paints the portrait. The Tar Heel State is today the most interesting of all in that richly interesting region which was the Confederacy.

THERE is gallantry in sacri- fice for an ideal. When such sacrifice is made by a rea- soning human we term it heroism, but when performed by an unreasoning fish we pass it off lightly under the heading of instinct.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Joseph Jolles, Polish-born founder of Vienna's Jolles Studio, makers of petit point embroidery, and a fugitive from the Nazi invasion of Austria, committed suicide early today by slashing his throat and wrists with a razor blade in his home at 243 Boulevard here.

Mayor La Guardia's statement that he had ordered no more "licenses" to be issued for gasoline stations in New York City during the emergency brought the reaction yesterday from a spokesman for the gasoline retailers that they approved his intent but questioned his ability to stop construction legally.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra opens its 100th anniversary season next Thursday night and it was announced last night that with still four days to go, more subscriptions already had been sold than for any of the last five seasons and that last season's total had been exceeded by 20 per cent.
Doubt was expressed in official Swiss quarters here last week that Great Britain intended to tighten her blockade of Switzerland, as reported from London the previous week.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Rutgers scored its second victory of the season today, defeating Springfield by 26 to 0 before 8,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- James J. McEntee, Civilian Conservation Corps director, said today the agency probably would turn back into the treasury at the end of this fiscal year $47,000,000 of its $247,000,000 appropriations, unneeded because of the reduced number of enrollees.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Military aircraft manufacturers delivered 1,914 airplanes in September, according to a report today by the Office of Production Management.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4 -- In a plane leaving Mexico City for the United States next Tuesday will be four Mexicans making a journey to Madrid at the expense of the Spanish Government to take part, with other Latin Americans, in a meeting expected to mark the beginning of a new and intense Axis propaganda effort throughout Latin America.

Choosing trees to shade sidewalks has become fairly simple, especially in cities where a scant half dozen kinds are officially approved; but choosing trees for one's own back yard is limited only by preference and the purpose to be accomplished in having them there.

THERE is an extraordinary quality to this book, not unlike that which Peter and Alban Dominick ascribed to one of its inconspicuous but basically important characters, Andy Ockham. On their way to his deathbed they tried to grasp and express it.

WHEN Jean Benoit-Levy first visited this country seven years ago for a brief series of lectures French films were on the ascendant and among them no one could forget his rarely compassionate "La Maternelle" or the equally tender "Ballerina."

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 4 -- Challenging the present economic system of government in its control of natural resources, speakers at the opening sessions today of the nineteenth assembly of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference looked to the future and began suggesting ways to prevent what the Right Rev. Mgr. L.C. Ligutti termed a "post-war chaos."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Viscount Halifax, emphasizing at a press conference today the need of aircraft to prepare for the eventual British offensive on the Continent, said that one bomber in 1941 was worth two or three in 1942.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Wexler and Shagrin's Red Dock captured the $5,000 added Autumn Handicap at Hawthorne today, with Mucho Gusto, Pink Gal and Sir Kid, the leading choices, trailing in the mile and one-sixteenth feature.

LETTERS have been pouring in, and doubtless will continue to do so, about what one correspondent calls a "prize mistake" in our column of Sept. 21. We referred to the St. James Bible when we meant the King James version.

With the six-day registration period to qualify voters for the coming November municipal elections opening throughout the city tomorrow, all indications last night pointed to a record turnout for a city election.

Five thousand members of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, and its women auxiliaries will parade from chapter headquarters, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, to Columbus Circle next Sunday, Columbus Day. The procession will start at 11:30 A.M. Patriotic and religious exercises will be held at the circle at the end of the parade.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Completion of Hamilton College's 1941 Alumni Fund with gifts totaling $26,926 as compared with $8,640 raised a year ago was announced today by President W.H. Cowley.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The National Defense Mediation Board recommended tonight an increase of 33 1/3 per cent in the war bonus rate paid A.F. of L. seamen of the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts and suggested voluntary establishment of machinery similar to the Railway Labor Act for settlement, without work stoppages, of future controversies over bonuses to sailors who enter hazardous waters or ports which are subject to bombing attacks.

IN addition to being a swift, vibrant tale, full of action and suspense. "Thunder in the Earth," Edwin Lanham's new novel, is a kind of compendium of the history of oil. In its scene, Texas in the early 1930's, his book is so richly packed with details and information that one absorbs the whole background of an industry without half realizing it.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- The Red Army has made powerful counterattacks on all fronts, rolling back German advance units, smashing several of them and recapturing dozens of villages, it was reported today as the fifteenth week of the Russo-German war drew to a close.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 4 -- The value of Mount Holyoke's honor work, now in its nineteenth year, has been emphasized by a faculty committee report, based on comments from 362 alumnae who reviewed their honors study in the perspective of the years since graduation.

WORLD WAR I brought Canadian nationality to full bloom and World War II reveals Canada to be an adult nation. Although in Canada -- as well as in every other democracy for the last ten years -- it has been fashionable to describe war as an unmitigated evil, actually it has contributed enormously to the development of the nation.

The sale in competitive bidding last Monday of $90,000,000 of American Telephone and Telegraph Company 2 3/4 per cent debentures to a group of three life insurance companies has a far deeper significance than that of merely depriving the investment banking community of an opportunity to participate in the business.

As national conferences begin to draw programs for women in defense into sharper outlines, a familiar phantom is gradually obscuring earlier visions of planeflying, car-greasing, fire-engineriding women in defense. The specter resembles the old kitchen stove.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 4 -- The Norwegian people were warned today by Josef Terboven, Nazi Commissioner for Norway, that they must accept the "new order" under Major Vidkun Quisling and consider Germany's enemies their own or be incorporated into the Reich and face the prospect of starvation.

WORLD SERIES Marius Russo, Brooklyn-born, pitched the New York Yankees to a 2-1 decision over the Brooklyn Dodgers before 33,100 at Ebbets Field. Thus the American League champions went ahead in the series, two games to one. Fred Fitzsimmons blanked the Yanks for seven innings, but was forced out in the seventh when Russo hit a line drive that struck the Brooklyn hurler on his left leg.

THE second annual conference on lighting and photographic problems to be sponsored by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company of Bloomfield, N.J., will open tomorrow night at Bloomfield. Lasting throughout the week, the conference will include talks on lighting problems in photography at the opening session, a dealers' session on Tuesday, a discussion of photography in war on Wednesday, merit in home movies on Thursday and an exposition and showing of pictures on Friday.

FROM the city already outstanding in the quality of its printing there comes a book perhaps no other place in America could produce; certainly no other has. San Francisco again demonstrates that it possesses the elements necessary for proper esthetic development.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Massachusetts State ended a five-game winning streak for Connecticut University today as they downed the Huskies, 8 -- 6.

DETROIT -- Contrary to some beliefs, there is little likelihood of truck production exceeding passenger-car output during the next calendar year. This is the off-the-record opinion of Office of Production Management officials who were here recently to testify at a Congressional hearing on labor migration.

HOLLYWOOD. BARRING leaks, the Gary Cooper-Barbara Stanwyck film, now in the making, ought to remain a tight mystery until the eve of the holidays, when it gets shown. "Ball of Fire" is Samuel Goldwyn's first comedy in ages, and he has decided it must be a surprise.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Oct. 5 -- Striking from the Nogais Steppe, Red Army troops launched a major counter-offensive yesterday morning along a wide front in an effort to threaten the Germans' eastern flank and relieve the pressure against Crimea.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- A snappy Furdue University eleven throttled the Pitt Panthers' attack in the first quarter and made a second period touchdown to win, 6--0, in Pitt's opening game before 24,000 fans today in Pitt Stadium.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Vassar College students have returned from Summer in their home towns, in work camps, in industrial plants, in student conferences, university Summer schools, travel in this country and South America, and a variety of social welfare and business jobs with a heightened consciousness of their personal relation to public affairs.

Neat and handsome closets being a source of deep satisfaction to all women, this column is pleased to report that there are endless practical and very attractive closet fixings about the stores this year. All people who are overcome by fits of neatness after having recently moved ought to be inspired by what various closet shops have to offer.

The Riverside Museum will open today an exhibition of 200 water-color paintings portraying works of art of pre-Columbian Peru, dating from the earliest Chavin culture, circa 400 A.D., to the Inca culture of the eleventh to the sixteenth century A.D.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 4 -- One hundred years of experience will be brought to bear on the problems and future of liberal education in the United States when the University of Michigan celebrates the centennial of her College of Literature, Science and the Arts, Oct. 15.

THE assertion by Mr. Jewell that I couldn't have had such a bad time eying a ten-year vista of American art is wholly correct. I've had a swell time. It is my conviction that no other period in American art has been so loaded with accomplishment as that of our past quarter-century.

Despite a situation which apparently has reached a temporary impasse, the meeting in Washington last week of the Inter-American Coffee Board ended on an optimistic note. The meeting concerned itself directly with the problem of export quotas for the principal coffee producing nations in Central and South America.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, prime mover in the fight to oust racketeers from positions of influence in the American Federation of Labor, will let other unions do the fighting at this year's A.F. of L. convention, it became known yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- A veteran Colgate eleven, held in check for three periods by hard-fighting Penn State, turned loose the power in the final quarter today to defeat the Nittany Lions, 7 -- 0, before 23,467 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Figures compiled here today show that to further public education in the United States the Federal Government has appropriated or allocated more than $700,000,000 for the year ending June 30, 1942. Over $280,000,000 will be spent directly for carrying on educational functions, and $430,000,000 for activities in which education is a basic objective.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 -- The recommended deportation of Harry Bridges has concentrated new attention on one of the most prolonged and embarrassing issues which the Roosevelt Administration has had to contend with in this part of the nation.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 4 -- R. Sterling Clark's Colchis, who ran a dead heat with Alsab in the Eastern Shore at Havre de Grace last month, came back today to win the fourteenth running of the Richard Johnson Stakes.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 -- United States naval vessels were engaged tonight in a search for the unidentified vessel which sank the tanker I.C. White on Sept. 27.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 -- The Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences has voted special concessions in Harvard College degree requirements "for the duration of the national emergency" for honor students and other approved students of high standing who wish to complete the requirements for the bachelor's degree in three years rather than the customary four years.

To the Radio Editor: THE recent outbursts of indignation appearing in your department and elsewhere in the Sunday TIMES, from listeners who are irritated over the constant mispronunciation of common words by radio announcers and commentators, have been a source of much interest to me for I too have frequently been tempted to commit mayhem upon my innocent little radio set for the same reason.

A UNIQUE radio organization -- largest of its type in the country -- which actually was built and maintained by those within its walls to train minds and hands for defense work, has just passed its first birthday.

Eager to make their own contribution in the national emergency more strongly felt, women of all Protestant denominations will meet tomorrow to review the work they have done and the further services they might give. The conference has been called by the women's cooperating commission of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, and will be held at the hall of Christ Church, 520 Park Avenue.

Drastic reorganization of the evening session program offered by the municipal colleges in this city to enable students to get a more useful and varied course of studies and provide a better working arrangement for the faculty members is recommended in a report by a Board of Higher Education special committee made public yesterday.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI will conduct the first fortnight of concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's centennial season. The opening program on Thursday night will include Beethoven's Symphony No. 5 in C minor, which was played at the first concert of the Philharmonic Society on Dec. 7, 1842.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 4 -- In a contemplative way, Holy Cross College has noted in a recent report by the Rev. John C. Proctor, professor of Greek, an increased attention, to the classics and has encouraged their study as a means of complementing the tenets of Christianity.
THIS is a season of fogs. Along the river front, down by the Battery, off near-by beaches, thick heavy mist is prone to settle and swirl. And where the fog settles, unusual pictures are to be found.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The State Department has been advised, by at least one of those experts whom it summoned to help draft the so-called Neutrality Act, that repeal or fundamental revision of the law will be obtained more easily and expeditiously if the argument is expanded from a mere attack on the act and expressions of Executive regret that it was ever advocated by the Administration.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 4 -- A strong West Virginia defense that held the powerful Navy attack in check during most of the first half collapsed in the last two periods today and the middies rolled through to win the fifth football clash between the schools, 40 to 0, before a crowd of 20,126 in Thompson Stadium.

The net amount of gold required to put Latin America on a gold basis for its post-war trade with the United States and at the same time establish the dollar as a basis of standard value would be $200,000,000 to $250,000,000, in the opinion of D. Stewart Iglehart, president of the Grace Line and W.R. Grace Co., international mercantile shipping house.

To the Art Editor: APROPOS of Mr. Kootz's letter I want to say we have too much painting that is new but not enough new art. It makes little difference if the painting is done in a new technique. That isn't necessarily what gives the vital quality to a picture.

The society's twenty-two chapters in Greater New York will be hostess this week to the New York State conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution, which will be in session at the Hotel Roosevelt, from Wednesday through Friday.

Welfare activities for every important belligerent nation in this country should be coordinated through a central advisory body in order to prevent, existing duplication and waste among the hundreds of agencies that have sprung up since the war, it is recommended by the special committee on war relief agencies appointed by President Roosevelt last March to investigate this problem.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 4 -- Booming prices for bright tobacco -- light in color, and flue cured -- now the highest in some markets since the post-World War year of 1919, are putting many additional millions into the jeans of the growers in the seaboard States.

CANCER AND VITAMINS -- Dr. Jules C. Abels told the American Roentgen Society last week that patients with cancer failed to utilize vitamins normally. In leukemia, a sort of cancer of the blood, the white blood cells contain more vitamin B-1 (thiamin) than those of normal persons.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 4 (AP) -- With national defense requiring 30 per cent of the paper production, Norbert A. McKenna of the Office of Production Management, said today that newspapers and other paper users in the United States would have 21 1/2 million tons of paper in the next year to do "the job which previously only the profligate use of 25 1/2 million tons could accomplish."

To aid the Madison Square Boys Club in its recreational and vocational projects for boys of the middle East Side, a Twilight Concert will be given on the afternoon of Oct. 14 at the Ritz Tower. Among the artists contributing to the program, will be Walter Mills, baritone; Georgia Graves, contralto, and Emilio Osta, pianist and diseur.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- The successful Moscow economic and supply conference, which completed its work this week, rounded out careful preparations made by the Soviet Union for a lengthy struggle with the Axis.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- Burnet Landreth Jr., chairman of the board of directors of the D. Landreth Seed Company of Bristol, Pa., died today at his home in Chestnut Hill. His age was 72.
WHEN the world has gone to the Dogs, Oliver Airedale was naturally one of those who would have to face Caninia's latest crisis, which was indeed the crisis of civilization throughout dog-dom.

Hundreds of examples of forgotten American art that have lain hidden in musty storage rooms for nearly half a century will be placed on public exhibition in New York shortly after Jan. 1 when the National Academy of Design opens its new galleries at 1083 Fifth Avenue.

With the duck season only two weeks off, prospective gunners seem to be worrying about the daily shooting hours, which are from sunrise to 4 P.M.

After a lapse of twenty-one years, they brought the world series to Brooklyn yesterday. But, in an unguarded moment, they also let in the Yankees and the mistake was one which eventually proved fatal.
City College's hopes for a successful football season, were jolted yesterday at the Lewisohn Stadium when the Beavers suffered a 6--0 setback at the hands of a fast University of Buffalo eleven.

Administration spokesmen have made eloquent statements in the last few weeks against any attempt to include control of wages in price control legislation. They have argued, as Secretary Morgenthau put it, that while prices should be fixed, wages should not be.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the article "Devotees of the Desert," by Martha Tucker, in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Sept. 21, I notice the omission of a name which think ought to have been included. I refer to Thomas Keith, born in Leith, Scotland, son of a jeweler there, who was apprenticed to a gunsmith in Edinburgh.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 4 -- The most promising prospect for obtaining energy after present sources such as petroleum are used up is to develop an electric storage battery to be chemically charged by sunlight, Professor C.C. Furnas of Yale University declared here tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- Great Britain was understood tonight to have urged Soviet Russia through diplomatic channels to aid in strengthening the Allies' position, especially in the United States, by cessation of anti-religious propaganda.

CHIT-CHATTING Ilka Chase will switch networks this week, taking her "Penthouse Party" to WJZ's chain Wednesday night at 9:30. Up to now she has conducted her hostess role on WABC. In the shuffle Vaughn Monroe's orchestra has come up with the music assignment, which is the only change in the program's line-up.

Featured by extremely heavy "beat the tax" buying on Monday and Tuesday, department store sales in the New York area showed increases of 40 per cent or more last week over a year ago. Furs, fur-trimmed cloth coats, cosmetics, jewelry and sporting goods led the demand.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- The daily communique of the German Supreme Command today repeated Reicnsfuehrer Hitler's announcement of new operations in Russia, saying that "on the Eastern front offensive operations of great proportions are in progress."

Costumes for Autumn and Winter wear, displayed by young women in society, will be featured at the luncheon and fashion show to be given Wednesday at Hampshire House under the auspices of the Social Service Committee of the New York Skin and Cancer Unit.

ABRAM HAITOWITSCH, the violinist, has entered the managerial realm: Mr. Haitowitsch will present three concerts on Sunday nights, Nov. 23 and 30, and Dec. 21, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Participants will include Lotte Lehmann, Harold Bauer, Charles Kullman, Yves Tinayre, the New York Philharmonic Trio and many others.

TWO more values have been issued in the Union of South Africa's pictorial series directing attention to the Union's war activities, and the Postmaster General in Pretoria has made available photographs of the designs.

The flag of the armed British tanker, the British Captain, has been presented by her captain, W. S. Vittle, to Bundles for Britain in appreciation of the aid given by the organization's Bundles for Bluejackets Division in outfitting seamen with knitted garments and other comforts.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 4 -- The price star of the Corn and Wheat Belt farmer is still in the ascendant. For the sixth consecutive month prices of farm products advanced pretty much all along the line in September, some representing substantial gains, some rather slight.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 4 -- A number of uncensored letters from French citizens who elected recently to leave Syria and Lebanon for the homeland that have been received by friends and relatives here indicate disillusionment and include frank confessions that "an unhappy choice in view of the tragically changed conditions" in the metropolitan area had been made.

As priorities begin to clamp down on residential building, the possible part to be played by the construction industry in carrying the nation through the inevitable post-war readjustment is becoming increasingly important.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 4 -- Political interest here centered today -- after a week in which the Cabinet crisis remained unsolved -- on a statement issued by the Chilean Communist party urging the adoption of anti-Nazi measures and "the establishment of a truly democratic government* * * to seek a solution for the grave problems faced by the people."

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Judge Thomas A. Keating imposed today a penalty of $100 and costs against the first Danbury Traffic Court defendant to contest legal- ity of the alcoholometer, a physio-mechanical device invented recently to determine whether a driver is under the influence of liquor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Formulation of a social mandate as a general declaration of international social policy should be a task for the International Labor Organization, Edward J. Phelan, acting director of the International Labor Office, said in a report on "the I.L.O. and Reconstruction" made public here today.

A GROUP show of oils and water-colors by artists associated with the gallery, mostly recent work, has just opened at Kraushaar's. Especially interesting is the landscape by Vaughn Flannery, very different in both palette and brushwork from his familiar racing scenes.

A TWENTY-TWO CAR special train loaded with wounded British soldiers sped from Germany through Switzerland and down across France last week. It came to a stop at a southern French seaport. German officers in charge and British officers waiting traded stiff military greetings and the first war captives to be exchanged since the war began two years ago were formally transferred from Germany to England.

SPANNING the great "down North" territory of Canada carrying all kinds of cargo, Canadian Airways, Ltd., the first airline to own and operate private radio stations and to purchase and use twin-engine planes in the Dominion, has shown in its eleven years of service the feasibility of transporting freight by air.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- Soviet freedom to believe and practice any and all religions, as well as continued liberty for the activities of anti-religious organizations and propaganda, were reaffirmed today on the basis of the 1936 Constitution in a prepared statement issued by the official spokesman, S.A. Lozovsky.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- It's thumbs up in this city tonight, with a buoyant challenge on the lips of all Tale men to all its rivals. A stout-hearted Eli football team, which retreated before the stabbing drive of Virginia's Cavaliers and trailed, 19 to 0, at the half, suddenly marshaled its forces for an about-face to score a 21-to-19 victory today in the Yale Bowl.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it was sending to all candidates for the Board of Estimate and the City Council a questionnaire asking each to give his attitude toward thirteen legislative issues which it regards as of major importance during the next two years.

PEABODY, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Scoring touchdowns in the second and fourth quarters. Peabody High School avenged last season's setback by defeating James Madison High of Brooklyn. 14 -- 0, before a crowd of 4,000 at the Leo Buckley Stadium today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

At last we have an answer to the riddle of why Germany did not follow up her great victories on the Continent of Europe with an attempt to end the war quickly by invading the British Isles when Great Britain was still staggered by the French collapse and the loss of guns and tanks at Dunkerque.

WHEN you come across a book like "The New Hope," by Joseph C. Lincoln and Freeman Lincoln, you are sorry you ever used the word "yarn" and "salty" lightly, because here is a true and accurate use for them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- For the first time since the Battle of the Atlantic began in earnest and despite sporadic attacks on American-owned shipping, the ocean situation on which hinges Britain's fate is looking relatively cheerful.

Substitute materials for cast iron, copper, gum, olive oil, rubber, cork and burlap are outlined in a special study by Colonel George S. Brady, chief of the substitution division, Civilian Allocation Division, of the Office of Production Management.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 4 -- The demands of war are forcing new unity and a new need for a centralized coordinated effort on the Far Eastern territories of the British Empire. Singapore has become the political and military focal point of these territories and here individuals and agencies are working out systems and organizations to meet the requirements of the times.

WAR writers are suggesting that if Russia or the Middle Eastern countries are forced to yield before the Nazi onslaught they may destroy their valuable oil fields before retreating. This tactic would be designed to block Nazi designs on Russia's daily output of 615,000 barrels as well as the 309,000 barrels that ordinarily come from Iraqi and Iranian wells each day.

A number of administrative changes in the New York Public Library system have taken place recently in addition to the retirement of four executives, including Dr. Harry Miller Lydenberg, the director, who has been succeeded by Franklin F. Hopper, formerly chief of the circulation department.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 4 -- Tulane's Green Wave reverted to its old role of a powerhouse today and completely outclassed a much lighter Auburn team, 32--0, before 35,000 fans.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 4 -- The Peddie School eleven was beaten by the Hill School team, 10 -- 0 today before a large Father's Day gathering. The game was marked by a 90-yard drive to a touchdown by Hill in the first period.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson, in a decision which if upheld will affect future assessment of New York City's vast watershed lands north of the city itself, ruled today that the town of Cortlandt in Northern Westchester County properly assessed Croton Dam at $5,000,000 in 1932.

To the Music Editor: EVER since I read the list of conductors for the coming WPA City Symphony series, I have been impelled to protest. It was a shock to me that all the names on the list were representatives of foreign traditions, and at a time when we are emphasizing America's independence of European influences!
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Oregon State College handed the University of Washington a jolt today, defeating the touted huskies from Seattle, 9 to 6, in a Coast Conference football game.

NOVELTIES by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, this season will include William Schuman's Third symphony and a new symphony by Arthur Lourie, both of which will receive their first performances.

BUENOS AIRES -- The French and the Italians have long used gestures as part and parcel of their conversation, but it has taken the Argentines to perfect an entire language of the hands, a language which has no need of the tongue and the vocal cords.

AT five minutes past 6 o'clock this evening several men and women will gather in a studio at Radio City and turn the clock back twenty years. Station WJZ, first of the great New York stations, will be celebrating two decades of service.

Myron C. Taylor, who as President Roosevelt's personal ambassador to the Vatican was the key man in the extremely confidential diplomatic negotiations between the President and Pope Pius XII, returned yesterday from Europe.

Higher education in the United States is having an opportunity to review itself this year. Fordham University, founded by Archbishop Hughes on the old Rose Hill Farm at Fordham, has but lately concluded the celebration of its first century.

AT last a literary artist who is at the same time a cosmopolitan observer comes to do full justice to a subject far surpassing the means of expression and the intellectual background of the ordinary visitor to our shores.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct 4 -- A meeting will be held Monday night at the Westchester County Center here by committees interested in plans for a gala concert to be given there the night of Oct. 25 as a benefit for the British War Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Office of Production Management moved today to reduce the consumption of critical materials in the manufacture of fire-fighting equipment. It called upon manufacturers not to make certain types of equipment and to eliminate bells from fire engines.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Underrated Mississippi State displayed amazing speed and power today to win a convincing 14-to-0 victory over the strongly favored Alabama eleven before 20,000 fans.

THE HUDSON RIVER has rightly been called the river of mountains. On its long-course from Whitehall at the entrance of Lake Champlain to the Battery, the river excursionist sees molded purple, as matured mountains unroll themselves, ending in the orange and magenta of the Palisades.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- President Roosevelt has approved the Social Security Board's proposal for a single, all-inclusive national social insurance system and will soon send a message to Congress recommending such a system.

By authority of Revenue Act of 1941, enacted on Sept. 20, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, with the approval of the Secretary of the Treasury on Sept. 24, granted to corporations a second general extension of time to file capital stock tax returns for the year ended June 30, 1941, to Oct. 29, 1941 (Treasury Decision 5069).

LAWRENCE TIBBETT has added a new role to his repertoire -- Figaro in Rossini's "II Barbiere di Siviglia." He will sing it for the first time with the San Francisco Opera Company and will probably be heard here in the role at the Metropolitan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- A poll indicated today that the Senate would approve some modification of the neutrality law, but that any proposal for a change would meet substantial opposition.

A six-point program designed to eliminate practices held subversive to orderly distribution in the present emergency was announced yesterday by the vendor relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, after a survey of merchandise prices, and some of the methods which manufacturers and retailers are employing.

The marine section of the National Safety Council will hold meetings in Chicago for four days this week in connection with the Thirtieth National Safety Congress and Exposition. The congress begins tomorrow in the Hotel Congress.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Forest Evashevski, Michigan's 1940 ace blocker, made a successful coaching debut today when the Hamilton College eleven routed R.P.I., 21 -- 0, in the season's opener.

Science and World Order The International Conference on Science and the World Order held in London, Sept. 26 to 28, by the British Association for the Advancement of Science, leaves no doubt that science is concerned about its future.

FROM the coast of Maine to that of California -- nay, from the islands east and west of there -- the juke box has become one of the important adjuncts of both Summer and Winter. In Summer, brilliant, gaudy and gay, it stands in the recreation rooms of hundreds of small, wooden hotels and in the resort's general store and on the veranda of the yacht club.

Municipalities throughout the country, forced to curtail many of their construction projects because they are unable to get materials given priority under the national defense program, have an excellent opportunity to cut their expenses and establish a "sound credit" for use in the post-war reconstruction period, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday.

Although they are too young to vote, nineteen junior and senior high school students, between 12 and 16 years old, organized last week at the Hotel Astor as a board of directors of the junior division of the Citizens Committee for La Guardia, McGoldrick and Morris.

ARGENTINA'S Banco de la Nacion (Bank of the Nation), which has enabled the South American republic to weather economic storms during the past half-century and which aided in developing Argentina's cattle-raising and agricultural industries, was created under a law enacted on Oct. 15, 1891, and opened its doors on Dec. 1 of that year.
Surprising Tenement Children President Roosevelt's discovery of religious freedom in Soviet Russia manages to get itself tied up, in one reader's mind at least, with another story in the news.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 4 -- Al Brosch, pro at Bethpage State Park, regained the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today in a stirring 36-hole final-round match. Brosch took back the title that he held in 1938 by defeating Willie Goggin of the Century Club in Westchester by 1 up at the Rockville Country Club.

VICHY, France, Oct. 4 -- Regarding military operations on the Russian front, competent military observers here are striving to define the "major movement" announced by Reichsfuehrer Hitler yesterday in Berlin as having been in progress for forty-eight hours.

THE tenth-century Benedictine nun Hrotsvitha was court poet to Otto I of Saxony and his pleasure-loving Queen. And since these rulers saw no reason for complete separation between the stage and the cloister, the gifted author of religious songs began to write plays, the first of which was performed by her sister nuns in her own convent.

Followers of the cocker spaniel in the field will have their first opportunity of the Autumn to watch their favorites in action during the trials of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club, which will get under way early Saturday morning and continue through the following Monday.

WHEN Jeff Troy takes to sleuthing, as he did once before in "Made Up to Kill," he becomes oblivious to everything else. Curiously enough, this idiosyncrasy of his leads to the solution of one of the puzzling features connected with the crime with which this new book deals, and, indirectly, to the capture of a murderer whose tracks have been covered with a skill that would have been admirable in a better cause.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4 -- The seventy-second annual Danbury Fair, largest in Connecticut and most famous agricultural exposition in New England, will open here tomorrow and continue through Oct. 12.

Convinced that piece-meal price control, with provision for flexibility, is the only practicable method of keeping prices in check, the Office of Price Administration is determined, with or without passage of the pending price control bill, to adhere to its present methods and to modify its policy as it goes along, according to information reaching New York last week from persons who had discussed OPA policy with high officials in the Administration.

AS we approach the rupture of relations with Germany and a declaration of war that will hearten our friends in England, France and other countries fighting the gangster bund, even as it rouses Uncle Sam from his Gulliver slumbers, we may expect a rising tide of fiction dealing, like this novel, with the German espionage and sabotage system in the United States.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- Under the impetus of the defense emergency, college-trained women are greatly extending their scope of service in many fields, and these gains will be held in large measure after the war, Dr. Samuel J. Lukens, director of the Simmons College School of Business and Secretarial Studies, said today in announcing that the school was unable to keep pace with the present demand in business and industry for its graduates.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 4 -- Be it under the slogan of "V for Victory" or only the manifestation of zealous nationalism, a wave of sabotage and destruction is sweeping the occupied countries of Europe today. From the declarations of official German sources as well as those made by the commanders of the occupied zones, this appears to be causing the occupying authorities from Norway to Greece considerable apprehension.

Prior to their shipment by air to London for the Christmas Fair sponsored by the Duchess of Gloucester, a collection of puppet dolls representing American stage personalities will be exhibited tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock at the quarters of the American Theatre Wing of British War Relief, 730 Fifth Avenue.

HERE and there in American circles concerned with literature and arts in general, a myth of a "Scandinavian dilemma" seems to flourish. No one can deny that through the centuries Iceland, Denmark, Norway and Sweden have been intensely preoccupied with the creative arts, but that very preoccupation establishes the "dilemma" in the minds of those critics who claim that Scandinavia has made no independent contribution to the arts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Roosevelt Administration's new social security program, announced in general terms by the President at his Tuesday press conference, appears to be dictated by both social and economic considerations. It will be sent to Congress in the near future, and its approval seems likely since both the Republican and Democratic party platforms pledged an improvement and extension of social insurance.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- To come right to the point, Harvard was stiffened by the heat and a 200-pound battering-ram fullback answering to the name of Bert Stiff today as Pennsylvania gained a crushing 19-0 victory in the opening game of the football season for the two teams on Franklin Field.

JUST why an American lad, or one of any other nationality, should choose to enlist under a foreign flag in the most dangerous branch of service is not readily understood by average settled people. Living dangerously, however, seems to be an almost unbreakable habit, once acquired, and one of which few addicts can say, "I can take it or leave it alone."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Official quarters here have been informed that those persons in Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania who early this Summer greeted vanguards of the German Armies as "liberators" from the yoke of Russia have been disillusioned.

To the Music Editor: ONE of the tragedies of today's cultural and political upheaval in Germany -- the hounding from pillar to post of eminent scholars and musicians of Hebrew origin -- has taken another toll in the untimely death of the noted musicologist, editor and conductor, Dr. Ludwig Landshoff.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is with grave misgivings that one follows diverse plans advanced by Slavonic groups forgetting entirely the principle of self-determination and "four freedoms."

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 4 -- The new Labor Prime Minister, who assumes office Tuesday, John Curtin, spent a busy day consulting officials on the mechanics of the change in government, including the time required to prepare a new budget.

LISA and her husband had never been really in love, and after ten years of pleasant association in various parts of the world both knew it. He was a Navy flier, present duty in Panama. It worried Lisa to have Nick fall so hard for the beautiful blonde refugee, not because she was jealous but because she had reason to suspect Gretchen of Fifth Column activities.

IN a quaint Old World bookshop in Hamburg, about the year 1866, a youngster of 14 stood staring, fascinated, at a set of Bell's "British Theatre" in thirty-four volumes. " He was a Biddeford, Me., boy who had just crossed the Atlantic alone to meet his father, a Down East clipper captain, and go with him on a long sea cruise.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your Sept. 29 issue you refer to that report of the Brookings Institution which declares that in order to save the nation from the disastrous effect of higher prices, the farmer must give up the parity price system.

Any athlete, regardless of his chosen sport, assumes a certain degree of risk -- even a chess player. However, the impression that sports writers are immune to injury should not be permitted to get around.

As the motorist drives east through Jones Beach State Park on an Autumn day he may notice the increase in the numbers of birds crossing his path. He is approaching the Tobay Beach Bird Sanctuary, formerly known as the Jones Beach State Bird Sanctuary and a part of the park, but now the property of the Town of Oyster Bay.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 4 -- Sophomore Angelo Bertelli and the veteran Dippy Evans, slippery fullback, led Notre Dame's Fighting Irish to a 19-to-6 victory over Indiana today before 45,000 spectators, a spectacular running, and aerial attack producing touchdowns in the first three periods.

WASHINGTON JUST before Hitler came to power in Germany a German author, Hans Fallada, wrote a novel which was published in this country under the title, "Little Man, What Now?" Hitler answered the question in his own way. By a strange turn of fate, it is the advance of Hitler's Little Man, by land, air and sea, that has now raised the same problems in an acute form in our own country.

THE Catskill Mountains, where Henry Hudson's men still can be beard on Summer evenings playing at ninepins, are inexplicably rich in legend and in the remote and secret atmosphere which fosters legend. Edmund Gilligan lives among them on a mountain lane called Rip Van Winkle Pass.

OMNIBUS volumes of every conceivable sort have become the fashion lately -- and a good one. I doubt, however, if better or richer value has ever been offered to the reader than in this anthology of distinguished short novels, English and American, chosen by the Editor of The Atlantic Monthly, Edward Weeks.

Editor The New York Times BOOK Review: FOR admirers of Little Wolf, hero of Howard Fast's moving historical novel, "The Last Frontier," it may be of interest to know that a fine portrait of this man, termed "one of the grandest Indian leaders of all time," may be found in "The Cheyenne Way," by Llewellyn and Hoebel, a book just issued by the University of Oklahoma Press.

Under Hitler Rule In Munich's festooned squares me and women did the Lambeth Walk, shouted in guttural Bavarian accent the cockney "Oy!" In London's Downing Street cheering crowds cried "Good old Neville!" as a lean black-coated figure declared he had brought back from Germany "peace with honor."

HOLLYWOOD. THE way of the transgressor is doubly difficult in Hollywood because of Frederick Cavens. Mr. Cavens is the fencing master who doubles for most of the leading men of the screen whenever they have a sword fight.

HOLLYWOOD. THE sincerity of theatre operators' clamor for new faces is to be tested. RKO has embarked upon the unprecedented venture of gambling in excess of $700,000 on an A picture involving two personalities unknown to American audiences.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- At Edgewood Arsenal in Maryland small groups of Army officers and civilians play a deadly serious game with poison gas and fire as one phase of the routine defensetraining program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- In answer to requests regarding the recent introduction of a system of "inverted navicerts" between the United States and Eire, the British Embassy issued this statement today:

LOS ANGELES -- The typical Southern Californian of this day and age, be he a retired banker from Iowa, a tall, heavy-shouldered citrus grower, or a Hollywood extra, has this in common with his dark-skinned Spanish ancestor who once lived in this sunny land: he loves a fiesta.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- A marriage license application for Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina and Miss Evalyn McLean was filed here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 4 -- Patrols from Tobruk scored several successes in raids carried out yesterday under cover of artillery fire and forced Axis troops to evacuate several strong points in the Eastern sector. The British destroyed an ammunition dump in the central sector.

NEW WINDSOR, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Charging that political interference by Mayor La Guardia was hampering the Board of Education, the New York Teachers Guild, Local 2, of the American Federation of Teachers, unanimously approved a statement today voicing distress at "the outrageous and unprecedented" procedure of the Mayor.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 4 -- Bowdoin edged out Wesleyan, 13--7, today in a spectacular football battle that saw the winners stage two goal-line stands in the last half.

Reports of unfavorable weather conditions in the Cotton Belt further stimulated the demand for cotton in the short session yesterday. After opening with minor overnight gains, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued upward to close near the top for the day at net advances of 14 to 25 points.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Food represented the chief feature of the British commodity news this week. Reviewing the war situation in the House of Commons on Tuesday, Prime Minister Churchill referred to the strong improvement in Great Britain's food position, pointing out that stocks, at present above the total when the war began, were higher than for the eight previous months.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Staff members and aides of the Long Island Children's Museum are now at work in the basement of the Adelphi College Science Building assembling materials for the museum's opening early next month.

THIS is the kind of book in which it is pleasant to browse. Mr. Harrison has gathered together a variety of themes, and his "Musical Box" tinkles a number of engaging tunes. Its separate sections can be, and have been, treated at full length in books of their own.

AN ENGLISH SOUTH COAST TOWN, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The first group of American members of Britain's new Civilian Technical Corps to work on the radiolocator have arrived in England and found themselves subject to military discipline, even though they are carefully classified as civilians on their United States passport.
RATHER remarkable, when you think of it, is the gasoline conservation actually effected by Federal recommendations in the seventeen Atlantic States.

SAN FRANCISCO. SAN FRANCISCANS, who take their music seriously, are pointing with pride to two factors marking the forthcoming season. The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, led for the last six seasons by Pierre Monteux, will be celebrating its thirtieth anniversary, and the San Francisco Opera Association is exciting interest with plans for its first Pacific Coast tour.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 4 -- The Fordham freshmen came from behind in the second period today to gain a 7-7 tie with the Naval Academy plebe eleven.

ONE of the most attractive of the B.B.C. programs is "Any Questions?" Every Sunday afternoon five persons of distinction in various walks of life sit round a table in the studio and spend three-quarters of an hour in answering, as best they can, from eight to ten questions selected from hundreds that have been sent in by listeners all over the country.

To the Art Editor: DUE to the fact that my studio will likely prove inadequate in size to accommodate all of those interested in the formation of a new exhibition society based on the Parisian Sur-Independants, it has been necessary to find a larger meeting place for the assembly scheduled to be held today at 4 P.M.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Recognizing the importance of psychiatry in a modern health program, and in line with the policy of providing its students with complete health-maintaining facilities, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has established a psychiatric and dental clinic, according to an announcement today by Dr. George W. Morse, medical director.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Georgia Tech's football team ambled to a 20-0 season opening victory over Chattanooga before 10,000 today.

THE companion volume in "America's Cook Book" is in effect an encyclopedia of household organization, management and care. Under the general direction of Miss Eloise Davison, the entire staff of The Herald Tribune Home Institute and many members of its advisory council have worked on "America's Housekeeping Book" for several years, and more than 100 specialists in various fields have been called upon for expert knowledge.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- If a Congressman had had time to visit every State in the Union during the recent recess and to search the minds of voters on innumerable questions relating to the war, what would he have found about the temper of the American public today?

THE day may come when a sardonic jacketeer will write on the wrapper of a new and enormously promising novel the austere boast: This book is guaranteed to have won absolutely no literary prize of any kind whatever.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Brooklyn College scored on a long pass with only a minute to play to break a tie and defeat Panzer on Viking Field today, 12--6. Both teams scored in the second quarter.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- One of the recurring leitmotifs in all German discussions of the new European order is that while Britain is indulging in wishful thinking about the future of the world, from which it is being steadily driven by the crushing weight of German arms and by the acquisitive expansion of American imperialism, the molding of a "new Europe" is becoming a tangible reality.

Norman Birkett, chairman of the Home Office Advisory Committee in London, who is making his first visit to the United States, expressed gratitude yesterday for the American aid that he said was making possible the fight for the rights of the "little fellow."

With stocks closing irregularly higher in an unimportant volume, bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday jumped to the heaviest figure for a Saturday since Sept. 9, 1939, the Saturday after the declaration of war. Activity in speculative rails and shipping shares sent transactions to $7,101,000.
KINGSTON -- On Oct. 17, at a ball at Kingston Municipal Auditorium, citizens of the Hudson Valley and Autumn visitors to the region will celebrate the area's first annual Apple Harvest Festival.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 4 -- Ample revenge for recent gridiron reverses received from Lafayette was obtained by N.Y.U.'s football forces today when the violet-jerseyed warriors struck with stunning swiftness in the fourth quarter for a 6-to-0 decision.

"BEAT the tax" buying: sent sales soaring on the first two days of last week as a climax to those spurts of public purchasing which were occasioned by actual shortages, fear of shortages and rising prices. Furs, jewelry and cosmetics were the lines immediately affected through retail excise taxes on Oct. 1.

To the Motor Boat Editor: I read your articles in the Sunday TIMES with much interest and am writing to ask you if you know of any motor boat leaving here for Miami by way of the inside passage. I would like to try this method of transportation for a change and am told the trip is quite worth while.

AS the output and distribution of records increase, the stuff which is graven on the shining black disks goes steadily beyond accepted musical compositions. Records are beginning to reflect the national scene, even its sore spots.

NEW airlines, or extensions of present ones, are speeding up travel for tourists pushing into South America's hinterland. Recently established services in Brazil include the line from the mouth of the Amazon to Tabatinga on the border of Peru, and another line from Rio de Janeiro to Corumba, on Bolivia's boundary, from which there is a connection with Asuncion, Paraguay.
