They were aged 5 1/2, in their first week of the pre-school program for children of superior intelligence at the Hunter College Elementary School.

Announcement last week of the conclusion of a lease-lend agreement with Brazil under which $90,000,000 to $110,000,000 worth of credits will be extended to the South American republic, brought a mixed reaction among foreign traders here yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 4 -- Although it required one period to get up steam, Dartmouth's football team finally started rolling today and flattened a game Amherst eleven ,47 -- 7, with the Lord Jeffs never having an outside chance.

VICHY, France, Oct. 4 -- In future the pension fund for the benefit of Senators and Deputies will be under State control. This step virtually completes abolition of parliamentary privileges, yet observers believe it is likely to win general support.
WHEN one reads a book one can conjure up an image of the author. This book is an expression of a man's convictions, not a mere compendium of quotations. On reading one sees the man's inmost soul.

Twenty thousand home-made cookies marching in and out of cookie jars every month are proving a strong attraction for service men off duty at Fort Dix, thanks to New Jersey women who have kept a fresh supply traveling from their kitchens to the camp for the last year.

An interesting experiment to determine the adaptability of the iris to city culture is proceeding at the gardens within Tudor City on Forty-second Street and the East River. Over 2,500 varieties of iris are being set out, with the planting practically completed.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Much has been written about the necessity for regulatory legislation governing jurisdictional disputes, and strikes, picketing and boycotts carried on in connection with such disputes, yet little has been said to distinguish the different circumstances under which jurisdictional labor activity takes place.

In his speech in Berlin Friday Adolf Hitler announced that Russia had been broken and "will never rise again." But it looks as if the Fuehrer expects it will take some time to clean up the scraps. It was only a few days ago that the Berlin propaganda organization predicted a Winter campaign, and in his speech the Nazi chief said operations had begun from which great results could be expected.

"Wild Fruits and Flowers of Autumn" will be the subject of the free Saturday afternoon lecture given by E.J. Alexander at the New York Botanical Garden at 3 P.M. Mr. Alexander is Assistant Curator at the Garden.

A survey of the shipping lines here in the last week disclosed that the defense demands made by the government on American flag shipping and the withdrawal of all but a few foreign-owned vessels from the transatlantic lanes have reduced facilities for sea transport from New York to a fleet of fewer than fifty passenger liners.

A complete line of Peruvian gift merchandise suitable for department and specialty shop promotion will be put on exhibition for retail buyers here tomorrow through the Official Commercial Agency of Peruvian Industries at 220 Fifth Avenue.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Marquette took to the air to upset a favored, veteran Wisconsin eleven, 28 to 7, today in the traditional game before a near-capacity crowd of 40,000.

Although the major film booking offices have been increasingly cooperative in selecting special double-feature programs suitable for child audiences, the film industry at large still has far to go in recognizing and meeting the special requirements of movie-goers under the age of 14, according to Mrs. Alonzo Klaw, reporting on progress made during the last year by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, which issues a weekly list of current films recommended for children.

An entertainment unique both in its locale and form of presentation is now being arranged for the night of Oct. 18 under the auspices of United China Relief. Designated the China Clipper Cabaret, with an offer to prospective subscribers to "Go High Hat at the Automat," the party will be held at an Automat restaurant at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street from 10 P.M. until dawn and will be featured by a floor show.

A week devoted to gatherings of business women, and dedicated to the theme of "Strengthening Democracy for Defense" opens tomorrow for members of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women. Endorsement of their efforts has been sent to the organization's president, Dr. Minnie L. Maffett of Dallas, Texas, by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

This week Rutgera is observing the 175th Anniversary of its fouding. Probably no university or college has observed an important anniversary of its birth at a mo critical period. In these critical days the real issue before the world, before our own country, the preservation of freedom with all that it means in dignity, opportunity and culture.

-- BOMBS AND WILDLIFE Where bombs, artillery fire and machine-gun ranges come in, wildlife is apt to vanish. Those concerned with conservation have been dismayed to read of large areas of wild lands being set aside for military purposes after years of effort to make them refuges.

One reason why prediction is not easy in the matter of the uprising against Germany by the people of Europe's occupied countries is that there is no close precedent in history for the situation which has actually arisen. There are instances in abundance of invasion of a European state and subjugation of its government, when the period of occupation was marked by guerrilla warfare or underground conspiracy against the conqueror.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 4 -- A three-point foreign trade program revealing that New Zealand's overseas commerce is being rigidly confined within the war pattern has been announced by Commerce Minister Daniel Sulivan.
NEW YORK Lieut. Comdr. Frederick M. Trapnell, U.S.N., and Mrs. Trapnell have arrived at the Ritz-Carlton from Washington.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 4 -- Championship events brought to a close the thirty-ninth annual Piping Rock Horse Show today on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club. There was an overwhelming number of classes in the two sessions, the last award being made as darkness fell.

PROTEST: The world was astounded last May by Rudolf Hess's sensational "solo flight" to Britain. The air buzzed with speculations. Had the No. 3 Nazi landed on enemy soil as a fugitive from his own party? Was he a "Trojan horse?" Or did he come as a deluded peace negotiator?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The torpedoing and sinking of the American-owned tanker J.C. White in the South Atlantic on Sept. 27 was denounced by Secretary Hull at his press conference today as "another act of lawlessness, piracy and attempted frightfulness in connection with the general movement to drive people off the Atlantic as part of the world movement of conquest."

Old-time pictorial textiles, in the hands of a skilled decorator, are an unusually interesting medium. Gone, perhaps, are the days when the walls of a bedroom were covered with the same toile which made the curtains, bedspreads and chair slip-covers; with more restraint, however, these fabrics which depict events in history, show pastoral scenes and tell mythological tales take on a more dramatic quality.

THROUGH centuries of tribal memory, man's life had had its unchanging part in the land's endless survival, nourished by the gifts of earth and water, at one with age-old Law carefree. How, then, could change come?

There was a flurry among patrons of the arts yesterday and Flossie the Wooden Cow" lost an ear. It all happened when R.H. Macy's, Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway, invited city school children to inspect the opening of an art exhibit especially styled to their interests.

IN her new book Mrs. Means returns to the Indians of the Southwest whom readers of "Tangled Waters" know she portrays with a sensitive understanding of an old people adjusting itself to new and only half-understood ways.

In preparing the student for the life he must lead as a useful citizen in a democracy, the college must recognize the need for training the student how to live and work with others, Ralph P. Bridgman, dean of students at Brooklyn College, says in his first annual report to President Harry D. Gideonse, made public yesterday.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 4 (U.P.)-Nebraska came up with a slow but methodical football team today to open its 1941 season with a 14-to-0 victory over Iowa State College.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Heraiding a possible return to gridiron greatness, Ohio State's 1941 machine today smashed the victory hopes of a proud University of Southern California eleven and walked out of the Coliseum, the roar of an amazed home-town crowd echoing over the rim of the huge stadium, with the first Buckeye triumph over a Pacific Coast Conference team in twenty years.

BEFORE the turn of the century "a fan" was an obsolete abbreviation for a fanatic. Since the advent of baseball it has crept back into usage and the movies have helped to revive it. In fact, today, the zeal of a Brooklyn Dodger fan is only matched by the loyalty of the movie fan to his favorite star.

MEXICO CITY -- More and better roads, more and better hotels, uniform traffic laws, fewer and less complicated passports, customs and other border regulations -- all these may soon come for the visitor in Latin America as the result of two big travel congresses recently held in this Mexican capital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Sept. 27 amounted to 246,649,000 barrels, according to data reported by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the preceding week, the total represented an increase of 149,000 barrels, comprising a rise of 473,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude but a drop of 324,000 Barrels in stocks of foreign-crude.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A communique issued by British Headquarters:

IT was a dreadful day for the Dodgers. They were baffled on their own Brooklyn soil in the first world series game played there in twenty-one years. Marius Russo of Ozone Park gave them the ozone. It was considered a traitorous deed by the aforesaid Russo, because he owed his early growth and baseball training to the salubrious climate and open lots of the Borough of Brooklyn.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Texas Christian University had everything -- especially defense -- today as the Horned Frogs gained a 9-0 victory over the University of Arkansas Razorbacks in the opening Southwest Conference football game before 6,000 rain-drenched fans.

THIS novel is the first installment of what must eventually be an immense trilogy. The author Joseph Wittlin, now a refugee in this country, comes from his native Poland with a ready-made and deserved reputation.

Following a custom of several years' standing, the Musicians Emergency Fund will sponsor the preview opening of the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for the Autumn and Winter season. The benefit party will take place Wednesday night, and already there is a large advance subscription from members of society who have reserved tables.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 4 -- German dive bombers raided four Serbian villages this week when heavy shelling failed to dislodge guerrillas in fierce mountain warfare by Chetnik groups in Western Serbia and Bosnia, according to reports received here today by short-wave radio to foreign military intelligence sources.

SILK stockings, perfumes and jewelry are usually associated with feminine shoppers, yet audit reports of the Navy Department Ship's Service show that these are among the leading items purchased by officers and enlisted men from the retail shops which the Navy maintains for its personnel aboard ship and at its shore barracks.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Arriving here with high hopes, Williams found Princeton's running attack too powerful today as the Nassau eleven opened its schedule with a 20-7 victory over the Little Three champion.

Majors in business have proved most popular with Hunter College freshmen in the present term, a survey showing the interests of 1,120 of the 1,238 freshmen enrolled reveals. Approximately 13 per cent of the class are business majors.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Holy Cross Crusaders, apparently fagged out by their heroic and successful efforts against Louisiana State last week, had to wage a gruelling battle to t eke out a 13-0 victory over the Friars of providence College in midsummer heat today before 15,000 spectators.

NEWHAVEN, England, Oct. 4 -- Plans for an exchange between Great Britain and Germany of a number of sick and wounded prisoners of war were jeopardized today after a last-minute hitch in the negotiations that had been conducted between the two belligerents by the International Red Cross and the United States Embassy in London.

THAT fine novelist whose last work is reviewed on today's front page was one of the small group of writers through whom the boundaries of the fictional art are widened. In its loss to literature the tragedy of Virginia Woolf's death was, like that of our own Elizabeth Madox Roberts, the removal of one who marched in the advance guard of her craft.

A benefit exhibition of interest to many members of society and artistic circles is that of twenty-nine recently discovered watercolor drawings by William Blake, which will be held at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, from Oct. 21 through Nov. 7.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 4 -- Reports from Afghanistan tonight to foreign diplomatic circles here gave strong indications that Soviet and British diplomatic activity was rapidly being intensified to force expulsion or internment of all Germans resident in Afghanistan, including fugitives from Iran.

President Roosevelt spent much of yesterday in the seclusion of his New York homes selecting, with the aid of Mrs. Roosevelt, the furniture and bric-a-brac that he wants to transfer to his home at Hyde Park on the Hudson. The two adjoining homes at 47 and 49 East Sixty-fifth Street have been for sale since the death of the President's mother, Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, on Sept. 7.

AUSTIN, Texas. Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Orange wave of the University of Texas, which threatens to engulf six other members of the Southwest Conference, showed its vast power today by rolling over a gallant Louisiana State University eleven, 34-0, before 19,000 fans.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- A green but willing Cornell team, successors to one of the greatest gridiron machines ever assembled, today inaugurated a new regime with a well-earned victory over its upState rival, Syracuse, before an almost capacity crowd of more than 18,000 on choelkopf Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Few times, if ever, in its dramatic history has the government of the United States had so many irons in the international fire as it has today. There is no part of the globe in which this country has not an active interest.

WHEN France declared war in September, 1939, there lived within her hospitable borders many tens of thousands of veteran anti-Nazi fighters. They were men and women toughened by experience, living only for their reckoning with Hitler.

The United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc., announced yesterday that nearly the entire resident populations of 120 towns in the Carolinas had now been mobilized to meet the recreational needs and provide personal services for the approximately half-million men of the First Army's manoeuvres.

Burgess P. Wallace will become the new commander of the North River Power Squadron at its annual meeting tomorrow at the Downtown A.C., if the slate of the nominating committee is accepted, as it will be in all probability. He will succeed Commander Herbert S. FitzGibbons, who resigned after one year because of business pressure.

There is some confusion in the public mind about the 1942 models of passenger automobiles which now are making their bid for acceptance. This confusion arises from two sources: first, a failure to understand the cycle of motor car annual model production and, second, a fear of reduced quality because of the use of alternate materials in place of certain strategic materials now under priority for national defense.

LONDON (By Wireless). OLIVER LYTTELTON is Britain's key man in the Middle East. He has many tasks. He has to establish a new government in Iran that will keep the Iranians happy, he must try to keep the Turks appeased and he must insure a route for supplies between Britain and the United States and Russia.

THE colorful life of the race track comes to the reader through this book with a startling clarity that reminds one of television. There are no heroes in these sketches, and not many rascals. The people who live and move in its pages are just ordinary muddle-headed, emotional men and women who like to bet on the nags and see them run.

If you were to ask Patrolmen Richard Fitzgerald and Miles Mc-Manus -- Irish to the core -- if they ever rode herd or listened to a cowboy radio program, they would give you a withering look and say: "You're nuts."

PHILADELPHIA AMERICA'S hardiest perennial of the legitimate stage, the Walnut Street Theatre in Philadelphia, which has been named, doomed, changed and reclaimed a dozen times since the bricks went into its walls in 1808, is coming back into its own once more.

Gloom was thick in the Dodgers' clubhouse yesterday, thick as a London fog. An unhappier looking group of ball players hasn't been seen after a world series game since the historic 1929 contest in Philadelphia when Hack Wilson las a fly ball in the sun and the Athletics scored ten runs in one inning.

Gloom was thick in the Dodgers' clubhouse yesterday, thick as a London fog. An unhappier looking group of ball players hasn't been seen after a world series game since the historic 1929 contest in Philadelphia when Hack Wilson las a fly ball in the sun and the Athletics scored ten runs in one inning.

ALTHOUGH Sime Silverman, a great man in the Broadway world, deserved a better book than Dayton Stoddart has written in "Lord Broadway," this biography of Variety's founder does serve a sort of purpose.

LAST week the commercial airlines of the United States began the eighth successive month of service without a single fatal accident. This mark, called to attention by Robert H. Hinckley, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Air, gains significance when it is realized that operations over airlines here in the last seven months were the heaviest in the history of aviation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's announcement that he had instructed W. Averell Harriman to take up with the Soviet Government the question of Russian religious freedom brought predictions from two Senators today that there would be no liberty of worship in that country so long as the Stalin regime remained in power.

A definition of the difference between religious freedom as provided in the Soviet Constitution and religious freedom as understood in America was offered in a statement by Dean Luther A. Weigle of Yale University, president of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, made public here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The reaffirmation by S.A. Lozovsky, the official Soviet spokesman, in Moscow yesterday of Russia's Constitutional stand on religion was declared today by the Rev. Edmund A. Walsh, vice president of George-town University, to be "tantamount to a scotching of President Roosevelt's hopes that true freedom of religion, might be recognized in Russia."

At 4:56 P.M. yesterday darkness and gloom came to Brooklyn This was no phenomenon, even though, the sun still was shining. After all, in a borough of nearly 3,000,000 persons whose daily happiness rises and falls with the for tunes of the Dodgers, one couldn't possibly expect sweetness and light after what had happened to The Bums in the ninth inning.

Post-war building activity exceeding in magnitude and importance the present defense construction program is predicted by Dean Leopold Arnaud of the Columbia University School of Architecture in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, it was announced yesterday.

NEW WINDSOR, N.Y., Oct 5 -- New York City public schools, while paying lip service to democracy, fail to carry out democratic principles or policies in the classroom, speakers at the annual conference of the Teachers Guild Associates and New York Teachers Guild declared at the final session of the three-day meeting.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- John Rigney held the Cubs to five safe blows today, while the White Sox slammed out a ten-hit 6-to-0 victory to give the American League team its third straight against no defeats in the city series.

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- The German Boerses last week showed some signs of recovery from the shock caused by the announcement of drastic government measures for curbing future violent advances of prices. Yet, in spite of a less nervous market and of a fair amount of buying at lower price levels, quotations continued to sag and the share index dropped 8 points to 200.08 on Oct. 3.

MARAGOGY, Alagoas State, Brazil, Oct. 5 -- Cannonading at sea accompanied by a display of searchlights last night was reported today by fishermen near Maceio, about sixty miles south of here, indicating possible continuation of a battle believed to have started between unidentified ships late Friday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- The text of the statement on religious freedom in the Soviet Union by the official spokesman, S.A. Lozovsky, yesterday, is printed on inside pages in today's Russian newspapers without editorial comment.

Registration for the New York City election, Nov. 4, will begin today and continue throughout the week. The registration places will be open today from 5 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. The hours will be the same each day up to and including Friday. On Saturday they will be from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES prints a statement by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, on excise tax pyramiding which will cause business men and others to wonder. Economists, business men and some members of Congress are aware that placing a tax on sales by "manufacturers, producers and importers" infallibly raises the tax content of the consumer's purchase in excess of the tax paid by the manufacturer, producer or importer.

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- While hoping that the forced liquidation of corporate holdings of shares, which is expected to follow their registration, in line with the decree of ten days ago, will remove the "narrowness" of the stock market and thus check any major advance of prices in the future, official financial circles point out that the government, does not contemplate any further reduction of interest rates.
The play-by-play description of the fourth game of the world series at Ebbets Field yesterday follows:

Additional lines were withdrawn from sale in the wholesale market last week as shortages of raw materials became more acute. One refrigerator manufacturer closed completely. Prices continued to rise on home furnishings as further curtailment of styles and patterns were, announced on various items.

The New York City Tunnel Authority announced yesterday its acceptance of the $13,984,619 bid submitted by Mason Hangar, Inc., for construction of the two parrallel tubes under New York Bay, comprising the Manhattan under-river section of the Brooklyn-Battery vehicular tunnel.

Few among the thousands who thronged Fifth Avenue yesterday to witness the parade of the Polish organizations of this area in memory of Count Casimir Pulaski, the brilliant soldier of fortune who gave his life in our own struggle for freedom a century and a half ago, can have had an opportunity to read the detailed report on the horrors of the German occupation of Poland recently compiled by the Vatican.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Scattered liquidation by holders of October contracts developed in lard last week, and while the action of the cotton, grain and bean markets caused rallies from time to time buying was not vigorous. Prices averaged lower despite purchases by packers and a liberal decrease in local stocks in the last month and further purchases by the government.

An unprecedented total of $117,490,000 will be spent for research this year by manufacturing industry throughout the nation, Robert L. Lund, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers' committee on patents and research, declared yesterday.
Nomination for the candor prize in the 1941 world series: Arnold (Mickey) Owen, the young Missouri farmer who is first-string catcher for the Dodgers.
NEW YORK Mrs. Augustus C. Downing and Miss Alys M. Downing are expected to arrive at the Plaza tomorrow from Whitefield, N.H.
With Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presiding In the sanctuary, Bishop Stephen J. Donahue celebrated pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

With the admonition that "a pail of water in the house can be worth the whole Fire Department," Fire Commissioner Walsh officially announced yesterday the start of Fire Prevention Week. He pointed out that virtually all fires, especially those in the home, begin on a small scale and that many could be put out with a bucket of water before they became serious.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Opponents of President Roosevelt's foreign policy indicated tonight that any Administration request for drastic modification or repeal of the Neutrality Act would be debated in Congress as if it were a request for a declaration of war.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt talked by telephone today with Myron C. Taylor, his personal representative to the Vatican, who arrived in New York by transatlantic clipper yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An official world-wide "information service," designed to crack the Axis news monopoly on the Continent of Europe and neutralize Germany's "lie campaign" against the United States in Latin America, is rapidly being' organized by the Administration.

The boxing program at Madison Square Garden tonight will present a preliminary bout between a fighter named Chief Crazy Horse and another known as Allie Stolz. But, the trend toward things mechanical being what it is, the 10,000 fans who are expected to attend Will be much more interested in the fortunes of a gladiator who recently has grown to be called Chief Crazy Motorcycle.

Louis Derabitz Brandeis was a great Justice of the Court, a great individualist, a great American. His death, in the ripeness of years, his work completed, is tragic only in the personal loss suffered by his family and his friends. But it is sad for all of us, because it removes one of our elder statesmen, and philosophers, truly cast in the American mold, deeply, even mystically, infused with the American spirit.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, Oct. 5 -- Edward Y. Crossmore Sr., 58 years old, retired executive vice president of the National Biscuit Company, was injured fatally today at his Summer estate, Tranquility, in the village here when he tripped, fell and discharged his shotgun accidentally while shooting hawks.

Ancient associates of the national game racked their brains last night for parallels to what happened in the ninth inning at Ebbets Field, but it remained for Jack Doyle, the sage of Broadway, who is by way of being a walking encyclopedia on baseball, to come up with the closest approach to it.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 5 -- The Moscow radio announced today that "a certain number" of modern Russian bombers had arrived in Yugoslavia to aid the Insurgents. Heavy German aerial attacks against several important centers in Hercegovina Province were said to have failed to do more than slight material damage.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra in a concert at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 10, it was announced yesterday. This is the first and only New York concert so far announced for the famous Italian conductor.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 4 -- Financial opinion here is that the American industrial position is being gradually built up on a base of defense requirements which, it is felt, means the growth of an ultimate one-sided development with a gradual contraction in the important consumption goods industries along the lines of the change in Europe.

Mrs. Arthur Smadbeck, former vice president and general manager of the Heckscher Foundation for Children, 1 East 104th Street, has been elected to its presidency, succeeding the late Mrs. August Heckscher, it was announced yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 5 -- Palm Beach and its sister city, West Palm Beach, across Lake Worth, were boarded up today in the face of a hurricane racing toward the southeast coast of Florida from the Bahamas.

SEATTLE, Oct. 5 -- On the eve of the opening of the American Federation of Labor's annual convention, during which, President William Green predicted, the war would "overshadow everything,' the federation's executive council urged the Federal Government today to continue giving Great Britain all aid possible "until Hitler and his allies are decisively defeated."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- In two days of anti-climax, but nevertheless serious, racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club, George Esselborn's International Class sloop Myth was brought home a winner. She won a drifting contest yesterday, a third place this morning and a second this afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With the doughnut-cruller question seemingly settled, Topics of The Times proceeds to champion the cause of the dried prune. I am all for it. To me the prune savors more of the philosophical than does the doughnut.

Harper Bros, announced yesterday that it had set up the largest literary prize ever offered in America -- $12,500 for the best nonfiction work written for the general public to be submitted to the editors by May 1. The award, which commemorates the 125th anniversary of the firm next year, tops by several thousand dollars any previous literary prize.

VICHY, France, Oct. 5 -- Simultaneously with the issue of the new 4 per cent bonds of the Autonomous Sinking Fund redeemable in fifty years, a decision by the Minister of Finance reduced from 1 3/4 to 1 5/8 per cent the rate of interest of the ordinary treasury bonds running from 75 to 105 days.

"All Men Are Alike," a farce by Vernon Sylvaine, opens tonight at the Hudson Theatre. It is a London importation previously entitled "Women Aren't Angels." Bobby Clark, generally associated with musical entertainments, and Reginald Denny are co-starred as two partners (an American and Englishman, respectively), who are unknown to each other's wives.
With thirteen named for the Interborough Handicap, a six-furlong dash that will gross close to $10,000, the Fall race meeting will begin today at Jamaica.

An all-out effort to dislodge Communists from positions of leadership in New York department store unions wag initiated yesterday by Samuel Wolchok, international president of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, C.I.O.

At this time, when America stands committed to the defeat of Hitlerism, those groups and persons who seek to arouse race prejudice or to spread propaganda against nations fighting Hitler are disloyal to the government and are giving direct aid to Hitler, Bishop William T. Manning asserted yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in a special sermon on the world crisis.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5 -- A moonlight sea battle in which an unidentified, ship reportedly was sunk and another steamed away under cover of a smoke screen was described today by travelers who said that the engagement occurred Friday night in full view of the Brazilian coast.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Trading in corn was somewhat restricted last week, with the market showing an easy undertone due, in large measilre, to the continued big discount prevailing for cash grain in the spot market relative to the December.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The previous week's somewhat trendless situation in the stock markets was replaced last week by a robust confidence such as ruled before the recent moderate reaction. Activity, too, returned with prices in almost all sections again moving forward fairly well.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 5 -- The Green Bay Packers came from behind in the closing minutes to connect on a forward pass good for a touchdown, then kicked the extra point to nose out the Chicago Cardinals, 14 to 13, in a National League football game today before a crowd of 10,000.

The retail price of gasoline in New York City will be advanced 1 1/2 cents to 2 cents a gallon before the Winter is over, it was predicted yesterday by Sol A. Herzog, attorney for the Metropolitan Gasoline Retailers Council, the organization that speaks for most of the city's filling station proprietors.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Although during the past three months something more than 10,000,000 tons of goods has been unloaded from ships in British ports, it is only within recent days that food, raw materials and finished goods from the United States under the lease-lend act have actually been arriving.

Flexibility will be the keynote of advertising campaigns on the 1942 automobiles because, despite curtailed output, manufacturers will attempt to retain present advantages in various competitive markets. No manufacturer will allow his dealers a disproportionate share of cars in a market in which he is entrenched if it means a corresponding loss in some other more competitive area.

Rosary Sunday, marked by the distribution of 1,000 blessed roses and a procession of 400 school children, was celebrated yesterday at the Dominican Church of St. Catherine of Siena, 411 East Sixty-eighth Street.

New England rail carriers have assured the Commerce and Industry Association of New York that they have withdrawn a proposal, opposed by the association since it was first made public, providing for cancellation of certain differential rates, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The National Food Distributors Association is launching a campaign against a certain type of specialized unemployment in the food industry which may have far-reaching consequences, Emmet J. Martin, secretary, announced at headquarters here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Griffith Stadium is still a hunger port for the football Dodgers. Like so many previous Brooklyn gridiron expeditions to this city, the visit today ended in defeat because Joe Aguirre, tall rookie end, booted a 36-yard third-period field goal for the Washington Redskins.

It takes an informative and fully illustrated report to the Mayor by Park Commissioner Moses to remind us that quietly and unobtrusively one of the city's oldest and most tantalizing headaches, the grade crossing, is evaporating. In the succinct words of Mr. Moses himself, "A problem which has vexed and bedeviled the city for several generations will soon be a memory."

Moscow reports that Yugoslav irregulars have notified the Nazi commander in Belgrade that they hold 650 Germans who will be shot if any more Serbian hostages are executed. The report is not confirmed, though these fanatical Chetniks are quite capable of such a grim reprisal.

The half-way mark in the construction of some $50,000,000 in grade-crossing eliminations within New York City has been passed and the entire program, except for a few minor projects, will be completed in 1943, according to a report that Park Commissioner Robert Moses will submit today to Mayor La Guardia.

Mrs. Rushmore Patterson of 1100 Park Avenue has been appointed chairman of the New York Membership Enrollment Committee of the Seeing Eye, 9 Rockefeller Plaza, it was announced yesterday by Henry A. Colgate, president of the Morristown, N.J., school for the training of guide dogs for the blind.
Bill Robinson, no Aryan, tap-danced on Adolf Hitler's coffin in Madison Square Garden last night before 17,000 persons, as the band played "When That Man Is Dead and Gone."

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5 -- The ten-goal Stewart Iglehart and his brilliant team-mates, the Gerry brothers, Ed and Ebby, and Charley Von Stade, gave the Meadow Brook quartet a thrilling 9-to-8 triumph over Bostwick Field in the second annual match for the Polo Writers Cup, which brought the high-goal season to an end on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

It couldn't, perhaps, have happened anywhere else on earth. But it did happen yesterday in Brooklyn, where in the short space of twenty-one minutes a dazed gathering of 33,813 at Ebbets Field saw a world series game miraculously flash two finishes before its eyes.
Mayor La Guardia seemed yesterday to be well on his way to obtaining support from both wings of organized labor in addition to that he derives as the nominee of the American Labor party.

SINCE all of 161 years have gone by, it may a little hard to believe it, but this morning, in Carl Van Doren's "Secret History of the American Revolution,"* certain details of the classic conspiracy in American history are made public for the first time.

When the United States recognized the Soviet Government in November, 1933, a good part of the opposition focused on the Soviet policy toward religion. The President, who had the intention of establishing normal relations with Russia when he took office, initiated and carried out the negotiations himself.

Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, as New York State Defense Coordinator, extended yesterday his congratulations to the State's industrialists and workers who, he reported, were rapidly putting the production facilities of the State on a full-time basis.

Bundles for Britain, Inc., 745 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had cabled contributions totaling $11,250 to London, as the latest gift in its drive to aid the British. Bomb-damaged voluntary hospitals in London and the provinces and the Women's Voluntary Services will share the gift.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5 -- In the face of persistent selling by a spot house on every ten-point advance,

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 5 -- A new order of life is arising "out of these troubled times of ours, filled with fury and bloodshed," the Most Rev. John J. Glennon, Archbishop of St. Louis, declared today before delegates to the nineteenth annual convention of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices reached another new 1936-41 high of 98.8, and is thus very close to its 1929-41 high of 99.1. The major raw materials group recovered following its decline of the past two weeks, as gains occurred in raw cotton, eggs and grains.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 -- The Berlin correspondent of the Aftonbladet reports today that an insurrectional Radical Socialist government has been established by Serbian patriots in the mountains of Montenegro and that the Germans are compelled to use divebombers to subdue the rebels.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- For the first two quarters today, the New York football Giants acted as if all they had to do to beat the Pittsburgh Steelers was to wave their press clippings at them. Held to a 3-3 tie for the first half, the Giants came to life in a hurry.

Before a background of palest taffy-colored slipper satin, tufted like the interior of a lavish Louis Quinze coach and fastened with tiny gold buttons, sit the scarlet bonbon boxes with their extravagant bows of scarlet silk. The bonbons may be seen below through the shining glass of the showcases, row after row of exquisite fluted shells, curled leaves, crescents and cubes -- tiny and perfect in satiny chocolate.

Six new films will arrive on Broadway this week, starting with two openings today. "The Man Who Seeks the Truth," first French picture of the new season, will have its premiere tonight at the World Theatre as a benefit for the war relief fund of the Federation of French Veterans of the Great War.

FORT-DIX, N.J., Oct. 5 -- The Thirty-ninth Pursuit Squadron, from Selfridge Field, Mich., moved into Fort Dix this week-end and will remain until Oct. 16 to participate in an aerial "blitz" of the Atlantic coastline, beginning Thursday, to test the efficiency of volunteer civilian air observers.

Visual evidence that Poland still lives, even if Hitler says she is dead, was given yesterday in New York City as 20,000 persons representing the several hundred thousand Americans of Polish extraction in New York and adjoining States paraded up Fifth Avenue before applauding relatives and friends in the fifth annual Pulaski Memorial Day parade.

Foundation Day, the ninety-third anniversary of the founding of the Church of the Episcopal Transfiguration, Twenty-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue, more famous to New Yorkers and countless visitors from all sections of the country as "The Little Church Around the Corner," was observed yesterday morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- Paramount has purchased "The Passionate Witch," Thorne Smith's last novel, which Norman Matson completed after Smith's death, as a vehicle for Veronica Lake. Rene Clair, French director, whose only previous American film was Universal's "Flame of New Orleans" with Martene Dietrich, has been engaged to direct the picture.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Rainy weather over a large part of the section that produces most of the commercial corn and soy bean crops checked harvest operations last week. But no damage is expected and a few days of dry weather are likely to witness further gathering of corn and combing of beans.
BERLIN, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The German High Command communique today follows:

The torpedoing by a German submarine in South Atlantic waters of the American-owned tanker I.C. White is rightly called by Secretary Hull an "act of lawlessness, piracy and attempted frightfulness" in the Nazi program of world conquest.

One way of explaining it is that college football went crazy with the heat on Saturday. Anyway, it gave the world series the stiffest kind of competition with the thrills and shocks provided all over the country in sweltering baseball weather.

The issue of American intervention in the war was debated yesterday by Corporation Counsel William C. Chanter, and advocate of aid to the Allies, and Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., isolationist, at a meeting of the Newman Club Federation, Catholic student group, at the Corpus Christi Church auditorium, 535 West 121st Street.

Preparations for the defense of public health in case of war, disaster or other emergency in New York City have already been undertaken by the City Health Department, it is disclosed in its annual report to Mayor La Guardia, which Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, will make public today.

Summer continued its last-ditch stand against Autumn yesterday as the temperature reached 90 degrees, setting a new record for the date, and hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers piled into cars and fled to beaches and woodlands, giving traffic policemen another dose of Sunday blues.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 -- That the Germans intend to abandon the offensive against Leningrad is reported today from Berlin by the correspondent of the Stockholm Tidningen, whose dispatches often seem to be inspired by the Wilhelmstrasse.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Louis Dembitz Brandeis, retired Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and one of the greatest liberals in the history of that tribunal, died at his residence here at 7:15 o'clock this evening.

Freedom, "of the press" but not "for the press" during war time is advocated by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes in a telegram to the New York Newspaper Women's Club, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, and released yesterday by Kay Thomas, president.

Growing popularity of the city's improved recreational facilities, including golf courses, oeaches, swimming pools" and tennis courts, produced a 20 per cent increase in revenues during the first nine months of the year, as compared with the same period in 1940, and more than 100 per cent as compared with 1933, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A Supreme Court averaging slightly under 56 years in age, the youngest in many years, will reassemble tomorrow to plunge into the work of deciding far-reaching legal controversies that accumulated during the four-month Summer recess.

Mayor La Guardia has tentatively setected ldlewild, Queens, as the site of a new 1,200-acre city airport that, while being "the first air freight terminal," will be used by the Navy for training purposes to supplement Floyd Bennett Field, will help relieve commercial air traffic congestion and, following the war, will "take care of the enormous additional transatlantic air traffic," it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 5 -- Governor Lehman endorsed the Community Mobilization for Human Needs today. He pointed out in a statement that the mobilization was not only a call to the spirit of the nation, but was "a pledge to protect, preserve and promote human values" through community chests.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick told members of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, in his sermon yesterday morning, that "the curse of fear is that it gets itself taken too seriously."

MIAMI, Monday, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau in an advisory message issued at 1 A.M., Eastern standard time, said that the hurricane was centered at midnight about seventy miles east southeast of Bimini, moving west-northwestward at 20 miles an hour, which is unusually fast for a tropical disturbance in this part of the world.
Several large apartments in the Park Avenue district were included in the list of rentals reported by brokers over the week-end.

GARY, Ind., Oct. 5 (AP) -- About 6,000 of the 10,500 Sunday workers at the Gary works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation were idle today after thirty-nine crane-men employed in key positions failed to report for work.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Cecil Smith's Texas Rangers eked out a 7-6 victory over the Blind Brook Knights today in a tense polo match held for the benefit of the United Service Organizations at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

SUCH things could happen only in Brooklyn. The Dauntless Dodgers had the Yankees licked with two out in the ninth. The Brooklyn pitcher struck out the next man. So what happened? The Yankees scored four runs and galloped off with the confounded ball game. Baffling Bewildering But truly Brooklyn baseball of the old whirling dervish tradition.

MANILA, Oct. 5 -- With the visit here of the British Commander in Chief of the Far East, Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, there has been some clarification of Philippine and American roles in the anti-Axis defense plans for East Asia and the Western Pacific.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 5 -- Moscow reported tonight that important progress had been made in the counter-offensive being carried out by the Red Army on the Nogais Steppe in an effort to relieve Nazi pressure on the Russians defending Crimea.

The American Academy in Rome will nearly double the money prizes that it will offer next year to young painters and sculptors throughout the country, Dr. Roscoe Guernsey, executive secretary, announced yesterday.
"If, if, if, there'll be no if tonight."

Attempts here and in London to straighten out the tangled affairs of the Chosen Corporation and its subsidiaries have been making gradual progress. The most recent step forward appears to have been filing of a report by Sir Harry Peat, appointed inspector for the British Board of Trade in 1938.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Harry Walker, Columbus center fielder, wrote a story-book finish for the little world series today when he drove a home run over the right-field wall with two mates on base to climax a five-run rally which gave the Redbirds a 9-to-8 victory over Montreal and the series laurels by four games to two.

Following the sharp downward trend in the previous two weeks, cotton prices last week recorded substantial net gains. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 77 to 100 points.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- The Red Army is continuing strong counterattacks in the Ukraine and in the vicinity of Leningrad. It Was reported today that Soviet troops had advanced as much as twenty miles in the former region, reoccupying a strategically important enemy stronghold, and that Major Gen. Knokoff's army in the north had forced another river passage, capturing a strongly defended village and pushing on three more miles.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 5 -- A American flag made of red Indian corn, dried white lima beans and blue pokeberries hung near a battleship built of potatoes, apple, eggplant and gourds here today and struck a keynote of the seventy-second annual Danbur Fair.

Mayor La Guardia is on solid ground when he cites the record of his two terms at City Hall as the basic argument for his re-election. He has accomplished much toward the realization of his dream of making New York the finest city in the world, and he seeks permission of the voters now to finish the job.

Enter Autumn Colors A change has come over the face of the earth hereabouts in recent days. Rumors of it began to be heard two weeks ago. The Green Mountains of conservative Vermont were said to be turning red. The somber North Woods and the Adirondacks, viewed from the Montreal plane, had gone, all of a sudden, to looking like highly unrestrained Turkish rugs.

A plea to the government to give colleges more information on the types of training particularly needed for defense was made yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Bernard College in her annual report.

Bankers Trust Company The Bankers Trust Company, one of the eight banks in New York City with resources in excess of $1,000,000,000, reported as of Sept. 30 total deposits of $1,321,474,582 and total assets of $1,439,449,389, compared, respectively, with $1,332,169,784 and $1,448,782,581 on June 30.

Twin Gables, the estate of the late Benjamin Lissberger with a large English Georgian brick residence and nine acres of land at Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., has been sold by Mrs. Juliet W. Lissberger to Louis Kaplan, who will occupy it.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- All indications today were that Mr. Roosevelt was preparing for one of the busiest weeks Washington has seen for some time. At a bipartisan meeting with Senate leaders Tuesday morning at the White House, the Executive is expected to make a final decision as to whether repeal or modification of the Neutrality Act is to be asked of Congress.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Oct. 5 -- A 102-mile-an-hour hurricane swept past Nassau early tonight, leaving the town littered with the wreckage of boats blown out of the harbor, uprooted trees and disabled electric wires.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The champion Chicago Bears performed like a steam roller to smash the Cleveland Rams today, 48 to 21, before 23,850 fans. The Bears got four touchdowns in the second period and coasted the remainder of the way.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 5 -- Recent operations on the Russian front and two announcements last week again emphasized the growing importance of armored and motorized vehicles in modern war.
MOSCOW, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau said in a communique issued shortly before midnight tonight that Stubborn fighting continued along the entire front.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The story in THE TIMES of the luncheon in celebration of the detective story centenary renews an irritation of years. Not one of the worthies supporting this class of fiction has ever, to my knowledge, deigned to admit the influence of the dime novel detective yarn.

NEWHAVEN, England, Oct. 5 -- The proposed repatriation of some physically unfit and noncombatant prisoners of war by officials of Great Britain and Germany was held in abeyance once again today for the second day in succession as the two belligerent countries continued to seek a satisfactory solution to last-minute difficulties blocking the whole plan.

BERLIN, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The High Command communique and other German war reports indicated today that the Russians were fighting hard on the approaches to the Crimean Peninsula as attack and counter-attack followed in quick succession.

Wires have just been received from the conservation departments of both Maine and New Hampshire announcing that the recent ban on hunting in all sections of these States has been removed as a result of the heavy rains of the past few days.

Although mill shipments of all types of hosiery set a new August record in that month this year, there was a decline from a year ago in the women's full-fashioned division, according to data issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Figures were given in greater detail than previously, to make it possible to follow the continuing effects of the freezing of raw silk, which occurred late in July.

"When Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes died, in 1935, the mantle of judicial liberalism long since had been wrapped about the lean shoulders of Louis Dembitz Brandeis, like his mentor an outstanding apostle of dissent. He already had spent a long lifetime in pursuit of justice, both real and in the abstract, before he was appointed to the highest court of the land by Woodrow Wilson in 1916.

The ten-story and penthouse office and showroom building at 874 Broadway, at the northeast corner of Eighteenth Street, has been sold by the United States Trust Company to Raymond Levine, reality operator, of 1410 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Former Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes tonight issued the following tribute to Justice Brandeis:

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 5 -- Measures applied on the Berlin Boerse against undue speculation and runaway securities prices, in line with the previously announced Reich policy, were the principal influence in determining the trend last week on the secondary stock exchanges of Continental Europe.

CONWAY, N.H., Oct. 6 -- A faint "Hi! Hi!" attracted a squad of CCC searchers for Pamela Hollingworth just as they turned back toward their base camp on the slope of Mount Chocorua at dusk this evening, downhearted after another apparently futile day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- An unauthorized strike of sixty crane opertors, which had made 17,600 workers idle at the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's Gary, Ind., works, was ended tonight when officials of the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee announced that the men would return to work at midnight.

A mock invasion of New York City across the lower bay will be staged sometime between Thursday and Saturday during the vast air manoeuvres in which 150 bombing planes and 250 fighters will fly up and down the Atlantic Coast from Massachusetts to North Carolina for a week beginning Thursday.
The world series which ended yesterday was worth $5,917.31 to each member of the victorious Yankees and $4,808 to the regulars of the Dodgers.
CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 6 -- Prime Minister John Curtin announced the composition of his Laborite Cabinet today after a party caucus had elected its personnel. The new government is as follows:

Emerson (Spike) Nelson, Yale coach, and the new substitution rule made the headlines at Toots Shop's restaurant yesterday as the Football Writers Association renewed their weekly luncheons for another season.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- A spectacular 64, seven strokes under par, on his own ball enabled Tony Tiao, assistant pro at Hickory, and his Fenway amateur partner, Saul Lantzis, to carry off first honors in the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur best-ball tournament today.

Since 1933 a group of University of California students who form the Book Arts Club have issued a book each year in collaboration with the University Press. Out of the club's study of the elements of good bookmaking has come this year one called "About Books: A Gathering of Essays" which has been printed in a small edition.

SUNDANCE, Wyo., Oct. 6 -- Bewhiskered and tired, but still cheerful, George Hopkins, 30-year-old daredevil from San Antonio, Texas, was rescued tonight from the Devil's Tower that had held him a prisoner for six days and five nights after he parachuted to its top on a $50 wager.

Registration of voters for the municipal elections in November started yesterday with a decided slump from last year's record-breaking totals. In most sections of the city first-day figures also fell below the mark for 1937, the last year in which a municipal election was held.
"I think my boys played some good baseball, but they beat us. We just didn't quite have enough."

A large reception, followed by the showing of the Paderewski film, "Moonlight Sonata," was given last night at the Museum of Modern Art under the sponsorship of the Paderewski Testimonial Fund, Inc. The evening's entertainment was under the chairmanship of Mrs. Chauncey Waddell.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Reports that ceiling prices on iron and steel scrap may be raised drew a denial today from Leon Henderson, Price Administrator.

A total of $375,258 has been raised in the 1941 Citizens Appeal for $375,000 for the Salvation Army as of Sept. 30, the date of the drive's formal ending, it was announced yesterday by Walbridge S. Taft, chairman of the Army's advisory board for Greater New York, at the Fall board meeting in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- Britain almost trapped "most of the German Fleet" at the start of the Norwegian campaign in April, 1940, it was revealed today in a 130-page booklet called "Bomber Command." The booklet discloses that failure of a radio message to get through may have prevented the British Fleet from engaging the German Fleet while it was enroute to Norway.

Freedom of worship guaranteed to Americans by their Constitution and the move of President Roosevelt to obtain a pledge of religious freedom in Russia from the Soviet Government were hailed in sermons preached by rabbis yesterday in observance of Succoth or the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles.

CONWAY, N.H., Oct. 6 -- Found unharmed after wandering for eight cold or rainy days in a White Mountain wilderness, 5-year-old Pamela Hollingworth was restored tonight to the parents who never had given up hope throughout the long search for her.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 6 -- Finishing up just before darkness overtook them, Tony Longo, playing pro at Inwood, and his partner, Irving Schloss of the same club, won today's Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro best ball golf with a 66 on the red course at Bethpage Park.

Hoping to duplicate the success of his previous historical offering ("Victoria Regina"), Gilbert Miller is bringing to the St. Tames Theatre this evening "Anne of England," another intimate glimpse of English history. Flora Robson as Sarah Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough, and Barbara Everest in the name part, are co-starred in this play written by Mary Cass Canfield and Ethel Borden.

Very definitely fashion is working from the ground up this season. It is concentrating on feet at this moment. This fact was again established yesterday afternoon when Herman Delman invited the fashion press to view his newly created shoe line in his glittering Fifth Avenue showroom.

"Yi-p-p-e-e-e-e!" The shriek, shrill and penetrating, echoed in the catacombs under the Ebbets Field stand yesterday and heralded the approach of the conquering Yankees as they came trooping into their dressing room.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- Official German dispatches tonight reported the execution of five more Czechs in Bruenn and competent Nazi sources said "strong measures" were being taken to suppress a Serbian revolt, which had been "largely quelled."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- Senator Mead, in his statement to the Senate today on Nazi persecution of the Catholic Church in Germany, said that many priests were being placed under "house arrest." He said that when he heard a report that the Bishop of Muenster had been arrested he investigated and got the "full story."

The revised estimates for this fiscal year announced by the Bureau of the Budget reflect the rising pace of defense spending and forecast an even sharper rise to come. The changes show how fast the scope of our preparedness program is expanding. In January President Roosevelt estimated that $10,811,000,000 would be spent for defense in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- At intervals today the grim, and relentless flow of war between Britain and Germany stood frozen in one sector at least, as back and forth between a Nazi radio station in France and British stations flashed message after message regarding the exchange of prisoners of war.

Weadell Willkie, asserting that the time has come for new and more united action, called upon the Republican party last night to assume the leadership of a fight to repeal the Neutrality Act. He made his appeal in an address at a dinner of the National Republican Club at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in honor of Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States.

Add to the list of film openings this week Warner's "Law of the Tropics," which will arrive at the Globe on Thursday. The adventure features Constance Bennett and Jeffrey Lynn.... Also opening on Thursday will be Universal's "Moonlight in Hawaii," at the Palace, a comedy with music featuring Johnny Downs, Jane Frazee, Leon Errol and Elaine Morey, which will be shown in conjunction with "The Little Foxes."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Oct. 11 was designated by President Roosevelt as Pulaski Day in commemoration of the death of the Polish nobleman who gave his life in the fight for American independence.

Pale-faced cheddar cheese -- light and sharp with a solid creaminess -- comes from Wisconsin to console Manhattan cheese lovers for the loss of their favorite food from the ancient township of Cheddar, England. This famous, sturdy cheese, beloved of Boswell, Thackeray and Dickens, has been re-created in America's own wide-open spaces without losing so much as a whisper of its delicious nippiness.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Increased wages for their workers would force the railroads to step up freight rates, A.F. Cleveland, traffic expert for the Association of American Railroads, told the President's fact-finding commission today. He pictured a gloomy outlook for the railroads at the end of the present emergency.

HONG KONG, Oct. 6 -- Although there have been no important military activities in Kwangtung since the Japanese withdrawal to Canton, Chinese reports say the guerrillas, encouraged by the Japanese retreat, are becoming more active. The Japanese are taking greater precautions in the vicinity of Canton and there are almost daily arrests of suspects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Panama's decision to forbid arming of foreign-owned ships caused surprise in unofficial quarters here today. There was no official comment beyond word that the State Department had no information of such a decision.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A campaign to stem America's rising accident toll trend, due mainly to national defense activities, will be mapped out at the thirtieth annual congress of the National Safety Council which convened here today.

Women who earn their livelihood by operating a typewriter were honored indirectly last night at the opening celebration of National Business Women's Week held at the Hotel Astor. The meeting was sponsored by the Transcription Supervisors Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- More than $150,000 in underwriting and management fees due Drexel Co. of Philadelphia in connection with issue and sale of securities of the United Gas Improvement Company, impounded by order of the Securities and Exchange Commission under its "arms-length" bargaining rule, were freed today by the commission.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (U.P) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler has launched a massive pincers drive against Moscow from the northern and central fronts, throwing in great forces of artillery and tanks and at least two air fleets of 3,000 planes each, hoping to capture and set up Winter headquarters in the Soviet cap-

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The War Department announced today that supply contracts amounting to $30,790,670.62 had been awarded. Among these were the following, not previously published, granted to companies in the New York area:

Charges that incompetency and carelessness by several Lincoln Hospital physicians were to blame for three deaths at the city institution were made yesterday in a report by a five-man committee of the City Council that will be presented to the full membership of the Council at City Hall today.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Asserting that there were signs of more religious toleration in the Soviet Union, the Archbishop of Canterbury predicted today as an outcome of the war a "new Russia" and a revival of the Russian people's "deep, ineradicable sense of religion."

The impromptu pheasant trials for gun dogs held by the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, which have proved so popular in the past, will be held again this Fall and Winter, with the first scheduled for next Sunday.

Supporters of William O'Dwyer, Democratic nominee for Mayor, yesterday fired a double-barreled attack at the opposition, first accusing two members of the Roosevelt Administration, supporting Mayor La Guardia, of violating the Hatch act, and secondly accusing the Mayor himself of having paid complimentary remarks to Soviet Russia in the past.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.
While priorities may block park construction now, plan-making and land acquisition should continue, the Regional Plan Association suggested in its Bulletin No. 56 issued yesterday.

Jim Crowley sent the Fordham football men through a light workout yesterday on Fordham Field. Strenuous work for the engagement Saturday with North Carolina will commence today. A scrimmage is planned tomorrow.

Don Snavely, Columbia's senior center, sustained a bruised cartilage in his left knee and will be out of action in next Saturday's contest at Princeton, it was announced yesterday as the Lions' football squad reported to Baker Field.

Congress, in passing the Public Utility Holding Company Act, a measure designed to break up the large holding companies, "never envisaged that the day would come when small investors would be frozen out of high-grade investments through the SEC's interpretation of the powers granted it under this act," Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, declared yesterday.

SEATTLE, Oct. 6 -- With the assertion that there were "no isolationists" in the American Federation of Labor and the prediction that the federation would "rise to new heights" in support of President Roosevelt's future conduct of the wartime emergency, William Green, A.F. of L. president, brought delegates to their feet, cheering and applauding, at the opening today of the annual convention.

NEWHAVEN, England, Tuesday, Oct. 7 -- A few minutes before the hospital ships Dinard and St. Julien were due to leave their berths here at 12:45 o'clock this morning to repatriate wounded German prisoners a War Office announcement canceling their departure became known.

The sixteen-story loft building at 230 West Thirty-ninth Street has been purchased by an investing client of Donald MacDonald, Inc., brokers, from the United States Trust Company of New York, acting as trustee of the estate of Julius H. Kayser.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The annual club president-pro best-ball tournament held under the auspices of the New Jersey P.G.A. today resulted in a tie between S.R. Rowland and Johnny Kinder of Plainfield and F.C. Brush and Tony Farese of Raritan Valley.

Freddie (Red) Cochrane, Elizabeth (N.J.) boxer who holds the welterweight championship of the world, had little trouble with Lew Jenkins in their ten-round main bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Engaging in his first fight since he became champion last July.
Brooklyn last night was a community of the saddened and heartbroken, but in the bars and estaminets from Irishtown to Bensonhurst loyal rooters spoke no evil of Lippy Durocher's stepchildren.

Mary Pickford and Alexander Korda arrived yesterday noon at La Guardia Airport from Hollywood, which they left Sunday night immediately after the signing of the contract by which David O. Selznick joined with them and Charles Chaplin in the ownership of the United Artists Corporation.

The Egyptian passenger liner Kawsar docked in Jersey City yesterday at the end of a nine-week voyage from Suez via Cape Town and South America with 243 passengers, the largest group to come from the Middle East in several months.

Sweeping irresistibly toward their goal in a manner to which they had long since become accustomed, the Yankees vanquished the Dodgers once more at Ebbets Field yesterday and, with this victory, achieved by a score of 3 to 1, again established themselves as undisputed baseball champions of the universe.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 6 -- Growing disorders and sabotage in Bulgaria and a full-scale war that now threatens the German rear in the Morava and Vardar Valleys in Serbia, were reported here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- "The Dawn's Early Light," a story of the life of Alexander Hamilton by Dorothy Thompson and Fritz Kortner which Metro has owned for two years, will be revived for Robert Taylor and Hedy Lamarr, the studio announced today.

Yesterday the Supreme Court opened its new term with a short session. Two new Associate Justices and the new Chief Justice took their seats. It is worth recalling that the title of each of the first six Chief Justices was Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.

The oldest horse in the $9,150 Interborough Handicap on Jamaica's opening program yesterday was the 8-year-old Speed to Spare, but he was not too old to take the measure of all the keen young ones that so many thought had a better chance.

Officials of Hamlet, N.C., announced yesterday that they will offer for sale on Oct. 14 an issue of $335,000 of general refunding bonds, for which bidders are asked to name the interest rate. Dated Nov. 1, 1941, the obligations will mature serially from Nov. 1, 1943 to 1969.

Accompanied by Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, and other officials of the State Labor Department, Governor Lehman inspected yesterday the new State employment office at 87 Madison Avenue, established as the first step toward the consolidation of twenty-nine district employment offices in the city into five central bureaus.

Colonel Manton Davis, vice president and general counsel of the Radio Corporation of America, was the first witness yesterday in hearings conducted by Special Supreme Court Referee Abraham J. Halprin on the fairness of the offer of $1,000,000 made by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in settlement of an accounting action by stockholders of R.C.A.

Trotsky will no doubt be asked to say whether he really plotted with Hitler and with Japan against the Soviet Union.

PANAMA, Oct. 6 -- Vessels flying the Panama flag which arm against raiders will have their registration canceled, the Cabinet Council decided at a conference today at which President Arnulfo Arias presided.

OTTAWA, Oct. 6 -- A constant stream of large merchant ships will begin to pour from Canadian shipyards soon, as this country's further contribution to the Battle of the Atlantic and the Battle of Britain.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Resenting the tangle into which the Westchester County airport proposal has fallen, several members of the Board of Supervisors aimed caustic criticism today at Chairman Raphael A. Carretta of the board, Mayor La Guardia of New York and officials in Washington.
The play-by-play description of the fifth and final game of the world series at Ebbets Field yesterday follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that it would soon take over direct supervision of the Hunter's Point drydocks from the Bethlehem Steel Company, San Francisco, primarily because of "emergency needs on the West Coast for docking and repair facilities for large vessels, battleships and aircraft carriers."

Three survivors of the 1,811-ton wooden twin-screw freighter Ethel Skakel, formerly the Libby Maine, which was sunk in the Caribbean Sea during a hurricane on Sept. 25, arrived here yesterday on the Porto Rico liner Borinquen from San Juan.

The Mayor said something the other day about the city's having acquired a soul. No doubt he had in mind not only the remarkable work that Mr. Moses has done in clearing away some ugly spots and providing more landscaped spaces for recreation but the achievements of our city Health Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- In an effort to combat Germany's economic and intellectual imperialism in Latin America, the United States Government has offered to subsidize the broadcasting of unbiased news to the Southern continent.

National defense and war relief activities were stressed in the work of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, during the year ended June 30, although normal services also were increased, according to the chapter's annual report, released yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director.

Foreign traders were called upon here yesterday to ask the American Government to give them "the support which national welfare deserves" in demanding a satisfactory explanation of the export operations of the British Government and British exporters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- In an order overriding virtually all contentions of the New York Stock Exchange, the Securities and Exchange Commission instructed today the Exchange to amend its proposed rule against multiple trading so that members no longer would be prevented from acting as dual odd-lot dealers or specialists in dually traded securities.

The record breaking high temperatures slowed up consumer demand which was reflected back to the wholesale markets, which opened only fair to slow yesterday. Call hindsaddles were weak to lower and some lamb cuts were lower. Fresh pork cuts showed weakness. Other classes were mostly steady.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Senator James M. Mead of New York submitted to the Senate today what he termed "concrete, documentary evidence" that Adolf Hitler and the Nazi police were plundering and destroying the Catholic church in Germany.

Apartment houses on the West Side received the bulk of the apartment rentals reported yesterday by brokers operating in various sections of the city. A number of suburban structures, principally on Long Island, also shared in the activity.

According to a report by the American European Securities Company for the first nine months of the current year, licenses have been issued to the company, from time to time, since the Executive order "freezing foreign assets" on June 14, permitting it to buy securities through Dominick Dominick to a total of $200,000, the items so acquired to be maintained in a "blocked" account by the brokers.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 6 -- The Turkish-German trade negotiations struck a second snag today, according to usually well-informed foreign trade and diplomatic circles, and the new Turkish-German trade pact may not be signed until next week or later.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 -- An authorized German spokesman told the foreign press today that a "period of military silence" concerning Reichsfuehrer Hitler's new operations against the Soviet Union had begun and that little specific news could be expected from the east for several days.

The government's charges that the Aluminum Company of America exercised an illegal monopoly in this country's aluminum industry were definitely and completely rejected yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey. He held that the Department of Justice had failed to show that it was entitled to "any relief" from the company, which means that no order of dissolution will be granted so far as the monopoly charges are concerned.
THE dream is over. Flatbush is wrapped in gloom. There was a burial party at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Yanks took the ball game and the series and left the Dodgers for dead on the field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Issuance by the Federal Communications Commission of its proposed order prohibiting multiple ownership of standard broadcast stations was opposed today by more than a score of broadcasters. Arguments that were presented on their behalf said that such a rule lacked merit and that the commission lacked authority to promulgate any blanket order against such ownerships.

ABOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S TRAIN, Oct. 6 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he would make an effort to obtain the support of as many Republican members of Congress as possible in the drive to be formally started this week for modification or repeal of the Neutrality Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The voice of wisdom and experience discussing domestic affairs can scarcely be heard these days amid the reverberations of violent world events. Two examples of this public preoccupation have been furnished as recently as last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A bill designed to check inflation, roughly patterned after the over-all price control plan outlined before the House Banking and Currency Committee by Bernard M. Baruch, was introduced in the House today by Representative Gore, Tennessee Democrat.

TOYKO, Tuesday, Oct. 7 (U.P) -- Ultra-nationalists are intensifying their pressure on the government either to show some concrete results from its conversations with the United States or to call off the effort and move drastically to curb British-American efforts to encircle this country, reliable informants said today.

The Whitney Museum of American Art opened yesterday afternoon an exhibition of children's paintings produced in classes conducted by Augustus Peck. For the preview reception this work filled the walls not only of the smaller galleries numbered 9 and 10, on the second floor of the museum, but also those of the large Gallery 8, adjoining.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Oct. 4:

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- The only remaining publication of the League of Militant Atheists, the Anti-Religioznik -- which means the anti-religious one -- has been suspended from publication, it was learned today.

Acting in behalf of the 275,000 members of the union, the general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers voted yesterday to back Philip Murray for re-election as president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- In a special communique issued today, the Italians announced that the British aircraft carrier Ark Royal had returned to Gibraltar at reduced speed after having been gravely damaged in the aero-naval battle in the Mediterranean on Sept. 27.

TOKYO, Oct. 6 -- The Japanese press is beginning to display considerable concern and some depression over the increasing number of military and economic conferences on the periphery of its projected Greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere and the slow progress in the Washington conversations.

Except for some unusual activity in low-priced public utility issues, the stock market was dull yesterday and, while there were no new definite disturbing factors, notice was taken of the reports concerning a possible peace offensive by Germany next year.
NEW YORK Crown Princess Martha of Norway has arrived from Bethesda, Md., accompanied by Countess Ragni Ostgaard, and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.
