After an advance of 7 to 14 points in the early trading on the New York Cotton Exchange prices turned easier yesterday and closed at net losses of 7 to 19 points. Commission house liquidation, in anticipation of the official crop report tomorrow, and hedge selling pressed the market down.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 28 (Delayed) -- The Battle of the Atlantic is entering a crucial period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Reports of a brewing filibuster and other last-ditch strategic moves of critics of the Administration's foreign policy were heard in Washington today on the eve of disclosure by President Roosevelt of his plans for changing the Neutrality Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 1: An increase of $58,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans; decreases of $96,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $113,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $117,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

The action of the Securities and Exchange Commission directing the New York Stock Exchange to change its rules specifically to permit its members to act as odd-lot dealers or specialists on other exchanges was more important from a procedural than from a functional standpoint, in the consensus of Wall Street.

Mayor La Guardia told 300 persons yesterday at the formal opening of Brooklyn Republican campaign headquarters that he did not want to return to City Hall for another four years unless Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, and Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick were re-elected.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, charged today that defense production has been hampered for ten months by "powerful groups who fear expansion may destroy their domination of industry." Mr. Arnold spoke at the opening here of the thirteenth annual Boston Conference on Distribution.
IN a genial book called "Native American,"* Ray Stannard Baker, now nearing 72, looks back to some of the things he saw and did during his first wide-eyed twenty-five years.

New Yorkers continued to swelter for the third consecutive day as the temperature touched 89 degrees at 3:40 P.M. yesterday, smashing by 4 degrees the record for the date that had stood for ten years.

Store Sales Here Rise 23% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores registered a 23 per cent increase for the week ended Oct. 4 over the corresponding week of 1940, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 30 a United States Senator of isolationist bent is reported as saying that "America has been made to fear by propaganda."

Treasury Calls Depositary banks of the United States Treasury in the Second Federal Reserve District were notified yesterday by the Treasury that it would withdraw $17,050,750 from this district on Thursday and the same amount the following day.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Coordinated Soviet land and air blows on the central and southern fronts smashed two German motorized columns and destroyed ninety-eight tanks, the Russians announced today in acknowledging that Nazi tanks had wedged into the Red Army lines at one point in the central area.

On the eve of the President's conference today with leaders of Congress on the question of repealing or amending the Neutrality Act, the Gallup survey finds that "a majority of the American people are in favor of more outright measures of intervention in the war than at any tune in the past twenty-five months."
ROME, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the folowing communique today:

The recent British decision to tighten the blockade of Switzerland in reply to the commercial agreement signed between that country and Germany has now been implemented by the issuance of a comprehensive list of commodities for which neither navicerts nor mailcerts can be accepted.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Since the start of the war savings campaign in November, 1939, small savers have lent L1,000,000,000 to the government. Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood announced this figure at a luncheon held here today to celebrate the achievement, and he said that the sum represented more than L20 per head of population, including children.

VICHY, France, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- The 8,194-ton French liner Theophile Gautier, sailing in an Italian convoy to protect her from British submarines and bombers, "whose recent aggressions" had cost France four other ships, was torpedoed Saturday in the Aegean Sea by a submarine believed to be British, with a possible loss of twenty lives, the Admiralty announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Office of Production Management was reported today to be formulating an order calling on the automobile industry to use no more "brightwork" on its new models.

The current shift in population, with wholesale migrations of workers from one territory to another, is posing a problem for marketing men, who know that brand loyalty can be easily changed, not only by a move from one city to another but in some instances from one section of a city to another.

Call Bobby Clark a circus and this department will make only one reservation. He is funnier than a circus. If all the clowns were put together, Oom Bobby could outmatch them laugh for laugh and toss in a couple of side-shows for good measure.

The Brooklyn espionage trial entered its fifth week yesterday, with William G. Sebold, counter-espionage agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, still on the witness stand giving evidence against the sixteen persons accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The captain and ten officers of a Norwegian motorship arrived in Hampton Roads with their ship today, bringing a story of an escape in July from Dakar, in French Africa, after fourteen months' interment.
BERLIN, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The text of the German High Command communique issued from the Fuehrer's Headquarters today follows:

"An American tragedy!" Thus in three little words did one Brooklyn fan sum up the world series. Slowly and unsteadily, head down, this fellow, like many others departing sadly from Ebbets Field yesterday, seemed to be speaking for the majority.

Further reports concerning the recommendations for modification of the Social Security Act that the President is expected to forward to Congress this week only strengthen the conviction that the most immediate need here is not hasty and ill-considered action but thorough study.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The volume of trading in wheat futures today was the smallest in some time. Prices held within a range of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel, a feature being the buying of the May against sales of the July at 1/2 cent difference by a house with Eastern connections.

HAVANA, Oct. 6 -- The conference of United States foreign service officers of the Carribean area opened in the American Embassy here this morning under the chairmanship of Ambassador George S. Messersmith. Twenty-eight officials and seven military and naval attaches attended, including Laurence Duggan from Washington, representing the State Department.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 6 -- Intelligence reports to high foreign military circles here tonight said that the German High Command was pushing preparations for a sea offensive against Crimea from Bulgarian ports.

SIMLA, India. Oct. 6 (AP) -- Mock warfare upon an unprecedented scale opened today along India's rugged northwestern frontier, the gateway from the West, with a surprise aerial "attack," in modern style before a formal declaration of war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Oct. 1 aggregated $11,505,000,000.

The former Liondale Bleach Dye and Print Works plant, containing 250,000 square feet of space, at Rockaway, N.J., was sold by the Consolidated Sterling Company to Standard Container, Inc., and will be used for the manufacture of shell cases and containers and other defense materials.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6 -- A dummy scrimmage today opened Yale's preparations for the Penn game. Because of the heat and the strenuous test against Virginia last Saturday, the players were not driven too hard. However, the five Eli elevens, including every player who faced Virginia, were still in action when the flood lights were turned on at Anthony Thompson Field.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- "Bomber Command," an official British historical work just published, brings to light conflicts between the British and French commands before the fall of France and gives new information on the smashing by the Royal Air Force of preparations for a German invasion attempt in the Autumn of 1940.
Virtually unscathed as yet despite the heavy toll taken of the major elevens of the country at this early date, the leaders of Eastern college football will head into heavy firing this week.
For the fourth successive week Infant mortality in New York City has been under 30 per 1,000 live births, a new low record, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

Unless a voter qualifies by registering he cannot vote in the municipal election this November. Registration places are open today through Friday from 5 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. and on Saturday from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.

The NBC Symphony Orchestra opened last night its fifth season of radio concerts in Radio City. Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, directed the performance, which is to be followed by twenty-seven others at weekly intervals on WJZ and a nation-wide hook-up of affiliated stations.
An exciting discovery for the lady with a meringue-glace appetite and a skimmed-milk-and-lettuce waistline is soy nut butter. That ubiquitous little bean has scored still another triumph.

The five buildings at the corner of Rogers Avenue and Sterling Place in Brooklyn, formerly occupied by the Swedish Hospital, have been sold by the hospital group to the Odessa Home for the Aged and will be occupied by the new owners after alterations are made. Leicher Heney, Inc., acted as brokers in the deal.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 7 -- The Manila visit of Air Chief Marshal Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, British Commander in Chief in the Far East, is hailed here as emphasizing the solidarity of the British-American position in the Far East.

What was "Viceroy Sarah" in England six years ago has become "Anne of England" here. It was produced with purple splendor at the St. James last evening with some actors worth revering. Since Americans are a little backward on fine points of English history, Mary Cass Canfield and Ethel Borden have rewritten the original play of Norman Ginsbury's authorship and an extensive program note provides the historical setting for polite hair-pulling in a palace.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 -- Completion of the agreement with the United States is expected to result in great constructive activity here, partly in fulfillment of Mexico's part of the compact, partly in consequence of an expected influx of American capital for industrial investment, it was said today by business and defense experts.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 7 -- The Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers of Central Presbyterian Church, New York City, told the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers tonight that democracy cannot function apart from self-sacrifice and the willing obedience of the individual to self-imposed laws.
Arnold Hanger's Dit, winner of the Grey Lag Handicap over the same track last Spring, returned to score in the Johnstown Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- With a total volume of $4,915,462,000 in 1939, 182,566 stores in the metropolitan district of New York City and Northeastern New Jersey accounted for 11.7 per cent of the total sales reported by retail stores in the United States, J.C. Capt, director of the census, announced today.
BERLIN, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
NEW YORK Mrs. Constantin Fotitch, wife of the Yugoslav Minister, has arrived from Washington and is at Hampshire House.

The 35,000-ton battleship Alabama, under construction at the Norfolk Navy Yard, is being built to music. There are "six concerts daily from phonograph records played through an amplifying system," four during the shifts and two at lunch-time. The music is described in an Associated Press dispatch as "sweet and swing, classic and corny."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Westchester County's November election tickets reached final form tonight with the deadline for filing with the Board of Elections here the nominations of candidates for town offices, of independents and of candidates for the Yonkers Proportional Representation City Council.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Home ownership for American families with annual incomes of $1,500 or less has taken another step toward reality near here with the development of "Stansbury Manor," a defense project of 300 pro-fabricated dwellings.

Trading in general was only fair to slow yesterday. Lamb and fresh pork cuts were weak to lower. Other classes were In light supply and steady. Owing to Jewish holidays, there were no Kosher markets nor kosher slaughter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Supply contracts awarded today by the War Department amounted to $2,100,997. Among these were the following, not previously published, which went to firms in the New York area:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Krock was wrong in his implication this morning that the recent offering by the A.T. T. of $90,000,000 of debentures at competitive bidding was under compulsion of the competitive bidding rule of this commission. The A.T. T. is in no way subject to this rule, because it is not, within the terms of our statute, a public utility holding company.

The twenty-five-acre estate formerly owned by Mrs. Ella F. Schmidt on Hardscrabble Road, Pleasantville, Westchester County, has been sold to a client of Howard L. Auerbach, Inc., brokers. The residence contains fifteen rooms and four baths.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Federal Works Administration will withhold a contract for 300 defense houses in Michigan from the Currier Lumber Company of Detroit, low bidder by $431,000, on the order of Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the Office of Production Management, in the interest of labor stability in the building trades, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Fascist censorship has become more and more severe in recent weeks, and the only reports available on the internal situation in Italy come through diplomatic channels. But these reports are definite enough to convey a clear picture.

Deaths Announced Fireman First Grade, William A. Dorritie, Special Service Squad, died Oct. 6. Funeral will take place from the undertaking parlors of Joseph B. McGrath, 91-20 Thirty-seventh Ave., Jackson Heights. Queens, at 9:30 A. M., Thursday, Oct. 9. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.
VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Oct. 7 -- The Long Island Indians solidified their hold on first place in the American Football Association by defeating Paterson, 6-3, before 3,000 at Memorial Field tonight.

BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 7 -- Robert W. Baird, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., spoke this afternoon at the annual convention of the National Association of Securities Commissioners in the Hotel Buena Vista. He said that as the membership in his organization became more experienced in self-regulation it would be equally critical of State regulations which now were not effective and were "merely red tape."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- Thirty-four survivors of the torpedoeing and sinking of the tanker I.C. White arrived here today and told of the destruction without warning of the fully lighted ship, on which a strong searchlight was spotted on the Panamanian flag, clearly showing the tanker's nationality.

The football Giants are going to meet a revamped Philadelphia Eagle combination when the teams get together on Sunday for the local eleven's home opener at the Polo Grounds. Coach Earle (Greasy) Neale of the invaders has announced important changes in his line-up.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 (AP) -- The thoroughbreds returned to Kentucky today for their annual Fall gallop as Keeneland inaugurated a ten-day meeting to be followed by a thirteen-day session at Churchill Downs. Conditions were ideal for the opener and the enthusiastic crowd presaged a successful season.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique:
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

ATLANTA, Oct. 7 -- A tropical storm howled inland from the Gulf of Mexico early today and cut a destructive path across a corner of Florida and on into Georgia, leaving at least nine deaths on the long trail from its birthplace deep in the West Indies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- A plea that agriculture and industry begin now to "create the production that can beat the next depression" was voiced today by Wheeler McMullin, president of the National Farm Chemurgic Council, in an addresss before the American Life Convention in the Edgewater Beach Hotel here.

Harassed by ten lawsuits challenging its right to assign a teacher to any subject other than that for which she is licensed, the Board of Education may be forced to discharge 1,100 regularly employed high school teachers and replace them by persons on existing eligible lists, Theodore Fred Kuper, law secretary, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Bill of Rights was celebrated today here by a luncheon meeting at the Raleigh Hotel at which Senator Capper of Kansas and Nicholas Roosevelt or New York were the guests of honor and by a pilgrimmage to Gunston Hall, Va., where the Bill of Rights was written by George Mason of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The greatest battle in history's greatest campaign roared along a deep and shifting front over Russia's western plains last night, as Adolf Hitler apparently launched 1941's climactic blow in his program for the conquest of Europe.
Nothing, not even yesterday's newspaper, seems to move more quickly into oblivion than a world series, and the 1941 classic, dramatic and nerve tingling as It was, apparently is no exception.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- George Bernard Shaw's "Arms and the Man" will be filmed with Ginger Rogers at RKO as the first of six pictures Gabriel Pascal has contracted to produce for that company in the next two years.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct 8 -- Timing its utterances to coincide with the expected arrival in Washington of Kahame Wakasugi, Japanese Minister, the entire Japanese press today concentrated on emphasizing Japan's firm determination to pursue her immutable policies and on urging the United States to abandon its policy of "interference in the Far East."

Seventeen hotel executives from sixteen Latin-American nations, ending a good-will tour of twelve United States cities as guests of the American Hotel Association, began a four-day visit to New York yesterday with a cocktail party in the Hotel St. Moritz and a dinner at the Hotel Astor at which Franklin Moore, president of the association, declared that the tour had contributed to international understanding and to "a solid front for democracy in this hemisphere."

Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti notified the O'Dwyer campaign headquarters yesterday that he can be counted upon to campaign for the election of the O'Dwyer-Church-Fertig ticket, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx placed himself similarly in readiness, and Charles E. Murphy, O'Dwyer campaign manager announced that radio time would be reserved for each of them.

Active renting in newly completed apartment houses in various sections of the city was reported yesterday by agents and brokers. Several large apartments were among the suites announced as having been rented.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said today that it might be necessary to establish a ceiling on wood pulp prices at or below third-quarter levels in order to prevent higher paper prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Fresident Roosevelt, his conviction of the necessity for rapid revision of the American Neutrality Act strengthened by the action of Panama in forbidding the arming of foreign-owned ships operating under its registry, called today for a second "strategy" meeting of Congressional leaders and administrative advisers at the White House at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

Plans were filed yesterday for two new apartment houses on the East Side, both of which are to replace old churches. The old Park Avenue Presbyterian Church on the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street will give way to a nineteen-story and penthouse building costing $800,000.

SEATTLE, Oct. 7 -- In a new appeal for peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations President Roosevelt told the A.P.L. convention in a letter today that such a move would be "a patriotic step forward of incalculable value in the creation of true national unity."
Eight realty parcels in Jersey City, N.J., were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Provident Institution for Savings. They were:

WASHINGTON, Qct. 7 -- The United States today threw its influence into the scales in an attempt to induce Finland to withdraw her troops from Soviet territory and thus reduce pressure on Russian troops in the north at a time when Germany is hurling huge forces forward in a reported attempt to break the Russian center and capture Moscow.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- How the blazing American-owned tanker I.C. White ran unmanned in wild circles after she was torpedoed, endangering the boats containing her survivors, was related tonight by her master, Captain William Mello, as rescue ships brought thirty-four of her crew of thirty-seven to this harbor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Visual presentation of all the major facts of the war, as a substitute for a mass of written reports, is a project of Colonel William J. Donovan, Coordinator of Information, and his committee that has reached the advanced planning stage.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Official Greek sources here and half-starved Greek refugees who reached Egypt and Palestine in rowboats said today that there had been wholesale executions throughout Greece in a ruthless campaign to crush resistance against Axis domination.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Prices of boss dropped 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds in slow trading in the livestock market today. Traders attributed the decline, which cancelled yesterday's rally, to weakness in dressed pork.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Louis D. Brandeis, the 84-year-old retired associate justice of the Supreme Court, who died Sunday night, left an estate of nearly $3,200,000, according to his will admitted to probate in the Federal District Court today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The American League White Sox defeated the National League Cubs, 3 to 1, at Comiskey Park tonight to retain the Chicago City championship they have held since 1931. The Sox swept the series with four straight victories.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 -- Following a conference with Ford Motor Company officials today George F. Addes, secretary-treasurer of the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.), announced that immediate layoffs at the River Rouge plant would not exceed 5,400 workers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 7 -- A communique today reported that one British officer and eight men were either killed or captured by a large force of Germans after a brief battle between patrols in the frontier area early yesterday.

A recount to determine the winner of the Democratic primary contest for leadership of the First Assembly District West was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer on the application of supporters of Carmine Di Sapio, contestant for the leadership against Sheriff Daniel E. Finn.

Vehicles and boats in public service or operating for defense requirements, with the exception of school and private buses, are exempt from gasoline conservation rules, it was announced yesterday by Carroll E. Mealey, State Petroleum Products Conservator, following a survey of the effect the new Federal regulations will have in the State.

Ten institutions share equally in the residuary estate of Rosa Livingston, who died on Sept. 28, it was learned here yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. The petition listed cash bequests for five individuals.

A survivor from the crew of the wooden freighter Ethel Skakel that foundered in a Caribbean storm on Sept. 25 testified yesterday that the ship's mechanical steering apparatus had broken down twice on her last voyage, necessitating the use of the hand gear aft.

After moving narrowly in rather dull trading active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with net losses of 5 to 9 points. The government will issue its crop estimate today, but it is not expected to have much effect on prices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Steven Brooks, 20-year-old jockey from McCook, Neb., continued his sensational streak by riding four winners at Hawthorne today. Brooks scored on Fujiwara, who ran a dead heat with Loch Ness in the first race; on Speedy Squaw in the third, on Chance Sord in the fourth and on Tusco in the McGee Purse.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the East Coast at the close of last week were 18,579,000 barrels, a decline of 293,000 from the 18,872,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks of light fuel oil were 18,803,000 barrels, a gain of 439,000, while heavy fuel oil stocks were up 327,000 barrels to 10,482,000.
SEATTLE, Oct. 7 -- Following is the text of the letter of President Roosevelt read to the American Federation of Labor convention today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A new method for getting a quick check on all serious cases of priorities unemployment with a view to granting special preference on defense contracts to communities hard hit, was established today by the labor division of the Office of Production Management and the United States Employment Service.

PLAINSBORO, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Dr. Thomas M. Parran, Surgeon General of the United States, said here today that the United States might be forced to ration vital food supplies until American farmers could build the extra protein production plant needed for our own country to be properly fed and to aid Britain's war effort.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Despite dense fog and a steady drizzle, forty competed today in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association on the Old Oaks Country Club course.

Oddity in Municipal Finance Veterans in the field of municipal finance could not recall yesterday any incident similar to that which had just taken place in the sale of $5,000,000 of Boston Metropolitan District bonds to a syndicate headed by the Union Securities Corporation.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- The Russians reported today that Soviet forces were winning impressive victories in the southern and Leningrad sectors. However, the critical battles were being fought on the route to Russia's capital.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Coming from behind to break up a battle between two long shots, G.R. Watkins's Gondalina won by two and a half lengths in the Wake-field Purse, feature of today's program at Laurel. The 3-year-old daughter of Challenger II, claimed from W.L. Brann, was one of three well-played horses in a field of ten and the only one of these to show real speed.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Rebel bands of armed farmers and Chetniks led by the daughter of a Serbian attorney have stormed Sabac, a city of 13,000, only thirty-five miles from Belgrade, the capital of Yugoslavia, but have been smashed by Nazi troops supported by two companies of Croat Ustachas, it was announced today.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors last night opened its ninth season with a concert at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall in which it presented the Henry Hadley Trio in a program of four unpublished American works, all of which were performed publicly for the first time.

At the eighty-eighth annual meeting of the New York Clearing House Association, Herbert P. Howell, chairman of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, was elected yesterday president for the ensuing year, succeeding Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

Three of the major performers in the Broadway aggregation of "Arsenic and Old Lace" are wanted by Frank Capra to appear under Ms direction in the Warner Brothers film transcription of the hit show. Inasmuch as the sponsors and twenty-two investors share in the film's profits, the management has been prevailed upon to release Josephine Hull and Jean Adair for a period of eight weeks, starting Oct. 20.

Five months ago in Glasgow, Scotland, a private war between two Norwegian seamen was interrupted by an incident in a World War, Yesterday, in peaceful Brooklyn, their feud was terminated -- temporarily at least.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 7 -- Sounding a warning that "a giant war is setting the stage for complete destruction" of civilization, the National Catholic Rural Life Conference adopted a resolution at its convention here tonight declaring that "false philosophies, unduly glorifying the State, concentrating ownerships, herding people in cities, stripping them of ownership and independence, have caused the economic, social and spiritual breakdown of man."

Misfortune befell Vincent Reitano and the New York University football team yesterday. Reitano, who as a result of his fine work had just been rewarded with the left-end assignment, supplanting Alverne Clark, suffered a fracture in his ankle during the hard scrimmage through which Coach Mal Stevens sent the team.

The cooperative shipbuilding project through which thirty-six tankers were to be constructed to relieve the threatened oil shortage along the Atlantic seaboard growing out of the diversion of eighty tankers of United States registry to the British and Russians, has been abandoned, according to a letter sent yesterday to the companies involved by W.S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's central armies, supported by enormous quantities of tanks, ranging from tiny whippets to lumbering heavy models, and by untold numbers of planes, are trying to break thro ugh toward Moscow at two points.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 7 -- According to an "official communique" from National Yugoslav Army headquarters -- "somewhere in the Drina massif" -- broadcast over a clandestine transmitter early this afternoon and repeated by the Moscow radio in several foreign languages this evening, Yugoslav irregulars after a pitched battle of several days with Axis forces succeeded in recapturing the important communications center of Plevlje, about forty-six miles southwest of Usice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A bill to limit profits from production for the national defense program to 7 per cent of manufacturing cost was introduced in the House today by Representative Vinson of Georgia, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Marion Collins, a 3-year-old chestnut filly from Frank J. Kearns's stable, made it three in a row today when she outnosed Dawn Portage in the featured race at Rockingham Park.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 7 -- The Japanese military spokesman said today that the Japanese forces in Northern Hunan were now concentrating on defensive preparations between the Hsinhsiang and Milo Rivers, ready for any Chinese attack.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- As one of many tests of American sentiment toward the war, the American Institute of Public Opinion has asked voters throughout the country at various times in the Fast few months the question whether they think President Roosevelt is going too far or not far enough in aiding Britain.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- What they called British broadcast propaganda was held responsible in German quarters today for the collapse in negotiations for the exchange of German and British wounded prisoners of war.

One out of every three babies born In Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens received care at some time during its first six weeks of life by the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service last year, it was announced yesterday. A drive to raise $425,000 to continue this work and similar efforts involving community service was opened when 100 volunteers met at organization headquarters, 262 Madison Avenue.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- The German drive to encircle Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces in the central sector in Russia continued throughout yesterday. Reports from Moscow this morning said that at all points the Russians were holding.

Councilman Louis Cohen, Bronx Democrat, lashed back yesterday at criticism directed at him by Mayor La Guardia and Hospitals Commissioner Willard C. Rappleye, calling the Mayor a "guttersnipe" and Dr. Rappleye an "anti-Semite" for his policies toward Jewish doctors in city service.

The first of the season's fashion luncheons held in the Salon d'Elegance of the Ritz took place yesterday noon. It was a smart crowd that occupied every seat in the restaurant. There was an attendance of well over 300 guests.

Mayor La Guardia caught the Democratic majority in the City Council completely off guard yesterday when he delivered a sudden emergency message calling for reduction of the city sales and compensating use taxes by Nov. 1 to save the taxpayers an estimated $27,500,000 a year.
The text of the address by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretory of State, at the World Trade Dinner of the National Foreign Trade Convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, follows:

Top management and boards of directors are proving to be the greatest stumbling blocks in the efforts of many advertising managers to maintain their budgets at a period when companies are either oversold or production is being cut, advertising executives complained yesterday.

HONG KONG, Oct. 7 -- Dr. Henry F. Grady, President Roosevelt's personal economic representative, said on his arrival from Chungking today that he had been working closely with the British Ministry of Supply and the Export Control Board concerning the maintenance of the flow of materials to and from the Far East.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 7 -- The Turkish Government agreed today to deliver chromium to Germany in 1943, after the expiration of the present agreement with Great Britain. In exchange, Germany will immediately deliver war materials to Turkey.

A large reception with many city officials in attendance was held last night by the Women's City Club to mark the opening both of the new clubrooms at 55 West Forty-fourth Street and the 1941-42 season of club activities.

Before turning his undivided attention to preparing his Lions for Saturday's encounter with Princeton in the latter's Palmer Stadium, Coach Lou Little did some more backfield juggling yesterday at Baker Field. The latest change in Columbia's backfield corps involves the shifting of Ed Arden, a sophomore, from tailback to fullback.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Play in the annual twelve-goal Autumn Plates polo tournament got under way on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club today, with Bostwick Field turning back the Broad Hollow riders, 10 to 6.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- In the largest transaction of the kind since World War I, the Treasury Department will borrow about $1,300,000,000 in new money on Thursday, issuing long-term bonds to cover the gum, it was announced here today.

John R. Davies, principal isolationist candidate in the Mayoralty picture, withdrew from the race at 10:30 last night, before the midnight deadline for the filing of independent candidacies with the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Only a small part of the American aeronautical equipment reaching the British air force is being shipped under the Lease-Lend Act, but in the first seven months of this year $284,000,000 worth of planes, engines and other aeronautical equipment were shipped to Britain's air forces in various parts of the world by American producers, Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., said tonight.

Banks and other institutions in the Second Federal Reserve District that act as agents for the sale of defense savings bonds will receive today formal notification from the Federal Reserve Bank that, effective immediately, these agencies will no longer be required to put up collateral for supplies of Series E defense bonds to sell to their customers.

Although the United States has made appreciable progress in the effort to take up the slack in Latin-American exports occasioned by the loss of Europe as a market, foreign traders were warned yesterday that in our own selling to Latin America we must develop a flexible trade system.

In a little less than two years small savers in Great Britain have lent the Government $4,000,000,000 to help finance the war. This is roughly equal to $80 for every man, woman and child in the kingdom. An equivalent effort in this country would mean subscriptions of $10,400,000,000 to Defense Savings Bonds and Stamps in a like period.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On the principle that the streets of New York are no place for the transaction of business and should be reserved exclusively for vehicular traffic, the Department of Markets has struggled for the past seven and a half years to eliminate itinerant peddling.

Never Say Die The impossible does happen. History is all the time giving the lie to people who say it's all over but the shouting. It is not all over when the third man strikes out in the ninth inning.

High on a piece of ground at Kew Gardens, Queens, which it shares with the impressive new Queens Borough Hall, the much maligned MacMonnies statue of Civic Virtue, former unwanted tenant of City Hall Park, was welcomed yesterday afternoon as a permanent newcomer to the bailiwick of George U. Harvey.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- As a preliminary to the 36-hole championship of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association, which starts at the Westchester Country Club tomorrow, forty-four members competed in the misty rain on the club's south course today for the association's two-ball four-some title.

It is of vital importance that American youth seeking a liberal education hold themselves above racial and religious intolerance, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, told 625 freshmen yesterday at the second weekly orientation lecture of the year.

Describing himself as a "propagandist for democracy," Wendell L. Willkie told 1,500 men and women attending a dinner at the Commodore Hotel last night opening the 1941 campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, that they were engaging in "the greatest propaganda for democracy."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Judging from Harvard's first-team line-up today in an offensive scrimmage against the freshman team, no changes will be made in the Crimson's starting array for the Cornell game here next Saturday as a result of the setback by Penn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 6:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- In a disagreement with the New Rochelle League of Women Voters over her isolationist activities as a member of the America First Committee, Mrs. Richard F. Wood announced today her resignation as president and as a member of the league.

Sleepy Jim Crowley wanted to talk football, Jack Coffey wanted to talk baseball and Ed Kelleher was in no mood to quibble, though fie probably would have preferred basketball. With Crowley then was no compromising, so while Coffey retired to the privacy of his office, thinking of Yankees ant Dodgers, base hits and passed balls, Sleepy Jim turned the conversation to Fordham and North Carolina, punts and passes.

ON the score of that big new historical novel about the settlement of Australia -- "The Timeless Land,"* by Eleanor Dark -- I find that I have, much to my astonishment, practically nothing disagreeable to say.

The tangled affairs of the $61,000,000 International Utilities Corporation took on a new aspect yesterday when William F. Carey, chairman of the utility and Commissioner of Sanitation of New York, charged "double dealing" to an independent stockholders' committee which is attempting in a proxy fight to oust the present board of the company.

THE stranger was direct, to say the least. He produced a card with a name that was preceded by a Dr. and followed toy several capital letters. He was, he said, a "practical psychiatrist." It also developed he was considerable of a conversationalist.

In one of the most unusual transactions which have taken place in the field of municipal finance in several years, the Boston Metropolitan District, Mass., awarded yesterday a new issue of $5,000,000 of bonds to a syndicate headed by the Union Securities Corporation.
Revised. The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Wrecking crews and United States Army engineers were at work tonight endeavoring to restore the flow of defense-vital iron ore through the St. Mary's Falls Canal, whose main channels had been blocked since early morning by the collapse of a lift bridge, said to be one of the longest of the bascule type in the world.

President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill emphasized the importance of the future development of international trade as a foundation for a better world order, in messages read last night at the world trade dinner of the twenty-eighth National Foreign Trade Convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Six of the seventy members of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., who were fined by the association for alleged violations of a selling agreement in the marketing of a $38,000,000 issue of bonds of the Public Service Company of Indiana will have their cases reviewed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a type of action new to the agency, it was announced today.

TRENTON, Oct 7 -- After Roger Hinds, who is conducting an investigation of the State Highway Department for Governor Charles Edison, announced today that public hearings would be discontinued for a few weeks while a progress report was prepared, Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner appealed to the Governor for an opportunity to "state my case not behind sealed doors but before the public."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Release "at least temporarily" of ten to fifteen of the United States oil tankers now in British service was reported today by Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Defense Oil Coordinator, as a possibility in the near future.

A one-man show of work by George Grosz opened yesterday afternoon with a preview for members at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. It opens to the public today and will be current through Nov. 2. This is one of the museum's traveling exhibitions and has already been seen in Honolulu, Seattle, San Francisco, Kansas City, Des Moines and Iowa City.

Stocks were returned yesterday to the low levels of July under a brief but intense selling wave that caused a retreat of as much as 2 points and more in values. The reason for the sudden liquidation was not immediately visible to Wall Street, although the fall of the general list came hot on the heels of selling in the steels and motors.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 -- Impersonating Bert Stiff, Paxon Gifford and Gene Davis of the Pennsylvania eleven, Frank Jones, Buck Jordan and Monk Meyer of the fourth team tested the Yale varsity's defenses for an hour this afternoon.

The authorized biography of Justice Louis D. Brandeis, for whom funeral services were held yesterday in Washington, Is being completed by Professor Alpheus Thomas Mason of Princeton University. Professor Mason has been studying and writing about the late justice for many years and in recent months has been in constant personal touch with him in the preparation of his definitive life story.

A death-blow against pre-fight advice by a manager to his boxer was struck by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday when it handed out a six months' suspension to Ray Carlen, well-known around these parts as the pilot of Lou Nova.

The success of women in the business and professional world constitutes a challenge to men, especially during the national emergency, when many complex problems have arisen, Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation, declared yesterday before a thousand business women and sales executives of this vicinity.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Washington is considering plans for an inventory of consumer goods, similar to the survey of defense stocks now being made by the Office of Production Management, it was revealed here today by Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman of the retailers advisory committee to the Office of Price Administration, in an address at the closing session of the Boston Conference on Distribution.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Finnish rejection of the British note warning Finland that if she continued to invade purely Russian territory she would be regarded as an open enemy by Britain was received here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Roosevelt, it was learned today, has approved the creation of a new government agency, called the Office of Facts and Figures, to cooperate with the established government departments in presenting to the American people a more detailed and coherent picture of the Administration's defense and foreign policies.

The nine-story apartment house at 116 East Fifty-eighth Street, built on a plot 57 by 100 feet, has been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to an investing client of the Raymond P. Quinn Company, who paid cash above a ten-year first-mortgage of $171,000.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- German troops, carrying out a part of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's new operations to crush the Red Army before Winter, have occupied Mariupol on the Sea of Azov and are less than 110 miles from Rostov on the Don, an authorized German spokesman declared tonight.

HILLSDALE, Mich., Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Rival union groups fought with clubs, stones and concrete blocks at the gates of the Hillsdale Steel Products Company today. One man's skull was fractured and at least six others were treated for head wounds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- The grain markets showed a weak undertone today on scattered liquidation induced by heaviness in other con modities, a forecast for clear an cool weather and the introduction in the Senate by Senator Thorns of Oklahoma of a bill which, if passed, would reduce the parity price on corn 6 1/2 cents a bushel and on oats more than 11 cents.

New deficiencies in the government's case against the Aluminum Company of America, whose dissolution has been the object of four years of litigation by the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, were pointed out yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

The British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had launched a special movement to provide Christmas gifts for British children otherwise facing a cheerless holiday season. The organization has mailed to some 10,000 industrial and mercantile concerns in this city and other leading cities of the country copies of a letter and a folder describing a special "dollar gift" campaign.

Keen competition marked yesterday the bidding for $5,600,000 of first mortgage thirty-year bonds of the Gulf Power Company, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation. Nine investment banking groups submitted tenders for the issue, which was sold under the competitive bidding rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission as applied to public utility securities.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

Van Campen Heilner, well-known sportsman and author, has just returned from a salmon fishing and hunting trip at Anticosti Island, Canada, and from his reports it must be the kind of place sportsmen dream about. He took salmon in the early morning, shot ducks later and killed a nice buck late in the afternoon.

An overflow crowd of 900 advertising men and women was assured last night by Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general and regarded by many as the arch-enemy of advertising, that their fears of an attack by the Department of Justice on the theory and practice of advertising were entirely without foundation.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Stringent new anti-Jewish measures as well as measures against "certain Czech circles who have been ostentatiously friendly to the Jews" in the Bohemian Protectorate have been decreed by Reinhard Heydrich, deputy Gestapo leader and the new German Protector for Bohemia-Moravia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A major domestic airline expansion program was approved today by the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board when it granted permission to aircraft manufacturers to accept orders, in the eighteen months beginning Jan. 1, for 228 planes.

The number of wars that are being fought within and under cover of the great war multiplies every day. This does not refer simply to the revolts boiling up all over Europe or to the tremors to be observed in nearly every part of the globe if one follows closely the little items of news that occasionally find their way into print from places like Borneo, Afghanistan and Saudi Arabia.
VICHY, France, Oct. 7 -- The body of Mme. Marie Masse, secretary to Eugene Deloncle, has been found in the Seine. She was murdered.

Donal M. Sullivan of Boston, president of the American Newspaper Guild and a candidate for re-election on the United Guild Committee slate, led Milton M. Murray of Detroit, candidate of the Pro-Guild Committee, by 158 votes in the balloting conducted by the New York Newspaper Guild, according to announcement made last night by Thomas Black, chairman of the elections committee, The vote was: Sullivan, 1,213; Murray, 1,055.

A little more than a year ago long hospital trains loaded with burned and wounded German soldiers were rumbling eastward across Germany. The Battle for France was over and there was no fighting on any front except in the air over the English Channel and the British Isles.

CHICAGO, Oct 8 -- Prides o grains and soy beans were on the down-grade in the early trading on the Board of Trade today in sym pathy with cotton and on continued scattered liquidation. Wheat sold at a new low level since Sept. 20, corn since July 31 and soy beans since Sept. 3, before covering by shorts and buying by professionals was able to stem the tide.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 8 -- When Tom Marshall of Fairfield insisted there were plenty of coots between Penfield Reefs and Southport he was telling the truth, but he, said nothing about the wind that made the shooting today wet and difficult.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Hogs dropped today 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight to the lowest levels In three months. Traders said a slow demand for dressed pork, which has caused a large supply to collect la storage, was mainly responsible for the downturn. Hogs have been declining with only two or three minor interruptions lor nearly a month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -- RKO today signed William Hawks to produce three pictures in addition to his already planned John Steinbeck story, "The Red Pony." Terms of the new deal call for Howard Hawks, brother of the producer, to direct one of the three, while Ronald Colman will be starred in another.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- What is "the perfect dinner" ?

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The defending champion, Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill, got away to a onestroke lead today when she posted a card of 43, 42 -- 85 for the south course of the Westchester C.C. in the first round of the eighteenth annual women's senior United States golf championship.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- A walk-out of 8,100 employes of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company's sheet and tin mills in Gary, Ind., halted all operations during the day, putting 2,000 more workers out of jobs.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The police announced tonight the arrest of two members of a secret organization and the seizure of documents in their homes indicating' that they belonged to a totalitarian group. Pictures of Adolf Hitler were among the items seized, the police said.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct.8 -- For the third straight afternoon, Coach Tad Wieman of Princeton had his squad drill on defense against the vaunted Columbia air attack today, working the first and second elevens against Lion passing plays as run off by a third team.

Steel production in the third quarter of 1941 at 20,642,345 net tons was the largest for any three months on record, bringing output for the first nine months of the year to 61,550,888 net tons, a new high mark for the period, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today that Defense Plant Corporation, RFC subsidiary, at the request of the War Department, has authorized an increase of $2,500,000 in its lease agreement with the Singer Manufacturing Company, for additional equipment for plants at Elizabeth, N.J., and Bridgeport, Conn.

Mayor La Guardia went into full stride last night in his campaign for re-election. At the notification dinner of the City Fusion party at the Park Central Hotel he declared that the ignorance of Democratic City Councilmen In not accepting his proposal for the reduction of the city sales tax furnished additional proof of his repeated warning that the Kelly-Flynn-Sullivan Democratic machine could not be entrusted with the city government.
NEW YORK President Justice and Mrs. Petham St. George Bissell have left Wayside, their Summer place In Freeport, L.I., and are at 270 Park Avenue for the season.

Attacking the charge by Mayor La Guardia that the report by the City Council committee on Lincoln Hospital was a political move, Joseph A. Brust and Carl E. Schiffer, attorneys for the committee, issued a statement yesterday declaring that "the only political angle to the Lincoln Hospital report recently submitted to the Council has been injected by Mayor La Guardia himself and his Commissioner of Hospitals, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye."

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 9 -- In a nation-wide broadcast on the distribution of food under air raid conditions, Kazuo Miura, Vice Minister of Agriculture, announced last night that while the rice crop was short in Japan proper, both Korea and Formosa expected bumper crops.

George Sylvester Viereck, registered since October, 1939, as publicist for German interests, was arrested yesterday in his home at 305 Riverside Drive, on charges of withholding from the State Department material information concerning his propaganda activity.

Manoeuvres to perfect the defense of the north and central Atlantic seaboard against enemy air attacks will be started by the First Air Force at 6 A.M. today along hundreds of miles of coastline, with 40,000 civilian volunteer air raid spotters assisting the Army defenders.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8-- Helen Morgan, who skyrocketed to fame from a Chicago ribbon counter, died shortly before midnight tonight in Henrotin Hospital from a liver ailment that had been a recurring threat since her childhood. For two decades she had been a singer of stage, screen, radio and in night clubs. Her age was 41.

Plans for a food market In Yorkville were announced yesterday in connection with the sale by Edward M. and Mary E. Gridley of the three three-story tenements on a plot 51 by HO feet at 1474-8 Third Avenue, between Eighty-third and Eighty-fourth Streets.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- This typical manufacturing city of North America opened today a four-day series of community-sponsored meetings in quest of a better understanding of the twenty republics of Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Senator Nye, a vigorous opponent of the Administration's foreign policy, contended today that the decision to confine neutrality law legislation to the armed ship issue was a "confession of weakness" on the part of the President.

BUFFALO, Oct. 8 -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation of this city has reduced by more than 50 per cent the number of man-hours needed to turn out one of the speedy Airacobras, flying gun platforms of the United States Air Corps and the British Royal Air Force.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 -- The Pimlico Special appeared headed today for billing as a "Race of Champions" -- a sporting classic in which the glory outweighs the gold.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Charlie Root, for sixteen years a Chicago Cubs' pitcher and a popular figure in the city's baseball scene, was given his unconditional release by the Cubs today.

Life was complicated yesterday for the 1,000 tenants of the Beaux Arts apartment hotels at 307 and 310 East Forty-fourth Street. A strike of 120 maids, elevator operators and other service employes made it necessary for many of the guests to make their beds, dust their rooms and carry their packages.

On the third day of registration 350,323 citizens qualified to vote in the November election. This figure is 1,472 less than the number who qualified on the third day of registration in 1937, when the last municipal elections were held, and 207,911 less than the number qualifying on the third day last year for the Presidential election.

The one-story taxpayer property on the southwest corner of Central and Chatterton Avenues, White Plains, Westchester, has been sold by Joseph Backer to a private investor through Louis Carreau, Inc., and Herbert R. Rosen, co-brokers. Built in 1939, the structure is airconditioned and is occupied as a supermarket by the Grand Union Company.

The short interest in all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange was 486,912 shares on Sept. 30, against 470,002 shares a month earlier, according to a tabulation issued yesterday. Both totals exclude short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 48,588 shares at the end of September, 50,190 shares at the end of August.
Fordham held its last long football drill yesterday afternoon on Fordham Field in preparation for Saturday's tussle with North Carolina in Chapel Hill, the Rams' second test of the season.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Gradual stepping-up of quantities of food obtained from the United States, until they reach 25 per cent of the total of British supplies, was declared to be the British program under the Lease-Lend Act by Lord Woolton, Minister of Food, in the House of Lords today.

The residential leasing covered by yesterday's reports involved suites in a wide area of Manhattan. Rouses bordering on both the East and Hudson Rivers, on two sides of Central Park, and in Greenwich Village, drew a good many of the new tenancies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Frank B. Plympton, chairman of a group of holders of securities of the New Jersey New York Railroad Company, on Oct. 2 petitioned the Federal District Court and today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission for reorganization of the New Jersey New York Railroad Company under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act, as amended, and for the appointment of a trustee or trustees to operate the property.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- The House Naval Affairs Committee today recommended passage of a bill authorizing the acquisition of 400 light draft vessels to take the place of larger warships engaged in naval patrol and minesweeping operations so that the latter could be used for more important duties on the high seas.

Two descendants of a founder of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and the son of an early president of the organization will be present tonight at Carnegie Hall when the orchestra, conducted by Leopold Stokowski, gives the first concert of its hundredth anniversary season.
BERLIN, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The following special communique was issued today:

Trading was slow In the wholesale dressed meat markets yesterday. Fresh pork cuts were weak to lower. Other classes were practically cleaned up In the slaughter houses since there has been no slaughter since last Friday. The first kosher markets of the week opened steady on veal and calf and stronger on steer beef and lamb.

Cognac, coffee and dummy engine parts played important roles in a Norwegian freighter's escape from the Vichy-controlled African port of Dakar in July, Captain N.F. Lindtner, the ship's master, disclosed when he arrived here yesterday.
The Provident Institution for Savings sold to Lawrence H. Miller the two-family dwelling at 64 Warner Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., through the George J. Wolf Realty Company and the A.F. Roe Company.
MALINES, Belgium, Oct. 8 -- Jef Denyn, the most famous player of church chimes in the Low Countries, died here today at the age of 79. He fell in the street a few days ago and fractured his skull.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 9 -- The German capture of Orel, some 200 miles south of Moscow, and a semiofficial appeal from Russia for British help caused grave anxiety today over the turn of events on the Eastern Front.

Tonight in Carnegie Hall the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society inaugurates its one hundredth season. The imposing list of guest conductors who will be its leaders during this period is symbolic of the development of the orchestra and of the knowledge of symphonic music in this country.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 8 -- The theme of the annual assembly of the Catholic Rural Life Conference was expressed today by a soldier, Captain Clare E. Wolf, 168th Infantry, Thirty-fourth Division, Camp Claiborne, La., in an address on "Youth of the Future."

PLANDOME, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Taking a 42 on each half of the tricky and hilly Plandome Golf Club course, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Lakeville carded an 84 today to win the low gross prize in the Long Island Women's Golf Association's final regularly scheduled one-day handicap tourney of the current season.

In a message to President Roosevelt yesterday, the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., through its president, Joseph Curran, declared that failure of ship operators to meet union proposals had created a "serious situation." It added that as a result the union could not be held responsible for any "confusion or interference" with ship service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- New York's general and special-trade contractors and builders performed work valued at $675,167,000 in 1939 as compared with an estimated $1,084,806,000 in 1929, the Census Bureau noted today, a drop of $409,639,000.

The message of tie President to the convention of the American Federation of Labor, and the address before that convention of Secretary Perkins, together form significant evidence of a firming attitude by the Administration toward labor union abuses. The President called for an end of "organizational rivalries and jurisdictional conflicts."

WASHINGTON, Oct 8 -- With a statement that a turn in the wa was imminent and that "clouds of airplanes, acres of tanks and fa avalanche of munitions" must bi sent to the Allies, the House Appropriations Committee approvet today the $5,985,000,000 second lease-lend bill and warned Congress that additional funds would be needed soon.

Conflicting views of the won trade policy of the British Empire were expressed at an "American British Commonwealth Luncheon" that was a feature of the closing session of the National Foreign Trade Convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The War Department issued the following orders today, dated Oct. 7:

Mayor La Guardia was assured of the support of all major labor forces last night when the Greater New York Industrial Union Council of the C.I.O. voted to conduct "a positive, militant and extensive campaign" in his behalf.

Scores of children went home yesterday afternoon from the matinee performance of "It Happens on Ice," at the Center Theatre, Forty-ninth Street and Sixth Avenue, laughing happily over the antics of Sam Barton, trick bicycle rider, unaware that Sam Barton was dead.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 8 -- Planes of four British air services -- the Royal Air Force, the Fleet Air Arm, the South African Air Force and the Royal Australian Air Force-have in the past three days attacked Axis objectives throughout almost the entire Mediterranean area -- from Piraeus to Tripoli to Sicily.

Production of coke pig iron in September, according to an Iron Age survey, totaled 4,716,901 net tons, compared with 4,791,432 tons in August. Output on a daily basis last month showed a gain of 1 per cent over that in August, or from 154,562 tons to 157,230 tons.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's powerful elite group of Russian armies defending Moscow is locked in a series of German rings and faces "inexorable annihilation," and in the Ukraine Soviet resistance has collapsed, while Marshal Semyon Budenny's armies there are in a state of dissolution, according to claims made here tonight.

No conspiracy has existed between the Aluminum Company of America and any of its co-defendants in the government's anti-trust suit during the last twenty-five years, Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey ruled yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- As the National Football League race assumes a steadier tempo, Clarence (Pug) Manders of Brooklyn continues to set a hot pace in total yards gained in the competition for individual honors.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Kurt Nevermann, German Consul at Arica, on Chile's northern frontier, has rented a theatre to show the German war propaganda film, "Victory In the West," to the members of the Chilean Army garrison there, the newspaper Critica said today. Herr Nevermann, the newspaper said, has invited the entire garrison to a showing of the film.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will produce a new American opera, this season, "The Island God," a one-act drama about three modern exiles and a Greek God, with libretto and music by Gian-Carlo Menotti, 30-year-old Italian-American composer, whose one-act comic opera, "Amelia Goes to the Ball," given in March, 1938, was the last American work to be introduced by the association.
Two hundred members of the Manhattan Chess Club and their friends attended the official opening of the club's new headquarters at 100 Central Park South last night.

E. Laurence White, chairman o the independent stockholders' com mittee of the International Utilities Corporation, declared yesterday that William F. Carey, chairman of the corporation, had made "inaccurate and misleading" statement; in his criticism of the committee on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Shortly after the German Government, through its official news agency, D.N.B., had made public today the purported text of President Roosevelt's letter to Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin, introducing W. Averell Harriman, head of the American delegation to the tripartite Moscow conference, the White House issued the official text and invited comparison.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Mayor La Guardia says of the Administration's newest public information bureau: "Whatever anybody says, the Office of Facts and Figures is not a propaganda agency. * * * It is a sort of reservoir with a purification process. The people are entitled to the facts, and they are going to get them."

The Juilliard School of Music has awarded sixty-six fellowships for a year's study in its graduate school, it was announced yesterday by Dean Oscar Wagner. The winners received preliminary training at twenty-two schools and conservatories in twenty-three States, Brazil, Cuba and Canada.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 -- Four Mexicans wondered today whether the British Government would permit them to pass through Bermuda on a free trip to Madrid for a Latin-American meeting under the auspices of the Fascist Spanish regime. Mexico does not recognize the government of General Francisco Franco.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- The Soviet High Command announced tonight that the Red Army, after extremely fierce battles, had evacuated Orel, an important city in the heart of old Russia. Orel, on the main railway line to Kharkov, is more than 200 miles below Moscow.

Multiple Trading The New York Stock Exchange board will consider today the order of the Securities and Exchange Commission that it amend its constitution to remove its prohibition against multiple trading-the practice of members of the New York Stock Exchange of making markets in New York stocks on the floors of other Exchanges.

No shipments of United States currency came from Europe in September, marking the first month since May, 1923, that this has occurred, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday in its monthly report on exports and imports of currency and coin.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Japanese Army spokesmen said today that a great Chinese offensive along the middle Yangtze River had carried the fighting to Shasi, sixty miles downstream from the major port of Ichang, but the situation at Ichang, the main Chinese objective, remained obscure.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 (Reuter) -- According to an announcement in the official Rumanian Gazette, 1,735 Rumanian legionaries who are serving prison sentences for taking part in the Iron Guarad disturbances of last January have been granted amnesty, says a Bucharest dispatch.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Although Britain is nearing peak production, Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary, told the people of the United States in a broadcast to America tonight that only their mightiest effort would save them.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- September clothing sales made the best showing in many years; standardization without sales damage can be effected in only a part of the lines handled by the average clothing store, and considerable economy can be effected in the use of wrapping paper, the monthly questionnaire replies of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers indicated today.

Subtle seasonings -- the essence of good cookery -- are efficiently contained in the chocolate-colored bottles that stand in neat rows on the shelves of city groceries. Each trig little container holds the essence of a fresh vegetable; the savory pungent juices of celery, green pepper, parsley, onion or garlic.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Ignorance of Germany caused Great Britain to throw away tier sacrifices of 19141918, said Minister of Information Brendan Bracken, speaking today at a luncheon of the British Survey Organization in London at which United States Ambassador John G. Winant was present.

The true "warmongers" of the United States are those who sow the seeds of disunity within the nation and weaken its faith in democratic institutions, making it "ripe for invasion" from abroad, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd said last night in an address over a Columbia Broadcasting System network.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Minister of Labor Ernest Bevin outlined in the House of Commons today possible points of departure in effecting changes in Great Britain's mobilization of manpower, which is among the most touchy questions before the public at this time.
BERLIN, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A large merchant ship was heavily damaged in renewed German air assaults last night in the Suez area, the High Command said today.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- Milan Grol, Communications Minister in the Free Yugoslav Government, charged today that 180,000 Serbs and Jews had been massacred, imprisoned or tortured into insanity in Yugoslavia up to the end of August in an Axis-inspired pogrom.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Acting to halt the practices of some combed cotton yarn manufacturers who are charging maximum yarn prices at their mills and compelling customers to pay freight charges in addition, Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, yesterday asked buyers who have been compelled to absorb freight charges to report each transaction to OPA, naming the seller.

A plea for support of the sixty-third annual city-wide appeal of the United Hospital Fund, which opens on Tuesday, was issued yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign Committee, in behalf of the seventy-five member hospitals represented.

Difficulties of raw material procurement were set forth at three annual meetings of stockholders yesterday. A fourth company, Victor Chemical Works, won approval of a public offering of its shares at a special meeting of its stockholders.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Oct. 8 -- The Bourse continued depressed, with small offerings meeting little demand. Some losses ran to 17 points. Royal Dutch dropped 11 1/4 points to 303 1/4; Amsterdam Trading 11 1/2 to 466 1/2; Amsterdam Rubber 3 to 305 1/3; Phillips 9 to 259 1/4; Unilever 4 5/8 to 155 1/4, and A.K.U. 1 1/2 to 13711-16.

ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Demonstrations for Premier Mussolini in four northern cities where he gave the people the slogan "Hold Fast!" were cited by the Fascisti tonight as Italy's answer to American suggestions of war-weakened morale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- The Washington Times-Herald said tonight that Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell was relieved of command of the Forty-fourth Division, based at Fort Dix, N.J., which is participating in the First Army manoeuvres in North and South Carolina.

The New York State organization of the Daughters of the American Revolution opened its annual conference at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday with a warning from the State Regent, Mrs. Stanley Thorpe Manlove, that the society is facing a difficult period which demands faith, courage and sacrifice on the part of its members.

Many members of society thronged the Iridium Room of the St. Regis last night for a preview opening dinner and supper dance given in behalf of the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is acting president. The new ice revue on the Iridium Room rink was the principal entertainment feature.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 8 -- Reich Ambassador Franz Von Papen returned here today as the Turkish-German trade talks neared their conclusion. A final compromise is due, according to high foreign diplomatic sources, upon Germany's eleventh-hour demand for Turkish chromium.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8 -- The government must spend more money to train teachers if "educational security" and democracy is to be preserved, Dr. Arvie Eldred of Albany, executive secretary of the State Teachers Association, told the State Parent-Teacher Congress today.

The National Association of Hosiery manufacturers will soon make a survey to determine to what extent, If any, the women's hosiery industry has been benefited by the latest order of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, increasing the amount of rayon production available to hosiery manufacturers seeking substitutes for silk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, called on the machine-tool industry today to work its critical tools seven days a week because of the increasing scope of the national defense program.

Dr. Albert A. Berg of 10 East Seventy-third Street, surgeon, book collector and benefactor of the New York Public Library, was elected a life member of the library's board of trustees yesterday at its October meeting in the library, it was announced by Frank L. Polk, president of the board.

LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Alvin Untermyer's Kellsboro was skillfully piloted to victory today before a crowd of 5,000 in the Rolling Rock Hunt Cup race, feature of the annual Fall steeple-chasing meet of the Rolling Rock Hunt Racing Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Labor Division of the Office of Production Management, headed by Sidney Hillman, was under fire today from several sources.

Plans are under way for shipment of foodstuffs and medicines from Turkey to Greece, Dean Alfange, a director of the Greek War Relief Association, disclosed yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel St. Moritz for two American women recently returned from Greece.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- While the German armies have started on their formidable new thrust eastward the Reich civilian administration is beginning to function in the territories handed over to it by the German High Command. The incorporation of Eastern Galicia into the Gouvernement General of Poland and the appointment of Reich commissioners for the "Ostland" were the first steps in this direction.

With Frank Kiesecker back in his fullback berth, recovered from injuries, Manhattan's football team sped through its last heavy drill yesterday for tomorrow night's game at the Polo Grounds with Duquesne. The return of the signal-calling line-bucker means that Coach Herb Kopf will start his strongest backfield against the highly rated Dukes.

JEROME WEIDMAN'S new novel, 'I'll Never Go There Any More,"* is fast, fresh, nasty, amusing, consistently clever and as moral and meaningful as a burlesque show. It runs like an express train for 422 pages and gets practically nowhere in the process. It is his third novel, his widest ranging and his latest contribution to the history of heels.

If peas and carrots are as masterfully treated by the Army's new cooks as were the ingredients that went into cakes for the Fort Jay Fort Dix cake-baking contest held yesterday, trainees will soon be checking another complaint from their lists.

TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- Japan should utilize the neutrality pact with Russia as a diplomatic lever to end the Russian - German war and thereby open the way for "the Waterloo of the British-American camp and eradication of its machinations in East Asia," according to Yoshitaro Shimizu, political commentator of Hochi.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 8 -- Serious disorders have broken out in Belgrade and Smederovo during the last twenty-four hours, according to a bulletin on the Moscow radio at 11 o'clock this evening, which said that the government of General Milan Neditch had been forced to leave the city "for the north" as popular demonstrations made it increasingly apparent that the people were going to attempt to storm his headquarters.

Details concerning the 1929 merger of the Victor Talking Machine Company with the Radio Corporation of America were presented yesterday by Colonel Manton Davis, vice president and general counsel, of RCA on the third day of hearings before Special Supreme Court Referee Abraham J. Halprin on the fairness of the $1,000,000 offer made by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in settlement of an accounting suit by RCA stockholders.

The government's estimate of this year's cotton crop, which was about 500,000 bales larger than the trade had expected, forced the cotton market yesterday to sharply lower levels. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the low marks for the day with net losses of 29 to 35 points, or $1.45 to $1.75 a bale.
Mayor La Guardia watched for one minute yesterday the nimble fingers of the world's champion typist, Miss Margaret Hamma of Brooklyn, tap out 165 words in his office at City Hall.
