R.H. Moulton Co. of Los Angeles received yesterday the award of an Issue of $2,247,468 of State of California general fund registered warrants at one-half of 1 per cent, plus a premium of $1,535. The obligations, dated Oct. 1, 1941, will become payable on or about Feb. 25, 1942.

Renewed demands by the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C.I.O., for exclusive collective bargaining rights in the Department of Welfare have been rejected by Commissioner William Hodson, he disclosed last night.

Awards made during September for engineering construction work reached a total of $514,251,000 and exceeded the volume for the corresponding month of 1940 by 40 per cent, according to The Engineering News-Record. This is the fourth consecutive month in which contracts awarded for this type of work passed the half-billion-dollar mark and marks a new September record.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East communique said today:

That Mayor La Guardia and Controller McGoldrick now find it possible to recommend a reduction in the sales tax by one-half is a matter for general satisfaction. In the first three months of this fiscal year the tax brought In over $21,000,000, an increase of better than $4,000,000 above the returns in the corresponding quarter of the last fiscal year.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We, the undersigned members of the faculty of Brooklyn College, wish to protest publicly and emphatically against the letter which you published on Sept 25 from the American Committee for Democracy and Intellectual Freedom.

Governor Lehman, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs. Anna D. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, will be among the speakers at a two-day training institute in Albany on Oct. 16 and 17 for new leaders of the women's corps of local civilian defense councils throughout the State.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 8 -- Scores more have been killed in new mountain battles between Serbian insurgent bands and German Army punitive expeditions equipped with flame throwers, dispatches from Belgrade reported tonight.

The official British historical publication, "Bomber Command," which formed the basis for news stories from London that appeared in Tuesday's papers, will be published in this country as soon as possible by Doubleday, Doran, who published the earlier Air Ministry record, "The Battle of Britain."

DETROIT, Oct. 8 -- Mrs. Roosevelt, in a radio speech from Washington opening the National Council of Campfire Girls, urged girls throughout the country to enlist for national defense and to make a point of learning how to prepare nourishing and small-cost breakfasts, luncheons and dinners for their families.

The Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, of which Thomas D. Thacher is chairman and Charles C. Burlingham and Samuel Seabury vice chairmen, announced yesterday its complete ticket for the City Council, endorsing six candidates in both Manhattan and Brooklyn, three each in the Bronx and Queens and one in Richmond.

Ramases, another or the Pharamond II breed that has done so well for Hal Price Headley, won yesterday at Jamaica for J.J. McIntyre and Lou Schaefer. The 4-year-old carried Mr. McIntyre's green and white silks, but he was sent to the post by Trainer Schaefer, best remembered as the man who brought Challedon to eminence.

By a 4-2 vote, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday reconsidered its action of two weeks ago, when it reinstated William P. Sullivan, a high school teacher charged with attending classes in a drunken condition. The teacher was once again suspended and the case will be placed before the full board acting as a committee of the whole.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

Stringing along with experience despite the presence of so many talented newcomers on his squad, Coach Steve Owen of the football Giants yesterday revealed his intention of starting a veteran backfield combination when the Eastern Division leaders face the Philadelphia Eagles in their National League home opener at the Polo Grounds Sunday.
Dr. Marvin. A. Stevens believes that bis luck is about to change. Any such turn would have to be for the better because his luck hardly could get worse.
The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened its fourth season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, with everybody all dressed up on both sides of the footlights and apparently in fine fettle.

Increasing shortages of retail store supplies are developing, with the situation in paper and paperboard items threatening to become "exceedingly acute" in the near future, according to a special survey issued yesterday by the store management group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Oct. 9 -- After thirty-six hours of the heaviest fighting on the Eastern Front thus far, during which both sides threw in men and material in unlimited quantities, Russian forces evacuated the important communications center of Orel, the Russians acknowledged in a communique last night.

In his address to Columbia College freshmen Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler brought the definition of a liberal education down to date. For Columbia it includes certain "orientation courses" in contemporary civilization, modern science and the liberal arts. But these involve an educational method which would be valueless if it did not lead to certain results.

Formation of a Public Health Committee for the election of William O'Dwyer for Mayor was announced yesterday by the Democratic campaign headquarters in the Chanin Building. The move was regarded of significance because the chairman of the committee, Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson, who resigned from the city Health Department last year "in protest against the violations and disregard of the interest of public health by the Health Department under the La Guardia administration."

George E. Browne and William Bioff, whose positions as leaders of the huge International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes make them two of the most powerful figures in the motion-picture industry, were accused yesterday of having treated the union solely as a weapon for extracting money from the film companies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A cotton crop this year well in excess of prospective domestic requirements for the cotton season was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture in a report stating that improved weather conditions in September had enlarged prospects by 351,000 bales.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 30 (By Air Mail) -- October 10, the "double-ten" anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic, now just thirty years old, is a day when all China remembers Dr. Sun Tat-sen and the "Principles and Policies" he laid down as a guide for the future development of his country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Contracts totaling $213,417,389 were announced today by the War Department. Those awarded in the New York area were:

To meet increasing competition from other media, newspapers were urged yesterday by George Benneyan, research, and promotion manager of the Bureau of Advertising, to resell the public the idea that the newspaper is the basic news medium and to resell dealers and retailers on the value to them of manufacturers' advertising in newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Discontinuance, as separate agencies, of both the National Youth Administration, and the Civilian Conservation Corps on completion of their present emergency assignments of training workers for national defense, was recommended in a statement issued today by the Educational Policies Commission, policy-making body of the National Education Association and the American Association of School Administrators.

The commission to study the bases of a just and durable peace of the Federal Council of Churches issued a statement entitled "Long Range Peace Objectives" yesterday to assist local church groups that are studying the problem. The paper was written by John Foster Dulles, a Presbyterian layman and chairman of the commission. It is available to church groups in j booklet form.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The Chicago Stock Exchange and fourteen other regional securities markets appealed today directly to Congress to preserve them from extinction.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 8 -- It is persistently rumored in Stockholm diplomatic circles that the Germans are about to take over the positions now held by the Finns on the old Soviet frontier on the Karelian Isthmus and on the Svir River, between Lake Onega and Lake Ladoga, to help from that direction the German offensive against Leningrad.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 8 -- Alarm felt by Mrs. Carl Nye, mother of four children, over Impending milk price rises started today a movement to organize housewives in a united front against the increase.

NOW that the huddle around the loudspeakers has broken up and all is calm save for that mournful wail along the Gowanus, it becomes pertinent to recognize, with an apologetic nod in the direction of Flatbush, that the season of madness is with us.

ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Italian High Command announced today that Italian infantry had repulsed British attempts to approach their positions on the Tobruk front in North Africa, and told of new aerial assaults upon the British Mediterranean base of Malta.

A curtailment of advertisable exports to Latin-American countries will seriously affect their advertising media, which depend on American advertising for more than a third of their revenue, Walter L. Bomer, of the Bristol-Myers Company, warned yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association, held in conjunction with the National Foreign Trade convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Atlantic, Gulf West Indies Steamship Lines and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the eight months ended on Aug. 31 last net profit of $1,952,729 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before excess profits taxes.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- German occupation authorities were reported today to have executed forty-six more alleged saboteurs and terrorists in Bohemia-Moravia and Serbia, principal trouble centers in the Balkans. Fourteen were hanged in Prague and Bruenn for industrial sabotage, the D.N.B., German news agency, reported from Prague.

Keyes Fibre Company An issue of $1,400,000 of first (closed) mortgage 4% per cent bonds of the Keyes Fibre Company will be offered today to the public by Coffin Burr, Inc. The bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1956, will be priced at 99% and accrued interest, to yield about 4.55 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Members of the House were told today that "confidential agreements" have been made with four "small countries" for "payments of some character" for lease-lend aid extended them but that no agreements have been concluded yet with Great Britain, the principal beneficiary.

The Germans claim they are 125 miles from Moscow in a battle the Russians describe as the mightiest of the war. In a campaign that cannot be reported except in superlatives, this suggests that the scale of the present action surpasses all that has gone before. It suggests that the two armies still have millions of men and vast reserves of machines to throw into the field.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan acknowledged yestrday that he had dismissed three corporation inspectors from his staff, but denied the charge of Abraham Bernstein, one of those dropped, that he had been dismissed for refusing to obtain signatures to Mr. Isaacs's petitions as a candidate for the City Council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Secretary Knox declared here tonight that "actual invasion" of the Near East and the British Isles by Germany's armed forces is not a possibility but a certainty the moment the Nazi iron octopus can ready itself for the assault.

SEATTLE, Oct. 8 -- A behind-the-scenes move to seek the ouster of Thurman Arnold as head of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice was under way today at the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor.

Crown Princess Martha of Norway was guest of honor at a tcstimonial luncheon yesterday in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, where 1,000 women of Scandinavian origin or descent and their friends were assembled under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Help Norway Sons of Norway.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Running back to her good effort in the Capital Handicap here on opening day, Mrs. C.E. Nelson's Sassy Lady led every jump of the way in the Wye Mill Handicap today. The 5-year-old daughter of Flying Heels, handled by Jockey J. Deering, drove to the finish line two and a half lengths ahead of Dan Macvean's Skin Deep.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Inability to obtain adequate deliveries of steel is interfering with the vital naval building program. Major work on two destroyers at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, for instance, has been held up for two months through lack of steel and, for the same reason, it has been impossible to start work there on one of the new super-battleships.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- An unidentified manufacturer is scheduled to appear before the Priorities Division of the Office of Production Management tomorrow to answer charges that he obtained "a considerable quantity" of aluminum through preference ratings for defense use and then used the alummum to fill non-defense orders.

C.E. Groesbeck, chairman of the board of the Electric Bond and Share Company, declared yesterday that the management of the $3,000,000,000 utility system is giving "serious consideration" to the possibility of petitioning regularatory commissions for higher rates to offset the mounting burden of higher taxes and increased operating costs.

A schedule of twenty-one championship and invitation tournament dates for 1940-41 was announced last night at the annual preseason dinner of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the University Club. More than 100 members attended the affair, a prelude to the launching of the organization's eighteenth season of competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Roosevelt will ask Congress in a special message tomorrow to repeal or revise the Neutrality Act so that American ships, under the protection of their own guns, may increase the flow of material aid to nations resisting Axis aggression.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Use of wire-tapping and wire-tapping evidence should be available to the Department of Justice in coping with spies, saboteurs and kidnappers, Attorney General Biddle said today in Ms first press conference since assuming office.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Globe the newcomer will be Warners' "Law of the Tropics," an adventure story featuring Constance Bennett and Jeffrey Lynn. Regis Toomey, Mona Maris and Hobart Bosworth head the supporting cast. . . . At the Palace Universal's "Moonlight in Hawaii" will be the new tenant Johnny Downs, Leon Errol, Jane Frazee and Mischa Auer are featured in the comedy with music.

First '42 Refrigerators Due First of the 1942 refrigerator lines will be that of Stewart-Warner Company, scheduled to be introduced next Wednesday. This showing is not indicative of earlier introductions by other makers, because Stewart-Warner was first last year also, bringing out its new line about the same date.
"Name, please? . . . Address? . . . Age? . . . Where born?"

BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 8 -- When securities are listed on Exchanges, investors are provided with additional safeguards, George P. Rea, president of the New York Curb Exchange, declared today before the National Association of Securities Commissioners, in convention here.

The reorganization managers of the Erie Railroad announced yesterday that they would apply to the courts for permission to pay a dividend of $5 on the preferred stock to be issued by the reorganized company. Reports that a preferred dividend would be prepared began to circulate when the company recently sold some bonds.

An unidentified "wealthy widow" with homes in both the United States and Cuba stood ready to finance German espionage activities in this country as recently as last May, according to testimony yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Government agencies are up in arms over an order issued by the Office of Production Management barring from government contracts a company which had refused to abide by the recommendations of the National Defense Mediation Board.

The stock market had a difficull time yesterday attempting to chart a course, and while the list righted itself somewhat from the break of Tuesday, irregularity marked the session, with price fluctuations narrow as activity declined. Whereas observers floundered around trying to place the blame for the sell-off during the previous day, the causes of the hesitancy yesterday were laid very definitely at the doorsteps of Washington and the Soviet-Nazi battleline.

John Santo, former International secretary-treasurer of the Transport Workers Union of America, C. I. O. affiliate, was free last night on bail totaling $4,000 after being arrested by Federal agencies on charges of illegal entry into the United States and making a false claim to American citizenship.

"Viva O'Brien!" Which Is Identified as an "aquamusical," opens tonight at the Majestic. In addition to the songs and dances of the traditional musical, there is a swimming pool on stage and during the evening's proceedings a gentleman "parachutes" to the stage.

Replete with the color of the once Wild West, and unofficially adorned with Sonja Henie, Mrs. Will Rogers and Sally Rand, the sixteenth annual World's Championship Rodeo opened before nearly 15,000 persons in Madison Square Garden last night.

The recovery of a patient suffering from a heretofore fatal infectious disease of the heart by the use of the latest newcomer to the family of the sulfanilamide drugs, known as sulfadiazine, was reported last night before the Tuberculosis Sanatorium Conference of Metropolitan New York by Dr. Norman Plummer, assistant professor of clinical medicine at Cornell University Medical College.

Until the President has actually sent his message to Congress today, it is well to suspend judgment on the decisions which are reported to have been reached in the White House conferences. There can be no doubt, however, that of the two questions considered in these conferences -- the proposal to arm American merchant ships and the proposal to authorize these ships to carry war supplies to Britain -the second is far more important.

TRENTON, Oct. 8 -- Three justices of the State Supreme Court, with definite opinions on the mission of pinball machines in American civilization, refused today to let the little bells toll and the multicolored lights flash for them.

The First Boston Corporation and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $13,250,000 of Union Pacific Railroad Company one-to-ten-year 1 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates. They received the award on an interest cost basis of 1.505 per cent.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Last Tuesday morning in an article on this page I wrote: "The SEC's mandate of competitive bidding for utility securities operated in exact reverse of its objective when three large insurance companies were able to obtain the whole of a prime A.T. T. issue of $90 millions in 2% per cent debentures."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
The second session of the auction sale of property of the late Max D. Steuer, the lawyer, drew $18,000 yesterday at the Crown Art Galleries, 126 West Twenty-second Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Rebelling against the isolationist activities of Mrs. Shelby Cullom Davis of Scarborough-on-Hudson as a member of the America First Committee, the Westchester County League of Women Voters announced today that her reappointment as chairman of the league's committee on government and foreign policy had been denied.

Of thirty-three chain-store and mail-order companies which announced sales for September and nine months, Bond Stores, Inc., reported the largest percentage gain for these periods over the corresponding totals a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct 9 -- From the comment in Congress on the President's message today it appears that:

BENDIX, N.J., Oct. 9 -- F. Leroy Hill, president of Air Associates, said tonight that the Federal Mediation Board's recommendation that the strikers be reinstated was an "impossible demand," although the company was willing to put the strikers on a preferential list and rehire them as vacancies occurred.

A suite of eleven rooms and five baths in the building at 1172 Park Avenue has been leased to Dr. David D. Moore by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., through whom quarters also were taken by Frederic E. Sturmer, in 25 East Eighty-third Street, by Philip Kaminer in 227 East Fifty-seventh Street and by Herbert L. Rowland in 155 East Forty-ninth Street.

HAZLETON, Pa., Oct. 9 -- The charter of District 7 of the United Mine Workers of America was revoked and all except one member of the district staff removed from office today by John L. Lewis, union president, as the result of a recent twenty-seven-day stoppage of work by 20,000 miners protesting increases in dues and assessments, and their officers' administration.
WILLIAM HENRY WELCH bought a conspicuously unwashed persimmon from a street vender in a Chinese town and immediately began to eat it.

Liquidation of cotton futures on the basis of adverse war news from Russia forced cotton futures lower yesterday for the fourth consecutive session. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange, after declining as much as 28 points in the early afternoon, recovered partly to close with net losses of 4 to 10 points.

Encouraged by last week's gross of $15,000 for "The Student Prince" in Boston, the Shuberts are resuscitating other well-known musicals of a bygone day for the road. Next Thursday "Rio Rita" will follow "The Student Prince" into Boston's Opera House with a cast including Jack Sheehan, Doris Patston, Nancy McCord, Melissa Mason, Hope Emerson, Jack Good, Elaine Lambert and Alexander Gray.

After long and painstaking editorial work the final volume by Thomas Wolfe is ready. It will be published on Tuesday by Harper's as "The Hills Beyond." When Wolfe died three years ago last month at the age of 37 he left more than a million unpublished words.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Officials of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee (C.I.O.) issued this ultimatum today to the steel workers of Gary: "Join the S.W.O.C. or lose your jobs." The ultimatum, announced by Frank Grider, subdistrict director, followed another of the disturbances which have become a daily occurrence at the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's Gary plants, the steel works division and the sheet and tin mill division.

TOKYO, Oct. 9 -- The Japanese news agency Domei declared today on the authority of "economic and political observers here" that Japan was now indifferent to the oil embargo said to have been imposed on her by an agreement between the United States, Britain and the Netherlands Indies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- General Robert E. Wood, national chairman of the America First Committee, contended tonight that President Roosevelt had asked Congress "to issue an engraved drowning license to American seamen."

Four hundred Army planes, flying in formidable squadrons of big bombers and swift fighters, cruised and criss-crossed through the skies over 80,000 square miles in the North and Middle Atlantic States yesterday and last night while 40,000 civilian volunteers, beginning a week-long vigil as part of the greatest air defense exercise ever conducted here by the Army, reported every movement to the Army's new First Interceptor Command.

Some of the specific proposals put forward by Administration sources for changes in the Social Security Act have not been reassuring. The Prpsident, for example, now speaks about working out a method by which greater Federal aid will be extended to poorer States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- In a sweeping move to strengthen defense production, the Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board prohibited today the start of any more non-essential public or private construction projects requiring "appreciable quantities of critical materials."

MONTREAL, Oct. 9 -- The first of Canada's fleet of 10,000-ton cargo ships, of which twenty-four keels are already laid, to help carry the tools of victory to Britain, was launched here today and named the Fort Ville Marie by Mrs. C.D. Howe, wife of the Minister of Munitions and Supply.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 9 -- A full German motorized division attacked the large village of Sabac, a Serbian Chetnik army stronghold ninety miles west of Belgrade, and in a thirty-six-hour assault with heavy artillery, dive-bombers and tanks, completely destroyed the Serbian settlement, according to short-wave radio reports to foreign military intelligence sources here tonight.

Judging from his emphasis on protection against running and passing this week, Coach Mal Stevens is confident the Violet defense will take care of the Texas Aggies when they meet tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium and that the offense will take care of itself.

In a reply to statements made Wednesday in a message to President Roosevelt by the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., in which ship owners were charged with creating a "serious situation" by failing to meet union proposals, the American Merchant Marine Institute said yesterday that the union had delayed negotiations for a new contract.

The new excise taxes on various types of goods have put an additional burden on the already harassed premium field, advertisers reported here yesterday. Many of the popular premiums are in fields affected by the new taxes and, even though such goods are given away by retailers, a retail excise tax must be paid on them.

Members of the law committees of the Democratic county organizations inspected yesterday the nominating petitions of William J. Goodwin, anti-war Mayoralty candidate of the American Rock party, with a view to protesting their validity.

Dimitrl Matvienko has purchased from the Board of Estimate of the City of New York the four-story tenement at 2487-9 Belmont Avenue, the Bronx, in a transaction negotiated by the Richard C. Califano Company, brokers. The house contains accomodation for sixteen families and is valued for taxation at $26,500.

A serious shortage of one of their important materials, waste paper, faces the paper manufacturing industry, as a result of the "sit-down" strike on which collectors and accumulators have entered since ceiling prices became effective on Oct. 1, reports here yesterday indicated.

The national debt exceeds $51,000,000,000; the deficit this year will be above $12,000,000,000; the Treasury will have to borrow seven or eight billions more in the remainder of the fiscal year; the Federal Reserve System has just taken steps to wipe out more than $1,000,000,000 of excess bank reserves.

Many widely known members of society have already subscribed to the Twilight Concert in behalf of the Madison Square Boys Club which will be given on Tuesday at the Ritz Tower. Persons active in the arrangements for the benefit met yesterday with Mrs. Ansel Phelps, chairman of the committee of patrons and patronesses, at a meeting and luncheon at the Ritz Tower to discuss further plans for the event.
Lou Little stood close to a group of his men working out at Baker Field yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's game with Princeton in Palmer Stadium.

There was sparkle from begining to end of Macy's fashion presentation yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel. First off, it sparkled with news: Present were the new skirts that are up in the front and down in the back, dark stockings, dangling jet and the fur linings that are in the smartest of new coats.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Bank of England note circulation continued on its skyrocketing course in the week ended on Oct. 8, increasing u5,545,000 to the new high record of u683,319,000.

Stressing health as an important item in the total national defense picture, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, initiated yesterday School Health Day for the 1,100,000 boys and girls in the New York City school system. All academic work was suspended for one hour to permit the teachers to take stock and compile medical reports.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 9 -- The sixteen-goal division of the Meadow Brook Club's Autumn Plates tournament ended in almost total darkness tonight when Walter Hayden poked through Mike Phipps's pass to give Gulf Stream victory over Delhi, 8 to 7.

SEATTLE, Oct. 9 -- A major responsibility for inflation, with rising cost of living wiping out wage increases, was put squarely up to the American worker today, and a remedy suggested, by Herbert E. Gaston, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, in an address before the American Federation of Labor convention.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 8 (AP) -- "Organized Housewives," an association of women dedicated to fight any rise in the price of milk, grew in number today as the surprised founders reported support which included that of a Syracuse University Zoology professor, Reginald D. Manwell; a mother of five, including triplets, who enlisted as a volunteer canvasser, and many Home Bureau members who telephoned to urge cooperation.

Initiating a series of weekly luncheons and fashion shows to be held on Thursdays throughout the Autumn and Winter in the Sert Room of the Waldort-Astoria, the first of these fetes took place there yesterday, with the Opportunity Shop as the beneficiary.

When William Bioff went to Hollywood from his old home in Chicago he was looking for $2,000,000, and he had no patience with anybody who told him he couldn't have it the first time he asked for it, according to statements by Nicholas M. Schenck in Federal court yesterday.

The 1,275 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $56,386,500,477 par value as of Sept. 30, had a total market value of $53,418,055,935, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Aug. 31, there were 1,272 issues, aggregating $56,100,967,080 par value, which had a total market value of $53,216,867,646.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9 -- "Lord Timothy Dexter," a novel by John P. Marquand published in 1925, was purchased today by RKO as a vehicle for Charles Laughton. The story deals with the adventures of a British nobleman in the United States.

No team in the National Football League has scored more points this season than the Giants, an unusual state of affairs for a club whose past habits were ultra-conservative and defense-minded. Yet this new, fast and flashy Giant offense has seen such part-time service that not a quarter of the plays in the New York bag of tricks has been used.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, today called upon life insurance companies to fight against "forces of inflation that are threatening to engulf the country."

CAMDEN, S.C., Oct. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the First Army, in this area for war games, said today that Major Gen. Powell was relieved of command at the request of the commanding general of the Second Army Corps, Major Gen. Lloyd R. Fredendall.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- Formulation of plans for the evacuation of more than 1,500,000 school children and aged and infirm persons from New York City's metropolitan area to the safer regions of the upper Hudson Valley, in the event that enemy aircraft bombed the metropolis, was started this afternoon by Governor Lehman and representatives of Federal, State and local defense agencies.
The new 5 per cent Federal excise tax on transportation -- rail, motor, air and water -- goes into effect today but skips lightly over New York City's most ubiquitous train rider, the commuter.

Stacy May, chief of the Bureau of Research and Statistics of the Office of Production Management, asserted last night in an address broadcast from station WQXR that the United States had failed to produce its share of arms for the defense of the democracies.

The city of Philadelphia awarded yesterday to a large banking syndicate headed jointly by Drexel Co. and Lehman Brothers $14,100,000 of refunding and water bonds at a net interest cost of 1.6535 per cent, a low record. The successful bid was 100.215 for $3,384,000 of the bonds due Jan. 1, 1943 to 1948, as 4s, and $10,716,000, due Jan. 1, 1949 to 1967, as 1 1/2s.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (UP) -- A report published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association by C.P. Yaglou and Anne Messer of Boston said that differences of comfort standards between men and women . . . largely due to differences in dress can only be reconciled by adjustment of clothing according to susceptibility to cold or heat.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Dana Osgood have come to the St. Regis from their Summer home in Narragansett, R.I.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- After some uneasiness in the early trading, hogs managed to close fairly steady today. The top price, however, was $11.15 a hundred pounds, against $11.20 yesterday. Packers continued bearish, and livestock men said difficulty was being encountered in moving pork products. Dressed prices remained firm, with light pork loins unchanged at 23 1/2 to 24 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The renewed agitation in Japan, which stresses in grave terms what is pictured as a serious turn in Far Eastern affairs with intimations that there is imminent danger of a spread of the world war to that area through the involvement of the United States and Great Britain, has failed to shake officials here.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed gold holdings and Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The American program of aid to Russia is proceeding undiminished, notwithstanding the great German drive to liquidate the remaining effective Soviet armies. This was said today by officials who emphasized that the view was maintained here that Russia was going to win eventually.

Declaring that the protection of liberty was as much a woman's job as man's, Mrs. William H. Pouch, president-general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, called yesterday upon American women to devote themselves to national defense, like the "heroic women of Britain and China."

SYRACUSE, Oct. 9 -- Parents and teachers must bridge the gap between the school and the community, Dean William E. Mosher of the Graduate School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University told 800 delegates to the annual convention of the State Congress of Parents and Teachers today.

Reviewing the history of strikes from 1937 to 1941 in the current issue of Collier's, President Roosevelt declares that events have justified "the validity of the calm, sensible, peaceful approach to the settlement of strikes" as followed under his Administration.

Builders in the New York district, already forced to curtail operations because of difficulty in getting deliveries on some basic materials, expressed themselves as being: "dismayed" at the latest and most sweeping ruling of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board.

The lowest bid on a contract for 300 defense houses in Michigan came from the Currier Lumber Company of Detroit. The next lowest bid, in fact, was 44 per cent higher. Nevertheless, though the Department of Justice advised John Carmody, the Federal Works Administrator, that there was no legal basis on which he could reject the Currier bid, Mr. Carmody did withhold the contract.

Franz Joseph Stigler's connection with an alleged German espionage ring was outlined in detail yesterday in a statement he made to agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation after his arrest last June. The statement was read into the record at the Brooklyn espionage trial by Assistant United States Attorney T. Vincent Quinn.

Asserting that Mayor La Guardia in his Wednesday night speech to right-wing Laborites had accused him of trying to split the American Labor party by raising the issue of communism, District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, declared that it was not he but the Mayor who split that party.

BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 9 -- Because investment bankers prefer to "bet on sure things" and accordingly concentrate on high-grade bonds, they "are getting farther and farther away from another source of business, the sale of securities and especially equity securities, to the individual investor," Edmund Burke Jr., member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told the National Association of Securities Commissioners here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Augustus F. Lindbergh, half cousin of the flier, and Herbert Agar, editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal, were applauded today by the Continental Congress for Freedom when the first advocated repeal of the neutrality act and the latter, "war -- preferably tomorrow."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on revision of the Neutrality Law follows:

Many dinner and supper parties were given last night at the formal opening for this season of the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. In the dinner party of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Pratt were Mr. and Mrs. Hunt T. Dickinson, Mr. and Mra. Fremont C. Peck, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Hughes, Mrs. Boylston A. Tompkins and Ian Macdonald.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique tonight:

PANAMA, Oct. 9. -- Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia, former Minister of Government and Justice, became President of Panama today by election of the Cabinet as a result of the departure of President Arnulfo Arias to Havana. This quiet and complete overthrow of the government was not only bloodless but a great surprise.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- "Shut down these munitions plants and we'll get some rain," was the advice of an amateur Virginia weather "expert" to the Weather Bureau today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania accused the Pennsylvania Supreme Court today of political servility, asserting that an election was stolen by the court's decision preventing Philadelphia from choosing a Mayor this year.

Two new pictures will arrive in theatres here today. "Musical Story," a feature-length Russian operatic film, will be the newcomer at the Stanley. Featuring Sergei Lemeshev, tenor of the Leningrad State Opera, the Soviet offering includes music from such works as "Carmen," "Prince Igor," "Eugene Onegin" and "Martha."

Asserting that acceptance of the pending proposal of the Mexican Government for the settlement of the oil controversy "would sacrifice the principles of international law by which this safety of foreign investments against confiscation depends," W.S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, speaking in behalf of the oil companies involved, said yesterday that "the companies cannot give their assent to the agreement now proposed."

Onondaga County, N.Y. F.S. Moseley Co. and the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo received yesterday the award of an issue of $661,000 Onondaga County, N.Y., refunding bonds on their bid of 100.279 for 1 1/4s. The bonds, dated July 1, 1941, and maturing from July 1, 1943 to 1961, were re-offered at prices to yield from 0.35 to 1.30 per cent, according to maturity.

Plans for the transfer to New York City from Washington of the administrative staff for the Eastern seaboard of the Petroleum Coordinator's office were applauded yesterday by executives of oil companies and dealers alike.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 9 -- Turkey signed the new trade treaty with Germany today.

In the face of increasing Nazi reports that the resistance of the Russians had been smashed and no effective counter-claims from Moscow, the stock market was forced yesterday to operate on uncertain news, and as a result prices were pushed back to the lowest levels since mid-June, values deteriorating 1 to 3 points.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- A prediction that by December ships for America's new merchant fleet would be sliding down the ways at the rate of one a day and that within a year two vessels a day would be launched was made today by J.F. McInnis, naval architect for the Maritime Commission, in an address before the National Safety Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The coming into power in Panama of Adolfo de la Guardia and the elimination of President Arnulfo Arias, a reputed pro-Nazi, is regarded here as meaning an administration friendly to the United States. It is assumed that it will smooth the path for cordial relations and understanding and for the development of hemisphere defense in the critical area of the Panama Canal.

"The tin boxes, the scandals, bribery and malfeasance in office will be back in City Hall" unless the citizens register and vote in the coming election, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, declared in a radio address over WOR last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- In the first instance in which he has "cracked down" on a ceiling-price violator, Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, today compelled one of the country's iron and steel scrap dealers and largest brokers to refund to buyers all amounts collected in excess of the established ceiling prices in respect to every such sale made since Sept. 2.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- Mayor La Guardia, as civilian Defense Director, told the House Military Affairs Committee today that the government should buy 50,000,000 gas masks to protect populations within a 300-mile deep area of the nation's coastal boundaries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The National Defense Mediation Board accused Air Associates, Inc., of Bendix, N.J., today, of non-cooperation in the defense effort, and criticized F. Leroy Hill, president of the company, and others of its officials as being the first persons to walk out on the board while mediation efforts were under way.

The President has sent his message to Congress in one of the great crises of the war. Under Hitler's savage blows, Russian resistance is weakening. We are not yet compelled to abandon hope that the Russian armies may be saved, that a new front may be formed, that Hitler may still be forced to fight the Winter War he dreads.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Finding the 14-cent duty no longer an obstacle to realizing a profit from sale of their products in this country, Argentine producers are shipping butter here in rapidly increasing quantities, Department of Commerce and private trade statistics disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Robert Rice Reynolds, the 57-year-old Senator from North Carolina, and 19-year-old Miss Evalyn Washington McLean, daughter of Mrs. Edward B. McLean, owner of the Hope Diamond, and the late Mr. McLean, Washington publisher, were married today at Friendship, home of the bride's mother.

Those who have been planning an excursion to Maine for the opening of the woodcock season, which gets under way today, may find the shooting rather disappointing, according to reports from several parts of the State, but the grouse shooting is expected to more than compensate the hunters.

Individuals and committees involved in the reorganization of McKesson Robbins, Inc., appeared yesterday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Cox and asked additional compensation and reimbursement of expenses of $1,452,586.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies in September showed the second largest increase over a year ago of any month this year, according to a compilation by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The September gain amounted to 26.7 per cent, compared with 29.8 in August and 25.7 in July.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- With the virtual collapse of opposition, the course of debate today on the $5,985,000,000 lease-lend bill clearly indicated that it would be passed by the House tomorrow without any major change.

Before His Time? The landscape in front of Queens Borough Hall is not quite a St. Helena. There are many worse places to which a statue of Civic Virtue, also known as the Fat Boy and the Tough Guy, might be banished after long years in City Hall Park.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Economic Defense Board disclosed today that it intended to requisition large stocks of war materials ordered by countries which later fell under Axis domination.
If you happen to see a man with prematurely gray hair walking down the street these days, the chances are you're looking straight at a college football coach.
DETROIT, Oct. 9 -- The place of Camp Fire Girls in national defense was the subject of study sessions and speakers today at the biannual meeting of the National Council of Camp Fire Girls here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The flow of income payments to individuals continued to expand in August, but at a diminished rate in comparison with recent months, the Department of Commerce announced to day. After adjustment for seasonal influences, the department's index of total income payments advanced to 133.5 in August, compared with 132.6 for July and 131.0 for June.

Thirty years ago today an uprising in the Yangtze city of Wuchang, near Hankow, led to the overthrow of the Manchu Dynasty and the establishment of the Chinese Republic. Four hundred and fifty million people, overwhelmingly illiterate, speaking many mutually incomprehensible dialects, accustomed by ages of tyranny and corruption to consider government, hunger and sickness as belonging in the same category of necessary evils, were suddenly declared free.

Salute, a magazine published by the British War Relief Society, made its appearance here yesterday and will be distributed at 25 cents a copy by 1,000 offices of the society throughout the United States and by book stores in this and other large cities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Army's newest weapon, an authoritative source disclosed today, will be a lightweight, semi-automatic carbine developed by the Winchester Repeating Arms Company of New Haven, Conn. It is thirty-six inches long.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Grain, soy bean and lard futures declined rapidly on the Board of Trade today with fairly general liquidation in evidence on the unfavorable character of the reports from Russia and easiness in securities. At no time were wheat prices above the close of the previous day and the finish was at the bottom with losses of 1 3/4 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 4 totaled 917,516 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,994 cars, or 0.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 111,512 cars, or 13.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 87,414 cars, or 10.5 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Because of a controversy between the Pittsburgh local of the American Federation of Musicians and Station WJAS, Pittsburgh outlet of the Columbia Broadcasting System, remote sustaining band programs here have been cut off the CBS network by order of James C. Petrillo, national president of the union.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- The study of cotton goods market action during the last five years to determine relationships between various yarns and fabrics, which was undertaken by the Office of Price Administration, "cannot possibly furnish an adequate foundation for price relationships during a period of profitable operations," according to Ralph E. Loper, industrial engineer.

One hundred school children got a first-hand view of the vitriolic side of politics yesterday when Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, accused Council President Newbold Morris in their presence of using the youngsters as helpers to re-elect the La Guardia-McGoldrick-Morris ticket.

Highlighting the largest and one of the most successful flotations yesterday of United States Treasury long-term bonds for cash since he first World War was the anouncement by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick that he had entered a subscription on behalf of the New York City sinking funds for $100,000,000 of the new 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Oct. 10, the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic, it might be appropriate to remind our American friends of the significant happenings in China during the three decades that have just elapsed. Such a brief review may help them to appreciate China's problems, as well as to understand more fully the China of today.

Henry Epstein, State Solicitor General and husband of Mrs. Ethel Epstein, Mayor La Guardia's labor secretary, called upon his fellow-Democrats in the City Council yesterday to repeal the sales tax entirely and let Mayor La Guardia "stew in his own juice."

The holders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., 3 1/4 per cent convertible debentures, of which $12,681,000 principal amount is outstanding in public hands, and of $7,355,782 aggregate principal amount of bank loans, were apprised by the company yesterday of an offer to exchange a maximum of $20,000,000 of new 4 per cent debentures, due 1956, for the foregoing securities on an even basis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- President Roosevelt sent an urgent message to Congress today asking immediate authority for the arming of American merchant ships and simultaneously defying Adolf Hitler to drive the United States flag from the seas "either by his submarines, his airplanes or his threats."

Complaints to various defense agencies over resales of chemical materials at fantastic prices will not be fruitful of more than general disapproval, since Washington has no effective machinery for preventing such selling, according to trade opinion expressed yesterday.

A rise of $33,000,000 in business loans by the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City for the week ended Wednesday was revealed yesterday in the weekly report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The national council of the Federation of Long-Lines Telephone Workers, an independent union representing 11,000 employes in the long-distance division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Instructed its members yesterday to refuse to connect equipment to telephone materials installed by A.F. of L. electricians on defense construction projects.

TOKYO, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- Japanese spokesmen and newspapers today criticized the "willful, arrogant" actions of the United States and warned that the war "is likely to spread to other regions" of the world at any moment.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 9 (AP) -- An increased German effort to strengthen Nazi influence in the Far East was forecast today by sources who said they had learned that Berlin had appointed Heinrich von Stahmer, one of its ace negotiators, as Ambassador to the Japanese-sponsored Nanking Government.
ROME, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The High Command issued the following communique today:
LONDON, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- The plan to amend the American neutrality law so American merchant ships may be armed was received with satisfaction in government circles today.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

James Stillman, financier and tenth president of the National City Bank, who died March 15, 1918, left an estate of $41,272,840 at the time of his death. He named as his executors his brother, Charles Stillman, and his sons, Charles Chauncey Stillman and James A. Stillman.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The following special communique was issued today from the Fuehrer's Headquarters:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A jurisdiction dispute between the American Federation of Labor Railway Clerks and Teamsters, which threatens to tie up as "hot cargo" all shipments of the Railway Express Agency and affect defense supplies has not been settled despite President Roosevelt's plea to the A.F. of L. convention to ban such controversies.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Sinking of a German U-boat after engagement with a small British Navy trawler, which picked up forty-four members of the submarine's crew, and a series of daylight "sweeps" by fighter planes that shot up enemy shipping along the German-occupied French coast, were announced today.

VICHY, France, Oct. 9 -- Although Marshal Henri Philippe PeStain, Chief of State, and Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, are away from Vichy for at least another twenty-four hours, it is no secret that certain diplomatic exchanges are occurring in their absence.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The British and American supply missions returned to England from Moscow today for a supreme effort to sustain imperiled Russia to the last, on the theory that if Moscow falls the armies beyond the Urals still

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Oct. 10 -- After twenty-four hours of important successes on the south central sector German forces, despite the boasts of their special communiques, have been halted in their terrific drives on Moscow from the south and southwest, it was declared early today by an official Soviet radio commentator on the basis of last night's war bulletin.

The Aluminum Company of America was cleared yesterday by Judge Francis G. Caffey in Federal court here of all charges made by the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice. The final decision was contained in the opinion which Judge Caffey finished dictating late in the afternoon, ten days after he had started.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Settlement of a war bonus dispute which tied up twenty-six ships on the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific coasts last month was virtually assured today with announcement that the A.F.L. Seafarers International Union had ratified increased bonus proposals recommended by the National Defense Mediation Board.

Fordham's football squad of thirty-three players, the coaching staff, student managers and officials of the Athletic Association left the campus by bus at 5 P.M. yesterday on the first lap of the trip for the game tomorrow with the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill.

The Communist party notified the Board of Elections yesterday that it was withdrawing the V-like emblem, consisting of a hammer and pitchfork meeting at the ends, as its proposed ballot emblem, in view of criticism that the party was trying to capitalize on the Victory V being used as anti-Hitler propaganda here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Air Associates, Inc., Bendix, N.J., has filed an amendment to its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosing that its 50,000 shares of $1.37 1/8 cumulative convertible preferred stock of no-par value will be offered to the public by the following underwriters, the firms being in New York unless designated otherwise:

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Circle M Ranch's Allessandro proved a worthy favorite in the Plains Purse, feature at Laurel Park today. Under a brilliant ride by Jockey George Woolf, the son of Cantankerous was an easy winner in a field of six operating over the mile and sixteenth course.
PANAMA, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias indicated sympathy for the Axis powers and strong dislike for the United States almost as soon as he took office as President Oct. 1, 1940.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Official, diplomatic and resident society turned out today for an Autumn fashion show held here for the benefit of the British American Ambulance Corps.

Duquesne's highly rated all-veteran eleven, with seven straight victories behind it, moves into action tonight at the Polo Grounds to renew a three-year rivalry with a confident Manhattan team. The series, which has seen the Dukes emerge victorious twice by close margins, will be renewed before about 12,000 spectators.

Excess Reserves Following declines in the two preceding weeks, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $20,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $5,210,000,000, as actual reserve balances rose $50,000,000 on the week while reserve requirements increased $30,000,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Police Captain Joseph P. Quinn declared in the Third Precinct Police Court here tooday that he intended to turn over to Naval Intelligence officers and to the Federal Bureau of Investigation allegations of suggested sabotage made in an intra-union fight among workers at the plant of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation here.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- Fighting what is acknowledged to be a life-and-death struggle of unimaginable intensity, the Red Army has withdrawn to new positions north of Orel and has struck back savagely at thrusts by Nazi armored units, it was announced today.

While the railroads so far in the national emergency have "functioned admirably," with "wonderful cooperation from the shippers," still "the margin for safety is none too wide," Joseph B. "Eastman, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commisson, warned in an address here yesterday.

To Show Resort Dresses Soon The Winter resort and cruise wear season will be launched next week when members of the Sportswear Guild will present their collections. The showings had originally been planned for this week, but the date was changed to permit the preparation of more extensive lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 4 were 34 per cent higher than for the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales in the week ended Sept. 27 were up 23 per cent (revised).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The increased tax on alcohol, coupled with sharp increases in prices for foodstuffs and some farm products, were responsible for a rise in the general level of wholesale prices, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 91.6 for the week ended on Oct. 4, compared with 91.2 on Sept. 27, 91.5 on Sept. 20 and 77.8 on Oct. 5, 1940.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild held its first general meeting of the season yesterday afternoon at Louis Sherry's. In the absence of Mrs. August Belmont, chairman, Mrs. William Barclay Parsons Jr., vice chairman, presided. Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was the guest of honor.

A group of home economics experts invited housewives yesterday to grope through an imaginary half-empty larder and prepare a last-minute dinner for seven persons, including a middle-aged colonel who is on a reducing diet and his wife, who is trying to gain weight.
Mrs. Bruce Ditmas Bromley, Relief in Brooklyn, last night declared that the women of a community exert a greater influence on its political life than do the men.

Jockey Alfred (Robby) Robertson a veteran of the riding ranks even though he is still a young man, stole the spotlight at Jamaica yesterday when he rode six winners on the seven-race card as 12,143 cheered and applauded and figured astronomical parlays.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Economic cooperation between the American republics which has been started to the interest of hemisphere defense must continue after the war or many thousands of Latin-American workers will be thrown out of work and the spread of fascism encouraged, Dr. Ernesto Galarza, chief of the Division of Labor and Social Information of the Pan American Union, declared today.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Mrs. Edward B. Stevens of Round Hill retained her United States senior golf championship when she added a great 80 today to her first-round 85 for a thirty-six-hole total of 165 as the eighteenth annual tournament ended on the south course of the Westchester Country Club.

The Hotel Earle at 57-59 Sip Avenue, at Journal Square, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, trustee for the mortgage certificateholders of the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company, to the Barnet Holding Company.
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Oct. 9 -- Prices on the Bourse made a slight recovery but the close showed net losses of 5 points in some directions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The terms and conditions on which Associated Press and United Press news reports are made available to radio stations, and the circumstances under which in a few isolated cases applications for such services have been denied or deferred, were explored at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission.

CAMDEN, S.C., Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- The First Army headquarters, with less than a week of a two-month manoeuvres finished, announced today a shakeup in which six ranking officers were relieved of field duty.
Snow was falling along a large part of the Russian front yesterday as what Adolf Hitler described as "the last great decisive battle of this year" opened its second week.

The Viennese Roof and adjoining Penthouse Suite of the St. Regis were thronged to capacity yesterday afternoon when more than 600 persons attended the third annual white elephant cocktail party and tea dance for the benefit of the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

When the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society gave the first concert of its centennial season last night in Carnegie Hall the stage was fully set for an exciting denouement. American flags flanked the stage. The hall was jammed to the extent the law allowed, with the biggest audience that has assembled for over a decade for any Philharmonic-Symphony opening.
Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday showed little change from the volume of the preceding week, the percentage gain was more than double that of the comparable period a year ago.

Louis Waldman, formerly a member of the State executive committee of the American Labor party, who announced his support of District Attorney William O'Dwyer, Democratic Mayoralty candidate, last week, again attacked Mayor La Guardia yesterday for an alleged deal with the Communists and asked why he had not removed Communists from positions in the Department of Welfare, in accordance with the Devany act forbidding employment of Communists in public positions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Social Security Reforms" you indicate the need for an intensive study by a body of experts of the basic problems involved in any revision of the Social Security Law.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Oct. 8:

A total of 367,238 persons registered yesterday throughout the city for the November elections it was disclosed this morning. This figure is 9,832 ahead of that for the corresponding day in 1937 when the last Mayoralty election was held but 169,128 behind the fourth day last year when interest was centered on the Presidential election to follow.

Don't look now, but the aqua-musical that opened at the Majestic last evening is "Viva O'Brien." It is one of the strangest experiences offered on Broadway for some time. Produced at a reputed cost of $80,000, which is certainly folding money, it includes all the familiar accoutrements of musical comedy with the addition of a swimming pool, nine feet deep, according to the press agent's soundings.

Rows of empty baby carriages outside the auditorium, rows of seated mothers and babies inside, dignitaries ensconced on the platform and silver loving cups ranged on the table -- in this setting yesterday afternoon the Red Hook Tenants Council prepared to reward the Red Hook Housing Project's healthiest mothers and babies.

The one-story garage building at 50 East Merrick Road, Freeport, L.I., After an ownership of eighteen years by John Wanamaker, New York, has been sold to LeRoy Smith, head of Smith Motors, the tenant, who will continue to use the building for its Bulck service station.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- The text of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's order of the day to his soldiers on the Eastern Front, issued a week ago but published only today, follows:

The Board of Elections, acting on a complaint made by Matthew M. Levy, Fusion candidate for Borough President of the Bronx, yesterday ordered election inspectors to waive presentation of citizenship papers by naturalized citizens registering to vote if they had voted previously, or were known by the registry officials to be citizens, or, in the case of new voters, if "other satisfactory proof" was offered.

A reader is bound to be impressed when he learns that the United States Army next year will eat 277,000,000 pounds of fresh meat and sausage, 82,000,000 pounds of cured and smoked meats, 26,000,000 pounds of canned meat, 50,000,000 pounds of butter, 50,000,000 pounds of poultry, and 55,000,000 dozen eggs.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In this matter of the Yankees ''always winning," we must admit there is some ground for grumping, as much as we love them. But most of the ideas advanced to even up things a bit are calamitous and impractical.

HAVANA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias, ousted President of Panama, said today that "certain differences" had arisen between his administration and United States authorities, and he added caustically that his case contained "a lesson for small countries."

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- The successes achieved in the first nine days of the "Battle of Moscow" were compared in Berlin today with the "bursting of a dam," and the communique of the German High Command estimated the width of the breach at 300 miles.

With sales of the new 1942 automobiles falling below expectations, manufacturers may be forced to put greater promotion efforts behind the latest models than they had originally anticipated, according to dealers here. The industry in general had thought that 1941 models were so well cleaned out there would be a general rush for the new styles but this has not developed.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10 -- Awaiting their twenty-first football meeting in the Bowl tomorrow, Pennsylvania and Yale today held their final light workouts on the Elis' practice gridiron, the visitors working later than the Blue.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation have reached new high records for September, for the third quarter of the year and for the first nine months of any year, according to an announcement made yesterday by the corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Because of the direct contact they have with the public, retailers have more at stake in an inflationary price movement than any other division of business and for their own protection must see to it that the public understands where price advances start, Louis E. Kirstein of Boston, chairman of the American Retail Federation, warned members gathered at the Hotel Mayflower today for the organization's annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Dr. Paul F. Douglass, aged 37, was inaugurated as president of American University tonight. Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, made the principal address at the ceremonies in Memorial Continental Hall.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Returning from Russia, Lord Beaverbrook declared today that Britain is operating on a lease-lend arrangement to Russia which up to now has neither a time nor a money limit.

Isabel French, soprano from Boston, who has made previous appearances in New York, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. Mrs. French did not begin to make a serious study of singing until she had reached middle age, but her musicianship was a family heritage, since two of her great-grandfathers, Pierre Duport and Alexander Reinagle, were artists of repute in the musical life of their day.

SEATTLE, Oct. 10 -- Without an audible word of protest, delegates to the convention of the American Federation of Labor paved the way today to oust from its executive council George F. Browne, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employes, who is on trial in New York with William Bioff, charged with extorting $550,000 from four motion picture companies.
The New York Police Department, after eighteen months of quiet preparation with the State Guard, last night tried out under simulated war conditions the movement of 3,200 troops through city traffic.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of following companies are after all charges, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final year-end adjustments.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Bouding back from the brink of defeat in a last half that pulled 25,000 spectators from their seats, Georgia's Bulldogs shoved across two touchdowns in a thrilling rally tonight to tie at 14 to 14 a Mississippi team that all but had a victory in the bag.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 10 -- The Croatian revolutionary Ustashi have killed between 300,000 and 340,000 Serbs and pro-Yugoslav Croats since last May, according to figures compiled by intelligence experts from agents operating in Croatia and Bosnia and released to this correspondent here today.

CAMP UPTON, Oct. 10 -- The first anniversary of the 1,222d reception center here was observed today in holiday manner, although heavy rain during the morning causing a postponement of the scheduled outdoor athletic contests until tomorrow morning.

Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia, and the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, in preparation for "World Mission Sunday" in the Roman Catholic Church which will be celebrated on Oct. 19, will speak tomorrow at 3 P.M. over the Blue Network of the National Broadcasting Company.

The Board of Education yesterday won the first round in its fight to assign regular teachers to subjects for which they are not licensed when Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel of the Bronx dismissed a suit brought by a mathematics teacher on an existing eligible list who has not been appointed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We are committed to a program of all aid for Britain short of war and are rapidly approaching a situation which will automatically eliminate this last qualifying phrase. Indeed, many writers declare that we have for some time been engaged in the modern undercover, undeclared form of war.

TROY, Oct. 10 -- Cultivation of closer understanding among women of the Americas was suggested by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today as a means of achieving better commercial and political relationships.

Claude Hall, 47-year-old World War veteran of 1258 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, and WPA worker, was booked on a charge of arson at the Ralph Avenue station yesterday after the police said he admitted setting six fires which drove scores of families to the street in the Bushwick section of the borough early Friday morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The House passed without a single major change today the second $5,985,000,000 lease-lend bill, bringing to $12,985,000,000 the amount appropriated to furnish aid to those countries whose defense President Roosevelt deems vital to the United States.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

Setting aside indefinitely a plan to build a clubhouse, the Dobbs Ferry Woman's Club, in the interest of national defense, invested yesterday 55,000 from its building fund in Federal Defense Bonds. Members said they hoped they had set a precedent that would be followed throughout the nation.

Miss Susan Brandeis, daughter of the late Louis Brandeis, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, assumed yesterday the chairmanship of the women's division of the Campaign Committee for the election of O'Dwyer, Church and Fertig at a tea for the three Democratic city-wide candidates at the headquarters in the Chanin Building.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The election of Cleveland E. Van Wert of Scarsdale as president of the Westehester County Realty Board was announced today by Walter G. De Witt, executive vice president Mr. Van Wert will take office Jan. 1 and succeed Percy M. Bibas of Larchmont.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- "Washington imperialists" are accused in German quarters of having staged a "Putsch" in Panama. The overthrow of the Arias regime, it is charged here, is part of the general scheme of the United States' political meddling in the Latin Americas.

Although suburban builders repeated yesterday earlier predictions that the Supply Priorities and Allocation Board's banning of most new construction except for defense would seriously affect their business, the Real Estate Board of New York epxressed the opinion that some wholesome results might be expected from the ruling, particularly in the urban realty field.

The record of transportation industries in the defense program was praised by J. Monroe Johnson, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, speaking yesterday in the Hotel Commodore at the final session of the twelfth annual meeting of the Association of Interstate Commerce Practitioners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Plans for rehabilitating 200,000 of the 1,000,000 youths who have been rejected for military service because of physical or mental deficiencies were announced by President Roosevelt at his press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Bridgeport Brass Company of Bridgeport, Conn., had filed with it a registration statement for 25,486 shares of cumulative convertible preferred stock, $100 par value, and an indeterminate number of shares of common stock, no par (including scrip certificates for fractions of shares), to be reserved for issuance upon conversion of the preferred stock registered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A scroll signed by 10,000 Chinese students and teachers in American-supported Christian colleges in China was presented to President Roosevelt today by Dr. Hu Shih, the Chinese Ambassador, and James G. Blaine, chairman of United China Relief, as an expression of Sino-American friendship on the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Federal Government has, through its SPAB, declared against new building of any kind not deemed by its staff member, Donald Nelson, to be essential. I believe this decision is too sweeping to be a wise one, in spite of my agreement with the Federal Government on the need for haste in defense production.

It is an interesting fact, generally overlooked, that losses of British merchant tonnage in the war at sea have been almost equaled by accretions of shipping from countries the Germans have overrun. Germany, on the other hand, was able to seize less than half the shipping of the conquered nations and has been prevented by British sea j and air power from making effective use of either the captured ships or harbors.
A national campaign for funds will be opened at a benefit in Madison Square Garden Oct. 27 by the newly organized Russian War Relief, Inc., 535 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

Fort Tilden on Rockaway Peninsula was successfully raided last night in a mock invasion by 1,250 soldiers from Fort Hancock representing a hostile "Black Army." The raid started at 10:36 P.M. and ended at 1:45 A.M.

A crisis is fast approaching in the monstrous Battle of Russia. The pounding of the guns is almost within earshot of the Sparrow Hills, the wooded heights where Napoleon once watched Moscow burning. Again the first snows whiten the trees and blur the silhouette of the imperiled city.

Repair and conversion work on seventeen ships urgently needed by the Navy Department was halted early yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn yard of the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company when 6,000 members of Local 39 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., walked out in protest against the refusal of four workers to join the union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Discussing the SPAB ban on nonessential building projects as announced yesterday, C.F. Palmer, Defense Housing Coordinator, gave his interpretation today of the order.

ATLANTIC, CITY, N.J., Oct. 10 -- C.A. Sienkiewicz, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, declared today that a general amendment to exclude all loans for business purposes from installment credit regulations now is under consideration.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 11 -- Blows struck by aircraft of the British Navy and the Royal Air Force against the Germans' northern lines of communication toward Russia along the coast of Norway were recounted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Washington and Lee and George Washington elevens, with good defensive lines but little or no offensive drive, battled to a scoreless deadlock before 7,000 spectators tonight.
PANAMA, Oct. 10 -- The new Panamanian government is expected to repeal soon the ban on the arming of merchant ships that had been decreed by the ousted Arias government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Approval by the Governors of seventeen States and by thirty-four city officials in three of these States and fifteen others, of a curtailment of all governmental expenditures not vital to essential functions or to the defense effort was reported today by Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University and chairman of the Citizens Emergency Committee on Non-Defense Expenditures.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Tests on animals and man have shown that malignant tumors of the bone have a selective affinity for the element strontium, providing a hope that this element, transformed artificially into a radioactive, cancer-destroying substance, may provide a new clinical approach for the treatment of bone malignancies.
Spurred by an active demand the cotton market turned upward yesterday. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with net gains of 12 to 19 points.

Tamara Toumanova walked away with the honors of the second bill of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. In her first appearance here in "The Nutcracker," she danced like a million dollars and looked like at least twice that sum.

Presumably to leave its members free to vote for Mayor La Guardia and with the avowed purpose of promoting national unity behind the policies of President Roosevelt, the Communist party yesterday withdrew Israel Amter, its candidate for Mayor, and all other candidates except those for the City Council.

The United States Army Air Corps may soon call for 25,000 women volunteers for enlistment in the regular Army in connection with the operation of the newly developed Army air-raid warning system that is receiving its first test in the East this week.

Sudden Dog Lovers One reason which makes us doubt that Hitler has really settled the rate of Europe for a hundred years is the kind of full-page display in the Dutch newspapers when the Germans announce a big victory or when the Fuehrer meets his good friend Il Duce.
DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 10 -- Down here in tobacco land, a gigantic Fordham football squad today awaited its second test of the season.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct 10 -- Doors were opened today to twenty-four newspaper women for a first-hand view of one of the largest naval operating bases and training stations in the country and study of the modern housing provided for uniformed and civilian personnel and their families, a population exceeding 70,000.

AMHERST vs. Bowdoin -- This baffled bystander went in search of a T-Formation Tycoon for aid in solving these Saturday problems and was shocked to learn that there are no such things as tycoons these days.
