The last one was legislated out of office in 1867. Staggering back, one bewildered vote for Bowdoin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Declaring that "small industry can win the war," Floyd Odium, OPM contract distribution director, said tonight that his organization would seek to withhold large defense contracts from any firm which did not agree to "farm out" a reasonable part of the work.

Henry Bernstein, French playwright, who with twenty-eight other men and women was deprived of French citizenship by the Vichy government last May, and whose membership in the Legion of Honor was canceled Thursday, replied yesterday to the action as follows:

Mayor La Guardia minimized last night the fears expressed by several speakers that defense priorities might hold up the construction of the Amsterdam Houses, ten modern apartment dwellings that are to be erected to replace ninety old-law tenements in the Columbus Hill area of Manhattan.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent who bemoans the use of the word "bums" when referring to the Brooklyn baseball team takes his place in a long queue of purists who have vainly sought to stem the evolutionary flow of our language.

There are twelve named for each of the stakes to be run at Jamaica today, and each event will gross approximately $12,000 for what will be the richest day's racing of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's Fall meeting. Fenelon, recent winner of the $58,000 New York Handicap, is one of the dozen named for the mile and a sixteenth of the Continental Handicap but he will have plenty of opposition.
LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

TOLEDO, Oct. 10 -- Caught in the middle of a jurisdictional dispute between A.F. of L. and C.I. O. unions, officials of the Spicer Manufacturing Company tonight announced a nead-paralysis of production of transmissions for Army tanks and other vehicles.

It took just twelve minutes last night to evacuate ninety-four persons from sixty apartments in a fifteen-story building at 290 Riverside Drive, where the Office of Civilian Defense staged an effective air-raid drill. The first alarm, sounded at 8:55 P.M., brought immediate action and at 9:07 P.M. the tenants, with the exception of six invalids, were in the lobby.

Democratic members of the City Council Finance Committee had a merry time in City Hall yesterday bedeviling Fusion officials with questions about Mayor La Guardia's plan for cutting the sales and compensating use taxes in two.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

Trading In locally dressed meats was only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were barely steady to weak. Veal and calf hind-saddles were weak, lamb carcasses higher, fresh pork cuts steady to lower, cow and bull beet steady. All kosher markets opened stronger today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -- Fannie Hurst's "Humoresque," sentimental melodrama of the silent screen, was bought today by Warners from Paramount for Winter production with John Garfield. Paramount filmed the work in 1920, with Alma Rubens, Vera Gordon and Gaston Glass, and it is expected that Garfield will repeat the Glass role, that of a violinist, whose career is tragically curtailed by military conscription.

The semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition opened yesterday despite threatening weather. The early rain sent the artists scurrying for cover, but when the sun came out later, many of them were back at their posts.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 10 -- The New York State Teachers Association will continue to oppose any reduction in State aid to schools in spite of the emergency conditions facing the State and nation, Dr. H. Claude Hardy, first vice president of the organization, declared today at the annual convention of the Long Island zone attended by 3,500 public school teachers from Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

The Democratic party organizations yesterday launched an attempt to rule out as invalid the independent nominating petitions of the City Fusion and United City parties, nominating Mayor La Guardia, Controller McGoldrick and Council President Newbold Morris.

Erno Valasek, 22-year-old violinist from Cleveland, was the winner of the second annual Young Artist's Philharmonic Award of the Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation, Inc., it was announced yesterday. This award entitles Mr. Valasek to appear as soloist this season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 11 -- The new German campaign against Moscow is being followed In Japan with the keenest attention, but so far without any conclusive indication as to what consequences Japan herself expects to draw from the outcome.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Alleged German atrocities in Crete, with the wholesale murder of civilians, including children and old people, numerous public executions, the looting and burning of villages and the desecration of at least one Greek church in Manolio, the altar of which was turned into a public lavatory, were described in an official report given out here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The shadows of priorities and heavy government buying have fallen across two important industries, a check of exhibitors at the trade shows of the National Restaurant Association and the National Stationers Association showed this week and while both associations went on record as urging better treatment in the defense set-up, nobody seemed to have any great hope of an immediate improvement in the situation.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 10 -- Benjamin Franklin Fackenthal Jr., of Riegelsville, retired iron manufacturer and president of the board of trustees of Franklin and Marshall College since 1915, was killed today in an automobile accident near here.

The appointment of Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson as chairman of the public health committee for the election of William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, was characterized yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, as a "new low in stupidity."

FORT BENNING, Oct. 10 -- In preparation, for the November manoeuvres, Major Gen. Oscar W. Sriswold, commanding general of the Fourth Motorized Division, announced this week a month-long training program for October designed to smooth the functioning of the newest-type division to operate in the 1941 manoeuvre period.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 10 -- The details of Germany's last-minute attempts to drive a wedge into British-Turkish relations on the eve of the Turkish-German trade pact's signature were disclosed to this correspondent tonight by a foreign diplomatic source.

The contract between the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, which was signed last April 1, provides, among other things, that: "The Union agrees not to intimidate or coerce employes into membership" and that "should any local trouble of any kind arise in any plant, there shall be no suspension of work on account of such differences."

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- A showdown to determine whether the United States Steel Corporation will accede to demands for a closed shop by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee (C.I.O.) developed today out of the dispute over independent and American Federation of Labor employes at the Gary Sheet and Tin Mills of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

Democratic members of the City Council Finance Committee had a merry time in City Hall yesterday bedeviling Fusion officials with questions about Mayor La Guardia's plan for cutting the sales and compensating use taxes in two.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- An accumulation of overnight selling orders, largely in the way of liquidation, resulted in a lower range of prices for grains on the Board of Trade in the early trading today. The markets steadied quickly, however, and when shorts tried to cover there was little opposition to a good rally.

Mayor La Guardia had only fair-to-middling luck last night as a member of the "board of experts" on the "Information Please" program broadcast from station WEAP of the National Broadcasting System. He muffed several questions on politics and civic administration and wrongly identified one operatic aria when part of it was sung, but easily identified as spaghetti sauce a mixture whose separate ingredients were listed by Clifton S. Fadiman, master of ceremonies.

Dropping behind the total for the last Mayoralty election again, registration of voters yesterday totaled 351,819, making the total for the first five days of the enrollment period this year 1,639,184. In 1937, the last time New York chose its Mayor, the fifth day registration reached 368,362 and the total for five days was 1,686,416.

The Philadelphia Electric Company, largest unit in the United Gas Improvement Company system, has under consideration plans looking toward the financing of a part of its future requirements through the sale of capital stock, it was announced yesterday by H.P. Liversidge, president of the Philadelphia utility.

The Monday Holiday As Columbus Day falls on Sunday this year, all financial markets and virtually all commodities markets in the United States will observe the holiday on Monday. As is customary on most holidays, the various livestock markets will remain open.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 10 -- Theodore A. Distler, dean of Lafayette College, was elected president of Franklin and Marshall today at a meeting of the board of trustees which was delayed by the accidental death of the chairman and interrupted when one of the members suffered a heart attack.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- The principal gains in employment and payrolls in September were the result of seasonal expansion, Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, explained in announcing that factory employment had risen 2.5 per cent and payrolls 3.8 per cent.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 10 -- With fifty communities cooperating and Garden City in a blackout, the Nassau County Defense Council tested the county's communications tonight under the "stress" of a simulated air raid.

With more than 90 per cent of the week's offerings coming on Tuesday from thirteen local housing authorities, the total of new State and municipal issues scheduled for sale next week will be lifted to $69,174,689 from $21,846,732 this week.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Oct. 10 -- A pointed warning that sales will become a major problem in the not-too distant future and that the so-called sellers' market will not last was given today to sales executives of Servel, Inc., gas appliance manufacturers, by officials of the company at their annual convention here at French Lick Springs Hotel.

The Communist candidates for city and county offices, except those running for the City Council, have declined their nominations, which were made by petition. That is their right. There is nothing to prevent their withdrawal from the contest, any more than there is anything to stop their entering it.

Diplomatic secrets transmitted by the British Embassy in Lisbon, Portugal, to London found their way into the hands of German espionage agents long before they reached their intended destination, according to testimony yesterday at the Brooklyn espionage trial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A contract for guns, amounting to $ 995,850, awarded to the Americ Type Founders, Inc., of Elizabe N.J., featured the day's misc laneous supply contract awards the Army. Total awards amount to $10,218,151, of which the following, not previously published, we to firms in the New York area:

Favored Duquesne once again proved a stumbling block for Manhattan College's football forces under the Polo Grounds floodlights last night as the Dukes passed and plunged for a 26-to-7 victory before 11,127 spectators.

The decision of the SPAB to prohibit "non-essential" public or private construction projects requiring "appreciable quantities of critical materials" has the great merit that it does recognize the absolute primacy of national defense. The Administration has indeed advanced far from the day when the President declared that the country should not be "discomboomerated" by the defense program.

In honor of Columbus Day patriotic sermons will be preached tomorrow in the churches of the New York area. Some clergymen will discuss the question of "Religious Liberty in Russia." Protesant pastors will voice approval of he idea of "a daily minute of sient prayer marked by the ringing if church bells" as advocated this week at a meeting of the Women's Division of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

With Wall Street assuming a less pessimistic attitude over the fortunes of the Russian Army and no marked carry-over of the selling of Thursday, the stock market managed yesterday to present a more stable appearance.

Somewhat circumstantial stories of a German armistice offer to Soviet Russia and one report that Moscow was considering the offer were received in New York yesterday from both neutral and belligerent countries of Europe, The Associated Press reported.

The Commodity Exchange, Inc., has bought 96 seats from its members at $600 each under an offer made on Aug. 13 by Edward L. McKendrew, president of the Exchange, to buy up to 100 seats at that price. The program was ordered by the board of governors owing to the reduced volume of trading on the Exchange.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 10 -- The proceedings against the Standard Oil Company of Bolivia are likely to be dropped as a result of a deposition of former Foreign Minister Alberto Ostria Gutierrez, it was believed today in court circles here.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Oct. 11 -- Soviet forces, striking back vigorously after their defensive structure had received a shaking for two days, held the Germans to such good effect during the last twenty-four hours that a Russian radio announcement early today was able to report "no change of any importance along the entire front."

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Oct. 10 -- After a steady to firm opening today the Bourse turned downward again with losses running to 8 points. Royal Dutch dropped 5 3/4 points to 294 1/4 guilders; Amsterdam Rubber, 7 3/4 to 292 1/4 guilders; Amsterdam Trading, 3 1/2 to 459 3/4 guilders; Unilever, 4 1/2 to 149 1/8 guilders, and Philips, 3 1/2 to 250 guilders.

A school-age child's big meal need not be at noon. In fact, Miss Pauline Murrah, nutrition consultant for the New York City Department of Health, thinks an evening dinner far better for those who have blown out the candles on six birthday cakes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- George Sylvester Viereck, accused by the government of being a Nazi propagandist, pleaded not guilty today when arraigned in the Federal District Court on charges of withholding vital information when he registered with the State Department under the Foreign Agents Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust prosecutions, has warned the Federal Works Agency that denial of a contract to the Currier Lumber Company of Detroit, low bidder for 300 defense houses in Michigan, might require action on the part of the Department of Justice.

Scnora Elisa G. de Batista, wife of the President of Cuba, was entertained at dinner late evening in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Dr. Aurelio F. Concheso, Cuban Ambasador to the United States, and Senora de Concheso.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- Amid praise for "carrying the gospel of good books far and wide," Miss Mary E. Eastwood, head of the information section of the State Library, was honored at a farewell luncheon today upon her retirement after forty years' service.

DETROIT, Oct. 10 -- Application to the immediate future of the lessons of the World War and especially the post-war period was urged upon the National Council of Camp Fire Girls at the annual convention today by Mrs. Arthur H. Vandenberg, wife of the Senator.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- one of the best distance race fleets of the year gathered tonight for the final event of sizable craft, that of the New Rochelle Yacht Club's annual contest out around Stratford Shoal, in the middle of Long Island Sound, between Bridgeport and Port Jefferson, L.I.

NEW YORK Mrs. Benjamin F. Cheatham, wife of Major Gen. Cheatham, U.S.A., retired, has arrived from Stratford Hall, her home in Stratford, Va., and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.
CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Chinese Army declared early today that Ichang, western stronghold of Japanese occupation, had been recaptured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The difficulties encountered by James D. Poag, independent broadcaster of Greenville, S.C., in obtaining news services for his station in a field locally controlled by a newspaper competitor owned by Roger O. Peace, who recently was appointed to succeed Senator James F. Byrnes, were presented to the Federal Communications Commission at today's hearing of press-radio relationships.

Gray-haired veterans of the last World War kept vigil over Manhattan last night from the vantage point of the Empire State Building's terrace observatory, eighty-six stories, or 1,048 feet, above street level, while the bombing planes of the mythical Black Army opened the attack on Fort Tilden.

Carpenters hammered on a wood and canvas house in City Hall Park last night -- representing a four-story tenement -- firemen dragged a hose into City Hall itself and three fire trucks painted in wartime gray scurried through the downtown streets.

Cuba's representatives in the international military jumping events at the National Horse Show to be held in Madison Square Garden Nov. 5 to 12, inclusive, arrived here last night on the Cuba Mail Line steamship Shawnee.

Thirty stalwart young men, most of them walking stiffly in high-heeled cowboy boots, wandered about New York yesterday, but these had nothing to do with the rodeo. They toured the city and, in their wanderings, caught a glimpse of the Yankee Stadium.
The neutral football observer hereabouts, if such there breathes, scarcely knows in which direction to turn for entertainment today.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Oct. 10 -- More than 15,000 men of the First Division have been preparing this week for the mass movement to Condor, N.C., headquarters during the Southern war games in the next six weeks.

BENDIX, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Confident that the government would take over operation of the Air Associates, Inc., airplane accessories plant here if F. Leroy Hill, president of the company, and other of its officials persisted in their refusal to reinstate strikers immediately pending settlement of their dispute, about 100 strikers voted tonight to return to work at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- Captain Andy Tomasic with two spectacular touchdown runs, helped Temple University gain its first victory in history over Georgetown at the Owls' stadium tonight. The score was 17 -- 7 and 33,000 fans were present.

Ceremonies at noon today will open the new three-and-one-half-mile six-lane Hutchinson River Parkway Extension in the Bronx connecting the Hutchinson River Parkway at the north end of Pelham Bay Park with the approach to the Whitestone Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Approval by the Governors of seventeen States and by thirty-four city officials in three of these States and fifteen others, of a curtailment of all governmental expenditures not vital to essential functions or to the defense effort was reported today by Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University and chairman of the Citizens Emergency Committee on Non-Defense Expenditures.
Revised. The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Concluding a six-week investigation of the copper scrap situation, the Office of Price Administration announced today an extensive revision of the copper scrap schedule to become effective Oct. 17. The new schedule will place ceiling prices on a shipping point instead of a delivered basis, allow quantity differentials to dealers and establish premiums for "briquetting" and other special services.

The chemical identification of a cellular "traffic cop," which directs the human body's utilization of food along the smooth and efficient road of respiration instead of the energy-wasting detour of fermentation, was announced last night by Dr. Kurt G. Stern of the Yale University School of Medicine.
The Federal investigation of the sinking of the wooden cargo carrier Ethel Skakel in the Caribbean on Sept. 25 continued yesterday before a board of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 9 (delayed) (AP) -- A communique from Royal Air Force headquarters in the Middle East said today:

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 10 -- Theodore A. Distler, dean of Lafayette College, was elected president of Franklin and Marshall today at a meeting of the board of trustees which was delayed by the accidental death of the chairman and interrupted when one of the members suffered a heart attack.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Continental Congress for Freedom passed a resolution today calling for a declaration of war against Germany and another for repeal of the Neutrality Act, even if it meant war.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 10 -- The latest ministerial crisis in Iraq, according to a reliable observer who has just arrived in Jerusalem, developed from the circumstances succeeding Rashid All el Gailani's ill-starred attempt to remove Iraq from traditional British influence and bring the nation into the Nazi orbit.

The mock raid on Fort Tilden found fire-fighting units alert all along the Rockaway Peninsula last night, with five regular and fifteen auxiliary companies of the New York Fire Department ready to go into action, supplemented by two Nassau County companies which had moved in under a mutual aid agreement.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a net income of $4,744,892 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, for the first eight months of this year. This was equal to $4.54 a share on 1,045,277 capital shares, and compares with $1,854,086, or $1.77 a capital share, in the first eight months of 1940.

VICHY, France, Oct. 10 -- Eugene Deloncle and Marcel Deat, group leaders of the "collaborationist" effort to establish a single party in the occupied zone of France, have parted company, according to an announcement in the Paris press today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that a 2 per cent improvement in crop prospects in September apparently lifted this year's aggregate production to near the record established in 1937.

Another casualty of the season, which already has had more than its quota, is "Anne of England," departing from the St. James tonight. Under the purple banner of Gilbert Miller, the production was unveiled on Tuesday night and will have chalked up only seven performances.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The British Army is now training guerrilla troops -- specifically picked "tough guys" who must be able to endure intense hardships and become skilled supersoldiers with mastery over many trades unknown to the ordinary infantryman, it was revealed today.

As a practical demonstration of its theme, "Strengthen Democracy for Defense," during National Business Women's Week, the New York League of Business and Professional Women, Inc., donated to the United Service Organizations yesterday about $300 raised at the annual tea held at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- War Department officials, brought near to the end of their patience with defense strikes, declared today a secondary boycott at a Toledo transmission plant was "as serious an obstacle to defense as anything yet encountered."

DETROIT, Oct. 10 -- Application to the immediate future of the lessons of the World War and especially the post-war period was urged upon the National Council of Camp Fire Girls at the annual convention today by Mrs. Arthur H. Vandenberg, wife of the Senator.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- Large numbers of Russian reserves have now been thrown into battle and the German drive north of Orel has been blocked, it was announced today. At the same time it was declared that Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's effort to encircle the central Soviet armies had been thwarted.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Training the Fourth Armored Division received new impetus yesterday with arrival of the first consignment of eight medium tanks for the Eightieth Armored Regiment, the medium tank unit of the command.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Are the New York papers afraid of Lou Little that they should fail to mention how questionable was the decision of "offside" against Brown after the referee signaled a touchdown toward the close of the third period at Baker Field last Saturday?

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 10 -- The Forty-fourth Division's rear detachment, which has been halved by the discharge of men completing one-year enlistments and release of officers to the inactive list, will lose 175 men by discharge Tuesday, Major Daniel Debrier, rear detachment commander, announced today.

In a ceremony between the halves of the National Football League clash between the Giants and Philadelphia at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, two service men, representing the Second Corps Area and the Third Naval District, will express the gratitude of the Army and Navy to John V. Mara, president of the Giants, for his donation of 5,000 tickets to the armed forces for each home game played by the team.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 10 -- Naval warplanes of the Royal Air Force added at least one vessel on Wednesday night to their total of Axis sinkings for the week -- one of the largest since the British began their aerial campaign against Nazi-Fascist ships in the Mediterranean, it was announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 10 -- What was generally regarded as a heavy blow to Argentine democratic institutions was delivered by a decision of the Cabinet Council this afternoon under the chairmanship of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo to dissolve the Buenos Aires elected Municipal Council and replace it with a board of twenty-one Government appointees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Battle lines over President Roosevelt's request for authority to arm American merchant ships were forming in Congress today with critics of Administration foreign policy expressing the feeling that they were compelled to make a stand on this issue to ward off further and even more fundamental changes in the Neutrality Act.

The interest shown by William O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, in the internal affairs of the American Labor party is due to Mr. O'Dwyer's inability to deal with constructive campaign issues, George Marlin, acting State executive director of the American Labor party, charged yesterday.

Acting on the advice or several hundred Catholic educators throughout the country the publishers, Sheed Ward, have started this month a new program of guided reading for Catholics. Under the general series heading of Catholic Masterpieces, the publishers will issue each month from October through May established titles of Catholic literature.

Four major classifications of borrowers were represented in this week's new bond financing which aggregated $40,322,000, the largest volume to reach the market since the period ended on Aug. 22, in which bonds for $62,627,000 were marketed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Columbia will visit Palmer Stadium tomorrow to meet Princeton in the twentieth contest of one of football's oldest rivalries. A crowd of 40,000 is expected to see the game, which will begin at 2 P.M.

ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Frank Leahy brought Notre Dame's football team to town today, hopeful that cool weather and the accurate passing of Sophomore Angelo Bertelli would give the Irish victory over Georgia Tech tomorrow "by one point -- certainly not more than one touchdown."

With the striped bass making a better showing in the surf at Montauk during the past few days, the chances for this week-end are much, better, according to Frank Tuma, who was rather optimistic in his latest bulletin on fishing conditions.
ANNISTON, Ala., Oct. 10 -- The Twenty-seventh Division, New York National Guard, back at Fort McClellan after two months of manoeuvres in Arkansas and Louisiana, is undergoing a change in personnel.

Abraham Epstein, executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security, which is sponsor for a health insurance bill introduced in Washington by Senator Capper, opened yesterday at a convention of the New York State Osteopathic Society an attack upon organized medicine's opposition to government health insurance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Adolf Hitler was challenged today by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, "to twist his lying tongue into a claim that his 'Battle of America* is 'progressing according to plan.' " Mr. Hoover addressed the graduation exercises of the eighteenth session of the National Police Academy.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- Two members of the United States Conciliation Service conferred for ten hours here today with representatives of the C.I.O. and of he A.F. of L. and with officials of the Spicer Manufacturing Company in an effort to settle the dispute at Hillsdale, Mich., which threatens to tie up 70 per cent of the nation's light-tank production.

Many interesting factors regarding real estate conditions in the Middle West were learned by Philip W. Kniskern, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, who has just completed a tour of Kansas, Indiana, Arkansas, Colorado, New Mexico and Oklahoma.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- When a zealous sentry refused to let the Duke of Windsor enter a Canadian airfield this week without some identification card or permission from a superior officer he was merely applying a procedure already quite extensive here in the national capital, even though this country is not officially at war.

Although tulips and daffodils will likely stand at the top of most bulb lists again this Fall, gardeners who overlook that section of the catalogues which dealers refer to as "miscellaneous items" will miss some of the most charming bulbous plants.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 11 -- Dartmouth's Indians, successfully met their first major test today under the coaching regime of Tass McLaughry and rallied to beat the Red Raiders of Colgate, 18-6.

Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed irregularly higher in a dull session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Aircraft issues provided almost the only activity. Sales of 227,050 shares covered 496 issues, of which 204 rose, 127 fell and 165 were unchanged.

WACO, Texas, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Baylor defeated Arkansas, 20 to 7, in today's only Southwest Conference football game.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11 -- Cornell made a first-period touchdown stand up to account for a hard-earned victory over Harvard today. Counting on an aerial combination by Ken Stofer and Louis Bufalino, the Ithacans got the jump on the gallant Harvard band in little more than eleven minutes and fought off every Cantab effort to even matters. The result was a 7-to-0 triumph for the invaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National Defense Mediation Board stated today that Air Associates Inc., Bendix, N.J., had refused to accept board recommendations for immediate reinstatement of all strikers and added: "The case now is out of our hands."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The "present-day solidarity and unity of purpose" of the American Republics was stressed by President Roosevelt tonight in a statement on the occasion of Columbus Day.

Opening the new Hutchinson River Parkway Extension in the Bronx yesterday, Mayor La Guardia invited a comparison between the methods of his administration in land acquisition and the "pap, patronage and pilfering" in condemnation proceedings by Tammany regimes.
ALFRED, N.Y., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Alfred University's football team was held to a 7-7 deadlock tonight by Clarkson Tech.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A substantial rise in United States exports during August, principally in shipments to the British Empire of lease-lend materials, notably machinery, aircraft and munitions, brought the total value to $455,000,000, a gain of nearly $100,000,000 over July figures, statistics made public today by the Commerce Department show.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Louisiana State University tonight fought Mississippi State to a 0-0 tie before 30,000 roaring fans.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 11 -- As evidence of the determination of the new Labor Cabinet of Prime Minister John Curtin to augment Australia's war effort, the government at Canberra has announced it will immediately make available for British-Soviet use sorely needed standard-gauge locomotives and freight cars for the Trans-Iranian Railway.

LINCOLN, Neb. Oct. 11 (AP) -- Nebraska slammed over five touchdowns today to wallop a sophomore-studded Kansas football team, 32 to 0, for the second Big Six Conference victory by the Corn Huskers, defending champions. A crowd of 25,000 saw the game.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The importance of supplies of foodstuffs from the United States to Great Britain was stressed this week by Lord Woolton, Food Minister, in the House of Lords. Last month the British Government stated officially that the United States then was supplying 5 to 6 per cent of Britain's total food stocks.
LIGONEER, Pa., Oct. 11 -- Himmel, the horse that "had no chance," led six finishers to capture the International Gold Cup Steeplechase, feature of the annual Rolling Rock hunts meeting today.

Direct participation of the United States Government in evacuating to the Western Hemisphere antiFascists of various nationalities now in the concentration camps and labor battalions of unoccupied France and North Africa was urged yesterday at a meeting of the Emergency Refugee Conference, sponsored by six groups active in extending aid to refugees, at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- The destruction of two trapped Russian armies north of the Sea of Azov was reported tonight by the High Command, which declared 64,325 prisoners were captured in a German-Rumanian sweep toward Rostov, oil pipeline port.

PANAMA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias, ousted as President of Panama in a bloodless coup Tuesday while he was in Cuba, sailed toward home tonight facing possible arrest or exile under one of his own laws.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Fighting back desperately in the shadows of their own goal posts, the Horned Frogs of Texas Christian University beat off two last-quarter Indiana attacks and emerged with a 20-to-14 decision over a scrappy Hoosier team today.

Registration of voters for the 1941 municipal election reached a final total of 2,449,819 when the books were closed last night. This is a decline of 33,416 from the total for 1937, the last year in which a Mayor was elected, and a drop of 940,641 from the figure for last year's Presidential election.

Leopold Stokowski played a joke last night on the 2,700 persons who filled Carnegie Hall for his third concert with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. He did it at the end of the American work on his program, Folk Dance for Strings and Percussion from Roy Harris's "Folk Song Symphony."

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11 -- David Dudley Field, an electrical engineer associated with the New York Telephone Company, died at the Field homestead here early this morning, after a long illness, at the age of 66.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 -- Duke's great Blue Devil array turned on an amazing display of offensive power and versatility today to rout completely Maryland's game, but futile Terrapins by a 50-to-0 score before 14,000 fans thrilled by the speed and ball-handling wizardry of Wallace Wade's undefeated eleven.

OTTAWA, Oct. 11 -- The Canadian Government took a tighter hold on the pocketbooks of the people today by curbing credit buying. Down payments, it ordered, must be at least one-third of the total cash price and never less than $10 at the time of delivery.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- Five hundred mechanics engaged in the production of transmissions for light tanks, combat cars and tractor-trucks at the main plant of the Spicer Manufacturing Company here continued idle today because of the refusal of their C.I.O. union to permit them to handle parts produced by A.F. of L. workers at the company's "feeder" plant in Hillsdale, Mich.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 11 -- Finland joined Germany in the attack against Russia, first and foremost, in order to recover territories lost to Russia during the 1939-1940 war. But at the same time the Finnish war machine has a direct and important part to play in Reichsfuehrer Hitler's war plans.

The strike of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks against the Railway Express Agency in Detroit has aroused interest in railroad circles because it not only is the first jurisdictional strike called against the agency but also the first to be called since President Roosevelt appealed to the American Federation of Labor to end jurisdictional strikes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Lincoln Mills of Huntsville, Ala., textile manufacturing firm which was being boycotted on government defense orders because of an alleged lock-out involving 1,800 employes, accepted today recommendations of the National Defense Mediation Board that it grant the C.I.O.'s Textile Workers Union of America a modified union "maintenance of membership" clause.
