WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 11 -- New Zealand's Army was expanded by 50,000 men last year, it was indicated by a report from the chief of the General Staff, General E. Puttick, presented to the House of Representatives today.

Mrs. Paul Ehrlich, widow of the German scientist who discovered salvarsan, was presented with a $1,000 check at a dinner held in commemoration of the thirtieth anniversary of the discovery last night, two months after her arrival in the United States as a refugee from Germany.
The winning pictures among 507 entries in the annual amateur photographic contest conducted by the City Park Department were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The outward aspect of detached interest maintained by the State Department toward the overthrow in Panama of President Arnulfo Arias and the installation of Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia as his successor has only thinly disguised the relief felt here over a change that focusses at the very center of the defense of the Western Hemisphere in a world at war.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A four-motored B-17 Army bomber crashed into a building and caught fire at Duncan Field today, killing two men and injuring sixteen others.

RETURNING to Randolph Field for what is undoubtedly the last command of his active career, as he will be retired in November when he reaches the age of 64, Major Gen. Frank P. Lahm, who was the first airplane pilot in the United States Army, last week was appointed commander of the Gulf Coast Air Corps Training Center.

TRAVEL LINES: With the flight from Miami to Oakes Field, Nassau, taking but seventy minutes, air travel between the two points is chalking new highs. . . . A new sport for Nassau vacationists is progin', which is looking for underseas life through a glass-bottomed bucket; a dinghy sculled into remote coves of shallow water helps the fun along.

AS happens almost everywhere, some of the literary figures of Latin America, both past and present, keep on gaining significance, while others who occupied a much larger niche until not so long ago are receding more and more into oblivion.

TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- Japanese official quarters gave neither confirmation nor denial to rumors from New York that Germany had offered Russia a truce or peace "through a certain country." A Board of Information spokesman said that "we have no official information."

A letter of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, urging American support for foreign missions facing "appalling conditions" because of war in Europe and the Far East, will be read today at masses in Catholic churches. The letter was written in connection with an appeal that will be taken up a week from today, designated by the Holy See as Mission Sunday.

The biggest news of the past week for the realty and building world was the ruling by the Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board virtually ending construction activity for the duration of the emergency except for defense purposes.

Sustained building activity in the Flushing-Third Ward area of Queens is being paralleled by rapid industrial development, according to John J. Halleran, president of the Flushing Chamber of Commerce.

EDITOR THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review: DR. EUGENIO MORREALE, who acted for Mussolini in Austria in 1934, proves by his letter to you (Aug. 31, 1941) from Lisbon that he is a clever writer. To disprove my statement in "Men and Politics" that he inspired the Austrian Government's attack on the workers' settlements in Vienna in February, 1934, Dr. Morreale asserts that this event had deep social caused.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 11 -- On touchdowns by West and Meyers, the Princeton Freshmen nosed out the Hill eleven, 12 to 8, today.

SEATTLE, Oct. 11 -- With racketeering a smoldering issue, delegates to the American Federation of Labor convention discussed today the prospective make-up of the new executive council which will be elected on Friday.

Working quickly and smoothly under the watchful eyes of Mayor La Guardia and high fire defense officials, cooperating fire fighting staffs of New York, Nassau and Westchester Counties and near-by New Jersey communities, aided by civilian auxiliary forces, made short work yesterday of theoretical fires that blazed in and around City Hall, following an imaginary air raid.

GENERATIONS of children have gone through nightmares and nail-biting and stomach upsets, and dear only knows how we accounted for these before movies and radio came along. In one school of opinion the screen and the air are responsible for scaring the present generation out of their young growth.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 11 -- In recent months New Deal members of Congress from the Pacific Northwest with large labor constituencies have been increasingly hostile to the foreign policy of President Roosevelt, whom they have always sustained on domestic issues.

LESS glamorous but far more logical than "Rebecca," which it somewhat resembles. "Hallowe'en" tells the story of another young wife who came a stranger to her husband's ancestral home and found bitter hate awaiting her.

FROM the moment she enters the Beacon family mansion Polly Drake is aware that she is not welcome. She has come from Pittsburgh, where she is secretary to Henry Gregory, superintendent of the Beacon Machine Tool Company, and her mission is to deliver certain papers to Godfrey Beacon, head of the company and of the family, and to no one else.

Yes, bodies are where you find them, as Michael Shayne well knows. He finds a body twice, each time in a different place, and then some one else finds it in still another place. It is all very confusing, but not to Shayne alone.

Columbus Day today, marking the 449th anniversary of the arrival of Christopher Columbus in the New World, will be observed here with parades, rallies and dinners. The celebration will be continued tomorrow, when schools, banks and public offices will be closed.

WHITFIELD, N.H., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, told the New Hampshire Bankers Association tonight that "if the dictators prevail, the struggle for the rights of the individual is lost for a long time to come." The most important contribution to the maintenance of a free economy and of the individual as a factor of society, he said, is the war effort.

LUMINOUS LAUNDRY -- To speed up the job of identifying shirts and handkerchiefs, sheets and underwear, more than 150 laundries are marking "linen" with invisible fluorescent ink which glows brightly under ultraviolet light and thus reveals "secret" markings.

The 55,000,000 art collection of Warner S. McCall of St. Louis, one of the most assiduous private collectors in the United States, has been shipped here and will go on sale at Gimbel Brothers, Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, on Oct. 20, it was announced yesterday by Frederick A. Gimbel, managing director.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 11 -- The awarding of an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws to Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands over a two-way transatlantic broadcast between New Brunswick and London featured the 175th anniversary convocation of Rutgers University here this morning.

The urban foreclosure rate for the first eight months of the present year, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, was only 3.3 per 1,000 dwellings. All of the twelve loan bank districts, it is reported, share in the general rate of decrease, which by percentages amounted to a 19.9 decline in the number of urban properties foreclosed during the same period of 1940.

ORONO, Me., Oct. 11 -- Expanded facilities for training and research in the fields of chemistry, chemical engineering, and pulp and paper technology provided in the recently dedicated addition to the University of Maine's equipment for instruction in those fields coincide with the increased demand from industry for trained men.

At the Waldorf Astoria Hotel next Saturday, prominent educators and psychiatrists will participate in a conference marking the tenth anniversary of the Board of Education's bureau of child guidance. Problems dealing with juvenile delinquency, exceptional children, child health and guidance in general will be explored at forums, ymposiums and round-table panels.
MOSCOW, Oct. 11 (AP) --The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

APARENTLY that was no idle gesture on the part of the brothers Warner when they announced a few weeks back the elimination of B pictures from their schedule. Of course, a couple may pop up in the months to come, but at least there are eight which will never see the light of day -- not, at any rate, under their present titles.

Because of a wide interest among its members in the subject of nutrition, the Westchester County Federation of Women is initiating a movement for the establishment of a county home bureau. Westcheater is one of seventeen counties in the State which does not support such a bureau.

Now that old Jack Frost has blitzed most suburban gardens, and city dwellers, newly returned from a land of green things to a world of stucco and wallpaper walls, the question of what can be grown to cheer up Winter living quarters assumes a position of greatest importance.

The Federal Home Loan Bank System which will begin its tenth year of operations Wednesday, has resources totaling $5,300,000,000, a gain of nearly $400,000,000 over the past year, James Twohy, governor of the system, announced yesterday.

The Board of Higher Education will be asked this week to approve a plan calling for an extensive reorganization of faculty government at City College, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of the college. The plan would replace the present faculty conference with a general faculty empowered "to act in all matters of educational policy, including student affairs as well as staff matters which affect the institution as a whole."

THE New Opera Company opens its six weeks' season on Tuesday night in a small theatre admirably adapted for the presentation of works of modest proportions and intimate appeal which make its repertory.

Two paintings that would cause only ripples in American art circles but that would make the eyes of the occupant of Berchtesgaden glisten were uncovered by Dr. Armand Hammer in cataloguing the McCall art collection that will go on sale at Gimbel Brothers a week from tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Out of the Treasury Department this week came a set of figures almost breath-taking in their astronomical immensity. They represented a revised estimate of how much money Uncle Sam is going to spend in the fiscal year that began last July 1 and what he is going to spend it for, and another estimate of where he is going to get it and from whom.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- G.A.J. Veen, 43 years old, a Netherlands East Indies official, died early today in Rahway Memorial Hospital of injuries suffered in an automobile accident Wednesday night. Mr. Veen, in this country as a member of the executive commission of the Netherlands Purchasing Committee, started his career as a naval officer and was head of the important navy yard at Surabaya, Java.

Many home owners are receiving advice from architects and technicians under the auspices of the Home Owners Loan Corporation on the best means of converting vacant space and substandard units into homes for defense workers.

Paralleling the enrichment of American culture by the contributions of notable European refugees who come to live among us is the gain to our decorative art through shipment of antique furnishings from abroad. The owners of these furnishings send them over, mainly from England, to avoid total loss of them through bombing.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The University of Virginia's touchdown machine, with Captain Bill Dudley at the throttle, rolled over the University of Richmond, 44 to 0, today before a Commonwealth Day crowd of 10,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11 -- Andover Academy scored a 9-7 victory over the Yale freshmen eleven today when Captain Keuffel kicked a dazzling field goal late in the last period. The ball went over the crossbar from the 35-yard line. Duden put Andover ahead with a first-period touchdown, closing a series of short gains, but failed at a placement effort at conversion.

"Progress reports," issued at Columbia University on the participation of students and alumni in the national preparedness program, show that more than 600 students are taking or have completed defense training courses.
VICHY, France, Oct. 11 -- In raids and police operations in Paris since June 76,500 persons have been searched and questioned, according to statistics issued in Paris today.

Defense contracts awarded to Nevada from June, 1940, through August, 1941, were equal to 346 per cent of the value of the State's manufactures in 1939, or the highest of any State, according to defense contract data released by the Office of Production Management.

To the Music Editor: I AM sure Mr. Fred Farr is correct in saying in last Sunday's TIMES (Oct. 5) that there is much unappreciated talent in America among the young conductors. Besides, I am quite in sympathy with his desire that such conductors be given their chance with the WPA City Symphony Series.

While nearly 100 Army planes roared over the city yesterday the last day of the first phase of the far-flung air defense manoeuvres, the big sixteen-inch guns at Ford Tilden "captured" by a raiding party early in the morning were back in Tilden hands and the raiders were for the most part asleep at Fort Hancock.
THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo got its fourth New York season under way a the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night.

THE New York City Infer mation Center, which set up shop across the street from Grand Central Station in December, 1939, answered its millionth question a short time ago. There was no formal celebration of the event; the ten members of the staff were too busy answering questions.

PULLMAN, Wash., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Two sophomore subs ran wild in the second half to bring the University of Washington from behind to a 23-13 victory over Washington State in a Coast Conference football game today.

CRO-MAGNON cave men crouched in rock shelters in prehistoric time. Now modern city dwellers crouch in caves of steel and concrete. The "progress" of civilization apparently has led merely from one cave to another. What is "civilization," and why, after centuries of growth, is it still so vulnerable?

Describing the plight of Jews in France, particularly of Jewish refugees from foreign countries, Herbert Katzki, secretary of the European executive council of the Joint Distribution Committee, with headquarters in Marseille, said yesterday that since July, 1940, when France was divided into the occupied and unoccupied zones, the committee had spent more than 55,000,000 francs on various forms of relief.

HUGE sections of the Western Hemisphere find themselves represented in exhibitions about town just now: The United States, copiously, as usual, by group and one-man shows; some eighteen Latin-American countries, by prints at the Grand Central, and one of the South American nations, Peru, by water-color drawings of objects produced in pre-Columbian eras, this work displayed at the Riverside Museum.

This charming tiny volume provides a peep into the little child's first world of make believe, a world that is peopled by animals, birds and insects, all busy about their own affairs and conducting them very much as human beings do, on a diminutive scale.

Prompt and "realistic" action to protect property values and the mortgage funds invested in homes in the face of the threat of Inflation is urged by Colonel Harold Lee, general counsel of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 11 -- While police occupied its chambers in the City Hall today the Buenos Aires Municipal Council met in a coffee house across the street and, after declaring that yesterday's Executive decree ordering its dissolution was illegal and unconstitutional, proclaimed that the management of the city's affairs was still in its hands.

To the Art Editor: IN writing to civilized people we take for granted their ability to read between the lines. Orlando Kootz Furioso, however, when reading, abandons his noble rage, turns Sancho Panza and becomes literal and pedantic.

THERE is one gracious thing about the movies upon which we have grown to depend: just when you least expect it, they're liable to pop the most pleasant surprise. This is a quaint peculiarity which does wonders for a critic's morale, for it lends to this picture-going business an exciting element of chance.

THIS is a book for those who remember when Christmas trees were illuminated with wax candles. Mr. Partridge's father kept a bucket of sand hard by in case the tree itself, or a frilly shirtwaist, sought to amplify the illumination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Federal Communications Commission suspended today its promulgated rule requiring the National Broadcasting System to dispose of one of its networks, and modified to some degree other rules which the broadcasting industry had objected to strenuously.

A story told of Aristides, Greet statesman and general, may or may not have direct application to the local political situation, but at least it highlights one factor in Mayor La Guardia's campaign for re-election.

LOST AND FOUND: For eight cold, rainy days 5-year-old Pamela Hollingworth, clad in playsuit and sneakers, was alone and lost in the wilderness of New Hampshire's White Mountains. Hundreds of CCC youths, forest rangers and civilians joined in a frantic hunt.

CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 11 -- Reading periods to encourage student reading for research and leisure were inaugurated in the new James W. Bosler Library with the beginning of Dickinson College's 169th academic year this month.

The American Republics liner Argentina sailed at 5 P.M. yesterday from Canal Street, North River, for Brazil and Argentina with 240 passengers in the first class and seventy in the tourist class. The latter were construction men going to work on the new United States base at Trinidad.

RIO DE JANEIRO. THE world premiere of "Malazarte" by the Brazilian composer, Oscar Lorenzo Fernandez, was the most interesting event of this year's opera season. It was staged on Sept. 30 at the Rio Municipal Theatre as the last of the subscription series of the International opera performances.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Built after large excavations in the marshy land of the Navy Yard's League Island at a cost of $10,000,000, the world's largest dry dock is ready for the construction of its first warship.

Casting up accounts for the ten years since Britain left the gold standard, The Economist of London concludes that the departure from gold marked a much more definite epoch than was apparent at the time. At first viewed as a bitter defeat for British economic statesmanship, the abandonment of the gold standard is now regarded by public opinion in England as a good thing.

ONCE we have shut the door of the Autumn Equinox behind us, we enter the flame of the year. The scarlet and gold of the Autumn foliage are nature's grand finale, the last glory of color before the splendors of the Summer dissolve in the pungent autumnal scent of burning leaves.

ANKARA. Special Broadcast to THE NEW YORK TIMES BEFORE the Luftwaffe's merciless bombing of Belgrade, beginning at dawn last April 6, wide windows of the apartment occupied by the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES commanded a view across the small park near the end of the Obilice Venac, a monument erected by the Serbs to one of their greatest heroes.

HANS HABE, the young, tall, brilliant author of "A Thousand Shall Pall" -- which is perhaps the most effective book that has been written about the fall of France -- is living on the reservation at West Point and taking lessons in English from a teacher in the local school.

FROM Vichy comes information that numbers of stamps are being prepared for use in the French colonies. One series will be inscribed "Defense de 1'Empire" (Defense of the Empire) and have designs showing types of French colonial troops and other military subjects.

FIFTEEN miles northeast of Manhattan a tiny island of steel, concrete, copper and glass has grown out of the waves of Long Island Sound. From the midst of this man-made pile of metal and masonry a 410-foot steel tower projects upward.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Both Wake Forest and South Carolina struck through the air today for touchdowns, but each failed to add the extra point and the result was a bruising 6-6 tie before 10,000 fans.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined during the week ended Oct. 4 to the lowest level since June 7. It stood at 127.7, compared with 128.2 for the week ended Sept. 27 and 111.1 for the week ended Oct. 5, 1940.

LONDON. NO one is more expert than J.B. Priestley in discerning and interpreting the signs of the times, as he has been showing once more in a Times Literary Supplement article on "The Cultural Problem."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- So far as has been disclosed, the seizure of the "German-sponsored expedition" in Greenland represented the first successful direct action by the Navy against Nazi activities in the North Atlantic, although the destroyer Greer and a German submarine engaged in a shooting incident early in September.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 11 -- The importance of America's stake in the rubber and tin resources of British Malaya and the Netherlands Indies is shown in figures available here, revealing that the United States is now importing roughly 80 per cent of their rubber and 85 per cent of their tin production.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- New plans to speed defense production were made public today as official statistics revealed that spending for implements of warfare for the United Stales armed services and the lease-lend program passed $1,000,000,000 in September for the first time in the fifteen-month-old defense program.

The Horticultural Society of New York will hold its regular monthly meeting and flower show Wednesday at, 2:30 P.M. at 598 Madison Avenue. A lecture on "Saving and Storing Seeds" will be given by Dr. Lela V. Barton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Department of Agriculture's latest development in the fight against the Japanese beetle -- death by deadly disease germs -- is revealed in a patent (No. 2,258,319) awarded to Samson R. Dutky of Moorestown, N.J.

Wooing the Voters New York City's political future for the four years beginning in 1942 was in the making last week -- in barber shops and undertaking establishments, in beauty parlors and bakeries, in radio stores and schools. All over the city places like these had been set up as neighborhood centers for the registration of voters.
Abraham Lincoln High School's football team routed Manual Training, 21-0, yesterday at Brooklyn College Field for its second straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A German radio station in Greenland has been discovered and "disposed of" by a United States naval vessel in the course of its regular patrol duties, it was announced by the Navy Department today. A small Norwegian steamer and her personnel of about twenty persons, who were supporting the station, are being brought to an American port "for examination."

Future Plainly Written The man next to him at table asked Ethelbert H. Smith how soon he thought the Germans would be in Moscow. With just an instant's pause for reflection, Smith said in crisp accents that carried all around the big table, "Not under three months, and probably twice as long."

INFLUENCE of the national defense effort is bringing a scourge of highway deaths. Last year's warnings that motorvehicle accidents would increase are being borne out. This in spite of nation-wide campaigns to guard ever more carefully against mishaps.

The Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board has permitted aircraft manufacturers to accept orders, beginning on Jan. 1, for 228 transport airplanes. The airlines have taken a commendable attitude throughout the defense emergency, recognizing its paramount importance and cheerfully relinquishing seventy-two civil aircraft for the use of the armed forces of the United States and Great Britain.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 12 -- Smashing blows at German industrial targets in the Ruhr and Rhineland and subsidiary attacks on the docks at Rotterdam, Ostend, Dunkerque and Bordeaux by more than 200 Royal Air Force bombers during Friday night were announced by the Air Ministry.

VICHY, France, Oct. 11 -- Edouard Barthe, a member of the Chamber of Deputies and a "questeur" of that assembly, was placed under "administrative internment" today by order of the Minister of Interior. The charge relates to interference with the shipping of wine from producer to consumer.

WINCHESTER, Ind., Oct. 11 -- Leaders in the Congress of Industrial Organizations today pledged a fight in Indiana's highest court to clear fourteen men convited of resisting police during a picketline fight in Richmond, Ind., in March.
A prominent French film producer recently arrived in this country discloses the follouring information about French screen personalities.

"BY LIGHT OF SUN" is one of those rare garden books which is at the same time, as Richardson Wright says in his foreword, "the story of the growth of the mind and soul of a gardener." Mrs. Symington, who has written for years for garden magazines, decided at last to give up writing to please editors and write to please herself.

A PROGRAM devoted to the works of Bach, Beethover and Brahms will inaugurate the New York season of ten concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra. The concert will take place Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall and will be conducted by Eugene Ormandy.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- Reports of German suggestions for an armistice were ridiculed today by an official Soviet spokesman, who dismissed them as Nazi propaganda. He asserted at the same time that the government would never evacuate Moscow.

Saving Steel Charles P. Disney, bridge engineer of the Canadian National Railways, informs this department that the United States could double its steel-producing capacity almost overnight without building a single new plant, simply by making structural steel do more work.

FOR exiles -- refugees from a homeland that no longer offers them a home -- any new shore must seem a dark shore, though bright by comparison with what they have left behind. Julian Levant, sailing from the Spanish to the African shore of the Strait of Gibraltar on Christmas Day, 1935, was not a political exile.

PANAMA, Oct. 11 -- Former Minister of Education Jose Pezet presented his resignation as First Vice President today and twenty-five of the thirty-two members of the National Assembly declared their support of the government of Provisional President Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia.

REPORTS from France tell of antiquarian booksellers waging a losing struggle to keep books on their shelves. Raids by buyers have left the shops virtually bookless, and since it is forbidden to send money out of the country it is impossible to replenish their stocks from abroad.

The names of many men who helped to build America are being commemorated by their use for government defense housing projects under construction by the Federal Works Agency throughout the country to provide homes for the nation's defense workers and for married enlisted personnel of the Army and Navy, Federal Works Administrator John M. Carmody points out.

IN writing about Pascal a dozen years ago, Aldous Huxley cautioned his readers that Pascal himself was "only incidentally" the subject of his essay. Had he chosen, he might have followed the same procedure in "Grey Eminence."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Invitations are being sent out for the Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held at the Tuxedo Club Oct. 25. Mrs. Herbert Reed Lawrence, chairman of the ball committee, called a meeting of her associates this week to pass on final plans.

Urging the discontinuance, as separate agencies, of both the National Youth Administration and the Civilian Conservation Corps, the Educational Policies Commission of the National Education Association has put new emphasis on the fear of Federal control of American education.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- Representative Martin, chairman of the Republican National Committee, told a group of district and county committeemen here tonight that the Republican party must regain control of the House through the elections of 1942 as "the only possible way now in which a wholesome curb can be put upon the vast powers which have been delegated to the Executive and the political bureaucrats."

Forced sales of Manhattan real estate during the first nine months of 1941 declined to the lowest level in at least six years, according to the monthly foreclosure survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.

PHILADELPHIA -- It has been a year now since the, first automobile purred almost effortlessly over the broad back of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, and already it is apparent that the socalled super-highway will be a financial success.

AN intercepted radiogram sent from Berlin last week announced that a decree issued by the Minister of Economics forbids all persons in Germany to trade in used and unused stamps of enemy countries. Specifically mentioned are Soviet Russia, Great Britain, Australia, India and its native States, Sudan, Egypt and Iraq, and the decree covers all British colonies, possessions, protectorates and mandated countries.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 11 -- Many Swedes and diplomatic observers of neutral nations here receive the German claim that the Battle of Russia is won with skepticism. Following is an extract from an article by the military expert of Dagens Nyheter:

A project to study economies and simplification in construction through the coordination of dimensions of building materials and equipment has been organized by the American Standards Association with the American Institute of Architects and the Producers Council as sponsors.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Oct. 11 -- In response to pleas from Washington, strikers and management ended tonight the two-week-old strike at the Calco Chemical Division of the American Cyanamid Company, which had threatened to halt the entire rubber industry.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 -- Oregon University's greatest football eleven in many years wrecked the come-back dreams of the Trojans of Southern California today and scored its first triumph over the Cardinal and Gold since 1915.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Stanford's football dynasty, its Rose Bowl hopes and a great victory string came to an end today on the rain-soaked field of Oregon State College. The fighting Beavers won all the way, 10 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Representative Lee E. Geyer, Democrat, who represented the Seventeenth California District, died of bronchial pneumonia in Walter Reed Hospital today after a short illness. His age was 53. He was taken to the hospital Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Traffic congestion has become so great in the national capital's metropolitan area as a result of the tremendous growth in population caused by the defense effort that local and Federal officials, the local newspapers and many civic groups are scrambling for every source of information they can find in an effort to solve the problem which is slowing up the life of the city.

Women, it is said, do the shirt-shopping for the majority of men. To these women the news that shirt prices are on the up-grade is not wholly unexpected. So far the increase is greatest on shirts that have sold at $1 or less.

Three residential centers in Kew Gardens, adjoining the Forest Hills home section, will be scenes of considerable activity this week as two of them will be formally opened with the exhibition of model houses, while in the third the final unit of homes will be completed and opened for occupancy.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- The National Council of Camp Fire Girls adopted at the close today of its biannual convention a five-point program designed to key immediate wartime service to long-range objectives.

The granting of defense priorities for the rehabilitation of obsolete loft and factory buildings in Manhattan is urged by two executives of the Charles F. Noyes Company, who point out that such action would benefit both the Federal and city governments in their defense efforts.

ROMILLY CAVAN'S London flat, where she has been living and working since war began, has been bombed twice. Her husband is a Fleet Street journalist. Put the two facts together and you might have expected a war book from her.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Penn State thrilled a homecoming crowd of 16,000 today by spotting Bucknell a 13-0 lead in the first ten minutes of play and then coming from behind to beat the Bisons, 27 to 13. Pepper Petrella, 160-pound senior halfback from Downingtown, Pa., sparked the Nittany Lions uphill drive, scoring all four touchdowns on short line bucks.

Coup in Panama A man wearing dark glasses, his hat pulled over his eyes, hastily boarded a plane waiting to take off from a Panama Canal Zone airport early one morning last week. According to his diplomatic passport, his name was A. Madrid, and he was bound for Cuba.

Religion alone can keep the world in equilibrium and bring peace and brotherly love back into the world, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declared yesterday as he presided at a solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral in memory of Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, who died fighting for the Americans at the siege of Savannah 162 years ago and in recognition of the suffering people of Poland.

To the spreading tune of national defense, an informal variety show will enliven WOR's Sunday nights from 10:30 to 11, beginning Nov. 9. The purpose of the as yet unnamed show is "to present in terms of radio what we are defending in America and the need for defending it."

Despite an impression to the contrary, the simplification of merhandise which has been cited as essential to the defense program by Donald M. Nelson, executive director of the SPAB, should mean an increase in the use of informative labels because adequate data on consumer goods are essential to the preservation of consumer morale, according to views in well-informed quarters last week.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 (AP) -- D.N.B., the official news agency, reported today that Karl Laznowsky, editor in-chief of Ceske Slovo, Prague newspaper, had died and that several other Czecho-Slovak editors friendly to Germany were ill as a result of poisoning.

The exploits of the New York Football Giants in winning their initial three games on foreign fields for the first time in the history of the club have whetted considerable curiosity among the followers of the professional gridiron sport in New York. So a banner crowd of some 35,000 is expected at the Polo Grounds today when the Giants stage their home opener against the Philadelphia Eagles.

RAY STANNARD BAKER, like Clarence Day and Bellamy Partridge, had a father. This autobiographical volume is not primarily about the elder Baker, but he is a good character and would have been able to hold his own with the elder Day and the elder Partridge.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH ceremonies on the lawn of Pickfair reminiscent of the old Hollywood, David O. Selznick last week rejoined United Artists, thus becoming a full-fledged partner with Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin and Alexander Korda under an agreement whereby he will deliver twenty films to the company during the next ten years.

Canned goods, blankets, sweaters and supplies filling cellar, attic and pantry in a rural community outside New York attest that women in at least one locality are not taking the possibility of airraid attacks lightly.

When the Trianon Room of the Ambassador is formally opened for the season on Wednesday night with a special dinner dance, the occasion will be a benefit for United China Relief. The fete has been arranged by the Women's Division of the Greater New York Committee of the beneficiary, with Mrs. Maurice T. Moore as chairman.

DETROIT -- Repair and replacement parts, with which America hopes to keep its transportation system in A-1 shape while new cars are being produced in curtailed quantities, are becoming scarcer despite efforts in the other direction.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Production in three plants of the Carnegie-illinois Steel Company was sharply curtailed today by a widespread work stoppage, in reality an unleclared strike, decreed by the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee in a drive for a closed shop.

In times like these when the world is rediscovering its dependence on courage and steadfastness, it is a matter of rejoicing to find among stories for older boys and girls a book with the integrity and clarity of vision of Merlin Ames's "Canthook Country."
HOW to cooperate in the drive for good nutrition without wrecking the family finances is a question which has many a veteran home-maker completely stumped.

For a long time Adolf Hitler's propaganda machine has carried on a campaign against American minds. This German war of word involves the highest stakes for Hitler and for the American people. How stands the score ?

Now and again the beauty of some common plant of wood or field seems to strike us anew. We delight in it, and triumphantly bring home a root. Of such finds few are more completely established in my garden and my affections than the bitter nightshade, Solanum dulcamara, an escape from Europe often mistakenly called Deadly Nightshade, which is properly the common name of its cousin, Atropa belladonna.

One of the largest theatre parties planned for the near future is the annual Autumn benefit for the Maternity Center Association. The board of directors of the beneficiary has taken over the second night performance of Cole Porter's new musical show, "Let's Face It," at the Imperial Theatre on Oct. 30.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Missouri's highly mobile football team today gave Kansas State a 35-to-0 defeat, the worst in the thirty-two-year series between the teams, and if it hadn't been for third and fourth stringers who were in at the finish, the margin would have been greater.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 11 -- Helsinki today confirmed reports that Finnish troops are helping the Germans in their hitherto unsuccessful drive on Murmansk, Russia, and in Stockholm it is believed that soon the Finns will take over all operations in this region.

ROME, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Italian bathing beaches, coastal roads and trunk highways bristled with guns, barbed-wire entanglements and multiple preparations against invasion tonight, and the Fascist press sarcastically urged the British "to come and try it."

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 11 (AP) -- With two stunning touchdown thrusts in the second half, Santa Clara University's powerful Broncos, giants of the Far West's independent football teams, defeated the University of California, 13 to 0, before a crowd of 65,000 in Memorial Stadium today.

WITH "America's Town Meeting of the Air" returning next Thursday night for its seventh consecutive season, Moderator George V. Denny is changing his plans again. Not that this is anything new for Mr. Denny.

Marking the formal inception of the Winter social season in New York, the fifty-sixth annual National Horse Show will open in Madison Square Garden on the night of Nov. 5. The series of colorful performances will continue through the night of Nov. 12 and attendant on these sessions will be a varied round of festivities.

THE assorted backers of "Arsenic and Old Lace" had the pleasure of clipping another coupon, last week. There sere really twenty-two of them (not twenty-one as formerly listed) in that circle; they hold certificates ranging downward to five-sixths of 1 per cent.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Active and vigorous interest in the church and the part it plays in our society is being shown at Sarah Lawrence College, where class and field work and extra-curricular activities are being brought together in a study of the church and its influence on the individual, the community and as a national factor.

The textile industries, which were the first to give an indication that the recovery of 1936 was "turning sour" and the recession of 1937 was on the way, gave indications last week of moving into uncertainty and it was freely suggested that the very definite "sellers' market" that had been fostred by the twin influences of defense buying and expanded public purchasing power was nearing its end.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuter) -- Belgium defeated the Netherlands by 5 to 4 at Wembley Stadium today in an international soccer match attended by a large representation of the Netherlands and Belgian governments in London, as well as by members of the land, sea and air forces of the two countries.

Dit and Apache were the winners of Jamaica's two $10,000 added stakes which, attracted 24,137 persons yesterday. The crowd bet 51,318,619 during the crisp Autumn afternoon, close to the record for the track.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago is reputed to have told President Roosevelt that if the 1942-congressional elections were held today, the President would not have enough supporters in the Middle West to keep the Democrats in control of the House.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- The H.K. Porter Company, manufacturer of shells, gun blocks and other defense essentials, was closed today by a strike of C.I.O. union workmen who were demanding a 10-cent hourly wage increase for the 450 on the payroll.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Nearly 2,000 Japanese will be evacuated from the West Coast of the United States and Hawaii on three Japanese ships that will make special trips to repatriate them, it was announced today.

MR. WINGFIELD CHEVRON began his practice in a luxurious resort hotel in North Carolina. That particular phase of his career did not last very long. Wing practiced medicine with knowledge, and he proposed to practice it with conscience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The opinion that a Nazi victory over Russia might lead to a serious clash of Japanese and American interests in the Pacific was expressed today by three members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

WHEREVER old connoisseurs of good acting gather, in Shubert Alley and other cultural centers, they are bound sooner or later to discuss a little matter that is the more fascinating because it can never be settled to the general satisfaction-the one about who, among the American stage's contemporary queens, can justly be called its First Lady.

Close economic collaboration between the United States and Canada on such problems as jointly providing food exports for the United Kingdom, pooling materials and manufacturing essential articles for the Latin-American market and conserving strategic materials was mapped by the Joint Economic Committees for the two countries, which closed a two-day conference here yesterday.

BENNINGTON, Vt, Oct. 11 -- The study of pressing issues on which Bennington College will center its program of afternoon and evening meetings began with a discussion of economic problems in war in peace by Geoffrey Crowther, editor of the London journal, The Economist.

OLD acquaintances and newcomers mingled in the more than thirty exhibitions which opened last week. At least a dozen of these deserve more extended notice than is possible under the circumstances. One is the showing of recent water-colors by the phenomenally successful Ax drew Wyeth, at Macbeth's.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11 -- Yale's new football structure tottered in the Bowl today before the awesome power of a fine Pennsylvania team, but it never fell. There was too much steel in the foundation for that.
LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 11 -- Panzer College of East Orange, N.J., struck once on the ground and once through the air today to defeat Lowell Textile Institute, 13 to 2.

A luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Yorkville Unit of the Speedwell Society will be held Tuesday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. Under the general chairmanship of Mrs. Trowbridge Heaton, a debutante committee has been formed to assist Mrs. Francis L. Blewer in plans for the event.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Army served further notice that its football prestige is on the upswing by outplaying Virginia Military Institute's scrappy warriors for a 27to-20 decision before 18,000 enthralled spectators in Michie Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A series of orders was issued by Secretary Hull today reorganizing the economic warfare activities of the State Department by bringing them into line with existing agencies in other departments engaged in similar activities and in general integrating them into a consolidated pattern.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 11 -- An inspired North Carolina team gave Fordham a tremendous surprise at Kenan Stadium today in their fourth meeting, but in the end the Rams' might prevailed. The score was 27-14.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 11 -- Wesleyan broke into the winning column today by setting back the University of Connecticut, 7 to 0. The Cardinals scored two minutes after the kick-off.

WHEN the Prince President, Louis-Napoleon, had announced that France was to become for the second time an empire, he had another piece of information to give his countrymen within a few weeks: that the Empress of the French was to be the Spanish beauty Eugenic de Montijo.

With an enrollment of 1,216 cadets and cadet officers, the New York University Reserve Officers Training Corps this year will have the largest unit in its twenty-oneyear history, Colonel Fred V.S. Chamberlain announced yesterday.

Department store sales in the New York area last week showed gains of 10 to 12 per cent over a year ago. The reaction continued on items heavily bought during the beat-the-tax buying rush. Warm weather hit apparel demand, men's wear trade in particular being spotty and only slightly ahead of 1940.

Editor THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review: In his review of " 'Fighting Joe' Wheeler," Herschel Brickell refers to the Spanish-American War as "tragi-comedy." In 1898 two youths left the village of North Pelham, N.Y., to volunteer.

"BOOKBINDING IN AMERICA" (the South-worth-Anthoensen Press, Portland, Me.) is the first attempt to treat this subject in a complete and consecutive manner and, like all initial efforts in a virgin field, the amount of labor necessary to establish the facts was infinitely greater than the casual reader suspects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Tire manufacturers were notified today by Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, that no objection would be made to advances in consumer list prices on tires and tubes of not more than 9 per cent over June 16 levels.

Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, leader of the Democratic majority in the City Council, announced yesterday that he would submit to that body on Tuesday a set of bills under which the city's sales and compensating use taxes would either be reduced to one-half of 1 per cent or abolished entirely.
RIO GRANDE, Ohio, Oct. 11A homecoming- football crowd of 300 went wild today, although its favorites, Rio Grande College's Redmen, lost, as usual.
Henry Walsh of De Witt Clinton High won the nineteenth annual invitation interscholastic crosscountry run held by Manhattan College in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 -- W.L. Brann's Pictor, being groomed to fill the shoes of his illustrious stablemate Challedon, raced to a impressive victory today in the twenty-eighth running of the one mile Laurel Stakes.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Germany's deep military involvement in Russia is not going to make any easier her job of feeding Europe. As the campaign seems to be developing into an all-Winter affair and as supplies of every kind pour in the direction of Russia, men here (and doubtless many in Germany as well) are wondering how it will work out.

WHEN Hitler marched into Austria in 1938 we realized not without a certain sentimental kind of resentment that Vienna, baroque city of musical tradition and carefree gayety, had become a suburb of Berlin.

The cultivation of desirable attitudes among children in the early adolescent period has to some extent been accomplished by junior high schools throughout the country, according to the results of a survey conducted recently by Professor Harold S. Tuttle of the City College School of Education.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 11 -- Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandies, about two decades ago, selected the Law School of the University of Louisville as beneficiary of specific current gifts from him because, in his judgment, this university is much less liable to political influence than institutions under complete public control.

VICHY, France, Oct. 11 -- Regarding military operations on the Eastern Front, competent neutral observers here, while recognizing the gravity of the Russian position, believe, nevertheless, that it would be wise to wait another forty-eight hours before passing final judgment.

The national emergency, with its heavy forward buying, shortages and priorities, is rapidly bringing about sweeping changes in methods of doing business, some of which have wiped out the developments of the last twenty years, business executives pointed out last week.
DALLAS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Mighty Texas crushed gallant Oklahoma, 40 -- 7, today with a show of power that amazed even the most ardent backers of Longhorn Rose Bowl hopes.

THE American Revolution was not only a war between colonies and mother country; it was, too, a civil war. Those who participated in it were aware of this, and now the fact has been rediscovered in our own day-rediscovered and to some extent misunderstood.

In typical pre-week-end holiday fashion the cotton market moved yesterday within a narrow range in quiet trading. The trend, however, was downward, and on the New York Cotton Exchange closing quotations showed net losses of 7 to 10 points for the two-hour session.

OTTAWA, Oct 11 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian industrial employment reached a new high record when 12,577 establishments reported a working force of 1,605,580 persons at Aug. 1, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

ABOARD A BATTLESHIP With Britain's Mediterranean Fleet, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Great Britain's war fleet returned today from a cruise along Italy's sea highway to Libya in a sweep that dared Premier Mussolini's navel and aerial forces to come out and fight.

ARRESTED: Into the office of the United States Commissioner in New York's Federal Building last week walked an impeccably dressed, mildmannered man clutching a worn leather brief case. He was 56-year-old George Sylvester Viereck, Munichborn poet, historian, journalist and propagandist.

THE "Little Red House" at Tanglewood near Lenox, Mass., where Hawthorne wrote "The House of Seven Gables" and the "Wonder Book," will be rebuilt by the National Federation of Music Clubs as a gift to the Boston Symphony Orchestra and a permanent memorial to Hawthorne. The original structure was destroyed by fire in 1890.

WESTON, Mass., Oct. 11 -- Boston University's football team defeated Upsala today, 17 to 0. The Terriers scored touchdowns in the first and fourth periods and a goal from the field by Morris in the final quarter.

F.W. Nichols, director of housing for Canada's Department of Finance, which administers its National Housing Act, a measure paralleling the FHA plan in the United States, will be one of the leading speakers at a home builders' problem dinner to be held on the evening of Nov. 4, the opening night of the annual convention in Detroit of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

WITH ever-mounting "load factors," airlines of the United States won a respite-on-paper last week from worries that have dogged their most successful year of operation. Short of planes, they were granted 228 new craft to be delivered next year and in the first half of 1943.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- Powerful German forces attacking in the Vyazma and Bryansk regions and north of Orel have again succeeded in pounding forward, despite tremendous losses inflicted by the Red Army. It was openly acknowledged here tonight that the central industrial areas were seriously menaced and that new German advances in the south presented a grave danger to the vital manufacturing centers on the Sea of Azov coast.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- A 90-yard runback of the secondhalf kick-off by Kenneth Rees, and a 7-yard pass from Bill Andruss to Jim Huston gave Bronxville a 12-0 victory over Lynbrook High of Long Island today.

JAROMIR WEINBERGER'S "A Lincoln Symphony" will receive its world premiere at the opening pair of concerts of the Cincinnati Orchestra, under Eugene Goossens, Friday afternoon and Saturday night, in Cincinnati. The new composition is dedicated to Mr. Goossens and the orchestra.

GATLINBURG, Tenn. -- Only a few years ago the idea of Fall vacations amounted to little more than a bit of wishful thinking on the part of hotel and resort men and such travel interests as the railroads, bus lines and service stations of the country.
